Dante Notes: Divina Commedia

6 elements of Dante's passion:
1. The Encyclopedia.  2.  The Journey  3. The Vision 4. The Autobiography 5. The Praise of Woman 6. Allegory

Canto I: Inferno

45 tercets, and 1 concluding line: total: 136 lines

Time: Good Friday morning after the tortured night of April 7th, April 8th of the Jubilee Year 1300 A.D.

1  Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita
2  mi retrovai per una selva oscura
3  che' la diritta via era smarrita.
1  Midway upon the journey of our life
2  I found myself within a forest dark,
3  For the straightforward pathway had been lost.

The first tercet: We begin in the dark, in the midst of a threatening confusion.  The Moralist's  bias here favors light and straightness, while the confusion paradoxically prompts the Poet to his calling.  Compare Blake's aphorism: Improvement makes straight roads, but the crooked roads without Improvement, are roads of genius.  The diachronic time sequence begins here, one Dante, the aspirant, following on his journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise, and one Dante, the narrator, who has already completed the journey and is relating his experiences.  Maybe the first Dante is the Poet, the perpetual beginner as Rilke says, and the second, the Moralist.

4  Ahi quanto a dir qual era e cosa dura
5  esta selva selvaggia e aspra e forte
6  che nel pensier rinova la paura!

4  Ah me! how hard a thing it is to say
5  What was this forest savage, rough, and stern,
6 Which in the very thought renews the fear.

The second triplet: The theme of both the inarticulate, and a warning that the words and the matter to be related are wild (selvaggia), aspra (rough), forte (stern, strong medicine), and the mere contemplation of it, even in retrospect, renews the original fear (la paura).  This is why traumas are so hard to resolve, we essentially suppress them, because we do not want to relive 
them, and we substitute for the feeling, a story about the feeling.  Dante is telling us that his 
story is going to be the feeling, not just something about the feeling.

7  Tant' e amara che poco a pui morte;
8  Ma per trattar del ben ch'i vi trovai,
9  Diro' de l'altre cose ch'i v'ho scorte.

7  So bitter is it, death is little more;
8  But of the good to treat, which there I found,
9  Speak will I of the other things I saw there.


The third triplet: The theme of risk, of death, and of the willingness to traverse a bitter (amara) landscape, as poet, in order to save the reader.  (Remember: one of the readers is Dante's ordinary mundane self, who is reading his poetic, inspired self's words.)  These two, Poet and Audience, like the couple of Poet and Moralist, have to be willing to endure an onslaught of images on the spiritual-artistic-creator-audience journey, many of which may be both difficult to contemplate, and difficult to understand.

10  Io non so ben ridir com'i' v'intrai,
11  tant'era pien di sonno a quel punto
12  che la verace via abbandonai.

10  I cannot well repeat how there I entered,
11  So full was I of slumber at the moment
12  In which I had abandoned the true way.

The fourth triplet: The beginning is lost in the obscurity of sleep, the unconscious, and it is also found there.  This true way, "la verace via", is the road of the poem itself, the creative act of writing or speaking, of reading or listening.  The first thing that a poet has to do is to listen to and trust his poetic self, although the self is forever obscured in the unconscious, or in Dante's vernacular, in a shade, a soul, that is undefined and undefinable.

13  Ma poi ch'i' fui al pie' d'un colle giunto,
14  'La dove terminava quella valle
15  che m'avea di paura il cor compunto,

16  guardai in alto, e vidi le sue spalle
17  vestite gai' de' raggi del pianeta
18  che mena dritto altrui per ogne calle.
13  But after I had reached a mountain's foot,
14  At that point where the valley terminated,
15  Which had with consternation pierced my heart,
16  Upward I looked, and I beheld its shoulders,
17  Vested already with that planet's rays
18  Which leadeth others right by every road.
Like Freud, who created a map of the unconscious, Libido, Ego, Superego, etc., Dante from the first few lines is creating an intelligible geography of the soul: The dark wood, the mountain with the first light hitting its crown, the valley where he (the poet in incubation) is beginning his quest.  Poignant here is his statement in line 18 that "others" can follow the road that he has left, but not him.  But what has he left the journey of the orthodox for?  The journey of the poem.  The pattern of light, high, up, clear and their opposites: dark, low, down, fogginess is being established.  Dante here is also hinting that others (the orthodox) can take an easier road (in fact, any road, ogne calle, will lead up), but the outcasts, the reader, and the poet, the questioners, the doubters, must travel a more arduous path, as explorers, and perhaps later, if they make it, as way-showers.

19  Allor fu la paura un poco queta
20  che nel lago del cor m'era durata 
21  la notte ch'i' passai con tanta pieta.

19  Then was the fear a little quieted
20  That in my heart's lake had endured throughout
21  The night, which I had passed so piteously.

Very I Ching-like metaphors here, the heart as a lake, calmed at the foot of a mountain, the mountain catching the sun's first rays of light.  Also, we learn here about having to endure (brilliant echo in the word durata in line 20, and the word dura in line 4) a piteous night.  Insomnia here is described as a metaphysical state —the paradox of being full of sleep, but unable to sleep.  Start paying attention to the word pieta, translated as pity, or pitiful, or piteous.   But that translation doesn't seem to capture the feeling of compassion elicited by viewing or hearing about the suffering of another, a feeling which will be thoroughly examined as Dante descends into a land of retributions and punishments.  Note also the relationship between pity and piety.  

22  E come quei che con lena affannata
23  uscito fuor del pelago al la riva
24  si volge a l'acqua perighiosa e guata,

25  cosi l'animo mio, ch'ancor fuggiva,
26  si volse a retro a rimirar lo passo
27  che non lascio' gai mai persona viva.
22  And even as he, who, with distressful breath,
23  Forth issued from the sea upon the shore,
24  Turns to the water perilous and gazes;
25  So did my soul, that still was fleeing onward,
26  Turn itself back to re-behold the pass
27  Which never yet a living person left.
The archetype here is of the night sea journey, and the aspirant, looking back — which is what he's doing by writing the poem — looking back on the water he's escaped from.  This is the voyage of the dead, and this metaphor of a sea passage will be renewed in Purgatorio as the souls arrive from having given up the troubled breath of life (the death rattle echoes here).  Note here also the word fuggiva, refuge and fugitive, both, from the word fuga, perhaps, "la fuga", meaning escape.  The crossing of water also occurs when the damned are ferried to hell in a later canto.  Water of course has the multiple meanings of unformed chaos, of source or of baptism.  Again, Blake echoes this in his drawing of Newton, seated on coral at the bottom of the sea of material space and time.

28  Poi ch'ei passato un poco il corpo lasso,
29  represi via per la piaggia diserta,
30  si' che 'l pie' fermo sempre era 'l piu basso.

28  After my weary body I had rested,
29  The way resumed I on the desert slope,
30  So that the firm foot ever was the lower.

The famous passage here in which Dante turns a metaphor of the body into a metaphysical instruction.  Firm footing on a climb is always leveraged from the lowest and hardest (most difficult) realization.  Whatever we might aspire to (note how the word aspire relates to height.) begins with our most fundamental needs and necessities.  Another way to put it, is that the pursuit of an ideal is only grounded when it rests first on the hard realization of exactly where you are on the climb.  You can't get ahead of yourself, even by one step, or down you go again.  Now, when Dante the quester, the fugitive, tries to climb, three bestial obstacles confront him: parts of himself that are too threatening and too savage to be recognized as his own face, but wherever he turns his face: they are there to stop him from looking away.

Language note: piaggia diserta: a sandy disserted shore.  Piaggia, not riva, the word used in line 23.  If you need to know why this is important, just recall how difficult it is to climb a hill of sand.

31  Ed ecco, quasi al cominciar de l'erta,
32  una lonza leggera e presta molto,
33  che di pel macolato era coverta.

34  e non mi si partia dinanzi al volto,
35  anzi 'mpediva tanto il mio cammino,
36  ch'i' fui per ritomar piu volte volto.
31  And lo! almost where the ascent began,
32  A panther light and swift exceedingly,
33  Which with a spotted skin was covered o'er!
34  And never moved she from before my face,
35  Nay, rather did impede so much my way,
36  That many times I to return had turned.
(The poetics here are stunning, especially in the repetition of the word cammino (from line 1), and the face to face play on the words volte and volto — times as in number of times, and face, the face of Dante and the face of the panther (una lonza).  Very succinctly Dante puts us face to face with ourselves and the linear time that is our mortal body's passage from birth to death.  At the very beginning the aspirant is driven back by some spotted beast (una lonza) which is both, nimble and fast, and has a blotched skin.  A spotted skin could indicate a disease, of a corruption that is beginning to break out on the surface, or a kind of moral plague or leprosy, in which the purity of every good inclination is spotted with some canker of collateral damage, either to self or others.  This beast, like a mirror, stays in front of the aspirant's face whichever way he turns, because it is his own reflection.  Fugitives, readers or writers, cannot escape or find refuge from themselves.  Their problem seems outside them, but it is only a projection of themselves that they refuse to see.  

The next lines renew the time theme, a description of the dawn, and not just any dawn, but the dawn of Good Friday, the crucifixion that will lead to salvation.  The aspirant's sight is raised by the cross and the vision of unjust torment and death, the beginning of pity, of piety.  This is the aspirant's hope, in spite of his own bestial nature.

37  Temp'era dal principio del mattino,
38  e 'l sol montava 'n su' con quelle stelle
39  ch'eran con lui quando l'amor divino

40  mosse di prima quelle cose belle;
41  si ch'a bene sperar m'era cagione
42  di quella fiera a la gaetta pelle

43  l'ora del tempo e la dolce stagione;
44  ma non si che paura non mi desse
45  la vista che m'apparve d'un leone.

46  Questi parea che contra me venisse
47  con la test'alta e con rabbiosa fame,
48  Si che parea che l'aere ne tremesse.
37  The time was the beginning of the morning,
38  And up the sun was mounting with those stars
39  That with him were, what time the Love Divine
40  At first in motion set those beauteous things;
41  So were to me occasion of good hope,
42  The variegated skin of that wild beast,
43  The hour of time, and the delicious season;
44  But not so much, that did not give me fear
45  A lion's aspect which appeared to me.
46  He seemed as if against me he were coming
47  With head uplifted, and with ravenous hunger,
48  So that it seemed the air was afraid of him;

Again, amazing and complex poetics, merging the light of dawn and the last remaining stars, with the fiera a la gaetta pelle, the fiery spots of the panther.  It is spring, la dolce stagione, the sweet season, but the aspirant's fear remains, his own bestial appetites appearing before him as a lion's face.  (Of the three beasts, this lion is the only one who could definitely be called male, so in the language of Jung, there are three shadow-sides that appear upon first awakening and getting a glimpse of the path towards individuation.  1) The ambivalent spotted panther or leopard, a confused anima-type figure, the male lion, 2) the male animus (the word here in English would be animosity, the pride of the male to dominate, and to view other males as their enemies), and finally 3) the she-wolf (una lupa), the last and most ferocious obstacle.  Note the two uses of parea, seemed, resembled, the equivocation tells us that this is not a "literal" lion, not a physical but a metaphysical challenge, and when it raises its head (the head of reason perverted by selfish appetite), it seems as if the very air (the breath of contemplation when first encountering distorted aspects of the soul that have been repressed) is trembling.  We are breathing in everyone's fear, anger, ambition, hunger.  Melville has a similar image in Moby Dick when he reminds us that the air of this earth is polluted by all those who have died exhaling it.

Note: Scholars have had a centuries-long debate as to whether Dante intended his journey to be taken literally, or if the entire Commedia is an allegory, such as The Dream of Scipio, or The Pilgrim's Progress.  I think Dante as a writer did everything he could to give his journey a physical presence.  You never think you have left the domain of the literal, physical body, a person situated in historical space and time.  And yet at the same time, he never allows the reader to be free of the ambiguity that there are dimensions beyond the literal interpretation — allegorical dimensions that have the same relationship to the body as thoughts do to the physical brain.  I think as an either/or argument, the point is moot.  It's both/and.

Next we come to the She-wolf:

49  Ed una lupa, che di tutte brame
50  sembiava carca ne la sua magrezza,
51  molte genti fe'gia viver grame,

52  questa mi porse tanto di gravezza
53  con la paura ch'uscia di sua vista,
54  ch'io perdie la speranza de l'altezza.
55  And a she-wolf, that with all hungerings
56  Seemed to be laden in her meagreness,
57  And many folk has caused to live forlorn!
58  She brought upon me so much heaviness,
59  With the affright that from her aspect came,
60  That I the hope relinquished of the height.
The image of starvation and the fear of lack, turned back on the aspiring self, perhaps in those terrible words of the earthly parental admonition: Be practical, don't waste your time with a spiritual or artistic aspiration, that won't put meat on your table or meat on your bones.  Dante here makes sure that we understand that this third beast, the starving and neglected anima, causes him to return to his original torpor (gravezza, heaviness, sluggishness, tied to the idea of gravity, that which pulls us down when we want to climb up, that which is the heaviness of the mortal flesh, when it tries to ascend a spiritual height, that which darkens light and kills hope (la speranza).  Note the rhyme of gravezza and altezza, gravity, or seriousness, and height.  More of the schema of up and down, that which draws us up contra natura, or against nature, as Jung calls the journey of individuation, and the physical mortal body which pulls us down.  The thinness of the she-wolf is lack in every sense, but for the artist or spiritual aspirant this is lack in the sense of: I am not good enough yet to start the spiritual journey.  I must read another book, go to another weekend course on spirituality, and then I will be ready.  Remember: spiritual birth, like death, is always premature.

Language note: The rhyming of brame (longings) with grame (forlorn)  — very Buddhist: to have longings, appetites, is inevitably the cause of suffering.

This is an important turning point, hope also is surrendered, because at this juncture, there is still a false belief that the divided (into the 3 beasts here) and foggy self can devise a plan to overcome the very terrors which the ego-self has used to build its identity.  This is really a question of Who am I?  Dante, the aspirant does not know, and what's more, he is too pulled down by moral ambivalence (the spotted panther), male dominating aggressiveness (the lion), and fear of lack (the she wolf), to be able to continue on the spiritual path without help.  Where is that help going to come from?   The aspirant doesn't have a clue.  Depression follows.  No pill to take here to ease that descent, which Dante the aspirant, the floundering quester, describes next, in a passage that makes clear that help is not to be acquired by will power (volontieri acquista).

55  E qual e quei che volontieri acquista,
56  a ginghe 'l tempo che perder lo face,
57  che 'n tutt'i suoi pensier piange e s'attrista;

58  tal mi fece la bestia sanza pace,
59  che, venendomi  'ncontro, a poco a poco
60 mi ripigneva la dove 'l sol tace.

 61  Mentre ch'i' rovinava in basso loco,
 62  dinanzi a li occhi mi si fu offerto
 63  chi per lungo silenzio parea fioco.
55  And as he is who willingly acquires,
56  And the time comes that causes him to lose,
57  Who weeps in all his thoughts and is despondent,
58  E'en such made me that beast withouten peace,
59  Which, coming on against me by degrees
60  Thrust me back thither where the sun is silent.
61  While I was rushing downward to the lowland,
62  Before mine eyes did one present himself,
63  Who seemed from long-continued silence hoarse.
Realizing the futility of his efforts (note the wonderful rhymed paring of acquista — acquiring — and s'attrista — self-generated sadness), little by little, the aspirant slips back, withdrawing 
from the touch of the sun, and returning to the lowest point again, when suddenly, his eyes are offered a glimpse of a something or a someone: someone who from long silence seems weak, 
that is to say, someone roused from a deep state of contemplation or coma, and who now 
endavors to speak.  (The word, fioco, translated here as hoarse, is more often translated as 
weak.  Hoarse comes from shouting, weak comes from being roused from sleep.)  

This is crucial too, because it points out that our guides and mentors also have problems: How
do they speak about something that the aspirant has never experienced, and how do they
speak in a voice that can be heard?  Dante points out here that the guide's words
are not necessarily going to be beautiful or easy to hear.  The aspirant here admits 
his helplessness, and cries out to this image with a meager voice, not knowing 
if he is talking to a physical man or a shade, another person or his own or another's  shadow.  
He cries out for compassion to the only projected image so far which does not threaten and 
impede him.  But his cry here shows that he has made a fundamental mistake.  The aspirant 
mistakes the soul as less fundamental than un omo certo (modern spelling uomo certo), i.e. a 
real man.  In some sense, the poem in its entirety is a battleground wherein the unsubstantial, 
the subtle, the soul and the flesh, the uomo certo, the real material person, are involved in a 
struggle over which aspect of the self will have the authority to guide action, will have the 
substantiality to be. 

64  Quando vidi costui nel gran diserto,
65  “Miserere di me,” gridai a lui,
66  “qual che tu sii, od ombra od omo certo!”

67  Rispuosemi: “Non omo, omo già fui,
68  e li parenti miei furon lombardi,
69  mantoani per patrïa ambedui.

70  Nacqui sub Iulio, ancor che fosse tardi,
71  e vissi a Roma sotto 'l buono Augusto
72  nel tempo de li dèi falsi e bugiardi.

73  Poeta fui, e cantai di quel giusto
74  figliuol d'Anchise che venne di Troia,
75  poi che 'l superbo Ilïón fu combusto.
64  When I beheld him in the desert vast,
65  "Have pity on me," unto him I cried,
66  "Whiche'er thou art, or shade or real man!"
67  He answered me: "Not man; man once I was,
68  And both my parents were of Lombardy,
69  And Mantuans by country both of them.
70  'Sub Julio' was I born, though it was late,
71  And lived at Rome under the good Augustus,
72  During the time of false and lying gods.
73  A poet was I, and I sang that just
74  Son of Anchises, who came forth from Troy,
75  During the time of false and lying gods.
A critical passage which seems just informational, but it begins to reinforce a persistent aspect of Dante's style in mythologizing or psychologizing history and historicizing myth.  
The place and time is important for those incarnated in place and time.  Just as in
Christianity it is crucial that Jesus has brought the timeless, placeless spiritual down 
into a specific point in history, a specific human body dealing with the specificities
of mortal life.  Note here too, that the word parenti, not the word genitori is used by the shade to describe where he is from.  Parenti, doesn't just mean human parents (which would be 
genitori), but patria: homeland.  That patria is the only word available to Dante and not
some word like matria (motherland, not fatherland), foreshadows, probably forever unknown 
to the historical Dante, the whole struggle between feminine nature and masculine 
culture, as it was lived in Dante's time, and also in our own.  That these two are
separated (Dante is separated from Beatrice, exiled from his patria) is the spiritual 
split that the poem is attempting to heal.  There are also something like "space spirits"
which seem to be obliquely referred to here.  Dante and Virgil separated in time by
about 13 centuries are still united, brothers or siblings so to speak, because they
are both Lombards from Mantua.  There is a difference in these brothers united
by space, and that difference is that they are divided by time, and the historical
event of the Savior's incarnation.  Virgil lived in a time where the divine was
divided into many pagan gods, and not made one by a spiritual historical
incarnation.  Virgil, qua Virgil, by virtue of this split in time, cannot reach
certain spiritual heights because the time of his human, historical experience
precluded that view of the soul.  He can know about justice, retribution,
even the purging of the soul, but the idea of unmerited grace is not something
he experienced as part of being a mortal human being.  The reader will
see how this plays out as the poem progresses.

Note: Some Native Americans instead of asking each other What do you do? What is your 
occupation?, ask instead: Where are your mother's people from?  And if you ask this question of yourself, you get a very different answer than if you think of yourself in the context of your 
patronym. 

76  Ma tu perché ritorni a tanta noia?
77  perché non sali il dilettoso monte
78  ch'è principio e cagion di tutta gioia?”

79  “Or se' tu quel Virgilio e quella fonte
80  che spandi di parlar sì largo fiume?”
81  rispuos' io lui con vergognosa fronte.

76  But thou, why goest thou back to such annoyance?
77  Why climb'st thou not the Mount Delectable,
78  Which is the source and cause of every joy?"

79  "Now, art thou that Virgilius and that fountain
80  Which spreads abroad so wide a river of speech?"
81  I made response to him with bashful forehead.

The question here is really an accusation.  Why does the dog return to his vomit?
Why does the spiritual aspirant, once awakening to the light, not proceed
upward to its source?  He already knows that his former way of living has
led to the three beasts and the terror of befuddlement, confusion, and raw and threatening
appetite, so why choose that path and ignore the path of the mountain, which is
the way of delight and the beginning and cause of all joy?  Here, the aspirant 
ignores the question, and instead remains in awe of the messenger's mere
presence in his predicament.  The recognition scene: Dante realizes
that this shade is that of Virgil, his poetic idol, and he is abashed.  He drops
his head.  Contrast this with the lion with raised head and open jaws.  It is however,
a false recognition scene, but neither we, the reader aspirants, nor Dante, the 
protagonist and spiritual chela, can know that at this point.  But it's worth keeping
in mind, because it goes to the heart of what is most fundamental in life.

Another great rhyme of lume (light) and volume (volume, book).

Dante goes on, in awe, telling Virgil, rather redundantly what Virgil obviously
already knows about himself.  Which is: being a great poet might 
get you fame, but it won't redeem you, unless there is that illogical unmerited
grace in what you do.  We moderns might view this unmerited grace as
those fortuitous synchronicities that lift us out of the spinning
squirrel cage of our own efforts, and which knock us out of the
not-so-merry-go-round of our obsessions, our thoughts, our beliefs.  It is only this grace 
which can put us on the path that leads "up" to liberation.  Dante pleads here for a life
of scholarship, the time and ease to study and learn from Virgil's book,
and, like Christ who prays for the bitter cup to pass, Dante wants this comfort.
But he is only thinking about the beautiful style of Virgil's, which he has copied.  He is only 
thinking of the way of beauty and of adornment with honors, and not of the hardship that
his spiritual journey requires.  At this point, Dante the aspirant is willing to 
accept the technical help which Virgil the master poet can provide, but he
is not ready for the grace of his own verse being given a moving inner content, which Virgil 
cannot supply, as we will see much later in the poem.  Which raises the question: Why is Virgil 
barred from heaven?  What has he done to deserve his excommunication?   It's very simple: He 
does not believe in the City of Heaven.  We have the same problem, whether it's with a world 
like Virgil's ruled by capricious gods, which are themselves ruled by chance, or whether it's with our world, ruled by capricious physical and biological imperatives.  It is very  hard to see in our 
surroundings or glean from our everyday experiences anything remotely like a just and loving 
God.  Essentially we do not believe in grace, and not believing in grace blocks grace.  But for 
Virgil, that is putting the effect before the cause.  Yet we must remember: There is no cause 
until the effect reveals it's hitherto hidden presence. 

82  “O de li altri poeti onore e lume,
83  vagliami 'l lungo studio e 'l grande amore
84  che m'ha fatto cercar lo tuo volume.

85  Tu se' lo mio maestro e 'l mio autore,
86  tu se' solo colui da cu' io tolsi
87  lo bello stilo che m'ha fatto onore.

88  Vedi la bestia per cu' io mi volsi;
89  aiutami da lei, famoso saggio,
90  ch'ella mi fa tremar le vene e i polsi.”
82  "O, of the other poets honour and light,
83  Avail me the long study and great love
84  That have impelled me to explore thy volume!
85  Thou art my master, and my author thou,
86  Thou art alone the one from whom I took
87  The beautiful style that has done honour to me.
88  Behold the beast, for which I have turned back;
89  Do thou protect me from her, famous Sage,
90  For she doth make my veins and pulses tremble."
Note the swift linkage from honor and light, experienced as something external,
to a return to the beast, and the internal, bodily experience of fear,
the very veins of the body trembling in their pulse.  The fear here is specifically tied
to the she-wolf, the hunger, want, and subsequent viciousness which Dante hopes
Virgil can help him overcome.  Virgil cannot do that, but he does tell Dante that the way Dante has chosen — that is, to know grace in the physical body — cannot go past this beast.  The 
poet's way is not this way.  Mortality destroys all the living, and the more it eats the thinner it 
becomes, so that physicality becomes like a drug which requires larger and larger doses to get 
less and less satisfaction.  Virgil takes time here to portray this futile ravenous hunger that 
drives the body, in order to show that the body politic mirrors this same natural process.  The 
she wolf first mating with all the animals, and then going from village to village to ravage 
humans.  Also note the contrast of these villages with the City of God mentioned later, a 
development of culture, and in this case, also a spiritual development, the arc climbing
upward from nomad group, to village, to beatific city.  This is more or less the opposite
of Rousseau, and also the Christian desert fathers, both of which saw the city as the 
essence of corruption, and sought a return to a simpler life.  This return to nature,
is not Dante's way.  Like Blake, he wants to transcend nature.      

91  “A te convien tenere altro vïaggio,”
92  rispuose, poi che lagrimar mi vide,
93 “se vuo' campar d'esto loco selvaggio;

94  ché questa bestia, per la qual tu gride,
95  non lascia altrui passar per la sua via,
96  ma tanto lo 'mpedisce che l'uccide;

97  e ha natura sì malvagia e ria,
98  che mai non empie la bramosa voglia,
99  e dopo 'l pasto ha più fame che pria.

100  Molti son li animali a cui s'ammoglia,
101  e più saranno ancora, infin che 'l veltro
102  verrà, che la farà morir con doglia.

103  Questi non ciberà terra né peltro,
104  ma sapïenza, amore e virtute,
105  e sua nazion sarà tra feltro e feltro.
91  "Thee it behoves to take another road,"
92  Responded he, when he beheld me weeping,
93  "If from this savage place thou wouldst escape;
94  Because this beast, at which thou criest out,
95  Suffers not any one to pass her way,
96  But so doth harass him, that she destroys him;
97  And has a nature so malign and ruthless,
98  That never doth she glut her greedy will,
99  And after food is hungrier than before.
100  Many the animals with whom she weds,
101  And more they shall be still, until the Greyhound
102  Comes, who shall make her perish in her pain.
103  He shall not feed on either earth or pelf,
104  But upon wisdom, and on love and virtue;
105  'Twixt Feltro and Feltro shall his nation be;
Some enigmatic passages here, in which the mythical, geographical, spiritual, and political 
merge in a powerful ambiguity.  This makes us want to read these tercets as symbol, not 
merely as sign.  The she wolf will go from village to village in Italy until a certain figure 
arises, represented by a Greyhound.  The Greyhound will destroy want and avarice, and drive 
them back to Hell — in other words the Greyhound will put a limit and a locale to pain.

Scholars have speculated what this passage means (lines 101 - 105), but to me,
it's just a series of images flashed into the brain, with the Greyhound being
a stronger but tamed and trained version of the she-wolf.  This hunting trope can
remind us that it is a life or death business not to just subdue our selfish and corral our fearful
passions, but we must also incorporate these instincts into our psyches.  In effect, we must 
train them, thus giving them the strength to pursue the spiritual path of peace.  

Line 105 — tra feltro e feltro — has puzzled readers for generations.  It has been
pointed out that feltro is part of two Italian place names, so that could be a region
in which political peace is sought.  Also, some have said that feltro is the past participle 
of the verb "to feel", so a physiological/psychological reference would be that peace is felt
from feeling to feeling, between feeling and feeling, yet maybe not in the feelings 
themselves, but in the aftermath of having felt them.

Note on line 103 (Questi non ciberà terra né peltro):  He (the savior, the saved) shall no
longer feed on dirt or pelf, which is kind of like a pica, the craving for non-nutritious 
foods and experience, eating hamburgers and fries until it kills us, polluting the air
for trinkets or for the abstraction of money, until it kills us, etc.  It's a striking image
built up here of this she wolf who attacks and kills everyone, and has the psychic
appearance of a desperately boney canine trying to fend off starvation by eating dirt
and skin.  

106  Di quella umile Italia fia salute
107  per cui morì la vergine Cammilla,
108  Eurialo e Turno e Niso di ferute.

109  Questi la caccerà per ogne villa,
110  fin che l'avrà rimessa ne lo 'nferno,
111  là onde 'nvidia prima dipartilla.
106  Of that low Italy shall he be the saviour,
107  On whose account the maid Camilla died,
108  Euryalus, Turnus, Nisus, of their wounds;
109  Through every city shall he hunt her down,
110  Until he shall have driven her back to Hell,
111  There from whence envy first did let her loose.
With the mention of Cammilla, a virgin warrior who died at the destruction of Troy, Dante
links the internecine wars in his Italy, to the mythic or historical destruction of Troy.  He
works throughout the whole of the Commedia to fold all these components together.
The cause of these dystopias is made clear in line 111 about the wave of envy.  But I think of
invidia as something more than what is usually meant by envy.  It's also an intense one-up-manship of nations wanting bigger armies, of men wanting more money and power, of
anyone feeling that life is a zero sum game of winners and losers, and in the end,
there can only be one winner.  The irony here is that this winner, like all the others he has 
defeated or tried to defeat, is, like them, claimed by death.

The next few lines are Virgil's preview of what Dante will experience if he, the
desperate aspirant, follows him.  It must be a choice, even a rational choice, but
once the foot touches the dragon path of the moving sidewalk, choice ends, as does
the hope of self-reliance.  Here, Virgil tells Dante just how far he can go before he has 
to turn Dante over to teachers who can complete, not his moral education, but his spiritual
one.     

112  Ond' io per lo tuo me' penso e discerno
113  che tu mi segui, e io sarò tua guida,
114  e trarrotti di qui per loco etterno;

115  (d) ove udirai le disperate strida,
116  vedrai li antichi spiriti dolenti,
117  ch'a la seconda morte ciascun grida;

118  e vederai color che son contenti
119  nel foco, perché speran di venire
120  quando che sia a le beate genti.

121  A le quai poi se tu vorrai salire,
122  anima fia a ciò più di me degna:
123  con lei ti lascerò nel mio partire;

124  ché quello imperador che là sù regna,
125  perch' i' fu' ribellante a la sua legge,
126  non vuol che 'n sua città per me si vegna.

127  In tutte parti impera e quivi regge;
128  quivi è la sua città e l'alto seggio:
129  oh felice colui cu' ivi elegge!”
112  Therefore I think and judge it for thy best
113  Thou follow me, and I will be thy guide,
114  And lead thee hence through the eternal place,
115  Where thou shalt hear the desperate lamentations,
116  Shalt see the ancient spirits disconsolate,
117  Who cry out each one for the second death;
118  And thou shalt see those who contented are
119  Within the fire, because they hope to come,
120  Whene'er it may be, to the blessed people;
121  To whom, then, if thou wishest to ascend,
122  A soul shall be for that than I more worthy;
123  With her at my departure I will leave thee;
124  Because that Emperor, who reigns above,
125  In that I was rebellious to his law,
126  Wills that through me none come into his city.
127  He governs everywhere, and there he reigns;
128  There is his city and his lofty throne;
129  O happy he whom thereto he elects!"
All this speech of Virgil begins with, Trust me, follow me, I know the way, and it ends
with Beyond this point I am not to be trusted or followed, and I cannot follow you.

There is a reference here to God on his throne in the midst of His Celestial city,
but Virgil, the earthly or earthy artist, cannot go there.  His whole rationale for
being and writing (and maybe this will become clearer, in a later Canto)
can only approach the boundary of this Other.  Virgil knows
that he can never know enough, and that somehow these "elect"
have, through an act of inconceivable (to him) grace, managed to surpass
what the ancients achieved through what they called "virtue", a kind
of developed set of masculine qualities admired by other men.

130  E io a lui: “Poeta, io ti richeggio
131  per quello Dio che tu non conoscesti,
132  a ciò ch'io fugga questo male e peggio,

133  che tu mi meni là dov' or dicesti,
134  sì ch'io veggia la porta di san Pietro
135  e color cui tu fai cotanto mesti.”

136  Allor si mosse, e io li tenni dietro.
130  And I to him: "Poet, I thee entreat,
131  By that same God whom thou didst never know,
132  So that I may escape this woe and worse,
133  Thou wouldst conduct me there where thou hast said,
134  That I may see the portal of Saint Peter,
135  And those thou makest so disconsolate."

136  Then he moved on, and I behind him followed.
These last lines of Canto I, the introduction, before entering Hell proper, are most
poignant because Dante the aspirant realizes that he is destined to go beyond
where his teacher can take him, and he prays to Virgil in the name of the God,
the spirit of grace, let us say, that Virgil does not know, and will be ever blind
to.  The aspirant aspires to reach "la porta di san Pietro," that is, Saint Peter's, i.e. the pearly 
gates, although the way lies through "those that you have made so disconsolate"  
(line 136, e color cui tu fai cotanto mesti.)  Dante the aspirant makes a huge
leap of faith here, he follows Virgil, humbly follows him, behind (dietro).  However, the 
next gate that Dante sees will not be the pearly one.

Canto II
Summary of Structure of Canto II, Inferno

Introduction: Space and Time
Atmosphere, Brown Air
Time: Good Friday Evening, April 8th, 1300; spring, in mythic terms: the beginning of the world

The animal nature going to sleep

First: Call 
Invocation to the Muses and Virgil for help
First Response
Dante's Enthusiasm followed by fear and paralysis
failure and delay
Virgil's admonishment and trope of an animal shying at shadows

Second Call
Beatrice to Virgil to help Dante
Tears. shining eyes metaphor
Second Response
Virgil's immediate response, success
Beginning of retrograde time

Third Call
Gentle Lady (Virgin Mary) to St. Lucy
Third response
St. Lucy's immediate response, success 

Fourth Call
St. Lucy to Beatrice (with Rachael)
Fourth Response
Beatrice's immediate response, success
shining eyes metaphor

Return to the First Call
(return to forward motion time)
Virgil to Dante
(Metaphor of frost blighted blossoms revived by the sun, foreshadowing of the frozen 
lake at the pit of Hell)
 
Response to Repeated First Call
Dante's immediate response, success

Descent into Hell Proper

Note: This "call and response" device mirrors the perfomance of the Catholic Mass.

Canto II is the prelude to the Inferno, as Canto I is the prelude to the entire Commedia.  This does not mean that it is some kind of summary, it's more like a preparation.  Dante, the pilgrim, 
the spiritual aspirant, cannot go forward if dragged back and down by fear or self-doubt.  When we intuit that we are going to start a great enterprise, the question arises: Why me?  How am even remotely qualified to do this?  How will I find the strength and the wisdom to answer my 
calling?  Like Canto I, Canto II also begins in darkness, as animals are relieved of their earthly 
fatigue by sleep.  Dante enters the darkness as a warrior, alone (among the living), but 
he does have spiritual guides.  We can say that the animal nature of man, the mortal man with 
his bodily, amoral, animal appetites, the three beasts that impede the aspirant in Canto I, are 
now going to sleep, released from the fatigue of pursuing earthly things (Darwinian fight for 
survival by mating and murdering).  But Dante, in a living body, not a dream body or spiritual 
body, moves forward.  We are reminded of Blake's vow: I will not cease from mental fight, nor 
shall my sword sleep in my hand, 'till we have built Jerusalem in England's green and sunny land.

There is an emphasis on Dante's physicality here, as opposed to the shades who have come to 
assist him, and Dante (the narrator, not Dante the pilgrim) even has to convince Virgil, or 
himself, that such is possible, because in the Aeneid, Virgil also has Aeneas descend to the 
nightmare land of shades  (As did Ulysses (Odysseus), while still in a living body.
Note: Dante never read Homer, but he knew of him by reputation, and so probably would have been aware that Virgil's verse concerning visiting the land of the dead was a recapitulation of
Odysseus' visit to the land of shades.  Pound also copied this theme in his Canto's.  It's a very 
old trope, it also appears in the Epic of Gilgamesh, the earliest piece of written literature that 
we have.  The descriptions all match closely: It's not a pleasant place.   

1  Lo giorno se n'andava, e l'aere bruno
2  toglieva li animai che sono in terra
3  da le fatiche loro; e io sol uno

4  m'apparecchiava a sostener la guerra
5  sì del cammino e sì de la pietate,
6  che ritrarrà la mente che non erra.
1  Day was departing, and the embrowned air
2  Released the animals that are on earth
3  From their fatigues; and I the only one
4  Made myself ready to sustain the war,
5  Both of the way and likewise of the woe,
6  Which memory that errs not shall retrace.
Poetry, like mortal life, relies on breath, the breath on atmosphere, so Dante is very concerned with the atmosphere of any given locale.  This is more than mood, it is the affectation of a certain pattern of breathing.  In Canto 2 of the Inferno, as night comes on in an air, not dark blue or black, but brown (e l'aere bruno), the beast self which is subject to mortal fatigue is stripped away.  The verb togliere is used here to describe what happens to the animals, it is poorly translated hear as released, but another more violent meaning is to strip away, fatigue stripped away, like a hunter skinning an animal, as if fatigue were a kind of pelt that protects the mortal from being attacked by the second death, mortal sleep, which will spirit the body and identity away into an unknown region.  Shakespeare: "Death's second self which seals up all in rest."  The insomnia theme comes back here with a very jarring image of the poet/pilgrim/aspirant girding up his loins to prepare for war.  What war?  The war of the downward way which unless one is militantly vigilant will strip away the memory of being a human spirit on a journey to unite with universal spirit.  The word mente is used (feminine here "la mente"), and I do not think this is the same as memoria, another translation problem.  Dante uses the word memoria in other contexts, so he is making a distinction that the translator doesn't.  Mente is mind, not a limited human mind, but mind at large, the conscious cosmos, or better, the cosmos of consciousness, whose operations out-picture what we perceive as the physical world, and make what we call material reality from what is tangible in the limited spectrum of our human senses.  It is fitting that from these lines, the next few follow, the classical invocation to the muses.
7  O Muse, o alto ingegno, or m'aiutate;
8  o mente che scrivesti ciò ch'io vidi,
9  qui si parrà la tua nobilitate.

7  O Muses, O high genius, now assist me!
8  O memory, that didst write down what I saw,
9  Here thy nobility shall be manifest!

We don't know who or what the Muse is, because it (she? he?) is the entire complicated background from which ideas, sensory experience, imagination, words, etc. arise, here, says the poet, 'your nobility will appear'.  We need to watch for the resonance of this word nobility, whose meaning has changed for us with the decline of a social aristocratic hierarchy.  But I think it is the feeling inside a person that says the universe, the Muse, has selected me to do great things, to paint the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, to write King Lear or the Commedia, a feeling that is not so much tied to self-aggrandizement, getting conflated with the sin of pride, but a feeling of duty, or of performing a sacred vow, of becoming the sacrifice, and of giving up all your time and diversions and even your common filial relationships to accomplish a task, for which you deserve no credit, because that kind of credit would have to have been usurped by an isolated and false identity.  Dante, the pilgrim, not Dante the poet, is lost here, and he cries out next to the only guide he knows: Virgil.  But it should be noted that this is only a substitute kind of assistance, genuine succor can only come after the moral decks have been cleared so to speak, after the animal has been stripped of his fatigue and appetites, and the shadow of hell has been seen and purged.

10  Io cominciai: “Poeta che mi guidi,
11  guarda la mia virtù s'ell' è possente,
12  prima ch'a l'alto passo tu mi fidi.

13  Tu dici che di Silvïo il parente,
 14  corruttibile ancora, ad immortale
 15  secolo andò, e fu sensibilmente.

16  Però, se l'avversario d'ogne male
17  cortese i fu, pensando l'alto effetto
18  ch'uscir dovea di lui, e 'l chi e 'l quale

19  non pare indegno ad omo d'intelletto;
20  ch'e' fu de l'alma Roma e di suo impero
21  ne l'empireo ciel per padre eletto:

22  la quale e 'l quale, a voler dir lo vero,
23  fu stabilita per lo loco santo
24  u' siede il successor del maggior Piero.

10  And I began: "Poet, who guidest me,
11  Regard my manhood, if it be sufficient,
12  Ere to the arduous pass thou dost confide me.
13  Thou sayest, that of Silvius the parent,
14  While yet corruptible, unto the world
15  Immortal went, and was there bodily.
16  But if the adversary of all evil
17  Was courteous, thinking of the high effect
18  That issue would from him, and who, and what,
19  To men of intellect unmeet it seems not;
20  For he was of great Rome, and of her empire
21  In the empyreal heaven as father chosen;
22  The which and what, wishing to speak the truth,
23  Were stablished as the holy place, wherein
24  Sits the successor of the greatest Peter.
So much is packed into these few lines that it would take volumes to effectively gloss them.  Why Virgil? and Why me?  That seems to be the gist.  Here Dante the aspirant is not only asking Virgil is he, Dante, is going to have sufficient strength (specifically virtù and possente, something like masculine attributes and puissance, an echo of the militancy alluded to in line 4) to carry out this task, this quest.  He is also telling Virgil what Virgil's qualifications are for assisting him.  The first is that Virgil (through his Aeneas' persona) went to the land of the dead while still in his mortal body, and the more interesting reasons are things that Virgil can know nothing about, because they were events in his future, which to him is a blank.  Specifically, Aeneas' offspring, Silvius, founded a line which founded Rome, and this is important because Rome becomes the Holy Seat of Saint Peter, Vicar of Christ.  Why should we care about that?  Because what Dante is really saying in these few lines is what he is saying with the whole Commedia:  namely, these lineages which are the sexual evolution, through sequential time, of the violent, fearful secular, become a center of sacred peace.  Not just the peace that is the calm absence of conflict, but the peace that is a source of radiance.  In Zen parlance, and viewing time as a simultaneity, not just a sequence: Samsara is Nirvana.  
Robert Louis Stevenson wrote a story in which a criminal act leads to a series of events which creates a more than compensatory good, and a good act, leads to events productive of a vast evil.  That seems to be what is being stated here.  Only the Adversary of all evil has the courtesy to see time not as a line, but as a sphere, a kind of ball of string which is composed of effects indistinguishable from causes.  
Then there is this, for us moderns, curious word courtesy.  I don't think this just means courtliness, or refinement, but something like a nose for the subtle perfume of the good wafting through the stench of corruption.  We think courtesy means being polite, but that is a terribly inadequate definition.  It's a word Chaucer uses a lot to mean something like what I've stated here, so I tip my metaphorical hat to him for helping me through that particular kink in the maze.
I would also say that visiting the realm of the dead shows us the effect of the past, as living is the effect of the present, and this is the only way to gain the perspective to see past, present, and future as false divisions.  If you were spirit, as we shall learn, the passage back to mortal life is impossible, or only possible in unique sorts of circumstances, you must examine spirit from the perspective of mortal life, or mortal life is simply a severed ganglion cut off from the creative processes of the cosmos.   The next few lines make this clearer, Virgil's work, held to be prophetic of Christ's birth, could only be possible as prophesy, not history, by virtue of this visitation to the land of the dead. 
25  Per quest' andata onde li dai tu vanto,
26  intese cose che furon cagione
27  di sua vittoria e del papale ammanto.

28  Andovvi poi lo Vas d'elezïone,
29  per recarne conforto a quella fede
30  ch'è principio a la via di salvazione.
25  Upon this journey, whence thou givest him vaunt,
26  Things did he hear, which the occasion were
27  Both of his victory and the papal mantle.
28  Thither went afterwards the Chosen Vessel,
29  To bring back comfort thence unto that Faith,
30  Which of salvation's way is the beginning.
Again, density on density, the very essence of poetic speech.  The translation here is just horrible, but to be fair, even the Italian is pretty difficult and compact.  The word onde means wave in modern Italian, although it means place here, so there is a hint here of a wave of time, taking a journey which is motivated by pride (vanto) to a place where it is possible to hear things that will lead to the victory of a papal mantle — the covering, or if you prefer, the adornment of the Chosen Vessel.  The rhyme of elezïone and salvazione knit together the idea of grace (unmerited election) and salvation (also unmerited election).  The little prideful self will always choose the way of moral inversion and perversion, while the big Jungian Self weaves the actions of mortal humans into the grander designs of what we have come to call destiny.
31  Ma io, perché venirvi? o chi 'l concede?
32  Io non Enëa, io non Paulo sono;
33  me degno a ciò né io né altri 'l crede.

34  Per che, se del venire io m'abbandono,
35  temo che la venuta non sia folle.
36  Se' savio; intendi me' ch'i' non ragiono.”

37  E qual è quei che disvuol ciò che volle
38  e per novi pensier cangia proposta,
39  sì che dal cominciar tutto si tolle,

40  tal mi fec' ïo 'n quella oscura costa,
41  perché, pensando, consumai la 'mpresa
42  che fu nel cominciar cotanto tosta.

31  But I, why thither come, or who concedes it?
32  I not Aeneas am, I am not Paul,
33  Nor I, nor others, think me worthy of it.
34  Therefore, if I resign myself to come,
35  I fear the coming may be ill-advised;
36  Thou'rt wise, and knowest better than I speak."
37  And as he is, who unwills what he willed,
38  And by new thoughts doth his intention change,
39  So that from his design he quite withdraws,
40  Such I became, upon that dark hillside,
41  Because, in thinking, I consumed the emprise,
42  Which was so very prompt in the beginning.
Lines 31 -42 are all a long quivering of equivocation.  A stroke of insight floods our consciousness with light, but it is only like a flash of lightning that illuminates everything, and then goes dark again.  Did we really see the whole work spread out before us in perfect clarity?  Are we really the one to shout to those who did not see that there is a world out there, a world of light, and forms of light, and there are unimaginable entities, trees, houses, cities, forests, and other people, people who see, people who take the light for granted?  Are we really going to claim that some special flash of fire from the darkness was meant for us alone, and that what ever that fire brought to light, it is now our task to illuminate it with words?  Dante, the aspirant, throws heavy shadows on his own first burst of enthusiasm, sees the monumentality of the quest, and shrinks back into the nebulosity which had wafted him into this very state of hopeless confusion.  He turns to Virgil for help.  And Virgil's help?  First to admonish, and then to inform.
There is also another way to read this, and that is that Dante the poet establishes his authority though humility, that is to say, by admitting his weakness.  He's no braggart Odysseus or Oedipus, this reading would echo the reading in Canto I of ascending by keeping the firm foot lowest.  The two readings may seem in conflict, but there is a difference in being paralyzed by a feeling of inadequacy and moving forward with humility.  At the end of this Canto, we see that Dante the pilgrim chooses the later. 
There is a little circle here in Virgil's reply to Dante, that mirrors what Dante says in line 6 of this Canto, namely, che ritrarrà la mente che non erra, that he now has to repeat that which has no error.   This is not the same as memory, per se, recounting and experience "without" error.  No, it is a recapitulation of the actual "error free" state of a spiritual experience so that it revivifies the spiritual experience.  In the spirit, there cannot be a before experience or an after experience, there is just this experience, all-encompassing and timeless.   That is Dante's poetic task in the whole Commedia, and that is also Virgil's task now in recounting to Dante how the intercession of Beatrice has brought him to help Dante.  Virgil must also be in this error-free state imparted to him by a series of down-shifts in love-power, from the transpersonal dynamo of the Virgin Mary, through Saint Lucy (a martyr who was blinded, and whose vision is therefore of spiritual not physical or temporal things.  Her name means light, and the light that we see by cannot see itself) and then through Beatrice, Dante's personal spiritual (not carnal) lover.  This is the closest Virgil can come to grace, his service's payment is to be praised to God, something that Virgil cannot understand.  He can only understand quid pro quo, or magnanimity (a virtue that Dante praises him for having), and not grace.  But what does motivate Virgil is his need to respond to a good and beautiful (line 53: beata e bella) lady, who comes for Dante's grace, not his own.
Note: Mary means sea.  Lucia, light.  Beatrice, blessedness, and the fact the Beatrice is with Rachael, who was associated with the contemplative life, shows one way that Beatrice is blessed, i.e., through spiritual contemplation, and as we shall see later, through praising.  

43  “S'i' ho ben la parola tua intesa,”
44  rispuose del magnanimo quell' ombra,
45   “l'anima tua è da viltade offesa;

46  la qual molte fïate l'omo ingombra
47  sì che d'onrata impresa lo rivolve,
48  come falso veder bestia quand' ombra.

49  Da questa tema a ciò che tu ti solve,
50  dirotti perch' io venni e quel ch'io 'ntesi
51  nel primo punto che di te mi dolve.

52  Io era tra color che son sospesi,
53  e donna mi chiamò beata e bella,
54  tal che di comandare io la richiesi.

55  Lucevan li occhi suoi più che la stella;
56  e cominciommi a dir soave e piana,
57  con angelica voce, in sua favella:

43  "If I have well thy language understood,"
44  Replied that shade of the Magnanimous,
45  "Thy soul attainted is with cowardice,
46  Which many times a man encumbers so,
47  It turns him back from honoured enterprise,
48  As false sight doth a beast, when he is shy.
49  That thou mayst free thee from this apprehension,
50  I'll tell thee why I came, and what I heard
51  At the first moment when I grieved for thee.
52  Among those was I who are in suspense,
53  And a fair, saintly Lady called to me
54  In such wise, I besought her to command me.
55  Her eyes where shining brighter than the Star;
56  And she began to say, gentle and low,
57  With voice angelical, in her own language:
Some specific thoughts about these lines.  Line 45 - 48: That Dante's soul is still tainted with that fear that makes it jump at shadows.  Anyone who has ridden a recalcitrant horse, knows what this means, when they shy and jump sideways because of some movement that frightens them.  These are peripheral events, as prey animals like the horse have eyes on the sides of their heads, so that they cannot be ambused from behind or the side, they are eyes trained to slight movements, shadows, when these shadows twitch, the animal cannot go forwards but jumps sideways or back.  This is Dante's state, he loses focus in an instant from going forward, to jumping back, and this image Virgil compares to that of a frightened animal.  More brilliant and ironic poetics here in that the word ombra (shadow, shade) is used both to describe Virgil and also the shadow that frightens, and both of these ombra's are rhymed with ingombra, which means cluttered, or encumbered, and also, in one of its synonyms to be strangled or suffocated.  Everything in Dante's poem fits together and overlaps, and the overlapping intensifies the meanings.  A shadow that frightens, a shadow that guides, a human spirit's doubts, and the reaction of a terrified animal — and I've only touched the surface of the repercussive depths of what even one word or one line reveals.  Line 48 ends Virgil's admonition, then he begins to inform Dante's understanding of why he has come and how he began to be aware of Dante and to grieve for him.
One other note of interest here pertains to line 55, which says that the Lady's eyes are brighter than the star (star singular, not plural).  Not an empty tired simile, but a signal to Virgil that this interlocutor is from Heaven, not earth, and certainly not Hell.  The star is a guiding star, like the star that led the wise men to the manger of Jesus. 
There is an echo contrasting the weakness of Virgil's voice in Canto I, and Beatrice's voice here.  Beatrice speaks sweetly and softly (soave e piana)  Dante the poet is very concerned about how people speak and not just what they are saying.  Beatrice's voice is sweet and soft, which reminds me of Yeats' in his poem Hound Voice:
Because we love bare hills and stunted trees
And were the last to choose the settled ground,
Its boredom of the desk or of the spade, because
So many years companioned by a hound,
Our voices carry; and though slumber-bound,
Some few half wake and half renew their choice,
Give tongue, proclaim their hidden name — 'Hound Voice.'

The women that I picked spoke sweet and low
And yet gave tongue.  'Hound Voices' were they all ...

Language note: For Virgil the word angelica could not have meant what we mean, because, for one thing, he would not have been aware of its meaning in Christian terms.  The word itself is very old, and predates Christianity.  Here, it's is more likely to mean simply messenger.  I think this heavy Christianization of language, which is in fact, Dante's medium, does keep contemporary readers from understanding the much more stark and powerful message of the Commedia.  My reading of Dante gets more relevant to me, anyway, when I work to reinterpret what Dante is saying in a mental idiom (as distinct from a solely linguistic one) that has more of the thrust and power of the original than Christian glosses impart to it.  The placement of this word in Virgil's mouth could also just be a mistake of Dante's, a little fabric grin wherein we see Dante the poet behind the curtain, as the mouthpiece for everyone.  But Dante doesn't make many mistakes — if any — what he does is usually on purpose, so if a puzzle like this crops up, it's better to dig deeper into the poem's intentions and not just assume that you're catching Dante in something slipshod.  Even those parts of the poem which seem like rather tortured constructions usually have some organic purpose to fulfill, and their tortured-ness will be found to be ingeniously apropos. 

58  'O anima cortese mantoana,
59  di cui la fama ancor nel mondo dura,
60  e durerà quanto 'l mondo lontana,

61  l'amico mio, e non de la ventura,
62  ne la diserta piaggia è impedito
63  sì nel cammin, che vòlt' è per paura;

64  e temo che non sia già sì smarrito,
65  ch'io mi sia tardi al soccorso levata,
66  per quel ch'i' ho di lui nel cielo udito.

67  Or movi, e con la tua parola ornata
68  e con ciò c'ha mestieri al suo campare,
69  l'aiuta sì ch'i' ne sia consolata.

70  I' son Beatrice che ti faccio andare;
71  vegno del loco ove tornar disio;
72  amor mi mosse, che mi fa parlare.

73  Quando sarò dinanzi al segnor mio,
74  di te mi loderò sovente a lui.'
75  Tacette allora, e poi comincia' io:
58  'O spirit courteous of Mantua,
59  Of whom the fame still in the world endures,
60  And shall endure, long-lasting as the world;
61  A friend of mine, and not the friend of fortune,
62  Upon the desert slope is so impeded
63  Upon his way, that he has turned through terror,
64  And may, I fear, already be so lost,
65  That I too late have risen to his succour,
66  From that which I have heard of him in Heaven.
67  Bestir thee now, and with thy speech ornate,
68  And with what needful is for his release,
69  Assist him so, that I may be consoled.
70  Beatrice am I, who do bid thee go;
71  I come from there, where I would fain return;
72  Love moved me, which compelleth me to speak.
73  When I shall be in presence of my Lord,
74  Full often will I praise thee unto him.'
75  Then paused she, and thereafter I began:
These lines (58 - 75) in which Virgil recounts to Dante, the aspirant, how he came to be called to help him, as soon as one begins to think about them, imply a rather shocking view of the relationship between hell and paradise.  Note the following points.
1) That the blessed retain their individual identities (line 70: I am Beatrice, l' son Beatrice).
2) That the blessed can feel grief for the living (line 69: Assist him so that I may be consoled, l'aiuta sì ch'i' ne sia consolata)
3) That even in paradise, knowledge of those in hell and of the living is incomplete, uncertain, and can still be subject to doubt and rumor  (lines 66 - from that which I have heard of him in heaven, per quel ch'i' ho di lui nel cielo udito.)
4)  That the blessed can share the feelings of the living.  Dante is losing his way through fear and Beatrice is likewise afraid.  Is there a difference in the fear of Dante denoted by the Italian phrase avere paura, and the fear of Beatrice, expressed in the word temo?  Is Dante's fear, fear for self, and Beatrice's fear for others?
5)  That those in hell may still assist those in heaven.  Which in some sense implies that the damned may possess powers and capabilities which the blessed do not.  And do those capabilities involve something like an Orphean power of poetic enchantment?  (line 67, the reference to Virgil's parola ornata, ornate speech, which is specifically what Dante needs for his release.  Apparently this power exceeds even the power of the prayers of the blessed.  Really!  What an extraordinary claim, or in this case acquiescence of the blessed to one of the damned, and the implication that the poetic power is a kind of magic that prevails in all possible worlds — in Hell, among the living, and even among the blessed.  This jaw-dropping claim for poetry may go back to Genesis, wherein God's power to create is specifically tied to a speech act: And God said ... etc.
6)  That even the blessed can make mistakes, be in doubt, have negative feelings, etc.  (Passim).
7)  That Hell is not normally a locale that is accessible to the blessed, and that they can feel uncomfortable there, and that the only ticket of passage in or out of Hell is love. (lines 71, 72).  Love compels the lover to abandon Heaven for Hell, and more crucially, it compels us to speak.  This power of love via speech is also exactly the power that Beatrice is using to convince Virgil to come to Dante's aid.  
8)  That fame (line 59) is the coin of the realm on earth, and praise (line 74) that of heaven. (We shall have to keep that word fame, fama, in mind.  We moderns interpret it as celebrity, but I think it means something like a psychic resonance which connects, in this case, writer and readers, fame being something like a transpersonal artery that connects two hearts with the same feeling, via, in Virgil's and Dante's case, that poetic power already alluded to.  In this sense, Virgil, though in Hell, is still connected to both those living in material bodies on earth and those in spiritual bodies in Paradise.
9)  That fortune (line 61) can afflict the living, in spite of the favor that they have from the blessed.  Another extraordinary claim.  Chance still seems to be either a shadowy attribute of God, or a God herself who out gods God.
Essentially all of these tropes are about relationships: the connections and the sharing of resources in a circulatory system that is transpersonal: like language.  This canto is about shared language, and more than 80% of it is devoted to dialog, only Canto XI in the inferno has more.  Dialog, of course, is not just between persons — inside each person, there are many voices, and whether these voices conflict or cooperate determines whether we are mad or sane.
None of this of course will mean anything to modern readers who do not share Dante's Christian worldview, and do not believe in the entire construct of the three worlds of spirit either arising from the imaginations of the living, or giving shape to the living's imagination.  Who are these blessed, these damned, these repentant?  If we are going to read Dante as anything more than a fable, we have to assess what validity if any this conceit of the many worlds still has for us.  A transference of these spiritual states to the realm of psyche, of soul, can give us a psychological interpretation that moderns will have no trouble seeing as relevant to their own life experience.  We know through our emotions whether we are in a hell state, a purgatorial state, a limbo or suspended state, or a beautiful state, so in that sense Dante's work is still quite relevant, although it's symbols are outmoded, and should be updated to those of the DSM - 5) (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders).  I think this is woefully inadequate.  Hint: the old Cabbalistic idea of the Ain Soph, the old physicists' idea of the ether, and the idea of Numa, or universal mind.  Essentially we are talking about the attributes of the Universe that makes a cosmos out of chaos, and a chaos from a cosmos.  These are the biggest most impersonal questions, and also the most personal and intimate ones.  What the Commedia is is a map for negotiating a path from fear, exclusion, punishment, and death to an individual's total immersion in light as light.  But this map is not just a map, there is also somehow a kind of entanglement in the very processes that birthed and evolve the universe.  
Why I'm using Dante's work as a map for my own spiritual evolution is because I know of no other writer or no other work of any kind which traces this journey so thoroughly as does the Commedia.  Dante's map is so conflated with these elemental processes that it has transcended the quality of mere map, and has become the territory.  And as usual, the devil, and the angels are in the details, and this is where Dante excels.  He is a master at amassing detail none of which in any least tittle of minutia are superfluous to his vision of the whole.  That's why I am taking such pains to examine these details of the text: because there is no aspect of the work, however seemingly inconsequential, or boring, or obscure, or informational that does not serve as a portal to a realm whose features would otherwise be inaccessible and unimaginable.
76  'O donna di virtù sola per cui
77  l'umana spezie eccede ogne contento
78  di quel ciel c'ha minor li cerchi sui,
79  tanto m'aggrada il tuo comandamento,
80  che l'ubidir, se già fosse, m'è tardi;
81  più non t'è uo' ch'aprirmi il tuo talento.

82  Ma dimmi la cagion che non ti guardi
83  lo scender qua giuso in questo centro
84  de l'ampio loco ove tornar tu ardi.'
76  'O Lady of virtue, thou alone through whom
77  The human race exceedeth all contained
78  Within the heaven that has the lesser circles,
79  So grateful unto me is thy commandment,
80  To obey, if 'twere already done, were late;
81  No farther need'st thou ope to me thy wish.
82  But the cause tell me why thou dost not shun
83  The here descending down into this centre,
84  From the vast place thou burnest to return to.'
The first thing we notice about this is that Virgil, unlike Dante, the pilgrim, does not shrink in fear from the great task he is given, but immediately undertakes to do it, and his very presence with Dante shows that indeed he has already pulled Dante back from the brink.  Virgil's and Beatrice's will are one. (Lines 79 - 81).  He is grateful to be able to answer this call of spirit.    
In line 76, again the word virtue, but what's different perhaps is that this is a virtue inherent in the blessed which causes them to exceed every human being who does not possess it.
Note: line 76, the lesser circle is Earth, below the circle of the moon (luna, lunacy).  Earth is dominated by fortune, caprice, chance, and Beatrice says in line 61  that Dante is her friend, the friend of blessedness, but not the friend of fortune.  In spiritual things, or artistic, or poetic, if you prefer, Dante is blessed, in Earthly, i.e., what we would call practical things, unlucky.
Then, in lines 82 - 84, Virgil, noticing the Beatrice is burning (ardi) to return to heaven (even the blessed, it seems, suffer when in hell), asks why she doesn't shun this place.  The center that he is alluding to here is Hell, which is in the core of Earth, and is farthest from God.  The answer that Beatrice gives him in the lines that follow establishes two things.  The first is none of miseries of hell can ordinarily touch the blessed, their only fear is the fear of that which has the power to do others harm (lines 88 - 89).  She has received grace (line 91), and cannot be touched by the sufferings of the soul's in hell.  And the second is, that her intervention is a unique dispensation, granted by "a gentle lady in Heaven" (line 94 — and there is that word gentle again), to break the law of separation between heaven and hell.  Dante in his poem will do what God has presumably done only twice: one, when he became incarnate in Jesus as the Christ, and two, when through the Virgin, he sent Beatrice to Virgil to save Dante.  Dante the pilgrim might falter again and again, but this passage tells us that Dante the poet is ordained to recapitulate a spiritual journey, without error.  Now that is confidence!
85  Da che tu vuo' saver cotanto a dentro,
86  dirotti brievemente,' mi rispuose,
87  'perch' i' non temo di venir qua entro.

88  Temer si dee di sole quelle cose
89  c'hanno potenza di fare altrui male;
90  de l'altre no, ché non son paurose.

91  I' son fatta da Dio, sua mercé, tale,
92  che la vostra miseria non mi tange,
93  né fiamma d'esto 'ncendio non m'assale.

94  Donna è gentil nel ciel che si compiange
95  di questo 'mpedimento ov' io ti mando,
96  sì che duro giudicio là sù frange.
85  'Since thou wouldst fain so inwardly discern,
86  Briefly will I relate,' she answered me,
87  'Why I am not afraid to enter here.
88  Of those things only should one be afraid
89  Which have the power of doing others harm;
90  Of the rest, no; because they are not fearful.
91  God in his mercy such created me
92  That misery of yours attains me not,
93  Nor any flame assails me of this burning.
94  A gentle Lady is in Heaven, who grieves
95  At this impediment, to which I send thee,
96  So that stern judgment there above is broken.
This recapitulation of Beatrice's speech is an example of Virgil repeating "without error" what transpired between them.  There is a bit of irony here which shows Virgil's limitations.  In line 84, he says after he notices Beatrice's discomfort, that she is burning to return to where she came from (the word used is ardi, which means "you burn"), but she assures him in line 93 that no flame can incinerate her, nothing of the miseries of hell can touch her.  Why?  It's the way she had been made.  She said before that she was moved by love, and here she says "a gentle lady in heaven grieves for this impediment."  (There's that word "gentle" again.)  This gentle lady apparently has sent Beatrice, just as she is now sending Virgil, each step of transfer, operating with less and less spiritual power, since the gentle lady has been assumed by commentators to be the Virgin Mary (Mary means "sea", in this case a sea of compassion.)  Very Catholic here, as Mary, or in this case her proxy, is assumed to be the intercessor between human degradation and divine perfection.  If Beatrice is moved by love, Mary seems moved by mercy, that these ideas are linked seems obvious enough, but the irony is that Dante is about to enter Hell proper where whenever he feels or tries to show mercy or compassion to the damned, he is admonished by Virgil.  The damned are not worthy of pity or mercy — a weird thought.  Apparently, for those in a state of bliss, suffering is anathema, and they are "made" impervious to both suffering and suffers.  Another translation issue in line 96 when dura, hard, is translated as stern.  This misses all the play on the word dura or its variations which has already been happening in the first two cantos.  Plus it misses the contrast in the line where "hard" judgement, is in the last word "frangible", so God's judgement here is depicted as something brittle and breakable like glass.
97  Questa chiese Lucia in suo dimando
98  e disse: «Or ha bisogno il tuo fedele
99 di te, e io a te lo raccomando.»

100  Lucia, nimica di ciascun crudele,
101  si mosse, e venne al loco dov' i' era,
102  che mi sedea con l'antica Rachele.

103  Disse: «Beatrice, loda di Dio vera,
104  ché non soccorri quei che t'amò tanto,
105  ch'uscì per te de la volgare schiera?

106  Non odi tu la pieta del suo pianto,
107  non vedi tu la morte che 'l combatte
108  su la fiumana ove 'l mar non ha vanto?»

109  Al mondo non fur mai persone ratte
110  a far lor pro o a fuggir lor danno,
111  com' io, dopo cotai parole fatte,

112  venni qua giù del mio beato scanno,
113  fidandomi del tuo parlare onesto,
114  ch'onora te e quei ch'udito l'hanno.'
97  In her entreaty she besought Lucia,
98  And said, "Thy faithful one now stands in need
99  Of thee, and unto thee I recommend him."
100  Lucia, foe of all that cruel is,
101  Hastened away, and came unto the place
102  Where I was sitting with the ancient Rachel.
103  "Beatrice" said she, "the true praise of God,
104  Why succourest thou not him, who loved thee so,
105  For thee he issued from the vulgar herd?
106  Dost thou not hear the pity of his plaint?
107  Dost thou not see the death that combats him
108  Beside that flood, where ocean has no vaunt?"
109  Never were persons in the world so swift
110  To work their weal and to escape their woe,
111  As I, after such words as these were uttered,
112  Came hither downward from my blessed seat,
113  Confiding in thy dignified discourse,
114  Which honours thee, and those who've listened to it.'
All of these lines can be summarized in the structure outline with which I began the notes for this chapter.  There is the retrograde time motion, going back from Virgil and Dante's point in the "present" of the poem, to where The Virgin Mary becomes aware of Dante's situation, then forward through St. Lucy and then to Beatrice, and then to Virgil, and finally pack to the present tense.  It's also crucial to notice that there is a continuing diminution of spiritual power in each iteration of the message transfer.  If this power were electricity, the power plant would be the Virgin Mary, and then on to a substation of St. Lucy, and then a further substation of Beatrice, and finally to the place, where an appliance, in this case Virgil, delivers that power to Dante, the pilgrim/aspirant.  It is almost as if what Dante the poet is telling us here is that his little 25 watt bulb would be burned out if all the spiritual power of the Virgin were channeled directly into it.  Which in fact is what happens at the end of the Paradisio.  
It should also be noted that the shining eye metaphor is used to frame the whole sequence describing the heavenly intercessions, and that this is related to the star which heralded Christ's birth — the ultimate source of compassion and grace.
A similar framing device occurs with the word vanto (vaunt), occurring first in line 25, and then reoccurring in line 108.  An obscure reference here, much debated be commentators throughout the centuries.  It may be that the ove, (where), really should be onde (wave, or place), and if it were, the two lines would match perfectly.  In the first instance Virgil's tale of Aeneas is described as a vaunt, a sort of boastful celebration of his hero's exploits.  In the second instance, it is a description of a river over which the ocean has no boast, i.e., no power.  The river then would be the river Jorden, which does not drain into the ocean, but into the Dead Sea.  This also points to the contrast of pagan virtue, pride, and Christian virtue, humility.   Vaunt is a weird word,  but if another easier word were chosen, it probably would not be read as a framing device.  Another example of Dante's near miraculous powers as a poet, once again with the utmost efficiency using each word to intensify his meaning.
Hearing and seeing: lines 106, and 107.  To hear, to see, that is the order of poetic inspiration, first we hear the words, and then we see the image that they are conveying.  To hear and to see is also to obey, to act in obedience to one's inspiration, one's personal divine command.  Julian Jaynes' discussion of this in his book The Origins of Consciousness and the Breakdown of the Bi-Cameral Mind is quite illuminating here.  He talks about the 'authority of sound' and 'the control of obedience.'  On one side of the brain we hear, on the other we hallucinate a meaning.  Jaynes says that in the preconscious mind this linking of brain hemispheres is synonymous with volition.  It is not like volition, it is volition.  The pertinent etymology from the Latin being ob + audire, or to hear while facing someone.  What someone?  The authority: your irresistible God.  If the God is face to face with you and close, his/her speech unites your will to the divine will.  Which is precisely what happens here at end of this Canto (line 139, below) when one will is forged from two.
Language note: vulgar, line 105.
