The etymology of the word is from Latin, meaning to throng, to crowd, and finally to participate in that which is common, now used in the pejorative sense of both common and disreputable, the opposite of what is praiseworthy, and praise is something specifically referred to in the first line of this tercet, when Beatrice is referred to as the "true praise of God".  (badly translated, since the adjective true is attached to God, not praise, so a better rendering would be: praise of the true God).  It would be interesting to track the body and brain chemistry of giving praise in contrast to that of condemnation.  At any rate, it's clear that one of the reasons that Dante is singled out for special treatment is that he has escaped the vulgar herd.  As in Proust, who first saw Albertine among a group of girls, Dante also first sees Beatrice, as he says in La Vita Nuova, among a group of ladies.  She is special, because she praises God, and Dante is special because he praises her.  He is singled out, alone, as is pointed out at the beginning of this Canto, line 3, to fight the war both of the way (the path he's on), and of the woe.  When you take a road that is not common, you can be sure that society will have an immune system response to reject, belittle you, or ignore you, and you will feel the danger and stress of that, since human primates seem to be clan or troop animals, and exile generally means death for the individual (hence the war metaphor in line 4).  Dante of course was in exile through the whole second half of his life, and certainly felt the sting of that.  There is some irony in the fact that Dante has chosen to write his masterpiece in the vulgar tongue, and in his book, De Vulgari Eloquentia, he defends that choice, partly with the odd excuse that it is one's first language, learned naturally, the mother tongue, whereas the Latin, or any subsequently learned second language must be acquired through difficult and long study.  The kind of language that is praised by Beatrice in this passage is that of Virgil — honest, it is that which brings honor to him (praise) and which presumably also fills the reader or listener of such language with those noble characteristics.  It is also a durable tongue, hard to understand, and imperishable through fame.
115  Poscia che m'ebbe ragionato questo,
116  li occhi lucenti lagrimando volse,
117 per che mi fece del venir più presto.
115  After she thus had spoken unto me,
116  Weeping, her shining eyes she turned away;
117  Whereby she made me swifter in my coming;
Three points to be made about these 3 lines (115 - 117).  
1) Line 115 is translated badly, it would be better translated as "After she had reasoned with me thusly," because Virgil responds to reason, not the grace of what we would now call inspiration.
2) Beatrice's discourse is closed as it was opened, with shining eyes.
3) Virgil reiterates the call and response sequence, and shows in his own behavior that immediate response is what is called for, his will one with Beatrice's just as at the end of this Canto, his will and Dante's will are one.  This is obedience, which was discussed above, and is verified by Virgil in the next lines:
118  E venni a te così com' ella volse:
119  d'inanzi a quella fiera ti levai
120  che del bel monte il corto andar ti tolse.

118  And unto thee I came, as she desired;
119  I have delivered thee from that wild beast,
120  Which barred the beautiful mountain's short ascent.

Next comes the formal closing of Virgil's argument, and a reiteration of the admonition at the beginning of this Canto (lines 43 -48), wherein Virgil compares Dante to a beast which shies at shadows — and remember the first lines of this Canto specifically state that it's the time when the beasts, and by association, the bestial (undeveloped, ignoble) part of Dante, have no place if the journey is to be undertaken, the poem written.  Line 120 also recapitulates the subject of the short ascent, that which is available to all those whom I have called the orthodox, those who believe without question, and are untroubled by reason's balking at superstition.  That way is not available to Dante, he's already swallowed the pill of reasonable doubt, and now must go the whole hog, tour hell, and then purge himself through purgatory.  Dante's path is

Transgression
Punishment
Purgation.

Then finally, blessedness. 

but those who never transgressed can skip the first three steps, and simply refine their original innocence.

121  Dunque: che è? perché, perché restai,
122  perché tanta viltà nel core allette,
123  perché ardire e franchezza non hai,

124  poscia che tai tre donne benedette
125  curan di te ne la corte del cielo,
126  e 'l mio parlar tanto ben ti promette?”

121  What is it, then? Why, why dost thou delay?
122  Why is such baseness bedded in thy heart?
123  Daring and hardihood why hast thou not,

124  Seeing that three such Ladies benedight
125  Are caring for thee in the court of Heaven,
126  And so much good my speech doth promise thee?"

These tercets reecho what has already been stated, with the litany of perché, perché, perché, perché — why, why, why, why.  Line 122 in which the word allette (embedded) appears as a metaphor of baseness in the heart, echoes line 20, in Canto one, where the heart is a lake which has been quieted.  We must watch for this system of metaphors, in this case those having to do with water, which is elaborated throughout the work.  We are at the bottom, the depths of the heart, but it is the sleeping heart again, with which the work began.  There is also a poetic church bell ringing here with the cor-sounds: in line 120, corto (short), line 122, core (heart), and corte (court, as in the court of heaven).

Note: the characteristics that the pilgrim needs to succeed in his quest (line 123) ardire (courage) and franchezza (candor).  

127  Quali fioretti dal notturno gelo
128  chinati e chiusi, poi che 'l sol li 'mbianca,
129  si drizzan tutti aperti in loro stelo,

130  tal mi fec' io di mia virtude stanca,
131  e tanto buono ardire al cor mi corse,
132  ch'i' cominciai come persona franca:

133  “Oh pietosa colei che mi soccorse!
134  e te cortese ch'ubidisti tosto
135  a le vere parole che ti porse!

136  Tu m'hai con disiderio il cor disposto
137  sì al venir con le parole tue,
138  ch'i' son tornato nel primo proposto.

139  Or va, ch'un sol volere è d'ambedue:
140  tu duca, tu segnore e tu maestro.”
141  Così li dissi; e poi che mosso fue,

142  intrai per lo cammino alto e silvestro.

127  Even as the flowerets, by nocturnal chill,
128  Bowed down and closed, when the sun whitens them,
129  Uplift themselves all open on their stems;

130  Such I became with my exhausted strength,
131  And such good courage to my heart there coursed,
132  That I began, like an intrepid person:

133  "O she compassionate, who succoured me,
134  And courteous thou, who hast obeyed so soon
135  The words of truth which she addressed to thee!

136  Thou hast my heart so with desire disposed
137  To the adventure, with these words of thine,
138  That to my first intent I have returned.

139  Now go, for one sole will is in us both,
140  Thou Leader, and thou Lord, and Master thou."
141  Thus said I to him; and when he had moved,

142  I entered on the deep and savage way.

The incredible symmetry of Canto II comes to a conclusion here as the completion of the call and response structure that has characterized this entire section.  Dante after hearing Virgil's discourse, and realizing that it is not Dante's confused and fearful self which is being called to undertake this journey — not solely for his own salvation as we already know from the lines 7 - 9 of Canto I, but to tell of the good he saw — and now Dante knows exactly who his Muses are: these forces or beings whose help he implored in lines  7 - 9 of this Canto.  This is at bottom a claim for poetry, which with courage and candor has the power to redeem not only Dante, but his readers.

The symmetry is shown also in two natural metaphors.  The first comes when Virgil compares Dante's cowardice to that of a beast which shies at shadows, and the bookend to that metaphor is this trope of the young flowers, blighted by night frost, but reified by the sun.
A flower is a lower life form than a balky animal, and yet it's humility is such that it always responds faithfully to the sun.  So again, we find that Dante emphasizes his own authority by a display of humility.  The automaticity of the response makes it infallible.  Dante's suspended response, after hearing and envisioning the answered calls of Lucy, Beatrice, and Virgil is now completed, and Dante's will and that of his leader, lord, and master — Virgil — are one.  And where does this unification take place?  The heart.  And what attributes does the heart now have?  Courage and candor.  Now, when Virgil moves, just as the flower which rises and follows the path of the sun, Dante also moves.  The Canto is finished, and the introductions are finished, so that now, in Canto III, we pass through the gate of Hell proper.

Canto III
 
Time: Evening, April 8th, 1300, Good Friday

1  “Per me si va ne la città dolente,
2  per me si va ne l'etterno dolore,
3  per me si va tra la perduta gente.

4  Giustizia mosse il mio alto fattore;
5  fecemi la divina podestate,
6  la somma sapïenza e 'l primo amore.

7  Dinanzi a me non fuor cose create
8  se non etterne, e io etterno duro.
9  Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch'entrate.”

1  "Through me the way is to the city dolent;
2  Through me the way is to eternal dole;
3  Through me the way among the people lost.
4  Justice incited my sublime Creator;
5  Created me divine Omnipotence,
6  The highest Wisdom and the primal Love.
7  Before me there were no created things,
8  Only eterne, and I eternal last.
9  All hope abandon, ye who enter in!"
Often what seems straightforward in Dante hides a little kink that a second look reveals, and these lines, among the most famous in all literature, seem to me to verge very close to heresy, and one wonders if Dante had been born 3 centuries later, he, like Bruno, would have been burned at the stake.  Here the Gate to Hell is inscribed, and the like the sêma tombstones of the ancient Greeks, the inscription is assumed to be the mouthpiece of the deceased below, which is activated by the passers-by when their own voice reads the words aloud — thereby bruiting the renown of the dead person.  What lines 4 - 8 imply is that Hell itself is speaking, both as being and as place, this entity created for the purpose of administering justice and gifted by it's (His?) maker with Divine omnipotence.  Nothing beyond the pale here, Hell knows without error just who is guilty and just how to punish them.  But what follows, if it were true, and not Hell's boast and lie, that Hell is sort of an necessary precursor to the rest of existence, and has been made before earth, and maybe before heaven.  In brief, this God of highest wisdom and primal love created Hell before He created anyone to put there!  This is very close to the Cathar heresy which the Church had crushed less than a century before in one of Europe's first genocides.  The Cathar's held that so much evil existed in the world that no just God could have created it, therefore this world was made by a demiurge as evil's toy.  If Hell comes first, that would be much like a mother digging the grave of her unborn child.  
If this makes no sense as Catholic Theology, a little twist of the lens seems to reveal the obvious fact that chaos precedes any possible order.  In fact, there can be no order if it did not have the grab-bag of the lowest elements from which to emerge.  And it also makes perfect poetic sense to depict this pre-created or uncreated thing as a gate, a maw, into which we enter to find a downward spiral into deeper levels of disorder, but a chaos that is winding down to heat death at its very nadir.  The image that Dante presents of this state which he calls Inferno is that of an inexorable downward pull, wherein the landscape and those doomed to inhabit it reveal greater and greater degrees of degradation, and lesser and lesser degrees of movement.  Abandon hope indeed!  The damned (la perduta gente) are like people who aspire to fly by attaching leaden wings — they grow heavier and more paralytic as they work harder to rise, the engine of their destruction being their own willful misapprehension of the laws of the universe.
More brilliant poetics:  In Canto II, Virgil asks why, why, why, why (perché) Dante is afraid, and that drumbeat repetition is recrudesced here with the phrase per me si va — well, this is why.  What we fear, what we have feared is made absolutely manifest in Hell.  Dante, the poet backs us into a terrible corner here, the same corner in which Dante the aspirant finds himself, that is to say, doomed, without a protector.  Now if Dante, the aspirant must obediently follow Virgil, to whom is our obedience salvation?  Answer: Dante, the poet.   
10  Queste parole di colore oscuro
11  vid' ïo scritte al sommo d'una porta;
12  per ch'io: “Maestro, il senso lor m'è duro.”

13  Ed elli a me, come persona accorta:
14  “Qui si convien lasciare ogne sospetto;
15  ogne viltà convien che qui sia morta.

16  Noi siam venuti al loco ov' i' t'ho detto
17  che tu vedrai le genti dolorose
18  c'hanno perduto il ben de l'intelletto.”
10  These words in sombre colour I beheld
11  Written upon the summit of a gate;
12  Whence I: "Their sense is, Master, hard to me!"
13  And he to me, as one experienced:
14  "Here all suspicion needs must be abandoned,
15  All cowardice must needs be here extinct.
16  We to the place have come, where I have told thee
17  Thou shalt behold the people dolorous
18  Who have foregone the good of intellect."
According to Douglas Hoffstadter in his book, I Am a Strange Loop, self-referentiality is the condition of the type of consciousness that makes humans human.  We know ourselves as ourselves.  This device that Dante uses, placing himself both in the poem as reader, and outside the poem, as writer, serves that function.  The text can interpret it's own dark words both through Virgil, and as the poem progresses, through many other characters.  Here dark words, words hard to understand (that word duro again), as we the readers also experience them, are commented upon by Virgil.  We could interpret Virgil thusly: "Your lack of understanding is the form that original sin (ignorance) takes inside you."  He calls it viltá, cowardice, the source of fear.  To understand this poem, we have to overcome the fear of our own ignorance, our own obstinance, and that is something we can decide to do by an act of volition, an act of reason.  This is Virgil's and Dante's definition of intellect: the ability to choose, and choose rightly.  And as Virgil says in line 18, the damned are in Hell because they have lost that ability.  It is not volition which guides them, but impulse, which in Dante's world is simply the animal nature in us dominating our human nature.
The next tercet shows a very tender moment, in which Virgil takes Dante's hand (image-hand in flesh-hand), and with a cheerful face (lieto volto), comforts Dante, and leads him inside (that's important: dentro, inside) secret things.  What things?  Why the things that are hard for us to understand, the things that are obscure to our intellect, the things that are being expressed in the Commedia — So here we are, the Commedia explaining itself to itself, and also to us, the readers, who use their intellect and, I would add, imaginations, to go inside the poem.  Commentators have pointed out secret things here means things that have been cut off from our understanding.  

19  E poi che la sua mano a la mia puose
20  con lieto volto, ond' io mi confortai,
21  mi mise dentro a le segrete cose.

19  And after he had laid his hand on mine
20  With joyful mien, whence I was comforted,
21  He led me in among the secret things.

22  Quivi sospiri, pianti e alti guai
23  risonavan per l'aere sanza stelle,
24  per ch'io al cominciar ne lagrimai.

25  Diverse lingue, orribili favelle,
26  parole di dolore, accenti d'ira,
27  voci alte e fioche, e suon di man con elle 

28  facevano un tumulto, il qual s'aggira
29  sempre in quell' aura sanza tempo tinta,
30  come la rena quando turbo spira.
22  There sighs, complaints, and ululations loud
23  Resounded through the air without a star,
24  Whence I, at the beginning, wept thereat.
25  Languages diverse, horrible dialects,
26  Accents of anger, words of agony,
27  And voices high and hoarse, with sound of hands,
28  Made up a tumult that goes whirling on
29  Forever in that air forever black,
30  Even as the sand doth, when the whirlwind breathes.
Quickly we pass from the implied pianissimo of secret things (le segrete cose, line 21), to a fortissimo human hubbub, a babble of laments and cries, all aural references because it is dark, but we will see later what is going on.  Think of fire at rush hour in a Tokyo subway station, or a terror attack in a crowded international airport.   Also note the enjambment of lines 27 — 29, the rhythms getting muddle, just like the voices that Dante hears are muddled — another of the myriad of instances where Dante's technique makes the physical sound, and the tongue, larynx, lungs of the reader conform to the sense of the verse.  We are moved because he physically moves us.    
The sky is without stars, and we are reminded of the metaphor in Canto II comparing the light in Beatrice's eyes to a star.  The passage ends with another metaphor from nature (note: this occurs in about the same place in Canto II, as the natural metaphor of the animal shying at shadows does in Canto II, Dante loves symmetry, and knows how to use it to create complexity).  This: of a dust devil swirled up in barren sand.  We will see how towards the end of this Canto another metaphor from nature bookends this one.  This: of autumn leaves being -— one by one — stripped from a tree.  The noise here is so great that in line 31- 33 (below), Dante binds his head, presumably in his hands to shut it out, and asks Virgil what he is hearing, and who these people are, who have been utterly vanquished by their sorrows.
Note: line 31 has an error, d'error, should horror, not error.  Although it might also be an error to neither see nor hear.  In meditation we cut off sound and sight in order to have inner guidance.      

31  E io ch'avea d'error la testa cinta,
32  dissi: “Maestro, che è quel ch'i' odo?
33  e che gent' è che par nel duol sì vinta?”

34  Ed elli a me: “Questo misero modo
35  tegnon l'anime triste di coloro
36  che visser sanza 'nfamia e sanza lodo.

37  Mischiate sono a quel cattivo coro
38  de li angeli che non furon ribelli
39  né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro.

40  Caccianli i ciel per non esser men belli,
41  né lo profondo inferno li riceve,
42  ch'alcuna gloria i rei avrebber d'elli.”

31  And I, who had my head with horror bound,
32  Said: "Master, what is this which now I hear?
33  What folk is this, which seems by pain so vanquished?"

34  And he to me: "This miserable mode
35  Maintain the melancholy souls of those
36  Who lived withouten infamy or praise.

37  Commingled are they with that caitiff choir
38  Of Angels, who have not rebellious been,
39  Nor faithful were to God, but were for self.
40  The heavens expelled them, not to be less fair;
41  Nor them the nethermore abyss receives,
42  For glory none the damned would have from them."
These lines depict the fate of those caught in the terrible double bind of having before them the starkest moral choice, on one side obvious infamy, on the other praise (lodo) (line 36), yet they can choose neither.  Infamy: to be renown for villainy of some sort; praise, to be renown for some good accomplishment.  But these are souls, along with those angels who in Satan's war against God, neither rebelled, nor were loyal, but selfishly stayed neutral (lines 38, 39).  They cannot attain heaven, nor will Hell accept them.  Further on, they are called blind (line 47).  They cannot learn, because they will not see.  This isn't just a quiet languishing in indifference, they are in what Bateson calls a double bind — that place in our psychic life where the contrast between what we should or should not do is so stark, and yet we bind our head, as Dante does here, to prevent his hearing ... hint, hint: it is too dark for him to see, and too intolerable with its cacophony of overlapping voices, languages, and sounds, for him to hear.  He bursts immediately into tears (line 24), which are not tears of pity, but more to the point, tears of his own anguish, springing from a confrontation of that which is disturbing and at the same time utterly incomprehensible.  The aspirant is suffering sensory overload, and so he closes himself off to the chaos that it roiling around and in him, and turns to Virgil's quiet and assured voice of reason (line 13: come persona accorta), and Virgil in the lines following (43 -51) explains.  

43  E io: “Maestro, che è tanto greve
44  a lor che lamentar li fa sì forte?”
45  Rispuose: “Dicerolti molto breve.

46  Questi non hanno speranza di morte,
47  e la lor cieca vita è tanto bassa,
48  che 'nvidïosi son d'ogne altra sorte.

49  Fama di loro il mondo esser non lassa;
50  misericordia e giustizia li sdegna:
51  non ragioniam di lor, ma guarda e passa.”

43  And I: "O Master, what so grievous is
44  To these, that maketh them lament so sore?"
45  He answered: "I will tell thee very briefly.
46  These have no longer any hope of death;
47  And this blind life of theirs is so debased,
48  They envious are of every other fate.
49  No fame of them the world permits to be;
50  Misericord and Justice both disdain them.
51  Let us not speak of them, but look, and pass."
Ah, this strikes so close to home for me: these sorrowful souls cannot live or die, and mercy and justice both refuse to claim them.  Their internal debate goes on, unresolved interminably.  In brief, they have and are a chronic disease in the soul which never reaches a healing crises, nor ever becomes fatal.  Virgil almost refuses to speak of them at all (they shall have no renown, no fame (line 45) I will tell thee very briefly, molto breve, their lives are so blind, so debased, that even the worse fates of those in Hell, they envy.  And then, in a very telling line (51): Let us not speak of them (give them no acknowledgement, no fame, as they gave none neither to God nor to the Devil), but look and pass.  The double bind here, is part of a doubling and mixing of images — opposites, complimentaries, and incongruous conflations — which will occur in other areas of the Canto. 
All of Canto III is about making irrevocable decisions, and crossing Rubicons of the spirit.  First we pass through the gates of Hell, from which there is no hope of return, and then we reach this chaos of indecisiveness, and from this too, we must choose.  Stay, and go into therapy for the rest of our lives without ever resolving our paralyzing issues, or stop talking about it, see what the problem is, and move on.  We cannot even harbor regret for this state of consciousness, and still manage to keep moving.
Note: The reader too must make a decision.  Is reading Dante about entertainment, requiring literary credentials, being intellectually well-rounded, or is it about transformation?  Lots of so-called artists or writers entertain, become famous, exert cultural influence  — Andy Warhol comes to mind —, but their work does not transform them or us, as artists like Joseph Beuys and Ansel Kiefer do.  When you read Dante, you have to ante up, put everything you have into the process, consider what he has to say, interpret it for yourself, and let what you are learning transform not just your reading but your living.   
52  E io, che riguardai, vidi una 'nsegna
53  che girando correva tanto ratta,
54  che d'ogne posa mi parea indegna;

55  e dietro le venìa sì lunga tratta
56  di gente, ch'i' non averei creduto
57  che morte tanta n'avesse disfatta.
52  And I, who looked again, beheld a banner,
53  Which, whirling round, ran on so rapidly,
54  That of all pause it seemed to me indignant;
55  And after it there came so long a train
56  Of people, that I ne'er would have believed
57  That ever Death so many had undone.
This is the first that we see of a typical punishment in Hell: some obsessive compulsive action which the damned are doomed to repeat, and which is symbolic of their error — in this case following a banner (as they refused to do in life), which whirls round and round, and goes nowhere.  It is just a banner, there is no symbol on it.  I like that the banner seems to have a kind of consciousness, a kind  of oddly sentient being taking a kind of pride in its perpetual motion, indignant (line 54) to pause.  The train of people following this banner are less conscious than the banner for they follow without thought.  And of course line 57 is the line that  Eliot so famously used in The Wasteland.
Note: The Gate to Hell, like the banner, also shows this sentience.  This war between impulse and reason is the war which Dante talks about in the beginning of Canto II, the war he fights alone.  And here Dante, by reversing the roles of sentient human and insentient object, emphasizes how far the damned have fallen, they are now irresistibly commanded by objects, or by the environment which engulfs them, their most egregious impulse harassing them continuously.    
58  Poscia ch'io v'ebbi alcun riconosciuto,
59  vidi e conobbi l'ombra di colui
60  che fece per viltade il gran rifiuto.

61  Incontanente intesi e certo fui
62  che questa era la setta d'i cattivi,
63  a Dio spiacenti e a' nemici sui.
58  When some among them I had recognized,
59  I looked, and I beheld the shade of him
60  Who made through cowardice the great refusal.
61  Forthwith I comprehended, and was certain,
62  That this the sect was of the caitiff wretches
63  Hateful to God and to his enemies.
What is important about these lines is that Dante reiterates what Virgil has told him, responding immediately to the lesson, as he did not immediately respond in Canto II.  He sees people he knows among this group, but pointedly does not mention their names, they're anonymity being part of their punishment.  They were those guilty of the "great refusal".  And what did they refuse?  They refused the call of their own genius, their own avocation (which means calling).  By grace, or if you prefer, the accident of their birth and their particular circumstances, they possessed a genius, and they squandered this treasure out of cowardice.  As such, not being loyal to their own best self, they could not be loyal to Satan or God either.  Curiously, this term "the great refusal" is how Walter Pater in his book of essays on the renaissance, listed as the primary attribute of Sandro Botticelli's work (which was a misreading on Pater's part), essentially describing an artist, who refused to take part in the political and theological violence of his day, and stood outside, or beyond, the influence of history to create an otherworldly beauty.  History, apparently, unknown to Dante, has ways of including even those who have deliberately tried to be free of it.  It's an interesting position Dante, the poet here, has taken, given that in his exile, he eventually dropped his political partisanship to become what appears to have been a kind of itinerant literary monk, he must have viewed his poet-self as his true self, as Blake would have said, the true partisan of a world where language itself is what he has committed himself to as a way to inject the ideals of transcendence down into the nitty-gritty of history.
One way that Dante historicizes his spiritual journey is by referring to real people, either those he personally knew, or those he knew of.  Here he speaks of his revelation, and his verification of Virgil's words, by seeing someone he knows, and from that achieving a certainy that these damned one he sees here are truly abominable enough to be enemies of both God and God's foes.  In line 64 (below) he says, they were never alive, and now they can never be truly dead. 
64  Questi sciaurati, che mai non fur vivi,
65  erano ignudi e stimolati molto
66  da mosconi e da vespe ch'eran ivi.

67  Elle rigavan lor di sangue il volto,
68  che, mischiato di lagrime, a' lor piedi
69  da fastidiosi vermi era ricolto.
64  These miscreants, who never were alive,
65  Were naked, and were stung exceedingly
66  By gadflies and by hornets that were there.
67  These did their faces irrigate with blood,
68  Which, with their tears commingled, at their feet
69  By the disgusting worms was gathered up.
Before leaving this group of excluded ones, he sees their punishment — gruesome indeed.  They are naked, and are stung by two types of insects: gadflies and hornets (mosconi, vespe), and that fact that there are two types of stinging insects reinforces that theme of the double bind.  Then this doubling continues as blood and tears mix and flow down there cheeks, to be eaten by worms at their feet.  The blood represents the body's excreta for physical pain, the tears, for emotional pain.  Now we move to the third experience recounted in this Canto (1— entering Hell's gate, and 2 — passing by this group of the uncommitted) to the crossing of the Acheron, and their confrontation with Charon.    
70  E poi ch'a riguardar oltre mi diedi,
71  vidi genti a la riva d'un gran fiume;
72  per ch'io dissi: “Maestro, or mi concedi

73  ch'i' sappia quali sono, e qual costume
74  le fa di trapassar parer sì pronte,
75  com' i' discerno per lo fioco lume.”

76  Ed elli a me: “Le cose ti fier conte
77  quando noi fermerem li nostri passi
78  su la trista riviera d'Acheronte.”

79  Allor con li occhi vergognosi e bassi,
80  temendo no 'l mio dir li fosse grave,
81  infino al fiume del parlar mi trassi.

70  And when to gazing farther I betook me.
71  People I saw on a great river's bank;
72  Whence said I: "Master, now vouchsafe to me,

73  That I may know who these are, and what law
74  Makes them appear so ready to pass over,
75  As I discern athwart the dusky light."

76  And he to me: "These things shall all be known
77  To thee, as soon as we our footsteps stay
78  Upon the dismal shore of Acheron."

79  Then with mine eyes ashamed and downward cast,
80  Fearing my words might irksome be to him,
81  From speech refrained I till we reached the river.

Dante, the aspirant, is beginning to see in the dusky light, that is to say, his own intellect is being slightly aroused, and when in the distance he sees a crowd clamoring to cross a river, he asks Virgil who these people are, and why they are gathered to cross the river, and Virgil rebukes him.  Why?  Apparently centuries worth of commentators have debated this question, but for me, the answer is: Don't let your little bit of vision outrun your experience.  As we go deeper, your insight will be better.  As Pope says: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing.  So, this refers to the sin of pride, which I think is verified by Dante's response.  He is ashamed, he drops his eyes, he considers the feelings of his guide, and he refrains from speaking until they reach the river.  Since this scene is a recapitulation of a scene in the Aeneid, Virgil's crankiness may have to do with Virgil's own feelings in returning to this dark place, which in a sense, was the dark, dense seed that sprouted into his own epic.  We know this because Virgil names the river, not the Homeric Styx, but the Aeneid's Acheron.  Remember how irksome it was when you were lost in a train of thought which someone interrupts to ask what they could see for themselves if they were attentive?  Well, that is how the aspirant reads his guide here.  This is also about obedience.  Here, Dante, the aspirant, is humbled, and instantly obeys.  He is still learning, but it's clear that from Canto II, he already has learned.     

82  Ed ecco verso noi venir per nave
83  un vecchio, bianco per antico pelo,
84  gridando: “Guai a voi, anime prave!

85  Non isperate mai veder lo cielo:
86  i' vegno per menarvi a l'altra riva
87  ne le tenebre etterne, in caldo e 'n gelo.

88  E tu che se' costì, anima viva,
89  pàrtiti da cotesti che son morti.”
90  Ma poi che vide ch'io non mi partiva,

91  disse: “Per altra via, per altri porti
92  verrai a piaggia, non qui, per passare:
93  più lieve legno convien che ti porti.”

94  E 'l duca lui: “Caron, non ti crucciare:
95  vuolsi così colà dove si puote
96  ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare.”

82  And lo! towards us coming in a boat
83  An old man, hoary with the hair of eld,
84  Crying: "Woe unto you, ye souls depraved!

85  Hope nevermore to look upon the heavens;
86  I come to lead you to the other shore,
87  To the eternal shades in heat and frost.

88  And thou, that yonder standest, living soul,
89  Withdraw thee from these people, who are dead!"
90  But when he saw that I did not withdraw,

91  He said: "By other ways, by other ports
92  Thou to the shore shalt come, not here, for passage;
93  A lighter vessel needs must carry thee."

94  And unto him the Guide: "Vex thee not, Charon;
95  It is so willed there where is power to do
96  That which is willed; and farther question not."

Here is the confrontation with Charon, who arrives in his empty boat, ready to take another load of the damned to eternal punishment.  Dante depicts him as an old man, and the word bianco, white, recurs here as an echo of the frost/flower metaphor in Canto II, and of course with the word gelo in the next tercet we find a foreshadowing of the very depths of Hell as a lake of ice.  Again the rhymes of pelo (hair) cielo (heaven, like the sun in Canto II) and gelo (frost, ice) tell a story of opposites colliding, as Dante, the living aspirant does here, with the dead.  More doubling and incongruous mixing.  The word Guai is an echo for one of the lamentable sounds the indecisive damned made earlier in this Canto, but Caron uses it as a threat: Woe!  (In modern Italian, I think it means troubles or problems.) Then Charon goes on to make a refusal (disobedience, unresponsiveness) saying that the living cannot find a way into Hell through him.  He is the ferryman of the dead.  This the first of many mythological characters we meet in Hell, a reference perhaps to the debased pagan tradition, that has now been replaced by Christianity.  We will meet others like him in the descent.  Charon is also one of the first of many throughout the entire Commedia who immediately notices the anomaly of a living person appearing among the dead, and he makes use of the term light (as in not heavy) as the kind of boat that Dante needs to ferry him.  I think this is a play on words that is about a heavy or light mood, and no living body can have a mood heavier than that of the damned.  On the other hand, no shade, can be as physically heavy as a living body.  It would not be uncharacteristic of an entity like Charon to be ironic, and throughout the Commedia there is a lot of irony, but Dante, the poet, generally puts this irony in the mouths of other characters, or in the situation, and is careful not to make the overall tone of the work ironic — irony is a feature of our age (as Northrup Frye points out in The Anatomy of Literature), as faith is a feature of Dante's.  The second that irony creeps into the mouth of one of the faithful regarding faith, that mouth is doomed to damnation.  I just read a quote from the architect Robert Venturi which seems pertinent here:

The movement of a view of life as essentially simple and orderly to a view of life as complex and ironic is what every individual passes through in becoming mature. { } Amid simplicity and order rationalism is born, but rationalism proves inadequate in any period of upheaval.  Then equilibrium must be created out of opposites.  Such inner peace as men grain must represent a tension among contradictions. { }  A feeling for paradox allows seemingly dissimilar things to exist side by side, their very incongruity suggesting a kind of truth.  (Venturi was fascinated by the Las Vegas strip, its signage, and hodge-podge of incongruous building, which he championed as emblematic of modern life.)  

Virgil rebukes Caron, and commands obedience on behalf of one who is, to barrow Steven's phrase: The Will of Wills.  As he had a moment before with the aspirant, Dante, he tells Charon not to question him.  A repetition that would not be lost on Dante, the aspirant.  Virgil's authority cannot be questioned in Hell because it is backed by the authority of Heaven.

Line 85, of course, is an echo of the inscription over the Gates of Hell, when Charon says: Hope never more to look upon the heavens.   

97  Quinci fuor quete le lanose gote
98  al nocchier de la livida palude,
99  che 'ntorno a li occhi avea di fiamme rote.

97  Thereat were quieted the fleecy cheeks
98  Of him the ferryman of the livid fen,
99  Who round about his eyes had wheels of flame.

Caron is quelled by Virgil's rebuke, quiet as a lamb (the reference to fleecy cheeks), but mad as the devil (the reference to the wheels of fire which are his eyes — again, doubling, and mixing of incongruous things.  There is also a description of the place (more atmosphere in Dante's map of Hell, painting a geographic picture which mirrors the state of the psyche, a very cinemagraphic technique.)

The crossing of water, of course, is revisited later when we see the souls bound for Purgatory and ferried, not by a demon, but by an angel. 
 
100  Ma quell' anime, ch'eran lasse e nude,
101  cangiar colore e dibattero i denti,
102  ratto che 'nteser le parole crude.

103  Bestemmiavano Dio e lor parenti,
104  l'umana spezie e 'l loco e 'l tempo e 'l seme
105  di lor semenza e di lor nascimenti.

106  Poi si ritrasser tutte quante insieme,
107  forte piangendo, a la riva malvagia
108  ch'attende ciascun uom che Dio non teme.

109  Caron dimonio, con occhi di bragia
110  loro accennando, tutte le raccoglie;
111  batte col remo qualunque s'adagia.

100  But all those souls who weary were and naked
101  Their colour changed and gnashed their teeth together,
102  As soon as they had heard those cruel words.

103  God they blasphemed and their progenitors,
104  The human race, the place, the time, the seed
105  Of their engendering and of their birth!

106  Thereafter all together they drew back,
107  Bitterly weeping, to the accursed shore,
107  Which waiteth every man who fears not God.

109  Charon the demon, with the eyes of glede,
110  Beckoning to them, collects them all together,
111  Beats with his oar whoever lags behind.

Weary and naked: Utterly vulnerable.  Doubling.

The power of language: the damned change color and gnash their teeth after hearing the words exchanged by Virgil and Charon.  Doubling.

The  degradation of cursing, as opposed to the elevation of praising.  Doubling.

The difference between being driven and being led.  Doubling.

112  Come d'autunno si levan le foglie
113  l'una appresso de l'altra, fin che 'l ramo
114  vede a la terra tutte le sue spoglie,

115  similemente il mal seme d'Adamo
116  gittansi di quel lito ad una ad una,
117  per cenni come augel per suo richiamo.

118  Così sen vanno su per l'onda bruna,
119  e avanti che sien di là discese,
120  anche di qua nuova schiera s'auna.
112  As in the autumn-time the leaves fall off,
113  First one and then another, till the branch
114  Unto the earth surrenders all its spoils;
115  In similar wise the evil seed of Adam
116  Throw themselves from that margin one by one,
117  At signals, as a bird unto its lure.
118  So they depart across the dusky wave,
119  And ere upon the other side they land,
120  Again on this side a new troop assembles.
Now we have the formal return of a natural metaphor: the fall of autumn leaves, but doubled with the metaphor of birds entering a trap (we will see much more of the bird-trope in the next Canto), which is a bookend to the natural metaphor of the whirlwind of sand in line 30 of this Canto, and in another repetition, a new troop of souls assembles to repeat the process.  The craftsmanship of Dante again being exquisite, or to paraphrase Pope, here form is an echo to the sense — with an almost clockwork precision.  And yet it doesn't feel mechanical or contrived, it seems more like we are viewing an animal with its left and right sides in organic symmetry. 
121  “Figliuol mio,” disse 'l maestro cortese,
122  “quelli che muoion ne l'ira di Dio
123  tutti convegnon qui d'ogne paese;

124  e pronti sono a trapassar lo rio,
125  ché la divina giustizia li sprona,
126  sì che la tema si volve in disio.

127  Quinci non passa mai anima buona;
128  e però, se Caron di te si lagna,
129  ben puoi sapere omai che 'l suo dir suona.”
121  "My son," the courteous Master said to me,
122  "All those who perish in the wrath of God
123  Here meet together out of every land;
124  And ready are they to pass o'er the river,
125  Because celestial Justice spurs them on,
126  So that their fear is turned into desire.
127  This way there never passes a good soul;
128  And hence if Charon doth complain of thee,
129  Well mayst thou know now what his speech imports."
Lines 121 — 129 are Virgil's homily, a sort of Aesop's Fable moral, which does sound ironic in the pagan's mouth, even with the sort mild ministerial beginning of "My son."  But this too is a symmetry, contrasting with his earlier rebuke of Dante for being too impetuous with his questions — again doublin and mixing.  Here in contrast, Virgil is courteous (another epithet for him, along with magnanimous), and offers information without being asked.  And now the aspirant is clearly humble enough to receive the lesson.
130  Finito questo, la buia campagna
131  tremò sì forte, che de lo spavento
132  la mente di sudore ancor mi bagna.

133  La terra lagrimosa diede vento,
134  che balenò una luce vermiglia
135  la qual mi vinse ciascun sentimento;

136  e caddi come l'uom cui sonno piglia.
130  This being finished, all the dusk champaign
131  Trembled so violently, that of that terror
132  The recollection bathes me still with sweat.
133  The land of tears gave forth a blast of wind,
134  And fulminated a vermilion light,
135  Which overmastered in me every sense,
136  And as a man whom sleep hath seized I fell.
This Canto which began with whirlwinds, ends with an earthquake, and a flash of vermillion light (the demonic double of the rose light at the end of the Paradisio).  Dante, the aspirant, breaks into a sweat, passes out, returning to the condition of sleep or coma, which obscured the first stirrings of his spiritual journey in Canto I.  Dante, the poet, is emphasizing here that real spiritual work has physiological consequences, not just psychological ones.  With current brain imaging techniques, we can now actually see changes in the brain in long-time meditators who are supposed to be enlightened, and maybe this is what is happening here.

Canto IV

Circle I, Limbo, Still Good Friday evening, April 8th, 1300. 

1  Ruppemi l'alto sonno ne la testa
2  un greve truono, sì ch'io mi riscossi
3  come persona ch'è per forza desta;

4  e l'occhio riposato intorno mossi,
5  dritto levato, e fiso riguardai
6  per conoscer lo loco dov' io fossi.

7  Vero è che 'n su la proda mi trovai
8  de la valle d'abisso dolorosa
9  che 'ntrono accoglie d'infiniti guai.

10  Oscura e profonda era e nebulosa
11  tanto che, per ficcar lo viso a fondo,
12  io non vi discernea alcuna cosa.

1  Broke the deep lethargy within my head
2  A heavy thunder, so that I upstarted,
3  Like to a person who by force is wakened;

4  And round about I moved my rested eyes,
5  Uprisen erect, and steadfastly I gazed,
6  To recognise the place wherein I was.

7  True is it, that upon the verge I found me
8  Of the abysmal valley dolorous,
9  That gathers thunder of infinite ululations.

10  Obscure, profound it was, and nebulous,
11  So that by fixing on its depths my sight
12  Nothing whatever I discerned therein.

One thing an artist has to learn is that the border area between sleep and waking has about it an extraordinary access to both the unconscious and the waking mind.  Dante explores that border area again in the first 12 lines of Canto IV.  The word portentous comes to mind.  There's a temptation for translators to translate the phrase l'alto sonno, as deep sleep, but it is a feature apparently of Dante's Italian to say high sleep.  That alto to me is a place where perspective is broadened, as it is when we survey a landscape from a mountain peak, and in this case the perspective, accompanied by a drum roll of heavy thunder (greve truono), is distorted, obscured, and as we learn, resonant with an infinite chain of aftershocks.  Canto III ended with thunder, Canto IV begins with it, but the term Ruppemi, Break, not only adds to the violence of this awakening, but literally breaks Canto IV apart from its predecessor, and tells us that we have entered some kind of timeless state, which separates the two.  This is another example of the extreme skill displayed in Dante's technique, how the placement of a single word serves as an axle which turns one mighty gear inside another.  

So much scholarly ink has been spilled on whether Dante expects the reader to believe that his is a literal physical journey.  But this little detail almost surely warns the savvy reader against believing so.  How would Dante get from one physical locale to another?  He could not possibly be carried by Virgil, because in other sections of the Commedia the shades pass right through each other and through Dante.  So, I think it is better to maintain that the whole of this journey takes place in some quasi-land like that stated above: something between the physical and the spiritual, with some characteristics of both states present.  

The term guai (simply trouble in modern Italian) is used again, translated by Longfellow as ululations, but since Charon uses it as an insult, translated as Woe (Woe to you) in Canto III, we have to feel around for another definition.  I don't think there is a single term in English that covers this.  It is a loud, lamenting cry, and an insult to the ears that are forced to hear it.  It is the human equivalent of that heavy meteorological thunder.  

Dante, the aspirant, stands up, looks around, but can see nothing, so we know that however horrible the atmosphere was in Canto III, this place is worse.  The aspirant is going to have go a bit owl-eyed to see in the dark, something more like insight than sight is required.  The ears too are taking a pounding, but they are operational, and if we tune up the volume of our imaginations, we can hear the depth of Virgil's voice, and even Dante's over the din.  In spite of Hell's awesome portentousness, our two protagonist reign in Hell, by virtue of a divine dispensation.  They are still able to speak to each other and hear, like the quiet or soundless voices in our heads, they are still mightier than the continuous rumblings of any external Hell. 

13  “Or discendiam qua giù nel cieco mondo,”
14  cominciò il poeta tutto smorto.
15  “Io sarò primo, e tu sarai secondo.”

16  E io, che del color mi fui accorto,
17  dissi: “Come verrò, se tu paventi
18  che suoli al mio dubbiare esser conforto?”

19  Ed elli a me: “L'angoscia de le genti
20  che son qua giù, nel viso mi dipigne
21  quella pietà che tu per tema senti.

22  Andiam, ché la via lunga ne sospigne.”
23  Così si mise e così mi fé intrare
24  nel primo cerchio che l'abisso cigne.

13  "Let us descend now into the blind world,"
14  Began the Poet, pallid utterly;
15  "I will be first, and thou shalt second be."

16  And I, who of his colour was aware,
17  Said: "How shall I come, if thou art afraid,
18  Who'rt wont to be a comfort to my fears?"

19  And he to me: "The anguish of the people
20  Who are below here in my face depicts
21  That pity which for terror thou hast taken.

22  Let us go on, for the long way impels us."
23  Thus he went in, and thus he made me enter
24  The foremost circle that surrounds the abyss.

In this passage, the aspirant-Dante's eyes suddenly grow acute, fixed on their guide, for he discerns in this blind world (cieco mondo) that Virgil has grown all pale (tutto smorto).  If I were going to make a film of this, I would give both these protagonists an inner light, rather like the light we see through the wax at the top of a candle, when the flame has burned down below the tip's lip.  It seems to me that what is happening here is very much like what I experience in my dreams where there is no directionality to the light, but where objects are self-illuminated, like those bioluminescent creatures of the ocean's benthic realms.  Fascinating.  Dante, the aspirant, suddenly draws back.  If Virgil is afraid, how can he have courage?  An allegorical interpretation would be: the human emotion of fear overcomes reason.  But reason, i.e., Virgil, does get the upper hand, as Virgil explains that Dante has mistaken his pale color for fear, when it is really is pity (pietà) for those below: pity for himself too, because the people below are his people — this is Virgil's place in Hell.  In the phrase nel viso mi dipigne (in my face is painted) the reflexive verb is used, as if Virgil were aware, as Longfellow translates it, of his own pallor.  It makes the reader ask, just how far Virgil's cognition extends in this, his world?  The phrase che tu per tema senti, (which you as fear have felt) carries with it the sense, lost in translation, of the closeness that Dante feels for Virgil, even mirroring his emotions in his own.  

Then they descend, reason leading feeling.  

25  Quivi, secondo che per ascoltare,
26  non avea pianto mai che di sospiri
27  che l'aura etterna facevan tremare;

28  ciò avvenia di duol sanza martìri,
29  ch'avean le turbe, ch'eran molte e grandi,
30  d'infanti e di femmine e di viri.

31  Lo buon maestro a me: “Tu non dimandi
32  che spiriti son questi che tu vedi?
33  Or vo' che sappi, innanzi che più andi,

34  ch'ei non peccaro; e s'elli hanno mercedi,
35  non basta, perché non ebber battesmo,
36  ch'è porta de la fede che tu credi;


37  e s' e' furon dinanzi al cristianesmo,
38  non adorar debitamente a Dio:
39  e di questi cotai son io medesmo.

40  Per tai difetti, non per altro rio,
41  semo perduti, e sol di tanto offesi
42  che sanza speme vivemo in disio.”

43  Gran duol mi prese al cor quando lo 'ntesi,
44  però che gente di molto valore
45  conobbi che 'n quel limbo eran sospesi.
25  There, as it seemed to me from listening,
26  Were lamentations none, but only sighs,
27  That tremble made the everlasting air.
28  And this arose from sorrow without torment,
29  Which the crowds had, that many were and great,
30  Of infants and of women and of men.
31  To me the Master good: "Thou dost not ask
32  What spirits these, which thou beholdest, are?
33  Now will I have thee know, ere thou go farther,
34  That they sinned not; and if they merit had,
35  'Tis not enough, because they had not baptism
36  Which is the portal of the Faith thou holdest;
37  And if they were before Christianity,
38  In the right manner they adored not God;
39  And among such as these am I myself.
40  For such defects, and not for other guilt,
41  Lost are we and are only so far punished,
42  That without hope we live on in desire."
43  Great grief seized on my heart when this I heard,
44  Because some people of much worthiness
45  I knew, who in that Limbo were suspended.
Throughout the Commedia, there seems to be a kind of connecting ether, by which the very atmosphere is charged with the emotional and moral state of its inhabitants: the place and the people and other entities in it are conflated in an inextricable entanglement.  Here, in line 27, che l'aura eterna facevan tremare (the everlasting air is made to tremble) by the sighs of those inhabiting it.  Dante comes again to his awareness, by listening first, the trope an exact rhyme of that in Canto III, wherein he heard the cacophonous babbling howls and curses of the indecisive, before he saw them.  The contrapuntal nature of his technique is almost closer to a cannon than a fugue, so precise is his placement from Canto to Canto of these tropes.  Here, however, there are no curses, no howls of torment, but only sighs, the sighs of those free of pain, but still heavy with unfulfillable desires.  The hear/see motif is also continued when in line 53 below, Virgil tells us that Dante not only hears these souls, but he also sees them.  A particular emotional coloration is infused throughout this Canto: these are people who are literally suspended like colloidals in an a nearly stagnant solute comprised of this one feeling.  What that feeling, or better feeling/cognitive state, is is vagueness.  They don't know what they want, they only know that they don't have it.  They are hungering for what I would call transcendence.  Dante, the aspirant, hears these soft laments, which the poet Dante describs as turbines (le turbe), whirlwinds, not crowds as the translator would have it, but whirlwinds of sighs issuing from infants, women, and men (viri, not uomo, men, but men of valor), which we learn further on in line 35 are the unbaptized — those living before the incarnation of Christ or who died before being baptized.  In Christian theology, this is pretty clear, and also cruelly doctrinal.  You can't really explain it away, as Christians have been trying to do for a couple of thousand years, without perverting morality to the point where souls are punished by the operations of fate and time alone, and not because — as Virgil informs us — they had volitional demerits. This postulates a God who makes souls to damn, just as He had in Canto III prepared a Hell before He created anyone to put in it.  So let's do something else.  If praise (the virtue that Beatrice possesses as we know from Canto II) is the coin of the realm of heaven, sorrow is Hell's atmosphere that the inhabitants both breathe and perpetuate with their hopelessness.  What all these people seem to lack is the feeling of adoration, colored, I think, with awe.  If we compare these two states: awe-inspired adoration and sorrowful depression, we find that they are mutually exclusive.  There are chemical states in the body (such as the brain chemistry that determines sleep or wakefulness), which operate like the two far ends of a teeter-totter.  They cannot both be in ascendance simultaneously, when one is up, the other is down, and whichever side is up has the feeling tone of everlastingness, l'aura eterna, as Dante calls it, an everlasting air.  Now this interpretation has bite: it doesn't matter what you believe as doctrine.  It doesn't matter what you have done, sinful or virtuous.  And infantile innocence is too needy and dependent to confer the state.  When this is your brain-state you are in limbo.  Now can you get out of limbo by bootstrapping from the limited brain-state resources available to you there: No.  You're stuck, you're suspended.

Caveat: I don't want to just replace the metaphor of Christian theological doctrine with brain-state metaphors.  Doctrine has its virtues: it's simple, it can be taught, it can be made into rules, and rules can be followed, obeyed.  But does obedience to doctrine lead to transcendence?  Probably it does for certain people for whom questioning does not arise.  But for those who have already questioned ... ?
Brain-state doctrine is slippery too, but perhaps more foundational.  It speaks in terms of chemistry, which may be as much effect as cause, while transcendence, it seems to me, is something other than that.  Those of us who took hallucinogenic drugs in the 1960's and 70's got blown away by brain chemistry.  Doctrine got exploded as an irrelevence.  But the questions did not cease, the chemical transcendence was a bubble state, great in its moment, but not very transferable as the kind of merging of external and internal environments which Dante is illustrating in a negative sense here.  
It seems to me that transcendence has a linguistic aspect, something between either the internal environment (brain/body chemistry) and the external environment (politics, economics, relationships, the weather).  Transcendence seems to arise neither from the sign nor from the signified, but from some process that conflates and magnifies the two and is indeed worthy of awe-inspired adoration.    
46  “Dimmi, maestro mio, dimmi, segnore, 
47  comincia' io per volere esser certo
48  di quella fede che vince ogne errore:

49  “uscicci mai alcuno, o per suo merto
50  o per altrui, che poi fosse beato?”
51  E quei che 'ntese il mio parlar coverto, 

52  rispuose: “Io era nuovo in questo stato,
53  quando ci vidi venire un possente,
54  con segno di vittoria coronato.

55  Trasseci l'ombra del primo parente,
56  d'Abèl suo figlio e quella di Noè,
57  di Moïsè legista e ubidente;

58  Abraàm patrïarca e Davìd re,
59  Israèl con lo padre e co' suoi nati
60  e con Rachele, per cui tanto fé,

61  e altri molti, e feceli beati.
62  E vo' che sappi che, dinanzi ad essi,
63  spiriti umani non eran salvati.”

46  "Tell me, my Master, tell me, thou my Lord,"
47  Began I, with desire of being certain
48  Of that Faith which o'ercometh every error,
49  "Came any one by his own merit hence,
50  Or by another's, who was blessed thereafter?"
51  And he, who understood my covert speech,
52  Replied: "I was a novice in this state,
53  When I saw hither come a Mighty One,
54  With sign of victory incoronate.
55  Hence he drew forth the shade of the First Parent,
56  And that of his son Abel, and of Noah,
57  Of Moses the lawgiver, and the obedient
58  Abraham, patriarch, and David, king,
59  Israel with his father and his children,
60  And Rachel, for whose sake he did so much,
61  And others many, and he made them blessed;
62  And thou must know, that earlier than these
63  Never were any human spirits saved."
What is happening here?  Dante addresses Virgil as teacher and Lord, exactly as the followers of Jesus addressed him, and not only that, the answer that Dante expects seems specifically to address the question that I alluded to previously: How could a moral God damn the innocent?  What the aspirant seems to be asking is this:  Is there a loophole somewhere in the doctrine that states that the unbaptized can attain the state of blessedness?  Why are all those born before the Incarnation damned?   Modern readers who do not necessarily adhere to the Catholic orthodox position in 14th century Italy will eventually have to ask this question too.  What does the Incarnation mean?  And — can unbelievers ever attain the state of blessedness?  Dante, the aspirant, seems to think that he can be certain of that faith which is victorious over every error  (quella fede che vince ogne errore), only if these two things are so.  1) There is such an escape hatch out of limbo and into paradise, and 2) If Virgil, one of those doomed to this eternal state of sad suspension, accepts his own fate, then reasonable people can find a punishment just, even if it falls on them.  Essentially it's an appeal to the infallibility of authority, no matter how arbitrary or quixotic that authority happens to be.

Virgil answers by describing a one-time off event (like the Incarnation!), which automatically puts the event in historical, sequential time.  What happened then, will never happen again.  And what exactly did happen?  A Divine intervention.  When Virgil was new in the state (and Longfellow's translation of novice, is wrong I think, because a novice in Dante's world would have been a religious novitiate: a monoco novizo, and Virgil could have never have been that.) Virgil witnessed un possente (a Mighty One: by implication, this is Jesus, harrowing Hell, which he would have done after his death on the cross on this Day, Good Friday, until his resurrection on Easter Sunday).  Note: There is an interesting prohibition against mentioning the name, like the old Jewish prohibition of saying the name of God, and curiously, further in this Canto, in the midst of a litany of names, there is another whose name is not spoken aloud, i.e. Aristotle.  But to resume.  This Mighty One is con segno di vittoria coronato (with the sign victory crowned).  What would this vittoria coronato be?  A halo?, or just an expression that indicates one who has passed beyond judgement, to someplace like that which Rumi refers to when he says:

Somewhere out beyond right and wrong,
There is a field — I'll meet you there.

We don't know what this sign is, but suffice it to say, that this question of authority is answered for Virgil because whoever this being is (he does not know) he has the power to do that which Virgil himself cannot do, which is to say: Get people out of Hell.  And that list would be:

Adam (the first parent)
Abel
Noah
Moses
Abraham
David
Israel
Isaac (name unmentioned)
David
and Rachel (already referred to in Canto II) which is probably Dante the poet's endorsement of the blessedness of a contemplative practice)

There are also altri molti (many others) so essentially this etcetera is an invitation to the reader to place anyone else that they deem worthy on to that flight.  The technique here of just rattling off a list of names is an old one.  It's a museum inventory list, which I believe is included because names have numa — names, especially for a poet, have power.  They are incantatory.  Each name is a kind of doorway to the adventure of the life whose possessor wore that name, an open sesame for anyone to use if they then decide to open that door, and go on to discover just what the experience and the lessons to be learned from that experience might be.  If you get bored by just having to read the name, perhaps that means that you are not ready or even worthy of that experience.  

We should also be clear here that this Divine intervention is (or in this case was) the only way to get out of Hell.  Virgil also adds that earlier than these, no human spirits were saved.  Since Adam, the first human is on the list, we can assume that this statement is essentially an affirmation that the list includes everyone ever born, whom the Divine deems worthy.  And as we shall see in the Purgatorio, when we find Cato there, the elect might also include a pagan and a suicide.

Any reasonable person will find this whole explanation of why certain people are in limbo rather oily and smarmy — but reason is not the issue here, faith and obedience are, and the justification for those attributes could never be found in Hell.
      
64  Non lasciavam l'andar perch' ei dicessi,
65  ma passavam la selva tuttavia,
66  la selva, dico, di spiriti spessi.

67  Non era lunga ancor la nostra via
68  di qua dal sonno, quand' io vidi un foco
69  ch'emisperio di tenebre vincia.

70  Di lungi n'eravamo ancora un poco,
71  ma non sì ch'io non discernessi in parte
72  ch'orrevol gente possedea quel loco.

73  “O tu ch'onori scïenzïa e arte,
74  questi chi son c'hanno cotanta onranza,
75  che dal modo de li altri li diparte?”

76  E quelli a me: “L'onrata nominanza
77  che di lor suona sù ne la tua vita,
78  grazïa acquista in ciel che sì li avanza.”
64  We ceased not to advance because he spake,
65  But still were passing onward through the forest,
66  The forest, say I, of thick-crowded ghosts.
67  Not very far as yet our way had gone
68  This side the summit, when I saw a fire
69  That overcame a hemisphere of darkness.
70  We were a little distant from it still,
71  But not so far that I in part discerned not
72  That honourable people held that place.
73  "O thou who honourest every art and science,
74  Who may these be, which such great honour have,
75  That from the fashion of the rest it parts them?"
76  And he to me: "The honourable name,
77  That sounds of them above there in thy life,
78  Wins grace in Heaven, that so advances them."
As they talk, they walk, and Dante, the poet, returns to the first trope of the first of first tercet of the entire Commedia: the forest.  Here, it's a dark forest too, just as it was at the very first (for all hominids this true) but Dante very pointedly repeats the word selva.  This is a forest thick with ghosts: la selva {} di spiriti spessi.  And isn't it true that as we grow older, descending back in memory through time, that we are always passing through this forest of spirits?  And this forest grows thicker as the skin of our bodies grows thinner with increasing senescence.  Again the trope of an atmosphere of the dead, which we remember are turbines of swirling energy, as a tree is a column of swirling energies.  Always the city boy, for Dante the forest is not a place of refuge, but a place of confusion, or regression.  Back we go from Homo Sapiens to Homo Erecti.  And it is obvious that here in Canto IV he is deliberately echoing the situation described in Canto I, when in addition to the word selva, he now uses the words: la nostra via, a slight phonetic change from la nostra vita.  And just as in Canto I, here again he has awakened from sleep, or from a swoon, as he says in line 68: di qua dal sonno (not far from sleep), again sticking to that borderline area between the unconscious and the conscious mind, that rich, but fuzzy both/and state thick with rich possibilities, but nothing as yet solid, nothing clear.  In the distance Dante sees a hemisphere of fire.  A hemisphere is half a sphere, so again we have the idea of something only partially manifested, something the aspirant only discerns in parte.  Its fire is victorious (vincia) over the darkness, just as the Christ who harrowed Hell was a victorious figure.  So this is how Dante is alerting us that this is the abode of those who are victorious, but only partially so.  This hemisphere of fire is held by honorable people, it is Virgil's place, and here, set apart with his fellows, the master of every science and art, lives — in Hell, a place illuminated by the brilliance of his and their earthly accomplishments.  The people we are about to encounter live in this bubble, set apart from the vulgar crowd, as people displaying some kind of genius are also set apart from people content to live more ordinary lives.  We are reminded her of the one of Beatrice's reasons, besides his love of her, that Dante was chosen for this special dispensation: He is a man set apart from the vulgar crowd.  Remember the etymology of the word vulgar.  It suggests thronging or crowding: the poor we find teeming in every city.  Any person now, who reads Dante, just for their own esthetic and spiritual edification, can feel this.  They too are people set apart, and they will be reminded of that by the throng.  How this situation plays out is the theme of this Canto.  Dante asks what makes these people so honorable that they are set apart.  And again, the value of praise and of a lasting name is confirmed.  They win grace (the first time this word appears in the Commedia) because heaven values the praise that the living have bestowed upon them.  It's really quite an extraordinary idea — that the living, by the respect they grant these dead for their accomplishments on earth, preserve and advance the dead.  No wonder naming and repetition of names is so important, it is as if the speaking of that name in praise is a kind of bell, the circle of whose resonance somehow protects the dead from falling into the post-mortem oblivion of anonymity, and in this case returning to that mass of mixed-up whirlwinds which constitute the forest of ghosts through which Virgil and Dante are passing.  And sure enough, what do we hear first in the following tercets: praise of Virgil, and a litany of names, repeated like mantras which keep these damned insulated — and let us not forget — suspended — from the tortures of the damned. 
79  Intanto voce fu per me udita:
80  “Onorate l'altissimo poeta;
81  l'ombra sua torna, ch'era dipartita.”

82  Poi che la voce fu restata e queta,
83  vidi quattro grand' ombre a noi venire:
84  sembianz' avevan né trista né lieta.

85  Lo buon maestro cominciò a dire:
86  “Mira colui con quella spada in mano,
87  che vien dinanzi ai tre sì come sire:

88  quelli è Omero poeta sovrano;
89  l'altro è Orazio satiro che vene;
90  Ovidio è 'l terzo, e l'ultimo Lucano.

91  Però che ciascun meco si convene
92  nel nome che sonò la voce sola,
93  fannomi onore, e di ciò fanno bene.”

79  In the mean time a voice was heard by me:
80  "All honour be to the pre-eminent Poet;
81  His shade returns again, that was departed."
82  After the voice had ceased and quiet was,
83  Four mighty shades I saw approaching us;
84  Semblance had they nor sorrowful nor glad.
85  To say to me began my gracious Master:
86  "Him with that falchion in his hand behold,
87  Who comes before the three, even as their lord.
88  That one is Homer, Poet sovereign;
89  He who comes next is Horace, the satirist;
90  The third is Ovid, and the last is Lucan.
91  Because to each of these with me applies
92  The name that solitary voice proclaimed,
93  They do me honour, and in that do well."

In these lines (80 - 81) a voice (whose voice, we do not know — the voice of the place itself?) speaks, welcoming Virgil, who is greeted on his return with the phase "Onorate l'altissimo poeta / l'ombra sua torna, ch'era dipartita. ( All honor be to the preeminent poet/his shade returns that had departed).  Most high poet: no jealousy or envy here, only mutual praise — but there is a hierarchy, as we shall see, a lineage actually, if we recall the idea of lineage from Canto I.  We might think of those passages in the Bible of who begat whom in the long chain of umbilicals stretching across the generations.  Again we have the motif: first hear, and then see. Virgil narrates.  He informs the aspirant, Dante, of the identities of those approaching, their facial expressions pointedly neither sad nor happy — a kind of toned-down parody of the indecisive damned in the previous Canto.  These shades are also caught in an inbetween state, but they seem to have accepted their fate, and, their only torment is this perpetual stagnation.

Now, let's consider what the conception of time must be like for those in limbo, and by implication, for all those in Hell.  First, it is clear from the voice's words that those there know they are shades.  This may seem like a small detail, but it violates the almost universal belief that "the dead do not know they are dead", just as the dreaming self does not know it is dreaming.  Here they know, and throughout the Commedia they know.  But perhaps more interesting is that by stating that Virgil departed, and has now returned, we learn that these people conceive of time as perpetual, not eternal.  In other words, they are not experiencing the timeless state that an artist or a poet experiences when he or she is totally absorbed in the creative process.  They are experiencing an interminable sequence of moments.  Time can thus weigh on them, but it cannot destroy them.  To me, this adds a considerable degree of torment to their existence, which I hope to be able to comment on later.  

The four great poets approach apparently in single file, like so many Chinese wives, from first to last, with Homer, the most ancient, the sire (that word being more than some commentators would have it: an abbreviation for segnore), it refers to a father, the head of a lineage, as noted above.  We have seen this kind of lineage before in Canto II with the Virgin Mary, St. Lucy, and Beatrice.  And also in Canto I with the lineage which led to the founding of Rome.  But there is another curious feature here, which Dante probably did not know about, although it does serve as an example of what every poet learns — the text that he or she is writing  has insights which go beyond their own conscious mind.  Note the following:

Homer
Horace: 65 b.c. to 8 b.c.
Ovid: 43 b.c. to 18 b.c.
Lucan: 39 a.d. to 65 a.d.

This is a list of poets who are sequential in historical time, in other words, each successive link in the chain could have been inspired by his predecessor.  We can only learn from people who precede us in historical time.  This may seem obvious, since in our minds everything we know or are influenced by exists as a simultaneity, and so experientially this is something we can only understand by abstract reasoning.  Our actual experience of those who have inspired us is more cloud-like than chain-like, but here, we see it as a chain.  Like the step by step procedure of walking, which is what Dante and Virgil, as the text tells us back in line 64, are doing.

If the text in these lines is a sequence from first to last in historical time, then by calling Virgil the preeminent poet, he should, after Homer, have come first historically in this group of poets.  Virgil's life span?  70 b.c. to 19 b.c.  He precedes Horace by half a decade.  Virgil also modelled the Aeneid after Homer's Odyssey.  Most influenced by Homer, eldest son, equals — l'altissimo poeta.

There is an important piece of external symbology here too, lest any of the other poets forget who their father is.  Homer carries a "spada" in his hand, (very Freudian and phallic) and Virgil calls him sovereign.

The sequence of course could be arranged in other ways, such as: the order in which we have read the poets, or the order of their merit — the most inspiring to the least.  And these orders are not mutually exclusive.  If I am right about sequentiality referring to historical time, then there are ways of ordering time that are not deterministic, except in the fact that one event follows another in some manner in our consciousness.

It's also worth thinking about the interplay of the word "honor" throughout this Canto.  I'll quote another commentator and translator of Dante, Robert Hollander:

This new place, the only place in hell in which light is said to overcome darkness (Inf. IV.68-69), is immediately linked to the 'key word' of this section of the canto, 'honor.' This is the densest repetition of a single word and its derivates in the Comedy: seven times in 29 lines (72-100: at vv. 72, 73, 74, 76, 80, 93, 100), with a 'coda' tacked on at v. 133. Can there be any doubt that honor and poetry are indissolubly linked in Dante's view of his own status? As lofty as noble actions and great philosophy may be for him (but that part of the canto, vv. 106-147, has only a single occurrence of the word 'honor'), it is poetry that, for Dante, is the great calling.

Why this is so, and why exactly poetry deserves this preeminence, is a lengthy discussion for another time, but it's worth noting here that poetry has some special qualities as a mode of knowing, feeling, and transforming that are unique, a proposition that will become more apparent as we delve deeper into the poem. 
  
One final note: If Homer is blind, as he was famously reputed to be in his earthly life, he does not seem to be here.  Because if he is, and it is not stated one way or another, this would be more ironic than the blind leading the blind, it would be the blind leading the sighted.  I would take this to mean that for poets the insight that comes from speaking and hearing can trump what we can garner from reading and seeing.  Too bad I don't have Marshall McLuhan here to tell me how one sensory mode/medium or another changes the way we assimilate knowledge and experience.   

94  Così vid' i' adunar la bella scola
95  di quel segnor de l'altissimo canto
96  che sovra li altri com' aquila vola.

97  Da ch'ebber ragionato insieme alquanto,
98  volsersi a me con salutevol cenno,
99  e 'l mio maestro sorrise di tanto;

100  e più d'onore ancora assai mi fenno,
101  ch'e' sì mi fecer de la loro schiera,
102  sì ch'io fui sesto tra cotanto senno.

103  Così andammo infino a la lumera,
104  parlando cose che 'l tacere è bello,
105  sì com' era 'l parlar colà dov' era.
94  Thus I beheld assemble the fair school
95  Of that lord of the song pre-eminent,
96  Who o'er the others like an eagle soars.
97  When they together had discoursed somewhat,
98  They turned to me with signs of salutation,
99  And on beholding this, my Master smiled;
100  And more of honour still, much more, they did me,
101  In that they made me one of their own band;
102  So that the sixth was I, 'mid so much wit.
103  Thus we went on as far as to the light,
104  Things saying 'tis becoming to keep silent,
105  As was the saying of them where I was.
In lines 96 -7, there is an ambivalence that is more or less unresolvable.  Does the text mean to say that Homer or Virgil soar eagle-like, seeing farther or further than the others?  Or does the text refer to the epic genre that both practiced, epic being the highest song (l'altissimo canto)?  Since it so ambivalent, I prefer to let it remain so: poets, poetry, and the style of poetry are so entangled that it would be a disparagement of one aspect to elevate it above the others.  They all rise like the eagle whose sight enables it to see everything below.  In modern parlance: it is simply a higher state of consciousness, a metaposition. 
There is one smile (sorrise), and one smile only in all of Dante's Hell, and it is here, when Virgil smiles at Dante as the assembled poets accept him as the sixth incarnation of their band of exalted brothers.  The word honor returns, and its nimbus envelops Dante.  Thus Dante, who has yet to write his greatest work, seems already laurelled.  Is this arrogance on Dante the poet's part?  Maybe.  But it could be that Dante needs that tonic in order to write the Commedia, an amazing attempt, which, in order to become an amazing accomplishment, must be fortified with a considerable amount of audacity, and anyone who purports to be revealing the secrets of Hell, Purgatory and Paradise certainly has got some Moxy.  Great enterprises require great energy, and by adding himself to this ongoing lineage, Dante places himself at the growing tip of a mighty dynasty.  The other poets pay him honor because he has carried on their work, because he has honored them too — again the theme of praising.
In the last tercet before Dante and Virgil come to the noble castle, the text speaks of moving more into the light, and of speaking of things that are better left in silence.  Another deliberate ambiguity.  We remember secret things from Canto III, things not necessarily hidden, but beyond our understanding, as if the things spoken about were transmitted in a foreign tongue which is the special province of poets to understand, and would only tempt the uninitiated to believe that they know something, which they have yet to do the hard work required to really experience.  If I tell you what transformation means, you only have a dictionary definition, not a poetic experience.
