And you might sit there comfortably smug in believing you have wisdom, when you only have a roadblock to achieving wisdom.  The text tells us that the group of poet is constantly moving toward the light.  That's good advice, and probably the only advice that will uncover what before seemed ineffable.     

106  Venimmo al piè d'un nobile castello,
107  sette volte cerchiato d'alte mura,
108  difeso intorno d'un bel fiumicello.

109  Questo passammo come terra dura;
110  per sette porte intrai con questi savi:
111  giugnemmo in prato di fresca verdura.

112  Genti v'eran con occhi tardi e gravi,
113  di grande autorità ne' lor sembianti:
114  parlavan rado, con voci soavi.

115  Traemmoci così da l'un de' canti,
116  in loco aperto, luminoso e alto,
117  sì che veder si potien tutti quanti.

118  olà diritto, sovra 'l verde smalto,
119  mi fuor mostrati li spiriti magni,
120  che del vedere in me stesso m'essalto.


106  We came unto a noble castle's foot,
107  Seven times encompassed with lofty walls,
108  Defended round by a fair rivulet;

109  This we passed over even as firm ground;
110  Through portals seven I entered with these Sages;
111  We came into a meadow of fresh verdure.

112  People were there with solemn eyes and slow,
113  Of great authority in their countenance;
114  They spake but seldom, and with gentle voices.

115  Thus we withdrew ourselves upon one side
116  Into an opening luminous and lofty,
117  So that they all of them were visible.

118  There opposite, upon the green enamel,
119  Were pointed out to me the mighty spirits,
120  Whom to have seen I feel myself exalted.

Now Virgil and Dante, along with the four poets who greeted them, come to the source of the light.  It is a castle, which has been traditionally called the Castle of Wisdom, and this castle is circled by seven high walls, and is ringed round by a beautiful little stream.  The seven walls have been said to represent the four moral virtues — prudence, temperance, fortitude and justice, plus the three intellectual virtues — understanding, knowledge, and wisdom.  The stream is allegorically assumed to represent eloquence.  Then our group of six, like a half-dozen versions of Jesus, walk over the water as if it were firm ground.  A little razzle dazzle here, it being easily done by shades who have no substance, but Dante, the living body, should have sunk.  That he does not shows us that the whole place is more dream image than anything else, and Dante for all his efforts to convince us that his is a literal physical body, and that the entire journey of the aspirant is as real as a journey would be from Florence to Rome, with a detail like this, again shows us that the laws of this place are not those that constrain material bodies in a material world.  Like the shades we find here, physical laws in limbo are in suspension too.  No gravity here, no electromagnetic force, no strong and weak nuclear forces, this place is governed by imagination, just as reading and writing is, it is a land where poetry supplants temporal restraints, and here we might have a reference in the representation of this castle of the things that Dante and the others spoke of in the previous lines, and which Dante thought better to leave unexpressed.  And yet here we see a mystery manifested, as our group of poets walk through seven gates and arrive in a green meadow.  The traditional allegorical reading is that these seven gates symbolize the seven liberal arts, the trivium of grammar, logic, and rhetoric, and the quadrivium of music, arithmetic, geometry, and astronomy.  The poets then would be passing through an intellectual curriculum to arrive at a fertile place where Hell itself is illuminated and where all the great figures of history troop about with eyes slow (tardi) and solemn (gravi).  Like people in a museum dedicated to their own accomplishments, their speech here comes rarely (rado) and from soft (soavi) voices.  No matter what we might think 6 into 7 twice might mean, and what the meadow symbolizes, all this is clear enough to visualize, but destined to remain opaque to the understanding.  We really only know what the text reveals, and after that the imagination may freely paint whatever graffiti it likes on those seven walls and those seven gates.  This, and all the rest of the considerable numerology of the poem, represents a kind of proportionality in the Commedia, which gives the imagination of both poet and reader a frame in which to order itself, a kind of city enclosing a garden that saves those inside from the general psychosis which would run amok in a dark, wild chaos without these secure borders to contain its excesses.  We are reminded of Blake's dictum in the Marriage of Heaven and Hell: Energy is the only life of the Body and Reason is the bound or outward circumference of Energy, and to add a gloss, the body without boundaries is only a cancer or a slime mold.  The six poets assume an elevated and illuminated position (the position of the reader and the writer in relation to the text), where they may survey and inventory what this castle both contains and protects.  

I must admit I find this place quite lugubrious, all these quiet ghosts padding about and speaking in soft, solemn whispers, not doing anything great, but just stagnating in their reputations of greatness and processing around in their old habiliments of fame, hollowed out and emptied of everything but their names.  And yet what names!  Thrilling names really for anyone who has imaginatively entered the story of their lives and accomplishments.  Dante, the aspirant, is in awe.  Like a kid at Disneyland, he is finally seeing the animatrons of all the heroes he has met in his studies, and as I said before, the names themselves each becoming a kind of mantra whose repetition can summon the vision of their bodies.  What follows is a catalog of greatness, held together by the phrase I saw (vidi).  I saw!  I saw!  I saw!  I saw!  I saw!  Now that is the eureka cry of every student and reader, when after long labor, suddenly the object of their contemplation comes alive in the mind, and illumination replaces darkness.  We are exalted.  The common grass becomes shining enamel (verde samlto), and we cry:  I see!  I finally see!  That is a great moment, but to stay in that moment, is to be a spectator, a scholar, and not a creator.  It is to be a fan, not a player, and it reminds me of those grown men in bars who have arguments about the sports and players that they can only watch.  Until I see becomes I am, we cannot enter the pantheon of greatness ourselves, we can only watch luminous ghosts and repeat their names and accomplishments.    

121  I' vidi Eletra con molti compagni,
122  tra ' quai conobbi Ettòr ed Enea,
123  Cesare armato con li occhi grifagni.

124  Vidi Cammilla e la Pantasilea;
125  da l'altra parte vidi 'l re Latino
126  che con Lavina sua figlia sedea.

127  Vidi quel Bruto che cacciò Tarquino,
128  Lucrezia, Iulia, Marzïa e Corniglia;
129  e solo, in parte, vidi 'l Saladino.

130  Poi ch'innalzai un poco più le ciglia,
131  vidi 'l maestro di color che sanno
132  seder tra filosofica famiglia.

133  Tutti lo miran, tutti onor li fanno:
134  quivi vid' ïo Socrate e Platone,
135  che 'nnanzi a li altri più presso li stanno;

136  Democrito che 'l mondo a caso pone,
137  Dïogenès, Anassagora e Tale,
138  Empedoclès, Eraclito e Zenone;

139  e vidi il buono accoglitor del quale,
140  Dïascoride dico; e vidi Orfeo,
141  Tulïo e Lino e Seneca morale;

142  Euclide geomètra e Tolomeo,
143  Ipocràte, Avicenna e Galïeno,
144  Averoìs che 'l gran comento feo.

121  I saw Electra with companions many,
122  'Mongst whom I knew both Hector and Aeneas,
123  Caesar in armour with gerfalcon eyes;

124  I saw Camilla and Penthesilea
125  On the other side, and saw the King Latinus,
126  Who with Lavinia his daughter sat;

127  I saw that Brutus who drove Tarquin forth,
128  Lucretia, Julia, Marcia, and Cornelia,
129  And saw alone, apart, the Saladin.

130  When I had lifted up my brows a little,
131  The Master I beheld of those who know,
132  Sit with his philosophic family.

133  All gaze upon him, and all do him honour.
134  There I beheld both Socrates and Plato,
135  Who nearer him before the others stand;

136  Democritus, who puts the world on chance,
137  Diogenes, Anaxagoras, and Thales,
138  Zeno, Empedocles, and Heraclitus;

139  Of qualities I saw the good collector,
140  Hight Dioscorides; and Orpheus saw I,
141  Tully and Livy, and moral Seneca,

142  Euclid, geometrician, and Ptolemy,
143  Galen, Hippocrates, and Avicenna,
144  Averroes, who the great Comment made.

There are 34 names on this list, and one person, unnamed, but referred to in the tercet beginning at line 130:

130  Poi ch'innalzai un poco più le ciglia,
131  vidi 'l maestro di color che sanno
132  seder tra filosofica famiglia.

130  When I had lifted up my brows a little,
131  The Master I beheld of those who know,
132  Sit with his philosophic family.

The first thing I should say is that the translation of le ciglia as brows is misleading.  It should be eyelashes.  Dante, the aspirant, has been half asleep the whole time!  And then the unnamed one's epithet is The Master "of those who know".  This is very sly on Dante the poet's part.  Why?  Because if you are not one of those "who know" that this is Aristotle, you don't belong in the family of philosophers.  The raised eye motif as we have noted before is not perhaps to be construed as spatial, but perspectival.  Aristotle, as is Caesar mentioned in line 123 with the gyrfalcon eyes, sees further, not farther, these two, like the highest poet mentioned earlier, have more insight than others.  But in Aristotle, there is something ineffable, or unmentionable, we have to ferret that something out on our own, otherwise it is quite superficial and worthless to us.

Now the list comes to 35 people, plus the 5 poets with Dante: that makes 40.  These numbers have a numerological symbology.  From a Bible Study website I find this quote:

Mentioned 146 times in Scripture, the number 40 generally symbolizes a period of testing, trial or probation. During Moses' life he lived forty years in Egypt and forty years in the desert before God selected him to lead his people out of slavery. 
Moses was also on Mount Sinai for 40 days and nights, on two separate occasions (Exodus 24:18, 34:1 - 28), receiving God's laws. He also sent spies, for forty days, to investigate the land God promised the Israelites as an inheritance (Numbers 13:25, 14:34).

The prophet Jonah powerfully warned ancient Nineveh, for forty days, that its destruction would come because of its many sins. The prophet Ezekiel laid on His right side for 40 days to symbolize Judah's sins (Ezekiel 4:6). 
Elijah went 40 days without food or water at Mount Horeb. Jesus was tempted by the devil not just three times, but MANY times during the 40 days and nights he fasted just before his ministry began. He also appeared to his disciples and others for 40 days after his resurrection from the dead.

I think Dante would have probably been very aware of this sort of thing.  And indeed, the entire Inferno and Purgatorio do represent a period of trial and testing.  Beyond that, I think it is safe to say that number for Dante, as much as number in the I Ching, is foundational, a kind of armature or skeleton, upon which the squishier parts of the universe hang.

If, as a reader, you had the intensity to go through this list and study each figure on it, you would be approaching the kind of education that Dante no doubt received, so we could say that each person on this list from soldiers to sufferers to philosophers to poets to historians to doctors to rulers to wives to sisters to mothers to astronomers to mathematicians — would be a torch which illuminates some area of human activity and experience.  As does the Commedia as a whole, the list demands exegesis, a delving into, and like dreams to Freud, interpretation is  even more crucial than surface content.  Interpretation — specifically "what this means to me" —  is what is transformational for the reader.

145  Io non posso ritrar di tutti a pieno,
146  però che sì mi caccia il lungo tema,
147  che molte volte al fatto il dir vien meno.

148  La sesta compagnia in due si scema:
149  per altra via mi mena il savio duca,
150  fuor de la queta, ne l'aura che trema.

151  E vegno in parte ove non è che luca.

145  I cannot all of them pourtray in full,
146  Because so drives me onward the long theme,
147  That many times the word comes short of fact.

148  The sixfold company in two divides;
149  Another way my sapient Guide conducts me
150  Forth from the quiet to the air that trembles;

151  And to a place I come where nothing shines.

"I cannot all of them portray in full," and don't I know how he feels!  Each name on this list is a temptation to be diverted from the downward journey into Hell.  And isn't this a fact about any intense and long-term project?  There are interruptions, fatigue, diversions — little shiny objects that tempt you from the path, which is arduous, and demands a constant, almost inhuman focus.  But onward and downward we must go, lest we be caught like these shades in limbo, suspended in in pleasant but unproductive suburban eddy, and cut off from the onward flow of our quest.
  
It should be pointed out here that the Dante who speaks in line 145 is the poet Dante, not the aspirant Dante.  We get a brief glimpse here of the wizard behind the curtain, and are reminded briefly of the diachronic nature of the quest: part of us in the middle, part of us already there.

In keeping with some of the other irreconcilable ambiguities already mentioned we come to the curious line: La sesta compagnia in due si scema (The sixfold fold company in two divides.)  6 divided by 2 is 3.  This is basic arithmetic, because every school child knows that 2, Dante and Virgil, is not 3.  The answer is wrong.  But is it?  A quote from T.S. Eliot's Wasteland might serve us here:

   Who is the third who walks always beside you?
When I count, there are only you and I together
But when I look ahead up the white road
There is always another one walking beside you
Gliding wrapt in a brown mantle, hooded
I do not know whether a man or a woman
— but who is that on the other side of you?

Is the other traveler the aspirant Dante accompanied by his gliding poet self?  Is it the future reader?  Is it Beatrice, his anima, his soul?  It's all so ambiguous, and, I believe meant to be.  The question opens us up to inquiry.  In the end, only unanswerable questions are worth asking, because they reveal to us the awesome nature of infinity.

The last two lines of this Canto are full of foreboding.  We are leaving a place of heady quiet and luminance, to where the air trembles and no light shines.  The poet in his study finds that the real risk to his spiritual journey is the ease and reassurance he finds in his former accomplishments.  All the people in limbo are quite literally resting on their laurels.  But how fearful it is to throw everything that you've done away to descend once more into the turbulent unknown.

Canto V
1  Così discesi del cerchio primaio
2  giù nel secondo, che men loco cinghia
3  e tanto più dolor, che punge a guaio.

4  Stavvi Minòs orribilmente, e ringhia:
5  essamina le colpe ne l'intrata;
6  giudica e manda secondo ch'avvinghia.

7  Dico che quando l'anima mal nata
8  li vien dinanzi, tutta si confessa;
9  e quel conoscitor de le peccata

10  vede qual loco d'inferno è da essa;
11  cignesi con la coda tante volte
12  quantunque gradi vuol che giù sia messa.

13  Sempre dinanzi a lui ne stanno molte:
14  vanno a vicenda ciascuna al giudizio,
15  dicono e odono e poi son giù volte.

1  Thus I descended out of the first circle
2  Down to the second, that less space begirds,
3  And so much greater dole, that goads to wailing.
4  There standeth Minos horribly, and snarls;
5  Examines the transgressions at the entrance;
6  Judges, and sends according as he girds him.
7  I say, that when the spirit evil-born
8  Cometh before him, wholly it confesses;
9  And this discriminator of transgressions
10  Seeth what place in Hell is meet for it;
11  Girds himself with his tail as many times
12  As grades he wishes it should be thrust down.
13  Always before him many of them stand;
14  They go by turns each one unto the judgment;
15  They speak, and hear, and then are downward hurled.

Overview note: Dante is passing through his greatest danger, he comes out of the quietude of the "Castle of Wisdom" lauded as a great poet, i.e. crowned with hubris, and forgets about humility.  This puts him into a kind of coma of self-congratulation, and he wakes up in this Canto as if being forcefully aroused (i.e., against his will), and then he proceeds in a downward spiral to the greatest of humiliations — his movement declining from deep sleep to death.  He stops listening to Virgil (reason), and begins listening to Francesca (impulsiveness), forgetting that in Hell, all the discourse of its denizens is fomented from a place of denial, ignorance, and deception.  Four words to think about: Humility, Hubris, Humiliation, Humus.  As in The Tibetan book of the Dead, he might have had an opportunity here to rise out of Hell, but he misses his chance through pity of Francesca's state, and falls even lower then he was in the very first Canto.
Dante uses the word circhio, circle, but this must be more like a spiral, a corkscrew actually, since he tells us that the second circle is wrapped tighter than the first.  We have seen this geometric figure before in the whirlwind columns of the sighs of the unbaptized in limbo, and we see it again in this python-like tail of Minos, which wraps round the sinners, born losers, as the text says in line 7: l'anima mal nata.  Consciously, as we follow the narrative line in the descent, we are apt to miss these repetitions, but they fractally mirror the entire shape of Hell, screwing down, tighter and tighter, as if we were on the inside of an auger, just as in the Purgatorio we wind up and up, on the outside of the same auger, the sinners there undoing what the sinners below have done.  The sinners line up in single file, as the celebrants of a diabolic mass might line up to take communion, but in this case the line is one of those about to take confession.  Minos, father of the Minotaur, is their demonic father confessor, who offers not absolution, but damnation.  Minos is a monstrous figure because he is a conglomeration of human, snarling canine, and serpent.  This means that he is a creature driven by warring aspects of his own self, there is no harmony in his being, and no harmony in those whom he is judging.  And anyone who has that voice in their heads which says: You're an idiot.  A louse.  A criminal.  A layabout.  A worthless piece of dung, etc. is facing Minos.  He coils his serpent tail around his victims, one cinching for every level of Hell they must descend.  This is punishment squared for every coil, because in the second turn you are not released from the first, so your agony is doubled, in the third doubled again, and so forth, so that even if you manage to free yourself from one judgement, another charge still must be answered.  Minos is the conoscitor — the one who knows, the one from whom nothing is hidden, because even if you hide your transgressions from everyone else, you cannot hide it from your own conscience.  From the words confessa (confess) in line 8, and offizio (office) further down in line (18), we can read Minos as a parody of the priest in his Holy office as a confessor.  The coiling of his tail repeats the vortical shape, which like a certain figuration in music, keeps returning again and again in various permutations.  The word guaio, translated here as wailing, recurs in line 3, and repeats the hear/see sequence, because after the wailing, the aspirant sees Minos standing at the entrance of this second turn of the screw, this another repetition, reminiscent of the entrance to Hell itself in Canto III, so once again we are crossing a certain Rubicon of conscience, of guilt, just as we had in Canto IV with Charon, the circle's demon gate keeper, who ferried sinners across Acheron.  These are clearly processing stations, a kind of Ellis Island where the immigrants do not continue on in hopefulness, but in sorrow, and when Minos confronts Dante and Virgil, he clearly recognizes that they are out of place.
Note: In line 7, the word Dico, I say, tells us that the writer Dante is speaking, not Dante the aspirant.  This is a knowing figure from the beyond, the author outside the work, as inspiration appears outside the everyday personality.  This Dico reminds me of the shamanic healers, transformed by psilocybin or some other hallucinogen, who keep repeating the word says: dawn of night says, river's spirit says, cure of all ills says — so again we hear a reiteration of the power of the word, as we do also in the dicono e odono (they speak and they hear) in line 15.  In Hell we are talking to ourselves, confessing with one voice, damning with another, and so it goes round and round like polluted water swirling down a drain.  The damned here are not in suspension as they were in Canto IV.  The swamp is being drained, but only into a more fetid swamp — and all is done through the power of the word.  This power cannot be quelled even in Hell, because, like everything else, Hell is its own creation.  Or as Steven's says: "It is a world of words to the end of it."  

16  “O tu che vieni al doloroso ospizio,”
17  disse Minòs a me quando mi vide,
18  lasciando l'atto di cotanto offizio

19  “guarda com' entri e di cui tu ti fide;
20  non t'inganni l'ampiezza de l'intrare!”
21  E 'l duca mio a lui: “Perché pur gride?

22  Non impedir lo suo fatale andare:
23  vuolsi così colà dove si puote
24  ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare.”

16  "O thou, that to this dolorous hostelry
17  Comest," said Minos to me, when he saw me,
18  Leaving the practice of so great an office,
19  "Look how thou enterest, and in whom thou trustest;
20  Let not the portal's amplitude deceive thee."
21  And unto him my Guide: "Why criest thou too?
22  Do not impede his journey fate-ordained;
23  It is so willed there where is power to do
24  That which is willed; and ask no further question."
In line 20, when Minos uses the word ospizio (hostelry: check our words hotel and hospital) should be read as a parody, since these souls are not guests but prisoners.  In Hell lies are the norm, not the exception, and then he goes on to warn Dante not to be fooled by the amplitude (L'ampiezze) of the entrance.  L'ampiezza means essentially the same in English as in Italian (according to my English/Italian Dizionario Tecnico), that is: vast.  I find it interesting that it's a term describing sound waves, an audio reference, then, as well as a spatial one.  It is said that the chemical changes in some of Vermeer's paintings over time have resulted in more verisimilitude, not less, and so Dante's sensitivity to language allows his vocabulary, even as time passes, to grow more rich, more apropos than anything he might have originally intended.  That's one reason why the text becomes our guide and not only some antiquated glossary of whatever Dante might have originally intended.  What the words meant in the 14th century, that's our starting point, but they have grown, and those original meanings are amplified by time, commentary, and migrations from culture to culture.  Dante's reference here is probably to the Biblical verse 
13 Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in there at:
14 Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.
					Matthew 7:13-14 King James Version 
Another parody this, because we learned in line 2 of this Canto that this way is getting smaller, although there are many indeed "which go in thereat."  It's a trap, and Minos, not ordained to judge the quick, but only the dead, warns Dante off.  But not without a dig at Virgil, telling Dante "Guarda ... di cui tu ti fide."  (Watch out in whom you have placed your trust.)  Virgil's response is essentially the same as it was to Charon in Canto IV.  And it boils down to "Shut up!, that which has more power than you wills this.  Don't ask any more questions."  That Minos clearly obeys (another lesson in obedience) shows that as contrary as he is, he too is ordained by that power, and he executes his office on its behalf.  I like the word impedir (impede) used here, because like the word amplitude. it too has expanded in significance (impedance/impedienza) by having a modern technical sense. These things add a depth to the text as we read more than seven centuries later, which would not have been discernable to Dante or his contemporaries.  And, I might add, in response to purests who want only to adhere to Dante's original intentions: We cannot help but add this depth, any more than we can reverse entropy.  
25  Or incomincian le dolenti note
26  a farmisi sentire; or son venuto
27  là dove molto pianto mi percuote.

28  Io venni in loco d'ogne luce muto,
29  che mugghia come fa mar per tempesta,
30  se da contrari venti è combattuto.

31  La bufera infernal, che mai non resta,
32  mena li spirti con la sua rapina;
33  voltando e percotendo li molesta.

34  Quando giungon davanti a la ruina,
35  quivi le strida, il compianto, il lamento;
36  bestemmian quivi la virtù divina.

37  Intesi ch'a così fatto tormento
38  enno dannati i peccator carnali,
39  che la ragion sommettono al talento.

40  E come li stornei ne portan l'ali
41  nel freddo tempo, a schiera larga e piena,
42  così quel fiato li spiriti mali

43  di qua, di là, di giù, di sù li mena;
44  nulla speranza li conforta mai,
45  non che di posa, ma di minor pena.

25  And now begin the dolesome notes to grow
26  Audible unto me; now am I come
27  There where much lamentation strikes upon me.

28  I came into a place mute of all light,
29  Which bellows as the sea does in a tempest,
30  If by opposing winds 't is combated.
31  The infernal hurricane that never rests
32  Hurtles the spirits onward in its rapine;
33  Whirling them round, and smiting, it molests them.

34  When they arrive before the precipice,
35  There are the shrieks, the plaints, and the laments,
36  There they blaspheme the puissance divine.

37  I understood that unto such a torment
38  The carnal malefactors were condemned,
39  Who reason subjugate to appetite.

40  And as the wings of starlings bear them on
41  In the cold season in large band and full,
42  So doth that blast the spirits maledict;

43  It hither, thither, downward, upward, drives them;
44  No hope doth comfort them for evermore,
45  Not of repose, but even of lesser pain.

In this tercet of lines 25 - 27, Dante's accute sense of hearing are compared to musical notes growing in volume, until they seem like an assault on the ears, which he likens to a hurricane at sea of contending winds.  Compare Shakespeare's line: "Mad as the sea and wind when both contend which is the mightier."  Like the red eye on the planet Jupiter, this is a storm that never ends, and it whirls (another vortice metaphor) around souls caught in its fury, and every pass they make near the precipice from which they were cast is pelted by their shrieks and laments, articulated enough to be recognized by Dante as blasphemies against the divine justice which has condemned them.  Here is the famous synaesthesia where the hear/see sequence is finally conflated into one sensation: luce muto (mute light) — marvelous.  We begin to percieve a pattern at the beginning of these Cantos wherein articulate speach is torn apart by sighs, wails, howls, shrieks, curses — in short, Hell is the vulgar mob all contending against one another, and against their fate.  What a contrast from the ornate speech which Beatrice praises in Virgil in Canto II!  It is almost as if Dante, the man, were injured by too much noise, and lived with a sort of hands-pressed-to-the-ears  attitude of an autistic child who cannot bear too much exterior intrusion into his private cognitive process.  The synaesthesia too indicates a person whose neurology worked differently from run-of-the-mill brains who are considered normal.  There is something else too: Dante's ears are affected by what he hears, his eyes take in the scene in the mute light, but his body somehow seems undisturbed as it stands and contemplates this tormenting hurricane.  This force whips about the bodies of the shades, and yet does not knock either him nor Virgil down.  Again, the laws of the physical universe are suspended here, and replaced by the laws of imagination, the laws of dream, and language.  Note the placement of the natural metaphor of the storm at sea, and how it compares to the placement of other natural metaphors in the earlier cantos.  In the next few lines another more original and famous natural metaphor continues the whirlwind trope, this one of starlings whipped about in a never-resting gale (37 - 45).  The sound in Italian is so perfect, so musical, but it is a mad music such as tormented birds might make when caught in ceaseless tumult: di qua, di là, di giù, di sù li mena — ah! ah! ooh! ooh!.  This not just a description, this is a reification of the sound of this place where those guilty of sins of the flesh — i peccator carnali — are damned, their lust subjugating their reason.

Reason?  We talk about it as if we knew what it is, or as if we could know what it is.  In my work with Neurolinguistic Programming (NLP) I became aware of the difference between the wholly reflexive part of the brain and nervous system, that which happens automatically as an interaction of the organism and the environment, and that which can choose to act "volitionally".  We call the reflexive automaticity "conditioning", of which there are two kinds:  Natural conditioning and learned conditioning.   An example of natural conditioning is what we see when the doctor donks our knee with a little rubber hammer and our leg kicks.  All the senses work on this principle, you open your eyes, you automatically see, sound waves flow through the environment, you automatically hear, something hot touches you, you automatically feel the heat.  In addition to this natural conditioning, we have conditioning that has been learned, whole sequences of gestures and chemical changes in the brain and body that are triggered by an event that has been imprinted by some type of experience in our past.  Traumas work like this.  You are bitten by a dog as a two year old, and thereafter all dogs, all pictures of dogs, all smells of dogs, trigger a fear response.  Probably many allergies work the same way, the allergen, which is harmless to others with your same physiology, causes your immune system to overreact and attack you.  Reading or learning your native tongue works the same: it becomes automatic, the sound of someone speaking, or the shape of letters flashed on your eyes automatically become this weird thing called "meaning".  You get in your car, and with thousands of triggers from learned responses, without consciously thinking about it, you drive.  In fact, all behaviors of any real complexity rely on these two systems of conditioning, interacting with one another and with the environment with an intelligence as old as the evolution of life — and — to try to think about these behaviors only interferes with them.  Watching your feet when you walk, for example, is likely to throw off your equilibrium and make you trip.  

Experiments have shown that while the conscious mind (and we will get to what this is in a minute) can only keep track of 7 things (perhaps the origin of the magic we attribute to the number 7) plus or minus 2.  The unconscious mind however — this interactive system of learned and natural conditioning — is tracking millions of bits of information, and automatically responding to keep you alive without your conscious mind having to be bothered about it at all.  So, we can see that the organism has a vested interest — a survival need — to transfer as much behavior into the system of conditioning as it can, or the conscious mind will be overloaded, become dysfunctional, and interfere with the operation of this evolutionary intelligence.  What then is the conscious mind?  Now inspite of research on the brain to discover what has become known as "the hard problem", we don't need to know how the brain does this to understand how consciousness actually functions.  What does it do?  Or to put it in terms that Dante would understand.  How does reason function?  How does it productively guide this evolutionary and learned system of conditioned responses?  We've already seen that consciousness is an interrupt, it breaks the chain of conditioning — the automaticity — and it serves as a pause button that stops the reflexive response.  And what happens in that pause — that moment of paralysis?  Alternative scenarios arise — what ifs — what if I do this instead of that? — what if I don't do what I did before that had such a disastrous result? — what if I do something different, how will the outcome be different?  In short, in these alternative scenarios we harrow Hell.  We think about restoring what was damaged.  We imagine a future with a more felicitous outcome.  This ability to split the mind off from automaticity, and allow it time to create multiple virtual possibilities seems to be what Dante is referring to by reason.  The crucial question is: Can we learn to instantly obey the precepts of the reasonable best case scenario? — i.e. blessedness, or right behavior, or moral behavior, or whatever else you might want to call it.  Can we learn to condition our responses to pause when the impulse of the conditioned system is going to lead to disaster for ourselves or others?  And if so, how do we learn that?  I think Dante's response would be: through the operations of language (which are automatic), and the power of language to create rhythms, sounds, images, "meanings", which vividly present alternative scenarios.  We become aware of other possible worlds by virtually creating them through language — our native tongue, music, mathematics, orthographic symbols, etc.  And what is the most powerful of these linguistic creators?  Poetry in our native tongue.  The whole of the Commedia is a kind of practical training in using the power of language to enter and respond in ways that allow us to "chose" the best case scenario when the evolutionary system of conditioning is failing, and leading us to interminably suffer, or go extinct.  This is what the shades in Hell have not learned, what the souls in Purgatory are learning, and what the spirits in Heaven have learned.   

All this is one way — and there must be others, for alternatives to work — to think about reason and impulse, and this would explain line 39: those who have let appetite subjugate reason are destined always to be slaves to impulse, even when that slavery causes them and others pain.  They are always at the effect of their environment, which is what Dante shows here, as the shades are whipped about by contrary winds.  

As we go through the three worlds presented in the Commedia, we shall see how reason deals with impulse, how it interferes and creates that pause, how it discovers the best or right or moral course of action, and how it then uses the evolutionary intelligence of the conditioned or learned response to automatically obey or respond to that best (most blessed) possible outcome.  Dante would have called that learning: obedience to God.  Blake simply said: The Imaginative Man is the true man — and that since all deities reside in the human breast, God is the impulse to live as God in God's world, and not as a perishable worm four score and ten years long.          

46  E come i gru van cantando lor lai,
47  faccendo in aere di sé lunga riga,
48  così vid' io venir, traendo guai,

49  ombre portate da la detta briga;
50  per ch'i' dissi: “Maestro, chi son quelle
51  genti che l'aura nera sì gastiga?”
46  And as the cranes go chanting forth their lays,
47  Making in air a long line of themselves,
48  So saw I coming, uttering lamentations,
49  Shadows borne onward by the aforesaid stress.
50  Whereupon said I: "Master, who are those
51  People, whom the black air so castigates?"
Like a master composer of music, Dante makes two subtle changes in the bird-trope, and the whole phrase takes on a different meaning and prepares us for what is happening next.  Why birds?  They're thought to be licentious.  Remember the line in Measure for Measure about the lecherous sparrows.  In this case, the starlings become cranes and instead of flocks driven chaotically about, the cranes form a single line, crying out as they fly.  Where have seen this crowd becoming a line before?  At the beginning of Canto IV where the crowds of the unbaptized become the single line of the four poets, and also at the beginning of this Canto where the dead line up for the satanic parody of their confession before Minos.  These birds are also a parody of angels, and perhaps since these are those who let their lust control them, the fact that they are in flight, seems to mirror that feeling of exhilaration that consumes people in the first throes of sexual passion.  But of course, these are not birds or angels, they are the shades of people, and the shades in this line are the distinguished — or should we say notorious — lustful.  So the parody of the distinguished shades in limbo continues here, but the fame of these shades is fomented by their negative characteristics.  The word guai rings its note again, like a leitmotif which keeps returning in different orchestral contexts and which alerts us to the fact that though things have changed, they echo what has gone before and perhaps foreshadow what is to come.  We should also be attentive to the air itself, it has gone from brown (twice mentioned) to black.  The geography in Hell is getting more intense, and worse.
52  “La prima di color di cui novelle
53  tu vuo' saper,” mi disse quelli allotta,
54  “fu imperadrice di molte favelle.

55  A vizio di lussuria fu sì rotta,
56  che libito fé licito in sua legge,
57  per tòrre il biasmo in che era condotta.

58  Ell' è Semiramìs, di cui si legge
59  che succedette a Nino e fu sua sposa:
60  tenne la terra che 'l Soldan corregge.

61  L'altra è colei che s'ancise amorosa,
62  e ruppe fede al cener di Sicheo;
63  poi è Cleopatràs lussurïosa.

64  Elena vedi, per cui tanto reo
65  tempo si volse, e vedi 'l grande Achille,
66  che con amore al fine combatteo.

67  Vedi Parìs, Tristano”; e più di mille
68  ombre mostrommi e nominommi a dito,
69  ch'amor di nostra vita dipartille.

70  Poscia ch'io ebbi 'l mio dottore udito
71  nomar le donne antiche e ' cavalieri,
72  pietà mi giunse, e fui quasi smarrito.

52  "The first of those, of whom intelligence
53  Thou fain wouldst have," then said he unto me,
54  "The empress was of many languages.

55  To sensual vices she was so abandoned,
56  That lustful she made licit in her law,
57  To remove the blame to which she had been led.

58  She is Semiramis, of whom we read
59  That she succeeded Ninus, and was his spouse;
60  She held the land which now the Sultan rules.

61  The next is she who killed herself for love,
62  And broke faith with the ashes of Sichaeus;
63  Then Cleopatra the voluptuous."

64  Helen I saw, for whom so many ruthless
65  Seasons revolved; and saw the great Achilles,
66  Who at the last hour combated with Love.

67  Paris I saw, Tristan; and more than a thousand
68  Shades did he name and point out with his finger,
69  Whom Love had separated from our life.

70  After that I had listened to my Teacher,
71  Naming the dames of eld and cavaliers,
72  Pity prevailed, and I was nigh bewildered.

This this lineage of the notorious lustful, there are nine figures.  They are grouped in threes.  The first three are 

Semiramis
Dido
Cleopatra

Not getting into Dante's sources, it's clear from the text that Dante attributed Simiramis, the first of these, to some association with Babylon, and with the tower of Babble, as Virgil says in line 54 that she was Empress of many languages (fu imperadrice di molte favelle).  Thus, she is associated with linguistic confusion, that is to say, our ability to understand one another.  She was a female sovereign who succeeded her husband, and while regent for her son — her husband's rightful heir — she retained power by passing a law which allowed her to marry her own son.  Thus, she was guilty of both usurpation and incest.  Her domain was where the current sultan rules.  Thus she is associated with infidels, the unfaithful, and with false religion.  Thus a blasphemer.  What the text does not elude to, but which have been common knowledge for Dante's contemporary readers who were familiar with his sources is that she was murdered by her son/spouse, in a sort of matriarchal version of the Oedipal myth.  Recall how in Canto IV Electra was the first name, who with her brother Orestes (echo of the incest theme only with siblings?), killed their mother Clytemnestra, in revenge for having killed their father, Agamemnon.  This legend Jung used to hypothesize an Electra complex, the girls desire to kill her mother in order to marry her father, this complex serving as a foil to the Oedipus Complex.  This echo of Electra in the same structural position as that of Electra is another example of Dante's extreme organizational fastidiousness, resonance after resonance is created, as if the entire Commedia were the interior of some kind of jewel whose facets reflect and refract the light of one another.  This list of the lustful also revives the refrain of "Vidi" (I saw), and the hear/see motif as Virgil explains first, then Dante sees.  I will say here, since I have so often maligned Longfellow's English translation, that he does a masterful job of translating line 56: che libito fé licito in sua legge as that lustful she made licit in her law, retaining all the alliterations which make the line so incestuously voluptuous with its three L's.  Giuseppe Mazzotta tells that this reference refers to the secular city which, in contrast to Saint Augustine's City of God, is founded on the lust — the lust for power, bodily lust, and violence — because in this secular city law and lust operate in tandem to corrupt the inhabitants.

The next in this first triplet is Dido.  Virgil does not mention her name, but since it was he who wrote her story in his Aeneid, he doesn't need to, and perhaps he is ashamed to, since it was his hero, Aeneas, who abandoned her, and for whose loss, she murdered herself.  The other reason that her name is not mentioned refers to a common device in Dante, called, periphrasis, that is, the omission of the name as in a riddle, which when solved by the readers tends to stand out in their minds with more vividness because it is they who have supplied the name, by answering the riddle.  We know why Dido merited this importance (as we earlier saw in Canto IV with Aristotle) because she is associated with Virgil, and because she is mentioned again in line 85, below, and is the only named entity there.  This affair, Virgil also condemns because Dido broke faith with the ashes of her deceased husband, Sichaeus, whose, power, like Semiramis, she assumed.  Now we see a motif developing.  Namely, that the figures here not only succumbed to lust, but that their weakness resulted in their deaths by murder or suicide.  Their affections were not just hurtful, they were fatal.

The last in this threesome is Cleopatra, whom as we know, placed the asp to her breast and committed suicide for the loss of Mark Antony.  She was a queen who inherited her power from her father, and along with her brother, whom she likely married, as it was an Egyptian custom, ruled as co-regents.  The brother and sister fell out, she killed him in battle, and she assumed sole sovereignty.  So, like Dido, and Semiramis, she was associated with usurpation, and like Semiramis, with incest. 

The next threesome is 

Helen
Achilles
Paris

All are associated with the Trojan War, that is to say, with Virgil, through his protagonist Aeneas.

Helen is an adulteress who caused the destruction of an Empire, and there is an account offered by Pausanias that Helen fled to Rhodes after the fall of Ilion, and was surprised while bathing by an enemy, and hung.  The explanatory line in the text is that she is one for whom so many ruthless seasons revolved.  So again we have the motif of a vortical movement.  Brilliant.

Next is Achilles, who fell in love with Polyxena, Paris' sister, and a Trojan princess.  If they married they could put an end to the war. When going to effect the marriage in a secret meeting, Paris, angered because the marriage would mean that he would have to surrender Helen, hid in the bushes and shot an arrow into Achilles' heel, killing him.  He is the first man in this list, but he is lured by a woman, and we will have more to say about this later.

Last in this group is Paris.  Bewitched by Helen's beauty, his abduction of her began the Trojan war, so that his lust was the cause of an Empire's death and of the deaths of many, his own father Priam and brother Hector included.  Paris is shown by Homer, whom Virgil knew, but whom Dante only knew through Virgil, as a coward and a lustpot.  He is killed in the war by Philoctetes.

The last grouping is 

Tristan 
Paolo
Francesca             

The last group of three are the most contemporary to Dante, and thus the latest in the lineage. Dante probably knew the work in a 12th Century romance, which was also the book that Paulo and Francesca were reading when they fell in love (the references to Launcelot in line 85 affirms this.  The point is that Tristan dies because of his illicit love, and so does his lover.  A summary of their end appears on the web site Infernopedia:

Tristan (Latin & Brythonic: Drustanus; Welsh: Trystan), also known as Tristram, was a Cornish knight in the service of his uncle, King Mark. Mark was betrothed to the princess of Ireland, the beautiful Iseult. As his most trusted knight, Tristan was sent to Ireland by Mark to bring Iseult to Cornwall to marry the king. To aid Iseult in her marriage, in her possession was a powerful love potion. Unfortunately, during a feast Tristan and Iseult accidentally consume the love potion and fall helplessly in love. The two become lovers, even after they arrive in Cornwall and Mark marries Iseult; they use trickery to fool Mark into believing nothing is going on. There are many variations of the legend's ending, but the more well-known ending, Mark finds out about the affair and tries to punish the couple, though Tristan escapes death by hanging and rescues Iseult from exile. He returns Iseult to Mark, then reconciles with the king by agreeing to leave Cornwall. Years later, Tristan is wounded by a poisoned spear and sends for Iseult to heal him. He requests that the sailor sent for her raise white sails if Iseult will come help him, and black sails if she refuses. Unable to rise, Tristan asks his wife what color the sails are, but the jealous woman lies to him, saying the sails are black. Tristan dies of grief, and when Iseult arrives and sees his corpse, she too drops dead of grief.

The story of the last two figures in this grouping is the subject of the second half of this Canto and comments will be reserved until those parts are examined.

But before we proceed.  Let's look at three more things: 

Why 9 nine lustfuls?  
Why are 6 of the 9 women?
What role does the medieval understanding of optics play in the role of eliciting lust?

The reader could go quite mad trying to track down all the significance of numbers in the Commedia.  Dante uses number both for the sake of establishing a degree of proportionality in relating one part of his narrative to another, and also for the purpose of evoking a deeper symbology to the content of his work.  Narrative is a line, like a melody in music.  How do you add depth to that line?  Through metaphor.  By referencing past events and foreshadowing future ones with sounds and images, the readers thoughts and emotions are constantly reminded, if only subconsciously, that although sequence is important, depth is important too, and the line of narrative becomes many lines, weaving themselves into an ever-thickening moiré of significance.  We saw how the number 40 pulsed below the poetry in the description of limbo in Canto IV, and now these 9 notorious exemplars of lust serve that same function here in Canto V.  Dante goes out of his way in the Vita Nuova to tell us that he first met Beatrice near the end of his 9th year and near the beginning of her 9th year.  He didn't say I was almost 10 and she was 8, he makes 9 the barycenter where their two orbits are synchronized, and in that same work, he goes out of his way several times to let us know that his reason never succumbed to the vileness of carnality.  No doubt so many references to Beatrice's purity has the effect of saying "why such an emphasis," if the spectre of lust was not ever present, and needed to be beaten down.  This is sublimation with a capital S, the sex impulse continually growing and having to be continually transformed into something else or it will overwhelm him.  What is this something else?  And how does the lover keep from being consumed by repression, which might be as bad or worse than being consumed by lust.  It is the release, the expression, of poetry.  If the word is made flesh, the flesh can be made word, and no one has been more successful at doing that than Dante.  As carnal as Beatrice is, from the very first she is spiritualized into poetry, and after her death, that spiritualization becomes more thorough and more powerful in its ability to transform Dante's own flesh into spirit.  Number is abstract, but it is fundamentally abstract, a type of language as basic as bone but as invulnerable to decay as prayer.

The last two questions, why so many women on the list? and what does this have to do with optics? are really focused around the power of the glance, the gaze.  The eyes for the troubadours, for Dante, and all the way through Shakespeare and beyond do not only receive light rays, but they emit them.  The eyes of women are phallic darts, which penetrate men with the radiance of love.  We will encounter many examples of this feminine power throughout Commedia, as we already have in Canto II, when Beatrice's eyes are described as the single guiding star which commands Virgil to intercede.  This poem from the Vita Nuova makes the point.  Here the power of looking, seeing, and being seen is most vividly described.

Love says of her: "How can a mortal body
achieve such beauty and such purity?"
He looks again and swears it must be true:
God does have something new in mind for earth.
Her color is the pallor of the pearl,
a paleness perfect for a gracious lady;
she is the best that nature can achieve
and by her mold all beaty tests itself;
her eyes, wherever she may choose to look,
send forth their spirits radiant with love
to strike the yes of anyone they meet,
and penetrate until they find the heart.
There where no one dares hold his gaze to long.

Dice di lei Amor: «Cosa mortale
come esser pò sì adorna e sì pura?»
Poi la reguarda, e fra se stesso giura
che Dio ne 'ntenda di far cosa nova.
Color di perle ha quasi in forma, quale
convene a donna aver, non for misura;
ella è quanto de ben pò far natura;
per esemplo di lei bieltà si prova.
De li occhi suoi, come ch'ella li mova,
escono spirti d'amore inflammati,
che fèron li occhi a qual che allor la guati,
e passan sì che 'l cor ciascun retrova:
voi le vedete Amor pinto nel viso,
là 've non pote alcun mirarla fiso.

It's pretty clear that Love — a male persona in Dante — has given the eyes of women the aggressive power of penetration, her gaze penetrates to the heart, but also no doubt to the genitals.  Its dart wounds helpless men, skewers their bodies with radiance, causes them to succumb to the madness of love.  It's a beautiful trope, but unfortunately it has had a very dark side in history, and would lead to the victimization of woman as witches in later centuries, with results that would have horrified Dante, and have made a mockery of his veneration.

In lines 70 - 72, Dante returns to the value of naming, and indicates that the feeling of pity has left him smarrito, translated here as bewildered.  And where have we heard this word before?  In the very first tercet of the entire Commedia.  We are now back at the beginning, lost and confused, and more than a little numb.  And what has driven us back to our starting point?  Pity.  Pity for all those, like Dante himself, who have been ravaged by love.  The tale of Paolo and Francesca — and Dante, the aspirant’s reaction to it — will later show us how Virgil's reason deals with pity in these circumstances — however in this Canto he remains silent.  The question which arises for us is: If love's dart wounds, how then does reason cauterize that wound? 

73  I' cominciai: “Poeta, volontieri
74  parlerei a que' due che 'nsieme vanno,
75  e paion sì al vento esser leggieri.”

76  Ed elli a me: “Vedrai quando saranno
77  più presso a noi; e tu allor li priega
78  per quello amor che i mena, ed ei verranno.”

79  Sì tosto come il vento a noi li piega,
80  mossi la voce: “O anime affannate,
81  venite a noi parlar, s'altri nol niega!”
 
82  Quali colombe dal disio chiamate
83  con l'ali alzate e ferme al dolce nido
84  vegnon per l'aere, dal voler portate;

85  cotali uscir de la schiera ov' è Dido,
86  a noi venendo per l'aere maligno,
87  sì forte fu l'affettüoso grido.

73  And I began: "O Poet, willingly
74  Speak would I to those two, who go together,
75  And seem upon the wind to be so light."

76  And, he to me: "Thou'lt mark, when they shall be
77  Nearer to us; and then do thou implore them
78  By love which leadeth them, and they will come."

79  Soon as the wind in our direction sways them,
80  My voice uplift I: "O ye weary souls!
81  Come speak to us, if no one interdicts it."

82  As turtle-doves, called onward by desire,
83  With open and steady wings to the sweet nest
84  Fly through the air by their volition borne,

85  So came they from the band where Dido is,
86  Approaching us athwart the air malign,
87  So strong was the affectionate appeal.

Dante sees two together, and would willingly (voluntiere) speak to them — he makes a point of that voluntiere.  His is an act of will, which is to say, unlike the two he sees who are so light that they are buffeted about together, against their will, he is choosing, reasonably choosing, to hear their story, as the reader is, through an act of volition, of will, choosing to hear Dante's story.  Caught in the throes of an impulse, in this case of sex, which the text refers to again and again as amore, as love, the ones to whom Dante would speak are helpless in their attraction for one another, in spite of the ceaseless punishment it brings them.  And here is a curious thing.  Are we to believe that these helpless creatures, yet have enough power of will to speak to Dante, a living soul, and what's more, do they want to speak to him, do they will to speak to him? and is there nothing to prevent them from doing so?  At this point, we can't answer these questions, but we read further down in line 96 that this incessant wind of their sexual desire has calmed, which is to say that when they begin to confess to an understanding ear, the ear of one who pities, things begin to calm down.  But is this calm induced by pity for their state the kind of calm which will cure them?  The answer to that question cannot be given, until we, the readers, have also pitied, that is to say, until we have read of the plight of these lovers.  

On a language note, listen to how the word leggieri, with its L sound, recalls the triple alliteration of libito, licito, legge in line 56, and how closely this world meaning light, i.e., not heavy, resembles the word for read — leggere — this association implies that the reader, once he or she has chosen voluntarily to read, is as one caught in the wind of the writer's obsessions, and buffeted about by forces which the text conjures forth.  Is this a legitimate interpretation?  I think so, because as Francesca describes how reading led her to surrender her will, and plummet into passion, it is reading — a certain kind of reading —  that has enticed her.  Virgil's words are telling here, for in lines 78 - 79 he says, do thou implore them/ By the love which leadeth them, and they will come ( tu allor li priega/ per quello amor che i mena, ed ei verranno).  In short, the word love to these two is the trigger to what seems like an hypnotic induction.  That word conjures their willless obedience.  Which leaves us to ponder another question: Is the confession that is to follow only a recapitulation of the confession they had previously made to Minos?  And does Dante now stand in for Minos as father confessor?  Dante speaks, and they come.  Is this an act of volition or just another instance of their obsession?  

Now with the metaphor comparing the two to turtle doves (columbe), we come to the third bird trope of this Canto, the progression being flocks of starlings, line of cranes, and now pair of doves.  And this evolution of tropes, while perhaps appearing as a move towards transcendence, still remains the same, and still implies that from the general to the infamous to the particular, the same passion rules, and the same result ensues.  Also, in case the reader missed the reference to Dido in the previous lines, here she is explicitly named.

Note 1: Line 80 which uses the adjective affannate to describe these souls is an echo of line 22 in Canto 1 of affannata, and would be better translated as breathless, than weary.  So Dante is comparing the breathlessness of these lovers to the breathlessness of a man who has just managed to save himself from drowning.  The kind of love we see in this Canto is a sea of drowning emotions and impulsive actions, which deprive its victims of the very breath of life.  Note too how by using a reiteration of this one adjective (up to now only occurring in these two places), Dante is able to make a metaphor that throws a long arc from one section of the work to another, causing the work to grow deeper and deeper by multiplying resonances.  We saw this just before in the word smarrito, and we will see it again and again throughout the entire Commedia.   

Note 2: The translation of appeal here for grido in line 87 obscures the desperation in this affectionate (l'affettüoso) utterance.  It is not an appeal, it is a cry, and the fact that it is, establishes the emotional tone of the passage, and emphasizes its erotic turbulence.  

88  “O animal grazïoso e benigno
89  che visitando vai per l'aere perso
90  noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,

91  se fosse amico il re de l'universo,
92  noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace,
93  poi c'hai pietà del nostro mal perverso.

94  Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace,
95  noi udiremo e parleremo a voi,
96  mentre che 'l vento, come fa, ci tace.

88  "O living creature gracious and benignant,
89  Who visiting goest through the purple air
90  Us, who have stained the world incarnadine,

91  If were the King of the Universe our friend,
92  We would pray unto him to give thee peace,
93  Since thou hast pity on our woe perverse.

94  Of what it pleases thee to hear and speak,
95  That will we hear, and we will speak to you,
96  While silent is the wind, as it is now.

These lines remind me of what Blake said about Rousseau: These are not confessions, they're boasts.  And Francesca’s words here, although they affect the protagonist Dante, and seem confessional, even submissive, in fact ... well what they are in fact is the lesson of the entire rest of this Canto.  Suffice it to say for now that Frencesca's speech is self-pitying and is designed to elicit pity.  I think it's significant that she addresses Dante “O animal grazïoso e benigno," not using the word persone, which would mean person, but animal, which has connotations of something alive — the quick — something animal-like or bestial, and also a shade, a ghost (anima).  She calls Dante gracious and benignant, someone who has received grace and blessings, and as such, perhaps someone who might also be able to bestow those boons.  She is definitely looking for a father confessor, but she has a very sly way of doing it — being as she is obsequious instead or remorseful.  It is almost as if she is seeking, by manipulating Dante to pity her, not absolution for her actions, but a co-conspirator.  And although she admits that her behavior was a perverse disease, stained the world with blood, and alienated her from the King of the Universe, all of this can be forgiven because — as Dante or anyone who has felt the way she feels can attest — love is a kind of madness.  The nature of love is that it drives us out of our minds, and when we are not in our right minds, we are not really culpable.  A close reading of her opinion of God will show that she relegates Him to the status of "friend", and this is a telltale sign of how she holds the judgements of the King of the Universe, since a "friend" is a far cry from a lover.  There is no question that between these two — her friend, God, and her lover Paolo —  that it is her lover whom she seeks to please, not God. 

In line 94, she says if it would give Dante pleasure, she will hear and speak, but what the following lines reveal is that she does not really want to hear, she wants to be heard, and she finds the silence of Dante's and Virgil's presence an apt opportunity to work her whiles.

97  Siede la terra dove nata fui
98  su la marina dove 'l Po discende
99  per aver pace co' seguaci sui.

100  Amor, ch'al cor gentil ratto s'apprende,
101  prese costui de la bella persona
102  che mi fu tolta; e 'l modo ancor m'offende.

103  Amor, ch'a nullo amato amar perdona,
104  mi prese del costui piacer sì forte,
105  che, come vedi, ancor non m'abbandona.

106  Amor condusse noi ad una morte.
107  Caina attende chi a vita ci spense.”
108  Queste parole da lor ci fuor porte.

97  Sitteth the city, wherein I was born,
98  Upon the sea-shore where the Po descends
99  To rest in peace with all his retinue.

100  Love, that on gentle heart doth swiftly seize,
101  Seized this man for the person beautiful
102  That was ta'en from me, and still the mode offends me.

103  Love, that exempts no one beloved from loving,
104  Seized me with pleasure of this man so strongly,
105  That, as thou seest, it doth not yet desert me;

106  Love has conducted us unto one death;
107  Caina waiteth him who quenched our life!"
108  These words were borne along from them to us.

One of the many fascinating things that Dante has mastered in his style, is how to give even what might be in lesser hands a mere bit of information, a sense of life and movement that reinforces the life and movement of the whole poem.  In lines 97 - 98, when Francesca tells of where she was born, she does so by describing the Po as a place where the turbulence of its tributaries find peace.  As stated before, Dante weaves the threads of geography, history, myth, philosophy, lessons on style, moral precepts, scripture, and natural phenomenon into a single pattern, weaving and reweaving his metaphors and motifs until they have depth and movement, and until reading and re-reading his poem confers on his audience a similar feeling of depth and movement.  What Francesca is seeking here is peace, as she had when she was born and baptized, as she had when she was presumably innocent of sin.  And what follows here with a litany of phrases each beginning with the word love, amor, are her excuses as to how she has been deprived of that place of peace which fostered her engendering.  The metaphor of the Po in conjunction with the word nato (born) also points to the legitimate expression of sexual appetite: It leads to birth, and is not just a pleasurable indulgence.  All this text from lines 97 - 108 shows what the writer Dante knows, and what the aspirant Dante does not know.  Namely: What love is, and how the sexual urge either sanctifies or perverts its expression.

The Buddhists have a doctrine referred to as near poisons.  Recklessness, for example, is the near poison of courage, vanity the near poison of self-respect, and so forth.  The love that Francesca says was and is her ruin, is the very near poison of what Dante feels for Beatrice, which in some part explains Dante's reaction to her story.  She is telling him in effect: everybody who feels this kind of love is damned, and particularly those with gentle rapidly palpitating hearts ( ch'al cor ratto).  Note the association with birds, which also have rapidly beating hearts, and which also are beautiful and licentious.  Her blaming also continues here.  Love has ensnared her with this beautiful person, who bewitched her in life, and who continues to bewitch her after death.  Anyone who has read Dante's Vita Nuova can see how near a poison this is to the poet's bewitchment by Beatrice.  She quotes him.  Ever the seductress and seduced, again Francesca in line 104 uses the word piacer, (to give pleasure), the same word she used to coax Dante into listening to her story in line 94: Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace. Francesca makes it clear that her attraction — an attraction to beauty, to appearance, and not to some inner virtue of her beloved — has yet to abandon her.  Love, her kind of love, clandestine, adulterous, sterile physical love, continues to torment her.  And she continues to blaspheme Love as an entity separate from herself by whom she is enslaved.  Just as Dante did in the Vita Nuova.  Francesca is obedient to impulse, and all of her reasoning is only a kind circuitous attempt to escape her responsibility to control that impulse and put it to some good use.  

There are four repetitions of the word amor in her speech, but one is hidden, as was her love.  Where is it hidden?  In a visual pun in line 106: ad unA MORte.  And the three rhymed words?  forte (strong), morte (death), porte (carry).  Her kind of love was a potency which carried her and her lover to a bloody death at the hands of her husband.  But all this is mere prelude, told I think to color Dante's bias against her husband and against the Divine judgement which has condemned her.  In line 107 she tells Dante that he will find her murderer in Caina, which is the first part of the 9th circle of Hell. 

One note further before continuing.  In line 108, the text reads: Queste parole da lor ci fuor porte (these words were borne along from them to us).  For Dante the reader, or in this case the listener, the words are almost physical, and seem to be like projectiles, like the darts of the wounding gaze we saw before, and they assault or penetrate their recipients, almost against their will.  It is a kind of listening or reading that Francesca's words will imply, and this says much about how the reader of the Commedia should not approach the text.  In Hell the moral exemplars are cautionary warnings.               

109  Quand' io intesi quell' anime offense,
110  china' il viso, e tanto il tenni basso,
111  fin che 'l poeta mi disse: “Che pense?”

112  Quando rispuosi, cominciai: “Oh lasso,
113  quanti dolci pensier, quanto disio
114  menò costoro al doloroso passo!”

115  Poi mi rivolsi a loro e parla' io,
116  e cominciai: “Francesca, i tuoi martìri
117  a lagrimar mi fanno tristo e pio.

118  Ma dimmi: al tempo d'i dolci sospiri,
119  a che e come concedette amore
120  che conosceste i dubbiosi disiri?”

121  E quella a me: “Nessun maggior dolore
122  che ricordarsi del tempo felice
123  ne la miseria; e ciò sa 'l tuo dottore.

124  Ma s'a conoscer la prima radice
125  del nostro amor tu hai cotanto affetto,
126  dirò come colui che piange e dice


109  As soon as I had heard those souls tormented,
110  I bowed my face, and so long held it down
111  Until the Poet said to me: "What thinkest?"

112  When I made answer, I began: "Alas!
113  How many pleasant thoughts, how much desire,
114  Conducted these unto the dolorous pass!"

115  Then unto them I turned me, and I spake,
116  And I began: "Thine agonies, Francesca,
117  Sad and compassionate to weeping make me.

118  But tell me, at the time of those sweet sighs,
119  By what and in what manner Love conceded,
120  That you should know your dubious desires?"

121  And she to me: "There is no greater sorrow
122  Than to be mindful of the happy time
123  In misery, and that thy Teacher knows.

124  But, if to recognise the earliest root
125  Of love in us thou hast so great desire,
126  I will do even as he who weeps and speaks.


In these lines from 109 - 126, there is a curious double switch.  Virgil questions Dante in line 111, after seeing his charge drop his head at Francesca's words, instead of Dante questioning Virgil.  His student is falling into his old errors, his old torpor of brooding and lack of discernment.  Virgil asks "Che pense?"  What are you thinking?  And Dante speaks, but is he answering Virgil, or Francesca?  "How many pleasant thoughts, how much desire / conducted these (Paolo and Francesca) unto the dolorous pass (quanti dolci pensier, quanto disio / menò costoro al doloroso passo!”).  Now the second switch: instead of turning to Virgil to answer his doubts, he turns to Francesca, and questions her.  Francesca has seduced him to turn from his teacher, and to listen to her story.  Dante, the aspirant has abandoned reason for the passion of emotion, and in doing so, he has opened once again the door that leads to coma.  He speaks of dolci sospiri (sweet sighs), and just as Dante has told us in the Vita Nuova how he first came to be enamored of Beatrice, he asks Francesca to tell him how it was that she came to be enthralled by these dubious desires (i dubbiosi disiri).  Then in a direct parody of the phrase Ed' elli a me (and he to me), which we have read so many times, we read: E quella a me (and she to me).  What we read should shock us.  Again, directing Dante's attention to her own emotions, Francesca says "There is no greater sorrow / than to be mindful of the happy time / in misery " (Nessun maggior dolore / che recordarsi del tempo feliice / ne la miseria).  And then, in what should be an outrageous affront to Dante, but it isn't, she tries to rope in Virgil as well, saying, as your teacher knows, supposing that since Virgil is a shade in Hell, like herself, he must also share her feelings.  How can Virgil answer this?  With silence.  The lesson that Dante has to learn will be harsher and more penetrating than any Virgil might give.  And it will be a lesson brought home with the pain of pity, not pity as Beatrice told us was her blessed concern in Canto II, but pity tainted with self-pity, pity that has allowed itself to be tainted by that which is pitiful.  If we are attentive here, we will also read in Francesca's sorrow at retelling her story, a parody of the lines in Canto I when Dante says that to retell his story is to relive his fear, but he will do so in order to tell of the good he has seen.  Dante, even at the beginning, is thinking how he may help others, but Francesca is still trying elicit pity from others by say that she will speak even as one who weeps while speaking (dirò come colui che piange e dice).

127  Noi leggiavamo un giorno per diletto
128  di Lancialotto come amor lo strinse;
129  soli eravamo e sanza alcun sospetto.

130  Per più fïate li occhi ci sospinse
131  quella lettura, e scolorocci il viso;
132  ma solo un punto fu quel che ci vinse.

133 Quando leggemmo il disïato riso
134  esser basciato da cotanto amante,
135  questi, che mai da me non fia diviso,

136  la bocca mi basciò tutto tremante.
137  Galeotto fu 'l libro e chi lo scrisse:
138  quel giorno più non vi leggemmo avante.”

127  One day we reading were for our delight
128  Of Launcelot, how Love did him enthral.
129  Alone we were and without any fear.

130  Full many a time our eyes together drew
131  That reading, and drove the colour from our faces;
132  But one point only was it that o'ercame us.

133  When as we read of the much-longed-for smile
134  Being by such a noble lover kissed,
135  This one, who ne'er from me shall be divided,

136  Kissed me upon the mouth all palpitating.
137  Galeotto was the book and he who wrote it.
138  That day no farther did we read therein."

In the common phrase "we read for edification and delight", we notice that edification comes first, and the delight arises from that edification.  This is the way I think that Dante intends us to read the Commedia, and this kind of reading demands a commitment to interpret, to engage in exegesis, to do what we are doing here as we try to discover the deepest significance of this text for ourselves and others.  But in Francesca's account, she skips edification and says that she and Paolo are reading for their delight (per diletto).  At this point, what they are doing is looking at pornography, monkey see, monkey do, and they imitate the actions of the text.  Dante goes out of his way here to tell us that the text is about and was written by (the author and protagonist the same, as they are in the Commedia) one Galeotto (known more familiarly to us as Galahaut, or Galahad).  It is an Arthurian romance which was probably circulating in Italy in the 13th century.  Lancelot is betraying his king, his fidelity oaths, and is engaging in adultery with his Lord's queen.  It's clear that Dante, the poet, is pointing out to us that this way of reading can lead to a moral debacle.  It weakens the reason and the will, and like those people who confuse soap opera performances for the acts of real people, and fall in love with them or try to injure them, or like those children who dress up as superheroes and jump off the house, Paolo and Francesco become the characters in a book.  But unlike the characters in a book, Francesco has a real husband who murders the both of them.  This is the tragedy of the fundamentalist Christian or Muslim who reads scripture as if God were a combination journalist and traffic cop and not the poet whose word creates worlds.  And just to be clear, this kind of fundamentalist reading is also indulged in by people who read books written by neuroscientists or doctors about how their brains determine their actions and feelings, or by nutritionists about how their diet influences them.  They too surrender their volition, their souls, to the influence of reading, and begin to proselytize and worship unthinkingly.  So, it's easy to see how pornographic this really is, how paralyzing it is to the intellect, and how poisonous to discerning action.  I think that when Dante insists on the literal truth of his journey, that what he means by "literal" is literary, not actual. 

Paolo and Francesca eyes meet as they read together, and they exchange those wounding darts, and then down their gazes drop, down to the mouth.  If the eyes are the windows of the soul, then the mouth is the voice of the soul.  But as one commentator has said, the mouth is veiled, that is, it can allegorize, flatter, or even lie — and in this case — it can kiss.  Trembling — this recalls the breathless palpitation in which all of this exposition takes place —  Paolo and Francesca, enthralled through the eyes by the words in the book, kiss.  And this brings up a curious, rather Borgesian thought: Is the book watching us, and imparting the same kind of influence as those darting eyes?  Well, in my case, reading Dante, this seems to be happening.  Paramahansa Yogananda says "God is always watching you, that's why you change."  When we read the Commedia, we get the same feeling that Rilke got upon viewing the Elgin marbles: You must change your life.   

139  Mentre che l'uno spirto questo disse,
140  l'altro piangëa; sì che di pietade
141  io venni men così com' io morisse.

142  E caddi come corpo morto cade.

139  And all the while one spirit uttered this,
140  The other one did weep so, that, for pity,
141  I swooned away as if I had been dying,

142  And fell, even as a dead body falls.

For pity, the aspirant Dante falls into a coma, and in a line rife with alliteration, the poet Dante collapses the curtain on this Canto.

Canto VI
1  Al tornar de la mente, che si chiuse
2  dinanzi a la pietà d'i due cognati,
3  che di trestizia tutto mi confuse,

4  novi tormenti e novi tormentati
5  mi veggio intorno, come ch'io mi mova
6  e ch'io mi volga, e come che io guati.

1  At the return of consciousness, that closed
2  before the pity of those two relations,
3  Which utterly with sadness had confused me,

4  New torments I behold, and new tormented
5  Around me, whichsoever way I move,
6  And whichsoever way I turn, and gaze.

These first 6 lines are a bridge from the previous Canto, and the verb tornare, suggest a return as from a distant place — Dante, the aspirant, was far gone in his pity-coma, once again returning to his state of physical and moral unconsciousness.   Pity has deprived him of all discernment, either physical or moral,  and he awakes from confusion.  Note the linkage of confuse and cognate — confuse etymologically from Latin meaning a mixing, a blending, to pour together, a disorder, a confusion, a shame, to that of cognate — together in birth, that is to say siblings.  This is Dante, the poet's, judgement against Dante, the aspirant.  Paola and Francesca are cognate — the word for in-laws, i.e., brother and sister in-law, and this compounds their sin from simple adultery, to adultery compounded in its egregiousness by incest.  Dante, the aspirant, confused by pity, cannot see this, hence his coma.  Like a drunk, suffering a black-out, he cannot remember how he got where he is.  Again we have here a turning, twisting motion, and as we will later learn, Dante in hell is always turning left, counterclockwise, following this auger of increasing torment as it drills down to the pit of hell.  Turning round and round he sees the torment and the tormented — torment: from a root meaning to twist, twisting.  By the aspirant's motion, we see that he has internalized the very shape of hell.  Guati, in line 6, translated as gaze, is to look with intensity.
