It is interesting to note that in this case, which differs from what we have read before in the hear/see tropes, Dante, the aspirant, does not hear first, but he sees, which suggests that pity has deprived him of hearing, and we recall that Virgil, the voice of reason, in the previous Canto, was silent, did not speak, and was not heard.  If this is so, then the chiuse, the closing of the senses, referred to in line 1, suggests that there was something voluntary about Dante's coma.  He closed his ears to reason, and to an adultery and incest that led to murder, and when he comes to, he sees torment, but is still deaf to reason.  Certainly a reversal, a turning in the wrong way — counterclockwise — contra natura, against nature, which in an ironical way is what Jung would have called consciousness itself, since all of nature winds on without any moral sense, and only man, conscious, as Dante would have said, of sin, can transgress against his own being.  With conscience, humans can hear what has not been sounded, see what has not been shown.  That is to say, conscience has something unnatural about it.  And what is that something?  Imagination.  I admit, this is twisted logic, but that's where we are now in our reading, going down and down, against nature, to deeper, more tormenting insights.        

7  Io sono al terzo cerchio, de la piova
8  etterna, maladetta, fredda e greve;
9  regola e qualità mai non l' è nova.

10  Grandine grossa, acqua tinta e neve
11  per l'aere tenebroso si riversa;
12  pute la terra che questo riceve.

7  In the third circle am I of the rain
8  Eternal, maledict, and cold, and heavy;
9  Its law and quality are never new.

10  Huge hail, and water sombre-hued, and snow,
11  Athwart the tenebrous air pour down amain;
12  Noisome the earth is, that receiveth this.

These next two tercets are what filmmakers would call a framing shot; they show where the characters are, and where we are as readers: the third circle of hell.  There is a meteorological logic about this.  In the previous Canto, there was wind, now comes the storm.  And what a storm it is! — eternal, maledict, cold, heavy rain, and since rain bears the suggestion of refreshment, Dante, the poet, is careful in line 9 to say that this rain has none of that, by telling us that its law and quality are never new: never.  This storm has every bad quality: huge hail, dark water and snow, and plus it stinks, and makes the earth stink as it pelts it.  One could write a very interesting essay on the senses of the shades in hell, those souls who seem to feel, see, hear, taste, and smell, and yet have no sense organs by which to perceive these things.  In brief, they resemble people in a nightmare, asleep, and yet awake in their inner world with dream senses, while their waking senses are turned off — an involuntary imagination, very like, and yet profoundly different too, from the imagination which a poet like Dante must turn on in order to do his work.  I believe that Dante, like Blake, was what Northrup Frye called "a literalist of the imagination".  That is, what happens in the imagination, is not only real, but maybe even more real than that which is merely part of the "vegetable" (to use another Blake term) body.  I don't think Dante would have disagreed with Blake's dictums: "The imaginative man is the true man" — or — "the imagination is nature itself." 

13  Cerbero, fiera crudele e diversa,
14  con tre gole caninamente latra
15  sovra la gente che quivi è sommersa.

16  Li occhi ha vermigli, la barba unta e atra,
17  e 'l ventre largo, e unghiate le mani;
18  graffia li spirti ed iscoia ed isquatra.

19  Urlar li fa la pioggia come cani;
20  de l'un de' lati fanno a l'altro schermo;
21  volgonsi spesso i miseri profani.

22  Quando ci scorse Cerbero, il gran vermo,
23  le bocche aperse e mostrocci le sanne;
24  non avea membro che tenesse fermo.

13  Cerberus, monster cruel and uncouth,
14  With his three gullets like a dog is barking
15  Over the people that are there submerged.
16  Red eyes he has, and unctuous beard and black,
17  And belly large, and armed with claws his hands;
18  He rends the spirits, flays, and quarters them.
19  Howl the rain maketh them like unto dogs;
20  One side they make a shelter for the other;
21  Oft turn themselves the wretched reprobates.
22  When Cerberus perceived us, the great worm!
23  His mouths he opened, and displayed his tusks;
24  Not a limb had he that was motionless.
The description of Cerberus is the most monstrous of the three guardians which we have met so far.  Charon was more or less a cruel human shape, Minos, a human with a python like extended caudal vertebrae, and now Cerberus, an absolute monster, cruel (crudele) as we might expect, but also diversa, because he has three heads, and because he is strangely composed of mixed up parts.  Cerberus is another conglomeration, like the centaur, the gryphon, the sphinx or like medusa — the kinds of being which are mushed unnaturally into monstrous shapes from two or more creatures.  The Greeks call these types of beings 'callicantzari'.  They are not atypical kinds of nightmare entities, although sometimes we see them alternating their forms as in the wolfman, or the vampire, who change from human to animal shape under certain circumstances.  Often, as with Cerberus, the more diverse the parts, the more monstrous the being.  Cerberus has no reasoning power at all, he is pure instinctual appetite, and he feeds on filth.  His three heads give him three mouths, so that he is a fitting monster to torment those who have succumbed to gluttony to a ruinous degree.  Cerberus is also inhuman, a violation of the human shape, which is what gluttony does too, when obesity destroys the normal human shape through excessive indulgence.  Cerberus is dog-like in that he barks, but the text is careful not to call him a dog, only caninamente latra (barking like a dog), and the text merges him with the tormented gluttons, who when pelted howl like dogs  (come cani).  His three gullets (tre gole) suggest a defile (una gola), one synonym for which is stretta, — something that grips, clutches, grasps, squeezes.  He has a beard like a goat — greasy and somber — unta and atra, talons like a raptor's afixed to human-like hands, tusks (sanne or zanne) like a boar, and a belly like a pig.  He has vermilion eyes — not red, not rosa, but vermigli, and this word recalls the vermilion flash of lightning that we saw at the end of Canto III, and which knocked the aspirant back into a coma.  Finally, and perhaps most tellingly, he is called il gran vermo, the great worm — because he feeds on offal, because he is wormlike in the sense that he is squirmy, and because he resembles the serpent who decieved Eve.  He cannot hold still (non avea membro che tenesso fermo).  A monstrous entity indeed! which flays (iscoia) and quarters (isquatra) the souls of the gluttons who are constantly turning from one side to the other to shield the buried side from his predations, and from the gross stuff that is always pummeling them, like some diobolic manna which falls, not for nournishment but for a punishment.  Everything here is mixed up, the body of Cerberus, as well as the rain/hail/snow that is falling from the sky.  Everything is like partially digested food, which has grown fecaloid and rancid. 

25  E 'l duca mio distese le sue spanne,
26  prese la terra, e con piene le pugna
27  la gittò dentro a le bramose canne.

28  Qual è quel cane ch'abbaiando agogna,
29  e si racqueta poi che 'l pasto morde,
30  ché solo a divorarlo intende e pugna,

31  cotai si fecer quelle facce lorde
32  de lo demonio Cerbero, che 'ntrona
33  l'anime sì, ch'esser vorrebber sorde.

25  And my Conductor, with his spans extended,
26  Took of the earth, and with his fists well filled,
27  He threw it into those rapacious gullets.

28  Such as that dog is, who by barking craves,
29  And quiet grows soon as his food he gnaws,
30  For to devour it he but thinks and struggles,

31  The like became those muzzles filth-begrimed
32  Of Cerberus the demon, who so thunders
33  Over the souls that they would fain be deaf.

As we saw a parody of confession in Canto V, here we see a parody of communion, as Virgil, spreading his wings like an avenging angel throws gobs of filth into the three mouths of Cerberus.  See also Genesis 3:14, where God, to punish the serpent for deceiving Eve, decrees to that other great worm: "Dust thou shalt eat all the days of thy life."  This act quiets Cerberus, who like the gluttons he torments, when offered food, even the food of filth, he does not stop to think about what he is eating, but chokes it down regardless of how noxious and toxic to him it might be.  Perhaps, inadvertently here, to secure their own safe passage, Virgil has also provided some temporary respite to the gluttons, since rather than hear the thunderous barking of Cerberus, they would prefer to be deaf.  Or, just as likely — and the two readings are not mutually exclusive — this would refer to how those in the grip of an impulse which has become their most consuming obsession, the gluttons would prefer to be deaf rather than hear all the warnings that are thundering against their transgressions.  Boccaccio read this bellowing as antithetical to music played at banquets, and we may think with some bemusement that restaurateurs often play music that will make their patrons eat more and eat faster.

34  Noi passavam su per l'ombre che adona
35  la greve pioggia, e ponavam le piante
36  sovra lor vanità che par persona.

37  Elle giacean per terra tutte quante,
38  fuor d'una ch'a seder si levò, ratto
39  ch'ella ci vide passarsi davante.

37  They all were lying prone upon the earth,
38  Excepting one, who sat upright as soon
39  As he beheld us passing on before him.

Dante and Virgil take a slip-slide walk here, proceeding over shadows beaten down by the heavy rain, placing their feet (le piante, understood here as piede = feet), atop those vanities which seemed like people.  Nicola Fosca, a contemporary Italian commentator, argues that in some instances this vanità (vanity) = inconsistenza (inconstancy, inconsistancy) which would make the lines seem as if the shades did not provide firm footing, a reading which, given the general slime of the place, and the constant evil percipitation, would be quite justified.  This reading would also echo what the text says about Cerberus, non avea membro che tenesse fermo (not a limb holds firm).  Walking on soaked inconstant shadow which only seemed to be people would be quite slippery indeed.  All are lying down, but one sits up as the poets pass.

40  “O tu che se' per questo 'nferno tratto,”
41  mi disse, “riconoscimi, se sai:
42  tu fosti, prima ch'io disfatto, fatto.”

43  E io a lui: “L'angoscia che tu hai
44  forse ti tira fuor de la mia mente,
45  sì che non par ch'i' ti vedessi mai.

46  Ma dimmi chi tu se' che 'n sì dolente
47  loco se' messo, e hai sì fatta pena,
48  che, s'altra è maggio, nulla è sì spiacente.” 

49  Ed elli a me: “La tua città, ch'è piena
50  d'invidia sì che già trabocca il sacco,
51  seco mi tenne in la vita serena.

52  Voi cittadini mi chiamaste Ciacco:
53  per la dannosa colpa de la gola,
54  come tu vedi, a la pioggia mi fiacco.

55  E io anima trista non son sola,
56  ché tutte queste a simil pena stanno
57  per simil colpa.” E più non fé parola.

40  "O thou that art conducted through this Hell,"
41  He said to me, "recall me, if thou canst;
42  Thyself wast made before I was unmade."

43  And I to him: "The anguish which thou hast
44  Perhaps doth draw thee out of my remembrance,
45  So that it seems not I have ever seen thee.

46  But tell me who thou art, that in so doleful
47  A place art put, and in such punishment,
48  If some are greater, none is so displeasing."

49  And he to me: "Thy city, which is full
50  Of envy so that now the sack runs over,
51  Held me within it in the life serene.

52  You citizens were wont to call me Ciacco;
53  For the pernicious sin of gluttony
54  I, as thou seest, am battered by this rain.

55  And I, sad soul, am not the only one,
56  For all these suffer the like penalty
57  For the like sin;" and word no more spake he.

These lines — from 40 to 57 — address the question of identity and it's concomitant issue: recognition.  Who are you?  How do you recognize yourself or others?  What makes you you, and by so doing separates you from the mass of others? and makes you an identity, not a generalized conglomeration.  Because whoever has popped out of this ordure, whose punishment, as the aspirant tells him in lines 47 - 48, may not be the worst, but is the most displeasing, he has certainly differentiated himself from the mass.  And although the aspirant does not recognize him, he recognizes Dante, and he also recognizes himself, defines himself, names himself, and even betrays himself, both in what he says about himself, and in what he glosses over or omits to say about himself.  Commentators for eight centuries have been trying to figure out who this might be, and if he were an historical figure from Florence, a person that Dante knew, as the shade himself implies when he asks Dante if he remembers him (riconoscimi).  The text in a very clever turn of phrase jambs the words unmade (disfatto) and made (fatto) together as way of illustrating that Dante and this person whom Dante does not recognize, the mystery persona's anguish having so altered his appearance, had a very close association.  In political circles — and this is what we are dealing with here — the polity, the polis, when a close associate falls into disgrace, his erstwhile friends, as is said, 'begin to distance themselves from him.'  The aspirant denies the association, is, or plays dumb, and in so doing the text uses the word mente, the same word that was used at the beginning of the Canto as the aspirant begins to recover his senses from his pity-swoon following his seduction by Francesca.  Who are you?  Are you your body?  Your habits?  Your moral choices?  Are you your social position?  Your lineage?  The parent of someone? the child of someone?  Are you your knowledge and experience?  your accomplishments or lack thereof?  Are you a product of your environment?  Are you the citizen of a country or city — an American, an Italian, a Florentine?  Are you your name, you epithet, your nickname?  This shade has distinguished himself from the other gluttons who lie undistinguished in this field of noisome waste by sitting up, by recognizing the aspirant, in short he sees the aspirant.  The glutton has separated himself from the vulgar mass — and we remember that such an act is what separated Beatrice from the ladies with whom the young Dante first saw her, and also what Beatrice says is what merited Dante for the special dispensation of hers, of Saint Lucy's, and of the Queen of Heaven's mercy.  The reader might also recall that Saint Lucy, whose name means light, was martyred by having her eyes removed, and it is sight, or lack of it, in this glutton, will be seen to be an important detail at the end of his discourse.   Francesca tried to seduce and deceive Dante by quoting his own words from the Vita Nuova, and of claiming that like Dante himself, in his feelings for Beatrice, she and Paolo, were also driven to their action by love.  Ciacco, the Hog, as the shade names himself, referring to his own epithet, only fleeting admits his damaging sin of gluttony (la dennosa colpa di gola), and instead concentrates on incurring Dante's sympathy by claiming their association as two citizens of Florence — recall the ingratiating phrase of politicians who seek our  assent: 'My fellow Americans.'   This ploy works too, as we shall see as we proceed in the text.   Dante, the aspirant, is indeed seduced, asks nothing about gluttony — except as we see tangentially, by way of vague insinuation.  Ciacco may be a glutton, may have been branded a glutton by his fellow citizens, but that is not what interests Dante about him, that is not what distinguishes him, and gives him a special identity from the general mass of gluttons.  What distinguishes him in his own eyes is his political taste, his tongue's ability to bitterly savor the sins of the two fellow Florentine's fellow citizens, and his ability to denounce them.  A glutton will eat like a horse that founders.  He will eat until the sack of his belly splits, and thus the glutton Ciacco says that the city of Florence is a sack that splits and spills the chankings of envy, which has in a sense deprived him of his society dinners, his ability to indulge in la vita dolce, their discord spoiling the serenity and conviviality of the city, that serenity which made his gluttony possible.  Read in this way, this fact makes The Hog guilty by the sin of omission, by being bitter not from remorse for his glottony, but for his fellow citizens actions, which have deprived him of the opportunity to eat.  If the city is a sack of sin, as the belly is a sack of waste for one who eats beyond the needs of healthy nourishment, than his fellow Florentines who have stuffed themselves full of envy are worse than Ciacco, and are deserving of greater damnation.  Dante knew his Latin and he read Ovid closely.   In many places the Commedia, including in the initiating lines of this Canto, he shows just how close his reading of Ovid has been.  Ovid associates Invidia, the etymology of the which is from invidere, to look against, to give the evil eye,  with seeing maliciously.  This is  instance of the misuse of light, hence the echo of the earlier appearance of Saint Lucy.  But the tongue does more than taste.  The glutton who feeds on envy uses the tongue to speak with evil intent, Ovid's personification of the trait in the Metamorphosis being one who

squinted horribly ... {as}
her tongue dripped venom,
gnawing at others and being gnawed,
She was herself her own torment.

And as we shall see in the prophesy that Ciacco has coaxed Dante to request, this is precisely what Ciacco is doing, and what Dante the poet is doing as well, although he puts his venom in the mouth of his gluttonous protagonist, and thereby tries to avoid the accusation against himself.  And we shall see below, in that prophesy, just how slyly the poet attempts to accomplish this sleight of mouth.  In this prophesy, as elsewhere in hell, we must remember that the speakers' words are forever tainted with deceit.  Whatever Ciacco's words to the aspirant are, we should not forget that the place where he is is an outpicturing of his inner state, and that the monster who would flay and quarter him is a beast with three mouths who only stops barking to eat filth.  Ciacco's parting words here, before his general torpor begins to silence him, is the same kind excuse as Francesca's in the previous Canto: I'm not the only one, others did it too.  This is the first of his evasions, the others follow in his dunciation of his fellow Florentines.  And it amounts to his: maybe I'm guilty, but others did worse.  We can see this now in our current politicl leaders.  Everybody does it.  And my opponants did worse.  You couldn't stand accused in any court docket and use these as a defense against your guilt.          

58  Io li rispuosi: “Ciacco, il tuo affanno
59  mi pesa sì, ch'a lagrimar mi 'nvita;
60  ma dimmi, se tu sai, a che verranno

61  li cittadin de la città partita;
62  s'alcun v'è giusto; e dimmi la cagione
63  per che l'ha tanta discordia assalita.”

64  E quelli a me: “Dopo lunga tencione
65  verranno al sangue, e la parte selvaggia
66  caccerà l'altra con molta offensione.

67  Poi appresso convien che questa caggia
68  infra tre soli, e che l'altra sormonti
69  con la forza di tal che testé piaggia.

70  Alte terrà lungo tempo le fronti,
71  tenendo l'altra sotto gravi pesi,
72  come che di ciò pianga o che n'aonti.

73  Giusti son due, e non vi sono intesi;
74  superbia, invidia e avarizia sono
75  le tre faville c'hanno i cuori accesi.”

76  Qui puose fine al lagrimabil suono.
77  E io a lui: “Ancor vo' che mi 'nsegni
78  e che di più parlar mi facci dono.

79  Farinata e 'l Tegghiaio, che fuor sì degni,
80  Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo e 'l Mosca
81  e li altri ch'a ben far puoser li 'ngegni,

82  dimmi ove sono e fa ch'io li conosca;
83  ché gran disio mi stringe di savere
84  se 'l ciel li addolcia o lo 'nferno li attosca.”

85  E quelli: “Ei son tra l'anime più nere;
86  diverse colpe giù li grava al fondo:
87  se tanto scendi, là i potrai vedere.

88  Ma quando tu sarai nel dolce mondo,
89  priegoti ch'a la mente altrui mi rechi:
90  più non ti dico e più non ti rispondo.”

91  Li diritti occhi torse allora in biechi;
92  guardommi un poco e poi chinò la testa:
93  cadde con essa a par de li altri ciechi.

58  I answered him: "Ciacco, thy wretchedness
59  Weighs on me so that it to weep invites me;
60  But tell me, if thou knowest, to what shall come

61  The citizens of the divided city;
62  If any there be just; and the occasion
63  Tell me why so much discord has assailed it."

64  And he to me: "They, after long contention,
65  Will come to bloodshed; and the rustic party
66  Will drive the other out with much offence.

67  Then afterwards behoves it this one fall
68  Within three suns, and rise again the other
69  By force of him who now is on the coast.

70  High will it hold its forehead a long while,
71  Keeping the other under heavy burdens,
72  Howe'er it weeps thereat and is indignant.
73  The just are two, and are not understood there;
74  Envy and Arrogance and Avarice
75  Are the three sparks that have all hearts enkindled."

76  Here ended he his tearful utterance;
77  And I to him: "I wish thee still to teach me,
78  And make a gift to me of further speech.

79  Farinata and Tegghiaio, once so worthy,
80  Jacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo, and Mosca,
81  And others who on good deeds set their thoughts,

82  Say where they are, and cause that I may know them;
83  For great desire constraineth me to learn
84  If Heaven doth sweeten them, or Hell envenom."

85  And he: "They are among the blacker souls;
86  A different sin downweighs them to the bottom;
87  If thou so far descendest, thou canst see them.

88  But when thou art again in the sweet world,
89  I pray thee to the mind of others bring me;
90  No more I tell thee and no more I answer."

91  Then his straightforward eyes he turned askance,
92  Eyed me a little, and then bowed his head;
93  He fell therewith prone like the other blind.

This interaction that the aspirant has with Ciacco suggests certain tacit assumptions about time, space, and knowledge, since Ciacco in these verses is asked for a prophesy.  Francesca only had knowledge of her own circumstances, until she mentions Caina, the 9th circle of hell, as the abode of her husband who murdered her and his own brother ... but, when later her murderer does not appear there, do we in retrospect assume that what Francesca has said was only self-serving wish-fulfillment on her part?  Here, however, straight out prophesy is asked for and supplied.  For most readers whoever the five Florentine's mentioned were in the late 13th and early 14th centuries, and whatever their politics might have been, are moot points.  What is important, then, is what the inclusion of historicity implies as another layer of meaning in the poem.  The historical, just as it did with the incarnation, makes time into a line with befores and afters, arranged in sequence in a communal history, and it is clear throughout the text that what happens in this historical time, however temporary, has eternal implications — or as Blake says, "Eternity is in love with the productions of time."  What is eternity then, and how does eternal time differ from historical time?  Eternity, whether below the plane of historical time, as it is here, of above it, as it is for those in Purgatory or Paradise, is a place wherefrom the denizens of those realms have a meta-perspective on history and historical actors.  The shades in eternity are able to see and know what those trapped in sequential time cannot.  In hell, the  the shades can see the roots of historical actions as their own conditions of torment.  They deal in time as torment, their actions as living people productive of torment, their speeches full of news of torment.  But this is news of a twisted sort born from the historical actions of twisted people.  And this is what the aspirant is asking for here, news from this meta-position of torment.  If we replaced the names of these 5 Florentines with 5 of our own contemporaries, then these passages would have the effect that they would have had on Dante's contemporaries when they first read the poem.  But, if we did that, we would destroy their historicity, and by implication the incarnation, for all physical bodies exist in historical time, just as all imaginative bodies exist in the non-local non-temporal worlds of their own making.  All this section of Ciacco's prophesy, as well as the discussion between the aspirant and Virgil which conclude this Canto, are but tortured ways to present the relationship between history and imagination — history that binds all temporal life with mortality's deterministic sequential chains of causes and effects — sins and punishments, virtues and rewards — and imagination, which moves among the shades of hell, the souls of those in purgatory, and the spirits of those in paradise, and determines what is sin and what is virtue, and what should be the eternal punishments and rewards for those thoughts, feelings and actions fomented by the blinkered temporal body.

Dante, the aspirant, is conducting a seance, contacting the dead for news that only the dead can have, because only the dead have this meta-perspective on the historical actors.  They see their twisted actions, even if the historical public only sees their social masks.  Dante, the historical character, pretends anxiety for the five men mentioned here — Farinata, Tegghiaio, Iacopo Rusticucci, Arrigo, and Mosca.  He speaks of them as those who upon good things placed their thoughts (ch'a ben far puoser li 'ngegni), and that pretense is ironic, because Dante the poet, from his imaginative meta-position, already knows the fate of these, his own contemporaries.  He knows it, because he has invented it in his imagination.  Note too that Ciacco's prophesies are couched in that strange ambiguity which all such utterances have: an allegorical vagueness — in three suns (soli) — not three days (not giorni).  Then there is the Wheel of Fortune aspect.  As one set of political actors weighs itself down by its own moral enormities, the other pops up, but only to be weighed down in their turn by the same motivations and actions which corrupted their enemies, and finally, to be animated from torpor by blood (sangue, line 63), as they are in the Odyssey and in the Aeneid.  The hearts of those on both sides of this political battle are consumed by the flames of pride (superbia), invidia (envy), and avarizia (avarice).  These are in fact the actual crimes that the city has bred in its inhabitants, and the banner of secular rule verses papal rule, or visa versa, is only another zero sum game that generates such conflagrations.  Civil war, raging in the political sphere, is caused by and causes the civil war raging inside historical actors, who are futilely using the soul weapons of pride, envy, and greed to accomplish a civic and personal good.  The results of this civil war are just what one would expect them to be — disastrous for the community, and disastrous for the citizens of the community.  And what did we discover were the connecting points of identity between Dante, the historical actor, the five people named here, and Ciacco?  They were all fellow citizens, the linkage between their identities forever and unbreakably forged by the geographical accident of their births in the same place.  This is the same thing that linked Dante and Virgil across time, the same thing that linked Dante and Beatrice in propinquitous space.  

But why discuss these political questions — these questions of inner corruption and civil war — in a canto ostensibly concerned with gluttony.  Because gluttony is a sin of the belly (the sack mentioned eariler, the throat and the tongue, and Ciacco, in his condemnation of these five fellow Florentines, is wielding one of the chief weapons of any civil conflict, or any inner conflict — that is to say, slander.  And just as gluttons can never stuff themselves with enough food, they can never purge their disgust and anger at those who have thwarted them, by vomiting enough slander.  Whatever else this heavy precipitation is, whatever Cerberus' thunderings, clawings, and quarterings are, they are slanderous, and slander is waste, crap, urine, vomit, and its heavy, grief-inducing pummeling is a perpetual feature of any conflict, internal or external.

Now the question to be dealt with in any civil conflict is one of justice.  Who is just, and who gets to arbitrate justice?  In this case, it is the accuser, the self-confessed glutton, the one who tries to identify himself, have himself recognized, even as he sinks back into the agglomeration of waste and wasted (line 89: I pray thee to the mind of others bring me — priegoti ch'a la mente altrui me rechi).  This accused and accuser is Ciacco, the Hog.  It is a Hog that elicits the aspirant's tears and pity.  So, just as with Francesca, it is Dante's pity that keeps him from seeing the propriety of Divine Justice, Dante's pity that makes him go to the pitiful for prophesy, even as Virgil, a truer guide, has to this point been unacknowledged and silent.

This Canto uses the framing device of arising from the unconscious, and falling back again into unconsciousness.  The aspirant had arisen from a coma wherein his mind (mente) was closed by pity for the incestuous adulterers.  Now when Ciacco hears a living soul passing, he arises from the general coma, falls back again after the question of his identity is examined but not resolved, is called forth again in a seance for the gift of prophesy, and after speaking ill of the dead, and ambiguously about justice, he is submersed again.  His final words?  that Dante, a living soul, should pray, and recall him to the minds (mente again) of others.   Here again in Ciacco's arising upon after seeing Virgil and Dante, he falls after speaking to them.  He looks forward, turns askance (biechi) and falls (cadde).  And now we are back with this word cadde with the aspirant at the end of Canto V, and we remember how the aspirant fell after hearing Francesca's deceitful tale.  Ciacco falls among the other blind, which is to say, Ciacco rose, saw, spoke, was heard, forgot or repressed it all, then fell again, doing a face-plant in his own and the collective's waste.   So, along with this twisting, tortured, torqued motif, we have this arising and falling of consciousness, a scale wherein one side of conscious/unconscious balance can only be in ascendance as the other side is repressed.  Historical actors are damned or praised in eternity, and those eternal actors of the soul, i.e., in the imagination, damn or praise historical actors.

In this third circle of hell, we are, in lines 65 and 69, brought back to the first canto by the word selvaggia (wild, bewildering, savage) and the references to the force (forza) of one on the coast (piaggia).  From the first instance, we remember the savage wood, and from the second instance, we are reminded of the metaphor of the swimmer who has almost drowned, after reaching the beach, then looks back upon the element which had almost submersed him.  It should also be noted that the condition of consciousness is not that of truth, or sensory acuity, or prophesy, it is the ability to speak and be heard, to call and respond, to confess and receive confessions, and to conduct a seance in order to coax knowledge from the dead, and thus provide a channel for the dead or absent to speak and to be heard.  The first canto is also echoed in the final exit of Ciacco, with the word diritte (line 91, Canto VI, and line 3, Canto I).  Ciacco ceases to look straight, and loses his sight and insight, this trope being repeated from Canto I, where the aspirant has lost the straight path, and cannot continue his spiritual climb, but must go down instead and harrow hell.  

94  E 'l duca disse a me: “Più non si desta
95  di qua dal suon de l'angelica tromba,
96  quando verrà la nimica podesta:

97  ciascun rivederà la trista tomba,
98  ripiglierà sua carne e sua figura,
99  udirà quel ch'in etterno rimbomba.”

100  Sì trapassammo per sozza mistura
101  de l'ombre e de la pioggia, a passi lenti,
102  toccando un poco la vita futura;

103  per ch'io dissi: “Maestro, esti tormenti
104  crescerann' ei dopo la gran sentenza,
105  o fier minori, o saran sì cocenti?”

106  Ed elli a me: “Ritorna a tua scïenza,
107  che vuol, quanto la cosa è più perfetta,
108  più senta il bene, e così la doglienza.

109  Tutto che questa gente maladetta
110  in vera perfezion già mai non vada,
111  di là più che di qua essere aspetta.”

112  Noi aggirammo a tondo quella strada,
113  parlando più assai ch'i' non ridico;
114  venimmo al punto dove si digrada:

115  quivi trovammo Pluto, il gran nemico.
 
94  And the Guide said to me: "He wakes no more
95  This side the sound of the angelic trumpet;
96  When shall approach the hostile Potentate,
97  Each one shall find again his dismal tomb,
98  Shall reassume his flesh and his own figure,
99  Shall hear what through eternity re-echoes."

100  So we passed onward o'er the filthy mixture
101  Of shadows and of rain with footsteps slow,
102  Touching a little on the future life.

103  Wherefore I said: "Master, these torments here,
104  Will they increase after the mighty sentence,
105  Or lesser be, or will they be as burning?"

106  And he to me: "Return unto thy science,
107  Which wills, that as the thing more perfect is,
108  The more it feels of pleasure and of pain.

109  Albeit that this people maledict
110  To true perfection never can attain,
111  Hereafter more than now they look to be."

112  Round in a circle by that road we went,
113  Speaking much more, which I do not repeat;
114  We came unto the point where the descent is;

115  There we found Plutus the great enemy.

Historical time is a sequence, and as such, it must have a beginning and it must have an end.  and the entelechy, time's end, as Terrance McKenna would call it, must be defined.  The historical incarnation is the center of a circle, and the historical sequence which that center point transacts begins with the creation and ends with the last trumpet.  When the last pages of this book, which can only be read sequentially, are closed, and we have perfected ourselves in its exegesis, than all that has been is seen as it is, the product of a divine justice.  The damned too will hear that trump, but it will not, as Virgil tells the aspirant, release them from the punishment of that justice, but will only almost, but not quite, perfect them in perfect/imperfect suffering.  We have to understand, that if this universe, as Dante is defining it, were to end with the end of suffering, almost all its history would be erased, and along with that erasure, the profound meaning of the incarnation.  That could never be, for that would destroy the center of the universe, and make things without form and void once again — which would hardly be perfection.  

The Canto ends with Virgil and Dante proceeding, as we are told elsewhere, counter-clockwise to the left on the circular, circulating road, and speaking of things, which are not repeated — a statement which hints at the talk between the poets in limbo, when they spoke of secret things that were better left unspoken.  And then, just as this Canto begins with a reference to the due cognati, the two murdered, adulterous in-laws of the previous Canto, it ends with a reference to Pluto, whose curses begin the next Canto.  Note: Cerbero: gran vermo / Pluto: gran nemico, like adjective, like rhymes, linking transitional monsters — examples of Dante's poetic skill abound.     Churchill once said: "If you're going through hell, keep going."  And our pilgrims, while speaking of final, unrepeated things (for nothing in historical time could ever be repeated, that is one of its purposes, it makes things unique, it makes decisions final) — our pilgrims, to repeat, must now continue on that road, twisting, and turning through the tortured and the torturous, down and down and down.  And what unique pilgrims are these, almost perfecting, in their respective poems, the history of human pain.  And where does this leave the readers, our readers, ourselves?   It leaves us reading and re-reading, interpreting and re-interpreting these same words, again and again, immersing ourselves, diving and rising, as imperfectly as we can, as we slowly perfect our imperfect understandings.

Canto VII
Canto VII unfolds as follows:

Introduction, the deflation of Pluto or The Power of Speech Defeating Nonsense, 

First group of sinners: hoarders and wastrals.

Virgil's first exposition, including the denunciation of corrupt clergy

Virgil's second expostion on the question of recognition, identity and Fame/Infamy

Virgil's third exposition on Lady Fortuna

Second group of sinners, the Wrathful and Sullen

Conclusion: Return to Inarticulateness as the submerged Sullen belch words they cannot pronounce   

1  Pape Satàn, pape Satàn aleppe!”
2  cominciò Pluto con la voce chioccia;
3  e quel savio gentil, che tutto seppe,

4  disse per confortarmi: “Non ti noccia
5  la tua paura; ché, poder ch'elli abbia,
6  non ci torrà lo scender questa roccia.”

7  Poi si rivolse a quella 'nfiata labbia,
8  e disse: “Taci, maladetto lupo!
9  consuma dentro te con la tua rabbia.

10  Non è sanza cagion l'andare al cupo:
11  vuolsi ne l'alto, là dove Michele
12  fé la vendetta del superbo strupo.”

13  Quali dal vento le gonfiate vele
14  caggiono avvolte, poi che l'alber fiacca,
15  tal cadde a terra la fiera crudele.

16  Così scendemmo ne la quarta lacca,
17  pigliando più de la dolente ripa
18  che 'l mal de l'universo tutto insacca.

1  "Pape Satan, Pape Satan, Aleppe!"
2  Thus Plutus with his clucking voice began;
3  And that benignant Sage, who all things knew,

4  Said, to encourage me: "Let not thy fear
5  Harm thee; for any power that he may have
6  Shall not prevent thy going down this crag."

7  Then he turned round unto that bloated lip,
8  And said: "Be silent, thou accursed wolf;
9  Consume within thyself with thine own rage.

10  Not causeless is this journey to the abyss;
11  Thus is it willed on high, where Michael wrought
12  Vengeance upon the proud adultery."

13  Even as the sails inflated by the wind
14  Involved together fall when snaps the mast,
15  So fell the cruel monster to the earth.

16  Thus we descended into the fourth chasm,
17  Gaining still farther on the dolesome shore
18  Which all the woe of the universe insacks.

Think of narrative as an analog of historical time, sequential and always moving forward.  Think of metaphor as that which cuts across that sequence, gives it depth, as harmony gives depth to music.  Dante drives his narrative forward, as in this case, by building a bridge between cantos. Pluto being mentioned as the great enemy at the end of the previous canto (as Cerberus was the great worm), is here linked to the Tourette Syndrome-like outburst, which begins this canto.  By means of these bridging devices, along with the purposeful annunciation of which "circle" of hell we are now in, Dante keeps driving the narrative forward, and does so with such precision that there is no chance of us shuffling the cantos, and producing them out of order, no disputes, as there are in Chaucer, for example, of what follows what in the narrative sequence.  It is midnight on Good Friday, April 8th, 1300, and yet, metaphorically we are continually being plunged into the depths of each moment, mythic time, dropping us into eddies and swirls that pull us into an undertow of analogies which cause us to recall earlier sequences in the poem, and give us fore-echoes of later ones.  The historical line is transected by stops, by gaps in the aspirant's conscious awareness, and by the asides and commentaries of the narrator Dante, who occasionally raises the curtain and shows us the wizard subtly and skillfully managing those effects and affects which he wants the reader or listener to experience.  

Canto VII begins with Pluto's verbal word-salad, a parody of "speaking in tongues", such as we might find in schizophrenics or magicians, and it ends with the Sullen, lying below swamp water, belching words that become noxious bubbles, their sense made nonsense, like that of stroke victims, whose speech intentions come out as gobblygook.  The last line of the canto leaves us at the foot of a tower, which metaphorically shadows all that has gone before with the curse of Babble.   Hell is not only deceitful, it also defies logic, i.e., the linguistic sequential sense, and the framing of Canto VII shows how language itself can be disordered, and with it historical time.  These poetic, metaphoric devices cut across the narrative line, cast forth irreconcilable ambiguities from the depths, and even though we have this continuous line of narrative to follow, the line is a downward spiral, into deeper levels of chaos, wherein the damned experience, not eternity, but interminable repetitions, like autistics who repeat the same actions, or Alzheimer victims, who repeat the same stories.  

There is something in this Canto which defines the power of speech, and of the music of speech, as we start in the first line with what might be called malevolent nonsense, Pluto's words almost but not quite being comprehensible, and end the canto with belched bubbles.  For 800 years commentators have not been able to definitively define Pluto's outburst — but its affect is clear enough.  These blatherings are curses, some kind of verbal formula meant to stop and deter the poets, and they have power (poder), but only power over the damned.  And like the other conglomerate beings that have previously tried to stop the poet's progress, Pluto too is a mess of irreconcilable parts.  He clucks like a chicken, has a bloated lip like some kind of sea monster, and has a ravenous and avaricious disposition like a wolf.  And yet, he is in a sense full of hot air, and when Virgil speaks to him — calling him out — describing him — denoucing him — confronting him with reason (cagion) and heaven's (or Dante, the poet's) will (voulsi ne l'alto), Pluto's inflated sense of power immediately collapses, as the sails of a ship in a gale immediately collapse when the mast is snapped (lines 13-15).  The power of Virgil's speech, of reason and will, is that gale which tears to tatters the nonsense of Pluto's magical curses, and makes their illusory power irrelevant — full of sound and fury and signifying nothing.  We should also add that Pluto, being the mythical diety associated with wealth, is a fit monster to oversee the sinners in this circle, whose only approach to wealth is to hoard or waste it.

There is a progression here, from air, to water, to rocks, and one way to view this progression is to interpret it as speech (air), the affects of speech (water), and the actions prompted by speech (rock).  And we will see, as the sequential narrative unfolds in this canto, how these metaphors continuously draw us down, not only into hell, but also into the deeper moral insights which will eventually deliver us from hell, and from the tyranny of sequential speech and historical time.

Language notes:

Line 11: Here Virgil refers to the war in Heaven in which the archangel Michael, sometimes depicted with a sword for a tongue, casts Lucifer and the rebellious angels out of heaven.  This sin is equated with the breaking of marriage vows through adultery (strupo), a very troubadorian act, and one which the historical Dante, at least in his heart, was thoroughly guilty of.  This one word gives as a brief window into the psyche of Dante, wherein poetry itself, especially the poetry of the Vita Nuova, is a kind fidelity based upon infidelity, a sin of the body, and a virtue of the spirit. 

Line 18: The word insacca (to insack), reminds us of how Ciacco compares the corruption of Florence to a busting sack. The word also has a bubble-like connotation, which foreshadows the swamp bubbles we find arising from the Sullen at the end of this canto.

The spiral, twisting motion, that motif which we have seen throughout the work so far, is here confined to the pirouette which Virgil makes as he turns (revolsi) from comforting the aspirant to cursing Pluto.      

The word cadde (falls) in line 18, reminds us of the alliterative line which ended Canto V: E caddi come corpo morto cade.      

19  Ahi giustizia di Dio! tante chi stipa
20  nove travaglie e pene quant' io viddi?
21  e perché nostra colpa sì ne scipa?

19  Justice of God, ah! who heaps up so many
20  New toils and sufferings as I beheld?
21  And why doth our transgression waste us so?

Lines 19-21: Another peak behind the curtain hidding the poet Dante, who is here commenting on the action — but also using this metaposition to speak on behalf of the reader, who may himself be wondering about the severity of God's justice.

22  Come fa l'onda là sovra Cariddi,
23  che si frange con quella in cui s'intoppa,
24  così convien che qui la gente riddi.

25  Qui vid' i' gente più ch'altrove troppa,
26  e d'una parte e d'altra, con grand' urli,
27  voltando pesi per forza di poppa.

28  Percotëansi 'ncontro; e poscia pur lì
29  si rivolgea ciascun, voltando a retro,
30  gridando: “Perché tieni?” e “Perché burli?”

31  Così tornavan per lo cerchio tetro
32  da ogne mano a l'opposito punto,
33  gridandosi anche loro ontoso metro;

34  poi si volgea ciascun, quand' era giunto,
35  per lo suo mezzo cerchio a l'altra giostra.
36  E io, ch'avea lo cor quasi compunto,

22  As doth the billow there upon Charybdis,
23  That breaks itself on that which it encounters,
24  So here the folk must dance their roundelay.
 
25  Here saw I people, more than elsewhere, many,
26  On one side and the other, with great howls,
27  Rolling weights forward by main force of chest.

28  They clashed together, and then at that point
29  Each one turned backward, rolling retrograde,
30  Crying, "Why keepest?" and, "Why squanderest thou?"

31  Thus they returned along the lurid circle
32  On either hand unto the opposite point,
33  Shouting their shameful metre evermore.

34  Then each, when he arrived there, wheeled about
35  Through his half-circle to another joust;
36  And I, who had my heart pierced as it were,

The remarkable skill in which Dante extends and develops metaphor is on grand display throughout this canto: as the wind or air metaphor of the collapsed sails evolves into waves crashing together, as they do at Charybdis, sidesteps into a circle metaphor of people dancing a senseless roundelay — which afterwards becomes a violent joust — then moves forward to the crashing rocks metaphor, as the hoarders and wastrels clash in a repetitive conflict in which their seeming opposites meet, just as when we travel in opposite directions from any point at the circumference of a circle, we will arrive at a point on the other side of the circle, where the opposites crash together again.  They then roll back to their starting point, only to repeat the cycle.  Everything in these few lines is compact and economical, and yet incredibly rich, as Dante's style demonstrates what the hoarders and wastrels did not.  We pick up the speech metaphor as well as the clashing hoarders and wastrels shout the same insults at one another, and with great efforts, pushing with their chests (poppa/modern Italian petto, or chest) the stones in which they hope to crush their eternal enemies.  Chest equals lungs, and it is the lungs, not the articulating tongues, which shout only the same two-word insults over and over in ceaseless refrains: Why grasp?!  Why squander?! (line 30).  These refrains are very pointedly compared both to music and to poetry in line 33 with the word meter: shouting their shameful metre evermore (gridandosi anche loro ontoso metro).  The rocks remind us of Sisyphus, who is punished by rolling a rock up a steep incline, only to have it roll back over him before reaching the crest, and then having to start the same process again.  

Once again, in line 36, we have the aspirant overcome with pity, but, unlike the situation in the circle of the lustful or in the circle of the gluttons, in which Virgil is silent, now the aspirant again turns to reason for comfort (line 4 of the canto), and for the an explanation.  And so begins Virgil's first lecture on who these sinners are, why their punishment is as it is, and finally, showing the aspirant that those devoted to a religious calling were not exempt from these sins.    

37  dissi: “Maestro mio, or mi dimostra
38  che gente è questa, e se tutti fuor cherci
39  questi chercuti a la sinistra nostra.”

40  Ed elli a me: “Tutti quanti fuor guerci
41  sì de la mente in la vita primaia,
42  che con misura nullo spendio ferci.

43  Assai la voce lor chiaro l'abbaia,
44  quando vegnono a' due punti del cerchio
45  dove colpa contraria li dispaia.
46  Questi fuor cherci, che non han coperchio
47  piloso al capo, e papi e cardinali,
48  in cui usa avarizia il suo soperchio.”
37  Exclaimed: "My Master, now declare to me
38  What people these are, and if all were clerks,
39  These shaven crowns upon the left of us."

40  And he to me: "All of them were asquint
41  In intellect in the first life, so much
42  That there with measure they no spending made.

43  Clearly enough their voices bark it forth,
44  Whene'er they reach the two points of the circle,
45  Where sunders them the opposite defect.

46  Clerks those were who no hairy covering
47  Have on the head, and Popes and Cardinals,
48  In whom doth Avarice practise its excess."

If we remember the hear/see motif that has been a feature throughout these early cantos of the inferno, then the sequence starting in line 40 of damaged sight (querci — literally one-eyed in modern Italian, and translated here as asquint) followed by inarticulate noise instead of speech (line 43 — assai la voice lor chiaro l'abaia — clearly enough their voices bark it forth), parodies what is the correct sequence, vis à vis, reading.  First we sound the words, then we see the meaning.  For these sinners that is not possible.  Their speech is damaged, just as their master Pluto's speech is damaged.  In fact, they bark like dogs or wolves.  Also their sight, or insight is marred.  Virgil, our interpreter here, says that even though the sinner's speech has descended into an animal-like patois, the reader: Dante, the aspirant, or whoever is reading these words in the moment, finds their meaning clear (chiaro) — a word that pertains both to hearing and seeing: clear sounds, clear sight, clear understanding (mente). 

The text also makes clear where the sinners who most interest the aspirant are: on the left (a la sinestra), left being the direction the poets are travelling, the Italian word sinestra saying enough about how leftness was viewed in the popular parlance.  In the Kabbalah, which Dante studied, the left path is a sort of via negativa of the spirit, so that being to the left of where the poets stand — presumably at the Aristotelian medium between the hoarders and wastrels — singles these sinners out as being particularly odious, both because they are clergy, and also because the text holds avarice (line 48: avarizia) to be an even worse sin the prodigality — perhaps because there is no joy in it, or perhaps because the gospel tale of the prodigal son gives the prodigal some little leeway that the greedy cannot claim.  At least the prodigal's wealth goes into circulation, whereas the hoarder deprives both himself and others.  (See Mark Jay Mirsky: Dante, Eros, Kabbalah for a fuller discussion of Dante's relationship to the Kabbalah.)  

There is also in lines 38 and 39 some punning around the words cherci (clerics) and chercuti (tonsured).  This tonsuring  should denote a religious calling, and over time, it has come to symbolize many things, among them being 

* the halo, 
* the fact that like slaves, whose heads were shaved, the renunciates were God's slaves
* celibacy: as hair was considered an erotic signification
* an homage to Saint Peter, who had his head shaved as a prisoner

Finally, there is this word misura, made famous among the troubadours as an attribute of the perfect lover, Eros here being attached to money — remember Christ's edict: the love of money is the root of all evil.  The troubadour, Marcebru, says that true love (fin'amor) has three attributes: Jois, Sofrirs e Misura — joy, patience, moderation.  (See the essay Fin'Amor, Moshe Lazar, page 68, A Handbook of the Troubadours, Akehurst, Davis, ed.), and these clerics — among whom are cardinals and popes, clearly have forgone all measure, all moderation, and all temperance when it came to wealth, either hoarding or squandering it.  And by analogy, the clerics have also perverted their calling as God's lovers.  In brief, if they were to be espoused to Christ, they are, like Francesca, in the previous canto, adulterers, and like Ciacco, they have stuffed themselves with wealth beyond any compacity for its nourishing use.  In all this, Dante, the poet, veers very close to heresy himself, especially by denouncing Popes, who are assumed to be the Vicars of Christ, and as such infallible.  And whether putting these words in the mouth of Virgil is an end-run to absolve himself of that heresy, or by having a pagan condemn Christians is an extra dig at the corrupt clergy, it skills not to ask, although there is every possibility that he intended both readings.       

49  E io: “Maestro, tra questi cotali
50  dovre' io ben riconoscere alcuni
51  che furo immondi di cotesti mali.”

52  Ed elli a me: “Vano pensiero aduni:
53  la sconoscente vita che i fé sozzi,
54  ad ogne conoscenza or li fa bruni.

55  In etterno verranno a li due cozzi:
56  questi resurgeranno del sepulcro
57  col pugno chiuso, e questi coi crin mozzi.

58  Mal dare e mal tener lo mondo pulcro
59  ha tolto loro, e posti a questa zuffa:
60  qual ella sia, parole non ci appulcro.

49  And I: "My Master, among such as these
50  I ought forsooth to recognise some few,
51  Who were infected with these maladies."

52  And he to me: "Vain thought thou entertainest;
53  The undiscerning life which made them sordid
54  Now makes them unto all discernment dim.

55  Forever shall they come to these two buttings;
56  These from the sepulchre shall rise again
57  With the fist closed, and these with tresses shorn.

58  Ill giving and ill keeping the fair world
59  Have ta'en from them, and placed them in this scuffle;
60  Whate'er it be, no words adorn I for it.

In this second lecture by Virgil, once again the text takes up the question of identity, which throughout the Commedia is an issue entangled with complex equivalencies around certain concepts.  These concepts would be recognition or anonymity, fame or infamy, praise or damnation.  It seems as if the poet, Dante, in these lines, adheres to a practice of not granting recognition to people who were not already famous or infamous, as was the case with Ciacco.  There is no attribution, in such cases, which would further spread the notariaty of the malefactors.   But in the case for Francesca, Cleopatra, Helen, Paolo, Tristram, et al, whose stories were well-known, he uses his metaposition as the poet, to denounce their transgressions.  

Virgil's words in line 60 are revealing: qual ella sia, parole non ci appulcro (Whate're it be, no words adorn I for it).  Further discussions of these people are not worthy to be enshrined in the temple of poetry.  This line too is another instance wherein the rhyme adds an extra depth of meaning.  Pulcro, possibly a coinage by Dante from the Latin pulcer, meaning beautiful or fair, and used here in the paraphrastic phrase lo mondo pulcro, to refer to heaven, is linked to the word appulcro (to adorn, to beautify), used by Virgil as an attribute of poetry.  This rhyme gives us a keen insight concerning just how much prestige Dante attributed to the art of poetry.  

61  Or puoi, figliuol, veder la corta buffa
62  d'i ben che son commessi a la fortuna,
63  per che l'umana gente si rabuffa;

64  ché tutto l'oro ch'è sotto la luna
65  e che già fu, di quest' anime stanche
66  non poterebbe farne posare una.”

67  “Maestro mio,” diss' io, “or mi dì anche:
68  questa fortuna di che tu mi tocche,
69  che è, che i ben del mondo ha sì tra branche?”

70  E quelli a me: “Oh creature sciocche,
71  quanta ignoranza è quella che v'offende!
72  Or vo' che tu mia sentenza ne 'mbocche.

73  Colui lo cui saver tutto trascende,
74  fece li cieli e diè lor chi conduce
75  sì, ch'ogne parte ad ogne parte splende,

76  distribuendo igualmente la luce.
77  Similemente a li splendor mondani
78  ordinò general ministra e duce

79  che permutasse a tempo li ben vani
80  di gente in gente e d'uno in altro sangue,
81  oltre la difension d'i senni umani;

82  per ch'una gente impera e l'altra langue,
83  seguendo lo giudicio di costei,
84  che è occulto come in erba l'angue.

85  Vostro saver non ha contasto a lei:
86  questa provede, giudica, e persegue
87  suo regno come il loro li altri dèi.

88  Le sue permutazion non hanno triegue:
89  necessità la fa esser veloce;
90  sì spesso vien chi vicenda consegue.

91  Quest' è colei ch'è tanto posta in croce
92  pur da color che le dovrien dar lode,
93  dandole biasmo a torto e mala voce;

94  ma ella s'è beata e ciò non ode:
95  con l'altre prime creature lieta
96  volve sua spera e beata si gode.

61  Now canst thou, Son, behold the transient farce
62  Of goods that are committed unto Fortune,
63  For which the human race each other buffet;

64  For all the gold that is beneath the moon,
65  Or ever has been, of these weary souls
66  Could never make a single one repose."

67  "Master," I said to him, "now tell me also
68  What is this Fortune which thou speakest of,
69  That has the world's goods so within its clutches?"

70  And he to me: "O creatures imbecile,
71  What ignorance is this which doth beset you?
72  Now will I have thee learn my judgment of her.

73  He whose omniscience everything transcends
74  The heavens created, and gave who should guide them,
75  That every part to every part may shine,

76  Distributing the light in equal measure;
77  He in like manner to the mundane splendours
78  Ordained a general ministress and guide,

79  That she might change at times the empty treasures
80  From race to race, from one blood to another,
81  Beyond resistance of all human wisdom.

82  Therefore one people triumphs, and another
83  Languishes, in pursuance of her judgment,
84  Which hidden is, as in the grass a serpent.

85  our knowledge has no counterstand against her;
86  She makes provision, judges, and pursues
87  Her governance, as theirs the other gods.

88  Her permutations have not any truce;
89  Necessity makes her precipitate,
90  So often cometh who his turn obtains.

91  And this is she who is so crucified
92  Even by those who ought to give her praise,
93  Giving her blame amiss, and bad repute.

94  But she is blissful, and she hears it not;
95  Among the other primal creatures gladsome
96  She turns her sphere, and blissful she rejoices.

This is Virgil's third lesson of the canto, a teaching on the Goddess Fortuna, who turns her sphere, and blissful she rejoices — line 96 — (volve sua spera e beata si gode).  The moral question is: How can the operations of chance be morally possible in a cosmos created and run by an omnipotent, omni-benevolent, omni-present, and omniscient God?   Consider the following commentary by Casini/Barbi concerning the High Middle Age's conception of fortune:

A given human being may typically move, along eight points on Fortune's wheel, from humility, to patience, to peace, to riches, to pride, to impatience, to war, to poverty. This is a typical 'ride' of anyone tied to Fortune's wheel, ending back at the starting point. 
 
Fortune in the Commedia, and in Virgil's speech, is not what we would call random, or the product of coincidence or chance.  It is ordained, and Fortuna has been authorized to judge and provide (provede, line 83), that is to say, fortune is a product of foreseeing by Divine Providence (which is what the word Providence means: foreseeing).  In this she is God-like, (line 87), and has, unlike messenger angels, for example, executive powers.  In brief, She can decide who gets what and when.  She is God's left hand, his female counterpart, the Binah Sephirot (sephirot = wheel), to return to our Kabbalistic metaphor, which might be another way of saying that she is the hidden, esoteric or occult aspect of Providence, like a serpent in the grass (line 84).  The fact that the text makes this simile, links her to what we would ordinarily call Devilish — incomprehensible evil and mischance, as incomprehensible good is called a blessing or grace.  In contrast to Chokmah on the Tree of Life, who represents wisdom, She is synonymous with understanding.  But this understanding should not be construed as any possibility of foreknowledge of her actions.  There is much that can be understood in hindsight, that are not at the same time predictive: Evolution, for example.  This is the kind of understanding we seem to be hearing about here.  It is an understanding of the emotional stance that humans should take when they are being spun about in Fortuna's vicissitudes.  What strikes me about Virgil's speech is it's Buddhistic aspect.  Fortuna is blissful, specifically blessed with joy in executing her duties (line 96), and by implication, we should not condemn her, or crucify her (lines 91 - 93) with blame, but rather praise her for teaching us that everything in this sublunar, mutable world is temporary and vanishing.  As our model of understanding, She is an exemplar of the joy of primal creatures, each of which is its own depository of God's equally distributed light.  If we would share in Her bliss, we would be as She is, light receiving light, and we would rejoice at any chance that comes to us, because every chance that comes to us teaches us the path of beatitude.  In line 94, Virgil says she is blissful, and hears not (ma ella s'è beata e ciò non ode), and we remember Canto II of the Inferno, where Beatrice was also impervious to suffering in her own person.  Fortuna seems also to be that.  But taking her bliss one step further, unlike Beatrice, who can hear of and respond to the sufferings of others, Fortuna cannot hear, or will not hear, of such sufferings.  And as we know from the hear/see motif displayed through these early cantos, not to hear, is not to see: hence Fortuna, like Justice, is often depicted as blindfolded.  

There are many exquisite details in Virgil's explication.  Lines 88 - 89: Her permutations have not any truce;/ Necessity makes her precipitate (Le sue permutazion non hanno triegue: / necessità la fa esser veloce ... literally: Necessity has caused her to be speedy).  In other words, the bullet that hits you you never hear or see coming, change being always swifter than our ability to track its permutations.  We also have here the Life is War metaphor.  Fortuna never makes a truce.  And perhaps this is a good place to say that we could arrange the entire Commedia into three basic metaphors for life:

Life is war — Inferno
Life is school — Purgatorio
Life is play — Paradiso

Finally, there are a couple of tropes regarding Virgil's teaching style, which gives us some insight into what Dante, the poet, considers, pertinent to instructing a tyro.  The first is a strong denunciation of any ignorance on the chela's part (lines 70 - 72).  The student offends himself by continuing in ignorance, a clear denunciation of the old adage: Ignorance is bliss.  And in this stanza too is a wonderful example of figurative speech in the word imbocchare (l'imbocche — to put it in your mouth), which is literally the teacher, like a mother bird, putting the teaching in the mouth of her chick, the student — so — words as worms.  One could also interpret this as a breath to breath transference, a resuscitation that is an inspiration.

One of the easier things — but still not easy — to do when commenting on Dante is to hone in on the details, and to finally begin to realize just how interwoven those details are with one another.  But we should not be ignorant of the fact that a certain tone, an impression, an overall morphology is constantly insinuating itself into the reader's consciousness.  As readers we get a Copernican worldview in which everything is enwombed or ensphered, and the old adage of the High Middle Ages that God is a circle whose center is everywhere and whose circumference is nowhere begins to assert its inexorable allure.  In short, to use an alchemical term, alive or dead, we remain in the round glass retort of God's vigilance and love.  It is a bit like being inside one of those glass souvenirs that you swirl so as to make a blizzard of artificial snow, our souls after death, and our bodies in life, always moving through unseen currents of circles, spirals, corkscrews, vortices, wheels, eddies, with, in this case, the Goddess Fortuna as the one who swirls the sphere.  The point is is that there is always a feeling in Dante of being inside something, moving through a vessel, the sky itself not being an openness, or even a beyond, but the dome of an imperium which is itself inside another sphere, and so on, until we reach the circle of the fixed stars.  What this might mean is that in the retort, there is no actual randomness, but only relative degrees of control or movement along currents and paths which are all inside that sphere — our souls a flow of God's breath, which circulates constantly according to that will, either as angels singing praises around a divine throne, or as malefactors exiled in the cyclonic gestures of hell.  Compare the Commedia to The Canterbury Tales.  In Chaucer there is always this openness — anything can happen, and there is no moral center.  Moreover, the tone is ironic, and even tales like The Knight's Tale, not ironic in itself, is undercut by the irony of The Miller's Tale which often follows it.  In Dante, the sense is that we never leave that moral center, and even the end of the poem is a dive deeper into the folds of the Rosa Mistica, the soul itself subsumed in the center's center.  I would even go so far as to say, that even in the worst parts of the Inferno, where the punishments and atmospheres are horrendous, disgusting, torturous, and so forth, there remains a feeling of being at home in the Center which is Everywhere.  It is perhaps Dante's great gift to we post-moderns, who live in a scattering random spray of unpredictable events and circumstances, that reading him infuses us once again with the feeling of Divine Order, the feeling that we are never outside the circle of God's care, or as Blake says: "God is everywhere, even in the depths of Hell," and where even Fortune is a wheel whose turning continually pulls us towards this center which is home.    
 
97  Or discendiamo omai a maggior pieta;
98  già ogne stella cade che saliva
99  quand' io mi mossi, e 'l troppo star si vieta.”

100  Noi ricidemmo il cerchio a l'altra riva
101  sovr' una fonte che bolle e riversa
102  per un fossato che da lei deriva.

103  L'acqua era buia assai più che persa;
104  e noi, in compagnia de l'onde bige,
105  intrammo giù per una via diversa.

106  In la palude va c'ha nome Stige
107  questo tristo ruscel, quand' è disceso
108  al piè de le maligne piagge grige.

109  E io, che di mirare stava inteso,
110  vidi genti fangose in quel pantano,
111  ignude tutte, con sembiante offeso.

112  Queste si percotean non pur con mano,
113  ma con la testa e col petto e coi piedi,
114  troncandosi co' denti a brano a brano.

115  Lo buon maestro disse: “Figlio, or vedi
116  l'anime di color cui vinse l'ira;
117  e anche vo' che tu per certo credi

118  che sotto l'acqua è gente che sospira,
119  e fanno pullular quest' acqua al summo,
120  come l'occhio ti dice, u' che s'aggira.

121  Fitti nel limo dicon: 'Tristi fummo
122  ne l'aere dolce che dal sol s'allegra,
123  portando dentro accidïoso fummo:

124  or ci attristiam ne la belletta negra.'
125  Quest' inno si gorgoglian ne la strozza,
126  ché dir nol posson con parola integra.”
97  Let us descend now unto greater woe;
98  Already sinks each star that was ascending
99  When I set out, and loitering is forbidden."
100  We crossed the circle to the other bank,
101  Near to a fount that boils, and pours itself
102  Along a gully that runs out of it.
103  The water was more sombre far than perse;
104  And we, in company with the dusky waves,
105  Made entrance downward by a path uncouth.
106  A marsh it makes, which has the name of Styx,
107  This tristful brooklet, when it has descended
108  Down to the foot of the malign gray shores.
109  And I, who stood intent upon beholding,
110  Saw people mud-besprent in that lagoon,
111  All of them naked and with angry look.
112  They smote each other not alone with hands,
113  But with the head and with the breast and feet,
114  Tearing each other piecemeal with their teeth.
115  Said the good Master: "Son, thou now beholdest
116  The souls of those whom anger overcame;
117  And likewise I would have thee know for certain
118  Beneath the water people are who sigh
119  And make this water bubble at the surface,
120  As the eye tells thee wheresoe'er it turns.
121  Fixed in the mire they say, 'We sullen were
122  In the sweet air, which by the sun is gladdened,
123  Bearing within ourselves the sluggish reek;
124  Now we are sullen in this sable mire.'
125  This hymn do they keep gurgling in their throats,
126  For with unbroken words they cannot say it."
Yeat's line "What's water but the generated soul," comes to mind as the poet protagonists descend along the rivulet of the Styx, following its sluggish course to a gaseous swamp.  Along this downward way, they encounter as a sort of symmetrical bookend to the opening of the canto with the Spenders and Hoarders, this second bookend being the Wrathful and Sullen.  It is easy enough to understand the battle of the wrathful, those people who are what they call in Neuro-linguistic Programming polarity responders.  If you say it's a nice day, they say it's rotten.  If you say it's black, they say it's white.  Having reduced their entire personalities to this residue of constant rage, their reactivity dooms them to perpetual war with those who are like themselves, or with other aspects of themselves.  They are naked, because the usual ornaments of clothes, i.e., civilized tact, modesty, and manners have been stripped from them, and the text makes it clear that their war is not guided by any subterranean set of Queensbury rules — theirs is just no holds barred cage-fighting, and to make it even more primitive, and disgusting, they tear themselves limb from limb (brano a brano) with their teeth.  They are nowhere as pure as animals — because an animal's violence is about obtaining food or sex — and their violence is only the pointless expression of ire.
While the Wrathful fight with each other, their counterparts, the Sullen, let their anger crater inward, as a sort of blackhole of surliness, which depresses everyone around them.  Like the gluttons we saw in Canto VI (the third circle), they are submerged — out of sight — except for the bubbles that reveal their ineffectual attempts at speech.  Sullenness and gluttony share this attribute: they are errors that lead to torpor, to a cess pool, where healthy circulation is arrested, and only a continual sinking in the mire is possible.  If the glutton is submerged in his own filth, the sullen are drowned in their own rancor.
We began this canto with Pluto's nonsense curses and we end it with the even greater inarticulateness of the sullen, whose words die in their throats, only to be released as noxious belches.   
127  Così girammo de la lorda pozza
128  grand' arco, tra la ripa secca e 'l mézzo,
129  con li occhi vòlti a chi del fango ingozza.

130  Venimmo al piè d'una torre al da sezzo.

127  Thus we went circling round the filthy fen
128  A great arc 'twixt the dry bank and the swamp,
129  With eyes turned unto those who gorge the mire;

130  Unto the foot of a tower we came at last.

The last of this canto is a bridge to the next, but there is still the circling motif (Così girammo de la lorda pozza — thus we went circling round the filthy den) to bring us there, and the last line (130), with its emphasis Coming on foot (Venimmo al piè) shows Dante's subtle skill in arranging proportions.  We look down to the swamp and the feet, but up to the tower, which has grown from this swamp, as if from a malevolent seed, as a beacon of something more horrible to come.   We also see this gullet-like reference to the passage through hell in the phrase con li occhi vòlti a chi del fango ingozza (with eyes turned to those which gorge the mire).  Again we are inside the body of hell, a body which is swallowing us like a bolus of undigestible food — inside, down, and around and around, that's the direction we keep heading.


Canto VIII

Bridge Material

The Towers and their signaling

Possible retrograde time: returning to the confrontation with Phlegyas

Confrontation with Filippo Argenti

Dante's denunciation of Argenti, Virgil's praise, and Dante's wish to see Argenti's punishment

Passage to Dis

Scene at the entrance of Dis, the flashback ended, and the possible return of progressive time.  Testing of faith, and recoiling back to doubt and to previous sections of the Inferno

Preliminary notes: Some commentators say that the approach to the tower ending Canto VII, and the towers referred to at the beginning of this Canto, are in real progressive time, and the confrontation with Phlegyas and Argenti, and the passage across the Styx are in retrograde time, or, in modern parlance, flashbacks.  This primarily is due to the fact that the tower is presumed to be a part of the walled city of Dis.  However, if there is a forward signaling tower not attached to the city's walls, there is no need to assume that the Phlegyas and Argenti episodes are flashbacks.  Either interpretation does not appreciably change the readings of these episodes, or even Dante's view of time, since we indeed have had flashbacks before, for example, in Virgil's recounting of Beatrice's intervention in Canto II of Inferno.

We should also note at the outset that this is a political canto, Argenti was a political player, possibly involved in Dante's exile, and the confiscation of his property, and of course there is the city of Dis itself, whose citizens are the fallen, rebellious angels.  We should also remember that the word politics is derived from the word polis, and it refers to the city and the governing of the city, which in his life in Florence, was Dante's passion and profession.  He found out, as his protagonist and literary effigy in this canto finds out, that the polis cannot be managed by any individual, or group of individuals, or political party.  The polis is a all-consuming self-developing, self-annihilating entity, which uses its citizens according to the whims of Fortuna, that goddess praised by Virgil in the previous canto, whose actions, although Divinely ordained, may completely override the intentions and actions of human beings, whether virtuous or villainous.  Now, we, who live in live in the midst of political turmoil ourselves, have a spiritual lesson to learn from this whole canto, and what that lesson is, is embodied, rather cynically perhaps, in the entire fabric of these one-hundred and thirty lines of verse.

1  Io dico, seguitando, ch'assai prima
2  che noi fossimo al piè de l'alta torre,
3  li occhi nostri n'andar suso a la cima

4  per due fiammette che i vedemmo porre,
5  e un'altra da lungi render cenno,
6  tanto ch'a pena il potea l'occhio tòrre.

7  E io mi volsi al mar di tutto 'l senno;
8  dissi: “Questo che dice? e che risponde
9  quell' altro foco? e chi son quei che 'l fenno?”

10  Ed elli a me: “Su per le sucide onde
11  già scorgere puoi quello che s'aspetta,
12  se 'l fummo del pantan nol ti nasconde.”
1  I say, continuing, that long before
2  We to the foot of that high tower had come,
3  Our eyes went upward to the summit of it,
4  By reason of two flamelets we saw placed there,
5  And from afar another answer them,
6  So far, that hardly could the eye attain it.
7  And, to the sea of all discernment turned,
8  I said: "What sayeth this, and what respondeth
9  That other fire? and who are they that made it?"
10  And he to me: "Across the turbid waves
11  What is expected thou canst now discern,
12  If reek of the morass conceal it not."
Unlike the previous cantos (lust, gluttony) where a certain circle of hell was illuminated in the confines of one canto, in Canto VII, we passed from the circle of the hoarders and wastrels to the circle of the wrathful/sullen, and here, Dante, the author, with another peek behind the curtain, tells us we are continuing along that path.  The tower that we saw at the end of Canto VII is now approached, but now the tower has two signals flames at its summit, and the poet/protagonists see in the far distance a second tower signaling back.  Apparently, commentators have had quite a wrangle over the centuries trying to pin down just what this signaling is about, and, of course, what the towers themselves might "mean".
Here communications are not even the word-salad of Pluto, but have degenerated to an ambiguous primitive signaling.  The word eye(s) (occhi/occhio) appears in line 3, and also in line 6 — far apart, just like the towers themselves, and with two small flames at the top of a tower, it is easy to imagine that these flames are eyes atop the spine and torso of an inert body, so that we have two Giant Forms (to use Blakean terminology) signaling to each other without the human attribute of speech across the swamp of the Styx.  The etymology of the name Styx is from a Greek word stugien, meaning hateful.  And this, indeed, is a hateful place, literally full of the wrathful and sullen who are doomed to be mired in its mire.  But returning to the towers — what do the signals mean?  My interpretation is that the two flames are telling Phlegyas that two enemies are approaching.
