And he sets out in his small boat to intercept them.  Like the other monstrous guardians that the protagonists have encountered, he will try to prevent them from proceeding deeper into hell.  Occult literature almost always has guardians at the gate of forbidden, or at least dangerous knowledge, to prevent both intrusion and the misuse of that knowledge by those who are not ready for it.  The more profound the knowledge, or let us say, the experience which could lead to knowledge, the more fierce the guardian.      

13  Corda non pinse mai da sé saetta
14  che sì corresse via per l'aere snella,
15  com' io vidi una nave piccioletta

16  venir per l'acqua verso noi in quella,
17  sotto 'l governo d'un sol galeoto,
18  che gridava: “Or se' giunta, anima fella!”

19  “Flegïàs, Flegïàs, tu gridi a vòto”
20  disse lo mio segnore, “a questa volta:
21  più non ci avrai che sol passando il loto.”

22  Qual è colui che grande inganno ascolta
23  che li sia fatto, e poi se ne rammarca,
24  fecesi Flegïàs ne l'ira accolta.

25  Lo duca mio discese ne la barca,
26  e poi mi fece intrare appresso lui;
27  e sol quand' io fui dentro parve carca.

28  Tosto che 'l duca e io nel legno fui,
29  segando se ne va l'antica prora
30  de l'acqua più che non suol con altrui.

13  Cord never shot an arrow from itself
14  That sped away athwart the air so swift,
15  As I beheld a very little boat

16  Come o'er the water tow'rds us at that moment,
17  Under the guidance of a single pilot,
18  Who shouted, "Now art thou arrived, fell soul?"

19  "Phlegyas, Phlegyas, thou criest out in vain
20  For this once," said my Lord; "thou shalt not have us
21  Longer than in the passing of the slough."

22  As he who listens to some great deceit
23  That has been done to him, and then resents it,
24  Such became Phlegyas, in his gathered wrath.

25  My Guide descended down into the boat,
26  And then he made me enter after him,
27 And only when I entered seemed it laden.

28  Soon as the Guide and I were in the boat,
29  The antique prow goes on its way, dividing
30  More of the water than 'tis wont with others.

The confrontation with Phlegyas, like others we've seen with Charon, Minos, and Pluto is one wherein an adversary who comes to obstruct or punish, is turned into a reluctant ally, a strange mutation, in which the emotional energy of a perverted purpose is re-directed inwardly towards a positive goal: in this case spiritual transformation.  Here, as we shall see later in the canto, the transfromation is from self-destructive wrath to righteous wrath.  Phlegyas, a king, whose daughter was raped by Apollo (literally ravaged by the light), in an act of vengeance, burned down the Temple of Apollo at Delphi — a sin against the light, and for this transgression, he is doomed to an eternity of rage.  His job: to help punish the wrathful.  Phlegyas arrives in his small boat which travels swifter than an arrow in flight across the fetid waters.  Self-animated boats are a regular feature of the Commedia, and we might learn from this that these crafts stand for some kind of agency of fate, not quite alive in themselves, but not quite dead matter either.  In dreams, of course, one is quite familiar with this sort of quasi animation of objects, and not only in dreams.  Think of the sentimental attachment that one acquires about an object, or an article of clothing.  The things we have and the things we make both enable and restrict us in unexpected ways.  At any rate, whatever this boat is, it is not an entirely insubstantial shade, as are Virgil and Phlegyas, for it reacts physically to Dante's physicality when he steps into it, and it displaces more water (lines 27, 30).   Upon seeing the poet protagonists, Phlegyas shouts — I believe in a rather mechanical way — as if, like some sort of demonic, will-less automaton, he repeats the same phrase to all who arrive for his condemnation: “Or se' giunta, anima fella!” — Now art thou arrived, fell soul (line 18)).  He must only be addressing Virgil, for only Virgil is a soul, Dante being still a living person.  Does he know Virgil?  The word or — now, seems to imply something like: At last you have arrived, evil soul.  Virgil had written about him in the Aeneid, and placed him in Tartarus, so that might be the reference.  If so, Phlegyas, in a manner typical of him, wants his revenge, just as he wanted his revenge against Apollo.  But more than anything here, Phlegyas shows us that his moral world has reversed poles.  For him evil is good, good evil, as he reveals in lines 22 - 24, when he feels deceived and wrathful as soon as he discovers that he is confronted by reason and virtue, and not by sin.  Evil hates good, and good hates evil, and as we proceed in this canto, we see just how virulent that mutual hatred is.   

31  Mentre noi corravam la morta gora,
32  dinanzi mi si fece un pien di fango,
33  e disse: “Chi se' tu che vieni anzi ora?”

34  E io a lui: “S'i' vegno, non rimango;
35  ma tu chi se', che sì se' fatto brutto?”
36  Rispuose: “Vedi che son un che piango.”

37  E io a lui: “Con piangere e con lutto,
38  spirito maladetto, ti rimani;
39  ch'i' ti conosco, ancor sie lordo tutto.”

40  Allor distese al legno ambo le mani;
41  per che 'l maestro accorto lo sospinse,
42  dicendo: “Via costà con li altri cani!”

31  While we were running through the dead canal,
32  Uprose in front of me one full of mire,
33  And said, "Who 'rt thou that comest ere the hour?"

34  And I to him: "Although I come, I stay not;
35  But who art thou that hast become so squalid?"
36  "Thou seest that I am one who weeps," he answered.

37  And I to him: "With weeping and with wailing,
38  Thou spirit maledict, do thou remain;
39  For thee I know, though thou art all defiled."

40  Then stretched he both his hands unto the boat;
41  Whereat my wary Master thrust him back,
42  Saying, "Away there with the other dogs!"

As we have seen before, the encounter with — at this point — unnamed denizen of this swamp — this toilet — begins with the question of recognition and identity.  But something happens here with Dante that did not happen with Francesca or Ciacco.  Here when the sinner answers in lieu of his name, which we discover Dante already knows, he says, Vedi che son un che piango — thou seest that I am one who weeps.  And Dante, instead of sympathy, offers insult, and an angry hope for retribution.  Quite a change in the aspirant's, response.  Anger here meets anger, and we are reminded of the response that Phlegyas had when at first confronting the poets.  It's the same scene, in terms of confrontation, recognition, and defiance, but what a difference!  Gratuitous self-serving wrath is something quite different than righteous indignation — as St. Augustine has said, although the affect in a physiological sense is quite the same.  

The sinner tries to climb into the boat, and Virgil thrusts him back into the mire, again with an insult: Via costà con li altri cani! — Away there with the other dogs!  All of this is straight forward enough, but I want to make a little digression here on the insult itself, specifically, why is this sinner likened to a dog?  It might be argued that idiomatic expressions come ready to hand and that everybody knows what they mean without having to think about it.  That's true, but if we allow ourselves to delve into them, as we have also delved into expressions thought to be original, we find that a master, like Dante, uses these expressions with an exactitude by which his own genius is adept at utilizing the collective linguistic genius in ways that do not flatten the text with a trite expression, but which, on the contrary, give the reader pause, and occasions them to think more deeply about why such an idiom would have such common usage in the first place.  Grand shows of emotion are common with demagogues, and by saying what he says here, the sinner gives us a clue as to how he was in life, i.e., one who fabricates a response designed to give himself some advantage.  The talk of such people is only thought out to the extent that it is designed to influence the listener, not to the listener's advantage, or even to some mutual advantage, but solely for the speaker's selfish ends.  The speech lacks articulation and eloquence, and in that sense it resembles barking, yelping, growling, whining — and so forth — in short, it is the kind of speech that is dog-like in so far as only an affect is communicated — as with Pluto's outburst at the beginning of the previous canto — and it elicits a like affect in the listeners.  This is speech empty of content, designed often in political rhetoric to hide intent, and to drive the listener back to the most visceral and uncritical of responses.  It is the speech of the con.  In the myth of Pandora, she is sometimes described with the epithet "doggish."  And what exactly is such a dog?  Shameless.  Without inhibition dogs eat carrion, defecate, urinate, fornicate, sniff each other’s butts, spread disease, and when rabid, attack with indiscriminate rage.  And although dogs are often considered to be, of all animals, most like humans, because of all animals they are the most intimate in participating in human communities, families, and relationships, when humans are compared to them in a derogatory sense, as Virgil does here, then these negative attributes of the species come to mind, and we are repulsed. 

43  Lo collo poi con le braccia mi cinse;
44  basciommi 'l volto e disse: “Alma sdegnosa,
45  benedetta colei che 'n te s'incinse!

46  Quei fu al mondo persona orgogliosa;
47  bontà non è che sua memoria fregi:
48  così s'è l'ombra sua qui furïosa.

49  Quanti si tegnon or là sù gran regi
50  che qui staranno come porci in brago,
51  di sé lasciando orribili dispregi!”

52  E io: “Maestro, molto sarei vago
53  di vederlo attuffare in questa broda
54  prima che noi uscissimo del lago.”

55  Ed elli a me: “Avante che la proda
56  ti si lasci veder, tu sarai sazio:
57  di tal disïo convien che tu goda.”

58  Dopo ciò poco vid' io quello strazio
59  far di costui a le fangose genti,
60  che Dio ancor ne lodo e ne ringrazio.

61  Tutti gridavano: “A Filippo Argenti!”
62  e 'l fiorentino spirito bizzarro
63  in sé medesmo si volvea co' denti.

64  Quivi il lasciammo, che più non ne narro;
65  ma ne l'orecchie mi percosse un duolo,
66  per ch'io avante l'occhio intento sbarro.

43  Thereafter with his arms he clasped my neck;
44  He kissed my face, and said: "Disdainful soul,
45  Blessed be she who bore thee in her bosom.

46  That was an arrogant person in the world;
47  Goodness is none, that decks his memory;
48  So likewise here his shade is furious.

49  How many are esteemed great kings up there,
50  Who here shall be like unto swine in mire,
51  Leaving behind them horrible dispraises!"

52  And I: "My Master, much should I be pleased,
53  If I could see him soused into this broth,
54  Before we issue forth out of the lake."

55  And he to me: "Ere unto thee the shore
56  Reveal itself, thou shalt be satisfied;
57  Such a desire 'tis meet thou shouldst enjoy."

58  A little after that, I saw such havoc
59  Made of him by the people of the mire,
60  That still I praise and thank my God for it.

61  They all were shouting, "At Philippo Argenti!"
62  And that exasperate spirit Florentine
63  Turned round upon himself with his own teeth.

64  We left him there, and more of him I tell not;
65  But on mine ears there smote a lamentation,
66  Whence forward I intent unbar mine eyes.

So many issues — poetic, moral, theological, political, familial — are summoned forth by these 24 lines, perhaps it would be best to try to summarize them in the form of a few questions.  I'm going to use the Christian theological word sinner, because that is how Dante refers to them.  But if the reader would prefer another term: the waywards, the transgressors, the criminally insane, and so forth, then she or he should feel free to substitute them.  One could write a book on any of these questions — and people have found — and still find that such questions have about them a proliferating quality which eludes definitive resolutions.  What Dante does here, and elsewhere throughout the Commedia, is present a tableaux that is contextual and textual.  That is to say, as in a dream, certain language and image games are set in dynamic motion to bedevil, engage, alert, and evolve those who encounter that tableaux.  Let us consider some of the features of that tableaux. 

Dante rejects the sinner, wishes him continued punishment, and although the soul is known to him, he refuses to name him, or give the sinner the comfort of fame or identity.

Virgil embraces Dante for his action, with an epithet echoing a reference to Jesus as the fruit of Mary's womb —  a reference to a divine personage as part of a human community or family.

Virgil thrusts the sinner back into the mire, with the other "dogs", in effect excluding the sinner from the human family with its divine connections.

Virgil tells of people in positions of power who enjoyed approbation on earth, and who are now degraded in hell — yet they continue to suffer the dispraises of infamy which presumably increases their hellish reward.  (Again the motif of praise or dispraise as instrument of fame or infamy.)

Dante, the protagonist, asks his mentor if he might have the privilege of seeing the sinner punished.  Virgil promises that boon; the sinner is identified and punished further by the other sinners, and also by biting himself.  Dante, thanks God for the enjoyment he has received, and continues to take delight in the memory of this enjoyment as if his act of Schadenfreude is in itself an ongoing blessing.

Dante hears a crescendoing lamentation, and deliberately and intently tries to see those who are in distress.

Some questions which arise from this tableaux: 
 
What should be the response of the righteous to the punishment of the sinner?  Sympathy? — as with Dante's sympathy for Francesca and Ciacco —  or anger? — as it is here. 

Should the righteous be involved in the punishment of the sinner?

Is it a virtue to condemn and punish?

Is there a point when all human attributes are consumed by sin, and the sinner falls out of the human family, becoming a cur, or rabid dog, as Virgil refers to Argenti here?

Does one's influence as a leader, a king, a prelate, or maybe even a poet, subject one to greater praise or punishment according to the fruits of one's actions or the purity or evil of one's intentions.

Should the righteous find delight in seeing the pain of transgressors?  

Can one visit, see, or read about hell, not for edification, but for delight?  

Does an affect — in this case of wrath — differ according to whether the wrath has a righteous or insidious purpose?

Is this righteous anger a necessary stage in a journey toward transcendence, where presumably, like Beatrice, the sufferings of hell no longer disturb the peace of beatitude? 

Should sinners be used for the Divine purpose of punishing one another?  Should sinners be used to punish themselves?

How is the post-mortem or post-offense affected by the praise or condemnation of others, specifically the communities of the living, or the non-offenders?

How does poetry evoke these issues?  And how does a poetic embodiment of them differ from a theological, psychological, or political didactic or propagandistic prose exhibition?  

Can we discern if the poet's intent is ironic, or is only the reader's interpretation ironic, parodic, or straightforward?

How does what has or will happen in the poem prior to or after this tableaux affect its meaning or our interpretation?

One of the reasons that the poet Dante is as great as he is, and his poem has had as much lasting influence as it has had, is that its text invades the reader's psyche and elicits these proliferating questions.  That is why the text is not only transcendent in itself, but a catalyst for the reader's transcendence.  That is why exegesis is both necessary and inevitable for any serious reading of the poem.  It would be easily possible for me, or any reader, to return to this brief tableaux, and these questions, and explicate all of these issues with references inside the poem and/or with events and readings suggested by the poem or by the day's news, or historically, or by episodes in my own or any other person's life.  That is the power of this poetry: it refuses finality, and invites a plunge into infinity.  It exercises the reader's reason, imagination, emotions, and moral sense in ways that continue to engage even after the book is closed.  The reading of this text can never be completed, and what's more, we never want it to be completed.   

67  Lo buon maestro disse: “Omai, figliuolo,
68  'appressa la città c'ha nome Dite,
69  coi gravi cittadin, col grande stuolo.”

70  E io: “Maestro, già le sue meschite
71  là entro certe ne la valle cerno,
72  vermiglie come se di foco uscite

73  fossero.” Ed ei mi disse: “Il foco etterno
74  ch'entro l'affoca le dimostra rosse,
75  come tu vedi in questo basso inferno.”

76  Noi pur giugnemmo dentro a l'alte fosse
77  che vallan quella terra sconsolata:
78  le mura mi parean che ferro fosse.

79  Non sanza prima far grande aggirata,
80  venimmo in parte dove il nocchier forte
81  “Usciteci,” gridò: “qui è l'intrata.”

67  And the good Master said: "Even now, my Son,
68  The city draweth near whose name is Dis,
69  With the grave citizens, with the great throng."

70  And I: "Its mosques already, Master, clearly
71  Within there in the valley I discern
72  Vermilion, as if issuing from the fire

73  They were." And he to me: "The fire eternal
74  That kindles them within makes them look red,
75  As thou beholdest in this nether Hell."

76  Then we arrived within the moats profound,
77  That circumvallate that disconsolate city;
78  The walls appeared to me to be of iron.

79  Not without making first a circuit wide,
80  We came unto a place where loud the pilot
81  Cried out to us, "Debark, here is the entrance."

You are the director of a movie, and you have just finished a scene in which your two protagonists are in a small boat piloted at great speed through murky, sewage water, by a resentful demon who would do harm if he dared.  Suddenly an accusatory voice rings out and asks one of your heroes, focusing on the weaker of the two, who he thinks he is, and why is he here.  A disgustingly squalid body rises out of the muck.  Quick close-up cuts from a bemired anguished face, and a horrified angry face.  There are contending shouts, the bemired one attempts to climb into the boat, he is thrust back with curses, and creatures like the one you have just spurned rise out of the festering swamp, and attack the would-be interloper, shouting his name, swirling through the waters in fast action close-ups, grimacing faces, body and face wounds, teeth, nails, fists, the one under attack is even biting himself — you want to make this struggle as desperate and as dangerous as great crocodiles fighting to the death.  Your protagonists are breathing heavily, the crocks slide under the gurgling reek of the swamp water, the horrible lamentations of the their cries begin to fade as your craft distances itself from them.  Now the camera slows and makes long pans of a distant shore, the walls are of molten iron, and the towers of this city in the distance loom upward through the gloom as the great minarets of a hostile creed.  Everything glows vermillion or darkens to red, casting the twisting reflections of flame on the surly waters.  The pan pulls back and up, and the screen shows just how infinitesimal the little boat  is in comparison to the great demonic city.  Now the shot changes to what seems a long slow glide along an interminable glowing wall.  The camera circles round as the boat navigates a twisting, circling series of dead canals which serve as moats to defend the city.  The weaker protagonist looks aghast; he looks back, but the way back is now shrouded in darkness.  The older protagonist looks steadfast, but concerned.  The pilot of the boat, with an incensed expression, swings the craft round in a wide arc, pulls into a suddenly appearing slip, and shouts for his passengers to get out.  A huge gate looms up and up, like a solid wall of flames woven more tightly than any chainmail.  The background music, ominous and pounding, rises to a crescendo.  You have arrived at Dis.

Essentially, what the text is doing here, in these 30 lines, is slowing down, and giving us a long, alarming look at the City of Dis, and this is Dante's great skill, managing mood, through violence and tension, and subtly juggling  proportionalities from close to far, fast to slow, small to large in such a way that that mood, and in this case all the anxiety which goes with, is transferred to the reader.  Everything is masterfully paced, and background and foreground, relationships and geography, emotions and reason, action and dialog, philosophy and description shuffle from one to another with a stage magician's legerdemain.

Note: All through the Commedia Time and Space have been handled in a curious way, in so far as Time, while mostly following a sequential order at the poets move through the landscape of the dead, outpaces itself.  Everywhere the space is clearly much too large for the amount of time allotted for its traversal.  In other words, Time is expanded enormously, minutes and hours, conforming to the immense distances of the spaces described.  I suspect that this effect is a common one in any reading or fiction, in that the so-called dramatic unities are usually accepted unconsciously by the reader because this is also a feature of memory, shrinking or expanding time and space in relation to one another to match an emotion, which unfolds as quickly or slowly in whatever space it needs to fulfill itself.    

82  Io vidi più di mille in su le porte
83  da ciel piovuti, che stizzosamente
84  dicean: “Chi è costui che sanza morte

85  va per lo regno de la morta gente?”
86  E 'l savio mio maestro fece segno
87  di voler lor parlar segretamente.

88  Allor chiusero un poco il gran disdegno
89  e disser: “Vien tu solo, e quei sen vada
90  che sì ardito intrò per questo regno.

91  Sol si ritorni per la folle strada:
92  pruovi, se sa; ché tu qui rimarrai,
93  che li ha' iscorta sì buia contrada.”

82  More than a thousand at the gates I saw
83  Out of the Heavens rained down, who angrily
84  Were saying, "Who is this that without death

85  Goes through the kingdom of the people dead?"
86  And my sagacious Master made a sign
87  Of wishing secretly to speak with them.

88  A little then they quelled their great disdain,
89  And said: "Come thou alone, and he begone
90  Who has so boldly entered these dominions.

91  Let him return alone by his mad road;
92  Try, if he can; for thou shalt here remain,
93  Who hast escorted him through such dark regions."

Now all those helpless birds that were buffeted about in the circle of lust have become more than a thousand hellish harpies, raining down from the dark smoke billows of an ironic heaven underlit from the flames of this city of molten iron.  It is almost as if these demons were some kind of evil condensate of the toxic smoke.  And once again the challenge comes: Who is this that without death goes through the kingdom of the people dead — Chi è costui che sanza morte / va per lo regno de la morta gente?”  The tercets run together, so that the speed of the poetry, as it had slowed to express the awesome dimensions of the terrible city, now picks up again, as this cloud of the rebellious, fallen angels hovers over the protagonists, like a Greek chorus in the rack of heaven, dissonantly declaiming.  It is the first time the the poets have been confronted not by a single demon, but by a huge squadron of them.  And now, also for the first time in the their descent, the poets are not only threatened as a pair, but are each singled out for a threat designed most to terrify them.  Dante is told to retrace his steps on the mad road (la folle strada) he has taken to this place — which of course the reader will see at once is impossible, for he and his guide have already crossed too many Rubicons, already left too many angry guardians behind them, and Virgil is told that here, in Dis, he will remain, no longer one of the unpunished damned of limbo, but doomed to reside in this land of interminable tortures.
 
94  Pensa, lettor, se io mi sconfortai
95  nel suon de le parole maladette,
96  ché non credetti ritornarci mai.

97  “O caro duca mio, che più di sette
98  volte m'hai sicurtà renduta e tratto
99  d'alto periglio che 'ncontra mi stette,

100  non mi lasciar,” diss' io, “così disfatto;
101  e se 'l passar più oltre ci è negato,
102  ritroviam l'orme nostre insieme ratto.”

103  E quel segnor che lì m'avea menato,
104  mi disse: “Non temer; ché 'l nostro passo
105  non ci può tòrre alcun: da tal n'è dato.

106  Ma qui m'attendi, e lo spirito lasso
107  conforta e ciba di speranza buona,
108  ch'i' non ti lascerò nel mondo basso.”

109  Così sen va, e quivi m'abbandona
110  lo dolce padre, e io rimagno in forse,
111  che sì e no nel capo mi tenciona.

94  Think, Reader, if I was discomforted
95  At utterance of the accursed words;
96  For never to return here I believed.

97  "O my dear Guide, who more than seven times
98  Hast rendered me security, and drawn me
99  From imminent peril that before me stood,

100  Do not desert me," said I, "thus undone;
101  And if the going farther be denied us,
102  Let us retrace our steps together swiftly."

103  And that Lord, who had led me thitherward,
104  Said unto me: "Fear not; because our passage
105  None can take from us, it by Such is given.

106  But here await me, and thy weary spirit
107  Comfort and nourish with a better hope;
108  For in this nether world I will not leave thee."

109  So onward goes and there abandons me
110  My Father sweet, and I remain in doubt,
111  For No and Yes within my head contend.

The poets finally reach an insurmountable obstacle.  And that is the main question that occupies the text for the remainder of this canto.  Back and forth, up and down, round and round — the morphological components  of the text, the reader's attention from the very first of the canto going down to the feet of the protagonists and up to the flame-signals at the top of the tower, going round and round as they circumnavigate Dis in Phlegyas boat, and here, most tellingly, going back and forth as Virgil goes to the gates to speak to the demons, and then back to Dante.  So the aspirant, Dante, is tossed back and forth on the horns of a double-bind dilemma.  Terrified, he realizes in line 96 that going back is impossible, and yet later he does suggest in line 102 that they quickly retrace their steps.  There is, in addition, a back and forth dialogue between the reader and the writer, as the text makes a direct appeal to the reader to share the aspirant/protagonist's feelings about this impasse (line 94).  This is a test of faith.  Up to now the aspirant could always rely on Virgil's reason and the journey's divine sanctioning to overcome the demons who stood in the way of their spiritual progress.  But that is not the case here as they attempt to penetrate the deepest levels of hell.  No or Yes contend with equal ferocity in the condition of DOUBT (line 111), and we are reminded as we face these hordes of fallen angels of the other place in the text where we have met hordes of angels, namely, in Canto III, where the indecisive angels were anguishing in the ante-room of hell.  Again, the reader's attention, is taken back.  It's significant too that this No or Yes battle takes place in the head (nel capo) presumably where reason should reside, and not in the heart, the seat of emotion.  To be abandoned by reason throws the emotions into a Charybdis sea of oscillations.

112  Udir non potti quello ch'a lor porse;
113  ma ei non stette là con essi guari,
114  che ciascun dentro a pruova si ricorse.

115  Chiuser le porte que' nostri avversari
116  nel petto al mio segnor, che fuor rimase
117  e rivolsesi a me con passi rari.

118  Li occhi a la terra e le ciglia avea rase
119  d'ogne baldanza, e dicea ne' sospiri:
120  “Chi m'ha negate le dolenti case!”

121  E a me disse: “Tu, perch' io m'adiri,
122  non sbigottir, ch'io vincerò la prova,
123  qual ch'a la difension dentro s'aggiri.

124  Questa lor tracotanza non è nova;
125  ché già l'usaro a men segreta porta,
126  la qual sanza serrame ancor si trova.

127  Sovr' essa vedestù la scritta morta:
128  e già di qua da lei discende l'erta,
129  passando per li cerchi sanza scorta,

130  tal che per lui ne fia la terra aperta.”

112  I could not hear what he proposed to them;
113  But with them there he did not linger long,
114  Ere each within in rivalry ran back.

115  They closed the portals, those our adversaries,
116  On my Lord's breast, who had remained without
117  And turned to me with footsteps far between.

118  His eyes cast down, his forehead shorn had he
119  Of all its boldness, and he said, with sighs,
120  "Who has denied to me the dolesome houses?"

121  And unto me: "Thou, because I am angry,
122  Fear not, for I will conquer in the trial,
123  Whatever for defence within be planned.

124  This arrogance of theirs is nothing new;
125  For once they used it at less secret gate,
126  Which finds itself without a fastening still.

127  O'er it didst thou behold the dead inscription;
128  And now this side of it descends the steep,
129  Passing across the circles without escort,

130  One by whose means the city shall be opened."

How should the city, the body-politic, this thing which takes on a life of its own — more the Moloch here which devours its citizens than a mother who nourishes them — be penetrated?  This is the final question of Canto VIII.  How should the body-politic be opened to our understanding?  And is it, this body politic of hell, something that can be lived through, if not in, by one, who by the operations of fate — i.e. Fortuna — finds himself there, or finds himself, as Dante did, exiled from there.   Someone is coming, alone, to break this lock, and reveal the guts of this mystery, which has remained impervious to reason.  But for now, we do not know who this someone is, so this a time of waiting, a time of immersing oneself in the condition of expectation, a time when one must rely on faith, not facts.  This is the condition of the protagonists and the reader at the end of the this canto.

Let's look at some of the text's details and see how Dante, the poet, casts the reader about in these final lines, literally turning our minds back to previous episodes in the Inferno, and throwing up barriers to any vision that we might have of a way forward in the narrative.  The text goes backward, recoils in a way, to gather the strength of faith, and wait, in a state of unresolve, but with faith, on how we might eventually be able to proceed.  As Virgil abandons his protégé to have a parley with the demons, there is a device wherein the aspirant cannot hear the results of that conversation.  I am reminded of all those scenes in Hitchcock movies where tension is ratcheted up when the protagonists cannot hear a conversation, perhaps because it is behind a sheet of glass or spoken in a foreign language, and that is what happens here too (line 112).  The gate is shut on Virgil's chest (petto), the seat of the heart, the emotions, and as Virgil goes back to his protégé, the demons to go back (si recorse), as the translator puts  it in rivalry - a pruova, presumably squabbling with one another, but also testing, proving, the faith of the protagonists with their obstinate refusal.  And just as the reader went back to Canto III to the doubting indecisive angels, here, when Virgil returns with the Christ-like phrase Ch'i m'ha negate le dolente case (who has denied to me the dolesome houses), we think of the doubt that Jesus expressed in his last moments of agony on the cross: Oh Lord, why hast thou forsaken me, where the Christ himself goes back to quote from Psalms 22:1.  And although Virgil states that they will get around (s'aggiri) whatever defense the demons have mounted, it will not be by his power, the power of reason, that they will be able to do so.  Virgil, in this circle of the wrathful, has succumbed to wrath (line 121), and wrath is Kryptonite to reason.  The canto ends as Virgil promises Dante that they are to await the one who comes alone across the wastes of hell to rescue them, which takes us back to Canto IV, where Christ is seen harrowing hell, and rescuing the unbaptized but worthy souls born before the incarnation.  Virgil takes Dante's mind back to the entrance to hell, a gate that Christ permanently opened, the operational word being segreta (secret), because the spiritual path is closed, secret, to those who have not tested their faith and accepted the unknowable aspects of experience, as we saw also back in Canto VII, with the discussion of Fortune.  And here we are, waiting, waiting, waiting, in the back and forth, up and down, round and round condition of uncertainty, but waiting in faith for our salvation.  This retrograde motion of the reader's attention which began this canto with events preceding those of the previous canto, mainly the approach to the tower, now also symmetrically ends it.

Canto IX
Structural armature:

Hypnotic Induction and a cry for help

Virgil's doubt, Dante's fear

Virgil's story about his previous visit to Hell's depths
	the comparison between magic and miracle, 
	attempting to compel fate or allowing grace to unfold

The appearance of the messanger

The entrance into the City of Dis and the view of the sepulchers of the heresiarchs

1  Quel color che viltà di fuor mi pinse
2  veggendo il duca mio tornare in volta,
3  più tosto dentro il suo novo ristrinse.

4  Attento si fermò com' uom ch'ascolta;
5  ché l'occhio nol potea menare a lunga
6  per l'aere nero e per la nebbia folta.

7  That hue which cowardice brought out on me,
8  Beholding my Conductor backward turn,
9  Sooner repressed within him his new colour.

10  He stopped attentive, like a man who listens,
11  Because the eye could not conduct him far
12  Through the black air, and through the heavy fog.

The canto starts with an extreme visual close-up, first of Dante's face, then of Virgil’s:  Dante's the color of fear, Virgil's presumably flushed from the anger he displayed when repulsed by the demons at the gate of Dis.  A white/red contrast, but Virgil averts his face (tonare in volta), and composes himself to such a degree that the color goes from his face, and yet, as we shall see as we proceed in the next few lines, the doubt from his split mind is still there: i.e., Was Beatrice wrong about the protected and ordained nature of their quest?  Then, after this close-up in the visual modality, we switch to listening, because the black air and thick fog (l'aere e per nebbia folta), hamper the operations of the eyes.  This then is the hear/see or see/hear motif which we have read of before throughout these first cantos of the Inferno, and I think it's clear that Dante understands that hearing words prompts the visual imagination, because this is not vision in the physical world, but the imaginative one.  How do we know this?  Because it would be impossible to physically see the subtle changes in skin pallor in black air and thick fog.  One may close one's eyes in meditation to the outward world, but not one's ears, and so, in the absence of physical sight, Virgil depends on listening, as the reader should too, because listening to the text is the physical sensory act which enables us to see what the poet is telling us, and to enter with an imaginative body the imaginative landscape of the work.  When we "see" Virgil cock his head to listen, we, the readers, should follow suit, sharpening our attention to the sounds of the words.  The closed eyes, the mastering of emotion and breath, the focused listening, these are elements of an hypnotic induction, and so the poem casts its spell.

7  “Pur a noi converrà vincer la punga,”
8  cominciò el, “se non... Tal ne s'offerse ... 
9  Oh quanto tarda a me ch'altri qui giunga!” 

10  I' vidi ben sì com' ei ricoperse
11  lo cominciar con l'altro che poi venne,
12  che fur parole a le prime diverse;

13  ma nondimen paura il suo dir dienne,
14  perch' io traeva la parola tronca
15  forse a peggior sentenzia che non tenne.

"Still it behoveth us to win the fight,"
Began he; "Else. . . Such offered us herself. . .
O how I long that someone here arrive!"

Well I perceived, as soon as the beginning
He covered up with what came afterward,
That they were words quite different from the first;

But none the less his saying gave me fear,
Because I carried out the broken phrase,
Perhaps to a worse meaning than he had.

After the induction of the first few lines, the protagonist Dante does indeed sharpen his hearing, and he notes that Virgil changes what he is going to say in midstream.  What was he going to say?  Presumably something about Beatrice's promise of Divine protection and Virgil's ordination to be Dante's protector and savior.  Virgil at this impasse has failed at that, and he, a pagan, who may believe in the contract of a human promise, cannot have a spiritual faith that the Divine will supplant his shortcomings with inhuman, spiritual, aid.  If Beatrice's promise has failed, Virgil's promise to her to save Dante, has failed too.  So, we hear a reiteration of the despair that Virgil expressed in line 120 of the previous canto, as he waits without the comfort of faith for divine intervention.  And yet, he makes an effort, a kind of whistling in the dark effort, to calm himself and his ward, by softening what he was going to say, and in the lines that follow, telling himself, and Dante, that he knows his way around down here, because he has been here before.   

16  “In questo fondo de la trista conca
17  discende mai alcun del primo grado,
18  che sol per pena ha la speranza cionca?”

19  Questa question fec' io; e quei “Di rado
20  incontra,” mi rispuose, “che di noi
21  faccia il cammino alcun per qual io vado. 

22  Ver è ch'altra fiata qua giù fui,
23  congiurato da quella Eritón cruda
24  che richiamava l'ombre a' corpi sui.

25  Di poco era di me la carne nuda,
26  ch'ella mi fece intrar dentr' a quel muro,
27  per trarne un spirto del cerchio di Giuda.

28   Quell' è 'l più basso loco e 'l più oscuro,
29  e 'l più lontan dal ciel che tutto gira:
30  ben so 'l cammin; però ti fa sicuro.

31  Questa palude che 'l gran puzzo spira
32  cigne dintorno la città dolente,
33  u' non potemo intrare omai sanz' ira.”

16  "Into this bottom of the doleful conch
17  Doth any e'er descend from the first grade,
18  Which for its pain has only hope cut off?"

19  This question put I; and he answered me:
20  "Seldom it comes to pass that one of us
21  Maketh the journey upon which I go.

22  True is it, once before I here below
23  Was conjured by that pitiless Erictho,
24  Who summoned back the shades unto their bodies.

25  Naked of me short while the flesh had been,
26  Before within that wall she made me enter,
27  To bring a spirit from the circle of Judas;

28  That is the lowest region and the darkest,
29  And farthest from the heaven which circles all.
30  Well know I the way; therefore be reassured.

31  This fen, which a prodigious stench exhales,
32  Encompasses about the city dolent,
33  Where now we cannot enter without anger."

In the last 8 centuries, a sea of scholarly ink has been spilt and buckets of intellectual elbow grease expended to trace the source of this tale by Virgil recounting his previous journey to the depths of hell.  The most probable answer is that Dante put together an original story from a number of sources, but this should interest us less than the why's and wherefore's of the matter.  Why does the text take this little interpolation detour?   Yes, we understand that the aspirant asks the question if anyone from the first circle — Virgil's fixed abode in limbo — has ever descended further into hell than this point.  Here, the two protagonists are now at an impasse,  and the aspirant wants to know if such a thing is even possible.  And in answer to this question, Virgil tells this tale of Erictho, a witch, who had, when Virgil was only newly denuded of his flesh — i.e., become a shade —bewitched him.  He was sent against his will, or by means of stripping him of his will, to fetch a soul from the deepest part of hell.  The question that I think is raised here is that of the  chasm which separates magic from miracle, conjuration from ordination.  In Virgil's first journey into hell, he has been deprived of his will in order to perform a supremely unnatural act: that is, the reanimation of its dead body by a departed soul.  And in this second expedition, Virgil, through a voluntary act of obedience to a higher source of inspiration — that is to say, his ordination as a guide to Dante by Beatrice —  agrees to shepherd a living person through hell for the purpose of that soul's salvation.  It should also be noted that back in line 9, Virgil too wishes to see into the future, which was how Erictho came to be summoned in the first place in the Roman Civil War, and Virgil laments about how long he has been in expectation.   Whatever more contemporary sources that Dante might have used to concoct this story of Virgil acting as the will-less instrument of Erictho, it seems that most of the information about Erichtho herself was gleaned from Lucan, specifically from Book Six of Pharsalia (a.k.a. Civil War).  Here is some of what Lucan says about this witch:

These rites of criminality, these spells of the direful race, 
the wild Erictho has condemned as being of piety too extreme, 
and has applied the polluted art to new ceremonies. 
For to her it is not permitted to place her deadly head within 
a roof or a home in the city; and she haunts the deserted piles, 
and, the ghosts expelled, takes possession of the tombs, 
pleasing to the Gods of Erebus. To hear the counsels of the dead, 
to know the Stygian abodes and the secrets of the concealed Pluto, 
not the Gods above, not a life on earth, forbids. Leanness has possession 
of the features of the hag, foul with filthiness, and, unknown 
to a clear sky, her dreadful visage, laden with uncombed locks, 
is beset with Stygian paleness. If showers and black clouds 
obscure the stars, then does the Thessalian witch stalk forth 
from the spoiled piles, and try to arrest the lightnings of the night. 
The seeds she treads on of the fruitful corn she burns up, 
and by her breathing makes air noxious that was not deadly before. 
She neither prays to the Gods of heaven, nor with suppliant prayer 
calls the Deity to her aid, nor does she know of the propitiating 
entrails; upon the altars she delights to place funereal flames, 
and frankincense which she has carried off from the lighted pile.
Her voice now first heard as she demands, the Gods of heaven 
accede to all the wickedness, and dread to hear a second address. 
Souls that live, and still rule their respective limbs, she buries 
in the tomb; and death reluctantly creeps on upon those who owe 
lengthened years to the Fates; the funeral procession turning back, 
the dead bodies she rescues from the tomb; corpses fly from death. 
The smoking ashes of the young and the burning bones she 
snatches from the midst of the piles, and the very torch which 
the parents have held; the fragments, too, of the funereal bier 
that fly about in the black smoke, and the flowing robes does she 
collect amid the ashes, and the embers that smell of the limbs.
But when corpses are kept within stone, from which the moisture within 
is taken away, and, the corruption withdrawn, the marrow has grown 
hard; then does she greedily raven upon all the limbs, 
and bury her hands in the eyes, and delight to scoop out 
the dried-up balls, and gnaw the pallid nails of the 
shrunken hand; with her mouth she tears asunder the halter 
and the murderous knots; the bodies as they hang she gnaws, 
and scrapes the crosses; the entrails, too, smitten by the showers she 
rends asunder, and the parched marrow, the sun's heat admitted thereto. 
Iron fastened into the hands, and the black corruption of the filthy matter 
that distils upon the limbs, and the slime that has collected, 
she bears off, and hangs to the bodies, as the sinews hold fast her bite.
Whatever carcass, too, is lying upon the bare ground, 
before the beasts and the birds of the air does she sit; nor does she wish 
to separate the joints with iron and with her hands, and about to tear 
the limbs from their parched jaws, she awaits the bites of the wolves. 
Nor do her hands refrain from murder, if she requires the 
life-blood, which is the first to spring from the divided throat. 
Nor does she shun slaughter, if her rites demand living gore, 
and her funereal tables demand the quivering entrails. 
So, through the wounds of the womb, not the way in which nature invites, 
is the embryo torn out, about to be placed upon the glowing altars. 
And as often as she has need of grim and stalwart shades, she herself 
makes the ghosts; every kind of death among mankind is in her employ.
She from the youthful body tears the down of the cheek; 
she with her left hand from the dying stripling cuts off the hair. 
Full often, too, at her kinsman's pile has the dire Thessalian witch 
brooded over the dear limbs, and imprinting kisses, 
has both cut off the head, and torn away the cheeks pressed with her teeth, 
and biting off the end of the tongue as it cleaves to the dried throat, 
has poured forth murmurs into the cold lips, and has 
dispatched accursed secrets to the Stygian shades.

Phew!  This is putrifaction personified, or rather, demonically diefied.  Erictho is the crone of the triple Goddess, she stands guard at the barrier between life and death, and when the spirit which animates the body flees its host, she rots the corpse, and takes its disgusting detritus into her own bodily substance, which is why she looks so terrifying and smells so bad.  

One of the great pleasures of reading Dante, is that of being diverted by the text to other texts: to Saint Augustine, to Aristotle, to Plato, to Ovid, to the Bible — and, here, to Lucan.  So much of Dante's topography of hell, the black air and the noxious landscapes, the city of Dis, the furies, the power of the voice to cast evil spells, the Giants that we find later in hell, the descriptions of the Erinyes/Furies, the sepulchers, and the river Styx, the civil war in heaven, and those on earth, like that of Lucan's Romans and Dante's Florentines ... Dante has extensively mined the details of Lucan and converted them for his own use.  I think Dante read Lucan with the same owl's eye for detail with which we now read Dante, and if the reader of Dante would go back to Lucan, just to follow what the earlier Latin poet has said about the Thessalian witches and about Erictho in particular, a great deal of how Dante thought about this subject, how he imagined it, and how he so perfectly placed this apparent re-assurance by Virgil in Canto IX, would be illuminated.  The correspondences just leap off the pages of the compared texts, and in the case here, Dante the poet, way more savvy than Dante the protagonist, is clearly stating that being a pagan, even so sagacious and honored a pagan as is Virgil, has it's damning limitations, not the least of which is this impious weakness to magic.  Lucan makes this clear.  Even the most powerful Gods of the pagan pantheon are slaves to her voice, her spells, and here a number of parodic contrasts are suggested: Beatrice's imprecations compared to Erictho's spells, Erictho's control of the sublunar terrestrial world, and what Virgil said about Fortuna in Canto  VII, prayer for divine intercession and conjuration to impell elementals.  Dante, the writer, has to thread the needle here, in so far as he must maintain Virgil as a viable guide and source of direction and wisdom, but he cannot ignore the fact that Virgil is a pagan, and, although we will later find Pagans among those to be saved in Purgatory, Virgil does not belong there.  Up to now in the Inferno, there are no passages more than these that at the beginning of Canto IX which spell out Virgil's limitations with the plain and glaring fact that his pagan mind remains tainted by doubt (was Beatrice's promise genuine?), and superstition (he was duped by Erictho to perform an impious act).  We don't want to believe it, but even a great person, a genius, a master of language, a fount of reason, and a treasure trove of wisdom, with the wrong beliefs, with a lack of faith, condemns him or herself to the hopeless suspension of limbo.  Such a person's highest pleasure is only that of the Symposium and never the transcendence of the blessed.

Here again, I think Dante is very concerned not to fall into the Manichean heresy of a God of Goodness who reigns in heaven beyond the evils of physical creation, and the demi-urge who created and rules Earth and all things caught in the warp and woof weavings of space and time.  And in studying Lucan so assiduously he must have also been aware that Civil War was not only the state of things between the Guelphs and the Ghibellines in Florence, but also throughout Italy between the Church and the rival secular powers, or beyond Italy, between the Church and the Albigensian heresies of the Cathars, which raged with genocidal fury throughout Languedoc in the century prior.   All of these external Civil Wars are the result of the war in the  psyche of each individual between faith and reasonable doubt.  Dante, the poet, chooses faith, but not before the effects of reasonable doubt have been thoroughly explored.   Very slyly and very backhandedly in these passages, Dante leads us to the understanding that the psyches, not only of evil doers, but also those of great and good geniuses like Virgil, can fall prey to both their own reason, and also to superstition.  If reason gives you no hope of beatitude, is it not a kind of stubborn superstitious acceptance of reason to reject the mystery of faith?  Pascal thought so, hence his famous wager.  Here too we find that Dante's work remains relevant, and perhaps even more relevant than it was in his own times, because this contest between reasonable doubt and faith still rages in almost all of us, and still is the source of much geopolitical and sectarian violence.  That being the case, Civil War, and its attendant rage, terror, and arrogance is a condition of being in all sublunar, terrestrial, and hell worlds.  Here is the stark presentation of what we have referred to as the metaphor of war, which rules all these lokas, and all their denizens.   This metaphor of existence as an eternal state of war, of suffering and of retribution, even as we have seen before in Canto III, when the Gates of Hell declare the existence of their domain before all created things, is a punishment that pre-exists even the creation of those to be punished.  It is in effect a statement about the power of language and its metaphors to create and control minds, hearts, and worlds.  That all of these arguments rise to a conscious level out of the condition of impasse, the condition of the unbreakable double-bind, and the condition of the seemingly insurmountable barrier leads the reader to confront the greatest barrier of them all: the barrier that mortality erects which blocks the body from entering the domain of the immortals.  This confrontation is emphasized again and again as the shades encounter Dante's mortal body traversing what we might call the imaginative realms of the spirit.  Dante, the poet, has escaped the bounds of nature, through his own poetry, something I believe that no theologian, philosopher, scholar, ethicist, or historian could do.  I think he shows the reader that the primacy of poetry derives from its protean ability to  straddle and unite, in a single aesthetic vision, these otherwise incompatible and always warring worlds.  Below, Dante shows how poetry does this by uniting metaphors for wind, fire, water, and giving them the same essential meaning.

I don't want to leave this section without referring to the existence of the faithful who perversely renounce virtue and all societal rules as a path to divine union.   There are Shiva sadhus of the Aghorï sect who despise all virtue, eat their own shit, live in cremation grounds, practice cannibalism, communicate with obscenities and profanities, and otherwise engage in any act thought by the traditionally pious to be impious, diabolical, and criminal.  There reasoning is that God cannot be excluded from any act, however vile, without creating a split in the Universal being, and that can never be.  In Russia too, there were sectarians, who, believing that Christ, the Shepard who left his flock of 99 sheep to rescue his one lost sheep, was compelled, as part of his divine nature as the Savior, to be the most attentive to the rescue of those who sin the most.  Therefore, every sin must be committed in the most orgiastic manner so that the sinner can move closer to the Savior.  We find like beliefs across the world in shamanic practices, where shamans engage in violent actions, abusive language, crying and howling for no reason, transformations into beasts, trance states, votive sacrifices, and Eucharistic cannibalism to attain supernatural powers.  Religion, as Frazer copiously illustrates in The Golden Bough, is rooted in magic, and magic is often rooted in the violently incomprehensible.  Dante eschews all this, and seeks instead miracle degreed by divine grace, and yet, like Yeats' Magi, he did indeed experience "the controllable mystery on the bestial floor". 

Finally, I want to look at the last line of this section (line 33) wherein Virgil declares that the City of Dis cannot me entered without anger.  Whether he means that anger — in this place where anger is the main affect — only begets anger, or that anger can only be overcome by anger, is not clear.  The fact that it is not clear, and cannot be made clear, goes back to the double-bind nature of the metaphor of war, which in hell reigns supreme, and even determines the actions of those heavenly entities who enter hell for heavenly purposes.  Nowhere in hell are we in a "resist not evil" or "turn the other cheek" mode.  In the place of fighting, be prepared to fight, but don't mistake the place of fighting as something universal.  All the irony and parody that the poem displays would not even be possible if this were true.  There are other places, more inclusive, more fundamental, maybe even more real, which are places of learning or places of blessing, and these places are where the parodist achieves his perspective, where he rises above the fray to expose the futility of it.   
  
34  E altro disse, ma non l'ho a mente;
35  però che l'occhio m'avea tutto tratto
36  ver' l'alta torre a la cima rovente,

37  dove in un punto furon dritte ratto
38  tre furïe infernal di sangue tinte,
39  che membra feminine avieno e atto,

40  e con idre verdissime eran cinte;
41  serpentelli e ceraste avien per crine,
42 onde le fiere tempie erano avvinte.

43  E quei, che ben conobbe le meschine
44  de la regina de l'etterno pianto,
45  “Guarda,” mi disse, “le feroci Erine.

46  Quest' è Megera dal sinistro canto;
47  quella che piange dal destro è Aletto;
48  Tesifón è nel mezzo”; e tacque a tanto.

49  Con l'unghie si fendea ciascuna il petto;
50  battiensi a palme e gridavan sì alto,
51  ch'i' mi strinsi al poeta per sospetto.

52  “Vegna Medusa: sì 'l farem di smalto,”
53  dicevan tutte riguardando in giuso;
54  “mal non vengiammo in Tesëo l'assalto.”
 

55  “Volgiti 'n dietro e tien lo viso chiuso;
56  ché se 'l Gorgón si mostra e tu 'l vedessi,
57  nulla sarebbe di tornar mai suso.”

58  Così disse 'l maestro; ed elli stessi
59  mi volse, e non si tenne a le mie mani,
60  che con le sue ancor non mi chiudessi.

61  O voi ch'avete li 'ntelletti sani,
62  mirate la dottrina che s'asconde
63  sotto 'l velame de li versi strani.

34  And more he said, but not in mind I have it;
35  Because mine eye had altogether drawn me
36  Tow'rds the high tower with the red-flaming summit,

37  Where in a moment saw I swift uprisen
38  The three infernal Furies stained with blood,
39  Who had the limbs of women and their mien,

40  And with the greenest hydras were begirt;
41  Small serpents and cerastes were their tresses,
42  Wherewith their horrid temples were entwined.

43  And he who well the handmaids of the Queen
44  Of everlasting lamentation knew,
45  Said unto me: "Behold the fierce Erinnys.

46  This is Megaera, on the left-hand side;
47  She who is weeping on the right, Alecto;
48  Tisiphone is between;" and then was silent.

49  Each one her breast was rending with her nails;
50  They beat them with their palms, and cried so loud,
51  That I for dread pressed close unto the Poet.

52  "Medusa come, so we to stone will change him!"
53  All shouted looking down; "in evil hour
54  Avenged we not on Theseus his assault!"

55  "Turn thyself round, and keep thine eyes close shut,
56  For if the Gorgon appear, and thou shouldst see it,
57  No more returning upward would there be."

58  Thus said the Master; and he turned me round
59  Himself, and trusted not unto my hands
60  So far as not to blind me with his own.

61  O ye who have undistempered intellects,
62  Observe the doctrine that conceals itself
63  Beneath the veil of the mysterious verses!

One of the things you come to realize in reading Dante is that the operations of consciousness and the operations of language are analogically linked, and as in lines 34 - 35, (And more he said, but not in mind I have it; / Because mine eye had altogether drawn me ... E altro disse, ma non l'ho a mente; / però che l'occhio m'avea tutto tratto ...) when the language shifts, in this case from hearing explanations to seeing descriptions, from listening to vision, the operations of the mind (mente) shift too, here, to the modality of visible fear.  One could say that what we see in the sudden vision of the furies is the underlying terror which Virgil has attempted to conceal behind his reasonable gloss.  This is a poetic process, which Dante, the author, takes time out from the narrative to alert us to in lines 61 - 63, and throughout the poem, we are always peeking beneath the veil of the mysterious verses, only to have thrust upon us the immediacy of a revelation.  But there is danger here too, as Virgil well knows when he covers his protégé’s eyes to prevent him from seeing Medusa and turning to stone.   We know that any kind of reasonable explanation may do much to displace our terror of these primal visions.  It takes a physical act by Virgil to divert the aspirant's attention away from the three Erinyes.  Dante does not fully describe the appearance of either the Erinyes or of Erictho, but his readers would have known that they would have had the same appearance as that of Medusa: snakes for hair, dog's heads, women's bodies charred black as coal or of a slimy swamp-green, bat wings, blood-shot, flaming eyes, taloned hands, and so forth.  So, we can collapse all of these figures down to an archetype of female malevolence, a parody of the three Women who stand for Heaven's care: The Blessed Virgin, Saint Lucy, and Beatrice.  Sometimes, we need to go to outside sources to fully imagine what Dante had fully imagined, so that we can crawl inside his mind and fully experience his world.  Reading Dante is like some slow burn of a psychedelic experience, not concentrated in a few hours of altered consciousness from taking psilocybin or mescaline, but spread out over months or even years.  This long, increasingly transforming tumble into awe reveals itself as a process of discovering the points of contact and diversion between two types of reality — one's everyday life and one's immersion into the poem.  Imagine those anatomical transparencies, where overlaying one sheet atop another changes what one sees, the picture becoming more and more opaque as sheets are added.  And now imagine turning the pages backwards and seeing more and more fundamental layers of the body exposed to your contemplation.  Boundaries, once thought to be inviolable, are seen to be fluid, interpenetrating, and interactive.  And psychedelics, however differently they affect our body/brain chemistry, are always boundary dissolvers.  The consciousness of the reader when reading about the three furies begins to break the normal time-line of past/present/future.  A temporal boundary is shattered, as the reader turns back and connects these threenesses to the three beasts in Canto I, the three-headed monster Cerberus, or, in a diabolic parody, the holy trinity of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, and of course a parody as noted above of the Virgin, Saint Lucy, and Beatrice.  How can three things be one, without being a monstrous conglomeration brought about by a dissolution of boundaries?  And we should be reminded here also of where we are in the Commedia: at a boundary separating the hell of the intemperate from the hell of the more criminally malicious.

We are stuck here: and the re-iteration of the tower, which we first encountered at the end of the previous canto, and the furies, entities, not just of wrath, but of retributive wrath, are now seen in the place of the twin flames: a weird two/three image trope, duple or triple meters in the poem that, read one way, and have a certain beat, while the same passage, read with a different emphasis, has another beat — again, boundaries dissolving, the same line becoming two or three different lines depending on the emphasis of the reader's interpretation or mood.  And what about this passage declaiming the threat (which turns out to be empty) of the conjuration of Medusa (a failed attempt at magic), in which Virgil shuts the eyes of the Dante by force, lest he be turned to stone?  Isn't this fear of petrification an unavoidable adjunct to rage?   It is all a reptile brain response.  A frightened lizard makes a threat display, runs a certain distance, freezes, then repeats the whole performance: another three: fight, flight, or freeze, the whole behavioral pattern locked in by an evolutionary dependence on automaticity, which is dependent upon cause and effect reflexivity, and which admits to no variations, even when the threat is death.  Reading Dante seems somehow to thrust one out of this reflexive cycle to become a roamer between different worlds. 

64  E già venìa su per le torbide onde
65  un fracasso d'un suon, pien di spavento,
66  per cui tremavano amendue le sponde

67  non altrimenti fatto che d'un vento
68  impetüoso per li avversi ardori,
69  che fier la selva e sanz' alcun rattento

70  li rami schianta, abbatte e porta fori;
71  dinanzi polveroso va superbo,
72  e fa fuggir le fiere e li pastori.

73  Li occhi mi sciolse e disse: “Or drizza il nerbo
74  del viso su per quella schiuma antica
75  per indi ove quel fummo è più acerbo.”

76  Come le rane innanzi a la nimica
77  biscia per l'acqua si dileguan tutte,
78  fin ch'a la terra ciascuna s'abbica,

79  vid' io più di mille anime distrutte
80  fuggir così dinanzi ad un ch'al passo
81  passava Stige con le piante asciutte.

82  Dal volto rimovea quell' aere grasso,
83  menando la sinistra innanzi spesso;
84  e sol di quell' angoscia parea lasso.

85  Ben m'accorsi ch'elli era da ciel messo,
86  e volsimi al maestro; e quei fé segno
87  ch'i' stessi queto ed inchinassi ad esso.

88  Ahi quanto mi parea pien di disdegno!
89  Venne a la porta e con una verghetta
90  l'aperse, che non v'ebbe alcun ritegno.

91  “O cacciati del ciel, gente dispetta,”
92  cominciò elli in su l'orribil soglia,
93  “ond' esta oltracotanza in voi s'alletta?

94  Perché recalcitrate a quella voglia
95  a cui non puote il fin mai esser mozzo,
96  e che più volte v'ha cresciuta doglia?

97  Che giova ne le fata dar di cozzo?
98  Cerbero vostro, se ben vi ricorda,
99  ne porta ancor pelato il mento e 'l gozzo.”

100  Poi si rivolse per la strada lorda,
101  e non fé motto a noi, ma fé sembiante
102  d'omo cui altra cura stringa e morda

103  che quella di colui che li è davante;
104  e noi movemmo i piedi inver' la terra,
105  sicuri appresso le parole sante.

64  And now there came across the turbid waves
65  The clangour of a sound with terror fraught,
66  Because of which both of the margins trembled;

67  Not otherwise it was than of a wind
68  Impetuous on account of adverse heats,
69  That smites the forest, and, without restraint,

70  The branches rends, beats down, and bears away;
71  Right onward, laden with dust, it goes superb,
72  And puts to flight the wild beasts and the shepherds.

73  Mine eyes he loosed, and said: "Direct the nerve
74  Of vision now along that ancient foam,
75  There yonder where that smoke is most intense."

76  Even as the frogs before the hostile serpent
77  Across the water scatter all abroad,
78  Until each one is huddled in the earth.

79  More than a thousand ruined souls I saw,
80  Thus fleeing from before one who on foot
81  Was passing o'er the Styx with soles unwet.

82  From off his face he fanned that unctuous air,
83  Waving his left hand oft in front of him,
84  And only with that anguish seemed he weary.

85  Well I perceived one sent from Heaven was he,
86  And to the Master turned; and he made sign
87  That I should quiet stand, and bow before him.

88  Ah! how disdainful he appeared to me!
89  He reached the gate, and with a little rod
90  He opened it, for there was no resistance.

91  "O banished out of Heaven, people despised!"
92  Thus he began upon the horrid threshold;
93  "Whence is this arrogance within you couched?

94  Wherefore recalcitrate against that will,
95  From which the end can never be cut off,
96  And which has many times increased your pain?

97  What helpeth it to butt against the fates?
98  Your Cerberus, if you remember well,
99  For that still bears his chin and gullet peeled."

100  Then he returned along the miry road,
101  And spake no word to us, but had the look
102  Of one whom other care constrains and goads

103  Than that of him who in his presence is;
104  And we our feet directed tow'rds the city,
105  After those holy words all confident.


How do you explain metaphors as richly complicated, and as naturally understood as those employed by Dante?  The coming of this heavenly messenger — grace personified — is anything but subtle.  With the tremendous force of a cyclone (wind) caused by diverse zones of heat (fire) this presence scares up the souls in the swamp (water), who flee like frogs from a serpent (note the choice of frogs, amphibians which live in two worlds, here, subaqueous and subterranean).  We also have the reference to the wild beasts and shepherds, which recalls a whole Orphean tradition of poetry, wherein a shepherd has the power to tame wild animals with his songs, and here this whole tradition of pastoral poetry is swept away by this cyclonic gust of epic verse.  Opposites are combined, as noted above, and made to serve a unified purpose in a way that is beyond the technical reach of didactic prose.  So without making a didactic speech at all, Dante shows why poetry, more than sermons, and equal to scripture, possess a power to transform the attentive reader, gathering up the hypersensual into a kind of hyperspace of metaphor, in which one metaphor grows out of another, or dives into another, like so many Russian dolls, which change position from external descriptions to internal emotional states to overarching metaphysical decrees in the most astonishing protean displays.  These metaphors infiltrate the mind and emotions of the reader in a kind of mutational yeast that transforms the body, and the ordinary act of reading, into a whirl of spiritual experiences and their attendant insights.  These few passage represent a poetic miracle — including the disdain shown by the heavenly messenger that absolutely mirrors the miracle described in the narrative.  With a little rod (a quill pen, a writing instrument, or the tongue of the reciter), and a little speech, after walking on water, the messenger opens the gate to Dis, and returns from whence he had come, already having forgotten his stupendous accomplishment, and occupied mentally with his next task.  As readers, we are witness to something in these passages, and the operation of these words in the brain, just like that little rod and little speech of the messenger.  Reading, we open up vast areas of exploration in the unconscious mind.  Certainly we will discover horrible things in this great depository of personal and species history.  But we may also discover, as the dazzling nature of the poetry even when describing odious things so miraculously illustrates:the path to our salvation — and we our feet directed towards the city / after those holy words all confident — e noi movemmo i piedi inver' la terra, / sicuri appresso le parole sante.
 
106  Dentro li 'ntrammo sanz' alcuna guerra;
107  e io, ch'avea di riguardar disio
108  la condizion che tal fortezza serra,

109  com' io fui dentro, l'occhio intorno invio:
110  e veggio ad ogne man grande campagna,
111  piena di duolo e di tormento rio.

112  Sì come ad Arli, ove Rodano stagna,
113  sì com' a Pola, presso del Carnaro
114  ch'Italia chiude e suoi termini bagna,

115  fanno i sepulcri tutt'il loco varo,
116  così facevan quivi d'ogne parte,
117  salvo che 'l modo v'era più amaro;

118  ché tra li avelli fiamme erano sparte,
119  per le quali eran sì del tutto accesi,
120  che ferro più non chiede verun' arte.

121  Tutti li lor coperchi eran sospesi,
122  e fuor n'uscivan sì duri lamenti,
123  che ben parean di miseri e d'offesi.

124  E io: “Maestro, quai son quelle genti
125  che, seppellite dentro da quell' arche,
126  si fan sentir coi sospiri dolenti?”

127  E quelli a me: “Qui son li eresïarche
128  con lor seguaci, d'ogne setta, e molto
129  più che non credi son le tombe carche.

130  Simile qui con simile è sepolto,
131  e i monimenti son più e men caldi.”
132  E poi ch'a la man destra si fu vòlto,

133  passammo tra i martìri e li alti spaldi.

106  Within we entered without any contest;
107  And I, who inclination had to see
108  What the condition such a fortress holds,

109  Soon as I was within, cast round mine eye,
110  And see on every hand an ample plain,
111 Full of distress and torment terrible.

112  Even as at Arles, where stagnant grows the Rhone,
113  Even as at Pola near to the Quarnaro,
114  That shuts in Italy and bathes its borders,

115  The sepulchres make all the place uneven;
116  So likewise did they there on every side,
117  Saving that there the manner was more bitter;

118  For flames between the sepulchres were scattered,
119  By which they so intensely heated were,
120  That iron more so asks not any art.

121  All of their coverings uplifted were,
122  And from them issued forth such dire laments,
123  Sooth seemed they of the wretched and tormented.

124  And I: "My Master, what are all those people
125  Who, having sepulture within those tombs,
126  Make themselves audible by doleful sighs?"

127  And he to me: "Here are the Heresiarchs,
128  With their disciples of all sects, and much
129  More than thou thinkest laden are the tombs.

130  Here like together with its like is buried;
131  And more and less the monuments are heated."
132  And when he to the right had turned, we passed

133  Between the torments and high parapets.

In and out, through and through, up and down, round and round — these morphological components  of the text are all on display in these last lines of Canto IX.  The protagonists enter the City of Dis, now without opposition, and what they see, as the text shows, in phrases that emphasize the circular motion of the scanning eyes, is a vast plain of sepulchers, interspersed by the spindly towers of the minarets and spurts of flame.  Here, moving the attention of the reader around, the text draws the attention to surface geography describing the swampland in certain Italian locales, where the spongy, watery ground forbids ordinary internment, and the dead are placed in above ground, or mostly above ground. sepulchers.  Readers who have visited cemeteries in New Orleans or Galveston will have clear picture of this ghastly scene.  These are people whose heresy was probably, among others, a strictly material view of the body.  They did not believe in an extra-corporeal, post-mortem existence, and they find themselves in their graves, but still living as entities composed entirely of that tormented state wherein the reality of one's situation completely negates the belief system in which one has fixed one's identity.  Disbelievers when alive, they find themselves in an unbelievable condition after death.  The canto ends with another up / down metaphor from the tormented souls in the sepulchers to the high parapets of the city's walls and towers, and this symmetrically closes what was opened with the metaphor of walking on foot towards the high tower with its enigmatic signal flames — a trope that began the previous Canto revealing the protagonists' first shadowy perceptions of the City of Dis.  

Canto X
1  Ora sen va per un secreto calle,
2  tra 'l muro de la terra e li martìri,
3  lo mio maestro, e io dopo le spalle.

4  “O virtù somma, che per li empi giri
5  mi volvi,” cominciai, “com' a te piace,
6  parlami, e sodisfammi a' miei disiri.

1  Now onward goes, along a narrow path
2  Between the torments and the city wall,
3  My Master, and I follow at his back.

4  "O power supreme, that through these impious circles
5  Turnest me," I began, "as pleases thee,
6  Speak to me, and my longings satisfy;

Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way,
that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat ... Mathew 7:13.

Is there a lesson in these first 6 lines of Canto X about reading, about learning, about following the path of a spiritual discipline?  As Churchill said: "When you're going through Hell, keep going," which is what the protagonists are doing here, following a virtuous path through the wide, gaping maw of Hell.  I think the narrow gate is something like following a disciplined path as opposed to just going along with the group's consensus thoughts, beliefs, and behaviors, or even our own inclinations to find comfort in following what's easiest.  There is also a general meaning to a text, as there is a general meaning to a dream, but only when we begin thinking inside the text, assuming that these imaginal characters have a real internal life that interfaces with our own life, will the text begin to offer us specific genuine guidance and inspiration.  Why are the protagonist exploring Hell, what is our need, our genuine need, to explore suffering and malfeasance?  And also, why does the protagonist, Dante, reiterate his veneration for Virgil in such glowing and reverential terms (O virtù somma — O power supreme) right after Virgil's first absolute failure?  After reason has failed, how can we still so trust reason?  If we learn something, with much effort, what do we do with that learning and effort, when what we learned turns out to be false or irrelevant?  Is the aspirant here trying to reassure himself or his teacher?  Any process that is a discipline is not steady, but has pitfalls and reversals, and there is nothing so unsteady as interpreting a text so that it provides spiritual guidance without become a set of dictatorial rules.   We are stopped by so many things, by our own fatigue, by hopelessness, by fear, by sickness, by the demands of ordinary life, by the ordinary pleasures of eating, drinking, sex, by boredom, by a feeling that what we are learning is irrelevant, or already known and understood, by a feeling that we are inadequate to complete such an important task, and so forth and so on ad infinitum.  But here, in these 6 lines, just as the aspirant is entering the most dangerous depths of Hell, he keeps following Virgil, keeps going, although he is still turning round and round in dreadful circles.  I think that after the grand impasse of Canto IX, everything becomes more somber, because we realize that even our best efforts have a limit: Failure is an option, and even an overwhelming probability.  How do we keep going when the going only promises more disappointment, more horror, more of the wretchedness of our own limitations?  And why would we want to? 

7  La gente che per li sepolcri giace
8  potrebbesi veder? già son levati
9  tutt' i coperchi, e nessun guardia face.”

7  The people who are lying in these tombs,
8  Might they be seen? already are uplifted
9  The covers all, and no one keepeth guard."

The words that come to mind here are: He is risen.  When the tomb of Jesus was found open, an Angel guarded the entrance, here there are no guards, and the bodies of the dead lie elsewhere while their undecaying shades suffer eternally from their misapprehension of who they are as souls.  The parody here goes with the pattern of parodies which we have seen elsehere: in Hell the patterns of sacremental blessedness are perverted to engines of pain.
But let's ask ourselves, what is the essence of the aspirant's question?  He sees sarcophagi with the lids open, but no bodies as yet.  And if we remember the reference to Erictho in the previous canto, who hexed Virgil to visit the realm of the damned to retrieve a shade so that the witch might reunite it with its corporeal body, then Dante's question here still has to do with magic, and what exactly the powers of Virgil might be.  We will see in Virgil's answer that he references the last judgement, as a way of telling Dante that these are shades without bodies, and that those who lie here as yet unseen are subject only to God's law.  It is a small moment, but telling, because the closeness of Virgil and Dante has been challenged by Virgil's failure in Canto IX, and both parties seem to be wanting to repair any damage caused by doubt and move closer to one another.  Political divisiveness is one of the major topics in this canto, so the text offers a contrast here of two — one pagan, one Christian, one dead, one living, one experienced, one inexperienced — who, despite their differences, are seeking ways to become more intimate.
