If we, the readers, take this to be parts inside ourselves, which represent divergent and even conflicting points of view, in our interior drama of the theme of internicine war, Dante, the poet, is here giving us an example of how that split could be healed, and made protecting and productive.

10  E quelli a me: “Tutti saran serrati
11  quando di Iosafàt qui torneranno
12  coi corpi che là sù hanno lasciati.

13  Suo cimitero da questa parte hanno
14  con Epicuro tutti suoi seguaci,
15  che l'anima col corpo morta fanno.

16  Però a la dimanda che mi faci
17  quinc' entro satisfatto sarà tosto,
18  e al disio ancor che tu mi taci.”

19  E io: “Buon duca, non tegno riposto
20  a te mio cuor se non per dicer poco,
21  e tu m'hai non pur mo a ciò disposto.”

10  And he to me: "They all will be closed up
11  When from Jehoshaphat they shall return
12  Here with the bodies they have left above.

13  Their cemetery have upon this side
14  With Epicurus all his followers,
15  Who with the body mortal make the soul;

16  But in the question thou dost put to me,
17  Within here shalt thou soon be satisfied,
18  And likewise in the wish thou keepest silent."

19  And I: "Good Leader, I but keep concealed
20  From thee my heart, that I may speak the less,
22  Nor only now hast thou thereto disposed me."

We live in a post-Darwinian, post-Freudian state of consciousness, in which the question of the soul is either irrelevant or tied irrevocably to biological processes.  We are all Epicureans in that sense, psyche, or mind, for us is a mere epiphenomenon of the brain.  Kill the brain, the soul dies too.  This belief is anathema to any 14th Century Christian, and should be to us as well. Even supposing the soul is only a biologically generated fiction, still, a belief in the soul's immortality, and it's primacy as the generator of the body itself, and not it's product, saves us from the second, unexpressed part of Epicureanism, which is: if the body does not serve the soul, then it only serves itself, and we become mere pleasure-seeking, pain-avoidance machines, and our morality can only logically be the self-centered demands of the flesh.  Can we lie? can we cheat? can we steal or murder? — of course, if the body demands it.  But if the soul is primary, then what we do with our bodies impacts the life of the soul, and the lives of the bodies and souls of others too.  This is not the forum wherein to discuss things like Rupert Sheldrake's morphic resonance, but ecologists studying eco-systems, biologists studying immune systems, sociologists studying war, economists studying fiduciary systems, psychologists studying relationship dynamics all must come to the conclusion that the idea of a network of relationships is something quite different from a network of physical bodies.  The body may die, but relationship does not, as any person grieving for a passed loved one can tell us.  

Given these circumstances: the question that dominates our lives, shapes our relationships, and determines our morality must deal with this interconnection of body and soul, hardware and software.  The Christian answer to this is very much tied up with time and history.  If time is only a mechanism for turning living bodies into decaying corpses, than history is only a means of piling up more corpses.  But if there is a last judgement, when body and soul are finally harmoniously married, then it is a time when time, and it's dreadful henchman, history, both cease to exist and the question of the mixing of mortal and immortal becomes moot.  The open tombs indicate that for those who believe only in mortality, the imagination which posits immortality is telling them that life and death both have the unfinished business of the soul to attend to.  There are still unanswered questions that keep opening up cans of worms, imaginations, and sarcophagi.     

22  “O Tosco che per la città del foco
23  vivo ten vai così parlando onesto,
24  piacciati di restare in questo loco.

25  La tua loquela ti fa manifesto
26  di quella nobil patrïa natio,
27  a la qual forse fui troppo molesto.”

28  Subitamente questo suono uscìo
29  d'una de l'arche; però m'accostai,
30  temendo, un poco più al duca mio.

31  Ed el mi disse: “Volgiti! Che fai?
32  Vedi là Farinata che s'è dritto:
33  da la cintola in sù tutto 'l vedrai.”

34  Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto;
35  ed el s'ergea col petto e con la fronte
36  com' avesse l'inferno a gran dispitto.

37  E l'animose man del duca e pronte
38  mi pinser tra le sepulture a lui,
39  dicendo: “Le parole tue sien conte.”

40  Com' io al piè de la sua tomba fui,
41  guardommi un poco, e poi, quasi sdegnoso,
42  mi dimandò: “Chi fuor li maggior tui?”

43  Io ch'era d'ubidir disideroso,
44  non gliel celai, ma tutto gliel' apersi;
45  ond' ei levò le ciglia un poco in suso;

46  poi disse: “Fieramente furo avversi
47  a me e a miei primi e a mia parte,
48  sì che per due fïate li dispersi.”

49  “S'ei fur cacciati, ei tornar d'ogne parte,”
50  rispuos' io lui, “l'una e l'altra fïata;
51  ma i vostri non appreser ben quell' arte.”

22  "O Tuscan, thou who through the city of fire
23  Goest alive, thus speaking modestly,
24  Be pleased to stay thy footsteps in this place.

25  Thy mode of speaking makes thee manifest
26  A native of that noble fatherland,
27  To which perhaps I too molestful was."

28  Upon a sudden issued forth this sound
29  From out one of the tombs; wherefore I pressed,
30  Fearing, a little nearer to my Leader.

31  And unto me he said: "Turn thee; what dost thou?
32  Behold there Farinata who has risen;
33  From the waist upwards wholly shalt thou see him."

34  I had already fixed mine eyes on his,
35  And he uprose erect with breast and front
36  E'en as if Hell he had in great despite.

37  And with courageous hands and prompt my Leader
38  Thrust me between the sepulchres towards him,
39  Exclaiming, "Let thy words explicit be."

40  As soon as I was at the foot of his tomb
41  Somewhat he eyed me, and, as if disdainful,
42  Then asked of me, "Who were thine ancestors?"

43  I, who desirous of obeying was,
44  Concealed it not, but all revealed to him;
45  Whereat he raised his brows a little upward.

46  Then said he: "Fiercely adverse have they been
47   To me, and to my fathers, and my party;
48  So that two several times I scattered them."

49  "If they were banished, they returned on all sides,"
50  I answered him, "the first time and the second;
51  But yours have not acquired that art aright."

The meaning of a text changes according to the perception of the person reading it.  This passage is the beginning of the first part of the dialogue between Dante, the aspirant, and this shade who rises half-way, and is seen from the waist up only, as we learn, his chest puffed out, his brow thrust forward.  Whoever this is he is appealing to Dante in a way most likely to arrest Dante's attention: He praises Dante's language, which binds the two together.  But we shall shortly see, how that very language becomes an instrument of divisiveness.  The aspirant pulls closer to Virgil, the Latin master of language, and Virgil turns him around and pushes him towards the figure who rises out of the sarcophagus.  Again we see the circling, turning, spiraling morphology that is characteristic of the whole poem, but here we see this turning needing to be straightened out, Dante's fearful act of running under Virgil's skirt, cannot be tolerated.  Whoever this shade is, he is not someone whom Dante can ignore.  Dante, again having to travel the straight and narrow between the sepulchers, and step forward to face this fearful, orgulous figure.  Virgil's injunction: Look: this is/was a great and powerful nemesis to you, your party, your family, your honor, step forward, and mind that your speech — note that speech — "let your words count" (line 39: Le parole tue sien conte), or another way to translate this, "your words are counted," somewhat like the feathers of that sparrow in the gospels.  No one ever counted words or made words count more than Dante, and here he is instructing us to weigh these words that we are reading, because the truth is in them, not merely in their obvious meaning as signs pointing to an external reality, but as the promulgators of history, aesthetics, morality, immortality, and the conduits to salvation.  In these lines, it looks as if there is a discussion of Florentine history which is being discussed, and it is, but only on the surface, that is the half of the body that is visible.  But the other, buried half, is about art, and about creating a reality which is not the political or economic external, which history foists upon us as a fate, but about something that is neither external nor internal, objective nor subjective, but transcendent.  The essential nature of this deeper part of reality is beginning to sink in, both for the neophyte aspirant Dante, who is a protagonist in the poem, but also for the reader, who has all along been drawn down through a process of language, of poetry, wherein the historical and theological are transformed into metaphors which have the power to alter our state of consciousness, from trapped by fate and fearful, to a place where freedom expands joyously in every conceivable direction.  Here, though, history must be faced.  Farinata, the historical person, must be faced, as also Dante, the historical person, must be.  Certainly the Italians, and especially the Florentines of the 14th century would not have needed a footnote to know about the political schisms of the Guelfs and Ghibellines, the Blacks and Whites, and the part that Farinata and Dante's persons and families played on this historical stage.  Farinata is still literally mired in a conflict which can have no meaning for him now that he is dead, just as those historical conflicts can have no meaning for us — all these centuries later.  And yet, Dante's and Farinata's conflict is emblematic of a kind of violent factionalism that every historical period up to now has suffered, and will continue to suffer, until time and history end in that unimaginable entelechy that Terrace McKenna postulates as the changelessness which will finally fulfill all the desires sought but not found in change.  This poem is a step by step, word by word, procedure guiding us from mutable mortality to immutable immortality, a transformation which can never be found in history, but only in art.  That's a bold statement, but there is some justification for it because the cave paintings at Lascaux, the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, the plays of Shakespeare, and the Divina Commedia have all been born in mutable time, and all have become portals into immutable timelessness.  In brief, the moment that a text like this transforms its political and theological conflicts into art — language, and the language of art — the text changes, and it changes in the direction of a timeless place of consciousness, which will give us a full recognition — not just from the waist up — of historical reality in its role as transformational agent.  That is to say, in its role as the parodic mutable image of eternity.  Farinata's political argument here is not about Florentine politics at all.   Farinata by making his soul still attend only to temporal things has converted eternity into an interminable squabble over historical clots of dust.  The text demands that we examine that dust as an aesthetic experience not as a conflict that time will make meaningless.  This redeems the dust in the same way that God's fashioning of Adam (a name that means dust or red clay) redeemed it.  The deeper we go into Dante's Hell, or our own, the more profound our insights must be to see through history's smoke, fire, and stench to timeless blessedness.

Imagine the following footnote explaining Farinato's historical existence with the names and places changed to those with historical meaning for you, the reader, and then the dialog leaps out of one historical circumstance to another, and then, too, the underlying aesthetic and moral meaning of the text can do the same kind of work for any current reader as it did for Dante's contemporaries.  By this method of learning about Dante's history, we not only learn something about our own, but we learn about the impact of historicity itself, and why the Epicurean position cuts us off from the deepest and most fundamental levels of our existence.  Historically each moment is wiped out by the succeeding one, and the Epicurean, seeing this, says: Seize the moment before it's gone.  Yet where has it gone?  Into the psyche, the soul, the individual and collective mind.  The historical moment dies into an irrelevant and irrevocably destroyed past, but historicity has not died at all, and it has indeed survived as a kind of pattern that still lives to determine the next moment of history.  Without seeing the immortal pattern (Blake's Bright statues in the Halls of Los(s)), we are doomed to repeat it.  Even after the death of the moment and even after the body's death — the pattern remains impregnable.  Thus Epicurean belief chains us to the primacy of the moment, even after the moment has passed, and the sin and sorrow of it is that though we are devoted to the pleasures of the moment, that very abbreviated attention turns the past into the stinking sewage of a chronically infected error in regards to the total movements of time — that is to say, that by seeking to arrest the burgeoning fountain of events and extract some drop for our personal pleasure and as a domain of existence that we can control, the living water becomes dust in our mouths, and everything that we say or do is like the recycling of dung as food.  The immortal spiritual and aesthetic banquet, the joy ever-new, as Paramahansa Yogananda calls it, is turned to skeletons attempting to reflesh their bones by cannibalizing their own past squalor.  In short: a constant enslavement to one's reputation, which is what all these damned souls are trying to restore in their self-serving interactions with a living person.

As to the history of Farinata, the following commentary will be enough for the contemporary reader to see what's at stake: 

The speaker is Farinata degli Uberti: 'Manente, called Farinata, son of Jacopo degli Uberti, the “Saviour of Florence,” was born in Florence at the beginning of Century xiii; while still a boy he witnessed the introduction into the city of the Guelf and Ghibelline factions, of the latter of which his family became the leaders; in 1239 be became the head of his house, and in 1248 he took a prominent part in the expulsion of the Guelfs, who however returned in 1251, and a few years later (in 1258) expelled the Ghibellines in their turn, Farinata among them; the latter, who was now acknowledged head of his party, took refuge with the rest of the Ghibelline exiles in Siena, where he organized the measures which led to the crushing defeat of the Florentine Guelfs and their allies at Montaperti, and left the Ghibellines masters of Tuscany (Sept. 4, 1260). After their victory the Ghibellines held a council at Empoli, about twenty miles from Florence, at which it was proposed, in order to put an end once for all to the power of the Florentines, that the city of Florence should be razed to the ground. To this proposal, which was generally approved, Farinata offered the most determined opposition, declaring that he would defend his native city with his own sword as long as he had breath in his body, even though he should have to do it single-handed. In consequence of this protest the proposal was abandoned and Florence was saved from destruction. The Florentines subsequently showed little gratitude to Farinata for his patriotic intervention, for they always expressly included the Uberti with the other Ghibelline families who were excepted from the terms offered to the other exiles. After Montaperti Farinata returned to Florence, where he died in or about 1264, the year before Dante's birth' (cited from Toynbee, “Farinata,” in his Concise Dante Dictionary [Oxford: Clarendon, 1914 (1898)]). For bibliography on his significance to Dante see Anthony K. Cassell (Dante's Fearful Art of Justice [Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1984]), p. 117.

Robert Hollander

53  un'ombra, lungo questa, infino al mento:
54  credo che s'era in ginocchie levata.

55  Dintorno mi guardò, come talento
56  avesse di veder s'altri era meco;
57  e poi che 'l sospecciar fu tutto spento,

58  piangendo disse: “Se per questo cieco
59  carcere vai per altezza d'ingegno,
60  mio figlio ov' è? e perché non è teco?”

61  E io a lui: “Da me stesso non vegno:
62  olui ch'attende là per qui mi mena,
63  orse cui Guido vostro ebbe a disdegno.”

64  Le sue parole e 'l modo de la pena
65  m'avean di costui già letto il nome;
66  però fu la risposta così piena.

67  Di sùbito drizzato gridò: “Come?
68  dicesti 'elli ebbe'? non viv' elli ancora?
69  non fiere li occhi suoi lo dolce lume?”

70  Quando s'accorse d'alcuna dimora
71  ch'io facëa dinanzi a la risposta,
72  supin ricadde e più non parve fora.

52  Then there uprose upon the sight, uncovered
53  Down to the chin, a shadow at his side;
54  I think that he had risen on his knees.

55  Round me he gazed, as if solicitude
56  He had to see if some one else were with me,
57  But after his suspicion was all spent,

58  Weeping, he said to me: "If through this blind
59  Prison thou goest by loftiness of genius,
60  Where is my son? and why is he not with thee?"

61  And I to him: "I come not of myself;
62  He who is waiting yonder leads me here,
63  Whom in disdain perhaps your Guido had."

64  His language and the mode of punishment
65  Already unto me had read his name;
66  On that account my answer was so full.

67  Up starting suddenly, he cried out: "How
68  Saidst thou,—he had? Is he not still alive?
69  Does not the sweet light strike upon his eyes?"

70  When he became aware of some delay,
72  Which I before my answer made, supine
73  He fell again, and forth appeared no more.

THE INTERRUPTION: Now in the middle of the exchange between Dante and Farinata, which is more like a renewal of old political factualism than anything like a debate, an internecine squabble rather a denial even of Epicureanism, in so far as the argument itself, continued after death, is the same argument that we see constantly between dead and living family members inside the heads of the survivors.  Haven't we seen this over and over again in sons and daughters whose parents have died?  They refuse to let them die, and renew the arguments daily as an internal chatter which wipes out any pleasure that might be had in the moment, and casts the survivor into the sarcophagus with the dead?  The dead may indeed cease living in their own bodies, but they then take up residence inside the bodies of the survivors, and the latter become rather like sarcophagi themselves, sarcophagi situated in Hell, alive only in the sense that their continued existence depends upon keeping the conflict alive at the expense of living.

When Cavalcante de ‘Cavalcanti pops up beside Farinata from the same tomb, the two, Cavalcante and Farinata seem not to recognize one another at all.  They are like the same re-run of a television program, shown at the same time, but on different channels, side by side, but on completely different frequencies so that only the watcher is aware of their propinquitous positions, and not they themselves.  Trying to visualize their positions in the same sarcophagus makes one think of those awful old newsreels of the Nazi deathcamps, where the bodies are all jumbled together, their limbs tessellated so that one body is entangled with several others, and yet it is all a mound of corpses, inseparably bound together in history and on film, but unable to really communicate to one another.  This situation should stun us, as readers, and make us weep both for what we have become in relation to the dead, and what we might become when we ourselves have left our mortal bodies.

Cavalcante de ‘Cavalcanti is the father of Dante's best friend, and he clearly expects his son, the poet Guido Cavalcanti, to be beside Dante as he must have, during life, seen the two friends side by side many times.  And yet he does not see his son, and neither does he see Virgil.  And what do we see in the tragic figure of the father who wishes that his son may still be alive, and not subject to the torment of living death, which is the elder Cavalcanti's fate.  We see the tissue of concern for father and son which survives death, but also that same tissue connecting them as doomed Epicureans.   Realizing this, it's easy to see one story as an analogy to the other.   Florence, and Florentines share the same language and home, yet they nevertheless fall into brutal conflict, which ends in exile, death, and nearly the razing of the city itself.  So, internal fracturing and political factioning show us that the city is the macrocosm of the family and the individual.   The city, or if you prefer the nation, or the religion, become, not the abode of one family of fellow citizens, but rather, like the mind of one tortured by conflicting thoughts, a nest of murderers, who in killing one another, do not realize that they are committing suicide.  It is fitting, that this place, being Hell, does not permit Dante to relieve Cavalcanti’s concern that his son is dead and damned as well, and in the stunned pause of seeing his friend's father and trying perhaps to imagine what his own part in these Florentine civil wars has been or might be, the father sinks back in despair, while Dante, self-absorbed, in a very un-Epicurean act, misses the opportunity of the moment, and he finds himself talking again to Farinata, and reviving the old argument about which faction of the city was crueler and deserved the most blame for the bloody strife that was destroying, generation after generation, so many lives of fellow citizens.  Further on, when Dante asks Farinata to inform Cavalcanti that his son still lives (line 109-114 below), the reader, if she or he has been following what has been going on, will have perhaps another pang of anguish at how unlikely it is that Farinata would or could deliver that comforting message.   

73  Ma quell' altro magnanimo, a cui posta
74  restato m'era, non mutò aspetto,
75  né mosse collo, né piegò sua costa;

76  e sé continüando al primo detto,
77    “S'elli han quell' arte,” disse, “male appresa,
78  ciò mi tormenta più che questo letto.

79  Ma non cinquanta volte fia raccesa
80  la faccia de la donna che qui regge,
81  che tu saprai quanto quell' arte pesa.

82  E se tu mai nel dolce mondo regge,
83  dimmi: perché quel popolo è sì empio
84  incontr' a' miei in ciascuna sua legge?”

85  Ond' io a lui: “Lo strazio e 'l grande scempio
86  che fece l'Arbia colorata in rosso,
87  tal orazion fa far nel nostro tempio.”

88  Poi ch'ebbe sospirando il capo mosso,
89  “A ciò non fu' io sol,” disse, “né certo
90  sanza cagion con li altri sarei mosso.

91  Ma fu' io solo, là dove sofferto
92  fu per ciascun di tòrre via Fiorenza,
93  colui che la difesi a viso aperto.”

94  “Deh, se riposi mai vostra semenza,”
95  prega' io lui, “solvetemi quel nodo
96  che qui ha 'nviluppata mia sentenza.

97  El par che voi veggiate, se ben odo,
98  dinanzi quel che 'l tempo seco adduce,
99  e nel presente tenete altro modo.”

100  “Noi veggiam, come quei c'ha mala luce,
101  le cose,” disse, “che ne son lontano;
102  cotanto ancor ne splende il sommo duce.

103  Quando s'appressano o son, tutto è vano
104  nostro intelletto; e s'altri non ci apporta,
105  nulla sapem di vostro stato umano.

106  Però comprender puoi che tutta morta
107  fia nostra conoscenza da quel punto
108  che del futuro fia chiusa la porta.”

109  Allor, come di mia colpa compunto,
110  dissi: “Or direte dunque a quel caduto
111 che 'l suo nato è co' vivi ancor congiunto;

112  e s'i' fui, dianzi, a la risposta muto,
113  fate i saper che 'l fei perché pensava
114  già ne l'error che m'avete soluto.”

73  But the other, magnanimous, at whose desire
74  I had remained, did not his aspect change,
75  Neither his neck he moved, nor bent his side.

76  "And if," continuing his first discourse,
77  "They have that art," he said, "not learned aright,
78  That more tormenteth me, than doth this bed.

79  But fifty times shall not rekindled be
80  The countenance of the Lady who reigns here,
81  Ere thou shalt know how heavy is that art;

82  And as thou wouldst to the sweet world return,
83  Say why that people is so pitiless
84  Against my race in each one of its laws?"

85  Whence I to him: "The slaughter and great carnage
86  Which have with crimson stained the Arbia, cause
87  Such orisons in our temple to be made."

88  After his head he with a sigh had shaken,
89  "There I was not alone," he said, "nor surely
90  Without a cause had with the others moved.

91  But there I was alone, where every one
92  Consented to the laying waste of Florence,
93  He who defended her with open face."

94  "Ah! so hereafter may your seed repose,"
95  I him entreated, "solve for me that knot,
96  Which has entangled my conceptions here.

97  It seems that you can see, if I hear rightly,
98  Beforehand whatsoe'er time brings with it,
99  And in the present have another mode."

100  "We see, like those who have imperfect sight,
101  The things," he said, "that distant are from us;
102  So much still shines on us the Sovereign Ruler.

103  When they draw near, or are, is wholly vain
104  Our intellect, and if none brings it to us,
105  Not anything know we of your human state.

106  Hence thou canst understand, that wholly dead
107  Will be our knowledge from the moment when
108  The portal of the future shall be closed."

109  Then I, as if compunctious for my fault,
110  Said: "Now, then, you will tell that fallen one,
111  That still his son is with the living joined.

112  And if just now, in answering, I was dumb,
113  Tell him I did it because I was thinking
114  Already of the error you have solved me."

What an image: the stiff, unmoving shade of Farinata, who, as though made of stone, simply continues speaking as if Cavalcanti had not interrupted.  It is as though time itself in these realms is divided up according to the consciousness of the person who perceives it.  In this case the time that Cavalcanti spoke to Dante does not seem to have existed for Farinata, nor did Farinata's conversation with Dante seem to exist for Cavalcanti.  Yet later, when asked, Farinata can tell Dante who resides in the sarcophagus with him, so that his perception seems entirely based on his arbitrary point-of-view of the moment.  Farinata exists only as a rather fuzzy amalgamation of beliefs, and he splashes around in that puddle of historical events concerned solely with his faction and his family.  He does not see how his thoughts have a certain transparency about them through which we can see superimposed on, or beneath, his obsessions.  As readers, we can see what the poet shows us: the clearer shapes and patterns of history which Farinata cannot see.  We realize that this superimposition or superinterpolation is in fact a deeper vision of reality than the physical eyes could ever see, but which imagination can see, and seeing, probe.  Language gives us this view, not in its literal and linear expositions, but in it metaphors.  The poem enables us to transcend, with our minds and emotions, the time and space which imprison our bodies and make them mortal.  And strange too that this superimposition of damned post-mortem bodies in the space of the sarcophagus seems also to have this superimposition of time — a thing spoken about by Borges in his story "The Alpha" — which is: the difficulty in expressing in linear language these kinds of simultaneities.  Dante does it by innuendo with the simple phrase "as if" (e sé) in line 76.  There is more argument about exile, and the mutual punishments of the warring factions, and, possibly out of maliciousness, Farinata prophesies Dante's exile, a prophesy that Dante accepts, as we see later when he asks the shade how it is that he can see into the future, but have no conception of the present.  And isn't this an amazing and succinct portrayal of anxiety, i.e., Farinata still retains all his rancor of the past, still obsesses on the wrongs done to him and his family, still makes a defense of his actions in recounting his refusing to allow his allies to destroy Florence, and still uses that obsession, as if following the pattern of a temporal weave, to predict that Dante too will suffer exile.  The damned, like the conglomerated beasts of Minos and Cerberus, seem to be, in consciousness, a conglomerate of past resentments and future premonitions, but with no more experience of the present than a corpse without a soul.  An ironic fate for an Epicurean, not to live in this present that philosophically they have exalted to a doctrine of pleasure without consequences during their lives.  Odd too, as in the case with Ciacco and gluttony in Canto VI, that most of this canto seems not to be about the heresy of Epicureanism at all, but rather the destruction of human beings by the factionalization and fractionalization of civil war and internal conflict.  And yet, Dante, the poet, is always concerned with deeper causes.  He may let his protagonist wallow in partisan vitriol, bemoaning the bloodbath at the Arbia river, and gloating a bit that his allies include in their prayers requests for the destruction of Farinata and his ilk, but as a poet, he is always digging deeper, burrowing into Hell, as if his knowledge about these states of consciousness which produce and perpetuate such agony, might later prove to be stairsteps, not deeper into the dungeon of Hell, but up to the blessings offered in Heaven.  In Hell, his is a kind Jnana Yoga, the Yoga of knowledge, of reason, the persistence to work at those knots that bind the soul to a miserable illusion.  Fundamentally, Farinata is in error, in error about the deeper meanings of the past, and is only darkly — by inner light — luce — perhaps his last remnant of God's grace — aware of the pattern of revenge and retribution as it continues to play out in his version of the future.  But everything he sees is filtered through a kind stiff and stubborn lunacy, and is but vaguely illuminated by the mutable light of the Lady of the Moon.  The moon metaphor here, like all of Dante's, suggest that Farinita's insight is only a parodic reflection of divine light, is only the confusing and fickle mix of darkness and light, as is the face of the moon.  The difference between Farinata's perception and Dante's is that for Farinata this pattern is an inescapable web of fate, but for Dante it is an illusory pattern that can, in this case, with the light of reason, be seen through and transcended.  Dante, the protagonist, is a question asker, a seeker in whatever time and place — and from whoever is the denizen of that time and place — of insight.  From Farinata, who is so deluded about time, so tragically ignorant of the present, he learns a curious thing about time, and that is, that when time's past and future illusions collide in a present blessedness, only the present will exist.  That collision, which destroys time itself is called "Last Judgement."   In the world of the eternally blessed, this last judgement is the final step into a state that can have no possibility of judgement.  This is the direction that Dante, the aspirant, is moving, and of which the petrified Farinata is ignorant.  And even here, Farinata keeps asking the wrong questions, the answers to which, simply mire him deeper in his illusions.  Yet, even in Hell, the poet keeps following this breadcrumb trail to a state of blessedness that is inconceivable in Hell, but which even the damned dimly sense.  In the early Hell cantos, Dante, the aspirant, is caught up in sympathy for the sinner (Francesca, for example), but here, through the sharing of a common language with his disputant, he is beginning to ask about and interpret a more probing kind of intelligence.  Dante, the aspirant, is becoming Dante, the poet.  And we, as readers, need to share in his transformation, so that our reading moves from the surface meaning of the text, to its deeper implications.

115  E già 'l maestro mio mi richiamava;
116  per ch'i' pregai lo spirto più avaccio
117  che mi dicesse chi con lu' istava.

118  Dissemi: “Qui con più di mille giaccio:
119  qua dentro è 'l secondo Federico
120  e 'l Cardinale; e de li altri mi taccio.”

121  Indi s'ascose; e io inver' l'antico
122  poeta volsi i passi, ripensando
123  a quel parlar che mi parea nemico.

124  Elli si mosse; e poi, così andando,
125  mi disse: “Perché se' tu sì smarrito?”
126  E io li sodisfeci al suo dimando.

127  “La mente tua conservi quel ch'udito
128  hai contra te,” mi comandò quel saggio;
129  “e ora attendi qui,” e drizzò 'l dito:

130  “quando sarai dinanzi al dolce raggio
131  di quella il cui bell' occhio tutto vede,
132  da lei saprai di tua vita il vïaggio.”

133  Appresso mosse a man sinistra il piede:
134  lasciammo il muro e gimmo inver' lo mezzo
135  per un sentier ch'a una valle fiede,

136  che 'nfin là sù facea spiacer suo lezzo.

115  And now my Master was recalling me,
116  Wherefore more eagerly I prayed the spirit
117  That he would tell me who was with him there.
118  He said: "With more than a thousand here I lie;
119  Within here is the second Frederick,
120  And the Cardinal, and of the rest I speak not."
121  Thereon he hid himself; and I towards
122  The ancient poet turned my steps, reflecting
123  Upon that saying, which seemed hostile to me.
124  He moved along; and afterward thus going,
125  He said to me, "Why art thou so bewildered?"
126  And I in his inquiry satisfied him.
127  "Let memory preserve what thou hast heard
128  Against thyself," that Sage commanded me,
129  "And now attend here;" and he raised his finger.
130  "When thou shalt be before the radiance sweet
131  Of her whose beauteous eyes all things behold,
132  From her thou'lt know the journey of thy life."
133  Unto the left hand then he turned his feet;
134  We left the wall, and went towards the middle,
135  Along a path that strikes into a valley,

136  Which even up there unpleasant made its stench.

Canto X ends with the aspirant being called back to reason — a reason that is bent on the discovery of soul-truths, and not just historical curiosity.  The aspirant wants to know what other Epicureans lie jumbled in the tomb with Farinata.  And in keeping with the entire text's reticence to spread the fame of the damned by bruiting their fates to the upper world, Farinata names only two of the more than a thousand who share his fate.  Those two are Frederic the second, and a man called the Cardinal — one a secular leader, the other an official of the church — each a partisan of the great factions whose conflicts bred so much hatred, deceit, and murder in Dante's time.  The commentary below from Robert Hollander* will tell the interested reader who these men were in history, but what the reader is challenged to learn by these cautionary examples of the damned is something deeper than historical facts — something like the way in which historicity itself calls us away from our mind's concomitance with the soul, and makes psyche a slave to physis, a slave to all the ego's mistaken way of sustaining its mortal house by dominating, using, and murdering other living entities.  Virgil tells Dante to mark well what Farinata has told him about his future exile.  Perhaps he is telling Dante to turn away from the little exile of his historical exile, and all the suffering it caused him and his family, and to remember instead, that it is this very historical lesson, which turns him on the path that will lead to his fulfillment in the gaze of his beloved Beatrice, she, so unlike Farinata, whose beauteous eyes all things behold (bell' occhio tutto vede), and in whose presence he will learn the purpose of his life.  The little gesture here, of Virgil raising his finger to make his point, is easy to visualize.  It was painted by Raphael two centuries later, as the figure of Plato (Leonardo da Vinci) in his work: The School of Athens.  And of course, Leonardo himself became almost obsessed with this gesture as it evolved to become a sign pointing to the enigma of Heaven.

*  Frederick II (1194-1250), King of Sicily and Naples (1212-50), known in his own day as stupor mundi (the wonder of the world) for his extraordinary verve and accomplishments, presided over one of the most glorious courts in Europe. His political battles with the papacy marked nearly the full extent of his reign (he was the victorious leader of the Sixth Crusade [1228-29], 'won' by treaty, while he was under interdict of excommunication). As exemplary of the Guelph view of him see Salimbene: 'Erat enim epicureus, et ideo quidquid poterat invenire in divina scriptura per se et per sapientes suos quod faceret ad ostendendum quod non esset alia vita post mortem, totum inveniebat' (For he was an Epicurean, and as a result whatever he could find in holy scripture itself, or from those who knew the scripture, that would help demonstrate that there were no life after death, he totally set himself to finding – Cronica). 
Cardinal Ottaviano degli Ubaldini, member of a powerful Tuscan Ghibelline family, known to his contemporaries as “the Cardinal” par excellence, was brother of Ubaldino della Pila (Purg. XXIV.29) and uncle of the Archbishop Ruggieri (Inf. XXXIII.14); he was made Bishop of Bologna in 1240, when he was under thirty, by special dispensation of Pope Gregory IX, and in 1244 he was created Cardinal by Innocent IV at the Council of Lyons; he was papal legate in Lombardy, and died in 1272. [He] was suspected of favouring the imperial party, and is credited with a saying: “If I have a soul, I have lost it a thousand times for the Ghibellines”' (the remark is cited by nearly every fourteenth-century commentator found in the DDP). The passage is cited from Paget Toynbee, Concise Dante Dictionary (Oxford: Clarendon, 1914 [1898]), “Cardinale, Il.” 

At the beginning of the journey, the two protagonists turn right, passing along a narrow path between the city's wall and the tombs of the tormented.  If they are going right, the wall must be on their right, and the tombs on their left — the left symbolizing the direction of torment, of error.  The fact that here at the end of the canto, they turn left again, indicates that they are passed these torments of the Epicureans, which seems a kind of high marshy plateau situated against the laws of nature wherein marshes are generally on low ground, a geographic perversion just as the uncovered sepulchers wherein the dead were entombed above ground was a perversion of burial rites of burying the dead below ground.  The protagonists stand on an eminence — turning left in an Aristotelian move to middle ground, the fumes of the deeper levels of Hell rising up as a stench.   Is this the stench of the undead, their bodies disappeared by the noisome process of putrefaction, and the putrefaction alone remaining?  Now these bodies are not the products of cellular activity, but mental reactivity.  A living man, as out of place as a zombie would be in world of sunlight which sustains physical bodies, has entered the realm of MIND, a world of secondary selves, the image of whose forms are not generated by biological processes, but by a certain affect — lust, gluttony, rage, a sense of injustice, a sense of entitlement, a need for retribution, and so forth.  Every person alive has such affects, but not every person ignores all the facts of physical and metaphysical possibilities — our needs, our dependence on the entire panoply of the living for our own lives — to indulge in one affect at the expense of all the others, to indulge in an affect to the detriment of the very body and bodies which sustain it.  If it is the responsibility of mind to care for and love the living, it is the fate of the damned that they betray the mind's or the soul's true responsibilities.  They do not take care of life, instead they only cultivate one parasitical emotion that destroys life, and dooms them to an afterlife of perpetual torment and decay.

Canto XI
There is a thoroughness in this step by step progression of contemplating the Commedia, which allows us to see how every detail of the text enriches and creates an overall pattern.  But we miss, by this method, seeing certain elements of the work which might be described as its accumulative overall effect on our own mind, or as Dante usually refers to it, our soul.  So before we start on the actual text of Canto XI, let's allow our minds to explore some of those accumulating overall effects.  If evolution shows the potential of Life to proliferate, to enrich, and to create innumerable niches for its activities and expressions, then Dante's text, shows how Mind can also proliferate into the realm of Death, creating innumerable niches for its activities and expressions.  Life has no judgements, and therefore no justice, but Death shows us that the mind's potential for expression can rectify that horror, and supply the punishments, lessons, and rewards that Life — Life in its Darwinian evolutionary processes — does not, and cannot have.  In this way, Death augments and completes Life, and provides a ground for justice, guidance, and grace.  What is wrong with Epicureanism and the heresy that Photinus represents in this Canto, namely, that Christ was wholly human, because no Divine personage could emerge between a piss hole and a shit hole from a corruptible human uterus, is that they deprive the mind of the potential to create any justice, guidance, or grace to supersede the temporality and suffering of Life.  Blake said: "God is everywhere, even in the depths of Hell,"   but substitute the word mind, for God, and we show that there is a power in mind, often called the imagination, that can break through the evolutionary process of survival of the fittest, wherein suffering is as pervasive as it is meaningless, and time is nothing more than the operation of chance as surely destroying as it creates its accidental progeny.  Mind, through imagination's power, can break through to a realm of transcendent potential: that is to say, the potential of imagination to create an atemporal realm wherein Divine justice and mercy cannot only exist, but can lend their potential for creativity to human life, and demand for Mind a cosmic kingdom to supplant the chaos of dissolution which awaits all mortal things at the threshold of Death.  Mind, Imagination, God, Soul, Potential — whatever you want to call this mysterious IT, IT can and does create Worlds not subject to the depredations of mere chance.  This is why in Canto VII (note the cryptological significance of the number 7) chance is changed to Lady Fortune.   She is Divinely appointed to reign over temporal life, as a wheel in which everyone eventually is subject to the same vicissitudes.  Life exists on this wheel and as this wheel, and the wheel turns from birth to death though all the randomly occurring degrees of pleasure and suffering.  But Death, more alive than all the living, is Mind's potential for creating and exploring that which omits chance from its geometric constants.  Death, as Dante shows again and again in the sublime structure of the Commedia, enriches life by giving it a place to transcend its own limitations and helplessness.  The punishments of those in Hell, the lessons of those in Purgatory, and the glory of those in Paradise are all aspects of the Mind's supreme power to expand IT's potential, and to colonize with imaginative entities a world beyond the meaningless machinations of Time.

When we meditate, contemplate, study, scientifically investigate, artistically create, read, listen, teach, speak, we are exploring the potentials of Mind, and expanding the potentials of the Divine to the very idea of the Divine.  To say that we cannot do this, is also a potential of the Mind.  The heresies of the Epicureans and the Photians, or of Marxist materialists, is that they deny the Mind access to its most fertile field of potentiality, and throw everything back into the meaningless domain of chance and temporality.  The more astringent their efforts to enforce this limitation, the more, in Dante's imagination, they condemn themselves, in the body or as a shade, to interminable suffering.

Sense of smell: resisting symbolization.  Freud's quote from the Interpretation of Dreams, quotes from the Smell Culture, replacing smell with hearing and seeing,  organizing the stench of sin, which removes the chaotic, omnidirectional nature of scent by human rationality not animal (bestial) sniffing — why the epithet "dog" is an insult.

I have had a harder time coming to grips with Canto XI than with any canto encounter thus far in the inferno.  I think the protagonist — and the committed reader — are in the greatest danger they have been in since the very first canto.  We have survived the impasse of Canto X, and in a sense, we are starting over with the number 1 again.  Having been shaken to our core by the impasse from the previous canto, now we are at a height overlooking the deepest abyss of Hell, and the stench exuded by that abyss presents to us another impasse, this time not fomented by the demons which guarded the Gate of Dis, but by our own senses.  The smell represents a repulsive sensory overload, which is more daunting, because it is inside us as a sensory perception, which has become a kind of autoimmune disease: our own defense mechanism, no longer just serving as a warning, buy actually attacking us, and preventing us from proceeding on our spiritual quest.  What to do?  Virgil's solution is emblematic of the entire thrust of Christianity's strategy to overcome the sense-based superstitious world of Paganism, with a rational moral order, held in place by the miracles of divine grace.  This strategy is spelled out by Virgil in lines 10 - 12:

10  “Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo,
11  sì che s'ausi un poco in prima il senso
12  al tristo fiato; e poi no i fia riguardo.”

10  "Slow it behoveth our descent to be,
11  So that the sense be first a little used
12  To the sad blast, and then we shall not heed it."

The protagonists draw behind a tomb to escape the blast, and here begins a rather Freudian exercise of displacement.  Namely, we begin to shift psychic or neuronal activity from smell to a story, the elements of which are abstract and a-sensory — a retreat, as we may call it, from sense to argument.  A hint of how the psyche accomplishes this displacement is given in Freud's Interpretation of Dreams:

The dream-thoughts are immediately comprehensible, as soon as we have learnt them.  The dream-content, on the other hand, is expressed as it were in a pictographic script, the characters of which have to be transposed individually into the language of the dream-thoughts.  If we attempted to read these characters according to their pictorial value instead of according to their symbolic relation, we should clearly be led into error:  Suppose I have a picture-puzzle, a rebus, i front of me.  It depicts a house with a boat on its roof, a single letter of the alphabet, the figure of a running man whose head has been conjured away, and so on.  Now I might be misled into raising objections and declaring the picture as a whole and its component parts are nonsensical.  A boat has no business to be on the roof of a house, and a headless man cannot run.  Moreover, the man is bigger than the house, and if the whole picture is intended to represent a landscape, letters of the alphabet are out of place in it since such objects do not occur in Nature.  But obviously we can only form a proper judgement of the rebus if we put aside criticisms such as these of the whole composition and its parts and if, instead, we try to replace each separate by a syllable or word that can by presented by that element in some way or other.  The words that are put together in this way are no longer nonsensical but may form a poetical phrase of the greatest beauty and significance.  A dream is a picture-puzzle of this sort and our predecessors in the field of dream-interpretation have made the mistake of treating the rebus as a pictorial composition and as such it has seemed to them nonsensical and worthless.

In Western languages, smells are notoriously un-symbolizable, and if from the above quote about the images in dreams, we change all the image references to smell ones, we get an inkling of what is happening in this canto.  We are displacing the intolerably complex and insupportable stench of sin, stink by stink with a logical, and geographical substitute.

Dante is showing the  power of the Mind (soul) to shift attention away from bodily discomfort (the stench).  As stated, Freud called displacement, but Dante saw this neurological strategy as the power of reason to move from body to soul, an equivalency of moving from ignorance to knowledge.  It is a distancing maneuver, from smell, to sight, as Virgil says in line 20.  If one reads the history of conversion of paganism to Christianity, invariably the evangelical Christian is seen challenging the local pagan to a rational debate, because reason has this power of neurological manipulation.  It is also the power for foreknowledge, which Virgil uses, as he tells the aspirant in detail, what he can expect to see as they descend deeper into Hell.

Do you remember when Virgil used the epithet "dog" to insult sinners.  Why is dog an insult?  Because they are guided by smell, the most bestial
of the senses, and "insane bestiality" is the third of Virgil's trinity of sins, the other two being incontinence and malice (incontenenza, malizia e la matta /Bestialitade).

Some internet sources on the sense of smell:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6015838/
link on smell in comparing Dutch and Jahai linguistic groups.

https://www.dana.org/uploadedFiles/Pdfs/Brain-Brief-Senses-Smell-and-Taste-FINAL.pdf
General article in the brain and smell
  
  
Geometry: Fixing a limit to injustice.  The ability of the Soul/Mind to do this demonstrates its Mastery over any condition: even the condition of interminable pain.

Smell is omni-directional, direct, with little or no mediation from the higher brain centers, and this is also true of sin.  Fixing a limit is an act of reason, we look in the closet to see that there is no monster there, but also we shut the closet door to confine the monster.  Virgil's entire exposition in this canto is to categorized and order the uncategorizable and the omnipresent.  He is making sin, the stink of sin, knowable, so that fear and injury has a limit.  He puts everything on the tabletop of reason, so that the Mind can manipulated what might otherwise destroy it.

It is also good to note here, that in the first three lines of this canto, the protagonists are standing near a circle of broken stones ... broken stones in a broken circle.  That is what sin does, it breaks the mold of life, love, vitality, and the possibility of grace.  It takes what is as solid as a rock (Remember Peter, and Christ's pun: On this rock I will build my church.) and as perfect and complete as a circle, and it breaks it up, and regresses creation back to chaos.  Virgil's exposition of all the geographical locations of sin in the remaining circles is how justice re-incorporates chaos back into divine order.  The justice — the often cruel justice — that we have seen, and will see more of as we complete our harrowing of Hell, is there to balance the scales.  But once those scales are balanced in the Last Judgement, neither justice, punishment, nor mercy will exist, because the scales have been balanced.  After that, we can throw the scales away.  But why is God's judgement so inflexible?  I think Dante might say because the quicker we balance those scales, the sooner we can throw them away.

Art as education, and as a mimesis of Nature's creative power.  The question of perpetual genesis.

Towards the end of this canto, the power of the artist is compared to the power God displays in Genesis.  His art could not be a copy of Nature, because before He spoke, there was no Nature, so mimesis cannot mean what it often commonly means: copy Nature's products.  What it does mean is that the artist, as Virgil says, is God's grandchild, and as such is also endowed with the power to create ex nihilo nihil fit?  It means that like God, the artist has the ability to create something out of nothing.  The interesting thing here is that Virgil emphasizes that it is Philosophy that teaches this, not art or poetry itself.  It is almost as if for the artist to recognize in him or herself this supreme power he or she must first rationally convince themselves that they have it — that is to say, we can, through the use of education — reason — find that portal to an inspiration that is beyond reason, and exists as God existed before He made the Universe: as a beinglessness with the pure and unlimited potential to manifest being. 

The pressure of time: At the beginning, pause, then learn, then move forward with alacrity.

At the beginning of this canto, the protagonists, pause, the stench creating an impasse that prevents them from immediately preceding.  They bide their time, and by means of insight and memory, they garner those resources, not the least of which is courage, which enables them to proceed.  Time, not Hell's Time, which as we have said is interminable, but Earth's mortal time, as it is made visible by celestial phenomenon, this earthly Time is the groove that the protagonists must follow on their pilgrimage to transcend Time.   Time, like Lady Fortune, is that Law which subjects all bodies, and is in this sense a source of compulsion, and even oppression, whereas, Space, as seem here in Virgil's comprehensive explanation of Hell's geography, can, even in Hell, be a comforting source of containment for those imprisoned by its laws.  Time and Space here are both sources of limitation, but just as narrow banks limit the course of water, they also add to its motion a self-purifying force.  So that even in Hell, they both become the generators of insight and art, the basic materials of manifestation so to speak, which imprison and circumscribe in order to tense a spring so that it might explode into eternity.  The fact that the protagonists know where to go — left, around, and down — and when to go, or stop, shows that their mastery comes not from resisting the laws of the 3 spatial dimensions (height, width, depth) and the 3 temporal ones (past, present, future), but by making use of them.  Knowing that creativity exists before Time and Space existed, tells us that the creative act comes through these dimensions, but does not draw its motive force from them.  The heresy of Photinus is the belief that the Son, of the Trinity, arose only as a temporal expression and did not exist prior to the time of the birth of Jesus is very similar to the Epicurean position which asserted that the soul is only the product and slave of space and time.  Dante, the writer, the artist, and the spiritual pilgrim, abominates these concepts, I would say, using a non-Christian symbology, because it is impossible to believe that potential — God — did not exist before the incarnation.  It is impossible to believe that something arose without the potential to arise.  Yet, something does arise from nothing, the vacuum is a plenum.  Potential is always the precursor of everything, including the operations of time and space.  To believe otherwise, may be a matter of faith, but not necessarily so.  Logic, philosophy, and reason also can guide us to a right understanding of this backgrounded illimitable quality.  There is ample evidence that Dante knew the Cabbala, and in that system, the Ain Soph is that unmanifest potential, which exists, and must have existed, as God's God, even before God's discovery of himself as a creative entity.  This is quite a different rationale for the existence of God than Saint Anselm's ontological tautology: God must exist, because we can conceive of a perfect being, and the primary element of perfection is existence.  But in this case, God must exist, because something is here, and potential must precede manifestation.  God is, the universe is, because it had the prior capacity to be. 


1  In su l'estremità d'un'alta ripa
2  che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio,
3  venimmo sopra più crudele stipa;

1  Upon the margin of a lofty bank
2  Which great rocks broken in a circle made,
3  We came upon a still more cruel throng;

4  e quivi, per l'orribile soperchio
5  del puzzo che 'l profondo abisso gitta,
6  ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio

4  And there, by reason of the horrible
5  Excess of stench the deep abyss throws out,
6  We drew ourselves aside behind the cover

7  d'un grand' avello, ov' io vidi una scritta
8  che dicea: “Anastasio papa guardo,
9  lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta.”

7  Of a great tomb, whereon I saw a writing,
8  Which said: "Pope Anastasius I hold,
9  Whom out of the right way Photinus drew."

10  “Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo,
11  sì che s'ausi un poco in prima il senso
12  al tristo fiato; e poi no i fia riguardo.”

10  "Slow it behoveth our descent to be,
11  So that the sense be first a little used
12  To the sad blast, and then we shall not heed it."

13  Così 'l maestro; e io “Alcun compenso,”
14  dissi lui, “trova che 'l tempo non passi
15  perduto.” Ed elli: “Vedi ch'a ciò penso.”

13  The Master thus; and unto him I said,
14  "Some compensation find, that the time pass not
15  Idly;" and he: "Thou seest I think of that.

16  “Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi,”
17  cominciò poi a dir, “son tre cerchietti
18  di grado in grado, come que' che lassi.

16  My son, upon the inside of these rocks,"
17  Began he then to say, "are three small circles,
18  From grade to grade, like those which thou art leaving.

19  Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti;
20  ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista,
21  intendi come e perché son costretti.

19  They all are full of spirits maledict;
20  But that hereafter sight alone suffice thee,
21  Hear how and wherefore they are in constraint.

22  D'ogne malizia, ch'odio in cielo acquista,
23  ingiuria è 'l fine, ed ogne fin cotale
24  o con forza o con frode altrui contrista.

22  Of every malice that wins hate in Heaven,
23  Injury is the end; and all such end
24  Either by force or fraud afflicteth others.


25  Ma perché frode è de l'uom proprio male,
26  più spiace a Dio; e però stan di sotto
27  li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale.

25  But because fraud is man's peculiar vice,
26  More it displeases God; and so stand lowest
27  The fraudulent, and greater dole assails them.

28  Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto;
29  ma perché si fa forza a tre persone,
30  in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto.

28  All the first circle of the Violent is;
29  But since force may be used against three persons,
30  In three rounds 'tis divided and constructed.

31  A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne
32  far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose,
33  come udirai con aperta ragione.

31  To God, to ourselves, and to our neighbour can we
32  Use force; I say on them and on their things,
33  As thou shalt hear with reason manifest.

34  Morte per forza e ferute dogliose
35  nel prossimo si danno, e nel suo avere
36  ruine, incendi e tollette dannose;

34  A death by violence, and painful wounds,
35  Are to our neighbour given; and in his substance
36  Ruin, and arson, and injurious levies;

37  onde omicide e ciascun che mal fiere,
38  guastatori e predon, tutti tormenta
39  lo giron primo per diverse schiere.

37  Whence homicides, and he who smites unjustly,
38  Marauders, and freebooters, the first round
39  Tormenteth all in companies diverse.

40  Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta
41  e ne' suoi beni; e però nel secondo
42  giron convien che sanza pro si penta

40  Man may lay violent hands upon himself
41  And his own goods; and therefore in the second
42  Round must perforce without avail repent

43  qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo,
44  biscazza e fonde la sua facultade,
45  e piange là dov' esser de' giocondo.

43  Whoever of your world deprives himself,
44  Who games, and dissipates his property,
45  And weepeth there, where he should jocund be.

46  Puossi far forza ne la deïtade,
47  col cor negando e bestemmiando quella,
48  e spregiando natura e sua bontade;

46  Violence can be done the Deity,
47  In heart denying and blaspheming Him,
48  And by disdaining Nature and her bounty.

49  e però lo minor giron suggella
50  del segno suo e Soddoma e Caorsa
51  e chi, spregiando Dio col cor, favella.

49  And for this reason doth the smallest round
50  Seal with its signet Sodom and Cahors,
51  And who, disdaining God, speaks from the heart.

52  La frode, ond' ogne coscïenza è morsa,
53  può l'omo usare in colui che 'n lui fida
54  e in quel che fidanza non imborsa.

52  Fraud, wherewithal is every conscience stung,
53  A man may practise upon him who trusts,
54  And him who doth no confidence imburse.

55  Questo modo di retro par ch'incida
56  pur lo vinco d'amor che fa natura;
57  onde nel cerchio secondo s'annida

55  This latter mode, it would appear, dissevers
56  Only the bond of love which Nature makes;
57  Wherefore within the second circle nestle

58  ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura,
59  falsità, ladroneccio e simonia,
60  ruffian, baratti e simile lordura.

58  Hypocrisy, flattery, and who deals in magic,
59  Falsification, theft, and simony,
60  Panders, and barrators, and the like filth.

61  Per l'altro modo quell' amor s'oblia
62  che fa natura, e quel ch'è poi aggiunto,
63  di che la fede spezïal si cria;

61  By the other mode, forgotten is that love
62  Which Nature makes, and what is after added,
63  From which there is a special faith engendered.

64  onde nel cerchio minore, ov' è 'l punto
65  de l'universo in su che Dite siede,
66  qualunque trade in etterno è consunto.”

64  Hence in the smallest circle, where the point is
65  Of the Universe, upon which Dis is seated,
66  Whoe'er betrays for ever is consumed."

67  E io: “Maestro, assai chiara procede
68  la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue
69  questo baràtro e 'l popol ch'e' possiede.

67  And I: "My Master, clear enough proceeds
68  Thy reasoning, and full well distinguishes
69  This cavern and the people who possess it.

70  Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue,
71  che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia,
72  e che s'incontran con sì aspre lingue,

70  But tell me, those within the fat lagoon,
71  Whom the wind drives, and whom the rain doth beat,
72  And who encounter with such bitter tongues,

73  perché non dentro da la città roggia
74  sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira?
75  e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?”

73  Wherefore are they inside of the red city
74  Not punished, if God has them in his wrath,
75  And if he has not, wherefore in such fashion?"

76  Ed elli a me “Perché tanto delira,”
77  disse, “lo 'ngegno tuo da quel che sòle?
78  o ver la mente dove altrove mira?

76  And unto me he said: "Why wanders so
77  Thine intellect from that which it is wont?
78  Or, sooth, thy mind where is it elsewhere looking?

79  Non ti rimembra di quelle parole
80  con le quai la tua Etica pertratta
81  le tre disposizion che 'l ciel non vole,

79  Hast thou no recollection of those words
80  With which thine Ethics thoroughly discusses
81  The dispositions three, that Heaven abides not,—

82  incontenenza, malizia e la matta
83  bestialitade? e come incontenenza
84  men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?

82  Incontinence, and Malice, and insane
83  Bestiality? and how Incontinence
84  Less God offendeth, and less blame attracts?

85  Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza,
86  e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli
87  che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,

85  If thou regardest this conclusion well,
86  And to thy mind recallest who they are
87  That up outside are undergoing penance,

88  tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli
89  sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata
90  la divina vendetta li martelli.”

88  Clearly wilt thou perceive why from these felons
89  They separated are, and why less wroth
90  Justice divine doth smite them with its hammer."

91  “O sol che sani ogne vista turbata,
92  tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi,
93  che, non men che saver, dubbiar m'aggrata.

91  "O Sun, that healest all distempered vision,
92  Thou dost content me so, when thou resolvest,
93  That doubting pleases me no less than knowing!

94  Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi,”
95  diss' io, “là dove di' ch'usura offende
96  la divina bontade, e 'l groppo solvi.”

94  Once more a little backward turn thee," said I,
95  "There where thou sayest that usury offends
96  Goodness divine, and disengage the knot."

97  “Filosofia,” mi disse, “a chi la 'ntende,
98  nota, non pure in una sola parte,
99  come natura lo suo corso prende

97  "Philosophy," he said, "to him who heeds it,
98  Noteth, not only in one place alone,
99  After what manner Nature takes her course

100  dal divino 'ntelletto e da sua arte;
101  e se tu ben la tua Fisica note,
102  tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,

100  From Intellect Divine, and from its art;
101  And if thy Physics carefully thou notest,
102  After not many pages shalt thou find,

103  che l'arte vostra quella, quanto pote,
104  segue, come 'l maestro fa 'l discente;
105  sì che vostr' arte a Dio quasi è nepote.

103  That this your art as far as possible
104  Follows, as the disciple doth the master;
105  That your art is, as it were, God's grandchild.

106  Da queste due, se tu ti rechi a mente
107  lo Genesì dal principio, convene
108  prender sua vita e avanzar la gente;

106  From these two, if thou bringest to thy mind
107  Genesis at the beginning, it behoves
108  Mankind to gain their life and to advance;

109  e perché l'usuriere altra via tene,
110  per sé natura e per la sua seguace
111  dispregia, poi ch'in altro pon la spene.

109  And since the usurer takes another way,
110  Nature herself and in her follower
111  Disdains he, for elsewhere he puts his hope.

112  Ma seguimi oramai che 'l gir mi piace;
113  ché i Pesci guizzan su per l'orizzonta,
114  e 'l Carro tutto sovra 'l Coro giace,

112  But follow, now, as I would fain go on,
113  For quivering are the Fishes on the horizon,
114  And the Wain wholly over Caurus lies,

115  e 'l balzo via là oltra si dismonta.”

115  And far beyond there we descend the crag."

Canto XII
If Canto XI was a kind of stagnation, a stuck place where stench accumulates and where the protagonist find shelter while Virgil lays out the map of Hell for the aspirant, then Canto XII is full of motion, even the cliff of the landscape moving down slope at the violent reaction of Hell and Earth to being injected by Divine Love.  There is motion, and there is mixture, which makes for monsters, those hybrid creatures — the Minotaur and the Centaurs — whose entities are conglomerates of species which were never meant to breed, and whose licentiousness gave birth to atrocities.  

Dante begins Canto XII be extending the broken rock metaphor with which he began Canto XI, but now the scale has grown enormously.  (Recall how he used this device of "evolving" a metaphor in the circle of lust, where the bird metaphor keeps evolving from flock, to line of cranes, to a pair of turtledoves, and here he carries the same metaphor over to begin these two canto's, tying the pair together stylistically, while totally changing the stagnant, theological explanation of Canto XI to a swirl of action and various speakers in Canto XII — the conversation wherein Virgil insults the Minotaur and compels the cannibal to let them past, this we have seen before, but now the insult is more subtle and more biting, and the Minotaur, for all his rage, still seems wedded to the cascade of rocks where he lounges, and the pilgrims pass.
Then come the Centaurs, who though in Hell, suffer only to the extent that their tasks and motions as punishers, is incessant.  Of these there are thousands and thousands, racing along the narrow banks of a boiling river of blood, and piercing with arrows any of the mobs of sinners who attempt to escape this dreadful moat.  Three Centaurs (for Cryptologists, there's that number 3 again) challenge the protagonists, but then help them, not unwillingly, as we have seen other monsters do in the poem so far, but with a sense of understanding.  Nessus, who is singled out for his crimes and impetuosity, becomes tame in ferrying the living body of Dante across the ford of the boiling blood river.  And it is Nessus, who with permission from Virgil, explains who these sinners are, and why some are allowed to rise from the boiling flood, some only to the eyebrows, some to the throat, some to the chest, and some, where the blood covers only their feet.  These are those  who have done deliberate violence to others, and since they are now in Hell for it, to themselves, and they are submerged to different depths according to the egregiousness of their crimes.

Here are some questions worth pondering: 

Are the punishers, the centaurs, themselves being punished?  After all, they are merely eternally pursuing the pleasures of the hunt, which was also the occupation of their lives.  And, in the case of Nessus, teaching too, which they in life took up as their professions, remains a possibility for them ... and all this prompts the question: Are there some unnatural mutations which nevertheless serve a purpose in Nature and for the Divine?  Can it be that some monsters are not monstrous?

Is the landscape that we all feel around us, as well as the weather, influenced by our collective moral and emotional state?  This idea is still with us: The idea that there are no truly impersonal events — and even the shapes of mountains and rivers and the destruction of storms, earthquakes, and cyclones are somehow the karmic results of human activity, and that activity would not only be burning fossil fuels, mining, clear-cutting, etc.  — but also waging war, expressing hatred and greed, wallowing one's whole life in a river of anger and that internal "blood boiling" feeling which rage is said to engender.  We know how the stress of incessant anger works on the body, and we know how this personal anger spills over into the destructive enterprises.  But do we seriously consider that in addition to shaping history, that there is also a geographical price to pay, as, for example, fracking causing earthquake, fossil fuel burning causing the greenhouse effect, melting the icecaps and raising the sea level, and over grazing or clear-cutting causing desertification.  Might there not also be an emotional state that influences not only our human internal state, but the climate and landscape too.  In the Divine Commedia, these human states create and sustain a landscape and an atmosphere that mirrors the moral condition of its denizen.  How far-fetched is it to ponder that our cities, our landscapes, our climate also mirrors our moral condition?  This monstrous mixing which has created monstrous mutants, is also happening at a macro scale, in so far that we are not only warping ourselves with our violence, but also warping our environment, so that it can no longer fulfill its natural function as a nourisher, but which, like the centaurs in Canto XII, has now become our punisher.  All this is very anthropomorphic, but is it wrong to relate to whatever world we find ourselves in as one subjectivity to another?  And is the only alternative to this anthropomorphizing that everything either inside us or outside us is only the result of blind chance and the cause and effect changes that happen in gravity, electromagnetic, chemical, and strong and weak nuclear force fields?  If we are reading Dante seriously, we have to decide if such a thing as an entity with volition could actually exist.  And if so, at what scale does this volitional subjective entity exist?  At the scale of tube worms?  Of galaxies?  Albert Sweitzer said: "I am life that wants to live, in the midst of life that wants to live."  Can we even develop a moral sense beyond our own gratification of the moment without the belief that others — at any scale — also have an inner sense of their own life, a sense that can be injured, and whose injury is part of a whole which suffers also when it causes or is made to suffer?

I think, and I believe Dante thought this too, that such questions elude theology and reason, for all their centuries of attempts to resolve them.  I think that poetry, because it involves the physiology of breathing and the speech act, and because it may utilize theology and reason to probe the profundity of dreams and of the waking-imagination, poetry, more even than physics, or neurological science, opens an experiential gap in the impregnability of others — poetry allows us to enter our own subjective states so fully that we begin also to experience the subjectivity of other people and also of what we too often consider to be inanimate in nature.  We are ourselves hybrid creatures, part physical metaphysics, and part metaphysics becoming physical, and Dante, by presenting the protagonist of his unenlightened self, as a living being among the dead, is showing us the ultimate conglomeration: A human being facing a moral dilemma.   

1  Era lo loco ov' a scender la riva
2  venimmo, alpestro e, per quel che v'er' anco,
3  tal, ch'ogne vista ne sarebbe schiva.

1  The place where to descend the bank we came
2  Was alpine, and from what was there, moreover,
3  Of such a kind that every eye would shun it.

4  Qual è quella ruina che nel fianco
5  di qua da Trento l'Adice percosse,
6  o per tremoto o per sostegno manco,

4  Such as that ruin is which in the flank
5  Smote, on this side of Trent, the Adige,
6  Either by earthquake or by failing stay,

7  che da cima del monte, onde si mosse,
8  al piano è sì la roccia discoscesa,
9  ch'alcuna via darebbe a chi sù fosse:

7  For from the mountain's top, from which it moved,
8  Unto the plain the cliff is shattered so,
9  Some path 'twould give to him who was above;

10  cotal di quel burrato era la scesa;
11  e 'n su la punta de la rotta lacca
12  l'infamïa di Creti era distesa

10  Even such was the descent of that ravine,
11  And on the border of the broken chasm
12  The infamy of Crete was stretched along,

13  che fu concetta ne la falsa vacca;
14  e quando vide noi, sé stesso morse,
15  sì come quei cui l'ira dentro fiacca.

13  Who was conceived in the fictitious cow;
14  And when he us beheld, he bit himself,
15  Even as one whom anger racks within.

16  Lo savio mio inver' lui gridò: “Forse
17  tu credi che qui sia 'l duca d'Atene,
18  che sù nel mondo la morte ti porse?

16  My Sage towards him shouted: "Peradventure
17  hou think'st that here may be the Duke of Athens,
18  Who in the world above brought death to thee?

19  Pàrtiti, bestia, ché questi non vene
20  ammaestrato da la tua sorella,
21  ma vassi per veder le vostre pene.”

19  Get thee gone, beast, for this one cometh not
20  Instructed by thy sister, but he comes
21  In order to behold your punishments."

22  Qual è quel toro che si slaccia in quella
23  c'ha ricevuto già 'l colpo mortale,
24  che gir non sa, ma qua e là saltella,

22  As is that bull who breaks loose at the moment
23  In which he has received the mortal blow,
24  Who cannot walk, but staggers here and there,

25  vid' io lo Minotauro far cotale;
26  e quello accorto gridò: “Corri al varco;
27  mentre ch'e' 'nfuria, è buon che tu ti cale.”

25  The Minotaur beheld I do the like;
26  And he, the wary, cried: "Run to the passage;
27  While he wroth, 'tis well thou shouldst descend."

28  Così prendemmo via giù per lo scarco
29  di quelle pietre, che spesso moviensi
30  sotto i miei piedi per lo novo carco.

28  Thus down we took our way o'er that discharge
29  Of stones, which oftentimes did move themselves
30  Beneath my feet, from the unwonted burden.

31  Io gia pensando; e quei disse: “Tu pensi
32  forse a questa ruina, ch'è guardata
33  da quell' ira bestial ch'i' ora spensi.

31  Thoughtful I went; and he said: "Thou art thinking
32  Perhaps upon this ruin, which is guarded
33  By that brute anger which just now I quenched.

34  Or vo' che sappi che l'altra fïata
35  ch'i' discesi qua giù nel basso inferno,
36  questa roccia non era ancor cascata.

34  Now will I have thee know, the other time
35  I here descended to the nether Hell,
36  This precipice had not yet fallen down.

37  Ma certo poco pria, se ben discerno,
38  che venisse colui che la gran preda
39  levò a Dite del cerchio superno,

37  But truly, if I well discern, a little
38  Before His coming who the mighty spoil
39  Bore off from Dis, in the supernal circle,

40  da tutte parti l'alta valle feda
41  tremò sì, ch'i' pensai che l'universo
42  sentisse amor, per lo qual è chi creda

40  Upon all sides the deep and loathsome valley
41  Trembled so, that I thought the Universe
42  Was thrilled with love, by which there are who think 

43  più volte il mondo in caòsso converso;
44  e in quel punto questa vecchia roccia,
45  qui e altrove, tal fece riverso.

43  The world ofttimes converted into chaos;
44  And at that moment this primeval crag
45  Both here and elsewhere made such overthrow.

46  Ma ficca li occhi a valle, ché s'approccia
47  la riviera del sangue in la qual bolle
48  qual che per vïolenza in altrui noccia.”

46  But fix thine eyes below; for draweth near
47  The river of blood, within which boiling is
48  Whoe'er by violence doth injure others."

49  Oh cieca cupidigia e ira folle,
50  che sì ci sproni ne la vita corta,
51  e ne l'etterna poi sì mal c'immolle!

49  O blind cupidity, O wrath insane,
50  That spurs us onward so in our short life,
51  And in the eternal then so badly steeps us!

52  Io vidi un'ampia fossa in arco torta,
53  come quella che tutto 'l piano abbraccia,
54  secondo ch'avea detto la mia scorta;

52  I saw an ample moat bent like a bow,
53  As one which all the plain encompasses,
54  Conformable to what my Guide had said.

55  e tra 'l piè de la ripa ed essa, in traccia
56  corrien centauri, armati di saette,
57  come solien nel mondo andare a caccia.

55  And between this and the embankment's foot
56  Centaurs in file were running, armed with arrows,
57  As in the world they used the chase to follow.

58  Veggendoci calar, ciascun ristette,
59  e de la schiera tre si dipartiro
