60  con archi e asticciuole prima elette;

58  Beholding us descend, each one stood still,
59  And from the squadron three detached themselves,
60  With bows and arrows in advance selected;

 
61  e l'un gridò da lungi: “A qual martiro
62  venite voi che scendete la costa?
63  Ditel costinci; se non, l'arco tiro.”

61  And from afar one cried: "Unto what torment
62  Come ye, who down the hillside are descending?
63  Tell us from there; if not, I draw the bow."

64  Lo mio maestro disse: “La risposta
65  farem noi a Chirón costà di presso:
66  mal fu la voglia tua sempre sì tosta.”

64  My Master said: "Our answer will we make
65  To Chiron, near you there; in evil hour,
66  That will of thine was evermore so hasty."

67  Poi mi tentò, e disse: “Quelli è Nesso,
68  che morì per la bella Deianira,
69  e fé di sé la vendetta elli stesso.

67  Then touched he me, and said: "This one is Nessus,
68  Who perished for the lovely Dejanira,
69  And for himself, himself did vengeance take.

70  E quel di mezzo, ch'al petto si mira,
71  è il gran Chirón, il qual nodrì Achille;
72  quell' altro è Folo, che fu sì pien d'ira.

70  And he in the midst, who at his breast is gazing,
71  Is the great Chiron, who brought up Achilles;
72  That other Pholus is, who was so wrathful.

73  Dintorno al fosso vanno a mille a mille,
74  saettando qual anima si svelle
75  del sangue più che sua colpa sortille.”

73  Thousands and thousands go about the moat
74  Shooting with shafts whatever soul emerges
75  Out of the blood, more than his crime allots."

76  Noi ci appressammo a quelle fiere isnelle:
77  Chirón prese uno strale, e con la cocca
78  fece la barba in dietro a le mascelle.

76  Near we approached unto those monsters fleet;
77  Chiron an arrow took, and with the notch
78  Backward upon his jaws he put his beard.

79  Quando s'ebbe scoperta la gran bocca,
80  disse a' compagni: “Siete voi accorti
81  che quel di retro move ciò ch'el tocca?

79  After he had uncovered his great mouth,
80  He said to his companions: "Are you ware
81  That he behind moveth whate'er he touches?

82  Così non soglion far li piè d'i morti.”
83  E 'l mio buon duca, che già li er' al petto,
84  dove le due nature son consorti,

82  Thus are not wont to do the feet of dead men."
83  And my good Guide, who now was at his breast,
84  Where the two natures are together joined,

85  rispuose: “Ben è vivo, e sì soletto
86  mostrar li mi convien la valle buia;
87  necessità 'l ci 'nduce, e non diletto.

85  Replied: "Indeed he lives, and thus alone
86  Me it behoves to show him the dark valley;
87  Necessity, and not delight, impels us.

88  Tal si partì da cantare alleluia
89  che mi commise quest' officio novo:
90  non è ladron, né io anima fuia.

88  Some one withdrew from singing Halleluja,
89  Who unto me committed this new office;
90  No thief is he, nor I a thievish spirit.

91  Ma per quella virtù per cu' io movo
92  li passi miei per sì selvaggia strada,
93  danne un de' tuoi, a cui noi siamo a provo,

91  But by that virtue through which I am moving
92  My steps along this savage thoroughfare,
93  Give us some one of thine, to be with us,

94  e che ne mostri là dove si guada,
95  e che porti costui in su la groppa,
96  ché non è spirto che per l'aere vada.”

94  And who may show us where to pass the ford,
95  And who may carry this one on his back;
96  For 'tis no spirit that can walk the air."

97  Chirón si volse in su la destra poppa,
98  e disse a Nesso: “Torna, e sì li guida,
99  e fa cansar s'altra schiera v'intoppa.”

97  Upon his right breast Chiron wheeled about,
98  And said to Nessus: "Turn and do thou guide them,
99  And warn aside, if other band may meet you."

100  Or ci movemmo con la scorta fida
101  lungo la proda del bollor vermiglio,
102  dove i bolliti facieno alte strida.

100  We with our faithful escort onward moved
101  Along the brink of the vermilion boiling,
102  Wherein the boiled were uttering loud laments.
 
103  Io vidi gente sotto infino al ciglio;
104  e 'l gran centauro disse: “E' son tiranni
105  che dier nel sangue e ne l'aver di piglio.

103  People I saw within up to the eyebrows,
104  And the great Centaur said: "Tyrants are these,
105  Who dealt in bloodshed and in pillaging.

106  Quivi si piangon li spietati danni;
107  quivi è Alessandro, e Dïonisio fero
108  che fé Cicilia aver dolorosi anni.

106  Here they lament their pitiless mischiefs; here
107  Is Alexander, and fierce Dionysius
108  Who upon Sicily brought dolorous years.

109  E quella fronte c'ha 'l pel così nero,
110  è Azzolino; e quell' altro ch'è biondo,
111  è Opizzo da Esti, il qual per vero

109  That forehead there which has the hair so black
110  Is Azzolin; and the other who is blond,
111  Obizzo is of Esti, who, in truth,

112  fu spento dal figliastro sù nel mondo.”
113  Allor mi volsi al poeta, e quei disse:
114  “Questi ti sia or primo, e io secondo.”

112  Up in the world was by his stepson slain."
113  Then turned I to the Poet; and he said,
114  "Now he be first to thee, and second I."

115  Poco più oltre il centauro s'affisse
116  sovr' una gente che 'nfino a la gola
117  parea che di quel bulicame uscisse.

115  A little farther on the Centaur stopped
116  Above a folk, who far down as the throat
117  Seemed from that boiling stream to issue forth.

118  Mostrocci un'ombra da l'un canto sola,
119  dicendo: “Colui fesse in grembo a Dio
120  lo cor che 'n su Tamisi ancor si cola.”

118  A shade he showed us on one side alone,
119  Saying: "He cleft asunder in God's bosom
120  The heart that still upon the Thames is honoured."

121  Poi vidi gente che di fuor del rio
122  tenean la testa e ancor tutto 'l casso;
123  e di costoro assai riconobb' io.

121  Then people saw I, who from out the river
122  Lifted their heads and also all the chest;
123  And many among these I recognised.

124  Così a più a più si facea basso
125  quel sangue, sì che cocea pur li piedi;
126  e quindi fu del fosso il nostro passo.

124  Thus ever more and more grew shallower
125  That blood, so that the feet alone it covered;
126  And there across the moat our passage was.

127  “Sì come tu da questa parte vedi
128  lo bulicame che sempre si scema,”
129  disse 'l centauro, “voglio che tu credi

127  "Even as thou here upon this side beholdest
128  The boiling stream, that aye diminishes,"
129  The Centaur said, "I wish thee to believe

130  che da quest' altra a più a più giù prema
131  lo fondo suo, infin ch'el si raggiunge
132  ove la tirannia convien che gema.

130  That on this other more and more declines
131  Its bed, until it reunites itself
132  Where it behoveth tyranny to groan.
 
133  La divina giustizia di qua punge
134  quell' Attila che fu flagello in terra,
135  e Pirro e Sesto; e in etterno munge

133  Justice divine, upon this side, is goading
134  That Attila, who was a scourge on earth,
135  And Pyrrhus, and Sextus; and for ever milks
 
136  le lagrime, che col bollor diserra,
137  a Rinier da Corneto, a Rinier Pazzo,
138  che fecero a le strade tanta guerra.”

136  The tears which with the boiling it unseals
137  In Rinier da Corneto and Rinier Pazzo,
138  Who made upon the highways so much war."

139  Poi si rivolse e ripassossi 'l guazzo.

139  Then back he turned, and passed again the ford.

Canto XIII
Dante slows the pace down from the previous Canto by giving us a comically ironic view of a horse's ass, re-crossing the ford of the blood river.  We are in another place where looking back is futile — the Centaur, Nessus, who brought Dante across the river is gone — and looking forward is also futile.   The protagonists are in a wood of poisonous thorn trees.  The wood is pathless and unmarked.  The way forward is through, and, as it turns out, through the pain of the souls who are doomed to this level of Hell.  These are suicides, turned into thorn bushes, and when Virgil asks Dante to break one of the branches, the branch sizzles like a green log, bleeding blood and words.  The suicide tells his story, self-justifying, as all the stories of the damned have been, and yet, unlike Virgil's condemnation of the emotion of pity for other sinners, here, not only Dante but Virgil too feels pity.  Why?  Perhaps because, as a pagan, Virgil's view of suicide, in this case that of a former minister to Frederick II, is not encumbered by the Christian view that we do not own our own lives — God does — and that taking this life is both committing murder, and also blaspheming God by refusing to accept the fate that He has assigned to us.  The suicide in this case, kills himself out of shame when accused of disloyalty and embezzlement.  Was he innocent of the embezzlement?  Well, to Dante, the poet, it does not matter.  Public shame, deserved or not, is not a justification for self-murder.  But you can't help wondering that Dante, the person, in his exile, and in his shame from being exiled, and falsely accused, also contemplated self-murder.  His pity for this character is so profound that he asks Virgil to speak for him — i.e., he surrenders his will, for that of his teacher — and Virgil lets him do it.  The master, feeling pity himself, he does not rebuke his protege for his weakness.  Yet, we are still left with the question of will, and with it, the question of culpability.  If there is no will, there can be no sin, so suicide is a kind of ultimate sin, in the sense that it is an act of will, perhaps the only act of will, which deprives the actor of all future acts of will.  Suddenly, we realize that suicide of the will is happening all the time, and is an element in a great many sins, especially sins of incontinence: overeating, over indulgence in sex, and so forth, and in all those behaviors where we say to ourselves: I can't help it.  Besides the disingenuous public minister, other sinners also appear in this Canto.  They are those who murdered their own stores by deliberate wastralness, and then put themselves in situations where someone else is obliged to take their lives.  There are two negative Anima figures appearing in this Canto: the Harpies who feed on the transformed sinners' foliage, and the shoe-mastiffs who chase the profligate sinners to tear them limb from limb.  When one of these pursued sinners attempts to take cover in a thorn bush, he continues his maliciousness, because he once again not only brings harm to himself, but also to another who have has no part in his previous debauchery.  It seems obvious enough that Dante has chosen this transformation of the sinners into plants as a way to emphasize this ultimate denial of will, since plants, unable to volitionally move from a fixed spot, cannot but accept the fate that their chance seeding and rooting has determined for them, and the text makes it clear that even after the last judgement, and the suicides are returned to their bodies, they will not be restoredto a condition of will.  On the contrary, they are doomed to drag their bodies back to this very wood, and are condemned to hang themselves from the very thorn bush that they once were.  There is a triple parody of scripture here: the parable of the sower, the thorn crown of Jesus during the crucifixion, and the hanging of Judas, these allusions being subtle but clear enough to readers who have not surrendered their will in interpreting the text.  The Canto ends with the story of a man who has hung himself in his own house, a crime that must have been particularly poignant to Dante, who was deprived of his home in exile.  How could anyone throw both home and life away as an act of their own will?  Here, Dante does show sympathy, but no compassion.  Violence against oneself for Dante, is simply intolerable.
     
1  Non era ancor di là Nesso arrivato,
2  quando noi ci mettemmo per un bosco
3  che da neun sentiero era segnato.

1  Not yet had Nessus reached the other side,
2  When we had put ourselves within a wood,
3  That was not marked by any path whatever.

4  Non fronda verde, ma di color fosco;
5  non rami schietti, ma nodosi e 'nvolti;
6  non pomi v'eran, ma stecchi con tòsco.
4  Not foliage green, but of a dusky colour,
5  Not branches smooth, but gnarled and intertangled,
6  Not apple-trees were there, but thorns with poison.
7  Non han sì aspri sterpi né sì folti
8  quelle fiere selvagge che 'n odio hanno
9  tra Cecina e Corneto i luoghi cólti.
7  Such tangled thickets have not, nor so dense,
8  Those savage wild beasts, that in hatred hold
9  'Twixt Cecina and Corneto the tilled places.
10  Quivi le brutte Arpie lor nidi fanno,
11  che cacciar de le Strofade i Troiani
12  con tristo annunzio di futuro danno. 
10  There do the hideous Harpies make their nests,
11  Who chased the Trojans from the Strophades,
12  With sad announcement of impending doom;
13  Ali hanno late, e colli e visi umani,
14  piè con artigli, e pennuto 'l gran ventre;
15  fanno lamenti in su li alberi strani.
13  Broad wings have they, and necks and faces human,
14  And feet with claws, and their great bellies fledged;
15  They make laments upon the wondrous trees.
16  E 'l buon maestro “Prima che più entre,
17  sappi che se' nel secondo girone,”
18  mi cominciò a dire, “e sarai mentre
16  And the good Master: "Ere thou enter farther,
17  Know that thou art within the second round,"
18 Thus he began to say, "and shalt be, till
19  che tu verrai ne l'orribil sabbione.
20  Però riguarda ben; sì vederai
21  cose che torrien fede al mio sermone.”
19  Thou comest out upon the horrible sand;
20  Therefore look well around, and thou shalt see
21  Things that will credence give unto my speech."

22  Io sentia d'ogne parte trarre guai
23  e non vedea persona che 'l facesse;
24  per ch'io tutto smarrito m'arrestai.
22  I heard on all sides lamentations uttered,
23  And person none beheld I who might make them,
24  Whence, utterly bewildered, I stood still.
25  Cred' ïo ch'ei credette ch'io credesse
26  che tante voci uscisser, tra quei bronchi,
27  da gente che per noi si nascondesse.
25  I think he thought that I perhaps might think
26  So many voices issued through those trunks
27  From people who concealed themselves from us;
28  Però disse 'l maestro: “Se tu tronchi
29  qualche fraschetta d'una d'este piante,
30  li pensier c'hai si faran tutti monchi.”
28  Therefore the Master said: "If thou break off
29  Some little spray from any of these trees,
30  The thoughts thou hast will wholly be made vain."
31  Allor porsi la mano un poco avante
32  e colsi un ramicel da un gran pruno;
33  e 'l tronco suo gridò: “Perché mi schiante?”
31  Then stretched I forth my hand a little forward,
32  And plucked a branchlet off from a great thorn;
33  And the trunk cried, "Why dost thou mangle me?"
34  Da che fatto fu poi di sangue bruno,
35  ricominciò a dir: “Perché mi scerpi?
36  non hai tu spirto di pietade alcuno?
34  After it had become embrowned with blood,
35  It recommenced its cry: "Why dost thou rend me?
36  Hast thou no spirit of pity whatsoever?
37  Uomini fummo, e or siam fatti sterpi:
38  ben dovrebb' esser la tua man più pia,
39  se state fossimo anime di serpi.”
37  Men once we were, and now are changed to trees;
38  Indeed, thy hand should be more pitiful,
39  Even if the souls of serpents we had been."
40  Come d'un stizzo verde ch'arso sia
41  da l'un de' capi, che da l'altro geme
42  e cigola per vento che va via,
40  As out of a green brand, that is on fire
41  At one of the ends, and from the other drips
42  And hisses with the wind that is escaping;
43  sì de la scheggia rotta usciva insieme
44  parole e sangue; ond' io lasciai la cima
45  cadere, e stetti come l'uom che teme.
43  So from that splinter issued forth together
44  Both words and blood; whereat I let the tip
45  Fall, and stood like a man who is afraid.
46  “S'elli avesse potuto creder prima,”
47  rispuose 'l savio mio, “anima lesa,
48  ciò c'ha veduto pur con la mia rima,
46  "Had he been able sooner to believe,"
47  My Sage made answer, "O thou wounded soul,
48  What only in my verses he has seen,
49  non averebbe in te la man distesa;
50  ma la cosa incredibile mi fece
51  indurlo ad ovra ch'a me stesso pesa.
49  Not upon thee had he stretched forth his hand;
50  Whereas the thing incredible has caused me
51  To put him to an act which grieveth me.
52  Ma dilli chi tu fosti, si che 'n vece
53  d'alcun' ammenda tua fama rinfreschi
54  nel mondo sù, dove tornar li lece.”
52  But tell him who thou wast, so that by way
53  Of some amends thy fame he may refresh
54  Up in the world, to which he can return."
55  E 'l tronco: “Si col dolce dir m'adeschi,
56  ch'i' non posso tacere; e voi non gravi
57  perch' ïo un poco a ragionar m'inveschi.
55  And the trunk said: "So thy sweet words allure me,
56  I cannot silent be; and you be vexed not,
57  That I a little to discourse am tempted.
58  Io son colui che tenni ambo le chiavi
59  del cor di Federigo, e che le volsi,
60  serrando e diserrando, sì soavi,

58  I am the one who both keys had in keeping
59  Of Frederick's heart, and turned them to and fro
60  So softly in unlocking and in locking,

61  che dal secreto suo quasi ogn' uom tolsi;
62  fede portai al glorïoso offizio,
63  tanto ch'i' ne perde' li sonni e ' polsi.
61  That from his secrets most men I withheld;
62  Fidelity I bore the glorious office
63  So great, I lost thereby my sleep and pulses.
64  La meretrice che mai da l'ospizio
65  di Cesare non torse li occhi putti,
66  morte comune e de le corti vizio,
64  The courtesan who never from the dwelling
65  Of Caesar turned aside her strumpet eyes,
66  Death universal and the vice of courts,
67  infiammò contra me li animi tutti;
68  e li 'nfiammati infiammar sì Augusto,
69  che ' lieti onor tornaro in tristi lutti.
67  Inflamed against me all the other minds,
68  And they, inflamed, did so inflame Augustus,
69  That my glad honours turned to dismal mournings.
70  L'animo mio, per disdegnoso gusto,
71  credendo col morir fuggir disdegno,
72  ingiusto fece me contra me giusto.

70  My spirit, in disdainful exultation,
71  Thinking by dying to escape disdain,
72  Made me unjust against myself, the just.
73  Per le nove radici d'esto legno
74  vi giuro che già mai non ruppi fede
75  al mio segnor, che fu d'onor sì degno.
73  I, by the roots unwonted of this wood,
74  Do swear to you that never broke I faith
75  Unto my lord, who was so worthy of honour;
76  E se di voi alcun nel mondo riede,
77  conforti la memoria mia, che giace
78  ancor del colpo che 'nvidia le diede.”
76  And to the world if one of you return,
77  Let him my memory comfort, which is lying
78  Still prostrate from the blow that envy dealt it."
79  Un poco attese, e poi “Da ch'el si tace,”
80  disse 'l poeta a me, “non perder l'ora;
81  ma parla, e chiedi a lui, se più ti piace.”
79  Waited awhile, and then: "Since he is silent,"
80  The Poet said to me, "lose not the time,
81  But speak, and question him, if more may please thee."
82  Ond' ïo a lui: “Domandal tu ancora
83  di quel che credi ch'a me satisfaccia;
84  ch'i' non potrei, tanta pietà m'accora.”
82  Whence I to him: "Do thou again inquire
83  Concerning what thou thinks't will satisfy me;
84  For I cannot, such pity is in my heart."
85  Perciò ricominciò: “Se l'om ti faccia
86  liberamente ciò che 'l tuo dir priega,
87  spirito incarcerato, ancor ti piaccia
85  Therefore he recommenced: "So may the man
86  Do for thee freely what thy speech implores,
87  Spirit incarcerate, again be pleased

88  di dirne come l'anima si lega
89  in questi nocchi; e dinne, se tu puoi,
90  s'alcuna mai di tai membra si spiega.”
88  To tell us in what way the soul is bound
89  Within these knots; and tell us, if thou canst,
90  If any from such members e'er is freed."
 91  Allor soffiò il tronco forte, e poi
92  si convertì quel vento in cotal voce:
93  “Brievemente sarà risposto a voi.
91  Then blew the trunk amain, and afterward
92  The wind was into such a voice converted:
93  "With brevity shall be replied to you.
94  Quando si parte l'anima feroce
95  dal corpo ond' ella stessa s'è disvelta,
96  Minòs la manda a la settima foce.
94  When the exasperated soul abandons
95  The body whence it rent itself away,
96  Minos consigns it to the seventh abyss.
97  Cade in la selva, e non l'è parte scelta;
98  ma là dove fortuna la balestra,
99  quivi germoglia come gran di spelta.
97  It falls into the forest, and no part
98  Is chosen for it; but where Fortune hurls it,
99  There like a grain of spelt it germinates.
100  Surge in vermena e in pianta silvestra:
101  l'Arpie, pascendo poi de le sue foglie,
102  fanno dolore, e al dolor fenestra.
100  It springs a sapling, and a forest tree;
101  The Harpies, feeding then upon its leaves,
102  Do pain create, and for the pain an outlet.
103  Come l'altre verrem per nostre spoglie,
104  ma non però ch'alcuna sen rivesta,
105  ché non è giusto aver ciò ch'om si toglie.

103  Like others for our spoils shall we return;
104  But not that any one may them revest,
105  For 'tis not just to have what one casts off.
106  Qui le strascineremo, e per la mesta
107  selva saranno i nostri corpi appesi,
108  ciascuno al prun de l'ombra sua molesta.”
106  Here we shall drag them, and along the dismal
107  Forest our bodies shall suspended be,
108  Each to the thorn of his molested shade."
109  Noi eravamo ancora al tronco attesi,
110  credendo ch'altro ne volesse dire,
111  quando noi fummo d'un romor sorpresi,
109  We were attentive still unto the trunk,
110  Thinking that more it yet might wish to tell us,
111  When by a tumult we were overtaken,
112  similemente a colui che venire
113  sente 'l porco e la caccia a la sua posta,
114  ch'ode le bestie, e le frasche stormire.
112  In the same way as he is who perceives
113  The boar and chase approaching to his stand,
114  Who hears the crashing of the beasts and branches;
115  Ed ecco due da la sinistra costa,
116  nudi e graffiati, fuggendo si forte,
117  che de la selva rompieno ogne rosta.
115  And two behold! upon our left-hand side,
116  Naked and scratched, fleeing so furiously,
117  That of the forest, every fan they broke.
118  Quel dinanzi: “Or accorri, accorri, morte!”
119  E l'altro, cui pareva tardar troppo,
120  gridava: “Lano, sì non furo accorte
118  He who was in advance: "Now help, Death, help!"
119  And the other one, who seemed to lag too much,
120  Was shouting: "Lano, were not so alert
121  le gambe tue a le giostre dal Toppo!”
122  E poi che forse li fallia la lena,
123  di sé e d'un cespuglio fece un groppo.
121  Those legs of thine at joustings of the Toppo!"
122  And then, perchance because his breath was failing,
123  He grouped himself together with a bush.
124  Di rietro a loro era la selva piena
125  di nere cagne, bramose e correnti
126  come veltri ch'uscisser di catena.
124  Behind them was the forest full of black
125  She-mastiffs, ravenous, and swift of foot
126  As greyhounds, who are issuing from the chain.
127  In quel che s'appiattò miser li denti,
128  e quel dilaceraro a brano a brano;
129  poi sen portar quelle membra dolenti.
127  On him who had crouched down they set their teeth,
128  And him they lacerated piece by piece,
129  Thereafter bore away those aching members.
130  Presemi allor la mia scorta per mano,
131  e menommi al cespuglio che piangea
132  per le rotture sanguinenti in vano.

130  Thereat my Escort took me by the hand,
131  And led me to the bush, that all in vain
132  Was weeping from its bloody lacerations.
133  “O Iacopo,” dicea, “da Santo Andre
134  che t'è giovato di me fare schermo?
135  che colpa ho io de la tua vita rea?”
133  "O Jacopo," it said, "of Sant' Andrea,
134  What helped it thee of me to make a screen?
135  What blame have I in thy nefarious life?"
136  Quando 'l maestro fu sovr' esso fermo,
137  disse: “Chi fosti, che per tante punte
138  soffi con sangue doloroso sermo?”
136  When near him had the Master stayed his steps,
137  He said: "Who wast thou, that through wounds so many
138  Art blowing out with blood thy dolorous speech?"
139  Ed elli a noi: “O anime che giunte
140  siete a veder lo strazio disonesto
141  c'ha le mie fronde sì da me disgiunte,
139  And he to us: "O souls, that hither come
140  To look upon the shameful massacre
141  That has so rent away from me my leaves,
142  raccoglietele al piè del tristo cesto.
143  I' fui de la città che nel Batista
144  mutò 'l primo padrone; ond' ei per questo
142  Gather them up beneath the dismal bush;
143  I of that city was which to the Baptist
144  Changed its first patron, wherefore he for this
145  sempre con l'arte sua la farà trista;
146  e se non fosse che 'n sul passo d'Arno
147  rimane ancor di lui alcuna vista,
145  Forever with his art will make it sad.
146  And were it not that on the pass of Arno
147  Some glimpses of him are remaining still,
148  que' cittadin che poi la rifondarno
149  sovra 'l cener che d'Attila rimase,
150  avrebber fatto lavorare indarno.
148  Those citizens, who afterwards rebuilt it
149  Upon the ashes left by Attila,
150  In vain had caused their labour to be done.
151  Io fei gibetto a me de le mie case.”
151  Of my own house I made myself a gibbet."

Canto XIV
The general tone of the Commedia is anything but humorous, and yet humor sneaks in in the form of irony, and this opening three lines is a fine example.  When Dante says that the charity of his native place, Florence, compels him  to act  charitably, we must remember that Florence by the time this was written had already betrayed and exiled him.   And yet, this poetic conceit that the action is taking place over Easter weekend of the year 1300 makes this irony possible.  The character Dante in the poem cannot know that this statement is ironic, because he had yet to be betrayed.  This opening also serves as a link to the previous canto, so that we see that Dante the poet is covering up the seams that stitch one section to another — so masterful.

Now we come to a desert sweltering under a slow rain of falling fire, brilliantly compared to large flakes of snow falling in the Alps in a windless storm, this metaphor combining high and low, earth and hell, heat and cold so that the reader's attention in a few lines has to traverse an immense mindscape of extremes, and then there is the historical reference to Cato.    Holland's commetary referencing Mazzota provides the pertinant background on this reference:

That Dante should refer here to Cato the Younger, who committed suicide at Utica (when further opposition by the republican forces led by him against Julius Caesar's army seemed futile) seems to invite a negative judgment on him. Cato, however, will be presented in Purgatorio I and II, in an authorial decision that still baffles commentators, as one of the saved. To refer to him here, a few verses from the wood of the suicides – where Christian readers might normally assume that Cato should be punished – given Dante's plan eventually to reveal his salvation, was a chancy choice for him to have made.
 
The poet is translating a line from Lucan's Pharsalia describing Cato's heroic decision to lead the remnant of dead Pompey's republican forces across the barren sands of Lybia in an attempt to escape from Caesar, and to do so, not carried by slaves, as Roman generals were wont to be transported, but on foot himself: 'primusque gradus in pulvere ponam' (and I, first among them, shall set my feet upon the sand [Phars. IX.395 – the citation was perhaps first noted by Daniello, comm. to XIV.13-15]). For a treatment of Cato in the context of canto XIV, see Giuseppe Mazzotta, Dante, Poet of the Desert (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1979), pp. 47-65.
 
Dante thus reads Cato's suicide as something other, an act resembling Christ's sacrifice of Himself so that others may be free (for discussion see Hollander, Allegory in Dante's “Commedia” [Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1969], pp. 123-31). Now such a view may seem blasphemous (a fitting thought when we turn back, from the opening cantos of Purgatorio, to this passage in the canto of blasphemy), and has caused extraordinary exertion on the part of commentators to 'allegorize' the saved Cato we find in Purgatorio and turn him into an abstract quality rather than an historical being. Dante's text will not permit us such luxury of avoidance. His Cato, a Christian through a process that no one can understand, is saved.

Some of the sinners here lie supine on the burning earth, some sit huddled in groups, some run around.  Those lying down cry the loudest, they are the blasphemers who cursed God, and we shall shortly come upon one of these.  Those bunched in groups are the usurers.  Those running about are the sodomites.  None of these facts are clear to the reader at first glance, but are made clear by paying close attention to previous and subsequent passages of the poem.  The utter sterility of the landscape mirrors the utter sterility of these three sins.  Blasphemy cutting the sinner off from his relationship with the whole of creation, usury providing wealth without art or industry, and sodomy being a form of sexuality which cannot lead to offspring.  Some nice evocative details here — the sinners who are running about go round (interno line 25) reiterating the going round shape of Hell itself, and the dance of hands referenced in line 40 is also a compelling image as the sinners try to beat out the flames that are falling on their bodies.  This dance reference is very specific, the tresca referred to in this line was performed with a leader who touched some part of his body, and then all the other dancers imitated him, the dance proceeding at greater and greater speed as the dancers touch different parts of their bodies in ever accelerating motions.  Also, the blasphemers, lying on the ground, struck lowest so to speak, cry loudest, presumably because their sin was committed with the voice, and so now their own voices torment them.  Recalling this last detail is important if we are to understand the rich irony of the protagonists' meeting with the chief blasphemer here: Capaneus.

The entire Capaneus section of this Canto is an another example of Dante's subtle and power and insight into human psychology.  Capaneus was one of the seven kings who besieged Thebes, who defied Jove, and was destroyed by one of the God's thunderbolts.  His arrogance is ironic, in that he shouts at the Jove from the city's walls that the god will have to cry to Hephaestus to make him more thunderbolts because his enemy has exhausted his own supply.  What's ironic is that far from being atop the city's walls, now he is down in hell, supine, and at God's mercy.  Also, it has not taken bushels of thunderbolts to subdue him, but only one.  Like all the sinners in Hell, he has learned nothing from his ordeals but continues to arrogantly blaspheme, just as before.  That is Capaneus, but what about the reactions of Virgil and Dante?  Virgil is angrier at Capaneus than he has been or will be with any other sinner.  Why?  My speculations are as follows: The god that Capaneus defied was Virgil's pagan god.  Capaneus betrayed his city, and in situation mirrored Virgil's as a citizen of Troy, another city which was besieged.  The situation also mirrors what the protagonists encountered when approaching the City of Dis, where Virgil failed to gain access, an episode that the aspirant, Dante, slyly reminds his master of, in a subtle act of defiance, the student's questioning of the master being a kind of blasphemy in itself.  In this later case, Virgil's anger towards Capaneus is also a sort of passive-aggressive demonstration to his protege to get in line.  The reader, in effect, is watching a series of lifting screens, each of which allows for more insight into the situation.  Virgil makes a very telling comment about Capaneus' punishment, viz., that it comes not so much from God, but is continually fueled by his own anger, which is a very explicit reference to all the sinners in Hell: they are the authors of their own torments.

After the episode with Capaneus, we come to the great allegory of the statue inside the mountain in ancient Crete, whose tears form the rivers of Hell.  This allegory is too complicated for any explication that could be given here.  Giuseppe Mazzotta does that job in his book: Dante, Poet of the Desert.  But a couple of things stand out: The statue is an image of time, specifically historical time: The statue's golden head the earliest prelapsarian condition of civilization, proceeding down through the body to iron legs and clay feet.  Time, like water, or tears, flows down in history and in mortal life, and yet in the imagination, i.e., the devotional life, it could flow (spiral) up, like vapors, to immortality.  It's such a fine, profound image.  Another word that catches the attentive reader's eye is in line 96: casto, chaste.  Chaste here is not just sexual, it is the prelapsarian condition of innocence, the time in human life when the culture or the individual has not yet realized that incarnation must lead to dissolution, suffering and death, all of which conditions unfold and time, and cannot exist in eternity.    

1  Poi che la carità del natio loco
2  mi strinse, raunai le fronde sparte
3  e rende'le a colui, ch'era già fioco.
1  Because the charity of my native place
2  Constrained me, gathered I the scattered leaves,
3  And gave them back to him, who now was hoarse.
4  Indi venimmo al fine ove si parte
5  lo secondo giron dal terzo, e dove
6  si vede di giustizia orribil arte.
4  Then came we to the confine, where disparted
5  The second round is from the third, and where
6  A horrible form of Justice is beheld.
7  A ben manifestar le cose nove,
8  dico che arrivammo ad una landa
9  che dal suo letto ogne pianta rimove.
7  Clearly to manifest these novel things,
8  I say that we arrived upon a plain,
9  Which from its bed rejecteth every plant;
10  La dolorosa selva l'è ghirlanda
11  intorno, come 'l fosso tristo ad essa;
12  quivi fermammo i passi a randa a randa.
10  The dolorous forest is a garland to it
11  All round about, as the sad moat to that;
12  There close upon the edge we stayed our feet.
13  Lo spazzo era una rena arida e spessa,
14  non d'altra foggia fatta che colei
15  che fu da' piè di Caton già soppressa.
13  The soil was of an arid and thick sand,
14  Not of another fashion made than that
15  Which by the feet of Cato once was pressed.
16  O vendetta di Dio, quanto tu dei
17  esser temuta da ciascun che legge
18  ciò che fu manifesto a li occhi mei!
16  Vengeance of God, O how much oughtest thou
17  By each one to be dreaded, who doth read
18  That which was manifest unto mine eyes!
19  D'anime nude vidi molte gregge
20  che piangean tutte assai miseramente,
21  e parea posta lor diversa legge.
19  Of naked souls beheld I many herds,
20  Who all were weeping very miserably,
21  And over them seemed set a law diverse.
22  Supin giacea in terra alcuna gente,
23  alcuna si sedea tutta raccolta,
24  e altra andava continüamente.
22  Supine upon the ground some folk were lying;
23  And some were sitting all drawn up together,
24  And others went about continually.
25  Quella che giva 'ntorno era più molta,
26  e quella men che giacëa al tormento,
27  ma più al duolo avea la lingua sciolta.
25  Those who were going round were far the more,
26  And those were less who lay down to their torment,
27  But had their tongues more loosed to lamentation.
28  Sovra tutto 'l sabbion, d'un cader lento,
29  piovean di foco dilatate falde,
30  come di neve in alpe sanza vento.
28  O'er all the sand-waste, with a gradual fall,
29  Were raining down dilated flakes of fire,
30  As of the snow on Alp without a wind.
31  Quali Alessandro in quelle parti calde
32  d'Indïa vide sopra 'l süo stuolo
33  fiamme cadere infino a terra salde,
31  As Alexander, in those torrid parts
32  Of India, beheld upon his host
33  Flames fall unbroken till they reached the ground.
34  per ch'ei provide a scalpitar lo suolo
35  con le sue schiere, acciò che lo vapore
36  mei si stingueva mentre ch'era solo:
34  Whence he provided with his phalanxes
35  To trample down the soil, because the vapour
36  Better extinguished was while it was single;
37  tale scendeva l'etternale ardore;
38  onde la rena s'accendea, com' esca
39  sotto focile, a doppiar lo dolore.
37  Thus was descending the eternal heat,
38  Whereby the sand was set on fire, like tinder
39  Beneath the steel, for doubling of the dole.
40  Sanza riposo mai era la tresca
41  de le misere mani, or quindi or quinci
42  escotendo da sé l'arsura fresca.
40  Without repose forever was the dance
41  Of miserable hands, now there, now here,
42  Shaking away from off them the fresh gleeds.
43  I' cominciai: “Maestro, tu che vinci
44  tutte le cose, fuor che ' demon duri
45  ch'a l'intrar de la porta incontra uscinci,
43  "Master," began I, "thou who overcomest
44  All things except the demons dire, that issued
45  Against us at the entrance of the gate,
46  chi è quel grande che non par che curi
47  lo 'ncendio e giace dispettoso e torto,
48  sì che la pioggia non par che 'l maturi?”
46  Who is that mighty one who seems to heed not
47  The fire, and lieth lowering and disdainful,
48  So that the rain seems not to ripen him?"
49  E quel medesmo, che si fu accorto
50  ch'io domandava il mio duca di lui,
51  gridò: “Qual io fui vivo, tal son morto.
49  And he himself, who had become aware
50  That I was questioning my Guide about him,
51  Cried: "Such as I was living, am I, dead.
52  Se Giove stanchi 'l suo fabbro da cui
53  crucciato prese la folgore aguta
54  onde l'ultimo dì percosso fui;
52  If Jove should weary out his smith, from whom
53  He seized in anger the sharp thunderbolt,
54  Wherewith upon the last day I was smitten,
55  o s'elli stanchi li altri a muta a muta
56  in Mongibello a la focina negra,
57  chiamando 'Buon Vulcano, aiuta, aiuta!'
55  And if he wearied out by turns the others
56  In Mongibello at the swarthy forge,
57  Vociferating, 'Help, good Vulcan, help!'
58  sì com' el fece a la pugna di Flegra,
59  e me saetti con tutta sua forza:
60  non ne potrebbe aver vendetta allegra.”
58  Even as he did there at the fight of Phlegra,
59  And shot his bolts at me with all his might,
60  He would not have thereby a joyous vengeance."
61  Allora il duca mio parlò di forza
62  tanto, ch'i' non l'avea si forte udito:
63  “O Capaneo, in ciò che non s'ammorza
61  Then did my Leader speak with such great force,
62  That I had never heard him speak so loud:
63  "O Capaneus, in that is not extinguished
64  la tua superbia, se' tu più punito;
65  nullo martiro, fuor che la tua rabbia,
66  sarebbe al tuo furor dolor compito.”
64  Thine arrogance, thou punished art the more;
65  Not any torment, saving thine own rage,
66  Would be unto thy fury pain complete."
67  Poi si rivolse a me con miglior labbia,
68  dicendo: “Quei fu l'un d'i sette regi
69  ch'assiser Tebe; ed ebbe e par ch'elli abbia
67  Then he turned round to me with better lip,
68  Saying: "One of the Seven Kings was he
69  Who Thebes besieged, and held, and seems to hold
70  Dio in disdegno, e poco par che 'l pregi;
71  ma, com' io dissi lui, li suoi dispetti
72  sono al suo petto assai debiti fregi.
70  God in disdain, and little seems to prize him;
71  But, as I said to him, his own despites
72  Are for his breast the fittest ornaments.
73  Or mi vien dietro, e guarda che non metti,
74  ancor, li piedi ne la rena arsiccia;
75  ma sempre al bosco tien li piedi stretti.”
73  Now follow me, and mind thou do not place
74  As yet thy feet upon the burning sand,
75  But always keep them close unto the wood."
76  Tacendo divenimmo là 've spiccia
77  fuor de la selva un picciol fiumicello,
78  lo cui rossore ancor mi raccapriccia.
76  Speaking no word, we came to where there gushes
77  Forth from the wood a little rivulet,
78  Whose redness makes my hair still stand on end.
79  Quale del Bulicame esce ruscello
80  che parton poi tra lor le peccatrici,
81  tal per la rena giù sen giva quello.
79  As from the Bulicame springs the brooklet,
80  The sinful women later share among them,
81  So downward through the sand it went its way.
82  Lo fondo suo e ambo le pendici
83  fatt' era 'n pietra, e ' margini da lato;
84  per ch'io m'accorsi che 'l passo era lici.
82  The bottom of it, and both sloping banks,
83  Were made of stone, and the margins at the side;
84  Whence I perceived that there the passage was.
85  “Tra tutto l'altro ch'i' t'ho dimostrato,
86  poscia che noi intrammo per la porta
87  lo cui sogliare a nessuno è negato,
85  "In all the rest which I have shown to thee
86  Since we have entered in within the gate
87  Whose threshold unto no one is denied,
88  cosa non fu da li tuoi occhi scorta
89  notabile com' è 'l presente rio,
90  che sovra sé tutte fiammelle ammorta.”
88  Nothing has been discovered by thine eyes
89  So notable as is the present river,
90  Which all the little flames above it quenches."
91  Queste parole fuor del duca mio;
92  per ch'io 'l pregai che mi largisse 'l pasto
93  di cui largito m'avëa il disio.
91  These words were of my Leader; whence I prayed him
92  That he would give me largess of the food,
93  For which he had given me largess of desire.
94  “In mezzo mar siede un paese guasto,”
95  diss' elli allora, “che s'appella Creta,
96  sotto 'l cui rege fu già 'l mondo casto.
94  "In the mid-sea there sits a wasted land,"
95  Said he thereafterward, "whose name is Crete,
96  Under whose king the world of old was chaste.
97  Una montagna v'è che già fu lieta
98  d'acqua e di fronde, che si chiamò Ida;
99  or è diserta come cosa vieta.
97  There is a mountain there, that once was glad
98  With waters and with leaves, which was called Ida;
99  Now 'tis deserted, as a thing worn out.
100  Rëa la scelse già per cuna fida
101  del suo figliuolo, e per celarlo meglio,
102  quando piangea, vi facea far le grida.
100  Rhea once chose it for the faithful cradle
101  Of her own son; and to conceal him better,
102  Whene'er he cried, she there had clamours made.
103  Dentro dal monte sta dritto un gran veglio,
104  che tien volte le spalle inver' Dammiata
105  e Roma guarda come süo speglio.
103  A grand old man stands in the mount erect,
104  Who holds his shoulders turned tow'rds Damietta,
105  And looks at Rome as if it were his mirror.
106  La sua testa è di fin oro formata,
107  e puro argento son le braccia e 'l petto,
108  poi è di rame infino a la forcata;
106  His head is fashioned of refined gold,
107  And of pure silver are the arms and breast;
108  hen he is brass as far down as the fork.
109  da indi in giuso è tutto ferro eletto,
110  salvo che 'l destro piede è terra cotta;
111  e sta 'n su quel, più che 'n su l'altro, eretto.
109  From that point downward all is chosen iron,
110  Save that the right foot is of kiln-baked clay,
111  And more he stands on that than on the other.

112  Ciascuna parte, fuor che l'oro, è rotta
113  d'una fessura che lagrime goccia,
114  le quali, accolte, fóran quella grotta.
112  Each part, except the gold, is by a fissure
113  Asunder cleft, that dripping is with tears,
114  Which gathered together perforate that cavern.
115  Lor corso in questa valle si diroccia;
116  fanno Acheronte, Stige e Flegetonta;
117  poi sen van giù per questa stretta doccia,
115  From rock to rock they fall into this valley;
116  Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon they form;
117  Then downward go along this narrow sluice
118  infin, là ove più non si dismonta,
119  fanno Cocito; e qual sia quello stagno
120  tu lo vedrai, però qui non si conta.”
118  Unto that point where is no more descending.
119  They form Cocytus; what that pool may be
120  Thou shalt behold, so here 'tis not narrated."
121  E io a lui: “Se 'l presente rigagno
122  si diriva così dal nostro mondo,
123  perché ci appar pur a questo vivagno?”
121  And I to him: "If so the present runnel
122  Doth take its rise in this way from our world,
123  Why only on this verge appears it to us?"
124  Ed elli a me: “Tu sai che 'l loco è tondo;
125  e tutto che tu sie venuto molto,
126  pur a sinistra, giù calando al fondo,
124  And he to me: "Thou knowest the place is round,
125  And notwithstanding thou hast journeyed far,
126  Still to the left descending to the bottom,
127  non se' ancor per tutto 'l cerchio vòlto;
128  per che, se cosa n'apparisce nova,
129  non de' addur maraviglia al tuo volto.”
127  Thou hast not yet through all the circle turned.
128  Therefore if something new appear to us,
129  It should not bring amazement to thy face."
130  E io ancor: “Maestro, ove si trova
131  Flegetonta e Letè? ché de l'un taci,
132  e l'altro di' che si fa d'esta piova.”
130  And I again: "Master, where shall be found
131  Lethe and Phlegethon, for of one thou'rt silent,
132  And sayest the other of this rain is made?"
133  “In tutte tue question certo mi piaci,”
134  rispuose, “ma 'l bollor de l'acqua rossa
135  dovea ben solver l'una che tu faci.
133  "In all thy questions truly thou dost please me,"
134  Replied he; "but the boiling of the red
135  Water might well solve one of them thou makest.
136  Letè vedrai, ma fuor di questa fossa,
137  là dove vanno l'anime a lavarsi
138  quando la colpa pentuta è rimossa.”
136  Thou shalt see Lethe, but outside this moat,
137  There where the souls repair to lave themselves,
138  When sin repented of has been removed."
139  Poi disse: “Omai è tempo da scostarsi
140  dal bosco; fa che di retro a me vegne:
141  li margini fan via, che non son arsi,
139  Then said he: "It is time now to abandon
140  The wood; take heed that thou come after me;
141  A way the margins make that are not burning,
142  e sopra loro ogne vapor si spegne.”
142  And over them all vapours are extinguished."
Canto XV
Ambiguity, irony, doubling, highs and lows, trash and treasure, mistiness, back and forths, turns and turns about — these are the characteristics of this niche in Hell wherein Dante places the sodomites.  As has been typical of Dante to this point, Dante does not so much dwell on the whatever the sin of sodomy might be sexually, except through rather vague allusions, rather he dwells on the relational aspects of the issue.  This inevitably leads to an obsessional theme of his, that is to say: politics.  

What is sodomy really?  In terms of the temporal, mortal world, it is contra natura, not because of any kind of atypical sexual pleasure, but because it is sterile.  It is a sin against Go, because it violates his command: "Be fruitful and multiply."  And in that sense, it mirrors the fate of all the denizens of Hell, in that it is self-referential, instead of being relationtional.  The sodomites here, represented by Dante's old teacher, Brunetto Latinini, dashing aimlessly about on burning sands as fire falls on them, doomed to be always running as fast into danger as they run from it.  Consider the double description at the beginning: The dikes holding back the sea, and the dikes holding back floodwaters from melting snow. (high and low)  If we consider water a metaphor for the Freudian libido, then these devices are "against nature" too, just as any kind of sexual repression would be — heterosexual, homosexual, conjugal, adulterous, consensual or non-consensual.  The urge needs an outlet, and also an inlet, and the ambiguity, the irony, of these examples, is that they provide neither.  As Frost says: "Something there is that doesn't love a wall."  But this dike in Hell ironically is the only firm ground by which the protagonists can traverse — their trail always having an inlet and an outlet — this landscape, following the course of Phlegathon's blood river as it drops down.  Now let's just examine one small technical device, the text in lines 15, 33, 52, 53, 95, and 121 contains some reference to turning — turn and turn about, oscillating, yet unable to come to rest or to reconcile the unreconcilable rights and lefts, backs and forths, ups and downs of space itself.   Brunetto must be running towards the protagonists so that he can see their faces and they his, and he bids Dante to turn too, as Virgil goes on ahead (here is another instance, where the aspirant Dante, eschews Virgil's teaching, for that of this old teacher), but here, Virgil is not totally silent, in as much as he makes a kind of departing, over-the-right-shoulder comment, dripping with irony, as he points out the irony of Dante's response to Brunetto's prophesy of Dante's exile.  Dante compares his own fate to that of being turned on Fortuna's wheel (turning again), and says, however this turn goes, he accepts his fate.

Dante's insight is on every topic subtler than any serpent of the field, and as radiant as any beacon of hope, and this is no more true than here, in this Canto.  The aspirant here is clearly sympathetic to his old teacher, even reverential, and yet, he places him among the violent, who have sinned against God.  Yes, Brunetto's speech, as are the speeches of all in hell, is clearly self-serving, and not more so in those passages where he compares the interbreeding of the Florentinean ancestors with the clearly uncultured hillbilly Fesoleans (still smelling of granite for their mountain enclaves) with the more cultured Roman's — a subtle swipe at the dangers of indiscriminate heterosexual coupling.  One could read this as comparing homosexual sex as a form of erotic celibacy, in that it does not breed devils.  And in this case it veers very close to the heresy of the Cathars, which held in its most extreme examples, it is an evil world created by an evil demi-urge and should not be perpetuated through generation.  That alone, would be a sin of violence against Creation itself, not mere incontinence or even perversion.  And, Brunetto, clearly owes his alliegence, not to theology, but to high culture, to art, and this too would be enought to damn him — at least in any orthodox estimation.  But what does Dante, the author, think about homosexual.  Well, since homosexuals also appear later with saved in the Purgatorio, I think it's safe to say, Dante did not condemn homosexuality out of hand, so there must be some other burr under his saddle that has caused him to denigrate Brunetto to this degree.  What that burr is, it skills not to ask.  All of the aspirant's words are sympathetic to Brunetto, and yet Brunetto is placed below him as he walks atop the dike, and worse, Brunetto is harshly lampooned in the final image of the canto: turning tail and running naked literally after other naked "assholes" in the lease dignified way imaginable.  The mist that rises from the blood stream protects from the falling fire and yet is in itself horrifying, a mist that veils and distorts, and adds another dimension to Hell's torments: perpetual uncertaintly.  In the end — no pun intended — we don't know what to make of this eternal confusion, except to say, that the more we try to probe it, the more ambiguous and unsettling it becomes.       

1  Ora cen porta l'un de' duri margini;
2  e 'l fummo del ruscel di sopra aduggia,
3  sì che dal foco salva l'acqua e li argini.

1  Now bears us onward one of the hard margins,
2  And so the brooklet's mist o'ershadows it,
3  From fire it saves the water and the dikes.

4  Quali Fiamminghi tra Guizzante e Bruggia,
5  temendo 'l fiotto che 'nver' lor s'avventa;
6  fanno lo schermo perché 'l mar si fuggia;

4  Even as the Flemings, 'twixt Cadsand and Bruges,
5  Fearing the flood that tow'rds them hurls itself,
6  Their bulwarks build to put the sea to flight;

7  e quali Padoan lungo la Brenta,
8  per difender lor ville e lor castelli,
9  anzi che Carentana il caldo senta:

7  And as the Paduans along the Brenta,
8  To guard their villas and their villages,
9  Or ever Chiarentana feel the heat;

10  a tale imagine eran fatti quelli,
11  tutto che né sì alti né sì grossi,
12  qual che si fosse, lo maestro félli.

10  In such similitude had those been made,
11  Albeit not so lofty nor so thick,
12  Whoever he might be, the master made them.

13  Già eravam da la selva rimossi
14  tanto, ch'i' non avrei visto dov' era,
15  perch' io in dietro rivolto mi fossi,

13  Now were we from the forest so remote,
14  I could not have discovered where it was,
15  Even if backward I had turned myself,

16  Quando incontrammo d'anime una schiera
17  che venian lungo l'argine, e ciascuna
18  ci riguardava come suol da sera

16  When we a company of souls encountered,
17  Who came beside the dike, and every one
18  Gazed at us, as at evening we are wont

19  guardare uno altro sotto nuova luna;
20  e sì ver' noi aguzzavan le ciglia
21  come 'l vecchio sartor fa ne la cruna.

19  To eye each other under a new moon,
20  And so towards us sharpened they their brows
21  As an old tailor at the needle's eye.

22  Così adocchiato da cotal famiglia,
23  fui conosciuto da un, che mi prese
24  per lo lembo e gridò: “Qual maraviglia!”

22  Thus scrutinised by such a family,
23  By some one I was recognised, who seized
24  My garment's hem, and cried out, "What a marvel!"

25  E io, quando 'l suo braccio a me distese,
26  ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto,
27  sì che 'l viso abbrusciato non difese

25  And I, when he stretched forth his arm to me,
26  On his baked aspect fastened so mine eyes,
27  That the scorched countenance prevented not

28  la conoscenza süa al mio 'ntelletto;
29  e chinando la mano a la sua faccia,
30  rispuosi: “Siete voi qui, ser Brunetto?”

28  His recognition by my intellect;
29  And bowing down my face unto his own,
30  I made reply, "Are you here, Ser Brunetto?"

31  E quelli: “O figliuol mio, non ti dispiaccia
32  se Brunetto Latino un poco teco
33  ritorna 'n dietro e lascia andar la traccia.”

31  And he: "May't not displease thee, O my son,
32  If a brief space with thee Brunetto Latini
33  Backward return and let the trail go on."

34  I' dissi lui: “Quanto posso, ven preco;
35  e se volete che con voi m'asseggia,
36  faròl, se piace a costui che vo seco.”

34  I said to him: "With all my power I ask it;
35  And if you wish me to sit down with you,
36  I will, if he please, for I go with him."

37  “O figliuol,” disse, “qual di questa greggia
38  s'arresta punto, giace poi cent' anni
39  sanz' arrostarsi quando 'l foco il feggia.

37  "O son," he said, "whoever of this herd
38  A moment stops, lies then a hundred years,
39  Nor fans himself when smiteth him the fire.

40  Però va oltre: i' ti verrò a' panni;
41  e poi rigiugnerò la mia masnada,
42  che va piangendo i suoi etterni danni.”

40  Therefore go on; I at thy skirts will come,
41  And afterward will I rejoin my band,
42  Which goes lamenting its eternal doom."

43  Io non osava scender de la strada
44  per andar par di lui; ma 'l capo chino
45  tenea com' uom che reverente vada.

43  I did not dare to go down from the road
44  Level to walk with him; but my head bowed
45  I held as one who goeth reverently.

46  El cominciò: “Qual fortuna o destino
47  anzi l'ultimo dì qua giù ti mena?
48  e chi è questi che mostra 'l cammino?”

46  And he began: "What fortune or what fate
47  Before the last day leadeth thee down here?
48  And who is this that showeth thee the way?"

49  “Là sù di sopra, in la vita serena,”
50  rispuos' io lui, “mi smarri' in una valle,
51  avanti che l'età mia fosse piena.

49  "Up there above us in the life serene,"
50  I answered him, "I lost me in a valley,
51  Or ever yet my age had been completed.

52  Pur ier mattina le volsi le spalle:
53  questi m'apparve, tornand'ïo in quella,
54  e reducemi a ca per questo calle.”

52  But yestermorn I turned my back upon it;
53  This one appeared to me, returning thither,
54  And homeward leadeth me along this road."

55  Ed elli a me: “Se tu segui tua stella,
56  non puoi fallire a glorïoso porto,
57  se ben m'accorsi ne la vita bella;

55  And he to me: "If thou thy star do follow,
56  Thou canst not fail thee of a glorious port,
57  If well I judged in the life beautiful.

58  e s'io non fossi sì per tempo morto,
59  veggendo il cielo a te così benigno,
60  dato t'avrei a l'opera conforto.

58  And if I had not died so prematurely,
59  Seeing Heaven thus benignant unto thee,
60  I would have given thee comfort in the work.

61  Ma quello ingrato popolo maligno
62  che discese di Fiesole ab antico,
63  e tiene ancor del monte e del macigno,

61  But that ungrateful and malignant people,
62  Which of old time from Fesole descended,
63  And smacks still of the mountain and the granite,

64  ti si farà, per tuo ben far, nimico;
65  ed è ragion, ché tra li lazzi sorbi
66  si disconvien fruttare al dolce fico.

64  Will make itself, for thy good deeds, thy foe;
65  And it is right; for among crabbed sorbs
66  It ill befits the sweet fig to bear fruit.

67  Vecchia fama nel mondo li chiama orbi;
68  gent' è avara, invidiosa e superba:
69  dai lor costumi fa che tu ti forbi.

67  Old rumour in the world proclaims them blind;
68  A people avaricious, envious, proud;
69  Take heed that of their customs thou do cleanse thee.

70  La tua fortuna tanto onor ti serba,
71  che l'una parte e l'altra avranno fame
72  di te; ma lungi fia dal becco l'erba.

70  Thy fortune so much honour doth reserve thee,
71  One party and the other shall be hungry
72  For thee; but far from goat shall be the grass.
 
73  Faccian le bestie fiesolane strame
74  di lor medesme, e non tocchin la pianta,
75  s'alcuna surge ancora in lor letame,

73  Their litter let the beasts of Fesole
74  Make of themselves, nor let them touch the plant,
75  If any still upon their dunghill rise,

76  in cui riviva la sementa santa
77  di que' Roman che vi rimaser quando
78  fu fatto il nido di malizia tanta.”

76  In which may yet revive the consecrated
77  Seed of those Romans, who remained there when
78  The nest of such great malice it became."

79  “Se fosse tutto pieno il mio dimando,”
80  rispuos' io lui, “voi non sareste ancora
81  de l'umana natura posto in bando;

79  "If my entreaty wholly were fulfilled,"
80  Replied I to him, "not yet would you be
81  In banishment from human nature placed;

82  ché 'n la mente m'è fitta, e or m'accora,
83  la cara e buona imagine paterna
84  di voi quando nel mondo ad ora ad ora

82  For in my mind is fixed, and touches now
83  My heart the dear and good paternal image
84  Of you, when in the world from hour to hour

85  m'insegnavate come l'uom s'etterna:
86  e quant' io l'abbia in grado, mentr' io vivo
87  convien che ne la mia lingua si scerna.

85  You taught me how a man becomes eternal;
86  And how much I am grateful, while I live
87  Behoves that in my language be discerned.

88  Ciò che narrate di mio corso scrivo,
89  e serbolo a chiosar con altro testo
90  a donna che saprà, s'a lei arrivo.

88  What you narrate of my career I write,
89  And keep it to be glossed with other text
90  By a Lady who can do it, if I reach her.

91  Tanto vogl' io che vi sia manifesto,
92  pur che mia coscïenza non mi garra,
93  ch'a la Fortuna, come vuol, son presto.

91  This much will I have manifest to you;
92  Provided that my conscience do not chide me,
93  For whatsoever Fortune I am ready.

94  Non è nuova a li orecchi miei tal arra:
95  però giri Fortuna la sua rota
96  come le piace, e 'l villan la sua marra.”

94  Such handsel is not new unto mine ears;
95  Therefore let Fortune turn her wheel around
96  As it may please her, and the churl his mattock."

97  Lo mio maestro allora in su la gota
98  destra si volse in dietro e riguardommi;
99  poi disse: “Bene ascolta chi la nota.”

97  My Master thereupon on his right cheek
98  Did backward turn himself, and looked at me;
99  Then said: "He listeneth well who noteth it."

100  Né per tanto di men parlando vommi
101  con ser Brunetto, e dimando chi sono
102  li suoi compagni più noti e più sommi.

100  Nor speaking less on that account, I go
101  With Ser Brunetto, and I ask who are
102  His most known and most eminent companions.

103  Ed elli a me: “Saper d'alcuno è buono;
104  de li altri fia laudabile tacerci,
105  ché 'l tempo saria corto a tanto suono.

103  And he to me: "To know of some is well;
104  Of others it were laudable to be silent,
105  For short would be the time for so much speech.

106  In somma sappi che tutti fur cherci
107  e litterati grandi e di gran fama,
108  d'un peccato medesmo al mondo lerci.

106  Know them in sum, that all of them were clerks,
107  And men of letters great and of great fame,
108  In the world tainted with the selfsame sin.

109  Priscian sen va con quella turba grama,
110  e Francesco d'Accorso anche; e vedervi,
111  s'avessi avuto di tal tigna brama,

109  Priscian goes yonder with that wretched crowd,
110  And Francis of Accorso; and thou hadst seen there
111  If thou hadst had a hankering for such scurf,

112  colui potei che dal servo de' servi
113  fu trasmutato d'Arno in Bacchiglione,
114  dove lasciò li mal protesi nervi.

112  That one, who by the Servant of the Servants
113  From Arno was transferred to Bacchiglione,
114  Where he has left his sin-excited nerves.

115  Di più direi; ma 'l venire e 'l sermone
116  più lungo esser non può, però ch'i' veggio
117  là surger nuovo fummo del sabbione.

115  More would I say, but coming and discoursing
116  Can be no longer; for that I behold
117  New smoke uprising yonder from the sand.

118  Gente vien con la quale esser non deggio.
119  Sieti raccomandato il mio Tesoro,
120  nel qual io vivo ancora, e più non cheggio.”

118  A people comes with whom I may not be;
119  Commended unto thee be my Tesoro,
120  In which I still live, and no more I ask."

121  Poi si rivolse e parve di coloro
122  che corrono a Verona il drappo verde
123  per la campagna; e parve di costoro

121  Then he turned round, and seemed to be of those
122  Who at Verona run for the Green Mantle
123  Across the plain; and seemed to be among them

124  quelli che vince, non colui che perde.

124  The one who wins, and not the one who loses.

Canto XVI
Can there be a vice that does no harm to others, or a virtue that does not do its bearer any good?  The fate of the three sinners featured here, seem to prompt that question.  

These two cantos wherein the sodomites are punished are swollen with ambiguity.  Here, the damned are courteously treated by the protagonist, especially here in Canto XVI, where the Virgil specifically tells the aspirant, Dante, to be courteous, and thereafter follows an interchange which stylistically bear the marks of a medieval manual on courtesy.  The whole canto is very stylized, in fact, with the framing of the waterfall (we are immediately directed to listen, and one almost thinks that this is a metaphoric pre-echo of the Shakespearean phrase "full of sound and fury and signifying nothing."  Everything here is marching in place, the three sodomites, required to keep moving, circle like wrestlers looking for an opening, but both they and the protagonists are literally going nowhere.  (Compare this kind of "looking" to the "looking" in the previous canto, where Brunetto's gaze is compared to those who search furtively under a dark new-moon shroud.  Dante is careful with observations like this, and maybe that other metaphor of the tailor threading a needle is an image of Dante himself is trying to do hear, carefully treading the edge of heresy, as he praises the characters of the damned.

To me the whole canto has the formality of a Masque, the sinners moving in a wheel, and speaking in unison.  But surely this formality is a mask, to use a phoneme, in the sense that it covers a monstrous reality.  The description of the wounds of the sinners gives us a glimpse of the pain and terror of this reality.  Surely these shades have committed some enormity in their lives, which cannot bear being directly talked about.  Brunetto's, the effeminate scholar and teacher, becomes in the end and object of ridicule.  But not these three.  They are spoken about as heroes of a lost cause ...     
  
Suddenly I realized that the sodomy that counts here is not sexual, but political: it is the inversion of one party or another championing its own cause while destroying the integrity of the whole.

The last image of the canto, the signal of the belt recalling the panther in Canto I, something coiled, uncoiling, like a fishline, which fetches forth the monster Geryon from the abyss.  And what an image Dante leaves us with: A monster with wings pumping his legs like a swimmer laboring towards the surface!  Only there is no surface here, we are in Hell, a kind of enclosed womb of a fetus that can neither be born or aborted.

1  Già era in loco onde s'udia 'l rimbombo
2  de l'acqua che cadea ne l'altro giro,
3  simile a quel che l'arnie fanno rombo,

1  Now was I where was heard the reverberation
2  Of water falling into the next round,
3  Like to that humming which the beehives make,

4  quando tre ombre insieme si partiro,
5  correndo, d'una torma che passava
6  sotto la pioggia de l'aspro martiro.

4  When shadows three together started forth,
5  Running, from out a company that passed
6  Beneath the rain of the sharp martyrdom.

7  Venian ver' noi, e ciascuna gridava:
8  “Sòstati tu ch'a l'abito ne sembri
9  essere alcun di nostra terra prava.”

7  Towards us came they, and each one cried out:
8  "Stop, thou; for by thy garb to us thou seemest
9  To be some one of our depraved city."

10  Ahimè, che piaghe vidi ne' lor membri,
11  ricenti e vecchie, da le fiamme incese!
12  Ancor men duol pur ch'i' me ne rimembri.

10  Ah me! what wounds I saw upon their limbs,
11  Recent and ancient by the flames burnt in!
12  It pains me still but to remember it.

13  A le lor grida il mio dottor s'attese;
14  volse 'l viso ver' me, e “Or aspetta,”
15  disse, “a costor si vuole esser cortese.

13  Unto their cries my Teacher paused attentive;
14  He turned his face towards me, and "Now wait,"
15  He said; "to these we should be courteous.

16 E se non fosse il foco che saetta
17  la natura del loco, i' dicerei
18  che meglio stesse a te che a lor la fretta.”

16  And if it were not for the fire that darts
17  The nature of this region, I should say
18  That haste were more becoming thee than them."

19  Ricominciar, come noi restammo, ei
20  l'antico verso; e quando a noi fuor giunti,
21  enno una rota di sé tutti e trei.

19  As soon as we stood still, they recommenced
20  The old refrain, and when they overtook us,
21  Formed of themselves a wheel, all three of them.

22  Qual sogliono i campion far nudi e unti,
23  avvisando lor presa e lor vantaggio,
24  prima che sien tra lor battuti e punti,

22  As champions stripped and oiled are wont to do,
23  Watching for their advantage and their hold,
24  Before they come to blows and thrusts between them,

25  così rotando, ciascuno il visaggio
26  drizzava a me, sì che 'n contraro il collo
27  faceva ai piè continüo vïaggio.

25  Thus, wheeling round, did every one his visage
26  Direct to me, so that in opposite wise
27  His neck and feet continual journey made.

28  E “Se miseria d'esto loco sollo
29  rende in dispetto noi e nostri prieghi,”
30  cominciò l'uno, “e 'l tinto aspetto e brollo,

28  And, "If the misery of this soft place
29  Bring in disdain ourselves and our entreaties,"
30  Began one, "and our aspect black and blistered,

31  la fama nostra il tuo animo pieghi
32  a dirne chi tu se', che i vivi piedi
33  così sicuro per lo 'nferno freghi.

31  Let the renown of us thy mind incline
32  To tell us who thou art, who thus securely
33  Thy living feet dost move along through Hell.

34  Questi, l'orme di cui pestar mi vedi,
35  tutto che nudo e dipelato vada,
36  fu di grado maggior che tu non credi:

34  He in whose footprints thou dost see me treading,
35  Naked and skinless though he now may go,
36  Was of a greater rank than thou dost think;

37  nepote fu de la buona Gualdrada;
38  Guido Guerra ebbe nome, e in sua vita
39  fece col senno assai e con la spada.

37  He was the grandson of the good Gualdrada;
38  His name was Guidoguerra, and in life
39  Much did he with his wisdom and his sword.

40  L'altro, ch'appresso me la rena trita,
41  è Tegghiaio Aldobrandi, la cui voce
42  nel mondo sù dovria esser gradita.

40  The other, who close by me treads the sand,
41  Tegghiaio Aldobrandi is, whose fame
42  Above there in the world should welcome be.

43  E io, che posto son con loro in croce,
44  Iacopo Rusticucci fui, e certo
45  la fiera moglie più ch'altro mi nuoce.”

43  And I, who with them on the cross am placed,
44  Jacopo Rusticucci was; and truly
45  My savage wife, more than aught else, doth harm me."

46  S'i' fossi stato dal foco coperto,
47  gittato mi sarei tra lor di sotto,
48  e credo che 'l dottor l'avria sofferto;

46  Could I have been protected from the fire,
47  Below I should have thrown myself among them,
48  And think the Teacher would have suffered it;

49  ma perch' io mi sarei brusciato e cotto,
50  vinse paura la mia buona voglia
51  che di loro abbracciar mi facea ghiotto.

49  But as I should have burned and baked myself,
50  My terror overmastered my good will,
51  Which made me greedy of embracing them.

52  Poi cominciai: “Non dispetto, ma doglia
53  la vostra condizion dentro mi fisse,
54  tanta che tardi tutta si dispoglia,

52  Then I began: "Sorrow and not disdain
53  Did your condition fix within me so,
54  That tardily it wholly is stripped off,

55  tosto che questo mio segnor mi disse
56  parole per le quali i' mi pensai
57  che qual voi siete, tal gente venisse.

55  As soon as this my Lord said unto me
56  Words, on account of which I thought within me
57  That people such as you are were approaching.

58  Di vostra terra sono, e sempre mai
59  l'ovra di voi e li onorati nomi
60  con affezion ritrassi e ascoltai.

58  I of your city am; and evermore
59  Your labours and your honourable names
60  I with affection have retraced and heard.

61  Lascio lo fele e vo per dolci pomi
62  promessi a me per lo verace duca;
63  ma 'nfino al centro pria convien ch'i' tomi.”

61  I leave the gall, and go for the sweet fruits
62  Promised to me by the veracious Leader;
63  But to the centre first I needs must plunge."

64  “Se lungamente l'anima conduca
65  le membra tue,” rispuose quelli ancora,
66  “e se la fama tua dopo te luca

64  "So may the soul for a long while conduct
65  Those limbs of thine," did he make answer then,
66  "And so may thy renown shine after thee,

67  cortesia e valor dì se dimora
68  ne la nostra città sì come suole,
69  o se del tutto se n'è gita fora;

67  Valour and courtesy, say if they dwell
68  Within our city, as they used to do,
69  Or if they wholly have gone out of it;

70  ché Guiglielmo Borsiere, il qual si duole
71  con noi per poco e va là coi compagni,
72  assai ne cruccia con le sue parole.”

70  For Guglielmo Borsier, who is in torment
71  With us of late, and goes there with his comrades,
72  Doth greatly mortify us with his words."

73  “La gente nuova e i sùbiti guadagni
74  orgoglio e dismisura han generata,
75  Fiorenza, in te, sì che tu già ten piagni.”

73  "The new inhabitants and the sudden gains,
74  Pride and extravagance have in thee engendered,
75  Florence, so that thou weep'st thereat already!"

76  Così gridai con la faccia levata;
77  e i tre, che ciò inteser per risposta,
78  guardar l'un l'altro com' al ver si guata.

76  In this wise I exclaimed with face uplifted;
77  And the three, taking that for my reply,
78  Looked at each other, as one looks at truth.

79  “Se l'altre volte sì poco ti costa,”
80  rispuoser tutti, “il satisfare altrui,
81  felice te se sì parli a tua posta!

79  "If other times so little it doth cost thee,"
80  Replied they all, "to satisfy another,
81  Happy art thou, thus speaking at thy will!

82  Però, se campi d'esti luoghi bui
83  e torni a riveder le belle stelle,
84  quando ti gioverà dicere 'I' fui,'

82  Therefore, if thou escape from these dark places,
83  And come to rebehold the beauteous stars,
84  When it shall pleasure thee to say, 'I was,'

85  fa che di noi a la gente favelle.”
86  Indi rupper la rota, e a fuggirsi
87  ali sembiar le gambe loro isnelle.

85  See that thou speak of us unto the people."
86  Then they broke up the wheel, and in their flight
87  It seemed as if their agile legs were wings.

88  Un amen non saria possuto dirsi
89  tosto così com' e' fuoro spariti;
90  per ch'al maestro parve di partirsi.

88  Not an Amen could possibly be said
89  So rapidly as they had disappeared;
90  Wherefore the Master deemed best to depart.

91  Io lo seguiva, e poco eravam iti,
92  che 'l suon de l'acqua n'era sì vicino,
93  che per parlar saremmo a pena uditi.

91  I followed him, and little had we gone,
92  Before the sound of water was so near us,
93  That speaking we should hardly have been heard.

94  Come quel fiume c'ha proprio cammino
95  prima dal Monte Viso 'nver' levante,
96  da la sinistra costa d'Apennino,

94  Even as that stream which holdeth its own course
95  The first from Monte Veso tow'rds the East,
96  Upon the left-hand slope of Apennine,

97  che si chiama Acquacheta suso, avante
98  che si divalli giù nel basso letto,
99  e a Forlì di quel nome è vacante,

97  Which is above called Acquacheta, ere
98  It down descendeth into its low bed,
99  And at Forli is vacant of that name,

100  rimbomba là sovra San Benedetto
101  de l'Alpe per cadere ad una scesa
102  ove dovea per mille esser recetto;

100  Reverberates there above San Benedetto
101  From Alps, by falling at a single leap,
102  Where for a thousand there were room enough;

103  così, giù d'una ripa discoscesa,
104  trovammo risonar quell' acqua tinta,
105  sì che 'n poc' ora avria l'orecchia offesa.

103  Thus downward from a bank precipitate,
104  We found resounding that dark-tinted water,
105  So that it soon the ear would have offended.

106  Io avea una corda intorno cinta,
107  e con essa pensai alcuna volta
108  prender la lonza a la pelle dipinta.

106  I had a cord around about me girt,
107  And therewithal I whilom had designed
108  To take the panther with the painted skin.

109  Poscia ch'io l'ebbi tutta da me sciolta,
110  sì come 'l duca m'avea comandato,
111  porsila a lui aggroppata e ravvolta.

109  After I this had all from me unloosed,
110  As my Conductor had commanded me,
111  I reached it to him, gathered up and coiled,

112  Ond' ei si volse inver' lo destro lato,
113  e alquanto di lunge da la sponda
114  la gittò giuso in quell' alto burrato.

112  Whereat he turned himself to the right side,
113  And at a little distance from the verge,
114  He cast it down into that deep abyss.

115  “E' pur convien che novità risponda,”
116  dicea fra me medesmo, “al novo cenno
117  che 'l maestro con l'occhio sì seconda.”

115  "It must needs be some novelty respond,"
116  I said within myself, "to the new signal
117  The Master with his eye is following so."

118  Ahi quanto cauti li uomini esser dienno
119  presso a color che non veggion pur l'ovra,
120  ma per entro i pensier miran col senno!

118  Ah me! how very cautious men should be
119  With those who not alone behold the act,
120  But with their wisdom look into the thoughts!

121  El disse a me: “Tosto verrà di sovra
122  ciò ch'io attendo e che il tuo pensier sogna;
123  tosto convien ch'al tuo viso si scovra.”

121  He said to me: "Soon there will upward come
122  What I await; and what thy thought is dreaming
123  Must soon reveal itself unto thy sight."

124  Sempre a quel ver c'ha faccia di menzogna
125  de' l'uom chiuder le labbra fin ch'el puote,
126  però che sanza colpa fa vergogna;

124  Aye to that truth which has the face of falsehood,
125  A man should close his lips as far as may be,
126  Because without his fault it causes shame;

127  ma qui tacer nol posso; e per le note
128  di questa comedìa, lettor, ti giuro,
129  s'elle non sien di lunga grazia vòte,

127  But here I cannot; and, Reader, by the notes
128  Of this my Comedy to thee I swear,
129  So may they not be void of lasting favour,

130  ch'i' vidi per quell' aere grosso e scuro
131  venir notando una figura in suso,
132  maravigliosa ad ogne cor sicuro,

130  Athwart that dense and darksome atmosphere
131  I saw a figure swimming upward come,
132  Marvellous unto every steadfast heart,

133  sì come torna colui che va giuso
134  talora a solver l'àncora ch'aggrappa
135  o scoglio o altro che nel mare è chiuso,

133  Even as he returns who goeth down
134  Sometimes to clear an anchor, which has grappled
135  Reef, or aught else that in the sea is hidden,

136  che 'n sù si stende e da piè si rattrappa.

136  Who upward stretches, and draws in his feet.

Canto XVII
Behold the monster with the pointed tail ... Behold him who infecteth all the world ... with this technical device Dante is not only parodying the Ecce Homo of the crucified Christ, but he is also telling his reader to read what is seen as well as what is heard.  He is introducing his great theme of Fraud, as a sort of faux beginning (like the faux codas in some of Haydn's symphonies) to a canto whose theme is the presentation of the usurers.  Geryon, another abhorrent mixture of creatures, is an emblem, a blazon, his very being like the heraldic blazons to be found on the purses of the usurers later in the canto.  As readers, we cannot trust the surfaces of what we see, but we can't ignore them either, and the double descriptions of the entire atmosphere, and the way the Geryon moves through it, shows a deep ambivalence: is this water?  is it air? does Geryon swim or fly?  Look at the description of Geryon — imagine di froda — the image of deceit — he has the trustworthy face of a human, but the body of serpent, whose tail carries a scorpion's sting.  The protagonists keep proceeding leftward, but they must move right for a while, keeping danger to their left, in order to continue.  And Geryon, like a boat both in and out of the water, his face visible, his tail lost in mist, is also a surface mass of barbaric, i.e. pagan, false, colors with an outward appearance of the unreadable symbols of wheels and shields, and when we come to Paradise, and see Beatrice's mystical magical car, perhaps we will remember this other diabolic vehicle of conveyance.
