A savvy reader can find many such instances of ambiguity and deceit in the metaphors that teem from this monstrous vision of Geryon, many clustered around various permutations of the number three, another parody here, but this time of the Holy Trinity.

For the second time, Virgil leaves Dante alone, and so it is alone that Dante faces the usurers.  And if we have any doubt about how we should read the images the text presents, it should be erased by this vision of the usurers.  Using money to make money is the most sterile of enterprises, it thwarts, as commentators have pointed out, the essence of industry and the Godlike attribute of humans to transform soil and seed, for example, into food, or wood and stone, into habitations.  It is the ultimate form of idolatry, in which a complete abstraction is put in place of things of useful substance, and here we have these money lenders, these loan sharks, as we might now call them, staring at their purses, they themselves having lost all semblance of human form, their names unspoken, but their identities clearly apparent to those who can read the heraldic signs emblazoned on their purses.   The blazon with the lion is that of the Gianfighiazzi family, that of the Goose, the Ubriachi, and that of the boar, the Scrovegni.  These names mean little to us now, except that the persons which they represent, crouching in a hollow, are the hollowed-out effigies of those who worshipped the hollowed-out effigy of money.  They stare at their purses tied like grief magnets around their necks, drawing forth their tears.  They whack at their own faces like dogs in summer futilely using their paws to rid their muzzles of flies, gadflies and fleas (there is that number 3 again), and they lift themselves from their hot seat on their hands, sitting on their hands (like idlers) and yet industriously working like hell to keep their asses and faces from being burned, and getting nowhere in the bargain.  They still are burned, or should we say more burned, in spite of all their efforts to prevent it.  Unlike the three sodomites in the previous canto who spoke in unison, only one of these sinners speaks, an outsider even among outsiders, a Paduan among Florentines, and he denounces the living and the dead, and makes a crude gesture (like a child sticking out his tongue), as he licks his snout like an ox licking his own nostrils.  This gesture, apparently well known to Dante's 14th century audience, is something as vulgar as giving someone the finger.  If we had any sympathy for the sodomites, who were due courtesy at least, if not salvation, for these characters we can only feel disgust and the sense of aversion that goes with disgust.  I felt such revulsion that a part of me wished that their punishment might even be greater.  One recalls Ezra Pound's great denunciation of usury in his own Cantos.  There is enough fuel to feed even more flames of hatred in these sinners, but, like the aspirant, we can hardly wait to get away from these damned souls, without further interpretations, the simple reading of their blazons and gestures is enough.  And we proceed from them to one of the most remarkable descriptions in the cantos up to this point: The protagonists' ride on Geryon's shoulders to the deeper level of Hell containing fraud.

Dante's text in this final part of the canto is an astonishing act of imagination, an accurate description of what that wheeling descent must feel and look like to a man who could have had no experience of flying, and who, only by putting himself fully, almost bodily, into his own imaginative experience, could find accurate words to describe his sensations.  Here Dante, as one commentator puts it, invents the first helicopter, and of course the attentive reader (seer) will equate this wheeling descent of Geryon with the entire corkscrew shape and movement of Hell itself.  Thinking of this shape, one might compare the drawing of two spirals to the feeling tone of Hell.  If we start at the center dot of the spiral, and turn outward in every expanding circle, we open to eternity, but if we start on the outside, and wind our spiral to its central dot, our movements becomes ever more confined and constricted.  We reach what Blake called the place of complete contraction, which is Adam, or the strictly physical man, and of complete opacity, which is the evil Christians call Satan.  Understanding these two contrary movements, which trace the same path, one towards temporal condensation, death, and decay, and one towards the utter ephemeralizing of the body into eternal spirit, I finally begin to grasp what Saint Augustine meant by reason.  It is reasonable to move toward God on this spiraling journey, and unreasonable to move towards self and selfishness.  The ultimate usury and violence towards God is using this abstraction of money to as our raison d'etre — using  these tears in our little purse of skin, as our motivation, our motive power, when all that we would have to do is turn on the screw in the other direction, drop the temporal physical identity, and experience, as we move into wider, freer rings, the ultimately fulfilling experience of being not just in the cosmos, but of it. 

What someone once said of Augustine's Confessions can also be said of Dante's Commedia, namely, that the main fiction of the work is that it is not fiction, and this passage of the descent on the back of Geryon is so vivid that our incredulity seems but an ephemerality next to the visceral experience we share with the aspirant on this journey.  We begin to feel the power of spirit as a truth wherein we life more fully than we could every live as mere physical beings in a finite, incarnation, moving towards annihilation.  In this sense, the fiction that pretends to truth, becomes truth.        

1  “Ecco la fiera con la coda aguzza,
2  che passa i monti e rompe i muri e l'armi!
3  Ecco colei che tutto 'l mondo appuzza!”

1  "Behold the monster with the pointed tail,
2  Who cleaves the hills, and breaketh walls and weapons,
3  Behold him who infecteth all the world."

4  Sì cominciò lo mio duca a parlarmi;
5  e accennolle che venisse a proda,
6  vicino al fin d'i passeggiati marmi.

4  Thus unto me my Guide began to say,
5  And beckoned him that he should come to shore,
6  Near to the confine of the trodden marble;

7  E quella sozza imagine di froda
8  sen venne, e arrivò la testa e 'l busto,
9  ma 'n su la riva non trasse la coda.

7  And that uncleanly image of deceit
8  Came up and thrust ashore its head and bust,
9  But on the border did not drag its tail.

10  La faccia sua era faccia d'uom giusto,
11  tanto benigna avea di fuor la pelle,
12  e d'un serpente tutto l'altro fusto;

10  The face was as the face of a just man,
11  Its semblance outwardly was so benign,
12  And of a serpent all the trunk beside.

13  due branche avea pilose insin l'ascelle;
14  lo dosso e 'l petto e ambedue le coste
15  dipinti avea di nodi e di rotelle.

13  Two paws it had, hairy unto the armpits;
14  The back, and breast, and both the sides it had
15  Depicted o'er with nooses and with shields.

16  Con più color, sommesse e sovraposte
17  non fer mai drappi Tartari né Turchi,
18  né fuor tai tele per Aragne imposte.

16  With colours more, groundwork or broidery
17  Never in cloth did Tartars make nor Turks,
18  Nor were such tissues by Arachne laid.

19  Come talvolta stanno a riva i burchi,
20  che parte sono in acqua e parte in terra,
21  e come là tra li Tedeschi lurchi

19  As sometimes wherries lie upon the shore,
20  That part are in the water, part on land;
21  And as among the guzzling Germans there,

22  lo bivero s'assetta a far sua guerra,
23  così la fiera pessima si stava
24  su l'orlo ch'è di pietra e 'l sabbion serra.

22  The beaver plants himself to wage his war;
23  So that vile monster lay upon the border,
24  Which is of stone, and shutteth in the sand.

25  Nel vano tutta sua coda guizzava,
26  torcendo in sù la venenosa forca
27  ch'a guisa di scorpion la punta armava.

25  His tail was wholly quivering in the void,
26  Contorting upwards the envenomed fork,
27  That in the guise of scorpion armed its point.

28  Lo duca disse: “Or convien che si torca
29  la nostra via un poco insino a quella
30  bestia malvagia che colà si corca.”

28  The Guide said: "Now perforce must turn aside
29  Our way a little, even to that beast
30  Malevolent, that yonder coucheth him."

31  Però scendemmo a la destra mammella,
32  e diece passi femmo in su lo stremo,
33  per ben cessar la rena e la fiammella.

31  We therefore on the right side descended,
32  And made ten steps upon the outer verge,
33  Completely to avoid the sand and flame;

34  E quando noi a lei venuti semo,
35  poco più oltre veggio in su la rena
36  gente seder propinqua al loco scemo.

34  And after we are come to him, I see
35  A little farther off upon the sand
36  A people sitting near the hollow place.

37  Quivi 'l maestro “Acciò che tutta piena
38  esperienza d'esto giron porti,”
39  mi disse, “va, e vedi la lor mena.

37  Then said to me the Master: "So that full
39  Experience of this round thou bear away,
39  Now go and see what their condition is.

40  Li tuoi ragionamenti sian là corti;
41  mentre che torni, parlerò con questa,
42  che ne conceda i suoi omeri forti.”

40  There let thy conversation be concise;
41  Till thou returnest I will speak with him,
42  That he concede to us his stalwart shoulders."

43  Così ancor su per la strema testa
44  di quel settimo cerchio tutto solo
45  andai, dove sedea la gente mesta.

43  Thus farther still upon the outermost
44  Head of that seventh circle all alone
45  I went, where sat the melancholy folk.

46  Per li occhi fora scoppiava lor duolo;
47  di qua, di là soccorrien con le mani
48  quando a' vapori, e quando al caldo suolo:

46  Out of their eyes was gushing forth their woe;
47  This way, that way, they helped them with their hands
48  Now from the flames and now from the hot soil.
 
49  non altrimenti fan di state i cani
50  or col ceffo or col piè, quando son morsi
51  o da pulci o da mosche o da tafani.

49  Not otherwise in summer do the dogs,
50  Now with the foot, now with the muzzle, when
51  By fleas, or flies, or gadflies, they are bitten.

52  Poi che nel viso a certi li occhi porsi,
53  ne' quali 'l doloroso foco casca,
54  non ne conobbi alcun; ma io m'accorsi

52  When I had turned mine eyes upon the faces
53  Of some, on whom the dolorous fire is falling,
54  Not one of them I knew; but I perceived

55  che dal collo a ciascun pendea una tasca
56  ch'avea certo colore e certo segno,
57  e quindi par che 'l loro occhio si pasca.

55  That from the neck of each there hung a pouch,
56  Which certain colour had, and certain blazon;
57  And thereupon it seems their eyes are feeding.

58  E com' io riguardando tra lor vegno,
59  in una borsa gialla vidi azzurro
60  che d'un leone avea faccia e contegno.

58  And as I gazing round me come among them,
59  Upon a yellow pouch I azure saw
60  That had the face and posture of a lion.

61  Poi, procedendo di mio sguardo il curro,
62  vidine un'altra come sangue rossa,
63  mostrando un'oca bianca più che burro.

61  Proceeding then the current of my sight,
62  Another of them saw I, red as blood,
63  Display a goose more white than butter is.

64  E un che d'una scrofa azzurra e grossa
 65  segnato avea lo suo sacchetto bianco,
 66  mi disse: “Che fai tu in questa fossa?

64  And one, who with an azure sow and gravid
65  Emblazoned had his little pouch of white,
66  Said unto me: "What dost thou in this moat?

67  Or te ne va; e perché se' vivo anco,
68  sappi che 'l mio vicin Vitalïano
69  sederà qui dal mio sinistro fianco.

67  Now get thee gone; and since thou'rt still alive,
68  Know that a neighbour of mine, Vitaliano,
69  Will have his seat here on my left-hand side.

70  Con questi Fiorentin son padoano:
71  spesse fïate mi 'ntronan li orecchi
72  gridando: 'Vegna 'l cavalier sovrano,

70  A Paduan am I with these Florentines;
71  Full many a time they thunder in mine ears,
72  Exclaiming, 'Come the sovereign cavalier,

73  che recherà la tasca con tre becchi!'”
74  Qui distorse la bocca e di fuor trasse
75  la lingua, come bue che 'l naso lecchi.

73  He who shall bring the satchel with three goats;'"
74  Then twisted he his mouth, and forth he thrust
75  His tongue, like to an ox that licks its nose.

76  E io, temendo no'l più star crucciasse
77  lui che di poco star m'avea 'mmonito,
78  torna'mi in dietro da l'anime lasse.

76  And fearing lest my longer stay might vex
77  Him who had warned me not to tarry long,
78  Backward I turned me from those weary souls.

79  Trova' il duca mio ch'era salito
80   già su la groppa del fiero animale,
81  e disse a me: “Or sie forte e ardito.

79  I found my Guide, who had already mounted
80  Upon the back of that wild animal,
81  And said to me: "Now be both strong and bold.

82  Omai si scende per sì fatte scale;
83  monta dinanzi, ch'i' voglio esser mezzo,
84  sì che la coda non possa far male.”

82  Now we descend by stairways such as these;
83  Mount thou in front, for I will be midway,
84  So that the tail may have no power to harm thee."

85  Qual è colui che sì presso ha 'l riprezzo
86  de la quartana, c'ha già l'unghie smorte,
87  e triema tutto pur guardando 'l rezzo,

85  Such as he is who has so near the ague
86  Of quartan that his nails are blue already,
87  And trembles all, but looking at the shade;

88  tal divenn' io a le parole porte;
89  ma vergogna mi fé le sue minacce,
90  che innanzi a buon segnor fa servo forte.

88  Even such became I at those proffered words;
89  But shame in me his menaces produced,
90  Which maketh servant strong before good master.

91  I' m'assettai in su quelle spallacce;
92  sì volli dir, ma la voce non venne
93  com' io credetti: “Fa che tu m'abbracce.”

91  I seated me upon those monstrous shoulders;
92  I wished to say, and yet the voice came not
93  As I believed, "Take heed that thou embrace me."

94  Ma esso, ch'altra volta mi sovvenne
95  ad altro forse, tosto ch'i' montai
96  con le braccia m'avvinse e mi sostenne;

94  But he, who other times had rescued me
95  In other peril, soon as I had mounted,
96  Within his arms encircled and sustained me,

97  e disse: “Gerïon, moviti omai:
98  le rote larghe, e lo scender sia poco;
99  pensa la nova soma che tu hai.”

97  And said: "Now, Geryon, bestir thyself;
98  The circles large, and the descent be little;
98  Think of the novel burden which thou hast."

100  Come la navicella esce di loco
101  in dietro in dietro, sì quindi si tolse;
102  e poi ch'al tutto si sentì a gioco,

100  Even as the little vessel shoves from shore,
101  Backward, still backward, so he thence withdrew;
102  And when he wholly felt himself afloat,

103  là 'v' era 'l petto, la coda rivolse,
104  e quella tesa, come anguilla, mosse,
105  e con le branche l'aere a sé raccolse.
103  There where his breast had been he turned his tail,
104  And that extended like an eel he moved,
105  And with his paws drew to himself the air.
106  Maggior paura non credo che fosse
107  quando Fetonte abbandonò li freni,
108  per che 'l ciel, come pare ancor, si cosse;
106  A greater fear I do not think there was
107  What time abandoned Phaeton the reins,
108  Whereby the heavens, as still appears, were scorched;

109  né quando Icaro misero le reni
110  sentì spennar per la scaldata cera,
111  gridando il padre a lui “Mala via tieni!”

109  Nor when the wretched Icarus his flanks
110  Felt stripped of feathers by the melting wax,
111  His father crying, "An ill way thou takest!"

112  che fu la mia, quando vidi ch'i' era
113  ne l'aere d'ogne parte, e vidi spenta
114  ogne veduta fuor che de la fera.

112  Than was my own, when I perceived myself
113  On all sides in the air, and saw extinguished
114  The sight of everything but of the monster.

115  Ella sen va notando lenta lenta;
 116  rota e discende, ma non me n'accorgo
 117  se non che al viso e di sotto mi venta.

115  Onward he goeth, swimming slowly, slowly;
116  Wheels and descends, but I perceive it only
117  By wind upon my face and from below.

118  Io sentia già da la man destra il gorgo
119  far sotto noi un orribile scroscio,
120  per che con li occhi 'n giù la testa sporgo. 

118  I heard already on the right the whirlpool
119  Making a horrible crashing under us;
120  Whence I thrust out my head with eyes cast downward.

121  Allor fu' io più timido a lo stoscio,
122  però ch'i' vidi fuochi e senti' pianti;
123  ond' io tremando tutto mi raccoscio.

121  Then was I still more fearful of the abyss;
122  Because I fires beheld, and heard laments,
123  Whereat I, trembling, all the closer cling.

124  E vidi poi, ché nol vedea davanti,
125  lo scendere e 'l girar per li gran mali
126  che s'appressavan da diversi canti.

124  I saw then, for before I had not seen it,
125  The turning and descending, by great horrors
126  That were approaching upon divers sides.
 
127  Come 'l falcon ch'è stato assai su l'ali,
128  che sanza veder logoro o uccello
129  fa dire al falconiere “Omè, tu cali!”

127  As falcon who has long been on the wing,
128  Who, without seeing either lure or bird,
129  Maketh the falconer say, "Ah me, thou stoopest,"

130  discende lasso onde si move isnello,
131  per cento rote, e da lunge si pone
132  dal suo maestro, disdegnoso e fello;

130  Descendeth weary, whence he started swiftly,
131  Thorough a hundred circles, and alights
132  Far from his master, sullen and disdainful;

133  così ne puose al fondo Gerïone
134  al piè al piè de la stagliata rocca,
135  e, discarcate le nostre persone,

136  si dileguò come da corda cocca.
133  Even thus did Geryon place us on the bottom,
134  Close to the bases of the rough-hewn rock,
135  And being disencumbered of our persons,
136  He sped away as arrow from the string.
Canto XVIII
In a sense this canto shows us a progression of the psyche from Canto I because the psyche of the aspirant is no longer in the groggy unorganized state half way between sleep and waking, but it has rediscovered, even as it probes the depths of hell, its own nature, which is to find in chaos and organizing intelligence, the reasoning power which is the very essence of its existence.  Line 4 of this canto (Nel dritto mezzo del campo maligno, in the direct middle of the malignant field) reminds us of the Nel mezzo del cammin (in the middle of the way), which begins the entire Commedia.  We are no longer drowning or just escaped from drowning as the swimmer in the first canto, even Hell now has a definite shape, a definite proportion, and in this canto Dante is very precise in telling us just how that shape and those proportions are — in his worldview at least — Divinely arranged.  One is reminded of the memory palaces revived from antiquity in the renaissance, and as murky and terrible as the Inferno is, it shows that it springs from this profound ability of the psyche to create order.  Here we find ourselves in a vast amphitheater (and perhaps here we recall St. Augustine’s denunciation of the theater) but an amphitheater not of seats for a spectacle, but a circular array of descending pouches or depression connected by one to another as the wind around an abyss by crags and bridges.  Crowds of sinners, in a parodic presentation, of the Jubilee crowds in Roman in the year 1300, run round these pouches, panderers and seducers in one direction and flatterers in another.  Here perhaps is the first attempt at traffic control, on group keeping to one side of the way, the other to the side opposite, yet both are pursued by demons (horned ones in the case of the panderers and seducers, to remind us of the role in the manufacture of cuckolds), which hurry them forward with lashes.  Hell is a place where wherein the psyche must move, but is going nowhere.  Hell is a place where rest is forbidden, and torment motivates every futile step.  

The numerological play which characterizes the whole of the Commedia, is much on display here, with the ten pouches of Malebolge, and we even have among the tercets the parody of the trinity as the sinners lashed from behind do not stay for a second lash, much less a third, and we might well recall here the folklore prohibition that demons must obey.  If a demon invades your house, you may give him a sieve, and demand that he count the holes.  He goes one, two, but cannot say three, because that would recall the holy trinity, and so he stays all night in his futile endeavor, until dawn forces him back into whatever crevasse of crack he crawled out of.  Here too in the demon's curse: Get thee gone, panderer, there are no women here for coin, we see an echo of the sin of usury, a trading of something fertile and good, for something abstract (money) and sterile.

We might also notice the eating metaphors (our eyes unfed or hell as a place of pungent sauces, or the sinner's head compared to a pumpkin or gourd {la zucca, line 124), used in the interactions between the aspirant and the sinners, which when we come to those who have used their mouths to flatter, are now force to eat this effluent like that, as text tells, which flows from human privies.  They dine, snorting like hogs and smacking with their open palms their own shit covered muzzles, on a mold which has adhered to the walls of their pouch, a mold whose stench makes the eyes water and offends the nostrils.  Here we meet one who sold his own kin for coin, and he is so encrusted with the ordure of his skin the aspirant cannot discern if he is layman or cleric, in brief, the man's hair is so slathered with shit that the viewer cannot tell if he is tonsured or not.  But the aspirant does recognize him.  The canto concludes with a disgusting image of Thais, a harlot and a flatterer, which Virgil bids his protégé to thrust his face foreword, face to face, a gesture we have also seen before.  This face is so disgusting that one good look is enough to satiate (the word, sazie plainly referring to having eaten enough, but mistranslated by Longfellow, as "satisfied", a word that misses the telling association with eating.

1  Luogo è in inferno detto Malebolge,
2  tutto di pietra di color ferrigno,
3  come la cerchia che dintorno il volge.

1  There is a place in Hell called Malebolge,
2  Wholly of stone and of an iron colour,
3  As is the circle that around it turns.

4  Nel dritto mezzo del campo maligno
5  vaneggia un pozzo assai largo e profondo,
6  di cui suo loco dicerò l'ordigno.

4  Right in the middle of the field malign
5  There yawns a well exceeding wide and deep,
6  Of which its place the structure will recount.

7  Quel cinghio che rimane adunque è tondo
8  tra 'l pozzo e 'l piè de l'alta ripa dura,
9  e ha distinto in dieci valli il fondo.

7  Round, then, is that enclosure which remains
8  Between the well and foot of the high, hard bank,
9  And has distinct in valleys ten its bottom.

10  Quale, dove per guardia de le mura
11  più e più fossi cingon li castelli,
12  la parte dove son rende figura,

10  As where for the protection of the walls
11  Many and many moats surround the castles,
12  The part in which they are a figure forms,

13  tale imagine quivi facean quelli;
14  e come a tai fortezze da' lor sogli
15  a la ripa di fuor son ponticelli,

13  Just such an image those presented there;
14  And as about such strongholds from their gates
15  Unto the outer bank are little bridges,

16  così da imo de la roccia scogli
17  movien che ricidien li argini e ' fossi
18  infino al pozzo che i tronca e raccogli.

16  So from the precipice's base did crags
17  Project, which intersected dikes and moats,
18  Unto the well that truncates and collects them.

19  In questo luogo, de la schiena scossi
20  di Gerïon, trovammoci; e 'l poeta
21  tenne a sinistra, e io dietro mi mossi.

19  Within this place, down shaken from the back
20  Of Geryon, we found us; and the Poet
21  Held to the left, and I moved on behind.

22  A la man destra vidi nova pieta,
23  novo tormento e novi frustatori,
24  di che la prima bolgia era repleta.

22  Upon my right hand I beheld new anguish,
23  New torments, and new wielders of the lash,
24  Wherewith the foremost Bolgia was replete.

25  Nel fondo erano ignudi i peccatori;
26  dal mezzo in qua ci venien verso 'l volto,
27  di là con noi, ma con passi maggiori,

25  Down at the bottom were the sinners naked;
26  This side the middle came they facing us,
27  Beyond it, with us, but with greater steps;


28  come i Roman per l'essercito molto,
29  l'anno del giubileo, su per lo ponte
30  hanno a passar la gente modo colto,

28  Even as the Romans, for the mighty host,
29  The year of Jubilee, upon the bridge,
30  Have chosen a mode to pass the people over;

31  che da l'un lato tutti hanno la fronte
32  verso 'l castello e vanno a Santo Pietro,
33  da l'altra sponda vanno verso 'l monte.

31  For all upon one side towards the Castle
32  Their faces have, and go unto St. Peter's;
33  On the other side they go towards the Mountain.

34  Di qua, di là, su per lo sasso tetro
35  vidi demon cornuti con gran ferze,
36  che li battien crudelmente di retro.

34  This side and that, along the livid stone
35  Beheld I horned demons with great scourges,
36  Who cruelly were beating them behind.

37  Ahi come facean lor levar le berze
38  a le prime percosse! già nessuno
39  le seconde aspettava nè le terze.

37  Ah me! how they did make them lift their legs
38  At the first blows! and sooth not any one
39  The second waited for, nor for the third.

40  Mentr' io andava, li occhi miei in uno
41  furo scontrati; e io sì tosto dissi:
42  “Già di veder costui non son digiuno.”

40  While I was going on, mine eyes by one
41  Encountered were; and straight I said: "Already
42  With sight of this one I am not unfed."

43  Per ch'ïo a figurarlo i piedi affissi;
44  e 'l dolce duca meco si ristette,
45  e assentio ch'alquanto in dietro gissi.
43  Therefore I stayed my feet to make him out,
44  And with me the sweet Guide came to a stand,
45  And to my going somewhat back assented;

46  E quel frustato celar si credette
47  bassando 'l viso; ma poco li valse,
48  ch'io dissi: “O tu che l'occhio a terra gette,

46  And he, the scourged one, thought to hide himself,
47  Lowering his face, but little it availed him;
48  For said I: "Thou that castest down thine eyes,

49  se le fazion che porti non son false,
50  Venedico se' tu Caccianemico.
51  Ma che ti mena a sì pungenti salse?”

49  If false are not the features which thou bearest,
50  Thou art Venedico Caccianimico;
51  But what doth bring thee to such pungent sauces?"

52  Ed elli a me: “Mal volontier lo dico;
53  ma sforzami la tua chiara favella,
54  che mi fa sovvenir del mondo antico.

52  And he to me: "Unwillingly I tell it;
53  But forces me thine utterance distinct,
54  Which makes me recollect the ancient world.

55  I' fui colui che la Ghisolabella
56  condussi a far la voglia del marchese,
57  come che suoni la sconcia novella.

55  I was the one who the fair Ghisola
56  Induced to grant the wishes of the Marquis,
57  Howe'er the shameless story may be told.

58  E non pur io qui piango bolognese;
59  anzi n'è questo loco tanto pieno,
60  che tante lingue non son ora apprese

58  Not the sole Bolognese am I who weeps here;
59  Nay, rather is this place so full of them,
60  That not so many tongues to-day are taught

61  a dicer 'sipa' tra Sàvena e Reno;
62  e se di ciò vuoi fede o testimonio,
63  rècati a mente il nostro avaro seno.”

61  'Twixt Reno and Savena to say 'sipa;'
62  And if thereof thou wishest pledge or proof,
63  Bring to thy mind our avaricious heart."

64  Così parlando il percosse un demonio
65  de la sua scurïada, e disse: “Via,
66  ruffian! qui non son femmine da conio.”

64  While speaking in this manner, with his scourge
65  A demon smote him, and said: "Get thee gone
66  Pander, there are no women here for coin."

67  I' mi raggiunsi con la scorta mia;
68  poscia con pochi passi divenimmo
69  là 'v' uno scoglio de la ripa uscia.

67  I joined myself again unto mine Escort;
68  Thereafterward with footsteps few we came
69  To where a crag projected from the bank.

70  Assai leggeramente quel salimmo;
71  e vòlti a destra su per la sua scheggia,
72  da quelle cerchie etterne ci partimmo.

70  This very easily did we ascend,
71  And turning to the right along its ridge,
72  From those eternal circles we departed.

73  Quando noi fummo là dov' el vaneggia
74  di sotto per dar passo a li sferzati,
75  lo duca disse: “Attienti, e fa che feggia

73  When we were there, where it is hollowed out
74  Beneath, to give a passage to the scourged,
75  The Guide said: "Wait, and see that on thee strike

76  lo viso in te di quest' altri mal nati,
77  ai quali ancor non vedesti la faccia
78  però che son con noi insieme andati.”

76  The vision of those others evil-born,
77  Of whom thou hast not yet beheld the faces,
78  Because together with us they have gone."

79  Del vecchio ponte guardavam la traccia
80  che venìa verso noi da l'altra banda,
81  e che la ferza similmente scaccia.

79  From the old bridge we looked upon the train
80  Which tow'rds us came upon the other border,
81  And which the scourges in like manner smite.

82  E 'l buon maestro, sanza mia dimanda,
83  mi disse: “Guarda quel grande che vene,
84  e per dolor non par lagrime spanda:

82  And the good Master, without my inquiring,
83  Said to me: "See that tall one who is coming,
84  And for his pain seems not to shed a tear;

85  quanto aspetto reale ancor ritene!
86  Quelli è Iasón, che per cuore e per senno
87  li Colchi del monton privati féne.

85  Still what a royal aspect he retains!
86  That Jason is, who by his heart and cunning
87  The Colchians of the Ram made destitute.

88  Ello passò per l'isola di Lenno
89  poi che l'ardite femmine spietate
90  tutti li maschi loro a morte dienno.

88  He by the isle of Lemnos passed along
89  After the daring women pitiless
90  Had unto death devoted all their males.

91  Ivi con segni e con parole ornate
92  Isifile ingannò, la giovinetta
93  che prima avea tutte l'altre ingannate.

91  There with his tokens and with ornate words
92  Did he deceive Hypsipyle, the maiden
93  Who first, herself, had all the rest deceived.

94  Lasciolla quivi, gravida, soletta;
95  tal colpa a tal martiro lui condanna;
96  e anche di Medea si fa vendetta.

94  There did he leave her pregnant and forlorn;
95  Such sin unto such punishment condemns him,
96  And also for Medea is vengeance done.

97  Con lui sen va chi da tal parte inganna;
98  e questo basti de la prima valle
99  sapere e di color che 'n sé assanna.”

97  With him go those who in such wise deceive;
98  And this sufficient be of the first valley
99  To know, and those that in its jaws it holds."

100  Già eravam là 've lo stretto calle
101  con l'argine secondo s'incrocicchia,
102  e fa di quello ad un altr' arco spalle.

100  We were already where the narrow path
101  Crosses athwart the second dike, and forms
102  Of that a buttress for another arch.

103  Quindi sentimmo gente che si nicchia
104  ne l'altra bolgia e che col muso scuffa,
105  e sé medesma con le palme picchia.

103  Thence we heard people, who are making moan
104  In the next Bolgia, snorting with their muzzles,
105  And with their palms beating upon themselves

106  Le ripe eran grommate d'una muffa,
107  per l'alito di giù che vi s'appasta,
108  che con li occhi e col naso facea zuffa.

106  The margins were incrusted with a mould
107  By exhalation from below, that sticks there,
108  And with the eyes and nostrils wages war.

109  Lo fondo è cupo sì, che non ci basta
110  loco a veder sanza montare al dosso
111  de l'arco, ove lo scoglio più sovrasta.

109  The bottom is so deep, no place suffices
110  To give us sight of it, without ascending
111  The arch's back, where most the crag impends.

112  Quivi venimmo; e quindi giù nel fosso
113  vidi gente attuffata in uno sterco
114  che da li uman privadi parea mosso.

112  Thither we came, and thence down in the moat
113  I saw a people smothered in a filth
114  That out of human privies seemed to flow;

115  E mentre ch'io là giù con l'occhio cerco,
116  vidi un col capo sì di merda lordo,
117  che non parëa s'era laico o cherco.

115  And whilst below there with mine eye I search,
116  I saw one with his head so foul with ordure,
117  It was not clear if he were clerk or layman.

118  Quei mi sgridò: “Perché se' tu sì gordo
119  di riguardar più me che li altri brutti?”
120  E io a lui: “Perché, se ben ricordo,

118  He screamed to me: "Wherefore art thou so eager
119  To look at me more than the other foul ones?"
120  And I to him: "Because, if I remember,

121  già t'ho veduto coi capelli asciutti,
122  e se' Alessio Interminei da Lucca:
123  però t'adocchio più che li altri tutti.”

121  I have already seen thee with dry hair,
122  And thou'rt Alessio Interminei of Lucca;
123  Therefore I eye thee more than all the others."

124  Ed elli allor, battendosi la zucca:
125  “Qua giù m'hanno sommerso le lusinghe
126  ond' io non ebbi mai la lingua stucca.”

124  And he thereon, belabouring his pumpkin:
125  "The flatteries have submerged me here below,
126  Wherewith my tongue was never surfeited."

127  Appresso ciò lo duca “Fa che pinghe,”
128  mi disse, “il viso un poco più avante,
129  sì che la faccia ben con l'occhio attinghe

127  Then said to me the Guide: "See that thou thrust
128  Thy visage somewhat farther in advance,
129  That with thine eyes thou well the face attain

130  di quella sozza e scapigliata fante
131  che là si graffia con l'unghie merdose,
132  e or s'accoscia e ora è in piedi stante.

130  Of that uncleanly and dishevelled drab,
131  Who there doth scratch herself with filthy nails,
132  And crouches now, and now on foot is standing.

133  Taïde è, la puttana che rispuose
134  al drudo suo quando disse 'Ho io grazie
135  grandi apo te?': 'Anzi maravigliose!'

133  Thais the harlot is it, who replied
134  Unto her paramour, when he said, 'Have I
135  Great gratitude from thee?'—'Nay, marvellous;'

136  E quinci sian le nostre viste sazie.”

136  And herewith let our sight be satisfied."

Canto XIX
In an often apostrophic, prophetic style (O Simon Mago, O miseri seguaci, O somma sapienza, O qual che se' che 'l di sù tien di sotto, Ahi, Costantin ...) Canto XIX is the canto of the simoniac Popes, the canto of inversions.  The chief inversion being that any Pope, the infallible Vicar of Christ on Earth, should so reverse the calling of his office as to use his position for money and secular power, selling church offices and sacraments.  One of the Popes that the protagonists meet here is Pope Nicholas III, and like all the other simoniacs he is upside down in his tomb, his feet protruding in the air being laced with running fire.  Like others in Hell these sinners run, but even more than the others, the motions of their feet, although incessant, are utterly futile.  Nicholas mistakes Dante for his successor, whom he denounces for the very sin that he himself helped to make routine in the office.  After, being corrected, he does not change his cynical accusatory tirade, but merely directs it towards his fellow Bolognese.  There are a lot of references to marriage, fornication, and offspring, the Bride of the church, the whore of Babylon, the nepotism of the Pope, etc. the text's way of drawing the portrait of an evil by showing it off against the foil of the good.  In a similar manner, Dante shows the correct relationship between authority and those whom authority must lead and serve, by emphasizing the devotion that he and Virgil have for one another, i.e., knowing each other’s thoughts, and at one point literally becoming one as Virgil carries his protege over rough ground in his very arms.  But wait ... if a Pope is infallible, how can a layman question or accuse him without himself being guilty of blasphemy or heresy?  How?  By virtue of his devotion to Christ's sole dictum: Follow me.  The aspirant now becomes the confessor to one who laments his punishment, but not his sins, and in this parodic scene, the confessee receives not absolution for his trouble but a tirade of denunciation.  There is also a little biographical illustration, wherein the aspirant tells of breaking a baptismal font of the Florentine church of Saint John's, which should be a grave desecration and impiety, but it is instead offered as an act of Christian virtue because it was done to save the life of a child who was drowning there.  Here, Dante becomes the midwife of a soul, which is drowning in amniotic waters of the uterine baptismal.  Does he means by this that when the church is corrupted then it can no longer be the good Mother to its children or the good bride of Christ, but becomes instead a poisonous womb that drowns and aborts its own pups?  The main argument here is the one that Christ elucidated when asked about paying taxes, showing that the talent to be given to the tax collector was minted with the face of Caesar.  In brief, secular power and sacred authority are clearly two different things, and that when the Church tries to be both, through the sin of simony, it inverts its calling, and becomes a hoarder and whore of wealth, not virtue.  And is such cases, virtue, even virtue without the authority of office, assumes the role of the prophet, and in that role it is the profane-seeming laymen who wears the mantle of Christ, not His sacred-seeming vicar.  It does not take much imagination to transfer this allegory to our own times.      

1  O Simon mago, o miseri seguaci
2  che le cose di Dio, che di bontate
3  deon essere spose, e voi rapaci

1  O Simon Magus, O forlorn disciples,
2  Ye who the things of God, which ought to be
3  The brides of holiness, rapaciously

4  per oro e per argento avolterate,
5  or convien che per voi suoni la tromba,
6  però che ne la terza bolgia state.

4  For silver and for gold do prostitute,
5  Now it behoves for you the trumpet sound,
6  Because in this third Bolgia ye abide.

7  Già eravamo, a la seguente tomba,
8  montati de lo scoglio in quella parte
9  ch'a punto sovra mezzo 'l fosso piomba.

7  We had already on the following tomb
8  Ascended to that portion of the crag
9  Which o'er the middle of the moat hangs plumb.

10  O somma sapïenza, quanta è l'arte
11  che mostri in cielo, in terra e nel mal mondo,
12  e quanto giusto tua virtù comparte!

10  Wisdom supreme, O how great art thou showest
11  In heaven, in earth, and in the evil world,
12  And with what justice doth thy power distribute!

13  Io vidi per le coste e per lo fondo
14  piena la pietra livida di fóri,
15  d'un largo tutti e ciascun era tondo.

13  I saw upon the sides and on the bottom
14  The livid stone with perforations filled,
15  All of one size, and every one was round.

16  Non mi parean men ampi né maggiori
17  che que' che son nel mio bel San Giovanni,
18  fatti per loco d'i battezzatori;

16  To me less ample seemed they not, nor greater
17  Than those that in my beautiful Saint John
18  Are fashioned for the place of the baptisers,

19  l'un de li quali, ancor non è molt' anni,
20  rupp' io per un che dentro v'annegava:
21  e questo sia suggel ch'ogn' omo sganni.

19  And one of which, not many years ago,
20  I broke for some one, who was drowning in it;
21  Be this a seal all men to undeceive.

22  Fuor de la bocca a ciascun soperchiava
23  d'un peccator li piedi e de le gambe
24  infino al grosso, e l'altro dentro stava.

22  Out of the mouth of each one there protruded
23  The feet of a transgressor, and the legs
24  Up to the calf, the rest within remained.

25  Le piante erano a tutti accese intrambe;
26  per che si forte guizzavan le giunte,
27  che spezzate averien ritorte e strambe.

25  In all of them the soles were both on fire;
26  Wherefore the joints so violently quivered,
27  They would have snapped asunder withes and bands.

28  Qual suole il fiammeggiar de le cose unte
29  muoversi pur su per la strema buccia,
30  tal era lì dai calcagni a le punte.

28  Even as the flame of unctuous things is wont
29  To move upon the outer surface only,
30  So likewise was it there from heel to point.

31  “Chi è colui, maestro, che si cruccia
32  guizzando più che li altri suoi consorti,”
33  diss' io, “e cui più roggia fiamma succia?”

31  "Master, who is that one who writhes himself,
32  More than his other comrades quivering,"
33  I said, "and whom a redder flame is sucking?"

34  Ed elli a me: “Se tu vuo' ch'i' ti porti
35  là giù per quella ripa che più giace,
36  da lui saprai di sé e de' suoi torti.”

34  And he to me: "If thou wilt have me bear thee
35  Down there along that bank which lowest lies,
36  From him thou'lt know his errors and himself."

37  E io: “Tanto m'è bel, quanto a te piace:
38  tu se' segnore, e sai ch'i' non mi parto
39  dal tuo volere, e sai quel che si tace.”

37  And I: "What pleases thee, to me is pleasing;
38  Thou art my Lord, and knowest that I depart not
39  From thy desire, and knowest what is not spoken."

40  Allor venimmo in su l'argine quarto;
41  volgemmo e discendemmo a mano stanca
42  là giù nel fondo foracchiato e arto.

40  Straightway upon the fourth dike we arrived;
41  We turned, and on the left-hand side descended
42  Down to the bottom full of holes and narrow.

43  Lo buon maestro ancor de la sua anca
44  non mi dipuose, sì mi giunse al rotto
45  di quel che si piangeva con la zanca.

43  And the good Master yet from off his haunch
44  Deposed me not, till to the hole he brought me
45  Of him who so lamented with his shanks.

46  “O qual che se' che 'l di sù tien di sotto,
47  anima trista come pal commessa,”
48  comincia' io a dir, “se puoi, fa motto.”

46  "Whoe'er thou art, that standest upside down,
47  O doleful soul, implanted like a stake,"
48  To say began I, "if thou canst, speak out."

49  Io stava come 'l frate che confessa
50  lo perfido assessin, che, poi ch'è fitto,
51  richiama lui per che la morte cessa.

49  I stood even as the friar who is confessing
50  The false assassin, who, when he is fixed,
51  Recalls him, so that death may be delayed.

52  Ed el gridò: “Se' tu già costì ritto,
53  se' tu già costì ritto, Bonifazio?
54  Di parecchi anni mi mentì lo scritto.

52  And he cried out: "Dost thou stand there already,
53  Dost thou stand there already, Boniface?
54  By many years the record lied to me.

55  Se' tu sì tosto di quell' aver sazio
56  per lo qual non temesti tòrre a 'nganno
57  la bella donna, e poi di farne strazio?”

55  Art thou so early satiate with that wealth,
56  For which thou didst not fear to take by fraud
57  The beautiful Lady, and then work her woe?"

58  Tal mi fec' io, quai son color che stanno,
59  per non intender ciò ch'è lor risposto,
60  quasi scornati, e risponder non sanno.

58  Such I became, as people are who stand,
59  Not comprehending what is answered them,
60  As if bemocked, and know not how to answer.

61  Allor Virgilio disse: “Dilli tosto:
62  'Non son colui, non son colui che credi'”;
63  e io rispuosi come a me fu imposto.

61  Then said Virgilius: "Say to him straightway,
62  'I am not he, I am not he thou thinkest.'"
63  And I replied as was imposed on me.

64  Per che lo spirto tutti storse i piedi;
65  poi, sospirando e con voce di pianto,
66  mi disse: “Dunque che a me richiedi?

64  Whereat the spirit writhed with both his feet,
65  Then, sighing, with a voice of lamentation
66  Said to me: "Then what wantest thou of me?

67  Se di saper ch'i' sia ti cal cotanto,
68  che tu abbi però la ripa corsa,
69  sappi ch'i' fui vestito del gran manto;

67  If who I am thou carest so much to know,
68  That thou on that account hast crossed the bank,
69  Know that I vested was with the great mantle;

70  e veramente fui figliuol de l'orsa,
71  cupido sì per avanzar li orsatti,
72  che sù l'avere e qui me misi in borsa.

70  And truly was I son of the She-bear,
71  So eager to advance the cubs, that wealth
72  Above, and here myself, I pocketed.

73  Di sotto al capo mio son li altri tratti
74  che precedetter me simoneggiando,
75  per le fessure de la pietra piatti.

73  Beneath my head the others are dragged down
74  Who have preceded me in simony,
75  Flattened along the fissure of the rock.

76  Là giù cascherò io altresì quando
77  verrà colui ch'i' credea che tu fossi,
78  allor ch'i' feci 'l sùbito dimando.

76  Below there I shall likewise fall, whenever
77  That one shall come who I believed thou wast,
78  What time the sudden question I proposed.

79  Ma più è 'l tempo già che i piè mi cossi
80  e ch'i' son stato così sottosopra,
81  ch'el non starà piantato coi piè rossi:

79  But longer I my feet already toast,
80  And here have been in this way upside down,
81  Than he will planted stay with reddened feet;

82  ché dopo lui verrà di più laida opra,
83  di ver' ponente, un pastor sanza legge,
84  tal che convien che lui e me ricuopra.

82  For after him shall come of fouler deed
83  From tow'rds the west a Pastor without law,
84  Such as befits to cover him and me.

85  Nuovo Iasón sarà, di cui si legge
86  ne' Maccabei; e come a quel fu molle
87  suo re, così fia lui chi Francia regge.”
85  New Jason will he be, of whom we read
86  In Maccabees; and as his king was pliant,
87  So he who governs France shall be to this one."

88  Io non so s'i' mi fui qui troppo folle,
89  ch'i' pur rispuosi lui a questo metro:
90  “Deh, or mi dì: quanto tesoro volle

88  I do not know if I were here too bold,
89  That him I answered only in this metre:
90  "I pray thee tell me now how great a treasure

91  Nostro Segnore in prima da san Pietro
92  ch'ei ponesse le chiavi in sua balìa?
93  Certo non chiese se non 'Viemmi retro.'

91  Our Lord demanded of Saint Peter first,
92  Before he put the keys into his keeping?
93  Truly he nothing asked but 'Follow me.'

94  Né Pier né li altri tolsero a Matia
95  oro od argento, quando fu sortito
96  al loco che perdé l'anima ria.

94  Nor Peter nor the rest asked of Matthias
95  Silver or gold, when he by lot was chosen
96  Unto the place the guilty soul had lost.

97  Però ti sta, ché tu se' ben punito;
98  e guarda ben la mal tolta moneta
99  ch'esser ti fece contra Carlo ardito.

97  Therefore stay here, for thou art justly punished,
98  And keep safe guard o'er the ill-gotten money,
99  Which caused thee to be valiant against Charles.

100  E se non fosse ch'ancor lo mi vieta
101  la reverenza de le somme chiavi
102  che tu tenesti ne la vita lieta,

100  And were it not that still forbids it me
101  The reverence for the keys superlative
102  Thou hadst in keeping in the gladsome life,

103  io userei parole ancor più gravi;
104  ché la vostra avarizia il mondo attrista,
105  calcando i buoni e sollevando i pravi.

103  I would make use of words more grievous still;
104  Because your avarice afflicts the world,
105  Trampling the good and lifting the depraved.

106  Di voi pastor s'accorse il Vangelista,
107  quando colei che siede sopra l'acque
108  puttaneggiar coi regi a lui fu vista;

106  The Evangelist you Pastors had in mind,
107  When she who sitteth upon many waters
108  To fornicate with kings by him was seen;

109  quella che con le sette teste nacque,
110  e da le diece corna ebbe argomento,
111  fin che virtute al suo marito piacque.

109  The same who with the seven heads was born,
110  And power and strength from the ten horns received,
111  So long as virtue to her spouse was pleasing.

112  Fatto v'avete dio d'oro e d'argento;
113  e che altro è da voi a l'idolatre,
114  se non ch'elli uno, e voi ne orate cento?

112  Ye have made yourselves a god of gold and silver;
113  And from the idolater how differ ye,
114  Save that he one, and ye a hundred worship?

115  Ahi, Costantin, di quanto mal fu matre,
116  non la tua conversion, ma quella dote
117  che da te prese il primo ricco patre!”

115  Ah, Constantine! of how much ill was mother,
116  Not thy conversion, but that marriage dower
117  Which the first wealthy Father took from thee!"

118  E mentr' io li cantava cotai note,
119  o ira o coscïenza che 'l mordesse,
120  forte spingava con ambo le piote.

118  And while I sang to him such notes as these,
119  Either that anger or that conscience stung him,
120  He struggled violently with both his feet.

121  I' credo ben ch'al mio duca piacesse,
122  con si contenta labbia sempre attese
123  lo suon de le parole vere espresse.

121  I think in sooth that it my Leader pleased,
122  With such contented lip he listened ever
123  Unto the sound of the true words expressed.

124  Però con ambo le braccia mi prese;
125  e poi che tutto su mi s'ebbe al petto,
126  rimontò per la via onde discese.

124  Therefore with both his arms he took me up,
125  And when he had me all upon his breast,
126  Remounted by the way where he descended.

127  Né si stancò d'avermi a sé distretto,
128  sì men portò sovra 'l colmo de l'arco
129  che dal quarto al quinto argine è tragetto.

127  Nor did he tire to have me clasped to him;
128  But bore me to the summit of the arch
129  Which from the fourth dike to the fifth is passage.

130  Quivi soavemente spuose il carco,
131  soave per lo scoglio sconcio ed erto
132  che sarebbe a le capre duro varco.

130  There tenderly he laid his burden down,
131  Tenderly on the crag uneven and steep,
132  That would have been hard passage for the goats:

133  Indi un altro vallon mi fu scoperto.

133  Thence was unveiled to me another valley.

Canto XX
It's about Time: and the relationship between origins, destinies, false divination, the impossibility of navigation without correct orientation, and the duel enigma of water (tears, lakes, marshes, rivers) and Time.  Which way does Time run for us, down like tears to water our hearts, or down our backs to innundate our anuses?   

As we go deeper into these levels of Hell, it is easy to begin shifting one's emotional energy away from what one is actually experiencing and into a commentator's role as bystander and witness, getting lost in scholarly quibbles over this or that meaning in the text or over what Dante's intention was in producing the text.  But the real horror, the real despair of seeing the soul-forms of the damned and their utter corruption of the human form and the human being's potential for love, and magnanimity works into one's own soul-form, and one find's oneself awake in the middle of the night pondering the actual state of pain and suffering.  What level of fear might drive a person to foment visions of the future in which a pure malignity is called forth to swallow other fearful people.  And what level of malignity finally releases the spring of cosmic retribution to release its torment upon you, and purge itself in delight at your suffering?   This is horrible beyond pity or piety, and we cannot help but feel that Virgil with his pagan point of view, aligned against pity, standing at the threshold of the future, which is Christian charity and forgiveness, to turn around himself, denounce his protege for his pity and despair, and then look backwards to the founding of this birth city, by a sorceress who, somehow, against all common sense, uses an evil gift for prognostication for everything else, but does not do so to establish her own place of habitation.  Virgil, in fact, seems to be divining about the past!, twisting his story that was written about his effigy in the Aeneid into an entirely different story which exonerates him from the very sin that he is denouncing Dante for pitying.  Dante does indeed suspend his pity, but it is not only the Dante who is the protagonist of the poem that does so.  It is the Dante, in his metaposition as the Poet, who suspends his pity as well, by making Virgil's speech and his aspirant-self's acceptance of it, subtly ironic.  Forget the bond that the mentor and teacher had in the previous canto where they were one, Dante like a babe in arms to his teacher, here, the text simple refers to Virgil as (line 26) as la mia scorta, my companion.  And later, when he begins to praise his teacher again in lines 100 - 103, as a Master whose teachings render all others as spent coals, we wonder what kind of transformation has happened inside the aspirant that he has accepted what the poet Dante has not.  Then too why does Virgil so degrade Manto, a woman, except as a terrible parody of what is to come when another woman, Beatrice, replaces him as the aspirant's lodestar?  Why indeed, and how, does Virgil tell the time at the end of the canto by the phases of a moon, that he cannot see, and which he refers to by an Old Testament icon, Cain, the brother killer, and the Man in the Moon, bristling with thorns.  Virgil is in fact a diviner here, and the aspirant is making use of him, not to mimic him, but to see him too as a cautionary example, and dare I say it, a person who is damned, but deserving of respect and pity.

All this is imbedded in the sex act and the parody of the tree with its entwined serpents in the aside about Tiresias, who becomes a symbol of coitus (back to origins again, and the magical nature that combines opposites, then separates them, and all this seems like an elaborate charade to fool us into believe that the conditions of these souls in hell do not touch us at all, but beneath the charade and smugness that comes from being judge and witness of the evil and punishment of others, is the deep, deep realization that the Universe is not, as Blake might say, a "cloven fiction," it is a whole, full of pain, full of malice, full of grace, full of love, full of intolerable suffering and unspeakable Jouissance, and it all lives inside each one of us, and makes us start in the middle of night and wish either for the oblivion of Death or the eradication of transcendence.

Everyone suffers, and everyone tries to avoid suffering, but not everyone denounces suffering, or revels in the suffering of others, and Dante, the poet, seems to be asking us to have faith in a God who does all these things simultaneously, yet without being tainted by his own creation.  And what a terrible double bind we find ourselves in trying to not only to believe in such an entity but to love IT. 

The whole experience of really reading Dante is awful in the deepest sense of that word.   

1  Di nova pena mi conven far versi
2  e dar matera al ventesimo canto
3  de la prima canzon, ch'è d'i sommersi.

1  Of a new pain behoves me to make verses
2  And give material to the twentieth canto
3  Of the first song, which is of the submerged.

4  Io era già disposto tutto quanto
5  a riguardar ne lo scoperto fondo,
6  che si bagnava d'angoscioso pianto;

4  I was already thoroughly disposed
5  To peer down into the uncovered depth,
6  Which bathed itself with tears of agony;

7  e vidi gente per lo vallon tondo
8  venir, tacendo e lagrimando, al passo
9  che fanno le letane in questo mondo.

7  And people saw I through the circular valley,
8  Silent and weeping, coming at the pace
9  Which in this world the Litanies assume.

10  Come 'l viso mi scese in lor più basso,
11  mirabilmente apparve esser travolto
12  ciascun tra 'l mento e 'l principio del casso,

10  As lower down my sight descended on them,
11  Wondrously each one seemed to be distorted
12  From chin to the beginning of the chest;

13  ché da le reni era tornato 'l volto,
14  e in dietro venir li convenia,
15  perché 'l veder dinanzi era lor tolto.

13  For tow'rds the reins the countenance was turned,
14  And backward it behoved them to advance,
15  As to look forward had been taken from them.

16  Forse per forza già di parlasia
17  si travolse così alcun del tutto;
18  ma io nol vidi, né credo che sia.

16  Perchance indeed by violence of palsy
17  Some one has been thus wholly turned awry;
18  But I ne'er saw it, nor believe it can be.

19  Se Dio ti lasci, lettor, prender frutto
20  di tua lezione, or pensa per te stesso
21  com' io potea tener lo viso asciutto,

19  As God may let thee, Reader, gather fruit
20  From this thy reading, think now for thyself
21  How I could ever keep my face unmoistened,

22  quando la nostra imagine di presso
23  vidi sì torta, che 'l pianto de li occhi
24  le natiche bagnava per lo fesso.

22  When our own image near me I beheld
23  Distorted so, the weeping of the eyes
24  Along the fissure bathed the hinder parts.

25  Certo io piangea, poggiato a un de' rocchi
26  del duro scoglio, sì che la mia scorta
27  mi disse: “Ancor se' tu de li altri sciocchi?

25  Truly I wept, leaning upon a peak
26  Of the hard crag, so that my Escort said
27  To me: "Art thou, too, of the other fools?

28  Qui vive la pietà quand' è ben morta;
29  chi è più scellerato che colui
30  che al giudicio divin passion comporta?

28  Here pity lives when it is wholly dead;
29  Who is a greater reprobate than he
30  Who feels compassion at the doom divine?

31  Drizza la testa, drizza, e vedi a cui
32  s'aperse a li occhi d'i Teban la terra;
33  per ch'ei gridavan tutti: 'Dove rui,

31  Lift up, lift up thy head, and see for whom
32  Opened the earth before the Thebans' eyes;
33  Wherefore they all cried: 'Whither rushest thou,

34  Anfïarao? perché lasci la guerra?'
35  E non restò di ruinare a valle
36  fino a Minòs che ciascheduno afferra.

34  Amphiaraus? Why dost leave the war?'
35  And downward ceased he not to fall amain
36  As far as Minos, who lays hold on all.

37  Mira c'ha fatto petto de le spalle;
38  perché volse veder troppo davante,
39  di retro guarda e fa retroso calle.

37  See, he has made a bosom of his shoulders!
38  Because he wished to see too far before him
39  Behind he looks, and backward goes his way:

40  Vedi Tiresia, che mutò sembiante
41  quando di maschio femmina divenne,
42  cangiandosi le membra tutte quante;

40  Behold Tiresias, who his semblance changed,
41  When from a male a female he became,
42  His members being all of them transformed;

43  e prima, poi, ribatter li convenne
44  li duo serpenti avvolti, con la verga,
45  che rïavesse le maschili penne.

43  And afterwards was forced to strike once more
44  The two entangled serpents with his rod,
45  Ere he could have again his manly plumes.

46  Aronta è quel ch'al ventre li s'atterga,
47  che ne' monti di Luni, dove ronca
48  lo Carrarese che di sotto alberga,

46  That Aruns is, who backs the other's belly,
47  Who in the hills of Luni, there where grubs
48  The Carrarese who houses underneath,

49  ebbe tra ' bianchi marmi la spelonca
50  per sua dimora; onde a guardar le stelle
51  e 'l mar non li era la veduta tronca.

49  Among the marbles white a cavern had
50  For his abode; whence to behold the stars
51  And sea, the view was not cut off from him.

52  E quella che ricuopre le mammelle,
53  che tu non vedi, con le trecce sciolte,
54  e ha di là ogne pilosa pelle,

52  And she there, who is covering up her breasts,
53  Which thou beholdest not, with loosened tresses,
54  And on that side has all the hairy skin,

55  Manto fu, che cercò per terre molte;
56  poscia si puose là dove nacqu' io;
57  onde un poco mi piace che m'ascolte.

55  Was Manto, who made quest through many lands,
56  Afterwards tarried there where I was born;
57  Whereof I would thou list to me a little.

58  Poscia che 'l padre suo di vita uscìo
59  e venne serva la città di Baco,
60  questa gran tempo per lo mondo gio.

58  After her father had from life departed,
59  And the city of Bacchus had become enslaved,
60  She a long season wandered through the world.

61  Suso in Italia bella giace un laco,
62  a piè de l'Alpe che serra Lamagna
63  sovra Tiralli, c'ha nome Benaco.

61  Above in beauteous Italy lies a lake
62  At the Alp's foot that shuts in Germany
63  Over Tyrol, and has the name Benaco.

64  Per mille fonti, credo, e più si bagna
65  tra Garda e Val Camonica e Pennino
66  de l'acqua che nel detto laco stagna.

64  By a thousand springs, I think, and more, is bathed,
65  'Twixt Garda and Val Camonica, Pennino,
66  With water that grows stagnant in that lake.

67  Loco è nel mezzo là dove 'l trentino
68  pastore e quel di Brescia e 'l veronese
69  segnar poria, s'e' fesse quel cammino.

67  Midway a place is where the Trentine Pastor,
68  And he of Brescia, and the Veronese
69  Might give his blessing, if he passed that way.

70  Siede Peschiera, bello e forte arnese
71  da fronteggiar Bresciani e Bergamaschi,
72  ove la riva 'ntorno più discese.

70  Sitteth Peschiera, fortress fair and strong,
71  To front the Brescians and the Bergamasks,
72  Where round about the bank descendeth lowest.

73  Ivi convien che tutto quanto caschi
74  ciò che 'n grembo a Benaco star non può,
75  e fassi fiume giù per verdi paschi.

73  There of necessity must fall whatever
74  In bosom of Benaco cannot stay,
75  And grows a river down through verdant pastures.

76  Tosto che l'acqua a correr mette co,
77  non più Benaco, ma Mencio si chiama
78  fino a Govèrnol, dove cade in Po.

76  Soon as the water doth begin to run,
77  No more Benaco is it called, but Mincio,
78  Far as Governo, where it falls in Po.

79  Non molto ha corso, ch'el trova una lama,
80  ne la qual si discende e la 'mpaluda;
81  e suol di state talor esser grama.

79  Not far it runs before it finds a plain
80  In which it spreads itself, and makes it marshy,
81  And oft 'tis wont in summer to be sickly.

82  Quindi passando la vergine cruda
83  vide terra, nel mezzo del pantano,
84  sanza coltura e d'abitanti nuda.

82  Passing that way the virgin pitiless
83  Land in the middle of the fen descried,
84  Untilled and naked of inhabitants;

85  Lì, per fuggire ogne consorzio umano,
86  ristette con suoi servi a far sue arti,
87  e visse, e vi lasciò suo corpo vano.

85  There to escape all human intercourse,
86  She with her servants stayed, her arts to practise
87  And lived, and left her empty body there.

88  Li uomini poi che 'ntorno erano sparti
89  s'accolsero a quel loco, ch'era forte
90  per lo pantan ch'avea da tutte parti.

88  The men, thereafter, who were scattered round,
89  Collected in that place, which was made strong
90  By the lagoon it had on every side;

91  Fer la città sovra quell' ossa morte;
92  e per colei che 'l loco prima elesse,
93  Mantüa l'appellar sanz' altra sorte.

91  They built their city over those dead bones,
92  And, after her who first the place selected,
93  Mantua named it, without other omen.

94  Già fuor le genti sue dentro più spesse,
95  prima che la mattia da Casalodi
96  da Pinamonte inganno ricevesse.

94  Its people once within more crowded were,
95  Ere the stupidity of Casalodi
96  From Pinamonte had received deceit.

97  Però t'assenno che, se tu mai odi
98  originar la mia terra altrimenti,
99  la verità nulla menzogna frodi.”

97  Therefore I caution thee, if e'er thou hearest
98  Originate my city otherwise,
99  No falsehood may the verity defraud."

100  E io: “Maestro, i tuoi ragionamenti
101  mi son sì certi e prendon sì mia fede,
102  che li altri mi sarien carboni spenti.

100  And I: "My Master, thy discourses are
101  To me so certain, and so take my faith,
102  That unto me the rest would be spent coals.

103  Ma dimmi, de la gente che procede,
104  se tu ne vedi alcun degno di nota;
105  ché solo a ciò la mia mente rifiede.”

103  But tell me of the people who are passing,
104  If any one note-worthy thou beholdest,
105  For only unto that my mind reverts."

106  Allor mi disse: “Quel che da la gota
107  porge la barba in su le spalle brune,
108  fu – quando Grecia fu di maschi vòta,

106  Then said he to me: "He who from the cheek
107  Thrusts out his beard upon his swarthy shoulders
108  Was, at the time when Greece was void of males,

109  sì ch'a pena rimaser per le cune –
110  augure, e diede 'l punto con Calcanta
111  in Aulide a tagliar la prima fune.

109  So that there scarce remained one in the cradle,
110  An augur, and with Calchas gave the moment,
111  In Aulis, when to sever the first cable.

112  Euripilo ebbe nome, e così 'l canta
113  l'alta mia tragedìa in alcun loco:
114  ben lo sai tu che la sai tutta quanta.

112  Eryphylus his name was, and so sings
113  My lofty Tragedy in some part or other;
114  That knowest thou well, who knowest the whole of it.

115  Quell' altro che ne' fianchi è così poco,
116  Michele Scotto fu, che veramente
117  de le magiche frode seppe 'l gioco.

115  The next, who is so slender in the flanks,
116  Was Michael Scott, who of a verity
117  Of magical illusions knew the game.

118  Vedi Guido Bonatti; vedi Asdente,
119  ch'avere inteso al cuoio e a lo spago
120  ora vorrebbe, ma tardi si pente.

118  Behold Guido Bonatti, behold Asdente,
119  Who now unto his leather and his thread
120  Would fain have stuck, but he too late repents.

121  Vedi le triste che lasciaron l'ago,
122  la spuola e 'l fuso, e fecersi 'ndivine;
123  fecer malie con erbe e con imago.

121  Behold the wretched ones, who left the needle,
122  The spool and rock, and made them fortune-tellers;
123  They wrought their magic spells with herb and image.

124  Ma vienne omai, ché già tiene 'l confine
125  d'amendue li emisperi e tocca l'onda
126  sotto Sobilia Caino e le spine;

124  But come now, for already holds the confines
125  Of both the hemispheres, and under Seville
126  Touches the ocean-wave, Cain and the thorns,

127  e già iernotte fu la luna tonda:
128  ben ten de' ricordar, ché non ti nocque
129  alcuna volta per la selva fonda.”

127  And yesternight the moon was round already;
128  Thou shouldst remember well it did not harm thee
129  From time to time within the forest deep."

130  Sì mi parlava, e andavamo introcque.

130  Thus spake he to me, and we walked the while.

Canto XXI
What should we say about this canto, which starts with a withholding of information about what has been said, the things that the protagonists speak of which is excluded from the domain of a poem that is otherwise encyclopedic?  Everything in this canto is a lie, told by malicious liars who delight in deception, demons who torment grifters, with a sticky, opaque, burning  pitch, wherein they are submerged like boiling hunks of meat in a toxic stew.  And what is strange, what is funny, peculiar and horrifying is that the punishers, the demons, are by all appearances, delighted with their own viciousness.  The punishers are enthusiastic, and most alacritous in their duties.  Compare them to the rather extended snippet of the Viniziani repairing and refitting ships at the beginning of the canto.  The dock workers disappear into their tasks, their division of labor, as Marx later so angrily and eloquently pointed out, deprives them of any personality, whereas the demon Malebranche are each individualized by their names.  The question that has haunted me in this canto is just this: Is evil motivated not by necessity, but by fun, is the zest of inflicting pain an inherent attribute of the cosmos itself, the universe delighting perhaps more in inflicting suffering, then in extending the joys of life?  The miraculous obscurity referred to at the beginning of this canto (mirabilmente oscura) is a horrifying, and yet strangely compelling peering into a pitchy mystery that I think we really do not want to clarify.  We don't want to know what's down there in the depths of these verses' implications.  But there is clearly something about ourselves, as readers, and in Dante, as a poet, that uses a distraction side-step into laughter, so that we may only obliquely see what is being both hidden and revealed in this canto.  And this distraction, or any distraction is quite risky, as we see when Dante the poet gets lost in the rather prosaic description of the Venetians shipyard workers, and does not notice that a demon carrying a skewered sinner is rushing down on him.

Finally, I would like to introduce a compositional and a cognitive aspect of perception.  And that is the framing of various superimposed tableaus.  The tableaux of the landscape of the this fifth pouch of the eighth circle, the tableaux of the crucifixion of Christ, the tableaux of the organization of the Venetians shipyard workers, and the military organization of the demons, the tableaux of the dogs attacking a beggar (an intruder, as our the protagonists here), and the tableaux of the surrendering soldiers, moving unarmed through the ranks of their armed enemies, the tableaux of the Church and icons of Lucca, and the barraters of Lucca — all these are like semi-transparent sheets one lying atop the other, but aspects of one or the other arising like the marks of a fluid palimpsest rising to the surface to leave its impression on the reader/observer/listener before they sink down again in the boiling fluid of an aroused awareness.  The first demon encountered is a vivid example of this technique which runs not only throughout this canto, but throughout the whole of the Commedia.  This demon can be alternately and eventually simultaneously viewed as a demon carrying a sinner, a butcher carrying a carcass, Christ carrying a lamb, the cross carrying the crucified Christ, the Madonna holding the corpse of her son.  Many commentators have pointed out how irony dominates this canto, irony being a form of indirect speech, which only partially hides what it overtly attempts to conceal — a kind of form of linguistic fraud.  And what could be more ironic than how Dante's style in this canto embodies the very sin he is trying both to hide and expose.
   
1  Così di ponte in ponte, altro parlando
2  che la mia comedìa cantar non cura,
3  venimmo; e tenavamo 'l colmo, quando

1  From bridge to bridge thus, speaking other things
2  Of which my Comedy cares not to sing,
3  We came along, and held the summit, when

4  restammo per veder l'altra fessura
5  di Malebolge e li altri pianti vani;
6  e vidila mirabilmente oscura.

4  We halted to behold another fissure
5  Of Malebolge and other vain laments;
6  And I beheld it marvellously dark.

7  Quale ne l'arzanà de' Viniziani
8  bolle l'inverno la tenace pece
9  a rimpalmare i legni lor non sani,

7  As in the Arsenal of the Venetians
8  Boils in the winter the tenacious pitch
9  To smear their unsound vessels o'er again,

10  ché navicar non ponno – in quella vece
11  chi fa suo legno novo e chi ristoppa
12  le coste a quel che più vïaggi fece;

10  For sail they cannot; and instead thereof
11  One makes his vessel new, and one recaulks
12  The ribs of that which many a voyage has made;

13  chi ribatte da proda e chi da poppa;
14  altri fa remi e altri volge sarte;
15  chi terzeruolo e artimon rintoppa –:

13  One hammers at the prow, one at the stern,
14  This one makes oars, and that one cordage twists,
15  Another mends the mainsail and the mizzen;

16  tal, non per foco ma per divin' arte,
17  bollia là giuso una pegola spessa,
18  che 'nviscava la ripa d'ogne parte.

16  Thus, not by fire, but by the art divine,
17  Was boiling down below there a dense pitch
18  Which upon every side the bank belimed.

19  I' vedea lei, ma non vedëa in essa
20  mai che le bolle che 'l bollor levava,
21  e gonfiar tutta, e riseder compressa.

19  I saw it, but I did not see within it
20  Aught but the bubbles that the boiling raised,
21  And all swell up and resubside compressed.

22  Mentr' io là giù fisamente mirava,
23  lo duca mio, dicendo “Guarda, guarda!”
24  mi trasse a sé del loco dov' io stava.

22  The while below there fixedly I gazed,
23  My Leader, crying out: "Beware, beware!"
24  Drew me unto himself from where I stood.

25  Allor mi volsi come l'uom cui tarda
26  di veder quel che li convien fuggire
27  e cui paura sùbita sgagliarda,

25  Then I turned round, as one who is impatient
26  To see what it behoves him to escape,
27  And whom a sudden terror doth unman,

28  che, per veder, non indugia 'l partire:
29  e vidi dietro a noi un diavol nero
30  correndo su per lo scoglio venire.

28  Who, while he looks, delays not his departure;
29  And I beheld behind us a black devil,
30  Running along upon the crag, approach.

31  Ahi quant' elli era ne l'aspetto fero!
32  e quanto mi parea ne l'atto acerbo,
33  con l'ali aperte e sovra i piè leggero!

31  Ah, how ferocious was he in his aspect!
32  And how he seemed to me in action ruthless,
33  With open wings and light upon his feet!

34  L'omero suo, ch'era aguto e superbo,
35  carcava un peccator con ambo l'anche,
36  e quei tenea de' piè ghermito 'l nerbo.

34  His shoulders, which sharp-pointed were and high,
35  A sinner did encumber with both haunches,
36  And he held clutched the sinews of the feet.

37  Del nostro ponte disse: “O Malebranche,
38  ecco un de li anzïan di Santa Zita!
39  Mettetel sotto, ch'i' torno per anche

37  From off our bridge, he said: "O Malebranche,
38  Behold one of the elders of Saint Zita;
39  Plunge him beneath, for I return for others

40  a quella terra, che n'è ben fornita:
41  ogn' uom v'è barattier, fuor che Bonturo;
42  del no, per li denar, vi si fa ita.”

40  Unto that town, which is well furnished with them.
41  All there are barrators, except Bonturo;
42  No into Yes for money there is changed."

43  Là giù 'l buttò, e per lo scoglio duro
44  si volse; e mai non fu mastino sciolto
45  con tanta fretta a seguitar lo furo.

43  He hurled him down, and over the hard crag
44  Turned round, and never was a mastiff loosened
45  In so much hurry to pursue a thief.

46  Quel s'attuffò, e tornò sù convolto;
47  ma i demon che del ponte avean coperchio,
48  gridar: “Qui non ha loco il Santo Volto!

46  The other sank, and rose again face downward;
47  But the demons, under cover of the bridge,
48  Cried: "Here the Santo Volto has no place!

49  qui si nuota altrimenti che nel Serchio!
50  Però, se tu non vuo' di nostri graffi,
51  non far sopra la pegola soverchio.”

49  Here swims one otherwise than in the Serchio;
50  Therefore, if for our gaffs thou wishest not,
51  Do not uplift thyself above the pitch."

52  Poi l'addentar con più di cento raffi,
53  disser: “Coverto convien che qui balli,
54  sì che, se puoi, nascosamente accaffi.”

52  They seized him then with more than a hundred rakes;
53  They said: "It here behoves thee to dance covered,
54  That, if thou canst, thou secretly mayest pilfer."

55  Non altrimenti i cuoci a' lor vassalli
56  fanno attuffare in mezzo la caldaia
57  la carne con li uncin, perché non galli.

55  Not otherwise the cooks their scullions make
56  Immerse into the middle of the caldron
57  The meat with hooks, so that it may not float.

58  Lo buon maestro “Acciò che non si paia
59  che tu ci sia,” mi disse, “giù t'acquatta
60  dopo uno scheggio, ch'alcun schermo t'aia;

58  Said the good Master to me: "That it be not
59  Apparent thou art here, crouch thyself down
60  Behind a jag, that thou mayest have some screen;

61  e per nulla offension che mi sia fatta,
62  non temer tu, ch'i' ho le cose conte,
63  per ch'altra volta fui a tal baratta.”

61  And for no outrage that is done to me
62  Be thou afraid, because these things I know,
63  For once before was I in such a scuffle."

64  Poscia passò di là dal co del ponte;
65  e com' el giunse in su la ripa sesta,
66  mestier li fu d'aver sicura fronte.

64  Then he passed on beyond the bridge's head,
65  And as upon the sixth bank he arrived,
66  Need was for him to have a steadfast front.

67  Con quel furore e con quella tempesta
68  ch'escono i cani a dosso al poverello
69  che di sùbito chiede ove s'arresta,

67  With the same fury, and the same uproar,
68  As dogs leap out upon a mendicant,
69  Who on a sudden begs, where'er he stops,

70  usciron quei di sotto al ponticello,
71  e volser contra lui tutt' i runcigli;
72  ma el gridò: “Nessun di voi sia fello!

70  They issued from beneath the little bridge,
71  And turned against him all their grappling-irons;
72  But he cried out: "Be none of you malignant!

73  Innanzi che l'uncin vostro mi pigli,
74  traggasi avante l'un di voi che m'oda,
75  e poi d'arruncigliarmi si consigli.”

73  Before those hooks of yours lay hold of me,
74  Let one of you step forward, who may hear me,
75  And then take counsel as to grappling me."

76  Tutti gridaron: “Vada Malacoda!”;
77  per ch'un si mosse – e li altri stetter fermi –
78  e venne a lui dicendo: “Che li approda?”

76  They all cried out: "Let Malacoda go;"
77  Whereat one started, and the rest stood still,
78  And he came to him, saying: "What avails it?"

79  “Credi tu, Malacoda, qui vedermi
80  esser venuto,” disse 'l mio maestro,
81  “sicuro già da tutti vostri schermi,

79  "Thinkest thou, Malacoda, to behold me
80  Advanced into this place," my Master said,
81  "Safe hitherto from all your skill of fence,

82  sanza voler divino e fato destro?
83  Lascian' andar, ché nel cielo è voluto
84  ch'i' mostri altrui questo cammin silvestro.”

82  Without the will divine, and fate auspicious?
83  Let me go on, for it in Heaven is willed
84  That I another show this savage road."

85  Allor li fu l'orgoglio sì caduto,
86  ch'e' si lasciò cascar l'uncino a' piedi,
87  e disse a li altri: “Omai non sia feruto.”

85  Then was his arrogance so humbled in him,
86  That he let fall his grapnel at his feet,
87  And to the others said: "Now strike him not."

88  E 'l duca mio a me: “O tu che siedi
89  tra li scheggion del ponte quatto quatto,
90  sicuramente omai a me ti riedi.”

88  And unto me my Guide: "O thou, who sittest
89  Among the splinters of the bridge crouched down,
90  Securely now return to me again."

91  Per ch'io mi mossi e a lui venni ratto;
92  e i diavoli si fecer tutti avanti,
93  sì ch'io temetti ch'ei tenesser patto;

91  Wherefore I started and came swiftly to him;
92  And all the devils forward thrust themselves,
93  So that I feared they would not keep their compact.

94  così vid' ïo già temer li fanti
95  ch'uscivan patteggiati di Caprona,
96  veggendo sé tra nemici cotanti.

94  And thus beheld I once afraid the soldiers
95  Who issued under safeguard from Caprona,
96  Seeing themselves among so many foes.


97  I' m'accostai con tutta la persona
