98  lungo 'l mio duca, e non torceva li occhi
99  da la sembianza lor ch'era non buona.

97  Close did I press myself with all my person
98  Beside my Leader, and turned not mine eyes
99  From off their countenance, which was not good.

100  Ei chinavan li raffi e “Vuo' che 'l tocchi,”
101  diceva l'un con l'altro, “in sul groppone?”
102  E rispondien: “Si, fa che gliel' accocchi.”

100  They lowered their rakes, and "Wilt thou have me hit him,"
101  They said to one another, "on the rump?"
102  And answered: "Yes; see that thou nick him with it."

103  Ma quel demonio che tenea sermone
104  col duca mio, si volse tutto presto
105  e disse: “Posa, posa, Scarmiglione!”

103  But the same demon who was holding parley
104  With my Conductor turned him very quickly,
105  And said: "Be quiet, be quiet, Scarmiglione;"

106  Poi disse a noi: “Più oltre andar per questo
107  iscoglio non si può, però che giace
108  tutto spezzato al fondo l'arco sesto.

106  Then said to us: "You can no farther go
107  Forward upon this crag, because is lying
108  All shattered, at the bottom, the sixth arch.

109  E se l'andare avante pur vi piace,
110  andatevene su per questa grotta;
111  presso è un altro scoglio che via face.

109  And if it still doth please you to go onward,
110  Pursue your way along upon this rock;
111  Near is another crag that yields a path.

112  Ier, più oltre cinqu' ore che quest' otta,
113  mille dugento con sessanta sei
114  anni compié che qui la via fu rottas

112  Yesterday, five hours later than this hour,
113  One thousand and two hundred sixty-six
114  Years were complete, that here the way was broken.

115  Io mando verso là di questi miei
116  a riguardar s'alcun se ne sciorina;
117  gite con lor, che non saranno rei.”

115  I send in that direction some of mine
116  To see if any one doth air himself;
117  Go ye with them; for they will not be vicious.

118  “Tra'ti avante, Alichino, e Calcabrina,”
119  cominciò elli a dire, “e tu, Cagnazzo;
120  e Barbariccia guidi la decina.

118  Step forward, Alichino and Calcabrina,"
119  Began he to cry out, "and thou, Cagnazzo;
120  And Barbariccia, do thou guide the ten.

121  Libicocco vegn' oltre e Draghignazzo,
122  Cirïatto sannuto e Graffiacane
123  e Farfarello e Rubicante pazzo.

121  Come forward, Libicocco and Draghignazzo,
122  And tusked Ciriatto and Graffiacane,
123  And Farfarello and mad Rubicante;

124  Cercate 'ntorno le boglienti pane;
125  ostor sian salvi infino a l'altro scheggio
126  che tutto intero va sovra le tane.”

124  Search ye all round about the boiling pitch;
125  Let these be safe as far as the next crag,
126  That all unbroken passes o'er the dens."

127  “Omè, maestro, che è quel ch'i' veggio?”
128  diss' io, “deh, sanza scorta andianci soli,
129  se tu sa' ir; ch'i' per me non la cheggio.

127  "O me! what is it, Master, that I see?
128  Pray let us go," I said, "without an escort,
129  If thou knowest how, since for myself I ask none.

130  Se tu se' sì accorto come suoli,
131  non vedi tu ch'e' digrignan li denti
132  e con le ciglia ne minaccian duoli?”

130  If thou art as observant as thy wont is,
131  Dost thou not see that they do gnash their teeth,
132  And with their brows are threatening woe to us?"

133  Ed elli a me: “Non vo' che tu paventi;
134  lasciali digrignar pur a lor senno,
135  ch'e' fanno ciò per li lessi dolenti.”

133  And he to me: "I will not have thee fear;
134  Let them gnash on, according to their fancy,
135  Because they do it for those boiling wretches."

136  Per l'argine sinistro volta dienno;
137  ma prima avea ciascun la lingua stretta
138  coi denti, verso lor duca, per cenno;

136  Along the left-hand dike they wheeled about;
137  But first had each one thrust his tongue between
138  His teeth towards their leader for a signal;

139  ed elli avea del cul fatto trombetta.

139  And he had made a trumpet of his rump.

Canto XXII
Is it possible to form a community whose connective tissue is deceit, each member motivated by a shared desire to do his fellow denizens harm?  The first simile of an army responding with a kind of coordinated automaticity, each soldier responding in a preconditioned way to the trigger of a signal, a fart, a trumpet, a drum, a pulse, a word, the whole arc of their association moving towards destruction: muster, attack, escape.  Here, in the Inferno, there is always as much madness in Dante's procedures as there is method, and the Demons in their military organization, are bound together, it seems, by a desire to do harm, if not to the sinners, then to one another.  Dante is showing us how situations with such an underlying motivation, are always on the verge of disintegration, and that to be armed with malevolence is be the torturer of oneself.  Caimpolo, the grifter, has fallen below even the baseness of the demons, and he tells of the agreement of his fellow sufferers, to signal (again with the signally, the trigger event that leads to pain), when the demons are approaching, so that they may escape their barbs, and escape back into lesser pain.  But Ciampolo intends to use this signal to escape in a deceitful matter, namely, as a way to summon forth new victims for his persecutors, and thereby escape punishment himself.   As dolphins, or as frogs, the sinners have attempted to adapt themselves to the element of their own torment, and throughout this canto, there is yet another kind of submersion: namely a submersion in the signal of a name.  Dante makes a point of naming, and the names border on nonsense, that yet give a sort of bitter aftertaste, an exterior label, which hides a poison.  The touch at the end, as Dante and Virgil escape this collective madness by rather anonymously sneaking away (Ciampolo does not ask who Dante and Virgil are, does not ask, as previous sinners have done, who they are, or what their names might be) is quietly masterful.  Far from being assertive, or seeking "fame", they make themselves unobtrusive, and by so doing, in this instance, escape infamy.     

1  Io vidi già cavalier muover campo,
2  e cominciare stormo e far lor mostra,
3  e talvolta partir per loro scampo;

I have erewhile seen horsemen moving camp,
Begin the storming, and their muster make,
And sometimes starting off for their escape;

4  corridor vidi per la terra vostra,
5  o Aretini, e vidi gir gualdane,
6  fedir torneamenti e correr giostra;

4  Vaunt-couriers have I seen upon your land,
5  O Aretines, and foragers go forth,
6  Tournaments stricken, and the joustings run,



7  quando con trombe, e quando con campane,
8  con tamburi e con cenni di castella,
9  e con cose nostrali e con istrane;

7  Sometimes with trumpets and sometimes with bells,
8  With kettle-drums, and signals of the castles,
9  And with our own, and with outlandish things,

10  né già con sì diversa cennamella
11  cavalier vidi muover né pedoni,
12  né nave a segno di terra o di stella.

10  But never yet with bagpipe so uncouth
11  Did I see horsemen move, nor infantry,
12  Nor ship by any sign of land or star.

13  Noi andavam con li diece demoni.
14  Ahi fiera compagnia! ma ne la chiesa
15  coi santi, e in taverna coi ghiottoni.

13  We went upon our way with the ten demons;
14  Ah, savage company! but in the church
15  With saints, and in the tavern with the gluttons!

16  Pur a la pegola era la mia 'ntesa,
17  per veder de la bolgia ogne contegno
18  e de la gente ch'entro v'era incesa.

16  Ever upon the pitch was my intent,
17  To see the whole condition of that Bolgia,
18  And of the people who therein were burned.

19  Come i dalfini, quando fanno segno
20  a' marinar con l'arco de la schiena
21  che s'argomentin di campar lor legno,

19  Even as the dolphins, when they make a sign
20  To mariners by arching of the back,
21  That they should counsel take to save their vessel,

22  talor così, ad alleggiar la pena,
23  mostrav' alcun de' peccatori 'l dosso
24  e nascondea in men che non balena.

22  Thus sometimes, to alleviate his pain,
23  One of the sinners would display his back,
24  And in less time conceal it than it lightens.

25  E come a l'orlo de l'acqua d'un fosso
26  stanno i ranocchi pur col muso fuori,
27  sì che celano i piedi e l'altro grosso,

25  As on the brink of water in a ditch
26  The frogs stand only with their muzzles out,
27  So that they hide their feet and other bulk,

28  sì stavan d'ogne parte i peccatori;
29  ma come s'appressava Barbariccia,
30  così si ritraén sotto i bollori.

28  So upon every side the sinners stood;
29  But ever as Barbariccia near them came,
30  Thus underneath the boiling they withdrew.

31  I' vidi, e anco il cor me n'accapriccia,
32  uno aspettar così, com' elli 'ncontra
33  ch'una rana rimane e l'altra spiccia;

31  I saw, and still my heart doth shudder at it,
32  One waiting thus, even as it comes to pass
33  One frog remains, and down another dives;

34  e Graffiacan, che li era più di contra,
35  li arruncigliò le 'mpegolate chiome
36  e trassel sù, che mi parve una lontra.

34  And Graffiacan, who most confronted him,
35  Grappled him by his tresses smeared with pitch,
36  And drew him up, so that he seemed an otter.

37  I' sapea già di tutti quanti 'l nome,
38  sì li notai quando fuorono eletti,
39  e poi ch'e' si chiamaro, attesi come.

37  I knew, before, the names of all of them,
38  So had I noted them when they were chosen,
39  And when they called each other, listened how.

40  “O Rubicante, fa che tu li metti
41  li unghioni a dosso, sì che tu lo scuoi!”
42  gridavan tutti insieme i maladetti.

40  "O Rubicante, see that thou do lay
41  Thy claws upon him, so that thou mayst flay him,"
42  Cried all together the accursed ones.

43  E io: “Maestro mio, fa, se tu puoi,
44  che tu sappi chi è lo sciagurato
45  venuto a man de li avversari suoi.”

43  And I: "My Master, see to it, if thou canst,
44  That thou mayst know who is the luckless wight,
45  Thus come into his adversaries' hands."

46  Lo duca mio li s'accostò allato;
47  domandollo ond' ei fosse, e quei rispuose:
48  “I' fui del regno di Navarra nato.

46  Near to the side of him my Leader drew,
47  Asked of him whence he was; and he replied:
48  "I in the kingdom of Navarre was born;

49  Mia madre a servo d'un segnor mi puose,
50  che m'avea generato d'un ribaldo,
51  distruggitor di sé e di sue cose.

49  My mother placed me servant to a lord,
50  For she had borne me to a ribald knave,
51  Destroyer of himself and of his things.

52  Poi fui famiglia del buon re Tebaldo;
53  quivi mi misi a far baratteria,
54  di ch'io rendo ragione in questo caldo.”

52  Then I domestic was of good King Thibault;
53  I set me there to practise barratry,
54  For which I pay the reckoning in this heat."

55  E Cirïatto, a cui di bocca uscia
56  d'ogne parte una sanna come a porco,
57  li fé sentir come l'una sdruscia.

55  And Ciriatto, from whose mouth projected,
56  On either side, a tusk, as in a boar,
57  Caused him to feel how one of them could rip.

58  Tra male gatte era venuto 'l sorco;
59  ma Barbariccia il chiuse con le braccia
60  e disse: “State in là, mentr' io lo 'nforco.”

58  Among malicious cats the mouse had come;
59  But Barbariccia clasped him in his arms,
60  And said: "Stand ye aside, while I enfork him."

61  E al maestro mio volse la faccia;
62  “Domanda,” disse, “ancor, se più disii
63  saper da lui, prima ch'altri 'l disfaccia.”

61  And to my Master he turned round his head;
62  "Ask him again," he said, "if more thou wish
63  To know from him, before some one destroy him."

64  Lo duca dunque: “Or dì: de li altri rii
65  conosci tu alcun che sia latino
66  sotto la pece?” E quelli: “I' mi partii,

64  The Guide: "Now tell then of the other culprits;
65  Knowest thou any one who is a Latian,
66  Under the pitch?" And he: "I separated

67  poco è, da un che fu di là vicino.
68  Così foss' io ancor con lui coperto,
69  ch'i' non temerei unghia né uncino!”

67  Lately from one who was a neighbour to it;
68  Would that I still were covered up with him,
69  For I should fear not either claw nor hook!"

70  E Libicocco “Troppo avem sofferto,”
71  disse; e preseli 'l braccio col runciglio,
72  sì che, stracciando, ne portò un lacerto.

70  And Libicocco: "We have borne too much;"
71  And with his grapnel seized him by the arm,
72  So that, by rending, he tore off a tendon.


73  Draghignazzo anco i volle dar di piglio
74  giuso a le gambe; onde 'l decurio loro
75  si volse intorno intorno con mal piglio.

73  Eke Draghignazzo wished to pounce upon him
74  Down at the legs; whence their Decurion
75  Turned round and round about with evil look.

76  Quand' elli un poco rappaciati fuoro,
77  a lui, ch'ancor mirava sua ferita,
78  domandò 'l duca mio sanza dimoro:

76  When they again somewhat were pacified,
77  Of him, who still was looking at his wound,
78  Demanded my Conductor without stay:

79  “Chi fu colui da cui mala partita
80  di' che facesti per venire a proda?”
81  Ed ei rispuose: “Fu frate Gomita,

79  "Who was that one, from whom a luckless parting
80  Thou sayest thou hast made, to come ashore?"
81  And he replied: "It was the Friar Gomita,

82  quel di Gallura, vasel d'ogne froda,
83  ch'ebbe i nemici di suo donno in mano,
84  e fé sì lor, che ciascun se ne loda.

82  He of Gallura, vessel of all fraud,
83  Who had the enemies of his Lord in hand,
84  And dealt so with them each exults thereat;

85  Danar si tolse e lasciolli di piano,
86  sì com' e' dice; e ne li altri offici anche
87  barattier fu non picciol, ma sovrano.

85  Money he took, and let them smoothly off,
86  As he says; and in other offices
87  A barrator was he, not mean but sovereign.

88  Usa con esso donno Michel Zanche
89  di Logodoro; e a dir di Sardigna
90  le lingue lor non si sentono stanche.

88  Foregathers with him one Don Michael Zanche
89  Of Logodoro; and of Sardinia
90  To gossip never do their tongues feel tired.

91  Omè, vedete l'altro che digrigna;
92  i' direi anche, ma i' temo ch'ello
93  non s'apparecchi a grattarmi la tigna.”

91  O me! see that one, how he grinds his teeth;
92  Still farther would I speak, but am afraid
93  Lest he to scratch my itch be making ready."

94  E 'l gran proposto, vòlto a Farfarello
95  che stralunava li occhi per fedire,
96  disse: “Fatti 'n costà, malvagio uccello!”

94  And the grand Provost, turned to Farfarello,
95  Who rolled his eyes about as if to strike,
96  Said: "Stand aside there, thou malicious bird."

97  “Se voi volete vedere o udire,”
98  ricominciò lo spaürato appresso,
99  “Toschi o Lombardi, io ne farò venire;

97  "If you desire either to see or hear,"
98  The terror-stricken recommenced thereon,
99  "Tuscans or Lombards, I will make them come.

100  ma stieno i Malebranche un poco in cesso,
101  sì ch'ei non teman de le lor vendette;
102  e io, seggendo in questo loco stesso

100  But let the Malebranche cease a little,
101  So that these may not their revenges fear,
102  And I, down sitting in this very place,

103  per un ch'io son, ne farò venir sette
104  quand' io suffolerò, com' è nostro uso
105  di fare allor che fori alcun si mette.”

103  For one that I am will make seven come,
104  When I shall whistle, as our custom is
105  To do whenever one of us comes out."

106  Cagnazzo a cotal motto levò 'l muso,
107  crollando 'l capo, e disse: “Odi malizia
108  ch'elli ha pensata per gittarsi giuso!”

106  Cagnazzo at these words his muzzle lifted,
107  Shaking his head, and said: "Just hear the trick
108  Which he has thought of, down to throw himself!"

109  Ond' ei, ch'avea lacciuoli a gran divizia,
110  rispuose: “Malizioso son io troppo,
111  quand' io procuro a' mia maggior trestizia.”

109  Whence he, who snares in great abundance had,
110  Responded: "I by far too cunning am,
111  When I procure for mine a greater sadness."

112  Alichin non si tenne e, di rintoppo
113  a li altri, disse a lui: “Se tu ti cali,
114  io non ti verrò dietro di gualoppo,

112  Alichin held not in, but running counter
113  Unto the rest, said to him: "If thou dive,
114  I will not follow thee upon the gallop,

115  ma batterò sovra la pece l'ali.
116  Lascisi 'l collo, e sia la ripa scudo,
117  a veder se tu sol più di noi vali.”

115  But I will beat my wings above the pitch;
116  The height be left, and be the bank a shield
117  To see if thou alone dost countervail us."

118  O tu che leggi, udirai nuovo ludo:
119  ciascun da l'altra costa li occhi volse,
120  quel prima, ch'a ciò fare era più crudo.

118  O thou who readest, thou shalt hear new sport!
119  Each to the other side his eyes averted;
120  He first, who most reluctant was to do it.

121  Lo Navarrese ben suo tempo colse;
122  fermò le piante a terra, e in un punto
123  saltò e dal proposto lor si sciolse.

121  The Navarrese selected well his time;
122  Planted his feet on land, and in a moment
123  Leaped, and released himself from their design.

124  Di che ciascun di colpa fu compunto,
125  ma quei più che cagion fu del difetto;
126  però si mosse e gridò: “Tu se' giunto!”

124  Whereat each one was suddenly stung with shame,
125  But he most who was cause of the defeat;
126  Therefore he moved, and cried: "Thou art o'ertaken."

127  Ma poco i valse: ché l'ali al sospetto
128  non potero avanzar; quelli andò sotto,
129  e quei drizzò volando suso il petto:

127  But little it availed, for wings could not
128  Outstrip the fear; the other one went under,
129  And, flying, upward he his breast directed;

130  non altrimenti l'anitra di botto,
131  quando 'l falcon s'appressa, giù s'attuffa,
132  ed ei ritorna sù crucciato e rotto.

130  Not otherwise the duck upon a sudden
131  Dives under, when the falcon is approaching,
132  And upward he returneth cross and weary.

133  Irato Calcabrina de la buffa,
134  volando dietro li tenne, invaghito
135  che quei campasse per aver la zuffa;

133  Infuriate at the mockery, Calcabrina
134  Flying behind him followed close, desirous
135  The other should escape, to have a quarrel.

136  e come 'l barattier fu disparito,
137  così volse li artigli al suo compagno,
138  e fu con lui sopra 'l fosso ghermito.

136  And when the barrator had disappeared,
137  He turned his talons upon his companion,
138  And grappled with him right above the moat.

139  Ma l'altro fu bene sparvier grifagno
140  ad artigliar ben lui, e amendue
141  cadder nel mezzo del bogliente stagno.

139  But sooth the other was a doughty sparhawk
140  To clapperclaw him well; and both of them
141  Fell in the middle of the boiling pond.

142  Lo caldo sghermitor sùbito fue;
143  ma però di levarsi era neente,
144  sì avieno inviscate l'ali sue.

142  A sudden intercessor was the heat;
143  But ne'ertheless of rising there was naught,
144  To such degree they had their wings belimed.

145  Barbariccia, con li altri suoi dolente,
146  quattro ne fé volar da l'altra costa
147  con tutt' i raffi, e assai prestamente

145  Lamenting with the others, Barbariccia
146  Made four of them fly to the other side
147  With all their gaffs, and very speedily

148  di qua, di là discesero a la posta;
149  porser li uncini verso li 'mpaniati,
150  ch'eran già cotti dentro da la crosta.

148  This side and that they to their posts descended;
149  They stretched their hooks towards the pitch-ensnared,
150  Who were already baked within the crust,

151  E noi lasciammo lor così 'mpacciati.

151  And in this manner busied did we leave them.

Canto XXIII
If there were tempo and dynamic markings for the first 57 lines of Canto XXIII they might be pianissimo, lento, then an introverted agitato, then a prestissimo forte, and finally a return to pianissimo.  Of course, what is moving, is not so much sound, but the metasound of the imagination (and that word is much in evidence at the beginning of this canto), a kind of movement of mind or spirit alone.  Of note here is that so much of the canto is devoted to the escape from the squadron of demons in the 5th pouch of the 8th circle to the 6th.  The beginning also emphasizes the mental, emotional, and physical rapport between the protagonists: they are literally as close as a mother and her fetus, and this first "escape" section has a wonderful pairing of metaphors, first of flame, as a picture is painted of a mother rescuing her child from flames, and then to water that douses those metaphoric flames as the movement of the poets is described as the swift, slickness of water sluicing off mill wheels — Masterful.

There is no denying that the whole of the Commedia offers a dazzling spectacle for the visual imagination, and this canto, of all the canto's of the Inferno, is the most dazzling while at the same time the most grotesque, because the glitter that commands our attention is only the thinnest veneer hiding an abject misery.  Sinners, moving so slowly in pairs, they scares seem to me moving at all, but rather form an rather Egyptian frieze wherein gold mantled monks shuffle by, their faces bejeweled with the wet and crust of tears — one imagines a red glint of Hell flashing and dancing along these golden, sparkling surfaces and one imagines the inner shock to an outward beauty so thoroughly deceitful.  The foil of the previous canto with its black pitch, red flames, and furious motion is the setting for this amulet of hypocrisy, and one could hardly imagine a better one.  One imagines too the black devil Malebranche mashing up suddenly against this utterly alien world of this pouch of malebolge like so many mosquitoes mashing up against a glass window pain, the dream has changed, and the nightmare entities whose home is in one area of the unconscious cannot manifest themselves in another area.  The worlds of the hypocrites and the grifters could not be more different — yet it must be remembered, that both are in Hell, and as such their foundation is torment for tormentors: all the sinners suffer the fates which they have inflicted on others.

It's about sequences and broken sequences, and about pairing or doubling.  Both sequencing and pairing  will foreground both the differences and similarities, which are much harder to notice when they remain in the background.   The pairing and doubling include —  Canto XXII and Canto XXIII, Dante (the protagonist) and Virgil, the lying of the Malebranche and the sarcasm of the hypocrites, Catalano and Loderingo, outer and inner, substance of thought and the mirror of that thought, and so forth.  Sequencing and chains include — the mouse tied to the frog, and the kite snaring both mouse and frog (a broken chain, as are the bridges that the Malebranche claimed were intact), and the line of hypocrites walking in an unbreakable chain or sequence, or as the text says in line 8 and 9: se ben s'accoppia/principio e fine con la mente fissa (if well we couple end and beginning with a steadfast mind.), and also sequences of thoughts (line 10: E come l'un pensier de l'altro scoppia etc.)  ... But when we sort through all that we come back to sequences of historical events leading up to the crucifixion of Christ and the sequences of poetical events — the journey of Dante and Virgil through the afterworld, and in particular these last few cantos wherein Virgil has shown again and again his shortcomings.

It must be remembered that while there is only one Virgil, there are always two Dantes: Dante the protagonist of the poem, and Dante the poet who has already had the transcendent experience which the protagonist Dante is undergoing.  As first time readers we are in the position of Dante, the protagonist, the aspirant.  We, like the aspirant, are dependent on Virgil, but we have seen him fail at the gates of Dis, we have seen him gullibly accept Malacoda's lie, and we have seen him peeved by Catalano's mockery, and finally we have seen him astonished at Ciaphas' punishment.  All this is subtly pointed out by Dante the poet in the transcendent offing, while Dante's the protagonist is more dependent than ever — he is as close to Virgil as an infant to his mother, Virgil can read his mind, and Dante follows literally in his footsteps ... insight, a move away from this dependence on Virgil's experienced guidance and pagan reasoning, is growing — and this insight is growing because that which is hidden beneath all of Virgil's care and skill is the realization by the aspirant that what is going to drive teacher and chela apart is this difference in worldviews between a wise pagan and an inspired Christian.  In Hell, Virgil is a dominating figure, but he is still a pagan.  Does his astonishment at Ciaphas' punishment arise because Ciaphas belief that it is just (in the sense that it causes, in a Utilitarian Jeremy Bentham sort of way, less overall suffering) that one man should be martyred to save a whole people seems quite reasonable, even correct to the pagan Virgil, while to the Christian Dante this sin is the ultimate sin, i.e., to presume that one can substitute one's one reasonable judgement for the utterly more subtle, complicated, and timeless mysteries of God, to presume that there is a fundamental difference that comes from the sequence of numbers or events and the sufferings of one innocent person (the first and only innocent person in the history of the world).  For Dante the poet, Christ is humanity, but not only humanity, he is Creation and that love which continuously brings creation out of nothing.  At the crucifixion Christ was nothing on the outside (the opposite of the gold/lead clad hypocrites here), naked and suffering, but on the inside He was everything.  To be a true follower of Christ, one accepts everything as one's charge, and everything always boils down to this single act of incarnation, to be an immortal imprisoned in a mortal body, for the sake of all mortal bodies, that is the Christian position.  And Virgil, a believer in the sequence of years in history, feels sorry for himself because he was born too late — but what is too late?  and too late according to whom?  What is growing here is the gap between a pagan belief and Christian belief, a gap which cannot be closed accept by the miracle of grace — and the courage to accept that irrational miracle.       
       
1  Taciti, soli, sanza compagnia
2  n'andavam l'un dinanzi e l'altro dopo,
3  come frati minor vanno per via.

1  Silent, alone, and without company
2  We went, the one in front, the other after,
3  As go the Minor Friars along their way.

4  Vòlt' era in su la favola d'Isopo
5  lo mio pensier per la presente rissa,
6  dov' el parlò de la rana e del topo;

4  Upon the fable of Aesop was directed
5  My thought, by reason of the present quarrel,
6  Where he has spoken of the frog and mouse;

7  ché più non si pareggia “mo” e “issa”
8  che l'un con l'altro fa, se ben s'accoppia
9  principio e fine con la mente fissa.

7  For 'mo' and 'issa' are not more alike
8  Than this one is to that, if well we couple
9  End and beginning with a steadfast mind.

10  E come l'un pensier de l'altro scoppia,
11  così nacque di quello un altro poi,
12  che la prima paura mi fé doppia.

10  And even as one thought from another springs,
11  So afterward from that was born another,
12  Which the first fear within me double made.

13  Io pensava così: “Questi per noi
14  sono scherniti con danno e con beffa
15  sì fatta, ch' assai credo che lor nòi.

13  Thus did I ponder: "These on our account
14  Are laughed to scorn, with injury and scoff
15  So great, that much I think it must annoy them.

16  Se l'ira sovra 'l mal voler s'aggueffa,
17  ei ne verranno dietro più crudeli
18  che 'l cane a quella lievre ch'elli acceffa.”

16  If anger be engrafted on ill-will,
17  They will come after us more merciless
18  Than dog upon the leveret which he seizes,"

19  Già mi sentia tutti arricciar li peli
20  de la paura e stava in dietro intento,
21  quand' io dissi: “Maestro, se non celi

19  I felt my hair stand all on end already
20  With terror, and stood backwardly intent,
21  When said I: "Master, if thou hidest not

22  te e me tostamente, i' ho pavento
23  d'i Malebranche. Noi li avem già dietro;
24  io li 'magino sì, che già li sento.”

22  Thyself and me forthwith, of Malebranche
23  I am in dread; we have them now behind us;
24  I so imagine them, I already feel them."

25  E quei: “S'i' fossi di piombato vetro,
26  l'imagine di fuor tua non trarrei
27  più tosto a me, che quella dentro 'mpetro.

25  And he: "If I were made of leaded glass,
26  Thine outward image I should not attract
27  Sooner to me than I imprint the inner.

28  Pur mo venieno i tuo' pensier tra ' miei,
29  con simile atto e con simile faccia,
30  sì che d'intrambi un sol consiglio fei.

28  Just now thy thoughts came in among my own,
29  With similar attitude and similar face,
30  So that of both one counsel sole I made.

31  S'elli è che sì la destra costa giaccia,
32  che noi possiam ne l'altra bolgia scendere,
33  noi fuggirem l'imaginata caccia.”

31  If peradventure the right bank so slope
32  That we to the next Bolgia can descend,
33  We shall escape from the imagined chase."

34  Già non compié di tal consiglio rendere,
35  ch'io li vidi venir con l'ali tese
36  non molto lungi, per volerne prendere.

34  Not yet he finished rendering such opinion,
35  When I beheld them come with outstretched wings,
36  Not far remote, with will to seize upon us.

37  Lo duca mio di sùbito mi prese,
38  come la madre ch'al romore è desta
39  e vede presso a sé le fiamme accese,

37  My Leader on a sudden seized me up,
38  Even as a mother who by noise is wakened,
39  And close beside her sees the enkindled flames,

40  che prende il figlio e fugge e non s'arresta,
41  avendo più di lui che di sé cura,
42  tanto che solo una camiscia vesta;

40  Who takes her son, and flies, and does not stop,
41  Having more care of him than of herself,
42  So that she clothes her only with a shift;

43  e giù dal collo de la ripa dura
44  supin si diede a la pendente roccia,
45  che l'un de' lati a l'altra bolgia tura.

43  And downward from the top of the hard bank
44  Supine he gave him to the pendent rock,
45  That one side of the other Bolgia walls.

46  Non corse mai sì tosto acqua per doccia
47  a volger ruota di molin terragno,
48  quand' ella più verso le pale approccia,

46  Ne'er ran so swiftly water through a sluice
47  To turn the wheel of any land-built mill,
48  When nearest to the paddles it approaches,

49  come 'l maestro mio per quel vivagno,
50  portandosene me sovra 'l suo petto,
51  come suo figlio, non come compagno.

49  As did my Master down along that border,
50  Bearing me with him on his breast away,
51  As his own son, and not as a companion.

52  A pena fuoro i piè suoi giunti al letto
53  del fondo giù, ch'e' furon in sul colle
54  sovresso noi; ma non lì era sospetto:

52  Hardly the bed of the ravine below
53  His feet had reached, ere they had reached the hill
54  Right over us; but he was not afraid;

55  ché l'alta provedenza che lor volle
56  porre ministri de la fossa quinta,
57  poder di partirs' indi a tutti tolle.

55  For the high Providence, which had ordained
56  To place them ministers of the fifth moat,
57  The power of thence departing took from all.

58  Là giù trovammo una gente dipinta
59  che giva intorno assai con lenti passi,
60  piangendo e nel sembiante stanca e vinta.

58  A painted people there below we found,
59  Who went about with footsteps very slow,
60  Weeping and in their semblance tired and vanquished.

61  Elli avean cappe con cappucci bassi
62  dinanzi a li occhi, fatte de la taglia
63  che in Clugnì per li monaci fassi.

61  They had on mantles with the hoods low down
62  Before their eyes, and fashioned of the cut
63  That in Cologne they for the monks are made.

64  Di fuor dorate son, sì ch'elli abbaglia;
65  ma dentro tutte piombo, e gravi tanto,
66 che Federigo le mettea di paglia.

64  Without, they gilded are so that it dazzles;
65  But inwardly all leaden and so heavy
66  That Frederick used to put them on of straw.

67  Oh in etterno faticoso manto!
68  Noi ci volgemmo ancor pur a man manca
69  con loro insieme, intenti al tristo pianto;

67  O everlastingly fatiguing mantle!
68  Again we turned us, still to the left hand
69  Along with them, intent on their sad plaint;



70  ma per lo peso quella gente stanca
71  venìa sì pian, che noi eravam nuovi
72  di compagnia ad ogne mover d'anca.

70  But owing to the weight, that weary folk
71  Came on so tardily, that we were new
72  In company at each motion of the haunch.

73  Per ch'io al duca mio: “Fa che tu trovi
74  alcun ch'al fatto o al nome si conosca,
75  e li occhi, sì andando, intorno movi.”

73  Whence I unto my Leader: "See thou find
74  Some one who may by deed or name be known,
75  And thus in going move thine eye about."

76  E un che 'ntese la parola tosca,
77  di retro a noi gridò: “Tenete i piedi,
78  voi che correte sì per l'aura fosca!

76  And one, who understood the Tuscan speech,
77  Cried to us from behind: "Stay ye your feet,
78  Ye, who so run athwart the dusky air!

79  Forse ch'avrai da me quel che tu chiedi.”
80  Onde 'l duca si volse e disse: “Aspetta
81  e poi secondo il suo passo procedi.”

79  Perhaps thou'lt have from me what thou demandest."
80  Whereat the Leader turned him, and said: "Wait,
81  And then according to his pace proceed."

82  Ristetti, e vidi due mostrar gran fretta
83  de l'animo, col viso, d'esser meco;
84  ma tardavali 'l carco e la via stretta.

82  I stopped, and two beheld I show great haste
83  Of spirit, in their faces, to be with me;
84  But the burden and the narrow way delayed them.

85  Quando fuor giunti, assai con l'occhio bieco
86  mi rimiraron sanza far parola;
87  poi si volsero in sé, e dicean seco:

85  When they came up, long with an eye askance
86  They scanned me without uttering a word.
87  Then to each other turned, and said together:

88  “Costui par vivo a l'atto de la gola;
89  e s'e' son morti, per qual privilegio
90  vanno scoperti de la grave stola?”

88  "He by the action of his throat seems living;
89  And if they dead are, by what privilege
90  Go they uncovered by the heavy stole?"

91  Poi disser me: “O Tosco, ch'al collegio
92  de l'ipocriti tristi se' venuto,
93  dir chi tu se' non avere in dispregio.”

91  Then said to me: "Tuscan, who to the college
92  Of miserable hypocrites art come,
93  Do not disdain to tell us who thou art."

94  E io a loro: “I' fui nato e cresciuto
95  sovra 'l bel fiume d'Arno a la gran villa,
96  e son col corpo ch'i' ho sempre avuto.

94  And I to them: "Born was I, and grew up
95  In the great town on the fair river of Arno,
96  And with the body am I've always had.

97  Ma voi chi siete, a cui tanto distilla
98  quant' i' veggio dolor giù per le guance?
99  e che pena è in voi che sì sfavilla?”

97  But who are ye, in whom there trickles down
98  Along your cheeks such grief as I behold?
99  And what pain is upon you, that so sparkles?"

100  E l'un rispuose a me: “Le cappe rance
101  son di piombo sì grosse, che li pesi
102  fan così cigolar le lor bilance.

100  And one replied to me: "These orange cloaks
101  Are made of lead so heavy, that the weights
102  Cause in this way their balances to creak.

103  Frati godenti fummo, e bolognesi;
104  io Catalano e questi Loderingo
105  nomati, e da tua terra insieme presi

103  Frati Gaudenti were we, and Bolognese;
104  I Catalano, and he Loderingo
105  Named, and together taken by thy city,

106  come suole esser tolto un uom solingo,
107  per conservar sua pace; e fummo tali,
108  ch'ancor si pare intorno dal Gardingo.”

106  As the wont is to take one man alone,
107  For maintenance of its peace; and we were such
108  That still it is apparent round Gardingo."

109  Io cominciai: “O frati, i vostri mali...”;
110  ma più non dissi, ch'a l'occhio mi corse
111 un, crucifisso in terra con tre pali.

109  "O Friars," began I, "your iniquitous. . ."
110  But said no more; for to mine eyes there rushed
111  One crucified with three stakes on the ground.

112  Quando mi vide, tutto si distorse,
113  soffiando ne la barba con sospiri;
114  e 'l frate Catalan, ch'a ciò s'accorse,

112  When me he saw, he writhed himself all over,
113  Blowing into his beard with suspirations;
114  And the Friar Catalan, who noticed this,

115  mi disse: “Quel confitto che tu miri,
116  consigliò i Farisei che convenia
117  porre un uom per lo popolo a' martìri.

115  Said to me: "This transfixed one, whom thou seest,
116  Counselled the Pharisees that it was meet
117  To put one man to torture for the people.

118  Attraversato è, nudo, ne la via,
119  come tu vedi, ed è mestier ch'el senta
120  qualunque passa, come pesa, pria.

118  Crosswise and naked is he on the path,
119  As thou perceivest; and he needs must feel,
120  Whoever passes, first how much he weighs;

121  E a tal modo il socero si stenta
122  in questa fossa, e li altri dal concilio
123  che fu per li Giudei mala sementa.”

121  And in like mode his father-in-law is punished
122  Within this moat, and the others of the council,
123  Which for the Jews was a malignant seed."

124  Allor vid' io maravigliar Virgilio
125  sovra colui ch'era disteso in croce
126  tanto vilmente ne l'etterno essilio

124  And thereupon I saw Virgilius marvel
125  O'er him who was extended on the cross
126  So vilely in eternal banishment.

127  Poscia drizzò al frate cotal voce:
128  “Non vi dispiaccia, se vi lece, dirci
129  s'a la man destra giace alcuna foce

127  Then he directed to the Friar this voice:
128  "Be not displeased, if granted thee, to tell us
129  If to the right hand any pass slope down

130  onde noi amendue possiamo uscirci,
131  sanza costrigner de li angeli neri
132  che vegnan d'esto fondo a dipartirci.”

130  By which we two may issue forth from here,
131  Without constraining some of the black angels
132  To come and extricate us from this deep."

133  Rispuose adunque: “Più che tu non speri
134  s'appressa un sasso che da la gran cerchia
135  si move e varca tutt' i vallon feri,

133  Then he made answer: "Nearer than thou hopest
134  There is a rock, that forth from the great circle
135  Proceeds, and crosses all the cruel valleys,

136  salvo che 'n questo è rotto e nol coperchia;
137  montar potrete su per la ruina,
138  che giace in costa e nel fondo soperchia.”

136  Save that at this 'tis broken, and does not bridge it;
137  You will be able to mount up the ruin,
138  That sidelong slopes and at the bottom rises."

139  Lo duca stette un poco a testa china;
140  poi disse: “Mal contava la bisogna
141  colui che i peccator di qua uncina.”

139  The Leader stood awhile with head bowed down;
140  Then said: "The business badly he recounted
141  Who grapples with his hook the sinners yonder."

142  E 'l frate: “Io udi' già dire a Bologna
143  del diavol vizi assai, tra ' quali udi'
144  ch'elli è bugiardo e padre di menzogna.”

142  And the Friar: "Many of the Devil's vices
143  Once heard I at Bologna, and among them,
144  That he's a liar and the father of lies."

145  Appresso il duca a gran passi sen gì,
146  turbato un poco d'ira nel sembiante;
147  ond' io da li 'ncarcati mi parti'

145  Thereat my Leader with great strides went on,
146  Somewhat disturbed with anger in his looks;
147  Whence from the heavy-laden I departed

148  dietro a le poste de le care piante.

149  After the prints of his beloved feet.

Canto XXIV
Metamorphosis
These first 18 lines of Canto 24 are so lucid on their surface, such an apparently simple and straight forward simile that it is easy to pass over their astonishing — almost paralyzing depth and complexity.  Armies of brilliant commentators have combed over the Commedia for 800 years and they have yet to fully explicate exactly how Dante has done what he has done — and they never will.  Why?  Because he has captured that phenomenon of language which physicists have also noticed from another end of the cosmic spectrum.  Namely, that the universe behaves like a language and language behaves like the universe.  How do we even start to talk about this?  I have been thinking of this complexity as various frames or cellular modules of activity superimposed upon one another in a way that depends upon, yet masks, the connections between them.  

IN quella parte del giovanetto anno ... if there is an "in" there must also be an "out" so that is a big frame.

QUELLA PARTE (that part) ... if there is "that part" there must also be a "whole".

GIOVANETTO (young) ... if there is a "young" there must be an "old".

I CRIN (locks of hair) ... a human understanding of a celestial phenomenon, that is, the frame of "human life" as a mirror of cosmic phenomena. 

HAIR — RAYS — TEMPERED ... if something is "tempered" there must also be a "full" expression, the idea of growth and development, another fundamental frame.

L'AQUARIO ... the water bearer (earth/water/flow), the celestial stars, the zodiacal sphere, waters of earth, blood, the idea of movement, solution and dissolution, Earth waters and heavenly fire, the movement of imagination from mechanical processes to beings, entities, the anthropomorphizing of cosmic energies: we are the stars, they are our larger selves.  The rivers of Hell, which we have been following all along, and which are tangentially referred to later in the Canto when Vanni Fucci says (line 122) I piovvi di Toscana — I rained down from Tuscany.

E GIÀ LE NOTTI AL MEZZO DÌ SEN VANNO ... the oscillation of dark and light as a sentient movement, the days' lightbeings already have gone to devour almost half the nightbeings, the idea of natural metamorphoses as a journey.  

Now imagine that the brain — your brain — in order to understand these words must make a journey

from part to whole
from young to old
from years to eternity
from unmeasured darkness to measured light (from nights to days)
from heaven above to Earth below
from process to being
from cosmos to human

all the while as you do this, various parts of the brain are lighting up, these lines not only telling you what time it is (narrative to metaphor) but how language works as an analogic replica of how Time itself functions.

Notice too the vast spatial and temporal scales involves as we go down to the minute thickness of a hair or a sunray and up to the immense, immemorial revolutions of the Zodiac — but still almost nothing of human life, human history, just these vast frames in which the human drama unfolds.  And that's just the frames of reference in the first three lines!

Then the simile continues with winter/spring/ white/green (and we recall the reviving of Dante's hopes from Inferno Canto II when the frost blights and the sun revives) and we now have in line 5 the idea of family, and the Church, a "white sister", and of writing, and of the ephemeralness of the written word, of fame (think of Keats: a name writ on water), and then we come to the shepherd, his nakedness (sexuality, vulnerability, ignorance, disappointment) who slaps his thigh in frustration (the thwarting of human will by Divine fiat).  He leaves, returns, goes out, comes into the house, he has gone from sleeping to waking, from lying down to rising, and then after the passage of an hour (time molecularized in a smaller sphere), he looks out to see that the frost has disappeared and he can lead his sheep to pasture.  So we have the good shepherd, and the Biblical references which that idea entails.  He has a shepard's hook, like a bishop, but the hook is to control the sheep — the idea of obedience — and to fend off wolves — the idea of weapon and the idea of enemy.  The frames are stacking up, one atop the other, and the grounds of experience are densifying.  

Now we come to Virgil’s visage, at first troubled (disturbed), then sweet (like fruit), and the words faccia "to do" becomes faccia "face", a face whose disturbance first wounds, and whose transformation to hope, applies a healing plaster (the imprint of the writing of the frost revived, but now in a different sense, as words that give succor, as the melting frost gives succor to the fields, and grass.

We have read — or travelled — a mere 18 lines, but what a journey it has been! and I have only touched upon a very few of the many associations that run rampant around these sounds, nor have I mentioned the interweaving of the sounds themselves.

Now let us look at the simile as a whole, and think about a couple of ways that it could be interpreted.  Let Virgil's frown allude to the frost, let Dante be the humble wretch, let the reader be the sheep.  Or let the devil's deception be the frost, the discouraged Virgil (from finding the bridge to the next pouch destroyed) the humble wretch, and Dante the sheep.  

Recall now, in Inferno, Canto IV on Lust, how the metaphor of the birds evolved from a swirling flock, to line of cranes, to a pair of turtle doves, and now see here how this entire simile evolves and harks back to the frozen plant in Canto II, and foreshadows the frozen lake at the end of the Inferno.  Of course, one could argue, that this is simply how language works — and it is — but what a feat Dante is accomplishing in his poetry to capture this essence of complexity, since we could go on and on and on finding more and more connections and associations, and in fact, the rest of the canto, which, let us remember, is about metamorphosis, it's serpentine subtilty, it's density of interweavings, does exactly that.

If you could see an MRI of your brain now, it would show all kinds of connections, all their original fire, all their afterglow.  And, if you had been reading this aloud, in Dante's Italian, your larynx would be vibrating and your breath would be orchestrated to a multitude of vibrations flowing throughout your body.  Your cerebral spinal fluid would be pulsing (as the spinal chord is almost wrapped round by the larynx) and Candice Pert's so-called molecules of emotion, i.e. certain neuro-transmitters, would be infusing your gut, heart, and skin with that whole panoply of motions which we grossly summerize as mood.  You would in fact be in an altered state, the complexity of which would be in analogic synchronization with the poetry.  Your very neuronal physiology would be metamorphosing, and in some sense, you would be entrained, not just with Dante's words, but with the phenomenon of language itself, the phenomenon of the universe. 

In this pouch of the eighth circle, the bodies of the sinners suffer a physical devolution, which has a spiritual purpose.  We can speculate on what that purpose might be upon the basis of what the text presents, and that speculation might be quite different than whatever Dante had in mind — but our speculation can still be valid as long as the text supports our provisional conclusions.  I say provisional because no finality can ever be definitively arrived at, as the exercise above demonstrates.  I would say that the kinds of metamorphosis that the text tells of have about them a kind of shorthand tour of what happens to the body after death, the invasion of the human form by deadly serpents (worms/maggots).  Do these forms attack the body, or do they arise as the true vision of mere physical function, like the exposure of the intestines, as the serpents arise from the body around the reins or kidneys?  These are like giant worms or maggots, and whatever human shape that body might have had, they prove that in the case of these malicious thieves that human-seeming shape had always been a fraud.  Vanni Fucci and all his ilk are not guided by any precept other than their own appetites, they are in fact parasitical worms, vampires who both feed on the human form, and also use that form as a deceitful disguise to deceive others.  In brief, the serpents that appear to be devouring them are also their true selves, not only in life, but here in death, where their bodies are transmogrified, fall to ashes, as if struck by the serpent tongue of lightning, and rise again to repeat the process.  One feels that the text here, with the broken bridge, is very much like one of those autoimmune diseases in which the connective tissue becomes diseased and instead of making the body coherent and mobile, attack that coherence and utterly destroy it, as if we witnessed in a second some form of ALS that reduces the body to ashes, but only to have it reform in a moment and repeat this same agonizing cycle.  Note too, that it is when the aspirant Dante is trying to deceive Virgil into believing that he has more breath and strength than he actually has — that it is in that precise moment that the voice of Vanni Fucci is heard — a kindred spirit in deceit and a kindred spirit in his Tuscan accent.  The irony is rich at this moment when Dante, the aspirant, asks Virgil to stop so that Dante can discover more of the incoherent voice (note that) which angrily accosts him.  Then in a lengthy assent about silent and immediate obedience, Virgil displays anything but silence by his very praise of the quality.  That the canto should end with the malicious prophecy that Vanni Fucci makes about Dante's political fortunes, we see that this shade maintains his own torment by being tormenting.  It's true that in an aside, the aspirant, stands amazed at God's power to punish, but as contemporary readers, we may say that there is an automaticity involved in Vanni Fucci's fate, just as there is an automaticity in the body's putrefaction after death.  One could even say that Vanni Fucci's fate is simply the fate of the decaying body, and if one does no soul building during life, than one automatically suffers this fate because one has in a sense only stolen a human form capable of moral choices and creativity, only stolen what is sacred, and by this form of wastage may no longer transfigure the mortal sufferer into a blissful immortality, but may only perpetuate the cycle of death. 

1  In quella parte del giovanetto anno
2  che 'l sole i crin sotto l'Aquario tempra
3  e già le notti al mezzo dì sen vanno,

1  In that part of the youthful year wherein
2  The Sun his locks beneath Aquarius tempers,
3  And now the nights draw near to half the day,

4  quando la brina in su la terra assempra
5  l'imagine di sua sorella bianca,
6  ma poco dura a la sua penna tempra,

4  What time the hoar-frost copies on the ground
5  The outward semblance of her sister white,
6  But little lasts the temper of her pen,

7  lo villanello a cui la roba manca,
8  si leva, e guarda, e vede la campagna
9  biancheggiar tutta; ond' ei si batte l'anca,

The husbandman, whose forage faileth him,
Rises, and looks, and seeth the champaign
All gleaming white, whereat he beats his flank,

10  ritorna in casa, e qua e là si lagna,
11  come 'l tapin che non sa che si faccia;
12  poi riede, e la speranza ringavagna,

10  Returns in doors, and up and down laments,
11  Like a poor wretch, who knows not what to do;
12  Then he returns and hope revives again,

13  veggendo 'l mondo aver cangiata faccia
14  in poco d'ora, e prende suo vincastro
15  e fuor le pecorelle a pascer caccia.

13  Seeing the world has changed its countenance
14  In little time, and takes his shepherd's crook,
15  And forth the little lambs to pasture drives.

16  Così mi fece sbigottir lo mastro
17  quand' io li vidi sì turbar la fronte,
18  e così tosto al mal giunse lo 'mpiastro;

16  Thus did the Master fill me with alarm,
17  When I beheld his forehead so disturbed,
18  And to the ailment came as soon the plaster.

19  ché, come noi venimmo al guasto ponte,
20  lo duca a me si volse con quel piglio
21  dolce ch'io vidi prima a piè del monte.

19  For as we came unto the ruined bridge,
20  The Leader turned to me with that sweet look
21  Which at the mountain's foot I first beheld.

22  Le braccia aperse, dopo alcun consiglio
23  eletto seco riguardando prima
24  ben la ruina, e diedemi di piglio.

22  His arms he opened, after some advisement
23  Within himself elected, looking first
24  Well at the ruin, and laid hold of me.

25  E come quei ch'adopera ed estima,
26  che sempre par che 'nnanzi si proveggia,
27  così, levando me sù ver' la cima

25  And even as he who acts and meditates,
26  For aye it seems that he provides beforehand,
27  So upward lifting me towards the summit

28  d'un ronchione, avvisava un'altra scheggia
29  dicendo: “Sovra quella poi t'aggrappa;
30  ma tenta pria s'è tal ch'ella ti reggia.”

28  Of a huge rock, he scanned another crag,
29  Saying: "To that one grapple afterwards,
30  But try first if 'tis such that it will hold thee."

31  Non era via da vestito di cappa,
32  ché noi a pena, ei lieve e io sospinto,
33  potavam sù montar di chiappa in chiappa.

31  This was no way for one clothed with a cloak;
32  For hardly we, he light, and I pushed upward,
33  Were able to ascend from jag to jag.

34  E se non fosse che da quel precinto
35  più che da l'altro era la costa corta,
36  non so di lui, ma io sarei ben vinto.

34  And had it not been, that upon that precinct
35  Shorter was the ascent than on the other,
36  He I know not, but I had been dead beat.

37  Ma perché Malebolge inver' la porta
38  del bassissimo pozzo tutta pende,
39  lo sito di ciascuna valle porta

37  But because Malebolge tow'rds the mouth
38  Of the profoundest well is all inclining,
39  The structure of each valley doth import

40  che l'una costa surge e l'altra scende;
41  noi pur venimmo al fine in su la punta
42  onde l'ultima pietra si scoscende.

40  That one bank rises and the other sinks.
41  Still we arrived at length upon the point
42  Wherefrom the last stone breaks itself asunder.

43  La lena m'era del polmon sì munta
44  quand'io fui sù, ch'i' non potea più oltre,
45  anzi m'assisi ne la prima giunta.

43  The breath was from my lungs so milked away,
44  When I was up, that I could go no farther,
45  Nay, I sat down upon my first arrival.

46  “Omai convien che tu così ti spoltre,”
47  disse 'l maestro; “ché, seggendo in piuma,
48  in fama non si vien, né sotto coltre;

46  "Now it behoves thee thus to put off sloth,"
47  My Master said; "for sitting upon down,
48  Or under quilt, one cometh not to fame,

49  sanza la qual chi sua vita consuma,
50  cotal vestigio in terra di sé lascia,
51  qual fummo in aere e in acqua la schiuma.

49  Withouten which whoso his life consumes
50  Such vestige leaveth of himself on earth,
51  As smoke in air or in the water foam.

52  E però leva sù; vinci l'ambascia
53  con l'animo che vince ogne battaglia,
54  se col suo grave corpo non s'accascia.

52  And therefore raise thee up, o'ercome the anguish
53  With spirit that o'ercometh every battle,
54  If with its heavy body it sink not.

55  Più lunga scala convien che si saglia;
56  non basta da costoro esser partito.
57  Se tu mi 'ntendi, or fa sì che ti vaglia.”

55  A longer stairway it behoves thee mount;
56  Tis not enough from these to have departed;
57  Let it avail thee, if thou understand me."

58  Leva'mi allor, mostrandomi fornito
59  meglio di lena ch'i'non mi sentia,
60  e dissi: “Va, ch'i' son forte e ardito.”

58  Then I uprose, showing myself provided
59  Better with breath than I did feel myself,
60  And said: "Go on, for I am strong and bold."

61  Su per lo scoglio prendemmo la via,
62  ch'era ronchioso, stretto e malagevole,
63  ed erto più assai che quel di pria.

61  Upward we took our way along the crag,
62  Which jagged was, and narrow, and difficult,
63  And more precipitous far than that before.

64  Parlando andava per non parer fievole;
65  onde una voce uscì de l'altro fosso,
66  a parole formar disconvenevole.

64  Speaking I went, not to appear exhausted;
65  Whereat a voice from the next moat came forth,
66  Not well adapted to articulate words.

67  Non so che disse, ancor che sovra 'l dosso
68  fossi de l'arco già che varca quivi;
69  ma chi parlava ad ire parea mosso.

67  I know not what it said, though o'er the back
68  I now was of the arch that passes there;
69  But he seemed moved to anger who was speaking.

70  Io era vòlto in giù, ma li occhi vivi
71  non poteano ire al fondo per lo scuro;
72  per ch'io: “Maestro, fa che tu arrivi

70  I was bent downward, but my living eyes
71  Could not attain the bottom, for the dark;
72  Wherefore I: "Master, see that thou arrive

73  da l'altro cinghio e dismontiam lo muro;
74  ché, com' i' odo quinci e non intendo,
75  così giù veggio e neente affiguro.”

73  At the next round, and let us descend the wall;
74  For as from hence I hear and understand not,
75  So I look down and nothing I distinguish."

76  “Altra risposta,” disse, “non ti rendo
77  se non lo far; ché la dimanda onesta
78  si de' seguir con l'opera tacendo.”

76  "Other response," he said, "I make thee not,
77  Except the doing; for the modest asking
78  Ought to be followed by the deed in silence."

79  Noi discendemmo il ponte de la testa
80  dove s'aggiugne con l'ottava ripa,
81  e poi mi fu la bolgia manifesta:

79  We from the bridge descended at its head,
80  Where it connects itself with the eighth bank,
81  And then was manifest to me the Bolgia;

82  e vidivi entro terrible stipa
83  di serpenti, e di sì diversa mena
84  che la memoria il sangue ancor mi scipa.

82  And I beheld therein a terrible throng
83  Of serpents, and of such a monstrous kind,
84  That the remembrance still congeals my blood

85  Più non si vanti Libia con sua rena;
86  ché se chelidri, iaculi e faree
87  produce, e cencri con anfisibena,

85  Let Libya boast no longer with her sand;
86  For if Chelydri, Jaculi, and Phareae
87  She breeds, with Cenchri and with Amphisbaena,

88  né tante pestilenzie né sì ree
89  mostrò già mai con tutta l'Etïopia
90  né con ciò che di sopra al Mar Rosso èe.

88  Neither so many plagues nor so malignant
89  E'er showed she with all Ethiopia,
90  Nor with whatever on the Red Sea is!

91  Tra questa cruda e tristissima copia
92  corrëan genti nude e spaventate,
93  sanza sperar pertugio o elitropia:

91  Among this cruel and most dismal throng
92  People were running naked and affrighted.
93  Without the hope of hole or heliotrope.

94  con serpi le man dietro avean legate;
95  quelle ficcavan per le ren la coda
96  e 'l capo, ed eran dinanzi aggroppate.

94  They had their hands with serpents bound behind them;
95  These riveted upon their reins the tail
96  And head, and were in front of them entwined.

97  Ed ecco a un ch'era da nostra proda,
98  s'avventò un serpente che 'l trafisse
99  là dove 'l collo a le spalle s'annoda.

97  And lo! at one who was upon our side
98  There darted forth a serpent, which transfixed him
99  There where the neck is knotted to the shoulders.

100  Né O sì tosto mai né I si scrisse,
101  com' el s'accese e arse, e cener tutto
102  convenne che cascando divenisse;

100  Nor 'O' so quickly e'er, nor 'I' was written,
101  As he took fire, and burned; and ashes wholly
102  Behoved it that in falling he became.

103  e poi che fu a terra sì distrutto,
104  la polver si raccolse per sé stessa
105  e 'n quel medesmo ritornò di butto.

103  And when he on the ground was thus destroyed,
104  The ashes drew together, and of themselves
105  Into himself they instantly returned.

106  Così per li gran savi si confessa
107  che la fenice more e poi rinasce,
108  quando al cinquecentesimo anno appressa;

106  Even thus by the great sages 'tis confessed
107  The phoenix dies, and then is born again,
108  When it approaches its five-hundredth year;

109  erba né biado in sua vita non pasce,
110  ma sol d'incenso lagrime e d'amomo,
111  e nardo e mirra son l'ultime fasce.

109  On herb or grain it feeds not in its life,
110  But only on tears of incense and amomum,
111  And nard and myrrh are its last winding-sheet.

112  E qual è quel che cade, e non sa como,
113  per forza di demon ch'a terra il tira,
114  o d'altra oppilazion che lega l'omo,

112  And as he is who falls, and knows not how,
113  By force of demons who to earth down drag him,
114  Or other oppilation that binds man,

115  quando si leva, che 'ntorno si mira
116  tutto smarrito de la grande angoscia
117  ch'elli ha sofferta, e guardando sospira:

115  When he arises and around him looks,
116  Wholly bewildered by the mighty anguish
117  Which he has suffered, and in looking sighs;

118  tal era 'l peccator levato poscia.
119  Oh potenza di Dio, quant' è severa,
120  che cotai colpi per vendetta croscia!

118  Such was that sinner after he had risen.
119  Justice of God! O how severe it is,
120  That blows like these in vengeance poureth down!

121  Lo duca il domandò poi chi ello era;
122  per ch'ei rispuose: “Io piovvi di Toscana,
123  poco tempo è, in questa gola fiera.

121  The Guide thereafter asked him who he was;
121  Whence he replied: "I rained from Tuscany
122  A short time since into this cruel gorge.

124  Vita bestial mi piacque e non umana,
125  sì come a mul ch'i'fui; son Vanni Fucci
126  bestia, e Pistoia mi fu degna tana.”

124  A bestial life, and not a human, pleased me,
125  Even as the mule I was; I'm Vanni Fucci,
126  Beast, and Pistoia was my worthy den."

127  E ïo al duca: “Dilli che non mucci,
128  e domanda che colpa qua giù 'l pinse;
129  ch'io 'l vidi omo di sangue e di crucci.”

127  And I unto the Guide: "Tell him to stir not,
128  And ask what crime has thrust him here below,
129  For once a man of blood and wrath I saw him."

130  E 'l peccator, che 'ntese, non s'infinse,
131  ma drizzò verso me l'animo e 'l volto,
132  e di trista vergogna si dipinse;

130  And the sinner, who had heard, dissembled not,
131  But unto me directed mind and face,
132  And with a melancholy shame was painted.

133  poi disse: “Più mi duol che tu m'hai colto
134  ne la miseria dove tu mi vedi,
135  che quando fui de l'altra vita tolto.

133  Then said: "It pains me more that thou hast caught me
134  Amid this misery where thou seest me,
135  Than when I from the other life was taken.

136  Io non posso negar quel che tu chiedi;
137  in giù son messo tanto perch'io fui
138  ladro a la sagrestia d'i belli arredi,

136  What thou demandest I cannot deny;
137  So low am I put down because I robbed
138  The sacristy of the fair ornaments,

139  e falsamente già fu apposto altrui.
140  Ma perché di tal vista tu non godi,
141  se mai sarai di fuor da' luoghi bui,

139  And falsely once 'twas laid upon another;
140  But that thou mayst not such a sight enjoy,
141  If thou shalt e'er be out of the dark places,

142  apri li orecchi al mio annunzio, e odi.
143  Pistoia in pria d'i Neri si dimagra;
144  poi Fiorenza rinova gente e modi.

142  Thine ears to my announcement ope and hear:
143  Pistoia first of Neri groweth meagre;
144  Then Florence doth renew her men and manners;

145  Tragge Marte vapor di Val di Magra
146  ch'è di torbidi nuvoli involuto;
147  e con tempesta impetüosa e agra

145  Mars draws a vapour up from Val di Magra,
146  Which is with turbid clouds enveloped round,
147  And with impetuous and bitter tempest

148  sovra Campo Picen fia combattuto;
149  ond'ei repente spezzerà la nebbia,
150  sì ch'ogne Bianco ne sarà feruto.

148  Over Campo Picen shall be the battle;
149  When it shall suddenly rend the mist asunder,
150  So that each Bianco shall thereby be smitten.

151  E detto l'ho perché doler ti debbia!”

151  And this I've said that it may give thee pain."

Canto XXV
Everything is in flux, and yet we persist in seeing everything as dependably solid.   Maybe as infants we see that blurry world before habit has deceived us into thinking that the forms we see, the forms of our own bodies, by a blessèd misperception of the quickness of time, the fickleness of space, are all immutably mutable.  Our bodies are turbines of swarming energies, like swarming bees, which appropriate the energies around us, and the very — albeit temporary — existence of a body with a human form dissipates all the lesser forms in the environment as it gathers substance for its existence.  Here is original sin: In order to maintain our little cosmos, we make the environment we inhabit a chaos.  We are all thieves of life, destined to return that gift of supreme and dynamic organization to the slurry vermiculture of disintegrating corpses, the noisome oviposition sites of flies, and the nursery to hordes of maggots.  We begin with a moral debt, and our further evolution to higher forms depends upon how we settle that debt in all that we relate to ... but how do we do that?  Dante, the poet, is answering that question with negative exemplars all through the aspirant's journey through the Inferno.  The thieves of Canto XXV with their incredible — and Dante goes to great pains in this canto to make the incredible credible — devolution to serpent and reptile forms — show us how that debt is increased, and how the lower forms, or the moral order of the cosmos, take their retribution in the post-mortem dream.  To quote Blake: They became what they beheld.  Worms, snakes, lizards, the bulwarks of form, however repulsive to the human eye, still forestall the utter destruction of the cosmos in the frozen tight heat-death that the readers of the Commedia will encounter soon enough in the very depths of Hell.  That's why, as the text reads in line 4, the serpents are Dante's friends.  

In this canto, we find there is an accumulation of confusion and of Boschean grotesqueness, and as we continue reading, the Inferno that saps our strength, taxes our imagination, challenges us to make sense of how, in our own lives, devolution, dissipation, diversion intrude and break down our firm intentions to accomplish something to justify our existence.  Like Milton's Lucifer, Dante's thief, Vanni Fucci, greets these D-demons by defiance.  His defiance against the very power that has given his existence order and identity shows how depraved he has become, and his defiance speeds up his disintegration, his continued waywardness serving as a catalyst to speed up the time of decay, and to the aspirant's eyes, at least, to almost instantaneously dissolve into serpent forms.  The horror of this devolution gives us pause, and creates a kind of debilitating horror of what we ourselves are constantly becoming as senescence inches us inevitably towards the utter dissolution of bodily death.  In this Canto, more than any other that has gone before, the identities of the sinners are very hard to track, and we have to disentangle them so to speak from the worm wrestle of the narrative, and even if we managed to come up with the names of these sinners, the effort is hardly worth it.  Their names mean nothing, the processes of change that punishes them, that is what we find we are being shown as we probe deeper into the text.  We might ask ourselves: Why this Hell? why post-mortem? why this dream of poetic fiction that purports to be a literal truth? — and these questions hang in the air around us like a perpetual angst, a stench, a round of torments which succeed one another with terrible rapidity.  In the biological realms, this corpse, this thief of life, enters the food chain, and gives rise again to complex forms, the mutations coming in many cycles, whose spirals can go up — as we shall see in the Purgatorio and the Paradiso — as well as down.  But here, and in all the Hell cantos, for the sinners, the perfect conservatives and right-wingers, nothing changes in the cycles themselves, their cosmology is fixed and repetitive, because they have become determined to maintain them just so, in spite of all the pain that leads nowhere but to a repetition.  Their circle of torments is closed and eternal.

Now, however, we come to a curious fact about this text.  The closer we study this disorder, the more we find an underlying order, a kind of cryptological code, that is the excellence of the poetry itself.  Robert Hollander, in the notes to his and Jean Hollander’s translation, presents a tripartite graph.  He shows that there are three types of sinners shown here (Vanni Fucci, Agnello and Cianfa, Buoso and Francesco, each displaying one of three types of transmogrification: Vanni Fucci: resurrection, Agnello and Cianfa: mutation, and Buoso and Francesco: transmutation; each described by three metaphors: Vanni Fucci (in Canto XXIV) by the letters O and I, by the phoenix, and by an epileptic fit; Agnello and Cianfa by ivy on a tree, by hot waxes blending, and by burning parchment; Buoso and Francesco by a lizard on a path, by a person in sleep or fever, and by a snail's horns;  each too are representative of three different kinds of theft, Vanni Fucci, the theft of church property (Aquinas' Sacrilegio); theft of goods commonly held (Aquinas' Peculato), and theft from fellow men (Aquinas' Plagio) theft from one's fellows.  The text's outward chaos emerges from a deeper aesthetic order.  

From the very first too, when Vanni Fucci makes an obscene gesture aimed at the God whom he feels is tormenting him, there is in this canto, to reverse Eliot's phrase, a raid on the articulate.  Dante is showing here his answer to how we escape from the original sin of theft from our environment to feed and maintain ourselves.  And what is that compensation?  Making poetry, making art ... continuing to create higher and more deeply ordered forms outside of physical time and space and their perpetual wranglings of destruction, creation, and ultimate entropically sterile gruel.  

Final note and question: the cosmos must have a shape, and Dante gives it a very precise shape, Ptolemaic in a way, which is now seen as metaphor not cosmology, but that does not negate its purpose for the imagination.  The question is: What is the shape of our contemporary cosmos?  Its internal constants?  The question must remain open as are our current cosmological description of a universe which is exploding without boundaries from a dot of density smaller than the head of a pin and briefer than a moment outside of time, a description, as Terrance McKenna points out, which is far more absurd than any other put forth in the mythologies of any religion or folklore, that is say: the one we cannot imagine, the one we believe.  And isn't it strange, that not seeing the ridiculousness of our beliefs, while denigrating the ridiculousness of these poetic cosmologies, we make of ourselves the most ridiculous of all things: people who laugh at everyone but ourselves.    
    
1  Al fine de le sue parole il ladro
2  le mani alzò con amendue le fiche,
3  gridando: “Togli, Dio, ch'a te le squadro!”

1  At the conclusion of his words, the thief
2  Lifted his hands aloft with both the figs,
3  Crying: "Take that, God, for at thee I aim them."

4  Da indi in qua mi fuor le serpi amiche,
5  perch' una li s'avvolse allora al collo,
6  come dicesse “Non vo' che più diche”;

4  From that time forth the serpents were my friends;
5  For one entwined itself about his neck
6  As if it said: "I will not thou speak more;"

7  e un'altra a le braccia, e rilegollo,
8  ribadendo sé stessa si dinanzi,
9  che non potea con esse dare un crollo.

7  And round his arms another, and rebound him,
8  Clinching itself together so in front,
9  That with them he could not a motion make.

10  Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi
11  d'incenerarti sì che più non duri,
12  poi che 'n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?

10  Pistoia, ah, Pistoia! why resolve not
11  To burn thyself to ashes and so perish,
12  Since in ill-doing thou thy seed excellest?

13  Per tutt' i cerchi de lo 'nferno scuri
14  non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo,
15  non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da' muri.

13  Through all the sombre circles of this Hell,
14  Spirit I saw not against God so proud,
15  Not he who fell at Thebes down from the walls!

16  El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo;
17  e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia
18  venir chiamando: “Ov' è, ov' è l'acerbo?”

16  He fled away, and spake no further word;
17  And I beheld a Centaur full of rage
18  Come crying out: "Where is, where is the scoffer?"

19  Maremma non cred' io che tante n'abbia,
20  quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa
21  infin ove comincia nostra labbia.

19  I do not think Maremma has so many
20  Serpents as he had all along his back,
21  As far as where our countenance begins.

22  Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa,
23  con l'ali aperte li giacea un draco;
24  e quello affuoca qualunque s'intoppa.

22  Upon the shoulders, just behind the nape,
23  With wings wide open was a dragon lying,
24  And he sets fire to all that he encounters.

25  Lo mio maestro disse: “Questi è Caco,
26  che, sotto 'l sasso di monte Aventino,
27  di sangue fece spesse volte laco.

25  My Master said: "That one is Cacus, who
26  Beneath the rock upon Mount Aventine
27  Created oftentimes a lake of blood.

28  Non va co' suoi fratei per un cammino,
29  per lo furto che frodolente fece
30  del grande armento ch'elli ebbe a vicino;

28  He goes not on the same road with his brothers,
29  By reason of the fraudulent theft he made
30  Of the great herd, which he had near to him;

31  onde cessar le sue opere biece
32  sotto la mazza d'Ercule, che forse
33  gliene diè cento, e non sentì le diece.”

31  Whereat his tortuous actions ceased beneath
32  The mace of Hercules, who peradventure
33  Gave him a hundred, and he felt not ten."

34  Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse,
35  e tre spiriti venner sotto noi,
36  de' quai né io né 'l duca mio s'accorse,

34  While he was speaking thus, he had passed by,
35  And spirits three had underneath us come,
36  Of which nor I aware was, nor my Leader,

37  se non quando gridar: “Chi siete voi?”
38  per che nostra novella si ristette,
39  e intendemmo pur ad essi poi.

37  Until what time they shouted: "Who are you?"
38  On which account our story made a halt,
39  And then we were intent on them alone.

40  Io non li conoscea; ma ei seguette,
41  come suol seguitar per alcun caso,
42  che l'un nomar un altro convenette,

40  I did not know them; but it came to pass,
41  As it is wont to happen by some chance,
42  That one to name the other was compelled,

43  dicendo: “Cianfa dove fia rimaso?”
44  per ch'io, acciò che 'l duca stesse attento,
45  mi puosi 'l dito su dal mento al naso.

43  Exclaiming: "Where can Cianfa have remained?"
44  Whence I, so that the Leader might attend,
45  Upward from chin to nose my finger laid.

46  Se tu se' or, lettore, a creder lento ciò
47  ch'io dirò, non sarà maraviglia,
48  ché io che 'l vidi, a pena il mi consento.

46  If thou art, Reader, slow now to believe
47  What I shall say, it will no marvel be,
48  For I who saw it hardly can admit it.

49  Com' io tenea levate in lor le ciglia,
50  e un serpente con sei piè si lancia
51  dinanzi a l'uno, e tutto a lui s'appiglia.

49  As I was holding raised on them my brows,
50  Behold! a serpent with six feet darts forth
51  In front of one, and fastens wholly on him.

52  Co' piè di mezzo li avvinse la pancia
53  e con li anterïor le braccia prese;
54  poi li addentò e l'una e l'altra guancia;

52  With middle feet it bound him round the paunch,
53  And with the forward ones his arms it seized;
54  Then thrust its teeth through one cheek and the other;

55  li diretani a le cosce distese,
56  e miseli la coda tra 'mbedue
57  e dietro per le ren sù la ritese.

55  The hindermost it stretched upon his thighs,
56  And put its tail through in between the two,
57  And up behind along the reins outspread it.

58  Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue
59  ad alber si, come l'orribil fiera
60  per l'altrui membra avviticchiò le sue.

58  Ivy was never fastened by its barbs
59  Unto a tree so, as this horrible reptile
60  Upon the other's limbs entwined its own.

61  Poi s'appiccar, come di calda cera
62  fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore,
63  né l'un né l'altro già parea quel ch'era:

61  Then they stuck close, as if of heated wax
62  They had been made, and intermixed their colour;
63  Nor one nor other seemed now what he was;

64  come procede innanzi da l'ardore,
65  per lo papiro suso, un color bruno
66  che non è nero ancora e 'l bianco more.

64  E'en as proceedeth on before the flame
65  Upward along the paper a brown colour,
66  Which is not black as yet, and the white dies.

67  Li altri due 'l riguardavano, e ciascuno
68  gridava: “Omè, Agnel, come ti muti!
69  Vedi che già non se' né due né uno.”

67  The other two looked on, and each of them
68  Cried out: "O me, Agnello, how thou changest!
69  Behold, thou now art neither two nor one."

70  Già eran li due capi un divenuti,
71  quando n'apparver due figure miste
72  in una faccia, ov' eran due perduti.

70  Already the two heads had one become,
71  When there appeared to us two figures mingled
73  Into one face, wherein the two were lost.

73  Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste;
74  le cosce con le gambe e 'l ventre e 'l casso
75  divenner membra che non fuor mai viste.

73  Of the four lists were fashioned the two arms,
74  The thighs and legs, the belly and the chest
75  Members became that never yet were seen.

76  Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso:
77  due e nessun l'imagine perversa
78  parea; e tal sen gio con lento passo.

76  Every original aspect there was cancelled;
77  Two and yet none did the perverted image
78  Appear, and such departed with slow pace.

79  Come 'l ramarro sotto la gran fersa
80  dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe,
81  folgore par se la via attraversa,

79  Even as a lizard, under the great scourge
80  Of days canicular, exchanging hedge,
81  Lightning appeareth if the road it cross;

82  sì pareva, venendo verso l'epe
83  de li altri due, un serpentello acceso,
84  livido e nero come gran di pepe;

82  Thus did appear, coming towards the bellies
83  Of the two others, a small fiery serpent,
84  Livid and black as is a peppercorn.

85  e quella parte onde prima è preso
86  nostro alimento, a l'un di lor trafisse;
87  poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso.

85  And in that part whereat is first received
86  Our aliment, it one of them transfixed;
87  Then downward fell in front of him extended.

88  Lo trafitto 'l mirò, ma nulla disse;
89  anzi, co' piè fermati, sbadigliava
90  pur come sonno o febbre l'assalisse.

88  The one transfixed looked at it, but said naught;
89  Nay, rather with feet motionless he yawned,
