90  Just as if sleep or fever had assailed him.

91  Elli 'l serpente e quei lui riguardava;
92  l'un per la piaga e l'altro per la bocca
93  fummavan forte, e 'l fummo si scontrava.

91  He at the serpent gazed, and it at him;
92  One through the wound, the other through the mouth
93  Smoked violently, and the smoke commingled.

94  Taccia Lucano omai là dov' e' tocca
95  del misero Sabello e di Nasidio,
96  e attenda a udir quel ch'or si scocca.

94  Henceforth be silent Lucan, where he mentions
95  Wretched Sabellus and Nassidius,
96  And wait to hear what now shall be shot forth.

97  Taccia di Cadmo e d'Aretusa Ovidio,
98  ché se quello in serpente e quella in fonte
99  converte poetando, io non lo 'nvidio;

97  Be silent Ovid, of Cadmus and Arethusa;
98  For if him to a snake, her to fountain,
99  Converts he fabling, that I grudge him not;

100  ché due nature mai a fronte a fronte
101  non trasmutò sì ch'amendue le forme
102  a cambiar lor matera fosser pronte

100  Because two natures never front to front
101  Has he transmuted, so that both the forms
102  To interchange their matter ready were.

103  Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme,
104  che 'l serpente la coda in forca fesse,
105  e 'l feruto ristrinse insieme l'orme.

103  Together they responded in such wise,
104  That to a fork the serpent cleft his tail,
105  And eke the wounded drew his feet together.

106  Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse
107  s'appiccar sì, che 'n poco la giuntura
108  non facea segno alcun che si paresse.

106  The legs together with the thighs themselves
107  Adhered so, that in little time the juncture
108  No sign whatever made that was apparent.

109  Togliea la coda fessa la figura
110  che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle
111  si facea molle, e quella di là dura.

109  He with the cloven tail assumed the figure
110  The other one was losing, and his skin
111  Became elastic, and the other's hard.

112  Io vidi intrar le braccia per l'ascelle,
113  e i due piè de la fiera, ch'eran corti,
114  tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle.

112  I saw the arms draw inward at the armpits,
113  And both feet of the reptile, that were short,
114  Lengthen as much as those contracted were.

115  Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti,
116  diventaron lo membro che l'uom cela,
117  e 'l misero del suo n'avea due porti.

115  Thereafter the hind feet, together twisted,
116  Became the member that a man conceals,
117  And of his own the wretch had two created.

118  Mentre che 'l fummo l'uno e l'altro vela
119  di color novo, e genera 'l pel suso
120  per l'una parte e da l'altra il dipela,

118  While both of them the exhalation veils
119  With a new colour, and engenders hair
120  On one of them and depilates the other,

121  l'un si levò e l'altro cadde giuso,
122  non torcendo però le lucerne empie,
123  sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso.

121  The one uprose and down the other fell,
122  Though turning not away their impious lamps,
123  Underneath which each one his muzzle changed.

124  Quel ch'era dritto, il trasse ver' le tempie,
125  e di troppa matera ch'in là venne
126  uscir li orecchi de le gote scempie;

124  He who was standing drew it tow'rds the temples,
125  And from excess of matter, which came thither,
126  Issued the ears from out the hollow cheeks;

127  ciò che non corse in dietro e si ritenne
128  di quel soverchio, fé naso a la faccia
129  e le labbra ingrossò quanto convenne.

127  What did not backward run and was retained
128  Of that excess made to the face a nose,
128  And the lips thickened far as was befitting.

130  Quel che giacëa, il muso innanzi caccia,
131  e li orecchi ritira per la testa
132  come face le corna la lumaccia;

130  He who lay prostrate thrusts his muzzle forward,
131  And backward draws the ears into his head,
132  In the same manner as the snail its horns;

133  e la lingua, ch'avèa unita e presta
134  prima a parlar, si fende, e la forcuta
135  ne l'altro si richiude; e 'l fummo resta.

133  And so the tongue, which was entire and apt
134  For speech before, is cleft, and the bi-forked
135  In the other closes up, and the smoke ceases.

136  L'anima ch'era fiera divenuta,
137  suffolando si fugge per la valle,
138  e l'altro dietro a lui parlando sputa.

136  The soul, which to a reptile had been changed,
137  Along the valley hissing takes to flight,
138  And after him the other speaking sputters.

139  Poscia li volse le novelle spalle,
140  e disse a l'altro: “I' vo' che Buoso corra,
141  com' ho fatt' io, carpon per questo calle.”

139  Then did he turn upon him his new shoulders,
140  And said to the other: "I'll have Buoso run,
141  Crawling as I have done, along this road."

142  Così vid' io la settima zavorra
143  mutare e trasmutare; e qui mi scusi
144  la novità se fior la penna abborra.

142  In this way I beheld the seventh ballast
143  Shift and reshift, and here be my excuse
144  The novelty, if aught my pen transgress.

145  E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi
146  fossero alquanto e l'animo smagato,
147  non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,

145  And notwithstanding that mine eyes might be
146  Somewhat bewildered, and my mind dismayed,
147  They could not flee away so secretly

148  ch'i' non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato;
149  ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni
150  che venner prima, non era mutato;

148  But that I plainly saw Puccio Sciancato;
149  And he it was who sole of three companions,
150  Which came in the beginning, was not changed;

151  l'altr' era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni.

151  The other was he whom thou, Gaville, weepest.

Canto XXVI
Ulysses would discover the highest (the vision of Mount Purgatory), and the lowest (the whirlpool that sucks him down to death and Hell) by means of physical, sensory experience.  His spirit of aspiration continuing to burn, even after has physical form has become, in a sense, fossilized by the ephemera of flame, just as a bone might be, cell by cell, fossilized to stone.  And yet ephemeral as he, Ulysses, is, he still is fixed by an idee fixe to know and experience more.  This is his way, which also includes deceit — the Trojan Horse, escape from lassitude — Circe, and absconding from familial responsibilities — leaving Penelope, Telemachus, and his aging father, and defying his own physical aging.  Virgil too would discover the highest and lowest, through reason and what he regards as truth.  And note how Virgil's vision of making the highest and the lowest discoverable through reason and through the aesthetics of poetry is the translator or intermediary between Ulysses' life of adventurure, and Dante's life as a mystic/poet.  Note too how both the adventurer's and the pagan reasoner's methods of exploration are anathema to Dante, the poet, and yet remain huge snares to Dante, the aspirant.  Dante, the aspirant, left wife, children and home too.  Dante the aspirant also burned to know the highest and the lowest.  Dante the aspirant too sought solace in reason and in learning.  But Dante the poet has discovered, or is discovering, that the path of Ulysses and the path of Virgil, are paths that lead only to Hell, pagan paths that are centered on what the individual, in his arrogance can will himself to do to satisfy his own curiosity, his own urge to be all that he can be.  What is left out of Virgil's and Ulysses' equations is faith, is the other, in Dante's case Beatrice, not his Penelope, which would have been Gemma, the wife he too abandoned, but the beloved spirit beyond any possibility of physical grasp and get.  Dante's ardor has moved from flesh to flame, and transfigured itself, through God's grace, from mortality to immortality.  Dante, the poet, is literally being turned on, and he flames on the fuel of Dante, the aspirant and exile, the man who is part of a history, which in the end would be nothing but ashes, were it not for the living word that the poet embodies.  Like Ulysses, Dante, the poet, is a speaking flame.

Dante, the aspirent's healing begins, as this canto begins, with shame.  The things that a man should be proud of — his place of birth, his earthly position and accomplishments, his wife and children have brought him shame.  He is beginning to feel and see, that mortality, without the promise of immortality, is a sty of shame.  This shame, as we saw Vanne Fucci discover, even survives death.  We could call shame the original sin, that is to say, shame in one's own birth on the physical plane, a shame that can pinch the spirit right out of the body, a shame in the unknown origins of conception and the unknown destiny which lies beyond life.

One thing that glaringly stands out in this canto, is the courtesy with which Ulysses is treated by the two protagonists, plus the straightforwardness with which Ulysses recounts his sin.  His explanation is certainly unrepentant, but I don't see where he attempts to shift the blame to others.  If the sin is giving fraudulent advice, then the vice of leaving his family, and the arrogance of having experience that no human has had before, are not what has damned him.  What damns him is his eloquence in persuading others to join him, and causing their deaths as well as his own.  Dante could not have written this without being aware that both he and Virgil were like Ulysses in the sense that it is a poet's job to sway, even if that persuasion is an aesthetic one only — i.e. to spend one's time on Earth with art, not politics, spiritual service, or charity.  And it is clearly a concern of Dante, the poet, that he must find some way to differentiate his "Christian" persuasions from Ulysses' exhortations to explore new realms and Virgil’s tales emphasizing his hero's piety and attention to his filial duties.  In the next canto, with Guido da Montefeltro, Dante, the poet tries to clarify what is ambiguous about his condemnation of Ulysses.  The juxtaposition of the two sinners in the same region of Hell for the same crime is vivid.  Guido's story in his own words, as is Ulysses', but Guido returns to the pattern which we have seen throughout Hell of blaming and self-pity.  We come away from this canto with an admiration for the sinner Ulysses, and a sense that we are dealing with a person with an heroic nature, who in classic tragic manner, falls because of that heroic nature.  As such, he is the only sinner in Hell, whose fate could be said to be tragic, i.e., not satisfactorily explained by the term Justice.  Ulysses fate seems not to be one of choice or will, but of nature.  We see him as someone to the manor born, as one would have a certain color of eyes or hair, he has it him to explore.  For that he is damned, but his damnation seems to have been a foregone conclusion.  He could not be the Ulysses the sinner, had he not been Ulysses the explorer, lover, husband, father, soldier.  His fame, his very identity rests upon his virtues in these roles, and it is these virtues that made his damnation inevitable.

No matter what you say or what you think your understand in Dante, there is always more.  That trick of poetic composition of developing a single metaphor, as we saw in Canto IV with the bird metaphor, is also employed here, as the metaphor of the flame evolves from that of fireflies in a field to the ascent of Elijah on his chariot of fire, and this leads us to  the question: Has Ulysses confused Natural splendor, with Divine splendor? — and are these two things, like the two Natures of Christ, connected by the Divine infusing Nature, or as in the Manichean heresies, does this world represent a dual aspect of the cosmos?, one Divine, the other merely accidental or even overtly evil.  One difference between Ulysses and Virgil's rhetoric and poetry respectively, is that their language is merely heroic, and will lead at best no further than a continuation of the heroic, or at worst, as is the case with both Ulysses and Virgil, since they have both ended their careers in Hell, to a circular repetition of that which leads from bland domesticity to destruction in a whirlwind.  But Dante's poetics cannot remain in this tradition.  And here we turn to Saint Augustine, as I feel certain Dante did, i.e. "the purpose of poetry is the promotion of charity to the end that God may be enjoyed.  His dictum on the true nature of eloquence: in words to love truth, not words.  Another way to put this, is that figures of poetry do not exist for their own sake, but for the sake of the reader's effort and sincerity of giving them meaning for the soul.  If in the beginning was the word, in the end, the word must be made flesh, and not just a description of flesh.  I think that Dante might have said that when we embody words, not just speak, write, or read them, we become what they are: A Creative Power.  For Dante, and Augustine, words must embody the Divine, or they are by definition false descriptions of illusory things.  

1  Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se' sì grande
2  che per mare e per terra batti l'ali,
3  e per lo 'nferno tuo nome si spande!
1  Rejoice, O Florence, since thou art so great,
2  That over sea and land thou beatest thy wings,
3  And throughout Hell thy name is spread abroad!
4  Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali
5  tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna,
6  e tu in grande orranza non ne sali.
4  Among the thieves five citizens of thine
5  Like these I found, whence shame comes unto me,
6  And thou thereby to no great honour risest.
7  Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna,
8  tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo,
9  di quel che Prato, non ch'altri, t'agogna.
7  But if when morn is near our dreams are true,
8  Feel shalt thou in a little time from now
9  What Prato, if none other, craves for thee.
10  E se già fosse, non saria per tempo.
11  Così foss' ei, da che pur esser dee!
12  ché più mi graverà, com' più m'attempo.
10  And if it now were, it were not too soon;
11  Would that it were, seeing it needs must be,
12  For 'twill aggrieve me more the more I age.
13  Noi ci partimmo, e su per le scalee
14  che n'avea fatto i borni a scender pria,
15  rimontò 'l duca mio e trasse mee;
13  We went our way, and up along the stairs
14  The bourns had made us to descend before,
15  Remounted my Conductor and drew me.
16  e proseguendo la solinga via,
17  tra le schegge e tra ' rocchi de lo scoglio
18  lo piè sanza la man non si spedia.
16  And following the solitary path
17  Among the rocks and ridges of the crag,
18  The foot without the hand sped not at all.
19  Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio
20  quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch'io vidi,
21  e più lo 'ngegno affreno ch'i' non soglio,
19  Then sorrowed I, and sorrow now again,
20  When I direct my mind to what I saw,
21  And more my genius curb than I am wont,
22  perché non corra che virtù nol guidi;
23  sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa
24  m'ha dato 'l ben, ch'io stessi nol m'invidi.

22  That it may run not unless virtue guide it;
23  So that if some good star, or better thing,
24  Have given me good, I may myself not grudge it.

25  Quante 'l villan ch'al poggio si riposa,
26  nel tempo che colui che 'l mondo schiara
27  la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
25  As many as the hind (who on the hill
26  Rests at the time when he who lights the world
27   His countenance keeps least concealed from us,
28  come la mosca cede a la zanzara,
29  vede lucciole giù per la vallea,
30  forse colà dov' e' vendemmia e ara:
28  While as the fly gives place unto the gnat)
29  Seeth the glow-worms down along the valley,
30  Perchance there where he ploughs and makes his vintage;
31  di tante fiamme tutta risplendea
32  l'ottava bolgia, sì com' io m'accorsi
33  tosto che fui là 've 'l fondo parea.
31  With flames as manifold resplendent all
32  Was the eighth Bolgia, as I grew aware
33  As soon as I was where the depth appeared.
34  E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi
35  vide 'l carro d'Elia al dipartire,
36  quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
34  And such as he who with the bears avenged him
35  Beheld Elijah's chariot at departing,
36  What time the steeds to heaven erect uprose,
37  che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire,
38  ch'el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola,
39  sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
37  For with his eye he could not follow it
38  So as to see aught else than flame alone,
39  Even as a little cloud ascending upward,
40  tal si move ciascuna per la gola
41  del fosso, ch nessuna mostra 'l furto,
42  e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola.
40  Thus each along the gorge of the intrenchment
41  Was moving; for not one reveals the theft,
42  And every flame a sinner steals away.
43  Io stava sovra 'l ponte a veder surto,
44  sì che s'io non avessi un ronchion preso,
45  caduto sarei giù sanz' esser urto.
43  I stood upon the bridge uprisen to see,
44  So that, if I had seized not on a rock,
45  Down had I fallen without being pushed.
46  E 'l duca, che mi vide tanto atteso,
47  disse: “Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti;
48  catun si fascia di quel ch'elli è inceso.”
46  And the Leader, who beheld me so attent,
47  Exclaimed: "Within the fires the spirits are;
48  Each swathes himself with that wherewith he burns."

49  “Maestro mio,” rispuos' io, “per udirti
50  son io più certo; ma già m'era avviso
51  che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
49  "My Master," I replied, "by hearing thee
50  I am more sure; but I surmised already
51  It might be so, and already wished to ask thee
52  chi è 'n quel foco che vien sì diviso
53  di sopra, che par surger de la pira
54  dov' Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?”
52  Who is within that fire, which comes so cleft
53  At top, it seems uprising from the pyre
54  Where was Eteocles with his brother placed."
55  Rispuose a me: “Là dentro si martira
56  Ulisse e Dïomede, e così insieme
57  a la vendetta vanno come a l'ira;
55  He answered me: "Within there are tormented
56  Ulysses and Diomed, and thus together
57  They unto vengeance run as unto wrath.
58  e dentro da la lor fiamma si geme
59  l'agguato del caval che fé la porta
60  onde uscì de' Romani il gentil seme.
58  And there within their flame do they lament
59  The ambush of the horse, which made the door
60  Whence issued forth the Romans' gentle seed;
61  Piangevisi entro l'arte per che, morta,
62  Deïdamìa ancor si duol d'Achille,
63  e del Palladio pena vi si porta.”
61  Therein is wept the craft, for which being dead
62  Deidamia still deplores Achilles,
63  And pain for the Palladium there is borne."
64  “S'ei posson dentro da quelle faville
65  parlar,” diss' io, “maestro, assai ten priego
66  e ripriego, che 'l priego vaglia mille,
64  "If they within those sparks possess the power
65  To speak," I said, "thee, Master, much I pray,
66  And re-pray, that the prayer be worth a thousand,
67  che non mi facci de l'attender niego
68  fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna;
69  vedi che del disio ver' lei mi piego!”
67  That thou make no denial of awaiting
68  Until the horned flame shall hither come;
69  Thou seest that with desire I lean towards it."
70  Ed elli a me: “La tua preghiera è degna
71  di molta loda, e io però l'accetto;
72  ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna.
70  And he to me: "Worthy is thy entreaty
71  Of much applause, and therefore I accept it;
72  But take heed that thy tongue restrain itself.
73  Lascia parlare a me, ch'i' ho concetto
74  ciò che tu vuoi; ch'ei sarebbero schivi,
75  perch' e' fuor greci, forse del tuo detto.”
73  Leave me to speak, because I have conceived
74  That which thou wishest; for they might disdain
75  Perchance, since they were Greeks, discourse of thine."
76  Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi
77  dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco,
78  in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
76  When now the flame had come unto that point,
77  Where to my Leader it seemed time and place,
78  After this fashion did I hear him speak:
79  “O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco,
80  s'io meritai di voi mentre ch'io vissi,
81  s'io meritai di voi assai o poco
79  "O ye, who are twofold within one fire,
80  If I deserved of you, while I was living,
81  If I deserved of you or much or little
82  quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi,
83  non vi movete; ma l'un di voi dica
84  dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi.”
82  When in the world I wrote the lofty verses,
83  Do not move on, but one of you declare
84  Whither, being lost, he went away to die."
85  Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica
86  cominciò a crollarsi mormorando,
87  pur come quella cui vento affatica;
85  Then of the antique flame the greater horn,
86  Murmuring, began to wave itself about
87  Even as a flame doth which the wind fatigues.
88  indi la cima qua e là menando,
89  come fosse la lingua che parlasse,
90  gittò voce di fuori e disse: “Quando
88  Thereafterward, the summit to and fro
89  Moving as if it were the tongue that spake,
90  It uttered forth a voice, and said: "When I
91  mi diparti' da Circe, che sottrasse
92  me più d'un anno là presso a Gaeta,
93  prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
91  From Circe had departed, who concealed me
92  More than a year there near unto Gaeta,
93  Or ever yet Aeneas named it so,
94  né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta
95  del vecchio padre, né 'l debito amore
96  lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
94  Nor fondness for my son, nor reverence
95  For my old father, nor the due affection
96  Which joyous should have made Penelope,
97  vincer potero dentro a me l'ardore
98  ch'i' ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto
99  e de li vizi umani e del valore;
97  Could overcome within me the desire
98  I had to be experienced of the world,
99  And of the vice and virtue of mankind;
100  ma misi me per l'alto mare aperto
101  sol con un legno e con quella compagna
102  picciola da la qual non fui diserto.
100  But I put forth on the high open sea
101  With one sole ship, and that small company
102  By which I never had deserted been.
103  L'un lito e l'altro vidi infin la Spagna,
104  fin nel Morrocco, e l'isola d'i Sardi,
105  e l'altre che quel mare intorno bagna.
103  Both of the shores I saw as far as Spain,
104  Far as Morocco, and the isle of Sardes,
105  And the others which that sea bathes round about.
106  Io e' compagni eravam vecchi e tardi
107  quando venimmo a quella foce stretta
108  dov' Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi
106  I and my company were old and slow
107  When at that narrow passage we arrived
108  Where Hercules his landmarks set as signals,
109  acció che l'uom più oltre non si metta;
110  da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia,
111  da l'altra già m'avea lasciata Setta.
109  That man no farther onward should adventure.
111  On the right hand behind me left I Seville,
111  And on the other already had left Ceuta.
112 'O frati,' dissi, 'che per cento milia
113  perigli siete giunti a l'occidente,
114  a questa tanto picciola vigilia
112  'O brothers, who amid a hundred thousand
113  Perils,' I said, 'have come unto the West,
114  To this so inconsiderable vigil
115  d'i nostri sensi ch'è del rimanente
116  non vogliate negar l'esperïenza,
117  di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente.
115  Which is remaining of your senses still
116  Be ye unwilling to deny the knowledge,
117  Following the sun, of the unpeopled world.
118  Considerate la vostra semenza:
119  fatti non foste a viver come bruti,
120  ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza.'
118  Consider ye the seed from which ye sprang;
119  Ye were not made to live like unto brutes,
120  But for pursuit of virtue and of knowledge.'
121  Li miei compagni fec' io sì aguti,
122  con questa orazion picciola, al cammino,
123  che a pena poscia li avrei ritenuti;
121  So eager did I render my companions,
122  With this brief exhortation, for the voyage,
123  That then I hardly could have held them back.
124  e volta nostra poppa nel mattino,
125  de' remi facemmo ali al folle volo,
126  sempre acquistando dal lato mancino.
124  And having turned our stern unto the morning,
125  We of the oars made wings for our mad flight,
126  Evermore gaining on the larboard side.
127  Tutte le stelle già de l'altro polo
128  vedea la notte, e 'l nostro tanto basso,
129  che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo.
127  Already all the stars of the other pole
128  The night beheld, and ours so very low
129  It did not rise above the ocean floor.
130  Cinque volte racceso e tante casso
131  lo lume era di sotto da la luna,
132  poi che 'ntrati eravam ne l'alto passo,
130  Five times rekindled and as many quenched
131  Had been the splendour underneath the moon,
132  Since we had entered into the deep pass,
133  quando n'apparve una montagna, bruna
134  per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto
135  quanto veduta non avëa alcuna.
133  When there appeared to us a mountain, dim
134  From distance, and it seemed to me so high
135  As I had never any one beheld.
136  Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto;
137  ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque
138  e percosse del legno il primo canto.
136  Joyful were we, and soon it turned to weeping;
137  For out of the new land a whirlwind rose,
138  And smote upon the fore part of the ship.
139  Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l'acque;
140  a la quarta levar la poppa in suso
141  e la prora ire in giù, com' altrui piacque,
139  Three times it made her whirl with all the waters,
140  At the fourth time it made the stern uplift,
141  And the prow downward go, as pleased Another,
142  infin che 'l mar fu sovra noi richiuso.”
142  Until the sea above us closed again."
Canto XXVII
Both Cantos XXVI and XXVII are engrossed with the issue of  "fraudulent councilor’s", who speaks to whom and in what "accent" seems to be almost for the purpose of discovering the speakers' places of origin.  What language one speaks or how and to whom one speaks seems to rely on a territorial sense of identity.  As sometimes, even now, Nationalists will become enraged when hearing a citizen or a foreigner in "their" land speaking in another language, thus us and them, friend or enemy, are derived from how one speaks.  That is to say: does your speech identify the place your coming from: Hell, Purgatory, or Heaven.  It is as if the word 'accent" is like an animal's marking of its territory by urinating and leaving a warning scent-sign to ward off rivals.  Who I am, where I first learned my name, where I learned the art — like Adam — of naming, gives me my sense of self, which is why exile is so damning.  (You see this in Proust too who devotes a great deal of thought to establishing the etymologies of words through place names, and in Vico, the very origins of mankind can be determined by recourse to etymologies).  The sinner spoken to in Canto XXVII is Guido da (from) Montefeltro, and the speaker, as have many speakers throughout the poem, identifies himself by conflating speech acts, identity, and place of origin.  An enemy Other betrays himself by an act of speech.  This I believe is why Ulysses and Guido are placed so deeply in Hell, because they not only have betrayed their fellows by corrupting the speech act, and using speech itself as a weapon, they have betrayed the very principle of what it means to be human, and to have a soul that may perpetuate itself, even in the afterlife, through the endurance of words and their imperishable fame.  Perhaps this also explains why the protagonists, both poets, are not enraged at these sinners, because in a strange way, a liar, a false councilor, honors language by realizing, just as poets do, its awesome power.  It's very telling, I believe, that this Canto opens with the image of the Sicilian Bull, a torture device, in which a hollow brass bull coffins its victim, and when heated, emits the victim's inarticulate cries.  Telling too, that this clever device's first victim is its creator.  It's fitting too, that the victim, as in this case Guido, speaks from torturing flames, his voice given over to a kind of mechanical animal, whose purpose is to torture and deceive.  Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven, as poetically conceived by Dante, are places created by speech acts (Just as Saint John says when he writes "In the beginning was the Word."), and the test of those speech acts, their ultimate truth or falseness, seems not to lie in whether or not their signs are an accurate representation of something that exists or that happens in the world, but rather the effects they affect in the world.  Do they cause pain?  Do they unify?  Do they bring peace or bloodshed?  In brief, do they bless or damn, the very two keys that Pope Boniface VIII used to compel even his enemies to serve him.  These "cloven fictions", as Blake would call them, are what make and balance or unbalance the scales of justice.  We know, that in Hell, the speakers continue to deceive, first themselves, then others, and so their damnation continues.  They have spoken words that condemn and they are condemned, exiled from themselves and from heaven, their tongues, in a parody of the Pentecostal tongues of flame, become only the purveyors of theirs and other's torture.  The question for Dante, the poet, and why he so often insists that everything he writes or speaks about this fantastic journey is the truth, is how can he make the speech act, not only an instrument of justice, but a vehicle, like Elijah's, in which the speaker and his listeners can ascend to bliss?

I have this question: Is a secret, that is, a truth unspoken, the same as a lie?  Guido says "no."  Silence, he decides, is worse than a lie.  But Guido is in Hell, and his blaming self-serving speech, is what damns him.  Are we to assume that his words are Bull ‚ Sicilian Bull that is, which would be better left unspoken, or in this case, spoken only under the false assumption that his listener will never be able to repeat them to anyone still living.  We all have secrets, those things we keep from others about them or ourselves, and if my reasoning is just here, are we not better off tactfully observing silence, no matter what the consequences, if our speech would do harm?  This question must remain an open one, determined, not as some absolute, but as a constant struggle to ascertain the difference between serving one's self and serving others — or even coming to the realization that Self and Other are unified in the same enigma.  Speech is born from silence and returns there, but it's journey seems always to be traversing a landscape fraught with the questons of: Who is it that is harmed are helped? what is their accent? where are they coming from, and where are they going?
           
1  Già era dritta in sù la fiamma e queta
2  per non dir più, e già da noi sen gia
3  con la licenza del dolce poeta,

1  Already was the flame erect and quiet,
2  To speak no more, and now departed from us
3  With the permission of the gentle Poet;

4  quand' un'altra, che dietro a lei venìa,
5  ne fece volger li occhi a la sua cima
6  per un confuso suon che fuor n'uscia.

4  When yet another, which behind it came,
5  Caused us to turn our eyes upon its top
6  By a confused sound that issued from it.

7  Come 'l bue cicilian che mugghiò prima
8  col pianto di colui, e ciò fu dritto,
9  che l'avea temperato con sua lima,

7  As the Sicilian bull (that bellowed first
8  With the lament of him, and that was right,
9  Who with his file had modulated it)

10  mugghiava con la voce de l'afflitto,
11  sì che, con tutto che fosse di rame,
12  pur el pareva dal dolor trafitto;

10  Bellowed so with the voice of the afflicted,
11  That, notwithstanding it was made of brass,
12  Still it appeared with agony transfixed; 

13  così, per non aver via né forame
14  dal principio nel foco, in suo linguaggio
15  si convertïan le parole grame.

13  Thus, by not having any way or issue
14  At first from out the fire, to its own language
15  Converted were the melancholy words.

16  Ma poscia ch'ebber colto lor vïaggio
17  su per la punta, dandole quel guizzo
18  che dato avea la lingua in lor passaggio,

16  But afterwards, when they had gathered way
17  Up through the point, giving it that vibration
18  The tongue had given them in their passage out,

19  udimmo dire: “O tu a cu' io drizzo
20  la voce e che parlavi mo lombardo,
21  dicendo 'Istra ten va, più non t'adizzo'

19  We heard it said: "O thou, at whom I aim
20  My voice, and who but now wast speaking Lombard,
21  Saying, 'Now go thy way, no more I urge thee,'

22  perch' io sia giunto forse alquanto tardo,
23  non t'incresca restare a parlar meco;
24  vedi che non incresce a me, e ardo!

22  Because I come perchance a little late,
23  To stay and speak with me let it not irk thee;
24  Thou seest it irks not me, and I am burning.

25  Se tu pur mo in questo mondo cieco
26  caduto se' di quella dolce terra
27  latina ond' io mia colpa tutta reco,

25  If thou but lately into this blind world
26  Hast fallen down from that sweet Latian land,
27  Wherefrom I bring the whole of my transgression,

28  dimmi se Romagnuoli han pace o guerra;
29  ch'io fui d'i monti là intra Orbino
30  e 'l giogo di che Tever si diserra.”

28  Say, if the Romagnuols have peace or war,
29  For I was from the mountains there between
30  Urbino and the yoke whence Tiber bursts."

31  Io era in giuso ancora attento e chino,
32  quando il mio duca mi tentò di costa,
33  dicendo: “Parla tu; questi è latino.”

31  I still was downward bent and listening,
32  When my Conductor touched me on the side,
33  Saying: "Speak thou: this one a Latian is."

34  E io, ch'avea già pronta la risposta,
35  sanza indugio a parlare incominciai:
36  “O anima che se' là giù nascosta,

34  And I, who had beforehand my reply
35  In readiness, forthwith began to speak:
36  "O soul, that down below there art concealed,

37  Romagna tua non è, e non fu mai,
38  sanza guerra ne' cuor de' suoi tiranni;
39  ma 'n palese nessuna or vi lasciai.

37  Romagna thine is not and never has been
38  Without war in the bosom of its tyrants;
39  But open war I none have left there now.

40  Ravenna sta come stata è molt' anni:
41  l'aguglia da Polenta la si cova,
42  sì che Cervia ricuopre co' suoi vanni.

40  Ravenna stands as it long years has stood;
41  The Eagle of Polenta there is brooding,
42  So that she covers Cervia with her vans.

43  La terra che fé già la lunga prova
44  e di Franceschi sanguinoso mucchio,
45  sotto le branche verdi si ritrova.

43  The city which once made the long resistance,
44  And of the French a sanguinary heap,
45  Beneath the Green Paws finds itself again;

46  E 'l mastin vecchio e 'l nuovo da Verrucchio,
47  che fecer di Montagna il mal governo,
48  là dove soglion fan d'i denti succhio.

46  Verrucchio's ancient Mastiff and the new,
47  Who made such bad disposal of Montagna,
48  Where they are wont make wimbles of their teeth.

49  Le città di Lamone e di Santerno
50  conduce il lïoncel dal nido bianco,
51  che muta parte da la state al verno.

49  The cities of Lamone and Santerno
50  Governs the Lioncel of the white lair,
51  Who changes sides 'twixt summer-time and winter;

52  E quella cu' il Savio bagna il fianco,
53  così com' ella sie' tra 'l piano e 'l monte,
54  tra tirannia si vive e stato franco.

52  And that of which the Savio bathes the flank,
53  Even as it lies between the plain and mountain,
54  Lives between tyranny and a free state.

55  Ora chi se', ti priego che ne conte;
56  non esser duro più ch'altri sia stato,
57  se 'l nome tuo nel mondo tegna fronte.”

55  Now I entreat thee tell us who thou art;
56  Be not more stubborn than the rest have been,
57  So may thy name hold front there in the world."

58  Poscia che 'l foco alquanto ebbe rugghiato
59  al modo suo, l'aguta punta mosse
60  di qua, di là, e poi diè cotal fiato:

58  After the fire a little more had roared
59  In its own fashion, the sharp point it moved
60  This way and that, and then gave forth such breath:

61  “S'i' credesse che mia risposta fosse
62  a persona che mai tornasse al mondo,
63  questa fiamma staria sanza più scosse;

61  "If I believed that my reply were made
62  To one who to the world would e'er return,
63  This flame without more flickering would stand still;

64  ma però che già mai di questo fondo
65  non tornò vivo alcun, s'i' odo il vero,
66  sanza tema d'infamia ti rispondo.

64  But inasmuch as never from this depth
65  Did any one return, if I hear true,
66  Without the fear of infamy I answer,

67  Io fui uom d'arme, e poi fui cordigliero,
68  credendomi, sì cinto, fare ammenda;
69  e certo il creder mio venìa intero,

67  I was a man of arms, then Cordelier,
68  Believing thus begirt to make amends;
69  And truly my belief had been fulfilled

70  se non fosse il gran prete, a cui mal prenda!,
71  che mi rimise ne le prime colpe;
72  e come e quare, voglio che m'intenda.

70  But for the High Priest, whom may ill betide,
71  Who put me back into my former sins;
72  And how and wherefore I will have thee hear.

73  Mentre ch'io forma fui d'ossa e di polpe
74  che la madre mi diè, l'opere mie
75  non furon leonine, ma di volpe.

73  While I was still the form of bone and pulp
74  My mother gave to me, the deeds I did
75  Were not those of a lion, but a fox.

76  Li accorgimenti e le coperte vie
77  io seppi tutte, e sì menai lor arte,
78  ch'al fine de la terra il suono uscie.

76  The machinations and the covert ways
77  I knew them all, and practised so their craft,
78  That to the ends of earth the sound went forth.

79  Quando mi vidi giunto in quella parte
80  di mia etade ove ciascun dovrebbe
81  calar le vele e raccoglier le sarte,

79  When now unto that portion of mine age
80  I saw myself arrived, when each one ought
81  To lower the sails, and coil away the ropes,

82  ciò che pria mi piacëa, allor m'increbbe,
83  e pentuto e confesso mi rendei;
84  ahi miser lasso! e giovato sarebbe.

82  That which before had pleased me then displeased me;
83  And penitent and confessing I surrendered,
84  Ah woe is me! and it would have bestead me;

85  Lo principe d'i novi Farisei,
86  avendo guerra presso a Laterano,
87  e non con Saracin né con Giudei,

85  The Leader of the modern Pharisees
86  Having a war near unto Lateran,
87  And not with Saracens nor with the Jews,

88  ché ciascun suo nimico era cristiano,
89  e nessun era stato a vincer Acri
90  né mercatante in terra di Soldano,

88  For each one of his enemies was Christian,
89  And none of them had been to conquer Acre,
90  Nor merchandising in the Sultan's land,

91  né sommo officio né ordini sacri
92  guardò in sé, né in me quel capestro
93  che solea fare i suoi cinti più macri.
91  Nor the high office, nor the sacred orders,
92  In him regarded, nor in me that cord
93  Which used to make those girt with it more meagre;

94  Ma come Costantin chiese Silvestro
95  d'entro Siratti a guerir de la lebbre,
96  così mi chiese questi per maestro

94  But even as Constantine sought out Sylvester
95  To cure his leprosy, within Soracte,
96  So this one sought me out as an adept

97  a guerir de la sua superba febbre;
98  domandommi consiglio, e io tacetti
99  perché le sue parole parver ebbre.

97  To cure him of the fever of his pride.
98  Counsel he asked of me, and I was silent,
99  Because his words appeared inebriate.

100  E' poi ridisse: 'Tuo cuor non sospetti;
101  finor t'assolvo, e tu m'insegna fare
102  sì come Penestrino in terra getti.

100  And then he said: 'Be not thy heart afraid;
101  Henceforth I thee absolve; and thou instruct me
102  How to raze Palestrina to the ground.

103  Lo ciel poss' io serrare e diserrare,
104  come tu sai; però son due le chiavi
105  che 'l mio antecessor non ebbe care.'

103  Heaven have I power to lock and to unlock,
104  As thou dost know; therefore the keys are two,
105  The which my predecessor held not dear.'

106  Allor mi pinser li argomenti gravi
107  là 've 'l tacer mi fu avviso 'l peggio,
108  e dissi: 'Padre, da che tu mi lavi

106  Then urged me on his weighty arguments
107  There, where my silence was the worst advice;
108  And said I: 'Father, since thou washest me

109  di quel peccato ov' io mo cader deggio,
110  lunga promessa con l'attender corto
111  ti farà trïunfar ne l'alto seggio.'

109  Of that sin into which I now must fall,
110  The promise long with the fulfilment short
111  Will make thee triumph in thy lofty seat.'

112  Francesco venne poi, com' io fu' morto,
113  per me; ma un d'i neri cherubini
114  li disse: 'Non portar; non mi far torto.

112  Francis came afterward, when I was dead,
113  For me; but one of the black Cherubim
114  Said to him: 'Take him not; do me no wrong;

115  Venir se ne dee giù tra ' miei meschini
116  perché diede 'l consiglio frodolente,
117  dal quale in qua stato li sono a' crini;

115  He must come down among my servitors,
116  Because he gave the fraudulent advice
117  From which time forth I have been at his hair;

118  ch'assolver non si può chi non si pente,
119  né pentere e volere insieme puossi
120  per la contradizion che nol consente.'

118  For who repents not cannot be absolved,
119  Nor can one both repent and will at once,
120  Because of the contradiction which consents not.'

121  Oh me dolente! come mi riscossi
122  quando mi prese dicendomi: 'Forse
123  tu non pensavi ch'io löico fossi!'

121  O miserable me! how I did shudder
122  When he seized on me, saying: 'Peradventure
123  Thou didst not think that I was a logician!'

124  A Minòs mi portò; e quelli attorse
125  otto volte la coda al dosso duro;
126  e poi che per gran rabbia la si morse,

124  He bore me unto Minos, who entwined
125  Eight times his tail about his stubborn back,
126  And after he had bitten it in great rage,

127  disse: 'Questi è d'i rei del foco furo';
128  per ch'io là dove vedi son perduto,
129  e sì vestito, andando, mi rancuro.”

127  Said: 'Of the thievish fire a culprit this;'
128  Wherefore, here where thou seest, am I lost,
129  And vested thus in going I bemoan me."

130  Quand' elli ebbe 'l suo dir così compiuto,
131  la fiamma dolorando si partio,
132  torcendo e dibattendo 'l corno aguto.

130  When it had thus completed its recital,
131  The flame departed uttering lamentations,
132  Writhing and flapping its sharp-pointed horn.

133  Noi passamm' oltre, e io e 'l duca mio,
134  su per lo scoglio infino in su l'altr' arco
135  che cuopre 'l fosso in che si paga il fio

133  Onward we passed, both I and my Conductor,
134  Up o'er the crag above another arch,
135  Which the moat covers, where is paid the fee

136  a quei che scommettendo acquistan carco.

136  By those who, sowing discord, win their burden.

Canto XXVII
The horror of viewing human bodies mutilated by stabbing, piercing, and slicing instruments, the horror of the innards suddenly exposed by violence, and the harmony of the human form converted into mucilage — something Dante would have known as a consequence of his military experience — that is how Canto XXVIII begins, and the first couple of stanzas show a revulsion that is literally, as Dante makes clear, unspeakable.  Like a heart surgeon, cutting into a chest, cracking the ribs apart, a sinner appears, sliced from chin to anus, entrails dangling between his legs, who, with his own cruel hands, rends his own chest, exposing his beating heart.  The simile here is that of a wine casque, losing its structural integrity, bursting, and spilling its liquid: a liquification, a complete dissolution of the human form into a kind of fluid and ubiquitous agony, no part free from the torment of perpetual rending.  This is the condition of one of the multitudes of sinners who first presents himself to Virgil and the aspirant.  He is Mohammed and it is Ali who stands near him.  Thus he reveals that he was a schismatic, a sower of discord, a man whose speech and actions led to a rending of the body-politic and to the anatomization of his human form.  

I think that it's clear from the opening lines of this canto that Dante is using the most vulgar language to illuminate the grotesque nature of violence, the grotesque nature of any language that incites discord and violence ... and yet, there is something else too, something subtler and weirder.  We see here the way that art can assume a kind of metaposition above this discord.  It can in fact use the language of discord to transcend discord.  It does not incite, it illuminates.  People kill each other from disputes in religious doctrine and political rhetoric, but art seems to be able to incite the passions without recourse to violence.  In brief, the extreme positions of art lead to ineffability, not to murder.  We also see here, as we have seen throughout the poem, this circular shape — the tormented trudging in an endless round of healing and rending, a geometric metaphor that illustrates the retributive nature of violence.  Violent speech acts begetting violent acts in an endless round of war, exhausted interregnums, and resumption of war.  That is the nature of the schismatic, he believes that he can heal the split in his own psyche by destroying one half of his own nature, by shattering his own integrity, and becoming the devil whom he believes his enemy to be.  His very healing is only the recovery of his own demonic self, rising again to revenge its injuries.  We learn all this before we come to line 43, wherein we must tackle once again the divisive nature of identity itself in the Hell of a conflicted psyche.  Dante is always taking us deeper and deeper into this question: Who am I?  And why are the many selves that constitute me, so often inimical to one another?

At this point in the canto, Virgil identifies himself as one of the dead, and as readers, we begin to glimpse a characteristic conservativism that infects all those fomenting internal and external hells — they are fixed in their own rounds of rigid beliefs, and this damnation has engulfed Virgil too, by the very nature of his paganism, his adherence to reason, which cannot possibly pacify his inner world of multiple conflicting gods, paganism being at bottom the deification of parts which prevent the pagan from ever glimpsing the marvelous harmony of the whole.  The sequence of cause and effect, premise and conclusion, will always be linear and circular, it can never be global.  But for the living body, the living psyche, life is never linear, circularly repetitive, or piecemeal.  It is always a whole participating in a greater wholeness, and at line 52, Dante has a marvelous image of the damned staring in wonder at a living being, as if they think it is impossible for such dynamic integrity to even exist.  The perpetual learner, the perpetual poet, the perpetual aspirant is the very antithesis of who they are, and yet he does not appear as another devil to rend them.  Dante, the aspirant, is a wonder to those who have decided their own fate by having falsely decided their own beliefs about fate.  Here, as elsewhere, the reader is confronted with a choice: To judge or to learn.  To say, "yes, I like this, or no, this is no good for me" — or to release that dichotomy and submerse oneself in the experience of art.  The poem can express pain, show the experience of pain, without being either pain's source or manifestation.   And there is a moment here, in which the sinners too forget their agony, as they are lost in wonder.  How marvelous!  How simply marvelous, how Dante, by this simple stroke, shows the healing and transforming power of the artist, the living person among armies of the dead.

Now comes the great moment of the suspended foot.  A moment in which Mohammed, having committed the beneficent act of asking Dante to warn Fra Dolcino against this fate, could choose to go another way.  Here is a hovering in uncertainty, in which Mohammed might choose to be someone other than the Mohammed of schismatics.  He might connect to a global field of compassion.  But that moment passes.  Why?  Because the delusion of a separate and separating identity is by its very nature an obsession.   Thus, obsessively, Mohammed continues being whom he believes himself to be.  With the certainty of gravitation, he moves on to continue his rounds of incessant torment.  This is grotesque, and immediately the poem returns us to the grotesque, as another horribly mutilated sinner presents himself.

Now we encounter Pier da Medicina, mutilated so that he may only speak through his windpipe, without a nose to sniff out falsehood, a man whose schismatic acts are political, it seems, rather than, religious — and an exemplar of what it means to be exposed.  For in Hell the mask of deceit is ripped or sliced off, and the ugly, red guts of disfigurement are revealed.  It seems the Dante is telling us that no matter how much we try to hide our splintered self, our speech and our acts will always expose us, and the placid exterior will always be hacked away to reveal the grotesque: chaotic, painful, repulsive to be or to see.  Pier's words are the words of an exile, an exile from life and also from his native land, and because he is linked to Dante by their language, language too is shown to be the ultimate homeland.  Ironically, as Dante, the poet, is discovering, the only homeland Dante, himself to be an exile from his native Florence, will ever know again.  In a parallel construction, Pier too implores Dante to warn those among the living, but his warning does not damn those of whom he speaks, but those who betrayed and drowned them — a crime which appalls nature itself, as the entire Mediterranean Sea (Neptune/Nattuno) has never witnessed so great a betrayal.  The fact that the sinner foresees that the victims will be drowned is telling, because evil, when it is pervasive in the culture, inundates the innocent too in an ocean of collateral damage.  The sea can be an emblem of dissolution and chaos, and it can have a roiling inner turbulence like that of the sinner.

The canto continues with parallel examples from both the ancient world and from Dante's contemporaries of false council, and the betrayal of speech itself (remember: the ultimate homeland), and its dismembering consequences.  The aspirant Dante's persistent questioning here and throughout the Commedia, until the very end, show him to be one who lives, because he continues to inquire, even into the conditions of Hell.  He does not repress his trauma, he examines it, and he even uses the damned as his teachers, just as he uses Virgil.  If Hell is a place of war, Purgatory a place of learning, and Paradise a place of transcendence, then Dante, even in Hell can never be truly among the company of the damned, because he is always, at the very least, in a learning mode, and to question, as every small child knows who asks why? why? why? is to engage, to enter the very mystery of the self, no matter how grotesquely the self is presenting in the moment.

The descriptions of the sinners which follows are particularly gruesome, and they reveal an even more fundamental language, the language of being — every act, every muscle, even our clothing exposes us to the penetrating gaze of an open and curious witness.  The true aspirant is like child in these matters, he sees through social conditioning and disguise to what truly is.  And as is the case here, he can read the difference between wholeness and mutilation, between beneficent truth and deceiving and self-deceiving rancor.  Line 111 puts it succinctly.  The essence of self-deception and self-aggrandizement at the expense of others is sadness and insanity.

The canto concludes with the most grotesque vision of all, that of Bertran de Born, who fomented the rebellion of Prince Harry against his father, King Henry II.  Bertran apparently loved the desolation of cities and towns by war, and he is condemned to carry, like a benighted lantern, his own head in his hands, and it is through his decapitated head that he speaks his self-pitying laments.  If we allow our thoughts and beliefs to betray the integrity of the body, the body of faith, or the body-politic, we are condemned perpetually to suffer the very schism of this grotesque perversion.  Apparently Bertran perceives in his condition, how his own monstrous misperceptions fractally repeated themselves in the culture at large.  He is both cause and effect, this and that, two in one, and one in two.  And Dante points out the mystery of this condition in a language that leaves it to the transcendent self to illuminate.             

1  Chi poria mai pur con parole sciolte
2  dicer del sangue e de le piaghe a pieno
3  ch'i' ora vidi, per narrar più volte?

1  Who ever could, e'en with untrammelled words,
2  Tell of the blood and of the wounds in full
3  Which now I saw, by many times narrating?

4  Ogne lingua per certo verria meno
5  per lo nostro sermone e per la mente
6  c'hanno a tanto comprender poco seno.

4  Each tongue would for a certainty fall short
5  By reason of our speech and memory,
6  That have small room to comprehend so much.

7  S'el s'aunasse ancor tutta la gente
8  che già, in su la fortunata terra
9  di Puglia, fu del suo sangue dolente

7  If were again assembled all the people
8  Which formerly upon the fateful land
9  Of Puglia were lamenting for their blood

10  per li Troiani e per la lunga guerra
11  che de l'anella fé sì alte spoglie,
12  come Livïo scrive, che non erra,

10  Shed by the Romans and the lingering war
11  That of the rings made such illustrious spoils,
12  As Livy has recorded, who errs not,

13  con quella che sentio di colpi doglie
14  per contastare a Ruberto Guiscardo;
15  e l'altra il cui ossame ancor s'accoglie

13  With those who felt the agony of blows
14  By making counterstand to Robert Guiscard,
15  And all the rest, whose bones are gathered still

16  a Ceperan, là dove fu bugiardo
17  ciascun Pugliese, e là da Tagliacozzo,
18  dove sanz' arme vinse il vecchio Alardo;

16  At Ceperano, where a renegade
17  Was each Apulian, and at Tagliacozzo,
18  Where without arms the old Alardo conquered,

19  e qual forato suo membro e qual mozzo
20  mostrasse, d'aequar sarebbe nulla
21  il modo de la nona bolgia sozzo.

19  And one his limb transpierced, and one lopped off,
20  Should show, it would be nothing to compare
21  With the disgusting mode of the ninth Bolgia.

22  Già veggia, per mezzul perdere o lulla,
23  com' io vidi un, così non si pertugia,
24  rotto dal mento infin dove si trulla.

22  A cask by losing centre-piece or cant
23  Was never shattered so, as I saw one
24  Rent from the chin to where one breaketh wind.

25  Tra le gambe pendevan le minugia;
26  la corata pareva e 'l tristo sacco
27  che merda fa di quel che si trangugia.

25  Between his legs were hanging down his entrails;
26  His heart was visible, and the dismal sack
27  That maketh excrement of what is eaten.

28  Mentre che tutto in lui veder m'attacco,
29  guardommi e con le man s'aperse il petto,
30  dicendo: “Or vedi com' io mi dilacco!

28  While I was all absorbed in seeing him,
29  He looked at me, and opened with his hands
30  His bosom, saying: "See now how I rend me;

31  vedi come storpiato è Mäometto!
32  Dinanzi a me sen va piangendo Alì,
33  fesso nel volto dal mento al ciuffetto.

31  How mutilated, see, is Mahomet;
32  In front of me doth Ali weeping go,
33  Cleft in the face from forelock unto chin;

34  E tutti li altri che tu vedi qui,
35  seminator di scandalo e di scisma
36  fuor vivi, e però son fessi così.

34  And all the others whom thou here beholdest,
35  Disseminators of scandal and of schism
36  While living were, and therefore are cleft thus.

37  Un diavolo è qua dietro che n'accisma
38  sì crudelmente, al taglio de la spada
39  rimettendo ciascun di questa risma,

37  A devil is behind here, who doth cleave us
38  Thus cruelly, unto the falchion's edge
39  Putting again each one of all this ream,

40  quand' avem volta la dolente strada;
41  però che le ferite son richiuse
42  prima ch'altri dinanzi li rivada.

40  When we have gone around the doleful road;
41  By reason that our wounds are closed again
42  Ere any one in front of him repass.

43  Ma tu chi se' che 'n su lo scoglio muse,
44  forse per indugiar d'ire a la pena
45  ch'è giudicata in su le tue accuse?”

43  But who art thou, that musest on the crag,
44  Perchance to postpone going to the pain
45  That is adjudged upon thine accusations?"

46  “Né morte 'l giunse ancor, né colpa 'l mena,”
47  rispuose 'l mio maestro, “a tormentarlo;
48  ma per dar lui esperïenza piena,

46  "Nor death hath reached him yet, nor guilt doth bring him,"
47  My Master made reply, "to be tormented;
48  But to procure him full experience,

49  a me, che morto son, convien menarlo
50  per lo 'nferno qua giù di giro in giro;
51  e quest' è ver così com' io ti parlo.”

49  Me, who am dead, behoves it to conduct him
50  Down here through Hell, from circle unto circle;
51  And this is true as that I speak to thee."

52  Più fuor di cento che, quando l'udiro,
53  s'arrestaron nel fosso a riguardarmi
54  per maraviglia, oblïando il martiro.

52  More than a hundred were there when they heard him,
53  Who in the moat stood still to look at me,
54  Through wonderment oblivious of their torture.

55  “Or dì a fra Dolcin dunque che s'armi,
56  tu che forse vedra' il sole in breve,
57  s'ello non vuol qui tosto seguitarmi,

55  "Now say to Fra Dolcino, then, to arm him,
56  Thou, who perhaps wilt shortly see the sun,
57  If soon he wish not here to follow me,

58  sì di vivanda, che stretta di neve
59  non rechi la vittoria al Noarese,
60  ch'altrimenti acquistar non saria leve.”

58  So with provisions, that no stress of snow
59  May give the victory to the Novarese,
60  Which otherwise to gain would not be easy."

61  Poi che l'un piè per girsene sospese,
62  Mäometto mi disse esta parola;
63  indi a partirsi in terra lo distese.

61  After one foot to go away he lifted,
62  This word did Mahomet say unto me,
63  Then to depart upon the ground he stretched it.

64  Un altro, che forata avea la gola
65  e tronco 'l naso infin sotto le ciglia,
66  e non avea mai ch'una orecchia sola,

64  Another one, who had his throat pierced through,
65  And nose cut off close underneath the brows,
66  And had no longer but a single ear,

67  ristato a riguardar per maraviglia
68  con li altri, innanzi a li altri aprì la canna,
69  ch'era di fuor d'ogne parte vermiglia,

67  Staying to look in wonder with the others,
68  Before the others did his gullet open,
69  Which outwardly was red in every part,

70  e disse: “O tu cui colpa non condanna
71  e cu' io vidi in su terra latina,
72  se troppa simiglianza non m'inganna,

70  And said: "O thou, whom guilt doth not condemn,
71  And whom I once saw up in Latian land,
72  Unless too great similitude deceive me,

73  rimembriti di Pier da Medicina,
74  se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano
75  che da Vercelli a Marcabò dichina.

73  Call to remembrance Pier da Medicina,
74  If e'er thou see again the lovely plain
75  That from Vercelli slopes to Marcabo,

76  E fa sapere a' due miglior da Fano,
77  a messer Guido e anco ad Angiolello,
78  che, se l'antiveder qui non è vano,

76  And make it known to the best two of Fano,
77  To Messer Guido and Angiolello likewise,
78  That if foreseeing here be not in vain,

79  gittati saran fuor di lor vasello
80  e mazzerati presso a la Cattolica
81  per tradimento d'un tiranno fello.

79  Cast over from their vessel shall they be,
80  And drowned near unto the Cattolica,
81  By the betrayal of a tyrant fell.

82  Tra l'isola di Cipri e di Maiolica
83  non vide mai sì gran fallo Nettuno,
84  non da pirate, non da gente argolica.

82  Between the isles of Cyprus and Majorca
83  Neptune ne'er yet beheld so great a crime,
84  Neither of pirates nor Argolic people.

85  Quel traditor che vede pur con l'uno,
86  e tien la terra che tale qui meco
87  vorrebbe di vedere esser digiuno,

85  That traitor, who sees only with one eye,
86  And holds the land, which some one here with me
87  Would fain be fasting from the vision of,

88  farà venirli a parlamento seco;
89  poi farà sì, ch'al vento di Focara
90  non sarà lor mestier voto né preco.”

88  Will make them come unto a parley with him;
89  Then will do so, that to Focara's wind
90  They will not stand in need of vow or prayer."

91  E io a lui: “Dimostrami e dichiara,
92  se vuo' ch'i' porti sù di te novella,
93  chi è colui da la veduta amara.”

91  And I to him: "Show to me and declare,
92  If thou wouldst have me bear up news of thee,
93  Who is this person of the bitter vision."

94  Allor puose la mano a la mascella
95  d'un suo compagno e la bocca li aperse,
96  gridando: “Questi è desso, e non favella.

94  Then did he lay his hand upon the jaw
95  Of one of his companions, and his mouth
96  Oped, crying: "This is he, and he speaks not.

97  Questi, scacciato, il dubitar sommerse
98  in Cesare, affermando che 'l fornito
99  sempre con danno l'attender sofferse.”

97  This one, being banished, every doubt submerged
98  In Caesar by affirming the forearmed
99  Always with detriment allowed delay."

100  Oh quanto mi pareva sbigottito
101  con la lingua tagliata ne la strozza
102  Curïo, ch'a dir fu così ardito!

100  O how bewildered unto me appeared,
101  With tongue asunder in his windpipe slit,
102  Curio, who in speaking was so bold!

103  E un ch'avea l'una e l'altra man mozza,
104  levando i moncherin per l'aura fosca,
105  sì che 'l sangue facea la faccia sozza,

103  And one, who both his hands dissevered had,
104  The stumps uplifting through the murky air,
105  So that the blood made horrible his face,

106  gridò: “Ricordera'ti anche del Mosca,
107  che disse, lasso! 'Capo ha cosa fatta,'
108  che fu mal seme per la gente tosca.”

106  Cried out: "Thou shalt remember Mosca also,
107  Who said, alas! 'A thing done has an end!'
108  Which was an ill seed for the Tuscan people."

109  E io li aggiunsi: “E morte di tua schiatta”;
110  per ch'elli, accumulando duol con duolo,
111  sen gio come persona trista e matta.

109  "And death unto thy race," thereto I added;
110  Whence he, accumulating woe on woe,
111  Departed, like a person sad and crazed.

112  Ma io rimasi a riguardar lo stuolo,
113  e vidi cosa ch'io avrei paura,
114  sanza più prova, di contarla solo;

112  But I remained to look upon the crowd;
113  And saw a thing which I should be afraid,
114  Without some further proof, even to recount,

115  se non che coscïenza m'assicura,
116  la buona compagnia che l'uom francheggia
117  sotto l'asbergo del sentirsi pura.

115  If it were not that conscience reassures me,
116  That good companion which emboldens man
117  Beneath the hauberk of its feeling pure.

118  Io vidi certo, e ancor par ch'io 'l veggia,
119  un busto sanza capo andar sì come
120  andavan li altri de la trista greggia;

118  I truly saw, and still I seem to see it,
119  A trunk without a head walk in like manner
120  As walked the others of the mournful herd.

121  e 'l capo tronco tenea per le chiome,
122  pesol con mano a guisa di lanterna:
123  e quel mirava noi e dicea: “Oh me!”

121  And by the hair it held the head dissevered,
122  Hung from the hand in fashion of a lantern,
123  And that upon us gazed and said: "O me!"

124  Di sé facea a sé stesso lucerna,
125  ed eran due in uno e uno in due;
126  com' esser può, quei sa che sì governa.

124  It of itself made to itself a lamp,
125  And they were two in one, and one in two;
126  How that can be, He knows who so ordains it.

127  Quando diritto al piè del ponte fue,
128  levò 'l braccio alto con tutta la testa
129  per appressarne le parole sue

127  When it was come close to the bridge's foot,
128  It lifted high its arm with all the head,
129  To bring more closely unto us its words,

130  che fuoro: “Or vedi la pena molesta,
131  tu che, spirando, vai veggendo i morti:
132  vedi s'alcuna è grande come questa.

130  Which were: "Behold now the sore penalty,
131  Thou, who dost breathing go the dead beholding;
132  Behold if any be as great as this.

133  E perché tu di me novella porti,
134  sappi ch'i' son Bertram dal Bornio, quelli
135  che diedi al re giovane i ma' conforti.

133  And so that thou may carry news of me,
134  Know that Bertram de Born am I, the same
135  Who gave to the Young King the evil comfort.

136  Io feci il padre e 'l figlio in sé ribelli;
137  Achitofèl non fé più d'Absalone
138  e di Davìd coi malvagi punzelli.

136  I made the father and the son rebellious;
137  Achitophel not more with Absalom
138  And David did with his accursed goadings.
 
139  Perch' io parti' così giunte persone,
140  partito porto il mio cerebro, lasso!,
141  dal suo principio ch'è in questo troncone.

139  Because I parted persons so united,
140  Parted do I now bear my brain, alas!
141  From its beginning, which is in this trunk.

142  Così s'osserva in me lo contrapasso.”

142  Thus is observed in me the counterpoise."

Canto XXIX
"They became what they beheld," a Blakean maxim, and we see at the beginning of Canto XXIX that Dante, the aspirant, is in danger of falling into this trap, of becoming fascinated by darkness and suffering.  Virgil rebukes him for it, and Dante rejects his rebuke.  But there's something to it, isn't there?  Because as readers, we too have long since become — not just ensnared by the wonder of Dante's poetic skills — but by the Hell he has revealed.  Dante says his eyes are inebriated, drunk, in an altered state, in which the eyes seek that which is inimical to them, i.e., darkness, then not seeing, they do the other thing they're known for: weep.  We return to a familiar theme.  If the people in Hell are there by Divine fiat, then pity for them is an ungodly response, a response that runs counter to the Divine will for justice.  For Hell is a place of justice, a place of perpetual violence and conflict, a continual war with no prospect of a conclusion in either victory or defeat.  This tiff between Virgil and Dante is also something we have seen before, and a great deal of insight is afforded the reader by noting those places in the text where the protagonists come closer to each other, and where, as here, they drift apart.  Dante, here, can be said to be perverse, in that he says to his teacher: "If you knew my motive, you would forgive me my seeming obsession."  There's a weird figuration here in line 10, of the moon being beneath their feet, mutability, night, the protagonists are walking on a timebomb.  They have a schedule to keep, something given to mortals, but not the shades of Hell.  That schedule is celestially maintained, and Virgil, as are many of the damned, seems to have a kind of metaposition on earthly Time, being able, to some extent, as say, we are in dreams, to look forward and backward through the medium, Time itself seeming to be a kind of enclosed, globe-like fishbowl, in which moments, from their perspective, are visible like the fish in the bowl.  Time is no longer a back-past moving always forward on a line, but a round and round kind of swirling ambiance through which mortals move, noting only their movements' directionality, and not the element which immerses them.  We are drowning in this Time, lost in it, compelled to move in its currents as passive sufferers, willless, in regards to shaping our own destinies.  Dante, the protagonist here, is in danger because he stops, and although we learn in the first line of the Canto the reason why he stops, that is to say, because his eyes (called "lights" here, not eyes in line 2) are drunk with the darkness and with tears, and he tells his guide that he is looking for a relative.  Virgil mentions the vast dimensions of Hell and the pressing nature of time, but Dante defies that assessment, and whether from curiosity or compassion, wishes to stay, risking his entire enterprise, and for what? or better, for whom?  For Geri del Bello, a father's cousin, a spirit malign who has already menaced Dante without his knowledge, and who now menaces him again by detaining him, and drawing his attention away from his teacher's guidance.  There's a great image here in which Virgil just walks away from Dante, while the latter follows after like a schoolboy, pleading.   Then in 22 - 24, the teacher says: 

22  Allor disse 'l maestro: “Non si franga
23  lo tuo pensier da qui innanzi sovr' ello.
24  Attendi ad altro, ed ei là si rimanga;

Longfellow translates franga as broken, but as English speakers we see the word frangible there, broken, yes, but broken as glass breaks.  Dante does not make the connection, that to ponder certain things too obsessively, as say the evil of an ancestor, is at best a distraction, and at worst, a snare.

Now, we have seen this theme of distraction before, and the text here, through Virgil, seems to be implying that distraction from one's calling is a great danger.  But is it?  For Dante, the poet, no.  Distraction too is part of the pattern he is creating.  An unreasonable implication, which Virgil does not seem to understand.  But Dante persists in his unreasonableness, and here we might find another Blakean maxim: "If a fool would persist in his folly, he would become wise."  The good student sometimes defies his teacher in order to learn what his teacher hasn't.  The reader is left to ponder if that is the case here, the light that guides him being only the lights of his own eyes.

Before Geri del Bello is ever given the chance to speak, Dante gives one more excuse: A blood feud.  An evil unavenged.  And Dante, a man exiled from his own wife and children, drenched in pity for this relative, once again sinks down to pity.  We have to remember "pity" has no pejorative sense here of condescension.  Pieta is what we feel when we see Michelangelo’s Virgin cradling on her lap her crucified son, and that is something quite different from the pity that we might feel for, as an example, the poet Villon, a condemned criminal.  Family is of course the ultimate excuse: I did it for my family, this, not patriotism, is perhaps the last refuge of a scoundrel.  So, on the spiritual path to liberation, we have to examine these connections.  Are the ties to family, the duty to family some kind of ultimate.  Here's what Jesus says about that:

31 There came then his brethren and his mother, and, standing without, sent unto him, calling him.
32 And the multitude sat about him, and they said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren without seek for thee.
33 And he answered them, saying, Who is my mother, or my brethren?
34 And he looked round about on them which sat about him, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren!
35 For whosoever shall do the will of God, the same is my brother, and my sister, and mother.

(I should like to add here, as an aside, the personification of Justice as a woman, which I think is the shadowside of Beatrice, the negative anima, as Beatrice is the positive one, if we were to view this feminine presense in a Jungian sense.)

Our allegiance to family, or city, or country becomes at some point in our spiritual lives a closed door, not an open one.  Dante and Virgil end this discussion by staring down into the darkness.  The aspirant, Dante, does not see, but a sound and a stench arises from the darkness.  He covers his ears, but he must breathe, and his sense of smell opens him, against his will, to the truth of this kind of filial devotion which trumps all else.  It is a coagulation of plagues, whose corruption may be hidden from the eyes, heard but not heeded, but still it announces itself in every breath we take.  This makes me think of how accustomed people become to the stench of air pollution, or how so-called good people could live near the crematoriums of a Nazi death camp, and claim no knowledge of those murderous proceedings.  It seems as if the senses of the mortal body are programmed to ignore that which offends them if they present things to us inimical to our most cherished beliefs.  It is the disease of the mind that it tries to make a remedy from the very fears which are eating into it like leprosy.

Dante, as a Christian, here uses the comparison from Ovid's description of plague ravaged Aegina, a plague that infected everything, right down to the worms in the ground, and whose utter despoliation of the island left it having to be repeopled by the seeds of ants ... all of this seriously brought forth in the text, primarily so that we have something fanciful with which to compare something that is actual.  Then the text reverts to the commonest household metaphors of pots and pans leaning against each other, or a stable boy currying a horse, or a man scaling fish ... as if to ground its truth in the ordinary, and thereby eschew the confabulations of the pagan poets.  Commentators often look at this insistence by Dante on the truth of his narrative as a kind of authorial leg-pulling, his tale being even more fantastic than the most fantastical of the pagan poets.  I think there is much more to it.  Dante is an Idealist, in the sense that the physical world is an epiphenomenon of the physical world, and it is through imagination as a spiritual vision that truth is found, not through fantasy, and certainly not through history.  These latter two being used, but used as one would subject a kind of useful beast to labor on one's behalf.  Dante has learned his lessons from the poets of old, but he means to surpass them, in the same way that the life of Jesus, through His incarnation as the Christ, has surpassed the pagan gods, which exist as mere products of human fancy.

Now, again, starting at line 94, Virgil tells the shades of the unique dispensation that he, as guide, and Dante, as a living man, have received so that they may traverse Hell without having to suffer Hells eternal punishment.  Just as Jesus allows others to call him the Messiah, so Dante allows Virgil to speak of his uniqueness.  Humility is thus preserved, as a form of homage given by others, and not as a boast that one makes of oneself.  This act by Virgil heals whatever split may have occurred between master and chela at the beginning of the canto, because now Virgil, from Dante's point of view, has returned to a subservient position.  He is teacher as guide, not Rabbi as Savior.  Virgil often forgets this, as does the Dante who is the aspirant.  But the Dante who is the poet never does.

Again, we come around to the question of identy: identiy as destiny, as the manifestation of Divine grace, or as an earthly name, a hellish crime and an eternal punishment.  Dante, the great psychologist, as he is the great metaphysician, is obsessed with this question, and this round and round, down and down, probing of Hell shows his relentless courage in following his obsession wherever it leads, no matter how brutal the truths discovered there.

With heavy irony, Dante returns the text to the question of inspiration, i.e., Griffolino d'Arezzo's story of suggesting fancy's flights, with the myth of Daedalus, with actual flight, the smoke given off by a physical body being burned at the stake.  Since fraud, and the counterfeiting of true metals by an alchemical subterfuge are the issues here, Griffolino is burned for a sin which he did not commit by a family member of his punisher — an accurser who is in actual fact a bastard, and not the son of the father who claims him.  In short: his punisher too is a counterfeit.  The true and the false are so closely set, that the false, as are the wild metaphors in Ovid, are often taken for the true.  The question of how we distinguish them in the text depends upon how penetrating we are as readers.  Dante is a poet, not a didactician.  His teaching goes much deeper than mere sermonizing, although one would be hard pressed to find a more effective sermonizer.  The final irony here is that the demon, Minos, is represented as infallible, an attribute given to popes, not a few of whom have we have encountered in Hell.  Here follows a catty remark about the gullibility of the Sienese and French, and we wonder, just how far Dante the poet is willing to go to show that Dante the aspirant still has a long way to go in the territory of forgiveness.  But what are we to make of this as readers?  Are we also being accused of being gullible if we ascribe to the literal, physical truth of Dante's vision?  If something does not fundamentally change inside of us as we read the Commedia, this may indeed be so.  As readers, we are so twisted into logical and narrative knots, that the only way we can escape these doublebinds is through an all-radiating revelation.

That revelation, for this canto, comes in the vary last line, when the counterfeiter, Capocchio, another victim of immolation, but this time for a crime he did commit, refers to himself as one who only aped the shape of a human being, being in fact something quite different than the shape he project.  The answer to the question posed before — that is to say, Who am I? — for these sinners, as also for so many of us as readers, is: I am the one who lies and suffers.    
  
   
1  La molta gente e le diverse piaghe
2  avean le luci mie sì inebrïate,
3  che de lo stare a piangere eran vaghe.

1  The many people and the divers wounds
2  These eyes of mine had so inebriated,
3  That they were wishful to stand still and weep;

4  Ma Virgilio mi disse: “Che pur guate?
5  perché la vista tua pur si soffolge
6  là giù tra l'ombre triste smozzicate?

4  But said Virgilius: "What dost thou still gaze at?
5  Why is thy sight still riveted down there
6  Among the mournful, mutilated shades?

7  Tu non hai fatto sì a l'altre bolge;
8  pensa, se tu annoverar le credi,
9  che miglia ventidue la valle volge.

7  Thou hast not done so at the other Bolge;
8  Consider, if to count them thou believest,
9  That two-and-twenty miles the valley winds,

10  E già la luna è sotto i nostri piedi;
11  lo tempo è poco omai che n'è concesso,
12  e altro è da veder che tu non vedi.”

10  And now the moon is underneath our feet;
11  Henceforth the time allotted us is brief,
12  And more is to be seen than what thou seest."

13  “Se tu avessi,” rispuos' io appresso,
14  “atteso a la cagion per ch'io guardava,
15  forse m'avresti ancor lo star dimesso.”

13  "If thou hadst," I made answer thereupon,
14  "Attended to the cause for which I looked,
15  Perhaps a longer stay thou wouldst have pardoned."

16  Parte sen giva, e io retro li andava,
17  lo duca, già faccendo la risposta,
18  e soggiugnendo: “Dentro a quella cava

16  Meanwhile my Guide departed, and behind him
17  I went, already making my reply,
18  And superadding: "In that cavern where

19  dov' io tenea or li occhi sì a posta,
