20  credo ch'un spirto del mio sangue pianga
21  la colpa che là giù cotanto costa.”

19  I held mine eyes with such attention fixed,
20  I think a spirit of my blood laments
21  The sin which down below there costs so much."

22  Allor disse 'l maestro: “Non si franga
23  lo tuo pensier da qui innanzi sovr' ello.
24  Attendi ad altro, ed ei là si rimanga;

22  Then said the Master: "Be no longer broken
23  Thy thought from this time forward upon him;
24  Attend elsewhere, and there let him remain;

25  ch'io vidi lui a piè del ponticello
26  mostrarti e minacciar forte col dito,
27  e udi' 'l nominar Geri del Bello.

25  For him I saw below the little bridge,
26  Pointing at thee, and threatening with his finger
27  Fiercely, and heard him called Geri del Bello.

28  Tu eri allor sì del tutto impedito
29  sovra colui che già tenne Altaforte,
30  che non guardasti in là, sì fu partito.”

28  So wholly at that time wast thou impeded
29  By him who formerly held Altaforte,
30  Thou didst not look that way; so he departed."

31  “O duca mio, la vïolenta morte
32  che non li è vendicata ancor,” diss' io,
33  “per alcun che de l'onta sia consorte,

31  "O my Conductor, his own violent death,
32  Which is not yet avenged for him," I said,
33  "By any who is sharer in the shame,

34  fece lui disdegnoso; ond' el sen gio
35  sanza parlarmi, sì com' ïo estimo:
36  e in ciò m'ha el fatto a sé più pio.”

34  Made him disdainful; whence he went away,
35  As I imagine, without speaking to me,
36  And thereby made me pity him the more."

37  Così parlammo infino al loco primo
38  che de lo scoglio l'altra valle mostra,
39  se più lume vi fosse, tutto ad imo.

37  Thus did we speak as far as the first place
38  Upon the crag, which the next valley shows
39  Down to the bottom, if there were more light.

40  Quando noi fummo sor l'ultima chiostra
41  di Malebolge, sì che i suoi conversi
42  potean parere a la veduta nostra,

40  When we were now right over the last cloister
41  Of Malebolge, so that its lay-brothers
42  Could manifest themselves unto our sight,

43  lamenti saettaron me diversi,
44  che di pietà ferrati avean li strali;
45  ond' io li orecchi con le man copersi.

43  Divers lamentings pierced me through and through,
44  Which with compassion had their arrows barbed,
45  Whereat mine ears I covered with my hands.

46  Qual dolor fora, se de li spedali
47  di Valdichiana tra 'l luglio e 'l settembre
48  e di Maremma e di Sardigna i mali

46  What pain would be, if from the hospitals
47  Of Valdichiana, 'twixt July and September,
48  And of Maremma and Sardinia

49  fossero in una fossa tutti 'nsembre,
50  tal era quivi, e tal puzzo n'usciva
51  qual suol venir de le marcite membre.

49  All the diseases in one moat were gathered,
50  Such was it here, and such a stench came from it
51  As from putrescent limbs is wont to issue.

52  Noi discendemmo in su l'ultima riva
53  del lungo scoglio, pur da man sinistra;
54  e allor fu la mia vista più viva

52  We had descended on the furthest bank
53  From the long crag, upon the left hand still,
54  And then more vivid was my power of sight

55  giù ver' lo fondo, là 've la ministra
56  de l'alto Sire infallibil giustizia
57  punisce i falsador che qui registra.

55  Down tow'rds the bottom, where the ministress
56  Of the high Lord, Justice infallible,
57  Punishes forgers, which she here records.

58  Non credo ch'a veder maggior tristizia
59  fosse in Egina il popol tutto infermo,
60  quando fu l'aere sì pien di malizia,

58  I do not think a sadder sight to see
59  Was in Aegina the whole people sick,
60  (When was the air so full of pestilence,

61  che li animali, infino al picciol vermo,
62  cascaron tutti, e poi le genti antiche,
63  secondo che i poeti hanno per fermo,

61  The animals, down to the little worm,
62  All fell, and afterwards the ancient people,
63  According as the poets have affirmed,

64  si ristorar di seme di formiche;
65  ch'era a veder per quella oscura valle
66  languir li spirti per diverse biche.

64  Were from the seed of ants restored again,)
65  Than was it to behold through that dark valley
66  The spirits languishing in divers heaps.

67  Qual sovra 'l ventre e qual sovra le spalle
68  l'un de l'altro giacea, e qual carpone
69  si trasmutava per lo tristo calle.

67  This on the belly, that upon the back
68  One of the other lay, and others crawling
69  Shifted themselves along the dismal road.

70  Passo passo andavam sanza sermone,
71  guardando e ascoltando li ammalati,
72  che non potean levar le lor persone.

70  We step by step went onward without speech,
71  Gazing upon and listening to the sick
72  Who had not strength enough to lift their bodies.

73  Io vidi due sedere a sé poggiati,
74  com' a scaldar si poggia tegghia a tegghia,
75  dal capo al piè di schianze macolati;

73  I saw two sitting leaned against each other,
74  As leans in heating platter against platter,
75  From head to foot bespotted o'er with scabs;

76  e non vidi già mai menare stregghia
77  a ragazzo aspettato dal segnorso,
78  né a colui che mal volontier vegghia,

76  And never saw I plied a currycomb
77  By stable-boy for whom his master waits,
78  Or him who keeps awake unwillingly,

79  come ciascun menava spesso il morso
80  de l'unghie sopra sé per la gran rabbia
81  del pizzicor, che non ha più soccorso;

79  As every one was plying fast the bite
80  Of nails upon himself, for the great rage
81  Of itching which no other succour had.

82  e sì traevan giù l'unghie la scabbia,
83  come coltel di scardova le scaglie
84  o d'altro pesce che più larghe l'abbia.

82  And the nails downward with them dragged the scab,
83  In fashion as a knife the scales of bream,
84  Or any other fish that has them largest.

85  “O tu che con le dita ti dismaglie,”
86  cominciò 'l duca mio a l'un di loro,
87  “e che fai d'esse tal volta tanaglie,

85  "O thou, that with thy fingers dost dismail thee,"
86  Began my Leader unto one of them,
87  "And makest of them pincers now and then,

88  dinne s'alcun Latino è tra costoro
89  che son quinc' entro, se l'unghia ti basti
90  etternalmente a cotesto lavoro.”

88  Tell me if any Latian is with those
89  Who are herein; so may thy nails suffice thee
90  To all eternity unto this work."

91  “Latin siam noi, che tu vedi sì guasti
92  qui ambedue,” rispuose l'un piangendo;
93  “ma tu chi se' che di noi dimandasti?”

91  "Latians are we, whom thou so wasted seest,
92  Both of us here," one weeping made reply;
93  "But who art thou, that questionest about us?"

94  E 'l duca disse: “I' son un che discendo
95  con questo vivo giù di balzo in balzo,
96  e di mostrar lo 'nferno a lui intendo.”

94  And said the Guide: "One am I who descends
95  Down with this living man from cliff to cliff,
96  And I intend to show Hell unto him."

97  Allor si ruppe lo comun rincalzo;
98  e tremando ciascuno a me si volse
99  con altri che l'udiron di rimbalzo.

97  Then broken was their mutual support,
98  And trembling each one turned himself to me,
99  With others who had heard him by rebound.

100  Lo buon maestro a me tutto s'accolse,
101  dicendo: “Dì a lor ciò che tu vuoli”;
102  e io incominciai, poscia ch'ei volse:

100  Wholly to me did the good Master gather,
101  Saying: "Say unto them whate'er thou wishest."
102  And I began, since he would have it so:

103  “Se la vostra memoria non s'imboli
104  nel primo mondo da l'umane menti,
105  ma s'ella viva sotto molti soli,

103  "So may your memory not steal away
104  In the first world from out the minds of men,
105  But so may it survive 'neath many suns,

106  ditemi chi voi siete e di che genti;
107  la vostra sconcia e fastidiosa pena
108  di palesarvi a me non vi spaventi.”

106  Say to me who ye are, and of what people;
107  Let not your foul and loathsome punishment
108  Make you afraid to show yourselves to me."

109  “Io fui d'Arezzo, e Albero da Siena,”
110  rispuose l'un, “mi fé mettere al foco;
111  ma quel per ch'io mori' qui non mi mena.

109  "I of Arezzo was," one made reply,
110  "And Albert of Siena had me burned;
111  But what I died for does not bring me here.

112  Vero è ch'i' dissi lui, parlando a gioco:
113  'I' mi saprei levar per l'aere a volo';
114  e quei, ch'avea vaghezza e senno poco,

112  'Tis true I said to him, speaking in jest,
113  That I could rise by flight into the air,
114  And he who had conceit, but little wit,

115  volle ch'i' li mostrassi l'arte; e solo
116  perch' io nol feci Dedalo, mi fece
117  ardere a tal che l'avea per figliuolo.

115  Would have me show to him the art; and only
116  Because no Daedalus I made him, made me
117  Be burned by one who held him as his son.

118  Ma ne l'ultima bolgia de le diece
119  me per l'alchìmia che nel mondo usai
120  dannò Minòs, a cui fallar non lece.”

118  But unto the last Bolgia of the ten,
119  For alchemy, which in the world I practised,
120  Minos, who cannot err, has me condemned."

121  E io dissi al poeta: “Or fu già mai
122  gente sì vana come la sanese?
123  Certo non la francesca sì d'assai!”

121  And to the Poet said I: "Now was ever
122  So vain a people as the Sienese?
123  Not for a certainty the French by far."

124  Onde l'altro lebbroso, che m'intese,
125  rispuose al detto mio: “Tra'mene Stricca
126  che seppe far le temperate spese,

124  Whereat the other leper, who had heard me,
125  Replied unto my speech: "Taking out Stricca,
126  Who knew the art of moderate expenses,

127  e Niccolò che la costuma ricca
128  del garofano prima discoverse
129  ne l'orto dove tal seme s'appicca;

127  And Niccolo, who the luxurious use
128  Of cloves discovered earliest of all
129  Within that garden where such seed takes root;

130  e tra'ne la brigata in che disperse
131  Caccia d'Ascian la vigna e la gran fonda,
132  e l'Abbagliato suo senno proferse.

130  And taking out the band, among whom squandered
131  Caccia d'Ascian his vineyards and vast woods,
132  And where his wit the Abbagliato proffered!

133  Ma perché sappi chi sì ti seconda
134  ontra i Sanesi, aguzza ver' me l'occhio,
135  sì che la faccia mia ben ti risponda:

133  But, that thou know who thus doth second thee
134  Against the Sienese, make sharp thine eye
135  Tow'rds me, so that my face well answer thee,

136  sì vedrai ch'io son l'ombra di Capocchio,
137  che falsai li metalli con l'alchìmia;
138  e te dee ricordar, se ben t'adocchio,
136  And thou shalt see I am Capocchio's shade,
137  Who metals falsified by alchemy;
138  Thou must remember, if I well descry thee,



139  com' io fui di natura buona scimia.”

139  How I a skilful ape of nature was."

Canto XXX
There seems to be at least two directions by which one might navigate the landscape of the Self.  In one direction, there is disintegration, the self divides into conflicted and conflicting parts.  This is Dante's Hell.  These selves are perhaps the equivalent of Blake's spectre, a sociopathic sink of pure selfishness with insatiable needs which it tries to fulfill in a world of others, like itself, in a constant pointless war, which, far from satisfying those needs, becomes an end in itself: the idea of winning, and the ultimate form of winning becomes the spectre's ability to inflict the pain it is feeling on another.  (Blake calls this spectre the "reasoning power in man", because this power begins with the cloven fiction, that self and other are separate entities, the bad opposing your desires, and although there is no good per se, there might be those who are temporarily under your control to do your bidding, or those who have money or power that you can grab.  Why is this the reason?  Because it divides.  And it attempts to add part to part to establish the whole.  This is the symptom of a dividing mind, all of nature is broken into pieces of eat or be eaten fragments.)  In the other direction, there is integration.  Integration begins when the reader or aspirant realizes that all of these fragments are a part of a single Self, whom Dante calls God.  And here's where it gets interesting: Every moment of life is a choice-point wherein one may pivot towards disintegration or integration.  Here in Canto XXX, we see perhaps what is the most chaotic and conflicted crowd of sinners yet encountered.  They have different punishments, and they also punish each other as part of their own punishment.  They are all frauds of one stripe or another, but they taunt, flail at, and flay one another.  Whatever the person has desired is now moot, because his real desire is for vengeance, the absolute addictive need in inflict pain on others, or baring that, to witness the pain of others.   Master Adams is the poster boy for this kind of consciousness.   Here is a shade tormented by an insatiable thirst, although to fulfill that thirst would only increase the torment of his dropsy, a condition in which the suffer retains water.  Here is one who cannot move, and yet his one haunting desire is to search this immense area of Hell to find and see punished his partners in crime.  Here is one, whose has only two avenues of expression: his mouth, and one arm, both devoted to causing pain.
 
The destruction of marriage and the family begin the Canto, as Juno, jealous of Semele's affair with Jupiter (Zeus) destroys here rival through her rival's own excess of desire.  The myth being that Semele was a granted a wish, which Juno knew would destroy her (and also indirectly, Thebes).  The wish was to see Zeus in his actual form, a site so dazzling that it destroys whomever sees it.  Juno here is a negative anima figure, and like the sinners in this circle, she uses deceit to enact her jealous revenge.  A side note here is that there is a legend that Thebes was founded by the playing of a lyre that made the stones speak.  Dante compares Master Adams' body to that of a lute, and there might be a parody here of the seductive power of music, to do ill or good, and Master Adams is certainly a source of dissonance.  One thinks too of the Jesus remark in the gospels about palm Sunday, that the very stones would cry out if the people did not, and also, of course, of Orpheus.  Presumably we are reading here, not so much an exposition of the power of music, but that of the power of poetry, and the power of a propagandistic misuse of either art.  One myth has it that Semele was derived from a word meaning stimulus, which in this case meant whips and goads to drive people into a Dionysian frenzy.  Juno also destroys Athamas' family by driving him mad so that he mistakes his wife and children for a lioness and her cubs.  Male lions will sometimes kill the cubs of a rival male  — the jealousy theme brought to the ground of biology and evolution, where the motivation is only to have one's own genes survive, not that of defeated rivals.  On the female side of these family-destroying perversions, we also have the example of Myrrha attempting to trick her father into incest.  Dante also includes here the story of Hecuba.  Her daughter destroyed by sacrifices to a false God for the success of a vengeful expedition, her son also killed, Hecuba goes mad and barks like a dog (bitch).  The implication here is that as the ego is fragmented, and those integrating associations of citizenship and family are destroyed, an insanity ensues, the various fragmented parts reverting to the behavior of beasts (see line 24 on the "goading of beasts"  —  punger bestie).  The fraud, Gianni Schicchi, like a beast, drags off Capocchio, another beast, his prey.  Darwin, if he had read this canto, could not have failed to be impressed, and the old Victorian conception of Nature being "red in tooth and claw" would certainly find support for its axiom in the examples shown here.  

We're not going to get to the integration of these warring selves in the Inferno, but all through the Inferno, Dante, either by adhering to Virgil's "reason" or his own Christian conscience, is learning about that choice point referred to earlier.  And Virgil's one piece of advice, rather petulantly delivered toward the end of this canto that Dante's desire for experience is in danger of developing into a morbid curiosity.  It is one thing to know about sin, and quite another to be obsessed by it.  Remember, the choice point is to move towards more disintegration or more integration.  That choice point is called God's Judgement or God's Mercy, but nothing is destroyed.  Disintegration will never be reformed into integration unless this pivot point is negotiated wisely.  And we are learning throughout the Commedia that it pagan reason is by its very proliferation of deities can never supplant spiritual vision, which connects everything inviolable glory.  If we recall all these hear/see metaphors present throughout the Inferno, but especially in the earlier cantos, we can see that it is not only what we hear and what we see that moves us towards this unification of the self as Self, but how we hear and how we see.  

As we move deeper into the darkness of hell, Hell's absolute moral blindness and the terrible cacophony of Hell's constant shrieking, roaring and conflicted voices.  We see in the figure of Master Adams, who cannot move, what we have been seeing all along in the Inferno: an inability to learn, to change, to make any other choices.  Hell is a place devoted to an inflexible formula: transgression and retribution, it is the world of the spectre whose reason begins and ends with a false notion of identity (the constant theme of the Commedia), that who and what I am is only my desire for self-preservation, self-aggrandizement, and finally self-flagellation, that who and what I am is only a conglomerate of such desires.  If that is reason, the soul that learns cannot find blessedness here, but only instances of transgression and rules for retribution.  For blessed souls, those who have had that totally integrating vision which we call mystical union with ALL THAT IS, hell is simply irrelevant, and in fact unreal.  Saint Lucy or Beatrice can feel concern for Dante, a potential freed, and however mistaken, loving soul, but for the torments of the damned they feel nothing.  Pity is an emotion for the pain of the Christed or potentially Christed person being crucified by the conflicts of the everyday, mundane world, but not for those who initiate or perpetuate those conflicts.   

1  Nel tempo che Iunone era crucciata
2  per Semelè contra 'l sangue tebano,
3  come mostrò una e altra fïata,

1  'Twas at the time when Juno was enraged,
2  For Semele, against the Theban blood,
3  As she already more than once had shown,

4  Atamente divenne tanto insano,
5  che veggendo la moglie con due figli
6  andar carcata da ciascuna mano,

4  So reft of reason Athamas became,
5  That, seeing his own wife with children twain
6  Walking encumbered upon either hand,

7  gridò: “Tendiam le reti, sì ch'io pigli
8  la leonessa e ' leoncini al varco”;
9  e poi distese i dispietati artigli,

7  He cried: "Spread out the nets, that I may take
8  The lioness and her whelps upon the passage;"
9  And then extended his unpitying claws,

10  prendendo l'un ch'avea nome Learco,
11  e rotollo e percosselo ad un sasso;
12  e quella s'annegò con l'altro carco.

10  Seizing the first, who had the name Learchus,
11  And whirled him round, and dashed him on a rock;
12  And she, with the other burthen, drowned herself;—

13  E quando la fortuna volse in basso
14  l'altezza de' Troian che tutto ardiva,
15  sì che 'nsieme col regno il re fu casso,

And at the time when fortune downward hurled
The Trojan's arrogance, that all things dared,
So that the king was with his kingdom crushed,

16  Ecuba trista, misera e cattiva,
17  poscia che vide Polissena morta,
18  e del suo Polidoro in su la riva

16  Hecuba sad, disconsolate, and captive,
17  When lifeless she beheld Polyxena,
18  And of her Polydorus on the shore

19  del mar si fu la dolorosa accorta,
20  forsennata latrò sì come cane;
21  tanto il dolor le fè la mente torta.

19  Of ocean was the dolorous one aware,
20  Out of her senses like a dog she barked,
21  So much the anguish had her mind distorted;

22  Ma nè di Tebe furie nè troiane
23  si vider mäi in alcun tanto crude,
24  non punger bestie, nonché membra umane,

22  But not of Thebes the furies nor the Trojan
23  Were ever seen in any one so cruel
24  In goading beasts, and much more human members,

25  quant' io vidi in due ombre smorte e nude,
26  che mordendo correvan di quel modo
27  che 'l porco quando del porcil si schiude.

25  As I beheld two shadows pale and naked,
26  Who, biting, in the manner ran along
27  That a boar does, when from the sty turned loose.

28  L'una giunse a Capocchio, e in sul nodo
29  del collo l'assannò, sì che, tirando,
30  grattar li fece il ventre al fondo sodo.

28  One to Capocchio came, and by the nape
29  Seized with its teeth his neck, so that in dragging
30  It made his belly grate the solid bottom.

31  E l'Aretin che rimase, tremando
32  mi disse: “Quel folletto è Gianni Schicchi,
33  e va rabbioso altrui così conciando.”

31  And the Aretine, who trembling had remained,
32  Said to me: "That mad sprite is Gianni Schicchi,
33  And raving goes thus harrying other people."

34  “Oh,” diss' io lui, “se l'altro non ti ficchi
35  li denti a dosso, non ti sia fatica
36  a dir chi è, pria che di qui si spicchi.”

34  "O," said I to him, "so may not the other
35  Set teeth on thee, let it not weary thee
36  To tell us who it is, ere it dart hence."

37  Ed elli a me: “Quell' è l'anima antica
38  di Mirra scellerata, che divenne
39  al padre, fuor del dritto amore, amica.

37  And he to me: "That is the ancient ghost
38  Of the nefarious Myrrha, who became
39  Beyond all rightful love her father's lover.

40  Questa a peccar con esso così venne,
41  falsificando sè in altrui forma,
42  come l'altro che là sen va, sostenne,

40  She came to sin with him after this manner,
41  By counterfeiting of another's form;
42  As he who goeth yonder undertook,

43  per guadagnar la donna de la torma,
44  falsificare in sè Buoso Donati,
45  testando e dando al testamento norma.”

43  That he might gain the lady of the herd,
44  To counterfeit in himself Buoso Donati,
45  Making a will and giving it due form."

46  E poi che i due rabbiosi fuor passati
47  sovra cu' io avea l'occhio tenuto,
48  rivolsilo a guardar li altri mal nati.

46  And after the two maniacs had passed
47  On whom I held mine eye, I turned it back
48  To look upon the other evil-born.

49  Io vidi un, fatto a guisa di lëuto,
50  pur ch'elli avesse avuta l'anguinaia
51  tronca da l'altro che l'uomo ha forcuto.

49  I saw one made in fashion of a lute,
50  If he had only had the groin cut off
51  Just at the point at which a man is forked.

52  La grave idropesì, che sì dispaia
53  le membra con l'omor che mal converte,
54  che 'l viso non risponde a la ventraia,

52  The heavy dropsy, that so disproportions
53  The limbs with humours, which it ill concocts,
54  That the face corresponds not to the belly,

55  faceva lui tener le labbra aperte
56  come l'etico fa, che per la sete
57  l'un verso 'l mento e l'altro in sù rinverte.

55  Compelled him so to hold his lips apart
56  As does the hectic, who because of thirst
57  One tow'rds the chin, the other upward turns.

58  “O voi che sanz' alcuna pena siete,
59  e non so io perché, nel mondo gramo,”
60  diss' elli a noi, “guardate e attendete

58  "O ye, who without any torment are,
59  And why I know not, in the world of woe,"
60  He said to us, "behold, and be attentive

61  a la miseria del maestro Adamo;
62  io ebbi, vivo, assai di quel ch'i' volli,
63  e ora, lasso!, un gocciol d'acqua bramo.

61  Unto the misery of Master Adam;
62  I had while living much of what I wished,
63  And now, alas! a drop of water crave.

64  Li ruscelletti che d'i verdi colli
65  del Casentin discendon giuso in Arno,
66  faccendo i lor canali freddi e molli,

64  The rivulets, that from the verdant hills
65  Of Cassentin descend down into Arno,
66  Making their channels to be cold and moist,

67  sempre mi stanno innanzi, e non indarno,
68  chè l'imagine lor vie più m'asciuga
69  che 'l male ond' io nel volto mi discarno.

67  Ever before me stand, and not in vain;
68  For far more doth their image dry me up
69  Than the disease which strips my face of flesh.

70  La rigida giustizia che mi fruga
71  tragge cagion del loco ov' io peccai
72  a metter più li miei sospiri in fuga.

70  The rigid justice that chastises me
71  Draweth occasion from the place in which
72  I sinned, to put the more my sighs in flight.

73  Ivi è Romena, là dov' io falsai
74  la lega suggellata del Batista;
75  per ch'io il corpo sù arso lasciai.

73  There is Romena, where I counterfeited
74  The currency imprinted with the Baptist,
75  For which I left my body burned above.

76  Ma s'io vedessi qui l'anima trista
77  di Guido o d'Alessandro o di lor frate,
78  per Fonte Branda non darei la vista.

76  But if I here could see the tristful soul
77  Of Guido, or Alessandro, or their brother,
78  For Branda's fount I would not give the sight.

79  Dentro c'è l'una già, se l'arrabbiate
80  ombre che vanno intorno dicon vero;
81  ma che mi val, c'ho le membra legate?

79  One is within already, if the raving
80  Shades that are going round about speak truth;
81  But what avails it me, whose limbs are tied?

82  S'io fossi pur di tanto ancor leggero
83  ch'i' potessi in cent' anni andare un'oncia,
84  io sarei messo già per lo sentiero,

82  If I were only still so light, that in
83  A hundred years I could advance one inch,
84  I had already started on the way,

85  cercando lui tra questa gente sconcia,
86  con tutto ch'ella volge undici miglia,
87  e men d'un mezzo di traverso non ci ha.

85  Seeking him out among this squalid folk,
86  Although the circuit be eleven miles,
87  And be not less than half a mile across.

88  Io son per lor tra sì fatta famiglia;
89  e' m'indussero a batter li fiorini
90  ch'avevan tre carati di mondiglia.”

88  For them am I in such a family;
89  They did induce me into coining florins,
90  Which had three carats of impurity."

91  E io a lui: “Chi son li due tapini
92  che fumman come man bagnate 'l verno,
93  giacendo stretti a' tuoi destri confini?”

91  And I to him: "Who are the two poor wretches
92  That smoke like unto a wet hand in winter,
93  Lying there close upon thy right-hand confines?"

94  “Qui li trovai – e poi volta non dierno –,”
95  rispuose, “quando piovvi in questo greppo,
96  e non credo che dieno in sempiterno.

94  "I found them here," replied he, "when I rained
95  Into this chasm, and since they have not turned,
96  Nor do I think they will for evermore.

97  L'una è la falsa ch'accusò Gioseppo;
98  l'altr' è 'l falso Sinon greco di Troia:
99  per febbre aguta gittan tanto leppo.”

97  One the false woman is who accused Joseph,
98  The other the false Sinon, Greek of Troy;
99  From acute fever they send forth such reek."

100  E l'un di lor, che si recò a noia
101  forse d'esser nomato sì oscuro,
102  col pugno li percosse l'epa croia.

100  And one of them, who felt himself annoyed
101  At being, peradventure, named so darkly,
102  Smote with the fist upon his hardened paunch.

103  Quella sonò come fosse un tamburo;
104  e mastro Adamo li percosse il volto
105  col braccio suo, che non parve men duro,

103  It gave a sound, as if it were a drum;
104  And Master Adam smote him in the face,
105  With arm that did not seem to be less hard,

106  dicendo a lui: “Ancor che mi sia tolto
107  lo muover per le membra che son gravi,
108  ho io il braccio a tal mestiere sciolto.”

106  Saying to him: "Although be taken from me
107  All motion, for my limbs that heavy are,
108  I have an arm unfettered for such need."

109  Ond' ei rispuose: “Quando tu andavi
110  al fuoco, non l'avei tu così presto;
111  ma sì e più l'avei quando coniavi.”

109  Whereat he answer made: "When thou didst go
110  Unto the fire, thou hadst it not so ready:
111  But hadst it so and more when thou wast coining."

112  E l'idropico: “Tu di' ver di questo:
113  ma tu non fosti sì ver testimonio
114  là 've del ver fosti a Troia richesto.”

112  The dropsical: "Thou sayest true in that;
113  But thou wast not so true a witness there,
114  Where thou wast questioned of the truth at Troy."

115  “S'io dissi falso, e tu falsasti il conio,”
116  disse Sinon; “e son qui per un fallo,
117  e tu per più ch'alcun altro demonio!”

115  "If I spake false, thou falsifiedst the coin,"
116  Said Sinon; "and for one fault I am here,
117  And thou for more than any other demon."

118  “Ricorditi, spergiuro, del cavallo,”
119  rispuose quel ch'avëa infiata l'epa;
120  “e sieti reo che tutto il mondo sallo!”

118  "Remember, perjurer, about the horse,"
119  He made reply who had the swollen belly,
120  "And rueful be it thee the whole world knows it."

121  “E te sia rea la sete onde ti crepa,”
122  disse 'l Greco, “la lingua, e l'acqua marcia
123  che 'l ventre innanzi a li occhi sì t'assiepa!”

121  "Rueful to thee the thirst be wherewith cracks
122  Thy tongue," the Greek said, "and the putrid water
123  That hedges so thy paunch before thine eyes."

124  Allora il monetier: “Così si squarcia
125  la bocca tua per tuo mal come suole;
126  chè, s'i' ho sete e omor mi rinfarcia,

124  Then the false-coiner: "So is gaping wide
125  Thy mouth for speaking evil, as 'tis wont;
126  Because if I have thirst, and humour stuff me

127  tu hai l'arsura e 'l capo che ti duole,
128  e per leccar lo specchio di Narcisso,
129  non vorresti a 'nvitar molte parole.”

127  Thou hast the burning and the head that aches,
128  And to lick up the mirror of Narcissus
129  Thou wouldst not want words many to invite thee."

130  Ad ascoltarli er' io del tutto fisso,
132  quando 'l maestro mi disse: “Or pur mira,
133  che per poco che teco non mi risso!”

130  In listening to them was I wholly fixed,
131  When said the Master to me: "Now just look,
132  For little wants it that I quarrel with thee."

133  Quand' io 'l senti' a me parlar con ira,
134  volsimi verso lui con tal vergogna,
135  ch'ancor per la memoria mi si gira.

133  When him I heard in anger speak to me,
134  I turned me round towards him with such shame
135  That still it eddies through my memory.

136  Qual è colui che suo dannaggio sogna,
137  che sognando desidera sognare,
138  ì che quel ch'è, come non fosse, agogna,

136  And as he is who dreams of his own harm,
137  Who dreaming wishes it may be a dream,
138  So that he craves what is, as if it were not;

139  tal mi fec' io, non possendo parlare,
140  che disïava scusarmi, e scusava
141  me tuttavia, e nol mi credea fare.

139  Such I became, not having power to speak,
140  For to excuse myself I wished, and still
141  Excused myself, and did not think I did it.

142  “Maggior difetto men vergogna lava,”
143  disse 'l maestro, “che 'l tuo non è stato;
144  però d'ogne trestizia ti disgrava.

142  "Less shame doth wash away a greater fault,"
143  The Master said, "than this of thine has been;
144  Therefore thyself disburden of all sadness,

145  E fa ragion ch'io ti sia sempre allato,
146  se più avvien che fortuna t'accoglia
147  dove sien genti in simigliante piato:

145  And make account that I am aye beside thee,
146  If e'er it come to pass that fortune bring thee
147  Where there are people in a like dispute;

148  chè voler ciò udire è bassa voglia.”

146  For a base wish it is to wish to hear it."

Canto XXXI
Canto XXXI is a bridge.  For several cantos now, the text has been carefully extending bridge material, the overlapping of material from one canto to another becoming something more here than a kind of musical blending of themes, so that here, for the first time, an entire canto becomes a bridge from Malebolgia, the 8th circle, to the 9th and final circle of the Inferno.  The Canto is about Gigantism, or in Jungian terms inflation.  The key lines here 55-57 talk about power and evil uncontrolled by "argument", that is language.  In our times, we know that power and evil can be distorted by propaganda, the big lie, as the Nazi called it, which people will believe better than the little lie.  One could say that the chief fraud is the use of language to convince others that your betrayal will be in their best interests.  Governments, parents, advertisers, churches and educational systems, are all giants compared to the individual, and all of them perpetrate this fraud.  This sin is a social one, not just the sin of individual will, and there is a way that the Giants in this canto are more like social forces acting in an entity-like manner, but essentially only representative of collective passions that overwhelm individuals, belittle people at the bottom of the social hierarchy and inflating people at the top.  These passions are both mindless, compassionless, and infantile.  They are tantrum energies, composed of selfishness, frustration, rage, and the irrational defensiveness which sprouts from fear — or as Dante the aspirant puts it, in sort of an Ernst Becker Denial of Death sort of way:

109  Then was I more afraid of death than ever,
110  For nothing more was needful than the fear ...

Dante was very prescient in terms of what was later called depth psychology, and also in terms of what Vico described in the New Science as the primitive, pre-linguistic state of human beings.  He had a very sophisticated view of the operations of language, vis a vis, its own protean nature (the same words may be used to hurt and to heal), and also how it operates as a refinement, or as Freud might have said, a displacement of highly charged emotions.  Here, Dante shows us that perception is a matter of position, problems near to us appear differently than problems distant from us.  The accuracy of perceptions is also determined by such things as darkness, fog, or murkiness, all of which conditions are in effect here.  Language, such as Virgil's explanation here to Dante as to the true nature of what Dante first perceives as defensive towers, but which are actually Giants, is the mediating force.  Through the proper use of language we can correct our sense perceptions, and even influence our emotions.  

The Giants generate fear in Dante, the aspirant, and as such they are the projected embodiments of that emotion, which is paramount in Hell.  Vico says that emotions are primal, not perceptions, because they are infantile, and if you have ever tried to calm a toddler in the midst of an inconsolable crying jag, you know that for them emotions supersede perceptions, in that it is difficult to distract them with a toy, and even more difficult to console them with mere words.  Both for Vico and Dante, emotions, especially rage and fear, are so big, so self-enclosing and so self-aggrandizing, that they may render language both incomprehensible and irrelevant.  If you check inside yourself, you will discover that this true: first we feel, and that feeling colors perception, and those perceptions evolve into rationales — which look like reason, but on close examination, are not logical at all, but rather outgrowths of, and attempts to, harness the energy of an underlying emotion.  Which may be why philosophy, for Dante, is a sort of denatured poetry, since it attempts to depotentiate its own seed of emotion, and thereby ignore its own genesis and foundation.

I think it is also telling that the Giants here, with the exception of Antaeus, are half-hidden, and bound.  Why  half-hidden?  Why bound?  Because what they display in their deluded states is a kind of projected egotistical power originating in their hidden or unconscious motive parts.  As we have seen throughout hell, they are stuck, not so much like organic entities or even shades, but more like towers, edifices fixed to the earth and without any volitional power to move.  There are four giants mentioned, each of which operates in the psyche of the reader in a slightly different way.  Nimrod, the inarticulate victim of his own inflationary pride, attempts to reach and perhaps even steal the creative power of the Word of God, through a kind of effusive self-aggrandizement, that is to say, egotistical boasting.   Ephialtes, not so much through the power of words, but through a strength of deeds, discovers that no egotistical action has the power to supersede the Jungian Self, or Soul.  Think of those celebrities who are rich with accomplishments and praise, but who nevertheless commit suicide, or otherwise self-destruct.  And Briareus, whom Dante wishes to see, and whom Virgil promises that he will see, but whom he does not see.  Why?  Because Virgil has given an outlandish (i.e., pagan hyperbole, fictional) account of him in the Aeneid as  One "with a hundred arms and hands and breathes fire from fifty mouths and breasts."  The description is an exaggeration for effect, and cannot be verified by actual experience.  The point here is a warning to poets, whose job is not to convince readers as propagandists or advertisers do, but to show the truth of the psyche, the soul.  
Now we come to Antaeus.  He is the only giant with the motive power to provide a bridge (back to the issue of bridges, or connective tissue, or vehicles, like ships, of conveyance) to the deepest, most alien, most primitive and selfish level of the psyche: Cocytus (etymologically derived from the Greek: lamentation).  Antaeus' sin may be pride and the destruction of nature (He is the slayer of a thousand lions, but he did not sin directly against God, he did not take up arms against Rome, the eternal city.  However strong Antaeus is, he was controlled by his mother Gea, the anima.  He is reachable, persuadable, but how?  How do you control a giant egotist?  Through flattery, cajolery, praise.  Yes.  But Virgil tries all of these, yet still falls short, until he tells the giant that Dante, still a living man, can add to his fame in the world.  The idea of fame controls the giant.  It may not humble him, but it makes him kneel, if not in prayer, at least in service.  Still it must be noted that it is only the idea of fame which is operational here, fame itself will do nothing to alleviate these primitive emotions.

Note: The last image of Antaeus rising up like the mast of a ship that rights itself when an uneven load is released, foreshadows the ship of the angel who is porting the souls to Purgatory, and also recalls the image in Canto I of Inferno of the swimmer who almost drowned and looks back upon reaching shore at the water that almost drowned him. 
  
1  Una medesma lingua pria mi morse,
2  sì che mi tinse l'una e l'altra guancia,
3  e poi la medicina mi riporse;

1  One and the selfsame tongue first wounded me,
2  So that it tinged the one cheek and the other,
3  And then held out to me the medicine;

4  così od' io che solea far la lancia
5  d'Achille e del suo padre esser cagione
6  prima di trista e poi di buona mancia.

4  Thus do I hear that once Achilles' spear,
5  His and his father's, used to be the cause
6  First of a sad and then a gracious boon.

7  Noi demmo il dosso al misero vallone
8  su per la ripa che 'l cinge dintorno,
9  attraversando sanza alcun sermone.

7  We turned our backs upon the wretched valley,
8  Upon the bank that girds it round about,
9  Going across it without any speech.

10  Quiv' era men che notte e men che giorno,
11  sì che 'l viso m'andava innanzi poco;
12  ma io senti' sonare un alto corno,

10  There it was less than night, and less than day,
11  So that my sight went little in advance;
12  But I could hear the blare of a loud horn,

13  tanto ch'avrebbe ogne tuon fatto fioco,
14  che, contra sé la sua via seguitando,
15  dirizzò li occhi miei tutti ad un loco.

13  So loud it would have made each thunder faint,
14  Which, counter to it following its way,
15  Mine eyes directed wholly to one place.

16  Dopo la dolorosa rotta, quando
17  Carlo Magno perdé la santa gesta,
18  non sonò sì terribilmente Orlando.

16  After the dolorous discomfiture
17  When Charlemagne the holy emprise lost,
18  So terribly Orlando sounded not.

19  Poco portäi in là volta la testa,
20  che me parve veder molte alte torri;
21  ond' io: “Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?”

19  Short while my head turned thitherward I held
20  When many lofty towers I seemed to see,
21  Whereat I: "Master, say, what town is this?"

22  Ed elli a me: “Però che tu trascorri
23  per le tenebre troppo da la lungi,
24  avvien che poi nel maginare abborri.

22  And he to me: "Because thou peerest forth
23  Athwart the darkness at too great a distance,
24  It happens that thou errest in thy fancy.

25  Tu vedrai ben, se tu là ti congiungi,
26  quanto 'l senso s'inganna di lontano;
27  però alquanto più te stesso pungi.”

25  Well shalt thou see, if thou arrivest there,
26  How much the sense deceives itself by distance;
27  Therefore a little faster spur thee on."

28  Poi caramente mi prese per mano
29  e disse: “Pria che noi siam più avanti,
30  acciò che 'l fatto men ti paia strano,

28  Then tenderly he took me by the hand,
29  And said: "Before we farther have advanced,
30  That the reality may seem to thee

31  sappi che non son torri, ma giganti,
32  e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa
33  da l'umbilico in giuso tutti quanti.”

31  Less strange, know that these are not towers, but giants,
32  And they are in the well, around the bank,
33  From navel downward, one and all of them."

34  Come quando la nebbia si dissipa,
35  lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura
36  ciò che cela 'l vapor che l'aere stipa,

34  As, when the fog is vanishing away,
35  Little by little doth the sight refigure
36  Whate'er the mist that crowds the air conceals,

37  così forando l'aura grossa e scura,
38  più e più appressando ver' la sponda,
39  fuggiemi errore e cresciemi paura;

37  So, piercing through the dense and darksome air,
38  More and more near approaching tow'rd the verge,
39  My error fled, and fear came over me;

40  però che, come su la cerchia tonda
41  Montereggion di torri si corona,
42  così la proda che 'l pozzo circonda

40  Because as on its circular parapets
41  Montereggione crowns itself with towers,
42  E'en thus the margin which surrounds the well

43  torreggiavan di mezza la persona
44  li orribili giganti, cui minaccia
45  Giove del cielo ancora quando tuona.

43  With one half of their bodies turreted
44  The horrible giants, whom Jove menaces
45  E'en now from out the heavens when he thunders.

46  E io scorgeva già d'alcun la faccia,
47  le spalle e 'l petto e del ventre gran parte,
48  e per le coste giù ambo le braccia.

46  And I of one already saw the face,
47  Shoulders, and breast, and great part of the belly,
48  And down along his sides both of the arms.

49  Natura certo, quando lasciò l'arte
50  di si fatti animali, assai fé bene
51  per tòrre tali essecutori a Marte.

49  Certainly Nature, when she left the making
50  Of animals like these, did well indeed,
51  By taking such executors from Mars;

52  E s'ella d'elefanti e di balene
53  non si pente, chi guarda sottilmente,
54  più giusta e più discreta la ne tene;

52  And if of elephants and whales she doth not
53  Repent her, whosoever looketh subtly
54  More just and more discreet will hold her for it;

55  ché dove l'argomento de la mente
56  s'aggiugne al mal volere e a la possa,
57  nessun riparo vi può far la gente.

55  For where the argument of intellect
56  Is added unto evil will and power,
57  No rampart can the people make against it.

58  La faccia sua mi parea lunga e grossa
59  come la pina di San Pietro a Roma,
60  e a sua proporzione eran l'altre ossa;

58  His face appeared to me as long and large
59  As is at Rome the pine-cone of Saint Peter's,
60  And in proportion were the other bones;

61  sì che la ripa, ch'era perizoma
62  dal mezzo in giù, ne mostrava ben tanto
63  di sovra, che di giugnere a la chioma

61  So that the margin, which an apron was
62  Down from the middle, showed so much of him
63  Above it, that to reach up to his hair

64  tre Frison s'averien dato mal vanto;
65  però ch'i' ne vedea trenta gran palmi
66  dal loco in giù dov' omo affibbia 'l manto.

64  Three Frieslanders in vain had vaunted them;
65  For I beheld thirty great palms of him
66  Down from the place where man his mantle buckles.

67  “Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi,”
68  cominciò a gridar la fiera bocca,
69  cui non si convenia più dolci salmi.

67  "Raphael mai amech izabi almi,"
68  Began to clamour the ferocious mouth,
69  To which were not befitting sweeter psalms.

70  E 'l duca mio ver' lui: “Anima sciocca,
71  tienti col corno, e con quel ti disfoga
72  quand' ira o altra passïon ti tocca!

70  And unto him my Guide: "Soul idiotic,
71  Keep to thy horn, and vent thyself with that,
72  When wrath or other passion touches thee.

73  Cèrcati al collo, e troverai la soga
74  che 'l tien legato, o anima confusa,
75  e vedi lui che 'l gran petto ti doga.”

73  Search round thy neck, and thou wilt find the belt
74  Which keeps it fastened, O bewildered soul,
75  And see it, where it bars thy mighty breast."

76  Poi disse a me: “Elli stessi s'accusa;
77  questi è Nembrotto per lo cui mal coto
78  pur un linguaggio nel mondo non s'usa.

76  Then said to me: "He doth himself accuse;
77  This one is Nimrod, by whose evil thought
78  One language in the world is not still used.

79  Lasciànlo stare e non parliamo a vòto;
80  ché così è a lui ciascun linguaggio
81  come 'l suo ad altrui, ch'a nullo è noto.”

79  Here let us leave him and not speak in vain;
80  For even such to him is every language
81  As his to others, which to none is known."

82  Facemmo adunque più lungo vïaggio,
83  vòlti a sinistra; e al trar d'un balestro
84  trovammo l'altro assai più fero e maggio.

82  Therefore a longer journey did we make,
83  Turned to the left, and a crossbow-shot oft
84  We found another far more fierce and large.

85  A cigner lui qual che fosse 'l maestro,
86  non so io dir, ma el tenea soccinto
87  dinanzi l'altro e dietro il braccio destro

85  In binding him, who might the master be
86  I cannot say; but he had pinioned close
87  Behind the right arm, and in front the other,

88  d'una catena che 'l tenea avvinto
89  dal collo in giù, sì che 'n su lo scoperto
90  si ravvolgëa infino al giro quinto.

88  With chains, that held him so begirt about
89  From the neck down, that on the part uncovered
90  It wound itself as far as the fifth gyre.

91  “Questo superbo volle esser esperto
92  di sua potenza contra 'l sommo Giove,”
93  disse 'l mio duca, “ond' elli ha cotal merto.

91  "This proud one wished to make experiment
92  Of his own power against the Supreme Jove,"
93  My Leader said, "whence he has such a guerdon.

94  Fïalte ha nome, e fece le gran prove
95  quando i giganti fer paura a' dèi;
96  le braccia ch'el menò, già mai non move.”

94  Ephialtes is his name; he showed great prowess.
95  What time the giants terrified the gods;
96  The arms he wielded never more he moves."

97  E io a lui: “S'esser puote, io vorrei
98  che de lo smisurato Brïareo
99  esperïenza avesser li occhi mei.”

97  And I to him: "If possible, I should wish
98  That of the measureless Briareus
99  These eyes of mine might have experience."

100  Ond' ei rispuose: “Tu vedrai Anteo
101  presso di qui che parla ed è disciolto,
102  che ne porrà nel fondo d'ogne reo.

100  Whence he replied: "Thou shalt behold Antaeus
101  Close by here, who can speak and is unbound,
102  Who at the bottom of all crime shall place us.

103  Quel che tu vuo' veder, più là è molto
104  ed è legato e fatto come questo,
105  salvo che più feroce par nel volto.”

103  Much farther yon is he whom thou wouldst see,
104  And he is bound, and fashioned like to this one,
105  Save that he seems in aspect more ferocious."

106  Non fu tremoto già tanto rubesto,
107  che scotesse una torre così forte,
108  come Fïalte a scuotersi fu presto.

106  There never was an earthquake of such might
107  That it could shake a tower so violently,
108  As Ephialtes suddenly shook himself.

109  Allor temett' io più che mai la morte,
110  e non v'era mestier più che la dotta,
111  s'io non avessi viste le ritorte.

109  Then was I more afraid of death than ever,
110  For nothing more was needful than the fear,
111  If I had not beheld the manacles.

112  Noi procedemmo più avante allotta,
113  e venimmo ad Anteo, che ben cinque alle,
114  sanza la testa, uscia fuor de la grotta.

112  Then we proceeded farther in advance,
113  And to Antaeus came, who, full five ells
114  Without the head, forth issued from the cavern.

115  “O tu che ne la fortunata valle
116  che fece Scipïon di gloria reda,
117  quand' Anibàl co' suoi diede le spalle,

115  "O thou, who in the valley fortunate,
116  Which Scipio the heir of glory made,
117  When Hannibal turned back with all his hosts,

118  recasti già mille leon per preda,
119  e che, se fossi stato a l'alta guerra
120  de' tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda

118  Once brought'st a thousand lions for thy prey,
119  And who, hadst thou been at the mighty war
120  Among thy brothers, some it seems still think

121  ch'avrebber vinto i figli de la terra:
122  mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo,
123  dove Cocito la freddura serra.

121  The sons of Earth the victory would have gained:
122  Place us below, nor be disdainful of it,
123  There where the cold doth lock Cocytus up.

124  Non ci fare ire a Tizio né a Tifo:
125  questi può dar di quel che qui si brama;
126  però ti china e non torcer lo grifo.

124  Make us not go to Tityus nor Typhoeus;
125  This one can give of that which here is longed for;
126  Therefore stoop down, and do not curl thy lip.

127  Ancor ti può nel mondo render fama,
128  ch'el vive, e lunga vita ancor aspetta
129  se 'nnanzi tempo grazia a sé nol chiama.”

127  Still in the world can he restore thy fame;
128  Because he lives, and still expects long life,
129  If to itself Grace call him not untimely."

130  Così disse 'l maestro; e quelli in fretta
131  le man distese, e prese 'l duca mio,
132  ond' Ercule sentì già grande stretta.

130  So said the Master; and in haste the other
132  His hands extended and took up my Guide,—
133  Hands whose great pressure Hercules once felt.

133  Virgilio, quando prender si sentio,
134  disse a me: “Fatti qua, sì ch'io ti prenda”;
135  poi fece sì ch'un fascio era elli e io.

133  Virgilius, when he felt himself embraced,
134  Said unto me: "Draw nigh, that I may take thee;"
135  Then of himself and me one bundle made.

136  Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda
137  sotto 'l chinato, quando un nuvol vada
138  sovr' essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:

136  As seems the Carisenda, to behold
137  Beneath the leaning side, when goes a cloud
138  Above it so that opposite it hangs;

139  tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada
140  di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora
141  ch'i' avrei voluto ir per altra strada.
139  Such did Antaeus seem to me, who stood
140  Watching to see him stoop, and then it was
142  I could have wished to go some other way.

142  Ma lievemente al fondo che divora
143  Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò;
144  né, sì chinato, li fece dimora,

142  But lightly in the abyss, which swallows up
143  Judas with Lucifer, he put us down;
144  Nor thus bowed downward made he there delay,

145  e come albero in nave si levò.

145  But, as a mast does in a ship, uprose.

Canto XXXII
Canto  32 begins with an invocation, so we have to ask, what is the purpose of this invocation or for that matter of any invocation?  Always it is to show that the weightiness of the theme requires more than an ordinary human skill to do it justice.  Dante is doing that too, but he is doing something else as well.  He seems to be distancing  the language of his poetry from the horrid conditions he is trying to describe.  In verses four through six , he invites the reader to imagine or, more precisely, to conceive of, a geography of feelings more complicated and terrible then any language has ever evolved to describe.  He uses a marvelous metaphor here, as if his subject matter were a kind of rock hard fruit that his poetry squeezes into the juice of  art.  Always the conception of any attentive writer is as full of detail and connections as reality itself, and to write effectively the essence of all that complexity must be juicy from the meaning of a few words.  This is far from child’s play, and Dante tells us so explicitly in verse nine: Hell is not a place that yields it’s secrets to baby talkers.  Well then, what kind of language is appropriate?  The kind that can communicate with stones, and animate them to the level of human will.  The reference, which is alluded to here, is to Christ’s assertion on Palm Sunday that if the people were silent, the very stones would cry out.  Dante’s classical reference to Amphion’s music bewitching stones to build the walls of Thebes is the overt expression through which the reader sees the deeper conception Christ, which, if Dante we’re proud, i. e., a pagan poet, he would have alluded to boastfully.  Here he achieves the same effect humbly because the reader makes the association by means of the subtle inference.  Who are the ladies whom he invokes to aid him? Those that aided Amphion?  Maybe.  But maybe Dante is seeing, through the semi-transparent veil of the classical muses, the more penetrating lights of Beatrice, St. Lucy, and the Virgin Mary.  Dante’s convoluted irony here surely has a deeper purpose.  The Commedia is not a poem constructed from pagan pride, a lesson the aspirant would have learned in the previous canto from seeing the fate of Nimrod.  In fact, in this canto Virgil is asked to stand aside and remains totally silent throughout the entire canto for the first time since line 67 of Canto I.  Here the chela’s authority surpasses the master’s to the same degree that the virtue of humility exceeds the sin of pride.

Dante is looking back and up at his own immediate past, up at the feet of the prideful giant, while his own small feet are blind, and yet blind as they are, and low as they are, they are able, through an unseen guidance, to kick the heads of these sinners locked to their necks in ice.  The poet is moving the reader’s perceptions up to feet and down to heads.  He is moving the reader through the cycle of the seasons too, first through winter, with the ice-bound Danube and Don rivers,  then through spring and summer with the mating croaks of frogs, then through fall with the gleaning peasant girls.  Here are boasting frogs under water, dreaming girls under covers in bed, and the chattering teeth and the clicking beaks of storks flying overhead.  Note too the humble posture of the girls in their dreams, who must bend (as the giant did in conveying the poets here) in order to retrieve the harvest’s final gleanings.  This is just the beginning of the connections that might be made in this canto's incredibly compacted richness of language.  Note the parallel construction of mommy and daddy in verse 9, and that of sheep and goats in verse 15.  Like original sin, our first language infects us with all the mommies' and daddies' world view from the beginning of time to now.  The culture that we inherit through our language, left unexamined, freezes both our spiritual and intellectual development, and locks us into a dog eat dog, self-versus-other world.  By contrast, the language of the Commedia takes us on a tour through the mythical past by its reference to Amphion from Horace and on through to the prophetic future of the Book of Revelations.  A perceptive reader can make many other connections and vastly expand these observations. It is Dante’s greatness that he can so succinctly light up so much time and space, and ignite the brain to experience so many levels of meaning almost simultaneously.

As always Dante tricks out his details in a way that continuously strengthens the weave of his total impression.  For example, the brothers Alberti are seen butting their heads together like sparing rams. This echoes the sheep and goats reference from verse 15, the goats referring to the division of souls at the end times, wherein the obedient sheep are saved, and the wayward goats are damned.  Note too the details of hair and heads, symbols of Samson-like strength and strength of character.   The brothers Alberti butt heads and their hair is entangled, and when the aspirant wishes Bocca to reveal his identity, it is his hair Dante grabs and pulls out — a direct assault on the sinner’s thought and will.  And, finally, the canto ends with the image of Ugolino eating the brain of his earthly tormentor, a parody of communion.

One should also note that in this canto the sinners compound their evil by continuing to be informants against their fellows.  Throughout the Commedia, the damned shades, in spite of their crimes, are still made pliable to the will of the living poet by the promise of fame, and throughout the Inferno, even for the damned, their own names still mesmerize them, and cause them to loosen their tongues with self-serving confessions.  Here, in the final circle of Hell, things are different. The damned do not want their names uttered, and so in keeping with their maliciousness, their fellow inmates inform on them.  We learn from this, like all the other sinners we have seen, that the sinners here have learned nothing from the severity of their punishment, but continue with their betrayals and treasons.

There is a spiritual question posed here that pertains to the whole of the Inferno, which is: Is justice achieved by retribution?  In Dante's version of hell, the sinners are clearly not awakened by the punishments meated out to them.  One could even say that his Hell is a place where punishment is not even about those who are being punished, but about the reaction of witnesses to that punishment.  In brief, if the sinners remain sinners, their very existence remains problematic.  The very idea of justice depends upon righting wrongs.  But here, the pain of the transgressors becomes a lesson for Dante, the aspirant, and for Dante the poet's readers.  To the second Dante, there is no room for pity for those who have earned their pain, and in fact, virtue accrues to those who heap more pain on those who have been the source of pain.  I'm still on the fence about this.  William Blake even goes so far as to claim that the only sin is the sin of vengeance, I suppose his reason being, we all make mistakes, and only forgiveness expunges those errors, not retribution.  Certainly one of the reasons that the sinners suffer so is that they have excluded compassion from their characters, even the compassion that they might have had for their own future selves, who are doomed to suffer from the enormity of the sinners' present actions.  They do not forgive, and in this canto and others, they do not even forgive others accused of the same crime which has condemned them.  And, we might add, that the first step in learning anything is forgiving one's own ignorance.

1  S'ïo avessi le rime aspre e chiocce,
2  come si converrebbe al tristo buco
3  sovra 'l qual pontan tutte l'altre rocce,

1  If I had rhymes both rough and stridulous,
2  As were appropriate to the dismal hole
3  Down upon which thrust all the other rocks,

4  io premerei di mio concetto il suco
5  più pienamente; ma perch' io non l'abbo,
6  non sanza tema a dicer mi conduco;

4  I would press out the juice of my conception
5  More fully; but because I have them not,
6  Not without fear I bring myself to speak;

7  ché non è impresa da pigliare a gabbo
8  discriver fondo a tutto l'universo,
9  né da lingua che chiami mamma o babbo.

7  For 'tis no enterprise to take in jest,
8  To sketch the bottom of all the universe,
9  Nor for a tongue that cries Mamma and Babbo.

10  Ma quelle donne aiutino il mio verso
11  ch'aiutaro Anfïone a chiuder Tebe,
12  sì che dal fatto il dir non sia diverso.

10  But may those Ladies help this verse of mine,
11  Who helped Amphion in enclosing Thebes,
12  That from the fact the word be not diverse.

13  Oh sovra tutte mal creata plebe
14  che stai nel loco onde parlare è duro,
15  mei foste state qui pecore o zebe!

13  O rabble ill-begotten above all,
14  Who're in the place to speak of which is hard,
15  'Twere better ye had here been sheep or goats!

16  Come noi fummo giù nel pozzo scuro
17  sotto i piè del gigante assai più bassi,
18  e io mirava ancora a l'alto muro,

16  When we were down within the darksome well,
17  Beneath the giant's feet, but lower far,
18  And I was scanning still the lofty wall,

19  dicere udi'mi: “Guarda come passi:
20  va sì, che tu non calchi con le piante
21  le teste de' fratei miseri lassi.”

19  I heard it said to me: "Look how thou steppest!
20  Take heed thou do not trample with thy feet
21  The heads of the tired, miserable brothers!"

22  Per ch'io mi volsi, e vidimi davante
23  e sotto i piedi un lago che per gelo
24  avea di vetro e non d'acqua sembiante.

22  Whereat I turned me round, and saw before me
23  And underfoot a lake, that from the frost
24  The semblance had of glass, and not of water.

25  Non fece al corso suo sì grosso velo
26  di verno la Danoia in Osterlicchi,
27  né Tanaï là sotto 'l freddo cielo,

25  So thick a veil ne'er made upon its current
26  In winter-time Danube in Austria,
27  Nor there beneath the frigid sky the Don,

28  com' era quivi; che se Tambernicchi
29  vi fosse sù caduto, o Pietrapana,
30  non avria pur da l'orlo fatto cricchi.

28  As there was here; so that if Tambernich
29  Had fallen upon it, or Pietrapana,
30  E'en at the edge 'twould not have given a creak.

31 E come a gracidar si sta la rana
32  col muso fuor de l'acqua, quando sogna
33  di spigolar sovente la villana,

31  And as to croak the frog doth place himself
32  With muzzle out of water,—when is dreaming
33  Of gleaning oftentimes the peasant-girl,—

34  livide, insin là dove appar vergogna
35  eran l'ombre dolenti ne la ghiaccia,
36  mettendo i denti in nota di cicogna.

34  Livid, as far down as where shame appears,
35  Were the disconsolate shades within the ice,
36  Setting their teeth unto the note of storks.

37  Ognuna in giù tenea volta la faccia;
38  da bocca il freddo, e da li occhi il cor tristo
39  tra lor testimonianza si procaccia.

37  Each one his countenance held downward bent;
38  From mouth the cold, from eyes the doleful heart
39  Among them witness of itself procures.

40  Quand' io m'ebbi dintorno alquanto visto,
41  volsimi a' piedi, e vidi due sì stretti,
42  che 'l pel del capo avieno insieme misto.

40  When round about me somewhat I had looked,
41  I downward turned me, and saw two so close,
42  The hair upon their heads together mingled.

43  “Ditemi, voi che sì strignete i petti,”
44  diss' io, “chi siete?” E quei piegaro i colli;
45  e poi ch'ebber li visi a me eretti,

43"Ye who so strain your breasts together, tell me,"
44  I said, "who are you;" and they bent their necks,
45  And when to me their faces they had lifted,

46  li occhi lor, ch'eran pria pur dentro molli,
47  gocciar su per le labbra, e 'l gelo strinse
48  le lagrime tra essi e riserrolli.

46  Their eyes, which first were only moist within,
47  Gushed o'er the eyelids, and the frost congealed
48  The tears between, and locked them up again.

49  Con legno legno spranga mai non cinse
50  forte così; ond' ei come due becchi
51  cozzaro insieme, tanta ira li vinse.

49  Clamp never bound together wood with wood
50  So strongly; whereat they, like two he-goats,
51  Butted together, so much wrath o'ercame them.

52  E un ch'avea perduti ambo li orecchi
53  per la freddura, pur col viso in giùe,
54  disse: “Perché cotanto in noi ti specchi?

52  And one, who had by reason of the cold
53  Lost both his ears, still with his visage downward,
54  Said: "Why dost thou so mirror thyself in us?

55  Se vuoi saper chi son cotesti due,
56  la valle onde Bisenzo si dichina
57  del padre loro Alberto e di lor fue.

55  If thou desire to know who these two are,
56  The valley whence Bisenzio descends
57  Belonged to them and to their father Albert.

58  D'un corpo usciro; e tutta la Caina
59  potrai cercare, e non troverai ombra
60  degna più d'esser fitta in gelatina:

58  They from one body came, and all Caina
59  Thou shalt search through, and shalt not find a shade
60   More worthy to be fixed in gelatine;

61  non quelli a cui fu rotto il petto e l'ombra
62  con esso un colpo per la man d'Artù;
63  non Focaccia; non questi che m'ingombra

61  Not he in whom were broken breast and shadow
62  At one and the same blow by Arthur's hand;
63  Focaccia not; not he who me encumbers

64  col capo sì, ch'i' non veggio oltre più,
65  e fu nomato Sassol Mascheroni;
66   se tosco se', ben sai omai chi fu.

64  So with his head I see no farther forward,
65  And bore the name of Sassol Mascheroni;
66  Well knowest thou who he was, if thou art Tuscan.

67  E perché non mi metti in più sermoni,
68  sappi ch'i' fu' il Camiscion de' Pazzi;
69  e aspetto Carlin che mi scagioni.”

67  And that thou put me not to further speech,
68  Know that I Camicion de' Pazzi was,
69  And wait Carlino to exonerate me."

70  Poscia vid' io mille visi cagnazzi
71  fatti per freddo; onde mi vien riprezzo,
72  e verrà sempre, de' gelati guazzi.

70  Then I beheld a thousand faces, made
71  Purple with cold; whence o'er me comes a shudder,
72  And evermore will come, at frozen ponds.

73  E mentre ch'andavamo inver' lo mezzo
74  al quale ogne gravezza si rauna,
75  e io tremava ne l'etterno rezzo;

73  And while we were advancing tow'rds the middle,
74  Where everything of weight unites together,
75  And I was shivering in the eternal shade,

76  se voler fu o destino o fortuna,
77  non so; ma, passeggiando tra le teste,
78  forte percossi 'l piè nel viso ad una.
76  Whether 'twere will, or destiny, or chance,
77  I know not; but in walking 'mong the heads
78  I struck my foot hard in the face of one.

79  Piangendo mi sgridò: “Perché mi peste?
80  se tu non vieni a crescer la vendetta
82  di Montaperti, perché mi moleste?”

79  Weeping he growled: "Why dost thou trample me?
80  Unless thou comest to increase the vengeance
81  of Montaperti, why dost thou molest me?"

82  E io: “Maestro mio, or qui m'aspetta,
83  sì ch'io esca d'un dubbio per costui;
84  poi mi farai, quantunque vorrai, fretta.”

82  And I: "My Master, now wait here for me,
83 That I through him may issue from a doubt;
84  Then thou mayst hurry me, as thou shalt wish."

85  Lo duca stette, e io dissi a colui
86  che bestemmiava duramente ancora:
87  “Qual se' tu che così rampogni altrui?”

85  The Leader stopped; and to that one I said
86  Who was blaspheming vehemently still:
87  "Who art thou, that thus reprehendest others?"

88  “Or tu chi se' che vai per l'Antenora,
89  percotendo,” rispuose, “altrui le gote,
90  sì che, se fossi vivo, troppo fora?”

88  "Now who art thou, that goest through Antenora
89  Smiting," replied he, "other people's cheeks,
90  So that, if thou wert living, 'twere too much?"

91  “Vivo son io, e caro esser ti puote,”
92  fu mia risposta, “se dimandi fama,
93  ch'io metta il nome tuo tra l'altre note.”

91  "Living I am, and dear to thee it may be,"
92  Was my response, "if thou demandest fame,
93  That 'mid the other notes thy name I place."

94  Ed elli a me: “Del contrario ho io brama.
95  Lèvati quinci e non mi dar più lagna,
96  ché mal sai lusingar per questa lama!”

94  And he to me: "For the reverse I long;
95  Take thyself hence, and give me no more trouble;
96  For ill thou knowest to flatter in this hollow."

97  Allor lo presi per la cuticagna
98  e dissi: “El converrà che tu ti nomi,
99  o che capel qui sù non ti rimagna.”

97  Then by the scalp behind I seized upon him,
98  And said: "It must needs be thou name thyself,
99  Or not a hair remain upon thee here."

100  Ond' elli a me: “Perché tu mi dischiomi,
101  né ti dirò ch'io sia, né mosterrolti
102  se mille fiate in sul capo mi tomi.”

100  Whence he to me: "Though thou strip off my hair,
101  I will not tell thee who I am, nor show thee,
102  If on my head a thousand times thou fall."

103  Io avea già i capelli in mano avvolti,
104  e tratti glien' avea più d'una ciocca,
105  latrando lui con li occhi in giù raccolti,

103  I had his hair in hand already twisted,
104  And more than one shock of it had pulled out,
105  He barking, with his eyes held firmly down,

106  quando un altro gridò: “Che hai tu, Bocca?
107  non ti basta sonar con le mascelle,
108  se tu non latri? qual diavol ti tocca?”

106  When cried another: "What doth ail thee, Bocca?
107  Is't not enough to clatter with thy jaws,
108  But thou must bark? what devil touches thee?"

109  “Omai,” diss' io, “non vo' che più favelle,
110  malvagio traditor; ch'a la tua onta
111  io porterò di te vere novelle.”
109  "Now," said I, "I care not to have thee speak,
110  Accursed traitor; for unto thy shame
111  I will report of thee veracious news."

112  “Va via,” rispuose, “e ciò che tu vuoi conta;
113  ma non tacer, se tu di qua entro eschi,
114  di quel ch'ebbe or così la lingua pronta.

112  "Begone," replied he, "and tell what thou wilt,
113  But be not silent, if thou issue hence,
114  Of him who had just now his tongue so prompt;

115  El piange qui l'argento de' Franceschi:
116  'Io vidi,' potrai dir, 'quel da Duera
117  là dove i peccatori stanno freschi.'

115  He weepeth here the silver of the French;
116  'I saw,' thus canst thou phrase it, 'him of Duera
117  There where the sinners stand out in the cold.'

118  Se fossi domandato 'Altri chi v'era?'
119  tu hai dallato quel di Beccheria
120  di cui segò Fiorenza la gorgiera.

118  If thou shouldst questioned be who else was there,
119  Thou hast beside thee him of Beccaria,
120  Of whom the gorget Florence slit asunder;

121  Gianni de' Soldanier credo che sia
122  più là con Ganellone e Tebaldello,
123  ch'aprì Faenza quando si dormia.”

121  Gianni del Soldanier, I think, may be
122  Yonder with Ganellon, and Tebaldello
123  Who oped Faenza when the people slep."

124  Noi eravam partiti già da ello,
125  ch'io vidi due ghiacciati in una buca,
126  sì che l'un capo a l'altro era cappello;

124  Already we had gone away from him,
125  When I beheld two frozen in one hole,
126  So that one head a hood was to the other;

127  e come 'l pan per fame si manduca,
128  così 'l sovran li denti a l'altro pose
129  là 've 'l cervel s'aggiugne con la nuca:

127  And even as bread through hunger is devoured,
128  The uppermost on the other set his teeth,
129  There where the brain is to the nape united.

130  non altrimenti Tidëo si rose
131  le tempie a Menalippo per disdegno,
132  che quei faceva il teschio e l'altre cose.

130  Not in another fashion Tydeus gnawed
131  The temples of Menalippus in disdain,
132  Than that one did the skull and the other things.

133  “O tu che mostri per sì bestial segno
134  odio sovra colui che tu ti mangi,
135  dimmi 'l perché,” diss' io, “per tal convegno,

133  "O thou, who showest by such bestial sign
134  Thy hatred against him whom thou art eating,
135  Tell me the wherefore," said I, "with this compact,

136  che se tu a ragion di lui ti piangi,
137  sappiendo chi voi siete e la sua pecca,
138  nel mondo suso ancora io te ne cangi,

136  That if thou rightfully of him complain,
137  In knowing who ye are, and his transgression,
138  I in the world above repay thee for it,

139  se quella con ch'io parlo non si secca.”

140  If that wherewith I speak be not dried up."

Canto XXXIII
Canto XXXIII of the Inferno is a propounding of multiple horrors, so atrocious, so repulsive and so grotesque that their very existence, especially as presented here as a sort of imperishable Akasic memory of God's response to sin, challenges, for me at least, the whole idea of retributive punishment.  In the first few lines — the image of Ugolino's head gnawing on the nape and brains of Archbishop Ruggieri — we already have the classic three positions: Victim, Victimizer, Witness.  Inside the poem the witness is the aspirant, Dante, but there are other witnesses too, the readers, us ... just how exactly are we to react to this kind of grotesque image of eternal punishment?  Is such evil archetypal in the Jungian psychological sense?  The second word of the canto is bocca, mouth, and when I read this, I thought of a concept that I marked years ago in a book on Alchemy (Alchemy: The Medieval Alchemists and their Royal Art; Johannes Fabricius, pg. 57).  In this book there is a caption for an image which reads: "The 'oral triad' of alchemy: the wish to eat, to be eaten, and to sleep."  And this passage seems apropos to what is happening here.  The wish to eat, the wish to sleep, it takes no great introspection to comprehend those desires ... but the wish to be eaten?  Isn't that the idea of the Eucharist?  The believer eats the body of Christ, so does that mean that the wish to be eaten would be an Imitation of Christ?  When one of Ugolino's sons tells him (lines 61-63) that they (the sons) would suffer less if he would feed on them, we have presented here the wish to be eaten, but presented here in such bizarre and repulsive circumstances that we could hardly suppose such a desire to part of normal human consciousness.  Is it?  This whole canto makes a point of showing instances when hosts invited their enemies to a banquet, and then murdered them: and we need only remember that the wafer which symbolizes Christ's body is called the "host", and we see here another parody in Hell, where salvation's rituals are infernally perverted.  All kinds of things swim into consciousness as we remember such things as Christ's words in Mathew 15:18: "And he called the multitude, and said unto them, Hear, and understand: Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man."  Ugolino's words defile him, but his silence does too, when his stoicism, or stunned grief, or false sense of pride, keeps him from offering comfort to his sons.  And we should not forget the text's use of that third desire: sleep, which is in this canto a harbinger of the true horror of the Ugolino clan's predicament.  Note too the maleness of this whole scene.  One would think food/mother would be an indivisible bond, but the food here is not mother's milk, it is murderous deceit, the deceit perhaps of incarnation, wherein, as a Zen saying goes, We eat to survive to be hungry.  Another way to look at this is that we share even with our worst enemies a terrible rapport formed by this oral triad.

What rapport is that?  And between whom?  Between Dante, the aspirant, Francesca (in Canto 5), and Ugolino here.  Note how lines 4 -6 in this canto echo lines 4 - 6 in Canto I.  In both, speaking recalls terrible emotions, respectively grief and fear.  In both the speaker consents to speak in spite of this.  But Ugolino wishes to speak because he desires to bring more ignominy to his enemy, while aspirant wishes to speak so that what he says might do some good to others.  The other image that links this canto with earlier ones with this one is the image of the hounds pursuing a wolf and whelps on the mountain, and this flashes us to the she-wolf who confronts the aspirant as he tries to climb the mountain, and also the mysterious lines allegorically comparing a political savior to a greyhound perusing a wolf.  (The canine imagery provides a lot of "food" for thought.  Dogs eat their own vomit, and also the feces of their pups, what then are the consumers of the communion of the Divine Comedy's text supposed to be eating here?).   Both Ugolino and Francesca say that they're speaking will be combined with weeping, and both plead for Dante's sympathy.  But in this case, the aspirant shows us the difference, since in the case of Francesca he feels sympathy (and is rebuked for it), yet in the case Ugolino, the aspirant breaks into a tirade which can only be interpreted as a case for mass murder of all the Pisans.  He imagines damming the Arno and drowning them all.  Are we supposed to think here or God's righteous anger when he destroyed the world by flood, or when he destroyed the population of Sodom and Gomorra?  The aspirant also lies and further torments other sinners in this canto.  He becomes more than a witness, his blood is up, and he lashes out physically ... and so we come to the issue of The Witness.  In these three cases, there are witnesses.  Not unusual, because there are always witnesses.  As readers, we are witnesses.  So?  So, how should a witness respond to this archetype of victim and victimizer?  In Canto I, it is the Virgin Mary (sending her surrogate St. Lucy, who informs Beatrice) who is witness to Dante's waywardness.  In Canto V and here in Canto XXXIII, it is Dante, the aspirant, who is witness.  What are we to make of all these connections and contrasts (only a sampling here, a good reader could no doubt find more)?  We could think of these relationships as constellations of figures who arrange themselves around a moral issue.  I think by presenting all these possibilities here that the poet, Dante, wants to leave the question of the placements of these figures, and even an absolute definition of what moral issue is at stake, to be answered in the minds and hearts of his readers.  It's not as if these questions can ever be answered, but contemplating them seems to me to wonderfully proliferating of insights, not only into Dante, but into the possibility of achieve a spiritual transcendence.   

We see for example a weird parody of Christ's "the stones would cry out" rebuke on Palm Sunday, to Ugolino's statement he turned to stone and would not cry out to comfort his dying sons.  And in line 150 we find the scattering of the Genovese (wonderful rhyming of diversi and spersi), like the scattering of people and their languages at the fall of the tower of Babble.  I find it fascinating that Dante the writer, as the shades in hell become more and more immobilized, literally frozen their agony, has not painted himself into a box at all, but continues to enrich his text, with all these culminations and connections.
