We could also talk about the cumulative portrayals of Time throughout the cantos: Why do some of the dead know the future or the fates of people distant from them in time?  I think you could think of the souls already bilocating in Hell while their bodies remain as shells on earth, shells inhabited by devils, as entities split and scattered not only in different places (above, on earth; below, in hell), but also in time (dead before they are dead, and alive after they are dead).  These possessions of the body's shell, reminded me of the Qliphot in the Kabbala, which at least one author (Mark Jay Mirsky, Dante, Eros, & Kabbalah) claims Dante knew.

Last note: I'm struggling with overwhelm reading this text, so many great and crucial things revealed, but it's so hard to assimilate them.  I feel swept away, drowning.    

1  La bocca sollevò dal fiero pasto
2  quel peccator, forbendola a' capelli
3  del capo ch'elli avea di retro guasto.

1  His mouth uplifted from his grim repast,
2  That sinner, wiping it upon the hair
3  Of the same head that he behind had wasted.

4  Poi cominciò: “Tu vuo' ch'io rinovelli
5  disperato dolor che 'l cor mi preme
6  già pur pensando, pria ch'io ne favelli.

4  Then he began: "Thou wilt that I renew
5  The desperate grief, which wrings my heart already
6  To think of only, ere I speak of it;

7  Ma se le mie parole esser dien seme
8  che frutti infamia al traditor ch'i' rodo,
9  parlare e lagrimar vedrai insieme.

7  But if my words be seed that may bear fruit
8  Of infamy to the traitor whom I gnaw,
9  Speaking and weeping shalt thou see together.

10  Io non so chi tu se' né per che modo
11  venuto se' qua giù; ma fiorentino
12  mi sembri veramente quand' io t'odo.

10  I know not who thou art, nor by what mode
11  Thou hast come down here; but a Florentine
12  Thou seemest to me truly, when I hear thee.

13  Tu dei saper ch'i' fui conte Ugolino,
14  e questi è l'arcivescovo Ruggieri:
15  or ti dirò perché i son tal vicino.

13  Thou hast to know I was Count Ugolino,
14  And this one was Ruggieri the Archbishop;
15  Now I will tell thee why I am such a neighbour.

16  Che per l'effetto de' suo' mai pensieri,
17  fidandomi di lui, io fossi preso
18  e poscia morto, dir non è mestieri;

16  That, by effect of his malicious thoughts,
17  Trusting in him I was made prisoner,
18  And after put to death, I need not say;

19  però quel che non puoi avere inteso,
20  cioè come la morte mia fu cruda,
21  udirai, e saprai s'e' m'ha offeso.

19  But ne'ertheless what thou canst not have heard,
20  That is to say, how cruel was my death,
21  Hear shalt thou, and shalt know if he has wronged me.

22  Breve pertugio dentro da la Muda,
23  la qual per me ha 'l titol de la fame,
24  e che conviene ancor ch'altrui si chiuda,

22  A narrow perforation in the mew,
23  Which bears because of me the title of Famine,
24  And in which others still must be locked up,

25  m'avea mostrato per lo suo forame
26  più lune già, quand' io feci 'l mal sonno
27  che del futuro mi squarciò 'l velame.

25  Had shown me through its opening many moons
26  Already, when I dreamed the evil dream
27  Which of the future rent for me the veil.

28  Questi pareva a me maestro e donno,
29  cacciando il lupo e ' lupicini al monte
30  per che i Pisan veder Lucca non ponno.

28  This one appeared to me as lord and master,
29  Hunting the wolf and whelps upon the mountain
30  For which the Pisans cannot Lucca see.

31  Con cagne magre, studïose e conte
32  Gualandi con Sismondi e con Lanfranchi
33  s'avea messi dinanzi da la fronte.

31  With sleuth-hounds gaunt, and eager, and well trained,
32  Gualandi with Sismondi and Lanfianchi
33  He had sent out before him to the front.

34  In picciol corso mi parieno stanchi
35  lo padre e ' figli, e con l'agute scane
36  mi parea lor veder fender li fianchi.

34  After brief course seemed unto me forespent
35  The father and the sons, and with sharp tushes
36  It seemed to me I saw their flanks ripped open.

37  Quando fui desto innanzi la dimane,
38  pianger senti' fra 'l sonno i miei figliuoli
39  ch'eran con meco, e dimandar del pane.

37  When I before the morrow was awake,
38  Moaning amid their sleep I heard my sons
39  Who with me were, and asking after bread.

40  Ben se' crudel, se tu già non ti duoli
41  pensando ciò che 'l mio cor s'annunziava;
42  e se non piangi, di che pianger suoli?

40  Cruel indeed art thou, if yet thou grieve not,
41  Thinking of what my heart foreboded me,
42  And weep'st thou not, what art thou wont to weep at?

43  Già eran desti, e l'ora s'appressava
44  che 'l cibo ne solëa essere addotto,
45  e per suo sogno ciascun dubitava;

43  They were awake now, and the hour drew nigh
44  At which our food used to be brought to us,
45  And through his dream was each one apprehensive;

46  e io senti' chiavar l'uscio di sotto
47  a l'orribile torre; ond' io guardai
48  nel viso a' mie' figliuoi sanza far motto.

46  And I heard locking up the under door
47  Of the horrible tower; whereat without a word
48  I gazed into the faces of my sons.

49  Io non piangëa, sì dentro impetrai:
50  piangevan elli; e Anselmuccio mio
51  disse: 'Tu guardi sì, padre! che hai?'

49  I wept not, I within so turned to stone;
50  They wept; and darling little Anselm mine
51  Said: 'Thou dost gaze so, father, what doth ail thee?'

52  Perciò non lagrimai né rispuos' io
53  tutto quel giorno né la notte appresso,
54  infin che l'altro sol nel mondo uscìo.

52  Still not a tear I shed, nor answer made
53  All of that day, nor yet the night thereafter,
54  Until another sun rose on the world.

55  Come un poco di raggio si fu messo
56  nel doloroso carcere, e io scorsi
57  per quattro visi il mio aspetto stesso,

55  As now a little glimmer made its way
56  Into the dolorous prison, and I saw
57  Upon four faces my own very aspect,

58  ambo le man per lo dolor mi morsi;
59  ed ei, pensando ch'io 'l fessi per voglia
60  di manicar, di sùbito levorsi

58  Both of my hands in agony I bit;
59  And, thinking that I did it from desire
60  Of eating, on a sudden they uprose,

61  e disser: 'Padre, assai ci fia men doglia
62  se tu mangi di noi: tu ne vestisti
63  queste misere carni, e tu le spoglia.'

61  And said they: 'Father, much less pain 'twill give us
62  If thou do eat of us; thyself didst clothe us
63  With this poor flesh, and do thou strip it off.'

64  Queta'mi allor per non farli più tristi;
65  lo dì e l'altro stemmo tutti muti;
66  ahi dura terra, perché non t'apristi?

64  I calmed me then, not to make them more sad.
65  That day we all were silent, and the next.
66  Ah! obdurate earth, wherefore didst thou not open?

67  Poscia che fummo al quarto dì venuti,
68  Gaddo mi si gittò disteso a' piedi,
69  dicendo: 'Padre mio, che non m'aiuti?'

67  When we had come unto the fourth day, Gaddo
68  Threw himself down outstretched before my feet,
69  Saying, 'My father, why dost thou not help me?'

70  Quivi morì; e come tu mi vedi,
71  vid' io cascar li tre ad uno ad uno
72  tra 'l quinto dì e 'l sesto; ond' io mi diedi,

70  And there he died; and, as thou seest me,
71  I saw the three fall, one by one, between
72  The fifth day and the sixth; whence I betook me,

73  già cieco, a brancolar sovra ciascuno,
74  e due dì li chiamai, poi che fur morti.
75  Poscia, più che 'l dolor, poté 'l digiuno.”

73  Already blind, to groping over each,
74  And three days called them after they were dead;
75  Then hunger did what sorrow could not do."

76  Quand' ebbe detto ciò, con li occhi torti
77  riprese 'l teschio misero co' denti,
78  che furo a l'osso, come d'un can, forti.

76  When he had said this, with his eyes distorted,
77  The wretched skull resumed he with his teeth,
78  Which, as a dog's, upon the bone were strong.

79  Ahi Pisa, vituperio de le genti
80  del bel paese là dove 'l sì suona,
81  poi che i vicini a te punir son lenti,

79  Ah! Pisa, thou opprobrium of the people
80  Of the fair land there where the 'Si' doth sound,
81  Since slow to punish thee thy neighbours are,

82  muovasi la Capraia e la Gorgona,
83  e faccian siepe ad Arno in su la foce,
84  sì ch'elli annieghi in te ogne persona!

82  Let the Capraia and Gorgona move,
83  And make a hedge across the mouth of Arno
84  That every person in thee it may drown!

85  Che se 'l conte Ugolino aveva voce
86  d'aver tradita te de le castella,
87  non dovei tu i figliuoi porre a tal croce.

85  For if Count Ugolino had the fame
86  Of having in thy castles thee betrayed,
87  Thou shouldst not on such cross have put his sons.

88  Innocenti facea l'età novella,
89  novella Tebe, Uguiccione e 'l Brigata
90  e li altri due che 'l canto suso appella.

88  Guiltless of any crime, thou modern Thebes!
89  Their youth made Uguccione and Brigata,
90  And the other two my song doth name above!

91  Noi passammo oltre, là 've la gelata
92  ruvidamente un'altra gente fascia,
93  non volta in giù, ma tutta riversata.

91  We passed still farther onward, where the ice
92  Another people ruggedly enswathes,
93  Not downward turned, but all of them reversed.

94  Lo pianto stesso lì pianger non lascia,
95  e 'l duol che truova in su li occhi rintoppo,
96  si volge in entro a far crescer l'ambascia;

94  Weeping itself there does not let them weep,
95  And grief that finds a barrier in the eyes
96  Turns itself inward to increase the anguish;

97  ché le lagrime prime fanno groppo,
98  e sì come visiere di cristallo,
99  rïempion sotto 'l ciglio tutto il coppo.

97  Because the earliest tears a cluster form,
98  And, in the manner of a crystal visor,
99  Fill all the cup beneath the eyebrow full.

100  E avvegna che, sì come d'un callo,
101  per la freddura ciascun sentimento
102  cessato avesse del mio viso stallo,

100  And notwithstanding that, as in a callus,
101  Because of cold all sensibility
102  Its station had abandoned in my face,

103  già mi parea sentire alquanto vento;
104  per ch'io: “Maestro mio, questo chi move?
105  non è qua giù ogne vapore spento?”

103  Still it appeared to me I felt some wind;
104  Whence I: "My Master, who sets this in motion?
105  Is not below here every vapour quenched?"

106  Ond' elli a me: “Avaccio sarai dove
107  di ciò ti farà l'occhio la risposta,
108  veggendo la cagion che 'l fiato piove.”

106  Whence he to me: "Full soon shalt thou be where
107  Thine eye shall answer make to thee of this,
108  Seeing the cause which raineth down the blast."

109  E un de' tristi de la fredda crosta
110  gridò a noi: “O anime crudeli
111  tanto che data v'è l'ultima posta,

109  And one of the wretches of the frozen crust
110  Cried out to us: "O souls so merciless
111  That the last post is given unto you,

112  levatemi dal viso i duri veli,
113  sì ch'ïo sfoghi 'l duol che 'l cor m'impregna,
114  un poco, pria che 'l pianto si raggeli.”

112  Lift from mine eyes the rigid veils, that I
113  May vent the sorrow which impregns my heart
114  A little, e'er the weeping recongeal."

115  Per ch'io a lui: “Se vuo' ch'i' ti sovvegna,
116  dimmi chi se', e s'io non ti disbrigo,
117  al fondo de la ghiaccia ir mi convegna.”

115  Whence I to him: "If thou wouldst have me help thee
116  Say who thou wast; and if I free thee not,
117  May I go to the bottom of the ice."

118  Rispuose adunque: “I' son frate Alberigo;
119  i' son quel da le frutta del mal orto,
120  che qui riprendo dattero per figo.”

118  Then he replied: "I am Friar Alberigo;
119  He am I of the fruit of the bad garden,
120  Who here a date am getting for my fig."

121  “Oh,” diss' io lui, “or se' tu ancor morto?”
122  Ed elli a me: “Come 'l mio corpo stea
123  nel mondo sù, nulla scïenza porto.

121  "O," said I to him, "now art thou, too, dead?"
122  And he to me: "How may my body fare
123  Up in the world, no knowledge I possess.

124  Cotal vantaggio ha questa Tolomea,
125  che spesse volte l'anima ci cade
126  innanzi ch'Atropòs mossa le dea.

124  Such an advantage has this Ptolomaea,
125  That oftentimes the soul descendeth here
126  Sooner than Atropos in motion sets it.

124  E perché tu più volontier mi rade
125  le 'nvetrïate lagrime dal volto,
126  sappie che, tosto che l'anima trade

127  And, that thou mayest more willingly remove
128  From off my countenance these glassy tears,
129  Know that as soon as any soul betrays

130  com fec' ïo, il corpo suo l'è tolto
131  da un demonio, che poscia il governa
132  mentre che 'l tempo suo tutto sia vòlto.

130  As I have done, his body by a demon
131  Is taken from him, who thereafter rules it,
132  Until his time has wholly been revolved.

133  Ella ruina in sì fatta cisterna;
134  e forse pare ancor lo corpo suso
135  de l'ombra che di qua dietro mi verna.

133  Itself down rushes into such a cistern;
134  And still perchance above appears the body
135  Of yonder shade, that winters here behind me.

136  Tu 'l dei saper, se tu vien pur mo giuso;
137  elli è ser Branca Doria, e son più anni
138  poscia passati ch'el fu sì racchiuso.”

136  This thou shouldst know, if thou hast just come down;
137  It is Ser Branca d' Oria, and many years
138  Have passed away since he was thus locked up."

139  “Io credo,” diss' io lui, “che tu m'inganni;
140  ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche,
141  e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni.”

139  "I think," said I to him, "thou dost deceive me;
140  For Branca d' Oria is not dead as yet,
141  And eats, and drinks, and sleeps, and puts on clothes."

142  “Nel fosso sù,” diss' el, “de' Malebranche,
143  là dove bolle la tenace pece,
144  non era ancora giunto Michel Zanche,

142  "In moat above," said he, "of Malebranche,
143  There where is boiling the tenacious pitch,
144  As yet had Michel Zanche not arrived,

145  che questi lasciò il diavolo in sua vece
146  nel corpo suo, ed un suo prossimano
147  che 'l tradimento insieme con lui fece.

145  When this one left a devil in his stead
146  In his own body and one near of kin,
147  Who made together with him the betrayal.

148  Ma distendi oggimai in qua la mano;
149  aprimi li occhi.” E io non gliel' apersi;
150  e cortesia fu lui esser villano.

148  But hitherward stretch out thy hand forthwith,
149  Open mine eyes;"—and open them I did not,
150  And to be rude to him was courtesy.

151  Ahi Genovesi, uomini diversi
152  d'ogne costume e pien d'ogne magagna,
153  perché non siete voi del mondo spersi?

151  Ah, Genoese! ye men at variance
152  With every virtue, full of every vice
153  Wherefore are ye not scattered from the world?

154  Ché col peggiore spirto di Romagna
155  trovai di voi un tal, che per sua opra
156  in anima in Cocito già si bagna,

154  For with the vilest spirit of Romagna
155  I found of you one such, who for his deeds
156 In soul already in Cocytus bathes,

157  e in corpo par vivo ancor di sopra.

157  And still above in body seems alive!

Canto XXXIV
In every Individual Man, and the limit of Opakeness,             
Is named Satan: and the limit of Contraction is named Adam.

William Blake

Well here we are, the last canto of the Inferno, and what an incredibly eerie place this is.  Here the source of all the evil in the world is portrayed, not in the Robert Lewis Stevenson sense of an alacritous life-loving Mr. Hyde-like force, but as something silent, frozen, impenetrable.  I wanted to say immovable, and that is true, in the sense of any movement animated by an internal or volitional sense of self, but Satan in this canto is depicted as more machine than being.  Dante makes this clear in line by comparing his motion of his wings to that of a windmill, a kind of gigantic piece of stage machinery, a gadget fueled my its own suffering, as it the angel which he once was was consumed by his own sense of egoistic pride.  If you are a serious, committed reader of Dante, when you get here, you may very well feel a paralysis of will, and a paralysis of insight, because here is the place where progressive time has stopped, and we are reminded of that notion that the fall of Satan was the first event to occur in time.  If we have seen in Canto XXXIII in the figure of Ugolino the misuse of the mouth as a source of cannibalism and deceptive speech, the last active apotheosis of evil, here we see evil's culmination: an artic waste whose wind is not the breath of spirit, but a merely mechanical whirring of wings ("Sails", with the duel meaning of a boat's sail and also of wings, since in falconry, the hawk's wings are also called sails.).  Satan here is can hardly be given the name entity, he has been reduced to the condition of a contrivance.  The description made me think of Descartes' view of animals as mere instinct machines without souls.  In which case, this evil-machine is like one of the cats in the famous cat clavier, which, when a key is depressed, it causes a creature to yowl.  Does this mean that God has offloaded the evil in His creation to one who has forfeited creature status (Dante calls Satan La creatura, in his former state as a light-giver, i.e. Lucifer, line 18) and is now a mere puppet, a kind of reversal of the path of Pinocchio, who through his nefarious misuse of freedom, has imprisoned himself forever as the mechanism of cause and effect, as cause, the source of suffering, as effect, it's ultimate depository.   The fact that we have inherited this view of the body and universe as mechanism (allopathic medical science operating precisely from this position), shows us just how pernicious such a condition is.  We ourselves have surrendered our beingness, our souls, to become a series of interlocking gears, driven by causes and subject to effects that operate automatically as the so-called Laws of Nature.  That is the materialist position, and when entities accept such a position as truth, they accept with it the unending despair of a true loss of subjectivity, all of its concerns for love, for freedom, for the warmth of family or friendship, for empathy, for meaning itself, become but links in a chain that bind us forever to the condition of a machine accidently assembled in the endless machinations of that old bugaboo: Time.  When the aspirant, Dante, in the poem confronts this condition he is so numbed by terror that he, like Satan himself, is speechless, and just as he was in Canto One of the Inferno, suspended in a state of unconsciousness scarcely to be distinguished from death, so here too, he enter a kind of in-between Bardo, described thusly in the following lines:

22  Com' io divenni allor gelato e fioco,
23  nol dimandar, lettor, ch'i' non lo scrivo,
24  però ch'ogne parlar sarebbe poco.

22  How frozen I became and powerless then,
23  Ask it not, Reader, for I write it not,
24  Because all language would be insufficient.

25  Io non mori' e non rimasi vivo;
26  pensa oggimai per te, s'hai fior d'ingegno,
27  qual io divenni, d'uno e d'altro privo.

25  I did not die, and I alive remained not;
26  Think for thyself now, hast thou aught of wit,
27  What I became, being of both deprived.

In brief, the condition of the sinners here, frozen in various attitudes, and fixed like figures embedded in glass (think of those heaps of corpses from the Nazi death camps, but here all higgledy-piggledy become preserved in the attitudes of their demise and fall), has become aspirant's condition.  The aspirant has now reached the very nadir of being, the last condition possible for an entity, before passing over into the utter waste of a landfill of broken machinery.

A note here about the Threeness, in the three heads/mouths/colors of Satan.  Certainly we are remined of the trinity, but also Cerberus whom we met in Canto VI, another conglomerate being with three heads, who, with his vermillion eyes and black beard (two of the three colors mentioned here) tears sinners with his mouth.  I think a contemporary reader, here, and throughout the Commedia, can easily substitute other historical figures for the Judas, Brutus, and Cassius-like figures depicted by Dante.  Anyone who subverts the health of all for his or her own personal desires can serve.  We have our own Stalins and Hitlers and Pol Pots, our own purveyors of genocide who are more of a match for the perfidy displayed by Dante's sinners.  But to return to subject of colors, in this case the vermillion (not red, or rosso), black, and a color between white and yellow.  A lot of speculation as to the symbology of these three colors has accrued over the centuries.  My own take on it is not symbolic at all, but physiological.  These I believe are the colors that the fetus in the womb experiences as light comes through the tissues of the mother's body.  Thus, for me, these colors represent the precursors of incarnation, the source of all our woes until a Christ-like realization of our matter's own divinity occurs.  These colors are like that processional of banners in the first verses of this canto, and their procession marches through time from birth to death, the first state inevitably producing the second, and moment when Dante and Virgil squeeze through that tiny opening to eventually emerge into the light of Purgatory (purgation/spiritual progress, or just the simple ability to learn, and thus change) is analogous to our passage through the birth canal.  But in this case we are being born, not into a mortal body, but into an eternal body, a body entirely comprised of spirit.  The reader should also note that time and space also change when we are reborn as spirit.  Jung has the concept of enantiodromia, a sudden psychic reversal, wherein an emotion becomes so strong that it flips to its opposite, as say, when a couple's passion for one another turns from love to hate.  Only here, the reverse is true, a universe of fear, hate, destructiveness, egotistical hooliganism, and monstrous ugliness, opens to the possibility of peace, love, creativity, compassion, and beauty.  The poem announces this just as God announced the birth of Jesus, with the vision of stars.  (The word star or stars being the last word in all three Canticles of the poem.)  And we should also note that just as Satan is speechless here, so too the aspirant at the end of the Paradiso ascends to a glory of ineffability.    

A final note on the subject of cause and effect.  There has been a lot of debate about how Virgil, an insubstantial shade, can at times be seen as substanceless, and at other times, as here, when he shields the aspirant from the freezing gales of hell, and when he carries the embodied Dante up the shank of Satan, he appears to have a material body.  There are many inconsistencies like this throughout the Commedia.  Some commentators simply assume that this is poetic licence, and in a sense it is.  But only in the sense that the creative self (and a creature in the Creator's image must in essence be nothing but a source of creativity) makes the rules, and remakes them.  That is to say, we have left the realm of mechanical cause and effect, and entered the realm of creative miracle.  For the true creator, the true artist, cause and effect is just another tool in the toolbox to make things new or stable or unstable as the spirit moves her or him.    

1  “Vexilla regis prodeunt inferni
2  verso di noi; però dinanzi mira,”
3  disse 'l maestro mio, “se tu 'l discerni.”

1  "'Vexilla Regis prodeunt Inferni'
2  Towards us; therefore look in front of thee,"
3  My Master said, "if thou discernest him."

4  Come quando una grossa nebbia spira,
5  o quando l'emisperio nostro annotta,
6  par di lungi un molin che 'l vento gira,

4  As, when there breathes a heavy fog, or when
5  Our hemisphere is darkening into night,
6  Appears far off a mill the wind is turning,

7  veder mi parve un tal dificio allotta;
8  poi per lo vento mi ristrinsi retro
9  al duca mio, ché non li era altra grotta.

7  Methought that such a building then I saw;
8  And, for the wind, I drew myself behind
9  My Guide, because there was no other shelter.

10  Già era, e con paura il metto in metro,
11  là dove l'ombre tutte eran coperte,
12  e trasparien come festuca in vetro.

10  Now was I, and with fear in verse I put it,
11  There where the shades were wholly covered up,
12  And glimmered through like unto straws in glass.

13  Altre sono a giacere; altre stanno erte,
14  quella col capo e quella con le piante;
15  altra, com' arco, il volto a' piè rinverte.

13  Some prone are lying, others stand erect,
14  This with the head, and that one with the soles;
15  Another, bow-like, face to feet inverts.

16  Quando noi fummo fatti tanto avante,
17  ch'al mio maestro piacque di mostrarmi
18  la creatura ch'ebbe il bel sembiante,

16  When in advance so far we had proceeded,
17  That it my Master pleased to show to me
18  The creature who once had the beauteous semblance,

19  d'innanzi mi si tolse e fé restarmi,
20  “Ecco Dite,” dicendo, “ed ecco il loco
21  ove convien che di fortezza t'armi.”

19  He from before me moved and made me stop,
20  Saying: "Behold Dis, and behold the place
21  Where thou with fortitude must arm thyself."

22  Com' io divenni allor gelato e fioco,
23  nol dimandar, lettor, ch'i' non lo scrivo,
24  però ch'ogne parlar sarebbe poco.

22  How frozen I became and powerless then,
23  Ask it not, Reader, for I write it not,
24  Because all language would be insufficient.

25  Io non mori' e non rimasi vivo;
26  pensa oggimai per te, s'hai fior d'ingegno,
27  qual io divenni, d'uno e d'altro privo.

25  I did not die, and I alive remained not;
26  Think for thyself now, hast thou aught of wit,
27  What I became, being of both deprived.

28  Lo 'mperador del doloroso regno
29  da mezzo 'l petto uscia fuor de la ghiaccia;
30  e più con un gigante io mi convegno,

28  The Emperor of the kingdom dolorous
29  From his mid-breast forth issued from the ice;
30  And better with a giant I compare

31  che i giganti non fan con le sue braccia:
32  vedi oggimai quant' esser dee quel tutto
33  ch'a così fatta parte si confaccia.

31  Than do the giants with those arms of his;
32  Consider now how great must be that whole,
33  Which unto such a part conforms itself.

34  S'el fu sì bel com' elli è ora brutto,
35  e contra 'l suo fattore alzò le ciglia,
36  ben dee da lui procedere ogne lutto.

34  Were he as fair once, as he now is foul,
35  And lifted up his brow against his Maker,
36  Well may proceed from him all tribulation.

37  Oh quanto parve a me gran maraviglia
38  quand' io vidi tre facce a la sua testa!
39  L'una dinanzi, e quella era vermiglia;

37  O, what a marvel it appeared to me,
38  When I beheld three faces on his head!
39  The one in front, and that vermilion was;

40  l'altr' eran due, che s'aggiugnieno a questa
41  sovresso 'l mezzo di ciascuna spalla,
42  e sé giugnieno al loco de la cresta:

40  Two were the others, that were joined with this
41  Above the middle part of either shoulder,
42  And they were joined together at the crest;

43  e la destra parea tra bianca e gialla;
44  la sinistra a vedere era tal, quali
45  vegnon di là onde 'l Nilo s'avvalla.

43  And the right-hand one seemed 'twixt white and yellow;
44  The left was such to look upon as those
45  Who come from where the Nile falls valley-ward.

46  Sotto ciascuna uscivan due grand' ali,
47  quanto si convenia a tanto uccello:
48  vele di mar non vid' io mai cotali.

46  Underneath each came forth two mighty wings,
47  Such as befitting were so great a bird;
48  Sails of the sea I never saw so large.

49  Non avean penne, ma di vispistrello
50  era lor modo; e quelle svolazzava,
51  sì che tre venti si movean da ello:

49  No feathers had they, but as of a bat
50  Their fashion was; and he was waving them,
51  So that three winds proceeded forth therefrom.

52  quindi Cocito tutto s'aggelava.
53  Con sei occhi piangëa, e per tre menti
54  gocciava 'l pianto e sanguinosa bava.

52  Thereby Cocytus wholly was congealed.
53  With six eyes did he weep, and down three chins
54  Trickled the tear-drops and the bloody drivel.

55  Da ogne bocca dirompea co' denti
56  un peccatore, a guisa di maciulla,
57  sì che tre ne facea così dolenti.

55  At every mouth he with his teeth was crunching
56  A sinner, in the manner of a brake,
57  So that he three of them tormented thus.

58  A quel dinanzi il mordere era nulla
59  verso 'l graffiar, che tal volta la schiena
60  rimanea de la pelle tutta brulla.

58  To him in front the biting was as naught
59  Unto the clawing, for sometimes the spine
60  Utterly stripped of all the skin remained.

61  “Quell' anima là sù c'ha maggior pena,”
62  disse 'l maestro, “è Giuda Scarïotto,
63  che 'l capo ha dentro e fuor le gambe mena.

61  "That soul up there which has the greatest pain,"
62  The Master said, "is Judas Iscariot;
63  With head inside, he plies his legs without.

64  De li altri due c'hanno il capo di sotto,
65  quel che pende dal nero ceffo è Bruto:
66  vedi come si storce, e non fa motto!;

64  Of the two others, who head downward are,
65  The one who hangs from the black jowl is Brutus;
66  See how he writhes himself, and speaks no word.

67  e l'altro è Cassio, che par sì membruto.
68   Ma la notte risurge, e oramai
69   è da partir, ché tutto avem veduto.”

67  And the other, who so stalwart seems, is Cassius.
68  But night is reascending, and 'tis time
69  That we depart, for we have seen the whole."

70  Com' a lui piacque, il collo li avvinghiai;
71  ed el prese di tempo e loco poste,
72  e quando l'ali fuoro aperte assai,

70  As seemed him good, I clasped him round the neck,
71  And he the vantage seized of time and place,
72  And when the wings were opened wide apart,

73  appigliò sé a le vellute coste;
74  di vello in vello giù discese poscia
75  tra 'l folto pelo e le gelate croste.

73  He laid fast hold upon the shaggy sides;
74  From fell to fell descended downward then
75  Between the thick hair and the frozen crust.

76  Quando noi fummo là dove la coscia
77  si volge, a punto in sul grosso de l'anche,
78  lo duca, con fatica e con angoscia,
76  When we were come to where the thigh revolves
77  Exactly on the thickness of the haunch,
78  The Guide, with labour and with hard-drawn breath,
79  volse la testa ov' elli avea le zanche,
80  e aggrappossi al pel com' om che sale,
81  sì che 'n inferno i' credea tornar anche.
79  Turned round his head where he had had his legs,
80  And grappled to the hair, as one who mounts,
81  So that to Hell I thought we were returning.
82  “Attienti ben, ché per cotali scale,”
83  disse 'l maestro, ansando com' uom lasso,
84  “conviensi dipartir da tanto male.”
82  "Keep fast thy hold, for by such stairs as these,"
83  The Master said, panting as one fatigued,
84  "Must we perforce depart from so much evil."
85  Poi uscì fuor per lo fóro d'un sasso
86  e puose me in su l'orlo a sedere;
87  appresso porse a me l'accorto passo.
85  Then through the opening of a rock he issued,
86  And down upon the margin seated me;
87  Then tow'rds me he outstretched his wary step.
88  Io levai li occhi e credetti vedere
89  Lucifero com' io l'avea lasciato,
90  e vidili le gambe in sù tenere;

88  I lifted up mine eyes and thought to see
89  Lucifer in the same way I had left him;
90  And I beheld him upward hold his legs.

91  e s'io divenni allora travagliato,
92  la gente grossa il pensi, che non vede
93  qual è quel punto ch'io avea passato.

91  And if I then became disquieted,
92  Let stolid people think who do not see
93  What the point is beyond which I had passed.

94  “Lèvati sù,” disse 'l maestro, “in piede:
95  la via è lunga e 'l cammino è malvagio,
96  e già il sole a mezza terza riede.”

94  "Rise up," the Master said, "upon thy feet;
95  The way is long, and difficult the road,
96  And now the sun to middle-tierce returns."

97  Non era camminata di palagio
98  là 'v' eravam, ma natural burella
99  ch'avea mal suolo e di lume disagio.

97  It was not any palace corridor
98  There where we were, but dungeon natural,
99  With floor uneven and unease of light.

100  “Prima ch'io de l'abisso mi divella,
101  maestro mio,” diss' io quando fui dritto,
102  “a trarmi d'erro un poco mi favella:

100  "Ere from the abyss I tear myself away,
101  My Master," said I when I had arisen,
102  "To draw me from an error speak a little;

103  ov' è la ghiaccia? e questi com' è fitto
104  sì sottosopra? e come, in sì poc' ora,
105  da sera a mane ha fatto il sol tragitto?”

103  Where is the ice? and how is this one fixed
104  Thus upside down? and how in such short time
105  From eve to morn has the sun made his transit?"

106  Ed elli a me: “Tu imagini ancora
107  d'esser di là dal centro, ov' io mi presi
108  al pel del vermo reo che 'l mondo fóra.

106  And he to me: "Thou still imaginest
107  Thou art beyond the centre, where I grasped
108  The hair of the fell worm, who mines the world.

109  Di là fosti cotanto quant' io scesi;
110  quand' io mi volsi, tu passasti 'l punto
111  al qual si traggon d'ogne parte i pesi.

109  That side thou wast, so long as I descended;
110  When round I turned me, thou didst pass the point
111  To which things heavy draw from every side,

112  E se' or sotto l'emisperio giunto
113  ch'è contraposto a quel che la gran secca
114  coverchia, e sotto 'l cui colmo consunto

112  And now beneath the hemisphere art come
113  Opposite that which overhangs the vast
114  Dry-land, and 'neath whose cope was put to death

115  fu l'uom che nacque e visse sanza pecca;
116  tu hai i piedi in su picciola spera
117  che l'altra faccia fa de la Giudecca.

115  The Man who without sin was born and lived.
116  Thou hast thy feet upon the little sphere
117  Which makes the other face of the Judecca.

118  Qui è da man, quando di là è sera;
119  e questi, che ne fé scala col pelo,
120  fitto è ancora si come prim' era.

118  Here it is morn when it is evening there;
119  And he who with his hair a stairway made us
120  Still fixed remaineth as he was before.

121  Da questa parte cadde giù dal cielo;
122  e la terra, che pria di qua si sporse,
123  per paura di lui fé del mar velo,

121  Upon this side he fell down out of heaven;
122  And all the land, that whilom here emerged,
123  For fear of him made of the sea a veil,

124  e venne a l'emisperio nostro; e forse
125  per fuggir lui lasciò qui loco vòto
126  quella ch'appar di qua, e sù ricorse.”

124  And came to our hemisphere; and peradventure
125  To flee from him, what on this side appears
126  Left the place vacant here, and back recoiled."

127  Luogo è là giù da Belzebù remoto
128  tanto quanto la tomba si distende,
129  che non per vista, ma per suono è noto

127  A place there is below, from Beelzebub
128  As far receding as the tomb extends,
129  Which not by sight is known, but by the sound

130  d'un ruscelletto che quivi discende
131  per la buca d'un sasso, ch'elli ha roso,
132  col corso ch'elli avvolge, e poco pende.

130  Of a small rivulet, that there descendeth
131  Through chasm within the stone, which it has gnawed
132  With course that winds about and slightly falls.

133  Lo duca e io per quel cammino ascoso
134  intrammo a ritornar nel chiaro mondo;
135  e sanza cura aver d'alcun riposo,

133  The Guide and I into that hidden road
134  Now entered, to return to the bright world;
135  And without care of having any rest

136  salimmo sù, el primo e io secondo,
137  tanto ch'i' vidi de le cose belle
138  che porta 'l ciel, per un pertugio tondo.

136  We mounted up, he first and I the second,
137  Till I beheld through a round aperture
138  Some of the beauteous things that Heaven doth bear;

139  E quindi uscimmo a riveder le stelle.

139  Thence we came forth to rebehold the stars.

Purgatorio: Canto I
Yeats asks: "What's water but the generated soul, and the first canto of the Purgatorio makes reference to water, that element of which a human being is mostly comprised.  Water, the sea, is our source, perhaps our destiny, and in the first six lines here the text returns us to an image we met with in Canto I of the Inferno where we saw the figure of the exhausted swimmer looking back on the rough waters that almost drowned him.  This fugal or parallel construction or formal structure or whatever you want to call it is one of many technical conjurings embodied in the Commedia as a text.  The cantos will not only show progression, that is to say a narrative impetus, but also a sort of metaphoric self-reflectiveness, the facets, as in this example where the two Canto Ones, that of the Inferno and the Purgatorio, show the same figure (a passage over dangerous rough waters) in completely different lights.  (In the first canto of the Paradiso we will be immersed in a different element, not that of water, but that of light.)  Dante has gone so far in this that he has even cryptologically embedded messages so that the surface of the text when viewed in a certain manner contains subtexts.  For example, he cryptographically inserts his name in all three of his canticles’ opening cantos.  (See The Cryptography of Dante by Walter Arensbery, Alfred A Knopf, 1921.)  The devoted reader can find other examples of this procedure.  For example, here, in the terza starting at line 106, Cato tells the protagonists that they must take another, easier ascent, and remember Virgil's advice in Canto I  of the Inferno (line 91), that the aspirant must take another, harder road.  In this first case, the much more difficult path of descent and passage through Hell, and in the second a stairway to heaven.  This whole poem is about transcendence, and again and again, the text dazzles by immersing us in/on a journey where the transformations of the elements of the poem continually morph and transcend their original purposes.  And isn't this exactly how our mind works?  For example, say that when you were a child, while wearing a red plaid shirt, your mother scolds you, and your emotion of sadness and shame is anchored to the trigger of a red plaid.  Years later, your wife goes into labor with your first child, and in another plaid shirt, you experience the great joy of birth.  Same plaid, two different feeling tones, and so these multiple reflections and refractions build up a deep and complex layering of associations which constitute the curious phenomenon that we refer to when we say "I."  The Buddhist say Samsara is Nirvana, that is, the ordinary world is also the Bliss World.  Dante might add something like what we witness constantly on the historical plane, in politics, economics, and religion: "The ordinary world is also the Hell-world."  Milton makes the same point when he says: "The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven."  And Blake returns to this subject again and again of how the sublunary world is also the transcendent world.  "A fool sees not the same tree that a wise man sees.  He whose face gives no light shall never become a star."  Dante makes his worlds of Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise palpable as geography, but we should not forget that in the end the truth of these geographies, their very existence, as is the case with every physical place in every historical time, is a quality of mind, and mind itself is a process where memory might transport itself into terror or into bliss.  This then seems to be what the Divine Comedy is all about.  I say seems, because that explanation is too facile, and would suggest that what we are talking about is a brain-state, something producible by a chemical or a meditation process, that is to say, something knowable, hackable, as contemporary parlance might put it, but is that true?  Reading the poem, and taking it both lightly and deeply as something that has consequence in our lives, holds out the promise of experiencing something not so easily attributable to any world of science or theology, though we are desperate, in our ego-self, to believe that this is possible.

Besides the symmetries noted above, a far stranger conjunction exists between Canto I of the Inferno and Canto I of the Purgatorio.  Namely, the guides are both pagans!  Virgil, a poet and Cato, a politician — and a politician who was in addition guilty of the mortal sin of suicide.  How could he be among the saved at all?  Dante's contemporary Christian audience would or at least should have been appalled by such an outrage, but I think Dante is asserting here that orthodox thinking can only get us so far, and that transcendence is about boundary-breaking.  Cato is a very funny kind of pagan, but it's clear that Dante sees him as a sort of Christ figure, a savior, at least in the political sense if not the spiritual sense, who offers himself as a scapegoat for the principle of freedom.  Now here we might recall all the political rigmarole in Canto I of the Inferno about that allegorized political savior, "the Greyhound", and thus, reading, we might sense how politics and poetics get married in the poem in many strange juxtapositions.   Then there is the curious attempt by Virgil to bribe Cato by an appeal to Cato's feeling for his wife, Marcia, whom Virgil can speak to as her fellow denizen in Hell.  It doesn't work.  Cato has transcended not only any goad of lust, but any attachment to what the physical organ of the eyes might present of the physical world.  Next we have Cato reiterate Beatrice's remark that she is untouched by the sufferings of those in Hell, by telling Virgil of his indifference to Marcia.  But then Virgil pulls his trump card: Heavenly ladies have ordained that Dante be saved, and just as this tact was an open sesame to the demons in Hell, so too, Cato is instantly moved (as was Virgil) to assist the aspirant.  From a Jungian perspective, this is another foreshadowing of Dante's future spiritual consummation with his animus, Beatrice, for whom all his poetry is written, as he himself says elsewhere, as love letters to a divine lady.  But Cato is not in heaven because of something he did in politics (war being also but a violent extension of politics, and civil war the most vile), but because his suicide is a renunciation of politics, and indeed, at least in Dante's view, a renunciation of the entire pagan world — leap of faith without the object of faith to redeem him.  His suicide is an affirmation of freedom in a spiritual future, that is, a realm of freedom where the neediness of the physical body is expunged in favor of the fulfillment of a spiritual body.  Virgil, the poet, never renounces poetry, and in particular, he never renounces that pagan element of poetry which sings of arms and the man.  Certainly, Dante, as poet is not about to "sing of arms and the man", some soldier "exiled by fate", and set off on a journey of conquest to change himself from an alien intruder in a strange land, to the founder of a homeland in Latinia.  Virgil is trapped in the historical consequences of his fate, a fate that is strangely intractable, frozen as it is by its fixed view of the past, a condition shared by everyone in Hell.  Trapped by Time, they cannot move through Time, which is precisely what Dante, the aspirant, is doing, and what Cato his done as a consequence of his extreme renunciation.  Let's add here also, Giuseppe Mazzotta's comments about an old man being the icon for the future, whereas traditionally the future is represented by a baby (think of the New Year's Baby), a youth or a maiden.  Mazzotta says this astonishing representation by Dante has been prompted by the poet's understanding that the past is not just some kind of Freudian trash heap which determines the present self, but is also a repository of seeds for new possibilities.  In other words, the past too is not predetermined in its outcomes, but is a possible source for many possible outcomes, and here, senescence itself, seen from the viewpoint as a repository of many experiences, becomes a sort of nursery for many possible scenarios, including the possibility of a future, non-physical bliss.  This idea of old age as a cornucopia of infant possibilities can only come into existence if the concept of Time, and with it deterministic cause and effect, is changed.  Purgatorio is a place where Time works change, not a place like the final circle of Hell, where Time is immutably frozen in a system of violations and retributions, where suffering is not only eternal, but absolutely meaningless for he sufferers themselves, who have become mechanical slaves to a kind of moral doctrine of survival of the vilest.  In the Purgatorio Time is more like an expanding sphere in which everything has the characteristic of what we might call the future, a condition in which possibilities may manifest, and even the past can be reinterpreted and used as a resource to expand those possibilities.  And although we will still proceed in the stream of Time as a developing narration, the hint from the invocation is that that stream is headed to that Egyptian ocean: The sky.  Yes, by all those references to the stars as Time signatures visible in the Heavens, the text has now brought as back to the initial conditions of the first two humans, seeing what might be called a celestial or metaphysical sky, whereas after the fall, they can only see an earthly or material one.   The invocation, is also to Calliope, mother of Orpheus, whose sort of wrong-ended attempt to rescue Persephone from Hades is put right by Dante, because it's the other way around.  It is Beatrice who from heaven rescues her beloved from Hell.  Dante is an Orphic poet, in that he intends his song to transfix our Nature-body, but he is more than Orphic, he is messianic, a prophet, not in the sense of predicting the future but in the sense of making freedom possible in an ever enriching Time.  

Finally we  have the baptismal motif, the purification ritual which Cato commands.  Again, we are back to water.  We should remember the earlier metaphors of frozen plants being revived by the sun, but here it is something altogether amazing in that it is the dew not yet evaporated by the sun which Virgil uses to cleanse his protege.  Dew and tears — we've just seen tears frozen in the last two canto's of Hell, but here they mean something totally different.  These are tears of joy or release, and they flow down like justice in the mighty stream which is the triumphant last two canticles of the Commedia.  The protagonists are wandering, exiled on a desert plain — and as Proust remind us, Sodom and Gomorrah are cities of the plain — but Dante, the aspirant, still glimpses from afar the trembling of the sea.  That sea is death, whom none who have ever crossed return.  How singular is Dante's position, and how singular the poet's task, through some kind of extreme self-abnegation, the poet is able to go like Orpheus into Hell, and return, or go through Purgatory to Heaven, and live to express that transcendence in a poem.

Something that struck me in the protagonists' meeting with Cato, was that when Cato renounces has earthly wife, Marcia, Dante then has leave to renounce his wife, Gemma, both instances reiterating Christs pronouncement: "For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marraige, but are live God's angels in Heaven.  And yet the old pagan suicide and the Hell-scorched Dante make for very unorthodox bachelors!  Once the reader travels with Dante for a while, all kinds of pictures flash into the mind, all kinds of connections, all kinds of psychological states, all kinds of philosophical and cosmological speculations, and most of all, all kinds wonder from the sheer beauty and intensity of the poetry. 

We should not leave this canto without considering the rushes found growing around this desert island, the rushes which can survive like the rocks, but with suppleness not durance (how very Zen!), the poundings of the surf, the rushes that arise from the washy ooze, and even when plucked immediately resurrect themselves.  What a faith Dante had in the resilience and healing powers of Nature!  And hasn't the aspirant also pulled his soiled self up by the very roots by traversing Hell?   His way down to the very heat-death and collapse of the physical universe has led, through all that darkness and pain, to a way through and beyond.  Through poetry, he has done what no mortal body without spiritual transformation can ever do.  He has discovered a way to transcendence without having to deny the presence of evil.  And except through poetry, no other use of language can accomplish this.  The aspirant is girded about by one of these rushes, and we think of those Mideastern myths going back to the earliest writings and present in the story of Moses or the orphan child of the waters found floating in a wicker or rush basket.  Again another instance of the layering of motifs, for now the vessel of deliverance, the boat or cradle if you will is transformed as a sort of badge of protection, a sort of prophylactic against any future plunge back to the inferno.  Paradise has not yet been found, but it is inevitably promised.  The many mysteries pertaining to this rush will always run off in any direction that we might devotedly follow, and even in the seeming chaos of the ocean, their currents will always flow upward to the vaporization of water and the crystallization of light.       
  
1  Per correr miglior acque alza le vele
2  omai la navicella del mio ingegno,
3  che lascia dietro a sé mar sì crudele;

1  To run o'er better waters hoists its sail
2  The little vessel of my genius now,
3  That leaves behind itself a sea so cruel;

4  e canterò di quel secondo regno
5  dove l'umano spirito si purga
6  e di salire al ciel diventa degno.

4  And of that second kingdom will I sing
5  Wherein the human spirit doth purge itself,
6  And to ascend to heaven becometh worthy.

7  Ma qui la morta poesì resurga,
8  o sante Muse, poi che vostro sono;
9  e qui Calïopè alquanto surga,

7  But let dead Poesy here rise again,
8  O holy Muses, since that I am yours,
9  And here Calliope somewhat ascend,

10  seguitando il mio canto con quel suono
11  di cui le Piche misere sentiro
12  lo colpo tal, che disperar perdono.

10  My song accompanying with that sound,
11  Of which the miserable magpies felt
12  The blow so great, that they despaired of pardon.

13  Dolce color d'orïental zaffiro,
14  che s'accoglieva nel sereno aspetto
15  del mezzo, puro infino al primo giro,

13  Sweet colour of the oriental sapphire,
14  That was upgathered in the cloudless aspect
15  Of the pure air, as far as the first circle,

16  a li occhi miei ricominciò diletto,
17  tosto ch'io usci' fuor de l'aura morta
18  che m'avea contristati li occhi e 'l petto.

16  Unto mine eyes did recommence delight
17  Soon as I issued forth from the dead air,
18  Which had with sadness filled mine eyes and breast.

19  Lo bel pianeto che d'amar conforta
20  faceva tutto rider l'orïente,
21  velando i Pesci ch'erano in sua scorta.

19  The beauteous planet, that to love incites,
20  Was making all the orient to laugh,
21  Veiling the Fishes that were in her escort.

22  I' mi volsi a man destra, e puosi mente
23  a l'altro polo, e vidi quattro stelle
24  non viste mai fuor ch'a la prima gente.

22  To the right hand I turned, and fixed my mind
23  Upon the other pole, and saw four stars
24  Ne'er seen before save by the primal people.

25  Goder pareva 'l ciel di lor fiammelle:
26  oh settentrïonal vedovo sito,
27  poi che privato se' di mirar quelle!

25  Rejoicing in their flamelets seemed the heaven.
26  O thou septentrional and widowed site,
27  Because thou art deprived of seeing these!

28  Com' io da loro sguardo fui partito,
29  un poco me volgendo a l'altro polo,
30  là onde 'l Carro già era sparito,

28  When from regarding them I had withdrawn,
29  Turning a little to the other pole,
30  There where the Wain had disappeared already,

31  vidi presso di me un veglio solo,
32  degno di tanta reverenza in vista,
33  che più non dee a padre alcun figliuolo.

31  I saw beside me an old man alone,
32  Worthy of so much reverence in his look,
33  That more owes not to father any son.

34  Lunga la barba e di pel bianco mista
35  portava, a' suoi capelli simigliante,
36  de' quai cadeva al petto doppia lista.

34  A long beard and with white hair intermingled
35  He wore, in semblance like unto the tresses,
36  Of which a double list fell on his breast.

37  Li raggi de le quattro luci sante
38  fregiavan sì la sua faccia di lume,
39  ch'i' 'l vedea come 'l sol fosse davante.

37  The rays of the four consecrated stars
38  Did so adorn his countenance with light,
39  That him I saw as were the sun before him.

40  “Chi siete voi che contro al cieco fiume
41  fuggita avete la pregione etterna?”
42  diss' el, movendo quelle oneste piume.

40  "Who are you? ye who, counter the blind river,
41  Have fled away from the eternal prison?"
42  Moving those venerable plumes, he said:

43  “Chi v'ha guidati, o che vi fu lucerna,
44  uscendo fuor de la profonda notte
45  che sempre nera fa la valle inferna?

43  "Who guided you? or who has been your lamp
44  In issuing forth out of the night profound,
45  That ever black makes the infernal valley?

46  Son le leggi d'abisso così rotte?
47  o è mutato in ciel novo consiglio,
48  che, dannati, venite a le mie grotte?”

46  The laws of the abyss, are they thus broken?
47  Or is there changed in heaven some council new,
48  That being damned ye come unto my crags?"

49  Lo duca mio allor mi diè di piglio,
50  e con parole e con mani e con cenni
51  reverenti mi fé le gambe e 'l ciglio.

49  Then did my Leader lay his grasp upon me,
50  And with his words, and with his hands and signs,
51  Reverent he made in me my knees and brow;

52  Poscia rispuose lui: “Da me non venni:
53  donna scese del ciel, per li cui prieghi
54  de la mia compagnia costui sovvenni.

52  Then answered him: "I came not of myself;
53  A Lady from Heaven descended, at whose prayers
54  I aided this one with my company.

55  Ma da ch'è tuo voler che più si spieghi
56  di nostra condizion com' ell' è vera,
57  esser non puote il mio che a te si nieghi.

55  But since it is thy will more be unfolded
56  Of our condition, how it truly is,
57  Mine cannot be that this should be denied thee.

58  Questi non vide mai l'ultima sera;
59  ma per la sua follia le fu sì presso,
60  che molto poco tempo a volger era.

58  This one has never his last evening seen,
59  But by his folly was so near to it
60  That very little time was there to turn.

61  Sì com' io dissi, fui mandato ad esso
62  per lui campare; e non lì era altra via
63  che questa per la quale i' mi son messo.

61  As I have said, I unto him was sent
62  To rescue him, and other way was none
63  Than this to which I have myself betaken.

64  Mostrata ho lui tutta la gente ria;
65  e ora intendo mostrar quelli spirti
66  che purgan sé sotto la tua balìa.

64  I've shown him all the people of perdition,
65  And now those spirits I intend to show
66  Who purge themselves beneath thy guardianship.

67  Com' io l'ho tratto, saria lungo a dirti;
68  de l'alto scende virtù che m'aiuta
69  conducerlo a vederti e a udirti.

67  How I have brought him would be long to tell thee.
68  Virtue descendeth from on high that aids me
69  To lead him to behold thee and to hear thee.

70  Or ti piaccia gradir la sua venuta:
71  libertà va cercando, ch'è sì cara
72  come sa chi per lei vita rifiuta.

70  Now may it please thee to vouchsafe his coming;
71  He seeketh Liberty, which is so dear,
72  As knoweth he who life for her refuses.

73  Tu 'l sai, ché non ti fu per lei amara
74  in Utica la morte, ove lasciasti
75  la vesta ch'al gran dì sarà sì chiara.

73  Thou know'st it; since, for her, to thee not bitter
74  Was death in Utica, where thou didst leave
75  The vesture, that will shine so, the great day.

76  Non son li editti etterni per noi guasti,
77  ché questi vive e Minòs me non lega;
78  ma son del cerchio ove son li occhi casti


76  Eyes of thy Marcia, who in looks still prays thee,
77  O holy breast, to hold her as thine own;
78  For her love, then, incline thyself to us.

79  di Marzia tua, che 'n vista ancor ti priega,
80  o santo petto, che per tua la tegni:
81  per lo suo amore adunque a noi ti piega.

79  Eyes of thy Marcia, who in looks still prays thee,
80  O holy breast, to hold her as thine own;
81  For her love, then, incline thyself to us.

82  Lasciane andar per li tuoi sette regni;
83  grazie riporterò di te a lei,
84  se d'esser mentovato là giù degni.”

82  Permit us through thy sevenfold realm to go;
83  I will take back this grace from thee to her,
84  If to be mentioned there below thou deignest."

85  “Marzïa piacque tanto a li occhi miei
86  mentre ch'i' fu' di là,” diss' elli allora,
87  “che quante grazie volse da me, fei.

85  "Marcia so pleasing was unto mine eyes
86  While I was on the other side," then said he,
87  "That every grace she wished of me I granted;

88  Or che di là dal mal fiume dimora,
89  più muover non mi può, per quella legge
90  che fatta fu quando me n'usci' fora.

88  Now that she dwells beyond the evil river,
89  She can no longer move me, by that law
90  Which, when I issued forth from there, was made.

91  Ma se donna del ciel ti move e regge,
92  come tu di', non c'è mestier lusinghe:
93  bastisi ben che per lei mi richegge.

91  But if a Lady of Heaven do move and rule thee,
92  As thou dost say, no flattery is needful;
93  Let it suffice thee that for her thou ask me.

94  Va dunque, e fa che tu costui ricinghe
95  d'un giunco schietto e che li lavi 'l viso,
96  sì ch'ogne sucidume quindi stinghe;

94  Go, then, and see thou gird this one about
95  With a smooth rush, and that thou wash his face,
96  So that thou cleanse away all stain therefrom,

97  ché non si converria, l'occhio sorpriso
98  d'alcuna nebbia, andar dinanzi al primo
99  ministro, ch'è di quei di paradiso.

97  For 'twere not fitting that the eye o'ercast
98  By any mist should go before the first
99  Angel, who is of those of Paradise.

100  Questa isoletta intorno ad imo ad imo,
101  là giù colà dove la batte l'onda,
102  porta di giunchi sovra 'l molle limo:

100  This little island round about its base
101  Below there, yonder, where the billow beats it,
102  Doth rushes bear upon its washy ooze;

103  null' altra pianta che facesse fronda
104  o indurasse, vi puote aver vita,
105  però ch'a le percosse non seconda.

103  No other plant that putteth forth the leaf,
104  Or that doth indurate, can there have life,
105  Because it yieldeth not unto the shocks.

106  Poscia non sia di qua vostra reddita;
107  lo sol vi mosterrà, che surge omai,
108  prendere il monte a più lieve salita.”

106  Thereafter be not this way your return;
107  The sun, which now is rising, will direct you
108  To take the mount by easier ascent."


109  Così sparì; e io sù mi levai
110  sanza parlare, e tutto mi ritrassi
111  al duca mio, e li occhi a lui drizzai.

109  With this he vanished; and I raised me up
110  Without a word, and wholly drew myself
111  Unto my Guide, and turned mine eyes to him.

112  El cominciò: “Figliuol, segui i miei passi:
113  volgianci in dietro, ché di qua dichina
114  questa pianura a' suoi termini bassi.”

112  And he began: "Son, follow thou my steps;
113  Let us turn back, for on this side declines
114  The plain unto its lower boundaries."

115  L'alba vinceva l'ora mattutina
116  che fuggia innanzi, sì che di lontano
117  conobbi il tremolar de la marina.

115  The dawn was vanquishing the matin hour
116  Which fled before it, so that from afar
117  I recognised the trembling of the sea.

118  Noi andavam per lo solingo piano
119  com' om che torna a la perduta strada,
120  che 'nfino ad essa li pare ire in vano.

118  Along the solitary plain we went
119  As one who unto the lost road returns,
120  And till he finds it seems to go in vain.

121  Quando noi fummo là 've la rugiada
122  pugna col sole, per essere in parte
123  dove, ad orezza, poco si dirada,

121  As soon as we were come to where the dew
122  Fights with the sun, and, being in a part
123  Where shadow falls, little evaporates,

124  ambo le mani in su l'erbetta sparte
125  soavemente 'l mio maestro pose:
126  ond' io, che fui accorto di sua arte,

124  Both of his hands upon the grass outspread
125  In gentle manner did my Master place;
126  Whence I, who of his action was aware,

127  porsi ver' lui le guance lagrimose;
128  ivi mi fece tutto discoverto
129  quel color che l'inferno mi nascose.

127  Extended unto him my tearful cheeks;
128  There did he make in me uncovered wholly
129  That hue which Hell had covered up in me.

130  Venimmo poi in sul lito diserto,
131  che mai non vide navicar sue acque
132  omo, che di tornar sia poscia esperto.

130  Then came we down upon the desert shore
131  Which never yet saw navigate its waters
132  Any that afterward had known return.

133  Quivi mi cinse sì com' altrui piacque:
134  oh maraviglia! ché qual elli scelse
135  l'umile pianto, cotal si rinacque

133  There he begirt me as the other pleased;
134  O marvellous! for even as he culled
135  The humble plant, such it sprang up again

136  subitamente là onde l'avelse.

136  Suddenly there where he uprooted it.

Purgatorio: Canto II
The first 30 lines of this canto might be summarized as the resurrection of light, sight, vision, time, and distance.  What an immense spectacle we enjoy here after the last dark, frozen narrowness of Hell!  Here we view a metaphysical Earth with Jerusalem at the center, the site of the crucifixion, the Ganges 90° to the east, the antipodes, 180° to the south, and Cadiz in Spain, 270° off the meridian.  This puts us inside the clock of a great half-dome, each quadrant of which holds its six of the 24 hours, and the protagonists are at the antipodes, at dawn — and a lot has changed.  We have an animus figure, Aurora, who lights the world, colors glowing warmly, white, vermillion, orange, the black smoke of night sinking with the red star of Mars, its fire sinking below the ocean floor.  In the sky, the stars are fading, the constellation Libra, the scales of justice, not visible at the Autumn solstice, opposite where we are in the spring solstice, with the sun in Aries (Mars).  The point here is that we are at a time and place of a new beginning, and it is just as it was at the beginning of Canto I of the Inferno, the protagonists are confused, lost — in a condition of exile, having just escaped a condition of bondage.  We should remember the repetition of the hear/see motif in Hell, because Hell is dark, and the ears are the organs that can first penetrate its horrors.  Now we have the see/hear motif, a reversal, because we have come to a place where the light, just as was the darkness in Hell, is overwhelming.  So, just as we saw in the previous canto, how the same images deliver many, and sometimes opposite messages, hear we have different images — night and day — delivering the same message: both overwhelm at the extremes.  With Libra's balance gone, and with it Aristotle's golden mean, we find ourselves at another extreme, this time, not the extreme of criminality, but the extreme of ignorance.  We simply don't know where to go or what to do.

Returning to our hear/see motif reversal to one of see/hear: Notice how precise Dante’s description is of how the eyes actually function when going from dark to light.  In lines 13 - 24, he takes us through a process in which we proceed from the blindness of dark to the blindness of overwhelming light, from an ominous ambiguity to a hopeful one.  The sight of the angel of transport is truly awesome, and its power and radiance command only one human response: humility.  Now think back to Canto II of the Inferno, when we get a secondhand account of the intercession of Beatrice.  In both cases brightness dispersed darkness.  There are so many examples of what we might call Dante’s network of protean extended metaphors that we can hardly keep up with them, but unconsciously we always have a sense that the Commedia is some kind of linguistic embodiment of the themes it presents.

Mazzotta has written an entire book to show that the Commedia is Dante’s recapitulation of the Biblical theme of Exodus, and the new souls being ported to Purgatory and singing psalm 114 concerning Israel’s deliverance makes his point.  They sing with one voice, a far cry from the cacophonies emitted by the souls in hell, who cry and moan their own individual fates, and never show any solidarity with one another.  Although they, like the souls here, are almost literally in the same boat.

This canto concludes with Dante meeting his friend, the singer, Casella. There is what by now the familiar trope of the shades' shock of finding a living person in this place reserved for the dead.  When Dante tries to embrace his friend, three times his arms pass through him.  We might ask, how is Virgil able in so many instances able to pick up Dante, if Virgil is a substanceless shade?  Maybe this device, which defies mortal logic, is actually meant to be mysterious. In effect, the device is meant to put the reader in the same emotional position as that of the shades when they encounter a living body.  That is to say, the state of awe.  Now Casella sings a song and entrances the whole company of recent immigrants. The lyrics of this song are Dante’s own, and this song was chosen specifically at Dante’s request.  Cato arrives and chastises the company, and they all scatter like frightened pigeons.  This a denunciation.  If the poet in the previous canto renounces the poetry of war and armed heroism, here he renounces troubadorian love poetry.  Both of these kinds of poetry are sources of pride, and pride is an anchor whose weight is too great to allow the soul to ascend.  Dante intends a new kind of poetry, which will be, for want of a better term: scriptural.  That is the path that Dante's poetry has now chosen, and he makes this clear by the contrast between the psalm that the pilgrims are singing as they arrive, and the song that Dante asks Casella to sing.  However wonderful and captivating the latter is, it is not the kind of music that will bring the soul nearer to its source.  That is Cato's reprimand.  For me too, there is a pun linking the name Cato with the Italian word gatto (cat), and indeed, the errant souls scatter like pigeons when cat Cato arrives.

1  Già era 'l sole a l'orizzonte giunto
2  lo cui meridïan cerchio coverchia
3  Ierusalèm col suo più alto punto;

1  Already had the sun the horizon reached
2  Whose circle of meridian covers o'er
3  Jerusalem with its most lofty point,

4  e la notte, che opposita a lui cerchia,
5  uscia di Gange fuor con le Bilance,
6  che le caggion di man quando soverchia;

4  And night that opposite to him revolves
5  Was issuing forth from Ganges with the Scales
6  That fall from out her hand when she exceedeth;

7  sì che le bianche e le vermiglie guance,
8  là dov' i' era, de la bella Aurora
9  per troppa etate divenivan rance.

7  So that the white and the vermilion cheeks
8  Of beautiful Aurora, where I was,
9  By too great age were changing into orange.

10  Noi eravam lunghesso mare ancora,
11  come gente che pensa a suo cammino,
12  che va col cuore e col corpo dimora.

10  We still were on the border of the sea,
11  Like people who are thinking of their road,
12  Who go in heart and with the body stay;

13  Ed ecco, qual, sorpreso dal mattino,
14  per li grossi vapor Marte rosseggia
15  giù nel ponente sovra 'l suol marino,

13  And lo! as when, upon the approach of morning,
14  Through the gross vapours Mars grows fiery red
15  Down in the West upon the ocean floor,

16  cotal m'apparve, s'io ancor lo veggia,
17  un lume per lo mar venir sì ratto,
18  che 'l muover suo nessun volar pareggia.

16  Appeared to me—may I again behold it!—
17  A light along the sea so swiftly coming,
18  Its motion by no flight of wing is equalled;

19  Dal qual com' io un poco ebbi ritratto
20  l'occhio per domandar lo duca mio,
21  rividil più lucente e maggior fatto.

19  From which when I a little had withdrawn
20  Mine eyes, that I might question my Conductor,
21  Again I saw it brighter grown and larger.

22  Poi d'ogne lato ad esso m'appario
23  un non sapeva che bianco, e di sotto
24  a poco a poco un altro a lui uscìo.

22  Then on each side of it appeared to me
23  I knew not what of white, and underneath it
24  Little by little there came forth another.

25  Lo mio maestro ancor non facea motto,
26  mentre che i primi bianchi apparver ali;
27  allor che ben conobbe il galeotto,

25  My Master yet had uttered not a word
26  While the first whiteness into wings unfolded;
27  But when he clearly recognised the pilot,

28  gridò: “Fa, fa che le ginocchia cali.
29  Ecco l'angel di Dio: piega le mani;
30  omai vedrai di sì fatti officiali.

28  He cried: "Make haste, make haste to bow the knee!
29  Behold the Angel of God! fold thou thy hands!
30  Henceforward shalt thou see such officers!

31  Vedi che sdegna li argomenti umani,
32  sì che remo non vuol, né altro velo
33  che l'ali sue, tra liti sì lontani.

31  See how he scorneth human arguments,
32  So that nor oar he wants, nor other sail
33  Than his own wings, between so distant shores.

34  Vedi come l'ha dritte verso 'l cielo,
35  trattando l'aere con l'etterne penne,
36  che non si mutan come mortal pelo.”

34  See how he holds them pointed up to heaven,
35  Fanning the air with the eternal pinions,
36  That do not moult themselves like mortal hair!"

37  Poi, come più e più verso noi venne
38  l'uccel divino, più chiaro appariva;
39  per che l'occhio da presso nol sostenne,

37  Then as still nearer and more near us came
38  The Bird Divine, more radiant he appeared,
39  So that near by the eye could not endure him,

40  ma chinail giuso; e quei sen venne a riva
41  con un vasello snelletto e leggero,
42  tanto che l'acqua nulla ne 'nghiottiva.

40  But down I cast it; and he came to shore
41  With a small vessel, very swift and light,
42  So that the water swallowed naught thereof.

43  Da poppa stava il celestial nocchiero,
44  tal che faria beato pur descripto;
45  e più di cento spirti entro sediero.

43  Upon the stern stood the Celestial Pilot;
44  Beatitude seemed written in his face,
45  And more than a hundred spirits sat within.

46  “In exitu Isräel de Aegypto”
47  cantavan tutti insieme ad una voce
48  con quanto di quel salmo è poscia scripto.

46  "In exitu Israel de Aegypto!"
47  They chanted all together in one voice,
48  With whatso in that psalm is after written.

49   Poi fece il segno lor di santa croce;
50   ond' ei si gittar tutti in su la piaggia:
51   ed el sen gì, come venne, veloce.

49  Then made he sign of holy rood upon them,
50  Whereat all cast themselves upon the shore,
51  And he departed swiftly as he came.

52  La turba che rimase lì, selvaggia
53  parea del loco, rimirando intorno
54  come colui che nove cose assaggia.

52  The throng which still remained there unfamiliar
53  Seemed with the place, all round about them gazing,
54  As one who in new matters makes essay.

55  Da tutte parti saettava il giorno
56  lo sol, ch'avea con le saette conte
57  di mezzo 'l ciel cacciato Capricorno,

55  On every side was darting forth the day.
56  The sun, who had with his resplendent shafts
57  From the mid-heaven chased forth the Capricorn,

58  quando la nova gente alzò la fronte
59  ver' noi, dicendo a noi: “Se voi sapete,
60  mostratene la via di gire al monte.”

58  When the new people lifted up their faces
59  Towards us, saying to us: "If ye know,
60  Show us the way to go unto the mountain."

61  E Virgilio rispuose: “Voi credete
62  forse che siamo esperti d'esto loco;
63  ma noi siam peregrin come voi siete.

61  And answer made Virgilius: "Ye believe
62  Perchance that we have knowledge of this place,
63  But we are strangers even as yourselves.

64  Dianzi venimmo, innanzi a voi un poco,
65  per altra via, che fu sì aspra e forte,
66  che lo salire omai ne parrà gioco.”

64  Just now we came, a little while before you,
65  Another way, which was so rough and steep,
66  That mounting will henceforth seem sport to us."

67  L'anime, che si fuor di me accorte,
68  per lo spirare, ch'i' era ancor vivo,
69  maravigliando diventaro smorte.

67  The souls who had, from seeing me draw breath,
68  Become aware that I was still alive,
69  Pallid in their astonishment became;

70  E come a messagger che porta ulivo
71  tragge la gente per udir novelle,
72  e di calcar nessun si mostra schivo,

70  And as to messenger who bears the olive
71  The people throng to listen to the news,
72  And no one shows himself afraid of crowding,

73  così al viso mio s'affisar quelle
74  anime fortunate tutte quante,
75  quasi oblïando d'ire a farsi belle.

73  So at the sight of me stood motionless
74  Those fortunate spirits, all of them, as if
75  Oblivious to go and make them fair.

76  Io vidi una di lor trarresi avante
77  per abbracciarmi, con sì grande affetto,
78  che mosse me a far lo somigliante.

76  One from among them saw I coming forward,
77  As to embrace me, with such great affection,
78  That it incited me to do the like.

79  Ohi ombre vane, fuor che ne l'aspetto!
80  tre volte dietro a lei le mani avvinsi,
81  e tante mi tornai con esse al petto.

79  O empty shadows, save in aspect only!
80  Three times behind it did I clasp my hands,
81  As oft returned with them to my own breast!

82  Di maraviglia, credo, mi dipinsi;
83  per che l'ombra sorrise e si ritrasse,
84  e io, seguendo lei, oltre mi pinsi.

82  I think with wonder I depicted me;
83  Whereat the shadow smiled and backward drew;
84  And I, pursuing it, pressed farther forward.

85  Soavemente disse ch'io posasse;
86  allor conobbi chi era, e pregai
87  che, per parlarmi, un poco s'arrestasse.

85  Gently it said that I should stay my steps;
86  Then knew I who it was, and I entreated
87  That it would stop awhile to speak with me.

88  Rispuosemi: “Così com' io t'amai
89  nel mortal corpo, così t'amo sciolta:
90  però m'arresto; ma tu perché vai?”

88  It made reply to me: "Even as I loved thee
89  In mortal body, so I love thee free;
90  Therefore I stop; but wherefore goest thou?"

91  “Casella mio, per tornar altra volta
92  là dov' io son, fo io questo vïaggio,”
93  diss' io; “ma a te com' è tanta ora tolta?”

91  "My own Casella! to return once more
92  There where I am, I make this journey," said I;
93  "But how from thee has so much time be taken?"

94  Ed elli a me: “Nessun m'è fatto oltraggio,
95  se quei che leva quando e cui li piace,
96  più volte m'ha negato esto passaggio;

94  And he to me: "No outrage has been done me,
95  If he who takes both when and whom he pleases
96  Has many times denied to me this passage,

97  ché di giusto voler lo suo si face:
98  veramente da tre mesi elli ha tolto
99  chi ha voluto intrar, con tutta pace.

97  For of a righteous will his own is made.
98  He, sooth to say, for three months past has taken
99  Whoever wished to enter with all peace;

100  Ond' io, ch'era ora a la marina vòlto
101  dove l'acqua di Tevero s'insala,
102  benignamente fu' da lui ricolto.

100  Whence I, who now had turned unto that shore
101  Where salt the waters of the Tiber grow,
102  Benignantly by him have been received.

103  A quella foce ha elli or dritta l'ala,
104  però che sempre quivi si ricoglie
105  qual verso Acheronte non si cala.”

103  Unto that outlet now his wing is pointed,
104  Because for evermore assemble there
105  Those who tow'rds Acheron do not descend."

106  E io: “Se nuova legge non ti toglie
107  memoria o uso a l'amoroso canto
108  che mi solea quetar tutte mie doglie,

106  And I: "If some new law take not from thee
107  Memory or practice of the song of love,
108  Which used to quiet in me all my longings,

109  di ciò ti piaccia consolare alquanto
110  l'anima mia, che, con la sua persona
111  venendo qui, è affannata tanto!”

109  Thee may it please to comfort therewithal
110  Somewhat this soul of mine, that with its body
111  Hitherward coming is so much distressed."

112  “Amor che ne la mente mi ragiona”
113  cominciò elli allor sì dolcemente,
114  che la dolcezza ancor dentro mi suona.

112  "Love, that within my mind discourses with me,"
113  Forthwith began he so melodiously,
114  The melody within me still is sounding.

115  Lo mio maestro e io e quella gente
116  ch'eran con lui parevan sì contenti,
117  come a nessun toccasse altro la mente.

115  My Master, and myself, and all that people
116  Which with him were, appeared as satisfied
117  As if naught else might touch the mind of any.

118  Noi eravam tutti fissi e attenti
119  a le sue note; ed ecco il veglio onesto
120  gridando: “Che è ciò, spiriti lenti?

118  We all of us were moveless and attentive
119  Unto his notes; and lo! the grave old man,
120  Exclaiming: "What is this, ye laggard spirits?

121  qual negligenza, quale stare è questo?
122  Correte al monte a spogliarvi lo scoglio
123  ch'esser non lascia a voi Dio manifesto.”

121  What negligence, what standing still is this?
122  Run to the mountain to strip off the slough,
123  That lets not God be manifest to you."

124  Come quando, cogliendo biado o loglio,
125  li colombi adunati a la pastura,
126  queti, sanza mostrar l'usato orgoglio,

124  Even as when, collecting grain or tares,
125  The doves, together at their pasture met,
126  Quiet, nor showing their accustomed pride,

127  se cosa appare ond' elli abbian paura,
128  subitamente lasciano star l'esca,
129  perch' assaliti son da maggior cura;

127  If aught appear of which they are afraid,
128  Upon a sudden leave their food alone,
129  Because they are assailed by greater care;

130  così vid' io quella masnada fresca
131  lasciar lo canto, e fuggir ver' la costa,
132  com' om che va, né sa dove rïesca;

130  So that fresh company did I behold
131  The song relinquish, and go tow'rds the hill,
132  As one who goes, and knows not whitherward;

133  né la nostra partita fu men tosta.

133  Nor was our own departure less in haste.

Purgatorio: Canto III
We've now traversed 36 cantos of the poem, and so many times we have been presented with this same paradox, which is, how can a spirit interact with a body.
