Sometimes, as in the last canto, the attempt at interaction is a failure.  Dante cannot hug Casella.  And yet, so many times previously, Virgil, a shade, is able to pick up and move the physical Dante.  Is Dante just a lazy and inconsistent poet?  No.  And as Dante sees his own shadow before him, and not Virgil's, he panics, thinking he is alone.  (See also, Eliot's The Wasteland: And I will show you something different from either / Your shadow at morning striding behind you / Or your shadow at evening rising to meet you / I will show you fear in a handful of dust ... )  In a Jungian sense, what Dante, the aspirant is seeing is not his soul, his spirit, but his shade, his Jungian shadow, the projection of all the limitations of incarnation and physicality, when the light is behind him, and he sees it.  He sees it!  And he is alarmed.  Not at his shadow, but upon the absence of shadow from Virgil.  Now Virgil launches into his explanation, an explanation that now begins to make sense of all those paradoxical times throughout the Commedia in which spirits are intermingling with living substance.  What we have here is the mystery of Incarnation, the mystery of the holy trinity.  How in the cosmos is spirit able to animate flesh?  That mystery is absolute nonsense to one whose perspective is entirely derived from the needs of the flesh and the Freudian ego, but from the point of view of that spirit which infuses and animates everything, it is simply the outward expression naturally occurring as its love expands, and just as naturally occurring as its attention contracts.  I know it's weird to use the word "natural" to describe what is usually thought to be beyond nature, but it is no weirder than having a pagan explain the operations of the Trinity to a Christian, the mechanism, that is to say, the metaphor, is the same.  When we try to reconcile the spirit and body with reason, that is to say, the brain or mind, they never mix, and their irreconcilability remains a constant thorn in our side.  But in the heart — in the emotional body — their paired existences are not mutually exclusive, but interpenetrating, and the realization of such is bliss, the bliss of God, in Dante's terminology.  Mind in its pride wants to know and is frustrated by its own limitations.  But the heart beats, it is simple being, it is.  There is no conundrum, only existence, only a pluse, which sets the world around it into the flow of some substance through some other substance.  This flow is what we might call, taking Dante's point of view if not his words: The flow of blessings through bliss.  This acceptance of the flow is the fruit of humility, and remains inaccessible to pride.  A baby can live what a sage cannot know.  Now, realizing this as readers helps us to make sense of how we should be reading this poem, and why poems about arms and the man or about human love remain fixed as being flows around them.  The Commedia, qua spiritual speech, is showing us the new way, the new person, and here in Purgatory we are beginning to shed those layers and layers of barnacled misconceptions which have hindered us.  Here we are growing lighter and more transparent.  We are beginning to recognize that our physical body is light, transparency, and bliss, through and through.  

Note the difference at the end of Virgil's discourse, that his head drops, as sadness overtakes him.  Outwardly, this is an attitude of prayer, but only outwardly.  What he is feeling is grief for himself that he has come so close to salvation ... and yet, a miss is a good as a mile.  He looks, down, after, while Dante looks up, and it is Dante's looking up, which gives the pair their first clue as to how to scale the cliffs and make their wary.  Compare this with Virgil's insistence that Dante kneel at the sheer awesomeness of the Angel pilot in the previous canto.  This kind of kneeling and bowing is true reverence, and the true attitude of prayer.  And to repeat what was said above: this kind of reverence in the presence of revelation is the body's natural response to a confrontation with its own non-physical essence.  That is to say, the attitude of a grateful submissive and servant.  We are all, as Muslims would have it, effendi, i.e. the slaves of God, all subject to the great operations of the cosmos.  It behooves us to ask here: What are we submitting ourselves to?  My answer would be: the force and flow of life from moment to moment as it animates matter.  Even a minute in such a state is more fulfilling than a lifetime of anxiety about sex, money, power, approbation ... et al.  A hard sell, I know, to anyone who has never felt that flow ... but to those who have felt it ... a truism.  

There is some interplay here about shadows, only Dante, being physical has one, and Dante, and Virgil, in a kind of fit of nostalgia talks about his own body, and its shadow.  I know it's weirdly anachronistic to talk about Jung's concept of the shadow in a poem written centuries before Jung was born.  But there is a simultaneity of all history in the mind, which, like the broken rock cliff that the protagonist cannot climb without wings (this passage up, a mirror image to the broken passage down to the ninth circle of Hell) is an impassable jumble.  The geologic strata of the mind is always like this, a record of constant upheaval, the detritus of memory constantly being heaped and jumbled by the unending welter of all those desires which the body and society foment, and which, like what we find here, is saturated in a kind of time that seems both anxious and excruciatingly slow, a feature that the text emphasizes both by the dash that ends the previous canto and the sight that the protagonists see here: the slow-moving line of pilgrims, which like the horizon, stays always as distant no matter how far we've come to reach it.  What's the antidote to this dilemma?  Dante gives a hint when he talks about the hurry that mars the dignity of every action.  (See the etymology of dignity and disdain, the first from a word meaning "worth", the second from one meaning "unworthy" ... again, substance and shadow.)  Opposites are at play in other instances too.  The Time is different in other places, and the throng of pilgrim to the left of the protagonists, turn them around, and move them to the right, a direction opposite from that which they followed as they corkscrewed down into Hell.  Is Dante pointing out this relationship that the play of opposites always entails, and not just opposites which are inimical to one another, but those like the opposable thumb and the rest of our hands, which complement and enable one another.  Such seems to be the case here between the living and the dead, as Manfred asks Dante to remind his living associates to pray for him, as their living breath, quite different here than the requests or disdain of the shades in Hell in their quest for fame or oblivion, can influence his fate in the afterworld.  Again, we have opposites.  In this case the continued vanity of those in Hell, concerned about their reputations, and the utter humility of Manfred, here in Purgatory, who humbly needs someone still involved in the hurly-burly of life still has some concern, some love for him.  This must be so.  That is, the communication between the spirit and the body is two-way, and just as Beatrice from her abode in non-physical bliss is concerned for the still-living Dante, so we, yet inhabiting a body, elevate both ourselves and our deceased loved ones by opening this channel of concern, which flows between us and connects us.  

1  Avvegna che la subitana fuga
2  dispergesse color per la campagna,
3  rivolti al monte ove ragion ne fruga,
1  Inasmuch as the instantaneous flight
2  Had scattered them asunder o'er the plain,
3  Turned to the mountain whither reason spurs us,
4  i' mi ristrinsi a la fida compagna:
5  e come sare' io sanza lui corso?
6  chi m'avria tratto su per la montagna?
4  I pressed me close unto my faithful comrade,
5  And how without him had I kept my course?
6  Who would have led me up along the mountain?
7  El mi parea da sé stesso rimorso:
8  o dignitosa coscïenza e netta,
9  come t'è picciol fallo amaro morso!

7  He seemed to me within himself remorseful;
8  O noble conscience, and without a stain,
9  How sharp a sting is trivial fault to thee!
10  Quando li piedi suoi lasciar la fretta,
11  che l'onestade ad ogn' atto dismaga,
12  la mente mia, che prima era ristretta, 
10  After his feet had laid aside the haste
11  Which mars the dignity of every act,
12  My mind, that hitherto had been restrained,
13  lo 'ntento rallargò, sì come vaga,
14  e diedi 'l viso mio incontr' al poggio
15  che 'nverso 'l ciel più alto si dislaga.
13  Let loose its faculties as if delighted,
14  And I my sight directed to the hill
15  That highest tow'rds the heaven uplifts itself.
16  Lo sol, che dietro fiammeggiava roggio,
17  rotto m'era dinanzi a la figura,
18  ch'avëa in me de' suoi raggi l'appoggio.
16  The sun, that in our rear was flaming red,
17  Was broken in front of me into the figure
18  Which had in me the stoppage of its rays;
19  Io mi volsi dallato con paura
20  d'essere abbandonato, quand' io vidi
21  solo dinanzi a me la terra oscura;
19  Unto one side I turned me, with the fear
20  Of being left alone, when I beheld
21  Only in front of me the ground obscured.

22  e 'l mio conforto: “Perché pur diffidi?”
23  a dir mi cominciò tutto rivolto;
24  “non credi tu me teco e ch'io ti guidi?
22  "Why dost thou still mistrust?" my Comforter
23  Began to say to me turned wholly round;
24  "Dost thou not think me with thee, and that I guide thee?
25  Vespero è già colà dov' è sepolto
26  lo corpo dentro al quale io facea ombra;
27  Napoli l'ha, e da Brandizio è tolto.
25  'Tis evening there already where is buried
26  The body within which I cast a shadow;
27  'Tis from Brundusium ta'en, and Naples has it.
28  Ora, se innanzi a me nulla s'aombra,
29  non ti maravigliar più che d'i cieli
30  che l'uno a l'altro raggio non ingombra. 
28  Now if in front of me no shadow fall,
29  Marvel not at it more than at the heavens,
30  Because one ray impedeth not another
31  A sofferir tormenti, caldi e geli
32  simili corpi la Virtù dispone
33  che, come fa, non vuol ch'a noi si sveli.

31  To suffer torments, both of cold and heat,
32  Bodies like this that Power provides, which wills
33  That how it works be not unveiled to us.

34  Matto è chi spera che nostra ragione
35  possa trascorrer la infinita via
36  che tiene una sustanza in tre persone.

34  Insane is he who hopeth that our reason
35  Can traverse the illimitable way,
36  Which the one Substance in three Persons follows!

37  State contenti, umana gente, al quia;
38  ché, se potuto aveste veder tutto,
39  mestier non era parturir Maria;

37  Mortals, remain contented at the 'Quia;'
38  For if ye had been able to see all,
39  No need there were for Mary to give birth;

40  e disïar vedeste sanza frutto
41  tai che sarebbe lor disio quetato,
42  ch'etternalmente è dato lor per lutto:

40  And ye have seen desiring without fruit,
41  Those whose desire would have been quieted,
42  Which evermore is given them for a grief.

43  io dico d'Aristotile e di Plato
44  e di molt' altri”; e qui chinò la fronte,
45  e più non disse, e rimase turbato.
43  I speak of Aristotle and of Plato,
44  And many others;"—and here bowed his head,
45  And more he said not, and remained disturbed.
46  Noi divenimmo intanto a piè del monte;
47  quivi trovammo la roccia sì erta,
48  che 'ndarno vi sarien le gambe pronte.
46  We came meanwhile unto the mountain's foot;
47  There so precipitate we found the rock,
48  That nimble legs would there have been in vain.
49  Tra Lerice e Turbìa la più diserta,
50  la più rotta ruina è una scala,
51 verso di quella, agevole e aperta. 
49  'Twixt Lerici and Turbia, the most desert,
50  The most secluded pathway is a stair
51  Easy and open, if compared with that.
52  “Or chi sa da qual man la costa cala,”
53  disse 'l maestro mio fermando 'l passo,
54 “sì che possa salir chi va sanz' ala?”
52  "Who knoweth now upon which hand the hill
53  Slopes down," my Master said, his footsteps staying,
54  "So that who goeth without wings may mount?"
55  E mentre ch'e' tenendo 'l viso basso
56  essaminava del cammin la mente,
57  e io mirava suso intorno al sasso,
55  And while he held his eyes upon the ground
56  Examining the nature of the path,
57  And I was looking up around the rock,
58  da man sinistra m'apparì una gente
59  d'anime, che movieno i piè ver' noi,
60  e non pareva, sì venïan lente.
58  On the left hand appeared to me a throng
59  Of souls, that moved their feet in our direction,
60  And did not seem to move, they came so slowly.
61  “Leva,” diss' io, “maestro, li occhi tuoi:
62  ecco di qua chi ne darà consiglio,
63  se tu da te medesmo aver nol puoi.”
61  "Lift up thine eyes," I to the Master said;
62  "Behold, on this side, who will give us counsel,
63  If thou of thine own self can have it not."
64  Guardò allora, e con libero piglio
65  rispuose: “Andiamo in là, ch'ei vegnon piano;
66  e tu ferma la spene, dolce figlio.”
64  Then he looked at me, and with frank expression
65  Replied: "Let us go there, for they come slowly,
66  And thou be steadfast in thy hope, sweet son."
67  Ancora era quel popol di lontano,
68  i' dico dopo i nostri mille passi,
69  quanto un buon gittator trarria con mano,
67  Still was that people as far off from us,
68  After a thousand steps of ours I say,
69  As a good thrower with his hand would reach,
70  quando si strinser tutti ai duri massi
71  de l'alta ripa, e stetter fermi e stretti
72  com' a guardar, chi va dubbiando, stassi.
70  When they all crowded unto the hard masses
71  Of the high bank, and motionless stood and close,
72  As he stands still to look who goes in doubt.
73  “O ben finiti, o già spiriti eletti,”
74  Virgilio incominciò, “per quella pace
75  ch'i' credo che per voi tutti s'aspetti,
73  "O happy dead! O spirits elect already!"
74  Virgilius made beginning, "by that peace
75  Which I believe is waiting for you all,
76  ditene dove la montagna giace,
77  sì che possibil sia l'andare in suso;
78  ché perder tempo a chi più sa più spiace.”
76  Tell us upon what side the mountain slopes,
77  So that the going up be possible,
78  For to lose time irks him most who most knows."
79  Come le pecorelle escon del chiuso
80  a una, a due, a tre, e l'altre stanno
81  timidette atterrando l'occhio e 'l muso;
79  As sheep come issuing forth from out the fold
80  By ones and twos and threes, and the others stand
81  Timidly, holding down their eyes and nostrils,
82  e ciò che fa la prima, e l'altre fanno,
83  addossandosi a lei, s'ella s'arresta,
84  semplici e quete, e lo 'mperché non sanno:
82  And what the foremost does the others do,
83  Huddling themselves against her, if she stop,
84  Simple and quiet and the wherefore know not;
85  sì vid' io muovere a venir la testa
86  di quella mandra fortunata allotta,
87 pudica in faccia e ne l'andare onesta.
85  So moving to approach us thereupon
86  I saw the leader of that fortunate flock,
87  Modest in face and dignified in gait.
88  Come color dinanzi vider rotta
89  la luce in terra dal mio destro canto,
90  sì che l'ombra era da me a la grotta,
88  As soon as those in the advance saw broken
89  The light upon the ground at my right side,
90  So that from me the shadow reached the rock,
91  restaro, e trasser sé in dietro alquanto,
92  e tutti li altri che venieno appresso,
93  non sappiendo 'l perché, fenno altrettanto.
91  They stopped, and backward drew themselves somewhat;
92  And all the others, who came after them,
93  Not knowing why nor wherefore, did the same.
94  “Sanza vostra domanda io vi confesso
95  che questo è corpo uman che voi vedete;
96  per che 'l lume del sole in terra è fesso.
94  "Without your asking, I confess to you
95  This is a human body which you see,
96  Whereby the sunshine on the ground is cleft.
97  Non vi maravigliate, ma credete
98  che non sanza virtù che da ciel vegna
99  cerchi di soverchiar questa parete.”
97  Marvel ye not thereat, but be persuaded
98  That not without a power which comes from Heaven
99   Doth he endeavour to surmount this wall."
100  Così 'l maestro; e quella gente degna
101  “Tornate,” disse, “intrate innanzi dunque,”
102  coi dossi de la man faccendo insegna.
100  The Master thus; and said those worthy people:
101  "Return ye then, and enter in before us,"
102  Making a signal with the back o' the hand
103  E un di loro incominciò: “Chiunque
104  tu se', così andando, volgi 'l viso:
105  pon mente se di là mi vedesti unque.”
103  And one of them began: "Whoe'er thou art,
104  Thus going turn thine eyes, consider well
105  If e'er thou saw me in the other world."
106  Io mi volsi ver' lui e guardail fiso:
107  biondo era e bello e di gentile aspetto,
108  ma l'un de' cigli un colpo avea diviso.
106 I turned me tow'rds him, and looked at him closely;
107  Blond was he, beautiful, and of noble aspect,
108  But one of his eyebrows had a blow divided.
109  Quand' io mi fui umilmente disdetto
110  d'averlo visto mai, el disse: “Or vedi”;
111  e mostrommi una piaga a sommo 'l petto.
109  When with humility I had disclaimed
110  E'er having seen him, "Now behold!" he said,
111  And showed me high upon his breast a wound.
112  Poi sorridendo disse: “Io son Manfredi,
113  nepote di Costanza imperadrice;
114  ond' io ti priego che, quando tu riedi,
112  Then said he with a smile: "I am Manfredi,
113  The grandson of the Empress Costanza;
114  Therefore, when thou returnest, I beseech thee
115  vadi a mia bella figlia, genetrice
116  de l'onor di Cicilia e d'Aragona,
117  e dichi 'l vero a lei, s'altro si dice.
115  Go to my daughter beautiful, the mother
116  Of Sicily's honour and of Aragon's,
117  And the truth tell her, if aught else be told.
118  Poscia ch'io ebbi rotta la persona
119  di due punte mortali, io mi rendei,
120  piangendo, a quei che volontier perdona.
118  After I had my body lacerated
119  By these two mortal stabs, I gave myself
120  Weeping to Him, who willingly doth pardon.
121  Orribil furon li peccati miei;
122  ma la bontà infinita ha sì gran braccia,
123  che prende ciò che si rivolge a lei.
121  Horrible my iniquities had been;
122  But Infinite Goodness hath such ample arms,
123  That it receives whatever turns to it.
124  Se 'l pastor di Cosenza, che a la caccia
125  di me fu messo per Clemente allora,
126  avesse in Dio ben letta questa faccia,
124  Had but Cosenza's pastor, who in chase
125  Of me was sent by Clement at that time,
126  In God read understandingly this page,
127  l'ossa del corpo mio sarieno ancora
128  in co del ponte presso a Benevento,
129  sotto la guardia de la grave mora.
127  The bones of my dead body still would be
128  At the bridge-head, near unto Benevento,
129 Under the safeguard of the heavy cairn.
130  Or le bagna la pioggia e move il vento
131  di fuor dal regno, quasi lungo 'l Verde,
132  dov' e' le trasmutò a lume spento.
130  Now the rain bathes and moveth them the wind,
131  Beyond the realm, almost beside the Verde,
132  Where he transported them with tapers quenched.
133  Per lor maladizion sì non si perde,
134  che non possa tornar, l'etterno amore,
135  mentre che la speranza ha fior del verde.
133  By malison of theirs is not so lost
134  Eternal Love, that it cannot return,
135  So long as hope has anything of green.
136  Vero è che quale in contumacia more
137  di Santa Chiesa, ancor ch'al fin si penta,
138  star li convien da questa ripa in fore,
136  True is it, who in contumacy dies
137  Of Holy Church, though penitent at last,
138  Must wait upon the outside this bank
139  per ognun tempo ch'elli è stato, trenta,
140  in sua presunzïon, se tal decreto
141  più corto per buon prieghi non diventa.
139  Thirty times told the time that he has been
140  In his presumption, unless such decree
141  Shorter by means of righteous prayers become.
142  Vedi oggimai se tu mi puoi far lieto,
143  revelando a la mia buona Costanza
144  come m'hai visto, e anco esto divieto;
142  See now if thou hast power to make me happy,
143  By making known unto my good Costanza
144  How thou hast seen me, and this ban beside,
145 ché qui per quei di là molto s'avanza.”
145  For those on earth can much advance us here."
Purgatorio: Canto IV
Any absorption in the senses, Dante argues in the first 15 lines of this canto, impedes for us any perception of time.  The aspirant, in listening to Manfred in the previous canto, has dawdled for hours without any awareness of Time, and in doing so, he has absented himself from that power in the soul — some sort of background running "reason" — that somehow keeps track of everything which has transpired, including, and Dante makes this clear in all his references to Time, the activity of the celestial spheres.  Like the miraculous blending of the tripartite of Father (the transcendent), Son (the incarnate), and the Holy Ghost, the barycenter which constitutes the power which governs the relationship between the two.  These three would be the vegetative soul, governing physical growth, development and decay; the sensitive, governing the emotions, prodded into motion by the input of the senses; and the rational or intellective, which governs thought.  This last is not I think what can be meant by deductive or inductive reasoning, but something much more than that.  Let's call at the Akashic record keeper of all that is, has, or will transpire in the vegetative or the sensitive.  As odd as it may sound, this is the part of us beyond time, which enables us, from, as it were, a metaposition — such as we experience when we interpret dreams or poetry — to perceive the operations of the temporal.  Or, as Blake says: "Eternity is in love with the production of Time."  If we want to understand Time and the changes and creativity which can only unfold in Time, we have to do so as subjects beyond time's perpetual influence.  We have to center ourselves beyond those faculties of the vegetative physical body and our sensory and emotional enslavement to it, and view time, and with it, I think, chance, or what Dante has elsewhere called the machinations of "fortune," from a position of freedom outside those mutating influences.  Freedom, in Time, can only be experienced, when we are free from Time.  This, I think, cannot happen in Purgatory, because, as a place of learning, it must also be a place of change, and again and again, as we move up this mountain, which is primarily a metaphor for greater and wider perspectives, we are reminded of the teachings of Time and change.

These things require a subtle understanding and the very finest distinctions, a situation which the text makes clear by reference to the narrowness of the passage and the steepness of the way that the protagonists must traverse.  Getting from Time as an expanding volume to the narrow, straight way of our ordinary perception of it, is allegorized by the steep cliff that Dante and Virgil must climb to reach the first ledge where they might rest.  And we will remember too, how distorted time was at the end of the Inferno, and the narrow way finally out to the light of the Purgatorio.  As in the previous canto where the passage of sheep from the fold is the metaphor, so here too is a humble metaphor of a peasant stopping a small opening with a forkful of thorns.  Beyond the obvious reference to the Gospels and Christ's reference to the narrow way to salvation, the humble metaphor here perhaps is Dante's way of telling us, that for the overly-cultivated man, the return to the naivite of faith, requires a little basic peasant awareness, not common sense so much, as simply taking to hand what must be done, without too much questioning as to why it must be done, an observation made in the previous canto with that "quia", i.e., the acceptance rather than the questioning of what is.  One can also think of these narrow passageways as birth canals, dangerous, crushing tunnels which nevertheless lead to some kind of new birth, some hitherto impossible state of expansiveness.  We also have reference to feet and wings, the earthly and the heavenly, and we see how the aspirant's motivation becomes wings for his flagging and tired feet and breath, the hard climb made possible — if not yet easy — by his faith in this guide and by the promises his guide has made.  How are we to do this?  Perseverance: Keep going in spite of fatigue, and in spite of not knowing the way), and encouragement: Even when Virgil does not know the way, as he did in the Inferno, having passed that journey before, he knows that encouragement does not require certainty, but it too is an affirmation of faith.

This canto contains another rather complicated cosmology of the path of the sun through the Zodiac, and although confusing to the aspirant (and no doubt to every modern reader), nevertheless gives a clear indication of two things.  We must orient ourselves according to the heavens, and that the cosmos itself is a kind of wheel turning around Jerusalem.  If we think of a gyroscope inside of a clear globe we see that of the sun is following a path inside the globe, one hemisphere would be light, but beneath our feet, another hemisphere would be dark.  The center of the gyroscope, it's balancing point would be the mating of spirit with Earth's geography, that is to say, Jerusalem.  The sun's path in winter would be to the North, left, and in the summer, south, or right.  Dante, the aspirant is still turned around, not realizing that he is no longer and Hell or on Earth, and in a cleverly ironic assertion (lines 76 through 78), that he has never seen so clearly how dense he has been and is.  This is the first smile we've had as readers for a long time, and after all of the aspirant's references to his fatigue, and for his need to stop and rest, we are about to get another, broader one.  The mention of the twins, the bear, and Phaeton have in each case their own symbolical value, quite apart from celestial mechanics.  The twins remind us, among other things, that Dante the aspirant, is the counterpart of Dante the poet, in the diachronic premise of the poem.  The bear, in winter, hibernates, a question of sleeping, waiting, delay, things of which this canto is illustrative.  And of course Phaeton, the audacious spiritual failure, in contrast to Dante, the humble spiritual success.  We can leave it to each reader to decide if Dante's humility is genuine or not at this stage in his journey.  In this canto he does everything he can to show the aspirant's weaknesses, both mental and physical, but he also shows his strength, not the least of which is this ability to laugh at himself, as he perseveres in his quest.

The last section of this Canto is the meeting between the slothful Belacqua, who delayed repentance until the last moments of his life, and therefore must wait another lifetime in the Purgatory before he can proceed.  Note, at the beginning of this segment how Virgil's encouragement is a sugar coated promise, a far cry from some of the sharp corrections he uttered to his protege in many places in the Inferno.  We note too that the acquaintances that Dante meets in Purgatory, Casella, and now Belacqua, are people that he likes, or did like when they were alive, and he is happy here to be relieved of his grief for Belacqua, who is here among those who are saved, and who moreover still retains his sense of humor and irony.  Belacqua is to the protagonists' left, seated behind a rock, in that pose so beloved by Blake, of fatigue and defeat, squatted, head and hands between his knees.  The aspirant has to smile when he is exhorted by the personification of indolence to be alacritous in continuing his steep journey.  Night is coming on.  And the canto concludes with Virgil repeating admonishment of Belacqua for Dante to get a move on.  Morocco, home of the fleshpots of infidels is already tread upon by night, and the aspirant, not wanting also to be trapped here by darkness, gets the hint, and moves. 

What we want to take away from all this is that this canto is about Time and how Time operates celestially and spiritually, and how we make use of it or waste it.  It may be that Time waits for no one, but it is certainly a weight on everyone.  And the question becomes, in every instant, what is the best spiritual use of that instant.  But really, is what we are seeking chosen, or allowed?    
1  Quando per dilettanze o ver per doglie,
2  che alcuna virtù nostra comprenda,
3  l'anima bene ad essa si raccoglie, 
1  Whenever by delight or else by pain,
2  That seizes any faculty of ours,
3  Wholly to that the soul collects itself,
4  par ch'a nulla potenza più intenda;
5  e questo è contra quello error che crede
6  ch'un'anima sovr' altra in noi s'accenda.
4  It seemeth that no other power it heeds;
5  And this against that error is which thinks
6  One soul above another kindles in us.
7  E però, quando s'ode cosa o vede
8  che tegna forte a sé l'anima volta,
9  vassene 'l tempo e l'uom non se n'avvede;
7  And hence, whenever aught is heard or seen
8  Which keeps the soul intently bent upon it,
9  Time passes on, and we perceive it not,
10  ch'altra potenza è quella che l'ascolta,
11  e altra è quella c'ha l'anima intera:
12  questa è quasi legata e quella è sciolta.
10  Because one faculty is that which listens,
11  And other that which the soul keeps entire;
12  This is as if in bonds, and that is free.
13  Di ciò ebb' io esperïenza vera,
14  udendo quello spirto e ammirando;
15  ché ben cinquanta gradi salito era
13  Of this I had experience positive
14  In hearing and in gazing at that spirit;
15  For fifty full degrees uprisen was
16  lo sole, e io non m'era accorto, quando
17  venimmo ove quell' anime ad una
18  gridaro a noi: “Qui è vostro dimando.”
16  The sun, and I had not perceived it, when
17  We came to where those souls with one accord
18  Cried out unto us: "Here is what you ask."
19  Maggiore aperta molte volte impruna
20  con una forcatella di sue spine
21  l'uom de la villa quando l'uva imbruna,
19  A greater opening ofttimes hedges up
20  With but a little forkful of his thorns
21  The villager, what time the grape imbrowns,
22  che non era la calla onde salìne
23  lo duca mio, e io appresso, soli,
24  come da noi la schiera si partìne.
22  Than was the passage-way through which ascended
23  Only my Leader and myself behind him,
24  After that company departed from us.
25  Vassi in Sanleo e discendesi in Noli,
26  montasi su in Bismantova e' n Cacume
27  con esso i piè; ma qui convien ch'om voli;
25  One climbs Sanleo and descends in Noli,
26  And mounts the summit of Bismantova,
27  With feet alone; but here one needs must fly;
28  dico con l'ale snelle e con le piume
29  del gran disio, di retro a quel condotto
30  che speranza mi dava e facea lume.
28  With the swift pinions and the plumes I say
29  Of great desire, conducted after him
30  Who gave me hope, and made a light for me.
31  Noi salavam per entro 'l sasso rotto,
32  e d'ogne lato ne stringea lo stremo,
33  e piedi e man volea il suol di sotto.
31  We mounted upward through the rifted rock,
32  And on each side the border pressed upon us,
33  And feet and hands the ground beneath required.
34  Poi che noi fummo in su l'orlo suppremo
35  de l'alta ripa, a la scoperta piaggia,
36  “Maestro mio,” diss' io, “che via faremo?”
34  When we were come upon the upper rim
35  Of the high bank, out on the open slope,
36  "My Master," said I, "what way shall we take?"
37  Ed elli a me: “Nessun tuo passo caggia;
38  pur su al monte dietro a me acquista,
39  fin che n'appaia alcuna scorta saggia.”
37  And he to me: "No step of thine descend;
38  Still up the mount behind me win thy way,
39  Till some sage escort shall appear to us."
40  Lo sommo er' alto che vincea la vista,
41  e la costa superba più assai
42  che da mezzo quadrante a centro lista.
40  The summit was so high it vanquished sight,
41  And the hillside precipitous far more
42  Than line from middle quadrant to the centre.
43  Io era lasso, quando cominciai:
44  “O dolce padre, volgiti, e rimira
45  com' io rimango sol, se non restai.”
43  Spent with fatigue was I, when I began:
44  "O my sweet Father! turn thee and behold
45  How I remain alone, unless thou stay!"
46  “Figliuol mio,” disse, “infin quivi ti tira,”
47  additandomi un balzo poco in sùe
48  che da quel lato il poggio tutto gira.
46  "O son," he said, "up yonder drag thyself,"
47  Pointing me to a terrace somewhat higher,
48  Which on that side encircles all the hill.
49  Sì mi spronaron le parole sue,
50  ch'i' mi sforzai carpando appresso lui,
51  tanto che 'l cinghio sotto i piè mi fue.
49  These words of his so spurred me on, that I
50  Strained every nerve, behind him scrambling up,
51  Until the circle was beneath my feet.
52  A seder ci ponemmo ivi ambedui
53  vòlti a levante ond' eravam saliti,
54  che suole a riguardar giovare altrui.
52  Thereon ourselves we seated both of us
53  Turned to the East, from which we had ascended,
54  For all men are delighted to look back.
55  Li occhi prima drizzai ai bassi liti;
56  poscia li alzai al sole, e ammirava
57  che da sinistra n'eravam feriti.
55  To the low shores mine eyes I first directed,
56  Then to the sun uplifted them, and wondered
57  That on the left hand we were smitten by it.
58  Ben s'avvide il poeta ch'ïo stava
59  stupido tutto al carro de la luce,
60  ove tra noi e Aquilone intrava.

58  The Poet well perceived that I was wholly
59  Bewildered at the chariot of the light,
60  Where 'twixt us and the Aquilon it entered.

61  Ond' elli a me: “Se Castore e Poluce
62  fossero in compagnia di quello specchio
63  che sù e giù del suo lume conduce
61  Whereon he said to me: "If Castor and Pollux
62  Were in the company of yonder mirror,
63  That up and down conducteth with its light,
64  tu vedresti il Zodïaco rubecchio
65  ancora a l'Orse più stretto rotare,
66  se non uscisse fuor del cammin vecchio.

64  Thou wouldst behold the zodiac's jagged wheel
65  Revolving still more near unto the Bears,
66  Unless it swerved aside from its old track.

67  Come ciò sia, se 'l vuoi poter pensare,
68  dentro raccolto, imagina Sïòn
69  con questo monte in su la terra stare
67  How that may be wouldst thou have power to think,
68  Collected in thyself, imagine Zion
69  Together with this mount on earth to stand,
70  sì, ch'amendue hanno un solo orizzòn
71  e diversi emisperi; onde la strada
72  che mal non seppe carreggiar Fetòn,
70  So that they both one sole horizon have,
71  And hemispheres diverse; whereby the road
72  Which Phaeton, alas! knew not to drive,
73  vedrai come a costui convien che vada
74  da l'un, quando a colui da l'altro fianco,
75  se lo 'ntelletto tuo ben chiaro bada.”
73  Thou'lt see how of necessity must pass
74  This on one side, when that upon the other,
75   If thine intelligence right clearly heed."
76  “Certo, maestro mio,” diss' io, “unquanco
77  non vid' io chiaro sì com' io discerno
78  là dove mio ingegno parea manco,
76  "Truly, my Master," said I, "never yet
77  Saw I so clearly as I now discern,
78  There where my wit appeared incompetent,
79  che 'l mezzo cerchio del moto superno,
80  che si chiama Equatore in alcun' arte,
81  e che sempre riman tra 'l sole e 'l verno,
79  That the mid-circle of supernal motion,
80  Which in some art is the Equator called,
81  And aye remains between the Sun and Winter,
82  per la ragion che di', quinci si parte
83  verso settentrïon, quanto li Ebrei
84  vedevan lui verso la calda parte.
82  For reason which thou sayest, departeth hence
83  Tow'rds the Septentrion, what time the Hebrews
84  Beheld it tow'rds the region of the heat.
85  Ma se a te piace, volontier saprei
86  quanto avemo ad andar; ché 'l poggio sale
87  più che salir non posson li occhi miei.”
85  But, if it pleaseth thee, I fain would learn
86  How far we have to go; for the hill rises
87  Higher than eyes of mine have power to rise."
88  Ed elli a me: “Questa montagna è tale,
89  che sempre al cominciar di sotto è grave;
90  e quant' om più va sù, e men fa male.
88  And he to me: "This mount is such, that ever
89  At the beginning down below 'tis tiresome,
90  And aye the more one climbs, the less it hurts.
91  Però, quand' ella ti parrà soave
92  tanto, che sù andar ti fia leggero
93  com' a seconda giù andar per nave,
91  Therefore, when it shall seem so pleasant to thee,
92  That going up shall be to thee as easy
93  As going down the current in a boat,
94  allor sarai al fin d'esto sentiero;
95  quivi di riposar l'affanno aspetta.
96  Più non rispondo, e questo so per vero.”

94  Then at this pathway's ending thou wilt be;
95  There to repose thy panting breath expect;
96  No more I answer; and this I know for true."

97  E com' elli ebbe sua parola detta,
98  una voce di presso sonò: “Forse
99  che di sedere in pria avrai distretta!”
97  And as he finished uttering these words,
98  A voice close by us sounded: "Peradventure
99  Thou wilt have need of sitting down ere that."
100  Al suon di lei ciascun di noi si torse,
101  e vedemmo a mancina un gran petrone,
102  del qual né io né ei prima s'accorse.
100  At sound thereof each one of us turned round,
101  And saw upon the left hand a great rock,
102  Which neither I nor he before had noticed.
103  Là ci traemmo; e ivi eran persone
104  che si stavano a l'ombra dietro al sasso
105  come l'uom per negghienza a star si pone.
103  Thither we drew; and there were persons there
104  Who in the shadow stood behind the rock,
105  As one through indolence is wont to stand.
106  E un di lor, che mi sembiava lasso,
107  sedeva e abbracciava le ginocchia,
108  tenendo 'l viso giù tra esse basso.
106  And one of them, who seemed to me fatigued,
107  Was sitting down, and both his knees embraced,
108  Holding his face low down between them bowed.
109  “O dolce segnor mio,” diss' io, “adocchia
110  colui che mostra sé più negligente
111  che se pigrizia fosse sua serocchia.”
109  "O my sweet Lord," I said, "do turn thine eye
110  On him who shows himself more negligent
111  Then even Sloth herself his sister were."
112  Allor si volse a noi e puose mente,
113  movendo 'l viso pur su per la coscia,
114  e disse: “Or va tu sù, che se' valente!”
112  Then he turned round to us, and he gave heed,
113  Just lifting up his eyes above his thigh,
114  And said: "Now go thou up, for thou art valiant."
115  Conobbi allor chi era, e quella angoscia
116  che m'avacciava un poco ancor la lena,
117  non m'impedì l'andare a lui; e poscia

115  Then knew I who he was; and the distress,
116  That still a little did my breathing quicken,
117  My going to him hindered not; and after

118  ch'a lui fu' giunto, alzò la testa a pena,
119  dicendo: “Hai ben veduto come 'l sole
120  da l'omero sinistro il carro mena?”
118  I came to him he hardly raised his head,
119  Saying: "Hast thou seen clearly how the sun
120  'er thy left shoulder drives his chariot?"
121  Li atti suoi pigri e le corte parole
122  mosser le labbra mie un poco a riso;
123  poi cominciai: “Belacqua, a me non dole
121  His sluggish attitude and his curt words
122  A little unto laughter moved my lips;
123  Then I began: "Belacqua, I grieve not
124  di te omai; ma dimmi: perché assiso
125  quiritto se'? attendi tu iscorta,
126  o pur lo modo usato t'ha' ripriso?”
124  For thee henceforth; but tell me, wherefore seated
125  In this place art thou? Waitest thou an escort?
126  Or has thy usual habit seized upon thee?"
127  Ed elli: “O frate, andar in sù che porta?
128  ché non mi lascerebbe ire a' martìri
129  l'angel di Dio che siede in su la porta.
127  And he: "O brother, what's the use of climbing?
128  Since to my torment would not let me go
129  The Angel of God, who sitteth at the gate.
130  Prima convien che tanto il ciel m'aggiri
131  di fuor da essa, quanto fece in vita,
132  per ch'io 'ndugiai al fine i buon sospiri,
130  First heaven must needs so long revolve me round
131  Outside thereof, as in my life it did,
132  ince the good sighs I to the end postponed,
133  se orazïone in prima non m'aita
134  che surga sù di cuor che in grazia viva;
135  l'altra che val, che 'n ciel non è udita?”
133  Unless, e'er that, some prayer may bring me aid
134  Which rises from a heart that lives in grace;
135  What profit others that in heaven are heard not?"
136  E già il poeta innanzi mi saliva,
137  e dicea: “Vienne omai; vedi ch'è tocco
138  meridïan dal sole, e a la riva
136  Meanwhile the Poet was before me mounting,
137  And saying: "Come now; see the sun has touched
138  Meridian, and from the shore the night
139  cuopre la notte già col piè Morrocco.”

139  Covers already with her foot Morocco."

Purgatorio: Canto V
Distraction, diversion, miracle, spectacle, celebrity — what do these things have in common?  They are all obstacles on the spiritual path — they are all things which make their promises to a soul in need of escape, of rest, of a break from the crushing burden (as Schopenhauer might see it) and boredom of the ordinary.  The first part of Canto IV Purgatorio pulls us into a kind of mini-vortex of what the Buddhist's call near poisons, things that look like sources of genuine wonder, but which eventually turn their allures into hindrances on the path.  All through the Purgatorio Time has become more important, but not so much as a kind of medium in which change can take place, but as catastrophic of wastage, for every moment not spent in union with the whole is eventually a source of fragmentation, of separation, and above all things, the soul is a unifying force, and yet the entire Commedia keeps revolving around this capacity of soul — even or should we say particularly after the shedding of that body which blocks the light and casts a shadow, even in the anteroom of paradise — to delay its own progress.  Every step we take on the path is both a step up or a step down, a step toward or a step away from, a step toward unification and freedom or a step towards selfishness and bondage.  And what is the most precious commodity of the soul?  The body?  Well, all the souls we meet here in this Canto, have yet to come up with any other answer, either being obsessed with Dante as a corpus or with their own bodies that in this case were shed by acts of violence during their Earthly existence.  Virgil somehow knows this — which is a mystery in itself — and he knows too that there is a deadly difference between curiosity for unusual things, which is what the shades here are displaying when they see Dante's shade, and a compassionate search for authenticity.  The shades here have made of Dante a celebrity, he is the ordinary showing up in an extraordinary place, and blocking the light, because he distracts the souls from their purpose.  Instead of looking at Dante's shadow, they should have been looking at the source of light.  In a word, they are dawdlers, men and women, who put off or were by the circumstances of their lives, were delayed until the very last moment, from seeing their need for salvation, and what is even more astonishing, the alacrity with which Divine beings offer their compassion, even in the most disturbing circumstances.  Virgil breaks the aspirant's trance here, by the invocation of shame.  To be fascinated by one's own course, one's own uniqueness, celebrity, talent, notoriety, past accomplishments, and so forth, is to set up a kind of false idol, which takes us away from transcendence by sneaking a changeling soul into the place where the real soul should be.  And where is that?  In the shadow, in that physical substance and the ego's attachment to it, which blocks the light.  Note too that Dante's shadow falls to the left, the direction of the protagonists' progress through the Inferno.  Here, on the road to salvation, Dante, the aspirant, is doing the most ordinary of things: which is, as line 6 tells us: to conduct himself like one of the living, and it is this degraded state that makes him a wonder in this place, which is the very foundation of wonder.  I think Dante does an extraordinary thing here.  So many times on this journey, he has pointed out the astonishment of those souls in the afterlife who confront one conducting himself like one of the living, so many times, in fact, that the reader might be tempted into thinking that this trope has become a kind of cliché, a filler, that allows both the poet's and the reader's imagination to rest, even while reading, by making us think, 'nothing new here, I understand this perfectly.  But do we understand.  I think not.  Not a rest, but a goad, or an obstacle to our spiritual aspirations, and we don't need a miracle or a spectacle to understand this.  Virgil can simply deduce it by not acting like one who lives.  Virgil, a denizen, of that circle of Hell where the virtuous pagans are stuck in the unmoving tableau of their own fame, knows that the nature of the soul, is to move, and like Yeats, the poem, in so many instances, and also here, in Jacopo's death in a swamp and Buonconte's corpse in its journey to the sea, seems to be saying "What's water but the generated soul."   
The other major issue at stake here is one of relationship, the relationships that we forge or break in life, and the relationship that we have between those things that pertain to the mortal body, one's political position, one's power, one's wealth, and the relationship that we have with our soul, our thoughts about the departed, our marriage, our genuine spiritual work, our humility, or our compassion.  The only proper relationship of the any to any is one based up this connective tissue of compassion.  Pray for me.  I will pray for you.  Those are the foundation stones that unite disparate things and beings in a ring of mutual concern, and when we come to the simple story of Pia at the end, we need only be brought to the bare image of a stone set in a ring as the promise of betrothal and faithfulness, her greatest treasure, and the means used to betray her.
      
1  I had already from those shades departed,
2  And followed in the footsteps of my Guide,
3  When from behind, pointing his finger at me,

1  Io era già da quell' ombre partito,
2  e seguitava l'orme del mio duca,
3  quando di retro a me, drizzando 'l dito,

4  One shouted: "See, it seems as if shone not
5  The sunshine on the left of him below,
6  And like one living seems he to conduct him."

4  una gridò: “Ve' che non par che luca
5  lo raggio da sinistra a quel di sotto,
6  e come vivo par che si conduca!”

7  Mine eyes I turned at utterance of these words,
8  And saw them watching with astonishment
9  But me, but me, and the light which was broken!

7  Li occhi rivolsi al suon di questo motto,
8  e vidile guardar per maraviglia
9  pur me, pur me, e 'l lume ch'era rotto.

10  "Why doth thy mind so occupy itself,"
11  The Master said, "that thou thy pace dost slacken?
12  What matters it to thee what here is whispered?

10  “Perché l'animo tuo tanto s'impiglia,”
11  disse 'l maestro, “che l'andare allenti?
12  che ti fa ciò che quivi si pispiglia?

13  Come after me, and let the people talk;
14  Stand like a steadfast tower, that never wags
15  Its top for all the blowing of the winds;

13  Vien dietro a me, e lascia dir le genti:
14  sta come torre ferma, che non crolla
15  già mai la cima per soffiar di venti;

16  For evermore the man in whom is springing
17  Thought upon thought, removes from him the mark,
18  Because the force of one the other weakens."

16  ché sempre l'omo in cui pensier rampolla
17  sovra pensier, da sé dilunga il segno,
18  perché la foga l'un de l'altro insolla.”
19  What could I say in answer but "I come"?
20  I said it somewhat with that colour tinged
21  Which makes a man of pardon sometimes worthy.

19  Che potea io ridir, se non “Io vegno”?
20  Dissilo, alquanto del color consperso
21  che fa l'uom di perdon talvolta degno.

22  Meanwhile along the mountain-side across
23  Came people in advance of us a little,
24  Singing the Miserere verse by verse.

22  E 'ntanto per la costa di traverso
23  venivan genti innanzi a noi un poco,
24  cantando “Miserere” a verso a verso.

25  When they became aware I gave no place
26  For passage of the sunshine through my body,
27  They changed their song into a long, hoarse "Oh!"

25  Quando s'accorser ch'i' non dava loco
26  per lo mio corpo al trapassar d'i raggi,
27  mutar lor canto in un “oh!” lungo e roco;

28  And two of them, in form of messengers,
29  Ran forth to meet us, and demanded of us,
30  "Of your condition make us cognisant."

28  e due di loro, in forma di messaggi,
29  corsero incontr' a noi e dimandarne:
30  “Di vostra condizion fatene saggi.”

31  And said my Master: "Ye can go your way
32  And carry back again to those who sent you,
33  That this one's body is of very flesh.

31  E 'l mio maestro: “Voi potete andarne
32  e ritrarre a color che vi mandaro
33  che 'l corpo di costui è vera carne.

34  If they stood still because they saw his shadow,
35  As I suppose, enough is answered them;
36  Him let them honour, it may profit them."

34  Se per veder la sua ombra restaro,
35  com' io avviso, assai è lor risposto:
36  fàccianli onore, ed esser può lor caro.”

37  Vapours enkindled saw I ne'er so swiftly
38  At early nightfall cleave the air serene,
39  Nor, at the set of sun, the clouds of August,

37  Vapori accesi non vid' io sì tosto
38  di prima notte mai fender sereno,
39  né, sol calando, nuvole d'agosto,

40  But upward they returned in briefer time,
41  And, on arriving, with the others wheeled
42  Tow'rds us, like troops that run without a rein.

40  che color non tornasser suso in meno;
41  e, giunti là, con li altri a noi dier volta,
42  come schiera che scorre sanza freno.

43  "This folk that presses unto us is great,
44  And cometh to implore thee," said the Poet;
45  "So still go onward, and in going listen."

43  “Questa gente che preme a noi è molta,
44  e vegnonti a pregar,” disse 'l poeta:
45  “però pur va, e in andando ascolta.”

46  "O soul that goest to beatitude
47  With the same members wherewith thou wast born,"
48  Shouting they came, "a little stay thy steps,

46  “O anima che vai per esser lieta
47  con quelle membra con le quai nascesti,”
48  venian gridando, “un poco il passo queta.

49  Look, if thou e'er hast any of us seen,
50  So that o'er yonder thou bear news of him;
51  Ah, why dost thou go on? Ah, why not stay?

49  Guarda s'alcun di noi unqua vedesti,
50  sì che di lui di là novella porti:
51  deh, perché vai? deh, perché non t'arresti?

52  Long since we all were slain by violence,
53  And sinners even to the latest hour;
54  Then did a light from heaven admonish us,

52  Noi fummo tutti già per forza morti,
53  e peccatori infino a l'ultima ora;
54  quivi lume del ciel ne fece accorti,

55  So that, both penitent and pardoning, forth
56  From life we issued reconciled to God,
57  Who with desire to see Him stirs our hearts."

55  sì che, pentendo e perdonando, fora
56  di vita uscimmo a Dio pacificati,
57  che del disio di sé veder n'accora.”

58  And I: "Although I gaze into your faces,
59  No one I recognize; but if may please you
60  Aught I have power to do, ye well-born spirits,

58  E io: “Perché ne' vostri visi guati,
59  non riconosco alcun; ma s'a voi piace
60  cosa ch'io possa, spiriti ben nati

61  Speak ye, and I will do it, by that peace
62  Which, following the feet of such a Guide,
63  From world to world makes itself sought by me."

61  voi dite, e io farò per quella pace
62  che, dietro a' piedi di sì fatta guida,
63  di mondo in mondo cercar mi si face.”

64  And one began: "Each one has confidence
65  In thy good offices without an oath,
66  Unless the I cannot cut off the I will;

64  E uno incominciò: “Ciascun si fida
65  del beneficio tuo sanza giurarlo,
66  pur che 'l voler nonpossa non ricida.

67  Whence I, who speak alone before the others,
68  Pray thee, if ever thou dost see the land
69  That 'twixt Romagna lies and that of Charles,

67  Ond' io, che solo innanzi a li altri parlo,
68  ti priego, se mai vedi quel paese
69  che siede tra Romagna e quel di Carlo,

70  Thou be so courteous to me of thy prayers
71  In Fano, that they pray for me devoutly,
72  That I may purge away my grave offences.

70  che tu mi sie di tuoi prieghi cortese
71  in Fano, sì che ben per me s'adori
72  pur ch'i' possa purgar le gravi offese.

73  From thence was I; but the deep wounds, through which
74  Issued the blood wherein I had my seat,
75  Were dealt me in bosom of the Antenori,

73  Quindi fu' io; ma li profondi fóri
74  ond' uscì 'l sangue in sul quale io sedea,
75  fatti mi fuoro in grembo a li Antenori,

76  There where I thought to be the most secure;
77  'Twas he of Este had it done, who held me
78  In hatred far beyond what justice willed.

76  là dov' io più sicuro esser credea:
77  quel da Esti il fé far, che m'avea in ira
78  assai più là che dritto non volea.

79  But if towards the Mira I had fled,
80  When I was overtaken at Oriaco,
81  I still should be o'er yonder where men breathe.

79  Ma s'io fosse fuggito inver' la Mira,
80  quando fu' sovragiunto ad Orïaco,
81  ancor sarei di là dove si spira.

82  I ran to the lagoon, and reeds and mire
83  Did so entangle me I fell, and saw there
84  A lake made from my veins upon the ground."

82  Corsi al palude, e le cannucce e 'l braco
83  m'impigliar sì ch'i' caddi; e lì vid' io
84  de le mie vene farsi in terra laco.”

85  Then said another: "Ah, be that desire
86  Fulfilled that draws thee to the lofty mountain,
87  As thou with pious pity aidest mine.

85  Poi disse un altro: “Deh, se quel disio
86  si compia che ti tragge a l'alto monte,
87  con buona pïetate aiuta il mio!

88  I was of Montefeltro, and am Buonconte;
89  Giovanna, nor none other cares for me;
90  Hence among these I go with downcast front."

88  Io fui di Montefeltro, io son Bonconte;
89  Giovanna o altri non ha di me cura;
90  per ch'io vo tra costor con bassa fronte.”

91  And I to him: "What violence or what chance
92  Led thee astray so far from Campaldino,
93  That never has thy sepulture been known?"

91  E io a lui: “Qual forza o qual ventura
92  ti travïò sì fuor di Campaldino,
93  che non si seppe mai tua sepultura?”

94  "Oh," he replied, "at Casentino's foot
95  A river crosses named Archiano, born
96  Above the Hermitage in Apennine.

94  “Oh!” rispuos' elli, “a piè del Casentino
95  traversa un'acqua c'ha nome l'Archiano,
96  che sovra l'Ermo nasce in Apennino.

97  There where the name thereof becometh void
98  Did I arrive, pierced through and through the throat,
99  Fleeing on foot, and bloodying the plain;

97  Là 've 'l vocabol suo diventa vano,
98  arriva' io forato ne la gola,
99  fuggendo a piede e sanguinando il piano.

100  There my sight lost I, and my utterance
101  Ceased in the name of Mary, and thereat
102  I fell, and tenantless my flesh remained.

100  Quivi perdei la vista e la parola;
101  nel nome di Maria fini', e quivi
102  caddi, e rimase la mia carne sola.

103  Truth will I speak, repeat it to the living;
104  God's Angel took me up, and he of hell
105  Shouted: 'O thou from heaven, why dost thou rob me?

103  Io dirò vero, e tu 'l ridì tra ' vivi:
104  l'angel di Dio mi prese, e quel d'inferno
105  gridava: 'O tu del ciel, perché mi privi?

106  Thou bearest away the eternal part of him,
107  For one poor little tear, that takes him from me;
108  But with the rest I'll deal in other fashion!'

106  Tu te ne porti di costui l'etterno
107  per una lagrimetta che 'l mi toglie;
108  ma io farò de l'altro altro governo!'

109  Well knowest thou how in the air is gathered
110  That humid vapour which to water turns,
111  Soon as it rises where the cold doth grasp it.

109  Ben sai come ne l'aere si raccoglie
110  quell' umido vapor che in acqua riede,
111  tosto che sale dove 'l freddo il coglie.

112  He joined that evil will, which aye seeks evil,
113  To intellect, and moved the mist and wind
114  By means of power, which his own nature gave;

112  Giunse quel mal voler che pur mal chiede
113  con lo 'ntelletto, e mosse il fummo e 'l vento
114  per la virtù che sua natura diede.

115  Thereafter, when the day was spent, the valley
116  From Pratomagno to the great yoke covered
117  With fog, and made the heaven above intent,

115  Indi la valle, come 'l dì fu spento,
116  da Pratomagno al gran giogo coperse
117  di nebbia; e 'l ciel di sopra fece intento,

118  So that the pregnant air to water changed;
119  Down fell the rain, and to the gullies came
120  Whate'er of it earth tolerated not;

118  sì che 'l pregno aere in acqua si converse;
119  la pioggia cadde, e a' fossati venne
120  di lei ciò che la terra non sofferse;

121  And as it mingled with the mighty torrents,
122  Towards the royal river with such speed
123  It headlong rushed, that nothing held it back.

121  e come ai rivi grandi si convenne,
122  ver' lo fiume real tanto veloce
123  si ruinò, che nulla la ritenne.

124  My frozen body near unto its outlet
125  The robust Archian found, and into Arno
126  Thrust it, and loosened from my breast the cross

124  Lo corpo mio gelato in su la foce
125  trovò l'Archian rubesto; e quel sospinse
126  ne l'Arno, e sciolse al mio petto la croce

127  I made of me, when agony o'ercame me;
128  It rolled me on the banks and on the bottom,
129  Then with its booty covered and begirt me."

127  ch'i' fe' di me quando 'l dolor mi vinse;
128  voltòmmi per le ripe e per lo fondo,
129  poi di sua preda mi coperse e cinse.”

130  "Ah, when thou hast returned unto the world,
131  And rested thee from thy long journeying,"
132  After the second followed the third spirit,

130  “Deh, quando tu sarai tornato al mondo
132  e riposato de la lunga via,”
133  seguitò 'l terzo spirito al secondo,

133  "Do thou remember me who am the Pia;
134  Siena made me, unmade me Maremma;
135  He knoweth it, who had encircled first,

133  “ricorditi di me, che son la Pia;
134  Siena mi fé, disfecemi Maremma:
135  salsi colui che 'nnanellata pria

136  Espousing me, my finger with his gem."

136  disposando m'avea con la sua gemma.”

Purgatorio: Canto VI
Neither the grandeur nor the subtlety of Dante’s insight can really be experienced through excerpts.  The significance of the opening simile of Canto VI of the Purgatorio on chance cannot be fully grasped without comparing it to Virgil's exposition in Canto VII of the Inferno on Fortune.  In the Inferno Fortune is both entity - Lady Fortune - and object - a vertically mounted wheel.  The wheel metaphor is very much in keeping with Hell-consciousness.  It postulates a sense of inevitability, a fatefulness about mortal life.  You may be thriving now, but the wheel turns, and you suffer a penurious defeat.  In this metaphor Lady Fortune becomes God’s designate, and his omnipotence is not tarnished by foreknowledge of either your accomplishments or your defeats.  It all happens automatically, in a sense, then, one’s virtue or viciousness is irrelevant to our mortal condition.  How then could we be either elevated to transcendence or consigned to perdition on the basis of arbitrary processes beyond our control?  We get into a rather Bhagavad Gita moral mess here.  In the sense that action is volitional, but the fruits of action exist at another level of what Bateson called logical hierarchies.  One could write an entire book on this subject alone, and one could also say that The Divine Comedy is that book.  Virgil also uses a rather intriguing figure in the Inferno about how each aspect of the universe reflects all other aspects in its distribution of pleasure and pain, virtue and vice — the cosmos being a kind of fractalized jewel of many facets, or in another line, the workings of Lady Fortune are secret, like the presence of a snake in the grass.  This then is Virgil's explanation.  Is it credible?  Well, we have to consider that, because Virgil's fallibility is just exactly what the aspirant does question here.  But now let’s return to the dice-throw metaphor in Canto VI of the Purgatorio.  Dice games are numbers games with odds.  Sometimes you win, sometimes you lose, but it is not inevitable as it is with the wheel that down is followed by up, or that up precedes down.  Each throw's effect is undetermined, and neither the actions of the winner nor the loser have any bearing on the outcome.  This looks suspiciously like Grace, as an auspicious result is simply given, and merit has nothing to do with winning or losing. It is very telling that Dante depicts his loser lingering over his misfortune as though by recalculating his actions he might find the causes of his loss and a pathway to future victories.  And so now we find the real tragedy of the loser - in this case Virgil, who missed salvation by the accidental timing of his birth before the incarnation.  He does not understand the incredible complexity of the apparently random events which led to his defeat.  He does not understand that he is not the author of his own book or fate.  And 'though the circumstances stances which defeated him were beyond his control, he still has his pagan pride by thinking that they should have been. This world of the loser, is one of justice and it’s inevitable corollary, injustice.  Once we cross the waters of chaos to arrive at purgatory, the world of such dichotomies is behind us.  By grace, not by merit, we have already won.  If Dante had postulated this conflation of chance and grace a few centuries later, he might have met Bruno’s fate at the stake.  Finally, we learn from Singleton's commentary that in this dice game, the player's win or lose by predicting the outcome of their throw, before it is made, so there is an element of divination in the game, the winner a correct diviner of the future, the loser a false prophet so to speak.  We discern from this that the winner is more in alignment with the times — to put it in I Ching-like terms — or with God's will — to use a more medieval Christian trope.  So this too infuses the winner with a kind of supernatural glow as the favorite of Lady Fortune, in short, blessed by luck, which, as mentioned above, becomes a kind of synonym for grace.

After this opening salvo, what follows is the presentation of those who have died by violence but have had the good fortune of being granted time to repent or have an angel intervene on their behalf, and also the good fortune to have met a living person who might carry their requests for prayer back to the mortal world.  Here, and later when we meet Sordello, Virgil's fellow Mantuan, we have another portrait of what we may call the extended self, the geographic self, the linguistic self, the political or cultural self.  That this self, the body without organs, as Delueze might phrase it, is in violent termoil, is a central theme of Dante's throughout the poem.  It is a level of self wherein the internal fissures of the skin-encapsulated ego are writ large in the body politic.  When we read the back stories of those presented here, we find the most horrendous tales of internicine violence, and, political wars, clan disputes, murders that exceed all the proprieties of religion or law.  Italy, and by extention, Earth in mortal life, is a region of terror and violence, where not good Lady Fortune, but evil chance, rules.  Should we infer from this that it is only in the domain of spirit, or conscience, or imagination that we might find some solace or healing of these terrible rifts?  This is not a light question at all.  And why, if this is so, does the good will of those living in this mortal terror still have the capablility of assisting the progress of those who have escaped from it?  What exactly is it that allows those of flesh and blood this special power?  Virgil gives us a hint, in his rather tortured answer to Dante's questioning of this power of the living to assist those who have shuffled off their mortal coil.  It is because human beings in their mortal condition, in spite of their blindness and violence are capable of the "fire of love" (foco d'amor, line 38).  Then in a telling check on his own insight, Virgil advises Dante to not expect an answer from him, but to wait until he reaches Beatrice higher up the mountain in order to resolve himself of these doubts.  An interesting feature of the text here, has Dante refering to Virgil, even as he questions the older poet's veracity as "o luce mia", oh light of mine.  And this throws as back to Saint Lucy, at the very beginning of the Commedia.  Light/Love are the only solutions to the reckless and violent idiocy of the human predicament.  We should not be surprised here to find that the previously exhausted Dante is infused with more strength and fervor upon hearing Virgil's promise.  

We should add an aside here, concerning Dante's attitude towards his teacher, or towards authority, even when that authority is very often shown to be fallible.  That attitude is always one of veneration.  But it cannot be veneration of the "information" that he receives, because that information is not always correct or useful.  What is that veneration for then?  It must be a veneration for the relationship itself, the gift or experience to ignorance, flows only through a channel of love, trust, respect, and if we damage that pipeline so to speak, then all is lost, because the connection is fouled and broken.  This relationship is the real teaching, not the information, a truth that has become so clouded, indeed, entirely lost in many cases in contemporary society, that voracious appetite for information (without regard to its truth, usefulness, or beauty) completely occluding any attitude of love, trust, or respect, and delivered to us via machine.  Dante's world, even as it wallows in violence, betrayals, and superstition is still a human world because there remains in it the motivating power of love.

Now we come to the meeting with the poet Sordello, imperious at first, until he realizes that Virgil is a fellow Mantuan.  The two successfully embrace — an obvious foil to the failed embrace earlier between Dante and Casella, which brings us a positive example of the unity of that extended self referred to above.  The two are poets, the two are are fellow countrymen (in the geographic, not the politcal sense), the two, are in effect one, at that level of the self.  A condition that we should remember as we read, because the poem constantly invites us to enter into relationship with it, and Dante, at this level of the self.  That is, as readers of the poem, we become, as Borges has cleverly shown in some of his works, we become that larger self, sharing with Dante the same identity that has made this masterpiece, and which has the power to free us from mortality's terror, if we will relate to with that love, trust, and respect which is required for — not just or understanding — but of our shared poetic experience.

The conclusion of this Canto, and the most lengthy section, the part that modern reader is most likely to skip over because we do not see the history spoken of here as our history is all an invective against the condition of this extended self, in Dante's case, Italy, but by extension, the secular world.  It is a mad rush of mixed metaphors: Italy is a slave to tyrants.  Italy is a rudderless ship.  Italy is a riderless horse.  Italy is a garden laid waste.  Italy is a bereft widow.  Italy is a violent circus ruled by clowns.  And then we come to what seems to be so out of place here (a digression as Dante refers to it), and that is the long concluding passage entirely and venomously drenched with irony, about Dante's own homeland, Florence.  That irony and it's implied invective yet has a high seat in Dante's consciousness shows us that the poet still has a lot to learn about the love, trust, and respect that he so values in this domain of the extended self.  Here is one aspect of the self gnawing at another.  How can the mystical union of transcendence be achieved when this internal rancor still rages?  This is not a question which can be answered in the shadow of this anteroom of Purgatory.  And the aspirant Dante seems only to have a vague inkling of this.  Yet it is an inkling.  The last metaphor here is that of a sick woman (a kind of negative anima figure here, as Beatrice is a positive one, and as the brief portrait of Pia in the previous canto is a tragic one ), tossing and turning in pain on a bed of self-congratulatory luxury.  To me this image rhymes ominously to the condition of America (and much of the rest of the world), now: Winter, 2019.       

1  Whene'er is broken up the game of Zara,
2  He who has lost remains behind despondent,
3  The throws repeating, and in sadness learns;

1  Quando si parte il gioco de la zara,
2  colui che perde si riman dolente,
3  repetendo le volte, e tristo impara;

4  The people with the other all depart;
5  One goes in front, and one behind doth pluck him,
6  And at his side one brings himself to mind;

4  con l'altro se ne va tutta la gente;
5  qual va dinanzi, e qual di dietro il prende,
6  e qual dallato li si reca a mente;

7  He pauses not, and this and that one hears;
8  They crowd no more to whom his hand he stretches,
9  And from the throng he thus defends himself.

7  el non s'arresta, e questo e quello intende;
8  a cui porge la man, più non fa pressa;
9  e così da la calca si difende.

10  Even such was I in that dense multitude,
11  Turning to them this way and that my face,
12  And, promising, I freed myself therefrom.

10  Tal era io in quella turba spessa,
11  volgendo a loro, e qua e là, la faccia
12  e promettendo mi sciogliea da essa.

13  There was the Aretine, who from the arms
14  Untamed of Ghin di Tacco had his death,
15  And he who fleeing from pursuit was drowned.

13  Quiv' era l'Aretin che da le braccia
14  fiere di Ghin di Tacco ebbe la morte,
15  e l'altro ch'annegò correndo in caccia. 

16  There was imploring with his hands outstretched
17  Frederick Novello, and that one of Pisa
18  Who made the good Marzucco seem so strong.

16  Quivi pregava con le mani sporte
17  Federigo Novello, e quel da Pisa
18  che fé parer lo buon Marzucco forte.

19  I saw Count Orso; and the soul divided
20  By hatred and by envy from its body,
21  As it declared, and not for crime committed,

19  Vidi conte Orso e l'anima divisa
20  dal corpo suo per astio e per inveggia,
21  com' e' dicea, non per colpa commisa;

22  Pierre de la Brosse I say; and here provide
23  While still on earth the Lady of Brabant,
24  So that for this she be of no worse flock!

22  Pier da la Broccia dico; e qui proveggia,
23  mentr' è di qua, la donna di Brabante,
24  sì che però non sia di peggior greggia.

25  As soon as I was free from all those shades
26  Who only prayed that some one else may pray,
27  So as to hasten their becoming holy,

25  Come libero fui da tutte quante
26  quell' ombre che pregar pur ch'altri prieghi,
27  sì che s'avacci lor divenir sante,

28  Began I: "It appears that thou deniest,
29  O light of mine, expressly in some text,
30  That orison can bend decree of Heaven;

28  io cominciai: “El par che tu mi nieghi,
29  o luce mia, espresso in alcun testo
30  che decreto del cielo orazion pieghi;

31  And ne'ertheless these people pray for this.
32  Might then their expectation bootless be?
33  Or is to me thy saying not quite clear?"

31  e questa gente prega pur di questo:
32  sarebbe dunque loro speme vana,
33 o non m'è 'l detto tuo ben manifesto?”

34  And he to me: "My writing is explicit,
35  And not fallacious is the hope of these,
36  If with sane intellect 'tis well regarded;

34  Ed elli a me: “La mia scrittura è piana;
35  e la speranza di costor non falla,
36  se ben si guarda con la mente sana

37  For top of judgment doth not vail itself,
38  Because the fire of love fulfils at once
39  What he must satisfy who here installs him.

37  ché cima di giudicio non s'avvalla
38  perché foco d'amor compia in un punto
39  ciò che de' sodisfar chi qui s'astalla;

40  And there, where I affirmed that proposition,
41  Defect was not amended by a prayer,
42  Because the prayer from God was separate.

40  e là dov' io fermai cotesto punto,
41  non s'ammendava, per pregar, difetto,
42  perché 'l priego da Dio era disgiunto.

43  Verily, in so deep a questioning
44  Do not decide, unless she tell it thee,
45  Who light 'twixt truth and intellect shall be.

43  Veramente a così alto sospetto
44  non ti fermar, se quella nol ti dice
45 che lume fia tra 'l vero e lo 'ntelletto.

46  I know not if thou understand; I speak
47  Of Beatrice; her shalt thou see above,
48  Smiling and happy, on this mountain's top."

46  Non so se 'ntendi: io dico di Beatrice;
47   tu la vedrai di sopra, in su la vetta
48  di questo monte, ridere e felice.”

49  And I: "Good Leader, let us make more haste,
50  For I no longer tire me as before;
51  And see, e'en now the hill a shadow casts."

49  E io: “Segnore, andiamo a maggior fretta,
50  ché già non m'affatico come dianzi,
51 e vedi omai che 'l poggio l'ombra getta.”

52  "We will go forward with this day" he answered,
53  "As far as now is possible for us;
54  But otherwise the fact is than thou thinkest.

52  “Noi anderem con questo giorno innanzi,”
53  rispuose, “quanto più potremo omai;
54  ma 'l fatto è d'altra forma che non stanzi.

55  Ere thou art up there, thou shalt see return
56  Him, who now hides himself behind the hill,
57  So that thou dost not interrupt his rays.

55  Prima che sie là sù, tornar vedrai
56  colui che già si cuopre de la costa,
57  sì che ' suoi raggi tu romper non fai.

58  But yonder there behold! a soul that stationed
59  All, all alone is looking hitherward;
60  It will point out to us the quickest way."

58  Ma vedi là un'anima che, posta
59  sola soletta, inverso noi riguarda:
60  quella ne 'nsegnerà la via più tosta.”

61  We came up unto it; O Lombard soul,
62  How lofty and disdainful thou didst bear thee,
63  And grand and slow in moving of thine eyes!

61  Venimmo a lei: o anima lombarda,
62  come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa
63 e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda!

64  Nothing whatever did it say to us,
65  But let us go our way, eying us only
66  After the manner of a couchant lion;

64  Ella non ci dicëa alcuna cosa,
65 ma lasciavane gir, solo sguardando
66 a guisa di leon quando si posa.

67  Still near to it Virgilius drew, entreating
68  That it would point us out the best ascent;
69  And it replied not unto his demand,

67  Pur Virgilio si trasse a lei, pregando
68  che ne mostrasse la miglior salita;
69  e quella non rispuose al suo dimando,

70  But of our native land and of our life
71  It questioned us; and the sweet Guide began:
72  "Mantua,"—and the shade, all in itself recluse,

70  ma di nostro paese e de la vita
71  ci 'nchiese; e 'l dolce duca incominciava
72  “Mantüa ...,” e l'ombra, tutta in sé romita,

73  Rose tow'rds him from the place where first it was,
74  Saying: "O Mantuan, I am Sordello
75  Of thine own land!" and one embraced the other.

73  surse ver' lui del loco ove pria stava,
74  dicendo: “O Mantoano, io son Sordello
75  de la tua terra!”; e l'un l'altro abbracciava.

76  Ah! servile Italy, grief's hostelry!
77  A ship without a pilot in great tempest!
78  No Lady thou of Provinces, but brothel!

76  Ahi serva Italia, di dolore ostello,
77  nave sanza nocchiere in gran tempesta,
78  non donna di province, ma bordello!

79  That noble soul was so impatient, only
80  At the sweet sound of his own native land,
81  To make its citizen glad welcome there;

79  Quell' anima gentil fu così presta,
80  sol per lo dolce suon de la sua terra,
81  di fare al cittadin suo quivi festa;

82  And now within thee are not without war
83  Thy living ones, and one doth gnaw the other
84  Of those whom one wall and one fosse shut in!

82  e ora in te non stanno sanza guerra
83  li vivi tuoi, e l'un l'altro si rode
84  di quei ch'un muro e una fossa serra.

85  Search, wretched one, all round about the shores
86  Thy seaboard, and then look within thy bosom,
87  If any part of thee enjoyeth peace!

85  Cerca, misera, intorno da le prode
86  le tue marine, e poi ti guarda in seno,
87  s'alcuna parte in te di pace gode.

88  What boots it, that for thee Justinian
89  The bridle mend, if empty be the saddle?
90  Withouten this the shame would be the less.

88  Che val perché ti racconciasse il freno
89  Iustinïano, se la sella è vòta?
90  Sanz' esso fora la vergogna meno.

91  Ah! people, thou that oughtest to be devout,
92  And to let Caesar sit upon the saddle,
93  If well thou hearest what God teacheth thee,

91  Ahi gente che dovresti esser devota,
92  e lasciar seder Cesare in la sella,
93 se bene intendi ciò che Dio ti nota,

94  Behold how fell this wild beast has become,
95  Being no longer by the spur corrected,
96  Since thou hast laid thy hand upon the bridle.

94  guarda come esta fiera è fatta fella
95  per non esser corretta da li sproni,
96  poi che ponesti mano a la predella.
 
97  O German Albert! who abandonest
98  Her that has grown recalcitrant and savage,
99  And oughtest to bestride her saddle-bow,

97  O Alberto tedesco ch'abbandoni
98   costei ch'è fatta indomita e selvaggia,
99   e dovresti inforcar li suoi arcioni,

100  May a just judgment from the stars down fall
101  Upon thy blood, and be it new and open,
102  That thy successor may have fear thereof;

100  giusto giudicio da le stelle caggia
101  sovra 'l tuo sangue, e sia novo e aperto,
102  tal che 'l tuo successor temenza n'aggia!

103  Because thy father and thyself have suffered,
104  By greed of those transalpine lands distrained,
105  The garden of the empire to be waste.

103  Ch'avete tu e 'l tuo padre sofferto,
104  per cupidigia di costà distretti,
105  che 'l giardin de lo 'mperio sia diserto.

106  Come and behold Montecchi and Cappelletti,
107  Monaldi and Fillippeschi, careless man!
108  Those sad already, and these doubt-depressed!

106  Vieni a veder Montecchi e Cappelletti,
107  Monaldi e Filippeschi, uom sanza cura:
108  color già tristi, e questi con sospetti!

109  Come, cruel one! come and behold the oppression
110  Of thy nobility, and cure their wounds,
111  And thou shalt see how safe is Santafiore!

109  Vien, crudel, vieni, e vedi la pressura
110  d'i tuoi gentili, e cura lor magagne;
111  e vedrai Santafior com' è oscura!
