112  Come and behold thy Rome, that is lamenting,
113  Widowed, alone, and day and night exclaims,
114  "My Caesar, why hast thou forsaken me?"

112  Vieni a veder la tua Roma che piagne
113  vedova e sola, e dì e notte chiama:
114  “Cesare mio, perché non m'accompagne?”

115  Come and behold how loving are the people;
116  And if for us no pity moveth thee,
117  Come and be made ashamed of thy renown!

115  Vieni a veder la gente quanto s'ama!
116  e se nulla di noi pietà ti move,
117  a vergognar ti vien de la tua fama.

118  And if it lawful be, O Jove Supreme!
119  Who upon earth for us wast crucified,
120  Are thy just eyes averted otherwhere?

118  E se licito m'è, o sommo Giove
119  che fosti in terra per noi crucifisso,
120  son li giusti occhi tuoi rivolti altrove?

121  Or preparation is 't, that, in the abyss
122  Of thine own counsel, for some good thou makest
123  From our perception utterly cut off?

121  O è preparazion che ne l'abisso
122  del tuo consiglio fai per alcun bene
123  in tutto de l'accorger nostro scisso?

124  For all the towns of Italy are full
125  Of tyrants, and becometh a Marcellus
126  Each peasant churl who plays the partisan!

124  Ché le città d'Italia tutte piene
125  son di tiranni, e un Marcel diventa
126  ogne villan che parteggiando viene.

127  My Florence! well mayst thou contented be
128  With this digression, which concerns thee not,
129  Thanks to thy people who such forethought take!

127  Fiorenza mia, ben puoi esser contenta
128  di questa digression che non ti tocca,
129  mercé del popol tuo che si argomenta.

130  Many at heart have justice, but shoot slowly,
131  That unadvised they come not to the bow,
132  But on their very lips thy people have it!

130  Molti han giustizia in cuore, e tardi scocca
131  per non venir sanza consiglio a l'arco;
132  ma il popol tuo l'ha in sommo de la bocca.

133  Many refuse to bear the common burden;
134  But thy solicitous people answereth
135 Without being asked, and crieth: "I submit."

133  Molti rifiutan lo comune incarco;
134  ma il popol tuo solicito risponde
135  sanza chiamare, e grida: “I' mi sobbarco!”

136  Now be thou joyful, for thou hast good reason;
137  Thou affluent, thou in peace, thou full of wisdom!
138  If I speak true, the event conceals it not.

136  Or ti fa lieta, ché tu hai ben onde:
137  tu ricca, tu con pace e tu con senno!
138  S'io dico 'l ver, l'effetto nol nasconde.

139  Athens and Lacedaemon, they who made
140  The ancient laws, and were so civilized,
141  Made towards living well a little sign

139  Atene e Lacedemona, che fenno
140  l'antiche leggi e furon sì civili,
141  fecero al viver bene un picciol cenno

142  Compared with thee, who makest such fine-spun
143  Provisions, that to middle of November
144  Reaches not what thou in October spinnest.

142  verso di te, che fai tanto sottili
144  provedimenti, ch'a mezzo novembre
144  non giugne quel che tu d'ottobre fili.

145  How oft, within the time of thy remembrance,
146  Laws, money, offices, and usages
147  Hast thou remodelled, and renewed thy members?

145  Quante volte, del tempo che rimembre,
146  legge, moneta, officio e costume
147  hai tu mutato, e rinovate membre!

148  And if thou mind thee well, and see the light,
149  Thou shalt behold thyself like a sick woman,
150  Who cannot find repose upon her down,

148  E se ben ti ricordi e vedi lume,
149  vedrai te somigliante a quella inferma
150  che non può trovar posa in su le piume,

151 But by her tossing wardeth off her pain.

151 ma con dar volta suo dolore scherma.

Canto VII
The essential issue in this canto seems to be Sordello's question — after his acceptance and embrace 3 and 4 times (7, if we're keeping track numerologically) — seems to be Voi, chi siete? — who are you?  Like Native Americans, we see from the text that before one has a name, one has a place, a people, a history, a language, and a destiny.  Again, throughout this canto we are presented with what I've been calling the extended self, from which one's destiny as a named or individualized separate self has emerged.  Sordello, although assuming Virgil has come from Hell, embraces him as an inferior embraces a person of higher rank and merit.1  Amazing.  Although Sordello is in Purgatory, and bound inevitably towards blessedness, and Virgil is mired in Hell, still Virgil's rank as a poet exalts him above the saved.  This gives us some idea of what importance Dante, the poet, assigns to poetry.  And yet, even the greatest poet cannot through his accomplishments as an artist be saved.  Curious, and instructive.  What follows this greeting is Virgil's apology, as he defines his own merits and deficiencies, the most interesting of which is his comparison of his own fate to that of an unbaptized infant, that is to say, to one innocent of individual sin, but condemned only by the original sin of mortality itself.  Does this mean that mortality itself is a kind of trauma to the undifferentiated bliss of the eternal?  A mighty question, not to be answered at the level of consciousness delimited by this level of Purgatory.  But, if we go back to the previous canto and the game of chance, it is chance that has placed Virgil among the damned, the accident of his birth, which brings us to another puzzle.  Is chance (grace or Fortune, if you prefer) also a part of this extended identity, another part like those listed above, which lie in some kind of limbo where the will, motivation, or the volitional have only a limited power in mortal life, being aspects of the Self that can be influenced perhaps, but not determined by one's personal actions, and must be given over to fate, for pagans, but to Divine will for the faithful.  Although it is outside the purview of the Commedia, it being a Christian poem, perhaps a Hindu would explain the attributes of these extended levels of the Self to karma, the results of actions in previous incarnations, which places one at the level not according to divine will or blind fate, but according to one's own state of consciousness in performing those actions.  This is not a question for literary scholars, but for the reader who sees the poem as a kind of map to follow to reach her or his own state of transcendence, certainly pertinent.

After these introductions, we then have a reversal of the hierarchy between Sordello, the subservient, and Virgil, the master.  Now Sordello becomes the master, the guide, and Virgil the chela.  It is as if Dante, the poet, (Dante the aspirant is completely absent from this canto for the first time in the poem, a silent witness, just as the reader has been all along.) cannot let a soul in anticipation of certain salvation remain in a subservient position to a pagan, 'though the pagan in question is his own guide.  There is a question of authority here, and what relationship authority has to those they ostensibly serve or who serve them.  What gives one authority, and what is the right attitude of those subject to authority towards those who possess it?  All through the poem, Dante, the poet, presents this relationship as being colored by a kind of medieval sense of courtesy, or what Chaucer, not much later, would often refer to as gentillesse, genteelness, a kind of refined sense of fidelity from both sides, which always is present even when the authority is mistaken or even pernicious and punishing.  Dante apparently sees this as a crucial part of the process of learning itself, a respect, not only of knowledge, but of the purveyor of knowledge, a very far cry from our current situation where information can be entirely divorce from any human attitude towards its font.  If knowledge, and especially if wisdom, is a kind of connective tissue which unites parts to the whole, then the quality of that transference must itself be an indespensible attribute of the process.  How could we possibly achieve any transcendence from our limited condition of ignorance if that connecting source is contrary or even absent? 

As we have seen throughout the Commedia, a great deal is made of positions in space, what’s above, what’s below, what’s left, what’s right, and just as we have read in the lines previous, there is a reversal of hierarchies again as three poets, powerless to control princes in mortal life, here, in the anteroom of Purgatory, are above them, in a metepysical sense, ascendant.  The poet's role as chroniclers is now the determining factor in the fate of any potentate's postmortem destiny.  There are 9 princes here viewed by 3 poets, which is no doubt of numerological significance, as the work is rife with Dante’s mania for numbers.  These nine sing the Salve Regina, another anima reference, and they have all died violently, sometimes at one another’s hands.  They could be said to represent a reconciliation of warring selves, either at the macro level of the state or the micro level of the individual.  They are huddled in the hollow of a landscape composed of what we might call astral or psychedelic colors and scents, a foretaste of what is to come in later cantos.  Night is falling, and in a curious and convoluted explanation, Sordello explains how darkness saps all motivation to move.  Could we interpret this to mean that at a certain stage of spiritual development one realizes the futility of action undertaken without the light of Divine inspiration? — a small but crucial bit of wisdom, which can only be perceived when becomes aware of and surrenders to the influence of a higher self. 
      
1  There is some doubt among commentators as to where exactly Sordello embraces Virgil.  My guess would be around the knees, since a little later Sardello is stooped low enough to draw a figure on the ground with his finger.
  
1  After the gracious and glad salutations
2  Had three and four times been reiterated,
3  Sordello backward drew and said, "Who are you?"

1  Poscia che l'accoglienze oneste e liete
2  furo iterate tre e quattro volte,
3  Sordel si trasse, e disse: “Voi, chi siete?”

4  "Or ever to this mountain were directed
5  The souls deserving to ascend to God,
6  My bones were buried by Octavian.

4  “Anzi che a questo monte fosser volte
5  l'anime degne di salire a Dio,
6  fur l'ossa mie per Ottavian sepolte.
7  I am Virgilius; and for no crime else
8  Did I lose heaven, than for not having faith;"
9  In this wise then my Leader made reply.
7  Io son Virgilio; e per null' altro rio
8  lo ciel perdei che per non aver fé.”
9  Così rispuose allora il duca mio.
10  As one who suddenly before him sees
11  Something whereat he marvels, who believes
12  And yet does not, saying, "It is! it is not!"
10  Qual è colui che cosa innanzi sé
11  sùbita vede ond' e' si maraviglia,
12  che crede e non, dicendo “Ella è... non è..,”
13  So he appeared; and then bowed down his brow,
14  And with humility returned towards him,
15  And, where inferiors embrace, embraced him.
13  tal parve quelli; e poi chinò le ciglia,
14  e umilmente ritornò ver' lui,
15  e abbracciòl là 've 'l minor s'appiglia.
16  "O glory of the Latians, thou," he said,
17  "Through whom our language showed what it could do
18  O pride eternal of the place I came from,
16  “O gloria di Latin,” disse, “per cui
17  mostrò ciò che potea la lingua nostra,
18  o pregio etterno del loco ond' io fui,
19  What merit or what grace to me reveals thee?
20  If I to hear thy words be worthy, tell me
21  If thou dost come from Hell, and from what cloister.
19  qual merito o qual grazia mi ti mostra?
20  S'io son d'udir le tue parole degno,
21  dimmi se vien d'inferno, e di qual chiostra.”
22  "Through all the circles of the doleful realm,"
23   Responded he, "have I come hitherward;
24   Heaven's power impelled me, and with that I come.
22  “Per tutt' i cerchi del dolente regno,”
23  rispuose lui, “son io di qua venuto;
24  virtù del ciel mi mosse, e con lei vegno.
25  I by not doing, not by doing, lost
26  The sight of that high sun which thou desirest,
27  And which too late by me was recognized.
25  Non per far, ma per non fare ho perduto
26  a veder l'alto Sol che tu disiri
27  e che fu tardi per me conosciuto.
28  A place there is below not sad with torments,
29  But darkness only, where the lamentations
30  Have not the sound of wailing, but are sighs.
28  Luogo è là giù non tristo di martìri,
29  ma di tenebre solo, ove i lamenti
30  non suonan come guai, ma son sospiri.
31  There dwell I with the little innocents
32  Snatched by the teeth of Death, or ever they
33  Were from our human sinfulness exempt.
31  Quivi sto io coi pargoli innocenti
32  dai denti morsi de la morte avante
33  che fosser da l'umana colpa essenti;
34  There dwell I among those who the three saintly
35  Virtues did not put on, and without vice
36  The others knew and followed all of them.
34  quivi sto io con quei che le tre sante
35  virtù non si vestiro, e sanza vizio
36  conobber l'altre e seguir tutte quante.
37  But if thou know and can, some indication
38  Give us by which we may the sooner come
39  Where Purgatory has its right beginning."
37  Ma se tu sai e puoi, alcuno indizio
38  dà noi per che venir possiam più tosto
39  là dove purgatorio ha dritto inizio.”
40  He answered: "No fixed place has been assigned us;
41  'Tis lawful for me to go up and round;
42  So far as I can go, as guide I join thee.
40  Rispuose: “Loco certo non c'è posto;
41  licito m'è andar suso e intorno;
42  per quanto ir posso, a guida mi t'accosto.
43  But see already how the day declines,
44  And to go up by night we are not able;
45  Therefore 'tis well to think of some fair sojourn.
43  Ma vedi già come dichina il giorno,
44  e andar sù di notte non si puote;
45  però è buon pensar di bel soggiorno.
46  Souls are there on the right hand here withdrawn;
47  If thou permit me I will lead thee to them,
48  And thou shalt know them not without delight."
46  Anime sono a destra qua remote;
47  se mi consenti, io ti merrò ad esse,
48  e non sanza diletto ti fier note.”
49  "How is this?" was the answer; "should one wish
50  To mount by night would he prevented be
51  By others? or mayhap would not have power?"
49  “Com' è ciò?” fu risposto.“Che volesse
50  salir di notte, fora elli impedito
51  d'altrui, o non sarria ché non potesse?”
52And on the ground the good Sordello drew
53  His finger, saying, "See, this line alone
54  Thou couldst not pass after the sun is gone;
52  E 'l buon Sordello in terra fregò 'l dito,
53  dicendo: “Vedi? sola questa riga
54  non varcheresti dopo 'l sol partito:
55  Not that aught else would hindrance give, however,
56  To going up, save the nocturnal darkness;
57  This with the want of power the will perplexes.
55  non però ch'altra cosa desse briga,
56  che la notturna tenebra, ad ir suso;
57  quella col nonpoder la voglia intriga.
58  We might indeed therewith return below,
59  And, wandering, walk the hill-side round about,
60  While the horizon holds the day imprisoned."
58  Ben si poria con lei tornare in giuso
59  e passeggiar la costa intorno errando,
60  mentre che l'orizzonte il dì tien chiuso.”
61  Thereon my Lord, as if in wonder, said:
62  "Do thou conduct us thither, where thou sayest
63  That we can take delight in tarrying."
61  Allora il mio segnor, quasi ammirando,
62  “Menane,” disse, “dunque là 've dici
63  ch'aver si può diletto dimorando.”
64  Little had we withdrawn us from that place,
65  When I perceived the mount was hollowed out
66  In fashion as the valleys here are hollowed.
64  Poco allungati c'eravam di lici,
65  quand' io m'accorsi che 'l monte era scemo,
66  a guisa che i vallon li sceman quici.
67  "Thitherward," said that shade, "will we repair,
68  Where of itself the hill-side makes a lap,
69  And there for the new day will we await."
67  “Colà,” disse quell' ombra, “n'anderemo
68  dove la costa face di sé grembo;
69  e là il novo giorno attenderemo.”
70  'Twixt hill and plain there was a winding path
71  Which led us to the margin of that dell,
72  Where dies the border more than half away.
70  Tra erto e piano era un sentiero schembo,
71  che ne condusse in fianco de la lacca,
72  là dove più ch'a mezzo muore il lembo.
73  Gold and fine silver, and scarlet and pearl-white,
74  The Indian wood resplendent and serene,
75  Fresh emerald the moment it is broken,
73  Oro e argento fine, cocco e biacca,
74  indaco, legno lucido e sereno,
75  fresco smeraldo in l'ora che si fiacca,
76  By herbage and by flowers within that hollow
77  Planted, each one in colour would be vanquished,
78  As by its greater vanquished is the less.
76  da l'erba e da li fior, dentr' a quel seno
77  posti, ciascun saria di color vinto,
78  come dal suo maggiore è vinto il meno.
79  Nor in that place had nature painted only,
80  But of the sweetness of a thousand odours
81  Made there a mingled fragrance and unknown.
79  Non avea pur natura ivi dipinto,
80  ma di soavità di mille odori
81  vi facea uno incognito e indistinto.
82  "Salve Regina," on the green and flowers
83  There seated, singing, spirits I beheld,
84  Which were not visible outside the valley.
82  “Salve, Regina” in sul verde e 'n su' fiori
83  quindi seder cantando anime vidi,
84  che per la valle non parean di fuori.
85  "Before the scanty sun now seeks his nest,"
86  Began the Mantuan who had led us thither,
87  "Among them do not wish me to conduct you.
85  “Prima che 'l poco sole omai s'annidi,”
86  cominciò 'l Mantoan che ci avea vòlti,
87  “tra color non vogliate ch'io vi guidi.
88  Better from off this ledge the acts and faces
89  Of all of them will you discriminate,
90  Than in the plain below received among them.
88  Di questo balzo meglio li atti e ' volti
89  conoscerete voi di tutti quanti,
90  che ne la lama giù tra essi accolti.
91  He who sits highest, and the semblance bears
92  Of having what he should have done neglected,
93  And to the others' song moves not his lips,
91  Colui che più siede alto e fa sembianti
92  d'aver negletto ciò che far dovea,
93  e che non move bocca a li altrui canti,
94  Rudolph the Emperor was, who had the power
95  To heal the wounds that Italy have slain,
96  So that through others slowly she revives.
94  Rodolfo imperador fu, che potea
95  sanar le piaghe c'hanno Italia morta,
96  sì che tardi per altri si ricrea.
97  The other, who in look doth comfort him,
98  Governed the region where the water springs,
99  The Moldau bears the Elbe, and Elbe the sea.
97  L'altro che ne la vista lui conforta,
98  resse la terra dove l'acqua nasce
99  che Molta in Albia, e Albia in mar ne porta:
100  His name was Ottocar; and in swaddling-clothes
102  Far better he than bearded Winceslaus
103  His son, who feeds in luxury and ease.
100  Ottacchero ebbe nome, e ne le fasce
101  fu meglio assai che Vincislao suo figlio
102  barbuto, cui lussuria e ozio pasce.
105  And the small-nosed, who close in council seems
106  With him that has an aspect so benign,
107  Died fleeing and disflowering the lily;
103  E quel nasetto che stretto a consiglio
104  par con colui c'ha sì benigno aspetto,
105  morì fuggendo e disfiorando il giglio:
106  Look there, how he is beating at his breast!
107  Behold the other one, who for his cheek
108  Sighing has made of his own palm a bed;
106  guardate là come si batte il petto!
107  L'altro vedete c'ha fatto a la guancia
108  de la sua palma, sospirando, letto.
109  Father and father-in-law of France's Pest
110  Are they, and know his vicious life and lewd,
111  And hence proceeds the grief that so doth pierce them.
109  Padre e suocero son del mal di Francia:
110  sanno la vita sua viziata e lorda,
111  e quindi viene il duol che sì li lancia.
112  He who appears so stalwart, and chimes in,
113  Singing, with that one of the manly nose,
114  The cord of every valour wore begirt;
112  Quel che par sì membruto e che s'accorda,
113  cantando, con colui dal maschio naso,
114  d'ogne valor portò cinta la corda;
115  And if as King had after him remained
116  The stripling who in rear of him is sitting,
117  Well had the valour passed from vase to vase,
115  e se re dopo lui fosse rimaso
116  lo giovanetto che retro a lui siede,
117  ben andava il valor di vaso in vaso,
118  Which cannot of the other heirs be said.
119  Frederick and Jacomo possess the realms,
120  But none the better heritage possesses.
118  che non si puote dir de l'altre rede;
119  Iacomo e Federigo hanno i reami;
120  del retaggio miglior nessun possiede.
121  Not oftentimes upriseth through the branches
122  The probity of man; and this He wills
123  Who gives it, so that we may ask of Him.
121  Rade volte risurge per li rami
122  l'umana probitate; e questo vole
123  quei che la dà, perché da lui si chiami.
124  Eke to the large-nosed reach my words, no less
125  Than to the other, Pier, who with him sings;
126  Whence Provence and Apulia grieve already
124  Anche al nasuto vanno mie parole
125  non men ch'a l'altro, Pier, che con lui canta,
130  onde Puglia e Proenza già si dole.
127  The plant is as inferior to its seed,
128  As more than Beatrice and Margaret
129  Costanza boasteth of her husband still.
127  Tant' è del seme suo minor la pianta,
128  quanto, più che Beatrice e Margherita,
129  Costanza di marito ancor si vanta.
130  Behold the monarch of the simple life,
131  Harry of England, sitting there alone;
132  He in his branches has a better issue.
130  Vedete il re de la semplice vita
131  seder là solo, Arrigo d'Inghilterra:
132  questi ha ne' rami suoi migliore uscita.
133  He who the lowest on the ground among them
134  Sits looking upward, is the Marquis William,
135  For whose sake Alessandria and her war
133  Quel che più basso tra costor s'atterra,
134  guardando in suso, è Guiglielmo marchese,
135  per cui e Alessandria e la sua guerra
136  Make Monferrat and Canavese weep."
136  fa pianger Monferrato e Canavese.”
Canto VIII
In this canto, we are going down, literally, down into the hollow where this group of penitents are huddled, going down into darkness, going down into chilling fear again with the reappearance of the serpent, going down into the farewells of sea and land voyages, going down towards sleep, going down from motion to stillness, going down to elemental forms, the green world of the protecting angels and the self-involved world of that most primitive of forms — recalling such things as DNA, blood vessels, cilia, maggots, the strands that make and unmake us, i.e., the cold worm which licks itself, sheds its skin, becomes new, but also is forever bringing back to our most primitive or physical origins, the enemy of the Blake's rose, the invisible worm which flies through the night, and cankers beauty and love.

The opening verses are full of nostalgia, the nostalgia ultimately of those who are departing not just physical life, for these first cantos of the Purgatorio are still very much about death, the circumstances of death, and the tussle of giving up the body and submitting oneself to the unknown, but when we come to verses 7 - 18 that nostalgia is quelled by an ecstasy that cannot be divided, as nostalgia always is because one feels the pull of the past dragging one back from the present, and blocking out all thought of the future.  A strange, unnamed figure arises, which might be identified as Dante's own soul, calling him back from his own nostalgia to his supreme purpose in embarking on this journey.  If we recall how many times throughout the Inferno that the aspirant, Dante, groped forward, unable to see, but having his ears assaulted, his hearing serving as his chief learning sense, here we have in him a temporary deafness, as he watches the figure signal him, and then assume the attitude of prayer.  Here is one whose entire thought is on God alone.  And when this figure begins to sing, Dante is drawn out of himself and into ecstasy.  The other figures, whom the three poets have descended to join, follow suit, all turning towards the east, the place of new beginnings, and singing the Tu lucis ante, joining the mysterious one, in unison devoutly singing this Compline prayer.  What do we do when we are tortured by grief, or fear, or sickness, or hopelessness?  What do we do when we feel exiled from whatever we had come to take for granted, to feel that we have loved, and in the case for the souls we meet throughout the Commedia, when we are losing the very thing that we had come to believe was ourselves, our physical life, our bodies ... we seek refuge, we seek comfort, we seek sleep, and forgetfulness ... the very opposite of the things that we have so vehemently sought to maintain, develop, and call our own ... but what is there that we can call our own?   Nothing.  Nothing at all.  There is nothing that we can possess or control, and at some point we are left with only with a longing, a longing for home.  Yet that home cannot be the home of our bodies, our families, our countries, our beliefs, our art, or even our spiritual practices.  The souls in this valley, violent men, important men, just men who have met unjust fates, have all discovered this colossal truth, the truth that Dante, the poet, turns aside to remind us of in lines 19 - 21, when he tells us that it is at these very times in which the veil which separates us from all that we have loved or hated, feared or desired, is most thin, most thin at those very times when we are huddled down in a night when the serpent-self is abroad, that is to say, our cynicism, our selfishness, our grandest delusions, and our most harrowing nightmares.  It is at this moment — which we would have given anything to avoid — it is at this the very moment when our deliverance is nearest.  Here the guardian angels rise, armed with swords, but not swords of violence, for the tips are broken.  No, these are swords of assurance.  They take up their posts, their bodies streaming with all that is green and budding, spring and promise, rising right out of the deepest dark, and, coming from Mary's womb (grembo, not "bosom" as has been often translated.)   And isn't it easy to imagine the singers crouched down in a fetal position as innocent as fetuses, when they are taken back in their ecstasy to  the sea, the mother, the female whose endless embrace is mercy, the mother/lover whom all of these souls address, confident that it is their very need that draws her grace to them.  And they sing to her, of her, calling her messengers forth, finally faithful, as they perhaps never were when they were full of the life of themselves, and absorbed in devotion.  Then when the serpent appears, they have no attention left to squander on all of the ruin that he represents, for they are far gone from his power over them, and however exalted they might have been in their positions during life, here they are even more exalted by their humility.  All this gets so quietly and beautifully expressed in the poetry, and if we recite it, listen closely to our voices caressing these sounds 

37  “Ambo vegnon del grembo di Maria,”
38  disse Sordello, “a guardia de la valle,
39  per lo serpente che verrà vie via.”
we might begin to feel just how thin that veil has become between ourselves and Dante, and we might see that this grand figure of a poet is never grander then at these moments when he shows himself as frightened and as awed as a child ... and in this very moment, just as Sordello and Judge Nino do, we are astonished that such a body, such a person could have ever been alive, real, historic, and subject to the very blows of Nature that we are.  And what is more astonishing yet is that our attention is drawn up to the three torches in heaven, that supernal wheel of brilliant stars, which pierce the darkness and promise even more than we have already received.  But note, too, that it is at this point, when looking up at the stars, the serpent intrudes.
The domestic drama of Judge Nino is then played out as a kind of starlit vestige of what was dearest to him (and us), but from which all memory is already fading.  Nino's wife has already forgotten him, gone on to another, and he begs that when Dante returns to the land of the living, that his 9 year-old daughter, Giovanna should be reminded to pray for him.  The last shade encountered is that of Currendo, whose family the aspirant praises as an examplar of how the powerful should behave themselves, and notably his praise embarasses its object.
 Ah, there is so much numerology included in this canto.  The three poets, the nine shades, the nine year old Giovanna (recalling the age of Beatrice when Dante first saw her), the four stars becoming three, the seven days in Aries, so that we feel that there remains an underlying significance to these proportions, something skeletal and basic, a potential that might manifest the richest creations, the most roiling emotions, and yet remain ever bright, and eerily free of all the troubles that beset us in our journey towards transcendence.  Truly, just as the first lines of the canto foretell, this is the hour which turns back desire, and raises our exiled poverty to gaze upon the stars.  
1  'Twas now the hour that turneth back desire
2  In those who sail the sea, and melts the heart,
3  The day they've said to their sweet friends farewell,
1  Era già l'ora che volge il disio
2  ai navicanti e 'ntenerisce il core
3  lo dì c'han detto ai dolci amici addio; 
4  And the new pilgrim penetrates with love,
5  If he doth hear from far away a bell
6  That seemeth to deplore the dying day,
4  e che lo novo peregrin d'amore
5  punge, se ode squilla di lontano
6 che paia il giorno pianger che si more;
7  When I began to make of no avail
8  My hearing, and to watch one of the souls
9  Uprisen, that begged attention with its hand.
7  quand' io incominciai a render vano
8  l'udire e a mirare una de l'alme
9  surta, che l'ascoltar chiedea con mano.
10  It joined and lifted upward both its palms,
11  Fixing its eyes upon the orient,
12  As if it said to God, "Naught else I care for."
10  Ella giunse e levò ambo le palme,
11  ficcando li occhi verso l'orïente,
12  come dicesse a Dio: “D'altro non calme.”
13  "Te lucis ante" so devoutly issued
14  Forth from its mouth, and with such dulcet notes,
15  It made me issue forth from my own mind.
13  “Te lucis ante” sì devotamente
14  le uscìo di bocca e con sì dolci note,
15  che fece me a me uscir di mente;
16  And then the others, sweetly and devoutly,
17  Accompanied it through all the hymn entire,
18  Having their eyes on the supernal wheels.
16  e l'altre poi dolcemente e devote
17  seguitar lei per tutto l'inno intero,
18  avendo li occhi a le superne rote.
19  Here, Reader, fix thine eyes well on the truth,
20  For now indeed so subtile is the veil,
21  Surely to penetrate within is easy.
19  Aguzza qui, lettor, ben li occhi al vero,
20  ché 'l velo è ora ben tanto sottile,
21  certo che 'l trapassar dentro è leggero.
22  I saw that army of the gentle-born
23  Thereafterward in silence upward gaze,
24  As if in expectation, pale and humble;
22  Io vidi quello essercito gentile
23  tacito poscia riguardare in sùe,
24  quasi aspettando, palido e umìle;
25  And from on high come forth and down descend,
26  I saw two Angels with two flaming swords,
27  Truncated and deprived of their points.
25  e vidi uscir de l'alto e scender giùe
26  due angeli con due spade affocate,
27  tronche e private de le punte sue.
28  Green as the little leaflets just now born
29  Their garments were, which, by their verdant pinions
30  Beaten and blown abroad, they trailed behind.
28  Verdi come fogliette pur mo nate
29  erano in veste, che da verdi penne
30  percosse traean dietro e ventilate.
31  One just above us came to take his station,
32  And one descended to the opposite bank,
33  So that the people were contained between them.
31  L'un poco sovra noi a star si venne,
32  e l'altro scese in l'opposita sponda,
33  sì che la gente in mezzo si contenne.
34  Clearly in them discerned I the blond head;
35  But in their faces was the eye bewildered,
36  As faculty confounded by excess.
34  Ben discernëa in lor la testa bionda;
35  ma ne la faccia l'occhio si smarria,
36  come virtù ch'a troppo si confonda
37  "From Mary's bosom both of them have come,"
38  Sordello said, "as guardians of the valley
39  Against the serpent, that will come anon."
37  “Ambo vegnon del grembo di Maria,”
38  disse Sordello, “a guardia de la valle,
39  per lo serpente che verrà vie via.”
40  Whereupon I, who knew not by what road,
41  Turned round about, and closely drew myself,
42  Utterly frozen, to the faithful shoulders.
40  Ond' io, che non sapeva per qual calle,
41  mi volsi intorno, e stretto m'accostai,
42  tutto gelato, a le fidate spalle.
43  And once again Sordello: "Now descend we
44  'Mid the grand shades, and we will speak to them;
45  Right pleasant will it be for them to see you."
43  E Sordello anco: “Or avvalliamo omai
44  tra le grandi ombre, e parleremo ad esse;
45  grazïoso fia lor vedervi assai.”
46  Only three steps I think that I descended,
47  And was below, and saw one who was looking
48  Only at me, as if he fain would know me.
46  Solo tre passi credo ch'i' scendesse,
47  e fui di sotto, e vidi un che mirava
48  pur me, come conoscer mi volesse.
49  Already now the air was growing dark,
50  But not so that between his eyes and mine
51  It did not show what it before locked up.
49  Temp' era già che l'aere s'annerava,
50  ma non sì che tra li occhi suoi e ' miei
51  non dichiarisse ciò che pria serrava.
52  Tow'rds me he moved, and I tow'rds him did move;
53  Noble Judge Nino! how it me delighted,
54  When I beheld thee not among the damned!
52  Ver' me si fece, e io ver' lui mi fei:
53  giudice Nin gentil, quanto mi piacque
54  quando ti vidi non esser tra ' rei!
55  No greeting fair was left unsaid between us;
56  Then asked he: "How long is it since thou camest
57  O'er the far waters to the mountain's foot?"
55  Nullo bel salutar tra noi si tacque;
56  poi dimandò: “Quant' è che tu venisti
57  a piè del monte per le lontane acque?”
58  "Oh!" said I to him, "through the dismal places
59  I came this morn; and am in the first life,
60  Albeit the other, going thus, I gain."
58  “Oh!” diss' io lui, “per entro i luoghi tristi
59  venni stamane, e sono in prima vita,
60  ancor che l'altra, sì andando, acquisti.”
61  And on the instant my reply was heard,
62  He and Sordello both shrank back from me,
63  Like people who are suddenly bewildered.
61  E come fu la mia risposta udita,
62  Sordello ed elli in dietro si raccolse
63  come gente di sùbito smarrita. 
64  One to Virgilius, and the other turned
65  To one who sat there, crying, "Up, Currado!
66  Come and behold what God in grace has willed!"
64  L'uno a Virgilio e l'altro a un si volse
65  che sedea lì, gridando: “Sù, Currado!
66  vieni a veder che Dio per grazia volse.”
67  Then, turned to me: "By that especial grace
68  Thou owest unto Him, who so conceals
69  His own first wherefore, that it has no ford,
67  Poi, vòlto a me: “Per quel singular grado
68  che tu dei a colui che sì nasconde
69  lo suo primo perché, che non lì è guado,
70  When thou shalt be beyond the waters wide,
71  Tell my Giovanna that she pray for me,
72  Where answer to the innocent is made.
70  quando sarai di là da le larghe onde,
71  dì a Giovanna mia che per me chiami
72  là dove a li 'nnocenti si risponde.
73  I do not think her mother loves me more,
74  Since she has laid aside her wimple white,
75  Which she, unhappy, needs must wish again.
73  Non credo che la sua madre più m'ami,
74  poscia che trasmutò le bianche bende,
75  le quai convien che, misera!, ancor brami.
76  Through her full easily is comprehended
77  How long in woman lasts the fire of love,
78  If eye or touch do not relight it often.
76  Per lei assai di lieve si comprende
77  quanto in femmina foco d'amor dura,
78  se l'occhio o 'l tatto spesso non l'accende.
79  So fair a hatchment will not make for her
80  The Viper marshalling the Milanese
81  A-field, as would have made Gallura's Cock."
79  Non le farà sì bella sepultura
80  la vipera che Melanesi accampa,
81  com' avria fatto il gallo di Gallura.”
82  In this wise spake he, with the stamp impressed
83  Upon his aspect of that righteous zeal
84  Which measurably burneth in the heart.
82  Così dicea, segnato de la stampa,
83  nel suo aspetto, di quel dritto zelo
84 che misuratamente in core avvampa.
85  My greedy eyes still wandered up to heaven,
86  Still to that point where slowest are the stars,
87  Even as a wheel the nearest to its axle.
85  Li occhi miei ghiotti andavan pur al cielo,
86  pur là dove le stelle son più tarde,
87  sì come rota più presso a lo stelo.
88  And my Conductor: "Son, what dost thou gaze at
89  Up there?" And I to him: "At those three torches
90  With which this hither pole is all on fire."
88  E 'l duca mio: “Figliuol, che là sù guarde?”
89  E io a lui: “A quelle tre facelle
90  di che 'l polo di qua tutto quanto arde.” 
91  And he to me: "The four resplendent stars
92  Thou sawest this morning are down yonder low,
93  And these have mounted up to where those were."
91  ond' elli a me: “Le quattro chiare stelle
92  che vedevi staman, son di là basse,
93  e queste son salite ov' eran quelle.”
94  As he was speaking, to himself Sordello
95  Drew him, and said, "Lo there our Adversary!"
96  And pointed with his finger to look thither.
94  Com' ei parlava, e Sordello a sé il trasse
95  dicendo: “Vedi là 'l nostro avversaro”;
96  e drizzò il dito perché 'n là guardasse.
97  Upon the side on which the little valley
98  No barrier hath, a serpent was; perchance
99  The same which gave to Eve the bitter food.
97  Da quella parte onde non ha riparo
98  la picciola vallea, era una biscia,
99  forse qual diede ad Eva il cibo amaro.
100  'Twixt grass and flowers came on the evil streak,
101  Turning at times its head about, and licking
102  Its back like to a beast that smoothes itself.
100  Tra l'erba e ' fior venìa la mala striscia,
101  volgendo ad ora ad or la testa, e 'l dosso
102  leccando come bestia che si liscia.
103  I did not see, and therefore cannot say
104  How the celestial falcons 'gan to move,
105  But well I saw that they were both in motion.
103  Io non vidi, e però dicer non posso,
104  come mosser li astor celestïali;
105  ma vidi bene e l'uno e l'altro mosso.
106  Hearing the air cleft by their verdant wings,
107  The serpent fled, and round the Angels wheeled,
108  Up to their stations flying back alike.
106  Sentendo fender l'aere a le verdi ali,
107  fuggì 'l serpente, e li angeli dier volta,
108  suso a le poste rivolando iguali.
109  The shade that to the Judge had near approached
110  When he had called, throughout that whole assault
111  Had not a moment loosed its gaze on me.
109  L'ombra che s'era al giudice raccolta
110  quando chiamò, per tutto quello assalto
111  punto non fu da me guardare sciolta.
112  "So may the light that leadeth thee on high
113  Find in thine own free-will as much of wax
114  As needful is up to the highest azure,"
112  “Se la lucerna che ti mena in alto
113  truovi nel tuo arbitrio tanta cera
114  quant' è mestiere infino al sommo smalto,”
115  Began it, "if some true intelligence
116  Of Valdimagra or its neighbourhood
117  Thou knowest, tell it me, who once was great there.
115  cominciò ella, “se novella vera
116  di Val di Magra o di parte vicina
117  sai, dillo a me, che già grande là era.
118  Currado Malaspina was I called;
119  I'm not the elder, but from him descended;
120  To mine I bore the love which here refineth."
118  Fui chiamato Currado Malaspina;
119  non son l'antico, ma di lui discesi;
120  a' miei portai l'amor che qui raffina.”
121  "O," said I unto him, "through your domains
122   I never passed, but where is there a dwelling
123  Throughout all Europe, where they are not known?
121  “Oh!” diss' io lui, “per li vostri paesi
122  già mai non fui; ma dove si dimora
123  per tutta Europa ch'ei non sien palesi?
124  That fame, which doeth honour to your house,
125  Proclaims its Signors and proclaims its land,
126  So that he knows of them who ne'er was there.
124  La fama che la vostra casa onora,
125  grida i segnori e grida la contrada,
126  sì che ne sa chi non vi fu ancora;
127  And, as I hope for heaven, I swear to you
128  Your honoured family in naught abates
129  The glory of the purse and of the sword.
127  e io vi giuro, s'io di sopra vada,
128  che vostra gente onrata non si sfregia
129  del pregio de la borsa e de la spada.
130  It is so privileged by use and nature,
131  That though a guilty head misguide the world,
132  Sole it goes right, and scorns the evil way."
130  Uso e natura sì la privilegia,
131  che, perché il capo reo il mondo torca,
132  sola va dritta e 'l mal cammin dispregia.”
133  And he: "Now go; for the sun shall not lie
134  Seven times upon the pillow which the Ram
135  With all his four feet covers and bestrides,
133  Ed elli: “Or va; che 'l sol non si ricorca
134  sette volte nel letto che 'l Montone
135  con tutti e quattro i piè cuopre e inforca,
136  Before that such a courteous opinion
137  Shall in the middle of thy head be nailed
138  With greater nails than of another's speech,
136  che cotesta cortese oppinïone
137  ti fia chiavata in mezzo de la testa
138  con maggior chiovi che d'altrui sermone,
139  Unless the course of justice standeth still."
139  se corso di giudicio non s'arresta.”
Canto IX
Can ordinary language suggest the level of complexity which the language of mathematics purports to attain?  Is there something about poetry that can elevate consciousness and awaken it to the true depths of the cosmos and of its own nature?  If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then we can attribute those affirmatives to passages such as these we find in Canto IX of Dante's Purgatorio.  Volumes of commentary through centuries of in-depth scholarship still fall short of explaining the sort of mythological-metaphoric condensation that this poetry achieves, and I can hardly hope to do more than suggest how the text manifests such luminance, elegance, seeming simplicity, and eloquence by means of this condensation.  Let's start with the question of Time.  What Time is it?  That seems a simple enough question, but it took almost seven hundred years before any student of the poem could determine the answer based un the text we are given.  It is early evening, just before moonrise, but that hardly answeres the question.  Consider the interweaving of myths used to suggest this.

Tithonus was a mortal who so infatuated the Goddess Aurora that she asked Zues to give him immortality, a boon granted, but since she neglected to also ask that he be graced with immortal youth, he tragically continued to age, ever approaching death, much like the famous paradox of Achilles persuing the tortoise, with each step the warrior cuts the distance between himself and his quarry in half, but not matter how small the gap becomes between them, he never reaches his prey.  So Time grows older, evolves with ever-increasing complexity, taxes itself with birth, maturation, and decay, and yet goes on without end.  The text here suggests that the Goddess (another one of the poems many anima figures) is the concubine of the Tithonus, and since we are speaking here of moonrise, not sunrise, Tithonic Time has two lovers, or else a lover with a duel nature, the dawn of night and the dawn of day, and here we have the former, the eastern horizon, compared to a palatial balcony, as it grows white at nightfall.  (We should remember the Commedia too is diachronic, one Dante inside the poem as the aspirant, and one outside the poem, writing it.)  The eastern horizon whitens.  This whitening we have seen in earlier parts of the Commedia as a killing frost, which is shaken off the dying vegetation when the sun rise spreads its warmth, and there is much here which suggests both warmth and cold, i.e., the chill of old age and the warmth of the embrace of lovers.  The moonrise Aurora has a forehead beset with cold gems in the shape of the constillation Scorpio, a cold-blooded animal, whose deadly sting kills with a chilling cold, its tail smiting the nations (peruote la gente) indicating a tumuluous period in historical times, the which tragedy is amply alluded to throughout the Commedia.  The Goddess has taken two steps already as the moon has yet to appear, but her ground or below-the-horizon speed is about to become air-speed as she undergoes a metamorphoses from one who walks to one who flies, the Time of youth seeming expansive and slow, and yet that of the aged interminably condensing and flying.  Time promises a lover's consumation, the sweet arms, as line three here asserts, of a lover, and yet delivers a heartbreaking abandonment.  Somewhere Rilke talks of lovers immersed in a kind of amniotic sea, and as one emerges, the other is submerged, and old Tithonus here is submerged, just as the Moon Aurora rises, and at this moment Dante the aspirant is overcome with sleep.  Why?  Because like Tithonus the aspirant's daytime consciousness has grown old and fatigued, and the living body whose flesh is ancient Adam's can no longer sustain itself, but falls into a sleep and a dream.  The number five is the number of mortal man, and five is the number of those on this bank/bed that Dante reclines on, because in ordinary waking consciousness we have five senses, and all but one of these senses disappears, only dream vision remaining, as the dreamer becomes a pilgrim separated from his daytime illusion, to achieve an almost (quasi) divinity.  The Divine here relating to the word divination, wherein the dreamer is able to see that Time is not divided into the known past, the passing present, and the unknown future, but is experienced a whole, i.e., it moves from line to plane to sphere.  The swallow cries as if remembering its former woes, the reference to the myth of Procne, Philomela, and Tireus, a story of rape, betrayal, the eating of one's own children, and the metamorphoses of tragic human language to plaintive bird song.  But the dreamer is free of the prison of flesh and its remembrance of former woes, and yet a transformation has occured within him as well, and he too is abducted, abducted by a golden eagle (a solar reference surely, and the animus figure of Zues, the ultimate male saducer and rapist) who catches the dreambody in his talons) like unto Ganymede taken up in rapture to the abode of the Gods.  That the figues of Ganymede and Tithonus are interwoven, there can be no doubt, since both had a mortal beauty which made then victims of an immortal's lust, the one becoming a decrepit old man, the other the cup-bearer slave of the Gods.  Ganymedeic Time is a time of exile, as the youth's rapture tears him away from earthly family and friends, just as the historical mortal Dante was likewise exiled.  The dreamer in the talons of the God, in his rapture, still retains a mortal thought, and that thought is that this celestial Time is mechanical, and only acting out of force of habit.  Now how brilliant is this?  Time being sentient, but not volitional in its unfolding, but rather a victim of it's own nature, it's own past.  The eagle falls like lightning, snatches the dreamer, and flies like Icarus into a sun-like fire.  Here sleep is broken by the heat, and here another complicated myth is birthed, that of Achille's, who is frozen with fear and confusion when he is abducted by his mother (whom he does not recognize) from the half-bestial state of the centuars to a human conflicted and warring state of consciousness, a state of Time, let us call it Achillian-Time, which is almost immortal, but not quite, his heel, still subject to mortality, being the grounding wherein he is most human (the word human, etymologically derived from humus, earth, mouse), and most vulnerable.  The heat of the dream-sun has been instantaneously transformed to freezing fright, and Dante discovers that he has been carried up the mountain and through Purgatorial Time by Saint Lucy, Light herself, the very saint whose chant the princes were performing in the valley before the aspirant Dante succumbed to sleep.  It is Lucy too who is the Saint intrumental in saving Dante when he started on this journey of transformation.  Dante awakes, and is again with Virgil at the gates of Purgatory proper.  He is facing that sea, which metaphorically nearly drowned him in the first canto of the poem, and which he somehow unconsciously crossed to arrive at the Purgatorial mount/island.  This sea now lies below him.  Virgil's explanation awakens the sleeper a second time, so that we see sleep from two sides, the side revealed from the dreamer's point of view, in the heat of the sun, and the side revealed from waking consciousness, at midmorning, the sun already two-hours old (the aging Tithonic sun), with the aspirant having arrived like Achilles into a new place, a new space, yet not knowing that his divine mother had ported him here, just as when, in the moment of birth, the infant arrives in this world, not knowing how his fetus was begotten and developed, or what this new world is which embraces him.  These few comments are but hints barely touching on all the diminsions of Time, consciousness and language that this poetry expresses, a poetry that is so daunting to the ordinary consciousness yet so exilerating to the altered state of awareness that it has birthed.  It is almost as if the complexity of this poetry, matching the complexity of ourselves and our world, has unified the conflicted things inside us, and reconciled them through its mythical-metaphoric permutations.  This is the simplicity of profoundity, so different from the simplicity of ignorance.  And we have not even entered Purgatory, but only stand outside its gate, the whole unfolding of our journey from anxiety to grace still awaiting its first steps towards fulfillment.  But by now, although we are but babes in this new world, we are at least starting to be able to read, to read in the Dantean sense, and this attainment may enable us to procede.

(After pondering how I might comment on this canto for a few days, I went to bed last night, during a storm, about 1 o'clock, woke at 3, wrote the above, returned to bed at 5, and dreampt that I awakened again, and accompanied by a friend from high school, came back into my office, to show him my work.  I flipped the light switch, but the light burned out.  At this point I did not realize I was dreaming.  Then others came, a pair of teenaged twins with caucasian skin, but knotted Rastifarian hair, which I compared to my own hair, and an old college professor who brought an antique typwriter to record my work.  This dream had about it a strong feeling of reality, as if, above all, it were trying to show me how we are simultaneously alive in many different space/time dimensions, and that sometimes the veil thins between these dimensions so that they touch and interchange those mythic-metaphors we find throughout Dante's poem.)

The study of cosmology is the study of the unconscious.  It cannot be otherwise, for whatever we might believe to be the conscious awareness has evolved from and emerges from the entire universe.  There is nothing that we can know or experience that is not dictated by this cosmology, and even our probings of that cosmology may only go so far and so deep as that entirety allows.  Dante is a cosmological poet, and the Commedia is an entity wherein that cosmology has been particularly forthcoming in allowing certain of its essences, its fundamentals, to be accessible to the conscious mind.  The poem's intense and involving reality, if we should presume to call it that, is what Dante would call the soul, that is to say, the cosmologist interacting with what he would call God, that is to say, cosmology.  His telescope, his microscope, his psychological techniques, are language.  There is a surface script and many deeper subscripts.  They are all one.  This subscript is written in what he would have called allegory.  Think of a surface being folded, folded again, folded again, and again, with rhymes, rhythms, pulses, with metaphors, historical references, geographic references, celestial observations, literary and mythological allusions, and so forth and so on.  His technique is based on the allegoria of this polysemous, multivalent folding: what is literal, is the surface — history, journalism, factual account; what is typological is the comparison of texts — Christian, Pagan, what have you; what is tropological is the moral implication of the texts, its revelations concerning the consequences of our actions or what Eastern religious modalities would call karma; and like Jung, the fourth, the allegrical, is categorically different then these other three, in that it is the composite of them.  Any kind of reading, writing, feeling, interpreting, translating that we might do, whether we are consciously aware of it or not, keeps tending towards this repeated layering or folding which is a set or subset of these four, some fragmentated fractalized glimpse of the entirety of the cosmos holographically presented as this allegoria.  What does the angel at the gate of Purgatory mean?  Why is he dressed in ashen-colored clothes?  Why is that Saint Lucy is Dante's passport to these higher realms of consciousness?  Why does the keeper of the gate carve seven letter P's in Dante's forehead?  Why does Dante strike his breast three times?  What is the significance of the three steps — the marble polished like a mirror, the dark conglomerate, and the sanguine?  What do the silver and the golden keys mean?  Why does the gate make such a wrenching sound as it turns on its hinges?  How is it that Dante, a poet and a living person, has access to these regions which are the domain only of disembodied souls?  Why does the Angel of the gate warn Dante not to look back?  Why does Dante hear, or think he hears, the Te Deum Laudamus, in polyphonic weavings, sometimes distinctly, and sometimes fading, as at the canto's conclusion.  All of these are cosmological questions, and the depth to which we pursue them in our own souls as we read is precisely the depth to which our souls are revealed to us.  Will we accept the given answers of centuries and centuries of commentators?  Or will we add new insights, new folds, new layers of richness and depth?

These particulars are laid out as particulars threaded together as a sequence, dots in a line, at first reading, which become a sphere of intermingling essences when we have assimilated them as a totality.  Contemplating this, a terrible and wondrous phrase comes to me: Revelation is obliteration.               

1  The concubine of old Tithonus now
2  Gleamed white upon the eastern balcony,
3  Forth from the arms of her sweet paramour;

1  La concubina di Titone antico
2  già s'imbiancava al balco d'orïente,
3  fuor de le braccia del suo dolce amico;

4  With gems her forehead all relucent was,
5  Set in the shape of that cold animal
6  Which with its tail doth smite amain the nations,

4  di gemme la sua fronte era lucente,
5  poste in figura del freddo animale
6  che con la coda percuote la gente;

7  And of the steps, with which she mounts, the Night
8  Had taken two in that place where we were,
9  And now the third was bending down its wings;

7  e la notte, de' passi con che sale,
8  fatti avea due nel loco ov' eravamo,
9  e 'l terzo già chinava in giuso l'ale;

10  When I, who something had of Adam in me,
11  Vanquished by sleep, upon the grass reclined,
12  There were all five of us already sat.

10  quand' io, che meco avea di quel d'Adamo,
11  vinto dal sonno, in su l'erba inchinai
12  là 've già tutti e cinque sedavamo.

13  Just at the hour when her sad lay begins
14  The little swallow, near unto the morning,
15  Perchance in memory of her former woes,

13  Ne l'ora che comincia i tristi lai
14  la rondinella presso a la mattina,
15 forse a memoria de' suo' primi guai,

16  And when the mind of man, a wanderer
17  More from the flesh, and less by thought imprisoned,
18  Almost prophetic in its visions is,

16  e che la mente nostra, peregrina
17  più da la carne e men da' pensier presa,
18  a le sue visïon quasi è divina,

19  In dreams it seemed to me I saw suspended
20  An eagle in the sky, with plumes of gold,
21  With wings wide open, and intent to stoop,

19  in sogno mi parea veder sospesa
20  un'aguglia nel ciel con penne d'oro,
21  con l'ali aperte e a calare intesa;

22  And this, it seemed to me, was where had been
23  By Ganymede his kith and kin abandoned,
24  When to the high consistory he was rapt.

22  ed esser mi parea là dove fuoro
23  abbandonati i suoi da Ganimede,
24  quando fu ratto al sommo consistoro.

25  I thought within myself, perchance he strikes
26  From habit only here, and from elsewhere
27  Disdains to bear up any in his feet.

25  Fra me pensava: “Forse questa fiede
26  pur qui per uso, e forse d'altro loco
27  disdegna di portarne suso in piede.”

28  Then wheeling somewhat more, it seemed to me,
29  Terrible as the lightning he descended,
30  And snatched me upward even to the fire.

28  Poi mi parea che, poi rotata un poco,
29  terribil come folgor discendesse,
30  e me rapisse suso infino al foco.

31  Therein it seemed that he and I were burning,
32  And the imagined fire did scorch me so,
33  That of necessity my sleep was broken.

31  Ivi parea che ella e io ardesse;
32  e sì lo 'ncendio imaginato cosse,
33  che convenne che 'l sonno si rompesse.

34  Not otherwise Achilles started up,
35  Around him turning his awakened eyes,
36  And knowing not the place in which he was,

34  Non altrimenti Achille si riscosse,
34  li occhi svegliati rivolgendo in giro
35  e non sappiendo là dove si fosse,

37  What time from Chiron stealthily his mother
38  Carried him sleeping in her arms to Scyros,
39  Wherefrom the Greeks withdrew him afterwards,

37  quando la madre da Chirón a Schiro
38  trafuggò lui dormendo in le sue braccia,
39  là onde poi li Greci il dipartiro;

40  Than I upstarted, when from off my face
41  Sleep fled away; and pallid I became,
42  As doth the man who freezes with affright.

40  che mi scoss' io, sì come da la faccia
41  mi fuggì 'l sonno, e diventa' ismorto,
42  come fa l'uom che, spaventato, agghiaccia.

43  Only my Comforter was at my side,
44  And now the sun was more than two hours high,
45  And turned towards the sea-shore was my face.

43  Dallato m'era solo il mio conforto,
44  e 'l sole er' alto già più che due ore,
45  e 'l viso m'era a la marina torto.

46  "Be not intimidated," said my Lord,
47  "Be reassured, for all is well with us;
48  Do not restrain, but put forth all thy strength.

46  “Non aver tema,” disse il mio segnore;
47  “fatti sicur, ché noi semo a buon punto;
48  non stringer, ma rallarga ogne vigore.

49  Thou hast at length arrived at Purgatory;
50  See there the cliff that closes it around;
51  See there the entrance, where it seems disjoined.

49  Tu se' omai al purgatorio giunto:
50  vedi là il balzo che 'l chiude dintorno;
51  vedi l'entrata là 've par digiunto.

52  Whilom at dawn, which doth precede the day,
53  When inwardly thy spirit was asleep
54  Upon the flowers that deck the land below,

52  Dianzi, ne l'alba che procede al giorno,
53  quando l'anima tua dentro dormia,
54  sovra li fiori ond' è là giù addorno

55  There came a Lady and said: 'I am Lucia;
56  Let me take this one up, who is asleep;
57  So will I make his journey easier for him.'

55  venne una donna, e disse: 'I' son Lucia;
56  lasciatemi pigliar costui che dorme;
57  sì l'agevolerò per la sua via.'

58  Sordello and the other noble shapes
59  Remained; she took thee, and, as day grew bright,
60  Upward she came, and I upon her footsteps.

58  Sordel rimase e l'altre genti forme;
59  ella ti tolse, e come 'l dì fu chiaro,
60  sen venne suso; e io per le sue orme.

61  She laid thee here; and first her beauteous eyes
62  That open entrance pointed out to me;
63  Then she and sleep together went away."

61  Qui ti posò, ma pria mi dimostraro
62  li occhi suoi belli quella intrata aperta;
63  poi ella e 'l sonno ad una se n'andaro.”

64  In guise of one whose doubts are reassured,
65  And who to confidence his fear doth change,
66  After the truth has been discovered to him, 

64  A guisa d'uom che 'n dubbio si raccerta
65  e che muta in conforto sua paura,
66  poi che la verità li è discoperta,

67  So did I change; and when without disquiet
68  My Leader saw me, up along the cliff
69  He moved, and I behind him, tow'rd the height.

67  mi cambia' io; e come sanza cura
68  vide me 'l duca mio, su per lo balzo
69  si mosse, e io di rietro inver' l'altura.

70  Reader, thou seest well how I exalt
71  My theme, and therefore if with greater art
72  I fortify it, marvel not thereat.

70  Lettor, tu vedi ben com' io innalzo
71  la mia matera, e però con più arte
72  non ti maravigliar s'io la rincalzo.

73  Nearer approached we, and were in such place,
74  That there, where first appeared to me a rift
75  Like to a crevice that disparts a wall,

73  Noi ci appressammo, ed eravamo in parte
74  che là dove pareami prima rotto,
75  pur come un fesso che muro diparte,

76  I saw a portal, and three stairs beneath,
77  Diverse in colour, to go up to it,
78  And a gate-keeper, who yet spake no word.

76  vidi una porta, e tre gradi di sotto
77 per gire ad essa, di color diversi,
78  e un portier ch'ancor non facea motto.

79  And as I opened more and more mine eyes,
80  I saw him seated on the highest stair,
81  Such in the face that I endured it not.

79  E come l'occhio più e più v'apersi,
80  vidil seder sovra 'l grado sovrano,
81  tal ne la faccia ch'io non lo soffersi;

 
82  And in his hand he had a naked sword,
83  Which so reflected back the sunbeams tow'rds us,
84  That oft in vain I lifted up mine eyes.

82  e una spada nuda avëa in mano,
83  che reflettëa i raggi sì ver' noi,
84  ch'io dirizzava spesso il viso in vano.

85  "Tell it from where you are, what is't you wish?"
86  Began he to exclaim; "where is the escort?
87  Take heed your coming hither harm you not!"

85  “Dite costinci: che volete voi?”
86  cominciò elli a dire, “ov' è la scorta?
87  Guardate che 'l venir sù non vi nòi.”
 
88  "A Lady of Heaven, with these things conversant,"
89  My Master answered him, "but even now
90  Said to us, 'Thither go; there is the portal.'"

88  “Donna del ciel, di queste cose accorta,”
89  rispuose 'l mio maestro a lui, “pur dianzi
90  ne disse: 'Andate là: quivi è la porta.'”

91  "And may she speed your footsteps in all good,"
92  Again began the courteous janitor;
93  "Come forward then unto these stairs of ours."

91  “Ed ella i passi vostri in bene avanzi,”
92  ricominciò il cortese portinaio:
93  “Venite dunque a' nostri gradi innanzi.”

94  Thither did we approach; and the first stair
95  Was marble white, so polished and so smooth,
96  I mirrored myself therein as I appear.

94  Là ne venimmo; e lo scaglion primaio
95  bianco marmo era sì pulito e terso,
96  ch'io mi specchiai in esso qual io paio.

97  The second, tinct of deeper hue than perse,
98  Was of a calcined and uneven stone,
99  Cracked all asunder lengthwise and across.

97  Era il secondo tinto più che perso,
98  d'una petrina ruvida e arsiccia,
99  crepata per lo lungo e per traverso.
 
100  The third, that uppermost rests massively,
101  Porphyry seemed to me, as flaming red
102  As blood that from a vein is spirting forth.
 
100  Lo terzo, che di sopra s'ammassiccia,
101  porfido mi parea, sì fiammeggiante
102  come sangue che fuor di vena spiccia.
 
103  Both of his feet was holding upon this
104  The Angel of God, upon the threshold seated,
105  Which seemed to me a stone of diamond.

103  Sovra questo tenëa ambo le piante
104 l'angel di Dio sedendo in su la soglia
105 che mi sembiava pietra di diamante.

106  Along the three stairs upward with good will
107  Did my Conductor draw me, saying: "Ask
108  Humbly that he the fastening may undo."

106 Per li tre gradi sù di buona voglia
107  mi trasse il duca mio, dicendo: “Chiedi
108  umilemente che 'l serrame scioglia.”

109  Devoutly at the holy feet I cast me,
110  For mercy's sake besought that he would open,
111  But first upon my breast three times I smote.

109  Divoto mi gittai a' santi piedi;
110  misericordia chiesi e ch'el m'aprisse,
111  ma tre volte nel petto pria mi diedi.

112  Seven P's upon my forehead he described
113  With the sword's point, and, "Take heed that thou wash
114  These wounds, when thou shalt be within," he said.

112  Sette P ne la fronte mi descrisse
113  col punton de la spada, e “Fa che lavi,
114  quando se' dentro, queste piaghe” disse.


115  Ashes, or earth that dry is excavated,
116  Of the same colour were with his attire,
117  And from beneath it he drew forth two keys.

115  Cenere, o terra che secca si cavi,
116  d'un color fora col suo vestimento;
117  e di sotto da quel trasse due chiavi.

118  One was of gold, and the other was of silver;
119  First with the white, and after with the yellow,
120  Plied he the door, so that I was content.

118  L'una era d'oro e l'altra era d'argento;
119  pria con la bianca e poscia con la gialla
120 fece a la porta sì, ch'i' fu' contento.
 
121  "Whenever faileth either of these keys
122  So that it turn not rightly in the lock,"
123  He said to us, "this entrance doth not open.

121  “Quandunque l'una d'este chiavi falla,
122  che non si volga dritta per la toppa,”
123  diss' elli a noi, “non s'apre questa calla.
 
124  More precious one is, but the other needs
125  More art and intellect ere it unlock,
126  For it is that which doth the knot unloose.

124  Più cara è l'una; ma l'altra vuol troppa
125 d'arte e d'ingegno avanti che diserri,
126 perch' ella è quella che 'l nodo digroppa.
 
127  From Peter I have them; and he bade me err
128  Rather in opening than in keeping shut,
129  If people but fall down before my feet."

127  Da Pier le tegno; e dissemi ch'i' erri
128  anzi ad aprir ch'a tenerla serrata,
129  pur che la gente a' piedi mi s'atterri.”
 
130  Then pushed the portals of the sacred door,
131  Exclaiming: "Enter; but I give you warning
132  That forth returns whoever looks behind."

130  Poi pinse l'uscio a la porta sacrata,
131  dicendo: “Intrate; ma facciovi accorti
132  che di fuor torna chi 'n dietro si guata.”
 
133  And when upon their hinges were turned round
134  The swivels of that consecrated gate,
135  Which are of metal, massive and sonorous,

133  E quando fuor ne' cardini distorti
134  li spigoli di quella regge sacra,
135  che di metallo son sonanti e forti,

136  Roared not so loud, nor so discordant seemed
137  Tarpeia, when was ta'en from it the good
138  Metellus, wherefore meagre it remained.

142  Tale imagine a punto mi rendea
143  ciò ch'io udiva, qual prender si suole
144  quando a cantar con organi si stea;

139  At the first thunder-peal I turned attentive,
140  And "Te Deum laudamus" seemed to hear
141  In voices mingled with sweet melody.

139  Io mi rivolsi attento al primo tuono,
140  e “Te Deum laudamus” mi parea
141  udire in voce mista al dolce suono.

142  Exactly such an image rendered me
143  That which I heard, as we are wont to catch,
144  When people singing with the organ stand; 

142  Tale imagine a punto mi rendea
143  ciò ch'io udiva, qual prender si suole
144  quando a cantar con organi si stea;

145  For now we hear, and now hear not, the words.

145  ch'or sì or no s'intendon le parole.

Canto X
The rusted seldom used gate of purgatory proper closes behind the protagonists, the aspirant Dante does not look back. The angel at the gate has warned him.  At the wide gate of Hell, the multitude is told to abandon hope, here at the narrow gate to purgatory the blessed few are told to surrender remorse. There follows a tortuous passage through that needle’s eye that Christ said would forbid the passage of those rich persons bloated to the size of camels by their pride in their possessions. The syntax here is tortured as is this rocky second birth canal (the first was at the exit of Hell), the hard unyielding rocks compared to the treacherous back and forth crashing of waves.  We are entering a different world where substance is simultaneously insubstantial and stones seem alive and capable of breath and speech.  Once through the needle’s eye, the protagonists arrive at a seeming desert opening out unto a limitless void, and bounded by a sheer rock wall three times (think trinity, or a human being’s tripartite nature) the height of man. Virgil has already told us we must use more art as we proceed, and here we find divine art carved into the adamantine walls.  This divine art is so infused with inspiration that it seems both permanent and ephemeral at once, like objects, or even are own bodies, which seem materially solid but whose value is as impermanent as a whim.

Heavy and light, hard/easy, yes/no these opposites are inclining more closely together now, Dante’s solid body is fatigued, Virgil’s dreambody is not.  But the dreambody is as lost here as the waking body, the moon of the dreamy and illusory night world is waning, and with her the entire labyrêve of twisted love —  art , imagination, beginning to dawn here as a more real reality, i.e., the fictive truths of Dante’s poem, his scripture, being more real than the maya of everday life.  The reader is being prepared here for lessons to be received in a more graceful and aesthetic way than those vulgar negative exemplars of Hell.

Three lessons are carved in the stone, and they draw yes and no like yin and yang together in one symbol. The first is the seven choruses which recall the seven P’s tattooed onto the aspirant’s brow (his consciousness, others can see those sins in him and he can feel them on himself), and forecasting the seven levels ascending up the mountain of Purgatory wherein each of the seven deadly sins will be purged.  The second lesson is of King David dancing before the Ark of the Covenant, while his wife, Michal, looks down disapprovingly.  (Note how this scene mirrors Beatrice looking down on the wayward Dante.) The third lesson is that of the Emperor Trajan obeying the command of a lowly widow. (Another anima figure, the aspirant here is sandwiched between Michal and the widow.).  Now Virgil warns Dante not to linger, to move along and to note the heavily laden prideful who are so encumbered by the burden of their sin that they cannot tolerate the least addition to their torment.  But we have been forewarned: Here the worst torments are but training exercises on the ascension towards blessedness, and the order of positive examples followed by negative ones has been established as the moral syntax of purgatory: first the carrot then the stick, the implication being that if we are alacritous in accepting the mercy of grace we need not have to balance the scales of justice by paying the debt of the suffering we have caused.  I am reminded here of the instructions of the priest to the corpse in The Tibetan Book of the Dead. Again and again the soul is guided towards the too-bright light of liberation, yet again and again the heavy deluded soul chooses the smoky light which draws them back down to that prison of suffering experienced as incarnation.

1  When we had crossed the threshold of the door
2  Which the perverted love of souls disuses,
3  Because it makes the crooked way seem straight,

1  Poi fummo dentro al soglio de la porta
2  che 'l mal amor de l'anime disusa,
3  perché fa parer dritta la via torta,

4  Re-echoing I heard it closed again;
5  And if I had turned back mine eyes upon it,
6  What for my failing had been fit excuse?

4  sonando la senti' esser richiusa;
5  e s'io avesse li occhi vòlti ad essa,
6  qual fora stata al fallo degna scusa?

7  We mounted upward through a rifted rock,
8  Which undulated to this side and that,
9  Even as a wave receding and advancing.

7  Noi salavam per una pietra fessa,
8  che si moveva e d'una e d'altra parte,
9  sì come l'onda che fugge e s'appressa.

10  "Here it behoves us use a little art,"
11  Began my Leader, "to adapt ourselves
12  Now here, now there, to the receding side."

10  “Qui si conviene usare un poco d'arte,”
11  cominciò 'l duca mio, “in accostarsi
12  or quinci, or quindi al lato che si parte.”

13  And this our footsteps so infrequent made,
14  That sooner had the moon's decreasing disk
15  Regained its bed to sink again to rest,

13  E questo fece i nostri passi scarsi,
14  tanto che pria lo scemo de la luna
15  rigiunse al letto suo per ricorcarsi,

16  Than we were forth from out that needle's eye;
17  But when we free and in the open were,
18  There where the mountain backward piles itself,

16  che noi fossimo fuor di quella cruna;
17  ma quando fummo liberi e aperti
18  sù dove il monte in dietro si rauna,

19  I wearied out, and both of us uncertain
20  About our way, we stopped upon a plain
21  More desolate than roads across the deserts.

19  ïo stancato e amendue incerti
20  di nostra via, restammo in su un piano
21  solingo più che strade per diserti.

22  From where its margin borders on the void,
23  To foot of the high bank that ever rises,
24  A human body three times told would measure;

22  Da la sua sponda, ove confina il vano,
23  al piè de l'alta ripa che pur sale,
24  misurrebbe in tre volte un corpo umano;
25  And far as eye of mine could wing its flight,
26  Now on the left, and on the right flank now,
27  The same this cornice did appear to me.

25  e quanto l'occhio mio potea trar d'ale,
26  or dal sinistro e or dal destro fianco,
27  questa cornice mi parea cotale.

28  Thereon our feet had not been moved as yet,
29  When I perceived the embankment round about,
30  Which all right of ascent had interdicted,

28  Là sù non eran mossi i piè nostri anco,
29  quand' io conobbi quella ripa intorno
30  che dritto di salita aveva manco,

31  To be of marble white, and so adorned
32  With sculptures, that not only Polycletus,
33  But Nature's self, had there been put to shame.

31  esser di marmo candido e addorno
32 d'intagli sì, che non pur Policleto,
33 ma la natura lì avrebbe scorno.

34  The Angel, who came down to earth with tidings
35  Of peace, that had been wept for many a year,
36  And opened Heaven from its long interdict,

34  L'angel che venne in terra col decreto
35 de la molt' anni lagrimata pace,
36 ch'aperse il ciel del suo lungo divieto,

37  In front of us appeared so truthfully
38  There sculptured in a gracious attitude,
39  He did not seem an image that is silent.

37  dinanzi a noi pareva sì verace
38  quivi intagliato in un atto soave,
39 che non sembiava imagine che tace.

40  One would have sworn that he was saying, "Ave;"
41  For she was there in effigy portrayed
42  Who turned the key to ope the exalted love,

40  Giurato si saria ch'el dicesse “Ave!”;
41  perché iv' era imaginata quella
42 ch'ad aprir l'alto amor volse la chiave;

43  And in her mien this language had impressed,
44  "Ecce ancilla Dei," as distinctly
45  As any figure stamps itself in wax.

43  e avea in atto impressa esta favella
44  “Ecce ancilla Deï,” propriamente
43  come figura in cera si suggella.

46  "Keep not thy mind upon one place alone,"
47  The gentle Master said, who had me standing
48  Upon that side where people have their hearts;

46  “Non tener pur ad un loco la mente,”
47  disse 'l dolce maestro, che m'avea
48  da quella parte onde 'l cuore ha la gente.

49  Whereat I moved mine eyes, and I beheld
50  In rear of Mary, and upon that side
51  Where he was standing who conducted me,

49  Per ch'i' mi mossi col viso, e vedea
50  di retro da Maria, da quella costa
51  onde m'era colui che mi movea,

52  Another story on the rock imposed;
53  Wherefore I passed Virgilius and drew near,
54  So that before mine eyes it might be set.

52  un'altra storia ne la roccia imposta;
53  per ch'io varcai Virgilio, e fe'mi presso,
54  acciò che fosse a li occhi miei disposta.

55  There sculptured in the self-same marble were
56  The cart and oxen, drawing the holy ark,
57  Wherefore one dreads an office not appointed.

55  Era intagliato lì nel marmo stesso
56  lo carro e ' buoi, traendo l'arca santa,
57  per che si teme officio non commesso.
58  People appeared in front, and all of them
59  In seven choirs divided, of two senses
60  Made one say "No," the other, "Yes, they sing."

58  Dinanzi parea gente; e tutta quanta,
59  partita in sette cori, a' due mie' sensi
60  faceva dir l'un “No,” l'altro “Sì, canta.”

61  Likewise unto the smoke of the frankincense,
62  Which there was imaged forth, the eyes and nose
63  Were in the yes and no discordant made.

61  Similemente al fummo de li 'ncensi
62  che v'era imaginato, li occhi e 'l naso
63 e al sì e al no discordi fensi.

64  Preceded there the vessel benedight,
65  Dancing with girded loins, the humble Psalmist,
66  And more and less than King was he in this.

64  Lì precedeva al benedetto vaso,
65  trescando alzato, l'umile salmista,
66  e più e men che re era in quel caso.

67  Opposite, represented at the window
68  Of a great palace, Michal looked upon him,
69  Even as a woman scornful and afflicted.

67  Di contra, effigïata ad una vista
68  d'un gran palazzo, Micòl ammirava
69  sì come donna dispettosa e trista.

70  I moved my feet from where I had been standing,
71  To examine near at hand another story,
72  Which after Michal glimmered white upon me.

70  I' mossi i piè del loco dov' io stava,
71  per avvisar da presso un'altra istoria,
72  che di dietro a Micòl mi biancheggiava.

73  There the high glory of the Roman Prince
74  Was chronicled, whose great beneficence
75  Moved Gregory to his great victory;

73  Quiv' era storïata l'alta gloria
74  del roman principato, il cui valore
75  mosse Gregorio a la sua gran vittoria;

76  'Tis of the Emperor Trajan I am speaking;
77  And a poor widow at his bridle stood,
78  In attitude of weeping and of grief.

76  i' dico di Traiano imperadore;
77  e una vedovella li era al freno,
78  di lagrime atteggiata e di dolore.

79  Around about him seemed it thronged and full
80  Of cavaliers, and the eagles in the gold
81  Above them visibly in the wind were moving.

79  Intorno a lui parea calcato e pieno
80  di cavalieri, e l'aguglie ne l'oro
81  sovr' essi in vista al vento si movieno.

82  The wretched woman in the midst of these
83  Seemed to be saying: "Give me vengeance, Lord,
84  For my dead son, for whom my heart is breaking."
