82  La miserella intra tutti costoro
83  pareva dir: “Segnor, fammi vendetta
84  di mio figliuol ch'è morto, ond' io m'accoro”;

85  And he to answer her: "Now wait until
86  I shall return." And she: "My Lord," like one
87  In whom grief is impatient, "shouldst thou not

85  ed elli a lei rispondere: “Or aspetta
86  tanto ch'i' torni”; e quella: “Segnor mio,”
87  come persona in cui dolor s'affretta,

88  Return?" And he: "Who shall be where I am
89  Will give it thee." And she: "Good deed of others
90  What boots it thee, if thou neglect thine own?"

88  “se tu non torni?”; ed ei: “Chi fia dov' io,
89  la ti farà”; ed ella: “L'altrui bene
90  a te che fia, se 'l tuo metti in oblio?”;
91  Whence he: "Now comfort thee, for it behoves me
92  That I discharge my duty ere I move;
93  Justice so wills, and pity doth retain me."

91  ond' elli: “Or ti conforta; ch'ei convene
92  ch'i' solva il mio dovere anzi ch'i' mova:
93  giustizia vuole e pietà mi ritene.”

94  He who on no new thing has ever looked
95  Was the creator of this visible language,
96  Novel to us, for here it is not found.

94  Colui che mai non vide cosa nova
95  produsse esto visibile parlare,
96  novello a noi perché qui non si trova.

97  While I delighted me in contemplating
98  The images of such humility,
99  And dear to look on for their Maker's sake,

97  Mentr' io mi dilettava di guardare
98  l'imagini di tante umilitadi,
99  e per lo fabbro loro a veder care,

100  "Behold, upon this side, but rare they make
101  Their steps," the Poet murmured, "many people;
102  These will direct us to the lofty stairs." 

100  “Ecco di qua, ma fanno i passi radi,”
101  mormorava il poeta, “molte genti:
102  questi ne 'nvïeranno a li alti gradi.”

103  Mine eyes, that in beholding were intent
104  To see new things, of which they curious are,
105  In turning round towards him were not slow.

103  Li occhi miei, ch'a mirare eran contenti
104  per veder novitadi ond' e' son vaghi,
105  volgendosi ver' lui non furon lenti. 

106  But still I wish not, Reader, thou shouldst swerve
107  From thy good purposes, because thou hearest
108  How God ordaineth that the debt be paid;

106  Non vo' però, lettor, che tu ti smaghi
107  di buon proponimento per udire
108 come Dio vuol che 'l debito si paghi.

109  Attend not to the fashion of the torment,
110  Think of what follows; think that at the worst
111  It cannot reach beyond the mighty sentence.

109  Non attender la forma del martìre:
110  pensa la succession; pensa ch'al peggio
111  oltre la gran sentenza non può ire.

112  "Master," began I, "that which I behold
113  Moving towards us seems to me not persons,
114  And what I know not, so in sight I waver."

112  Io cominciai: “Maestro, quel ch'io veggio
113  muovere a noi, non mi sembian persone,
114  e non so che, sì nel veder vaneggio.”

115  And he to me: "The grievous quality
116  Of this their torment bows them so to earth,
117  That my own eyes at first contended with it;

115  Ed elli a me: “La grave condizione
116  di lor tormento a terra li rannicchia,
117  sì che ' miei occhi pria n'ebber tencione.

118  But look there fixedly, and disentangle
119  By sight what cometh underneath those stones;
120  Already canst thou see how each is stricken."

118  Ma guarda fiso là, e disviticchia
119  col viso quel che vien sotto a quei sassi:
120  già scorger puoi come ciascun si picchia.”

121  O ye proud Christians! wretched, weary ones!
122  Who, in the vision of the mind infirm
123  Confidence have in your backsliding steps,

121  O superbi cristian, miseri lassi,
122  che, de la vista de la mente infermi,
123  fidanza avete ne' retrosi passi,
124  Do ye not comprehend that we are worms,
125  Born to bring forth the angelic butterfly
126  That flieth unto judgment without screen?

124  non v'accorgete voi che noi siam vermi
125  nati a formar l'angelica farfalla,
126  che vola a la giustizia sanza schermi?

127  Why floats aloft your spirit high in air?
128  Like are ye unto insects undeveloped,
129  Even as the worm in whom formation fails!

127  Di che l'animo vostro in alto galla,
128  poi siete quasi antomata in difetto,
129  sì come vermo in cui formazion falla?

130  As to sustain a ceiling or a roof,
131  In place of corbel, oftentimes a figure
132  Is seen to join its knees unto its breast,

130  Come per sostentar solaio o tetto,
131  per mensola talvolta una figura
132  si vede giugner le ginocchia al petto,

133  Which makes of the unreal real anguish
134  Arise in him who sees it, fashioned thus
135  Beheld I those, when I had ta'en good heed.

133  la qual fa del non ver vera rancura
134  nascere 'n chi la vede; così fatti
135  vid' io color, quando puosi ben cura.

136  True is it, they were more or less bent down,
137  According as they more or less were laden;
138  And he who had most patience in his looks

136  Vero è che più e meno eran contratti
137  secondo ch'avien più e meno a dosso;
138  e qual più pazïenza avea ne li atti,

139  Weeping did seem to say, "I can no more!"

139  piangendo parea dicer: “Più non posso."

Canto XI
Our senses, with the possible exception of smell, are only emergent properties to explore a temporally evolving 3-D space, thus we can never explore higher dimensions with them, they simply are not designed to so.  But language is a kind of out-of-this world sense, a meta-sense, if you will, in its metaphoric/metonymic functions and so we could hypothesize that it is this sense that allows us glimpses of higher dimensions.  The Commedia, taken as a whole, could almost be described as a higher dimension incursion into our 3-D space/entropic time-universe, and Dante's version of the Lord's prayer could be read as a key to a higher dimensional universe.  Something is passing back and forth between higher and lower dimensions, and what Dante would call this something is prayer, but not any kind of prayer, prayer that is praise.  Why this praise, because when we encounter awe, we feel gratitude, and gratitude elicits praise.  If you're a traditional Christian theist, that praise is not only for God, it is God's very organizational substance, bubbling up chaotically from a lower state of organization to be formed by "accident" "fortuitousness" "synchronicity" "chance" "grace" into a higher level of organization.  Not for example the rhyme of "valore" (power, value, worth, courage") in line 4 with the word vapore (breath, vapor, line 6), wherein we see the relationship between the breath of earthly creatures and the praise that links them to ALL THAT IS.  One could say that praise for ALL THAT IS is the antidote to pride, and pride the first, the most dangerous and most Luciferian of sins because it leads us into the terrible delusion that we are living in a universe from which we are separated, where everything beyond our innervated/appetitive self is predator or prey, and that our personal power, safety and worthiness can only comb by forcing others to succumb, to be subservient, in short to be our slaves or victims.  In such a universe, there can never be harmony, nor grace, nor these higher levels of bliss and cooperation that we see here as our incarnated, lower dimensional selves, and our disincarnate higher dimensional selves touch and enrich one another in this field of mutual praise, a praise, which both sides must remember is not something originating inside their individual selves, i.e., their selfishness, but which only arises as a phenomenon of the whole.  All this is the lesson that the prideful, weighted down by the delusion of a separate self, must learn to lighten, or "enlighten" themselves and ascend. 

What else is happening in this Canto?  Virgil and Dante are looking for a way to ascend that is passable for one who is still incarnated, in short, a to ascend for the incarnated reader as well.  The prideful who have learned — learned, as the damned never learned — through the process of their purgation.  As they feel the weight of the separated self fully (line 20: the old adversary), only then are they willing to release that burden, as no real part of their essential selves, only then can they take the path that they will show to the protagonists.  And, it is important to note, it is not that separated self who may be the judge of their progress, one could say, that this lightening of the load happens automatically as soon as that purging has been authentically accomplished.  Clearly, praise and gratitude for ALL THAT IS quickens this process.  One should also note that as long as any vestige of the separated self remains, that self must be subject to the vicissitudes of Time, progress is a temporal process, just as punishment was an interminable process.  What is the most impervious natural material to Time's transformations?  Stone.  And that is why the prideful penitents find themselves wearily weighted down as stony shadows burdened by stone, their weariness, no a punishment per se, as the torments of Hell were, but a necessary precondition for utter surrender, utter release of that burden.  That those whom the protagonists meet in the Canto are in the process of coming to this point of surrender is show by their recitation of the Lord's prayer, and their reluctance to say their own names, referring to themselves in the broader sense of their ancestors, for example, or their place in the procession of penitents.  That they have not yet reached their goal of surrender is conversely shown by the fact that they are still more connected to that which lies below them, the circumstances and connections of their earthly life, rather than whatever or whomever might have risen above them.  When they give their exegesis of fame, and it's ephemerality, they revert to earthly metaphors, grass greened and then withered by the same sun.  It has not yet occurred to them that each stage of each blade of that grass in cooperation with the sun has an eternal function to fulfill in the harmony of ALL THAT IS, and that no one's effort or life at any stage is a waste.  Their view is a temporal one — inception, maturity, decay— and as long as this temporality exists in them, they are incapable of rising further and cannot ascend to Paradise.

Once again, at the end of this Canto, Dante's earthly exile from Florence is presaged.  Already Dante is beginning to get the inkling that his home can never again be any place on earth or anywhere in incarnation.  As readers, at this point in the Commedia, we should feel the same.   
 
1  "Our Father, thou who dwellest in the heavens,
2   Not circumscribed, but from the greater love
3   Thou bearest to the first effects on high,

1  “O Padre nostro, che ne' cieli stai, 
2   non circunscritto, ma per più amore
3  ch'ai primi effetti di là sù tu hai,

4  Praised be thy name and thine omnipotence
5  By every creature, as befitting is
6  To render thanks to thy sweet effluence.

4  laudato sia 'l tuo nome e 'l tuo valore
5  da ogne creatura, com' è degno
6  di render grazie al tuo dolce vapore.

7  Come unto us the peace of thy dominion,
8  For unto it we cannot of ourselves,
9  If it come not, with all our intellect.

7  Vegna ver' noi la pace del tuo regno,
8  ché noi ad essa non potem da noi,
9  s'ella non vien, con tutto nostro ingegno.

10  Even as thine own Angels of their will
11  Make sacrifice to thee, Hosanna singing,
12  So may all men make sacrifice of theirs.

10  Come del suo voler li angeli tuoi
11  fan sacrificio a te, cantando osanna,
12  così facciano li uomini de' suoi.

13  Give unto us this day our daily manna,
14  Withouten which in this rough wilderness
15  Backward goes he who toils most to advance.

13  Dà oggi a noi la cotidiana manna,
14  sanza la qual per questo aspro diserto
15  a retro va chi più di gir s'affanna.

16  And even as we the trespass we have suffered
17  Pardon in one another, pardon thou
18  Benignly, and regard not our desert.

16  E come noi lo mal ch'avem sofferto
17  perdoniamo a ciascuno, e tu perdona
18  benigno, e non guardar lo nostro merto.

19  Our virtue, which is easily o'ercome,
20  Put not to proof with the old Adversary,
21  But thou from him who spurs it so, deliver.

19  Nostra virtù che di legger s'adona,
20  non spermentar con l'antico avversaro,
22  ma libera da lui che sì la sprona.

22  This last petition verily, dear Lord,
23  Not for ourselves is made, who need it not,
24  But for their sake who have remained behind us."

22  Quest' ultima preghiera, segnor caro,
23  già non si fa per noi, ché non bisogna,
24  ma per color che dietro a noi restaro.”

25  Thus for themselves and us good furtherance
26  Those shades imploring, went beneath a weight
27  Like unto that of which we sometimes dream,

25  Così a sé e noi buona ramogna
26  quell' ombre orando, andavan sotto 'l pondo,
27 simile a quel che talvolta si sogna,

28  Unequally in anguish round and round
29  And weary all, upon that foremost cornice,
30  Purging away the smoke-stains of the world.

28  disparmente angosciate tutte a tondo
29  e lasse su per la prima cornice,
30  purgando la caligine del mondo.

31  If there good words are always said for us,
32  What may not here be said and done for them,
33  By those who have a good root to their will?

31  Se di là sempre ben per noi si dice,
32  di qua che dire e far per lor si puote
33  da quei c'hanno al voler buona radice?

34  Well may we help them wash away the marks
35  That hence they carried, so that clean and light
36  They may ascend unto the starry wheels!

34  Ben si de' loro atar lavar le note
35  che portar quinci, sì che, mondi e lievi,
36  possano uscire a le stellate ruote.

37  "Ah! so may pity and justice you disburden
38  Soon, that ye may have power to move the wing,
39  That shall uplift you after your desire,

37  “Deh, se giustizia e pietà vi disgrievi
38  tosto, sì che possiate muover l'ala,
39  che secondo il disio vostro vi lievi,

40  Show us on which hand tow'rd the stairs the way
41  Is shortest, and if more than one the passes,
42  Point us out that which least abruptly falls;

40  mostrate da qual mano inver' la scala
41  si va più corto; e se c'è più d'un varco,
42  quel ne 'nsegnate che men erto cala;

43  For he who cometh with me, through the burden
44  Of Adam's flesh wherewith he is invested,
45  Against his will is chary of his climbing."

43  ché questi che vien meco, per lo 'ncarco
44  de la carne d'Adamo onde si veste,
45  al montar sù, contra sua voglia, è parco.”

46  The words of theirs which they returned to those
47  That he whom I was following had spoken,
48  It was not manifest from whom they came,

46  Le lor parole, che rendero a queste
47  che dette avea colui cu' io seguiva,
48  non fur da cui venisser manifeste;

49  But it was said: "To the right hand come with us
50  Along the bank, and ye shall find a pass
51  Possible for living person to ascend.

49  ma fu detto: “A man destra per la riva
50  con noi venite, e troverete il passo
51  possibile a salir persona viva.

52  And were I not impeded by the stone,
53  Which this proud neck of mine doth subjugate,
54  Whence I am forced to hold my visage down,

52  E s'io non fossi impedito dal sasso
53  che la cervice mia superba doma,
54  onde portar convienmi il viso basso,

55  Him, who still lives and does not name himself,
56  Would I regard, to see if I may know him
57  And make him piteous unto this burden.

55  cotesti, ch'ancor vive e non si noma,
56  guardere' io, per veder s'i' 'l conosco,
57  e per farlo pietoso a questa soma.

58  A Latian was I, and born of a great Tuscan;
59  Guglielmo Aldobrandeschi was my father;
60  I know not if his name were ever with you.

58  Io fui latino e nato d'un gran Tosco:
59  Guiglielmo Aldobrandesco fu mio padre;
60  non so se 'l nome suo già mai fu vosco.

61  The ancient blood and deeds of gallantry
62  Of my progenitors so arrogant made me
63  That, thinking not upon the common mother,

61  L'antico sangue e l'opere leggiadre
62  d'i miei maggior mi fer sì arrogante,
63  che, non pensando a la comune madre,

64  All men I held in scorn to such extent
65  I died therefor, as know the Sienese,
66  And every child in Campagnatico.

64  ogn' uomo ebbi in despetto tanto avante,
65  ch'io ne mori', come i Sanesi sanno,
66  e sallo in Campagnatico ogne fante.

67  I am Omberto; and not to me alone
68  Has pride done harm, but all my kith and kin
69  Has with it dragged into adversity.

67  Io sono Omberto; e non pur a me danno
68  superbia fa, ché tutti miei consorti
69  ha ella tratti seco nel malanno.

70  And here must I this burden bear for it
71  Till God be satisfied, since I did not
72  Among the living, here among the dead."

70  E qui convien ch'io questo peso porti
71  per lei, tanto che a Dio si sodisfaccia,
72  poi ch'io nol fe' tra ' vivi, qui tra ' morti.”

73  Listening I downward bent my countenance;
74  And one of them, not this one who was speaking,
75  Twisted himself beneath the weight that cramps him,

73  Ascoltando chinai in giù la faccia;
74  e un di lor, non questi che parlava,
75 si torse sotto il peso che li 'mpaccia,

76  And looked at me, and knew me, and called out,
77  Keeping his eyes laboriously fixed
78  On me, who all bowed down was going with them.

76  e videmi e conobbemi e chiamava,
77  tenendo li occhi con fatica fisi
78 a me che tutto chin con loro andava.

79  "O," asked I him, "art thou not Oderisi,
80  Agobbio's honour, and honour of that art
81  Which is in Paris called illuminating?"

79  “Oh!” diss'io lui, “non se' tu Oderisi,
80  l'onor d'Agobbio e l'onor di quell' arte
81 ch'alluminar chiamata è in Parisi?”

82  "Brother," said he, "more laughing are the leaves
83  Touched by the brush of Franco Bolognese;
84  All his the honour now, and mine in part.

82  “Frate,” diss' elli, “più ridon le carte
83  che pennelleggia Franco Bolognese;
84  l'onore è tutto or suo, e mio in parte.

85  In sooth I had not been so courteous
86  While I was living, for the great desire
87  Of excellence, on which my heart was bent.

85  Ben non sare' io stato sì cortese
86  mentre ch'io vissi, per lo gran disio
87  de l'eccellenza ove mio core intese.

88  Here of such pride is paid the forfeiture;
89  And yet I should not be here, were it not
90  That, having power to sin, I turned to God.

88  Di tal superbia qui si paga il fio;
89  e ancor non sarei qui, se non fosse
90  che, possendo peccar, mi volsi a Dio.

91  O thou vain glory of the human powers,
92  How little green upon thy summit lingers,
93  If't be not followed by an age of grossness!

91  Oh vana gloria de l'umane posse!
92  com' poco verde in su la cima dura,
93  se non è giunta da l'etati grosse!

94  In painting Cimabue thought that he
95  Should hold the field, now Giotto has the cry,
96  So that the other's fame is growing dim.

94  Credette Cimabue ne la pittura
95  tener lo campo, e ora ha Giotto il grido,
96  sì che la fama di colui è scura.

97  So has one Guido from the other taken
98  The glory of our tongue, and he perchance
99  Is born, who from the nest shall chase them both.

97  Così ha tolto l'uno a l'altro Guido
98  la gloria de la lingua; e forse è nato
99  chi l'uno e l'altro caccerà del nido.

100  Naught is this mundane rumour but a breath
101  Of wind, that comes now this way and now that,
102  And changes name, because it changes side.

100  Non è il mondan romore altro ch'un fiato
101 di vento, ch'or vien quinci e or vien quindi,
102 e muta nome perché muta lato.

103  What fame shalt thou have more, if old peel off
104  From thee thy flesh, than if thou hadst been dead
105  Before thou left the 'pappo' and the 'dindi,'

103  Che voce avrai tu più, se vecchia scindi
104  da te la carne, che se fossi morto
105  anzi che tu lasciassi il 'pappo' e 'l 'dindi,'

106  Ere pass a thousand years? which is a shorter
107  Space to the eterne, than twinkling of an eye
108  Unto the circle that in heaven wheels slowest.

106  pria che passin mill' anni? ch'è più corto
107  spazio a l'etterno, ch'un muover di ciglia
108  al cerchio che più tardi in cielo è torto.

109  With him, who takes so little of the road
110  In front of me, all Tuscany resounded;
111  And now he scarce is lisped of in Siena,

109  Colui che del cammin sì poco piglia
110  dinanzi a me, Toscana sonò tutta;
111  e ora a pena in Siena sen pispiglia,

112  Where he was lord, what time was overthrown
113  The Florentine delirium, that superb
114  Was at that day as now 'tis prostitute.

112  ond' era sire quando fu distrutta
113  la rabbia fiorentina, che superba
114  fu a quel tempo sì com' ora è putta.

115  Your reputation is the colour of grass
116  Which comes and goes, and that discolours it
117  By which it issues green from out the earth."

115  La vostra nominanza è color d'erba,
116  che viene e va, e quei la discolora
117  per cui ella esce de la terra acerba.”

118  And I: "Thy true speech fills my heart with good
119  Humility, and great tumour thou assuagest;
120  But who is he, of whom just now thou spakest?"

118  E io a lui: “Tuo vero dir m'incora
119  bona umiltà, e gran tumor m'appiani;
120  ma chi è quei di cui tu parlavi ora?”

121  "That," he replied, "is Provenzan Salvani,
122  And he is here because he had presumed
123  To bring Siena all into his hands.

121  “Quelli è,” rispuose, “Provenzan Salvani;
122  ed è qui perché fu presuntüoso
123  a recar Siena tutta a le sue mani.

124  He has gone thus, and goeth without rest
125  E'er since he died; such money renders back
126  In payment he who is on earth too daring."

124  Ito è così e va, sanza riposo,
125  poi che morì; cotal moneta rende
126  a sodisfar chi è di là troppo oso.”

127  And I: "If every spirit who awaits
128  The verge of life before that he repent,
129  Remains below there and ascends not hither,

127  E io: “Se quello spirito ch'attende,
128  pria che si penta, l'orlo de la vita,
129 qua giù dimora e qua sù non ascende,

130  (Unless good orison shall him bestead,)
131  Until as much time as he lived be passed,
132  How was the coming granted him in largess?"

130  se buona orazïon lui non aita,
131  prima che passi tempo quanto visse,
132  come fu la venuta lui largita?”

133  "When he in greatest splendour lived," said he,
134  "Freely upon the Campo of Siena,
135  All shame being laid aside, he placed himself;

133  “Quando vivea più glorïoso,” disse,
134  “liberamente nel Campo di Siena,
135  ogne vergogna diposta, s'affisse;

136  And there to draw his friend from the duress
137  Which in the prison-house of Charles he suffered,
138  He brought himself to tremble in each vein.

136  e lì, per trar l'amico suo di pena,
137  ch'e' sostenea ne la prigion di Carlo,
138  si condusse a tremar per ogne vena.

139  I say no more, and know that I speak darkly;
140  Yet little time shall pass before thy neighbours
141  Will so demean themselves that thou canst gloss it.

139  Più non dirò, e scuro so che parlo;
140  ma poco tempo andrà, che ' tuoi vicini
141  faranno sì che tu potrai chiosarlo.

142  This action has released him from those confines."

142  Quest' opera li tolse quei confini.”

Canto XII
A name is an address, an indexes, not a chiseled substitute for an identity fit only for a gravestone (which we have in this canto).  It is a homing signal only for certain libraries of experience and knowledge, and to yoke it to pride is to be a the lowliest kind of slave, an ox, burdened to perform laborious functions which in no way benefits your soul.  The weight of pride only arrogates and obscures the true function of a name.  The entities in these canto are quite careful to only tangentially refer to themselves through their position or family or by their position in this line of penitents.  And just as Dante, without knowing it, is erasing the tattoo on his forehead, which stands for, and is, the sin of pride, these penitents also, by a process of exhaustive erosion, are erasing the arrogance which brought them fame and also death.  Dante is working with negative exemplars here, the presence of pride, which should be absent, but is instead immortalized in stone, with an acrostic of pride, i.e. MAN, which includes 12 negative exemplars, that start with Lucifer (a periphrasis, he is unnamed) and concludes with the destruction of Troy.  The list ends, as only such a negative list could end, with a display of irony.  Because irony invokes an absence with its presence.  

All this done, Dante, the aspirant and prideful penitent, meets the angel, who apostrophizes all sinners — because it is a kind of original sin to have assigned to the ego function what properly belongs to the soul, and here, at a cleft in the rock — an absence which needs to be present — Dante has his first sin, the tattoo on his brow, removed.  Immediately his former fatigue, which has plagued him terribly throughout his climb, is expelled.  He becomes light, and he hears the music of the Beatitude (Blessed are the poor in spirit, i.e., the humble).  He is exhilarated, and Virgil smiles, because, as in the game of Indian poker, Virgil can see what is missing, and through the smile, and his own sense of lightness, Dante comes to know what is unstated, humility, with what has been effaced, Pride.

This whole canto is a tour de force of this game of absence and presence, with the emphasis, or rather the de-emphasis on humility, but humility as seen through negative exemplars of pride.  It would improper, and far from humble, for this virtue to call attention to itself.

An epidemic of over excitation always accompanies any deep reading of Dante. If it doesn’t dazzle and confound you with its brambling overgrowth of resonances, you haven’t fully committed yourself to your responsibilities as a reader.  The acrostic and the six pairs of pride exemplars which comprise the central pillar of this canto are cases in point.  But before we delve into the content of our reading, we have to consider the manner of our reading.  We are reading at a slow, walking pace, looking down at our own steps as they traverse not letters but images carved in gravestones.  How somber and how contemplative!  (Remember how both McLuhan and Benjamin told us how the content of our experience changes according to medium and our posture.  Words lying flat on a table in a book are not perceived in the same way as those same arrangements of letters seen raised gigantically above on a billboard or read on the tiny lit screen of a cell phone.). Bearing that circumstance in mind, we can now point out at least some cursory correspondences underlying these twelve exemplars.

The 12 arer arranged in 6 pairs and summarized by a 13th observation, not part of them, but implied in the twelve.  Think of the paired team of oxen metaphor beginning this canto.  Each pairing has a Biblical node and a pagan node linked by some commonality.  Imagine two termination points, a string vibrating with resonance flowing between them.  

The first pairing is that of Satan, unnamed, but referred to, and his is the Biblical node, the pagan node is that of Briareus, a giant who was mentioned, but not met, in the Inferno.  (Again absence and presence linked).  They are connected by the thunderbolt of lightning which defeated them.  There is also a pairing of opposites from the heat of lightning to the chill of death (mortal frost, line 30).  We think of hot fire, cold ashes, and also Satan frozen at the nadir of Hell.

Pairing two's pagan node are unnamed.  They are the Titans, whom Jove and his triumvirate of children, Apollo (Tymbaeus), Pallas Athena and Mars, brought to ruin.  The children of Jove are seen gazing  down (as we readers are gazing down) on the scattered members of the defeated giants, all brought low by Jove's thunderbolt, all exemplars of defeated pride.  The Biblical node is Nimrod, the vain builder of the tower of Babel, around him lie the titanic fragments of his arrogant assay.    

Pairing three is Niobe, as the pagan node, and Saul, and as the Biblical node.  Niobe's boasting of her children (7 sons, 7 daughters) has led to their murder by arrow by the 2 children of Latona, Apollo and Diana.  Niobe is turned into weeping stone, a clear correspondence between a stone that weeps, and the stones that Dante is walking on and reading as stones that cause weeping.  Niobe's tears become mountain springs.  (The numbers 7, and 2 are also important here.)  The pagan node here is Saul, who fled wounded after a battle with the Philistines, and committed suicide in the mountains of Samaria.  David curses the place, and thereafter these mountains become forever dry (think of the dry rocks in Eliot's the Wasteland).  The two are linked by dialectical opposites, Niobe as an overabundance of tears (water) and Saul's grave a waterless desert.  Both allude to rocky, mountainous places.

Pairing four is of Arachne, the pagan, and Rehoboam, the Biblical node.  Arachne is a braggart who attempts of hang herself, but is turned into a spider by Minerva.  Arachne could be said to be the artist whose arrogant ego over identifies with her work.  She becomes her work, in a kind cowardly failed suicide, succumbing to the jealously of divine inspiration.  Rehoboam was the son of Solomon.  His name, according to Charles Fillmore’s dictionary of Biblical names and places means one who dissipates himself with sensory profligacy.  Both a fool and a coward, he flees, where none give chase, the victim, like Arachne, of his own illusions and pretensions.

The fifth pairing is that of Eriphyle (pagan) and Sennacherib (Biblical).  Both victims of vanity, the child of pride, and both murdered by their own sons.

The last and sixth pairing is that of Cyrus the Elder as the pagan node and Holofernes as the Biblical one.  Both of these men were beheaded by women, Cyrus by the queen of his enemies, who placed his head in a jar of human blood.  (The head speaks, and these words of Dante's are attributed to this disembodied head, which links the poet himself to the sin of pride, for which this remote reference is a kind of echo of an otherwise absent confession).   Holofernes was beheaded by Judith.  Anachronistically we could compare this pairing to the anima/animus psychological archetypes of Jung.  Here the Anima chops off the overly aggressive head of the Animus.  Humility defeating pride as faith defeats reason.   

The 13th, the summary, is that the proud Towers of Troy, reduced to ashes and fragments, provide a link back to the destruction of the Satan and Briareus in the first pairing and also to Virgil as his Aeneas persona.  Aeneas is a fragment of Troy, who like the eye of a sliced up potato, sprouts Rome, the seat of St. Peter (stone), vicar of Christ.  Rome is also the new Jerusalem of the Christian world and also the former capitol of the pagan world.

This entire section contains the acrostic "Man" (Umo), each letter repeated 4 times in the acrostic where the U (Christian, Vulgate, Tuscan U) is replaced the Roman V, which is how the pagans carved the letter U in stone.   This acrostic was either unseen or uncommented upon for about 6 centuries, which suggests that it was not meant for any but the most attentive of readers or the eyes of God.  Note: whether people like it or not, cryptography is a thing throughout the Commedia, and it is clearly deliberate.

There is no way that I could elucidate all of the numerological correspondences here, but I think we must acknowledge throughout this work that Dante was a product of the Trivium (grammar, logic, rhetoric) and Quadrivium (arithmetic, astronomy, music, geometry) curriculums of medieval education.  We should therefore be on the alert for the intertwining of these disciplines in his work.  There is a curious geometrical phenomenon called "kissing numbers" or "Newton numbers" relating the number 1 to the number 12 (total 13).  If one places 12 identical spheres in a configuration wherein each sphere is in contact with as many other spheres as is possible, there is space for an identical 13th sphere at the center of the configuration: an absent presence, or present absence — take your pick.  Did Dante know about this?  I think he did.  And I think he was also aware of the 1/12 significance in music.  But even if he did not know about it, he still at least unconsciously expressed it, and as readers armed with this insight, we can see how such a correspondence helps to harmonize the amazing structure of the entire Commedia.       

1  Abreast, like oxen going in a yoke,
2  I with that heavy-laden soul went on,
3  As long as the sweet pedagogue permitted;

1  Di pari, come buoi che vanno a giogo,
2  m'andava io con quell' anima carca,
3  fin che 'l sofferse il dolce pedagogo.

4  But when he said, "Leave him, and onward pass,
5  For here 'tis good that with the sail and oars,
6  As much as may be, each push on his barque;"

4  Ma quando disse: “Lascia lui e varca;
5  ché qui è buono con l'ali e coi remi,
6  quantunque può, ciascun pinger sua barca”;

7  Upright, as walking wills it, I redressed
8  My person, notwithstanding that my thoughts
9  Remained within me downcast and abashed.

7  dritto sì come andar vuolsi rife'mi
8  con la persona, avvegna che i pensieri
9  mi rimanessero e chinati e scemi.

10  I had moved on, and followed willingly
11  The footsteps of my Master, and we both
12  Already showed how light of foot we were,

10  Io m'era mosso, e seguia volontieri
11  del mio maestro i passi, e amendue
12  già mostravam com' eravam leggeri;

13  When unto me he said: "Cast down thine eyes;
14  'Twere well for thee, to alleviate the way,
15  To look upon the bed beneath thy feet."

13  ed el mi disse: “Volgi li occhi in giùe:
14  buon ti sarà, per tranquillar la via,
15  veder lo letto de le piante tue.”

16  As, that some memory may exist of them,
17  Above the buried dead their tombs in earth
18  Bear sculptured on them what they were before;

16  Come, perché di lor memoria sia,
17  sovra i sepolti le tombe terragne
18  portan segnato quel ch'elli eran pria,

19  Whence often there we weep for them afresh,
20  From pricking of remembrance, which alone
21  To the compassionate doth set its spur;

19  onde lì molte volte si ripiagne
20  per la puntura de la rimembranza,
21  che solo a' pïi dà de le calcagne;

22  So saw I there, but of a better semblance
23  In point of artifice, with figures covered
24  Whate'er as pathway from the mount projects.

22  sì vid' io lì, ma di miglior sembianza
23  secondo l'artificio, figurato
24  quanto per via di fuor del monte avanza.

25  I saw that one who was created noble
26  More than all other creatures, down from heaven
27  Flaming with lightnings fall upon one side.

25  Vedea colui che fu nobil creato
26  più ch'altra creatura, giù dal cielo
27  folgoreggiando scender, da l'un lato.

28  I saw Briareus smitten by the dart
29  Celestial, lying on the other side,
30  Heavy upon the earth by mortal frost.

28  Vedëa Brïareo fitto dal telo
29  celestïal giacer, da l'altra parte,
30  grave a la terra per lo mortal gelo.

31  I saw Thymbraeus, Pallas saw, and Mars,
32  Still clad in armour round about their father,
33  Gaze at the scattered members of the giants.

31  Vedea Timbreo, vedea Pallade e Marte,
32  armati ancora, intorno al padre loro,
33  mirar le membra d'i Giganti sparte.

34  I saw, at foot of his great labour, Nimrod,
35  As if bewildered, looking at the people
36  Who had been proud with him in Sennaar.

34  Vedea Nembròt a piè del gran lavoro
35  quasi smarrito, e riguardar le genti
36  che 'n Sennaàr con lui superbi fuoro.

37  O Niobe! with what afflicted eyes
38  Thee I beheld upon the pathway traced,
39  Between thy seven and seven children slain!

37  O Nïobè, con che occhi dolenti
38  vedea io te segnata in su la strada,
39  tra sette e sette tuoi figliuoli spenti!

40  O Saul! how fallen upon thy proper sword
41  Didst thou appear there lifeless in Gilboa,
42  That felt thereafter neither rain nor dew!

40  O Saùl, come in su la propria spada
41  quivi parevi morto in Gelboè,
42  che poi non sentì pioggia né rugiada!

43  O mad Arachne! so I thee beheld
44  E'en then half spider, sad upon the shreds
45  Of fabric wrought in evil hour for thee!

43  O folle Aragne, sì vedea io te
44  già mezza ragna, trista in su li stracci
45  de l'opera che mal per te si fé.

46  O Rehoboam! no more seems to threaten
47  Thine image there; but full of consternation
48  A chariot bears it off, when none pursues!

46  O Roboàm, già non par che minacci
47  quivi 'l tuo segno; ma pien di spavento
48  nel porta un carro, sanza ch'altri il cacci.

49  Displayed moreo'er the adamantine pavement
50  How unto his own mother made Alcmaeon
51  Costly appear the luckless ornament;

49  Mostrava ancor lo duro pavimento
50  come Almeon a sua madre fé caro
51  parer lo sventurato addornamento.

52  Displayed how his own sons did throw themselves
53  Upon Sennacherib within the temple,
54  And how, he being dead, they left him there;

52  Mostrava come i figli si gittaro
53  sovra Sennacherìb dentro dal tempio,
54  e come, morto lui, quivi il lasciaro.

55  Displayed the ruin and the cruel carnage
56  That Tomyris wrought, when she to Cyrus said,
57  "Blood didst thou thirst for, and with blood I glut thee!"

55  Mostrava la ruina e 'l crudo scempio
56  che fé Tamiri, quando disse a Ciro:
57  “Sangue sitisti, e io di sangue t'empio.”

58  Displayed how routed fled the Assyrians
59  After that Holofernes had been slain,
60  And likewise the remainder of that slaughter.

58  Mostrava come in rotta si fuggiro
59  li Assiri, poi che fu morto Oloferne,
60  e anche le reliquie del martiro.

61  I saw there Troy in ashes and in caverns;
62  O Ilion! thee, how abject and debased,
63  Displayed the image that is there discerned!

61  Vedeva Troia in cenere e in caverne;
62  o Ilïón, come te basso e vile
63  mostrava il segno che lì si discerne!

64  Whoe'er of pencil master was or stile,
65  That could portray the shades and traits which there
66  Would cause each subtile genius to admire?

64  Qual di pennel fu maestro o di stile
65  che ritraesse l'ombre e ' tratti ch'ivi
66  mirar farieno uno ingegno sottile?

67  Dead seemed the dead, the living seemed alive;
68  Better than I saw not who saw the truth,
69  All that I trod upon while bowed I went.

67  Morti li morti e i vivi parean vivi:
68  non vide mei di me chi vide il vero,
69  quant' io calcai, fin che chinato givi.

70  Now wax ye proud, and on with looks uplifted,
71  Ye sons of Eve, and bow not down your faces
72  So that ye may behold your evil ways!

70  Or superbite, e via col viso altero,
71  figliuoli d'Eva, e non chinate il volto
72  sì che veggiate il vostro mal sentero!

73  More of the mount by us was now encompassed,
74  And far more spent the circuit of the sun,
75  Than had the mind preoccupied imagined,

73  Più era già per noi del monte vòlto
74  e del cammin del sole assai più speso
75  che non stimava l'animo non sciolto,

76  When he, who ever watchful in advance
77  Was going on, began: "Lift up thy head,
78  'Tis no more time to go thus meditating.

76  quando colui che sempre innanzi atteso
77  andava, cominciò: “Drizza la testa;
78  non è più tempo di gir sì sospeso.

79  Lo there an Angel who is making haste
80  To come towards us; lo, returning is
81  From service of the day the sixth handmaiden. 

79  Vedi colà un angel che s'appresta
80  per venir verso noi; vedi che torna
81  dal servigio del dì l'ancella sesta.

82  With reverence thine acts and looks adorn,
83  So that he may delight to speed us upward;
84  Think that this day will never dawn again."

82  Di reverenza il viso e li atti addorna,
83  sì che i diletti lo 'nvïarci in suso;
84  pensa che questo dì mai non raggiorna!”

85  I was familiar with his admonition
86  Ever to lose no time; so on this theme
87  He could not unto me speak covertly.

85  Io era ben del suo ammonir uso
86  pur di non perder tempo, sì che 'n quella
87  materia non potea parlarmi chiuso.

88  Towards us came the being beautiful
89  Vested in white, and in his countenance
90  Such as appears the tremulous morning star.

88  A noi venìa la creatura bella,
89  biancovestito e ne la faccia quale
90  par tremolando mattutina stella.

91  His arms he opened, and opened then his wings;
92  "Come," said he, "near at hand here are the steps,
93  And easy from henceforth is the ascent."

91  Le braccia aperse, e indi aperse l'ale;
92  disse: “Venite: qui son presso i gradi,
93  e agevolemente omai si sale.

94  At this announcement few are they who come!
95  O human creatures, born to soar aloft,
96  Why fall ye thus before a little wind?

94  A questo invito vegnon molto radi:
95  o gente umana, per volar sù nata,
96  perché a poco vento così cadi?”

97  He led us on to where the rock was cleft;
98  There smote upon my forehead with his wings,
99  Then a safe passage promised unto me.

97  Menocci ove la roccia era tagliata;
98  quivi mi batté l'ali per la fronte;
99  poi mi promise sicura l'andata.

100  As on the right hand, to ascend the mount
101  Where seated is the church that lordeth it
102  O'er the well-guided, above Rubaconte,

100  Come a man destra, per salire al monte
101  dove siede la chiesa che soggioga
102  la ben guidata sopra Rubaconte,

103  The bold abruptness of the ascent is broken
104  By stairways that were made there in the age
105  When still were safe the ledger and the stave,

103  si rompe del montar l'ardita foga
104  per le scalee che si fero ad etade
105  ch'era sicuro il quaderno e la doga;

106  E'en thus attempered is the bank which falls
107  Sheer downward from the second circle there;
108  But on this, side and that the high rock graze.

106  così s'allenta la ripa che cade
107  quivi ben ratta da l'altro girone;
108  ma quinci e quindi l'alta pietra rade.

109  As we were turning thitherward our persons,
110  "Beati pauperes spiritu," voices
111  Sang in such wise that speech could tell it not.

109  Noi volgendo ivi le nostre persone
110  “Beati pauperes spiritu!” voci
111  cantaron sì, che nol diria sermone.

112  Ah me! how different are these entrances
113  From the Infernal! for with anthems here
114  One enters, and below with wild laments.

112  Ahi quanto son diverse quelle foci
113  da l'infernali! ché quivi per canti
114  s'entra, e là giù per lamenti feroci.

115  We now were hunting up the sacred stairs,
116  And it appeared to me by far more easy
117  Than on the plain it had appeared before.

115  Già montavam su per li scaglion santi,
116  ed esser mi parea troppo più lieve
117  che per lo pian non mi parea davanti.

118  Whence I: "My Master, say, what heavy thing
119  Has been uplifted from me, so that hardly
120  Aught of fatigue is felt by me in walking?"

118  Ond' io: “Maestro, dì, qual cosa greve
119  levata s'è da me, che nulla quasi
120  per me fatica, andando, si riceve?”

121  He answered: "When the P's which have remained
122  Still on thy face almost obliterate
123  Shall wholly, as the first is, be erased,

121  Rispuose: “Quando i P che son rimasi
122  ancor nel volto tuo presso che stinti,
123  saranno, com' è l'un, del tutto rasi,

124  Thy feet will be so vanquished by good will,
125  That not alone they shall not feel fatigue,
126  But urging up will be to them delight."

124  fier li tuoi piè dal buon voler sì vinti,
125  che non pur non fatica sentiranno,
126  ma fia diletto loro esser sù pinti.”

127  Then did I even as they do who are going
128  With something on the head to them unknown,
129  Unless the signs of others make them doubt,

127  Allor fec' io come color che vanno
128  con cosa in capo non da lor saputa,
129  se non che ' cenni altrui sospecciar fanno;

130  Wherefore the hand to ascertain is helpful,
131  And seeks and finds, and doth fulfill the office
132  Which cannot be accomplished by the sight;

130  per che la mano ad accertar s'aiuta,
131  e cerca e truova e quello officio adempie
132  che non si può fornir per la veduta;

133  And with the fingers of the right hand spread
134  I found but six the letters, that had carved
134  Upon my temples he who bore the keys;

133  e con le dita de la destra scempie
134  trovai pur sei le lettere che 'ncise
135  quel da le chiavi a me sovra le tempie:

135  Upon beholding which my Leader smiled.

136  a che guardando, il mio duca sorrise.

Canto XIII
With each successive canto, the reader is confronted with a kind of all or nothing bet.  After having come so far, it would be easy to allow one’s self to adopt a mechanical procedure and just keep following the template that Dante has so expertly constructed without submitting oneself to the gravity of its moral implications at all. It is almost as if one is praying to be released from the odious task of self-examination, and whispering ‘Just let me continue this as an interesting intellectual exercise, and turn off this poem's pitiless, relentless light, which exposes every canker of my conscience."  Of course, these are just the kinds of things one should not do.  This text demands a sacrifice, the sacred gift of the total self, flaws and all, before it can work its transcendent power.  

Dante and Virgil have reached the summit of another stair, and although they travel on a mountain with a known conical shape, they appear to be rudderless, lost.  Lost in what way?  Surely not lost in the geographical sense: keep right, keep climbing, that's all the directions in that sense that they will ever need.  How then are they lost?  They are left to their own devices, here is what appears to be an uninhabited landscape, and as reader we realize that as far as the geography of the soul goes, it cannot be discovered without an incursion from powers concomitant with itself.  If the soul does not recognize its position in the domain of spirit, it is lost, lost in a dry and empty meditation.  The feet are able to move, but the force that motivates them is withdrawn.  Virgil here shows a bit of panic.  Why panic?  Because he senses that he and his charge are also traversing a temporal landscape, they cannot afford to waste time or the spirit will not make that spiritual rendezvous which (or rather who) promises fulfillment.  Virgil, a pagan, turns to the sun, and Dante, the poet, is pretty clear that in so doing, his teacher has reverted to an almost plant-like condition, following the only source he knows for spiritual guidance.  I find this sad.  There is a parody here of the gospels, Matthew 5:45: That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven; for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the good — and Virgil has missed the allegory and taken the sun for the spirit animating the sun.  His miss is good as a mile.  He fears that they do not have the time to wait for people, i.e., entities, souls to guide them, and he does all he knows to do: follow the light.  Not a bad guess, but not a guess, I think, that could ever lead to transcendence.  And yet, his effort is rewarded.  As the protagonists proceed they hear disembodied voices rushing by them.

Mary's words at the wedding of Canaan.  "They have no wine."  The pagan voice of Pylades, saying "I am Orestes," attempting to take the blame and the punishment for his friend.  And after this, just when the aspirant asks: What voices are these?  The voice of Jesus, the one voice that Virgil did not recognize in his life, and should not be able to identify here, says (line 36): “Amate da cui male aveste.”  (Love those who've done you evil.).  Here, we are blind, but here we hear, i.e., we have ears to hear, and these words do what the sunlight could not do.  They open our eyes.  They invite us to a wedding, a marriage of souls, in an ensouled world.  The invitation and Dante's question reawaken Virgil to his role as teacher and guide, and he says a curious, self-contradicting thing: That the scourge of punishment here is drawn from love.  Here we meet souls who are so insubstantial that they almost merge into the background — shades, who not only cannot see, but are themselves difficult to see.  They and the landscape that has swallowed them are the color of a bruise.  Wearing sackcloth, their smallest movement, lacerates, irritates, and calls them to remembrance of their sin.  They must move en masse, the blind literally leading the blind, their eyes sewn shut, but not so tightly that their tears do not find agonizing passage through the sutures.  The text compares them to wild falcons, whose rapacious nature cannot be tamed unless they are blinded, because everything they see reflexively lures them to attack.  That which we see here, however, could never be anything to incite our envy, and, unlike those punished in hell, their fate does not provoke our scorn, but rather our pity — our piety.  Now, other cries arise: "Mary pray for us," and then comes a litany of saints.  The manna of prayer, which has been the insistent prescription for pain throughout the Purgatorio, spontaneously sounds here, the very stones seeming to cry out, just as Jesus promised that they would.  The first words that Dante addresses to these spirits are literally enlightening, for he reminds them of their salvation, reminds them that they have been chosen to be among the illuminated, and that it is only a continuing snare of temporality which has tricked them into believing they are blind.  What a revelation!  Their eyes are blind but the sole care of their faith is light!  Is it possible that even in this piteous condition, blind, stone-like, helpless, tortured in sackcloth, that they are actually following that inner sun which Virgil mistook in the outer?  (There is a little masterful aside here — lines 79 - 84 — wherein Dante, the aspirant, places himself between the wall of the mountain that almost completely camouflages the penitents, and Virgil, reasonable, pagan, beloved Virgil, who is there to protect his charge from tumbling into the void.  It makes me think of the Blakean maxim: " ... reason is the bound or outward circumference of energy ... " ).

Now we come to certain expressions in the text which tell us that we have indeed experienced a moral elevation, that the spirits here, although suffering purgation for their own personal transgressions, now have experienced a broadening of perspective, vis à vis the question: Who am I?  When Dante asks in versus 91-93 if there be any shades in this place who are Latina, his whole question being referential to himself, his condition, his dwelling place on earth, a voice corrects him.  This is a female voice, a shift that foreshadows the females that yet dwell above the aspirant on his ascent, and recalls both the original intervention of Beatrice through Saint Lucy that began his journey, and also the voice of Mary at the beginning of this canto, when she, from concern for the wedding party, informs her son: "They have no wine."  Here, this shade corrects Dante by telling him that those on Earth who identify themselves with a specific city, country, language or lineage are mistaken.  All are in fact are but pilgrims, wandering exiles in the physical domain.   In truth, all are united as the citizens of the New Jerusalem in heaven or in the seat of Peter, Rome, the earthly Jerusalem.  A momentous shift in the placement of identity has occurred, and it is against this background that this shade, Sapia, a lady from Siena, tells a story that illustrates the madness which manifests when a person feels an exile while yet living in their own country.  Sapia, who points out that her name ironically means "wisdom," is the exemplar of this folly.  In a distasteful act of Schadenfreude she exalts when she sees her countrymen defeated in battle, the sight of their smoking corpses and ignominious route bringing her what is literally referred to as a kind of birdbrained squawk of joy.  One ray of false spring sunshine convincing her that her personal winter has ended, and she need not fear anything of God's or anyone else's disfavor.  This is the nadir of her fall, because the comb-seller, Peter, a local Sienese saint, prays for her, and reverses her downward trajectory, his prayer opening her inner eyes to her blindness.  From Virgil's prayer to the sun, to the unseen, disembodied voices, to the difficulty of even seeing the blind penitents who blend into the livid landscape, this entire canto is a flickering play of seeing, not seeing, light and blindness.  And this flickering quality continues to the very last verses, wherein Sapia tells of the folly of her countrymen seeking to swell their power and importance by giving landlocked Siena a seaport, and by fruitlessly seeking a non-existent underground river beneath their city.  Are Sapia's last words ironic, an unpurged example of her envy?  Or does she now have genuine concern for the spiritual life of her countrymen?  A moment before she has demonstrated her unselfishness by expressing true delight in Dante's blessedness, and then immediately following she refers to the vanity of her countrymen.  The shift in tone is a rapid flickering.  Has she suddenly changed from magnanimous to carping?  The answer to this question depends entirely upon the tone by which the reader imagines how her words are spoken.  In brief, by how much the reader's own envious nature has been purged.  This brings us to an obvious but often overlooked truth.  That is, the interpretation, the reading, of any text depends upon the spiritual condition of its reader, and this is most apparent when one hears the interpretation of scripture, the same verses suggesting such things as vengeance, murder, and the justification for slavery and exclusion to some, yet forgiveness, salvation, freedom, and inclusion to others.  In every text, we only read ourselves.       

1  We were upon the summit of the stairs,
2  Where for the second time is cut away
3  The mountain, which ascending shriveth all.

1  Noi eravamo al sommo de la scala,
2  dove secondamente si risega
3  lo monte che salendo altrui dismala.

4  There in like manner doth a cornice bind
5  The hill all round about, as does the first,
6  Save that its arc more suddenly is curved.

4  Ivi così una cornice lega
5  dintorno il poggio, come la primaia;
6  se non che l'arco suo più tosto piega.

7  Shade is there none, nor sculpture that appears;
8  So seems the bank, and so the road seems smooth,
9  With but the livid colour of the stone.

7  Ombra non lì è né segno che si paia:
8  parsi la ripa e parsi la via schietta
9  col livido color de la petraia.

10  "If to inquire we wait for people here,"
11  The Poet said, "I fear that peradventure
12  Too much delay will our election have."

10  “Se qui per dimandar gente s'aspetta,”
11  ragionava il poeta, “io temo forse
12  che troppo avrà d'indugio nostra eletta.”

13  Then steadfast on the sun his eyes he fixed,
14  Made his right side the centre of his motion,
15  And turned the left part of himself about.

13  Poi fisamente al sole li occhi porse;
14  fece del destro lato a muover centro,
15  e la sinistra parte di sé torse.

16  "O thou sweet light! with trust in whom I enter
17  Upon this novel journey, do thou lead us,"
18  Said he, "as one within here should be led.

16  “O dolce lume a cui fidanza i' entro
17  per lo novo cammin, tu ne conduci,”
18  dicea, “come condur si vuol quinc' entro.

19  Thou warmest the world, thou shinest over it;
20  If other reason prompt not otherwise,
21  Thy rays should evermore our leaders be!"

19  Tu scaldi il mondo, tu sovr' esso luci;
20  s'altra ragione in contrario non ponta,
21  esser dien sempre li tuoi raggi duci.”

22  As much as here is counted for a mile,
23  So much already there had we advanced
24  In little time, by dint of ready will;

22  Quanto di qua per un migliaio si conta,
23  tanto di là eravam noi già iti,
24  con poco tempo, per la voglia pronta;

25  And tow'rds us there were heard to fly, albeit
26  They were not visible, spirits uttering
27  Unto Love's table courteous invitations,

25  e verso noi volar furon sentiti,
26  non però visti, spiriti parlando
27  a la mensa d'amor cortesi inviti.

28  The first voice that passed onward in its flight,
29  "Vinum non habent," said in accents loud,
30  And went reiterating it behind us.

28  La prima voce che passò volando
29  “Vinum non habent” altamente disse,
30  e dietro a noi l'andò reïterando.

31  And ere it wholly grew inaudible
32  Because of distance, passed another, crying,
33  "I am Orestes!" and it also stayed not.

31  E prima che del tutto non si udisse
32  per allungarsi, un'altra “I' sono Oreste”
33  passò gridando, e anco non s'affisse.

34  "O," said I, "Father, these, what voices are they?"
35   And even as I asked, behold the third,
36  Saying: "Love those from whom ye have had evil!"

34  “Oh!” diss' io, “padre, che voci son queste?”
35  E com' io domandai, ecco la terza
36  dicendo: “Amate da cui male aveste.”

37  And the good Master said: "This circle scourges
38  The sin of envy, and on that account
39  Are drawn from love the lashes of the scourge.

37  E 'l buon maestro: “Questo cinghio sferza
38  la colpa de la invidia, e però sono
39  tratte d'amor le corde de la ferza.

40  The bridle of another sound shall be;
41  I think that thou wilt hear it, as I judge,
42  Before thou comest to the Pass of Pardon.

40  Lo fren vuol esser del contrario suono;
41  credo che l'udirai, per mio avviso,
42  prima che giunghi al passo del perdono.

43  But fix thine eyes athwart the air right steadfast,
44  And people thou wilt see before us sitting,
45  And each one close against the cliff is seated."

43  Ma ficca li occhi per l'aere ben fiso,
44  e vedrai gente innanzi a noi sedersi,
45  e ciascun è lungo la grotta assiso.”

46  Then wider than at first mine eyes I opened;
47  I looked before me, and saw shades with mantles
48   Not from the colour of the stone diverse.

46  Allora più che prima li occhi apersi;
47  guarda'mi innanzi, e vidi ombre con manti
48  al color de la pietra non diversi.

49  And when we were a little farther onward,
50  I heard a cry of, "Mary, pray for us!"
51  A cry of, "Michael, Peter, and all Saints!"

49  E poi che fummo un poco più avanti,
50  udia gridar: “Maria òra per noi”:
51  gridar “Michele” e “Pietro” e “Tutti santi.”

52  I do not think there walketh still on earth
53  A man so hard, that he would not be pierced
54  With pity at what afterward I saw.

52  Non credo che per terra vada ancoi
53  omo sì duro, che non fosse punto
54  per compassion di quel ch'i' vidi poi;

55  For when I had approached so near to them
56  That manifest to me their acts became,
57  Drained was I at the eyes by heavy grief.

55  ché, quando fui sì presso di lor giunto,
56  che li atti loro a me venivan certi,
57  per li occhi fui di grave dolor munto.

58  Covered with sackcloth vile they seemed to me,
59  And one sustained the other with his shoulder,
60  And all of them were by the bank sustained.

58  Di vil ciliccio mi parean coperti,
59  e l'un sofferia l'altro con la spalla,
60  e tutti da la ripa eran sofferti.

61  Thus do the blind, in want of livelihood,
62  Stand at the doors of churches asking alms,
63  And one upon another leans his head,

61  Così li ciechi a cui la roba falla,
62  stanno a' perdoni a chieder lor bisogna,
63  e l'uno il capo sopra l'altro avvalla,

64  So that in others pity soon may rise,
65  Not only at the accent of their words,
66  But at their aspect, which no less implores.

64  perché 'n altrui pietà tosto si pogna,
65  non pur per lo sonar de le parole,
66  ma per la vista che non meno agogna.

67  And as unto the blind the sun comes not,
68  So to the shades, of whom just now I spake,
69  Heaven's light will not be bounteous of itself;

67  E come a li orbi non approda il sole,
68  così a l'ombre quivi, ond' io parlo ora,
69  luce del ciel di sé largir non vole;

70  For all their lids an iron wire transpierces,
71  And sews them up, as to a sparhawk wild
72  Is done, because it will not quiet stay.

70  ché a tutti un fil di ferro i cigli fóra
71  e cusce sì, come a sparvier selvaggio
72  si fa però che queto non dimora.

73  To me it seemed, in passing, to do outrage,
74  Seeing the others without being seen;
75  Wherefore I turned me to my counsel sage.

73  A me pareva, andando, fare oltraggio,
74  veggendo altrui, non essendo veduto:
75  per ch'io mi volsi al mio consiglio saggio.

76  Well knew he what the mute one wished to say,
77  And therefore waited not for my demand,
78  But said: "Speak, and be brief, and to the point."

76  Ben sapev' ei che volea dir lo muto;
77  e però non attese mia dimanda,
78  ma disse: “Parla, e sie breve e arguto.”

79  I had Virgilius upon that side
80  Of the embankment from which one may fall,
81  Since by no border 'tis engarlanded;

79  Virgilio mi venìa da quella banda
80  de la cornice onde cader si puote,
81  perché da nulla sponda s'inghirlanda;

82  Upon the other side of me I had
83  The shades devout, who through the horrible seam
84  Pressed out the tears so that they bathed their cheeks.

82  da l'altra parte m'eran le divote
83  ombre, che per l'orribile costura
84  premevan sì, che bagnavan le gote.

85  To them I turned me, and, "O people, certain,"
86  Began I, "of beholding the high light,
87  Which your desire has solely in its care,

85  Volsimi a loro e: “O gente sicura,”
86  incominciai, “di veder l'alto lume
87   che 'l disio vostro solo ha in sua cura,

88  So may grace speedily dissolve the scum
89  Upon your consciences, that limpidly
90  Through them descend the river of the mind,

88  se tosto grazia resolva le schiume
89  di vostra coscïenza sì che chiaro
90  per essa scenda de la mente il fiume,

91  Tell me, for dear 'twill be to me and gracious,
92  If any soul among you here is Latian,
93  And 'twill perchance be good for him I learn it."

91  ditemi, ché mi fia grazioso e caro,
92  s'anima è qui tra voi che sia latina;
93  e forse lei sarà buon s'i' l'apparo.”

94  "O brother mine, each one is citizen
95  Of one true city; but thy meaning is,
96  Who may have lived in Italy a pilgrim."

94  “O frate mio, ciascuna è cittadina
95  d'una vera città; ma tu vuo' dire
96  che vivesse in Italia peregrina.”

97  By way of answer this I seemed to hear
98  A little farther on than where I stood,
99  Whereat I made myself still nearer heard.

97  Questo mi parve per risposta udire
98  più innanzi alquanto che là dov' io stava,
99  ond' io mi feci ancor più là sentire.
100  Among the rest I saw a shade that waited
101  In aspect, and should any one ask how,
102  Its chin it lifted upward like a blind man.
100  Tra l'altre vidi un'ombra ch'aspettava
101  in vista; e se volesse alcun dir “Come?”
102  lo mento a guisa d'orbo in sù levava.
103  "Spirit," I said, "who stoopest to ascend,
104  If thou art he who did reply to me,
105  Make thyself known to me by place or name."
103  “Spirto,” diss' io, “che per salir ti dome,
104  se tu se' quelli che mi rispondesti,
105  fammiti conto o per luogo o per nome.”
106  "Sienese was I," it replied, "and with
107  The others here recleanse my guilty life,
108  Weeping to Him to lend himself to us.
106  “Io fui sanese,” rispuose, “e con questi
107  altri rimendo qui la vita ria,
108  lagrimando a colui che sé ne presti.
109  Sapient I was not, although I Sapia
110  Was called, and I was at another's harm
111  More happy far than at my own good fortune.
109  Savia non fui, avvegna che Sapìa
110  fossi chiamata, e fui de li altrui danni
111  più lieta assai che di ventura mia.
112  And that thou mayst not think that I deceive thee,
113  Hear if I was as foolish as I tell thee.
114  The arc already of my years descending,
112  E perché tu non creda ch'io t'inganni,
113  odi s'i' fui, com' io ti dico, folle,
114  già discendendo l'arco d'i miei anni.
115  My fellow-citizens near unto Colle
116  Were joined in battle with their adversaries,
117  And I was praying God for what he willed.
115  Eran li cittadin miei presso a Colle
116  in campo giunti co' loro avversari,
117  e io pregava Iddio di quel ch'e' volle.
118  Routed were they, and turned into the bitter
119  Passes of flight; and I, the chase beholding,
120  A joy received unequalled by all others;
118  Rotti fuor quivi e vòlti ne li amari
119  passi di fuga; e veggendo la caccia,
120  letizia presi a tutte altre dispari,
121  So that I lifted upward my bold face
122  Crying to God, 'Henceforth I fear thee not,'
123  As did the blackbird at the little sunshine.
121  tanto ch'io volsi in sù l'ardita faccia,
122  gridando a Dio: 'Omai più non ti temo!'
123  come fé 'l merlo per poca bonaccia.
124  Peace I desired with God at the extreme
125  Of my existence, and as yet would not
126  My debt have been by penitence discharged,
124  Pace volli con Dio in su lo stremo
125  de la mia vita; e ancor non sarebbe
126  lo mio dover per penitenza scemo,
127  Had it not been that in remembrance held me
128  Pier Pettignano in his holy prayers,
129  Who out of charity was grieved for me.
127  se ciò non fosse, ch'a memoria m'ebbe
128  Pier Pettinaio in sue sante orazioni,
129  a cui di me per caritate increbbe.
130  But who art thou, that into our conditions
131  Questioning goest, and hast thine eyes unbound
132  As I believe, and breathing dost discourse?"
130  Ma tu chi se', che nostre condizioni
131  vai dimandando, e porti li occhi sciolti,
132  sì com' io credo, e spirando ragioni?”
133  "Mine eyes," I said, "will yet be here ta'en from me,
134   But for short space; for small is the offence
135   Committed by their being turned with envy.
133  “Li occhi,” diss' io, “mi fieno ancor qui tolti,
134  ma picciol tempo, ché poca è l'offesa
135  fatta per esser con invidia vòlti.
136  Far greater is the fear, wherein suspended
137  My soul is, of the torment underneath,
138  For even now the load down there weighs on me."
136  Troppa è più la paura ond' è sospesa
137  l'anima mia del tormento di sotto,
138  che già lo 'ncarco di là giù mi pesa.”
139  And she to me: "Who led thee, then, among us
140  Up here, if to return below thou thinkest?"
141  And I: "He who is with me, and speaks not;
139  Ed ella a me: “Chi t'ha dunque condotto
140  qua sù tra noi, se giù ritornar credi?”
141  E io: “Costui ch'è meco e non fa motto.
142  And living am I; therefore ask of me,
144  Spirit elect, if thou wouldst have me move
145  O'er yonder yet my mortal feet for thee."
142  E vivo sono; e però mi richiedi,
143  spirito eletto, se tu vuo' ch'i' mova
144 di là per te ancor li mortai piedi.”
145  "O, this is such a novel thing to hear,"
146  She answered, "that great sign it is God loves thee;
147  Therefore with prayer of thine sometimes assist me.
145  “Oh, questa è a udir sì cosa nuova,”
146  rispuose, “che gran segno è che Dio t'ami;
147  però col priego tuo talor mi giova.
148  And I implore, by what thou most desirest,
149  If e'er thou treadest the soil of Tuscany,
150  Well with my kindred reinstate my fame.
148  E cheggioti, per quel che tu più brami,
149  se mai calchi la terra di Toscana,
150  che a' miei propinqui tu ben mi rinfami.
151  Them wilt thou see among that people vain
152  Who hope in Talamone, and will lose there
153  More hope than in discovering the Diana;
151  Tu li vedrai tra quella gente vana
152  che spera in Talamone, e perderagli
153  più di speranza ch'a trovar la Diana;
154  But there still more the admirals will lose."
154  ma più vi perderanno li ammiragli.”
Canto XIV
We are protected — or we imagine we are protected — from Dante's text by its reputation, by its centuries of commentary, by the distance that our attitudes afford us about poetry as an aesthetic experience, which far from bringing us closer to the affairs of life and of the soul, allows us the space to intellectually consider what should be grappled with with the same intensity with which a sleepless person grapples with a 3 a.m. panic attack or an addict with the symptoms of drug withdrawal.  But as we deeply study the poem, at some point it dawns on us that this text is a kind of in extremis challenge: beautiful, intricately woven, stubbornly insistent on what strikes us as an excursion into a hyperdimensional reality, its mere words, mouth-sounds, letter-shapes, elevating it far beyond the usual weight we are accustomed to give to a product of the imagination.  Again and again, the reader feels haunted by the suspicion that her's or his' own version of reality is but a pale projection, and that whatever Dante is asking us to accept is more real than any fantasy.  Rather it seems like some unique species of dream collected from millions of sleepers over thousands of years, and we are one of those dreamers, still in the dream, but with the illusion that we are awake, and all this can be brushed off as the contents of a book.  We do not grasp that this book is a centuries-old body which has incorporated our experience as readers into its own organ functioning.  We are enlivened and engrossed in this work, one moment becoming a bit of its heart tissue, in the next, a bit of its lung, or its intestine.  Dante's poem incorporates us as a part of its life, and by so doing it becomes a necessary part of our own.  

Canto XIV of the Purgatorio does not so much begin as it elides into its domain as a subtle overtone, two shades overhearing the aspirant even as he them.  And we succumb, because we realize that we have been given instructions on how to read the poem, i.e., as an echo from another world calling this world to account, its shades making Earth, even as they speak of it, shimmer, not as so many physical things and people, but as something a bit tainted by unreality, the projection of a host of cruel and deluded maniacs who have forgotten what IS and are thereby left to scrap over what is not.  The characters of these two, one Guido del Duca, and one Rinieri da Caboli, both blind, and huddled together in sackcloth, are finely drawn.  Guido is abrupt, easily annoyed, a person of whom we might say: He does not suffer fools gladly.  While Rinieri is kinder, more tentative, retiring, dependent, courteous.  Guido was in life a Ghibelline, Rinieri, a Guelph, and both are here to purge the sin of Envy.   These two factions were the splits which ignited men's passions in Dante's historical times, the abstract beasts, whose perpetual conflicts were paid out in human lives and environmental destruction.  Every age has their own versions of them, and they are the writ large double-binds of the body politic of each individual's irreconcilable psychic splits.  They pose questions of identity — who am I? — and authority — how should I live?  For all the factions in Dante's time the first question — who am I — was embedded in family and in hereditary lines, in City, or citizenship allegiances, and in language and custom.  The second question — how should I live? — was embedded in either political or family loyalties in the case of the Ghibellines, or under the authority of a spiritual hierarchy and its moral teachings, as the Guelph party would have it.  The offices of Ghibellines were either hereditary, passed down through blood lineages or usurped by force of arms, and those of the papacy ostensibly through moral and spiritual merit, but in practice fought out among family and political rivals.  If all this seems confusing, it should, because conflicts, whether internal or external, run a pell-mell course without any logical consistency, and it is this violent course that much of the Commedia is meant to expose, curb, and ultimately transcend.  Dante's own position, and the personal tragedy of his nomadic exile, bounced from one party to another, to come to rest in neither.   The figure of Cato, in the Purgatorio, both a pagan and a suicide, seems to have been saved by his act of extreme renunciation.  And this appears to be Dante's position: renounce all factionalism.  By inclination he seems to have favored the Ghibelline position on authority.  He would render unto Caesar what is Caesar’s, keeping the secular powers separate from the spiritual ones, a separation of Church and State, to put it in contemporary American parlance.  The idea being that political authority would hopelessly corrupt a spiritual authority, and that politics and economics were things of this fallen world, best influenced, but not controlled by a spiritual power, morality in the former sphere being relative, in the latter, absolute.  The one demands only loyalty, but the other devotion.  That's Dante's Ghibelline-like position reflected in the very first cantos of the Inferno, which prophesize a secular ruler uniting a fractured Italy.  However, through family connections, Dante was also attached to the Guelph party, and his consistent idea is that man's life ultimately lies under a spiritual auspices.  If we were to graph his ideal of the flow of power it might look like this:

God/Christ
I
Pope
I
Emperor or Republic
I
People

But, if this vastly simplified graph seems straightforward, the actual achievement of such a power/authority configuration is almost hopelessly convoluted.  This dichotomy is reflected in the simple, numerical construction of a poem whose internal metaphors are an almost chaotic whirl of reflecting and refracting complexity, a swirl of verbal vapors and liquids held in check by the rigid container of a formal design.  One of the greatest, and almost unique, hallmarks of Dante's genius is his ability to reconcile these irreconcilable positions in the overall body of his poem.

This canto as it develops, as are so many of the cantos of the poem, is in some sense a litany of names, and most of these names are strewn throughout the public records of his day.  Their fame becomes the extension of their identity through time, thus their names resound by virtue of the fact that they have become texts, that is to say, enduring as communal memory.  When Dante says to Guido and Rinieri that his name as yet (that prideful "ancor" in line 21) is not renowned, he means that there is not much text by which his existence might be known.  In this sense, as one orphaned young, an exile, a minor member of a declining aristocratic family, he has nothing to recommend him or preserve his existence in a name.  The poem, of course, is his enormously successful rectification of those handicaps.  For he has not only threaded his own name throughout the centuries' tapestry, but also the names of those whom he includes in his text.  Those people, well-known in his own time, would be utterly forgotten in ours, if he had not cursed or praised them in his work.  He preserves people like Guido or Rinieri in the amber of his verses, and even through the persistently used device of periphrasis, he has enticed his readers in subsequent generations to ferret out the significance of not just a name, but an identity.  Their place in his poem assured them a degree of fame, and given the large number of shades throughout the work who plead for exactly that, Dante is as magnanimous as the Deity in that the sun of his verses shines equally on the just and unjust.  But names in this canto flicker in and out of obscurity.  We have to play hide and seek with them, guess at them, a circumstance which emphasizes their arbitrary necessity.  We even have to guess the name of the Arno, the river itself, taking on multiplicitous identities, its first being that of one ashamed, then it is seen as a serpentining breeder of humans, who, like those cursed by Circe, have degenerated to the condition of beasts.  And of course, as a serpent, it recalls that primal, prideful Serpent: Lucifer.  More hide and seek, thesis and antithesis, shame and pride, in the ever-shifting, elusive, and illusory reflections of its waters.  Dante also points out how the river is part of the larger water cycle, springing from Earth at its mountain source, returning to the sea, and then rising as vapors again, only to fall to Earth again as rain.  He refers to this cycle as the burdened of debt, which must be perpetually repaid, this cycle becoming a metaphor for the endless round of crime and retributive justice, which is to say: the condition of nature and natural man.  All this makes the river an image of mutability and necessity, and its appearance near the beginning of the canto is contrasted with the wheeling eternal stars which conclude it.  The Arno's course breeds, in successive order, hogs, whelps, dogs, wolves, foxes from the men who infest its banks.  

This canto's subject is Envy, which is portrayed by Dante as a kind of schadenfreude, i.e., delight in the misery of others.  This definition of Envy we have also seen in the previous canto, but here there is a crucial difference.  In Canto XIII, Sapia's schadenfreude is a sin because she takes delight in the defeat of her fellow citizens.  Here, in Canto XIV, Guido's apostrophe against the "animals" inhabiting the banks of the Arno is more like the "correct" attitude we were to have at the sufferings of the sinners in Hell.  These "animals" deserve whatever insults we can make of their names and fame.  In fact, the names of the cities are suppressed, and only their geographical domains referred to.  Coupled with this degeneration of humans into beasts, is the degeneration of families and the environment itself, the decadent descendant of a once noble family (Rinieri's grandson, Fulcieri) carrying out such depredations that not only is he covered with his victims' blood, but he has denuded the very trees of their leaves and left the forest so barren that it will not recover in a thousand years.

Note: Dante derived his understanding of Envy from St. Augustine.  Envy is sorrow at another's joy, or joy at another's sorrow.  The virtues countering it are pity (compassion) for another's sorrow, and, charity, joy shared with another.  Of this latter case, Guido refers to it when he says virtue can only come from that which can be shared.

Just as the canto began by the blind sinners overhearing voices, and the sinners, unseen at first, overheard by the protagonists, it also ends with disembodied voices.  One, the Biblical Cain, and the other, the pagan Aglauros.  These later voices, the negative exemplars of Envy, however, are far from subtle.
