They are thunderclaps, so loud they hurt the ears, and they prompt the marvelous spate of multivalent metaphors at the end of the canto, which include the bridling of a wild horse, a bait to poison a bird, the devil's parodic shepard's hook which too easily snares men, the lure used to call back a hunting falcon, and finally the wheeling, eternal stars, ignored by humans, who remain fixated, in spite of the splendors above them, as do the speakers in this canto, on Earthly squalor.

(One final observation: In the last canto, the aspirant, Dante, exhibits pity when viewing the envious with their eyes sutured shut, here he only observes, and it is Virgil, in the final verses, who shows emotion.  Is Dante exhibiting here the beginnings of what many spiritual teachers call "witness consciousness?"  If so, one could read this as another indication that he is progressing on his path towards transcendence.)       
 
1  "Who is this one that goes about our mountain,
2  Or ever Death has given him power of flight,
3  And opes his eyes and shuts them at his will?"
1  “Chi è costui che 'l nostro monte cerchia
2  prima che morte li abbia dato il volo,
3  e apre li occhi a sua voglia e coverchia?”
4  "I know not who, but know he's not alone;
5  Ask him thyself, for thou art nearer to him,
6  And gently, so that he may speak, accost him."
4  “Non so chi sia, ma so ch'e' non è solo;
5  domandal tu che più li t'avvicini,
6  e dolcemente, sì che parli, acco'lo.”
7  Thus did two spirits, leaning tow'rds each other,
8  Discourse about me there on the right hand;
9  Then held supine their faces to address me.
7  Così due spirti, l'uno a l'altro chini,
8  ragionavan di me ivi a man dritta;
9  poi fer li visi, per dirmi, supini;
10  And said the one: "O soul, that, fastened still
11  Within the body, tow'rds the heaven art going,
12  For charity console us, and declare
10  e disse l'uno: “O anima che fitta
11  nel corpo ancora inver' lo ciel ten vai,
12  per carità ne consola e ne ditta
13  Whence comest and who art thou; for thou mak'st us
14  As much to marvel at this grace of thine
15  As must a thing that never yet has been."
13  onde vieni e chi se'; ché tu ne fai
14  tanto maravigliar de la tua grazia,
15  quanto vuol cosa che non fu più mai.”
16  And I: "Through midst of Tuscany there wanders
17  A streamlet that is born in Falterona,
18  And not a hundred miles of course suffice it;
16  E io: “Per mezza Toscana si spazia
17  un fiumicel che nasce in Falterona,
18  e cento miglia di corso nol sazia.
19  From thereupon do I this body bring.
20  To tell you who I am were speech in vain,
21  Because my name as yet makes no great noise."
19  Di sovr' esso rech' io questa persona:
20  dirvi ch'i' sia, saria parlare indarno,
21  ché 'l nome mio ancor molto non suona.”
22  "If well thy meaning I can penetrate
23  With intellect of mine," then answered me
24  He who first spake, "thou speakest of the Arno."
22  “Se ben lo 'ntendimento tuo accarno
23  con lo 'ntelletto,” allora mi rispuose
24  quei che diceva pria, “tu parli d'Arno.”
25  And said the other to him: "Why concealed
26  This one the appellation of that river,
27  Even as a man doth of things horrible?"
25  E l'altro disse lui: “Perché nascose
26  questi il vocabol di quella riviera,
27  pur com' om fa de l'orribili cose?”
28  And thus the shade that questioned was of this
29  Himself acquitted: "I know not; but truly
30  'Tis fit the name of such a valley peris
28  E l'ombra che di ciò domandata era,
29  si sdebitò così: “Non so; ma degno
30  ben è che 'l nome di tal valle pèra;
31  For from its fountain-head (where is so pregnant
32  The Alpine mountain whence is cleft Peloro
33  That in few places it that mark surpasses)
31  ché dal principio suo, ov' è sì pregno
32  l'alpestro monte ond' è tronco Peloro,
33  che 'n pochi luoghi passa oltra quel segno,
34  To where it yields itself in restoration
35  Of what the heaven doth of the sea dry up,
36  Whence have the rivers that which goes with them,
34  infin là 've si rende per ristoro
35  di quel che 'l ciel de la marina asciuga,
36  ond' hanno i fiumi ciò che va con loro,
37  Virtue is like an enemy avoided
38  By all, as is a serpent, through misfortune
39  Of place, or through bad habit that impels them;
37  vertù così per nimica si fuga
38  da tutti come biscia, o per sventura
39  del luogo, o per mal uso che li fruga:
40  On which account have so transformed their nature
41  The dwellers in that miserable valley,
42  It seems that Circe had them in her pasture.
40  ond' hanno sì mutata lor natura
41  li abitator de la misera valle,
42  che par che Circe li avesse in pastura.
43  'Mid ugly swine, of acorns worthier
44  Than other food for human use created,
45  It first directeth its impoverished way.
43  Tra brutti porci, più degni di galle
44  che d'altro cibo fatto in uman uso,
45  dirizza prima il suo povero calle.
46  Curs findeth it thereafter, coming downward,
47  More snarling than their puissance demands,
48  And turns from them disdainfully its muzzle.
46  Botoli trova poi, venendo giuso,
47  ringhiosi più che non chiede lor possa,
48  e da lor disdegnosa torce il muso.
49  It goes on falling, and the more it grows,
50  The more it finds the dogs becoming wolves,
51  This maledict and misadventurous ditch.
49  Vassi caggendo; e quant ella più 'ngrossa,
50  tanto più trova di can farsi lupi
51  la maladetta e sventurata fossa.
52  Descended then through many a hollow gulf,
53  It finds the foxes so replete with fraud,
54  They fear no cunning that may master them.
52  Discesa poi per più pelaghi cupi,
53  trova le volpi sì piene di froda,
54  che non temono ingegno che le occùpi.
55  Nor will I cease because another hears me;
56  And well 'twill be for him, if still he mind him
57  Of what a truthful spirit to me unravels.
55  Né lascerò di dir perch' altri m'oda;
56  e buon sarà costui, s'ancor s'ammenta
57  di ciò che vero spirto mi disnoda.
58  Thy grandson I behold, who doth become
59  A hunter of those wolves upon the bank
60  Of the wild stream, and terrifies them all.
58  Io veggio tuo nepote che diventa
59  cacciator di quei lupi in su la riva
60  del fiero fiume, e tutti li sgomenta.
61  He sells their flesh, it being yet alive;
62  Thereafter slaughters them like ancient beeves;
63  Many of life, himself of praise, deprives.
61  Vende la carne loro essendo viva;
62  poscia li ancide come antica belva;
63  molti di vita e sé di pregio priva.
64  Blood-stained he issues from the dismal forest;
65  He leaves it such, a thousand years from now
66  In its primeval state 'tis not re-wooded."
64  Sanguinoso esce de la trista selva;
65  lasciala tal, che di qui a mille anni
66  ne lo stato primaio non si rinselva.”
67  As at the announcement of impending ills
68  The face of him who listens is disturbed,
69  From whate'er side the peril seize upon him;
67  Com' a l'annunzio di dogliosi danni
68  si turba il viso di colui ch'ascolta,
69 da qual che parte il periglio l'assanni,
70  So I beheld that other soul, which stood
71  Turned round to listen, grow disturbed and sad,
72  When it had gathered to itself the word.
70  così vid' io l'altr' anima, che volta
71  stava a udir, turbarsi e farsi trista,
72  poi ch'ebbe la parola a sé raccolta.
73  The speech of one and aspect of the other
74  Had me desirous made to know their names,
75  And question mixed with prayers I made thereof,
73 Lo dir de l'una e de l'altra la vista
74  mi fer voglioso di saper lor nomi,
75  e dimanda ne fei con prieghi mista;
76  Whereat the spirit which first spake to me
77  Began again: "Thou wishest I should bring me
78  To do for thee what thou'lt not do for me;
76  per che lo spirto che di pria parlòmi
77  ricominciò: “Tu vuo' ch'io mi deduca
78  nel fare a te ciò che tu far non vuo'mi.
79  But since God willeth that in thee shine forth
80  Such grace of his, I'll not be chary with thee;
81  Know, then, that I Guido del Duca am.
79  Ma da che Dio in te vuol che traluca
80  tanto sua grazia, non ti sarò scarso;
81  però sappi ch'io fui Guido del Duca.
82  My blood was so with envy set on fire,
83  That if I had beheld a man make merry,
84  Thou wouldst have seen me sprinkled o'er with pallor.
82  Fu il sangue mio d'invidia sì rïarso,
83  che se veduto avesse uom farsi lieto,
84  visto m'avresti di livore sparso.
85  From my own sowing such the straw I reap!
86  O human race! why dost thou set thy heart
87  Where interdict of partnership must be?
85  Di mia semente cotal paglia mieto;
86  o gente umana, perché poni 'l core
87  là 'v' è mestier di consorte divieto?
88  This is Renier; this is the boast and honour
89  Of the house of Calboli, where no one since
90  Has made himself the heir of his desert.
88  Questi è Rinier; questi è 'l pregio e l'onore
89  de la casa da Calboli, ove nullo
90  fatto s'è reda poi del suo valore.
91  And not alone his blood is made devoid,
92  'Twixt Po and mount, and sea-shore and the Reno,
93  Of good required for truth and for diversion;
91  E non pur lo suo sangue è fatto brullo,
92  tra 'l Po e 'l monde e la marina e 'l Reno,
93  del ben richesto al vero e al trastullo;
94  For all within these boundaries is full
95  Of venomous roots, so that too tardily
96  By cultivation now would they diminish.
94  ché dentro a questi termini è ripieno
95  di venenosi sterpi, sì che tardi
96  per coltivare omai verrebber meno.
97  Where is good Lizio, and Arrigo Manardi,
98  Pier Traversaro, and Guido di Carpigna,
99  O Romagnuoli into bastards turned?
97  Ov' è 'l buon Lizio e Arrigo Mainardi?
98  Pier Traversaro e Guido di Carpigna?
99  Oh Romagnuoli tornati in bastardi!
100  When in Bologna will a Fabbro rise?
101  When in Faenza a Bernardin di Fosco,
102  The noble scion of ignoble seed?
100  Quando in Bologna un Fabbro si ralligna?
101 quando in Faenza un Bernardin di Fosco,
102  verga gentil di picciola gramigna?
103  Be not astonished, Tuscan, if I weep,
104  When I remember, with Guido da Prata,
105  Ugolin d' Azzo, who was living with us,
103  Non ti maravigliar s'io piango, Tosco,
104  quando rimembro, con Guido da Prata,
105  Ugolin d'Azzo che vivette nosco,
106  Frederick Tignoso and his company,
107  The house of Traversara, and th' Anastagi,
108  And one race and the other is extinct;
106  Federigo Tignoso e sua brigata,
107  la casa Traversara e li Anastagi
108  (e l'una gente e l'altra è diretata),
109  The dames and cavaliers, the toils and ease
110  That filled our souls with love and courtesy,
111  There where the hearts have so malicious grown!
109  le donne e ' cavalier, li affanni e li agi
110  che ne 'nvogliava amore e cortesia
112  là dove i cuor son fatti sì malvagi.
112  O Brettinoro! why dost thou not flee,
113  Seeing that all thy family is gone,
114  And many people, not to be corrupted?
112  O Bretinoro, ché non fuggi via,
113  poi che gita se n'è la tua famiglia
114  e molta gente per non esser ria?
115  Bagnacaval does well in not begetting
116  And ill does Castrocaro, and Conio worse,
117  In taking trouble to beget such Counts.
115  Ben fa Bagnacaval, che non rifiglia;
116  e mal fa Castrocaro, e peggio Conio,
117  che di figliar tai conti più s'impiglia.
118  Will do well the Pagani, when their Devil
119  Shall have departed; but not therefore pure
120  Will testimony of them e'er remain.
118  Ben faranno i Pagan, da che 'l demonio
119  lor sen girà; ma non però che puro
120  già mai rimagna d'essi testimonio.
121  O Ugolin de' Fantoli, secure
122  Thy name is, since no longer is awaited
123  One who, degenerating, can obscure it!
121  O Ugolin de' Fantolin, sicuro
122  è 'l nome tuo, da che più non s'aspetta
123  chi far lo possa, tralignando, scuro.
124  But go now, Tuscan, for it now delights me
125  To weep far better than it does to speak,
125  So much has our discourse my mind distressed."
124  Ma va via, Tosco, omai; ch'or mi diletta
125  troppo di pianger più che di parlare,
126  sì m'ha nostra ragion la mente stretta.”
127  We were aware that those beloved souls
128  Heard us depart; therefore, by keeping silent,
129  They made us of our pathway confident.
127  Noi sapavam che quell' anime care
128  ci sentivano andar; però, tacendo,
129  facëan noi del cammin confidare.
130  When we became alone by going onward,
131  Thunder, when it doth cleave the air, appeared
132  A voice, that counter to us came, exclaiming:
130  Poi fummo fatti soli procedendo,
131  folgore parve quando l'aere fende,
132  voce che giunse di contra dicendo:
133  "Shall slay me whosoever findeth me!"
134  And fled as the reverberation dies
135  If suddenly the cloud asunder bursts.
133  “Anciderammi qualunque m'apprende”;
134  e fuggì come tuon che si dilegua,
135  se sùbito la nuvola scoscende.
136  As soon as hearing had a truce from this,
137  Behold another, with so great a crash,
138  That it resembled thunderings following fast:
136  Come da lei l'udir nostro ebbe triegua,
137  ed ecco l'altra con sì gran fracasso,
138  che somigliò tonar che tosto segua:
139  "I am Aglaurus, who became a stone!"
140  And then, to press myself close to the Poet,
141  I backward, and not forward, took a step.
139  “Io sono Aglauro che divenni sasso”;
140  e allor, per ristrignermi al poeta,
141  in destro feci, e non innanzi, il passo.
142  Already on all sides the air was quiet;
143  And said he to me: "That was the hard curb
144  That ought to hold a man within his bounds;
142  Già era l'aura d'ogne parte queta;
143  ed el mi disse: “Quel fu 'l duro camo
144  che dovria l'uom tener dentro a sua meta.
145  But you take in the bait so that the hook
146  Of the old Adversary draws you to him,
147  And hence availeth little curb or call.
145  Ma voi prendete l'esca, sì che l'amo
146  de l'antico avversaro a sé vi tira;
147  e però poco val freno o richiamo.
148  The heavens are calling you, and wheel around you,
149  Displaying to you their eternal beauties,
150  And still your eye is looking on the ground;
148  Chiamavi 'l cielo e 'ntorno vi si gira,
149  mostrandovi le sue bellezze etterne,
150  e l'occhio vostro pur a terra mira;
151  Whence He, who all discerns, chastises you."

151  onde vi batte chi tutto discerne.”
Canto XV
This canto's opening with a double description of Time mirrors the diachronic nature of the entire Commedia — on Earth it may be as it is in Heaven, but in Purgatory their clocks clearly talk tick differently.  The language is convoluted in the Italian, and the translators, in trying to straighten it out for the benefit of their readers, make it harder to see how the text is turning us round and round as we try to grasp these discrepancies between Earth Time and Purgatory Time.   Here, that  difference is juggled playfully as a child might bat around a ball, albeit this is a ball of light — light being, as we shall see, the principle metaphor of this canto.   This passage is also an answer to Virgil's apostrophe concluding the previous canto that men should not look to mutable Earth but to the eternal wheel of the stars — i.e., the heavens, and so, that is exactly what Dante is doing here, with exactly the right zest of innocence, having no more pride or envy to encumber him.  The fact that some commentators consider these verses to be overly pedantic or their tone too playful or confusing misses their invocation of amazement.  Dante literally disorients us, preparing us for the appearance of an angel, which can only happen by our return to naiveté.  "Every poem," as Blake says, "must necessarily be a perfect unity," and any attentive reader who has come this far in the poem and who somehow concludes that Dante is a bungler says as much about Dante's subtilty as it does about these critics' lack of acuity.  Note to self: Make it your rule to follow the Master, for his critics will divert you down blind alleys.

I said light is the principle metaphor of this canto, but that observation must be refined.  As impure metals are refined by fire, our reaction to light is the terrible wonderful thing being played with here.  The whole canto is perforated with words that translate into seem or seeming, and this imparts to us the flickering nature of our physical apprehension of the phenomenon.  Our physical eyes can only catch hints of eternity, and we can only live inside a subjectivity whose main characteristic is a protean ephemerality.  How then are we to find our way?  That question is  our universally and unifying quest, and how we follow that uncertain flickering determines the strength of our inner light.  Doubt obscures it, faith clarifies it, and the whole purpose of doubt seems to be (there is that seems again) to be to sort the flash of Hellfire's trinketry, from the saving light of grace.  To quote Blake again: "If the Sun and Moon should ever doubt, they'd immediately go out."  In every moment of our lives, even in sleep, we are tasked to keep these lights lit.  The light of the physical sun in this canto is both guide and capricious Time master, it falls on the faces of the protagonists.  And here is where translations lead us astray.  This light hits us on the nose (per mezzo 'l naso), in that place that Hindu meditators call the bindu, or the third eye.  The commentators and the translators have tried to un-pretzel lines 7 - 9 to simply say what Dante does not simply say at all.  Yes, the protagonists are guided by sunlight, and are moving west, but so much more is happening here.  We have to remember that the entire Commedia is unfolding, is illuminated, if you will, in the retort of the imagination.  You might say that it is Dante's imagination, but you could as easily say that it is God's imagination, or each reader's own.  And this is where you, as a reader, begin to break down.  Reading this canto certainly has broken me down.  I have read it again and again, and can see each successive element, as one verse unfolds into the next, the words doing the work of words in presenting a kaleidoscope-like structure, wherein each turn of phrase floriates into a richer, more dazzling presentation.  One reads about the presence of the Angel.  One reads about the qualities of reflected light in a mirroring surface.  One hears Virgil's lesson on what it means to share, on what it means to accept a philosophical explanation, and on what it means to learn to wait, wait, wait for one's own spiritual development to be readied for the anima encounter of one's own supreme Beatrice.  One follows the light of the text, and reads about the three visions that stagger the aspirant, Dante: the vison of Saint Mary upon discovering the young Jesus in the Temple, and one asks: When Mary tells Jesus that she and his father have been searching for him for days, which father does she mean?  Joseph, or the one whose Word has made light?  One reads of Pisistratus turning aside the wrath of his wife, and of Saint Stephan sinking down into the darkness of a violent death, while fixing his eyes on the light above him, and like the Dante we are reading about, we are staggered.  (Note too, that the stoniness of the previous cantos are transmuted into these stones that bludgeon Stephan.)  One reads about the many masks of the self, that suddenly become more invisible than glass, all those baffling Funhouse mirrors of our manyMaya selves suddenly ceasing to be obscuring and distorting, and becoming, like those old lighthouse mirrors, which by the intricacies of their precise beveling are able to multiply the light of a single candle — in this case, the candle of the little human ego, the little human soul — by many orders of magnitude.  And one reads about the eternal fountain, which dowses all fires of envy or wrath with eternal peace — for this is the antidote to one's negative light, fired into existence through desire, and through those errors which are not false, that is to say the visions, mistakes, and faults which turn out to be our most reliable signposts on our way to transcendence.  And one reads about an approaching dark, a smoke that obscures all these reading lights — if we might call them that — and leaves one groping forward at the end of the canto, in too much darkness, just as one was groping at the beginning of the canto in too much light.  One reads, and reads, and reads, but as one reads, that word "about" keeps distancing us from what must become an unflinching immersion into this poem's vast, yet invisible organizing power.  Something is happening between the words, around and inside their sounds, that may literally drown us in inspiration, something both awesome and terrifying, an ultimate glorifying gladness that has pulled us in, but whether up or down, we do not know.  It seems that in the depths, there are no surfaces which say up or down.  Directionality means to move or to be still, to go toward or away from, and nothing else is of any consequence.  If we expect to keep company with Dante from here on up or in, we cannot keep our distance with an "about" manner of reading.  Like Jacob wrestling the angel, we have to grapple with what is happening, not just in the poem itself, but in our lives, and in our world, as we read the poem.  We must grapple and flail, just as a drowning man must grapple with water, fighting for air, fighting for light, yet not realizing that this ocean of mystery is the very element which sustains him.  There is no outside here, we have vision inside a vision, inside a vision, and these visions unfolding in the poem, unfolding in a timeless Dante, are likewise unfolding in ourselves.  If we as readers are not overwhelmed, overdazzled, and staggered by the light which ignites these visions, we remain stunted, both aesthetically and spiritually, since we have passed through Hell without learning, just as we are passing through purgatory without being purified.  If we read at the state of these distancing abouts, we will never reach the paradise of transcendence.  The 14th century world that Dante uses to elucidate the workings of the soul was no less sordid and violent, no less seething with undercurrents of wonder and salvation, than any of the various worlds that his readers have inhabited throughout history, and none of these worlds were any less baffling and babbling with evil than our own.  In truth, all of these worlds coalesce in the experience of the reader:  They are what is.  If we are not to drown in the light of our own inspiration, we have to do as Dante has done.  We have to surrender to the full scope, however complex, however excoriating, however fantastical and miraculous, of this Isness which always is.  

1  As much as 'twixt the close of the third hour
2  And dawn of day appeareth of that sphere
3  Which aye in fashion of a child is playing,

1  Quanto tra l'ultimar de l'ora terza
2  e 'l principio del dì par de la spera
3  che sempre a guisa di fanciullo scherza,

4  So much it now appeared, towards the night,
5  Was of his course remaining to the sun;
6  There it was evening, and 'twas midnight here;

4  tanto pareva già inver' la sera
5  essere al sol del suo corso rimaso;
6  vespero là, e qui mezza notte era.

7  And the rays smote the middle of our faces,
8  Because by us the mount was so encircled,
9  That straight towards the west we now were going

7  E i raggi ne ferien per mezzo 'l naso,
8  perché per noi girato era sì 'l monte,
9  che già dritti andavamo inver' l'occaso,

10  When I perceived my forehead overpowered
11  Beneath the splendour far more than at first,
12  And stupor were to me the things unknown,

10  quand' io senti' a me gravar la fronte
11  a lo splendore assai più che di prima,
12  e stupor m'eran le cose non conte;

13  Whereat towards the summit of my brow
14  I raised my hands, and made myself the visor
15  Which the excessive glare diminishes.

13  ond' io levai le mani inver' la cima
14  de le mie ciglia, e fecimi 'l solecchio,
15  che del soverchio visibile lima.

16  As when from off the water, or a mirror,
17  The sunbeam leaps unto the opposite side,
18  Ascending upward in the selfsame measure

16  Come quando da l'acqua o da lo specchio
17  salta lo raggio a l'opposita parte,
18  salendo su per lo modo parecchio

19  That it descends, and deviates as far
20  From falling of a stone in line direct,
21  (As demonstrate experiment and art,)

19  a quel che scende, e tanto si diparte
20  dal cader de la pietra in igual tratta,
21  sì come mostra esperïenza e arte;

22  So it appeared to me that by a light
23  Refracted there before me I was smitten;
24  On which account my sight was swift to flee.

22  così mi parve da luce rifratta
23  quivi dinanzi a me esser percosso;
24  per che a fuggir la mia vista fu ratta.

25  "What is that, Father sweet, from which I cannot
26  So fully screen my sight that it avail me,"
27  Said I, "and seems towards us to be moving?"

25  “Che è quel, dolce padre, a che non posso
26  schermar lo viso tanto che mi vaglia,”
27  diss' io, “e pare inver' noi esser mosso?”

28  "Marvel thou not, if dazzle thee as yet
29  The family of heaven," he answered me;
30  "An angel 'tis, who comes to invite us upward.

28  “Non ti maravigliar s'ancor t'abbaglia
29  la famiglia del cielo,” a me rispuose:
30  “messo è che viene ad invitar ch'om saglia.

31  Soon will it be, that to behold these things
32  Shall not be grievous, but delightful to thee
33  As much as nature fashioned thee to feel."

31  Tosto sarà ch'a veder queste cose
32  non ti fia grave, ma fieti diletto
33  quanto natura a sentir ti dispuose.”

34  When we had reached the Angel benedight,
35  With joyful voice he said: "Here enter in
36  To stairway far less steep than are the others."

34  Poi giunti fummo a l'angel benedetto,
35  con lieta voce disse: “Intrate quinci
36  ad un scaleo vie men che li altri eretto.”

37  We mounting were, already thence departed,
38  And "Beati misericordes" was
39  Behind us sung, "Rejoice, thou that o'ercomest!"

37  Noi montavam, già partiti di linci,
38  e “Beati misericordes!” fue
39  cantato retro, e “Godi tu che vinci!”

40  My Master and myself, we two alone
41  Were going upward, and I thought, in going,
42  Some profit to acquire from words of his;

40  Lo mio maestro e io soli amendue
41  suso andavamo; e io pensai, andando,
42  prode acquistar ne le parole sue;

43  And I to him directed me, thus asking:
44  "What did the spirit of Romagna mean,
45  Mentioning interdict and partnership?"

43  e dirizza'mi a lui sì dimandando:
44  “Che volse dir lo spirto di Romagna,
45  e 'divieto' e 'consorte' menzionando?”

46  Whence he to me: "Of his own greatest failing
47  He knows the harm; and therefore wonder not
48  If he reprove us, that we less may rue it.

46  Per ch'elli a me: “Di sua maggior magagna
47  conosce il danno; e però non s'ammiri
48  se ne riprende perché men si piagna.

49  Because are thither pointed your desires
50  Where by companionship each share is lessened,
51  Envy doth ply the bellows to your sighs.

49  Perché s'appuntano i vostri disiri
50  dove per compagnia parte si scema,
51  invidia move il mantaco a' sospiri.

52  But if the love of the supernal sphere
53  Should upwardly direct your aspiration,
54  There would not be that fear within your breast;

52  Ma se l'amor de la spera supprema
53  torcesse in suso il disiderio vostro,
54  non vi sarebbe al petto quella tema;

55  For there, as much the more as one says 'Our,'
56  So much the more of good each one possesses,
57  And more of charity in that cloister burns."

55  ché, per quanti si dice più lì 'nostro,'
56  tanto possiede più di ben ciascuno,
57  e più di caritate arde in quel chiostro.”

58  "I am more hungering to be satisfied,"
59    I said, "than if I had before been silent,
60   And more of doubt within my mind I gather.

58  “Io son d'esser contento più digiuno,”
59  diss' io, “che se mi fosse pria taciuto,
60  e più di dubbio ne la mente aduno.

61  How can it be, that boon distributed
62  The more possessors can more wealthy make
63  Therein, than if by few it be possessed?"

61  Com' esser puote ch'un ben, distributo
62  in più posseditor, faccia più ricchi
63  di sé che se da pochi è posseduto?”

64  And he to me: "Because thou fixest still
65  Thy mind entirely upon earthly things,
66  Thou pluckest darkness from the very light.

64  Ed elli a me: “Però che tu rificchi
65  la mente pur a le cose terrene,
66  di vera luce tenebre dispicchi.

67  That goodness infinite and ineffable
68   Which is above there, runneth unto love,
69   As to a lucid body comes the sunbeam.

67  Quello infinito e ineffabil bene
68  che là sù è, così corre ad amore
69  com' a lucido corpo raggio vene.

70  So much it gives itself as it finds ardour,
71  So that as far as charity extends,
72  O'er it increases the eternal valour.

70  Tanto si dà quanto trova d'ardore;
71  sì che, quantunque carità si stende,
72  cresce sovr' essa l'etterno valore.

73  And the more people thitherward aspire,
74  More are there to love well, and more they love there,
75  And, as a mirror, one reflects the other.

73  E quanta gente più là sù s'intende,
74  più v'è da bene amare, e più vi s'ama,
75  e come specchio l'uno a l'altro rende.

76  And if my reasoning appease thee not,
77  Thou shalt see Beatrice; and she will fully
78  Take from thee this and every other longing.

76  E se la mia ragion non ti disfama,
77  vedrai Beatrice, ed ella pienamente
78  ti torrà questa e ciascun' altra brama.

79  Endeavour, then, that soon may be extinct,
80  As are the two already, the five wounds
81  That close themselves again by being painful."

79  Procaccia pur che tosto sieno spente,
80  come son già le due, le cinque piaghe,
81  che si richiudon per esser dolente.”

82  Even as I wished to say, "Thou dost appease me,"
83  I saw that I had reached another circle,
84  So that my eager eyes made me keep silence.

82  Com' io voleva dicer “Tu m'appaghe,”
83  vidimi giunto in su l'altro girone,
84  sì che tacer mi fer le luci vaghe.

85  There it appeared to me that in a vision
86  Ecstatic on a sudden I was rapt,
87  And in a temple many persons saw;

85  Ivi mi parve in una visïone
86  estatica di sùbito esser tratto,
87  e vedere in un tempio più persone;

88  And at the door a woman, with the sweet
89  Behaviour of a mother, saying: "Son,
90  Why in this manner hast thou dealt with us?

88  e una donna, in su l'entrar, con atto
89  dolce di madre dicer: “Figliuol mio,
90  perché hai tu così verso noi fatto?

91  Lo, sorrowing, thy father and myself
92  Were seeking for thee;"—and as here she ceased,
93  That which appeared at first had disappeared.

91  Ecco, dolenti, lo tuo padre e io
92  ti cercavamo.” E come qui si tacque,
93  ciò che pareva prima, dispario.

94  Then I beheld another with those waters
95  Adown her cheeks which grief distils whenever
96  From great disdain of others it is born,

94  Indi m'apparve un'altra con quell' acque
95  giù per le gote che 'l dolor distilla
96  quando di gran dispetto in altrui nacque,

97  And saying: "If of that city thou art lord,
98  For whose name was such strife among the gods,
99  And whence doth every science scintillate,

97  e dir: “Se tu se' sire de la villa
98  del cui nome ne' dèi fu tanta lite,
99  e onde ogne scïenza disfavilla,

100  Avenge thyself on those audacious arms
101  That clasped our daughter, O Pisistratus;"
102  And the lord seemed to me benign and mild

100  vendica te di quelle braccia ardite
101  ch'abbracciar nostra figlia, o Pisistràto.”
102 E 'l segnor mi parea, benigno e mite,

103  To answer her with aspect temperate:
104  "What shall we do to those who wish us ill,
105  If he who loves us be by us condemned?"

103  risponder lei con viso temperato:
104  “Che farem noi a chi mal ne disira,
105  se quei che ci ama è per noi condannato?”

106  Then saw I people hot in fire of wrath,
107  With stones a young man slaying, clamorously
108  Still crying to each other, "Kill him! kill him!"

106  Poi vidi genti accese in foco d'ira
107  con pietre un giovinetto ancider, forte
108  gridando a sé pur: “Martira, martira!”

109  And him I saw bow down, because of death
110  That weighed already on him, to the earth,
111  But of his eyes made ever gates to heaven,

109  E lui vedea chinarsi, per la morte
110  che l'aggravava già, inver' la terra,
111  ma de li occhi facea sempre al ciel porte,

112  Imploring the high Lord, in so great strife,
113  That he would pardon those his persecutors,
114  With such an aspect as unlocks compassion.

112  orando a l'alto Sire, in tanta guerra,
113  che perdonasse a' suoi persecutori,
114  con quello aspetto che pietà diserra.

115  Soon as my soul had outwardly returned
116  To things external to it which are true,
117  Did I my not false errors recognize.

115  Quando l'anima mia tornò di fori
116  a le cose che son fuor di lei vere,
117  io riconobbi i miei non falsi errori.

118  My Leader, who could see me bear myself
119  Like to a man that rouses him from sleep,
120  Exclaimed: "What ails thee, that thou canst not stand?

118  Lo duca mio, che mi potea vedere
119  far sì com' om che dal sonno si slega,
120  disse: “Che hai che non ti puoi tenere,

121  But hast been coming more than half a league
122  Veiling thine eyes, and with thy legs entangled,
123  In guise of one whom wine or sleep subdues?"

121  ma se' venuto più che mezza lega
122  velando li occhi e con le gambe avvolte,
123  a guisa di cui vino o sonno piega?”

124  "O my sweet Father, if thou listen to me,
125  I'll tell thee," said I, "what appeared to me,
126  When thus from me my legs were ta'en away."

124  “O dolce padre mio, se tu m'ascolte,
125  io ti dirò,” diss' io, “ciò che m'apparve
126  quando le gambe mi furon sì tolte.”

127  And he: "If thou shouldst have a hundred masks
128  Upon thy face, from me would not be shut
129  Thy cogitations, howsoever small.

127  Ed ei: “Se tu avessi cento larve
128  sovra la faccia, non mi sarian chiuse
129  le tue cogitazion, quantunque parve.

130  What thou hast seen was that thou mayst not fail
131  To ope thy heart unto the waters of peace,
132  Which from the eternal fountain are diffused.

130  Ciò che vedesti fu perché non scuse
131  d'aprir lo core a l'acque de la pace
132  che da l'etterno fonte son diffuse.

133  I did not ask, 'What ails thee?' as he does
134  Who only looketh with the eyes that see not
135  When of the soul bereft the body lies,

133  Non dimandai 'Che hai?' per quel che face
134  chi guarda pur con l'occhio che non vede,
135  quando disanimato il corpo giace;

136  But asked it to give vigour to thy feet;
137  Thus must we needs urge on the sluggards, slow
138  To use their wakefulness when it returns."

136  ma dimandai per darti forza al piede:
137  così frugar conviensi i pigri, lenti
138  ad usar lor vigilia quando riede.”

139  We passed along, athwart the twilight peering
140  Forward as far as ever eye could stretch
141  Against the sunbeams serotine and lucent;

139  Noi andavam per lo vespero, attenti
140  oltre quanto potean li occhi allungarsi
141  contra i raggi serotini e lucenti.

142  And lo! by slow degrees a smoke approached
143  In our direction, sombre as the night,
144  Nor was there place to hide one's self therefrom.

142  Ed ecco a poco a poco un fummo farsi
143  verso di noi come la notte oscuro;
144  né da quello era loco da cansarsi.

145  This of our eyes and the pure air bereft us.

145  Questo ne tolse li occhi e l'aere puro.

Canto XVI
Again, in this canto, the sky, our guidance, cannot be seen.  This is the darkest point of the entire Commedia.  Here, in this sixteenth canto of the Purgatorio, where Dante, the aspirant, has already been purged of Pride and Envy, why this darkness?  The reason is both structural and moral.  We have reached the center, the 50th canto in toto.  The fact that the poet makes the darkest part of the Commedia at its center reminds us of Black Holes, or of the pre-conditions before the Big Bang, or of the brooding of God before He spoke the creative Word, or of that experience of the meditator before the 3rd eye opens and light inundates the body and unites it with its source.  Perhaps the accumulative experience that we have had up to now in our reading has, through a conglomerated mass of judgements, by whatever incensed feeling we may have had at all the atrocities that we have witnessed heretofore, densified as an acrid smoke: Wrath.  Here we find that no matter if we are rightfully righteous in our condemnations of human depravity, with which the Commedia has been rife, we are still blind, if our discernment remains clouded by wrath's fires.  In Canto XV, the Envious are blind, because their eyes are sutured shut, but here the eyes are closed for a different reason, the entire atmosphere is poisoned, and even Dante must protect himself by squeezing his eyes closed.  Note how this canto's opening mirrors that of the previous one, where Dante was blinded, not by darkness and smoke, but by a light too bright to endure.  In an image rhyme of the Envious, who, as in the Biblical parable, the blind lead the blind, and must lay their hands on one another’s shoulders, making a long chain of the handicapped, here, Dante must do the same, but with Virgil as his support.  Some ink has been spilled by commentators on why Virgil is able to see here, and some have equated this capability to what Thomas Aquinas called the light of "rational discernment."  Certainly, Virgil, being a shade, has never been possessed with physical eyes.  If we have not realized it by now, Virgil has always been a protean kind of being, whose capabilities and shortcomings, expediently answer to Dante's imaginative requirements in the moment, just as our interpretations of Dante's meanings answer in a like manner for us readers.  But Virgil, here, need not be able to see at all, and his guidance might be entirely accounted for by his knowledge of the shape of the mountain, the direction in which they are moving, and his past experience that he and his ward are protected in their foreordained journey by divine grace.  He need only trust his rational discernment to proceed.  Also, Virgil's guidance may be conceived of as the fixed condition of his paganism.  Virgil is a denizen of Hell, but because of his virtue, his only punishment is that he cannot attain Christian Salvation.  Therefore, none of the punishments in Purgatory can touch him.  There is no reason for him to be punished, since purgation for such a pagan would be moot.  If Virgil possesses these qualifications, his rational discernment, his fate to be unredeemable by enticements or punishment, his ability to adapt his capabilities according to his charge's needs, than line 15 here becomes a motto for any aspirant on such a pilgrimage: “Guarda che da me tu non sia mozzo.” ( Look that you're not cut off from me.)  I think this also addresses readers, who should not get cut off from their own rational discernment as they pursue this or any other text.  Any faith, that abandons the light of reason and reason's fact, is nothing more than a dangerous superstition, the delusion of light in a cloud of bitter darkness.  Virgil's position here as guide is also alerting us to something else, which is happening as the aspirant ascends the mountain of Purgatory.  If Hell was a kind of compendium of screaming yellow journalism, history heated by self-interest and a partisanship so virulent that it has devolved to justify a single corrupted ego, here, in Purgatory, the cooler passions of philosophy prevail.  We are indeed dealing with the same issues and with even some of the same kinds of punishments as those of Hell, but from a more disinterested (in the Keatsean sense) position.  The text has become less of a diatribe of competing self-interests, and more of a disputation among fellow truth-seekers.  The We-position is harmonizing with that of the postion of the I.  If, in the previous canto, we get variations of the words seems, or seeming, or appearing, i.e., the vocabulary of illusion, in this canto words like cagione — cause — or words and phrases denoting reason, predominate.  We are moving into realms of consideration and of contemplation, and by so doing, we are beginning to understand the Whys and Wherefores of how things are and who we are.  We are beginning to probe with reason, a light which emanates from devotion, and from our darkness, we are beginning to ferret out how a prayer such as the Agnus Dei has the power to placate anger.   

If no stars, if no planets, if nothing to be seen above in the blighted heavens can serve as compass, yet there are sounds here, songs of unseen and unseeing spirits infusing the sordid air with a Gregorian chanting of the Agnus Dei — lamb of God, the meek surrendering to the vates' knife, the innocent, infant version of the old scapegoat, whose blood here is a kind of multi-directional music which immerses and cleanses the confused soul of wrath.  We've seen enough wrath throughout the Commedia, and here Dante tells us what he believes is ire's antidote.  I think this is a very bitter pill to gulp, that the innocent must meekly surrender to the predations of the guilty — but perhaps if one realizes that each of us harbors everyone, then the guilty, even in their most vicious incarnations, are parts of us that can only be placated by this baptism in their victim's blood.  Is this the baptism that is happening here as these disembodied voices sing: Lamb of God, Thou takest away the sins of the world, thou takest away the sins of the world, Grant us peace."  This prayer is a kind of blind realization that our own worst natures, our cynicism, our violence, our constant selfish desire to destroy all those things and all those people whose presence spoils our illusions of how we think the world should conform to our beliefs about it, and confronts us simply with the medicine of compassion, forgiveness, innocence, the sacrifice of the best that we are to alleviate the torments of the worst that we are.  If wrath rends us into warring ganglions unconnected and cancerous to one another, it is this acceptance, this willingness to close the wound with the sacrifice of our own body-beliefs, that returns us to initial conditions, that gives us the chance to start again in Eden and to progress from the garden of paradise to the paradisal city of Jerusalem, to evolve from children of Nature, to parents of humans, to a city of transcendent angels.  This prayer is the pillar of sound which this harmonious chant raises before our benighted spirit, although here, in the condition of still unpurged wrath, that pillar seems yet but bits of hope dispersed in a dark, bitter mist.

The opening of the mutually laudatory dialog between Marco and Dante is quite different from those slashing exchanges between the Dante and the shades in Hell.  In the manner we have become accustomed to, the shade Marco, asks, in amazement, who this might be whose breath and movements are substantial enough to cleave the heavy atmosphere, and then adds, as a way of distinguishing a living soul from postmortem ones, who this might be who counts time, not in steps of repentance as the souls here in Purgatory must, but by means of an earthly calendar.   Dante praises Marco as one blessed to be purifying himself to return, cleansed of sin, to his Creator, and further he promises that Marco will hear of wonders, should he reverse his direction and follow.  The wonder is Dante's self, as much as his story, and in the most extensive declaration to this point in the Commedia, Dante tells of his grace with a metaphor which continues an earlier statement by Virgil.  The metaphor is of winding and unwinding, be it a knot, as Virgil has said, be it the sins of the mortal flesh unwound with the death shroud, or be it the swaddling clothes of an infant.  This being yet another instance of Dante's virtuosity in creating a resonating infrastructure throughout the work, which continually weaves many different images and sounds for the reader, some now rising above the surface, to appear in consciousness, while others sink below, to resonate from unconscious depths.  We might also notice in this canto how this image of a babe in swaddling clothes, about a third of the way into the canto is contrasted with the three old men, who symmetrically appear about a third of the way from the end.  And to go further, recollecting the beginning of the previous canto, where time itself is presented as prayer stations, simultaneously occurring at the 3rd hour and the 9th.  There is a proportionality here which is observed thematically, spatially, and temporally.   This whole poem has about it the characteristics of a living system, which some ecologists have summarized as:

Networks — interlocking sounds and themes
Nested Systems — Lines, verses, cantos, canticles
Cycles — repeating themes at different levels of awareness, for example each canto of a certain number taking up the theme in another canto in a different canticle
Flows (flow through of shared resources) — narrations, metaphors, meanings
Development — increasing sophistication of understandings progressing from earlier to later expositions 
Dynamic Equilibrium — the entire Commedia handling all these movements without breaking the bounds of its form, and without become static

If one wants to know why this work has continued to resonate with successive generations for century after century, you might consider how the Commedia so emulates how life itself develops and maintains its vitality in spite of the many vicissitudes which it faces.  If, quoting Dumas, we say: "After God, Shakespeare has created most," we might say, "After God, Dante has created best."

I think we can safely assume here that the philosophy which Marco imparts to Dante, the aspirant and protagonist of the poem, is the philosophy of Dante, the author of the poem.  That Marco is Dante's mouthpiece, while true enough, should not lull readers into believing that Marco is a totally reliable informant.  After all, Marco is in Purgatory, and is still blinded by the sin of wrath.  His whole exposition is colored by a kind resigned exasperation, and he is easily coaxed by Dante's invitation to reveal to him (Dante) the cause of the world's evil.  The aspirant's question is a loaded one.  Dante believes the world is evil — that is, Dante's prejudice, his own wrath, as he has shown time and time again when traversing Hell.  It is this prejudice which he assumes that Marco — who is still working through the consequences of his own wrath — shares.  The philosophical position discussed throughout this canto begins with this conclusion, and then works back through those premises which are this conclusion's cause.  It's a reverse logic, which may well be traced to the Christian belief in Original Sin, and as the talk of these two proceeds, if readers likewise have assumed this conclusion, what remains for readers and protagonists alike is to find some way to justify that evil, exonerate fate, the mechanics of the heavens, or God, and transform their anguished rage against these injustices, to arrive at the condition of peace.  No small task for any of us.  And the aspirant Dante puts it very well, by exclaiming in lines 53 and 54: ma io scoppio/ dentro ad un dubbio (I am bursting inside with doubt).  This may be philosophy, and not more of the screeching and howling of Hell, it's cooler, yes, but it's still boiling within the soul, and begging for a tempering resolution.  We have to take what is presented here seriously, if we are ever to find peace for ourselves and be the messengers of peace.
Imagine that the city/state, the polis, the place, the culture, the language that you were born into was deeply felt as an extension of that which gave you your sense of you as you.  Imagine  that you fought wars for this deep, broad sense of Youness, that you served this You at the highest levels of government, and that when on a mission for that Polis, you were betrayed, exiled in abstentia, your family name and inheritance, your wife and children likewise betrayed, and torn away, and without trial or any semblance of justice.  Imagine that on pain of death, you could not set foot again in this entire domain of your larger, extended self, save in that last remnant, which nothing could deprive you of — your language.  Independence would no longer be your lot.  You could never say again, for the rest of your life: This is my home.  Henceforth, the food you eat, the bed you sleep in, the roof over your head protecting you from night and from human and animal predators can come only through the uncertainty of another's charity.  Anger, a sense of vengeance, a sense of guilt and shame, a mental anguish that goes round and round in your head, that gnaws at your heart, that occludes every clarity of thought, intruding without cessation whenever you lie down to sleep, whenever you have a moment alone, whenever you meet another person, wondering, fearing, who is this, will they extend their hand in friendship, yet harbor for me a literal dagger? — this is Dante, and in some form or other, this is also your own guilt, shame, envy, anger, doubt, fret ... in a word, your world, your You.  To be free of this internal conflict, which you helplessly see writ large everywhere in the world that you know, to have just a moment of peace, to make sense of things so irrational and cruel, so colossally unjust, so contrary to the religion, which everyone proclaims, but which no one practices, you are thrown back on your own devices, and you incessantly ask yourself: How am I to be free, but not cynical, decent, but not a dupe of evil people and evil causes?  How can I become what I've been taught since the earliest days of my childhood: A good, humane, spiritually upright person?  This is the aspirant, Dante's, situation, the source of his passion, the goad that constantly harasses him, and as a reader, you come to the horrible, yet sublime realization, that this also is your situation, and that your own expanded sense of Youness, your sense of self in a world that is so often punishing and unjust, a world that not only betrays you through your excesses, but also through your natural appetites, and through the very best of your virtues.  All this hypocritical, insane, dangerous, ever-present, every-impinging self, in all its riotous confusion, its cruelty, and even its beauty, confronts you as You, and it begs in every moment for you to make sense of it, for you to convert its chaos into a humane and compassionate order, for you somehow to be redeemed.  It is from this roiling background that the poetry of the Commedia emerges, coming, with that last vestige of yourself — your language — as that single, slender hope you have to extricate yourself from the poisonous thicket of your circumstances, and to find something to love, something that merits love and propagates it — if not in the world at large — your extended You — then in the replication of this world which has excavated the internal geopolitical geography, which you call your soul.
You recognize that what you are has two quite distinct yet quite inseparable qualities, two suns, as the text of this canto has it, and that these two suns might double the glory of who you are in a mutually supportive opposition, as in the opposition of the thumb and fingers of the hand, or that each might, in a disastrous error of self-aggrandizement, vie to dominate and even destroy the other.  You can seeing nothing without the light of these two suns, and yet if one attempts to eclipse the other, then its light, the brighter it becomes, creates an ever-deepening shadow, an ever more destructive and self-destructing blindness.  You see all this quite clearly in moments of balance, which are also moments of revelation, moments of vision, moments wherein supreme elements of dissonance are brought into sublime harmony, and in those moments, you no longer identify yourself with one or the other of these suns, but rather with the light that each lends the other, with the barycenter which unites them, and which creates a You, not out of comprise, or the victory or defeat of one sun by the other, but rather out of a  brilliant interpenetration of illuminations from opposites ends of a transcendent spectrum.  This barycenter is love.
The dialogue that we read here, that we hear here, because as we know these characters are united solely by sound, is an attempt to quell the wrath that one sun has for the other, and to re-establish them in their proper relationship as a simultaneity and as a totalizing entity.  The enterprise of this canto is one of naming these two suns, and attributing to each their proper role anent the operations of the other.   Should we call them Politics and Religion, intellect and inspiration, Ghibellines and Guelphs, Liberals and Conservatives, Papacy and Emperor, spiritual and material, practical and aesthetic, factual and mystical, temporal and immortal, particular and universal, ego and soul ... ?  although each is protean, each maintains in its own sphere immutable attributes, and neither can ever completely usurp the domain of the other without bringing calamity to both.  Each of the deadly sins, which the mount of Purgatory is designed to erase, is a misperception, which obliterates the possibility of transcendent wholeness, and each has its own peculiar modality for producing the lopsidedness which is despair and pain.
We reach a point in reading Dante, or any great author, wherein we move from confronting the text as the problem of interpreting the author's intention, to a condition wherein the amorphous blob of our thought is pricked here and there and the inchoate, temporarily at least, whirls into a moment of clarity.  Thoughts and feelings arise as a result of an immersive reading.  Questions, and aphorisms arise that may have no direct connection to the text, but which the text has provided a prompt for a new way of thinking and feeling, almost as if, to use the metaphor of the two suns presented in this canto, some hitherto un-examinable thing was arising between the author's text and the reader's response, which neither the text nor the interpretation of the text could have begotten.  This is what I have called the barycenter, a thing inexplicable in itself, but which nevertheless spins into being whole galaxies of insights.  Below are some of those aphorisms and questions which arose when my reading of this canto began to revolve in this shared gravitational field.

This is a different style of reading than is commonly practiced.  It is defined by what it is not.  It is not academic reading, that uses knowledge to distance.  It is not reading for diversion or entertainment.  It is not reading to establish a bond between other readers of the same material or to show off one's learning in conversation.  It is not reading to ornament the mind, or garner admiration.  It is not scriptural reading for moral proscriptions.  It is not philosophical reading.  It is not aesthetic reading.  It is not fantasy reading.  It does not traffic in paradox nor aspire to totalization.  It does not summarize nor does it parse.  It is reading that includes what it excludes and is what it is not.

A miscellany of contemplations derived from a reading of this canto:

The inside of a poem — like the words of this canto, and of the entire Commedia — is a place of sound alone.  The light of vision must be created by sound, as it is in Genesis when "God said, "Let there be Light ... "  

Due soli — twin suns: Each person must bear within themselves that which provides health and well-being to the mortal power.  The conscious ego in charge of the temporal body, while that which provides guidance on "how" to perform the ego function: the transcendental soul.

The swaddling clothes that death unwinds — the philosophy of this and the previous canto begins to supplant history as concerns of the spirit begin to supplant concerns of the flesh.

Exemplars of contemporary evil:
* Evangelical pastors who fleece, poison, and mislead their flocks.
* Political officials and judges who violate the law and their oath to serve for private profit or power
Their chief control mechanisms: lying, propaganda, fear-mongering, gaslighting, scapegoating, projecting their own crimes on others.
The role of the guide (pastor, ruler, leader, parent) is to instruct their charges to be able to discern the difference between bodily and spiritual nourishment and poison
The will — the conscious mind — remains free to choose because it can harbor various perceptions of good.  The source of your freedom is also the source of many of our double-binds.  The conscious mind can generate images — Blakean "imagination" — not just reflexively respond to sensory input.

What is the liberated soul's proper response to evil?  righteous indignation?  anger?  sadness?  philosophical calm?  laughter at its absurdity?  If fate is an emergent property of reflective action — one still must respond to this fate — and hopefully help turn the automaticity of circumstance towards public virtue, ecological harmony, and inner peace.

This whole discussion of necessity and free will (lines 65 - 69) in the I Ching is a sort of predilection of the Times to render certain behaviors auspicious, others, inauspicious.  The choice to preserve the auspicious is the will of the "Superior Man," while the "inferior man" follows the inauspicious course, thereby defying the predilection of the Times.

Conditions of Mind
Worry ¬¬–  fret
Conniving — scheming
Planning — preparing
Contemplation — meditation (not involving intellect)
Inspiration — imagination
Expression — action

Play and devotion as opposed to necessity or duty.  Not "I must," but "I am free to ... "

Is newborn's innocence a che sa nulla (line 88) or a tabula rasa (blank slate) of mind?  Only in the sense that Thomas Aquinas seems to mean when he says that in order for learning (development, progress for mortality to transcendence) to take place, the mind must be cleared of all prejudice and stilled.  This is the very things that conservative thinkers and those transfixed by tradition refuse to or cannot do.  Which is why the conservative position in any field inevitably morphs into a moribund evil.  To learn, one must return to initial conditions of quietude and nothingness, remaining passive as a form of passionate expectation, which is why Aquinas calls the intellect "a passive power."  When this passive power of initial conditions is attained the organizing power of the Cosmos is free to act in accordance with its own unfolding wholeness (see ecological principles above).

The activity of the Cosmos is innocent — even as the activity of plants or animals is innocent.  They never cease to play their part — be it predator or prey, eater or eaten, in harmonizing the whole.  With the gift of choice, free will, humans as they mature from innocent childhood have the quality to corrupt this faculty of intellect.  A childish, animal, or plant-like delight in the trinkets of incarnation may be increasingly corrupted in the human as the maturing person keeps trying to augment this delight of the sensory appetite by accruing a substitutive quantity of privilege and power.  True maturity as Peace Pilgrim expostulated it is the transference of this childish delight to those things discussed in the previous canto as those which are augmented and nut diminished by sharing.

Mortal life is a pilgrimage from infancy and the infant's pursuit of and need to obtain the fulfillment of basic desires to an ideal of transcendence, i.e., a freedom from mortal desires.  Marcos, in this canto refers to mortals as dense, not very bright, as the bitter smoke of this terrace of Purgatory illustrates.  Even a desire for a cookie can be a barrier to that pilgrims spiritual progress if that desire is not purified by a gratitude for its gift — the desire to read turns base and is an obstruction if it is motivated by a desire to excel over others, to be a "know it all," versus the desire to instruct, i.e., transform the body on its pilgrimage to liberate its soul.

The soul — a term we use as a place marker for a process.  What is that process?  It must be the recognition that the joys of selfless love shine through even the black smoke of wrath in the presence of injustice and death.

Free will cannot be subject by necessity or any other mechanism such as celestial determinism, or a compulsion of the senses and their appetitive nature.  Why?  Because free will is incorporeal.  It is formed by choice, not by habit, social, of innate conditioning.  Free will is that in meditation which meditates, in contemplating which contemplates, and that in the creative person which creates.  It's highest merit is that it follows a freedom which leads to calm exhilaration for all whom it touches.  Free of the fetters of conditioning's praise or blame, its virtues follow the ideal of health and blessings for all.

Freedom is choice.  And choice is the metaposition of the conscious mind, which by its imaginative powers is able to conjure up a possible future by examining various possible scenarios and assessing the probable consequences for the manifestation of each.  This power can reflect and project and is not just reflexively a slave to present circumstance.  Reason, in Dante, enables one to use chance occurrences as the seeds of liberation.  Responsibility is the "yoke of liberty."

Free will can only arise from an ideal, and adapting to circumstances.  The "practical" person is only a parody of freedom, only a clever slave to circumstance.  The realist position has no room for morality.  Expediency is its only prompt to action. 

The same Intellect is a regulating mechanism that can maintain the organism in a state of healthy equilibrium, just as other mechanisms of the physical body maintain a steady internal temperature not matter what the vicissitudes of the weather.

In the medieval mind the state/polis/empire is personified, and its temporal body is not a congregation, which we might call its people, they would call its king.  This is state as ego, whose job is to preserve the health and well-being of its components, i.e., its lands, its people, its borders, the smooth operations of its laws and its commerce.  The ego's authority is inborn, unalienable as the king's title is inherited, the is to say, an attribute of his blood.  He is the past circulating as the present and serving as the progenitor of the future.  As such he is perpetual.  His two suns are valor and courtesy.  Valor and courtesy revolve around the barycenter of gentillesse, genteelness, and is due respect.  This ego/king is possessed of glamor, a magically quality which shines through time as fame, and is bruited on the lips of the people as renown, which are not to be confused with our modern sense of celebrity.  An ideal earthly leader is an exemplar of particular virtue — magnanimity, courage, piety, compassion, faithfulness, responsibility, dignity, and his capitol is the true city, fed and surrounded by its Garden of Eden, Blake's Jerusalem, arising from Beulah, his beautiful land.  The goal of the polis, or secular city/state is to curb the animal passions and provide universal justice.  Its function are insuring domestic tranquility and prosperity, since economic systems based upon animal desire are bound to produce inequalities as those who are most rapacious acquire the most wealth and power and create a greedocracy, the grandiosity and vulgarity of a mogul’s casinos and golf estates, garishness usurping the rightful place of splendor.

The figures of history possessing fame, the number of these figures on earth at any one time is magical, i.e., 40 or as in Borges' "Lamed Wufnics" from The Book of Imaginary Beings, 36.  These are the righteous for whose sake God does not destroy this wicked world.  In this canto they are telescoped down to 3 (another magical number) old Guelphs, which balance out previous appearances of righteous Ghibellines, as the poem attempts to a reconciliation of the warring political positions based upon shared virtues.  And the two positions, the due soli, are reconciled in this way: The collective looks to the State for nourishment, the individual conscience to the guidance of the Church.

The proper responses to corruption in either State of Church are
denunciation
renunciation
rehabilitation
return to the ideal of forgiveness, peace, prosperity 

1  Darkness of hell, and of a night deprived
2  Of every planet under a poor sky,
3  As much as may be tenebrous with cloud,
1  Buio d'inferno e di notte privata
2  d'ogne pianeto, sotto pover cielo,
3  quant' esser può di nuvol tenebrata,
4  Ne'er made unto my sight so thick a veil,
5  As did that smoke which there enveloped us,
6  Nor to the feeling of so rough a texture;
4  non fece al viso mio sì grosso velo
5  come quel fummo ch'ivi ci coperse,
6  né a sentir di così aspro pelo,
7 For not an eye it suffered to stay open;
8  Whereat mine escort, faithful and sagacious,
9  Drew near to me and offered me his shoulder.
7  che l'occhio stare aperto non sofferse;
8  onde la scorta mia saputa e fida
9  mi s'accostò e l'omero m'offerse.
10  E'en as a blind man goes behind his guide,
11  Lest he should wander, or should strike against
12  Aught that may harm or peradventure kill him,
10  Sì come cieco va dietro a sua guida
11  per non smarrirsi e per non dar di cozzo
12  in cosa che 'l molesti, o forse ancida,
13  So went I through the bitter and foul air,
14  Listening unto my Leader, who said only,
15  "Look that from me thou be not separated."
13  m'andava io per l'aere amaro e sozzo,
14  ascoltando il mio duca che diceva
15  pur: “Guarda che da me tu non sia mozzo.”
16  Voices I heard, and every one appeared
17  To supplicate for peace and misericord
18  The Lamb of God who takes away our sins.
16  Io sentia voci, e ciascuna pareva
17  pregar per pace e per misericordia
18  l'Agnel di Dio che le peccata leva.
19  Still "Agnus Dei" their exordium was;
20  One word there was in all, and metre one,
21  So that all harmony appeared among them.
19  Pur “Agnus Dei” eran le loro essordia;
20  una parola in tutte era e un modo,
21  sì che parea tra esse ogne concordia.
22  "Master," I said, "are spirits those I hear?"
23  And he to me: "Thou apprehendest truly,
24  And they the knot of anger go unloosing."
22  “Quei sono spirti, maestro, ch'i' odo?”
23  diss' io. Ed elli a me: “Tu vero apprendi,
24  e d'iracundia van solvendo il nodo.”
25  "Now who art thou, that cleavest through our smoke
26  And art discoursing of us even as though
27  Thou didst by calends still divide the time?"
25  “Or tu chi se' che 'l nostro fummo fendi,
26  e di noi parli pur come se tue
27  partissi ancor lo tempo per calendi?”
28  After this manner by a voice was spoken;
29  Whereon my Master said: "Do thou reply,
30  And ask if on this side the way go upward."
28  Così per una voce detto fue;
29  onde 'l maestro mio disse: “Rispondi,
30  e domanda se quinci si va sùe.”
31  And I: "O creature that dost cleanse thyself
32  To return beautiful to Him who made thee,
33  Thou shalt hear marvels if thou follow me."
31  E io: “O creatura che ti mondi
32  per tornar bella a colui che ti fece,
33  maraviglia udirai, se mi secondi.”
34  "Thee will I follow far as is allowed me,"
35  He answered; "and if smoke prevent our seeing,
36  Hearing shall keep us joined instead thereof."
34  “Io ti seguiterò quanto mi lece,”
35  rispuose; “e se veder fummo non lascia
36  l'udir ci terrà giunti in quella vece.”
37  Thereon began I: "With that swathing band
38  Which death unwindeth am I going upward,
39  And hither came I through the infernal anguish.
37  Allora incominciai: “Con quella fascia
38  che la morte dissolve men vo suso,
39  e venni qui per l'infernale ambascia.
40  And if God in his grace has me infolded,
41  So that he wills that I behold his court
42  By method wholly out of modern usage,
40  E se Dio m'ha in sua grazia rinchiuso,
41  tanto che vuol ch'i' veggia la sua corte
42  per modo tutto fuor del moderno uso,
43  Conceal not from me who ere death thou wast,
44  But tell it me, and tell me if I go
45  Right for the pass, and be thy words our escort."
43  non mi celar chi fosti anzi la morte,
44  ma dilmi, e dimmi s'i' vo bene al varco;
45  e tue parole fier le nostre scorte.”
46  "Lombard was I, and I was Marco called;
47  The world I knew, and loved that excellence,
48  At which has each one now unbent his bow.
46  “Lombardo fui, e fu' chiamato Marco;
47  del mondo seppi, e quel valore amai
48  al quale ha or ciascun disteso l'arco.
49  For mounting upward, thou art going right."
50  Thus he made answer, and subjoined: "I pray thee
51  To pray for me when thou shalt be above."
49  Per montar sù dirittamente vai.”
50  Così rispuose, e soggiunse: “I' ti prego
51  che per me prieghi quando sù sarai.”
52  And I to him: "My faith I pledge to thee
53  To do what thou dost ask me; but am bursting
54  Inly with doubt, unless I rid me of it.
52  E io a lui: “Per fede mi ti lego
53  di far ciò che mi chiedi; ma io scoppio
54  dentro ad un dubbio, s'io non me ne spiego.
55  First it was simple, and is now made double
56  By thy opinion, which makes certain to me,
57  Here and elsewhere, that which I couple with it.
55  Prima era scempio, e ora è fatto doppio
56  ne la sentenza tua, che mi fa certo
57  qui, e altrove, quello ov' io l'accoppio.
58  The world forsooth is utterly deserted
59  By every virtue, as thou tellest me,
60  And with iniquity is big and covered;
58  Lo mondo è ben così tutto diserto
59  d'ogne virtute, come tu mi sone,
60  e di malizia gravido e coverto;
61  But I beseech thee point me out the cause,
62  That I may see it, and to others show it;
63  For one in the heavens, and here below one puts it."
61  ma priego che m'addite la cagione,
62  sì ch'i' la veggia e ch'i' la mostri altrui;
63  ché nel cielo uno, e un qua giù la pone.”
64  A sigh profound, that grief forced into Ai!
65  He first sent forth, and then began he: "Brother,
66  The world is blind, and sooth thou comest from it!
64  Alto sospir, che duolo strinse in “uhi!”
65  mise fuor prima; e poi cominciò: “Frate,
66  lo mondo è cieco, e tu vien ben da lui.
67  Ye who are living every cause refer
68  Still upward to the heavens, as if all things
69  They of necessity moved with themselves.
67  Voi che vivete ogne cagion recate
68  pur suso al cielo, pur come se tutto
69  movesse seco di necessitate.
70  If this were so, in you would be destroyed
71  Free will, nor any justice would there be
72  In having joy for good, or grief for evil.
70  Se così fosse, in voi fora distrutto
71  libero arbitrio, e non fora giustizia
72  per ben letizia, e per male aver lutto.
73  The heavens your movements do initiate,
74  I say not all; but granting that I say it,
75  Light has been given you for good and evil,
73  Lo cielo i vostri movimenti inizia;
74  non dico tutti, ma, posto ch'i' 'l dica,
75  lume v'è dato a bene e a malizia,
76  And free volition; which, if some fatigue
77  In the first battles with the heavens it suffers,
78  Afterwards conquers all, if well 'tis nurtured.
76  e libero voler; che, se fatica
77  ne le prime battaglie col ciel dura,
78  poi vince tutto, se ben si notrica.
79  To greater force and to a better nature,
80  Though free, ye subject are, and that creates
81  The mind in you the heavens have not in charge.
79  A maggior forza e a miglior natura
80  liberi soggiacete; e quella cria
81  la mente in voi, che 'l ciel non ha in sua cura.
82  Hence, if the present world doth go astray,
83  In you the cause is, be it sought in you;
84  And I therein will now be thy true spy.
82  Però, se 'l mondo presente disvia,
83  in voi è la cagione, in voi si cheggia;
84  e io te ne sarò or vera spia.
85  Forth from the hand of Him, who fondles it
86  Before it is, like to a little girl
87  Weeping and laughing in her childish sport,
85  Esce di mano a lui che la vagheggia
86  prima che sia, a guisa di fanciulla
87  che piangendo e ridendo pargoleggia,
88  Issues the simple soul, that nothing knows,
89  Save that, proceeding from a joyous Maker,
90  Gladly it turns to that which gives it pleasure.
88  l'anima semplicetta che sa nulla,
89  salvo che, mossa da lieto fattore,
90  volontier torna a ciò che la trastulla.
91  Of trivial good at first it tastes the savour;
92  Is cheated by it, and runs after it,
93  If guide or rein turn not aside its love.
91  Di picciol bene in pria sente sapore;
92  quivi s'inganna, e dietro ad esso corre,
93  se guida o fren non torce suo amore.
94  Hence it behoved laws for a rein to place,
95  Behoved a king to have, who at the least
96  Of the true city should discern the tower.
94  Onde convenne legge per fren porre;
95  convenne rege aver, che discernesse
96  de la vera cittade almen la torre.
97  The laws exist, but who sets hand to them?
98  No one; because the shepherd who precedes
99  Can ruminate, but cleaveth not the hoof;
97  Le leggi son, ma chi pon mano ad esse?
98  Nullo, però che 'l pastor che procede,
99  rugumar può, ma non ha l'unghie fesse;
100  Wherefore the people that perceives its guide
101  Strike only at the good for which it hankers,
102  Feeds upon that, and farther seeketh not.
100  per che la gente, che sua guida vede
101  pur a quel ben fedire ond' ella è ghiotta,
102  di quel si pasce, e più oltre non chiede.
103  Clearly canst thou perceive that evil guidance
104  The cause is that has made the world depraved,
105  And not that nature is corrupt in you.
103  Ben puoi veder che la mala condotta
104  è la cagion che 'l mondo ha fatto reo,
105  e non natura che 'n voi sia corrotta.
106  Rome, that reformed the world, accustomed was
107  Two suns to have, which one road and the other,
108  Of God and of the world, made manifest.
106  Soleva Roma, che 'l buon mondo feo,
107  due soli aver, che l'una e l'altra strada
108  facean vedere, e del mondo e di Deo.
109  One has the other quenched, and to the crosier
110  The sword is joined, and ill beseemeth it
111  That by main force one with the other go,
109  L'un l'altro ha spento; ed è giunta la spada
110  col pasturale, e l'un con l'altro insieme
111  per viva forza mal convien che vada;
112  Because, being joined, one feareth not the other;
113  If thou believe not, think upon the grain,
114  For by its seed each herb is recognized.
112  però che, giunti, l'un l'altro non teme:
113  se non mi credi, pon mente a la spiga,
114  ch'ogn' erba si conosce per lo seme.
115  In the land laved by Po and Adige,
116  Valour and courtesy used to be found,
117  Before that Frederick had his controversy;
115  In sul paese ch'Adice e Po riga,
116  solea valore e cortesia trovarsi,
117  prima che Federigo avesse briga;
118  Now in security can pass that way
119  Whoever will abstain, through sense of shame,
120  From speaking with the good, or drawing near them.
118  or può sicuramente indi passarsi
119  per qualunque lasciasse, per vergogna,
120  di ragionar coi buoni o d'appressarsi.
121  True, three old men are left, in whom upbraids
122  The ancient age the new, and late they deem it
123  That God restore them to the better life:
121  Ben v'èn tre vecchi ancora in cui rampogna
122  l'antica età la nova, e par lor tardo
123  che Dio a miglior vita li ripogna:
124  Currado da Palazzo, and good Gherardo,
125  And Guido da Castel, who better named is,
126  In fashion of the French, the simple Lombard:
124  Currado da Palazzo e 'l buon Gherardo
125  e Guido da Castel, che mei si noma,
130  francescamente, il semplice Lombardo.
127  Say thou henceforward that the Church of Rome,
128  Confounding in itself two governments,
129  Falls in the mire, and soils itself and burden."
127  Dì oggimai che la Chiesa di Roma,
128  per confondere in sé due reggimenti,
129  cade nel fango, e sé brutta e la soma.”
130  "O Marco mine," I said, "thou reasonest well;
131  And now discern I why the sons of Levi
132  Have been excluded from the heritage.
130  “O Marco mio,” diss' io, “bene argomenti;
131  e or discerno perchè dal retaggio
132  li figli di Levì furono essenti.
133  But what Gherardo is it, who, as sample
134  Of a lost race, thou sayest has remained
135  In reprobation of the barbarous age?"
133  Ma qual Gherardo è quel che tu per saggio
134  di' ch'è rimaso de la gente spenta,
135  in rimprovèro del secol selvaggio?”
136  "Either thy speech deceives me, or it tempts me,"
137  He answered me; "for speaking Tuscan to me,
138  It seems of good Gherardo naught thou knowest.
136  “O tuo parlar m'inganna, o el mi tenta”
137  rispuose a me; “ché parlandomi tosco,
138  par che del buon Gherardo nulla senta.
139  By other surname do I know him not,
140  Unless I take it from his daughter Gaia.
141  May God be with you, for I come no farther.
139  Per altro sopranome io nol conosco,
140  s'io nol togliessi da sua figlia Gaia.
141  Dio sia con voi, ché più non vegno vosco.
142  Behold the dawn, that through the smoke rays out,
143  Already whitening; and I must depart—
144  Yonder the Angel is—ere he appear."
102  Vedi l'albor che per lo fummo raia
143  già biancheggiare, e me convien partirmi
144  (l'angelo è ivi) prima ch'io li paia.”

145  Thus did he speak, and would no farther hear me.
145  Così tornò, e più non volle udirmi.
Canto XVII
In a not atypical maneuver, Dante begins Canto XVII of the Purgatorio by creating a linguistic caliper for the depths and heights of the imagination: the mole below the dirt, the moutain's heights, the sinking sun above, the death of light upon of the shores below.  In Purgatorio XV words denoting seeming, appearing, apparently predominate, in Canto XVI, words denoting reason saturate the text, here variations of the word imagination infuse his verses.  We may surmise from their places lower to higher on the mountain how he values each of these attributes, and we may also surmise from his swooning, not for the first time in the Commedia, that there is something autistic about both the spiritual aspirant and the poet, as again and again his consciousness deserts the physical body, to journey inside this already inward journey.
