When the senses are closed, as the sense of sight is in the mole or for the shades and the aspirant in the previous cantos on Envy and Wrath, the imagination, a light from heaven, or even more profoundly, since we have just, in the last canto so thoroughly explored the topic, the Free Will of that entity who distributes light, one may enter an entirely different realm, a realm, sometimes called astral, which is not subject to all those slings and arrows so tormenting to the flesh, but which may depict all the qualities, either joyous or tormenting, in a state of rapture, completely impervious to harm.  This is the absorbed reader's realm, and here, his or her imagination joins with that of the creative poet and the creator, in a heaven which enjoys all things, suffers all things, in that state transcending physical sensation, and even ordinary emotion, which the masters refer to as bliss. 

There seems to be a hierachical relationship between what the free will creates, in the case cited here in lines 17 - 18, between the Free Will and God, i.e., as Wallace Stevens phrases it "the will of wills."  Here, the celestial bodies influence us as fate or destiny in the astrological sense,  but what sets these mechanisms in motion is the Free Will of the imagination.  This latter is free, entity-like, not subject to any law but that law which it chooses to enact its Will in the moment, while the former is teleological, a clock-work mechanism, that may can continue without the attentions of the will which created them.  Any one who does creative work, or who treats their work creatively, has had the experience of recieving an impluse seemingly out of nowhere (grace), and then, as an opertion of free will, chosing to attend to this impluse.  After, we experience how that impulse continues to elaborate itself, almost as a complete automaticity.  Such visions unfold silently in a totally interior state, and here Dante's sees the nightengale (the transformed Procne), as a kind of visible source of singing which does not in any way intrude upon his quietude.

In the beginning of this canto, we are still in the terrace of Wrath, and the 3 visions that enclosed the aspiratnt in his divine imagination-bubble, that of Procne, Haman, and Amata, act as a single unfolding metaphor, of a type we have seen before in the poem.  Together these three visions present a conflated picture of the three types of violence already defined in the Inferno: violence against oneself, against others, and against God (fate, circumstance).  It is important to note that none of these victims of wrath are named but only periphrastically alluded to, as are their stories, a wierd kind of technique which depends on the fame of the exemplars and at the same time, by refusing to directly name them, an indirect assertion that such fame is undeserving and should be denied.  The reader either already knows who is being alluded to or they must reseach their stories.  Sometimes I think of such situations as the porosity of the text.  A text with little porosity is self-contained, and does not require or refer to texts beyond itself, a text of high porostiy, is intruded upon and saturated with many references outside of itself.  The measurement is subjective, as it is determined by how little or how great is the individual reader's background of general knowledge and experience.  Because the Commedia gains a high degree of resonance with whole worlds of experiences of myth, philosophy, history, geography, nature, scripture and so forth, only alluded to by its text, it can be said to have a very high degree of porosity.  The more each reader discovers about the allusions, the greater the reach of resonance the poem has for them.  Hence the value of commentary, a kind of communal or transpersonal reading that in each generation adds more meaning to the poem.  Procne is turned into a nightengale as a result of her murder of her sister's rapist's son.  Haman, the prime minister of king Ahasuerus, because of Mordecai's refusal to bow down to him, propsed to have all the jews in the kingdom executed.  But when the king's wife, Esther, appeals to the king, it is Haman who is crucified, while Mordecai looks on.  Amata commits suicide after her machinations to prevent her daughter from marrying a suitor not of her mother's choice, starts a war in which she believes the intended suitor is killed.  These divinely inspired visions, illustrate why wrath is different than, say, self-righteous anger as the result of an injustice, in that this sin of Wrath is characterized by some desire for vengeance, vendetta.  If violence is a sort of infection spread by the need for vengeance, then foregiveness (think Lincoln's "with malice towards none, with charity for all) is the method by which the cycle of violence is halted, and the spread of this disease curtailed.  The three metaphors develop thusly: singing that is seen, seeing that is silence — the bursting bubble — then vision accompanied by the sound of weeping and then of words (lines 35 - 39).  At this point, the aspirant emerges from his astral journey, by the intusion of — what else? — light.  The light is that of a being so bright, that its own light conceals itself, and from this angelic effulgence, comes the answer to the unasked question: How do we proceed?  The answer is directional, or heirarchcal: Ascend.  The words "Qui si monta" are an awakening, and the light of the one who pronounced them acts on the aspirant as sunlight acts on a plant, he has only one desire, to follow, to feed on that source.  This light of this angel is Providence, literally the grace of foreseeing, and Virgil's words here emphasize the distinction between a guide who maliciously waits for the question to be posed, suspending fulfillment, with the possibility of a refusal or even by ignoring the need of the aspirant, to one who feels in themselves the need of the aspirant, and fulfills that need before it pustules into a cry for help.  At this point in the canto, the stairway to the next level appears, and at this point too, is where the aspirant has no other desire except to ascend.  A wing brushes the aspirant, and the words "Blessed are the peacemakers" (Beati pacifici) are heard, and it is here that the last vestiges of Wrath are gently swept away, along with the strength, which Wrath often gives those who indulge it.  The wingsweep of this being erases the "P" of Wrath from the aspirant's forehead.  (Note to ponder: When Pride is gone, a weight is lifted, when Wrath goes, a weight descends — Why?).  Now the protagonists, reaching a level plateau on the stairway they are climbing, come to rest — like a ship come to port at nightfall.  In this peaceful pause, the aspirant's questioning mind, has surrendered its former sense of prodding urgency, and he can ask, without anxiety, what sin this new circle expunges.  The tone of the poem has changed, and Virgil's explanation proceeds almost like a bedtime story for a groggy, inquisative child.  This is a tone of lassitude, and it befits the place they have reached: the circle excising sloth. It is also an assertion, that even evil has it's source in love.   Virgil than summaries and succinctly defines the sins that lie below them on the mountain: The sin of Pride, the lowest and most egregious, being the love of exultation by belittling others, the sin of Envy, the love of honor despoiled by the feat that anothers honor must besmirch one's own, and the sin of Wrath, the love of justice, wherein one demands a punishing retribution for a percieved injustice.  The canto concludes with a foreshadowning of the sins of "excessive love" (L'amor ch'ad esso troppo), which lie above the circle of Sloth.  Sloth then is the central sin, as this canto is also one of the two central cantos of the entire Commedia, around whose still center, whirls all the poem.  One might also add, that a poem of 100 cantos' barycenter is between canto 50 and canto 51.  We might call this the negative center, but the positive center would be split, like the two suns we examined in the previous canto, one rotating at the center of canto 50 (line 73: Lo cielo i vostri movimenti inizia (The heavens your movements do initiate, and its twin at the center of canto 51 (lines 70-71 Già eran sovra noi tanto levati /  li ultimi raggi che la notte segue, (already over us are upliftd / the lasts sunrays which night will follow).

At the conclusion of this canto, Virgil's words trail off, leaving the aspirant, and the reader, in a state of contemplation.       

1  Remember, Reader, if e'er in the Alps
2  A mist o'ertook thee, through which thou couldst see
3  Not otherwise than through its membrane mole,

1  Ricorditi, lettor, se mai ne l'alpe
2  ti colse nebbia per la qual vedessi
3  non altrimenti che per pelle talpe,

4  How, when the vapours humid and condensed
5  Begin to dissipate themselves, the sphere
6  Of the sun feebly enters in among them,

4  come, quando i vapori umidi e spessi
5  a diradar cominciansi, la spera
6  del sol debilemente entra per essi;

7  And thy imagination will be swift
8  In coming to perceive how I re-saw
9  The sun at first, that was already setting.

7  e fia la tua imagine leggera
8  in giugnere a veder com' io rividi
9  lo sole in pria, che già nel corcar era.

10  Thus, to the faithful footsteps of my Master
11  Mating mine own, I issued from that cloud
12  To rays already dead on the low shores.

10  Sì, pareggiando i miei co' passi fidi
11  del mio maestro, usci' fuor di tal nube
12  ai raggi morti già ne' bassi lidi.

13  O thou, Imagination, that dost steal us
14  So from without sometimes, that man perceives not,
15  Although around may sound a thousand trumpets,

13  O imaginativa che ne rube
14  talvolta sì di fuor, ch'om non s'accorge
15  perché dintorno suonin mille tube,

16  Who moveth thee, if sense impel thee not?
17  Moves thee a light, which in the heaven takes form,
18  By self, or by a will that downward guides it.

16  chi move te, se 'l senso non ti porge?
17  Moveti lume che nel ciel s'informa,
18  per sé o per voler che giù lo scorge.

19  Of her impiety, who changed her form
20  Into the bird that most delights in singing,
21  In my imagining appeared the trace;

19  De l'empiezza di lei che mutò forma
20  ne l'uccel ch'a cantar più si diletta,
21  ne l'imagine mia apparve l'orma;

22  And hereupon my mind was so withdrawn
23  Within itself, that from without there came
24  Nothing that then might be received by it.

22  e qui fu la mia mente sì ristretta
23  dentro da sé, che di fuor non venìa
24  cosa che fosse allor da lei ricetta.

25  Then reigned within my lofty fantasy
26  One crucified, disdainful and ferocious
27  In countenance, and even thus was dying.

25  Poi piovve dentro a l'alta fantasia
26  un crucifisso, dispettoso e fero
27  ne la sua vista, e cotal si moria;

28  Around him were the great Ahasuerus,
29  Esther his wife, and the just Mordecai,
30  Who was in word and action so entire.

28  intorno ad esso era il grande Assüero,
29  Estèr sua sposa e 'l giusto Mardoceo,
30  che fu al dire e al far così intero.

31  And even as this image burst asunder
32  Of its own self, in fashion of a bubble
33  In which the water it was made of fails,

31  E come questa imagine rompeo
32  sé per sé stessa, a guisa d'una bulla
33  cui manca l'acqua sotto qual si feo,

34  There rose up in my vision a young maiden
35  Bitterly weeping, and she said: "O queen,
36  Why hast thou wished in anger to be naught?

34  surse in mia visione una fanciulla
35  piangendo forte, e dicea: “O regina,
36  perché per ira hai voluto esser nulla?

37  Thou'st slain thyself, Lavinia not to lose;
38  Now hast thou lost me; I am she who mourns,
39  Mother, at thine ere at another's ruin."

37  Ancisa t'hai per non perder Lavina;
38  or m'hai perduta! Io son essa che lutto,
39  madre, a la tua pria ch'a l'altrui ruina.”

40 As sleep is broken, when upon a sudden
41  New light strikes in upon the eyelids closed,
42  And broken quivers ere it dieth wholly,

40  Come si frange il sonno ove di butto
41  nova luce percuote il viso chiuso,
42  che fratto guizza pria che muoia tutto;

43  So this imagining of mine fell down
44  As soon as the effulgence smote my face,
45  Greater by far than what is in our wont.

43  così l'imaginar mio cadde giuso
44  tosto che lume il volto mi percosse,
45  maggior assai che quel ch'è in nostro uso.

46  I turned me round to see where I might be,
47  When said a voice, "Here is the passage up;"
48  Which from all other purposes removed me,

46  I' mi volgea per veder ov' io fosse,
47  quando una voce disse “Qui si monta,”
48  che da ogne altro intento mi rimosse;

49  And made my wish so full of eagerness
50  To look and see who was it that was speaking,
51  It never rests till meeting face to face;

49  e fece la mia voglia tanto pronta
50  di riguardar chi era che parlava,
51  che mai non posa, se non si raffronta.

52  But as before the sun, which quells the sight,
53  And in its own excess its figure veils,
54  Even so my power was insufficient here.

52  Ma come al sol che nostra vista grava
53  e per soverchio sua figura vela,
54  così la mia virtù quivi mancava.

55  "This is a spirit divine, who in the way
56  Of going up directs us without asking,
57  And who with his own light himself conceals.

55  “Questo è divino spirito, che ne la
56  via da ir sù ne drizza sanza prego,
57  e col suo lume sé medesmo cela.

58  He does with us as man doth with himself;
59  For he who sees the need, and waits the asking,
60  Malignly leans already tow'rds denial.

58  Sì fa con noi, come l'uom si fa sego;
59  ché quale aspetta prego e l'uopo vede,
60  malignamente già si mette al nego.

61  Accord we now our feet to such inviting,
62  Let us make haste to mount ere it grow dark;
63  For then we could not till the day return."

61  Or accordiamo a tanto invito il piede;
62  procacciam di salir pria che s'abbui,
63  ché poi non si poria, se 'l dì non riede.”

64  Thus my Conductor said; and I and he
65  Together turned our footsteps to a stairway;
66  And I, as soon as the first step I reached,

64  Così disse il mio duca, e io con lui
65  volgemmo i nostri passi ad una scala;
66  e tosto ch'io al primo grado fui,

67  Near me perceived a motion as of wings,
68  And fanning in the face, and saying, "'Beati
69  Pacifici,' who are without ill anger."

67  senti'mi presso quasi un muover d'ala
68  e ventarmi nel viso e dir: “Beati
69  pacifici, che son sanz' ira mala!”

70  Already over us were so uplifted
71  The latest sunbeams, which the night pursues,
72  That upon many sides the stars appeared.

70  Già eran sovra noi tanto levati
71  li ultimi raggi che la notte segue,
72  che le stelle apparivan da più lati.

73  "O manhood mine, why dost thou vanish so?"
74  I said within myself; for I perceived
75  The vigour of my legs was put in truce.

73 “O virtù mia, perché sì ti dilegue?”
74  fra me stesso dicea, ché mi sentiva
75  la possa de le gambe posta in triegue.

76  We at the point were where no more ascends
77  The stairway upward, and were motionless,
78  Even as a ship, which at the shore arrives;

76  Noi eravam dove più non saliva
77  la scala sù, ed eravamo affissi,
78  pur come nave ch'a la piaggia arriva.

79  And I gave heed a little, if I might hear
80  Aught whatsoever in the circle new;
81  Then to my Master turned me round and said:

79  E io attesi un poco, s'io udissi
80  alcuna cosa nel novo girone;
81  poi mi volsi al maestro mio, e dissi:

82  "Say, my sweet Father, what delinquency
83  Is purged here in the circle where we are?
84  Although our feet may pause, pause not thy speech."

82  “Dolce mio padre, dì, quale offensione
83  si purga qui nel giro dove semo?
84  Se i piè si stanno, non stea tuo sermone.”

85  And he to me: "The love of good, remiss
86  In what it should have done, is here restored;
87  Here plied again the ill-belated oar;

85  Ed elli a me: “L'amor del bene, scemo
86  del suo dover, quiritta si ristora;
87  qui si ribatte il mal tardato remo.

88  But still more openly to understand,
89  Turn unto me thy mind, and thou shalt gather
90  Some profitable fruit from our delay.

88  Ma perché più aperto intendi ancora,
89  volgi la mente a me, e prenderai
90  alcun buon frutto di nostra dimora.”

91  Neither Creator nor a creature ever,
92  Son," he began, "was destitute of love
93  Natural or spiritual; and thou knowest it.

91  “Né creator né creatura mai,”
92  cominciò el, “figliuol, fu sanza amore,
93  o naturale o d'animo; e tu 'l sai.

94  The natural was ever without error;
95  But err the other may by evil object,
96  Or by too much, or by too little vigour.

94  Lo naturale è sempre sanza errore,
95  ma l'altro puote errar per malo obietto
96  o per troppo o per poco di vigore.

97  While in the first it well directed is,
98  And in the second moderates itself,
99  It cannot be the cause of sinful pleasure;

97  Mentre ch'elli è nel primo ben diretto,
98  e ne' secondi sé stesso misura,
99  esser non può cagion di mal diletto;

100  But when to ill it turns, and, with more care
101  Or lesser than it ought, runs after good,
102  'Gainst the Creator works his own creation.

100  ma quando al mal si torce, o con più cura
101 o con men che non dee corre nel bene,
102 contra 'l fattore adovra sua fattura.

103  Hence thou mayst comprehend that love must be
104  The seed within yourselves of every virtue,
105  And every act that merits punishment.

103  Quinci comprender puoi ch'esser convene
104  amor sementa in voi d'ogne virtute
105  e d'ogne operazion che merta pene.

106  Now inasmuch as never from the welfare
107  Of its own subject can love turn its sight,
108  From their own hatred all things are secure;

106  Or, perché mai non può da la salute
107  amor del suo subietto volger viso,
108  da l'odio proprio son le cose tute;

109  And since we cannot think of any being
110  Standing alone, nor from the First divided,
111  Of hating Him is all desire cut off.

109  e perché intender non si può diviso,
110  e per sé stante, alcuno esser dal primo,
111  da quello odiare ogne effetto è deciso.

112  Hence if, discriminating, I judge well,
113  The evil that one loves is of one's neighbour,
114  And this is born in three modes in your clay.

112  Resta, se dividendo bene stimo,
113  che 'l mal che s'ama è del prossimo; ed esso
114  amor nasce in tre modi in vostro limo.

115  There are, who, by abasement of their neighbour,
116  Hope to excel, and therefore only long
117  That from his greatness he may be cast down;

115  É chi, per esser suo vicin soppresso,
116  spera eccellenza, e sol per questo brama
117  ch'el sia di sua grandezza in basso messo;

118  There are, who power, grace, honour, and renown
119  Fear they may lose because another rises,
120  Thence are so sad that the reverse they love;

118  è chi podere, grazia, onore e fama
119  teme di perder perch' altri sormonti,
120  onde s'attrista sì che 'l contrario ama;

121  And there are those whom injury seems to chafe,
122  So that it makes them greedy for revenge,
123  And such must needs shape out another's harm.

121  ed è chi per ingiuria par ch'aonti,
122  sì che si fa de la vendetta ghiotto,
123  e tal convien che 'l male altrui impronti.

124  This threefold love is wept for down below;
125  Now of the other will I have thee hear,
126  That runneth after good with measure faulty.

124  Questo triforme amor qua giù di sotto
125  si piange: or vo' che tu de l'altro intende,
126  che corre al ben con ordine corrotto.

127  Each one confusedly a good conceives
128  Wherein the mind may rest, and longeth for it;
129  Therefore to overtake it each one strives.

127  Ciascun confusamente un bene apprende
128  nel qual si queti l'animo, e disira;
129  per che di giugner lui ciascun contende.

130  If languid love to look on this attract you,
131  Or in attaining unto it, this cornice,
132  After just penitence, torments you for it.

130  Se lento amore a lui veder vi tira
131  o a lui acquistar, questa cornice,
132  dopo giusto penter, ve ne martira.

133  There's other good that does not make man happy;
135  'Tis not felicity, 'tis not the good
136  Essence, of every good the fruit and root.

133  Altro ben è che non fa l'uom felice;
134  non è felicità, non è la buona
135  essenza, d'ogne ben frutto e radice.

136  The love that yields itself too much to this
137  Above us is lamented in three circles;
138  But how tripartite it may be described,

136  L'amor ch'ad esso troppo s'abbandona,
137  di sovr' a noi si piange per tre cerchi;
138  ma come tripartito si ragiona,

139  I say not, that thou seek it for thyself."

139  tacciolo, acciò che tu per te ne cerchi.”



Canto XVIII
Can the senses, innate in all of us, be said to love, or in less inflammatory parlance, can they have an affinity for the impressions that they convey to the organism?  Do the eyes love seeing, the ears hearing, the skin feeling, the tongue tasting, the nose smelling?  This canto, as does the previous one, to which it is seamlessly attached, is saturated with philosophical discourse about love, but does it really express love?  (One thinks of Bergson's book on Laughter, and how unfunny it is.)  The answer to that question is: No.  And I would venture to say, it is not meant to.  I make that statement from Virgil's remark, echoing other times when his cool reason stops short of embodying with emotion his discourses on emotion.  The answer to that question will not be a philosophical one, but rather a statement, if we can call it such, of the sheer wonder of Beatrice's presence.  In a way, the aspirant, Dante, in his almost breathless need to milk Virgil for a rational demonstration of the various aspect of love, stands in stark contrast, in its tone, to the sort of pagan dignity of Virgil's anachronistically Thomistic explanations.  Love is a passion, not an explanation, and if we would understand that passion, we need only refer to Dante's Vita Nuova, wherein he writes while in its throes, and not as he writes here, through his mouthpiece, Virgil, as one who seeks a balm for the passion that has so scorched him.  Indeed, this passion is what has the set entire journey of the Commedia into motion.  Here is Mark Musa's translation of two passages from that earlier, seminal work which display the starkness of this difference:

I must tell you that whenever and wherever she appeared, I, in anticipation of her miraculous greeting, could not have considered any man my enemy; on the contrary, a flame of charity was lit within me and made me forgive whoever had offended me.  And if, at his moment, anyone has asked me about anything, I could only have answered, my face all kindness: "Love."  And when she was about to greet me, one of Love's spirits, annihilating all the others of the senses, would drive out the feeble spirits of sight, saying to them, "Go and pay homage to your mistress," and Love would take their place.  And if anyone had wished to know Love, he might had done so by looking at my glistening eyes.   And when this most gracious one greeted me, Love was no medium capable of tempering my unbearable bliss, but rather, as if possessed of an excess of sweetness, he became so powerful that my body, which was completely under his rule, often moved like a heavy, inanimate object.  By now it should be most evident that in her salutation dwelt my bliss, a bliss often exceeded by my capacity to contain it.

***

I raised my eyes and, looking at the ladies, I saw among them the most gracious Beatrice.  Then my spirits were so disrupted by the strength Love acquired when he saw himself this close to the most gracious lady, that none survived except the spirits of sight; and even these were driven forth, because Love desired to occupy their enviable post in order to behold the marvelous lady.  And even though I was not quite myself, I was still very sorry for these little spirits who bitterly protested, saying: "if this one had not thrust us from our place like a bolt of lightning, we could have stayed to see the wonders of this lady as all our peers are doing."

That we are in Purgatory, and on the wrong side of this question of love, trying to stack step by step arguments to reach the unattainable stars, is the whole irony of this canto, as the spirits, attempting to erase the stain of their laggard dispositions, are on a perpetual run.  They run and run, but in circles, attempting to acquire enough ground speed to eventually attain that air speed which might lift them into flight.  In some ways, to me, this is one of the saddest of the Canto's, because the aspiration to be in love, and yet to be denied the fulfillment of that transcendent emotion, cannot be satiated by any philosophical explanation.  Then perhaps we might ask ourselves: Is it futile to run after grace?  In short, is this impatience to grab what may only annihilate us like a "lightning bolt' a form of impatience, which, after a time, when left unsatisfied, lies crestfallen in that hopelessness that we feel as sloth?  A heaviness not born in the wake of the overwhelming experience of Love, but of the exhaustion which comes from fruitlessly seeking it.

Is it from these passages of the Vita Nuova, and not from Virgil's explanations, that we may have a foretaste of the experience that awaits us at the zenith of Paradise?  Yes ... but ...

The love that Dante describes in the Vita Nuova is not the only kind of love that moves us.  There are loves, though milder, which still run quite deep, and one of these cooler forms of love is much on desplay here. This is the love of understanding, the love that loves to make sense of the senses, the love that orders the chaos of knowledge into an harmonious wisdom.  This kind of love, perhaps represented by the prefix "philo" as in the world philosophy, is imparted by a teacher, who preceding us in this love, which has no taint of jealosy, no need to exclusively possess, may guide us by a softer, but hardly less potent kind of affection.  This is the love of the sincere student for his teacher.  And the affection that Dante and Virgil have for one another, an affection which has sustained the two of them throughout this whole arduous journey, has it's own special kind of purity.  That point is enphasized here, when Dante, silent, but possessing in his mind more burning questions, is answered before he asks.  By this means the poet, Dante, equates Virgil's love for him with that special love spoken of in the previous canto, a love, almost angelic in its purity.  And, in addition to the poignancy of the running sinners, there is a wondrous kind of poignancy here too, and it revolves as well around the figure of Beatrice.  Virgil, for all his love of Dante, again here, as he has done before, defers the most vital of his chela's questions to Beatrice, and it is this unselfish action, an action in which he loses much, in order that his charge will gain more than he himself could ever hope to.  We may call this Virgil's loving sacrifice, always giving the best that he is, the best that he knows, for love of his protégé.  And doesn't this move us, as readers, even more than the weight of Virgil's arguments?  If sloth is a kind of laggardness in persuing love, and the hurry of the sinners on this cornice, is an exemplar of its cure, then sloth too is the enemy of that quieter current of love that more gently flows all through the Commedia, a current that stays hidden, sudues the turbulance of destructive passions, and, though ever present, ever comforting, even in the worst, the most violent, the most wrenching of circumstances, it "never faileth."  Indeed, its stength is such that it overcomes the very terrors of Hell.  This is the love exemplified that in this canto sustains the aspirant, even as fatigue overtakes him.  This is the love that links Virgil and Dante.  It a love that connects them, a love the marries past and present, dead and living.  It is the love of poetry.  And if we are reading this great poem as we should be reading it, we should be feeling that love as it flows between Dante and ourselves.    

1  An end had put unto his reasoning
2  The lofty Teacher, and attent was looking
3  Into my face, if I appeared content;

1  Posto avea fine al suo ragionamento
2  l'alto dottore, e attento guardava
3  ne la mia vista s'io parea contento;

4  And I, whom a new thirst still goaded on,
5  Without was mute, and said within: "Perchance
6  The too much questioning I make annoys him."

4  e io, cui nova sete ancor frugava,
5  di fuor tacea, e dentro dicea: “Forse
6  lo troppo dimandar ch'io fo li grava.”

7  But that true Father, who had comprehended
8  The timid wish, that opened not itself,
9  By speaking gave me hardihood to speak.

7  Ma quel padre verace, che s'accorse
8  del timido voler che non s'apriva,
9  parlando, di parlare ardir mi porse.

10  Whence I: "My sight is, Master, vivified
11  So in thy light, that clearly I discern
12  Whate'er thy speech importeth or describes.

10  Ond'io: “Maestro, il mio veder s'avviva
11  sì nel tuo lume, ch'io discerno chiaro
12  quanto la tua ragion parta o descriva.

13  Therefore I thee entreat, sweet Father dear,
14  To teach me love, to which thou dost refer
15  Every good action and its contrary."

13  Però ti prego, dolce padre caro,
14  che mi dimostri amore, a cui reduci
15  ogne buono operare e 'l suo contraro.”

16  "Direct," he said, "towards me the keen eyes
17  Of intellect, and clear will be to thee
18  The error of the blind, who would be leaders.

16  “Drizza,” disse, “ver' me l'agute luci
17  de lo 'ntelletto, e fieti manifesto
18  l'error de' ciechi che si fanno duci.

19  The soul, which is created apt to love,
20   Is mobile unto everything that pleases,
21   Soon as by pleasure she is waked to action.

19  L'animo, ch'è creato ad amar presto,
20  ad ogne cosa è mobile che piace,
21  tosto che dal piacere in atto è desto.

22  Your apprehension from some real thing
23   An image draws, and in yourselves displays it
24   So that it makes the soul turn unto it.

22  Vostra apprensiva da esser verace
23  tragge intenzione, e dentro a voi la spiega,
24  sì che l'animo ad essa volger face;

25  And if, when turned, towards it she incline,
26  Love is that inclination; it is nature,
27  Which is by pleasure bound in you anew

25  e se, rivolto, inver' di lei si piega,
26  quel piegare è amor, quell' è natura
27  che per piacer di novo in voi si lega.

28  Then even as the fire doth upward move
29  By its own form, which to ascend is born,
30  Where longest in its matter it endures,

28  Poi, come 'l foco movesi in altura
29  per la sua forma ch'è nata a salire
30  là dove più in sua matera dura,

31  So comes the captive soul into desire,
32   Which is a motion spiritual, and ne'er rests
33  Until she doth enjoy the thing beloved.

31  così l'animo preso entra in disire,
32  ch'è moto spiritale, e mai non posa
33  fin che la cosa amata il fa gioire.

34  Now may apparent be to thee how hidden
35   The truth is from those people, who aver
36   All love is in itself a laudable thing;

34  Or ti puote apparer quant' è nascosa
35  la veritate a la gente ch'avvera
36  ciascun amore in sé laudabil cosa;

37  Because its matter may perchance appear
38  Aye to be good; but yet not each impression
39  Is good, albeit good may be the wax."

37  però che forse appar la sua matera
38  sempre esser buona, ma non ciascun segno
39  è buono, ancor che buona sia la cera.”

40  "Thy words, and my sequacious intellect,"
41  I answered him, "have love revealed to me;
42  But that has made me more impregned with doubt;

40 “Le tue parole e 'l mio seguace ingegno,”
41  rispuos' io lui, “m'hanno amor discoverto,
42  ma ciò m'ha fatto di dubbiar più pregno;

43  For if love from without be offered us,
44  And with another foot the soul go not,
45  If right or wrong she go, 'tis not her merit."

43  ché, s'amore è di fuori a noi offerto
44  e l'anima non va con altro piede,
45  se dritta o torta va, non è suo merto.”
46  And he to me: "What reason seeth here,
47  Myself can tell thee; beyond that await
48  For Beatrice, since 'tis a work of faith.

46  Ed elli a me: “Quanto ragion qui vede,
47  dir ti poss' io; da indi in là t'aspetta
48  pur a Beatrice, ch'è opra di fede.

49  Every substantial form, that segregate
50  From matter is, and with it is united,
51  Specific power has in itself collected,

49  Ogne forma sustanzïal, che setta
50  è da matera ed è con lei unita,
51  specifica vertute ha in sé colletta,

52  Which without act is not perceptible,
53  Nor shows itself except by its effect,
54  As life does in a plant by the green leaves.

52  la qual sanza operar non è sentita,
53  né si dimostra mai che per effetto,
54  come per verdi fronde in pianta vita.

55  But still, whence cometh the intelligence
56  Of the first notions, man is ignorant,
57  And the affection for the first allurements,

55  Però, là onde vegna lo 'ntelletto
56  de le prime notizie, omo non sape,
57  e de' primi appetibili l'affetto,

58  Which are in you as instinct in the bee
59  To make its honey; and this first desire
60  Merit of praise or blame containeth not.

58  che sono in voi sì come studio in ape
59  di far lo mele; e questa prima voglia
60  merto di lode o di biasmo non cape.

61  Now, that to this all others may be gathered,
62  Innate within you is the power that counsels,
63  And it should keep the threshold of assent.

61  Or perché a questa ogn' altra si raccoglia
62  innata v'è la virtù che consiglia,
63  e de l'assenso de' tener la soglia.

64  This is the principle, from which is taken
65  Occasion of desert in you, according
66  As good and guilty loves it takes and winnows.

64  Quest' è 'l principio là onde si piglia
65  ragion di meritare in voi, secondo
66  che buoni e rei amori accoglie e viglia.

67  Those who, in reasoning, to the bottom went,
68  Were of this innate liberty aware,
69  Therefore bequeathed they Ethics to the world.

67  Color che ragionando andaro al fondo,
68  s'accorser d'esta innata libertate;
69  però moralità lasciaro al mondo.

70  Supposing, then, that from necessity
71  Springs every love that is within you kindled,
72  Within yourselves the power is to restrain it.

70  Onde, poniam che di necessitate
71  surga ogne amor che dentro a voi s'accende,
72  di ritenerlo è in voi la podestate.

73  The noble virtue Beatrice understands
74  By the free will; and therefore see that thou
75  Bear it in mind, if she should speak of it."

73  La nobile virtù Beatrice intende
74  per lo libero arbitrio, e però guarda
75  che l'abbi a mente, s'a parlar ten prende.”

76  The moon, belated almost unto midnight,
77  Now made the stars appear to us more rare,
78  Formed like a bucket, that is all ablaze,

76  La luna, quasi a mezza notte tarda,
77  facea le stelle a noi parer più rade,
78  fatta com' un secchion che tuttor arda;

79  And counter to the heavens ran through those paths
80  Which the sun sets aflame, when he of Rome
81  Sees it 'twixt Sardes and Corsicans go down;

79  e correa contra 'l ciel per quelle strade
80  che 'l sole infiamma allor che quel da Roma
81  tra ' Sardi e ' Corsi il vede quando cade.

82  And that patrician shade, for whom is named
83  Pietola more than any Mantuan town,
84  Had laid aside the burden of my lading;

82  E quell' ombra gentil per cui si noma
83  Pietola più che villa mantoana,
84  del mio carcar diposta avea la soma;

85  Whence I, who reason manifest and plain
86  In answer to my questions had received,
87  Stood like a man in drowsy reverie.

85  per ch'io, che la ragione aperta e piana
86  sovra le mie quistioni avea ricolta,
87  stava com' om che sonnolento vana.

88  But taken from me was this drowsiness
89  Suddenly by a people, that behind
90  Our backs already had come round to us.

88  Ma questa sonnolenza mi fu tolta
89  subitamente da gente che dopo
90  le nostre spalle a noi era già volta.

91  And as, of old, Ismenus and Asopus
92  Beside them saw at night the rush and throng,
93  If but the Thebans were in need of Bacchus,

91  E quale Ismeno già vide e Asopo
92  lungo di sé di notte furia e calca,
93  pur che i Teban di Bacco avesser uopo,

94  So they along that circle curve their step,
95  From what I saw of those approaching us,
96  Who by good-will and righteous love are ridden.

94  cotal per quel giron suo passo falca,
95  per quel ch'io vidi di color, venendo,
96  cui buon volere e giusto amor cavalca.

97  Full soon they were upon us, because running
98  Moved onward all that mighty multitude,
99  And two in the advance cried out, lamenting,

97  Tosto fur sovr' a noi, perché correndo
98  si movea tutta quella turba magna;
99  e due dinanzi gridavan piangendo:

100  "Mary in haste unto the mountain ran,
101  And Caesar, that he might subdue Ilerda,
102  Thrust at Marseilles, and then ran into Spain."

100  “Maria corse con fretta a la montagna;
101 e Cesare, per soggiogare Ilerda,
102 punse Marsilia e poi corse in Ispagna.”

103  "Quick! quick! so that the time may not be lost
104  By little love!" forthwith the others cried,
105  "For ardour in well-doing freshens grace!"

103  “Ratto, ratto, che 'l tempo non si perda
104  per poco amor,” gridavan li altri appresso,
105  “che studio di ben far grazia rinverda.”

106  "O folk, in whom an eager fervour now
107  Supplies perhaps delay and negligence,
108  Put by you in well-doing, through lukewarmness,

106  “O gente in cui fervore aguto adesso
107  ricompie forse negligenza e indugio
108  da voi per tepidezza in ben far messo,

109  This one who lives, and truly I lie not,
110  Would fain go up, if but the sun relight us;
111  So tell us where the passage nearest is."

109  questi che vive, e certo i' non vi bugio,
110  vuole andar sù, pur che 'l sol ne riluca;
111  però ne dite ond' è presso il pertugio.”

112  These were the words of him who was my Guide;
113  And some one of those spirits said: "Come on
114  Behind us, and the opening shalt thou find;

112  Parole furon queste del mio duca;
112  e un di quelli spirti disse: “Vieni
113  di retro a noi, e troverai la buca.

115  So full of longing are we to move onward,
116  That stay we cannot; therefore pardon us,
117  If thou for churlishness our justice take.

115  Noi siam di voglia a muoverci sì pieni,
116  che restar non potem; però perdona,
117  se villania nostra giustizia tieni.
118  I was San Zeno's Abbot at Verona,
119  Under the empire of good Barbarossa,
120  Of whom still sorrowing Milan holds discourse;

118  Io fui abate in San Zeno a Verona
119  sotto lo 'mperio del buon Barbarossa,
120  di cui dolente ancor Milan ragiona.

121  And he has one foot in the grave already,
122  Who shall erelong lament that monastery,
123  And sorry be of having there had power,

121  E tale ha già l'un piè dentro la fossa,
122  che tosto piangerà quel monastero,
123  e tristo fia d'avere avuta possa;

124  Because his son, in his whole body sick,
125  And worse in mind, and who was evil-born,
126  He put into the place of its true pastor."

124  perché suo figlio, mal del corpo intero,
125  e de la mente peggio, e che mal nacque,
126  ha posto in loco di suo pastor vero.”

127  If more he said, or silent was, I know not,
128  He had already passed so far beyond us;
129  But this I heard, and to retain it pleased me.

127  Io non so se più disse o s'ei si tacque,
128  tant' era già di là da noi trascorso;
129  ma questo intesi, e ritener mi piacque.

130  And he who was in every need my succour
131  Said: "Turn thee hitherward; see two of them
132  Come fastening upon slothfulness their teeth."

130  E quei che m'era ad ogne uopo soccorso
131  disse: “Volgiti qua: vedine due
132  venir dando a l'accidïa di morso.”

133  In rear of all they shouted: "Sooner were
134  The people dead to whom the sea was opened,
135  Than their inheritors the Jordan saw;

133  Di retro a tutti dicean: “Prima fue
134  morta la gente a cui il mar s'aperse,
135  che vedesse Iordan le rede sue.

136  And those who the fatigue did not endure
137  Unto the issue, with Anchises' son,
138  Themselves to life withouten glory offered."

136  E quella che l'affanno non sofferse
137  fino a la fine col figlio d'Anchise
138  sé stessa a vita sanza gloria offerse.”

139  Then when from us so separated were
140  Those shades, that they no longer could be seen,
141  Within me a new thought did entrance find,

139  Poi quando fuor da noi tanto divise
140  quell' ombre, che veder più non potiersi,
141  novo pensiero dentro a me si mise,

142  Whence others many and diverse were born;
143  And so I lapsed from one into another,
144  That in a reverie mine eyes I closed,

142  del qual più altri nacquero e diversi;
143  e tanto d'uno in altro vaneggiai,
144  che li occhi per vaghezza ricopersi,

145  And meditation into dream transmuted.

145  e 'l pensamento in sogno trasmutai.

Canto XIX
This canto begins with a framing device, which generally speaks to the influence of two things beyond what Dante would call free will, namely, Time, and mechanical influences, in his case, the movements of celestial bodies, in a configuration called Maggior Fortuna.*  These are those things which seem like chance or fate to us, because we cannot determine what they will be or when they might befall us.  This is a further development which we have already seen elsewhere in the Commedia — Fortune as a wheel spun by a divinely ordained Goddess, or chance as the product of a dice throw, and now we have an even more sophisticated argument, which continues in an astrological/astronomical sense, the further elaboration of what we have been pondering in the last few cantos, i.e., how such things as love or free-will operate both in the human world, and in the imaginative worlds beyond.  Enter here, the figure of the geomancer, or diviner, he or she who tries to employ a method by which the undeterminable can be determined.  The aspirant then is captured by a dream.  The this images this dream are bizarre portents, presented in a condensed version, first as a negative anima-type figure, and then as a positive one, if we are to give these pair of feminine personas a Jungian interpretation.  The images presented are highly condensed presentations of a whole matrix of psychological, geomantical, astrological associations, and they, like any sacrifice to a capricious God, demand interpretation, which the Dante, the dreamer demands of Virgil.  Now, one of the aspects of our time that comes to the fore whenever we encounter unmanageable complexity, is called systems thinking.  This kind of thinking requires that we study relationships not just subjects, processes not just product, the modes of perception, not just the objects of sense.  The eyes, as Plato says, are fixed on astrology and the ears on harmonics, and this (although Dante would have known Plato only from secondary sources) is precisely how this canto presents them.  This kind of thinking was the entire basis of Medieval education.  Finn Cleary's web-article concerning Dr. Jeffrey Lehman's (Hillside College) understanding of this education summarizes some of values which are conferred through the applications of its two major components, the so-called trivium (grammar, logic, and rhetoric) and the quadrivium (arithmetic, music, and geometry.)  To elaborate:   

 “[The trivium and quadrivium] lead us to speak with clarity and see the relations between things,” Dr. Lehman says. “Keeping that in mind, it helps to overcome the old opposition between humanities and sciences.  You can understand how a university is a university when you understand those basic concepts.”

The trivium consists of grammar, dialectic, and rhetoric, while the quadrivium consists of arithmetic, astronomy, music, and geometry.  Together, Dr. Lehman says they lead students to see a “unified idea of reality.”

“The trivium was always pursued first,” Dr. Lehman says. “It’s commonly called the ‘Arts of the Word’ and focuses on different ways you can attend to words. Grammar is used in logic, which is used in rhetoric, for example. All of them move toward a proper presentation of the truth, which speaks to the mind and to the passions.”

Next, students of the liberal arts traditionally move to the quadrivium, or the ‘Arts of Number or Quantity.’

“Humans communicate with each other using words.  Humans communicate with the natural order in numbers and in quantities.  By discerning those natural relationships, we come to better understand the cosmos.  It speaks to us, and we can talk to the greater universe."

Dr. Lehman focuses not just on the study of the liberal arts but the practice of them. “It’s one thing,” he says, “to think about the arts historically, to describe them, but to practice them is what has happened for centuries, and what I try to do here is make my students practice them.”

Practicing the liberal arts involves uncovering the beginning principles of each art, which span out into lines of reasoning, and then connecting them.

“For instance, in logic, you start with looking at the terms, categorizing them, then working them into propositions and figuring out how they relate to each other and form syllogisms and so on.”

Balancing the relationship between the humanities and sciences provides trenchant insight into the practicality of a liberal arts education.  However, Dr. Lehman’s classes aren’t just for practical benefits.

“Plato saw the difference between the lower utility of using geometry to construct a temple and a higher utility of forming the soul,” he says. “These arts each contribute to the formation and ordering of the soul, and that is the amazing capacity of the liberal arts.”

As has been often decried, our educational system turns out specialists, with little or no understanding of how their profession connects to the world at large, and environmental problems show this kind of specialization leads to huge effects of collateral damage.  This kind of education puts its recipients in an artificial box, both isolating and dangerous.  It alienates the individual and fragments society.  And one of the issues that any reader of Dante faces is that of the extraordinary mind behind the poem, a mind that just does not think or feel the way we moderns too often do.  We can comment on the content of the Commedia until we are blue in the face, and parse interpretations of this or that verse to a faretheewell, but until we see how this text operates as an organic system, we cannot really gain the transcendence which it promises.  Dante's poem, on both macro and micro levels, is the actual embodiment of how a vast conglomerate and seemingly chaotic accumulation of individual parts are unified in a whole system.  ** (See link below for a dissertation showing how Kepler, a couple of hundred years after Dante, was able to use the systems of mathematics and geometry to elucidate the idea of harmony and intervals in music.)  I would categorize Dantean type of education as a way to grasp phenomena like complexity and depth, a kind of thinking our unsystemized educational processes actually suppress.  The focus is on how to learn, not what to learn, and as such, once mastered, it can be applied to any subject.  As I've said before, Hell is a region where learning is not possible, but here, in Purgatory, learning becomes the means to liberation — hence literally, the liberal arts.

What is this system?  In short it something built up from the foundations of language (from Vico, to Proust, to Joyce, it's the same) as an analog of brain and mind.  If we make a distinction between that which is organized (chemistry into cells, cells into organisms, phonemes into words) and what we may call an Organizing Power, we can begin to grasp that there is a fundamental difference between them.  We can never understand the former, without using the later, so in this sense, the Organizing Power is the most fundamental, although it does not exist as "thingness" at all.  The I Ching calls the former the Receptive, the later the Creative.  The Kabbalah calls the former Adam Kadmon, or the Tree of Life, and the latter the Ainsoph.  We might call the former, the manifest, and the latter potential.  The point of all these systems, whatever their manifested expression, are ways to immerse the mind in the deeper aspects of the cosmos, its creative or organizing power.  Each of these systems assume a cosmos that continuously converts a chaos into an order where everything is related to everything else, and where the understanding may expand out from any point of focus to any other point of focus in the total network.  Dante's methodology for training this organizing power was the system of scholastic education known as trivium and the quadrium.   A diagram from Johnson's Universal Cyclopedia i.e.,  Unified Collection of Cycles or Circles, is arranged as follows.

Liberal Arts — The Trivium 
("Liberal" Arts, those arts which free us from the bondage of random, chaotic circumstance.  Those arts which denote systems of organization.  Not arts of things but of those functions of language by which we understand that all the physical universe, as the post-Copenhagen School physicists also tell us, operates more like a linguistic phenomenon than like colliding billiard balls.)

Grammar			Moon			Angels
Dialectic/Logic			Mercury		Archangels
Rhetoric			Venus			Thrones

The Quadrium (Applied linguistics; i.e. content, subjects of study)

Arithmetic			Sun			Dominions
Music				Mars			Virtues
Geometry			Jupiter			Principalities
Astrology/Astronomy		Saturn			Powers

Philosophy (Love of knowledge/learning/truth (truth is how things are related to one another), taken together the activities embodied in the soul

Physics/Metaphysics		Starry Heavens	Cherubim
Moral Sciences		Crystalline Heavens	Seraphim
Theology			Empyrean		God

You can see that the value of such a system *** is that it maximizes our organizing powers, already a property of our pattern-making brains, to discern and describe complex relationships, and even the far righthand categories of Angels, Archangels, Thrones, etc. gives us a concrete way to think and communicate about what we would now call virtual realities.  Also, in terms of this canto, we begin to fathom why sloth prevents us from doing the brain/organizing work required to contemplate the highest, deepest, and most complex apex of this hierarchy: God.  The spirits in this canto have to start over, as it were, looking at the ground, and seeing how that which is most basic, is still organized along the same principals as the most inclusive, the broadest, the most minute, the most ephemeral, and the greatest treasure house of potential for the myriad manifest.  We also can begin to grasp why the thing that Dante calls prayer is able to link and influence all the elements of the entirety, because consciousness, as this organizing power's power, interpenetrates, influences, and creates all things.  For Dante, the essence of this power is Love.     

Now, when we think about this particular canto, with its layers of association: the position of the planets (the moon/grammar, Saturn/Astrology), the condensed imagery of the dream, the siren song or music of the negative anima figure, the deceptive quality of sight in the form of illusions, and the undisguisable nature of smell, the philosophy that Virgil can expound, and that which he must defer to Beatrice, the nature of sloth, which renders us unable or unwilling to make the effort to connect seemingly disparate experiences, and instead slide into idleness or idle diversions, we then can begin to be aware of the vast organizing power of the entire Commedia, and why the entity of this poem is able to be mined for generation after generation, as a source of philosophical wisdom, aesthetic beauty, and spiritual transcendence.

* Maggior Fortuna, a configuration of stars which appear in the sky from a certain point on the Earth's surface, at a specific time, in this case, just before dawn.  The Geomancer draws this configuration in sand on the ground, and by certain divinatory operations, interprets for his client the will of heaven.

1  It was the hour when the diurnal heat
2  No more can warm the coldness of the moon,
3  Vanquished by earth, or peradventure Saturn,

1  Ne l'ora che non può 'l calor dïurno
2  intepidar più 'l freddo de la luna,
3  vinto da terra, e talor da Saturno

4  When geomancers their Fortuna Major
5  See in the orient before the dawn
6  Rise by a path that long remains not dim,

4  – quando i geomanti lor Maggior Fortuna
5  veggiono in oriente, innanzi a l'alba,
6  surger per via che poco le sta bruna–,

7  There came to me in dreams a stammering woman,
8  Squint in her eyes, and in her feet distorted,
9  With hands dissevered and of sallow hue.

7  mi venne in sogno una femmina balba,
8  ne li occhi guercia, e sovra i piè distorta,
9  con le man monche, e di colore scialba.

10  I looked at her; and as the sun restores
11  The frigid members which the night benumbs,
12  Even thus my gaze did render voluble

10  Io la mirava; e come 'l sol conforta
11  le fredde membra che la notte aggrava,
12  così lo sguardo mio le facea scorta

13  Her tongue, and made her all erect thereafter
14  In little while, and the lost countenance
15  As love desires it so in her did colour.

13  la lingua, e poscia tutta la drizzava
14  in poco d'ora, e lo smarrito volto,
15  com' amor vuol, così le colorava.

16  When in this wise she had her speech unloosed,
17  She 'gan to sing so, that with difficulty
18  Could I have turned my thoughts away from her.

16  Poi ch'ell' avea 'l parlar così disciolto,
17  cominciava a cantar sì, che con pena
18  da lei avrei mio intento rivolto.

19  "I am," she sang, "I am the Siren sweet
20  Who mariners amid the main unman,
21  So full am I of pleasantness to hear.

19  “Io son” cantava, “io son dolce serena
20  che ' marinari in mezzo mar dismago;
21  tanto son di piacere a sentir piena!

22  I drew Ulysses from his wandering way
23  Unto my song, and he who dwells with me
24  Seldom departs so wholly I content him."

22  Io volsi Ulisse del suo cammin vago
23  al canto mio; e qual meco s'ausa,
24  rado sen parte; sì tutto l'appago!”

25  Her mouth was not yet closed again, before
26  Appeared a Lady saintly and alert
27  Close at my side to put her to confusion.

25  Ancor non era sua bocca richiusa,
26  quand' una donna apparve santa e presta
27  lunghesso me per far colei confusa.

28  "Virgilius, O Virgilius! who is this?"
29  Sternly she said; and he was drawing near
30  With eyes still fixed upon that modest one.

28  “O Virgilio, Virgilio, chi è questa?”
29  fieramente dicea; ed el venìa
30  con li occhi fitti pur in quella onesta.

31  She seized the other and in front laid open,
32  Rending her garments, and her belly showed me;
33  This waked me with the stench that issued from it.

31  L'altra prendea, e dinanzi l'apria
32  fendendo i drappi, e mostravami 'l ventre;
33  quel mi svegliò col puzzo che n'uscia.

34  I turned mine eyes, and good Virgilius said:
35  "At least thrice have I called thee; rise and come;
36  Find we the opening by which thou mayst enter."

34  Io mossi li occhi, e 'l buon maestro: “Almen tre
35  voci t'ho messe!” dicea, “Surgi e vieni;
36  troviam l'aperta per la qual tu entre.”

37  I rose; and full already of high day
38  Were all the circles of the Sacred Mountain,
39  And with the new sun at our back we went.

37  Sù mi levai, e tutti eran già pieni
38  de l'alto dì i giron del sacro monte,
39  e andavam col sol novo a le reni.

40  Following behind him, I my forehead bore
41  Like unto one who has it laden with thought,
42  Who makes himself the half arch of a bridge,

40  Seguendo lui, portava la mia fronte
41  come colui che l'ha di pensier carca,
42  che fa di sé un mezzo arco di ponte;

43  When I heard say, "Come, here the passage is,"
44  Spoken in a manner gentle and benign,
45  Such as we hear not in this mortal region.

43  quand' io udi' “Venite; qui si varca”
44  parlare in modo soave e benigno,
45  qual non si sente in questa mortal marca.

46  With open wings, which of a swan appeared,
47  Upward he turned us who thus spake to us,
48  Between the two walls of the solid granite.

46  Con l'ali aperte, che parean di cigno,
47  volseci in sù colui che sì parlonne
48  tra due pareti del duro macigno.

49  He moved his pinions afterwards and fanned us,
50  Affirming those 'qui lugent' to be blessed,
51  For they shall have their souls with comfort filled.

49  Mosse le penne poi e ventilonne,
50  “Qui lugent” affermando esser beati,
51  ch'avran di consolar l'anime donne.

52  "What aileth thee, that aye to earth thou gazest?"
53  To me my Guide began to say, we both
54  Somewhat beyond the Angel having mounted.

52  “Che hai che pur inver' la terra guati?”
53  la guida mia incominciò a dirmi,
54  poco amendue da l'angel sormontati.

55  And I: "With such misgiving makes me go
56  A vision new, which bends me to itself,
57  So that I cannot from the thought withdraw me."

55  E io: “Con tanta sospeccion fa irmi
56  novella visïon ch'a sé mi piega,
57  sì ch'io non posso dal pensar partirmi.”

58  "Didst thou behold," he said, "that old enchantress,
59   Who sole above us henceforth is lamented?
60   Didst thou behold how man is freed from her?

58  “Vedesti,” disse, “quell'antica strega
59  che sola sovr' a noi omai si piagne;
60  vedesti come l'uom da lei si slega.

61  Suffice it thee, and smite earth with thy heels,
62  Thine eyes lift upward to the lure, that whirls
63  The Eternal King with revolutions vast."

61  Bastiti, e batti a terra le calcagne;
62  li occhi rivolgi al logoro che gira
63  lo rege etterno con le rote magne.”

64  Even as the hawk, that first his feet surveys,
65  Then turns him to the call and stretches forward,
66  Through the desire of food that draws him thither,

64  Quale 'l falcon, che prima a' piè si mira,
65  indi si volge al grido e si protende
68  per lo disio del pasto che là il tira,

67  Such I became, and such, as far as cleaves
68  The rock to give a way to him who mounts,
69  Went on to where the circling doth begin.

67  tal mi fec' io; e tal, quanto si fende
68  la roccia per dar via a chi va suso,
69  n'andai infin dove 'l cerchiar si prende.

70  On the fifth circle when I had come forth,
71  People I saw upon it who were weeping,
72  Stretched prone upon the ground, all downward turned.

70  Com' io nel quinto giro fui dischiuso,
71  vidi gente per esso che piangea,
72  giacendo a terra tutta volta in giuso.

73  "Adhaesit pavimento anima mea,"
74  I heard them say with sighings so profound,
75  That hardly could the words be understood.

73  “Adhaesit pavimento anima mea”
74  sentia dir lor con sì alti sospiri,
75  che la parola a pena s'intendea.

76  "O ye elect of God, whose sufferings
77  Justice and Hope both render less severe,
78  Direct ye us towards the high ascents."

76  “O eletti di Dio, li cui soffriri
78  e giustizia e speranza fa men duri,
79  drizzate noi verso li alti saliri.”

79  "If ye are come secure from this prostration,
80  And wish to find the way most speedily,
81  Let your right hands be evermore outside."

79  “Se voi venite dal giacer sicuri,
80  e volete trovar la via più tosto,
81  le vostre destre sien sempre di fori.”

82  Thus did the Poet ask, and thus was answered
83  By them somewhat in front of us; whence I
84  In what was spoken divined the rest concealed,

82  Così pregò 'l poeta, e sì risposto
83  poco dinanzi a noi ne fu; per ch'io
84  nel parlare avvisai l'altro nascosto,

85  And unto my Lord's eyes mine eyes I turned;
86  Whence he assented with a cheerful sign
87  To what the sight of my desire implored.

85  e volsi li occhi a li occhi al segnor mio:
86  ond' elli m'assentì con lieto cenno
87  ciò che chiedea la vista del disio.

88  When of myself I could dispose at will,
89  Above that creature did I draw myself,
90  Whose words before had caused me to take note,

88  Poi ch'io potei di me fare a mio senno,
89  trassimi sovra quella creatura
90  le cui parole pria notar mi fenno,

91  Saying: "O Spirit, in whom weeping ripens
92  That without which to God we cannot turn,
93  Suspend awhile for me thy greater care.

91  dicendo: “Spirto in cui pianger matura
92  quel sanza 'l quale a Dio tornar non pòssi,
93  sosta un poco per me tua maggior cura.

94  Who wast thou, and why are your backs turned upwards,
95  Tell me, and if thou wouldst that I procure thee
96  Anything there whence living I departed."

94  Chi fosti e perché vòlti avete i dossi
95  al sù, mi dì, e se vuo' ch'io t'impetri
96  cosa di là ond' io vivendo mossi.”

97  And he to me: "Wherefore our backs the heaven
98  Turns to itself, know shalt thou; but beforehand
99  'Scias quod ego fui successor Petri.'

97  Ed elli a me: “Perché i nostri diretri
98  rivolga il cielo a sé, saprai; ma prima
99  scias quod ego fui successor Petri.

100  Between Siestri and Chiaveri descends
101  A river beautiful, and of its name
102  The title of my blood its summit makes.

100  Intra Sïestri e Chiaveri s'adima
101  una fiumana bella, e del suo nome
102  lo titol del mio sangue fa sua cima.

103  A month and little more essayed I how
104  Weighs the great cloak on him from mire who keeps it,
105  For all the other burdens seem a feather.

103  Un mese e poco più prova' io come
104  pesa il gran manto a chi dal fango il guarda,
105  che piuma sembran tutte l'altre some.

106  Tardy, ah woe is me! was my conversion;
107  But when the Roman Shepherd I was made,
108  Then I discovered life to be a lie.

106  La mia conversïone, omè!, fu tarda;
107  ma, come fatto fui roman pastore,
108  così scopersi la vita bugiarda. 

109  I saw that there the heart was not at rest,
110  Nor farther in that life could one ascend;
111  Whereby the love of this was kindled in me.

109  Vidi che lì non s'acquetava il core,
110  né più salir potiesi in quella vita;
111  per che di questa in me s'accese amore.

112  Until that time a wretched soul and parted
113  From God was I, and wholly avaricious;
114  Now, as thou seest, I here am punished for it.

112  Fino a quel punto misera e partita
113  da Dio anima fui, del tutto avara;
114  or, come vedi, qui ne son punita.

115  What avarice does is here made manifest
116  In the purgation of these souls converted,
117  And no more bitter pain the Mountain has.

115  Quel ch'avarizia fa, qui si dichiara
 116  in purgazion de l'anime converse;
 117  e nulla pena il monte ha più amara.

118  Even as our eye did not uplift itself
119  Aloft, being fastened upon earthly things,
120  So justice here has merged it in the earth.

118  Sì come l'occhio nostro non s'aderse
119  in alto, fisso a le cose terrene,
120  così giustizia qui a terra il merse.

121  As avarice had extinguished our affection
122  For every good, whereby was action lost,
123  So justice here doth hold us in restraint,

121  Come avarizia spense a ciascun bene
122  lo nostro amore, onde operar perdési,
123  così giustizia qui stretti ne tene,

124  Bound and imprisoned by the feet and hands;
125  And so long as it pleases the just Lord
126  Shall we remain immovable and prostrate."

124  ne' piedi e ne le man legati e presi;
124  e quanto fia piacer del giusto Sire,
126  tanto staremo immobili e distesi.”

127  I on my knees had fallen, and wished to speak;
128  But even as I began, and he was 'ware,
129  Only by listening, of my reverence,

127  Io m'era inginocchiato e volea dire;
128  ma com' io cominciai ed el s'accorse,
129  solo ascoltando, del mio reverire

130  "What cause," he said, "has downward bent thee thus?"
131  And I to him: "For your own dignity,
132  Standing, my conscience stung me with remorse."

130  “Qual cagion,” disse, “in giù così ti torse?”
131  E io a lui: “Per vostra dignitate
132  mia coscïenza dritto mi rimorse.”

133  "Straighten thy legs, and upward raise thee, brother,"
134  He answered: "Err not, fellow-servant am I
135  With thee and with the others to one power.

133  “Drizza le gambe, lèvati sù, frate!”
134  rispuose; “non errar: conservo sono
135  teco e con li altri ad una podestate.

136  If e'er that holy, evangelic sound,
137  Which sayeth 'neque nubent,' thou hast heard,
138  Well canst thou see why in this wise I speak.

136  Se mai quel santo evangelico suono
137  che dice 'Neque nubent' intendesti,
139  ben puoi veder perch' io così ragiono.

139  Now go; no longer will I have thee linger,
140  Because thy stay doth incommode my weeping,
141  With which I ripen that which thou hast said.

139  Vattene omai: non vo' che più t'arresti;
140  ché la tua stanza mio pianger disagia,
141  col qual maturo ciò che tu dicesti.

142  On earth I have a grandchild named Alagia,
143  Good in herself, unless indeed our house
144  Malevolent may make her by example,

142  Nepote ho io di là c'ha nome Alagia,
143  buona da sé, pur che la nostra casa
144  non faccia lei per essempro malvagia;

145  And she alone remains to me on earth."

145  e questa sola di là m'è rimasa.”

Canto XX
The first verses in this canto are a demonstration of what Dante has been talking about throughout the Commedia, that is: free choice.  Here the aspirant, pushed by the inclination of his own desires, weighs this stronger will, against the "better" will of Adrian, who wishes to return to his penance.  Already, in the first three lines we see how this disease of insatiability is curbed — in Dante by surrendering his insatiable curiosity, and in Adrian, by surrendering something presumably as pleasant as a conversation to the harshness of his purgation.  What is the source of these refusals, which Jung might call contra natura (against nature)?  Both the penitent and the poet are wedded to a common, unseen, good, and a faith that the consequences of this expressing this good will deliver them into a state of being far better than any which would only entangle them in more suffering.  Each creature in nature has the task of its own survival, and propagation.  But in nature, as in animals or in young human children, each creature's innate limitations do not allow them to significantly harm the whole.  That is a fundamental organizing principle of ecology, and all living things are subject to the boundary conditions which support and nourish their material existence.  But human beings have the ability to make choices which allow them to exceed these necessary individual and species limitations.  And the sin of avarice is a failure to evolve beyond animal appetite, or in humans the retention of the moral neoteny of a baby.  Every human is pushed by a natural propensity to selfishness and greed, and that natural propensity can only be curbed by the humble realization that our individual health and well-being must be nourished in the context of our realizing that we are only a part of myriad relationships, and that we are wisest when we consider the needs and affairs of others, as if they were our own. Thus the first positive exemplar of the need to choose the divine will, over our personal will, is already expressed in these first three lines.  The tercet ends with the wonderful image of a brain, which like a sponge, will fill itself up to the point of saturation (an image of avarice and learning and what we would call conditioning), unless the will intervenes.  This makes of avarice a natural condition, or as Blake says: "More!  More! is the cry of a mistaken soul.  Less than all cannot satisfy man."  The grief absorbed by that natural sponge gets squeezed out drop by drop in line 7 as the tears of the penitents.  And in a later verse in this canto, this sponge evolves into the sop that separates the effluent of the crucified Christ into vinegar and gall.  The souls in this canto are legion, for the sin they are purging is nearly ubiquitous among humans, and they mob at the very verge of the terrace, forcing the protagonists to slowly pick their way through them, hugging the mountain wall.  If we did not understand the image of the she-wolf in the very first canto of the Inferno, that image is make clear here, and also the image, or should we say the function of the grey hound, the leader, and the duty of the vassal is also made plain.  Dante, the vassel, the chela, like an iron filing drawn to magnet, moves as Virgil moves.

The above exposition not only deals with how this humility or charity plays out in the space of personal relationships, but it also also how it plays out in the temporal field.  The entire exposition of Hugh Capet in this canto is about dynastic succession.  Century by century, year by year, both as individuals and as members of a vast collective, we are faced with choice.  Who or what in society, in the collective soul, and in the individual psyche is most authorized to make those choices.  The ego?  The soul?  The appetitie.  The conscience?  Does authority belong to the emotion, or to the intellect?  To the reason?  Or to the intuition?  And does authority shift according to the context?  Who leads, and by what principles, moral, economic, or ecological, are these leaders guided to guide the rest.  We have already read in a previous canto that no individual, beginning as a baby, can discover anything about how to maturely and sustainably be able to recognize the consequences of its choice.  We have neither the innate tools nor the temporal perceptions to do anything but follow the course of nature, but with this addition, the human brain can devise an almost infinite number of ways to feed these insatiable desires.  Choice, Divine choice, in the moral infant, becomes cruelty, greed, violence, and cunning.  And the whole panoply of political actors whose nefarious deeds are so bitterly recounted here are all purveyors of ruin because they break the bonds of relationship and the bounds of nature.  If the last couple of the Purgatorio's cantos have been about philosophy, this canto, by the very nature of its subject matter, must be about politics.  The text here is very porous, and the modern reader at least, must go outside the text and study the reams of commentary which explains who these people referrenced are and what they did or failed to do.  And as we read this commentary, we begin to see all these warring, duplicitous, money-grubbing, power-mad princes and popes, not simply as historical, mythical, or Biblical figures, but as types, types that show up in every generation, types that represent an on-going dynasty of usurpers, all of them enslaved by avarice, which is the thief of time, and the decayer of every temporal order.  It is not by accident that Dante returns to the very first canto of the work to allegorically link the figure of the ever-ravenous she-wolf to the players enacting the drama which Hugh Capet denounces.  By this device, Dante shows that the entire Commedia has also been an illustration of these constant wars of succession, as both society and individual attempt to progress from these animalistic, infantile excesses, to a place of moral maturity and peace.  This can be, to some extent, a rational process, as in Virgil it has been.  But something more, much more is needed, and without this something duty can never mature into devotion, and learning will always be laborious, and never an experience of grace and inspiration.  All of Hugh's denunciations are operations of the night, of just but benighted judgement.  And all of these night judgements darken the judge's own consciousness.  The positive exemplars are the transformational ones.  They are the daylight ones, and although they are fewer in number (thus economically humble) than the rapacious negative ones, they are necessarily the true attributes of leaders.  We can see them as valor, generosity, service, protection, nourishment, and a parental humility to place the other's needs, if necessary, before your own.  At night, we may learn, but we cannot move, we cannot make use of our learning ... so between the two types of exemplars, the two types of guidance, one sticks us in the mire of negative emotions, even if those emotions are right, just, and appropriate to the enormity of the situation, while the other type of guidance allows us to actually move towards paradise.  It would have been possible, and even rational for Dante to have concluded this canto with a logical syllogism, but that would have been a backward movement to some mythical, pagan golden age, a temporal solution to a purely temporal problem.  That kind of conclusion might have been expected, and also quite Virgilian.  But it would hardly have defined the inspiration which constitutes a true transcendence.  What happens here is something radically more transforming.  Here an angelic earthquake abruptly shakes the entire island mountain of Purgatory and unites each spirit in one great cry: "Glory to God in the Highest."

1  Ill strives the will against a better will;
2  Therefore, to pleasure him, against my pleasure
3  I drew the sponge not saturate from the water.

1  Contra miglior voler voler mal pugna;
2  onde contra 'l piacer mio, per piacerli,
3  trassi de l'acqua non sazia la spugna.

4  Onward I moved, and onward moved my Leader,
5  Through vacant places, skirting still the rock,
6  As on a wall close to the battlements;

4  Mossimi; e 'l duca mio si mosse per li
5  luoghi spediti pur lungo la roccia,
6  come si va per muro stretto a' merli;

7  For they that through their eyes pour drop by drop
8  The malady which all the world pervades,
9  On the other side too near the verge approach.

7  ché la gente che fonde a goccia a goccia
8  per li occhi il mal che tutto 'l mondo occupa,
9  da l'altra parte in fuor troppo s'approccia.

10  Accursed mayst thou be, thou old she-wolf,
11  That more than all the other beasts hast prey,
12  Because of hunger infinitely hollow!

10  Maladetta sie tu, antica lupa,
11  che più che tutte l'altre bestie hai preda
12  per la tua fame sanza fine cupa!

13  O heaven, in whose gyrations some appear
14  To think conditions here below are changed,
15  When will he come through whom she shall depart?

13  O ciel, nel cui girar par che si creda
14  le condizion di qua giù trasmutarsi,
15  quando verrà per cui questa disceda?

16  Onward we went with footsteps slow and scarce,
17  And I attentive to the shades I heard
18  Piteously weeping and bemoaning them;

16  Noi andavam con passi lenti e scarsi,
17  e io attento a l'ombre, ch'i' sentia
18  pietosamente piangere e lagnarsi;

19  And I by peradventure heard "Sweet Mary!"
20  Uttered in front of us amid the weeping
21  Even as a woman does who is in child-birth;

19  e per ventura udi' “Dolce Maria!”
20  dinanzi a noi chiamar così nel pianto
21  come fa donna che in parturir sia;

22  And in continuance: "How poor thou wast
23  Is manifested by that hostelry
24  Where thou didst lay thy sacred burden down."

22  e seguitar: “Povera fosti tanto,
23  quanto veder si può per quello ospizio
24  dove sponesti il tuo portato santo.”

25  Thereafterward I heard: "O good Fabricius,
26  Virtue with poverty didst thou prefer
27  To the possession of great wealth with vice."

25  Seguentemente intesi: “O buon Fabrizio,
26  con povertà volesti anzi virtute
27  che gran ricchezza posseder con vizio.”

28  So pleasurable were these words to me
29  That I drew farther onward to have knowledge
30  Touching that spirit whence they seemed to come.

28  Queste parole m'eran sì piaciute,
29  ch'io mi trassi oltre per aver contezza
30  di quello spirto onde parean venute.

31  He furthermore was speaking of the largess
32  Which Nicholas unto the maidens gave,
33  In order to conduct their youth to honour.

31  Esso parlava ancor de la larghezza
32  che fece Niccolò a le pulcelle,
33  per condurre ad onor lor giovinezza.

34  "O soul that dost so excellently speak,
35  Tell me who wast thou," said I, "and why only
36  Thou dost renew these praises well deserved?

34  “O anima che tanto ben favelle,
35  dimmi chi fosti,” dissi, “e perché sola
36  tu queste degne lode rinovelle.

37  Not without recompense shall be thy word,
38  If I return to finish the short journey
39  Of that life which is flying to its end."

37  Non fia sanza mercé la tua parola,
38  s'io ritorno a compiér lo cammin corto
39  di quella vita ch'al termine vola.”

40  And he: "I'll tell thee, not for any comfort
41  I may expect from earth, but that so much
42  Grace shines in thee or ever thou art dead.

40  Ed elli: “Io ti dirò, non per conforto
41  ch'io attenda di là, ma perché tanta
42  grazia in te luce prima che sie morto.

43  I was the root of that malignant plant
44  Which overshadows all the Christian world,
45  So that good fruit is seldom gathered from it;

43  Io fui radice de la mala pianta
44  che la terra cristiana tutta aduggia,
45  sì che buon frutto rado se ne schianta.

46  But if Douay and Ghent, and Lille and Bruges
47  Had Power, soon vengeance would be taken on it;
48  And this I pray of Him who judges all.

46  Ma se Doagio, Lilla, Guanto e Bruggia
47  potesser, tosto ne saria vendetta;
48  e io la cheggio a lui che tutto giuggia.

49  Hugh Capet was I called upon the earth;
50  From me were born the Louises and Philips,
51  By whom in later days has France been governed.

49  Chiamato fui di là Ugo Ciappetta;
 50  di me son nati i Filippi e i Luigi
52   per cui novellamente è Francia retta.

52  I was the son of a Parisian butcher,
53  What time the ancient kings had perished all,
54  Excepting one, contrite in cloth of gray.

52  Figliuol fu' io d'un beccaio di Parigi:
53  quando li regi antichi venner meno
54  tutti, fuor ch'un renduto in panni bigi,

55  I found me grasping in my hands the rein
56  Of the realm's government, and so great power
57  Of new acquest, and so with friends abounding,

55  trova'mi stretto ne le mani il freno
56  del governo del regno, e tanta possa
57  di nuovo acquisto, e sì d'amici pieno,

58  That to the widowed diadem promoted
59  The head of mine own offspring was, from whom
60  The consecrated bones of these began.

58  ch'a la corona vedova promossa
59  la testa di mio figlio fu, dal quale
60  cominciar di costor le sacrate ossa.

61  So long as the great dowry of Provence
62  Out of my blood took not the sense of shame,
