63  'Twas little worth, but still it did no harm.

61  Mentre che la gran dota provenzale
62  al sangue mio non tolse la vergogna,
63  poco valea, ma pur non facea male.

64  Then it began with falsehood and with force
65  Its rapine; and thereafter, for amends,
66  Took Ponthieu, Normandy, and Gascony.

64  Lì cominciò con forza e con menzogna
65  la sua rapina; e poscia, per ammenda,
66 Pontì e Normandia prese e Guascogna.

67  Charles came to Italy, and for amends
68  A victim made of Conradin, and then
69  Thrust Thomas back to heaven, for amends.

67  Carlo venne in Italia e, per ammenda,
68  vittima fé di Curradino; e poi
69  ripinse al ciel Tommaso, per ammenda.

70  A time I see, not very distant now,
71   Which draweth forth another Charles from France,
72   The better to make known both him and his.

70  Tempo vegg' io, non molto dopo ancoi,
71  che tragge un altro Carlo fuor di Francia,
72  per far conoscer meglio e sé e ' suoi.

73  Unarmed he goes, and only with the lance
74  That Judas jousted with; and that he thrusts
75  So that he makes the paunch of Florence burst.

73  Sanz' arme n'esce e solo con la lancia
74  con la qual giostrò Giuda, e quella ponta
75  sì, ch'a Fiorenza fa scoppiar la pancia.

76  He thence not land, but sin and infamy,
77  Shall gain, so much more grievous to himself
78  As the more light such damage he accounts.

76  Quindi non terra, ma peccato e onta
77  guadagnerà, per sé tanto più grave,
78  quanto più lieve simil danno conta.

79  The other, now gone forth, ta'en in his ship,
80  See I his daughter sell, and chaffer for her
81  As corsairs do with other female slaves.

79 L'altro, che già uscì preso di nave,
80  veggio vender sua figlia e patteggiarne
81  come fanno i corsar de l'altre schiave.

82  What more, O Avarice, canst thou do to us,
83  Since thou my blood so to thyself hast drawn,
84  It careth not for its own proper flesh?

82  O avarizia, che puoi tu più farne,
83  poscia c'ha' il mio sangue a te sì tratto,
84  che non si cura de la propria carne?

85  That less may seem the future ill and past,
86  I see the flower-de-luce Alagna enter,
87  And Christ in his own Vicar captive made.

85  Perché men paia il mal futuro e 'l fatto,
86  veggio in Alagna intrar lo fiordaliso,
87  e nel vicario suo Cristo esser catto.

88  I see him yet another time derided;
89  I see renewed the vinegar and gall,
90  And between living thieves I see him slain.

88  Veggiolo un'altra volta esser deriso;
89  veggio rinovellar l'aceto e 'l fiele,
90  e tra vivi ladroni esser anciso.

91  I see the modern Pilate so relentless,
92  This does not sate him, but without decretal
93  He to the temple bears his sordid sails!

91  Veggio il novo Pilato sì crudele,
92  che ciò nol sazia, ma sanza decreto
93  portar nel Tempio le cupide vele.

94  When, O my Lord! shall I be joyful made
95  By looking on the vengeance which, concealed,
96  Makes sweet thine anger in thy secrecy?

94  O Segnor mio, quando sarò io lieto
95  a veder la vendetta che, nascosa,
96  fa dolce l'ira tua nel tuo secreto?

97  What I was saying of that only bride
98  Of the Holy Ghost, and which occasioned thee
99  To turn towards me for some commentary,

97  Ciò ch'io dicea di quell' unica sposa
98  de lo Spirito Santo e che ti fece
99  verso me volger per alcuna chiosa,

100  So long has been ordained to all our prayers
101  As the day lasts; but when the night comes on,
102  Contrary sound we take instead thereof.

100  Ciò ch'io dicea di quell' unica sposa
101  de lo Spirito Santo e che ti fece
102  verso me volger per alcuna chiosa,

103  At that time we repeat Pygmalion,
104  Of whom a traitor, thief, and parricide
105  Made his insatiable desire of gold;

103  Noi repetiam Pigmalïon allotta,
104  cui traditore e ladro e paricida
105  fece la voglia sua de l'oro ghiotta;

106  And the misery of avaricious Midas,
107  That followed his inordinate demand,
108  At which forevermore one needs but laugh.

106  e la miseria de l'avaro Mida,
107  che seguì a la sua dimanda gorda,
108  per la qual sempre convien che si rida.

109  The foolish Achan each one then records,
110  And how he stole the spoils; so that the wrath
111  Of Joshua still appears to sting him here.

109  Del folle Acàn ciascun poi si ricorda,
110  come furò le spoglie, sì che l'ira
111  di Iosüè qui par ch'ancor lo morda.

112  Then we accuse Sapphira with her husband,
113  We laud the hoof-beats Heliodorus had,
114  And the whole mount in infamy encircles

112  Indi accusiam col marito Saffira;
113  lodiamo i calci ch'ebbe Elïodoro,
114  e in infamia tutto 'l monte gira 

115  Polymnestor who murdered Polydorus.
116  Here finally is cried: 'O Crassus, tell us,
117  For thou dost know, what is the taste of gold?'

115  Polinestòr ch'ancise Polidoro;
116  ultimamente ci si grida: 'Crasso,
117  dilci, che 'l sai: di che sapore è l'oro?'

118  Sometimes we speak, one loud, another low,
119  According to desire of speech, that spurs us
120  To greater now and now to lesser pace.

118  Talor parla l'uno alto e l'altro basso,
119  secondo l'affezion ch'ad ir ci sprona
120  ora a maggiore e ora a minor passo:

121  But in the good that here by day is talked of,
122  Erewhile alone I was not; yet near by
123  No other person lifted up his voice."

121  però al ben che 'l dì ci si ragiona,
122  dianzi non era io sol; ma qui da presso
123  non alzava la voce altra persona.”

124  From him already we departed were,
125  And made endeavour to o'ercome the road
126  As much as was permitted to our power,

124  Noi eravam partiti già da esso,
125  e brigavam di soverchiar la strada
126  tanto quanto al poder n'era permesso,

127  When I perceived, like something that is falling,
128  The mountain tremble, whence a chill seized on me,
129  As seizes him who to his death is going.

127  quand' io senti', come cosa che cada,
128  tremar lo monte; onde mi prese un gelo
130  qual prender suol colui ch'a morte vada.

130  Certes so violently shook not Delos,
131  Before Latona made her nest therein
132  To give birth to the two eyes of the heaven.

130  Certo non si scoteo sì forte Delo,
131  pria che Latona in lei facesse 'l nido
132  a parturir li due occhi del cielo.

133  Then upon all sides there began a cry,
134  Such that the Master drew himself towards me,
135  Saying, "Fear not, while I am guiding thee."

133  Poi cominciò da tutte parti un grido
134  tal, che 'l maestro inverso me si feo,
135  dicendo: “Non dubbiar, mentr' io ti guido.”



136  "Gloria in excelsis Deo," all
137  Were saying, from what near I comprehended,
138  Where it was possible to hear the cry.

136  “Glorïa in excelsis” tutti “Deo”
137  dicean, per quel ch'io da' vicin compresi,
138  onde intender lo grido si poteo.

139  We paused immovable and in suspense,
140  Even as the shepherds who first heard that song,
141  Until the trembling ceased, and it was finished.

139  No' istavamo immobili e sospesi
140  come i pastor che prima udir quel canto,
141  fin che 'l tremar cessò ed el compiési.

142  Then we resumed again our holy path,
143  Watching the shades that lay upon the ground,
144  Already turned to their accustomed plaint.

142  Poi ripigliammo nostro cammin santo,
143  guardando l'ombre che giacean per terra,
144  tornate già in su l'usato pianto.

145  No ignorance ever with so great a strife
146  Had rendered me importunate to know,
147  If erreth not in this my memory,

145  Nulla ignoranza mai con tanta guerra
146  mi fé desideroso di sapere,
147 se la memoria mia in ciò non erra

148  As meditating then I seemed to have;
149  Nor out of haste to question did I dare,
150  Nor of myself I there could aught perceive;

148  quanta pareami allor, pensando, avere;
149  né per la fretta dimandare er' oso,
150  né per me lì potea cosa vedere:


151  So I went onward timorous and thoughtful.

151  così m'andava timido e pensoso.

Canto XXI
We are on the cornice of hoarders and wasters here, but what exactly is being hoarded and wasted?  What can simultaneously be hoarded and wasted?  It has to be Time, and more specifically the perception of Time that wastes itself by hoarding the status quo.  Here the shades cannot move.  

If in the previous canto, the poem has concerned itself with the idea of political dynasties and the chaotic disruptions of what should be peaceful successions, here we begin to focus on something that is indeed a peaceful and venerable process, that is to say, the influence of poets on successive poets, and the evolution and transmigrations of poetic styles and themes.  One of the satisfactions of reading Dante becomes upon closer examination also one of the frustrations, and vice versa because in attempting to plot a point to point graph of themes, metaphors, rhymes, connective tissues, et al, which constitute the work, one's awareness outstrips one's ability to connect the dots, and a sort of pulsing living mass of inextricable correspondences begins to corrode any static sense of order.  Then an organic proliferation arises in which any point whirls and melts along runnels that connects it to all other points.  The first three lines of this canto presents the metaphor of the well, and the dialog between Jesus in the woman of Samaria.  In the previous canto we have the mind as a sponge, the quest for knowledge is a thirst, here too it is a thirst.  Jesus may change ordinary water into living waters, as he changed ordinary water into wine at the wedding of Cana.   In Purgatorio, Canto XV we are advised to drink the waters of peace from a living fountain (line 132), and in Canto I, of the Inferno, Virgil is compared to a fountain (line 79).  All through the Commedia such connections arise, percolating throughout the work, and by a kind of osmosis travelling along microtubules of association,  They link up, one to another, and intermingle with Biblical, Historical, Political, Philosophical, Poetic, Linguistical, Moral, Mythical, Musical, Mathematical, Celestial, Geographical, and Geometrical references, until we realize this rhizomatic system (as Deleuze/Gauttari might say) continuously coalesces out of vapors, solidifies, grows, retreats, re-emerges and dissolves in a way that is not so much an analogy of the chaosmos as it is an extension of it — but with this caveat: Dante's organizing power is humanly intimate, personal, and humanly, intimately and personally selective.  Dante in his quest for God, in some ways exceeds the object of his quest, because he has eliminated the accidental and superfluous, and distilled out the liquor of genius.  And yet, look at line 4 here, and note the feeling tone of the entire first six lines.  The pivot is the word travail (mi travagliava), a word suggestive a woman in labor.  The aspirant has gone through Hell, and here in Purgatory, he sees shades in the throes of punishments, which in many ways are equal to or even more painfully astringent than those of Hell, and in spite of reassurances, he is in travail, the travail of desperation, of anxiety, of breathless need to "know" is escalating.  He must find something that will convert this desperation, if not into bliss, at least some modicum of calm.  Like a woman in labor, he has to be wondering what he has gotten himself into, and then Statius comes up from behind — note that, behind, his appearance following a Kundalini like tremoring, a literal sea change occurring in the text.  That hoarding and wasting of Time as status quo has changed.  There is movement.  Well, as Virgil notes, the entire mountain of Purgatory has been shaken to the chaos of its oceanic roots, and now we can pass into a feeling tone of admiration and gratitude, the very idea, at least for Statius, of punishment, self-punishment has worn itself out, and the zero point of new beginnings appears.  This admiration and gratitude must sneak up from behind, because with our two predators' eyes in the front, we will always be hypervigilant for the prey that the ego must feed upon to sustain its false sense of identity.  But what is being born here, can only be born of humility, and, in a way, in silence, in gestures, in positionality ... the penitents on the ground, the protagonists laboriously picking their slow way through crowds of unmoving bodies, shades so solid, that they must be respected as corporal bodies, and not just breezed through, an eyebrow raised to enforce an irrepressible smile, and from all this, a genuine joy is born.  Where have we seen Dante the aspirant smile before this?  This is not raucous laughter, but nevertheless this subtle joy provides a relief from the status quo of travail of desperation and anxiety.  What follows is a recognition scene, the recognition of the long-orphaned child for his progenitor.  The head of a newborn emotion is breeching, but it is still too male.  And yet, the poetry is clearly changing, becoming more humble, like the woman of Samaria, a humility that could only be from the anima, the feminine soul.  Note line 28, the soul being referred to by the diminutive of sorella, serocchia (sister, little sister), just as the woman of Samaria is referred to by the diminutive la femminetta.  Theirs is not the egotistic posture of humility: they are humble.  And what a change of tone from that first reference to the next one!  A feminization is occurring, but only in its first glimmers, as the almost inconsequential little sister who tags along and is easy to ignore or belittle.  The three male protagonists proceed with their exchanges of mutual admiration, yet still there is something off the mark.  That power which caused the entire mountain of Purgatory to be shaken to its tenuous foothold in the fecundity of the sea has been reduced to a little sister, a suppressed woman by the well.  If we have read Vita Nuova, we know that this cannot be the culmination point of our spiritual journey, the numinous earth-shattering quality of Beatrice is hardly a "little sister."   

The last image of the canto is especially touching, precisely because the need of Statius to touch, touch, mind you, the non-material feet of Virgil, reveals the humility of Virgil, but also is  a clear statement of his tragic limitations.  The poetry that Virgil represents, whose style gave birth to the poetry of Statius and that of Dante cannot fulfill the purpose of the Commedia, and did not lead to the liberation of Statius' soul.  The reader must realize this, and must realize that their own travail continues.  The birth process is beginning, but deliverance, delivery, is not yet at hand.  Certainly, Virgil's position here is genuinely tragic, in that the triumph of his style, and even the prophetic nature of his work, cannot lead to the triumph of the soul.  All this perhaps is the result of the aspirant's "timorous" pondering in the previous canto.  This timorous tentativeness puts him on the very ground of thought, and if he is to move it all, it can only be to ascend.

1  The natural thirst, that ne'er is satisfied
2  Excepting with the water for whose grace
3  The woman of Samaria besought,

1  La sete natural che mai non sazia
2  se non con l'acqua onde la femminetta
3  samaritana domandò la grazia,

4  Put me in travail, and haste goaded me
5  Along the encumbered path behind my Leader
6  And I was pitying that righteous vengeance;

4  mi travagliava, e pungeami la fretta
5  per la 'mpacciata via dietro al mio duca,
6  e condoleami a la giusta vendetta.

7  And lo! in the same manner as Luke writeth
8  That Christ appeared to two upon the way
9  From the sepulchral cave already risen,

7  Ed ecco, sì come ne scrive Luca
8  che Cristo apparve a' due ch'erano in via,
9  già surto fuor de la sepulcral buca,

10  A shade appeared to us, and came behind us,
11  Down gazing on the prostrate multitude,
12  Nor were we ware of it, until it spake,

10  ci apparve un'ombra, e dietro a noi venìa,
11  dal piè guardando la turba che giace;
12  né ci addemmo di lei, sì parlò pria,

13  Saying, "My brothers, may God give you peace!"
14  We turned us suddenly, and Virgilius rendered
15  To him the countersign thereto conforming.

13  dicendo: “O frati miei, Dio vi dea pace.”
14  Noi ci volgemmo sùbiti, e Virgilio
15  rendéli 'l cenno ch'a ciò si conface.

16  Thereon began he: "In the blessed council,
17  Thee may the court veracious place in peace,
18  That me doth banish in eternal exile!"

16  Poi cominciò: “Nel beato concilio
17  ti ponga in pace la verace corte
18  che me rilega ne l'etterno essilio.”

19  "How," said he, and the while we went with speed,
20  "If ye are shades whom God deigns not on high,
21  Who up his stairs so far has guided you?"

19  “Come!” diss' elli, e parte andavam forte:
20  “se voi siete ombre che Dio sù non degni,
21  chi v'ha per la sua scala tanto scorte?”

22  And said my Teacher: "If thou note the marks
23  Which this one bears, and which the Angel traces
24  Well shalt thou see he with the good must reign.

22  E 'l dottor mio: “Se tu riguardi a' segni
23  che questi porta e che l'angel profila,
24  ben vedrai che coi buon convien ch'e' regni. 

25  But because she who spinneth day and night
26  For him had not yet drawn the distaff off,
27  Which Clotho lays for each one and compacts,

25  Ma perché lei che dì e notte fila
26  non li avea tratta ancora la conocchia
27  che Cloto impone a ciascuno e compila,

28  His soul, which is thy sister and my own,
29  In coming upwards could not come alone,
30  By reason that it sees not in our fashion.

28  l'anima sua, ch'è tua e mia serocchia,
29  venendo sù, non potea venir sola,
30  però ch'al nostro modo non adocchia.

31  Whence I was drawn from out the ample throat
32  Of Hell to be his guide, and I shall guide him
33  As far on as my school has power to lead.

31  Ond' io fui tratto fuor de l'ampia gola
32  d'inferno per mostrarli, e mosterrolli
33  oltre, quanto 'l potrà menar mia scola.

34  But tell us, if thou knowest, why such a shudder
35  Erewhile the mountain gave, and why together
36  All seemed to cry, as far as its moist feet?"

34  Ma dimmi, se tu sai, perché tai crolli
35  diè dianzi 'l monte, e perché tutto ad una
36  parve gridare infino a' suoi piè molli.”

37  In asking he so hit the very eye
38  Of my desire, that merely with the hope
39  My thirst became the less unsatisfied.

37  Sì mi diè, dimandando, per la cruna
38  del mio disio, che pur con la speranza
39  si fece la mia sete men digiuna.

40  "Naught is there," he began, "that without order
41  May the religion of the mountain feel,
42  Nor aught that may be foreign to its custom.

40  Quei cominciò: “Cosa non è che sanza
41  ordine senta la religione
42  de la montagna, o che sia fuor d'usanza.

43  Free is it here from every permutation;
44  What from itself heaven in itself receiveth
45  Can be of this the cause, and naught beside;

43  Libero è qui da ogne alterazione:
44  di quel che 'l ciel da sé in sé riceve
45  esser ci puote, e non d'altro, cagione.

46  Because that neither rain, nor hail, nor snow,
47  Nor dew, nor hoar-frost any higher falls
48  Than the short, little stairway of three steps.

46  Per che non pioggia, non grando, non neve,
47  non rugiada, non brina più sù cade
48  che la scaletta di tre gradi breve;

49  Dense clouds do not appear, nor rarefied,
50  Nor coruscation, nor the daughter of Thaumas,
51  That often upon earth her region shifts;
 
49  nuvole spesse non paion né rade,
50  né coruscar, né figlia di Taumante,
51  che di là cangia sovente contrade;

52  No arid vapour any farther rises
53  Than to the top of the three steps I spake of,
54  Whereon the Vicar of Peter has his feet.

52  secco vapor non surge piu avante
53  ch'al sommo d'i tre gradi ch'io parlai,
54  dov' ha 'l vicario di Pietro le piante. 

55  Lower down perchance it trembles less or more,
56  But, for the wind that in the earth is hidden
57  I know not how, up here it never trembled.

55  Trema forse più giù poco o assai;
56  ma per vento che 'n terra si nasconda,
57  non so come, qua sù non tremò mai.

58  It trembles here, whenever any soul
59  Feels itself pure, so that it soars, or moves
60  To mount aloft, and such a cry attends it.

58  Tremaci quando alcuna anima monda
59  sentesi, sì che surga o che si mova
60  per salir sù; e tal grido seconda.

61  Of purity the will alone gives proof,
62  Which, being wholly free to change its convent,
63  Takes by surprise the soul, and helps it fly.

61  De la mondizia sol voler fa prova,
62  che, tutto libero a mutar convento,
63  l'alma sorprende, e di voler le giova.

64  First it wills well; but the desire permits not,
65  Which divine justice with the self-same will
66  There was to sin, upon the torment sets.

64  Prima vuol ben, ma non lascia il talento
65  che divina giustizia contra voglia,
66  come fu al peccar, pone al tormento.

67  And I, who have been lying in this pain
68  Five hundred years and more, but just now felt
69  A free volition for a better seat.

67  E io, che son giaciuto a questa doglia
68  cinquecent' anni e più, pur mo sentii
69  libera volontà di miglior soglia:

70  Therefore thou heardst the earthquake, and the pious
71  Spirits along the mountain rendering praise
72  Unto the Lord, that soon he speed them upwards."

70  però sentisti il tremoto e li pii
71  spiriti per lo monte render lode
72  a quel Segnor, che tosto sù li 'nvii.”

73  So said he to him; and since we enjoy
74  As much in drinking as the thirst is great,
75  I could not say how much it did me good.

73  Così ne disse; e però ch'el si gode
74  tanto del ber quant' è grande la sete,
75  non saprei dir quant' el mi fece prode.

76  And the wise Leader: "Now I see the net
77  That snares you here, and how ye are set free,
78  Why the earth quakes, and wherefore ye rejoice.

76  E 'l savio duca: “Omai veggio la rete
 77  che qui vi 'mpiglia e come si scalappia,
 78  perché ci trema e di che congaudete.

79  Now who thou wast be pleased that I may know;
80  And why so many centuries thou hast here
81  Been lying, let me gather from thy words."

79  Ora chi fosti, piacciati ch'io sappia,
80  e perché tanti secoli giaciuto
81  qui se', ne le parole tue mi cappia.”

82  "In days when the good Titus, with the aid
83  Of the supremest King, avenged the wounds
84  Whence issued forth the blood by Judas sold,

82  “Nel tempo che 'l buon Tito, con l'aiuto
83  del sommo rege, vendicò le fóra
84  ond' uscì 'l sangue per Giuda venduto

85  Under the name that most endures and honours,
86  Was I on earth," that spirit made reply,
87  "Greatly renowned, but not with faith as yet.

85  col nome che più dura e più onora
86  era io di là,” rispuose quello spirto,
87  “famoso assai, ma non con fede ancora.

88  My vocal spirit was so sweet, that Rome
89  Me, a Thoulousian, drew unto herself,
90  Where I deserved to deck my brows with myrtle.

88  Tanto fu dolce mio vocale spirto,
89  che, tolosano, a sé mi trasse Roma,
90  dove mertai le tempie ornar di mirto.

91  Statius the people name me still on earth;
92  I sang of Thebes, and then of great Achilles;
93  But on the way fell with my second burden.

91  Stazio la gente ancor di là mi noma:
92  cantai di Tebe, e poi del grande Achille;
93  ma caddi in via con la seconda soma.

94  The seeds unto my ardour were the sparks
95  Of that celestial flame which heated me,
96  Whereby more than a thousand have been fired;

94  Al mio ardor fuor seme le faville,
95  che mi scaldar, de la divina fiamma
96  onde sono allumati più di mille;

97  Of the Aeneid speak I, which to me
98  A mother was, and was my nurse in song;
99  Without this weighed I not a drachma's weight.

97  de l'Eneïda dico, la qual mamma
98  fummi, e fummi nutrice, poetando:
99  sanz' essa non fermai peso di drama.

100  And to have lived upon the earth what time
101  Virgilius lived, I would accept one sun
102  More than I must ere issuing from my ban."

100  E per esser vivuto di là quando
101  visse Virgilio, assentirei un sole
102  più che non deggio al mio uscir di bando”

103  These words towards me made Virgilius turn
104  With looks that in their silence said, "Be silent!"
105  But yet the power that wills cannot do all things;

103  Volser Virgilio a me queste parole
104  con viso che, tacendo, disse “Taci”;
105  ma non può tutto la virtù che vuole;

106  For tears and laughter are such pursuivants
107  Unto the passion from which each springs forth,
108  In the most truthful least the will they follow.

106  ché riso e pianto son tanto seguaci
107  a la passion di che ciascun si spicca,
108  che men seguon voler ne' più veraci.

109  I only smiled, as one who gives the wink;
110  Whereat the shade was silent, and it gazed
111  Into mine eyes, where most expression dwells;

109  Io pur sorrisi come l'uom ch'ammicca;
110  per che l'ombra si tacque, e riguardommi
111  ne li occhi ove 'l sembiante più si ficca;

112  And, "As thou well mayst consummate a labour
113  So great," it said, "why did thy face just now
114  Display to me the lightning of a smile?"

112  e “Se tanto labore in bene assommi,”
113  disse, “perché la tua faccia testeso
114  un lampeggiar di riso dimostromi?”

115  Now am I caught on this side and on that;
116  One keeps me silent, one to speak conjures me,
117  Wherefore I sigh, and I am understood.

115  Or son io d'una parte e d'altra preso:
116  l'una mi fa tacer, l'altra scongiura
107  ch'io dica; ond' io sospiro, e sono inteso

118  "Speak," said my Master, "and be not afraid
119  Of speaking, but speak out, and say to him
120  What he demands with such solicitude."

118  dal mio maestro, e “Non aver paura,”
119  mi dice, “di parlar; ma parla e digli
120  quel ch'e' dimanda con cotanta cura.”

121  Whence I: "Thou peradventure marvellest,
122  O antique spirit, at the smile I gave;
123  But I will have more wonder seize upon thee.

121  Ond' io: “Forse che tu ti maravigli,
122  antico spirto, del rider ch'io fei;
123  ma più d'ammirazion vo' che ti pigli.

124  This one, who guides on high these eyes of mine,
125  Is that Virgilius, from whom thou didst learn
126  To sing aloud of men and of the Gods.

124  Questi che guida in alto li occhi miei,
125  è quel Virgilio dal qual tu togliesti
126  forte a cantar de li uomini e d'i dèi.

127  If other cause thou to my smile imputedst,
128  Abandon it as false, and trust it was
129  Those words which thou hast spoken concerning him."

127  Se cagion altra al mio rider credesti,
128  lasciala per non vera, ed esser credi
129  quelle parole che di lui dicesti.”

130  Already he was stooping to embrace
131  My Teacher's feet; but he said to him: "Brother,
132  Do not; for shade thou art, and shade beholdest."

130  Già s'inchinava ad abbracciar li piedi
131  al mio dottor, ma el li disse: “Frate,
132  non far, ché tu se' ombra e ombra vedi.”

133  And he uprising: "Now canst thou the sum
134  Of love which warms me to thee comprehend,
135  When this our vanity I disremember,

133  Ed ei surgendo: “Or puoi la quantitate
134  comprender de l'amor ch'a te mi scalda,
135  quand' io dismento nostra vanitate,

136 Treating a shadow as substantial thing."

136  trattando l'ombre come cosa salda.”

Canto XXII
At the very beginning of this Canto, there is a retrograde temporal motion, in as much as the guardian angel of this new cornice has already appeared and already erased from the aspirant's forehead the "P" symbolizing the sin of avarice.  And yet a more surprising time distortion awaits.  The fact that Statius has modeled his verse on Virgil's a century after the maestro's death, is not surprising.  The fact that Dante has also done so, 13 centuries later is not surprising.  The fact that I am reading Dante's Commedia 8 hundred years after it was written is not surprising.  The fact that the post-mortem Virgil has read Statius' work written a more than a century after his death, this is surprising — very.  Because it implies that poetry exists in a sort of atemporal cloud, which any poet may tap into at any time, and so, if this is indeed the case, when I am writing now, Dante is reading me, and the influence runs both ways.  Such a phenomenon is absurd on the plane of historical time.  But not absurd in spiritual and/or poetic time.  For as Jesus affirms: Before Abraham was, I am. Does poetry live in an eternal present, which contains all times, all places, all entities?  Yes, because inspiration cannot be confined.  As we readers probe more deeply into the Commedia, we find that any of its verses might serve as a portal into a limitless domain where time is no longer a prison, and the organ-sack of the body no longer cloisters our identity.  Once we realize this, everywhere we look, ordinary reality is shown to be riddled with lacunae, wounds, holes, escape hatches, portals, and as does the Angel who erased another emblem of sin form the aspirant’s brow, we hear or internally sing that unfinished hymn, which hear an unseen voice voices.  There is always the effect here of unseen or untraceable cause, always the not quite here here, and even the living body of flesh, and blood, and bones, becomes lighter, becomes perforated with insight, becomes like the swift-footed spirits infused with the lightness of love.  The fact that centuries of commentators still ponder and squabble over the shapes of the ditches of hell, the cornices of purgatory, still seriously discuss the psychology of Virgil, or of the multitudes of shades, still puzzle over the time by the placement of fictional (or are they?) celestial bodies, still probe and concretize innumerable scenes, and ephemeralizing innumerable philosophical and theological conundrums shows us how skillful Dante is in creating a reality in his poem that becomes more compelling than the world of the reader beyond the text.  This poem warps our world, shows us its paradoxes, and everywhere burgeons with a way out, a way through the greater and far more painful absurdity of our mortal existence.  A great deal of what we read in this canto is a litany of names, of entities, most of who are in limbo, a strange place indeed for these pagan poets, where they live in a hell without suffering, where they exist in a hospital of the not quite there, not quite complete, where they express experiences that were never quite real, nor ever quite unreal.  Here, Dante, the supreme poet, talks about poetry's limitations, why poetry must be the servant of faith, and, paradoxically, how faith is revealed in the poetry of the scriptures.  Interestingly enough, this canto contains the single instance of what the commentators call a "nod", a temporary loss of consciousness, in so far as he has bilocated Manto, a soothsayer, both in limbo in and in the eighth circle of Hell.  Was this deliberate?  A way to show his own limitations?  In a like manner Amish quilt makers always incorporate on fouled stitch in their work, because only God can be perfect.  Whether this "mistake" were conscious or not, hardly matters, it's there, and it reinforces this theme of poetry's limitations.  Every poet, every proof reader, every programmer, every engineer knows that there are invariable little nodes of chaos embedded in even the most orderly of assemblages, almost as if perfection, to prove itself perfect, must retain a bit of chaos so that it will not become too static, and thereby, too oppressive.    Commentators have pointed out that Dante had little direct knowledge, if any, of the names he immortalizes, they are shadows of that cloud of poetry, which directly or indirectly, feed the entire corpus of the art.  Perhaps Dante is showing us another miracle here, one which infuses any language with all languages, as Joyce shows us in Finnegans Wake, a miracle which postulates something like a diffuse mystery of affinities, and perhaps the tree, we see at the end of this canto, with its curious shape, more like that of a fountain, than a tree, is really the stream of inspiration which every poet is presented with, its fruits, so tempting, and so nourishing, being those insights that poets derive from other poets, and not from some inner source burgeoning forth from life itself, and even more richly, from that faith which promises transcendence.  I would surmise that every symbol, every conversation, every image in this canto, and in all the versus of the Commedia, like this fountaining tree, are a kind of holographic waveform that may be interpreted by each reader in a way most conducive to their own understanding, their own growing-tip, their own need for nourishment or need for abstinence.  But we select parts and take them for the whole, and every bite from this tree of knowledge, serves as a kind of truncated summary which suggests to us that we are wisdom-fed, when really we are looking at ourselves in a funhouse mirror, which shows us as arrogantly obese with knowledge when, in actuality, that which we only think we know has left us extremely emaciated.  Whatever the case, Dante, the supreme poet, who does not in this canto enter into this discussion of the other poets, shows us by his silence, the very limitations of poetry, when compared to the fulness of faith.  He shows us that the greatest of poems are cross-fed by an unseen fountain and a mystical cloud, and do in fact achieve their greatness by incorporating in their expression the incomplete, the limited, the retrograde, the silence of the greatest in the presence of the merely vocal great.       

1  Already was the Angel left behind us,
2  The Angel who to the sixth round had turned us,
3  Having erased one mark from off my face;

1  Già era l'angel dietro a noi rimaso,
2  l'angel che n'avea vòlti al sesto giro,
3  avendomi dal viso un colpo raso;

4  And those who have in justice their desire
5  Had said to us, "Beati," in their voices,
6  With "sitio," and without more ended it.

4  e quei c'hanno a giustizia lor disiro
5  detto n'avea beati, e le sue voci
6  con 'sitiunt,' sanz'altro, ciò forniro.

7  And I, more light than through the other passes,
8  Went onward so, that without any labour
9  I followed upward the swift-footed spirits;

7  E io più lieve che per l'altre foci
8  m'andava, sì che sanz'alcun labore
9  seguiva in sù li spiriti veloci;

10  When thus Virgilius began: "The love
11  Kindled by virtue aye another kindles,
12  Provided outwardly its flame appear.

10  quando Virgilio incominciò: “Amore,
11  acceso di virtù, sempre altro accese,
12  pur che la fiamma sua paresse fore;

13  Hence from the hour that Juvenal descended
14  Among us into the infernal Limbo,
15  Who made apparent to me thy affection,

13  onde da l'ora che tra noi discese
14   nel limbo de lo 'nferno Giovenale,
15  che la tua affezion mi fé palese,

16  My kindliness towards thee was as great
17  As ever bound one to an unseen person,
18  So that these stairs will now seem short to me.

16  mia benvoglienza inverso te fu quale
17  più strinse mai di non vista persona,
18  sì ch'or mi parran corte queste scale.

19  But tell me, and forgive me as a friend,
20  If too great confidence let loose the rein,
21  And as a friend now hold discourse with me;

19  Ma dimmi, e come amico mi perdona
20  se troppo sicurtà m'allarga il freno,
21  e come amico omai meco ragiona:

22  How was it possible within thy breast
23  For avarice to find place, 'mid so much wisdom
24  As thou wast filled with by thy diligence?"

22  come poté trovar dentro al tuo seno
23  loco avarizia, tra cotanto senno
24  di quanto per tua cura fosti pieno?”

25  These words excited Statius at first
26  Somewhat to laughter; afterward he answered:
27  "Each word of thine is love's dear sign to me.

25  Queste parole Stazio mover fenno
26  un poco a riso pria; poscia rispuose:
27  “Ogne tuo dir d'amor m'è caro cenno.

28  Verily oftentimes do things appear
29  Which give fallacious matter to our doubts,
30  Instead of the true causes which are hidden!

28  Veramente più volte appaion cose
29  che danno a dubitar falsa matera
30  per le vere ragion che son nascose.

31  Thy question shows me thy belief to be
32  That I was niggard in the other life,
33  It may be from the circle where I was;

31  La tua dimanda tuo creder m'avvera
32  esser ch'i' fossi avaro in l'altra vita,
33  forse per quella cerchia dov'io era.

34  Therefore know thou, that avarice was removed
35  Too far from me; and this extravagance
36  Thousands of lunar periods have punished.

34  Or sappi ch'avarizia fu partita
35  troppo da me, e questa dismisura
36  migliaia di lunari hanno punita.

37  And were it not that I my thoughts uplifted,
38  When I the passage heard where thou exclaimest,
39  As if indignant, unto human nature,

37  e se non fosse ch'io drizzai mia cura,
38  quand'io intesi là dove tu chiame,
39  crucciato quasi a l'umana natura:

40  'To what impellest thou not, O cursed hunger
41  Of gold, the appetite of mortal men?'
42  Revolving I should feel the dismal joustings.

40  'Per che non reggi tu, o sacra fame
41  de l'oro, l'appetito de' mortali?',
42  voltando sentirei le giostre grame.

43  Then I perceived the hands could spread too wide
44  Their wings in spending, and repented me
45  As well of that as of my other sins;

43  Allor m'accorsi che troppo aprir l'ali
44  potean le mani a spendere, e pente'mi
45  così di quel come de li altri mali.

46  How many with shorn hair shall rise again
47  Because of ignorance, which from this sin
48  Cuts off repentance living and in death!

46  Quanti risurgeran coi crini scemi
47  per ignoranza,che di questa pecca
48  toglie 'l penter vivendo e ne li stremi!

49  And know that the transgression which rebuts
50  By direct opposition any sin
51  Together with it here its verdure dries.

51  E sappie che la colpa che rimbecca
52  per dritta opposizione alcun peccato,
53  con esso insieme qui suo verde secca;

52  Therefore if I have been among that folk
53  Which mourns its avarice, to purify me,
54  For its opposite has this befallen me."

54  però, s'io son tra quella gente stato
55  che piange l'avarizia, per purgarmi,
56  per lo contrario suo m'è incontrato.”

55  "Now when thou sangest the relentless weapons
56  Of the twofold affliction of Jocasta,"
57  The singer of the Songs Bucolic said,

55  “Or quando tu cantasti le crude armi
56  de la doppia trestizia di Giocasta,”
57  disse 'l cantor de' buccolici carmi,

58  "From that which Clio there with thee preludes,
59  It does not seem that yet had made thee faithful
60  That faith without which no good works suffice.
 
58  “per quello che Clïò teco lì tasta,
59  non par che ti facesse ancor fedele
60  la fede, sanza qual ben far non basta.

61  If this be so, what candles or what sun
62  Scattered thy darkness so that thou didst trim
63  Thy sails behind the Fisherman thereafter?"

61  Se così è, qual sole o quai candele
62  ti stenebraron sì, che tu drizzasti
63  poscia di retro al pescator le vele?”

64  And he to him: "Thou first directedst me
65  Towards Parnassus, in its grots to drink,
66  And first concerning God didst me enlighten.

64  Ed elli a lui: “Tu prima m'invïasti
65  verso Parnaso a ber ne le sue grotte,
66  e prima appresso Dio m'alluminasti.

67  Thou didst as he who walketh in the night,
68  Who bears his light behind, which helps him not,
69  But wary makes the persons after him,

67  Facesti come quei che va di notte,
68  che porta il lume dietro e sé non giova,
69  ma dopo sé fa le persone dotte,

70  When thou didst say: 'The age renews itself,
71  Justice returns, and man's primeval time,
72  And a new progeny descends from heaven.'

70  quando dicesti: 'Secol si rinova;
71  torna giustizia e primo tempo umano,
72  e progenïe scende da ciel nova.'

73  Through thee I Poet was, through thee a Christian;
74  But that thou better see what I design,
75  To colour it will I extend my hand.

73  Per te poeta fui, per te cristiano:
74  ma perché veggi mei ciò ch'io disegno,
75  a colorare stenderò la mano.

76  Already was the world in every part
77  Pregnant with the true creed, disseminated
78  By messengers of the eternal kingdom;

76  Già era 'l mondo tutto quanto pregno
77  de la vera credenza, seminata
78  per li messaggi de l'etterno regno;

79  And thy assertion, spoken of above,
80  With the new preachers was in unison;
81  Whence I to visit them the custom took.

79  e la parola tua sopra toccata
80  si consonava a' nuovi predicanti;
81  ond'io a visitarli presi usata.

82  Then they became so holy in my sight,
83  That, when Domitian persecuted them,
84  Not without tears of mine were their laments;

82  Vennermi poi parendo tanto santi,
83  che, quando Domizian li perseguette,
84  sanza mio lagrimar non fur lor pianti;

85  And all the while that I on earth remained,
86  Them I befriended, and their upright customs
87  Made me disparage all the other sects.

85  e mentre che di là per me si stette,
86  io li sovvenni, e i lor dritti costumi
87  fer dispregiare a me tutte altre sette.

88  And ere I led the Greeks unto the rivers
89  Of Thebes, in poetry, I was baptized,
90  But out of fear was covertly a Christian,

88  E pria ch'io conducessi i greci a' fiumi
89  di Tebe poetando, ebb' io battesmo;
90  ma per paura chiuso cristian fu'mi,

91  For a long time professing paganism;
92  And this lukewarmness caused me the fourth circle
93  To circuit round more than four centuries.

91  lungamente mostrando paganesmo;
92  e questa tepidezza il quarto cerchio
93  cerchiar mi fé più che 'l quarto centesmo.

94  Thou, therefore, who hast raised the covering
95  That hid from me whatever good I speak of,
96  While in ascending we have time to spare,

94  Tu dunque, che levato hai il coperchio
95  che m'ascondeva quanto bene io dico,
96  mentre che del salire avem soverchio,

97  Tell me, in what place is our friend Terentius,
98  Caecilius, Plautus, Varro, if thou knowest;
99  Tell me if they are damned, and in what alley."

97  dimmi dov' è Terrenzio nostro antico,
98  Cecilio e Plauto e Varro, se lo sai:
99  dimmi se son dannati, e in qual vico.”
100  "These, Persius and myself, and others many,"
101  Replied my Leader, "with that Grecian are
102  Whom more than all the rest the Muses suckled,

100  “Costoro e Persio e io e altri assai,”
101  rispuose il duca mio, “siam con quel Greco
102  che le Muse lattar più ch'altri mai,

103  In the first circle of the prison blind;
104  Ofttimes we of the mountain hold discourse
105  Which has our nurses ever with itself.

103  nel primo cinghio del carcere cieco;
104  spesse fïate ragioniam del monte
105  che sempre ha le nutrice nostre seco.

106  Euripides is with us, Antiphon,
107  Simonides, Agatho, and many other
108  Greeks who of old their brows with laurel decked.

106  Euripide v'è nosco e Antifonte,
107  Simonide, Agatone e altri piùe
108  Greci che già di lauro ornar la fronte.

109  There some of thine own people may be seen,
110  Antigone, Deiphile and Argia,
111  And there Ismene mournful as of old.

109  Quivi si veggion de le genti tue
110  Antigone, Deïfile e Argia,
111  e Ismene sì trista come fue.

112  There she is seen who pointed out Langia;
113  There is Tiresias' daughter, and there Thetis,
114  And there Deidamia with her sisters."

112  Védeisi quella che mostrò Langia;
113  èvvi la figlia di Tiresia, e Teti,
114  e con le suore sue Deïdamia.”

115  Silent already were the poets both,
116  Attent once more in looking round about,
117  From the ascent and from the walls released;

115  Tacevansi ambedue già li poeti,
116  di novo attenti a riguardar dintorno,
117  liberi da saliri e da pareti;

118  And four handmaidens of the day already
119  Were left behind, and at the pole the fifth
120  Was pointing upward still its burning horn,

118  e già le quattro ancelle eran del giorno
119  rimase a dietro, e la quinta era al temo,
120  drizzando pur in sù l'ardente corno,

121  What time my Guide: "I think that tow'rds the edge
122  Our dexter shoulders it behoves us turn,
123  Circling the mount as we are wont to do."

121  quando il mio duca: “Io credo ch'a lo stremo
122 le destre spalle volger ne convegna,
123  girando il monte come far solemo.”

124  Thus in that region custom was our ensign;
125  And we resumed our way with less suspicion
126  For the assenting of that worthy soul

124  Così l'usanza fu lì nostra insegna,
125  e prendemmo la via con men sospetto
126  per l'assentir di quell' anima degna.

127  They in advance went on, and I alone
128  Behind them, and I listened to their speech,
129  Which gave me lessons in the art of song.

127  Elli givan dinanzi, e io soletto
128  di retro, e ascoltava i lor sermoni,
129  ch'a poetar mi davano intelletto.

130  But soon their sweet discourses interrupted
131  A tree which midway in the road we found,
132  With apples sweet and grateful to the smell.

130  Ma tosto ruppe le dolci ragioni
131  un alber che trovammo in mezza strada,
132  con pomi a odorar soavi e buoni;

133  And even as a fir-tree tapers upward
134  From bough to bough, so downwardly did that;
135  I think in order that no one might climb it.

133  e come abete in alto si digrada
134  di ramo in ramo, cosi quello in giuso,
135  cred' io, perché persona sù non vada.

136  On that side where our pathway was enclosed
137  Fell from the lofty rock a limpid water,
138  And spread itself abroad upon the leaves.

136  Dal lato onde 'l cammin nostro era chiuso,
137  cadea de l'alta roccia un liquor chiaro
138  e si spandeva per le foglie suso.

139  The Poets twain unto the tree drew near,
140  And from among the foliage a voice
141  Cried: "Of this food ye shall have scarcity."

139  Li due poeti a l'alber s'appressaro;
140  e una voce per entro le fronde
141  gridò: “Di questo cibo avrete caro.”

142  Then said: "More thoughtful Mary was of making
143  The marriage feast complete and honourable,
144  Than of her mouth which now for you responds;

142  Poi disse: “Più pensava Maria onde
143  fosser le nozze orrevoli e intere,
144  ch'a la sua bocca, ch'or per voi risponde.

145  And for their drink the ancient Roman women
146  With water were content; and Daniel
147  Disparaged food, and understanding won.

145  E le Romane antiche, per lor bere,
146  contente furon d'acqua; e Danïello
147  dispregiò cibo e acquistò savere.

148  The primal age was beautiful as gold;
149  Acorns it made with hunger savorous,
150  And nectar every rivulet with thirst.

148  Lo secol primo, quant' oro fu bello,
149  fé savorose con fame le ghiande,
150  e nettare con sete ogne ruscello.

151  Honey and locusts were the aliments
152  That fed the Baptist in the wilderness;
153  Whence he is glorious, and so magnified

151  Mele e locuste furon le vivande
152  che nodriro il Batista nel diserto;
153  per ch'elli è glorïoso e tanto grande

154  As by the Evangel is revealed to you."

154  quanto per lo Vangelio v'è aperto.”

Canto XXIII
On this cornice devoted to the sin of gluttony, we learn that all the fat added to the basic bones — i.e., the just necessities — of life is subtracted by a hunger and thirst for that mysterious tree whose icon completed the last canto.  The shades here are reduced to that single longing, and for this reason, for all their suffering, they are discovering the paradoxical truth that freedom does not come from giving oneself the licence to over-indulge, but rather by a proper restraint.  But here, because of their previous excesses, the penitents must ride the pendulum as it swings from one extreme to another, and they find themselves reduced to a leprous emaciation.  There is something very Aristotelian about this, and a damned hard way to discover a golden mean.  But put another way, that out of the pleasure of indulging in the extreme sensual pleasure of a tongue devoted to eating is born, here in purgatory, the extreme spiritual pleasure of using the tongue for prayer.  The rather excruciating analogy for this is Christ crying out in the extremity of his pain on the cross, the terrible prayer of confused forsakenness.  Here, Jesus does not take the atheistical position of "there is no God," but rather cries to re-establish an intimacy with God through the inexplicable suffering of his crucifixion.  Pain, grief, hopelessness, despair are all excoriations, the stripping away of any illusion, including the supreme illusion of the permanence of mortal life — because who in the midst of life, can believe in their own death? — and a return to something barebones, an initial condition, which never explains itself, because its very Isness needs no justification.  In extreme states of either suffering or bliss, as the pendulum swings to the farthest point on its arch, we get a glimpse of the ever-mysterious beyond, and it is this glimpse of the unattainable, that draws as back to the mean, almost as if we were children, curious about a flame, who, reach into it, only to feel that blistering revelation, from which all mortal bodies, quickly and reflexively withdraw.  The real miracle of Dante's pilgrimage as a living person, as a poet, and as a mendicant is his courage in exploring these extremes, while still remaining centered in his task.  What makes this grace possible?  I think two things.  On the one hand a thirst and hunger for knowledge, a curiosity to discover how language can explore and expose the inner workings of history, of personalities, of geographies, of nature, and of the roots of suffering and joy — and it is this curiosity which Commedia personifies in Virgil.  He satisfies that curiosity with the wisdom that can be satisfied by mere knowledge.  But knowledge is limited, while grace is not.  Grace is based on that which can never be satisfied by mere knowledge, which in the Commedia, is not just Dante's love for Beatrice, but even more crucially, her love for him.  As the reader has moved steadily up the mount of purgatory, more and more, this curiosity is being satisfied, not by Virgilian knowledge, but by a continually reiterated promise: Your curiosity will be obviated by love.  You will see your version of Beatrice again.  This promise is faith, and Donati's story contrasting the licentious women of Florence and the virtue of his widow, Nella, whose prayers have quite literally drawn him out of Hell, is meant, I believe, as a foreshadowing of Dante's coming meeting with Beatrice.  If we remember those passages in Vita Nuova wherein the very sight of Beatrice scattered his senses and made him almost incapable of movement, we see the confusion of bliss which has swung to the other extreme from the confusion of Jesus on the cross.  On what subject does prayer, contemplation, and meditation dwell?  This canto's very first verses of the naive aspirant being mesmerized by the this strange green tree and its company of little (trivial?) birds provides the frame for what follows.  And what follows concludes with a reiteration of that earthshaking liberation of salvation, by which every soul in purgatory is shaken.   

1  The while among the verdant leaves mine eyes
2  I riveted, as he is wont to do
3  Who wastes his life pursuing little birds,

1  Mentre che li occhi per la fronda verde
2  ficcava ïo sì come far suole
3  chi dietro a li uccellin sua vita perde,

4  My more than Father said unto me: "Son,
5  Come now; because the time that is ordained us
6  More usefully should be apportioned out."

4  lo più che padre mi dicea: “Figliuole,
5  vienne oramai, ché 'l tempo che n'è imposto
6  più utilmente compartir si vuole.”

7  I turned my face and no less soon my steps
8  Unto the Sages, who were speaking so
9  They made the going of no cost to me;

7  Io volsi 'l viso, e 'l passo non men tosto,
8  appresso i savi, che parlavan sìe,
9  che l'andar mi facean di nullo costo.

10  And lo! were heard a song and a lament,
11  "Labia mea, Domine," in fashion
12  Such that delight and dolence it brought forth.

10  Ed ecco piangere e cantar s'udìe
11 “Labïa mëa, Domine” per modo
12  tal, che diletto e doglia parturìe.

13  "O my sweet Father, what is this I hear?"
14  Began I; and he answered: "Shades that go
15  Perhaps the knot unloosing of their debt."

13  “O dolce padre, che è quel ch'i' odo?”
14  comincia' io; ed elli: “Ombre che vanno
15  forse di lor dover solvendo il nodo.”

16  In the same way that thoughtful pilgrims do,
17  Who, unknown people on the road o'ertaking,
18  Turn themselves round to them, and do not stop,

16  Sì come i peregrin pensosi fanno,
17  giugnendo per cammin gente non nota,
18  che si volgono ad essa e non restanno,

19  Even thus, behind us with a swifter motion
20  Coming and passing onward, gazed upon us
21  A crowd of spirits silent and devout.

19  così di retro a noi, più tosto mota,
20  venendo e trapassando ci ammirava
21  d'anime turba tacita e devota.

22  Each in his eyes was dark and cavernous,
23  Pallid in face, and so emaciate
24  That from the bones the skin did shape itself.

22  Ne li occhi era ciascuna oscura e cava,
23  palida ne la faccia, e tanto scema
24  che da l'ossa la pelle s'informava.

25  I do not think that so to merest rind
26  Could Erisichthon have been withered up
27  By famine, when most fear he had of it.

25  Non credo che così a buccia strema
26  Erisittone fosse fatto secco,
27  per digiunar, quando più n'ebbe tema.

28  Thinking within myself I said: "Behold,
29  This is the folk who lost Jerusalem,
30  When Mary made a prey of her own son."

28  Io dicea fra me stesso pensando: “Ecco
29  la gente che perdé Ierusalemme,
30  quando Maria nel figlio diè di becco!”

31  Their sockets were like rings without the gems;
32  Whoever in the face of men reads 'omo'
33  Might well in these have recognised the 'm.'

31  Parean l'occhiaie anella sanza gemme:
32  chi nel viso de li uomini legge “omo”
33  ben avria quivi conosciuta l'emme. 

34  Who would believe the odour of an apple,
35  Begetting longing, could consume them so,
36  And that of water, without knowing how?

34  Chi crederebbe che l'odor d'un pomo
35  sì governasse, generando brama,
36  e quel d'un'acqua, non sappiendo como?

37  I still was wondering what so famished them,
38  For the occasion not yet manifest
39  Of their emaciation and sad squalor;

37  Già era in ammirar che sì li affama,
38  per la cagione ancor non manifesta
39  di lor magrezza e di lor trista squama,

40  And lo! from out the hollow of his head
41  His eyes a shade turned on me, and looked keenly;
42  Then cried aloud: "What grace to me is this?"

40  ed ecco del profondo de la testa
41  volse a me li occhi un'ombra e guardò fiso;
42  poi gridò forte: “Qual grazia m'è questa?”

43  Never should I have known him by his look;
44  But in his voice was evident to me
45  That which his aspect had suppressed within it.

43  Mai non l'avrei riconosciuto al viso;
44  ma ne la voce sua mi fu palese
45  ciò che l'aspetto in sé avea conquiso.

46  This spark within me wholly re-enkindled
47  My recognition of his altered face,
48  And I recalled the features of Forese.

46  Questa favilla tutta mi raccese
47  mia conoscenza a la cangiata labbia,
48  e ravvisai la faccia di Forese.

49  "Ah, do not look at this dry leprosy,"
50  Entreated he, "which doth my skin discolour,
51  Nor at default of flesh that I may have;

49  “Deh, non contendere a l'asciutta scabbia
50  che mi scolora,” pregava, “la pelle,
51  né a difetto di carne ch'io abbia;

52  But tell me truth of thee, and who are those
53  Two souls, that yonder make for thee an escort;
54  Do not delay in speaking unto me."

52  ma dimmi il ver di te, dì chi son quelle
53  due anime che là ti fanno scorta;
54  non rimaner che tu non mi favelle!”

55  "That face of thine, which dead I once bewept,
56  Gives me for weeping now no lesser grief,"
57  I answered him, "beholding it so changed!

55  “La faccia tua, ch'io lagrimai già morta,
56  mi dà di pianger mo non minor doglia,”
57  rispuos' io lui, “veggendola sì torta.

58  But tell me, for God's sake, what thus denudes you?
59  Make me not speak while I am marvelling,
60  For ill speaks he who's full of other longings."

58  Però mi dì, per Dio, che sì vi sfoglia;
59  non mi far dir mentr' io mi maraviglio,
60  ché mal può dir chi è pien d'altra voglia.”

61  And he to me: "From the eternal council
62  Falls power into the water and the tree
63  Behind us left, whereby I grow so thin.

61  Ed elli a me: “De l'etterno consiglio
62  cade vertù ne l'acqua e ne la pianta
63  rimasa dietro, ond' io sì m'assottiglio.

64  All of this people who lamenting sing,
65  For following beyond measure appetite
66  In hunger and thirst are here re-sanctified.

64  Tutta esta gente che piangendo canta
65  per seguitar la gola oltra misura,
66  in fame e 'n sete qui si rifà santa.

67  Desire to eat and drink enkindles in us
68  The scent that issues from the apple-tree,
69  And from the spray that sprinkles o'er the verdure;

67  Di bere e di mangiar n'accende cura
68  l'odor ch'esce del pomo e de lo sprazzo
69  che si distende su per sua verdura.

70  And not a single time alone, this ground
71  Encompassing, is refreshed our pain,—
72  I say our pain, and ought to say our solace,—

70  E non pur una volta, questo spazzo
71  girando, si rinfresca nostra pena:
72  io dico pena, e dovria dir sollazzo,

73  For the same wish doth lead us to the tree
74  Which led the Christ rejoicing to say 'Eli,'
75  When with his veins he liberated us."

73  ché quella voglia a li alberi ci mena
74  che menò Cristo lieto a dire 'Elì,'
75  quando ne liberò con la sua vena.”

76  And I to him: "Forese, from that day
77  When for a better life thou changedst worlds,
78  Up to this time five years have not rolled round.

76  E io a lui: “Forese, da quel dì
77  nel qual mutasti mondo a miglior vita,
78  cinqu' anni non son vòlti infino a qui.

79  If sooner were the power exhausted in thee
80  Of sinning more, than thee the hour surprised
81  Of that good sorrow which to God reweds us,

79  Se prima fu la possa in te finita
80  di peccar più, che sovvenisse l'ora
81  del buon dolor ch'a Dio ne rimarita,

82  How hast thou come up hitherward already?
83  I thought to find thee down there underneath,
84  Where time for time doth restitution make."

82  come se' tu qua sù venuto ancora?
83  Io ti credea trovar là giù di sotto,
84  dove tempo per tempo si ristora.”

85  And he to me: "Thus speedily has led me
86  To drink of the sweet wormwood of these torments,
87  My Nella with her overflowing tears;

85  Ond' elli a me: “Sì tosto m'ha condotto
86  a ber lo dolce assenzo d'i martìri
87  la Nella mia con suo pianger dirotto.

88  She with her prayers devout and with her sighs
89  Has drawn me from the coast where one where one awaits,
90  And from the other circles set me free.

88  Con suoi prieghi devoti e con sospiri
89  tratto m'ha de la costa ove s'aspetta,
90  e liberato m'ha de li altri giri.

91  So much more dear and pleasing is to God
92  My little widow, whom so much I loved,
93  As in good works she is the more alone;

91  Tanto è a Dio più cara e più diletta
92  la vedovella mia, che molto amai,
93  quanto in bene operare è più soletta;

94  For the Barbagia of Sardinia
95  By far more modest in its women is
96  Than the Barbagia I have left her in.

94  ché la Barbagia di Sardigna assai
95  ne le femmine sue più è pudica
96  che la Barbagia dov' io la lasciai.

97  O brother sweet, what wilt thou have me say?
98  A future time is in my sight already,
99  To which this hour will not be very old,

97  O dolce frate, che vuo' tu ch'io dica?
98  Tempo futuro m'è già nel cospetto,
99  cui non sarà quest' ora molto antica,

100  When from the pulpit shall be interdicted
101  To the unblushing womankind of Florence
102  To go about displaying breast and paps.

100  nel qual sarà in pergamo interdetto
101  a le sfacciate donne fiorentine
102  l'andar mostrando con le poppe il petto.

103  What savages were e'er, what Saracens,
104  Who stood in need, to make them covered go,
105  Of spiritual or other discipline?

103  Quai barbare fuor mai, quai saracine,
104  cui bisognasse, par farle ir coperte,
105  o spiritali o altre discipline?

106  But if the shameless women were assured
107  Of what swift Heaven prepares for them, already
108  Wide open would they have their mouths to howl;

106  Ma se le svergognate fosser certe
107  di quel che 'l ciel veloce loro ammanna,
108  già per urlare avrian le bocche aperte;

109  For if my foresight here deceive me not,
110  They shall be sad ere he has bearded cheeks
111  Who now is hushed to sleep with lullaby.

109  ché, se l'antiveder qui non m'inganna,
110  prima fien triste che le guance impeli
111  colui che mo si consola con nanna.

112  O brother, now no longer hide thee from me;
113  See that not only I, but all these people
114  Are gazing there, where thou dost veil the sun."

112  Deh, frate, or fa che più non mi ti celi!
113  vedi che non pur io, ma questa gente
114  tutta rimira là dove 'l sol veli.”

115  Whence I to him: "If thou bring back to mind
116  What thou with me hast been and I with thee,
117  The present memory will be grievous still.

115  Per ch'io a lui: “Se tu riduci a mente
116  qual fosti meco, e qual io teco fui,
117  ancor fia grave il memorar presente.

118  Out of that life he turned me back who goes
119  In front of me, two days agone when round
120  The sister of him yonder showed herself,"

118  Di quella vita mi volse costui
119  che mi va innanzi, l'altr' ier, quando tonda
120  vi si mostrò la suora di colui,”

121  And to the sun I pointed. "Through the deep
122  Night of the truly dead has this one led me,
123  With this true flesh, that follows after him.

121  e 'l sol mostrai; “costui per la profonda
122  notte menato m'ha d'i veri morti
123  con questa vera carne che 'l seconda.

124  Thence his encouragements have led me up,
125  Ascending and still circling round the mount
126  That you doth straighten, whom the world made crooked.

124  Indi m'han tratto sù li suoi conforti,
124  salendo e rigirando la montagna
125  che drizza voi che 'l mondo fece torti. 

127  He says that he will bear me company,
128  Till I shall be where Beatrice will be;
129  There it behoves me to remain without him.

127  Tanto dice di farmi sua compagna
128  che io sarò là dove fia Beatrice;
128  quivi convien che sanza lui rimagna.

130  This is Virgilius, who thus says to me,"
131  And him I pointed at; "the other is
132  That shade for whom just now shook every slope

130  Virgilio è questi che così mi dice,”
131  e addita'lo; “e quest' altro è quell' ombra
132  per cuï scosse dianzi ogne pendice

133  Your realm, that from itself discharges him."

133  lo vostro regno, che da sé lo sgombra.”

Canto XXIV
One feature of Dante's style that made the Commedia especially alive for his contemporaries and especially daunting for each generation since is that he names names.  Naming comes to the forefront in this canto, although there is hardly a canto in the poem wherein it is not featured, so that we have to ask, for Dante, What's in a name?  Names are the ego's boast, but does even our own name belong to us?  Or is it something like a linguistic pheromone that marks our passage through a variety of points of view, a social orientation and navigation device, that leaves it beaconing marker beeping in times and places, in families, in languages, in occupations, in the class distinctions of human primate troop hierarchies, in ancestral catalogs, in communal memory, or as exemplars of praise or infamy in systems of morality.  Names also provide a way to coordinate the action of pack hunters, to identify skills and occupation, and perhaps, most importantly of all, as a way to knit together a gossip community which may refer to a person, discuss them, probe their influences, when they are not physically present, or even if they are dead.  Names are file markers to trigger memory and by which we might deduce the outlines of a hypothetical future or of the loka of such realms as Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven.  Forese says that the necessity for his naming the shades on this cornice is derived from the circumstance that emaciation has so distorted their features that they would otherwise be unrecognizable, and no doubt it is true that most of us have dreams, in which a figure appears, whose features are a mystery, but whom nevertheless, we know, that this image represents our mother, a friend or even ourselves.  Naming goes deep, and is so essential that current research suggests (See Virginia Morell's book: Animal Wise) that many other animals, also have ways of distinguishing individuals.  This canto continues the discussion of poetry, the quintessential conjuring of non-present people and of emotional states in the absence of any response trigger in the environment except that of the poem.  In a curious way, Dante is linking poetic inspiration, the soul, naming, faith, transcendence, and immortality.  And how does he connect all these things?  If we recall discussions from the previous cantos, we might already divine the answer.  They spring from the same source as the cosmos itself, and constitute the creating and connecting power that Dante called God, namely: Love.  The following verses are the pivot point for the canto, spoken by Bonaguinta to Dante about Dante:

49  But say if him I here behold, who forth
50  Evoked the new-invented rhymes, beginning,
51  'Ladies, that have intelligence of love?'"

49  Ma dì s'i'veggio qui colui che fore
50  trasse le nove rime, cominciando
51  “Donne ch'avete intelletto d'amore.”

The line "Donne ch'avete intellectto d'amore" (Ladies who have the intelligence of love) comes from a canzone of Dante's in his Vita Nuova, a line which he says was dictated to him by Love, and which he says he noted down.  The poet is the amanuensis of a higher power, and that power is Love.  Simple, no?  How does the poet, the scribe, make himself fit for his task?  Certainly not through the mere knowledge or by egotistical puffing.  He walks along a river, and becomes the mere process of flow, he allows himself to become, like the Virgin Mary, a humble vessel of love's grace.  We have here a very sharp distinction between what Dante claims is the source of his poetry, and the kind of poetry that Virgil and Statius have been talking about.  It is almost as if Dante, absorbed in the talk of the two older poets, lost even in adulation, suddenly wakes up when Forese mentions the name Piccarda.  Forese's sister is in heaven, and Dante now seems to understand as he hears a whole litany of names, that as swiftly as he has been walking, he, like Statius, who has been freed of this cornice, is now being held back by Virgilian concepts of fame, wisdom, and style, and we have here a recapitulation with the line "Ladies that have the intelligence of love," of the scene in which Dante originally saw Beatrice — one lady, among others, whose influence is like that of one star in the heavens spangled with stars. Now he remembers who sent Virgil to begin with, and why.  So why have this discussion on a cornice devoted to gluttony?  Perhaps because, Dante, the aspirant, has repeatedly shown himself to be a glutton in the few cantos previous by too assiduously hungering and thirsting for knowledge (the fountain metaphor, the sponge metaphor).  He is now realizing, as are the shades on this cornice, that his appetite may have been misdirected, and the very reason for this insatiability, this gluttonousness, was because he was feeding his capon with air.  The hunger, the thirst was a craving for love.

None of this would be news to any doctor who has studied the psychology of eating disorders.  If food is not food, but an inadequate substitute for something else, no amount of food will ever satisfy that ghost hunger.  The emaciation of the shades on this cornice shows the true condition of someone who has attempted this substitution.  The trees here represent food that is denied, and which if eaten would perpetuate this state of misplaced desire in the gluttonous.  Gluttony has sexual connotations, gluttony in lust are enmeshed, as Forese misogynistic denunciation of wanton women in the previous canto has informed us.  Nevertheless, as serious as the sin of gluttony is, there is something innocent about it too, as the text shows us by comparing the penitents to children leaping to catch a treat from an adult who withholds it.  All these sins of concupiscence — avarice, gluttony, and lust — are merely perverted excesses of natural desires, and they do not damage the soul so much the spiritual sins of pride, wrath, envy, and sloth.  More tangential to this argument linking gluttony/lust is that which associates the sin of gluttony with the politics of factionalism, and, what is the main argument in this canto the contrasting of vituperation and praise as styles of poetry.  Are we to bark like dogs, as they do in the Inferno, or to sing like angels?  This links the styles of poetry with the impulse which motivates its expression.  Is that impulse destructive, the expression of pride or hatred, or is it one of humility, a longing for justice, an expression of love?  In the first instance, it is the ego's barking, and in the second it is souls submission to the dictations of its own deepest source.  Why link gluttony with poetry?   Because they are both matters of taste, matters of the mouth, as Jesus has said, in Matthew 15: 11: "Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which moveth out of the mouth, this defileth a man."  And now, lest we misunderstand by this the question of themes, it is not simply what the poet talks about, but how he talks about it, the appropriateness of his rhythms, his harmonies, and that is why Bonaguinta can say that Dante is exhibiting the sweet new style, even when the latter deals with subject that are most vile.    
  
1  Nor speech the going, nor the going that
2  Slackened; but talking we went bravely on,
3  Even as a vessel urged by a good wind.

1  Né il dir l' andar, né l' andar lui più lento
2  facea, ma ragionando andavam forte,
3  sì come nave pinta da buon vento;

4  And shadows, that appeared things doubly dead,
5  From out the sepulchres of their eyes betrayed
6  Wonder at me, aware that I was living.

4  e l'ombre, che parean cose rimorte,
5  per le fosse de li occhi ammirazione
6  traean di me, di mio vivere accorte.

7  And I, continuing my colloquy,
8  Said: "Peradventure he goes up more slowly
9  Than he would do, for other people's sake.

7  E io, continüando al mio sermone,
8  dissi: “Ella sen va sù forse più tarda
9  che non farebbe, per altrui cagione.

10  But tell me, if thou knowest, where is Piccarda;
11  Tell me if any one of note I see
12  Among this folk that gazes at me so."

10  Ma dimmi, se tu sai, dov' è Piccarda;
11  dimmi s'io veggio da notar persona
12  tra questa gente che sì mi riguarda.” 

13  "My sister, who, 'twixt beautiful and good,
14  I know not which was more, triumphs rejoicing
15  Already in her crown on high Olympus."

13  “La mia sorella, che tra bella e buona
14  non so qual fosse più, trïunfa lieta
15  ne l'alto Olimpo già di sua corona.”

16  So said he first, and then: "'Tis not forbidden
17  To name each other here, so milked away
18  Is our resemblance by our dieting.

16  Sì disse prima; e poi: “Qui non si vieta
17  di nominar ciascun, da ch'è sì munta
18  nostra sembianza via per la dïeta.

19  This," pointing with his finger, "is Buonagiunta,
20  Buonagiunta, of Lucca; and that face
21  Beyond him there, more peaked than the others,

19  ”Questi,“ e mostrò col dito, ”è Bonagiunta,
20  Bonagiunta da Lucca; e quella faccia
21  di là da lui più che l'altre trapunta

22  Has held the holy Church within his arms;
23  From Tours was he, and purges by his fasting
24  Bolsena's eels and the Vernaccia wine."

22  ebbe la Santa Chiesa in le sue braccia:
23  dal Torso fu, e purga per digiuno
24  l'anguille di Bolsena e la vernaccia.“

25  He named me many others one by one;
26  And all contented seemed at being named,
27  So that for this I saw not one dark look.

25  Molti altri mi nomò ad uno ad uno;
26  e del nomar parean tutti contenti,
27  sì ch'io però non vidi un atto bruno.

28  I saw for hunger bite the empty air
29  Ubaldin dalla Pila, and Boniface,
30  Who with his crook had pastured many people.

28  Vidi per fame a vòto usar li denti
29  Ubaldin da la Pila e Bonifazio
30  che pasturò col rocco molte genti.

31  I saw Messer Marchese, who had leisure
32  Once at Forli for drinking with less dryness,
33  And he was one who ne'er felt satisfied.

31  Vidi messer Marchese, ch'ebbe spazio
32  già di bere a Forlì con men secchezza,
33  e sì fu tal, che non si sentì sazio.

34  But as he does who scans, and then doth prize
35  One more than others, did I him of Lucca,
36  Who seemed to take most cognizance of me.

34  Ma come fa chi guarda e poi s'apprezza
35  più d'un che d'altro, fei a quel da Lucca,
36  che più parea di me aver contezza.

37  He murmured, and I know not what Gentucca
38   From that place heard I, where he felt the wound
39  Of justice, that doth macerate them so.

37  El mormorava; e non so che ”Gentucca“
38  sentiv' io là, ov' el sentia la piaga
39  de la giustizia che sì li pilucca.

40  "O soul," I said, "that seemest so desirous
41  To speak with me, do so that I may hear thee,
42  And with thy speech appease thyself and me."

40  ”O anima,“ diss' io, ”che par sì vaga
41  di parlar meco, fa sì ch'io t'intenda,
42  e te e me col tuo parlare appaga.“

43  "A maid is born, and wears not yet the veil,"
44  Began he, "who to thee shall pleasant make
45  My city, howsoever men may blame it.

43  ”Femmina è nata, e non porta ancor benda,“
44  cominciò el, ”che ti farà piacere
45  la mia città, come ch'om la riprenda.

46  Thou shalt go on thy way with this prevision;
47  If by my murmuring thou hast been deceived,
48  True things hereafter will declare it to thee.

46  Tu te n'andrai con questo antivedere:
47  se nel mio mormorar prendesti errore,
48  dichiareranti ancor le cose vere.

49  But say if him I here behold, who forth
50  Evoked the new-invented rhymes, beginning,
51  'Ladies, that have intelligence of love?'"

49  Ma dì s'i'veggio qui colui che fore
50  trasse le nove rime, cominciando
51  “Donne ch'avete intelletto d'amore.”

52  And I to him: "One am I, who, whenever
53  Love doth inspire me, note, and in that measure
54  Which he within me dictates, singing go."

52  E io a lui: “I' mi son un che, quando
53  Amor mi spira, noto, e a quel modo
54  ch'e' ditta dentro vo significando.”

55  "O brother, now I see," he said, "the knot
56  Which me, the Notary, and Guittone held
57  Short of the sweet new style that now I hear.

55  “O frate, issa vegg' io,” diss' elli, “il nodo
56  che 'l Notaro e Guittone e me ritenne
57  di qua dal dolce stil novo ch'i' odo!

58  I do perceive full clearly how your pens
59  Go closely following after him who dictates,
60  Which with our own forsooth came not to pass;

58  Io veggio ben come le vostre penne
59  di retro al dittator sen vanno strette,
60  che de le nostre certo non avvenne;

61  And he who sets himself to go beyond,
62  No difference sees from one style to another;"
63  And as if satisfied, he held his peace.

61  e qual più a gradire oltre si mette,
62  non vede più da l'uno a l'altro stilo”;
63  e, quasi contentato, si tacette.

64  Even as the birds, that winter tow'rds the Nile,
65  Sometimes into a phalanx form themselves,
66  Then fly in greater haste, and go in file;

61  e qual più a gradire oltre si mette,
62  non vede più da l'uno a l'altro stilo”;
63  e, quasi contentato, si tacette.

67  In such wise all the people who were there,
68  Turning their faces, hurried on their steps,
69  Both by their leanness and their wishes light.

67  così tutta la gente che lì era,
68  volgendo 'l viso, raffrettò suo passo,
69  e per magrezza e per voler leggera.

70  And as a man, who weary is with trotting,
71  Lets his companions onward go, and walks,
72  Until he vents the panting of his chest;

70  E come l'uom che di trottare è lasso,
71  lascia andar li compagni, e sì passeggia
72   fin che si sfoghi l'affollar del casso,

73  So did Forese let the holy flock
74  Pass by, and came with me behind it, saying,
75  "When will it be that I again shall see thee?"

73  sì lasciò trapassar la santa greggia
74  Forese, e dietro meco sen veniva,
75  dicendo: “Quando fia ch'io ti riveggia?”

76  "How long," I answered, "I may live, I know not;
77  Yet my return will not so speedy be,
78  But I shall sooner in desire arrive;

76  “Non so,” rispuos' io lui, “quant' io mi viva;
77  ma già non fïa il tornar mio tantosto,
78  ch'io non sia col voler prima a la riva;

79  Because the place where I was set to live
80  From day to day of good is more depleted,
81  And unto dismal ruin seems ordained."

79  però che 'l loco u' fui a viver posto,
80  di giorno in giorno più di ben si spolpa,
81  e a trista ruina par disposto.”

82  "Now go," he said, "for him most guilty of it
83  At a beast's tail behold I dragged along
84  Towards the valley where is no repentance.

82  “Or va,” diss' el; “che quei che più n'ha colpa,
83  vegg' ïo a coda d'una bestia tratto
84  inver' la valle ove mai non si scolpa.

85  Faster at every step the beast is going,
86  Increasing evermore until it smites him,
87  And leaves the body vilely mutilated.

85  La bestia ad ogne passo va più ratto,
86  crescendo sempre, fin ch'ella il percuote,
87  e lascia il corpo vilmente disfatto.
88  Not long those wheels shall turn," and he uplifted
89  His eyes to heaven, "ere shall be clear to thee
90  That which my speech no farther can declare.

88  Non hanno molto a volger quelle ruote,”
89 e drizzò li occhi al ciel, “che ti fia chiaro
90  ciò che 'l mio dir più dichiarar non puote.

91  Now stay behind; because the time so precious
92  Is in this kingdom, that I lose too much
93  By coming onward thus abreast with thee."

91  Tu ti rimani omai; ché 'l tempo è caro
92  in questo regno, sì ch'io perdo troppo
93  venendo teco sì a paro a paro.”

94  As sometimes issues forth upon a gallop
95  A cavalier from out a troop that ride,
