96  And seeks the honour of the first encounter,

94  Qual esce alcuna volta di gualoppo
95 lo cavalier di schiera che cavalchi,
96 e va per farsi onor del primo intoppo,

97  So he with greater strides departed from us;
98  And on the road remained I with those two,
99  Who were such mighty marshals of the world.

97  tal si partì da noi con maggior valchi;
98  e io rimasi in via con esso i due
99 che fuor del mondo sì gran marescalchi.

100  And when before us he had gone so far
101  Mine eyes became to him such pursuivants
102  As was my understanding to his words,

100  E quando innanzi a noi intrato fue,
101  che li occhi miei si fero a lui seguaci,
102  come la mente a le parole sue,

103  Appeared to me with laden and living boughs
104  Another apple-tree, and not far distant,
105  From having but just then turned thitherward.

103  parvermi i rami gravidi e vivaci
104  d'un altro pomo, e non molto lontani
105  per esser pur allora vòlto in laci.

106  People I saw beneath it lift their hands,
107  And cry I know not what towards the leaves,
108  Like little children eager and deluded,

106  Vidi gente sott' esso alzar le mani
107  e gridar non so che verso le fronde,
108  quasi bramosi fantolini e vani

109  Who pray, and he they pray to doth not answer,
109  But, to make very keen their appetite,
110  Holds their desire aloft, and hides it not.

108  che pregano, e 'l pregato non risponde,
110  ma, per fare esser ben la voglia acuta,
110  tien alto lor disio e nol nasconde.

112  Then they departed as if undeceived;
113  And now we came unto the mighty tree
114  Which prayers and tears so manifold refuses.

112  Poi si partì sì come ricreduta;
113  e noi venimmo al grande arbore adesso,
114  che tanti prieghi e lagrime rifiuta.

115  "Pass farther onward without drawing near;
116  The tree of which Eve ate is higher up,
117  And out of that one has this tree been raised."

115  “Trapassate oltre sanza farvi presso:
116  legno è più sù che fu morso da Eva,
117  e questa pianta si levò da esso.”

118  Thus said I know not who among the branches;
119  Whereat Virgilius, Statius, and myself
120  Went crowding forward on the side that rises.

118  Sì tra le frasche non so chi diceva;
119  per che Virgilio e Stazio e io, ristretti,
120  oltre andavam dal lato che si leva.

121  "Be mindful," said he, "of the accursed ones
122  Formed of the cloud-rack, who inebriate
123  Combated Theseus with their double breasts;

121  “Ricordivi,” dicea, “d'i maladetti
122  nei nuvoli formati, che, satolli,
123  Tesëo combatter co' doppi petti;

124  And of the Jews who showed them soft in drinking,
125  Whence Gideon would not have them for companions
126  When he tow'rds Midian the hills descended."

124  e de li Ebrei ch'al ber si mostrar molli,
125  per che no i volle Gedeon compagni,
126  quando inver' Madïan discese i colli.”

127  Thus, closely pressed to one of the two borders,
128  On passed we, hearing sins of gluttony,
129  Followed forsooth by miserable gains;

127  Sì accostati a l'un d'i due vivagni
128  passammo, udendo colpe de la gola
129  seguite già da miseri guadagni.

130  Then set at large upon the lonely road,
131  A thousand steps and more we onward went,
132  In contemplation, each without a word.

130  Poi, rallargati per la strada sola,
131  ben mille passi e più ci portar oltre,
132  contemplando ciascun sanza parola.

133  "What go ye thinking thus, ye three alone?"
134  Said suddenly a voice, whereat I started
135  As terrified and timid beasts are wont.

133  “Che andate pensando sì voi sol tre?”
134  sùbita voce disse; ond' io mi scossi
135  come fan bestie spaventate e poltre.

136  I raised my head to see who this might be,
137  And never in a furnace was there seen
138  Metals or glass so lucent and so red

136  Drizzai la testa per veder chi fossi;
137  e già mai non si videro in fornace
138  vetri o metalli sì lucenti e rossi,

139  As one I saw who said: "If it may please you
140  To mount aloft, here it behoves you turn;
141  This way goes he who goeth after peace."

139  com'io vidi un che dicea: “S'a voi piace
140  montare in sù, qui si convien dar volta;
141  quinci si va chi vuole andar per pace.”

142  His aspect had bereft me of my sight,
143  So that I turned me back unto my Teachers,
144  Like one who goeth as his hearing guides him.

142  L'aspetto suo m'avea la vista tolta;
143  per ch'io mi volsi dietro a' miei dottori,
144  com' om che va secondo ch'elli ascolta.

145  And as, the harbinger of early dawn,
146  The air of May doth move and breathe out fragrance,
147  Impregnate all with herbage and with flowers,

145  E quale, annunziatrice de li albori,
146  l'aura di maggio movesi e olezza,
147  tutta impregnata da l'erba e da' fiori;

148  So did I feel a breeze strike in the midst
149  My front, and felt the moving of the plumes
150  That breathed around an odour of ambrosia;

148  tal mi senti' un vento dar per mezza
149  la fronte, e ben senti' mover la piuma,
150  che fé sentir d'ambrosïa l'orezza.

151  And heard it said: "Blessed are they whom grace
152  So much illumines, that the love of taste
153  Excites not in their breasts too great desire,

151  E senti' dir: “Beati cui alluma
152  tanto di grazia, che l'amor del gusto
153  nel petto lor troppo disir non fuma,

154  Hungering at all times so far as is just."

154  esurïendo sempre quanto è giusto!”

Canto XXV
The impossible-to-resolve difficulty of prosifying poetry is analogous to what Freud discovered when attempting to analyze a dream, the analyzing prose as it enters the dream or the poem, becomes interminably verbose and incomplete.   The poem, being the product of condensation, displacement, and puns has sequestered within its porous membrane an immensity of times, a plurosity of spaces, and like an atom, contains only the tiniest smatters of matter, organizing and dispersing what, upon any prosaic examination, appears to be nothing but a vacuum.  From these infinitesimal bits of virtually virtual substantialities the poet leaps from one tidbit to another, traversing like smoke the fascinating gaps that constitute the ephemeral body of the poem.  This leaping about from one gravitational field, through antigravitational or amorphous gravitational mysteries, is poetry métier, and because it can express the inexpressible it is the queen of all philosophies, theologies and sciences, the music of language when language explodes from its algebra.  Robert Bly recognized this, and wrote:

The links {i.e., leaps} are not private, but somehow bound to nature.

Thought of in terms of language, then, leaping is the ability to associate fast.  In a great ancient or modern poem, the considerable distance between the associations, the distance the spark has to leap, gives the lines their bottomless feeling, their space, and the speed of the association increases the excitement of the poetry (Leaping Poetry, p.4,).

Any audience of a poem will find themselves in multiple worlds, those consisting of the text, as selected by the poet, according to his own associations, and those consisting of the text as it appears to them, according to their own associations.  Must we add that the more nimble the poet, the more associations, and the subtler the audience, the more those associations proliferate?  Dante's text reaches backward in time to Virgil (and here also to Statius), and then through Virgil to Homer.   Our Dantean text reaches backward in time to Dante, and via Dante to Virgil, and via Virgil to Homer, and all the possible texts cast a light forward to who knows how many readers in how many times and places in the future.  Backward and forward, up and down, are important here, but are not the only way to perceive this text.  One might also say that the associations form a sort of temporal gravity well, in which past and future are swept down to the point of the present, where, looking or reading up from that point, the reader/listener may see the entire panorama of associations, whirling around in kaleidoscopic fashion, each slight shift of perspective bringing a dazzling new configuration, wherein, at the moment when text and text interpreter meet, an entire universe arises from this psychic-Ptolemaic pivot, spinning and transmuting as fast or as slow as the reader/listener's perception and imagination may allow. 

The situation in Canto XXV of the Purgatorio is this: Circling to the right around the conical mountain, Virgil, Statius, and Dante, are speeding up a narrow defile between lust's fires that shoot out of the mountain, and the edge of the abyss, the updraft from below bending the flames back enough to clear a dangerous corridor for their ascent.  The constellation Taurus (stubbornness, persistence) and Scorpio (single-mindedness, ambition) lie 180 degrees opposite one another, one in light, one in night, and from these heavenly wheelings we tell the time.  The threesome hurries, lest the sting (il traffigge) pierce or wound them.  

The narrowness of the gap separates the climbers, Virgil in the lead, and we remember from a previous canto, that his pagan wisdom is a lantern which shines behind him, guiding Statius and Dante on a path obscure to his own soul.  In this single-file manner, cranes, or storks (often confused with one another) fly.  And we remember how in Canto V of the Inferno, the most illustrious of the lechers, fly by in a line, like cranes.  Now we have the simile of Dante, the aspirant and questioner, comparing himself to a fledgling stork, i.e., an infant (that word is important, and we will come back to it) wanting to fly, to understand, but as yet unable or too timid to ask to be fed (remember the gluttonous, and associations conflating eating and speaking, i.e. the recitations of poems.)  Dante opens his mouth, like a baby bird, signaling that he wants to be fed.  Virgil reads this gesture and being referred to as "father" (i.e., provider, feeder), grants Dante permission to speak.  The simile Virgil uses is that of an arrow, when the string of the bow is extended to the full, and the iron tip (a penetrating tip like the Scorpion's sting) is touching the shaft of the bow — Association of speed, time's arrow, a fledgling ready to launch from the nest (lo nido).  Now the mouth opens to eat a substance that has no substance (wisdom) to ask how shades without substance and without the need for physical nourishment, can grow gaunt from lack of eating — their mouths abjuring food, as we know, to feast on prayer, the obesity of their sin thereby blissfully wasting so that they may grow light enough, as Statius has done, and Dante is doing, to fly up the mountain to paradise.  

Now, Statius speaks, because being Christian, his authority exceeds that of pagan Virgil's, not as a poet, but as a soul.  And he precedes his dissertation on gestation with curious stories whereby events may be connected without being linked by substance, or the propinquity of time or space. (Shades of Bell's theorem! acausal causes, we might say!)  The first exemplar is that of the  length of Meleager's life being determined by how long a log brand takes to be consumed by fire (lust, eating).  Statius tells Dante that remembering this tale would make his question seem less sour (taste, mouth, sweetness).  The second exemplar is that of a mirror, wherein an image, or shade, is absolutely subservient to its cause, the substance, through a medium that is neither shade nor substance, the mirror.  The verse here connects guizzo/tremulous and guizza/trembling, just as a mirror connects image-source and image.  Virgil then tells Dante that Statius will speak and heal his (Dante's) wounds, and we are brought back to that Scorpion’s sting, which tells us where we are in time.  All this in the first 30 lines of the canto, leap after leap after leap of metaphors that continually connect the links of the narrative flow.  Here, we might stop, too, in consider how the operations of language itself, its incongruous small-mouth noises, it's scrawled scratchings, translating sound to silence and silence to sound, seems also to be an entity operating in an intermediate state, its effects on the world of substance being non-material, it's meaning and metaphors produced independent of its sounds and scrawls.  What is language?  And more to the point here, What is poetry.  How does it work?  How does it achieve it's effects?  How is it made, and to what purpose?  All of these fundemental questions, curiously enough, lie beyond the power of poetry, or even language, to explain.  All we can say is that it is an art which weaves a web of mystery around it's own sources.

From verse 37 to verse 108 there follows a long dissertation by Statius on physical and psychic embryology, which the modern reader might well be tempted, mistakenly I believe, to skip, as obsolete medieval superstition masking as science.  But recall what was said above about the text speaking in two worlds, the world of the poet's intention, and the world of reader's retention.  What we contemporary readers are called upon to do is not to dismiss, but to transmutate — for Statius' exposition is all about transmutation — the substance of the text, to a new set of images, which fit our world.  This act of transmutation is exactly what our own future readers will hopefully do when they examine our works, our seeming literalness becoming allegorical.  Recall here what Jung did for alchemy turning what seemed to be bad chemistry into deep psychology, for the medieval mind, as we've previously pointed out, was systematic, the soul was always embedded in any material or natural substance, and this is a process of universal mind, our mind as well as the minds of 1st century Statius and Virgil, and the mind of 14th century Dante, and if we look into the tremulous trembling mirror image of Statius' embryology, we will find curious parallels to those ways of knowing which we, too often abandoning the truths of poetry, have come to regard as the observations of science.  For the facts of scientific observation are also transmuted, that is, turned into theory, and these theories are always meta-explanations which attempt to account for the observations, in short, we often use scientific "facts" to support metaphysical positions, and this is what Statius is doing here, and this is neither the fact of substance, nor the image of observations, as the proponents of physics' Copenhagen School have told us, but some curious entangled hybrid, revealed in the deep poetry of their equations.  Reality, whatever it may be, is less like Newtonian billiard balls and more like the protean ephemeralities of language. The curious linkages between the material and the immaterial is what this canto, and also what poetry at its most profound, is all about.

Poetry is the easiest thing in the world to experience, and the hardest thing in the world to understand.  A poem is an immersion and an emergence, not a puzzle.  The conscious prose mind seeks clarity, but instead creates hard edges and impenetrable surfaces.  Real clarity is dazzling, a prismatic mist that becomes more dazzling and finer mist as it is more deeply probed.  Verses 91 -93 in this canto describe this process, the forms of the spirits are as air, full of rain, illuminated by the alien mist of the superconsciousness.  This is the world that has nothing to do with linear time, scholastic grammar, or pagan logic.  On one side of the brain is a world stripped down by so-called waking consciousness to a mere plus or minus seven elements, these elements shelter in connective words like "and," and "now," and "when," and "thus," and "therefore," and "hence," and by this means this last bit of evolution's cerebral experiments ventures into a realm called logic and apparent choice.  But seven is an unbalanced number, it cannot be divided into two, thus one side of the spit will always be dominant.  The conscious mind has the gift of choice, it can create alternative scenarios, and is not merely reflexive, and yet its choices cannot be enacted, only virtually perceived.  That tiny seven has nothing like the power of the unconscious.  It finds that its impotence, its inability to balance itself, its perpetual conflict is a stricture, a ligature that binds, and that binding arranges each infinite image of the unconscious or superconscious into a finite progression called logic, or grammar, which are experienced as sequential time.  This part of the mind attempts to resolve its unending, uneven conflicts by enforcing a deliberate act of limitation.  The clue to resolving this uneven conflict lies in its unevenness, domination and repression, pride and shame, keep oscillating in that perpetual war which Dante describes so well in the Inferno.  The resolution to the finite is the infinite, and just beneath this order of logic with its disorder of moral judgement is poetry, and the dream.  Just beneath this thinnest of veneers is the entire matrix of sensory and conceptual impressions and associations, the actual teeming morass from which the truncating dishonesty of grammatical syntax emerges.  These prose words enforce the conscious waking belief that we perceive things and associate one thing to another in the orderly manner by which those connecting words arrange them.  But let us take those words away, in this case from Statius' long dissertation.  Let us cut the string of syntax that arranges our impressions in single file, just as the poets are ascending in single file, from oldest to youngest, up the purgatorial mountain.  And further, let us dissolve the historical glue that conflates physiology, theology, and philosophy into something like an explanation of the acausal magic of events; i.e. Einstein's "spooky action at a distance," all these trillions and trillions of things operating together as if they were floating in the invisible current which mandated their affinity ... what then do we make of Statius' speech?  Do we not experience it just as we would a poem by Garcia Lorca, by Caesar Vallejo, by Pablo Neruda?  Would we not find affinities between these verses and those of Wallace Stevens in works like Sea Surface Full of Clouds?  Suddenly we are tumbling and swirling about in Dante's verses in a cascade of images, perceptions, concepts: Blood, thirsts, the leavings of a feast, the opalescence of semen, several processes of digestion, by infants (there's that word again, derived from the Latin fari, i.e., one with the potential of speech), the fermentation of sunlight into wine, the bursting of seeds into plants, the contractive pulses of sponges, insanguinated vessels, the animation of the primate animal into a human intellect by a puff of the same Divine Breath, which spoke the world into being with its word, and by which force the clouds above our heads are moved, and the poet's mouth is moved to versify.  And we find death, and the existence of post-mortem poem-bodies, entities as intricate as those composed of physical matter, weird things like reputations comprised not of flesh, bone, nerve, and blood, but of rainbow mists, organized insolubly by intensified affect and belief ... this, this then is the actual realm of Bly's lightning quick associations, the leaping ephemeral qualia which neuroscientists call the "hard problem" of consciousness.  That hard problem is not solved, but it is certainly exposed and expressed by poetry, and in no poetry that I know, is it better expressed than by Dante's.   
         
1  Now was it the ascent no hindrance brooked,
2  Because the sun had his meridian circle
3  To Taurus left, and night to Scorpio;

1  Ora era onde 'l salir non volea storpio;
2  ché 'l sole avëa il cerchio di merigge
3  lasciato al Tauro e la notte a lo Scorpio:

4  Wherefore as doth a man who tarries not,
5  But goes his way, whate'er to him appear,
6  If of necessity the sting transfix him,

4  per che, come fa l'uom che non s'affigge
5  ma vassi a la via sua, che che li appaia,
6  se di bisogno stimolo il trafigge,

7  In this wise did we enter through the gap,
8  Taking the stairway, one before the other,
9  Which by its narrowness divides the climbers.

7  così intrammo noi per la callaia,
8  uno innanzi altro prendendo la scala
9  che per artezza i salitor dispaia.

10  And as the little stork that lifts its wing
11  With a desire to fly, and does not venture
12  To leave the nest, and lets it downward droop,

10  E quale il cicognin che leva l'ala
11  per voglia di volare, e non s'attenta
12  d'abbandonar lo nido, e giù la cala;

13  Even such was I, with the desire of asking
14  Kindled and quenched, unto the motion coming
15  He makes who doth address himself to speak.

13  tal era io con voglia accesa e spenta
14  di dimandar, venendo infino a l'atto
15  che fa colui ch'a dicer s'argomenta.

16  Not for our pace, though rapid it might be,
17  My father sweet forbore, but said: "Let fly
18  The bow of speech thou to the barb hast drawn."

16  Non lasciò, per l'andar che fosse ratto,
17  lo dolce padre mio, ma disse: “Scocca
18  l'arco del dir, che 'nfino al ferro hai tratto.”

19  With confidence I opened then my mouth,
20  And I began: "How can one meagre grow
21  There where the need of nutriment applies not?"

19  Allor sicuramente apri' la bocca
20  e cominciai: “Come si può far magro
21  là dove l'uopo di nodrir non tocca?”

22  "If thou wouldst call to mind how Meleager
23  Was wasted by the wasting of a brand,
24  This would not," said he, "be to thee so sour;

22  “Se t'ammentassi come Meleagro
23  si consumò al consumar d'un stizzo,
24  non fora,” disse, “a te questo sì agro;

25  And wouldst thou think how at each tremulous motion
26  Trembles within a mirror your own image;
27  That which seems hard would mellow seem to thee.

25  e se pensassi come, al vostro guizzo,
26  guizza dentro a lo specchio vostra image,
27  ciò che par duro ti parrebbe vizzo.

28  But that thou mayst content thee in thy wish
29  Lo Statius here; and him I call and pray
30  He now will be the healer of thy wounds."

28  Ma perché dentro a tuo voler t'adage,
29  ecco qui Stazio; e io lui chiamo e prego
30  che sia or sanator de le tue piage.”

31  "If I unfold to him the eternal vengeance,"
32  Responded Statius, "where thou present art,
33  Be my excuse that I can naught deny thee."

31  “Se la veduta etterna li dislego,”
32  rispuose Stazio, “là dove tu sie,
33  discolpi me non potert' io far nego.”

34  Then he began: "Son, if these words of mine
35  Thy mind doth contemplate and doth receive,
36  They'll be thy light unto the How thou sayest.

34  Poi cominciò: “Se le parole mie,
35  figlio, la mente tua guarda e riceve,
36  lume ti fiero al come che tu die.

37  The perfect blood, which never is drunk up
38  Into the thirsty veins, and which remaineth
39  Like food that from the table thou removest,

37  Sangue perfetto, che poi non si beve
37  da l'assetate vene, e si rimane
39  quasi alimento che di mensa leve,

40  Takes in the heart for all the human members
41  Virtue informative, as being that
42  Which to be changed to them goes through the veins

40  prende nel core a tutte membra umane
41  virtute informativa, come quello
42  ch'a farsi quelle per le vene vane.

43  Again digest, descends it where 'tis better
44  Silent to be than say; and then drops thence
45  Upon another's blood in natural vase.

43  Ancor digesto, scende ov' è più bello
44  tacer che dire; e quindi poscia geme
45  sovr' altrui sangue in natural vasello. 

46  There one together with the other mingles,
47  One to be passive meant, the other active
48  By reason of the perfect place it springs from;

46  Ivi s'accoglie l'uno e l'altro insieme,
47  l'un disposto a patire, e l'altro a fare
48  per lo perfetto loco onde si preme;

49  And being conjoined, begins to operate,
50  Coagulating first, then vivifying
51  What for its matter it had made consistent.

49  e, giunto lui, comincia ad operare
50  coagulando prima, e poi avviva
51  ciò che per sua matera fé constare.

52  The active virtue, being made a soul
53  As of a plant, (in so far different,
54  This on the way is, that arrived already,)

52  Anima fatta la virtute attiva
53  qual d'una pianta, in tanto differente,
54  che questa è in via e quella è già a riva,

55  Then works so much, that now it moves and feels
56  Like a sea-fungus, and then undertakes
57  To organize the powers whose seed it is.

55  tanto ovra poi, che già si move e sente,
56  come spungo marino; e indi imprende
57  ad organar le posse ond' è semente.

58  Now, Son, dilates and now distends itself
59  The virtue from the generator's heart,
60  Where nature is intent on all the members.

58  Or si spiega, figliuolo, or si distende
59  la virtù ch'è dal cor del generante,
60  dove natura a tutte membra intende.

61  But how from animal it man becomes
62  Thou dost not see as yet; this is a point
63  Which made a wiser man than thou once err

61  Ma come d'animal divegna fante,
62  non vedi tu ancor: quest' è tal punto,
63  che più savio di te fé già errante,

64  So far, that in his doctrine separate
65  He made the soul from possible intellect,
66  For he no organ saw by this assumed.

64  sì che per sua dottrina fé disgiunto
65  da l'anima il possibile intelletto,
66  perché da lui non vide organo assunto.

67  Open thy breast unto the truth that's coming,
68  And know that, just as soon as in the foetus
69  The articulation of the brain is perfect,

67  Apri a la verità che viene il petto;
68  e sappi che, sì tosto come al feto
68  l'articular del cerebro è perfetto,

70  The primal Motor turns to it well pleased
71  At so great art of nature, and inspires
72  A spirit new with virtue all replete,

70  lo motor primo a lui si volge lieto
71  sovra tant' arte di natura, e spira
72  spirito novo, di vertù repleto,

73  Which what it finds there active doth attract
74  Into its substance, and becomes one soul,
75  Which lives, and feels, and on itself revolves.

73  che ciò che trova attivo quivi, tira
74  in sua sustanzia, e fassi un'alma sola,
75  che vive e sente e sé in sé rigira.

76  And that thou less may wonder at my word,
77  Behold the sun's heat, which becometh wine,
78  Joined to the juice that from the vine distils.

76  E perché meno ammiri la parola,
77  guarda il calor del sol che si fa vino,
78  giunto a l'omor che de la vite cola.

79  Whenever Lachesis has no more thread,
80  It separates from the flesh, and virtually
81  Bears with itself the human and divine;

79  Quando Làchesis non ha più del lino,
80  solvesi da la carne, e in virtute
81  ne porta seco e l'umano e 'l divino:

82  The other faculties are voiceless all;
83  The memory, the intelligence, and the will
84  In action far more vigorous than before.

82  l'altre potenze tutte quante mute;
83  memoria, intelligenza e volontade
84  in atto molto più che prima agute.

85  Without a pause it falleth of itself
86  In marvellous way on one shore or the other;
87  There of its roads it first is cognizant.

85  Sanza restarsi, per sé stessa cade
86  mirabilmente a l'una de le rive;
87  quivi conosce prima le sue strade.

88  Soon as the place there circumscribeth it,
89  The virtue informative rays round about,
90  As, and as much as, in the living members.

88  Tosto che loco lì la circunscrive,
89  la virtù formativa raggia intorno
90  così e quanto ne le membra vive.

91  And even as the air, when full of rain,
92  By alien rays that are therein reflected,
93  With divers colours shows itself adorned,

91  E come l'aere, quand' è ben pïorno,
92  per l'altrui raggio che 'n sé si reflette,
93  di diversi color diventa addorno;

94  So there the neighbouring air doth shape itself
95  Into that form which doth impress upon it
96  Virtually the soul that has stood still.

94  così l'aere vicin quivi si mette
95  e in quella forma ch'è in lui suggella
96  virtüalmente l'alma che ristette;

97  And then in manner of the little flame,
98  Which followeth the fire where'er it shifts,
99  After the spirit followeth its new form.

97  e simigliante poi a la fiammella
98  che segue il foco là 'vunque si muta,
99  segue lo spirto sua forma novella.

100  Since afterwards it takes from this its semblance,
101  It is called shade; and thence it organizes
102  Thereafter every sense, even to the sight.

100  Però che quindi ha poscia sua paruta,
101  è chiamata ombra; e quindi organa poi
102  ciascun sentire infino a la veduta.

103  Thence is it that we speak, and thence we laugh;
104  Thence is it that we form the tears and sighs,
105  That on the mountain thou mayhap hast heard.

103  Quindi parliamo e quindi ridiam noi;
104  quindi facciam le lagrime e ' sospiri
105  che per lo monte aver sentiti puoi.

106  According as impress us our desires
107  And other affections, so the shade is shaped,
108  And this is cause of what thou wonderest at."

106  Secondo che ci affliggono i disiri
107  e li altri affetti, l'ombra si figura;
108  e quest' è la cagion di che tu miri.”

109  And now unto the last of all the circles
110  Had we arrived, and to the right hand turned,
111  And were attentive to another care.

109  E già venuto a l'ultima tortura
110  s'era per noi, e vòlto a la man destra,
111  ed eravamo attenti ad altra cura.

112  There the embankment shoots forth flames of fire,
113  And upward doth the cornice breathe a blast
114  That drives them back, and from itself sequesters.

112  Quivi la ripa fiamma in fuor balestra,
113  e la cornice spira fiato in suso
114  che la reflette e via da lei sequestra;

115  Hence we must needs go on the open side,
116  And one by one; and I did fear the fire
117  On this side, and on that the falling down.

115  ond' ir ne convenia dal lato schiuso
116  ad uno ad uno; e io temëa 'l foco
117  quinci, e quindi temeva cader giuso.

118  My Leader said: "Along this place one ought
119  To keep upon the eyes a tightened rein,
120  Seeing that one so easily might err."

118  Lo duca mio dicea: “Per questo loco
119  si vuol tenere a li occhi stretto il freno,
120  però ch'errar potrebbesi per poco.”

121  "Summae Deus clementiae," in the bosom
122  Of the great burning chanted then I heard,
123  Which made me no less eager to turn round;

121  “Summae Deus clementïae” nel seno
122  al grande ardore allora udi' cantando,
123  che di volger mi fé caler non meno;

124  And spirits saw I walking through the flame;
125  Wherefore I looked, to my own steps and theirs
126  Apportioning my sight from time to time.

124  e vidi spirti per la fiamma andando;
125  per ch'io guardava a loro e a' miei passi,
126  compartendo la vista a quando a quando.

127  After the close which to that hymn is made,
128  Aloud they shouted, "Virum non cognosco;"
129  Then recommenced the hymn with voices low.

127  Appresso il fine ch'a quell' inno fassi,
128  gridavano alto: “Virum non cognosco”;
129  indi ricominciavan l'inno bassi.

130  This also ended, cried they: "To the wood
131  Diana ran, and drove forth Helice
132  Therefrom, who had of Venus felt the poison."

130  Finitolo, anco gridavano: “Al bosco
131  si tenne Diana, ed Elice caccionne
132  che di Venere avea sentito il tòsco.”

133  Then to their song returned they; then the wives
134  They shouted, and the husbands who were chaste.
135  As virtue and the marriage vow imposes.

133  Indi al cantar tornavano; indi donne
134  gridavano e mariti che fuor casti
135  come virtute e matrimonio imponne.

136  And I believe that them this mode suffices,
137  For all the time the fire is burning them;
138  With such care is it needful, and such food,

136  E questo modo credo che lor basti
137  per tutto il tempo che 'l foco li abbruscia:
138  con tal cura conviene e con tai pasti

139  That the last wound of all should be closed up.

139  che la piaga da sezzo si ricuscia.

Canto XXVI
An entire dissertation could easily be written on poetry based upon one or another of the seven deadly sins: 

Poetry based upon pride — patriotic newspaper verse, Kiplingesque  jingoism; 

Poetry based upon envy — the denunciation of other poets who are the poet's betters (more on the reverse of that below, i.e. the denunciation of poor poets being rated better than their betters); 

Poetry based upon wrath — these works are legion, but some of Pound's denunciations of usurers might serve as examples — if he were a worse poet; 

Poetry based upon sloth — greeting card verse by people too lazy to learn their craft, Rod McKuenesque type stuff; 

Poetry based upon avarice, the ekphratic  extravagancies of works like Hypnerotomachia Poliphili, or something like the Bower of Bliss episodes of Spenser's Faerie Queene, 

Poetry based upon gluttony, certain passages in Finnegans Wake in the Ondt and the Gracehoper section for example, or, of course, tons of Rabelais, if read superficially;

and finally 

Poetry based upon lust — one of poetry's main themes, and specific to this canto, one of the main themes of the troubadours, who very often conflated lust and love, or used the camouflage of love to disguise their lust.  

What Dante is arguing for in this and the other cantos dealing with poetry is that poetry should be based on love, the chaste love of a woman, such as Beatrice, who is the manifestation of his own soul, the love of language — specifically the love of one's mother tongue, and the love of God, the organizing power of all matter and morals of the universe.  The Commedia is an example of the kind of poetry that Dante is championing, all other styles of poetry being but parodies of the genuine article.  One should add here, something like the Buddhist example of near poisons.  Remember Virgil's only words at the beginning of this canto:  "Guarda," "be careful" for it is easy to lose your way here, and fall into one or another of these parodies.  Virgil should know, because much of the Aeneid could easily be said to be about pride or wrath, and what Guido Guinizzelli says about poets who are overpraised but, in his estimation, inferior, could easily be said to have been motivated by envy.  I think this last example is important, not because we should fall into the trap of ranking poetry in the manner of good, better, best, or bad, worse, the worst, but because something like taste, or the ability to recognize quality, is independent of fame or popular adulation.  What frees Guido's words from the morass of envy is Guido's humility in pointing out one whom he considered his "better" in Daniel Arnaut, and this attribute of humility, is double-underlined by Dante in praising Guido, and his own "betters" in the art of poetry.  (This bow to his own betters by Dante, is, I find, one of the few places in the entire Commedia where Dante seems to be a bit emotionally disingenuous.  I don't think that Dante felt that anyone, including Virgil, was his own better, and considering his accomplishment, this judgement might not have been based upon pride at all, but simply on what he discerned to be his own accomplishments.  Somewhere Blake said something to the effect that: No man can be a genius and be ignorant of the fact that he is one.) 

If you take this journey with Dante, it's a fool's paradise to think that you can just keep reading the poem, studying the commentary, having insight after insight on the depth of Dante's thinking, the astounding felicity of his technique, and it's so interesting, so wonderful, that you are lulled into thinking that you can just keep on doing what you're doing, in a kind of steady progression, feeling wiser and more confident that you are really make head-way, then, suddenly, a great gap opens in your psyche, and you realize what is really at stake — not just a mortal life, but a soul — your own soul, and you begin to doubt if you're really up to this, you begin to think that generations of men and women who have spent their lives studying and delving into this work haven't really been able to explain what has made them dedicate so much of themselves to even so great a cultural artifact as this is — because they didn't tell you, or couldn't tell you about the despair, the exhilaration — and the doubt — my God, the doubt, the feeling that you're not reaching, and may never reach the real promise of this work, that you have vastly underestimated the costs, the rewards, and your own commitment and capabilities.  Something happens inside of you, a wound that permanently shreds your previous assurance, and you think — this is too much, and I am too little, now I can't stand outside or beyond this poem, and be a mere reader, now I am too far in to get out, and I don't know what I'm doing or where I'm going.  Now I need to feel as Dante felt in the first Canto of the Inferno, when Virgil appeared to him, not as a product of the imagination, but as an autonomous entity born from a timeless psyche that vastly exceeds anything previously imagined as a part of myself.  Now I need Dante's help, or my own Beatrice's numinosity, or, or ... I can't even say it, I can't even imagine what I could say, think, or feel, because it's beyond my capacity to hope or to despair ... and I realize that the whole enterprise is coming apart for me, tearing me apart, and I no longer know what I am doing or why, or how I'm are going to meet what is coming next.

The blue skies are turning white as the afternoon wanes towards evening.  The sun is at your back, throwing your shadow into a wall of flames, and from this wall of flames souls appear like fish which you see through the translucency of waves, and your attention grows to encompass the heights of the sky, where two lines of cranes fly, one migrating north crossing another line flying south, you look down where two lines of ants gleam at your feet, one line streaming in one direction, the other in the opposite, you remember a bestiary telling of ants in India and Ethiopia, they're as big as dogs, they guard hoards of gold, you burn with thirst to know the names of these souls, there is a mention of cold water, you remember those Indian and Ethiopian deserts, souls comes forward to ask if you have as yet been entangled in the net of death, you stop to consider, muted by your rapidly expanding impressions: fire, water, the air of the cranes, the earth of the ants  — all the elements of existence.  Those cranes could not be flying as they are unless time had collapsed the seasons between their migrations — what is happening?  One line of the souls in the fire go in one direction, one line counter-flowing in the other, the one a group of sodomites, homosexuals, the other, is that strange alchemical amalgamation — hermaphrodites — these are heterosexuals who have married within themselves both male and females aspects of the psyche.  The souls shout snatches of phrases, trying to outshout those they are passing, each side attempting to call attention to their having committed the greater sin.  Images of Sodom and Gomorrah, scenes of orgiastic debauchery, of destruction, of a woman turned to a pillar of salt, scenes of peasants whose jaws drop as they enter a great city, scenes of a mighty Roman triumph, the great Caesar catcalled as a queen, and we see him sodomized in the bed of a king he has defeated in battle.  Scenes of moonlight hunts with a bare-breasted goddess, the sound of a prayer to the Blessèd Virgin, terrible scenes of a woman crawling into a hollow wooden cow so that she might be humped by a heaving bull.  The crisscrossing lines of penitents stop for a moment in their opposite flaming currents to greet one another with a chaste fraternal kiss.  And you now recognize your friend, your model as a poet, and like sons who split the battle lines of armies to fall at the feet of the mother they thought was dead, you too would fall at the feet of this dear poet, but the flames prevent you ... and now with your friend you talk of poetry and love, the poetry of love, the poetry springing only from love, although here there are only those bathing in the fires of lust, the scorching agony is something they embrace, because this pain alone clarifies for them what love truly is ... and you realize that all this movement and counter movement, this fire, this poetry, are like the circulation of transmuting and transmutational elements in some kind of retort boiling with an alchemical process meant to clarify your own base soul into that sun of gold, that sun which beats upon your back and hurries you along — and then, stepping forth from the flames, comes the poet who embodied the troubadorian ideal of love as a task, a devotion, an inspiration, for him, love is as concrete as a physical body, with its smells, and hair, and skin, but this love is unattainable in the physical body, so that it grows as an autonomous soul in his own body, and in the body of his work.  This poet, this legend speaks.  He speaks in a language that you know, but which is not your Motherese.  He speaks in the vernacular of the kind of love poetry that has led you here, to this moment, where this poet is asking you, you, who are so overwhelmed and who has come so far, and accomplished so much, but who now feels so humbled by this master's presence.  It is all so impossible, so wondrous, so hyper real, but here he is asking from this fire, whose pain he so relishes, that as you ascend towards what bliss or pain you do not know, to pray for him — for you, whose admiration has always been of him, for you to speak to a greater one on his behalf.  Your friend looks at you in wonder.  Are you really going to heaven?  Then both poets disappear, like fish too exposed by the oppression of air, fading down into those undulating, ululating, circulating flames. 

No matter how histrionic you make this, it is going to seem pale and understated next to the experience.  The body that you have carried all this way, is just too small for this ... you are being hollowed out, you are being expanded past the point of confusion, the membrane of your skin is dissolving, infinity is calling, and you are feeling an exhaustion which requires a more than ordinary sleep.   

1  While on the brink thus one before the other
2  We went upon our way, oft the good Master
3  Said: "Take thou heed! suffice it that I warn thee."

1  Mentre che sì per l'orlo, uno innanzi altro,
2  ce n'andavamo, e spesso il buon maestro
3  diceami: “Guarda: giovi ch'io ti scaltro”;

4  On the right shoulder smote me now the sun,
5  That, raying out, already the whole west
6  Changed from its azure aspect into white.

4  feriami il sole in su l'omero destro,
5  che già, raggiando, tutto l'occidente
6   mutava in bianco aspetto di cilestro;

7  And with my shadow did I make the flame
8  Appear more red; and even to such a sign
9  Shades saw I many, as they went, give heed.

7  e io facea con l'ombra più rovente
8  parer la fiamma; e pur a tanto indizio
9  vidi molt' ombre, andando, poner mente.

10  This was the cause that gave them a beginning
11  To speak of me; and to themselves began they
12  To say: "That seems not a factitious body!"

10  Questa fu la cagion che diede inizio
11  loro a parlar di me; e cominciarsi
12  a dir: “Colui non par corpo fittizio”;

13  Then towards me, as far as they could come,
14  Came certain of them, always with regard
15  Not to step forth where they would not be burned.

13  poi verso me, quanto potëan farsi,
14  certi si fero, sempre con riguardo
15  di non uscir dove non fosser arsi.

16  "O thou who goest, not from being slower
17  But reverent perhaps, behind the others,
18  Answer me, who in thirst and fire am burning.

16  “O tu che vai, non per esser più tardo,
17  ma forse reverente, a li altri dopo,
18  rispondi a me che 'n sete e 'n foco ardo.

19  Nor to me only is thine answer needful;
20  For all of these have greater thirst for it
21  Than for cold water Ethiop or Indian.

19  Né solo a me la tua risposta e uopo;
20  ché tutti questi n'hanno maggior sete
21  che d'acqua fredda Indo o Etïopo.

22  Tell us how is it that thou makest thyself
23  A wall unto the sun, as if thou hadst not
24  Entered as yet into the net of death."

22  Dinne com' è che fai di te parete
23  al sol, pur come tu non fossi ancora
24  di morte intrato dentro da la rete.”

25  Thus one of them addressed me, and I straight
26  Should have revealed myself, were I not bent
27  On other novelty that then appeared.

25  Sì mi parlava un d'essi; e io mi fora
26  già manifesto, s'io non fossi atteso
27  ad altra novità ch'apparve allora;

28  For through the middle of the burning road
29  There came a people face to face with these,
30  Which held me in suspense with gazing at them.

28  ché per lo mezzo del cammino acceso
29  venne gente col viso incontro a questa,
30  la qual mi fece a rimirar sospeso.

31  There see I hastening upon either side
32  Each of the shades, and kissing one another
33  Without a pause, content with brief salute.

31  Lì veggio d'ogne parte farsi presta
32  ciascun' ombra e basciarsi una con una
33  sanza restar, contente a brieve festa;

34  Thus in the middle of their brown battalions
35  Muzzle to muzzle one ant meets another
36  Perchance to spy their journey or their fortune.

34  così per entro loro schiera bruna
35  s'ammusa l'una con l'altra formica,
36  forse a spïar lor via e lor fortuna.

37  No sooner is the friendly greeting ended,
38  Or ever the first footstep passes onward,
39  Each one endeavours to outcry the other;

37  Tosto che parton l'accoglienza amica,
38  prima che 'l primo passo lì trascorra,
39  sopragridar ciascuna s'affatica:

40  The new-come people: "Sodom and Gomorrah!"
41  The rest: "Into the cow Pasiphae enters,
42  So that the bull unto her lust may run!"

40  a nova gente: “Soddoma e Gomorra”;
41  e l'altra: “Ne la vacca entra Pasife,
42  perché 'l torello a sua lussuria corra.”

43  Then as the cranes, that to Riphaean mountains
44  Might fly in part, and part towards the sands,
45  These of the frost, those of the sun avoidant,

43  Poi, come grue ch'a le montagne Rife
44 volasser parte, e parte inver' l'arene,
45  queste del gel, quelle del sole schife,

46  One folk is going, and the other coming,
47  And weeping they return to their first songs,
48  And to the cry that most befitteth them;

46  l'una gente sen va, l'altra sen vene;
47  e tornan, lagrimando, a' primi canti
48  e al gridar che più lor si convene;

49  And close to me approached, even as before,
50  The very same who had entreated me,
51  Attent to listen in their countenance.

49  e raccostansi a me, come davanti,
50  essi medesmi che m'avean pregato,
51 attenti ad ascoltar ne' lor sembianti.

52  I, who their inclination twice had seen,
53  Began: "O souls secure in the possession,
54  Whene'er it may be, of a state of peace,

52  Io, che due volte avea visto lor grato,
53  incominciai: “O anime sicure
54  d'aver, quando che sia, di pace stato,

55  Neither unripe nor ripened have remained
56  My members upon earth, but here are with me
57  With their own blood and their articulations.

55  non son rimase acerbe né mature
56  le membra mie di là, ma son qui meco
57  col sangue suo e con le sue giunture.

58  I go up here to be no longer blind;
59  A Lady is above, who wins this grace,
60  Whereby the mortal through your world I bring.

58  Quinci sù vo per non esser più cieco;
59  donna è di sopra che m'acquista grazia,
60  per che 'l mortal per vostro mondo reco.

61  But as your greatest longing satisfied
62  May soon become, so that the Heaven may house you
63  Which full of love is, and most amply spreads,

61  Ma se la vostra maggior voglia sazia
62  tosto divegna, sì che 'l ciel v'alberghi
63  ch'è pien d'amore e più ampio si spazia,

64  Tell me, that I again in books may write it,
65  Who are you, and what is that multitude
66  Which goes upon its way behind your backs?"

64  ditemi, acciò ch'ancor carte ne verghi,
65 chi siete voi, e chi è quella turba
66 che se ne va di retro a' vostri terghi.”

67  Not otherwise with wonder is bewildered
68  The mountaineer, and staring round is dumb,
69  When rough and rustic to the town he goes,

67  Non altrimenti stupido si turba
68  lo montanaro, e rimirando ammuta,
69  quando rozzo e salvatico s'inurba,

70  Than every shade became in its appearance;
71  But when they of their stupor were disburdened,
72  Which in high hearts is quickly quieted,

70  che ciascun' ombra fece in sua paruta;
71  ma poi che furon di stupore scarche,
72  lo qual ne li alti cuor tosto s'attuta,

73  "Blessed be thou, who of our border-lands,"
74  He recommenced who first had questioned us,
75  "Experience freightest for a better life.

73  “Beato te, che de le nostre marche,”
74  ricominciò colei che pria m'inchiese,
75  “per morir meglio, esperienza imbarche!

76  The folk that comes not with us have offended
77  In that for which once Caesar, triumphing,
78  Heard himself called in contumely, 'Queen.'

76  La gente che non vien con noi, offese
77 di ciò per che già Cesar, trïunfando,
78  'Regina' contra sé chiamar s'intese:

79  Therefore they separate, exclaiming, 'Sodom!'
80  Themselves reproving, even as thou hast heard,
81  And add unto their burning by their shame.

79  però si parton 'Soddoma' gridando,
80  rimproverando a sé com' hai udito,
81  e aiutan l'arsura vergognando.

82  Our own transgression was hermaphrodite;
83  But because we observed not human law,
84  Following like unto beasts our appetite,

82  Nostro peccato fu ermafrodito;
83  ma perché non servammo umana legge,
84  seguendo come bestie l'appetito,

85  In our opprobrium by us is read,
86  When we part company, the name of her
87  Who bestialized herself in bestial wood.

85  in obbrobrio di noi, per noi si legge,
86  quando partinci, il nome di colei
87  che s'imbestiò ne le 'mbestiate schegge.

88  Now knowest thou our acts, and what our crime was;
89  Wouldst thou perchance by name know who we are,
90  There is not time to tell, nor could I do it.

88  Or sai nostri atti e di che fummo rei:
89  se forse a nome vuo' saper chi semo,
90  tempo non è di dire, e non saprei.

91  Thy wish to know me shall in sooth be granted;
92  I'm Guido Guinicelli, and now purge me,
93  Having repented ere the hour extreme."

91  Farotti ben di me volere scemo:
92  son Guido Guinizzelli, e già mi purgo
93  per ben dolermi prima ch'a lo stremo.”

94  The same that in the sadness of Lycurgus
95  Two sons became, their mother re-beholding,
96  Such I became, but rise not to such height,

94  Quali ne la tristizia di Ligurgo
95  si fer due figli a riveder la madre,
96  tal mi fec' io, ma non a tanto insurgo,

97  The moment I heard name himself the father
98  Of me and of my betters, who had ever
99  Practised the sweet and gracious rhymes of love;

97  quand' io odo nomar sé stesso il padre
98  mio e de li altri miei miglior che mai
99  rime d'amor usar dolci e leggiadre; 

100  And without speech and hearing thoughtfully
101  For a long time I went, beholding him,
102  Nor for the fire did I approach him nearer.

100  e sanza udire e dir pensoso andai
101  lunga fïata rimirando lui,
102  né, per lo foco, in là più m'appressai.

103  When I was fed with looking, utterly
104  Myself I offered ready for his service,
105  With affirmation that compels belief.

103  Poi che di riguardar pasciuto fui,
104  tutto m'offersi pronto al suo servigio
105  con l'affermar che fa credere altrui.

106  And he to me: "Thou leavest footprints such
107  In me, from what I hear, and so distinct,
108  Lethe cannot efface them, nor make dim.

106  Ed elli a me: “Tu lasci tal vestigio,
107  per quel ch'i' odo, in me, e tanto chiaro,
108  che Letè nol può tòrre né far bigio.

109  But if thy words just now the truth have sworn,
110  Tell me what is the cause why thou displayest
111  In word and look that dear thou holdest me?"

109  Ma se le tue parole or ver giuraro,
110  dimmi che è cagion per che dimostri
111  nel dire e nel guardar d'avermi caro.”

112  And I to him: "Those dulcet lays of yours
113  Which, long as shall endure our modern fashion,
114  Shall make for ever dear their very ink!"

112  E io a lui: “Li dolci detti vostri,
113  che, quanto durerà l'uso moderno,
114  faranno cari ancora i loro incostri.”

105  "O brother," said he, "he whom I point out,"
106  And here he pointed at a spirit in front,
107  "Was of the mother tongue a better smith.

115  “O frate,” disse, “questi ch'io ti cerno
116  col dito,” e additò un spirto innanzi,
117  “fu miglior fabbro del parlar materno.

118  Verses of love and proses of romance,
119  He mastered all; and let the idiots talk,
120  Who think the Lemosin surpasses him.

118  Versi d'amore e prose di romanzi
119  soverchiò tutti; e lascia dir li stolti
120  che quel di Lemosì credon ch'avanzi.

121  To clamour more than truth they turn their faces,
122  And in this way establish their opinion,
123  Ere art or reason has by them been heard.

121  A voce più ch'al ver drizzan li volti,
122  e così ferman sua oppinïone
123  prima ch'arte o ragion per lor s'ascolti.

124  Thus many ancients with Guittone did,
125  From cry to cry still giving him applause,
126  Until the truth has conquered with most persons.

124  Così fer molti antichi di Guittone,
125  di grido in grido pur lui dando pregio,
126  fin che l'ha vinto il ver con più persone.

127  Now, if thou hast such ample privilege
128  'Tis granted thee to go unto the cloister
129  Wherein is Christ the abbot of the college,

127  Or se tu hai sì ampio privilegio,
128  che licito ti sia l'andare al chiostro
129  nel quale è Cristo abate del collegio,

130  To him repeat for me a Paternoster,
131  So far as needful to us of this world,
132  Where power of sinning is no longer ours."

130  falli per me un dir d'un paternostro,
130  quanto bisogna a noi di questo mondo,
132  dove poter peccar non è più nostro.”

133  Then, to give place perchance to one behind,
134  Whom he had near, he vanished in the fire
135  As fish in water going to the bottom.

133  Poi, forse per dar luogo altrui secondo
134  che presso avea, disparve per lo foco,
135  come per l'acqua il pesce andando al fondo.

136  I moved a little tow'rds him pointed out,
137 And said that to his name my own desire
138  An honourable place was making ready.

136  Io mi fei al mostrato innanzi un poco,
137  e dissi ch'al suo nome il mio disire
138  apparecchiava grazïoso loco.

139  He of his own free will began to say:
140  'Tan m' abellis vostre cortes deman,
         *So pleases me your courteous demand,        
141  Que jeu nom' puesc ni vueill a vos cobrire;
         *  I cannot and I will not hide me from you.


142  Jeu sui Arnaut, que plor e vai chantan;
        * I am Arnaut, who weep and singing go;
143  Consiros vei la passada folor,
        * Contrite I see the folly of the past,
144  E vei jauzen lo jorn qu' esper denan.
         * And joyous see the hoped-for day before me.

142  Ieu sui Arnaut, que plor e vau cantan;
143  consiros vei la passada folor,
144  e vei jausen lo joi qu'esper, denan.

145  Ara vus prec per aquella valor,
       *Therefore do I implore you, by that power
146  Que vus condus al som de la scalina
       *Which guides you to the summit of the stairs,
147  Sovenga vus a temprar ma dolor.'
       *Be mindful to assuage my suffering!

145  Ara vos prec, per aquella valor
146  que vos guida al som de l'escalina,
147  sovenha vos a temps de ma dolor!”

148  Then hid him in the fire that purifies them.

148  Poi s'ascose nel foco che li affina.

Canto XXVII
We have seen so much, we have forgotten how to see.  We have heard so much, we have forgotten how to listen.  And we have felt so much, that we are inured against any depth of feeling.  And worse, perhaps of all, we have read so much, we are no longer moved by what we read, and instead, poetry, which should be an exaltation of the body's and the spirit's sensitivities becomes an analgesic against life, and life's deeper joys and pains.  We begin to live our lives between the oscillating poles of duties and distractions, and as such, we reach what Schopenhauer discovered as the ultimate existential despair.  Is life, when it is finally stripped of all of its self-delusions, worth its costs?  Do we find ourselves living when at bottom we really don't want to be alive?  As we proceed on this journey of the Commedia, revitalizing our attention, restoring our ability to attend, whatever sensitivities we had systematically anesthetized, Dante's text has systematically reified.  Essentially Dante awakens to the depth of his despair, and from what he had perceived as the lowest point of his anguish, he finds that he has only found a false-floor, and with a split-off portion of his psyche — his historical and poetic psyche — he finds the courage to break through, and go down.  Up to this point in the poem there has been a continuity centered around the gravity of pain, the human ability, not only to endure the ordinary pain that comes with the possession of a vulnerable, mortal body, but the human capacity to magnify that pain, and to force it on others, the human depravity of even feeling triumphant in its virtuosity in producing ever more excruciating forms of pain.  The gigantic moral dilemma that seethes throughout Hell and Purgatory: Is why does pain arise?  How can pain have a purpose?  How can a cosmos so fully saturated with pain be in its most fundamental aspects, an expression of love?  What those duties and distractions were all about is avoiding a confrontation with this terrifying dilemma.  Oddly, this is a dilemma that Dante's guide, Virgil, really does not address.  Virgil's guidance, his knowledge, seems to fulfill only one purpose: To give his charge the courage to face this Why-Pain? issue, an issue that he himself — although certainly he has dealt with pain, but not the "why" of it — has never and will never face.  If we are reading Dante for some kind of Virgilian erudition, or out of a sense of duty or a need for diversion, we have profoundly missed the point.

A drop of Christ's blood falls from the place of the skull in that center which is Jerusalem, it feeds the rivers of the earth under the sign of Libra.  Those rivers are time, incarnated time, and they flow with Justice.  Time, like space, is everywhere all at once, although its appearance manifest differently according to where you are from its center.  In the center, it is midnight, where the poet protagonists are, it is sunset, Justice has been achieved, the scales balanced, all sins punished or purged, and henceforth the very idea of Justice is moot, for without injustice Justice has no meaning.  A wall of fire confronts us, and from beyond that wall comes of the voice of an Angel of God, a voice more alive than that of the living, he chants Blessed is the World's heart ...  Beati mundo corde! and he tells you that to proceed you must pass through this wall of flame.  Agony will ignite you, but you must not be deaf the beckoning voice sounding beyond the flame, that voice is your beacon and your assurance.  So, the poet tells us, listen.  Listen.  Listen to that voice calling beyond the fires of mortality, beyond incarnation.  And although you inhabit a body which may suffer, as Christ suffered, all the pains of incarnation, that voice is your Alpha and Omega, it is your "In the beginning was the Word ... "  Does the poet, aspirant feel joy at that news.  No.  He does not.  He feels as one who has been put in the pit, the pit of hell, his mortal body's grave.  There is a scene at the beginning of Ingmar Bergman's great film Persona, in which the actor, both an actor in the film, and an actor playing the character of an actor, sees on a television screen a Buddhist Monk in Saigon deliberately burning himself to death as an act of peace, and a protest against the war.  We see his body, continuing to sit in meditation, darkening in the center of the flames, one hand raised, and so much of that body is destroyed that it topples.  The actress in her hospital room recoils in horror.  Is the world a stage and all its people players?  If so, it is quite a terrible thing to be on this stage, and to play your part.  In the film the actress is silent, she becomes a listener, an audience for those who continue to live, to play their parts, and to suffer.  This is the Dante's and his readers position.  He vividly imagines burning bodies.  He's seen this before.  Smelled it too, no doubt,  and he recoils.  No matter how far he's come, no matter what trials he's endured to arrive her at this final ascent to the summit of all purgation, he freezes in terror and can go no farther, all his previous trials and triumphs waisted, this wall of flame negating them all.   Here, the theology of the journey, the moral judgements, have changed into aesthetics, and it is poets, poetry, that turn to him, note that, for he is not the manufacturer of his own grace, his own inspiration, they turn to him and tell him the truth of his situation.  He may suffer the most horrible pangs of pain, but nothing of his body can be destroyed.  What a curious statement to all us readers who live in mortal bodies, who firmly believe that we have no life beyond the body, and who, at all costs, feel all evolution's mandates, to preserve, not only that body's life, but also its freedom from pain.  Bentham even so far that the morality of all of your life's choices rests upon this one precept: Avoid pain.  And now we are asked to willingly go through the worst pain imaginable for the sake of what?  The song beyond.  Here, reason performs its last service, the logos of logic is about to be transferred to the logos of the heart, but this final surrender, this submission, although the most difficult and trusted and right of all the decisions it has made before, must be irrational, it must be to embrace its own body's pain, and the destruction of that mortal body's greatest human attribute, its power to reason: to foresee, and to act from what it knows, to enter the unknow.  In short, its ability to master the  vicissitudes of Time.  Virgil's last appeal is to memory: Recorditi!  Recorditi!, he calls twice, and that twice is structurally important, but this appeal fails.  Next he exhorts Dante by reminding him the Beatrice awaits him beyond these flame, and Dante remembers, recollects himself, his sacrifice — in the divine sense — his sacred act which will abnegate his little self merge with his great Self, and the image of one who in his dying act, lifts his eyes to his beloved.  So now the transfer of logic to heart is complete.  In the pagan world, Pyrramus dies looking on his beloved Thisbe, when he is called, by the sound of her name.  There is no Christian exemplar here, as there have been in the Canto's before, because Dante is that exemplar.  He goes through the flames, one poet, the pagan, to guide, and one poet the Christian, to prevent his retreat.  A voice from the other side, chants, Come, blessed of the Father, and they go through, as the sun sets, night falls, and true to what we have learned before of Purgatory, no further movement is possible in the dark, light and the motive power being one.  They sleep on the cliff, like mountain goats, and Dante imagines himself both sheep and goat of the last days protected by his two shepherds.  His sleep is safe, even from the law of gravity.  The poet dreams.  He dreams of two ladies.  Leah, who is weaving her self a garland, and Racheal who never leaves her mirror, action and sight, both wedded to the fire of love, Self-love first, a love for the beauty of that soul within us which always embodies love, sees it with her eyes, honors it with her hands.  They are satisfied.  The sacrifice of pain, of love's pain, and all the memories of loves unsatisfied desires, has fulfilled its purpose, and I might add, it's illusory purpose.  The dream shows Dante a preview of the new world that awaits him: A world of beauty and fulfillment.  When he awakes it is dawn.  The world of crime and retribution, sin and purging is past, and so is the need of Virgil’s guidance, hence forth the purified will may choose what gives it pleasure, all other criteria of choice, but deviations from the beautiful and divine.  The head is golden and crowned with both practical and moral mastery of itself, and the heart assumes it's reign.    

1  As when he vibrates forth his earliest rays,
2  In regions where his Maker shed his blood,
3  (The Ebro falling under lofty Libra,

1  Sì come quando i primi raggi vibra
2  là dove il suo fattor lo sangue sparse,
3  cadendo Ibero sotto l'alta Libra,

4  And waters in the Ganges burnt with noon,)
5  So stood the Sun; hence was the day departing,
6  When the glad Angel of God appeared to us.

4  e l'onde in Gange da nona rïarse,
5  sì stava il sole; onde 'l giorno sen giva,
6  come l'angel di Dio lieto ci apparse.

7  Outside the flame he stood upon the verge,
8  And chanted forth, "Beati mundo corde,"
9  In voice by far more living than our own.

7  Fuor de la fiamma stava in su la riva,
8  e cantava “Beati mundo corde!”
9  in voce assai più che la nostra viva.

10  Then: "No one farther goes, souls sanctified,
11  If first the fire bite not; within it enter,
12  And be not deaf unto the song beyond."

10  Poscia “Più non si va, se pria non morde,
11  anime sante, il foco: intrate in esso,
12  e al cantar di là non siate sorde,”

13  When we were close beside him thus he said;
14  Wherefore e'en such became I, when I heard him,
15  As he is who is put into the grave.

13  ci disse come noi li fummo presso;
14  per ch'io divenni tal, quando lo 'ntesi,
15  qual è colui che ne la fossa è messo.

16  Upon my clasped hands I straightened me,
17  Scanning the fire, and vividly recalling
18  The human bodies I had once seen burned.

16  In su le man commesse mi protesi,
17  guardando il foco e imaginando forte
18  umani corpi già veduti accesi.

19  Towards me turned themselves my good Conductors,
20  And unto me Virgilius said: "My son,
21  Here may indeed be torment, but not death.

19  Volsersi verso me le buone scorte;
20  e Virgilio mi disse: “Figliuol mio,
21  qui può esser tormento, ma non morte.

22  Remember thee, remember! and if I
23  On Geryon have safely guided thee,
24  What shall I do now I am nearer God?

22  Ricorditi, ricorditi! E se io
23  sovresso Gerïon ti guidai salvo,
24  che farò ora presso più a Dio?

25  Believe for certain, shouldst thou stand a full
26  Millennium in the bosom of this flame,
27  It could not make thee bald a single hair.

25  Credi per certo che se dentro a l'alvo
26  di questa fiamma stessi ben mille anni,
27  non ti potrebbe far d'un capel calvo.

28  And if perchance thou think that I deceive thee,
29  Draw near to it, and put it to the proof
30  With thine own hands upon thy garment's hem.

28  E se tu forse credi ch'io t'inganni,
29  fatti ver' lei, e fatti far credenza
30  con le tue mani al lembo d'i tuoi panni.

31  Now lay aside, now lay aside all fear,
32  Turn hitherward, and onward come securely;"
33  And I still motionless, and 'gainst my conscience!

31  Pon giù omai, pon giù ogne temenza;
32  volgiti in qua e vieni: entra sicuro!”
33  E io pur fermo e contra coscïenza.

34  Seeing me stand still motionless and stubborn,
35  Somewhat disturbed he said: "Now look thou, Son,
36  'Twixt Beatrice and thee there is this wall."

34  Quando mi vide star pur fermo e duro,
35  turbato un poco disse: “Or vedi, figlio:
36  tra Bëatrice e te è questo muro.”

37  As at the name of Thisbe oped his lids
38  The dying Pyramus, and gazed upon her,
39  What time the mulberry became vermilion,

37  Come al nome di Tisbe aperse il ciglio
38  Piramo in su la morte, e riguardolla,
39  allor che 'l gelso diventò vermiglio;

40  Even thus, my obduracy being softened,
41  I turned to my wise Guide, hearing the name
42  That in my memory evermore is welling.

40  così, la mia durezza fatta solla,
41  mi volsi al savio duca, udendo il nome
42  che ne la mente sempre mi rampolla.

43  Whereat he wagged his head, and said: "How now?
44  Shall we stay on this side?" then smiled as one
45  Does at a child who's vanquished by an apple.

43  Ond' ei crollò la fronte e disse: “Come!
44  volenci star di qua?”; indi sorrise
45  come al fanciul si fa ch'è vinto al pome.

46  Then into the fire in front of me he entered,
47  Beseeching Statius to come after me,
48  Who a long way before divided us.

46  Poi dentro al foco innanzi mi si mise,
47  pregando Stazio che venisse retro,
48  che pria per lunga strada ci divise.

49  When I was in it, into molten glass
50  I would have cast me to refresh myself,
51  So without measure was the burning there!

49  Sì com' fui dentro, in un bogliente vetro
50  gittato mi sarei per rinfrescarmi,
51  tant' era ivi lo 'ncendio sanza metro.

52  And my sweet Father, to encourage me,
53  Discoursing still of Beatrice went on,
54  Saying: "Her eyes I seem to see already!"

52  Lo dolce padre mio, per confortarmi,
53  pur di Beatrice ragionando andava,
54  dicendo: “Li occhi suoi già veder parmi.”

55  A voice, that on the other side was singing,
56  Directed us, and we, attent alone
57  On that, came forth where the ascent began.

55  Guidavaci una voce che cantava
56  di là; e noi, attenti pur a lei,
57  venimmo fuor là ove si montava.

58  "Venite, benedicti Patris mei,"
59  Sounded within a splendour, which was there
60  Such it o'ercame me, and I could not look.

58  “Venite, benedicti Patris mei,”
59  sonò dentro a un lume che lì era,
60  tal che mi vinse e guardar nol potei.

61  "The sun departs," it added, "and night cometh;
62  Tarry ye not, but onward urge your steps,
63  So long as yet the west becomes not dark."

61  “Lo sol sen va,” soggiunse, “e vien la sera;
62  non v'arrestate, ma studiate il passo,
63  mentre che l'occidente non si annera.”

64  Straight forward through the rock the path ascended
65  In such a way that I cut off the rays
66  Before me of the sun, that now was low.

64  Dritta salia la via per entro 'l sasso
65  verso tal parte ch'io toglieva i raggi
66  dinanzi a me del sol ch'era già basso.

67  And of few stairs we yet had made assay,
68  Ere by the vanished shadow the sun's setting
69  Behind us we perceived, I and my Sages.

67  E di pochi scaglion levammo i saggi,
68  che 'l sol corcar, per l'ombra che si spense,
69  sentimmo dietro e io e li miei saggi. 

70  And ere in all its parts immeasurable
71  The horizon of one aspect had become,
72  And Night her boundless dispensation held,

70  E pria che 'n tutte le sue parti immense
71  fosse orizzonte fatto d'uno aspetto,
72  e notte avesse tutte sue dispense

73  Each of us of a stair had made his bed;
74  Because the nature of the mount took from us
75  The power of climbing, more than the delight.

73  ciascun di noi d'un grado fece letto;
74  ché la natura del monte ci affranse
75  la possa del salir più e 'l diletto.

76  Even as in ruminating passive grow
77  The goats, who have been swift and venturesome
78  Upon the mountain-tops ere they were fed,

76  Quali si stanno ruminando manse
77  le capre, state rapide e proterve
78   sovra le cime avante che sien pranse,

79  Hushed in the shadow, while the sun is hot,
80  Watched by the herdsman, who upon his staff
81  Is leaning, and in leaning tendeth them;

79  tacite a l'ombra, mentre che 'l sol ferve,
80  guardate dal pastor, che 'n su la verga
81  poggiato s'è e lor di posa serve;

82  And as the shepherd, lodging out of doors,
83  Passes the night beside his quiet flock,
84  Watching that no wild beast may scatter it,

82  e quale il mandrïan che fori alberga,
82  lungo il pecuglio suo queto pernotta,
83  guardando perché fiera non lo sperga;

85  Such at that hour were we, all three of us,
86  I like the goat, and like the herdsmen they,
87  Begirt on this side and on that by rocks.

85  tali eravamo tutti e tre allotta,
86  io come capra, ed ei come pastori,
87  fasciati quinci e quindi d'alta grotta.

88  Little could there be seen of things without;
89  But through that little I beheld the stars
90  More luminous and larger than their wont.

88  Poco parer potea lì del di fori;
89  ma, per quel poco, vedea io le stelle
90  di lor solere e più chiare e maggiori.

91  Thus ruminating, and beholding these,
92  Sleep seized upon me,—sleep, that oftentimes
93  Before a deed is done has tidings of it.

91  Sì ruminando e sì mirando in quelle,
92  mi prese il sonno; il sonno che sovente,
93  anzi che 'l fatto sia, sa le novelle.

94  It was the hour, I think, when from the East
95  First on the mountain Citherea beamed,
96  Who with the fire of love seems always burning;

94  Ne l'ora, credo, che de l'orïente
95  prima raggiò nel monte Citerea,
96  che di foco d'amor par sempre ardente,

97  Youthful and beautiful in dreams methought
98  I saw a lady walking in a meadow,
99  Gathering flowers; and singing she was saying:

97  giovane e bella in sogno mi parea
98  donna vedere andar per una landa
99  cogliendo fiori; e cantando dicea:

100  "Know whosoever may my name demand
101  That I am Leah, and go moving round
102  My beauteous hands to make myself a garland.

100  “Sappia qualunque il mio nome dimanda
101  ch'i' mi son Lia, e vo movendo intorno
102  le belle mani a farmi una ghirlanda.

103  To please me at the mirror, here I deck me,
104  But never does my sister Rachel leave
105  Her looking-glass, and sitteth all day long.

103  Per piacermi a lo specchio, qui m'addorno;
104  ma mia suora Rachel mai non si smaga
105  dal suo miraglio, e siede tutto giorno.

106  To see her beauteous eyes as eager is she,
107  As I am to adorn me with my hands;
108  Her, seeing, and me, doing satisfies."

106  Ell' è d'i suoi belli occhi veder vaga
107  com' io de l'addornarmi con le mani;
108  lei lo vedere, e me l'ovrare appaga.”

109  And now before the antelucan splendours
110  That unto pilgrims the more grateful rise,
111  As, home-returning, less remote they lodge,

109  E già per li splendori antelucani,
110  che tanto a' pellegrin surgon più grati,
111  quanto, tornando, albergan men lontani,

112  The darkness fled away on every side,
113  And slumber with it; whereupon I rose,
114  Seeing already the great Masters risen.

112  le tenebre fuggian da tutti lati,
113  e 'l sonno mio con esse; ond' io leva'mi,
114  veggendo i gran maestri già levati.

115  "That apple sweet, which through so many branches
116  The care of mortals goeth in pursuit of,
117  To-day shall put in peace thy hungerings."

115  “Quel dolce pome che per tanti rami
116  cercando va la cura de' mortali,
117  oggi porrà in pace le tue fami.”

118  Speaking to me, Virgilius of such words
119  As these made use; and never were there guerdons
120  That could in pleasantness compare with these.

118  Virgilio inverso me queste cotali
119  parole usò; e mai non furo strenne
120  che fosser di piacere a queste iguali.

121  Such longing upon longing came upon me
122  To be above, that at each step thereafter
123  For flight I felt in me the pinions growing.

121  Tanto voler sopra voler mi venne
122  de l'esser sù, ch'ad ogne passo poi
123  al volo mi sentia crescer le penne.

124  When underneath us was the stairway all
125  Run o'er, and we were on the highest step,
126  Virgilius fastened upon me his eyes,

124  Come la scala tutta sotto noi
125  fu corsa e fummo in su 'l grado superno,
126  in me ficcò Virgilio li occhi suoi,

127  And said: "The temporal fire and the eternal,
128  Son, thou hast seen, and to a place art come
129  Where of myself no farther I discern.

127  e disse: “Il temporal foco e l'etterno
128  veduto hai, figlio; e se' venuto in parte
129  dov' io per me più oltre non discerno.

130  By intellect and art I here have brought thee;
131  Take thine own pleasure for thy guide henceforth;
132  Beyond the steep ways and the narrow art thou.

130  Tratto t'ho qui con ingegno e con arte;
131  lo tuo piacere omai prendi per duce;
132  fuor se' de l'erte vie, fuor se' de l'arte.

133  Behold the sun, that shines upon thy forehead;
134  Behold the grass, the flowerets, and the shrubs
135  Which of itself alone this land produces.

133  Vedi lo sol che 'n fronte ti riluce;
134  vedi l'erbette, i fiori e li arbuscelli
135  che qui la terra sol da sé produce.

136  Until rejoicing come the beauteous eyes
137  Which weeping caused me to come unto thee,
138  Thou canst sit down, and thou canst walk among them.

136  Mentre che vegnan lieti li occhi belli
137  che, lagrimando, a te venir mi fenno,
138  seder ti puoi e puoi andar tra elli.

139  Non aspettar mio dir più né mio cenno;
140  libero, dritto e sano è tuo arbitrio,
141  e fallo fora non fare a suo senno:

139  Expect no more or word or sign from me;
140  Free and upright and sound is thy free-will,
141  And error were it not to do its bidding;

142  Thee o'er thyself I therefore crown and mitre!"

142  per ch'io te sovra te corono e mitrio.”

Canto XXVIII
In Homo sapiens long evolutionary climb from tree shrew to civilization, in spite of terror and hunger, there must be in all of us a nostalgia for the wild animal we once were, times when the belly was full and food plentiful, when all sexual appetites were quelled by satiation, and no dangers were immediately present, times when we simply were at home in the nature from which we arose, one with that green world, and with our family, our clan, our mate, times when we were at ease, with nothing to do but be in the lap of an enveloping and friendly place, which was so familiar, that it was almost indistinguishable from our own bodies.  Dante, the aspirant, has done the impossible, step by arduous step, he has felt all pains, seen all sins, and walked through a wall of fire to arrive here, in a primeval forest, where all hurry is stilled by wonder.  He is home.  The exile and the nomad has come home.  Now that there is no place to be other than where he is, like those Buddhists doing their walking meditation, or those medieval Christians walking the labyrinths laid out on the pavings of their church floors, he walks slowly, and imbibes this place wherein with each step the ground releases a burgeoning perfume.  Here it is perpetually morning, perpetually spring, and yet the environment is so rich and dense, so gratifying to the senses, that there is no possibility of any Schopenhauerian boredom or staleness.
