This variety is without the changes that comes from the arc of mortality which is always developing from seed to maturity and then declining and disintegrating toward death, and here for the first time, since the disastrous first lines of the Inferno, Dante, the aspirant, is in the lead, and his silent, and almost forgotten alter-egos, Virgil and Statius, have, Cheshire-cat-like been reduced at the end of the Canto to knowing and approving smiles.  This is Eden, a garden whose only tending, is not that of pruning, or planting, or harvesting, but enjoying, one's task only the weaving of garlands for ornamentation, and for gently expressing an attitude of love.  We think of gardens as the imposition of order on nature, an aesthetic practice, but this forest is not like that.  It is Nature as an exultation of its own inner freedom, an expression of the divine life-force that adds beauty to beauty only for the sake of doing so. The poem has evolved to this point as the apex of pastoral poetry, and in deep accord with that position, the wanderer in paradise meets a "lady", unnamed at here, but a sort of Eve-figure, who cannot have been born from Adam's rib, for she is alone, and clearly awaiting her lover, the expected intruder, who can be no other person than Dante himself.  She is, as some commentators have pointed out the Eve, who is only named such after the fall, as she existed in her original innocence and purity.  We will only learn her name in a subsequent canto.  There is such a long tradition of the knight errant coming upon the beautiful peasant girl, and the two coming together for an erotic tryst, that leads to sorrow on both sides, the girl ruined, and sometimes, as in Keats’s La Belle Dame Sans Merci, the knight destroyed.  But here, the poet, having just been purged of lust, quickly learns that Eros here has been transformed, partially because there is no need of it, because we are in a post-coital world where all desire has been satiated, so that the experience here is not one of longing but that of fulfillment.  The higher spiritual frequencies of agape or caritas have gathered all that sexual passion, not into the form of a denial of that passion, but into that passion's natural elevation.  Blake's cry of the mistaken man of "More!  More!"  has given way to the sweet mystery of a song, at first just out of reach of comprehension, on the other side of an uncrossable stream.  This stream is the origin of all rivers on Earth, and is one of two possible streams of thought, i.e., the stream which forgets its past regrets and mistakes, and the stream that recalls one's feelings of love.  You could call this stream a flow of music, which passes between performer and listener, a musical passage of time, wherein the solo instrument of the lady's voice arises naturally out of the orchestral surround of water ripplings, birdchirp and breeze-harped trees, a song which distills the essence of the human from the already rich elixir of Nature.  Dante, enthralled, asks the singer to draw nearer so that he can hear what she is singing, a wish the singer grants, but which we readers, contrary to former parts of the Commedia, are not privy to.  Whatever she sings remains a mystery for us, because, although all other desires have been extinguish, the childlike stirrings of curiosity remain.  How wonderful that Dante should link love and curiosity into this whole atmosphere of fulfillment.  To ask and to receive, that is as natural as the infant's need for the mother's breast and the mother's need to offer it.  And yet, having gone through all of Hell and Purgatory, we cannot really conceive of this place as a nursery.  Indeed, it is specifically stated that this place arises, not from seed, its fruits not part of any developmental mortal life cycle.  This is a place, where grace flows-in as Time-transformed, but not obliterated.  And this Time naturally flows in when the seeker has exhaled all of that identity which defined itself as the divisive actions of Me and Not Me, actions which lead to the destructive narcissisms of Hell and which required purging in the punishments of Purgatory.  In Hell, Time is interminable, in Purgatory, it is an endurance and a breaking-down of mistaken perceptions.  Here, it is suspended, and only unfolds at the pace with which our movements elicit the most awe, the most wonder, the most love.  The aspirant, as Virgil has previously stated, has acquired, through the experiences of Hell, and the cleansing of Purgatory, the freedom to choose what most pleases, and this is the new experience of Time, a flowing forth of change, which only leads from one pleasure to another, or as Paramahansa Yogananda puts it about the depths of meditation, it is "Joy, ever-new."   Here curiosity does not come from the brain, but from the heart, and the lady's response to the poet's inquiries really makes no logical or scientific sense at all, because the reference point of its motivation is not to know in any abstract academic sense — that kind of intellect, as the lady says in line 89, needs to be unclouded, de-mistified.  No, her answer is for the heart, which alone has the power to clear the mind, her explanations are propounded only to satisfy, and to call forth from that satisfaction more wonder, more inspiring curiosity, more love.  They are beyond the reach of any dialectic.

Of course, any post 20th Century reader will see Jungian archetypal depth-psychology all over this canto, the anima-figure of the nameless lady being a projection of the aspirant's own psyche.  The lady is all that, but not only that, and the "not only" is a portal into which the reader of the poem may plunge into the heart of his or her own journey towards transcendence.  The devil of course is in the details, but the angel is there to, even in such changes as the word "vermillion", which has had quite a different emotional coloration in the Inferno.  Thus we find in so many touches here a transformative power awakened, where even the mountain, which in the first canto of the Inferno was a barrier guarded by those three terrible beasts, here has become a lofty and beautiful serenity, no longer even a challenge to the climber, but a presence, whose beautiful and enduring nature serve only to inspire.

1  Eager already to search in and round
2  The heavenly forest, dense and living-green,
3  Which tempered to the eyes the new-born day,

1  Vago già di cercar dentro e dintorno
2  la divina foresta spessa e viva,
3  ch'a li occhi temperava il novo giorno,

4  Withouten more delay I left the bank,
5   Taking the level country slowly, slowly
6   Over the soil that everywhere breathes fragrance.

4  sanza più aspettar, lasciai la riva,
5  prendendo la campagna lento lento
6  su per lo suol che d'ogne parte auliva.

7  A softly-breathing air, that no mutation
8   Had in itself, upon the forehead smote me
9   No heavier blow than of a gentle wind,

7  Un'aura dolce, sanza mutamento
8  avere in sé, mi feria per la fronte
9  non di più colpo che soave vento;

10  Whereat the branches, lightly tremulous,
11  Did all of them bow downward toward that side
12  Where its first shadow casts the Holy Mountain;

10  per cui le fronde, tremolando, pronte
11  tutte quante piegavano a la parte
12  u' la prim' ombra gitta il santo monte;

13  Yet not from their upright direction swayed,
14  So that the little birds upon their tops
15  Should leave the practice of each art of theirs;

13  non però dal loro esser dritto sparte
14  tanto, che li augelletti per le cime
15  lasciasser d'operare ogne lor arte;

16  But with full ravishment the hours of prime,
17  Singing, received they in the midst of leaves,
18  That ever bore a burden to their rhymes,

16  ma con piena letizia l'ore prime,
17  cantando, ricevieno intra le foglie
18  che tenevan bordone a le sue rime,

19  Such as from branch to branch goes gathering on
20  Through the pine forest on the shore of Chiassi,
21  When Eolus unlooses the Sirocco.

19  tal qual di ramo in ramo si raccoglie
20  per la pineta in su 'l lito di Chiassi,
21 quand'Eölo scilocco fuor discioglie.

22  Already my slow steps had carried me
23  Into the ancient wood so far, that I
24  Could not perceive where I had entered it.

22  Già m'avean trasportato i lenti passi
23  dentro a la selva antica tanto, ch'io
24  non potea rivedere ond' io mi 'ntrassi;

25  And lo! my further course a stream cut off,
26  Which tow'rd the left hand with its little waves
27  Bent down the grass that on its margin sprang.

25  ed ecco più andar mi tolse un rio,
26  che 'nver' sinistra con sue picciole onde
27  piegava l'erba che 'n sua ripa uscìo.

28  All waters that on earth most limpid are
29  Would seem to have within themselves some mixture
30  Compared with that which nothing doth conceal,

28   Tutte l'acque che son di qua più monde,
29   parrieno avere in sé mistura alcuna
30   verso di quella, che nulla nasconde

31  Although it moves on with a brown, brown current
32  Under the shade perpetual, that never
33  Ray of the sun lets in, nor of the moon.

31  avvegna che si mova bruna bruna
32  sotto l'ombra perpetüa, che mai
33  raggiar non lascia sole ivi né luna.

34  With feet I stayed, and with mine eyes I passed
35  Beyond the rivulet, to look upon
36  The great variety of the fresh may.

34  Coi piè ristetti e con li occhi passai
35  di là dal fiumicello, per mirare
36  la gran varïazion d'i freschi mai;

37  And there appeared to me (even as appears
38  Suddenly something that doth turn aside
39  Through very wonder every other thought)

37  e là m'apparve, sì com' elli appare
38  subitamente cosa che disvia
39  per maraviglia tutto altro pensare,

40  A lady all alone, who went along
41  Singing and culling floweret after floweret,
42  With which her pathway was all painted over.

40  una donna soletta che si gia
41  e cantando e scegliendo fior da fiore
42  ond' era pinta tutta la sua via. 

43  "Ah, beauteous lady, who in rays of love
44  Dost warm thyself, if I may trust to looks,
45  Which the heart's witnesses are wont to be,

43  “Deh, bella donna, che a' raggi d'amore
44  ti scaldi, s'i' vo' credere a' sembianti
45  che soglion esser testimon del core,

46  May the desire come unto thee to draw
47  Near to this river's bank," I said to her,
48  "So much that I might hear what thou art singing.

46  vegnati in voglia di trarreti avanti,”
47  diss' io a lei, “verso questa rivera,
48  tanto ch'io possa intender che tu canti.

49  Thou makest me remember where and what
50  Proserpina that moment was when lost
51  Her mother her, and she herself the Spring."

49  Tu mi fai rimembrar dove e qual era
50  Proserpina nel tempo che perdette
51  la madre lei, ed ella primavera.” 

52  As turns herself, with feet together pressed
53  And to the ground, a lady who is dancing,
54  And hardly puts one foot before the other,

52  Come si volge, con le piante strette
53  a terra e intra sé, donna che balli,
54  e piede innanzi piede a pena mette,

55  On the vermilion and the yellow flowerets
56  She turned towards me, not in other wise
57  Than maiden who her modest eyes casts down;

55  volsesi in su i vermigli e in su i gialli
55  fioretti verso me, non altrimenti
56  che vergine che li occhi onesti avvalli;

58  And my entreaties made to be content,
59  So near approaching, that the dulcet sound
60  Came unto me together with its meaning

58  e fece i prieghi miei esser contenti,
59  sì appressando sé, che 'l dolce suono
60  veniva a me co' suoi intendimenti.

61  As soon as she was where the grasses are.
62  Bathed by the waters of the beauteous river,
63  To lift her eyes she granted me the boon.

61  Tosto che fu là dove l'erbe sono
62  bagnate già da l'onde del bel fiume,
63  di levar li occhi suoi mi fece dono.

64  I do not think there shone so great a light
65  Under the lids of Venus, when transfixed
66  By her own son, beyond his usual custom!

64  Non credo che splendesse tanto lume
65  sotto le ciglia a Venere, trafitta
66  dal figlio fuor di tutto suo costume.

67  Erect upon the other bank she smiled,
68   Bearing full many colours in her hands,
69   Which that high land produces without seed.

67  Ella ridea da l'altra riva dritta,
68  trattando più color con le sue mani,
69  che l'alta terra sanza seme gitta.

70  Apart three paces did the river make us;
71   But Hellespont, where Xerxes passed across,
72  (A curb still to all human arrogance,)

70  Tre passi ci facea il fiume lontani;
71  ma Elesponto, là 've passò Serse,
72  ancora freno a tutti orgogli umani,

73  More hatred from Leander did not suffer
74  For rolling between Sestos and Abydos,
75  Than that from me, because it oped not then.

73  più odio da Leandro non sofferse
74  per mareggiare intra Sesto e Abido,
75  che quel da me perch' allor non s'aperse.

76  "Ye are new-comers; and because I smile,"
77  Began she, "peradventure, in this place
78  Elect to human nature for its nest,

76  “Voi siete nuovi, e forse perch' io rido,”
77  cominciò ella, “in questo luogo eletto
78  a l'umana natura per suo nido

79  Some apprehension keeps you marvelling;
80  But the psalm 'Delectasti' giveth light
81  Which has the power to uncloud your intellect.

79  maravigliando tienvi alcun sospetto;
80  ma luce rende il salmo Delectasti,
81  che puote disnebbiar vostro intelletto.

82  And thou who foremost art, and didst entreat me,
83  Speak, if thou wouldst hear more; for I came ready
84  To all thy questionings, as far as needful."

82  E tu che se' dinanzi e mi pregasti,
83  dì s'altro vuoli udir; ch'i' venni presta
84  ad ogne tua question tanto che basti.”

85  "The water," said I, "and the forest's sound,
86  Are combating within me my new faith
87  In something which I heard opposed to this."

85  “L'acqua,” diss' io, “e 'l suon de la foresta
86  impugnan dentro a me novella fede
87  di cosa ch'io udi' contraria a questa.”

88  Whence she: "I will relate how from its cause
89  Proceedeth that which maketh thee to wonder,
89  And purge away the cloud that smites upon thee.

88  Ond' ella: “Io dicerò come procede
89  per sua cagion ciò ch'ammirar ti face,
90  e purgherò la nebbia che ti fiede.

91  The Good Supreme, sole in itself delighting,
92  Created man good, and this goodly place
93  Gave him as hansel of eternal peace.

91  Lo sommo Ben, che solo esso a sé piace,
92  fé l'uom buono e a bene, e questo loco
93  diede per arr' a lui d'etterna pace.

94  By his default short while he sojourned here;
95  By his default to weeping and to toil
96  He changed his innocent laughter and sweet play.

94  Per sua difalta qui dimorò poco;
95  per sua difalta in pianto e in affanno
96  cambiò onesto riso e dolce gioco.

97  That the disturbance which below is made
98  By exhalations of the land and water,
99  (Which far as may be follow after heat,)

97  Perché 'l turbar che sotto da sé fanno
98  l'essalazion de l'acqua e de la terra,
99  che quanto posson dietro al calor vanno,

100  Might not upon mankind wage any war,
101  This mount ascended tow'rds the heaven so high,
102  And is exempt, from there where it is locked.

100  a l'uomo non facesse alcuna guerra,
101  questo monte salìo verso 'l ciel tanto,
102  e libero n'è d'indi ove si serra.

103  Now since the universal atmosphere
104  Turns in a circuit with the primal motion
105  Unless the circle is broken on some side,

103  Or perché in circuito tutto quanto
102   l'aere si volge con la prima volta,
103  se non li è rotto il cerchio d'alcun canto,

106  Upon this height, that all is disengaged
107  In living ether, doth this motion strike
108  And make the forest sound, for it is dense;

106  in questa altezza ch'è tutta disciolta
107  ne l'aere vivo, tal moto percuote,
108  e fa sonar la selva perch' è folta;

109  And so much power the stricken plant possesses
110  That with its virtue it impregns the air,
111  And this, revolving, scatters it around;

109  e la percossa pianta tanto puote,
110  che de la sua virtute l'aura impregna
111  e quella poi, girando, intorno scuote;

112  And yonder earth, according as 'tis worthy
113  In self or in its clime, conceives and bears
114  Of divers qualities the divers trees;

112  e l'altra terra, secondo ch'è degna
113  per sé e per suo ciel, concepe e figlia
114  di diverse virtù diverse legna.

115  It should not seem a marvel then on earth,
116  This being heard, whenever any plant
117  Without seed manifest there taketh root.

115  Non parrebbe di là poi maraviglia,
116  udito questo, quando alcuna pianta
117  sanza seme palese vi s'appiglia.

118  And thou must know, this holy table-land
119  In which thou art is full of every seed,
120  And fruit has in it never gathered there.

118  E saper dei che la campagna santa
119  dove tu se', d'ogne semenza è piena,
120  e frutto ha in sé che di là non si schianta.

121  The water which thou seest springs not from vein
122  Restored by vapour that the cold condenses,
123  Like to a stream that gains or loses breath;

121  L'acqua che vedi non surge di vena
122  che ristori vapor che gel converta,
123  come fiume ch'acquista e perde lena;

124  But issues from a fountain safe and certain,
125  Which by the will of God as much regains
126  As it discharges, open on two sides.

124  ma esce di fontana salda e certa,
125  che tanto dal voler di Dio riprende,
126  quant' ella versa da due parti aperta.

127  Upon this side with virtue it descends,
128  Which takes away all memory of sin;
129  On that, of every good deed done restores it.

127  Da questa parte con virtù discende
128  che toglie altrui memoria del peccato;
129  da l'altra d'ogne ben fatto la rende.

130  Here Lethe, as upon the other side
131  Eunoe, it is called; and worketh not
132  If first on either side it be not tasted.

130  Quinci Letè; così da l'altro lato
131  Eünoè si chiama, e non adopra
132  se quinci e quindi pria non è gustato:

133  This every other savour doth transcend;
134  And notwithstanding slaked so far may be
134  Thy thirst, that I reveal to thee no more,

133  a tutti altri sapori esto è di sopra.
132  E avvegna ch'assai possa esser sazia
133  la sete tua perch' io più non ti scuopra,

136  I'll give thee a corollary still in grace,
137  Nor think my speech will be to thee less dear
138  If it spread out beyond my promise to thee.

136  darotti un corollario ancor per grazia;
137  né credo che 'l mio dir ti sia men caro,
138  se oltre promession teco si spazia.

139  Those who in ancient times have feigned in song
140  The Age of Gold and its felicity,
141  Dreamed of this place perhaps upon Parnassus.

139  Quelli ch'anticamente poetaro
140  l'età de l'oro e suo stato felice,
141  forse in Parnaso esto loco sognaro.

142  Here was the human race in innocence;
143  Here evermore was Spring, and every fruit;
144  This is the nectar of which each one speaks."

142  Qui fu innocente l'umana radice;
143  qui primavera sempre e ogne frutto;
144  nettare è questo di che ciascun dice.”

145  Then backward did I turn me wholly round
146   Unto my Poets, and saw that with a smile
147  They had been listening to these closing words;

145  Io mi rivolsi 'n dietro allora tutto
146  a' miei poeti, e vidi che con riso
147  udito avëan l'ultimo costrutto;

148  Then to the beautiful lady turned mine eyes.

148  poi a la bella donna torna' il viso.

Canto XXIX
Is the allegorical the enemy of the visionary?  Or do we contemplate the allegory so deeply, that it conjures vision?  In Dry Salvages, Eliot says: "We had the experience but missed the meaning."  But here in this canto, we are tempted to do the reverse, to have the meaning, or at least what the numerous commentators have told us is the meaning, while we miss the experience.  I think of the DMT experiences described by Terrance McKenna, those Machine Elves, whose purpose seems to be to teach us a way to speak a language that gives birth to things.  This is an IT experience, jarringly alien to our everyday waking or even everynight dreaming conceptions of reality.  This IT experience strips away as utter, and very pale illusion, whatever previous conceptions we had of things and of ourselves, and makes us think, so intense is its occurrence, that we might be dying or have already died, but if we have died, it was, as McKenna says "death by astonishment."  What I am arguing for here is a reification of the experience of realness.  This IT experience, which is the subject of Canto XXIX, is that which for all its Christian connotations cannot be held within the boundaries of Christian iconography, or for that matter, within any ordinary boundaries at all.  What I am arguing for is the necessity for the reader to accept the visionary element, and not the allegorical one, as the most crucial aspect of what the text here, and throughout, really (and I use that word with deliberate emphasis) conveys — and that is: the transformative power of vision.  The vision is not ours, until every element kills us by astonishment, and rebirths us in a state of wonder.

For Dante, I think, as he worked more deeply in the vernacular phenomenon in projects which preceded the Commedia, he began to experience language as vision.  As a scientist might use an electron microscope, or perhaps more to the point, as some avatar might develop a sense organ beyond those traditionally assigned to humans as sight, hearing, touch, taste, and smell, Dante developed the organ of poetry, a type of language that was in and of itself an aspect of the visionary, a probe, with two-fold searchlights, one view reaching from what we might call the ordinary world of sense experience in our state of a heightened but still everyday experience of the world and an everynight experience of our dreams, and the other view that from the hyperdimensional, which is entangled and interpenetrating our ordinary world, but also a loka quite beyond it.  Why Dante keeps insisting upon the images and experiences his astral body undergoes in the 3-fold world of the Commedia as real, and in fact, more real, than the so-called ordinary world, is because in this loka of the Commedia, through the living vehicle of poetic language, he has an expanded freedom in space, that is, an ability to create, imagine, and navigate the geographies of Hell and Purgatory, and the cosmology of Paradise by means of an expanded freedom in Time.  Of this latter freedom, we can think of it like this.  In ordinary reality Time is a unidirectional flow from past, through the present, and towards the future, with the present alone as real, the past a virtual reality of causes creating the reality of the present, and the future a possible reality determined by the actions of the present.  This is Time's arrow, moving always as a point along its line, and we, in ordinary experience, have no more freedom to move off of this line, than a passenger in a train car might move in some other direction other than that of the track the train must follow.  Through the poetry of the Commedia, Dante has acquired the ability to experience, not only the diachronic time of a Dante, as aspirant, and a Dante, as poet, the former experiencing what the latter is creating, but also any number of expanded or contracted temporal areas, which give us a sense of a Time which has the volume supplied by metaphor and allegory, the volume supplied by hyperreal visions, the volume that has created readers in all subsequent eras since the poem suddenly erupted onto our historical track in the early years of the 14th century.  The time of the entire journey of aspirant-vehicle through the experience of Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise is the seven days of Holy Week, his Earth time, in the calendrical historical year of 1300 A.D.  But the poem navigates this Time with a freedom which stretches in several directions, through the historical past, through the prophesized future, through the realms of pagan mythology, and Christian exemplars, through the Time dimensions of various styles of poetry, from Virgil, the troubadours, Statius, Guido Cavalcanti, and even his own earlier work, and most astonishingly through the times of all his subsequent readers and commentators, who continue to proliferate areas of Time that the poem anticipates, just as Virgil's poetry anticipates Dante's, and as Homer's Virgil's.  It may be that we experience, in our ordinary temporal reality, this hyperdimensional volume of Time as a kind of flickering of consciousnesses, as in the metaphor that the text uses in lines 4 - 6 of this canto, as Nymphs dashing through forest shades and forest lights.  This flickering phenomenon is well known as a portal to altered states of consciousness, probably beginning as early humans stared into the flicker of firelight, or lounged under a canopy of flickering leaf apertures.  It comes into the present as the flicker of film projectors, of Brion Gysin's Dream Machine, of Disco balls and other stroboscopic phenomenon, which were found to have the power of certain psychedelic drugs as a way to trigger hallucinatory visions.  These visions are experienced as superstimuli, more real than real (Watch a small child before the flicker of a TV screen.), and this is what I believe the aspirant, Dante, is experiencing here, in a weird temporal locale between a lightning flash and its subsequent thunderclap.  

What is this vision and how did it take shape in this particular form.  It is a procession, a type of spectacle, "a live, shared, experience," as one event designer puts it, between participants and audience.  We have evidence of processions as old as the Bronze Age (sixth Millennium B.C.) rock carvings of Boghaz-Keui in modern day Turkey, so it's safe to say that this is one of the primal experiences of humans, which we find in Egypt, in Greece phallic processions, in the Roman Triumph, and of course in wedding marches, funeral rites, and in religious ceremonies.  Dante’s vision here seems to by an amalgamation concocted from various scriptural sources, which one commentator, Gian Luca Pierotti,  traces as follows

1) 24 books of the Old Testament
2) 4 Gospels, Mathew, Mark, Luke, John
3) 1 griffin
4) 3 theological virtues (love, hope, faith)
5) 4 cardinal virtues (prudence, fortitude, temperance, justice)
6) 2 "authors" of Book of Acts and major Epistles: Luke and Paul
7) 4 "authors" of lesser Epistles: Peter, James, John, Jude
8) 1 Apocalypse: John

Nothing invalid about this listing, it can be textually supported, and if you were a Christian Monk practicing the Liturgy of the hours 8 times a day, everyday of your life, and contemplating these images, no doubt a huge superstimulus would be created in your mind, that would give birth to all kinds of dreams and visions, and if we add to this experience of countless practitioners for centuries together into what Rupert Sheldrake has described as a field of morphic resonance, these visions, in this form would pervade the individual as a kind of group consciousness, with a cultural and psychological resonance that might take on the rather fabulous rainbow luminance by which Dante colors the entire spectacle.  But for many contemporary readers this cultural resonance has faded, it no longer grips us, and seems more scholarly than spectacular.  That is why chasing down cultural references, I believe, depotentiates the vision, and serves the very opposite function, which the intensity of the poetic experience requires.  If the reader, instead, would call to mind, rehearse, and contemplate the image presenter here, than their own set of resonances might arise, and still supported by the text, each might well create an eccentric set of metaphors regarding the so-called meanings behind the elements of this processional.

Have you ever walked across a field towards dusk, approaching a line of trees, the last gold of the sunset backlighting the trees which cast you in shadow as you approach?  Have you suddenly been possessed by a feeling of awe, a feeling of presence, whereby the flickering leaves lent to your emotions an otherworldliness, a feeling that your ordinary vision was being transcended and you were entering a world of time distortions and hyperreality light?  Now these 7 trees exude as a candle exudes light, a moony eeriness, in the form of translucent rainbows, beneath which there follows in slow processing, two by two, four and twenty elders.  Who are these solemn celebrants, and what does their processional mean?  After them, a boxlike formation appears, the four-corners of which are wheel-like vortices which spin prismatically, the forms of living creatures arising from the whirl, and then sinking back into it: a man, a lion, a cherubic figure suggestive with a somewhat bovine or ox-like countenance, and an eagle, and in the midst of these four, there is a two-wheeled chariot, pulled by a creature half-lion, half eagle, the lion parts red and white, the raptor parts gold.  By the right wheel of this chariot, are three beautiful women, all diaphanously dressed, one silken clothed like to rubies, one like to emeralds, and one like the sparkle of sun or moon light on deep, new-fallen snow.  These three dance round and round, the ruby then the snow maiden, in graceful succession, leading the emerald.  By the left wheel of the chariot, four ladies, all in purple, dance, one of these ladies having a third eye open in the place which the Hindus call the bindu, between the brows.  Behind this car, 2 men follow, diversely clad.  One you intuit is a healer, perhaps a dispenser of herbs, the other is a surgeon, who wields a scalpel-sharp sword.  Behind this pair trod four whose demeanor suggests a sort of commoners' poverty, and behind these four, and bringing up the rear of this astonishing procession, an old man hobbles, eyes closed, as if sleepwalking.  

This vision is so powerful for you, that for days, perhaps months or years afterward, you contemplate its elements, arriving at one conclusion after another, any one of which could be correct, but always the vision seems to suggest more and deeper meanings.  You think about the arrangement of numbers.  the 7 candle-trees, the 4 and 20 elders, the four living creatures, the single chariot, with its 3 dancers on one side, and 4 on the other, and the seven figures concluding the rite, sequenced 2, 4, and 1 (7 in all).  Could the whole procession be proportional aspects, not of Time as a line, but of Time as a volume? the 7 days of the week, the 24 hours in the day, the four seasons of the year, the 2 halves of the day — 1 bright, 1 dark — the four quarters of the moon ... and is the sleepwalking old man, really the dreamer who dreams all of this? and have we seen the entire procession in reverse, the last figure, who seems to be a trailer, really the source and leader after all?  And what do the wheels represent, and these circular motions of dances, combined with the progressive motion of the entire procession?  Why dancing ladies? why all these displays of rainbow lights? and these particular and brilliant colors so precisely attributed to the forms?  The more you ponder all this — as vision — the stronger the vision becomes, until finally you come to realize that there is something archetypal at work here, as if somehow you have come to experience something very precise in its elements, but very porous and accepting of any meaning you might ascribe to the it.  If this is Time condensed, does such Time represent non-physical aspects of the body, or of phases of human history or of experience, usually spread out in the sequences of minutes, hours, centuries, things as non-visualizable as emotions, but now appearing in visual form?  And does the music and its progressive order of this along with its numerological precision, expand its power, precisely because of it abstract qualities, giving us some hint of the non-physical organizing power of the cosmos to arrange matter into its myriad forms?

If we keep reviewing the vision qua vision, keep multiplying questions in lieu of freezing our inquiries with definitive answers, perhaps this experience will take root in us as an experience, and we will see, that it is the meaning which shifts or magnifies, because the experience, like a spiritual yeast or like a chemical catalyst, keeps shifting and magnifying who we are in relation to who we might become.

1  Singing like unto an enamoured lady
2  She, with the ending of her words, continued:
3  "Beati quorum tecta sunt peccata."

1  Cantando come donna innamorata,
2  continüò col fin di sue parole:
3  “Beati quorum tecta sunt peccata!”

4  And even as Nymphs, that wandered all alone
5  Among the sylvan shadows, sedulous
6  One to avoid and one to see the sun,

4  E come ninfe che si givan sole
5  per le salvatiche ombre, disïando
6  qual di veder, qual di fuggir lo sole,

7  She then against the stream moved onward, going
8  Along the bank, and I abreast of her,
9  Her little steps with little steps attending.

7  allor si mosse contra 'l fiume, andando
8  su per la riva; e io pari di lei,
9  picciol passo con picciol seguitando.

10  Between her steps and mine were not a hundred,
11  When equally the margins gave a turn,
12  In such a way, that to the East I faced.

10  Non eran cento tra ' suoi passi e ' miei,
11  quando le ripe igualmente dier volta,
12  per modo ch'a levante mi rendei.

13  Nor even thus our way continued far
14  Before the lady wholly turned herself
15  Unto me, saying, "Brother, look and listen!"

13  Né ancor fu così nostra via molta,
14  quando la donna tutta a me si torse,
15  dicendo: “Frate mio, guarda e ascolta.”

16  And lo! a sudden lustre ran across
17  On every side athwart the spacious forest,
18  Such that it made me doubt if it were lightning.

16  Ed ecco un lustro sùbito trascorse
17  da tutte parti per la gran foresta,
18  tal che di balenar mi mise in forse.

19  But since the lightning ceases as it comes,
20  And that continuing brightened more and more,
21  Within my thought I said, "What thing is this?"

19  Ma perché 'l balenar, come vien, resta,
20  e quel, durando, più e più splendeva,
21  nel mio pensier dicea: “Che cosa è questa?”

22  And a delicious melody there ran
23  Along the luminous air, whence holy zeal
24  Made me rebuke the hardihood of Eve;

22  E una melodia dolce correva
23  per l'aere luminoso; onde buon zelo
24  mi fé riprender l'ardimento d'Eva,

25  For there where earth and heaven obedient were,
26  The woman only, and but just created,
27  Could not endure to stay 'neath any veil;

25  che là dove ubidia la terra e 'l cielo,
26  femmina, sola e pur testé formata,
27  non sofferse di star sotto alcun velo; 

28  Underneath which had she devoutly stayed,
29  I sooner should have tasted those delights
30  Ineffable, and for a longer time.

28  sotto 'l qual se divota fosse stata,
29  avrei quelle ineffabili delizie
30  sentite prima e più lunga fïata.

31  While 'mid such manifold first-fruits I walked
32   Of the eternal pleasure all enrapt,
33  And still solicitous of more delights,

31  Mentr' io m'andava tra tante primizie
32  de l'etterno piacer tutto sospeso,
33  e disïoso ancora a più letizie,
34  In front of us like an enkindled fire
35  Became the air beneath the verdant boughs,
36  And the sweet sound as singing now was heard.

34  dinanzi a noi, tal quale un foco acceso,
35  ci si fé l'aere sotto i verdi rami;
36  e 'l dolce suon per canti era già inteso.

37  O Virgins sacrosanct! if ever hunger,
38  Vigils, or cold for you I have endured,
39  The occasion spurs me their reward to claim!

37  O sacrosante Vergini, se fami,
38  freddi o vigilie mai per voi soffersi,
39  cagion mi sprona ch'io mercé vi chiami.

40  Now Helicon must needs pour forth for me,
41  And with her choir Urania must assist me,
42  To put in verse things difficult to think.

40  Or convien che Elicona per me versi,
41  e Uranìe m'aiuti col suo coro
42  forti cose a pensar mettere in versi.

43  A little farther on, seven trees of gold
44  In semblance the long space still intervening
45  Between ourselves and them did counterfeit;

43  Poco più oltre, sette alberi d'oro
44  falsava nel parere il lungo tratto
45  del mezzo ch'era ancor tra noi e loro;

46 But when I had approached so near to them
47  The common object, which the sense deceives,
48  Lost not by distance any of its marks,

46  ma quand' i' fui sì presso di lor fatto,
47  che l'obietto comun, che 'l senso inganna,
48  non perdea per distanza alcun su atto,

49  The faculty that lends discourse to reason
50  Did apprehend that they were candlesticks,
51  And in the voices of the song "Hosanna!"

49  la virtù ch'a ragion discorso ammanna,
50  sì com' elli eran candelabri apprese,
51  e ne le voci del cantare “Osanna.”

52  Above them flamed the harness beautiful,
53  Far brighter than the moon in the serene
54  Of midnight, at the middle of her month.

52  Di sopra fiammeggiava il bello arnese
53  più chiaro assai che luna per sereno
54  di mezza notte nel suo mezzo mese.

55  I turned me round, with admiration filled,
56  To good Virgilius, and he answered me
57  With visage no less full of wonderment.

55  Io mi rivolsi d'ammirazion pieno
56  al buon Virgilio, ed esso mi rispuose
57  con vista carca di stupor non meno. 

58  Then back I turned my face to those high things,
59  Which moved themselves towards us so sedately,
60  They had been distanced by new-wedded brides.

58  Indi rendei l'aspetto a l'alte cose
59  che si movieno incontr' a noi sì tardi,
60  che foran vinte da novelle spose.

61  The lady chid me: "Why dost thou burn only
62  So with affection for the living lights,
63  And dost not look at what comes after them?"

61  La donna mi sgridò: “Perché pur ardi
62  sì ne l'affetto de le vive luci,
63  e ciò che vien di retro a lor non guardi?”

64  Then saw I people, as behind their leaders,
65  Coming behind them, garmented in white,
66  And such a whiteness never was on earth.

64  Genti vid' io allor, come a lor duci,
65  venire appresso, vestite di bianco;
66  e tal candor di qua già mai non fuci.
67  The water on my left flank was resplendent,
68  And back to me reflected my left side,
69  E'en as a mirror, if I looked therein.

67  L'acqua imprendëa dal sinistro fianco,
68  e rendea me la mia sinistra costa,
69  s'io riguardava in lei, come specchio anco.

70  When I upon my margin had such post
71  That nothing but the stream divided us,
72  Better to see I gave my steps repose;

70  Quand' io da la mia riva ebbi tal posta,
71  che solo il fiume mi facea distante,
72  per veder meglio ai passi diedi sosta,

73  And I beheld the flamelets onward go,
74  Leaving behind themselves the air depicted,
75  And they of trailing pennons had the semblance,

73  e vidi le fiammelle andar davante,
74  lasciando dietro a sé l'aere dipinto,
75  e di tratti pennelli avean sembiante;

76  So that it overhead remained distinct
77  With sevenfold lists, all of them of the colours
78  Whence the sun's bow is made, and Delia's girdle.

76  sì che lì sopra rimanea distinto
77  di sette liste, tutte in quei colori
78  onde fa l'arco il Sole e Delia il cinto.

79  These standards to the rearward longer were
80  Than was my sight; and, as it seemed to me,
81  Ten paces were the outermost apart.

79  Questi ostendali in dietro eran maggiori
80  che la mia vista; e, quanto a mio avviso,
81  diece passi distavan quei di fori.

82  Under so fair a heaven as I describe
83  The four and twenty Elders, two by two,
84  Came on incoronate with flower-de-luce.

82  Sotto così bel ciel com' io diviso,
83  ventiquattro seniori, a due a due,
84  coronati venien di fiordaliso.

85  They all of them were singing: "Blessed thou
86  Among the daughters of Adam art, and blessed
87  For evermore shall be thy loveliness."

85  Tutti cantavan: “Benedicta tue
86  ne le figlie d'Adamo, e benedette
87  sieno in etterno le bellezze tue!”

88  After the flowers and other tender grasses
89  In front of me upon the other margin
90  Were disencumbered of that race elect,

88  Poscia che i fiori e l'altre fresche erbette
89  a rimpetto di me da l'altra sponda
90  libere fuor da quelle genti elette,

91  Even as in heaven star followeth after star,
92  There came close after them four animals,
93  Incoronate each one with verdant leaf.

91  sì come luce luce in ciel seconda,
92  vennero appresso lor quattro animali,
93  coronati ciascun di verde fronda.
94  Plumed with six wings was every one of them,
95  The plumage full of eyes; the eyes of Argus
96  If they were living would be such as these.

94  Ognuno era pennuto di sei ali;
95  le penne piene d'occhi; e li occhi d'Argo,
96  se fosser vivi, sarebber cotali.

97  Reader! to trace their forms no more I waste
98  My rhymes; for other spendings press me so,
99  That I in this cannot be prodigal.

97  A descriver lor forme più non spargo
98  rime, lettor; ch'altra spesa mi strigne,
99  tanto ch'a questa non posso esser largo;

100  But read Ezekiel, who depicteth them
101  As he beheld them from the region cold
102  Coming with cloud, with whirlwind, and with fire;

100  ma leggi Ezechïel, che li dipigne
101  come li vide da la fredda parte
102  venir con vento e con nube e con igne;

103And such as thou shalt find them in his pages,
104  Such were they here; saving that in their plumage
105  John is with me, and differeth from him.

103  e quali i troverai ne le sue carte,
104  tali eran quivi, salvo ch'a le penne
105  Giovanni è meco e da lui si diparte.

106  The interval between these four contained
107  A chariot triumphal on two wheels,
108  Which by a Griffin's neck came drawn along;

106  Lo spazio dentro a lor quattro contenne
107  un carro, in su due rote, trïunfale,
108  ch'al collo d'un grifon tirato venne.

109  And upward he extended both his wings
110  Between the middle list and three and three,
111  So that he injured none by cleaving it.

109  Esso tendeva in sù l'una e l'altra ale
110  tra la mezzana e le tre e tre liste,
111  sì ch'a nulla, fendendo, facea male.

112  So high they rose that they were lost to sight;
113  His limbs were gold, so far as he was bird,
114  And white the others with vermilion mingled.

112  Tanto salivan che non eran viste;
113  le membra d'oro avea quant' era uccello,
114  e bianche l'altre, di vermiglio miste.

115  Not only Rome with no such splendid car
116  E'er gladdened Africanus, or Augustus,
117  But poor to it that of the Sun would be,—

115  Non che Roma di carro così bello
116  rallegrasse Affricano, o vero Augusto,
117  ma quel del Sol saria pover con ello;

118  That of the Sun, which swerving was burnt up
119  At the importunate orison of Earth,
120  When Jove was so mysteriously just.

118  quel del Sol che, svïando, fu combusto
119  per l'orazion de la Terra devota,
120  quando fu Giove arcanamente giusto.

121  Three maidens at the right wheel in a circle
122  Came onward dancing; one so very red
123  That in the fire she hardly had been noted.

121  Tre donne in giro da la destra rota
122  venian danzando; l'una tanto rossa
123  ch'a pena fora dentro al foco nota;

124  The second was as if her flesh and bones
125  Had all been fashioned out of emerald;
126  The third appeared as snow but newly fallen.

124  l'altr' era come se le carni e l'ossa
125  fossero state di smeraldo fatte;
126  la terza parea neve testé mossa;

127  And now they seemed conducted by the white,
128  Now by the red, and from the song of her
129  The others took their step, or slow or swift.

127  e or parëan da la bianca tratte,
128  or da la rossa; e dal canto di questa
129  l'altre toglien l'andare e tarde e ratte.

130  Upon the left hand four made holiday
131  Vested in purple, following the measure
132  Of one of them with three eyes m her head.

130  Da la sinistra quattro facean festa,
131  in porpore vestite, dietro al modo
132  d'una di lor ch'avea tre occhi in testa.

133  In rear of all the group here treated of
134  Two old men I beheld, unlike in habit,
135  But like in gait, each dignified and grave.

133  Appresso tutto il pertrattato nodo
134  vidi due vecchi in abito dispari,
136  ma pari in atto e onesto e sodo.

137  One showed himself as one of the disciples
138  Of that supreme Hippocrates, whom nature
139  Made for the animals she holds most dear;

136  L'un si mostrava alcun de' famigliari
137  di quel sommo Ipocràte che natura
138   a li animali fé ch'ell' ha più cari;

139  Contrary care the other manifested,
140  With sword so shining and so sharp, it caused
141  Terror to me on this side of the river.

139  mostrava l'altro la contraria cura
140  con una spada lucida e aguta,
141  tal che di qua dal rio mi fé paura.

142  Thereafter four I saw of humble aspect,
143  And behind all an aged man alone
144  Walking in sleep with countenance acute.

142  Poi vidi quattro in umile paruta;
143  e di retro da tutti un vecchio solo
144  venir, dormendo, con la faccia arguta.

145  And like the foremost company these seven
146  Were habited; yet of the flower-de-luce
147  No garland round about the head they wore,

145  E questi sette col primaio stuolo
146  erano abitüati, ma di gigli
147  dintorno al capo non facëan brolo,

148  But of the rose, and other flowers vermilion;
149  At little distance would the sight have sworn
150  That all were in a flame above their brows.

148  anzi di rose e d'altri fior vermigli;
149  giurato avria poco lontano aspetto
150  che tutti ardesser di sopra da' cigli.

151  And when the car was opposite to me
152  Thunder was heard; and all that folk august
153  Seemed to have further progress interdicted,

151  E quando il carro a me fu a rimpetto,
152  un tuon s'udì, e quelle genti degne
153  parvero aver l'andar più interdetto,

154  There with the vanward ensigns standing still.

154  fermandosi ivi con le prime insegne.

Canto XXX
The meeting with Beatrice, the departure of Virgil, how cannot these be the culmination of the poem?  The aspirant has gone through Hell, has been purged of each of the 7 deadly sins in Purgatory, is now in Eden, and is reunited with his beloved, his own split off soul and interior immortal self and conscience, shouldn't we be witnessing a marriage ceremony?  What pageant is this, what rite or triumph is being presented?  The complicated metaphor of the Septentrion, the 7, the number of virginity, the return to the metaphor of the sea, a metaphor which recalls the image in Canto One of the entire Commedia, wherein Dante imagines himself a swimmer looking back from shore on the ocean which almost drowned him, and now we have the image of an admiral, who stands on the deck of one ship, shouting encouragement to his fleet as they finally arrive safely in port, the talk of duty, and of veils and clouds, albeit clouds of flower, like confetti thrown into the air to flurry down on the figure in the griffin-drawn car, how can this not be a moment of supreme joy, supreme relief, and the most blissful of consummations?  Maybe it should be, but it is not.  It is a moment of double grief, the one the loss of Virgil, the other for that sin which is not remembered, that sin so heinous that the unconscious has hidden it from the sinner, and, unremembered, it is a loss, unwept for, unpurged.  If this is a wedding, it is one in which the bride assumes the role that in the Bible is given over to Satan, the father of crime, whose sole named crime is that of Accuser.  Bride as virgin, bride as the untouchable, bride as the old Troubadorian trope of the cold, cruel ice-queen punisher, the one who demands ordeals and impossible feats, the one who asks all, and rewards nothing, here Beatrice is the bride that denies union, denies joy, even denies the oblivion of Lethe and its baptismal waters of forgetfulness.  She turns the aspirant's attention to what she has had to endure on his behalf, she makes him ashamed of his own image in the stream which divides them.  In his shame, he transfers his gaze to the grass, which all living flesh must become, and that grave is preferable to his shame.  But that grave, as the aspirant well knows, is only a portal to more grief and not a release.  There is no wedding, and Dante's, and by extension the reader's own soul — my soul, my life — cannot be fulfilled until this final shame is fully realized, fully felt, and fully purged by tears of true repentance.  It is almost as if Beatrice is asking Dante to take responsibility for being born, and to admit that the entirety of original sin, and the unnaturalness of inhabiting a body which comes with murderous desires, and which must be inhabited, loved, possessed, but only so that it may suffer torment and death.  But how could Dante, or the reader, or to be more anguished, I myself, feel guilt for my very life, for all that is mortal, and repent for a sin, the purging of which is the death of the flesh that not only houses, but which seems indistinguishable from my very soul?  I must confess that it is not only grief that I experience at this juncture, but terror.  The crux of this Canto is a huge question mark, whose Sphinx-like riddle is well known: Man, humanity, the creature made by Time and destroyed by Time.  This plague that Dante is suffering, that I am suffering, is Oedipal to the nth degree.  The bride that awaits after he has killed God in himself, is his own mother, and after Dante has killed reason, Virgil, the bride that awaits him is the most inviolable taboo.  So, here we are: in the midst of the supreme Vision, the spectacle of spectacles, and the dazzle of our vision must be dimmed by tears.    

1  When the Septentrion of the highest heaven
2  (Which never either setting knew or rising,
3  Nor veil of other cloud than that of sin,

1  Quando il settentrïon del primo cielo,
2  che né occaso mai seppe né orto
3  né d'altra nebbia che di colpa velo,

4  And which made every one therein aware
5  Of his own duty, as the lower makes
6  Whoever turns the helm to come to port)

4  e che faceva lì ciascuno accorto
5  di suo dover, come 'l più basso face
6  qual temon gira per venire a porto,

7  Motionless halted, the veracious people,
8  That came at first between it and the Griffin,
9  Turned themselves to the car, as to their peace.

7  fermo s'affisse: la gente verace,
8  venuta prima tra 'l grifone ed esso,
9  al carro volse sé come a sua pace;

10  And one of them, as if by Heaven commissioned,
11  Singing, "Veni, sponsa, de Libano"
12  Shouted three times, and all the others after.

10  e un di loro, quasi da ciel messo,
11  “Veni, sponsa, de Libano” cantando
12  gridò tre volte, e tutti li altri appresso.

13  Even as the Blessed at the final summons
14  Shall rise up quickened each one from his cavern,
15  Uplifting light the reinvested flesh,

13  Quali i beati al novissimo bando
14  surgeran presti ognun di sua caverna,
15  la revestita voce alleluiando,

16  So upon that celestial chariot
17  A hundred rose 'ad vocem tanti senis,'
18  Ministers and messengers of life eternal.

16  cotali in su la divina basterna
17  si levar cento, ad vocem tanti senis,
18  ministri e messaggier di vita etterna.

19  They all were saying, "Benedictus qui venis,"
20  And, scattering flowers above and round about,
21  "Manibus o date lilia plenis."

19  Tutti dicean: “Benedictus qui venis!”
20  e fior gittando e di sopra e dintorno,
21  “Manibus, oh, date lilïa plenis!”

22  Ere now have I beheld, as day began,
23  The eastern hemisphere all tinged with rose,
24  And the other heaven with fair serene adorned;

22  Io vidi già nel cominciar del giorno
23  la parte orïental tutta rosata,
24  e l'altro ciel di bel sereno addorno;

25  And the sun's face, uprising, overshadowed
26  So that by tempering influence of vapours
27  For a long interval the eye sustained it;

25  e la faccia del sol nascere ombrata,
26  sì che per temperanza di vapori
27  l'occhio la sostenea lunga fïata:

28  Thus in the bosom of a cloud of flowers
29  Which from those hands angelical ascended,
30  And downward fell again inside and out,

28  così dentro una nuvola di fiori
29  che da le mani angeliche saliva
30  e ricadeva in giù dentro e di fori,

31  Over her snow-white veil with olive cinct
32  Appeared a lady under a green mantle,
33  Vested in colour of the living flame.

31  sovra candido vel cinta d'uliva
32  donna m'apparve, sotto verde manto
33  vestita di color di fiamma viva.

34  And my own spirit, that already now
35  So long a time had been, that in her presence
36  Trembling with awe it had not stood abashed,

34  E lo spirito mio, che già cotanto
35  tempo era stato ch'a la sua presenza
36  non era di stupor, tremando, affranto,

37  Without more knowledge having by mine eyes,
38  Through occult virtue that from her proceeded
39  Of ancient love the mighty influence felt.

37  sanza de li occhi aver più conoscenza,
38  per occulta virtù che da lei mosse,
39  d'antico amor sentì la gran potenza.

40  As soon as on my vision smote the power
41  Sublime, that had already pierced me through
42  Ere from my boyhood I had yet come forth,

40  Tosto che ne la vista mi percosse
41  l'alta virtù che già m'avea trafitto
42  prima ch'io fuor di püerizia fosse,

43  To the left hand I turned with that reliance
44  With which the little child runs to his mother,
45  When he has fear, or when he is afflicted,

43  volsimi a la sinistra col respitto
44  col quale il fantolin corre a la mamma
45  quando ha paura o quando elli è afflitto,

46  To say unto Virgilius: "Not a drachm
47  Of blood remains in me, that does not tremble;
48  I know the traces of the ancient flame."

46  per dicere a Virgilio: “Men che dramma
47  di sangue m'è rimaso che non tremi:
48  conosco i segni de l'antica fiamma.”

49  But us Virgilius of himself deprived
50  Had left, Virgilius, sweetest of all fathers,
51  Virgilius, to whom I for safety gave me:

49  Ma Virgilio n'avea lasciati scemi
50  di sé, Virgilio dolcissimo patre,
51  Virgilio a cui per mia salute die'mi;

52  Nor whatsoever lost the ancient mother
53  Availed my cheeks now purified from dew,
54  That weeping they should not again be darkened.

52  né quantunque perdeo l'antica matre,
53  valse a le guance nette di rugiada
54  che, lagrimando, non tornasser atre.

55  "Dante, because Virgilius has departed
56  Do not weep yet, do not weep yet awhile;
57  For by another sword thou need'st must weep."

55  “Dante, perché Virgilio se ne vada,
56  non pianger anco, non piangere ancora;
57  ché pianger ti conven per altra spada.”

58  E'en as an admiral, who on poop and prow
59  Comes to behold the people that are working
60  In other ships, and cheers them to well-doing,

58  Quasi ammiraglio che in poppa e in prora
59  viene a veder la gente che ministra
60  per li altri legni, e a ben far l'incora;

61  Upon the left hand border of the car,
62  When at the sound I turned of my own name,
63  Which of necessity is here recorded,

61  in su la sponda del carro sinistra,
62  quando mi volsi al suon del nome mio,
63  che di necessità qui si registra,

64  I saw the Lady, who erewhile appeared
65  Veiled underneath the angelic festival,
66  Direct her eyes to me across the river.

64  vidi la donna che pria m'appario
65  velata sotto l'angelica festa,
66  drizzar li occhi ver' me di qua dal rio.

67  Although the veil, that from her head descended,
68  Encircled with the foliage of Minerva,
69  Did not permit her to appear distinctly,

67  Tutto che 'l vel che le scendea di testa,
68  cerchiato de le fronde di Minerva,
69  non la lasciasse parer manifesta,

70  In attitude still royally majestic
71  Continued she, like unto one who speaks,
72  And keeps his warmest utterance in reserve:

70  regalmente ne l'atto ancor proterva
71  continüò come colui che dice
72  e 'l più caldo parlar dietro reserva:

73  "Look at me well; in sooth I'm Beatrice!
74  How didst thou deign to come unto the Mountain?
75  Didst thou not know that man is happy here?"

73  “Guardaci ben! Ben son, ben son Beatrice.
74  Come degnasti d'accedere al monte?
75  non sapei tu che qui è l'uom felice?”

76  Mine eyes fell downward into the clear fountain,
77  But, seeing myself therein, I sought the grass,
78  So great a shame did weigh my forehead down.

76  Li occhi mi cadder giù nel chiaro fonte;
77  ma veggendomi in esso, i trassi a l'erba,
78  tanta vergogna mi gravò la fronte.

79  As to the son the mother seems superb,
80  So she appeared to me; for somewhat bitter
81  Tasteth the savour of severe compassion.

79  Così la madre al figlio par superba,
80  com' ella parve a me; perché d'amaro
81  sente il sapor de la pietade acerba.

82  Silent became she, and the Angels sang
83  Suddenly, "In te, Domine, speravi:"
84  But beyond 'pedes meos' did not pass.

82  Ella si tacque; e li angeli cantaro
83  di sùbito “In te, Domine, speravi”;
84  ma oltre “pedes meos” non passaro.

85  Even as the snow among the living rafters
86  Upon the back of Italy congeals,
87  Blown on and drifted by Sclavonian winds,

85  Sì come neve tra le vive travi
86  per lo dosso d'Italia si congela,
87  soffiata e stretta da li venti schiavi,

88  And then, dissolving, trickles through itself
89  Whene'er the land that loses shadow breathes,
90  So that it seems a fire that melts a taper;

88  poi, liquefatta, in sé stessa trapela,
89  pur che la terra che perde ombra spiri,
90  sì che par foco fonder la candela;

91  E'en thus was I without a tear or sigh,
92  Before the song of those who sing for ever
93  After the music of the eternal spheres.

91  così fui sanza lagrime e sospiri
92  anzi 'l cantar di quei che notan sempre
93  dietro a le note de li etterni giri;

94  But when I heard in their sweet melodies
95  Compassion for me, more than had they said,
96  "O wherefore, lady, dost thou thus upbraid him?"

94  ma poi che 'ntesi ne le dolci tempre
95  lor compartire a me, par che se detto
96  avesser: “Donna, perché sì lo stempre?”

97  The ice, that was about my heart congealed,
98  To air and water changed, and in my anguish
99  Through mouth and eyes came gushing from my breast.

97  lo gel che m'era intorno al cor ristretto,
98  spirito e acqua fessi, e con angoscia
99  de la bocca e de li occhi uscì del petto.

100  She, on the right-hand border of the car
101  Still firmly standing, to those holy beings
102  Thus her discourse directed afterwards:

100  Ella, pur ferma in su la detta coscia
101  del carro stando, a le sustanze pie
102  volse le sue parole così poscia:

103  "Ye keep your watch in the eternal day,
104  So that nor night nor sleep can steal from you
105  One step the ages make upon their path;

103  “Voi vigilate ne l'etterno die,
104  sì che notte né sonno a voi non fura
105  passo che faccia il secol per sue vie;

106  Therefore my answer is with greater care,
107  That he may hear me who is weeping yonder,
108  So that the sin and dole be of one measure.

106  onde la mia risposta è con più cura
107  che m'intenda colui che di là piagne,
108  perché sia colpa e duol d'una misura.

109  Not only by the work of those great wheels,
110  That destine every seed unto some end,
111  According as the stars are in conjunction,

109  Non pur per ovra de le rote magne,
110  che drizzan ciascun seme ad alcun fine
111  secondo che le stelle son compagne,

112  But by the largess of celestial graces,
113  Which have such lofty vapours for their rain
114  That near to them our sight approaches not,

112  ma per larghezza di grazie divine,
113  che sì alti vapori hanno a lor piova,
114  che nostre viste là non van vicine,

115  Such had this man become in his new life
116  Potentially, that every righteous habit
117  Would have made admirable proof in him;

115  questi fu tal ne la sua vita nova
116  virtüalmente, ch'ogne abito destro
117  fatto averebbe in lui mirabil prova.
118  But so much more malignant and more savage
119  Becomes the land untilled and with bad seed,
120  The more good earthly vigour it possesses.

118  Ma tanto più maligno e più silvestro
119  si fa 'l terren col mal seme e non cólto,
120  quant' elli ha più di buon vigor terrestro.

121  Some time did I sustain him with my look;
122  Revealing unto him my youthful eyes,
123  I led him with me turned in the right way.

121  Alcun tempo il sostenni col mio volto:
122  mostrando li occhi giovanetti a lui,
123  meco il menava in dritta parte vòlto.

124  As soon as ever of my second age
125  I was upon the threshold and changed life,
126  Himself from me he took and gave to others.

124  Sì tosto come in su la soglia fui
125  di mia seconda etade e mutai vita,
126  questi si tolse a me, e diessi altrui.

127  When from the flesh to spirit I ascended,
128  And beauty and virtue were in me increased,
129  I was to him less dear and less delightful;

127  Quando di carne a spirto era salita,
128  e bellezza e virtù cresciuta m'era,
129  fu' io a lui men cara e men gradita;

130  And into ways untrue he turned his steps,
131  Pursuing the false images of good,
132  That never any promises fulfil;

130  e volse i passi suoi per via non vera,
131  imagini di ben seguendo false,
132  che nulla promession rendono intera.

133  Nor prayer for inspiration me availed,
134  By means of which in dreams and otherwise
135  I called him back, so little did he heed them.

133  Né l'impetrare ispirazion mi valse,
134  con le quali e in sogno e altrimenti
135  lo rivocai: sì poco a lui ne calse!

136  So low he fell, that all appliances
137  For his salvation were already short,
138  Save showing him the people of perdition.

136  Tanto giù cadde, che tutti argomenti
137  a la salute sua eran già corti,
138  fuor che mostrarli le perdute genti.

139  For this I visited the gates of death,
140  And unto him, who so far up has led him,
141  My intercessions were with weeping borne.

139  Per questo visitai l'uscio d'i morti,
140  e a colui che l'ha qua sù condotto,
141  li preghi miei, piangendo, furon porti.

142  God's lofty fiat would be violated,
143  If Lethe should be passed, and if such viands
144  Should tasted be, withouten any scot

142  Alto fato di Dio sarebbe rotto,
143  se Letè si passasse e tal vivanda
144  fosse gustata sanza alcuno scotto

145  Of penitence, that gushes forth in tears."

145  di pentimento che lagrime spanda.”

Canto XXXI
Who could Beatrice be to us?  If not the highest form of embodied exultation that we have ever experienced.  Her confrontation in this canto brings the terrible realization that at some point in our spiritual development is the question "Why, if we have ever had such an experience, would we ever gravitate back to those Hell states that the Commedia so vividly describes in the Inferno and also in the Purgatorio?"  There is some question of identity here, which, if we recall (and recollection itself is made treacherous in this canto), has been such an issue throughout the poem.  Naming, identifying, vilifying, praising, fame and obscurity, these have been the major themes and the dominating modus operandi of the poem, and now we see that as the spirit in the body and beyond it begins to express itself, its light overwhelms all of these shadowy remembrances, and whatever this thing called Self or identity is, it has consistently and tragically chosen lesser and darker expressions, it has corrupted its substance by a willful gluttony of the moment, which, no matter how turgidly poisonous, is devoured, and the being grows more obese, and more opaque, remembering only these Mayaesque distortions, and forgetting the clear light of that exultation.  If we have read the Tibetan Bardo Thodol, we should be familiar with this pattern, how the bright light of pure spirit overwhelms, and is rejected in favor of the dull, smokiness of these suffering states.  How then do we escape from this predicament, this death-shroud we have woven of our own skin?  This canto presents Dante's solution to this dilemma, and the question we have to ask is this: Does Dante's solution for himself hold for us too?  The question presented in this canto as some kind of visionary theology based upon confession, contrition, and satisfaction quite transcends any pat theological solution.  How, in the name of Heaven or of whatever each reader holds most dear, are we to experience our regrets, ego-puffing, self-naming and self-definitions, and how is such a re-collection of all our wayward disparate acts to be accomplished, so that we may be purged of our illusions, and be free and innocent enough to be baptized once again in exultation?  The aspirant in the poem, now on his own, abandoned by all guides and protectors, is being de-selved by awe, beauty, confusion, grief, fear, desire, and most of all by such a dazzling of lights that he begins to decohere at the onslaught, this decoherence accomplished by a double kind of drowning, one in floods of tears, and the other in a river of forgetfulness.  If I watch little children who have yet to be damaged by botched parenting and social malversations, I see that they freely alternate between what might be called the extremes of releasing emotions: tears and laughter.  There is zest in both, and in both a sort of cleansing of the emotional palette, so that in the next instant, the miracle of creation can be presented afresh, and an Eden of bliss, which is the default state of innocence, can be experienced again in all its glory as if for the first time.  The miracle of this poem is that Dante has found a way to present this ever-wondrous world or language and spirit, language as spirit, as an ongoing source of renewed splendor, even when the subject matter delves into the most atrocious aspects of existence.  The aspirant Dante as a protagonist of his own poem is an emotional innocent.  Throughout all the canticles, he does not suppress his feelings, and is like a child asking why? why?, not only for the sake of whatever answer is given, but for the reassurance of connection.  He never stops being that innocent child, and for all his missteps, and misunderstandings, there is in him a willingness to embrace experience as a source of exaltation, a source, so often as tears, but tears with a cleansing purpose.  And now as we enter these parts of the poem, where the recompense of joy and laughter are to be experienced, if we have faithfully followed the aspirant's progress, and have, not in some remote scholarly way, but in the way of rapport, which all children have with those elders around them through the operation of the brain's mirror neurons, we too are dazzled, we too have prepared ourselves to re-enter this state of prelapsarian innocence ... and not only that ... for this state is only a seed-state ... but we are also prepared to embark upon that course of development that we would have been able to follow if exultation and not fear, anger, grief, desire for that which damages, selfishness, pride, sloth, indecisiveness and all the other torments that mortal flesh is heir to had not collectively been the pole star of our life's journey.  Blot out that black star, and follow the bright star of beauteous, beatific love, and how different our lives would have been?  That bright star, for Dante is Beatrice, and somewhere, for most of us, there is a Beatrice moment, a moment that might have been the seed from which we might have grown a life of bliss, but instead, through cultural pressures, survival issues, through fear and shame, chose the darker path.  Too many modern readers have been stuck in Dante's Inferno, not even delving into the lessons of Purgatory, let alone the wonders of Paradise, these latter seeming to be boring, or irrelevant to their own experience.  But one could say, that the Dante who makes Dante great, and what he is really trying to express for us, starts after the end of his swim through and swallowing of the waters of Lethe.  Everything up to now has been preamble.  Whatever is to come is what all of the rest of this aesthetic and spiritual journey has been preparing us to receive.  

1  "O thou who art beyond the sacred river,"
2  Turning to me the point of her discourse,
3  That edgewise even had seemed to me so keen,

1  “O tu che se' di là dal fiume sacro,”
2  volgendo suo parlare a me per punta,
3  che pur per taglio m'era paruto acro,

4  She recommenced, continuing without pause,
5  "Say, say if this be true; to such a charge,
6  Thy own confession needs must be conjoined."

4  ricominciò, seguendo sanza cunta,
5  “dì, dì se questo è vero; a tanta accusa
6  tua confession conviene esser congiunta.”

7  My faculties were in so great confusion,
8  That the voice moved, but sooner was extinct
9  Than by its organs it was set at large.

7  Era la mia virtù tanto confusa,
8  che la voce si mosse, e pria si spense
9  che da li organi suoi fosse dischiusa.

10  Awhile she waited; then she said: "What thinkest?
11  Answer me; for the mournful memories
12  In thee not yet are by the waters injured."

10  Poco sofferse; poi disse: “Che pense?
11  Rispondi a me; ché le memorie triste
12  in te non sono ancor da l'acqua offense.”

13  Confusion and dismay together mingled
14  Forced such a Yes! from out my mouth, that sight
15  Was needful to the understanding of it.

13  Confusione e paura insieme miste
14  mi pinsero un tal “sì” fuor de la bocca,
15  al quale intender fuor mestier le viste.

16  Even as a cross-bow breaks, when 'tis discharged
17  Too tensely drawn the bowstring and the bow,
18  And with less force the arrow hits the mark,

16  Come balestro frange, quando scocca
17  da troppa tesa, la sua corda e l'arco,
18   e con men foga l'asta il segno tocca,

19  So I gave way beneath that heavy burden,
20  Outpouring in a torrent tears and sighs,
21  And the voice flagged upon its passage forth.

19  sì scoppia' io sottesso grave carco,
20  fuori sgorgando lagrime e sospiri,
21  e la voce allentò per lo suo varco. 
22  Whence she to me: "In those desires of mine
23  Which led thee to the loving of that good,
24  Beyond which there is nothing to aspire to,

22  Ond' ella a me: “Per entro i mie' disiri,
23  che ti menavano ad amar lo bene
24  di là dal qual non è a che s'aspiri 

25  What trenches lying traverse or what chains
26  Didst thou discover, that of passing onward
27  Thou shouldst have thus despoiled thee of the hope?

25  quai fossi attraversati o quai catene
26  trovasti, per che del passare innanzi
27  dovessiti così spogliar la spene?

28  And what allurements or what vantages
29  Upon the forehead of the others showed,
30  That thou shouldst turn thy footsteps unto them?"

28  E quali agevolezze o quali avanzi
29  ne la fronte de li altri si mostraro,
30  per che dovessi lor passeggiare anzi?”

31  After the heaving of a bitter sigh,
32  Hardly had I the voice to make response,
33  And with fatigue my lips did fashion it.

31  Dopo la tratta d'un sospiro amaro,
32 a pena ebbi la voce che rispuose,
33  e le labbra a fatica la formaro.

34  Weeping I said: "The things that present were
35  With their false pleasure turned aside my steps,
36  Soon as your countenance concealed itself."

34  Piangendo dissi: “Le presenti cose
35  col falso lor piacer volser miei passi,
36  tosto che 'l vostro viso si nascose.”

37  And she: "Shouldst thou be silent, or deny
38  What thou confessest, not less manifest
39  Would be thy fault, by such a Judge 'tis known.


37  Ed ella: “Se tacessi o se negassi
38  ciò che confessi, non fora men nota
39  la colpa tua: da tal giudice sassi!

40  But when from one's own cheeks comes bursting forth
41  The accusal of the sin, in our tribunal
42  Against the edge the wheel doth turn itself.

40  Ma quando scoppia de la propria gota
41  l'accusa del peccato, in nostra corte
42  rivolge sé contra 'l taglio la rota.

43  But still, that thou mayst feel a greater shame
44  For thy transgression, and another time
45  Hearing the Sirens thou mayst be more strong,

43  Tuttavia, perché mo vergogna porte
44  del tuo errore, e perché altra volta,
45  udendo le serene, sie più forte,

46  Cast down the seed of weeping and attend;
47  So shalt thou hear, how in an opposite way
48  My buried flesh should have directed thee.

46  pon giù il seme del piangere e ascolta:
47  sì udirai come in contraria parte
48  mover dovieti mia carne sepolta.

49  Never to thee presented art or nature
50  Pleasure so great as the fair limbs wherein
51  I was enclosed, which scattered are in earth.

49  Mai non t'appresentò natura o arte
50  piacer, quanto le belle membra in ch'io
51  rinchiusa fui, e che so' 'n terra sparte;

52  And if the highest pleasure thus did fail thee
53  By reason of my death, what mortal thing
54  Should then have drawn thee into its desire?

52  e se 'l sommo piacer sì ti fallio
53  per la mia morte, qual cosa mortale
54  dovea poi trarre te nel suo disio?

55  Thou oughtest verily at the first shaft
56  Of things fallacious to have risen up
57  To follow me, who was no longer such.

55  Ben ti dovevi, per lo primo strale
56  de le cose fallaci, levar suso
57  di retro a me che non era più tale.

58  Thou oughtest not to have stooped thy pinions downward
59  To wait for further blows, or little girl,
60  Or other vanity of such brief use.

58  Non ti dovea gravar le penne in giuso,
59  ad aspettar più colpo, o pargoletta
60  o altra novità con sì breve uso.

61  The callow birdlet waits for two or three,
62  But to the eyes of those already fledged,
63  In vain the net is spread or shaft is shot."

61  Novo augelletto due o tre aspetta;
62  ma dinanzi da li occhi d'i pennuti
63  rete si spiega indarno o si saetta.”

64  Even as children silent in their shame
65  Stand listening with their eyes upon the ground,
66  And conscious of their fault, and penitent;

64  Quali fanciulli, vergognando, muti
65  con li occhi a terra stannosi, ascoltando
66  e sé riconoscendo e ripentuti,

67  So was I standing; and she said: "If thou
68  In hearing sufferest pain, lift up thy beard
69  And thou shalt feel a greater pain in seeing."

67  tal mi stav' io; ed ella disse: “Quando
68  per udir se' dolente, alza la barba,
69  e prenderai più doglia riguardando.”
70  With less resistance is a robust holm
71  Uprooted, either by a native wind
72  Or else by that from regions of Iarbas,

70  Con men di resistenza si dibarba
71  robusto cerro, o vero al nostral vento
72  o vero a quel de la terra di Iarba,

73  Than I upraised at her command my chin;
74  And when she by the beard the face demanded,
75  Well I perceived the venom of her meaning.

73  ch'io non levai al suo comando il mento;
74  e quando per la barba il viso chiese,
75  ben conobbi il velen de l'argomento.

76  And as my countenance was lifted up,
77  Mine eye perceived those creatures beautiful
78  Had rested from the strewing of the flowers;

76  E come la mia faccia si distese,
77  posarsi quelle prime creature
78  da loro aspersïon l'occhio comprese;

79  And, still but little reassured, mine eyes
80  Saw Beatrice turned round towards the monster,
81  That is one person only in two natures.

79  e le mie luci, ancor poco sicure,
80  vider Beatrice volta in su la fiera
81  ch'è sola una persona in due nature.
 
82  Beneath her veil, beyond the margent green,
83  She seemed to me far more her ancient self
84  To excel, than others here, when she was here.

82  Sotto 'l suo velo e oltre la rivera
82  vincer pariemi più sé stessa antica,
83  vincer che l'altre qui, quand' ella c'era.

85  So pricked me then the thorn of penitence,
86  That of all other things the one which turned me
87  Most to its love became the most my foe.

85  Di penter sì mi punse ivi l'ortica,
86  che di tutte altre cose qual mi torse
87  più nel suo amor, più mi si fé nemica.

88  Such self-conviction stung me at the heart
89  O'erpowered I fell, and what I then became
90  She knoweth who had furnished me the cause.

88  Tanta riconoscenza il cor mi morse,
89  ch'io caddi vinto; e quale allora femmi,
90  salsi colei che la cagion mi porse.

91  Then, when the heart restored my outward sense,
92  The lady I had found alone, above me
93  I saw, and she was saying, "Hold me, hold me."

91  Poi, quando il cor virtù di fuor rendemmi,
92  la donna ch'io avea trovata sola
93  sopra me vidi, e dicea: “Tiemmi, tiemmi!”

94  Up to my throat she in the stream had drawn me,
95  And, dragging me behind her, she was moving
96  Upon the water lightly as a shuttle.

94  Tratto m'avea nel fiume infin la gola,
95  e tirandosi me dietro sen giva
96  sovresso l'acqua lieve come scola.

97  When I was near unto the blessed shore,
98  "Asperges me," I heard so sweetly sung,
99  Remember it I cannot, much less write it.

97  Quando fui presso a la beata riva,
98  “Asperges me” sì dolcemente udissi,
99  che nol so rimembrar, non ch'io lo scriva.

100  The beautiful lady opened wide her arms,
101  Embraced my head, and plunged me underneath,
102  Where I was forced to swallow of the water.

100  La bella donna ne le braccia aprissi;
101  abbracciommi la testa e mi sommerse
102  ove convenne ch'io l'acqua inghiottissi.

103  Then forth she drew me, and all dripping brought
104  Into the dance of the four beautiful,
105  And each one with her arm did cover me.

103  Indi mi tolse, e bagnato m'offerse
104  dentro a la danza de le quattro belle;
105  e ciascuna del braccio mi coperse.

106  'We here are Nymphs, and in the Heaven are stars;
107  Ere Beatrice descended to the world,
108  We as her handmaids were appointed her.

106  “Noi siam qui ninfe e nel ciel siamo stelle;
107  pria che Beatrice discendesse al mondo,
108  fummo ordinate a lei per sue ancelle.
 
109  We'll lead thee to her eyes; but for the pleasant
110  Light that within them is, shall sharpen thine
111  The three beyond, who more profoundly look.'

109  Merrenti a li occhi suoi; ma nel giocondo
110  lume ch'è dentro aguzzeranno i tuoi
111  le tre di là, che miran più profondo.”

112  Thus singing they began; and afterwards
113  Unto the Griffin's breast they led me with them,
114  Where Beatrice was standing, turned towards us.

112  Così cantando cominciaro; e poi
113  al petto del grifon seco menarmi,
114  ove Beatrice stava volta a noi.

115  "See that thou dost not spare thine eyes," they said;
116  "Before the emeralds have we stationed thee,
117  Whence Love aforetime drew for thee his weapons."
