115  Disser: “Fa che le viste non risparmi;
116  posto t'avem dinanzi a li smeraldi
117  ond' Amor già ti trasse le sue armi.”

118  A thousand longings, hotter than the flame,
119  Fastened mine eyes upon those eyes relucent,
120  That still upon the Griffin steadfast stayed.

118  Mille disiri più che fiamma caldi
119  strinsermi li occhi a li occhi rilucenti,
120  che pur sopra 'l grifone stavan saldi.

121  As in a glass the sun, not otherwise
122  Within them was the twofold monster shining,
123  Now with the one, now with the other nature.

121  Come in lo specchio il sol, non altrimenti
122  la doppia fiera dentro vi raggiava,
123  or con altri, or con altri reggimenti.

124  Think, Reader, if within myself I marvelled,
125  When I beheld the thing itself stand still,
126  And in its image it transformed itself.

124  Pensa, lettor, s'io mi maravigliava,
125  quando vedea la cosa in sé star queta,
126  e ne l'idolo suo si trasmutava.

127  While with amazement filled and jubilant,
128  My soul was tasting of the food, that while
129  It satisfies us makes us hunger for it,

127  Mentre che piena di stupore e lieta
128  l'anima mia gustava di quel cibo
129  che, saziando di sé, di sé asseta,

130  Themselves revealing of the highest rank
131  In bearing, did the other three advance,
132  Singing to their angelic saraband.

130  sé dimostrando di più alto tribo
131  ne li atti, l'altre tre si fero avanti,
132  danzando al loro angelico caribo.

133  "Turn, Beatrice, O turn thy holy eyes,"
134  Such was their song, "unto thy faithful one,
135  Who has to see thee ta'en so many steps.

133  “Volgi, Beatrice, volgi li occhi santi,”
134  era la sua canzone, “al tuo fedele
135  che, per vederti, ha mossi passi tanti!

136  In grace do us the grace that thou unveil
137  Thy face to him, so that he may discern
138  The second beauty which thou dost conceal."

136  Per grazia fa noi grazia che disvele
137  a lui la bocca tua, sì che discerna
138  la seconda bellezza che tu cele.”

139  O splendour of the living light eternal!
140  Who underneath the shadow of Parnassus
141  Has grown so pale, or drunk so at its cistern,

139  O isplendor di viva luce etterna,
140  chi palido si fece sotto l'ombra
141  sì di Parnaso, o bevve in sua cisterna,

142  He would not seem to have his mind encumbered
143  Striving to paint thee as thou didst appear,
144  Where the harmonious heaven o'ershadowed thee,

142  che non paresse aver la mente ingombra,
143  tentando a render te qual tu paresti
144  là dove armonizzando il ciel t'adombra,

145  quando ne l'aere aperto ti solvesti?

145  When in the open air thou didst unveil?

Canto XXXII
In Canto XXXII of the Purgatorio, one has the realization that we are moving into a domain, wherein Dante, of all poets, displays his special gift of rendering as narrative and quasi-visualizable allegories certain physiological and metaphysical states, states experienced in the living body as awe, bliss, terror or agony, or, even more astonishingly, as amalgamated intensities colored with all of these states simultaneously.  I think contemporary readers are particularly bored by allegory, and this chiefly because of that Freudian psychological maneuver called displacement.  That which is too intense, too traumatic, or as we see here, too joyful, is represented psychologically as something that lessens and also often obscures  — or perhaps we should make a new verb here, and say "obscurates".  The displacement is something we can emotionally handle, as the allegorical meaning behind the emotion moves the energy of vision and of the heart into the cooler domain of the intellect.  The overwhelming mystery that as vision must remain overwhelming, is depotentiated — one might say "tamed" — by the intellect's ability to decipher a mysterious code, as it does the mysterious shapes of letters on the page, or the small mouth movements of a language's sounded syllables, into that which is manipulable.  Think here of the inception of knowledge for a small child, who begins to understand her or his descent into the three-dimensions of space and the one of time, by manipulating small objects — blocks, or puzzle pieces, or cutout letters — with the hand.  One sees in this child, the almost inconceivable level of concentration required to subdue the inchoate wonders of the world into that which can be grasped.  So it is in the Commedia, in these sections where allegory arises as vision.  Commentators over the centuries have done all that they can to depotentiate these visions as meanings, representations of vast areas of transpersonal, historical experience, as is the case here, of the so-ascribed history of the Church up to Dante's time.  This meaning, which may well have been what Dante's conscious mind was aiming for, and which served to placate the hidden anxieties of his contemporaries, has, for us, in the early 21st Century, become far too vapid to have the impact required to move us, and we, like Dante, towards the end of this canto, are put to sleep, a particularly deep, and dreamless sleep, which is essentially a dark gap in space/time, wherein the psyche can assimilate the enormity of its experience.  I find it particularly amazing that Dante, who as a character in his own poem, understood that the psyche exists on many levels, which, like Russian dolls, enclose one another, dreams expanding inside of dreams, visions and metaphors changing shape and meaning, as the reader penetrates ever more deeply into the truly epic quality of the poem.  If we really want to experience this poem, we cannot rest in the religious symbolism of the early 14th Century.  We must, as Dante did, become the wondering and wandering spiritual aspirant.  We have entered a strange, and marvelous country, and with Coleridge's "willing suspension of disbelief," and also, I think, a deliberate severing, for a time, of the intellect's need to depotentiate through its activity of offering comforting explanations, we must make ourselves over into those little children, encountering for the first time the problem of making the miraculous manipulable.

I did not want to write what I am now writing.  It seems to me that there is an organic quality to the Commedia which obliges one to treat it as a living thing, a creature, not unlike the Griffin in this canto of a hybrid nature, but one which is slowly surrounding you, digesting you as you read.  Your intellectual body, and any sheathing or shell it has erected to protect its own vulnerabilities is the first layer that is assimilated.  The immense commentary tradition of serious scholars, who have spent their lives studying this text, discussing it, engaging in explorations and controversies, is ample testimony to this process.  But perhaps these intellectual endeavors mask even deeper processes, those that could be called the dissolution of the reader's morality/mortality body.  If there is a deeper aspect to the physical self, to life on Earth, I don't know what it is, but Dante seems to.  And from this deeper place, this place of the individual soul and the universal spirit, he gets at you.  I dreamt that I was listening to a lecture on Dante given by a prestigious scholar from the most prestigious university.  After the lecture, I made some comment to the effect that there was a way in which the academic treatment of Dante could turn one's reading into something almost as trivial as a "pastime".  The scholar became incensed.  He attacked me, essentially accusing me of cowardice because as an academic outsider I had not submitted myself and my ideas to the merciless gauntlet of judgement by experts, and moreover, I had refused, even when invited, to be included in that company.  I protested that I had never received or ever knew about any such invitations ... and then I awakened much disturbed, and stricken with the doubts of the autodidact.  Undoubtedly my comments on the text, not being subject to any correction or review, have covered old ground, have promulgated misreadings, have made innumerable errors in readings and in judgement, and have been saturated by the arrogance which infects one when one is protected from scrutiny and safe in the privacy of one's own mind.  The huge debt that I owe to the scholars and translators of this work cannot be adequately acknowledged.  The meanings that Dante himself might have ascribed to the allegories presented in this canto, with the chariot as the historical church, the griffin as Christ, the wood of chariot's hitch, as the cross, I have rather too cavalierly dismissed, and thereby robbed the work of its immense historical significance.  I simply have been too ignorant or too timid to take on the task of considering the ponderous question of the entirety of Christianity.  My own spiritual eclecticism, knowing some smattering of other religious traditions — Hinduism, Islam, Buddhism, Taoism, Shamanism, etc. — plus some generalized tidbits of psychology and brain science have made of me a perpetual dilettante, and the dream, drove that home for me, giving me an upset that I now have to live with, a splinter of that true cross perhaps, which will not be assimilated, and which will unceasingly fester and bleed, or, and this is more likely, will be insulated by a callus, a cynicism, and I will feel a little less, and hardened in my own opinions, remain, to use Singleton's term for Dante, the aspirant, at this stage: Justified.  I have always understood Justice and Injustice as Blakean opposites, and that there would be no need for justice, if, returning to our prelapsarian condition of innocence, we no longer committed injustices.  In such an Edenic state, there would be no weight of wrong to counterbalance in those iconic scales.  I had not considered the Law —  that mortality itself, and one's spiritual assumption of a physical body in 3D space/time is subject to certain physical constants, the only escape from which is to enter into some poetic/imaginative realm, shucking the shell of the body, and embracing what seems unreal, as the only real.  It comes as a shock to realize that to be in a body, to want in a sense, to live forever in bodily bliss, is a set of blinders that obscures the true import of this poem.  When Dante, the protagonist of his own poetic self, realizes this in the Purgatorio's Canto XXXI, he dissolves into tears of shame and remorse, and here, in Canto XXXII, he passes out in a dreamless sleep.  What indeed is the true cost of transcendence?  Everything.  Tears are this poem's digestive juices, and the total oblivion of assimilation is this great creature's appetite.  Assimilation, transformation, and elimination, these are the constants of mortal life, and they take place in an ordered cycle, the wheels of the chariot of a church that sweeps me — and all serious readers of the poem — along on this vanity project.  A voice with prestigious authority tells me: Nobody writes a diary without the expectation that it will be read, even if that reader is only his own future self.  I am sorry, for this, because it seems as if I am doomed to go on with my audacities and sweeping generalizations.  I can't stop, the momentum of my fall is just too great.  I would to God that I might have one of those transforming visions which are the substance of this work.  I am tired of the me who only reads Dante.  I want to be him.   

1  So steadfast and attentive were mine eyes
2  In satisfying their decennial thirst,
3  That all my other senses were extinct,

1  Tant' eran li occhi miei fissi e attenti
2  a disbramarsi la decenne sete,
3  che li altri sensi m'eran tutti spenti.

4  And upon this side and on that they had
5  Walls of indifference, so the holy smile
6  Drew them unto itself with the old net

4  Ed essi quinci e quindi avien parete
5  di non caler–così lo santo riso
6  a sé traéli con l'antica rete!–;

7  When forcibly my sight was turned away
8  Towards my left hand by those goddesses,
9  Because I heard from them a "Too intently!"

7  quando per forza mi fu vòlto il viso
8  ver' la sinistra mia da quelle dee,
9  perch' io udi' da loro un “Troppo fiso!”

10  And that condition of the sight which is
11  In eyes but lately smitten by the sun
12  Bereft me of my vision some short while;

10  e la disposizion ch'a veder èe
11  ne li occhi pur testé dal sol percossi,
12  sanza la vista alquanto esser mi fée.

13  But to the less when sight re-shaped itself,
14  I say the less in reference to the greater
15  Splendour from which perforce I had withdrawn,

13  Ma poi ch'al poco il viso riformossi
14  (e dico “al poco” per rispetto al molto
15  sensibile onde a forza mi rimossi),

16  I saw upon its right wing wheeled about
17  The glorious host returning with the sun
18  And with the sevenfold flames upon their faces.

16  vidi 'n sul braccio destro esser rivolto
17  lo glorïoso essercito, e tornarsi
18  col sole e con le sette fiamme al volto.

19  As underneath its shields, to save itself,
20  A squadron turns, and with its banner wheels,
21  Before the whole thereof can change its front,

19  Come sotto li scudi per salvarsi
20  volgesi schiera, e sé gira col segno,
21  prima che possa tutta in sé mutarsi;

22  That soldiery of the celestial kingdom
23  Which marched in the advance had wholly passed us
24  Before the chariot had turned its pole.

22  quella milizia del celeste regno
23  che procedeva, tutta trapassonne
24  pria che piegasse il carro il primo legno.

25  Then to the wheels the maidens turned themselves,
26  And the Griffin moved his burden benedight,
27  But so that not a feather of him fluttered.

25  Indi a le rote si tornar le donne,
26  e 'l grifon mosse il benedetto carco
27  sì, che però nulla penna crollonne.

28  The lady fair who drew me through the ford
29  Followed with Statius and myself the wheel
30  Which made its orbit with the lesser arc.

28  La bella donna che mi trasse al varco
29  e Stazio e io seguitavam la rota
30  che fé l'orbita sua con minore arco.
31  So passing through the lofty forest, vacant
32  By fault of her who in the serpent trusted,
33  Angelic music made our steps keep time.
31  Sì passeggiando l'alta selva vòta,
32  colpa di quella ch'al serpente crese,
33  temprava i passi un'angelica nota.
34  Perchance as great a space had in three flights
35  An arrow loosened from the string o'erpassed,
36  As we had moved when Beatrice descended.
34  Forse in tre voli tanto spazio prese
35  disfrenata saetta, quanto eramo
36  rimossi, quando Bëatrice scese.
37  I heard them murmur altogether, "Adam!"
38  Then circled they about a tree despoiled
39  Of blooms and other leafage on each bough.
37  Io senti' mormorare a tutti “Adamo”;
38  poi cerchiaro una pianta dispogliata
39  di foglie e d'altra fronda in ciascun ramo.
40  Its tresses, which so much the more dilate
41  As higher they ascend, had been by Indians
42  Among their forests marvelled at for height.
40  La coma sua, che tanto si dilata
41  più quanto più è sù, fora da l'Indi
42  ne' boschi lor per altezza ammirata.
43  "Blessed art thou, O Griffin, who dost not
44  Pluck with thy beak these branches sweet to taste,
45  Since appetite by this was turned to evil."

43  “Beato se', grifon, che non discindi
 44  col becco d'esto legno dolce al gusto,
45  poscia che mal si torce il ventre quindi.”
46  After this fashion round the tree robust
47  The others shouted; and the twofold creature:
48  "Thus is preserved the seed of all the just."
46  Così dintorno a l'albero robusto
47  gridaron li altri; e l'animal binato:
48  “Sì si conserva il seme d'ogne giusto.”
49  And turning to the pole which he had dragged,
50  He drew it close beneath the widowed bough,
51  And what was of it unto it left bound.
49  E vòlto al temo ch'elli avea tirato,
50  trasselo al piè de la vedova frasca,
51  e quel di lei a lei lasciò legato.
52  In the same manner as our trees (when downward
53  Falls the great light, with that together mingled
54  Which after the celestial Lasca shines)
52  Come le nostre piante, quando casca
53  giù la gran luce mischiata con quella
54  che raggia dietro a la celeste lasca,

55  Begin to swell, and then renew themselves,
56  Each one with its own colour, ere the Sun
57  Harness his steeds beneath another star:

55  turgide fansi, e poi si rinovella
56  di suo color ciascuna, pria che 'l sole
57  giunga li suoi corsier sotto altra stella;
58  Less than of rose and more than violet
59  A hue disclosing, was renewed the tree
60  That had erewhile its boughs so desolate.
58  men che di rose e più che di vïole
59  colore aprendo, s'innovò la pianta,
60  che prima avea le ramora sì sole.

61  I never heard, nor here below is sung,
62  The hymn which afterward that people sang,
63  Nor did I bear the melody throughout.

61  Io non lo 'ntesi, né qui non si canta
62  l'inno che quella gente allor cantaro,
63  né la nota soffersi tutta quanta.

64  Had I the power to paint how fell asleep
65  Those eyes compassionless, of Syrinx hearing,
66  Those eyes to which more watching cost so dear,

64  S'io potessi ritrar come assonnaro
65  li occhi spietati udendo di Siringa,
66  li occhi a cui pur vegghiar costò sì caro;

67  Even as a painter who from model paints
68  I would portray how I was lulled asleep;
69  He may, who well can picture drowsihood.

67  come pintor che con essempro pinga,
68  disegnerei com' io m'addormentai;
69  ma qual vuol sia che l'assonnar ben finga.
70  Therefore I pass to what time I awoke,
71  And say a splendour rent from me the veil
72  Of slumber, and a calling: "Rise, what dost thou?"

70  Però trascorro a quando mi svegliai,
71  e dico ch'un splendor mi squarciò 'l velo
72  del sonno, e un chiamar: “Surgi: che fai?”

73  As to behold the apple-tree in blossom
74  Which makes the Angels greedy for its fruit,
75  And keeps perpetual bridals in the Heaven,

73  Quali a veder de' fioretti del melo
74  che del suo pome li angeli fa ghiotti
75  e perpetüe nozze fa nel cielo,

76  Peter and John and James conducted were,
77  And, overcome, recovered at the word
78  By which still greater slumbers have been broken,

76  Pietro e Giovanni e Iacopo condotti
77 e vinti, ritornaro a la parola
78 da la qual furon maggior sonni rotti,

79  And saw their school diminished by the loss
80  Not only of Elias, but of Moses,
81  And the apparel of their Master changed;

79  e videro scemata loro scuola
80  così di Moïsè come d'Elia,
81  e al maestro suo cangiata stola;

82  So I revived, and saw that piteous one
83  Above me standing, who had been conductress
84  Aforetime of my steps beside the river,

82  tal torna' io, e vidi quella pia
83  sovra me starsi che conducitrice
84  fu de' miei passi lungo 'l fiume pria.

85  And all in doubt I said, "Where's Beatrice?"
86  And she: "Behold her seated underneath
87  The leafage new, upon the root of it.

85  E tutto in dubbio dissi: “Ov' è Beatrice?”
86  Ond' ella: “Vedi lei sotto la fronda
87  nova sedere in su la sua radice.

88  Behold the company that circles her;
89  The rest behind the Griffin are ascending
90  With more melodious song, and more profound."

88  Vedi la compagnia che la circonda:
89  li altri dopo 'l grifon sen vanno suso
90  con più dolce canzone e più profonda.”

91  And if her speech were more diffuse I know not,
92  Because already in my sight was she
93  Who from the hearing of aught else had shut me.

91  E se più fu lo suo parlar diffuso,
92  non so, però che già ne li occhi m'era
93  quella ch'ad altro intender m'avea chiuso.

94  Alone she sat upon the very earth,
95  Left there as guardian of the chariot
96  Which I had seen the biform monster fasten.

94  Sola sedeasi in su la terra vera,
95  come guardia lasciata lì del plaustro
96  che legar vidi a la biforme fera.

97  Encircling her, a cloister made themselves
98  The seven Nymphs, with those lights in their hands
99  Which are secure from Aquilon and Auster.

97  In cerchio le facevan di sé claustro
98  le sette ninfe, con quei lumi in mano
99  che son sicuri d'Aquilone e d'Austro.

100  "Short while shalt thou be here a forester,
101  And thou shalt be with me for evermore
102  A citizen of that Rome where Christ is Roman.

100  “Qui sarai tu poco tempo silvano;
101  e sarai meco sanza fine cive
102  di quella Roma onde Cristo è romano

103  Therefore, for that world's good which liveth ill,
104  Fix on the car thine eyes, and what thou seest,
105  Having returned to earth, take heed thou write."

103  Però, in pro del mondo che mal vive,
104   al carro tieni or li occhi, e quel che vedi,
105  ritornato di là, fa che tu scrive.”

105  Thus Beatrice; and I, who at the feet
107  Of her commandments all devoted was,
108  My mind and eyes directed where she willed.

106  Così Beatrice; e io, che tutto ai piedi
107  d'i suoi comandamenti era divoto,
108  la mente e li occhi ov' ella volle diedi.

109  Never descended with so swift a motion
110  Fire from a heavy cloud, when it is raining
111  From out the region which is most remote,

109  Non scese mai con sì veloce moto
110  foco di spessa nube, quando piove
111  da quel confine che più va remoto,

112  As I beheld the bird of Jove descend
113  Down through the tree, rending away the bark,
114  As well as blossoms and the foliage new,

112  com' io vidi calar l'uccel di Giove
113  per l'alber giù, rompendo de la scorza,
114  non che d'i fiori e de le foglie nove;

115  And he with all his might the chariot smote,
116  Whereat it reeled, like vessel in a tempest
117  Tossed by the waves, now starboard and now larboard.
115  e ferì 'l carro di tutta sua forza;
116  ond' el piegò come nave in fortuna,
117  vinta da l'onda, or da poggia, or da orza.

118  Thereafter saw I leap into the body
119  Of the triumphal vehicle a Fox,
120  That seemed unfed with any wholesome food.


118  Poscia vidi avventarsi ne la cuna
119  del trïunfal veiculo una volpe
120  che d'ogne pasto buon parea digiuna;

121  But for his hideous sins upbraiding him,
122  My Lady put him to as swift a flight
123  As such a fleshless skeleton could bear.

121  ma, riprendendo lei di laide colpe,
122 la donna mia la volse in tanta futa
123  quanto sofferser l'ossa sanza polpe.

124  Then by the way that it before had come,
125  Into the chariot's chest I saw the Eagle
126  Descend, and leave it feathered with his plumes.

124  Poscia per indi ond' era pria venuta,
125  l'aguglia vidi scender giù ne l'arca
126  del carro e lasciar lei di sé pennuta;

127  And such as issues from a heart that mourns,
128  A voice from Heaven there issued, and it said:
129  "My little bark, how badly art thou freighted!"

127  e qual esce di cuor che si rammarca,
128  tal voce uscì del cielo e cotal disse:
129  “O navicella mia, com' mal se' carca!”

130  Methought, then, that the earth did yawn between
131  Both wheels, and I saw rise from it a Dragon,
132  Who through the chariot upward fixed his tail,

130  Poi parve a me che la terra s'aprisse
131  tr'ambo le ruote, e vidi uscirne un drago
132  che per lo carro sù la coda fisse;

133  And as a wasp that draweth back its sting,
134  Drawing unto himself his tail malign,
135  Drew out the floor, and went his way rejoicing.

133  e come vespa che ritragge l'ago,
134  a sé traendo la coda maligna,
135  trasse del fondo, e gissen vago vago.
136  That which remained behind, even as with grass
137  A fertile region, with the feathers, offered
138  Perhaps with pure intention and benign,

136  Quel che rimase, come da gramigna
137  vivace terra, da la piuma, offerta
138  forse con intenzion sana e benigna,

139  Reclothed itself, and with them were reclothed
140  The pole and both the wheels so speedily,
141  A sigh doth longer keep the lips apart.

139  si ricoperse, e funne ricoperta
140  e l'una e l'altra rota e 'l temo, in tanto
141  che più tiene un sospir la bocca aperta.

142  Transfigured thus the holy edifice
143  Thrust forward heads upon the parts of it,
144  Three on the pole and one at either corner.

142  Trasformato così 'l dificio santo
143  mise fuor teste per le parti sue,
144  tre sovra 'l temo e una in ciascun canto.

145  The first were horned like oxen; but the four
146  Had but a single horn upon the forehead;
147  A monster such had never yet been seen!

144  Le prime eran cornute come bue,
145  ma le quattro un sol corno avean per fronte:
146  simile mostro visto ancor non fue.

148  Firm as a rock upon a mountain high,
149  Seated upon it, there appeared to me
150  A shameless whore, with eyes swift glancing round,

148  Sicura, quasi rocca in alto monte,
149   seder sovresso una puttana sciolta
150   m'apparve con le ciglia intorno pronte;

151  And, as if not to have her taken from him,
152  Upright beside her I beheld a giant;
153  And ever and anon they kissed each other.

151  e come perché non li fosse tolta,
152  vidi di costa a lei dritto un gigante;
153  e basciavansi insieme alcuna volta.

154  But because she her wanton, roving eye
155  Turned upon me, her angry paramour
156  Did scourge her from her head unto her feet.

154  Ma perché l'occhio cupido e vagante
155  a me rivolse, quel feroce drudo
156  la flagellò dal capo infin le piante;

157  Then full of jealousy, and fierce with wrath,
158  He loosed the monster, and across the forest
159  Dragged it so far, he made of that alone

157  poi, di sospetto pieno e d'ira crudo,
158  disciolse il mostro, e trassel per la selva,
159   tanto che sol di lei mi fece scudo

160  A shield unto the whore and the strange beast.

160  a la puttana e a la nova belva.

Canto XXXIII
The first canto of the Inferno presented what we might call a psychic allegory of the three beasts which confront the aspirant and drive him back.  Here, the allegory is of the people, "gentes", an allegory of the collective nature of human kind, and if we were expecting a celebration, that is, some kind of graduation ceremony for the aspirant for having passed through purgatory, learned all of his moral lessons, and expiated himself from the seven deadly sins, we will be very much confused and disappointed by the darkness herein presented.  To be sure, this is a darkness of "art", of beautiful voices singing in three and four part harmonies, which is a far cry from the cacophonic howlings of the Inferno.  But the content of this art, what is communicated emotionally by this transcendent beauty, is grief.  Imagine, the final lesson of the soul, is grief for the human condition!  And not just any grief, but a grief that imagines, as we should have been aware through all of the first two canticles of the poem, a punishing correction, a judgement, in which those who have been the cause of suffering are made to suffer in kind for the deviations that they have fomented.  We should perhaps now be thinking of what justice might be in the absence of injustice.  In other words, is paradise only only feasible in contrast to the condition of Hell?  Dante's Purgatory's last gasp, begins with its guiding spirit's sorrowful suspiration and her terrible prophesy of God's vengeance.  But it does not end there.  It ends, as does the Inferno, with a vision of the stars.

Another word about allegory needs to be expressed here.  Commentators for more than eight centuries have been busy trying to ferret out just what these visionary figures are meant to express, and they've done a tremendous job of this too, if what we should be getting out of the poem is the view of a 14th century Christian vis à vis the movements of history and of the individual human psyche as it is embedded in the collective of the people.  For me, that is not enough.  I am not a 14th century Christian, and no reader alive today or who might confront this poem in the future, can ever be what Dante's historical self was.  I do not think this poem is a museum piece, or even something that should be studied and venerated solely for its influence on the culture we have inherited partly through its powerful influence down through the centuries.  Its import, its meaning, continues to grow and mutate in the field of time.  It is not as if it's old meanings pertinent to a 14th Century Christian, or to any Christian, have been made moot, but they have through time, and through each reader's consciousness, mutated.  And it is this ability to mutate, to expand and adapt itself to each new generation of readers, and to the specific life circumstances of each individual reader, that has given, and will continue to give, this poem its power.  How does one even begin to think about a body that has through a lifetime processed millions of sense impressions, perhaps even hundreds of millions of thoughts about those impressions, let alone conceive of what a collective humanity has experienced in a domain consisting of millions of people over millennia of time, or the even vaster ecological and evolutionary processes of life and the universe?  Dante's answer is not surprising.  But it is hidden from us, until we begin to conceive of that enormity in the way his poetry presents itself, which is, just as astrophysicists do today in seeking for the constants which allow our type of universe to exist, a type of universe which can create observers, who may ask and even attempt to answer how such a universe came into existence, observers who can seek to discover the parameters by which their universe continues to function beneath the allegory of language.   Linguistic allegories are visions which begin to enable us to think about these enormities, much as a small child begins to discover how his body interacts with the world through what primary educators call "manipulables".   Words are things that the mind may grasp, examine, turn over, and think with and about, feel with and about.  This is what everyone is doing whether they acknowledge the activity or not, through those Freudian processes of condensation, displacement and jokes or puns.  In order to find our own harmony, our own Edenic condition, we are all allegorizing all that is into something the mind can grasp.  We are creating mental and emotional manipulables that will help us return to our original home in our own personal heaven.   And if there has never been some golden collective age, almost any of us has experienced some moment in which our world comes right, in which health and joy ushers us out of the endless dichotomies of Time, its just or unjust actions, into what we might call the perfectly regulated system.  This perfect balance is something inconceivable to us in any situation wherein we are out of balance, just as history — personal, collective, or cosmological — makes this balance seem inconceivable except as a litany of what has gone wrong — Dante's Inferno — or how we put things right again — Dante's seven story mountain of Purgatory.  These two virtual  places are involved with history, involved with a temporal past composed of pain's imbalances, where that which is and was, juts out painfully like the bones of a broken limb, and tells each historical actor that the harmony and joy which they at some moments at least experienced, even if only in childhood or in sleep or in the womb, have been violently interrupted.  Dante called this interruption "sin", the original meaning of which is a vale, a valley, a place of confusion.  This is a state that we all know quite well, a state that brings the struggle for survival, or a Schopenhauerian despair or boredom.  It is a state of inner war and outer violence.  It is a state of crime and punishment, a state, as Dante as shown all too persuasively in the Inferno, of interminable agony, wherein even suicide or death cannot grant the repose of oblivion.   In this state of consciousness, the past is a terrible deviation and the future, as it is here, is, at best, only a prophesy of retribution to correct that deviation.  All this is encapsulated here in Beatrice's prophesy, and her testing of Dante's ability to remember, i.e., resurrect his own deviations through the processes of fear and shame — that is, through the affects of primal guilt.  He has been baptized in Lethe.  He has forgotten that world of imbalance and of deviation, a step that is necessary, but insufficient.  The canto concludes with a second baptism, in the river Eunoe, in which he "remembers" original harmony and joy.  That tree of judgement and of the knowledge of good and evil is now a fruitful fountain of ever nourishing joy.  But of this joy, the poet does not speak.  Perhaps because it is not something that can be expressed in purgatorial language.  Its expression belongs in another realm.  Still, there is something about this which refers to our own experience of health, an experience which is generalized and diffused throughout our whole system, while sickness or injury is particularized as the pain or discomfort of a symptom.  Perhaps now, at this important juncture of the poem, we are being invited to infuse ourselves, not with this or that particular meaning of this or that particular canto, but to feel — really feel — how wonderful this total immersion in the poem has been.  This work, although in its particulars, deals with the pain of human existence as the symptom of the mortal human condition, wherein life is only a race towards death, is asking that we shift our attention to all the exhilarating harmonies we have experienced while reading it.  Over or under or enveloping all these particular tortures is art, light, geometry, and number.1  For make no mistake, Dante's underlying allegory is number, as abstract as starlight, and as remote from the ordinary (note that word) tormented and tormenting human existence as are the stars.  Dante ends this canto with what he calls the necessary "curbing" or curtailing constant of art, which is not a balance of the opposites of crime and retribution, it is law, the Latin, jus, that which puts things right. This law defines those parameters through which our universe came into existence and through which it continues on its paths of development and creativity.  Dante was such an audacious poet that he set out to discover or devise a poem which embodied those constants, in its sound patterns, in its numbers, in its visions, in its allegories, and it may be that he has come as close to doing this as any of our contemporary astrophysics or spiritual gurus, and the wonder of this audaciousness is that its only chance of succeeding is through the deepest kind of humility, the humility of the lover in the presence of his or her beloved.

1.  Number for Dante may refer to something more than quantity or proportionality, there is also the question of number as allegory, that is to say, number as it is used in the Kabbalistic and numerological esoteria of Gematria.  Specifically here we have the famous mystery of the prophecy of 515 or DXV, i.e., nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque (line 43).  Like the Feltro prophesy in Canto I of Inferno,  this and other, most commentators over the centuries link to a possible political leader who might come and bring peace and order to the chaos and violence of the Italian City States.  I would like to note that Aleister Crowley in 777 and Other Qabalistic Writings reads the Gematria of the number 515 as equated with three Latin phrases: Possessio sine angustiis, that is "Possession without restrictions;" Minister iudicii, "Minister of justice," and Phylacterium, "talisman" or "amulet."  I have no idea where Crowley came up with his knowledge, but the fit here is intriguing and I have already noted elsewhere the evidence we have for Dante's knowledge of the Kabbala.  The most interesting, and most convincing solution to the mystery that I have seen so far is that of Massimo Verdicchio, who, in his book, The Poetics of Dante's Paradiso, claims that both the 515 and the Feltro allegories refer to the poem itself, which would mean that for Dante no political or ecclesiastical solution is possible for the violent injustices of the world, but only an aesthetic/spiritual one, the one we find in poetry.  This solution also jives with that proposed by Walter Arensberg in his book The Cryptological Dante, in which he claims that there is in the DXV an anagram in Latin script for DUX, or Duc, that is, leader.  Arensbery finds in these lines a cryptological reference to Dante himself, as poet.  Using Kabbalistic numerical equivalencies of Gematria, Arensbery shows how the verses spell out Dante's name.  The interesting thing about all of these highly esoteric solutions, which I doubt many commentators would accept, is that they provide evidence from completely different sources, which are consistent with the text, and thus they provide a solution which has eluded scholars who have been seeking in vain for eight centuries for an historical figure that fits the poem's given criteria for the sought-for leader.   

1  "Deus venerunt gentes," alternating
2  Now three, now four, melodious psalmody
3  The maidens in the midst of tears began;

1  Deus, venerunt gentes,“ alternando
2  or tre or quattro dolce salmodia,
3  le donne incominciaro, e lagrimando;

4  And Beatrice, compassionate and sighing,
5  Listened to them with such a countenance,
6  That scarce more changed was Mary at the cross.

4  e Bëatrice, sospirosa e pia,
5  quelle ascoltava sì fatta, che poco
6  più a la croce si cambiò Maria.

7  But when the other virgins place had given
8  For her to speak, uprisen to her feet
9  With colour as of fire, she made response:

7  Ma poi che l'altre vergini dier loco
8  a lei di dir, levata dritta in pè,
9  rispuose, colorata come foco:

10  "'Modicum, et non videbitis me;
11  Et iterum,' my sisters predilect,
12  'Modicum, et vos videbitis me.'"

10  ”Modicum, et non videbitis me;
11  et iterum, sorelle mie dilette,
12  modicum, et vos videbitis me.“

13  Then all the seven in front of her she placed;
14  And after her, by beckoning only, moved
15  Me and the lady and the sage who stayed.

13  Poi le si mise innanzi tutte e sette,
14  e dopo sé, solo accennando, mosse
15  me e la donna e 'l savio che ristette.

16  So she moved onward; and I do not think
17  That her tenth step was placed upon the ground,
18  When with her eyes upon mine eyes she smote,

16  Così sen giva; e non credo che fosse
17  lo decimo suo passo in terra posto,
18  quando con li occhi li occhi mi percosse;

19  And with a tranquil aspect, "Come more quickly,"
20  To me she said, "that, if I speak with thee,
21  To listen to me thou mayst be well placed."

19  e con tranquillo aspetto ”Vien più tosto,“
20  mi disse, ”tanto che, s'io parlo teco,
21  ad ascoltarmi tu sie ben disposto.“

22  As soon as I was with her as I should be,
23  She said to me: "Why, brother, dost thou not
24  Venture to question now, in coming with me?"

22  Sì com' io fui, com' io dovëa, seco,
23  dissemi: ”Frate, perché non t'attenti
24  a domandarmi omai venendo meco?“

25  As unto those who are too reverential,
26  Speaking in presence of superiors,
27  Who drag no living utterance to their teeth,

25  Come a color che troppo reverenti
26  dinanzi a suo maggior parlando sono,
27  che non traggon la voce viva ai denti,

28  It me befell, that without perfect sound
29  Began I: "My necessity, Madonna,
30  You know, and that which thereunto is good."

28  avvenne a me, che sanza intero suono
29  incominciai: ”Madonna, mia bisogna
30  voi conoscete, e ciò ch'ad essa è buono.“

31  And she to me: "Of fear and bashfulness
32  Henceforward I will have thee strip thyself,
33  So that thou speak no more as one who dreams.

31  Ed ella a me: ”Da tema e da vergogna
32  voglio che tu omai ti disviluppe,
33  sì che non parli più com' om che sogna.

34  Know that the vessel which the serpent broke
35  Was, and is not; but let him who is guilty
36  Think that God's vengeance does not fear a sop.

34  Sappi che 'l vaso che 'l serpente ruppe,
35  fu e non è; ma chi n'ha colpa, creda
36  che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe.

37  Without an heir shall not for ever be
38  The Eagle that left his plumes upon the car,
39  Whence it became a monster, then a prey;

37  Non sarà tutto tempo sanza reda
38  l'aguglia che lasciò le penne al carro,
39  per che divenne mostro e poscia preda;

40  For verily I see, and hence narrate it,
41  The stars already near to bring the time,
42  From every hindrance safe, and every bar,

40  ch'io veggio certamente, e però il narro,
41  a darne tempo già stelle propinque,
42  secure d'ogn' intoppo e d'ogne sbarro,

43  Within which a Five-hundred, Ten, and Five,
44  One sent from God, shall slay the thievish woman
45  And that same giant who is sinning with her.

43  nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque,
44  messo di Dio, anciderà la fuia
45  con quel gigante che con lei delinque.

46  And peradventure my dark utterance,
47  Like Themis and the Sphinx, may less persuade thee,
48  Since, in their mode, it clouds the intellect;

46  E forse che la mia narrazion buia,
47  qual Temi e Sfinge, men ti persuade,
48  perch' a lor modo lo 'ntelletto attuia;

49  But soon the facts shall be the Naiades
50  Who shall this difficult enigma solve,
51  Without destruction of the flocks and harvests.

49  ma tosto fier li fatti le Naiade,
50  che solveranno questo enigma forte
51  sanza danno di pecore o di biade.

52  Note thou; and even as by me are uttered
53 These words, so teach them unto those who live
54  That life which is a running unto death;

52  Tu nota; e sì come da me son porte,
53  così queste parole segna a' vivi
54  del viver ch'è un correre a la morte.

55  And bear in mind, whene'er thou writest them,
56  Not to conceal what thou hast seen the plant,
57  That twice already has been pillaged here.

55  E aggi a mente, quando tu le scrivi,
56  di non celar qual hai vista la pianta
57  ch'è or due volte dirubata quivi.

58  Whoever pillages or shatters it,
59  With blasphemy of deed offendeth God,
60  Who made it holy for his use alone.

58  Qualunque ruba quella o quella schianta,
59  con bestemmia di fatto offende a Dio,
60  che solo a l'uso suo la creò santa.

61  For biting that, in pain and in desire
62  Five thousand years and more the first-born soul
63  Craved Him, who punished in himself the bite.

61  Per morder quella, in pena e in disio
62  cinquemilia anni e più l'anima prima
63  bramò colui che 'l morso in sé punio.

64  Thy genius slumbers, if it deem it not
65  For special reason so pre-eminent
66  In height, and so inverted in its summit.

64  Dorme lo 'ngegno tuo, se non estima
65  per singular cagione essere eccelsa
66  lei tanto e sì travolta ne la cima.

67  And if thy vain imaginings had not been
68  Water of Elsa round about thy mind,
69  And Pyramus to the mulberry, their pleasure,

67  E se stati non fossero acqua d'Elsa
68  li pensier vani intorno a la tua mente,
69  e 'l piacer loro un Piramo a la gelsa,

70  Thou by so many circumstances only
71  The justice of the interdict of God
72  Morally in the tree wouldst recognize.

70  per tante circostanze solamente
71  la giustizia di Dio, ne l'interdetto,
72  conosceresti a l'arbor moralmente.

73  But since I see thee in thine intellect
74  Converted into stone and stained with sin,
75  So that the light of my discourse doth daze thee,

73  Ma perch' io veggio te ne lo 'ntelletto
74  fatto di pietra e, impetrato, tinto,
75  sì che t'abbaglia il lume del mio detto, 

76  I will too, if not written, at least painted,
77  Thou bear it back within thee, for the reason
78  That cinct with palm the pilgrim's staff is borne."

76  voglio anco, e se non scritto, almen dipinto,
77 che 'l te ne porti dentro a te per quello
78 che si reca il bordon di palma cinto.“

79  And I: "As by a signet is the wax
80  Which does not change the figure stamped upon it,
81  My brain is now imprinted by yourself.

79  E io: ”Sì come cera da suggello,
80  che la figura impressa non trasmuta,
81  segnato è or da voi lo mio cervello.

82  But wherefore so beyond my power of sight
83  Soars your desirable discourse, that aye
84  The more I strive, so much the more I lose it?"

82  Ma perché tanto sovra mia veduta
83  vostra parola disïata vola,
84  che più la perde quanto più s'aiuta?“

85  "That thou mayst recognize," she said, "the school
86  Which thou hast followed, and mayst see how far
87  Its doctrine follows after my discourse,

85  ”Perché conoschi,“ disse, ”quella scuola
86  c'hai seguitata, e veggi sua dottrina
87  come può seguitar la mia parola;

88  And mayst behold your path from the divine
89  Distant as far as separated is
90  From earth the heaven that highest hastens on."

88  e veggi vostra via da la divina
89  distar cotanto, quanto si discorda
90  da terra il ciel che più alto festina.“

91  Whence her I answered: "I do not remember
92  That ever I estranged myself from you,
93  Nor have I conscience of it that reproves me."

91  Ond' io rispuosi lei: ”Non mi ricorda
92  ch'i' stranïasse me già mai da voi,
93  né honne coscïenza che rimorda.“

94  "And if thou art not able to remember,"
95  Smiling she answered, "recollect thee now
96  That thou this very day hast drunk of Lethe;

94  ”E se tu ricordar non te ne puoi,“
95  sorridendo rispuose, ”or ti rammenta
96  come bevesti di Letè ancoi;

97  And if from smoke a fire may be inferred,
98  Such an oblivion clearly demonstrates
99  Some error in thy will elsewhere intent.

97  e se dal fummo foco s'argomenta,
98  cotesta oblivïon chiaro conchiude
99 colpa ne la tua voglia altrove attenta.

100  Truly from this time forward shall my words
101  Be naked, so far as it is befitting
102  To lay them open unto thy rude gaze."

100  Veramente oramai saranno nude
101  le mie parole, quanto converrassi
102 quelle scovrire a la tua vista rude.“

103  And more coruscant and with slower steps
104  The sun was holding the meridian circle,
105  Which, with the point of view, shifts here and there

103  E più corusco e con più lenti passi
104  teneva il sole il cerchio di merigge,
105 che qua e là, come li aspetti, fassi,

106  When halted (as he cometh to a halt,
107  Who goes before a squadron as its escort,
108  If something new he find upon his way)

106  quando s'affisser, sì come s'affigge
107  chi va dinanzi a gente per iscorta
108  se trova novitate o sue vestigge,

109  The ladies seven at a dark shadow's edge,
110  Such as, beneath green leaves and branches black,
111  The Alp upon its frigid border wears.

109  le sette donne al fin d'un'ombra smorta,
110  qual sotto foglie verdi e rami nigri
111  sovra suoi freddi rivi l'alpe porta.

112  In front of them the Tigris and Euphrates
113  Methought I saw forth issue from one fountain,
114  And slowly part, like friends, from one another.

112  Dinanzi ad esse ”Ëufratès e Tigri
113  veder mi parve uscir d'una fontana,
114  e, quasi amici, dipartirsi pigri.

115  "O light, O glory of the human race!
116  What stream is this which here unfolds itself
117  From out one source, and from itself withdraws?"

115  “O luce, o gloria de la gente umana,
116  che acqua è questa che qui si dispiega
117  da un principio e sé da sé lontana?”
118  For such a prayer, 'twas said unto me, "Pray
119  Matilda that she tell thee;" and here answered,
120  As one does who doth free himself from blame,

118  Per cotal priego detto mi fu: “Priega
119  Matelda che 'l ti dica.” E qui rispuose,
120  come fa chi da colpa si dislega,

121  The beautiful lady: "This and other things
122  Were told to him by me; and sure I am
123  The water of Lethe has not hid them from him."

121  la bella donna: “Questo e altre cose
122  dette li son per me; e son sicura
123  che l'acqua di Letè non gliel nascose.”

124  And Beatrice: "Perhaps a greater care,
125  Which oftentimes our memory takes away,
126  Has made the vision of his mind obscure.

124  E Bëatrice: “Forse maggior cura,
125  che spesse volte la memoria priva,
126  fatt' ha la mente sua ne li occhi oscura.

127  But Eunoe behold, that yonder rises;
128  Lead him to it, and, as thou art accustomed,
129  Revive again the half-dead virtue in him."

127  Ma vedi Eünoè che là diriva:
128  menalo ad esso, e come tu se' usa,
129  la tramortita sua virtù ravviva.”

130  Like gentle soul, that maketh no excuse,
131  But makes its own will of another's will
132  As soon as by a sign it is disclosed,

130  Come anima gentil, che non fa scusa,
131  ma fa sua voglia de la voglia altrui
132  tosto che è per segno fuor dischiusa;

133  Even so, when she had taken hold of me,
134  The beautiful lady moved, and unto Statius
135  Said, in her womanly manner, "Come with him."

133  così, poi che da essa preso fui,
134  la bella donna mossesi, e a Stazio
135  donnescamente disse: “Vien con lui.”

136  If, Reader, I possessed a longer space
137  For writing it, I yet would sing in part
138  Of the sweet draught that ne'er would satiate me;

136  S'io avessi, lettor, più lungo spazio
137  da scrivere, i' pur cantere' in parte
138  lo dolce ber che mai non m'avria sazio;

139  But inasmuch as full are all the leaves
140 Made ready for this second canticle,
141  The curb of art no farther lets me go.

139  ma perché piene son tutte le carte
140 ordite a questa cantica seconda,
141  non mi lascia più ir lo fren de l'arte.

142  From the most holy water I returned
143  Regenerate, in the manner of new trees
144  That are renewed with a new foliage,

142  Io ritornai da la santissima onda
143  rifatto sì come piante novelle
144  rinovellate di novella fronda,

145  Pure and disposed to mount unto the stars.

145  puro e disposto a salire a le stelle.

Paradiso

Canto I
When we come into the Paradiso, we have arrived at the central problem of narrative, and indeed, that of listening to language or of reading its written representations on a page, a stone wall, a piece of bark, or a computer screen.  If not to be on Earth, as Beatrice emphatically tells Dante (line 91) that he is not, is to be in eternity, should we assume that this ascendance means we have escaped the narrative stream of language as it sequentially unfolds?  If so, have we then arrived in a world whose unity allows change, but not that change associated with beginnings, middles, or ends — inception, growth, or decay.   In this world, how is language, even poetic language as great and as subtle as is Dante's, ever going create a representation of that unified, ever-new state?  Inferno told us the consequences of self-centered action taken solely to slake the crudest of animal passions, wherein the human mind, becomes sub-bestial.  The actors in Hell are not only wholly perverted to pursue their bodily appetites, which have their limits in the natural world, and do not pollute the creatures whose bodies have evolved to purely express them, they are also wholly addicted to abstractions — abstractions such as political factions, prestige, family pride, reputation, things that by their very nature are no-things, and are thus unbounded in their rapacious capacities to damage and destroy.  Rising above that catastrophe,  Purgatorio shows us the evolution of a human mind ruled by the heart of compassion.  The abstractions become curbs on the appetites, not prods to indulge them, and we meet with remorse, guilt, justice, concern for others, humility, acceptance, devotion.  In Purgatory, the human mind that had accrued all the torments of Hell, in an endless war of not merely survival, but, as certain deranged politicians in our times evilly image it: Full spectrum dominance — the attempt to subdue inner fears with outward control, and the complete subjugation of the Other.  All this, in Purgatory has been renounced, and suffering, although still present, is only the stubbornness of that old demonic mind's resistance to losing that identity which had calcified around the old terror-based ambitions.  Now we come to Paradise, and if that human, sub-bestial mind has been purged, its identity washed away in the oblivion of Lethe, while the compassionate mind's virtues have been infused by its baptism in the river Eunoe, to what is this post-lapsarian mind devoted?  Does it remain in a void of Buddhistic No-Mind, or is this new vessel ready to receive a different kind of identity, one that we had been destined to have and be all along?  And how can poetry, with only an Earth space and time-bound language at its disposal, express this new heart/mind's identity?   The kind of reading, the kind of narration, that we have been used to in the first two canticles of the Commedia, and in virtually every other kind of reading in our lives, is now going to be inadequate, or maybe, more to the point, made irrelevant, to this place of bliss without surcease, of multiplicity without conflict, of eternity without the effects of mutantizing and death-dealing Time.  In Hell, evil is finally frozen, as unfree as a machine, Satan's mechanized body generating the foul wind wherein temporal change is always a buffeting and fetid degradation, and fate is the automaticity of mortal life, racing always, in Beatrice's words, towards Death —  not a releasing Death, but rather a cessation of free will, and a moral paralysis which locks one into the most abominable and interminable experience of pain.  Is the opposite of this paralysis to be only a second kind unfreedom, an eternal sameness of bliss, wherein only the One exists, which — or rather who — subsumes all others in his radiant stasis?  We know who we are in Satan.  We know who we are in the act of purgation.  But who are we, unique and free, in the orbit of One who neither changes nor revolves?  Dante's audacious enterprise in the Paradiso is to answer this question and resolve this mighty paradox.  In Canto One of the Inferno, Dante talks of the ineffable as a matter of choice, that the tale he is about to remember is so abominable, so terrifying to recall, that nothing less than the desire to do good for others could compel him to write about it.  Here, in Paradise, ordinary memory, which is always a second-hand dredging-up of the past, and thus a temporally bound thing, has little or no role.  Eternity has no past, and no future either, it is perpetual presence.  The ineffability of the experience is not a matter of conscious choice.  Nothing short of divine inspiration can in any way produce a language that can relate the ever-presentness of Paradise, because all earthly languages are rooted in memory, rooted in their meaning-sense in the past.  What is, in fact, present in language, is not it's meaning, but its sound.  And sound is the thing that leaps to the fore here, with Dante's long and stunningly pagan invocation, not to Jesus, nor to the Christian God, but to Apollo — and in lieu of the fruit from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, the tree invoked by the aspirant gives the laurel crown of poetry.  One has to ask why this is so, and why moreover does he conjure up the horrible image of the Apollo-defeated poet as being skinned, as was Marsyas, when he attempted to transcend human skill, and pretend to be filled with the divine.  What Dante seems to be alluding to here is a fundamental difference between Judeo-Christian scripture and pagan mythology.  The first being an historicization of the divine, a bringing of the treasure of eternity into the temporal realm of cultural memory transmission, a process that must lead to the mystery of Jesus, the divine/human/father/son, and the second being derived from a kind of species-childhood, an imaginative effort to make sense of the mysteries of experience through the culturally shared fantasy of myth.  In the first case God is reality, and in the second a god is the product of human psychology.  Perhaps the mythological invocation alludes to that old taboo, which warns that to speak the true name of God is to be immolated, and since Dante — the diachronic Dante, who exists both inside his text as aspirant and outside his text as poet — can only be immolated as aspirant, but never as poet.  As poet, he must elevate the meaning-text of his language through psychological mythologization, while the sound text blazes forth the actual experience of Paradise.  Other solutions also presents themselves, not necessarily as alternatives, but perhaps as both/ands, thereby deepening the text as a mimetic representation of the cosmos, not merely a symbolic one, in so far as at the level of signification it may seem one-dimensional or dialectical, but at the various levels of metaphor and allegory it is shown to be, like creation, inclusive of multidimensional processes, processes which regulate one another to achieve both novelty and homeostasis.  Consider the example of Marsyas, a figure traditionally associated with overweening pride and the human usurpation of divine power — and it is that.  But Dante asks to assume that very role, with perhaps the caveat that, unlike Marsyas, he wants to humbly negate his own arrogance and align himself with those creative powers responsible for Creation.  After all, throughout the poem, Dante selects references from a wide variety of texts to elevate his own, so that he may be said to acknowledge that his creative power is not merely his own, but only a part of a living network of creators, which collectively are channeling and guiding the universe's own powers of creation.  Similarly, there may be both affirmation and negation in the way the text deals with Apollo.  It may be that the well-worn interpretation of the god as a failed suitor to Daphne, wherein she is turned into a Laurel tree, is really a consummation, since trees feed on sunlight, as Dante feeds on the light of Beatrice, and we will find as we proceed in the Paradiso, an increasing array of light metaphors.   It would not be unlike Dante to present in his mythological readings surprisingly ironic interpretations, especially ones that negate that old saw that there are some things which are impossible for language to express.  That may be, and the text asserts such more than once, but Dante attempts to humbly elevate poetry to a degree that as much or more than any other human endeavor, it puts us in touch with the divine.  It is a very tricky business he is embarked upon here, and we, as readers and listeners, must realize where we are.  We must not contextualize everything from where we have been.  The animal mind that we found manifested in the depraved shades of Hell will be bored by this kind of poetry, and the emotional mind, like those minds in Purgatory, will be confused by it.  But here, there is something new — ever-new.  Perhaps — barrowing a term from a different tradition — we might call this ever-new mind the Satori mind.  After illumination, what then?  The awakened one is still a stranger in a strange heaven, and his development, to find more of God's light from his condition of embodying less of it, must change via a kind of philosophical/theological series of openings, via the logic of the logos, whereby the already absolved and cleansed spirit can become the vessel (as the text claims in line 14) of more of that light — and let us not forget, also more of its movement (line 1), that is to say, of its freedom.  One could contemplate this movement as the relatively greater activity in an organic being, in terms of the organization of atoms, molecules, cells, and in terms of sensory, ideational, and affective capacities (line 120), than in an inorganic substance.  And yet an organism for all of its trillions of independent cells, operates as a unity.  How does this happen?  Dante suggests that this phenomenon is the result of some kind of harmonizing virtue (virtue in the sense of creative power), which has evolved itself to express its own organization, in short, a universe which has evolved observers, observers which may examine the mysteries of that universe where observers such as themselves are possible.  For Dante, this potential of the universe to create and organize matter to the extent that such things as a Dante, his Commedia, and especially his love for Beatrice, is divine, is God.  I think this is still the most serious cosmological and personal issue that human beings can undertake to contemplate or to in any way comprehend, and the contemplation of this confrontation is the subject of the Paradiso, no different for Dante than it was for Einstein, or for us.  This poem attempts to refine the mind of its author, and by extension, its readers, to more and more subtly contemplate this most personal and cosmological of mysteries.  What we should be experiencing as we read and contemplate the Paradiso is the subtle expansion of our own capabilities to manifest that Mind whose potential continues to evolve, with no diminution of its own potential.  Is such a thing even possible?  Well, it is as possible as the force of gravity, which no matter how much influence it exerts upon mass never suffers any diminution of its potential force.  To my way of thinking, the Paradiso opens our minds to that potential, and the two subjects that spring to the fore, besides Dante's own theological thinking, are ecology and astrophysics, wherein a systems-thinking approach to life in the cosmos is the only way to proceed, and objects are seen as temporary expressions of relationships in constant flow.  There is certainly an approach here, which all scientists and theologians unconsciously accept, but few artists or poets do, namely, that our greatness comes from the greatness of our calling, our advocation, not the other way around.  The invocation to this first canto of the Paradiso is quite direct in making this claim.  Dante's greatness as a poet comes from his faith in poetry to express the most profound aspects of existence.  To Dante (and to me as well), poetry is as good a vehicle for these inquiries as is science or theology, and perhaps, in terms of its accessibility to the non-expert, and its potential for relating the biggest issues at cosmological scales to the most intimate and personal ones, the best way for most of us to relate our individual existences to the existence of the ALL.  Plus, poetry has one added dimension that is not an attribute of ecology or astrophysics.  It is the expression of love.

One could argue that in the Paradiso, poetry has become a sort of Augustinian branch of theology for the minions, a sort of sugar-coated homily to help the unschooled mind swallow the subtilties of scholasticism — that the purpose of poetry and of the figurative and poetic aspects of scripture is to prepare the mind to receive the more elevated theology of revelation.  I think Dante would assert that this is bass ackwards.  We read Augustine to better understand Dante, we don't read Dante to better understand Augustine.  Poetry is not an allegorical shadow pointing to revelation, it is revelation.  Why? because it alone elevates language and makes it an analog expression of the most subtle curves and ellipticals of experience.  It does not bully language into a theological argument or a scientific abstract.  It allows language the freedom to flow, which is what all aspects of the universe and of consciousness are constantly doing.  For poetry, contradictions and paradoxes, yeses and no's, assertions and denials, are no barriers to expression or experience, or as Whitman expresses it: "Do I contradict myself.  Very well then I contradict myself, I am large I contain multitudes."  Poetry is an open system which contains multitudes without constraining them.  It is form forming at the borders of formlessness and formlessness dissolving the too rigid boundaries of imprisoning forms.  Augustine held that everything worthwhile in language was to be found in the scriptures, and that the entire purpose of any kind of writing or exposition was to enable us to better understand scripture.  He would have found Dante's invocation to Apollo here to be at best, allegory, and at worst, heresy.  And herein lies the difference between Augustine and Dante, for Dante can use his linguistic figures in the same way as do scriptures, as allegory, yes, but also as an analog and guide to the soul both in the putrid swarthy regions of Hell, and in the light-saturated regions of Paradise.  Poetry embraces the worst and the best, the false and the true, and in the essence of its existence, it infuses an aesthetic beauty into all that it expresses, so that like penetrating light itself, it enlivens and illuminates all that it touches.   By comparison,  science and theology can only allude to such phenomena.  Poetry can be both about revelation, and be revelation.  In Paradise, language and light are the penetrating tropes used to reveal the universal mind.  Dante says here that what he is experiencing cannot be contained by memory, and yet something still blazes forth from these verses, and the great paradox is that the language of any poem cannot contain that total essence of poetry, but only expresses that essence in greater or lesser degrees.  Can we not hear that Dante is simultaneously showing poetry's  expressive power and its ineffibility in the same breath?   Can we not see how he is making of light and language a unity, which the author of The Cloud of Unknowing tells us both serves as a buffer that keeps us from being immolated and reduced to a mere vapor in the universal flux, and as a linking conduit, which umbelicals us to it?  This duel nature of the fundaments of diversity and multiplicity, of individual identity obliterated in God's singular bliss but without losing its own sense of self as it is conflated with the cosmic Self, has here an oscillating directionality: up/down, reflect/emit, greater/lesser, odd/even, opaque/transparent, dense/ephemeral, expressible/ineffable.  At the beginning of the canto in line 6 there is a descent and at the end in line 142 there is an ascent.  The heaviest elements of earth rise like fire, and miracles are made mundane.  The same time exists as day and night.  There is the odd and even, the curved and angular of 4 circles and 3 crosses (these being celestial calendrical markings of Time relating to the seasons of Earth).   There are two Parnassian mountains.  There are two suns.  There is a sun that emits rays.  There is a moon that reflects them.  Beatrice's eyes reflect but also pierce, like the eyes of an eagle, human, inhuman, transhuman, Christlike, but not Christ.  She scolds, but smiles.  There is light that illuminates, yet blinds.  There is fire that rises as naturally as water falls, or falls as lightning just as naturally, against its own inclination to rise, and there is the soul of poetry in the midst of all these paradoxes, shuffling about universals with peculiar metaphors embedded in particular sounds.  

1  The glory of Him who moveth everything
2  Doth penetrate the universe, and shine
3  In one part more and in another less.

1  La gloria di colui che tutto move
2  per l'universo penetra, e risplende
3  in una parte più e meno altrove. 

4  Within that heaven which most his light receives
5  Was I, and things beheld which to repeat
6  Nor knows, nor can, who from above descends;

4  Nel ciel che più de la sua luce prende
5  fu' io, e vidi cose che ridire
6  né sa né può chi di là sù discende; 

7  Because in drawing near to its desire
8  Our intellect ingulphs itself so far,
9  That after it the memory cannot go.

7  perché appressando sé al suo disire,
8  nostro intelletto si profonda tanto,
9  che dietro la memoria non può ire. 

10  Truly whatever of the holy realm
11  I had the power to treasure in my mind
12  Shall now become the subject of my song.

10  Veramente quant' io del regno santo
11  ne la mia mente potei far tesoro,
12 13 sarà ora materia del mio canto.

13  O good Apollo, for this last emprise
14  Make of me such a vessel of thy power
15  As giving the beloved laurel asks!

13  O buono Appollo, a l'ultimo lavoro
14  fammi del tuo valor sì fatto vaso,
15  come dimandi a dar l'amato alloro.

16  One summit of Parnassus hitherto
17  Has been enough for me, but now with both
18  I needs must enter the arena left.

16  Infino a qui l'un giogo di Parnaso
17  assai mi fu; ma or con amendue
18  m'è uopo intrar ne l'aringo rimaso.

19  Enter into my bosom, thou, and breathe
20  As at the time when Marsyas thou didst draw
21  Out of the scabbard of those limbs of his.

19  Entra nel petto mio, e spira tue
20  sì come quando Marsïa traesti
21  de la vagina de le membra sue.

22  O power divine, lend'st thou thyself to me
23  So that the shadow of the blessed realm
24  Stamped in my brain I can make manifest,

22  O divina virtù, se mi ti presti
23  tanto che l'ombra del beato regno
24  segnata nel mio capo io manifesti,

25  Thou'lt see me come unto thy darling tree,
26  And crown myself thereafter with those leaves
27  Of which the theme and thou shall make me worthy.

25  vedra'mi al piè del tuo diletto legno
26  venire, e coronarmi de le foglie
27  che la materia e tu mi farai degno.

28  So seldom, Father, do we gather them
29  For triumph or of Caesar or of Poet,
30  (The fault and shame of human inclinations,)

28  Sì rade volte, padre, se ne coglie
29  per trïunfare o cesare o poeta,
30  colpa e vergogna de l'umane voglie,

31  That the Peneian foliage should bring forth
32  Joy to the joyous Delphic deity,
33  When any one it makes to thirst for it.

31  che parturir letizia in su la lieta
32  delfica deïtà dovria la fronda
33  peneia, quando alcun di sé asseta.

34  A little spark is followed by great flame;
35  Perchance with better voices after me
36  Shall prayer be made that Cyrrha may respond!

34  Poca favilla gran fiamma seconda:
35 forse di retro a me con miglior voci
36  si pregherà perché Cirra risponda.

37  To mortal men by passages diverse
38  Uprises the world's lamp; but by that one
39  Which circles four uniteth with three crosses,

37  Surge ai mortali per diverse foci
38  la lucerna del mondo; ma da quella
39  che quattro cerchi giugne con tre croci,

40  With better course and with a better star
41  Conjoined it issues, and the mundane wax
42  Tempers and stamps more after its own fashion.

40  con miglior corso e con migliore stella
41  esce congiunta, e la mondana cera
42  più a suo modo tempera e suggella.

43  Almost that passage had made morning there
44  And evening here, and there was wholly white
45  That hemisphere, and black the other part,

43  Fatto avea di là mane e di qua sera
44  tal foce, e quasi tutto era là bianco
45  quello emisperio, e l'altra parte nera,

46  When Beatrice towards the left-hand side
47  I saw turned round, and gazing at the sun;
48  Never did eagle fasten so upon it!

46  quando Beatrice in sul sinistro fianco
47  vidi rivolta e riguardar nel sole:
48  aguglia sì non li s'affisse unquanco.

49  And even as a second ray is wont
50  To issue from the first and reascend,
51  Like to a pilgrim who would fain return,

49  E sì come secondo raggio suole
50  uscir del primo e risalire in suso,
51  pur come pelegrin che tornar vuole,

52  Thus of her action, through the eyes infused
53  In my imagination, mine I made,
54  And sunward fixed mine eyes beyond our wont.

52  così de l'atto suo, per li occhi infuso
53  ne l'imagine mia, il mio si fece,
54  e fissi li occhi al sole oltre nostr' uso.

55  There much is lawful which is here unlawful
56  Unto our powers, by virtue of the place
57  Made for the human species as its own.

55  Molto è licito là, che qui non lece
56  a le nostre virtù, mercé del loco
57  fatto per proprio de l'umana spece.

58  Not long I bore it, nor so little while
59  But I beheld it sparkle round about
60  Like iron that comes molten from the fire;

58  Io nol soffersi molto, né sì poco,
59  ch'io nol vedessi sfavillar dintorno,
60  com' ferro che bogliente esce del foco;

61  And suddenly it seemed that day to day
62  Was added, as if He who has the power
63  Had with another sun the heaven adorned.

61  e di sùbito parve giorno a giorno
62  essere aggiunto, come quei che puote
63  avesse il ciel d'un altro sole addorno.

64  With eyes upon the everlasting wheels
65  Stood Beatrice all intent, and I, on her
66  Fixing my vision from above removed,

64  Beatrice tutta ne l'etterne rote
65  fissa con li occhi stava; e io in lei
66  le luci fissi, di là sù rimote.

67  Such at her aspect inwardly became
68  As Glaucus, tasting of the herb that made him
69  Peer of the other gods beneath the sea.

67  Nel suo aspetto tal dentro mi fei,
68  qual si fé Glauco nel gustar de l'erba
69  che 'l fé consorto in mar de li altri dèi.

70  To represent transhumanise in words
71  Impossible were; the example, then, suffice
72  Him for whom Grace the experience reserves.

70  Trasumanar significar per verba
71  non si poria; però l'essemplo basti
72  a cui esperïenza grazia serba.

73  If I was merely what of me thou newly
74  Createdst, Love who governest the heaven,
75  Thou knowest, who didst lift me with thy light!

73  S'i' era sol di me quel che creasti
74  novellamente, amor che 'l ciel governi,
75  tu 'l sai, che col tuo lume mi levasti.

76  When now the wheel, which thou dost make eternal
77  Desiring thee, made me attentive to it
78  By harmony thou dost modulate and measure,

76  Quando la rota che tu sempiterni
77  desiderato, a sé mi fece atteso
78  con l'armonia che temperi e discerni,

79  Then seemed to me so much of heaven enkindled
80  By the sun's flame, that neither rain nor river
81  E'er made a lake so widely spread abroad.

79  parvemi tanto allor del cielo acceso
80  de la fiamma del sol, che pioggia o fiume
81  lago non fece alcun tanto disteso.

82 The newness of the sound and the great light
83  Kindled in me a longing for their cause,
84  Never before with such acuteness felt;

82  La novità del suono e 'l grande lume
83  di lor cagion m'accesero un disio
84  mai non sentito di cotanto acume.

85  Whence she, who saw me as I saw myself,
86  To quiet in me my perturbed mind,
87  Opened her mouth, ere I did mine to ask,

85  Ond' ella, che vedea me sì com' io,
86  a quïetarmi l'animo commosso,
87  pria ch'io a dimandar, la bocca aprio

88  And she began: "Thou makest thyself so dull
89  With false imagining, that thou seest not
90  What thou wouldst see if thou hadst shaken it off.

88  e cominciò: “Tu stesso ti fai grosso
89  col falso imaginar, sì che non vedi
90  ciò che vedresti se l'avessi scosso.

91  Thou art not upon earth, as thou believest;
92  But lightning, fleeing its appropriate site,
93  Ne'er ran as thou, who thitherward returnest."

91  Tu non se' in terra, sì come tu credi;
92  ma folgore, fuggendo il proprio sito,
93  non corse come tu ch'ad esso riedi.”

94  If of my former doubt I was divested
95  By these brief little words more smiled than spoken,
96  I in a new one was the more ensnared;

94  S'io fui del primo dubbio disvestito
95  per le sorrise parolette brevi,
96  dentro ad un nuovo più fu' inretito

97  And said: "Already did I rest content
98  From great amazement; but am now amazed
99  In what way I transcend these bodies light."

97  e dissi: “Già contento requïevi
98  di grande ammirazion; ma ora ammiro
99  com' io trascenda questi corpi levi.”

100  Whereupon she, after a pitying sigh,
101  Her eyes directed tow'rds me with that look
102  A mother casts on a delirious child;

100  Ond' ella, appresso d'un pïo sospiro,
101  li occhi drizzò ver' me con quel sembiante
102  che madre fa sovra figlio deliro,

103  And she began: "All things whate'er they be
104  Have order among themselves, and this is form,
105  That makes the universe resemble God.

103  e cominciò: “Le cose tutte quante
104  hanno ordine tra loro, e questo è forma
105  che l'universo a Dio fa simigliante.

106  Here do the higher creatures see the footprints
107  Of the Eternal Power, which is the end
108  Whereto is made the law already mentioned.

106  Qui veggion l'alte creature l'orma
107  de l'etterno valore, il qual è fine
108  al quale è fatta la toccata norma.

109  In the order that I speak of are inclined
110  All natures, by their destinies diverse,
111  More or less near unto their origin;

109  Ne l'ordine ch'io dico sono accline
110  tutte nature, per diverse sorti,
111  più al principio loro e men vicine;

112  Hence they move onward unto ports diverse
113  O'er the great sea of being; and each one
114  With instinct given it which bears it on.

112  onde si muovono a diversi porti
113  per lo gran mar de l'essere, e ciascuna
114  con istinto a lei dato che la porti.

115  This bears away the fire towards the moon;
116  This is in mortal hearts the motive power
117  This binds together and unites the earth.

115  Questi ne porta il foco inver' la luna;
116  questi ne' cor mortali è permotore;
117  questi la terra in sé stringe e aduna;

118  Nor only the created things that are
119  Without intelligence this bow shoots forth,
120  But those that have both intellect and love.

118  né pur le creature che son fore
119  d'intelligenza quest' arco saetta,
120  ma quelle c'hanno intelletto e amore.

121  The Providence that regulates all this
122  Makes with its light the heaven forever quiet,
123  Wherein that turns which has the greatest haste.

121  La provedenza, che cotanto assetta,
122 del suo lume fa 'l ciel sempre quïeto
123 nel qual si volge quel c'ha maggior fretta;

124  And thither now, as to a site decreed,
125  Bears us away the virtue of that cord
126  Which aims its arrows at a joyous mark.

124  e ora lì, come a sito decreto,
125 c en porta la virtù di quella corda
126  che ciò che scocca drizza in segno lieto.

127  True is it, that as oftentimes the form
128  Accords not with the intention of the art,
129  Because in answering is matter deaf,

127  Vero è che, come forma non s'accorda
128  molte fïate a l'intenzion de l'arte,
129  perch' a risponder la materia è sorda,

130  So likewise from this course doth deviate
131  Sometimes the creature, who the power possesses,
132  Though thus impelled, to swerve some other way,

130  così da questo corso si diparte
131  talor la creatura, c'ha podere
132  di piegar, così pinta, in altra parte;

133  (In the same wise as one may see the fire
134  Fall from a cloud,) if the first impetus
135  Earthward is wrested by some false delight.

133  e sì come veder si può cadere
134  foco di nube, sì l'impeto primo
135  l'atterra torto da falso piacere.

136  Thou shouldst not wonder more, if well I judge,
137  At thine ascent, than at a rivulet
138  From some high mount descending to the lowland.

136  Non dei più ammirar, se bene stimo,
137  lo tuo salir, se non come d'un rivo
138  se d'alto monte scende giuso ad imo.
