139  Marvel it would be in thee, if deprived
140  Of hindrance, thou wert seated down below,
141  As if on earth the living fire were quiet."

139  Maraviglia sarebbe in te se, privo
140  d'impedimento, giù ti fossi assiso,
141  com' a terra quïete in foco vivo.”

142  Thereat she heavenward turned again her face.

142  Quinci rivolse inver' lo cielo il viso.

Canto II
Let's call the poetworld, the universe-as Isness.  Isness is all-inclusive.  Like an ocean, it is the mother of all earthly things, like the sky, it's domain is limitless.  Its creatures are legion and protean.  The sound-image world of water-sky denotes one interchanging and interchangeable thing.  In these interchanges, the speakerlisteners, from one point of view, are constantly interchanging positions, there is movement, oscillation.  But from a sort of Barycenter between these positions, there is stillness.  This Barycenter has been depicted in various mythic traditions from times immemorial as a well, or a whirlpool in its concavity and as a central pillar in its convexity, uterus and umbilical.  Fosse and mountain.  Inside every present-tense movement of sound, this Barycenter is the eternal presence of silence.  How does Dante express this?  By gathering together various positions points in the movements of sound with abiding metaphors. These metaphor are elemental — in some traditions, fire, water, earth, air, and a sheath or membrane that contains them.  Think: the cell of an organic creature — the substance stuff inseparable from its functions — the metaphoric/meaning-making elements of a poem.  One of these metaphors is the sea, another is the sky, another a desert, another a wood, another a mountain, another a pit or cave.  Here the poem speaks of the sea, and the in-between state of two positions, large ship of poetry, a small bark of listeners/readers.  Canto One, Inferno: metaphor of a swimmer who nearly drowned, from shore, looks back on the sea which almost swallowed him.  Canto One, Purgatorio, saved sinners transported by the angel/craft to the isle mountain of purgation.  Here, a sea passage, a warning and an invitation.  Inside all of these dualities is that still pivot-point of transcendence, in which one thing becomes another, the drowning victim, the saved, the invocation to sky-father Apollo, at whose rapist/lover's touch, Daphne became the laurel.  The crown that completes the initiation of ephebe to poet.  This image from the previous canto interacts, with the breath of the weaver, Minerva, the star guidance of the Bears, Ursa Major, Ursa minor.  Remember there are seven starts in Ursa Major, seven planets in the Commedia's heaven, seven chakras climbing up the spine, seven colors in the spectrum of visible light.  Remember the festivals of Athens, the Bear Festivals, the virgin girls, called bears, their first menses, their secret rites, like the huntress goddesses, virgin, untamed, moon-mad, awakening from childhood's hibernation, pursued by gods, transformed to trees, to stars.  Bears.  Names mean something, epithets are condensed genealogies, allegories of experiences, stories told and retold, through the seasons, in firelight, at feasts, to chase away plague, hunger, and the night.  The bogey's, the Bears.   Dante will meet with St. Bernard of Clairvaux later, that name meaning "Bold Bear."  Could it be that this figure was chosen because of his name? because that name links it with the constellations which never dip below the horizon, and which contain the pole star?   Never dipping below the horizon means never returning to the chaos of the sea, and yet, as the dippers, these constellations could be thought of the sea's celestial source.  Begin to wonder: Why myth?  Why not scripture?  Myth is eternal, scripture historical, where they cross is the time of incarnation, mortal/immortal, the Barycenter of Time.  The exoteric and the esoteric.  Hair and horns.  The casual reader is exoteric, gets lost in the complexity of all the mytho-scriptural allusions.  The esoteric reader follows allusions to infinity.  These latter few batten on Angel's bread, ever nourished, never sated.  Each myth in its burgeoning families of associations leads to infinite reflection, infinite musings.  The muses are ever-present, ever-elaborating, ever-singing, ever-weaving.  Sailing is song, a sea passage across the infinite.  Breath fills the sails, conducts the ship of the poem.  At the poem's conclusion, the sails are furled, but the breath's breezes go on.  In the poetic Isness world — and in the world — one thing becomes another — one thing is another.  Apollo is Phoebus, Minerva is Pallas Minerva, Pallas Athena.  Remember the stories.  The human/divine contests: Apollo, Maryses, Minerva/Arachne.  Remember the difference between human skill and divine revelation, and the punishments for confusing one with the other.  Remember the spider woman myths of Native Americans.  She brought fire back to a world of darkness.  The small and the subtle triumphs over the large and the gross, the universe is spun of gossamer.  Remember how the works of creature and Creator are conflated, creation from Creation, the minute complexities of evolution unfolding from an originating singularity.  Remember the fate of the prideful adventurers, Ulysses and Jason.  Remember the brevity of the wake of a ship's prow ploughing ocean water or the sounds of words passing in a poem.  Remember Jason's plough in Colchos, sewing dragon's teeth for soldiers.  Remember the constellation Drago, the dragon myths, the serpent strands of DNA, the serpent myths, the Emerald Tablet's pronouncement, "As above, so below," the same laws governing atoms and galaxies.  Dante is in exile, a middle aged wanderer, homeless, a guest on Earth, writing the poem of his younger self, losing his mundane misery in myriad mirrors of mythic speculation, singing, weaving, challenging the gods, master made master at the feet of the bear girl, Beatrice.  Remember how the divine child, Cupid, masters mighty Apollo, how love is innocence, its wanton caprices conquering all the gods, cowing them with desire, conjuring them with jealousies, all saved and victimized by the con-created and perpetual thirst of the dei-formed realms, whose effects are so swift, that we perceive them before their causes, the arrow striking before its flight, its flight re-perceived before its release from the notch of the bow, Time in reverse, a symbol of simultaneity in the sequences of words, the light reflected from the belovèd's eyes.  Those twin stars freeze the velocities of our multiplicitous musings, she tells us:  "Fix gratefully your mind on God."  We are no longer exiled orphans on fallen Earth,  we are diffused, yet whole, in the luminous cloud of the moon.  We are ready.  We have and are the divine curiosity-child. whose innocence has sprung from the seasoned adult.  

In the previous canto, Beatrice has told Dante, you are no longer on Earth, and throughout the poem, in Hell, on Purgatory's mountain, Time has been curiously both a celestial and terrestrial wonder.  Here we are in heaven, but what is heaven? and what was Earth?  This passage from Hamlet's Mill (de Santillana & von Dechend) reveals:

Meanwhile  it is necessary to explain again what this "earth' is that modern interpreters like to take for a pancake.  The mythical earth is, in fact, a plane, but this earth is not our earth.  "Earth" is the implied plane through the four points of the year, marked by the equinoxes and solstices, in other words the ecliptic.  And this is why this earth is very frequently said to be quadrangular.  The four "corners," that is, the zodiacal constellations rising heliacally at both equinoxes and solstices, parts of the "frame" { }, are the points which determine an "earth."  Every world-age has its own "earth."  It is for this very reason that "ends of the world" are said to take place.  A new "earth" arises, when another set of zodiacal constellations brought in by precession determines the year points.

Remember from the previous canto, that elaborate definition of the time: the circle of the equator, the zodiac, and the equinoctial colure?  Why is Dante able to say that he is traversing poetic territory that has never before been explored?  Remember the Time of the entire Commedia: Easter Week, the Jubilee Year of 1300.  Never before means times have changed, and heaven means Time has changed.  Dante is entering a new era, which means a new state of awareness, and he, or his poem, is the midwife to that birth.  Think of the question of self in the Inferno.  What is happening to me?  Who is to blame?  Think of the question of self in the Purgatorio.  What have I done?  And what must die in me?  Now, think of the question of Self in the Paradiso.  To feel such an urge, is to leave the earth of the old self, and arrive in the heaven of the Self.  Here, in heaven, wonder births those questions of Self which can only birth new wonders, only exist as wonder.  What is at stake as we enter this new state?  Read and reread these lines:

25  Arrived I saw me where a wondrous thing
26  Drew to itself my sight; and therefore she
27  From whom no care of mine could be concealed,

25  giunto mi vidi ove mirabil cosa
26  mi torse il viso a sé; e però quella
27  cui non potea mia cura essere ascosa,

28  Towards me turning, blithe as beautiful,
29  Said unto me: "Fix gratefully thy mind
30  On God, who unto the first star has brought us."

28  volta ver' me, sì lieta come bella,
29  “Drizza la mente in Dio grata,” mi disse,
30  “che n'ha congiunti con la prima stella.”

31  It seemed to me a cloud encompassed us,
32  Luminous, dense, consolidate and bright
33  As adamant on which the sun is striking.

31  Parev' a me che nube ne coprisse
32  lucida, spessa, solida e pulita,
33  quasi adamante che lo sol ferisse.

34  Into itself did the eternal pearl
35  Receive us, even as water doth receive
36  A ray of light, remaining still unbroken.

34  Per entro sé l'etterna margarita
35  ne ricevette, com' acqua recepe
36  raggio di luce permanendo unita.

37  If I was body, (and we here conceive not
38  How one dimension tolerates another,
39  Which needs must be if body enter body,)

37  S'io era corpo, e qui non si concepe
38  com' una dimensione altra patio,
39  ch'esser convien se corpo in corpo repe,

40  More the desire should be enkindled in us
41  That essence to behold, wherein is seen
42  How God and our own nature were united.

40  accender ne dovria più il disio
41  di veder quella essenza in che si vede
42  come nostra natura e Dio s'unio.

43  There will be seen what we receive by faith,
44  Not demonstrated, but self-evident
45  In guise of the first truth that man believes.

43  Lì si vedrà ciò che tenem per fede,
44  non dimostrato, ma fia per sé noto
45  a guisa del ver primo che l'uom crede.

And what is the first wondrous question in Paradise?  It is a question of spots on the moon, and of that transgression of brother murdering brother, a question that asks: What is the matter? What indeed is matter that we should perceive it in the opposites of shadow and light, good and evil — and how is this question posed by the mutable moon?  This is an essential question.  Do  we speculate (remember speculum is mirror, is reflection, of the moon or of Beatrice's upward glancing eyes) from our everyday perceptions? or from the insights gathered from our souls?  What is the light/dark nature of our ethical musings and our sensual perceptions?  What is the grammer of it — because for Dante the moon and the trivium's subject of grammer are associates, the mutable structure of one reflecting the variations of the other, an issue that differentiates the question mark from the period, the equivocation from the assertion.  Here, then, Dante's question is at first answered by another question.  Beatrice quizzes: What do you think is the answer?  Dante replies: Substance must interact with light according to its thinness or density, simplicity or complexity.  Beatrice's answer refutes this, and so does the very nature of their current position dissolved and yet coherent in the pearlescent cloud of the moon.  Substance is light, or as Einstein put it, matter is energy.  All painters know this: shadows and lights are both luminescent areas called "values," each of their iterations as rich as all the others.  Differences are accounted for by the different qualities of light, their velocities relative to one another, not their substantive differences.  

As readers, we must remember that Dante lived in a time operating as a sort of background radiation which colored the form and content of his expression.  This background radiation is often only obliquely presented, especially in regards to his life circumstances at the time he was writing the poem.  He tells us nothing about where he is living, his patrons and hosts, his family, his health, his economic or his legal situation.  We might be interested in these aspects of his life, and we might learn much from them, but for him, they are only the paper on which he writes, a background which hardly pertains to the content of his poem.  In this he much differs from poets in my particular Now, who seem to concern themselves solely with this background.  In my view, this makes much of my contemporaries' poetry soul-ignorant and narcissistic, in many ways much like Dante's Francesca in the second circle of Hell.  Yes, we too live our lives as readers and recipients of his art enveloped in the field of our own era, and immersed in the individual circumstances in that Aion from which only those peculiarities of those circumstances could have arisen.  But if we read only from this sense, the Commedia will be very distant from us, and it will not be able to work its transformational magic.  In this final canticle, we are entering into the realm of scholasticism, i.e., of a kind of reasoning which in our age seems as tedious as it is false.  The relics of this scholasticism is what commentators of the Commedia have been exploring for eight centuries.  But this poem is not only an historical relic, not only the musings of a 14th Century Christian on the theological doctrines which might lead to what he called "salvation."  This poem is, as the first lines of this canto illustrate, also mythological, i.e., atemporal.  Its tropes, images, metaphors, sound and number patterns pose timeless questions.  The Commedia is just as pertinent when viewed through the prism of ours or of any age.  If the soul is, what is it?  And if it is the atemporal organizing power which makes matter matter, and Time both temporary and eternal, how must an individual intellect be schooled to play its part in the delights of the Universal Intellect?  Certainly, if we read in this way, we will find that sense of wonder which so awesomely arises when the deeper musings of our intellects meet with the deeper musing of an intellect from a far different place and time.  That is the power, as Jung re-discovered, of the archetype, whose numinous protean constant live in and forms the depths of our psyches.  In this second song of Paradise, we are launched, like that great ship of the poem whose passage begins this musing music, on a voyage to explore, as it pertains to us, each in our individual Now, the particular poetic Isness of this dimension. We are tasked to prepare our intellects for wonders.  Or as Beatrice says:

109  Thee thus remaining in thy intellect,
110  Will I inform with such a living light,
111  That it shall tremble in its aspect to thee.

109  così rimaso te ne l'intelletto
110  voglio informar di luce sì vivace,
111  che ti tremolerà nel suo aspetto.

112  Within the heaven of the divine repose
113  Revolves a body, in whose virtue lies
114  The being of whatever it contains.

112  Dentro dal ciel de la divina pace
113  si gira un corpo ne la cui virtute
112  l'esser di tutto suo contento giace.


		*****

1  O Ye, who in some pretty little boat,
2  Eager to listen, have been following
3  Behind my ship, that singing sails along,

1  O voi che siete in piccioletta barca,
2  desiderosi d'ascoltar, seguiti
3  dietro al mio legno che cantando varca,

4  Turn back to look again upon your shores;
5  Do not put out to sea, lest peradventure,
6  In losing me, you might yourselves be lost.

4  tornate a riveder li vostri liti:
5  non vi mettete in pelago, ché forse,
6  perdendo me, rimarreste smarriti.

7  The sea I sail has never yet been passed;
8  Minerva breathes, and pilots me Apollo,
9  And Muses nine point out to me the Bears.

7  L'acqua ch'io prendo già mai non si corse;
8  Minerva spira, e conducemi Appollo,
9  e nove Muse mi dimostran l'Orse.

10  Ye other few who have the neck uplifted
11  Betimes to th' bread of Angels upon which
12  One liveth here and grows not sated by it,

10  Voialtri pochi che drizzaste il collo
11  per tempo al pan de li angeli, del quale
12  vivesi qui ma non sen vien satollo,

13  Well may you launch upon the deep salt-sea
14   Your vessel, keeping still my wake before you
15  Upon the water that grows smooth again.

13  metter potete ben per l'alto sale
14  vostro navigio, servando mio solco
15  dinanzi a l'acqua che ritorna equale.

16  Those glorious ones who unto Colchos passed
17  Were not so wonder-struck as you shall be,
18  When Jason they beheld a ploughman made!

16  Que' glorïosi che passaro al Colco
17  non s'ammiraron come voi farete,
18  quando Iasón vider fatto bifolco.

19  The con-created and perpetual thirst
20  For the realm deiform did bear us on,
21  As swift almost as ye the heavens behold.

19  La concreata e perpetüa sete
20  del deïforme regno cen portava
21  veloci quasi come 'l ciel vedete.

22  Upward gazed Beatrice, and I at her;
23  And in such space perchance as strikes a bolt
24  And flies, and from the notch unlocks itself,

22  Beatrice in suso, e io in lei guardava;
23  e forse in tanto in quanto un quadrel posa
24  e vola e da la noce si dischiava,

25  Arrived I saw me where a wondrous thing
26  Drew to itself my sight; and therefore she
27  From whom no care of mine could be concealed,

25  giunto mi vidi ove mirabil cosa
26  mi torse il viso a sé; e però quella
27  cui non potea mia cura essere ascosa,

28  Towards me turning, blithe as beautiful,
29  Said unto me: "Fix gratefully thy mind
30  On God, who unto the first star has brought us."

28  volta ver' me, sì lieta come bella,
29  “Drizza la mente in Dio grata,” mi disse,
30  “che n'ha congiunti con la prima stella.”

31  It seemed to me a cloud encompassed us,
32  Luminous, dense, consolidate and bright
33  As adamant on which the sun is striking.

31  Parev' a me che nube ne coprisse
32  lucida, spessa, solida e pulita,
33  quasi adamante che lo sol ferisse.

34  Into itself did the eternal pearl
35  Receive us, even as water doth receive
36  A ray of light, remaining still unbroken.

34  Per entro sé l'etterna margarita
35  ne ricevette, com' acqua recepe
36  raggio di luce permanendo unita.

37  If I was body, (and we here conceive not
38  How one dimension tolerates another,
39  Which needs must be if body enter body,)

37  S'io era corpo, e qui non si concepe
38  com' una dimensione altra patio,
39  ch'esser convien se corpo in corpo repe,

40  More the desire should be enkindled in us
41  That essence to behold, wherein is seen
42  How God and our own nature were united.

40  accender ne dovria più il disio
41  di veder quella essenza in che si vede
42  come nostra natura e Dio s'unio.

43  There will be seen what we receive by faith,
44  Not demonstrated, but self-evident
45  In guise of the first truth that man believes.

43  Lì si vedrà ciò che tenem per fede,
44  non dimostrato, ma fia per sé noto
45  a guisa del ver primo che l'uom crede.

46  I made reply: "Madonna, as devoutly
47  As most I can do I give thanks to Him
48  Who has removed me from the mortal world.

46  Io rispuosi: “Madonna, sì devoto
47  com' esser posso più, ringrazio lui
48  lo qual dal mortal mondo m'ha remoto.

49  But tell me what the dusky spots may be
50  Upon this body, which below on earth
51  Make people tell that fabulous tale of Cain?"

49  Ma ditemi: che son li segni bui
50  di questo corpo, che là giuso in terra
51  fan di Cain favoleggiare altrui?”

52  Somewhat she smiled; and then, "If the opinion
53  Of mortals be erroneous," she said,
54  "Where'er the key of sense doth not unlock,

52  Ella sorrise alquanto, e poi “S'elli erra
53  l'oppinïon,” mi disse, “d'i mortali
54  dove chiave di senso non diserra,

55  Certes, the shafts of wonder should not pierce thee
56  Now, forasmuch as, following the senses,
57  Thou seest that the reason has short wings.

55  certo non ti dovrien punger li strali
56  d'ammirazione omai, poi dietro ai sensi
57  vedi che la ragione ha corte l'ali.

58  But tell me what thou think'st of it thyself."
59  And I: "What seems to us up here diverse,
60  Is caused, I think, by bodies rare and dense."

58  Ma dimmi quel che tu da te ne pensi.”
59  E io: “Ciò che n'appar qua sù diverso
60  credo che fanno i corpi rari e densi.”

61  And she: "Right truly shalt thou see immersed
62  In error thy belief, if well thou hearest
63  The argument that I shall make against it.

61  Ed ella: “Certo assai vedrai sommerso
62  nel falso il creder tuo, se bene ascolti
63  l'argomentar ch'io li farò avverso.

64  Lights many the eighth sphere displays to you
65  Which in their quality and quantity
66  May noted be of aspects different.

64  La spera ottava vi dimostra molti
65  lumi, li quali e nel quale e nel quanto
66  notar si posson di diversi volti.

67  If this were caused by rare and dense alone,
68  One only virtue would there be in all
69  Or more or less diffused, or equally.

67  Se raro e denso ciò facesser tanto,
68  una sola virtù sarebbe in tutti,
69  più e men distributa e altrettanto.

70  Virtues diverse must be perforce the fruits
71  Of formal principles; and these, save one,
72  Of course would by thy reasoning be destroyed.

70  Virtù diverse esser convegnon frutti
71  di princìpi formali, e quei, for ch'uno,
72  seguiterieno a tua ragion distrutti.

73  Besides, if rarity were of this dimness
74  The cause thou askest, either through and through
75  This planet thus attenuate were of matter,

73  Ancor, se raro fosse di quel bruno
74  cagion che tu dimandi, o d'oltre in parte
75  fora di sua materia sì digiuno

76  Or else, as in a body is apportioned
77  The fat and lean, so in like manner this
78  Would in its volume interchange the leaves.

76  esto pianeto, o, sì come comparte
77  lo grasso e 'l magro un corpo, così questo
78  nel suo volume cangerebbe carte.

79  Were it the former, in the sun's eclipse
80  It would be manifest by the shining through
81  Of light, as through aught tenuous interfused.

79  Se 'l primo fosse, fora manifesto
80  ne l'eclissi del sol, per trasparere
81  lo lume come in altro raro ingesto.

82  This is not so; hence we must scan the other,
83  And if it chance the other I demolish,
84  Then falsified will thy opinion be.

82  Questo non è: però è da vedere
83  de l'altro; e s'elli avvien ch'io l'altro cassi,
84  falsificato fia lo tuo parere.

85  But if this rarity go not through and through,
86  There needs must be a limit, beyond which
87  Its contrary prevents the further passing,

85  S'elli è che questo raro non trapassi,
86  esser conviene un termine da onde
87  lo suo contrario più passar non lassi;

88  And thence the foreign radiance is reflected,
89  Even as a colour cometh back from glass,
90  The which behind itself concealeth lead.

88  e indi l'altrui raggio si rifonde
89  così come color torna per vetro
90  lo qual di retro a sé piombo nasconde.

91  Now thou wilt say the sunbeam shows itself
92  More dimly there than in the other parts,
93  By being there reflected farther back.

91  Or dirai tu ch'el si dimostra tetro
92  ivi lo raggio più che in altre parti,
93  per esser lì refratto più a retro.

94  From this reply experiment will free thee
95  If e'er thou try it, which is wont to be
96  The fountain to the rivers of your arts.

94  Da questa instanza può deliberarti
95  esperïenza, se già mai la provi,
96  ch'esser suol fonte ai rivi di vostr' arti.

97  Three mirrors shalt thou take, and two remove
98  Alike from thee, the other more remote
99  Between the former two shall meet thine eyes.

97  Tre specchi prenderai; e i due rimovi
98  da te d'un modo, e l'altro, più rimosso,
99  tr'ambo li primi li occhi tuoi ritrovi.

100  Turned towards these, cause that behind thy back
101  Be placed a light, illuming the three mirrors
102  And coming back to thee by all reflected.

100  Rivolto ad essi, fa che dopo il dosso
101  ti stea un lume che i tre specchi accenda
102  e torni a te da tutti ripercosso.

103  Though in its quantity be not so ample
104  The image most remote, there shalt thou see
105  How it perforce is equally resplendent.

103  Ben che nel quanto tanto non si stenda
104  la vista più lontana, lì vedrai
105  come convien ch'igualmente risplenda.

106  Now, as beneath the touches of warm rays
107  Naked the subject of the snow remains
108  Both of its former colour and its cold,

106  Or, come ai colpi de li caldi rai
107   de la neve riman nudo il suggetto
108  e dal colore e dal freddo primai,

109  Thee thus remaining in thy intellect,
110  Will I inform with such a living light,
111  That it shall tremble in its aspect to thee.

109  così rimaso te ne l'intelletto
110  voglio informar di luce sì vivace,
111  che ti tremolerà nel suo aspetto.

112  Within the heaven of the divine repose
113  Revolves a body, in whose virtue lies
114  The being of whatever it contains.

112  Dentro dal ciel de la divina pace
113  si gira un corpo ne la cui virtute
112  l'esser di tutto suo contento giace.

115  The following heaven, that has so many eyes,
116  Divides this being by essences diverse,
117  Distinguished from it, and by it contained.

115  Lo ciel seguente, c'ha tante vedute,
116  quell' esser parte per diverse essenze,
117  da lui distratte e da lui contenute.

118  The other spheres, by various differences,
119  All the distinctions which they have within them
120  Dispose unto their ends and their effects.

118  Li altri giron per varie differenze
119  le distinzion che dentro da sé hanno
120  dispongono a lor fini e lor semenze.

121  Thus do these organs of the world proceed,
122  As thou perceivest now, from grade to grade;
123  Since from above they take, and act beneath.

121  Questi organi del mondo così vanno,
122  come tu vedi omai, di grado in grado,
123  che di sù prendono e di sotto fanno.

124  Observe me well, how through this place I come
125  Unto the truth thou wishest, that hereafter
126  Thou mayst alone know how to keep the ford

124  Riguarda bene omai sì com' io vado
125  per questo loco al vero che disiri,
126 sì che poi sappi sol tener lo guado.

127  The power and motion of the holy spheres,
128  As from the artisan the hammer's craft,
129  Forth from the blessed motors must proceed.

127  Lo moto e la virtù d'i santi giri,
128  come dal fabbro l'arte del martello,
129  da' beati motor convien che spiri;

130  The heaven, which lights so manifold make fair,
131  From the Intelligence profound, which turns it,
132  The image takes, and makes of it a seal.

130  e 'l ciel cui tanti lumi fanno bello,
131  de la mente profonda che lui volve
132  prende l'image e fassene suggello.

133  And even as the soul within your dust
134  Through members different and accommodated
135  To faculties diverse expands itself,

130  e 'l ciel cui tanti lumi fanno bello,
131  de la mente profonda che lui volve
132  prende l'image e fassene suggello.

136  So likewise this Intelligence diffuses
137  Its virtue multiplied among the stars.
138  Itself revolving on its unity.

130  e 'l ciel cui tanti lumi fanno bello,
131  de la mente profonda che lui volve
132  prende l'image e fassene suggello.

139  Virtue diverse doth a diverse alloyage
140  Make with the precious body that it quickens,
141  In which, as life in you, it is combined.

139  Virtù diversa fa diversa lega
140  col prezïoso corpo ch'ella avviva,
141  nel qual, sì come vita in voi, si lega.

142  From the glad nature whence it is derived,
143  The mingled virtue through the body shines,
144  Even as gladness through the living pupil.

142  Per la natura lieta onde deriva,
143  la virtù mista per lo corpo luce
144  come letizia per pupilla viva.

145  From this proceeds whate'er from light to light
146  Appeareth different, not from dense and rare:
147  This is the formal principle that produces,

145  Da essa vien ciò che da luce a luce
146  par differente, non da denso e raro;
147  essa è formal principio che produce,

148  According to its goodness, dark and bright."

148  conforme a sua bontà, lo turbo e 'l chiaro.”

Canto III
All of us are constantly bombarded with inner thoughts and outer perceptions.  We feel sensations, smell smells, taste tastes, hear sounds and see sights from both sides of the skin and skull and we record these myriad magnitudes, minitudes, and multitudes in the most complicated organic structure that we know of: our brains.  With the exceptions of some pheromone types of smells, everything that arises from this enormously complex and ever-active field is mediated by a network of cephalic nerves and neurotransmitters, which have been conditioned by the field itself to interpret and sort for relevance.  So, amidst this bombardment, how can we discern what is true, or what seems most relevant for us?  The first three lines of this canto reveal to us Dante's criteria for sorting wheat from chaff.  He says it is a feeling in his breast.  What kind of feeling?  A feeling of warmth, and specifically that warmth which his first vision of Beatrice at the age of nine enkindled in the region of his heart pump — perhaps a quickening that he interpreted as being warmed, as if by the sun.  This feeling, besides being warm, also seems beauteous to the inner vision (di bella) and sweet to the imagination's taste (dolce), and as he describes this feeling — his head bowed to check on what seems to be radiating from inside his chest — he discovers that the feeling is self-evident, a thing that uncovers (scoverto) its own qualities, proving and reproving its own authenticity.  From this feeling-state, then, Dante obtains the confidence to act by raising his head to speak.  Here we have the clear source of his certitude concerning those necessary credentials that enables a writer or speaker to become a poet.  He has said this before in previous cantos, but with each iteration, his poetry makes this clearer, and from the midst of this growing clarity, what does he see?  A vision, not through Saint Paul's "glass darkly," but as though through polished, transparent glass or crystalline, still water.  If we had not realized it before, the reader now knows Dante's neurological strategy 1 for creating poetry: Feel, see, hear, speak.  That is what is happening inside him, and it is happening in that order.  Knowing this, perhaps as readers, we should reverse engineer that neurological process.  Recite, listen, envision, and feel that realness, which seems to be the formula for enriching ourselves through these verses, as readers, just as Dante enriched himself through them as their writer.  These beginning verses of the canto describe "how" Dante is perceiving, or rather, creating, this experience.  This Howness is what he is invoking as a guide to the reader/listener.  This Howness is the map which frames and serves as a context or background for the Whatness which follows.

Now that we know the how, we are prepared to perceive the "what," the first part of which is the marvel (because as already promised, in Paradise, the marvelous is de rigueur) of multitudes of spirits appearing as apparitions, but — and here is the marvel — being, in truth, the actual condition of these post-mortem bodies, as Beatrice assures us.  We might want to think of these as non-physical, atemporal templates — what biologist Rupert Sheldrake might refer to as a "morphic resonance," through which physical, temporal bodies manifest, a field effect, which is so subtle that the forms are only as barely discernable, as the verses tell us, as a white pearl placed on a pallid forehead.  If the aspirant's experience described in the first six verses must be checked for its authenticity by comparing his present feeling with the memory of his feeling the first time he saw Beatrice, what follows is a return to an absolute presence, wherein his past is subsumed in a new vision, a vision which can only occur in a Paradise which is not segmented into the serpentine sequential movement of past-present-future.  Dante sees faces, which he falsely believes are projections of his own psyche.  We can ascertain this from the fact that — returning to the atemporal world of mythology — he flees from the fate of Narcissus, who, obsessed with his own reflection in water, attempted to mate with it, and was drowned.  Here, Dante has made a fundamental, and childish (puerile) mistake, seduced by an idea, which he fears he must reject or else be lost.  He has gone from one error — that the projections of the psyche are as physical as a physical body — to the opposite error — that these visions are mere projections, and thus inauthentic — untrue, unreal.  We can compare his state here with that of an earlier experience in the Purgatorio, wherein he was too ashamed to look at his reflection in the water, and instead, gazed on the grass.  His old habit of mind has certainly changed, but vestiges remain, as Beatrice reminds him in lines 28-30.  He has forgotten that the body which he now inhabits has been interpenetrated by the luminance of the moon, and has been enhanced by this transformation.  He is still in a physical body, but this body has been cleansed of much of its psychic neediness, and infused by the particular light of this moony sphere.  It is this phenomenon which has enabled him to perceive, through his newly reconditioned senses, these representations of an unearthly truth.  This truth exists simultaneously as figures of his own psyche and as something in the Universe.  He is seeing what is generally ungraspable through the ego-conditioned veils of sensory-based perception.  He is seeing what Jacques Lacan calls "The Real."2  Later, in the Commedia, the veracity of this vision might be amended, and once again we may be returned to the how of these representations, but for now, here, we are assured that these spirits, however the aspirant perceives them, are not mere products of either of Lacan's symbolic or imaginary orders.  They are denizens of The Real.  If as readers or listeners, we are not stunned by this marvel, this mundane marvel of Paradise, we should account ourselves as one of those doddering old people who have remained puerile in their conditioned perceptions, unable to see the wonders unfolding around them.  When we follow the text as aspirants, not just critics, we are also in need at this point of Beatrice's mild admonishment and reassurance: "Marvel not."  Keep your wits about you, and begin to train them to experience these things which arise as a challenge to your conditioned experience, these things which allow you to glimpse the light of The Real.  Dante's transcendence is not going to be a Buddhistic vision of the clear light of the void.  Personal identity, at least at this point, is enhanced, as in Jung's theory of Individuation.  Identity here has not been obliterated.  In this vision, we are one with the whole, always distinctly ourselves, but never separated.  Our point of nexus is, as Piccarda says, the will.  Our individual will is one with the divine will.  We flash back here to the previous canto wherein Beatrice explains that differences in light are not substantive, any more than notes on a scale are ethically lesser or greater than one another.  So too the souls in Paradise — though they experience narrower or wider domains of blessedness according to their individual capacities —  feel no diminution of bliss because their place  does not afford them "higher" states than they have.  All are suspended in the solute of the Divine's own state, as Piccarda tells us in lines 85-87.  I have always thought that this was one of the most hopeful revelations in the whole of the Commedia, this realization that wherever we are is the best place that we can be.  It is only in our present here and now that we can realize that we are inextricably and holographically a part of the entire cosmos.  Perhaps we could think of this as the I AM of the godhead, but an I AM brought down to the level of our individual aspirations.  Any moment can become eternal the instant that we come to realize that everything we may have desired for ourselves is best obtained when our desires are aligned with the harmony of the whole.  We should also remember at this point, despite, or rather because of, the reference to the sun in the first line, that we are still in the resonance field of what the text calls "The Moon," which, like a tonal mode in music, or as line 51 says in la spera più tarda ( in the slowest of the spheres), colors everything we see or hear in its domain.  We know this because, returning to the metaphor of lines 14 and 15, this subtle state is compared to the luminous quality of a pearl seen on a pearlescent forehead (perhaps an archetypal vision of Diana or Minerva, with their moon disc headbands), and also because the aspirant confesses that his memory of the faces he sees also works more slowly.  The moon, the pearl, the spirits, the aspirant's memory and his perceptions are all vibrating in the same resonance field, their frequencies all tones or siblings of the same metaphoric mode — moony pearlescent lights slowly dancing in a certain family of pitches to form the features of faces.  

The Moon is a female place, an anima place — to again barrow a Jungian term — and the spirits met here are those of women.  When they speak to Dante, their faces are alight in love's first fire (d'amor nel primo foco), a phrase that echoes that of the first line of the canto.  It should be noted, that just as the text does in the first verses, throughout the canto we find figurations denoting music, taste, weaving, feeling, light, gesture — the whole gamut really of sensory-based perceptions, but all raised to this higher key of spirit.  The slowness motif concludes the appearance of Piccarda as she exits, singing Ave Maria "like something heavy through deep water," (come per aqua cupa cosa grave line 123).  The light of Beatrice's eyes — the sight again of his first love — flashes so brightly that the aspirant is blinded, and the canto ends with a reminder of slowness, as Dante is delayed in asking his questions — again più tardo.  The feeling quality of the entire canto takes on the effect of being in some luminous flotation tank3, as we feel ourselves suspended in the solute of a uterine bliss — an ideal state for the inception of boundary-blurring ideas and the ability to associate and conflate diverse images.  This is a remarkable poetic performance, but one whose marvelous aspect has become, for all of its commonness throughout the Commedia, no less wondrous because we have been schooled to expect it.  Dante makes this clear, that as the intellect is schooled in the marvelous, it becomes more capable of experiencing the miracles which his poetry has to offer.  To me, it seems as if we are experiencing a theology of the aesthetics of reading, and the more we absorb this theology and apply it in our everyday lives, the more transformative it becomes.4     

This canto deals with two linked issues: The Will and The Vow.  It deals with the whom and the what and the how of their domains.  We have already dealt above with the will, but we might succinctly say that the will can choose but one of two directions on its path.  If the will follows in the direction of "what's in it for me," the individual eventually is at odds with the harmony of the whole.  All of the Commedia's Inferno deals with the horrible consequences which devolve when this path is obstinately followed to its extreme.  This narcissistic obsession is the logic of evil.  In the other direction, when the path is followed towards what helps to harmonize the whole, we find bliss.   Our will is ecologically and psychologically aligned with the highest possible purposes.  Here, the individual will becomes the cosmological will.   Now how does this pertain to The Vow?  Well, clearly, no vow is possible without the will to fulfill it.  Here we find ourselves at the crux of what in English we would call a promise, an oath, or a vow, similar, but hardly synonymous obligations.  We could surmise here that the promise belongs wholly to the human temporal realm.  Indeed, Nietzsche argues that the ability to make and keep promises is the attribute which makes us human.  In a sense, the entire idea of the promise must always involve the idea of freedom.  A promise binds, and causes us always — no matter how far we have travelled through time from its inception — to the initial conditions in which the promise was made.  Hanna Arendt refers to this memory attribute of the promise as it pertains to the political or public sphere, and she points out that paradoxically it is the people's ability to adhere to those promises enshrined in communal laws, which also ensures their freedom.  Collectively, we surrender a portion of our freedoms to the public good, so that we may be free to be free.  In this she argues we are dependent in our human condition on memory, the ability to renew that first promise as to why we banded together to begin with.  But she also ties this surrender to memory's constraints to that state of forgiveness, which allows us the freedom to be fallible, fallible even at times to transgress the laws we have promised to keep, even when the ends of a strict justice are not served.  In a mutating and mutable world, the circumstances in which our promises are constantly changing, sometimes being favorable, sometimes contrary 5 — the presence of forgiveness is as necessary to the preservation of freedom as is the presence of memory.  This is precisely the case in this canto with Piccarda and Costanza.  In the human world of promises, their breaking of their vows is forgivable, because both women were compelled against their personal wills to break their promises.  If the ability to keep promises is dependent on memory, the need to be free from them in a changing world, is dependent on forgetfulness.  Nietzsche argues that we must forget that we are animals to become human, and conversely to be human requires the ability to make and keep promises.  It is easy to see how these dilemmas of a human will — bound by the oscillations of submission/surrender vs. freedom/licence, or memory/tradition vs. adaptability/forgetfulness — have landed us in the mortal realm of the play of opposites, an immutable condition for mutable bodies operating  in a temporal world.  But in the Paradiso, as Beatrice reminds Dante in the previous canto, we are not on Earth, we are not in a mutable, temporal world, we are beyond that, in the metaposition of the Divine, and from this position, we are in the world of oath and vow.  To be clear about this, we can refer to Thomas Aquinas, who said:      
The obligation both of a vow and of an oath arises from something Divine; but in different ways.  For the obligation of a vow arises from the fidelity we owe God, which binds us to fulfil our promises to Him.  On the other hand, the obligation of an oath arises from the reverence we owe Him which binds us to fulfil our promises to Him. 
Summa Theologica, Volume 3, Part II, Second Section

If a promise is a mutual commitment between humans, this lacks that sense of obligation which pertains to the oath, in which the divine, or the whole of the cosmos, bears witness to the contract.  But the vow exceeds even the obligation of the oath, because in that case the entirety of the cosmos is one of the parties of the contract.   More than three decades ago, I read of a sculptor who had vowed to carve 10,000 Buddhas.  That idea intrigued me — or to be more precise: entrapped me.  So much so that I vowed to write 10,000 poems.  10,000 is a big number.  To write 10,000 poems, one must write a poem every day for 27 years and 4 months.  I have fulfilled that vow, and I continue to fulfill it.  During my life, like most of us, I have broken many resolutions and promises, and have failed, to my everlasting shame, to fulfill things that I called vows — even marriage vows — but that one vow I have managed to keep.  During these decades, so many temporal circumstances arose that might have prohibited me from keeping my vow to write — sickness, relocations, work and family obligations, financial stress — the list goes on and on — but none of those potential interferences interfered.  One could say that it is not the vow that I am fulfilling, but the vow which is fulfilling me.  Although I have tried again and again to give other very important things the eternal quality of this domain of the vow, in every other instance at some point these promises and resolutions were relaxed, broken, or forgotten.  When we read this canto, we might be very critical of the Divine's punishment — although we can hardly think of it as such — of these spirits who in life broke their sacred promises, not by a failure of their own will, but through the compulsions imposed upon them by more powerful others.  In brief, although these women never varied in their intentions, those powerful circumstances in this mutable world, in the end, ruled them, and by their surrender, they proved that what they had attempted to fulfill was only a temporal, not an atemporal obligation, and the moment those outer circumstances crushed or overwhelmed them, was the moment that their vows descended from the eternal world to the temporal one.  Their fault, if it can be called that, was hardly a failure of their personal will, but that did not, does not, matter.  Their human fallibility broke its connection to the entirety.  They lost connection with those very currents which alone could have enabled them to fulfill their vows.  Years ago, I read something from Delores LaChapelle, the mountaineer, cross-country skier, and pioneer deep ecologist.  She said, Nature will always give you "affordances."   I took this word "affordances" to mean that no matter how rugged or seemingly impassable is the physical or metaphysical terrain we are trying to traverse, if our will is mated with the landscape we will see what no one else could see in the same circumstances — that is to say — a way over, a way around, a way through.  The whole of the Commedia is a chronicle of that way over, that way around, that way through, which Dante found as a poet in a world that so often defeated him as a man.  Dante, the poet, knew about those affordances, and they made a path for him through exile and betrayal.  Each word, each syllable and sound of this poem was to him like a mountaineer’s faith in the rockface  — a metaphor he uses at the beginning of Inferno — a place to place one's faith — a place lower down no doubt on the cliff— but one from which he might place his foot to climb.  This poem, it seems to me, is a living example of the power of the vow, and if we read it in the right spirit, we will get a sense of how a strength beyond anything that we might personally summon exists for us in the very structure of the Universe, if we can align ourselves with it.           



1. For more detailed information on neurological strategies, check Jan Seager's website (https://www.easychangeworks.com/articles-nlp/markova-1-intro.htm) or Dawna Markova's book: Open Mind: Exploring the 6 Patterns of Natural Intelligence.

2. See An Introductory Dictionary of Lacanian Psychoanalysis, Dylan Evans.  Lacan theorizes that all psychic experience is divided into three orders: The Symbolic, The Imaginary, and The Real.  The Real is that which exists, not as a play of opposites, such as absence and presence, as is the Symbolic, but as "absolutely without fissure."  The Real is always present, but we do not ordinarily perceive it because it is usually beyond the symbolization of language.  We do not live in our corporeal bodies in The Real, but in the brain's simulation of The Real, in the orders of symbolization and imagination (see I of the Vortex: From Neurons to Self, Rodolfo R. Llinás) .  Here, in Paradise, having transcended the ordinal/temporal/ corporeal, we are indeed able to perceive some aspects of The Real.

3. The flotation or sensory isolation tank was an invention of John C. Lily, and a brief history of its application and effects can be found in a book he wrote with E. J. Gold, entitled "Tanks for the Memories."  The original idea of the tank was to study the effects of extreme solitude, which we have evidence of in such cross-cultural practices such as meditation, prayer, initiation rites, and so forth.  This kind of solitude was deeply enhanced in the complete sensory isolation of the tank.  Read the following quote from their book, and by reading I mean enter the altered state of consciousness that deep reading confers,    

You go into the tank, and the tank is a functional exit and entry point to tis universe.  In the tank you no longer have to relate to or communicate with anyone.  You are completely alone.  You are free from the tank to move out of and back into the universe.  The tank does not obey the same laws that this universe obeys.  The tank is not created under the same laws.  IT violates many laws in this universe, and as you work more and more toward become a transit operator, you will find that these laws that are violated will be pointed out to you.  You'll discover the laws that are violated and why they are violated and how they can be violated in that kind of space.

When you get into the tank you can focus on several questions, one of why is,

Who are you really apart from your identity?

You know that you are not your identity.  You know that your identity limits you.

When you let go of your identity, who are you?
What creates you individuality?

Another question you could ask is,

How can you break free now from the physical limitations of the tank?

Those who became proficient in the use of this tank, experienced a "transit" state, in which they could leave the ordinarily conditioning of their brains, and from a place of stillness and void, travel, as they said, to "different universes."  Dante seems to have used poetry, and reading in general, to effect a similar "transit" state whereby he could travel to the worlds he creates in the Commedia.  Throughout, he emphasizes the absolute reality of the Commedia's universe, and in this canto, through his avatar, Beatrice, he again reiterates this position.  The Commedia's universe is not "mere" psychic projection or fantasy.  Nor is it simply the reiteration of a certain kind of historic Christian theology.  It is its own universe, with its own geographies and laws.  The experience of "expert" users of the tank and of Dante and of Dr. Stan Groff's holotropic breathing, to name a few possible examples, is no different from that of the desert fathers, or of the Rishi's of ancient India, or of the Chinese sages of The Secret of the Golden Flower, or of any number of shamanic figures from traditional cultures.  The world that they encountered in these depths is a real, or even the real world.  Either this other world is an alternative to the world of ordinary consciousness, or it is one whose light reveals ordinary consciousness to be a sham.  The committed readers of the Commedia begin to have these same realizations.

4. This relationship of our everyday perception of events and the process of reading seems greatly enhanced when we read Dante's poetry.  Far from being a mere description or even an analog of reality, this poetry is mimetic of reality in the sense that our response to the poem is the same as our response to what we imagine to be real.  I would even go so far as to say that the experience of reading this poem outpaces our ordinary experience of reality and becomes that super stimulus which I am calling an aesthetic theology of reading.  A quote from A. N. Whitehead, which Wolfgang Iser uses in his book, The Act of Reading: A theory of Aesthetic Response, presents a similar proposition.  Whitehead's position and Isher's commentary appear below.  Both seem pertinent here, when we consider the impact the Commedia has had on centuries of serious readers.  That the act of reading might become a super stimulous, especially when we engage a text as highly — one might even say — as organically organized as is this poem of Dante's, is one way to account for Dante's insistence that the world he presents in the Commedia is as real and in some cases more real than the world which he embodies in it.  

One all-pervasive fact, inherent in the very character of what is real is the transition* of things, the passage one to another.  This passage is not a mere linear precession of discrete entities.  However we fix a determinate entity, there is always a narrower determination of something which is presupposed in our first choice.  Also there is always a wider determination into which our first choice fades by transition beyond itself ... These unities, which I call events, are the emergence into actuality of something.  How are we to characterize the something which thus emerges?  The same 'event' given to such a unity, draws attention to the inherent transitoriness, combined with the actual unity.  But this abstract word cannot be sufficient to characterize what the fact of the reality of the event is in itself.  A moment's thought shows us that no one idea can in itself be sufficient.  For every idea which finds its significance in each event must represent something which contributes to what realization is in itself ... Aesthetic attainment is interwoven in the texture of realization.  

A. N. Whitehead, Science and the Modern World.

* The transition of things is of course what the entire Commedia is about, which is why, perhaps even more than Virgil, it's guiding light is Ovid's Metamorphosis.



To which statement Iser comments:

Events are a paradigm of reality in that they designate a process and are not merely a "discrete" entity.  Each event represents the intersecting point of a variety of circumstances, but circumstances also change the event as soon as it has taken on a shape.  As a shape, it marks off certain borderlines, so that these may then be transcended in the continuous process of realization that constitutes reality.  In literature, where the reader is constantly feeding back reaction as he obtains new information there is just such a continual process of realization, and so reading itself  'happens' like an event, in the sense that what we read takes on the character of an open-ended situation, at one and the same time concrete and yet fluid.  The concreteness arises out of each new attitude we are forced to adopt toward the text, and the fluidity out of the fact that each new attitude bears the seeds of its own modification.  Reading, then, is experienced as something which is happening — and happening is the hallmark of reality.  For Whitehead the process of realization entails aesthetic attainment because reality can only be conceived in a sequence of transitory shapes.  These shapes are the signifieds which are in reading constantly being shifted into different situational frames, thus effecting a constant shift of position.  The text can never be grasped as a whole — only as a series of changing viewpoints, each one restricted in itself and so necessitating further perspectives.  This is the process by which the reader 'realizes' an overall situation.

Of course Whitehead's position and Iser's use of it, still beg the question of how the happening of reading might change once the entire text is read and thoroughly assimilated.  Does, in fact, this sequential transitoriness with all its mutating parts, gel into a single, timeless unity?  That is the question that occupies Dante in the Paradiso.

It should be noted that the Heaven of the Moon, which is where we are in this canto, is to be associated, according to the commentators and medieval tradition, with grammar, the first subject and the foundation of the Trivium.  Always underlying Dante's poetry there flows a fundamental aspect of mind and learning, and since grammar is the foundation upon which all higher attainments of the intellect depend, it is associated with this first of the seven heavens which constitute paradise.  His is a totum pole arrangement, with the most basic, and in some sense, the most aesthetically crucial figuration supports the weight of all the others.

Obviously this text is not a fanciful recapitulation of scholastism or a didactic lesson plan for the soul.  It is poetry, and poetry of a genre which comes closest in its style and aim to the kind of scripture we find in the Bible.  Yet, as deep as this connection is, I think this poem is from a genre no longer generally recognize in the Western Canon, although it still has a lively popular presense in the so-called "self-help" book.  In his book, A Story as Sharp as a Knife, The Classical Haida mythtellers and their World, Robert Bringhurst discusses the oral stories and myths of a highly sophisticated preliterate culture.  Stories are acted, sung, danced, carved into totums, worn as masks and costumes, and tatooed and painted on the very skin of the body, and not merely appropriated by what Rudolf Stiener referred to when he said that North American aborigines deplored and feared the letters which trapped sounds in written alphabets' little demons.  Bringhurst, in catagorizing the literature of the Haida culuture of the Northwest Pacific Coast, speaks of a genre "almost lost in European literature."  He calls the artifacts of this genere "medicine stories."  They are the "tales of vision quests and the spiritual journeys of shamans."  Although he says that these medicine stories are, like myths, generally told in the third person, they are "set in historical time."  The Commedia seems to be just this type of medicine story, but told in the first person to establish an intimate one on one connection of speaker to listener.  This poem is medicine, not only for the soul of the reader, but also for this historical soul of humankind.  For Dante that humankind soul was expressed in the turbulant and violent politics of the Italian penisula and throughout the old domains of the Roman Empire.  Perhaps, by choosing to write this medicine story in the vulgate and not in Latin, Dante is aligning his work with the old oral traditions of motherese that still danced and played with the healing spirits of speech acts before they were imprisoned by the alphabet's little demons.  In order for those demons to really do their medicinal work, I think we are required to once again release them, as we should all great poetry, in the ritual act of divinely enhanced and inspired speech.  

How should we go about reconstituting this written recipe for soul medicine, and what would this poetry be like if it were truly freed to perform its true function?  It might look like some sort of wild combination of Steiner's eurythmy visalble speech dance gestures, Antonin's revitalized theater, a high Catholic mass, a rave, and a Saint Vitus dance — but of course, all this would be an interior event, an act of Vipassana-like meditation, whose stillness embodied all the possible activities of life in the constant throes of transformation.  

5. For a further analysis of these issues see "Memory and Promise in Arendt and Nietzsche" by Vanessa Lemm (https://scielo.conicyt.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0718-090X2006000200009)  Note: However one thinks or feels about Nietzsche’s and/or Arendt's concepts of memory and forgetfulness, will and freedom, individuality and plurality, one thing is for sure that their concepts of promise are tied to the human realm which is subject to vicissitudes of time.  The original sin of Christianity is to be born in a temporal world, and to accept that world as the sole reality.
 
1  That Sun, which erst with love my bosom warmed,
2  Of beauteous truth had unto me discovered,
3  By proving and reproving, the sweet aspect.

1  Quel sol che pria d'amor mi scaldò 'l petto,
2  di bella verità m'avea scoverto,
3  provando e riprovando, il dolce aspetto;

4  And, that I might confess myself convinced
5  And confident, so far as was befitting,
6  I lifted more erect my head to speak.

4  e io, per confessar corretto e certo
5  me stesso, tanto quanto si convenne
6  leva' il capo a proferer più erto;

7  But there appeared a vision, which withdrew me
8  So close to it, in order to be seen,
9  That my confession I remembered not.

7  ma visïone apparve che ritenne
8  a sé me tanto stretto, per vedersi,
9  che di mia confession non mi sovvenne.

10  Such as through polished and transparent glass,
11  Or waters crystalline and undisturbed,
12  But not so deep as that their bed be lost,

10  Quali per vetri trasparenti e tersi,
11  o ver per acque nitide e tranquille,
12  non sì profonde che i fondi sien persi,

13  Come back again the outlines of our faces
14  So feeble, that a pearl on forehead white
15  Comes not less speedily unto our eyes;

13  tornan d'i nostri visi le postille
14  debili sì, che perla in bianca fronte
15  non vien men forte a le nostre pupille;

16  Such saw I many faces prompt to speak,
17  So that I ran in error opposite
18  To that which kindled love 'twixt man and fountain.

16  tali vid' io più facce a parlar pronte;
17  per ch'io dentro a l'error contrario corsi
18  a quel ch'accese amor tra l'omo e 'l fonte.


19  As soon as I became aware of them,
20  Esteeming them as mirrored semblances,
21  To see of whom they were, mine eyes I turned,

19  Sùbito sì com' io di lor m'accorsi,
20  quelle stimando specchiati sembianti,
21  per veder di cui fosser, li occhi torsi;

22  And nothing saw, and once more turned them forward
23  Direct into the light of my sweet Guide,
24  Who smiling kindled in her holy eyes.

22  e nulla vidi, e ritorsili avanti
23  dritti nel lume de la dolce guida,
24  che, sorridendo, ardea ne li occhi santi.

25  "Marvel thou not," she said to me, "because
26  I smile at this thy puerile conceit,
27  Since on the truth it trusts not yet its foot,

25  “Non ti maravigliar perch' io sorrida,”
26  mi disse, “appresso il tuo püeril coto,
27  poi sopra 'l vero ancor lo piè non fida,

28  But turns thee, as 'tis wont, on emptiness.
29  True substances are these which thou beholdest,
30  Here relegate for breaking of some vow.

28  ma te rivolve, come suole, a vòto:
29  vere sustanze son ciò che tu vedi,
30  qui rilegate per manco di voto.

31  Therefore speak with them, listen and believe;
32  For the true light, which giveth peace to them,
33  Permits them not to turn from it their feet."

31  Però parla con esse e odi e credi;
32  ché la verace luce che le appaga
33  da sé non lascia lor torcer li piedi.”

34  And I unto the shade that seemed most wishful
35  To speak directed me, and I began,
36  As one whom too great eagerness bewilders:

34  E io a l'ombra che parea più vaga
35  di ragionar, drizza'mi, e cominciai,
36  quasi com' uom cui troppa voglia smaga:

37  "O well-created spirit, who in the rays
38  Of life eternal dost the sweetness taste
39  Which being untasted ne'er is comprehended,

37  “O ben creato spirito, che a' rai
38  di vita etterna la dolcezza senti
39  che, non gustata, non s'intende mai,

40  Grateful 'twill be to me, if thou content me
41  Both with thy name and with your destiny."
42  Whereat she promptly and with laughing eyes:

40  grazïoso mi fia se mi contenti
41  del nome tuo e de la vostra sorte.”
42  Ond' ella, pronta e con occhi ridenti:

43  "Our charity doth never shut the doors
44  Against a just desire, except as one
45  Who wills that all her court be like herself.

43  “La nostra carità non serra porte
44  a giusta voglia, se non come quella
45  che vuol simile a sé tutta sua corte.

46  I was a virgin sister in the world;
47  And if thy mind doth contemplate me well,
48  The being more fair will not conceal me from thee,

46  I' fui nel mondo vergine sorella;
47  e se la mente tua ben sé riguarda,
48  non mi ti celerà l'esser più bella,

49  But thou shalt recognise I am Piccarda,
50  Who, stationed here among these other blessed,
51  Myself am blessed in the slowest sphere.

49  ma riconoscerai ch'i' son Piccarda,
50  che, posta qui con questi altri beati,
51  beata sono in la spera più tarda.

52  All our affections, that alone inflamed
53  Are in the pleasure of the Holy Ghost,
54  Rejoice at being of his order formed;

52  Li nostri affetti, che solo infiammati
53  son nel piacer de lo Spirito Santo,
54  letizian del suo ordine formati.

55  And this allotment, which appears so low,
56  Therefore is given us, because our vows
57  Have been neglected and in some part void."

55  E questa sorte che par giù cotanto,
56  però n'è data, perché fuor negletti
57  li nostri voti, e vòti in alcun canto.”

58  Whence I to her: "In your miraculous aspects
59  There shines I know not what of the divine,
60  Which doth transform you from our first conceptions.

58  Ond' io a lei: “Ne' mirabili aspetti
59  vostri risplende non so che divino
60  che vi trasmuta da' primi concetti:

61  Therefore I was not swift in my remembrance;
62  But what thou tellest me now aids me so,
63  That the refiguring is easier to me.

61  però non fui a rimembrar festino;
62  ma or m'aiuta ciò che tu mi dici,
63  sì che raffigurar m'è più latino.

64  But tell me, ye who in this place are happy,
65  Are you desirous of a higher place,
66  To see more or to make yourselves more friends?"

64  Ma dimmi: voi che siete qui felici,
65  disiderate voi più alto loco
66  per più vedere e per più farvi amici?”

67  First with those other shades she smiled a little;
68  Thereafter answered me so full of gladness,
69  She seemed to burn in the first fire of love:

67  Con quelle altr' ombre pria sorrise un poco;
68  da indi mi rispuose tanto lieta,
69  ch'arder parea d'amor nel primo foco:

70  "Brother, our will is quieted by virtue
71   Of charity, that makes us wish alone
72   For what we have, nor gives us thirst for more.

70  “Frate, la nostra volontà quïeta
71  virtù di carità, che fa volerne
72  sol quel ch'avemo, e d'altro non ci asseta.

73  If to be more exalted we aspired,
74  Discordant would our aspirations be
75  Unto the will of Him who here secludes us;

73  Se disïassimo esser più superne,
74  foran discordi li nostri disiri
75  dal voler di colui che qui ne cerne;

76  Which thou shalt see finds no place in these circles,
77  If being in charity is needful here,
78  And if thou lookest well into its nature;

76  che vedrai non capere in questi giri,
77  s'essere in carità è qui necesse,
78  e se la sua natura ben rimiri.

79  Nay, 'tis essential to this blest existence
80  To keep itself within the will divine,
81  Whereby our very wishes are made one;

79  Anzi è formale ad esto beato esse
80  tenersi dentro a la divina voglia,
81  per ch'una fansi nostre voglie stesse;

82  So that, as we are station above station
83  Throughout this realm, to all the realm 'tis pleasing,
84  As to the King, who makes his will our will.

82  sì che, come noi sem di soglia in soglia
83  per questo regno, a tutto il regno piace
84  com' a lo re che 'n suo voler ne 'nvoglia.

85  And his will is our peace; this is the sea
86  To which is moving onward whatsoever
87  It doth create, and all that nature makes."

85  E 'n la sua volontade è nostra pace:
86  ell' è quel mare al qual tutto si move
87  ciò ch'ella crïa o che natura face.”

88  Then it was clear to me how everywhere
89  In heaven is Paradise, although the grace
90  Of good supreme there rain not in one measure.

88  Chiaro mi fu allor come ogne dove
89  in cielo è paradiso, etsi la grazia
90  del sommo ben d'un modo non vi piove.

91  But as it comes to pass, if one food sates,
92  And for another still remains the longing,
93  We ask for this, and that decline with thanks,

91  Ma sì com' elli avvien, s'un cibo sazia
92  e d'un altro rimane ancor la gola,
93  che quel si chere e di quel si ringrazia,

94  E'en thus did I; with gesture and with word,
95  To learn from her what was the web wherein
96  She did not ply the shuttle to the end.

94  così fec' io con atto e con parola,
95  per apprender da lei qual fu la tela
96  onde non trasse infino a co la spuola.

97  "A perfect life and merit high in-heaven
98  A lady o'er us," said she, "by whose rule
99  Down in your world they vest and veil themselves,

97  “Perfetta vita e alto merto inciela
98  donna più sù,” mi disse, “a la cui norma
99  nel vostro mondo giù si veste e vela,

100  That until death they may both watch and sleep
101  Beside that Spouse who every vow accepts
102  Which charity conformeth to his pleasure.

100  perché fino al morir si vegghi e dorma
101  con quello sposo ch'ogne voto accetta
102  che caritate a suo piacer conforma.

103  To follow her, in girlhood from the world
104  I fled, and in her habit shut myself,
105  And pledged me to the pathway of her sect.

103  Dal mondo, per seguirla, giovinetta
104  fuggi'mi, e nel suo abito mi chiusi
105  e promisi la via de la sua setta.

106  Then men accustomed unto evil more
107  Than unto good, from the sweet cloister tore me;
108  God knows what afterward my life became.

106  Uomini poi, a mal più ch'a bene usi,
107  fuor mi rapiron de la dolce chiostra:
108  Iddio si sa qual poi mia vita fusi.

109  This other splendour, which to thee reveals
110  Itself on my right side, and is enkindled
111  With all the illumination of our sphere,

109  E quest' altro splendor che ti si mostra
110  da la mia destra parte e che s'accende
111   di tutto il lume de la spera nostra,

112  What of myself I say applies to her;
113  A nun was she, and likewise from her head
114  Was ta'en the shadow of the sacred wimple.

112  ciò ch'io dico di me, di sé intende;
113  sorella fu, e così le fu tolta
114  di capo l'ombra de le sacre bende.

115  But when she too was to the world returned
116  Against her wishes and against good usage,
117  Of the heart's veil she never was divested.

115  Ma poi che pur al mondo fu rivolta
116  contra suo grado e contra buona usanza,
117  non fu dal vel del cor già mai disciolta.

118  Of great Costanza this is the effulgence,
119  Who from the second wind of Suabia
120  Brought forth the third and latest puissance."

118  Quest' è la luce de la gran Costanza
119  che del secondo vento di Soave
120  generò 'l terzo e l'ultima possanza.”

121  Thus unto me she spake, and then began
122  "Ave Maria" singing, and in singing
123  Vanished, as through deep water something heavy.

121  Così parlommi, e poi cominciò “Ave,
122  Maria” cantando, e cantando vanio
123  come per acqua cupa cosa grave.

124  My sight, that followed her as long a time
125  As it was possible, when it had lost her
126  Turned round unto the mark of more desire,

124  La vista mia, che tanto lei seguio
125  quanto possibil fu, poi che la perse,
126  volsesi al segno di maggior disio

127  And wholly unto Beatrice reverted;
128  But she such lightnings flashed into mine eyes,
129  That at the first my sight endured it not;

127  e a Beatrice tutta si converse;
128  ma quella folgorò nel mïo sguardo
129  sì che da prima il viso non sofferse;

130  And this in questioning more backward made me.

130  e ciò mi fece a dimandar più tardo.

Canto IV
Although ostensibly this canto — as is the previous one — is about human will and the vow, or as I have rather arbitrarily tried to translate this to a more 21st Century me-key, i.e., Nietzsche’s and Arendt's definition of the human as one who can make and keep promises, it begins to dawn on the reader that for Dante the human is uniquely ensouled by an ability to ask and answer questions.  Whatever the topic at hand, this is what is happening throughout the Commedia — a continuous ask and answer — or to put it in liturgical terms, a call and response.  This poetic technique plays out in the form of dialog, a method that allows the text to pack a tremendous depth of knowledge and experience into a highly condensed format, insofar as any dialog necessarily springs the entire worldview of the participants, and thus allows for ever-deepening interpretations.  Conversations do the same, but they are not quite the same kinds of exchanges as the dialogue, which can be unpacked  to reveal far more sources of knowledge. And yet there is so much near-redundancy in the aspirant's questions in this canto, so much apparent dry-as-sticks theology in Beatrice's patient schoolmarm answers, that one wonders how the protagonist Dante, even if still drunk on the waters of Lethe, can remain such a dope, and an attentive reader who has followed the poet Dante's subtlety of thought and perception through 70 cantos of the poem begins to wonder if there is not a little leg-pulling going on here, an ironic smile behind the solemn pronouncements, like that of an altar boy who finds the sermon a little too dull and begins to entertain himself with secondary thoughts about why the words sound so weird, or why the lights through the stained glass windows are whirling clownish patches across the celebrants' faces.  Maybe there's a hidden subtlety here too, hinted at by Beatrice when she explains in a convoluted fashion that the surface of Plato's thought has misled many credentialed scholastics to misinterpret as false doctrine that which is hidden but true.  Is this a clue?  Are we dealing with irony here or are we not dealing with irony, the answer depends upon how the reader defines the context of their experience in reading, a topic which will be explored in some detail below.  But suffice it to say that the two types of interpretation are not mutually exclusive, this text, jewel-like in the sense that as you turn each facet to or away from the light of our mood while reading, it shines forth accordingly.  For now, we can say that inner and outer or text and context are insolubly connected, but may be quite divergent in their expressions.  Examples: Dante the aspirant's dumb student act, masking Dante the poet's sly sagacity.  Beatrice's dusty scholastic obscurantisms sparking out of a radiant appearance.  If we are going to say that the child's emotive state is the one that has kept burgeoning its primal intensity in the adult aspirant and ecstatic poet, then it's best to return to that moment when the child Dante first saw the child Beatrice, because there seems to be an almost deliberate intellectual regression here, as if, until all that the adult might have learned from the experience of maturing in a rotten fallen world is wiped clean, the naive child — frozen, desiring, and fearful in his attempt to orient himself in the confusing whirl of his powerful, inchoate emotions — cannot develop until he is re-educated to live as was first intended in love's Eden.  The tropes seem to be 1) mother/species dependence, i.e., dependence on the conditions of physical existence, the same if you are an insect, an alligator, a human being, an amoeba,  2) cultural dependence, that is, things like prestige, image, reputation, popularity, celebrity, and their obverse, ignominy, ostracization, ridicule, and the like, 3) sexual dependence, not just sexuality and the pleasure of mating, but any carnal pleasure: drinking, eating, smoking, or even the pleasures of denials and austerities, such as picking scabs, biting nails, forcing yourself to vomit, and so forth ... and then there is something that is utterly transcendent, some Jungian quaternity of fulfillment, the fourth being inclusive of the other three, but something qualitatively different, and far, far more than the sum of its parts.  In fact, it is the absolute sum, the unifying, harmonizing whole that continually births variety and continually enfolds and embraces that variety in an ever-new wholeness.  Dante's Eden opened when he saw as a child, the child Beatrice.  The child, as Wordsworth's poem famously told us, is the father of the man, and in his Vita Nuova, Dante describes the experience which fathered his adult self.  If we read these first sections of that work with the intensity of attention and minute care required, we will discover the nature of this seed, which grew into one of the greatest works of the Western Canon:

I
In My Book Of Memory, in the early part where there is little to be read, there comes a chapter with the rubric: Incipit vita nova (The new life begins).  It is my intention to copy into this little book the words I find written under that heading — if not all of them, at least the essence of their meaning.

II
Nine times already since my birth the heaven of light had circled back to almost the same point, when there appeared before my eyes the now glorious lady of my mind, who was called Beatrice even by those who did know what her name was.  She had been in this life long enough for the heaven of the fixed stars to be able to move a twelfth of a degree to the East in her time, that is, she appeared to me near the end of her ninth year.  She appeared dressed in the most patrician of colors, a subdued and decorous crimson, her robe bound round and adorned in a style suitable to her years.  At that very moment,1 and I speak the truth, the vital spirit, the one that dwells in the most secret chamber of the heart, began to tremble so violently that even the most minute veins of my body were strangely affected, and trembling, it spoke these words: Ecce deus fortior me, qui veniens dominabitur michi (Here is a god stronger than I who comes to rule over me.).  At that point, the animal spirit, the one abiding in the high chamber to which all the senses bring their perceptions was stricken with amazement and, speaking directly to the spirits of sight, said these words: Apparuit iam beatitudo vestra (Now your bliss has appeared.)  At that point, the natural spirit, the one dwelling in that part where our food is digested, began to weep, and weeping said these words: Heo miser, quia frequenter impeditus ero deinceps (Oh, wretched me, for I shall be disturbed often from now on.).
