Love governed my soul, which became immediately devoted to him, and he reigned over me with such assurance and lordship, given him by the power of my imagination, that I could only dedicate myself to fulfilling his every pleasure.  Often he commanded me to go and look for this youngest of angels; so, during those early years, I often went in search of her, and I found her to be of such natural dignity and worthy of such admiration that the words of the poet Homer fitted her perfectly: "She seemed to be the daughter not of a mortal, but of a god."  And though her image, which remained constantly with me, was Love's assurance of holding me, it was of such a pure quality that it never allowed me to be ruled by Love without the faithful council of reason, in all those things where such advice might be profitable.   Since to dwell on my passions and actions when I was so young might seem like recounting fantasies, I shall put them aside and, omitting many things that could be copied from the text which is the source of my present words, I shall turn to those written in my memory under more important headings.

III
After so many days had passed that precisely nine years were ending since the appearance, just described, of this most gracious lady, it happened that on the last one of these days the miraculous lady appeared, dressed in purest white, between two ladies of noble bearing both older than she was; and passing along a certain street, she turned her eyes to where I was standing faint-hearted and, with that indescribable graciousness for which today she is rewarded in the eternal life, she greeted me so miraculously that I seemed at that moment to behold the entire range of possible bliss.  It was precisely the ninth hour of that day, three o'clock in the afternoon, when her sweet greeting came to me.  Since this was the first time her words had ever been directed to me, I because so ecstatic that, like a drunken man, I turned away from everyone and I sought the loneliness of my room, where I began thinking of this most gracious lady and, thinking of her, I fell into a sweet sleep, and a marvelous vision appeared to me.  I seemed to see a cloud the color of fire and, in that cloud, a lordly man, frightening to behold, yet he seemed also to be wondrously filled with joy.  He spoke and said many things, of which I understood only a few,: one was Ego dominus tuus (I am thy master.).  I seemed to see in his arms a sleeping figure, naked but lightly wrapped in a crimson cloth, looking intently at this figure, I recognized the lady of the greeting, the lady who earlier in the day had deigned to greet me.  On one hand he seemed to be holding something that was all in flames, and it seemed to be that he said these words: Vide cor tuum (Behold thy heart.).  And after some time had passed, he seemed to awaken the one who slept, and he forced her cunningly to eat of that burning object in his hand; she ate of it timidly.  A short time after this his happiness gave way to bitter weeping, and weeping he folded his arms around this lady, and together they seemed to ascend towards the heavens.  At that point my drowsy sleep could not bear the anguish that I felt; it was broken, and I awoke. 

Vita Nuova,
Translated by Mark Musa

1.  "At that very moment" — In quello punto dico veracemente, and later, repeated as In quello punto — at that point.  Note the exactitude by which Dante repeats this phrase coupled with the exactitude in which he describes the times of these events, time being not determined by a clock, but by celestial bodies, the motions, the very motivations of heaven.  This exactitude and the numbers and colors associated with it, namely the number nine, and the colors red and white, imprint his experience with the feeling of a cosmological imperative, in brief, Dante experiences his destiny as something heavenly.  A note: Readers may well pause here and wonder if all of this is just a literary invention, a fantasy (fabuloso).  Dante says: No, and I don't doubt him.  Once during a counseling session, a client kept recounting life traumas associated with the number 11.  Every eleven years a business failure, a divorce, an accident, a sickness struck him.  Finally I asked him, "What happened to you at the age of eleven?"  "Oh, I was riding my bicycle and got run over by a truck."  Thereafter, something inside of him, in his unconscious, kept track, and on the anniversary of that primal event, another trauma would invariably occur.  For good or ill, every intense event that we experience seems to become encoded into a survival program ("survival," not because it was harmful or healthful, but simply because we survived the event) and, faithful to that program, and absent any subsequent interference, this program continues to run its course with clockwork precision.  We think of causes and their effects as being closely associated in time, because that is the way the conscious mind notices them.  But they can also be widely separated on the temporal plane, and thus completely evade conscious notice, unless we have made some sort of record of them.  Dante speaks of this record as the Book of Memory, a text.  Language, his vernacular language, and the church language of Latin, these are his scripture, his transcribed soul, and because this record is so personal, so intense, it becomes the precise structural armature for his poetry, numbers and celestial time becoming for him underlying verities, and he repeats them with the uncanny precision of the zodiac's precessions.   

After these experiences, one as a nine-year old, and one as a teenager of eighteen, Dante begins to write poetry.  Between and after the two events, as he says, "by the power of my imagination," he continues to expand and conflate this diachronic experience as if the two, or the many, were one miraculous event, since now he has discovered that through the vehicle of poetry, the feeling can be replicated, infinitely enhanced, moved out of the line of sequential time, manipulated, compressed, expanded, and shared.  Thus poetry becomes for him the enactment of love, the test for truth and authenticity, and even the guiding light of reason.  The mighty tree that was his future artistic expression, and the forest of commentators that continues to expand around his work, all grow from this one mustard seed.  This seed is grammatical in its origins, and especially when we consider that aspect of grammar, which is not syntactical, or concerned with phonemes or definitions, but with entomology, the origin and propagation of families and generational lineages of words, how memes originate, how they propagate, and how they mutate.  Think now of all the references in his poem of scriptural, philosophical, mythic, and poetic texts, and how precisely he martials all of these linguistic streams to form the fountain of his own inspiration.  How Dante relates all this to the trope of eating as a metaphor for learning and spiritual transformation to the trope of the vow equated with the constancy/inconstancy cycle of the moon, will be dealt with more fully below, but for now we return to the idea of love, as the beginning and end of all authentic experience. In New Age jargon this is called the Law of Attraction, which asserts that things of a like emotional or imagistic frequency have an affinity for one another, that in fact this frequency of our inner state is the source of those seemingly outer perceptions which we call reality.  This is a very ancient idea, and one that Sir James Fraser catalogues with exuberant redundancy in the huge compendium of The Golden Bough.  Fraser calls it sympathetic magic, and consigns its practice to what his thinks of as the primitive stages of humanity's development.  But there are a few contemporary physicists who do not scoff at these notions, when they speak of quantum entanglement, or as Einstein called it: Spooky action at a distance.   The entire sequence of Beatrice's untangling of literal versus figurative language in scripture and in Plato's Timaeus, turns on line 51: però che, come dice, par che senta.  It's the kind of line that gives translators fits, because they too easily fall into the trap of mistaking one logical type for another, namely confusing how something is said to how something is perceived.  Whatever truth is it is not a thing, any more than the word water is in substance like that substance which chemists calls H2O.  Perhaps this is easier to understand in a different medium for those of us too mesmerized by words.  A picture of a landscape with trees is a statement in paint about a statement about our perception about which we make a statement in words when we say: This is a picture of a landscape with  trees.  None of these statements are unconditionally true, but they are provisionally operational in terms of our conditioned thoughts and behavior.  Beatrice's logic is not so much the logic of temporal cause and effect, but the logic of atemporal affinities derived by comparing differences from different levels of signification, and there is enough in our most current views of biology, physics, and semiotics to justify this supposition.  From this point, we might better be able to see that Dante's poetic subtilty is constantly emerging from under this surface of scholastic argument in a much more prophetic fashion.  These levels of description are each different types of signification hinting at either more particular or more inclusive statements of what Dante would call Intellect, and what Bateson called Mind.  All of the Inferno, all of the Purgatorio are, as it were, a sort of archeological gardening through various misinterpretations of the coding for different levels of a the more particular or more inclusive hierarchies.  Throughout these first two canticles, Dante the poet shows Dante the protagonist digging and scraping away these misinterpretations to uncover more inclusive and more organic origins.  The outcome of this process is the revelation of the Edenic forest concluding the Purgatorio, wherein the protagonist finds himself again as a sort of embryo entirely innocent of anything that distorted his previous development which had led him to the state of confusion in the in the first Canto of Inferno's savage wood.  At this point, he and we have returned to the beginning, but with a difference.  What is really wrong about the misinterpretation that Plato's message which on its surface asserts that the soul returns to the star of its origin, is that if this is so, than the temporal world of earthly life does not make any difference, it was all a chimera, with no will, no choice, no morality, no learning, no suffering, no joy, no hatred, not even any love.  All that experience was simply an open and closed set of parenthesis called birth and death, but containing between them no message at all, not even a message definable as zero.  This of course to Dante is a monstrous heresy, temporal life does make a difference, and what that difference is is what the entire Commedia is meant to express.  That entirety of the message of the poem cannot of course be contained in any part of the poem.  Our question as readers, as are Dante's questions as an aspirant, and also his question as a poet is always something like: Where do I go from here?  What we find in these first canti of the Paradiso is the neophyte soul beginning to develop that New Life which was promised by Love at the very inception of his consciousness.  All other experiences of his childhood were lost to memory, and not encoded in Memory's "text."   Thus the aspirant whom we find in these early canti of the Paradiso is still. as stated, a neophyte, and in this condition of not just innocence but utter naivite, he turns to Beatrice in his heavenly consternations as he had before turned to Virgil in his earthy and infernal traumas.  But we must remember here, that just as Dante, the aspirant, at some point outgrew the need for Virgil, we can anticipate that at some point he will also outgrow his dependence on Beatrice.  Incredible as this seems, it is not Beatrice per se who will ultimately free him, it is the spirit of Love, which is, like himself — because it is his Self, a male figure, to be represented by ... well that's getting way too far ahead of ourselves.  Here we have enough to do to be in the present tense of the poem, and to immerse ourselves on what is happening in the Commedia's here and now.  To do otherwise is to acquire a false sense of meaning and to use that falsity to murder any authenticity that might come from having a true sense of what we are reading as we are reading it.  We would only have a pseudo knowledge, unvalidated by experience.

Conflated with this this original validation, this most fruitful seed of development for authentic experience, there is also the substance and transformation of experience, which is equated in the first six lines as food, and specifically in the processes of the positions of eater and eaten, which the first six lines of this canto present as follows.  A person starving between two equally desirable and equally accessible types of food — the position of the eater's relationship to the eaten; a lamb between two wolves — the position of the to be eaten to the potential eaters — and a hound between two does — a return to the position of the eater between two possibilities of that which is to be eaten.  This is a cycle, a going out and a returning, but not quite to the same point.  This is not quite a closed circle.  But mirroring the geography of the first two canticles of the poem, we find here, in a sort of fractal of the whole, a spiral, as it begins to open its coil at the widening end.  Although all the tropes illustrate a paralysis of the will, a double bind that leads to the termination of the cycle itself, i.e., starvation and death, or to put it in a more theological or philosophical way, the murder of motivation by indecisiveness and doubt, there is in this cycle both a degradation and the beginnings of a regeneration.  The degradation is from human to animal, human being to wolf (remember the wolf from the first canto of Inferno), and the hint of regeneration as wolf evolves to hound — a regeneration also present in Inferno's first canto, where the greyhound drives the she-wolf back to Hell.  This last trope is an exemplar for the beginning of the taming of the appetites, as a hound is the tamed wolf, but still essentially a predator, and here, frozen by its own animal appetites when confronted by a double-bind situation.  (For an exposition of the nature of the double-bind see: Gregory Bateson: Mind and Nature a Necessary Unity1, and his theory of coding mistakes due to confusion between levels of what he calls logical hierarchies, and what Dante in this canto calls the literal and the metaphoric.)  But why the moon, why food? and what does all this have to do with grammar and constancy, will, and vows?  Some further elucidation is available by referencing another work by Dante, the Convivio, or The Banquet, in which he makes an extensive exposition of knowledge and learning as a type of metaphorical eating, the learner being the eater, and the knowledge, as delivered through the medium of language, as the food.  Why?  Because just as material food is 
necessary to sustain a material temporal body, knowledge or learning, the ability to assimilate, change, and create, is necessary to sustain the immaterial immortal form.  One should note here that the immaterial does not mean without form, it means something like the potential to create and assume forms.  Two quotes from Convivio are pertinent here, the first showing the relationship between knowledge or learning and food, and the second showing the relationship between Grammar and the Moon.

As the Philosopher says at the beginning of the First Philosophy, all men by nature desire to know.  The reason for this can be and is that each thing, impelled by a force provided by its own nature, inclines towards its own perfection.  Since knowledge is the ultimate perfection of our soul, in which resides our ultimate happiness, we are all therefore by nature subject to a desire for it.  Many are, however, deprived of this most noble perfection by various causes within and outside of man which remove him from the habit of knowledge.  Within man there exist two kinds of defects which impede him, one pertaining to the body, the other to the soul.  That pertaining to the body occurs when its parts are not properly disposed, so that it can receive nothing, as is the case with the deaf, the dumb, and the like.  That pertaining to the soul occurs when malice overcomes it, so that it becomes the follower of vicious pleasures, by which it is so deceived that because of them it degrades the worth of all things.  Likewise outside of man two causes may be discerned, one of which subjects him to necessity, the other to indolence. The first consists of domestic and civic responsibilities, which properly engage the greater number of men, so that they are permitted no time for contemplation. The other is the handicap that derives from the place where a person is born and bred, which at times will not only lack a university but be far removed from the company of educated persons.

Two of these causes, namely the first from within and the first from outside, are not to be blamed but excused and are deserving of pardon; the other two, although one more than the other, deserve our censure and scorn.  Anyone therefore can plainly see upon careful reflection that there remain few who are capable of achieving the habit of knowledge desired by all, and that the handicapped who live forever starved of this food are almost too numerous to count.  Blessed are the few who sit at the table where the bread of the angels is eaten, and most unfortunate those who share the food of sheep!

Convivio, Book I, Chapter 1, Translation by Richard Lansing


I say that the heaven of the Moon resembles Grammar because it may be compared to it; for if the Moon is closely examined, two things will be seen peculiar to it which are not seen in the other stars: one is the shadow in it, which is nothing but the rarity of its substance in which the rays of the Sun cannot terminate and be reflected back as in its other parts; the other is the variation of its luminosity, which shines now on one side, now on the other, according as the Sun looks upon it. These two properties Grammar possesses; for because of its infinitude the rays of reason are not terminated, especially in the particular of words; and it shines now on this side, now on that, insofar as certain words, certain declensions, and certain constructions are now in use which formerly were not, and many were formerly in use which will yet be in use again, as Horace says at the beginning of his Poetics, when he says: “Many words shall be born which have long since fallen out of use.” 

Ibid. Book II, Chapter 13

These excerpts from Convivio make the affinities, as noted above, easy enough to discern, as is the logic.  That is, if we consider that the logic is the natural logic of metaphor, which even when it lies below the surface of a step by step exposition of causation, is seen, not as something sequential at all, but is in fact a technique that exposes simultaneities, which is to say, eternal, atemporal,  rather than relativistic, temporal truths.  And this is the point that Beatrice makes in this canto when she explains that the difference in what she is saying and how Piccarda presents is not a difference where one side invalidates the other.  The difference is that the two expressions are differently coded messages, both true, one in a specific, peculiar context, and one in a universal context.  This coding error of the aspirant Dante is precisely the source of the double-bind situation described in the first six lines of the canto.  Placed between the truth of the particular and the truth of the general, he sees them as contradictory, and his will is paralyzed.  Devoted to truth, as the necessary food of his soul, and the only means of moving from naivite to transcendence, he has, as Bateson describes the schizophrenic, been placed in a state of catalepsy, which if continued would lead to catatonia, which if continued would lead to death.  The interim internal state of such a schizophrenic would be the mad process by which hallucinations keep insisting upon actions which are contradictory, internally self-destructive, and externally criminal.  All of the characters in the Inferno suffer from this particular malady of not only me-first, but me only, and even the protracted punishment that they suffer does not awaken them from this frozen state, exemplified finally by the image of Lucifer himself, as a completely frozen, non-autonomous, mechanical parody of a living being.  None of this should come as a surprise or as some sort of fantastic (fabuloso) literary invention, if one has a bit of understanding of the nature of some hypnotic trances.  Milton Ericson, a master hypnotist, was able to put people into a state of catalepsy by merely interrupting the conditioned response of a handshake.  When a person has a conditioned response to the trigger of the extended hand, he codes a sequence of actions as one action, and if that sequence is interrupted, the physiology gets stuck.  Ericson could leave that hand floating in the air in a complete state of autonomous catalepsy.  This catalepsy would persist until Ericson himself "unstuck" his subject.  That hand would be floating involuntarily in space, and the subject's eyes would be staring at this entirely autonomous phenomenon, and Ericson would then say: "You'll be able to lower your hand when you resolve that inner conflict you've been having."   Since everyone has some inner conflict, Ericson did not need to know the specifics in order to loose the double-bind.  Because Ericson moved smoothly from the specific to the general, he showed that he did not make the coding error of conflating, confusing, or creating an equal oppositional quality between the two.  He understood that the two messages were related in a  logical hierarchy, the higher level entraining the lower, hence the instantaneity of the hypnotic trance.  I bring up this lengthy example, because we all have inner conflicts which renders the will and our actions catalytic, or even catatonic, and until we solve the coding issue, that catatonia will continue indefinitely.   This is just nature, and no will whatsoever is involved.  The cataleptic is just reacting like an eyelid blinking in the presence of a sand grain.  Lines 7 and 8 show that Dante understood this, no blame could be attached to his inaction, it was, as he says, simply necessary (ch'era necessario).  Now if we re-read this canto from line 106 — A questo punto (from this point)— on through to the aspirant's realization that Beatrice's truth has resolved his inner conflict (lines 115 through 132), we end at a new beginning, i.e. the uncovering of a deeper inner conflict.  Noting the variation of the motionless phrase In quello punto (At this point) quoted above from the Vita Nuova, we see that the phrase A questo punto, from this canto, serves a similar recursive purpose, but with a difference, and the difference is one of movement, of freedom, of a closed circle or circuit becoming an open-ended spiral, a conducting coil.  If Lucifer is frozen like ice, then Beatrice's truth is ever-changing yet in substance ever-the same.  In this, her truth is like water, which the text affirms with a series of water metaphors.  The aspirant says that this truth is rippling, like a stream, yet brings peace, as in Psalm 23's "he leadeth me beside the still waters.;" it floods him and it scalds him, but makes him more alive, and it increases the "depth" of his affection.  Readers can find for themselves this whole pattern of water metaphors appearing throughout the poem, but in this case, it is specifically enlightening to look at how water is used as a metaphor vis à vis the mutable nature of these canti dedicated to the sphere of the moon.

Now let's read how Dante uses his exemplars in this canto to poetically present these subtle and multivalent expressions.  We've already dealt above with the issue of the double-bind as a coding error which paralyzes the will because it fails to read the differences between logical types.  Right away the text shows us that Dante cannot speak, gives no verbal or auditory expression, but his face and breath are even clearer expressions of his doubts.  The fact that these two types of expression, auditory and visual, are different codings for the same thing is something that Beatrice easily reads, and this ability to distinguish — to use a McLuhan distinction — the media from the message runs throughout the canto.  She is mind-reading, but not from Dante's speech, and her skill surely is not magic.  Such mind-reading we have seen before in Virgil, so it should not puzzle us.  One could argue that the aspirant learns this method by example in the way he presents, at the conclusion of the canto, a visual reading of Beatrice's expression in response to his verbal query. 

Now we have the exemplar of Nebuchadnezzar in lines 13 - 15, with Dante equated with Nebuchadnezzar and Beatrice with Daniel.  The story in question is this: Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, dreams of a statue with a head of gold, arms of silver, thighs of brass, legs of iron, feet of iron and clay.  Just as Freud centuries later saw how the dream operations of condensation, displacement and Witz present in visual simultaneities, which subsequently needed to be unraveled in sequential, verbal interpretations.  Likewise Daniel interpreted this dream as an historical, i.e., sequential appearance of various kingdoms or ages, correctly seeing the same message in two very different modalities of expression.  Here Beatrice shows a like facility in correcting Dante's paralyzing confusion.  Another message is also presented, and that is Nebuchadnezzar's proposed cruelty (fello), namely, to kill all the wise men in his kingdom for their failure to interpret the dream.  The adjective modifying "fello" is inguistamente (unjustly).  For justice to occur, its scales must balance, another presentation of the same but different, just as crime is different from punishment although the pain of both is the same.  All injustices are by their nature cruel, in so far as they disrupt the peace necessary to achieve the bliss of contemplation, or civil tranquility, or aesthetic pleasure.  If we've already read the first two canticles of the poem, we are well aware of how Dante proposes to set things right in terms of punishment to rectify the imbalances of transgression.  But here, Beatrice rights transgression through education, through the  presentation of knowledge, a very important distinction, and the distinction that Dante himself makes in the Convivio.  We do not have to balance a weight of led with led, we can also balance it with gold.  To be symmetrical, balance need not involve redundancy of substance, as long as it involves redundancy of essence.  Finally, the name Nebuchadnezzar evokes another association, not mentioned here, but surely tangentially pertinent.  Namely, the king went mad, and collapsing from human to animal in the condition of boanthropy, he "was driven from men and did eat grass as oxen."  Now isn't this the regressive cycle that we find in the first 6 lines of this canto, and doesn't it also recall that line in the Convivio wherein the ignorant are consigned to eat the food of sheep?  Here sheep, as any person raised in a Judeo-Christian culture realizes, has, in addition to the negative connotation give here and in the Convivio, the positive one which postulates the Lord as caretaker and the flock as obedient worshipers.  This then becomes a code with different meanings, as distinct from the codes we have been reading wherein different codes have the same meaning. 

Now we have the exemplar Beatrice uses to resolve the aspirant's doubts concerning the hierarchies of heaven.  In a sense this is a reiteration of that which has also been answered in the same but different way in the previous canto, when Piccarda compares those in Paradise as particles dissolved in the sea or solute of God's love.  Here, Beatrice makes a further distinction, wherein she says that for the sake of human understanding (a literal reading) distinctions such as high and low, less and more, better and worse are made, but in a metaphorical reading, these qualitative distinctions are only relative truths, not general or universal ones, only particulars and not universals.  We may be compelled by nature and the nature of languages, that is perceptions, be they auditory, visual, or sensate, but through our intellect we can read these differences as the particular species of a general class.  Her examples are drawn from the hierarchies of angels, that is, Seraphim, from the Old Testament of Hebrew souls, Moses and Samuel, any John, either the Baptist or the disciple, as transitional figures, and finally a Christian figure, Mary (whose name means "sea").  All of this is related to grammar, as sort of a primer on how to read, and Beatrice continue with her exposition of how scripture delivers its multitudes of messages all pointing to the same truths.  

Now we come to the Timaeus reading, which has already been dealt with above, and as a preview as to how we are to read the spheres of the stars which will be presented as we continue reading the Paradiso, Beatrice educates us in the correct interpretation of these spheres, which are different in expression, but the same in their relationship to that transcendent entirety, which Dante calls God.

Now we have the exemplar of Lawrence and Mucius, exemplars of martyrdom set as counter examples of absolute will (the sacred vow), not subject to even the most extreme conditions, versus relative will, the situation of Piccarda and Constance whose will turned out to be conditioned by the violence of others.  I think it is significant that both Lawrence and Mucius were tested by fire, and proved in a way that their will was more fiery, whereas Piccarda and Constance are associated with mutable water and the mutable moon.  

Now we have the exemplar of Alcmaeon who committed matricide in order to fulfill his obligation of paternal piety.  Beatrice then tells Dante to reflect (a moony kind of action of the memory) on how violence destroys any kind of piety, and cannot be excused or should we say harmonized with the whole, until it is purged.  Her answer is very like Arendt's supposition of the necessity of forgetfulness as a necessity in the preservation of justice, that word forget, standing in as synonym for the word forgive, or we might, going a step further, say the operations of grace and salvation.  If we had not realized it before, we now know, in our newly recovered naivite, that we are in Paradise, not in hell, nor in purgatory, with their systems of retributive justice.  Here Love is the balancing factor, and to learn is not to enter some Blakean dark cloud of experience, but to expand in our knowledge of forgiveness, of grace, of affinity, and of affection.  Recall all those angelic injunctions to "Fear not," because here, even in the presence of awesome, irresistible power, that power is on our side, that power teaches us how to love and be loved.

1. A great deal of what I have said in these notes about logical typing or logical hierarchies, encoding, and double-binds has been derived from the work of Gregory Bateson, mostly as presented in his book, Mind and Nature: A Necessary Unity.  That work is difficult to summarize succinctly because of the very nature of what we call summarizations or definitions or explanations, these being what Bateson calls metacommunications, which he illustrates in a series of examples, one of which is the so-called Cretan paradox, which is: "Epimenides, a Cretan, says: "Cretans always lie." "  The premise, Cretans always lie, is negated by the context of the premise, that Epimenides, the person making the assertion, is a Cretan.  Logically, if the context is true, then the statement must be false, and if the statement is true, then the context must be false.  The quotation marks represent different logical types, and what you are reading now represents a statement about those types, made as a metacommunication at the next higher level of logical types.  If fed into a computer, this paradox, as Bateson points out that Norbert Wiener pointed out, the computer would answer Yes ... No ... Yes ... No ... Yes ... No ... until the system broke down.  This is the nature of a double-bind, and this is what Dante is illustrating at the beginning of the canto, using food, just as did Pavlov with dogs in his experiments with operant conditioning.  Those experiments proceeded until the dog could not tell the difference between messages (stimuli), which brought a reward, and messages, which brought punishment or no reward.  The dogs so conditioned went mad, biting, refusing all food, or even becoming comatose.  Bateson says that "In all such cases, the step from one logical type to the next higher is a step from information about an event to information about a class of events or from considering the class to considering the class of classes."  The fact that the computer breaks down, the dogs go mad, or in Dante's example, the man starves, the sheep gets eaten, and the hounds go cataleptic, shows that although information is not a physical thing in the same way a perceiving organism is a physical thing, nevertheless an organism's failure to distinguish the encoding of logical types of information has physical consequences such as paralysis, madness, or death.  Classes of failure to correctly read the logical typing of a communication might be: failure to distinguish the literal from the metaphorical/allegorical, failure to  read a play fight from a real fight, a statement meant to be humorous from a statement meant to be serious, failure to see the double nature of a pun, failure to read irony, and so forth.  Dante's poetry exhibits all these types of metacommunication and many more, and it shows that he is able to read their different types of codings so deftly, that in the context we might call poem/reader, the reader can become enlightened about the nature of many logical types of information and thus learn how to read their codes.  We might interpret from this that poetry, and art in general, much like dreams, are types of play, whose actions have no particular or even useful immediate physical consequences, in the way that eating or sexual congress do, but which can teach us how to organize whole classes of our physical actions.  And this is a type of experience which is crucial to our sanity and even to our survival.

1  Between two viands, equally removed
2  And tempting, a free man would die of hunger
3  Ere either he could bring unto his teeth.

1  Intra due cibi, distanti e moventi
2  d'un modo, prima si morria di fame,
3  che liber' omo l'un recasse ai denti;

4  So would a lamb between the ravenings
5  Of two fierce wolves stand fearing both alike;
6  And so would stand a dog between two does.

4  sì si starebbe un agno intra due brame
5  di fieri lupi, igualmente temendo;
6  sì si starebbe un cane intra due dame:

7  Hence, if I held my peace, myself I blame not,
8  Impelled in equal measure by my doubts,
9  Since it must be so, nor do I commend.

7  per che, s'i' mi tacea, me non riprendo,
8  da li miei dubbi d'un modo sospinto,
9  poi ch'era necessario, né commendo.

10  I held my peace; but my desire was painted
11  Upon my face, and questioning with that
12  More fervent far than by articulate speech.

10  Io mi tacea, ma 'l mio disir dipinto
11 m'era nel viso, e 'l dimandar con ello,
12 più caldo assai che per parlar distinto.

13  Beatrice did as Daniel had done
14  Relieving Nebuchadnezzar from the wrath
15  Which rendered him unjustly merciless,

13  Fé sì Beatrice qual fé Danïello,
14  Nabuccodonosor levando d'ira,
15  che l'avea fatto ingiustamente fello;

16  And said: "Well see I how attracteth thee
17  One and the other wish, so that thy care
18  Binds itself so that forth it does not breathe.

16  e disse: “Io veggio ben come ti tira
17  uno e altro disio, sì che tua cura
18  sé stessa lega sì che fuor non spira.

19  Thou arguest, if good will be permanent,
20  The violence of others, for what reason
21  Doth it decrease the measure of my merit?

19  Tu argomenti: 'Se 'l buon voler dura,
20  la vïolenza altrui per qual ragione
21  di meritar mi scema la misura?'

22  Again for doubting furnish thee occasion
23  Souls seeming to return unto the stars,
24  According to the sentiment of Plato.

22  Ancor di dubitar ti dà cagione
23  parer tornarsi l'anime a le stelle,
24  secondo la sentenza di Platone.

25  These are the questions which upon thy wish
26  Are thrusting equally; and therefore first
27  Will I treat that which hath the most of gall.

25  Queste son le question che nel tuo velle
26  pontano igualmente; e però pria
27  tratterò quella che più ha di felle.

28  He of the Seraphim most absorbed in God,
29  Moses, and Samuel, and whichever John
30  Thou mayst select, I say, and even Mary,

28  D'i Serafin colui che più s'india,
29  Moïsè, Samuel, e quel Giovanni
30  che prender vuoli, io dico, non Maria,

31  Have not in any other heaven their seats,
32  Than have those spirits that just appeared to thee,
33  Nor of existence more or fewer years;

31  non hanno in altro cielo i loro scanni
32  che questi spirti che mo t'appariro,
33  né hanno a l'esser lor più o meno anni;

34  But all make beautiful the primal circle,
35  And have sweet life in different degrees,
36  By feeling more or less the eternal breath.

34  ma tutti fanno bello il primo giro,
35  e differentemente han dolce vita
36  per sentir più e men l'etterno spiro.

37  They showed themselves here, not because allotted
38  This sphere has been to them, but to give sign
39  Of the celestial which is least exalted.

37  Qui si mostraro, non perché sortita
38  sia questa spera lor, ma per far segno
39  de la celestïal c'ha men salita.

40  To speak thus is adapted to your mind,
41  Since only through the sense it apprehendeth
42  What then it worthy makes of intellect.

40  Così parlar conviensi al vostro ingegno,
41  però che solo da sensato apprende
43  ciò che fa poscia d'intelletto degno.

43  On this account the Scripture condescends
44  Unto your faculties, and feet and hands
45  To God attributes, and means something else;

44  Per questo la Scrittura condescende
45  a vostra facultate, e piedi e mano
46  attribuisce a Dio e altro intende;

46  And Holy Church under an aspect human
47  Gabriel and Michael represent to you,
48  And him who made Tobias whole again.

46  e Santa Chiesa con aspetto umano
47  Gabrïel e Michel vi rappresenta,
48  e l'altro che Tobia rifece sano.

49  That which Timaeus argues of the soul
50  Doth not resemble that which here is seen,
51  Because it seems that as he speaks he thinks.

49  Quel che Timeo de l'anime argomenta
50  non è simile a ciò che qui si vede,
51  però che, come dice, par che senta.

52  He says the soul unto its star returns,
53  Believing it to have been severed thence
54  Whenever nature gave it as a form.

52  Dice che l'alma a la sua stella riede,
53  credendo quella quindi esser decisa
54  quando natura per forma la diede;

55  Perhaps his doctrine is of other guise
56  Than the words sound, and possibly may be
57  With meaning that is not to be derided.

52  Dice che l'alma a la sua stella riede,
53  credendo quella quindi esser decisa
54  quando natura per forma la diede;

58  If he doth mean that to these wheels return
59  The honour of their influence and the blame,
60  Perhaps his bow doth hit upon some truth.

58  S'elli intende tornare a queste ruote
59  l'onor de la influenza e 'l biasmo, forse
60  in alcun vero suo arco percuote.

61  This principle ill understood once warped
62  The whole world nearly, till it went astray
63  Invoking Jove and Mercury and Mars.

61  Questo principio, male inteso, torse
62  già tutto il mondo quasi, sì che Giove,
63  Mercurio e Marte a nominar trascorse.

64  The other doubt which doth disquiet thee
65  Less venom has, for its malevolence
66  Could never lead thee otherwhere from me.

64  L'altra dubitazion che ti commove
65  ha men velen, però che sua malizia
66  non ti poria menar da me altrove.

67  That as unjust our justice should appear
68  In eyes of mortals, is an argument
69  Of faith, and not of sin heretical.

67  Parere ingiusta la nostra giustizia
68  ne li occhi d'i mortali, è argomento
69  di fede e non d'eretica nequizia.

70  But still, that your perception may be able
71  To thoroughly penetrate this verity,
72  As thou desirest, I will satisfy thee.

70  Ma perché puote vostro accorgimento
71  ben penetrare a questa veritate,
72  come disiri, ti farò contento.

73  If it be violence when he who suffers
74  Co-operates not with him who uses force,
75  These souls were not on that account excused;

73  Se vïolenza è quando quel che pate
74  nïente conferisce a quel che sforza,
75  non fuor quest' alme per essa scusate:

76  For will is never quenched unless it will,
77  But operates as nature doth in fire
78  If violence a thousand times distort it.

76  ché volontà, se non vuol, non s'ammorza,
77  ma fa come natura face in foco,
78  se mille volte vïolenza il torza.

79  Hence, if it yieldeth more or less, it seconds
80  The force; and these have done so, having power
81  Of turning back unto the holy place.

79  Per che, s'ella si piega assai o poco,
80  segue la forza; e così queste fero
81  possendo rifuggir nel santo loco.

82  If their will had been perfect, like to that
83  Which Lawrence fast upon his gridiron held,
84  And Mutius made severe to his own hand,

82  Se fosse stato lor volere intero,
83  come tenne Lorenzo in su la grada,
84  e fece Muzio a la sua man severo,

85  It would have urged them back along the road
86  Whence they were dragged, as soon as they were free;
87  But such a solid will is all too rare.

85  così l'avria ripinte per la strada
86  ond' eran tratte, come fuoro sciolte;
87  ma così salda voglia è troppo rada.

88  And by these words, if thou hast gathered them
89  As thou shouldst do, the argument is refuted
90  That would have still annoyed thee many times.

88  E per queste parole, se ricolte
89  l'hai come dei, è l'argomento casso
90  che t'avria fatto noia ancor più volte.

91  But now another passage runs across
92  Before thine eyes, and such that by thyself
93  Thou couldst not thread it ere thou wouldst be weary.

91  Ma or ti s'attraversa un altro passo
92  dinanzi a li occhi, tal che per te stesso
93  non usciresti: pria saresti lasso.

94  I have for certain put into thy mind
95  That soul beatified could never lie,
96  For it is near the primal Truth,

94  Io t'ho per certo ne la mente messo
95  ch'alma beata non poria mentire,
96  però ch'è sempre al primo vero appresso;

97  And then thou from Piccarda might'st have heard
98  Costanza kept affection for the veil,
99  So that she seemeth here to contradict me.

97  e poi potesti da Piccarda udire
98  che l'affezion del vel Costanza tenne;
99  sì ch'ella par qui meco contradire.

100  Many times, brother, has it come to pass,
101  That, to escape from peril, with reluctance
102  That has been done it was not right to do,

100  Molte fïate già, frate, addivenne
101  che, per fuggir periglio, contra grato
102  si fé di quel che far non si convenne;

103  E'en as Alcmaeon (who, being by his father
104  Thereto entreated, his own mother slew)
105  Not to lose pity pitiless became.

103  come Almeone, che, di ciò pregato
104  dal padre suo, la propria madre spense,
105  per non perder pietà si fé spietato.

106  At this point I desire thee to remember
107  That force with will commingles, and they cause
108  That the offences cannot be excused.

106  A questo punto voglio che tu pense
107  che la forza al voler si mischia, e fanno
108  sì che scusar non si posson l'offense.

109  Will absolute consenteth not to evil;
110  But in so far consenteth as it fears,
111  If it refrain, to fall into more harm.

109  Voglia assoluta non consente al danno;
110  ma consentevi in tanto in quanto teme,
111  se si ritrae, cadere in più affanno.

112  Hence when Piccarda uses this expression,
113  She meaneth the will absolute, and I
114  The other, so that both of us speak truth."

112  Però, quando Piccarda quello spreme,
113  de la voglia assoluta intende, e io
114  de l'altra; sì che ver diciamo insieme.”

115  Such was the flowing of the holy river
116  That issued from the fount whence springs all truth;
117  This put to rest my wishes one and all.

115  Cotal fu l'ondeggiar del santo rio
116  ch'uscì del fonte ond' ogne ver deriva;
117  tal puose in pace uno e altro disio.

118  "O love of the first lover, O divine,"
119  Said I forthwith, "whose speech inundates me
120  And warms me so, it more and more revives me,

118  “O amanza del primo amante, o diva,”
119  diss' io appresso, “il cui parlar m'inonda
120  e scalda sì, che più e più m'avviva,

121  My own affection is not so profound
122  As to suffice in rendering grace for grace;
123  Let Him, who sees and can, thereto respond.

121  non è l'affezion mia tanto profonda,
122  che basti a render voi grazia per grazia;
123  ma quei che vede e puote a ciò risponda.

124  Well I perceive that never sated is
125  Our intellect unless the Truth illume it,
126  Beyond which nothing true expands itself.

124  Io veggio ben che già mai non si sazia
125  nostro intelletto, se 'l ver non lo illustra
126  di fuor dal qual nessun vero si spazia.

127  It rests therein, as wild beast in his lair,
128  When it attains it; and it can attain it;
129  If not, then each desire would frustrate be.

127  Posasi in esso, come fera in lustra,
128  tosto che giunto l'ha; e giugner puollo:
129  se non, ciascun disio sarebbe frustra.

130  Therefore springs up, in fashion of a shoot,
131  Doubt at the foot of truth; and this is nature,
132  Which to the top from height to height impels us.

130  Nasce per quello, a guisa di rampollo,
131  a piè del vero il dubbio; ed è natura
132  ch'al sommo pinge noi di collo in collo.

133  This doth invite me, this assurance give me
134  With reverence, Lady, to inquire of you
135  Another truth, which is obscure to me.

133  Questo m'invita, questo m'assicura
134  con reverenza, donna, a dimandarvi
135  d'un'altra verità che m'è oscura.

136  I wish to know if man can satisfy you
137  For broken vows with other good deeds, so
138  That in your balance they will not be light."

136  Io vo' saper se l'uom può sodisfarvi
137  ai voti manchi sì con altri beni,
138  ch'a la vostra statera non sien parvi.”

139  Beatrice gazed upon me with her eyes
140  Full of the sparks of love, and so divine,
141  That, overcome my power, I turned my back

139  Beatrice mi guardò con li occhi pieni
140  di faville d'amor così divini,
141  che, vinta, mia virtute diè le reni,

142  And almost lost myself with eyes downcast.

142  e quasi mi perdei con li occhi chini.

Canto V
How does one radicalize one's response to this fantastic poem, and return its accumulated commentaries, which have worked tirelessly to tame it to sanity, to an inner landscape, an IN-sanity, wherein one has already crossed, in one's very mortal flesh, into an afterworld, where death's phantasmagoria becomes more real than anything seen in life, wherein the spirit of a woman who died young, and as a child, enthralled the life of another child, and bent the whole of history, with a passion exceeding the light of the physical sun, a light, like all photonic phenomena, without any mass, but with an organizing, revelatory power that raises the chaotic collisions of atoms into the magical forms of evolution, the magic of human beings, and of violent, exotic cultures, and the greater magic of poets and poetry, transformed by the megajoule wattage of a lover's glance?  It strikes me, that given the mad psychic geography of the Commedia, that it is only the power of Dante's organizing mind, his extreme ordering of his linguistic materials, which keeps us from declaring his entire enterprise as the product of a lunatic.  He has wrestled order out of chaos, but that chaos infuses every particular of his order.  Chaos is tamed, but only at its edges, at the membrane where theological order is sanctified by poetic form, beyond which lies that monstrous thing called God.  In the first twelve lines of this canto, wherein Dante self-references twice that this is a canto, from the place of the eyes to the soles of the feet is one hot mass of loving flame, of sight perfected, which infectiously, as one flame begets another, ignites the passion of the beloved with that of the lover.  Think of how pale our understanding of the intellect has become compared to this resplendent, eternal light, and think what manner of seduction we, as readers, are being coaxed to succumb to, as the words revolve around this question of the vow.  Like some sort of diabetic neuropathy the blaze of this sweetness comes bursting through the skin, and whether it is agony or sanctity, we can hardly tell, but it is a sort of irresistible prompting, and it defines the moment when the evolution of the universe and the self, turns, and with a will, which Dante defines as belonging only to angels and humans, chooses to observe its own processes, and to ask after its own geneses and destiny.  How did it come to pass that the cosmos had this potential to create a being not merely with the animal desire to live, but with the more-than animal desire: To know, and not only to know by some sort of philosophical or scientific probing, but to know through the passion of love.  To me, this seems to be what these questions of the vow are all about.  How is such a thing, in such a mutable universe, to be made constant?  Because, the weight of Beatrice's argument is just such an affirmation.  That the vow is that binding force which unites creature to Creator, which, if broken, negates that link of love that calls both into existence; the vow is a demonstration that the universe is not just a roiling, ongoing catastrophe, born with explosive violence, and heading for the gray, entropic soup of heat-death.  The vow marries the consent and largess of grace to the consenting, and all-generous sacrifice of the devoted.  It is clear that the conversation that the aspirant has had with Piccarda has created in him an anxiety that it might be too late for him, that he has already broken vows and that his intent to be faithful has been tried by the harsh conditions of a harsh society and found wanting.  He is still thinking of the vow as a sort of legal arrangement involving rules and retribution, whereas Piccarda has already said that her experience of grace is not diminished by any sense of punishment or lack, she is simply fulfilled — filled and full to the brim.  For some the fermented sunlight in a drop of wine is enough to intoxicate, while others are able to enjoy a goblet or a flask, but the wine and the intoxication is the same for all, only the capacity of the imbiber is less or more.  Or as the poem says, comparing the consuming of this experience of grace to the earthy act of digestion, some may sit at the communion table longer, because they have taken their nourishment from grosser food.  Perhaps the vow is another example of what the Buddhists call interdependent co-arising, wherein context, or in Dante's sense, God, and content, the devotee, are synchronized to produce something which could not conceivably exist without this bond of love which unites and harmonizes them.  If so, than Beatrice's words could be interpreted to mean that love as this binding force is that which may only grow stronger and still be called love, and that any contention is of necessity a weakening of that force — and, as she says and these "moon" canti illustrate, there are inevitable consequences to that weakening.  If this is  so, her observation in the first lines of the canto that the light of her mind is beginning to grow in Dante's mind is an indication that a vow is uniting them, a vow, as we see, where response through loving intuition precedes call, and answer precedes question.  In the vow, then, there arises the omnipotence of love as a third thing, a kind of grace that unites the two things that Beatrice enumerates as the thing agreed upon and the agreement itself.  This reversal is also reiterated in a temporal context in lines 91 and 92, where the quivering of the bow string is mentioned before the arrow striking its target, which indicates the speed of the transition from the realm of the Moon to that of Mercury, but it also shows something more than just a short lapse of time, it demonstrates the possibility of a time reversal.  If a vow negates time by always remaining at its original point of inspiration no matter how many temporal contingencies arise to thwart it, this trope shows us that in the realm of consciousness, or as Dante says elsewhere, through the power of imagination, love, which manifests the vow, is not a temporal phenomenon, and, being eternal, may move in any direction it wills with total freedom.

What follows this transition to Mercury is the remarkable trope of fish in a fishpond, a crystalline bubble containing luminous bubbles.  Such a humble metaphor!  And so easy to picture that any child could do it.  But fish are free to move in all directions through their element, whereas humans are surface dwellers, only able to move across a two-dimensional plane, and what a mysterious juxtaposition of the mutually observing.  Dante's aside to the reader emphasizes this mystery and reiterating that claim he makes in the Convivio, that all people hunger for knowledge, this image certainly keens our appetite to know.  Who are these spirits whose joy is so intense to share with another creature, unlike themselves, their overflow of love?  The water metaphor gives way to one of fire, and the peace of the serene pond is jarred by the rhyming of the words malizia (battlefield) and grazia (grace).  At this point, as all  the company of spirits overflows (like water) and overflares (like fire) with collective joy, these fish, who nest in light like birds, so dazzle Dante, that for a moment he is mute, and it is just here that he is prompted by Beatrice to speak! speak!  He does,  asking what we too most want to know.  Thus, like his own, our intellect is illumined.

One thing to notice here is that the distance between Dante the aspirant, who is the protagonist in the poem, and Dante the poet outside the poem, which was very great at the beginning of the Inferno, is beginning to narrow to the point of convergence.  Both will end in silence when the poem ceases to speak.  And yet, as readers, each of us, by now by the millions, are travelling from our own direction, each moving from a point of silent absorption towards the last spoken word of the poem, where, when the poet becomes quiet, we are endowed with his speech.  

1  "If in the heat of love I flame upon thee
2  Beyond the measure that on earth is seen,
3  So that the valour of thine eyes I vanquish,

1  “S'io ti fiammeggio nel caldo d'amore
2  di là dal modo che 'n terra si vede,
3  sì che del viso tuo vinco il valore,

4  Marvel thou not thereat; for this proceeds
5  From perfect sight, which as it apprehends
6  To the good apprehended moves its feet.

4  non ti maravigliar, ché ciò procede
5  da perfetto veder, che, come apprende,
6  così nel bene appreso move il piede.

7  Well I perceive how is already shining
8  Into thine intellect the eternal light,
9  That only seen enkindles always love;

7  Io veggio ben sì come già resplende
8  ne l'intelletto tuo l'etterna luce,
9  che, vista, sola e sempre amore accende;

10  And if some other thing your love seduce,
11  'Tis nothing but a vestige of the same,
12  Ill understood, which there is shining through.

10  e s'altra cosa vostro amor seduce,
11  non è se non di quella alcun vestigio,
12  mal conosciuto, che quivi traluce.

13  Thou fain wouldst know if with another service
14  For broken vow can such return be made
15  As to secure the soul from further claim."

13  Tu vuo' saper se con altro servigio,
14  per manco voto, si può render tanto
15  che l'anima sicuri di letigio.”

16  This Canto thus did Beatrice begin;
17  And, as a man who breaks not off his speech,
18  Continued thus her holy argument:

16  Sì cominciò Beatrice questo canto;
17  e sì com' uom che suo parlar non spezza,
18  continüò così 'l processo santo:

19  "The greatest gift that in his largess God
20  Creating made, and unto his own goodness
21  Nearest conformed, and that which he doth prize

19  “Lo maggior don che Dio per sua larghezza
20  fesse creando, e a la sua bontate
21  più conformato, e quel ch'e' più apprezza,

22  Most highly, is the freedom of the will,
23  Wherewith the creatures of intelligence
24  Both all and only were and are endowed.

22  fu de la volontà la libertate;
23  di che le creature intelligenti,
24  e tutte e sole, fuoro e son dotate.

25  Now wilt thou see, if thence thou reasonest,
26  The high worth of a vow, if it he made
27  So that when thou consentest God consents:

25  Or ti parrà, se tu quinci argomenti,
26  l'alto valor del voto, s'è sì fatto
27  che Dio consenta quando tu consenti;

28  For, closing between God and man the compact,
29  A sacrifice is of this treasure made,
30  Such as I say, and made by its own act.

28  ché, nel fermar tra Dio e l'omo il patto,
29  vittima fassi di questo tesoro,
30  tal quale io dico; e fassi col suo atto.

31  What can be rendered then as compensation?
32  Think'st thou to make good use of what thou'st offered,
33  With gains ill gotten thou wouldst do good deed.

31  Dunque che render puossi per ristoro?
32  Se credi bene usar quel c'hai offerto,
33 di maltolletto vuo' far buon lavoro.

34  Now art thou certain of the greater point;
35  But because Holy Church in this dispenses,
36  Which seems against the truth which I have shown thee,

34  Tu se' omai del maggior punto certo;
35  ma perché Santa Chiesa in ciò dispensa,
36  che par contra lo ver ch'i' t'ho scoverto,

37  Behoves thee still to sit awhile at table,
38  Because the solid food which thou hast taken
39  Requireth further aid for thy digestion.

37  convienti ancor sedere un poco a mensa,
38  però che 'l cibo rigido c'hai preso,
39  richiede ancora aiuto a tua dispensa.

40  Open thy mind to that which I reveal,
41  And fix it there within; for 'tis not knowledge,
42  The having heard without retaining it.

40  Apri la mente a quel ch'io ti paleso
41  e fermalvi entro; ché non fa scïenza,
42  sanza lo ritenere, avere inteso.

43  In the essence of this sacrifice two things
44  Convene together; and the one is that
45  Of which 'tis made, the other is the agreement.

43  Due cose si convegnono a l'essenza
44  di questo sacrificio: l'una è quella
45  di che si fa; l'altr' è la convenenza.

46  This last for evermore is cancelled not
47  Unless complied with, and concerning this
48  With such precision has above been spoken.

46  Quest' ultima già mai non si cancella
47  se non servata; e intorno di lei
48  sì preciso di sopra si favella:




49  Therefore it was enjoined upon the Hebrews
50  To offer still, though sometimes what was offered
51  Might be commuted, as thou ought'st to know.

49  però necessitato fu a li Ebrei
50  pur l'offerere, ancor ch'alcuna offerta
51  si permutasse, come saver dei.

52  The other, which is known to thee as matter,
53  May well indeed be such that one errs not
54  If it for other matter be exchanged.

52  L'altra, che per materia t'è aperta,
53  puote ben esser tal, che non si falla
54  se con altra materia si converta.

55  But let none shift the burden on his shoulder
56  At his arbitrament, without the turning
57  Both of the white and of the yellow key;

55  Ma non trasmuti carco a la sua spalla
56  per suo arbitrio alcun, sanza la volta
57  e de la chiave bianca e de la gialla;

58  And every permutation deem as foolish,
59  If in the substitute the thing relinquished,
60  As the four is in six, be not contained.

58  e ogne permutanza credi stolta,
59  se la cosa dimessa in la sorpresa
60  come 'l quattro nel sei non è raccolta.

61  Therefore whatever thing has so great weight
62  In value that it drags down every balance,
63  Cannot be satisfied with other spending.

61  Però qualunque cosa tanto pesa
62  per suo valor che tragga ogne bilancia,
63 sodisfar non si può con altra spesa.

64  Let mortals never take a vow in jest;
65   Be faithful and not blind in doing that,
66  As Jephthah was in his first offering,

64  Non prendan li mortali il voto a ciancia;
65  siate fedeli, e a ciò far non bieci,
66  come Ieptè a la sua prima mancia;

67  Whom more beseemed to say, 'I have done wrong,
68  Than to do worse by keeping; and as foolish
69  Thou the great leader of the Greeks wilt find,

67  cui più si convenia dicer 'Mal feci,'
68  che, servando, far peggio; e così stolto
69  ritrovar puoi il gran duca de' Greci,

70  Whence wept Iphigenia her fair face,
71  And made for her both wise and simple weep,
72  Who heard such kind of worship spoken of.'

70  onde pianse Efigènia il suo bel volto,
71  e fé pianger di sé i folli e i savi
72  ch'udir parlar di così fatto cólto.

73  Christians, be ye more serious in your movements;
74  Be ye not like a feather at each wind,
75  And think not every water washes you.

73  Siate, Cristiani, a muovervi più gravi:
74  non siate come penna ad ogne vento,
75  e non crediate ch'ogne acqua vi lavi.

76  Ye have the Old and the New Testament,
77  And the Pastor of the Church who guideth you
78  Let this suffice you unto your salvation.

76  Avete il novo e 'l vecchio Testamento,
 77  e 'l pastor de la Chiesa che vi guida;
78  questo vi basti a vostro salvamento.

79  If evil appetite cry aught else to you,
80  Be ye as men, and not as silly sheep,
81  So that the Jew among you may not mock you.

79  Se mala cupidigia altro vi grida,
80  uomini siate, e non pecore matte,
81  sì che 'l Giudeo di voi tra voi non rida!

82  Be ye not as the lamb that doth abandon
83  Its mother's milk, and frolicsome and simple
84  Combats at its own pleasure with itself."

82  Non fate com' agnel che lascia il latte
83  de la sua madre, e semplice e lascivo
84  seco medesmo a suo piacer combatte!”

85  Thus Beatrice to me even as I write it;
86  Then all desireful turned herself again
87  To that part where the world is most alive.

85  Così Beatrice a me com'ïo scrivo;
86  poi si rivolse tutta disïante
87  a quella parte ove 'l mondo è più vivo.

88  Her silence and her change of countenance
89  Silence imposed upon my eager mind,
90  That had already in advance new questions;

88  Lo suo tacere e 'l trasmutar sembiante
89  puoser silenzio al mio cupido ingegno,
90  che già nuove questioni avea davante;

91  And as an arrow that upon the mark
92  Strikes ere the bowstring quiet hath become,
93  So did we speed into the second realm.

91  e sì come saetta che nel segno
92  percuote pria che sia la corda queta,
93  così corremmo nel secondo regno.

94  My Lady there so joyful I beheld,
95  As into the brightness of that heaven she entered,
96  More luminous thereat the planet grew;

94  Quivi la donna mia vid' io sì lieta,
95  come nel lume di quel ciel si mise,
96  che più lucente se ne fé 'l pianeta.

97  And if the star itself was changed and smiled,
98  What became I, who by my nature am
99  Exceeding mutable in every guise!

97  E se la stella si cambiò e rise,
98  qual mi fec' io che pur da mia natura
99  trasmutabile son per tutte guise!

100  As, in a fish-pond which is pure and tranquil,
101  The fishes draw to that which from without
102  Comes in such fashion that their food they deem it;

100  Come 'n peschiera ch'è tranquilla e pura
101  traggonsi i pesci a ciò che vien di fori
102  per modo che lo stimin lor pastura,

103  So I beheld more than a thousand splendours
104  Drawing towards us, and in each was heard:
105  "Lo, this is she who shall increase our love."

103  sì vid' io ben più di mille splendori
104  trarsi ver' noi, e in ciascun s'udia:
105  “Ecco chi crescerà li nostri amori.”

106  And as each one was coming unto us,
107  Full of beatitude the shade was seen,
108  By the effulgence clear that issued from it.

106  E sì come ciascuno a noi venìa,
107  vedeasi l'ombra piena di letizia
108  nel folgór chiaro che di lei uscia.

109  Think, Reader, if what here is just beginning
110  No farther should proceed, how thou wouldst have
111  An agonizing need of knowing more;

109  Pensa, lettor, se quel che qui s'inizia
110  non procedesse, come tu avresti
111  di più savere angosciosa carizia;

112  And of thyself thou'lt see how I from these
113  Was in desire of hearing their conditions,
114  As they unto mine eyes were manifest.

112  e per te vederai come da questi
113  m'era in disio d'udir lor condizioni,
114  sì come a li occhi mi fur manifesti.

115  "O thou well-born, unto whom Grace concedes
116  To see the thrones of the eternal triumph,
117  Or ever yet the warfare be abandoned

115  “O bene nato a cui veder li troni
116  del trïunfo etternal concede grazia
117  prima che la milizia s'abbandoni,

118  With light that through the whole of heaven is spread
119  Kindled are we, and hence if thou desirest
120  To know of us, at thine own pleasure sate thee."

118  del lume che per tutto il ciel si spazia
119  noi semo accesi; e però, se disii
120  di noi chiarirti, a tuo piacer ti sazia.”

121  Thus by some one among those holy spirits
122  Was spoken, and by Beatrice: "Speak, speak
123  Securely, and believe them even as Gods."

121  Così da un di quelli spirti pii
122  detto mi fu; e da Beatrice: “Dì, dì
123  sicuramente, e credi come a dii.”

124  "Well I perceive how thou dost nest thyself
125  In thine own light, and drawest it from thine eyes,
126  Because they coruscate when thou dost smile,

124  “Io veggio ben sì come tu t'annidi
125  nel proprio lume, e che de li occhi il traggi,
126  perch' e' corusca sì come tu ridi;

127  But know not who thou art, nor why thou hast,
128  Spirit august, thy station in the sphere
129  That veils itself to men in alien rays."

127  ma non so chi tu se', né perché aggi,
128  anima degna, il grado de la spera
128  che si vela a' mortai con altrui raggi.”

130  This said I in direction of the light
131  Which first had spoken to me; whence it became
132  By far more lucent than it was before.

130  Questo diss' io diritto a la lumera
131  che pria m'avea parlato; ond' ella fessi
132  lucente più assai di quel ch'ell' era.

133  Even as the sun, that doth conceal himself
134  By too much light, when heat has worn away
135  The tempering influence of the vapours dense,

133  Sì come il sol che si cela elli stessi
134  per troppa luce, come 'l caldo ha róse
135  le temperanze d'i vapori spessi,

136  By greater rapture thus concealed itself
137  In its own radiance the figure saintly,
138  And thus close, close enfolded answered me

136  per più letizia sì mi si nascose
137  dentro al suo raggio la figura santa;
138  e così chiusa chiusa mi rispuose

139  In fashion as the following Canto sings.

139 nel modo che 'l seguente canto canta.

Canto VI
The heaven of Mercury may be compared to Dialectics because of two properties: for Mercury is the smallest star of heaven, because the magnitude of its diameter is not more than 232 miles, according to Alfraganus, who says it is 1/28th of the diameter of the earth, which is 6500 miles; the other property is that in its passage it is veiled by the rays of the sun more than any other star. These two properties are found in Dialectics, for Dialectics is less in substance than any other science, for it is entirely constituted by and contained within that text alone which is found in the Old Art and in the New; and its passage is veiled more than that of any science, in that it proceeds by a more sophistical and polemical mode of argument than any other.

Convivio, Book II, Chapter 13

I don't think it's wise for a reader to hold that Dante can be overestimated, which is not quite the same thing as being uncritical of whatever the text presents.  Dante has done his job, and more than done his job, and if the readers are to benefit from what cost Dante so much, they must allow the texts to enter into them and do their work.  What is that work?  It has historical elements, as it does here in Paradiso, Canto VI, but it is not history, perhaps it is more like a revelation of history's effects and even more crucially, history's potential to influence the present and the future.  Of course, too, the work has allegorical implications, but those implications are not historically fixed in the early 14th Century.  It certainly has moral implications, which seem to have been able to survive changes in customs and belief systems in a way that goes beyond Christian ethics as it had developed up to his time, because you don't have to be a Christian to understand the psychological efficacy of his continued moral guidance.  And finally, in its most stable and at the same time most adaptable form, it has an anagogic function, and that function seems to be its foundational core, its seedbed for new forms and new affects and effects.   And it does not seem to matter much if we decide to call that core mystical, spiritual, transformational, organicizational (to coin a word), or to use some Sanskrit word, or Buddhist terminology, or a coinage from quantum mechanics, the Jewish Kabbala, or some concept from aboriginal myth ... when we get down to this level of the work, if we go this far, it works like evolution, capable both of stabilizing and changing, of conserving, adapting, mutating, and/or harmonizing, while all the while remaining the same words in the mouth, the same words on the page, in whatever translation it gloms on to.  Because we know that these beautiful, profound, exciting 14th Century Tuscan Italian Dialect wonders quite audaciously beg to be translated, and to extend their rhizome into other linguistic ecosystems, while those translations also spawn readers and commentators, who have to scurry back to the originals to prove, disprove, clarify, or obfuscate their impressions.  I think of these things as a sort of way to mark time, when I'm trying to digest, or rather, be digested by, the next canto on my agenda.  It would be so easy to just take the literal level of the work, read the historical commentary on this history, put the whole thing into some kind of mental museum case, and just admire and wonder at it, as one might admire the fossil of a fantastic extinct animal, as a way to pass the time on a rainy afternoon, a way to garner a little culture, but not too much ... this would not be a critter you would want to run into on the way back to the car.  This canto on history and justice, looks so easy to confine in that case, but ... 

 Well, from the above, we already know that the whole of the Commedia is geometrical in the sense that in addition to its vertical aspect of narration — the journey of the aspirant through the times and places of the afterlife — there is always also this horizontal aspect of the poem, which is traditionally arranged thusly: 

Literal
Allegorical
Moral
Anagogic

These aspects cannot be separated as say notes on the staffs of music are visually separated on a printed page, but like the sounds generated by the musicians, they interweave, overlap, sometimes one of them soloing, sometimes the members of the group dialoging, sometimes all of them sounding in consort, either dissonantly or harmoniously.  All this is easy enough to grasp theoretically, but not always too easy to grasp as the horizontal elements play out through the vertical movement the narrative, and this is especially so when one element contradicts another or when one element undercuts or changes the meaning of another in the case of an ironic cast of one expression coloring an apparently sincere expression or in the case of one expression reversing another's  "meaning" in a cross-current.  One question that stands out for me is this: Is it possible that the spirits in Paradise can be victims of self-deception in a way that perpetuates their blessedness as the shades in Hell by their self-deception perpetuate their damnation?  Are the blessed confined to their sphere by an ideal of service to the greater good as the damned are confined to their sphere by an ideal peculiar to their own brand of selfishness?  And, here, I want to incorporate, at least tangentially one familiar Freudian idea, i.e., that of the ego, and one idea from magical traditions, i.e., that of the Egregore.  We are familiar with the ego as a sort of emergent property from a vast host of unconscious psychological and physiological processes, but we are less familiar with the Egregore-concept, which postulates that there is also a virtual identity analogous to the ego that emerges from some social or historical collectivity.  The Egregore emerges from ideals of a Nationality, or ethnicity, or even from such things as sports affiliation or company cultures.  Christianity as it arises in an historical context is an Egregore, and Dante, the historical figure, in his ego self, was embedded in this Egregore.  But was his poetic self likewise embedded?  Or did he find, through these texts, a way through to transcendence of both ego and Egregore.  Did he find a soul or spirit who operations remain in bliss in spite of the machinations which emerge as personality, evolutionary development, or historical imperatives?  When we begin to approach the text from the spheres of such questions, then the fosses, the ledges, and the heavens respectively of the Inferno, the Purgatorio, and the Paradiso begin to reveal their transcendent natures.  We have to leave whatever speculation we might have about how Dante, a personage of 14th Century Tuscany, believed or felt about these issues, because he too had a conscious and unconscious self, and his purposes could not be revealed by only his ego side, even if he were still around to ask.  What speaks now is the text, and to further refine this consideration, it is the text as it does its work in the conscious/unconscious self of each individual reader.  The text is the meeting ground of the mutual faith of poet and reader to create the poem.  The word faith has always been subject to spoilage by the actions of those who appropriate it for selfish ends, or for the Egregore of a religion,  and the word fealty denoted a concept that held the whole Medieval world, with its social hierarchies and extreme stratifications, into a semi-workable governance, but, that being said, we can't throw away all feelings of trust around what the text is doing inside of us and among us as we attempt to assimilate it, and also as we permit it to assimilate us.  Skepticism as to the importance, and I would say for me, sacredness, of the text is more than anything else a dodge to protect one's ignorance, to stay safely nestled in the down or thorns of one's own concepts about what words are and about what they can do vis a vis any cosmological questions concerning the self or Creation and creativity.  And, having said this, it is just as clear to me that I cannot summon this faith without recognizing that its tissue is absolutely riddled with the dark matter of cynicism, doubt, laziness, hopelessness, confusion, boredom, derision, randomness and the like, and that these elements cannot be separated from either the text or my reading of it.  One could say that these darker elements are the causes of the suffering we feel when confronting this disunity inside ourselves (Justinian in the text says in line 21: ogne contradizione e falsa e vera — each contradiction is false and true.).  But so are the lighter elements (And Justinian and the whole planet of Mercury/dialectic/logic is veiled by the Sun/Apollo/Poetic Inspiration), which tell us that Whitman was on to something when he declared: "Do I contradict myself, very well then, I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes)."  Any text that is going to mimic and therefore embody Creation and creativity has to express aspects of both faith and doubt, formation and destruction, in the operations of its elements.  And as I've proceeded in reading Dante, I am struck by how faithful his texts are in expressing these apparently conflicting and contrasting elements.  I don't believe that there is any bedrock of truth here, yet there does seem to be a process of truthiness, there does seem to be to be something which embraces the contradictions, something which I am going to call a kind of ether or solute of aesthetics, a kind of deep and abiding wonder at the immense beauty which is imbued in both the triumphs and tragedies of Creation, and is equally present, though not similarly expressed, in all three canticles of the Commedia.  Beatrice embodies it, and love expresses it, but the Nothing — in both its noun-ness as Nothingness, and its verb-ness as a process of erasure — contains it, this IT being what was, what is, and the potential for what is to be.  What separates the damned in the Inferno and the blessed in the Paradiso, and what is being revealed to the pilgrims in the Purgatorio, is an orientation towards this aesthetic.  In brief: Are the spirits experiencing themselves and their situation as beautiful or grotesque, as blessed or as blasted?  And if this aesthetical theological cosmology is the underlying, or in the schema above, anagogic fundamental of the text, how do readers catch the ghost in the machine which makes of the machine a living organism, a meaning-matter endowed with spirit?

From the Convivio we can ascertain this.

Dialectic/Logic is of less magnitude than the earth. 

Dialectic/logic is veiled by the brighter light of the sun.

Dialectic/logic is of less substance than any of the other sciences, being entirely textual.

Dialectic/logic promotes itself through that which is sophistical (fallacious?) and polemic (argumentative?).

Note that all of these definitions are seemingly detracting, and if that is so, than how can dialectic/logic by itself be a methodology for arriving at anything like a universal truth?  To use an irony to promote an irony, in a paraphrase of Polonius: By indirection we might still find direction out.
