And in this canto, wherein there are as many as 40 historical figures mentioned, it may well seem contradictory to say that much of what is said here is ahistorical, in the sense that the text traverses the distance between historical acts and destiny's purposes, and reveals how often the one is negated by the other and vice versa.  Just so, it seems strange that the main protagonist of the canto is not its primary speaker, Justinian, but Romeo of Villeneuve, a  personage of low birth who, like the historical Dante, was an exile, i.e., the courtier, steward and chief minister of the Provençal Count, Raymond Berenger.  Romeo does not speak, does not appear, but he is the hidden composer of this canto's Contrapuntus.  He is the Dantean doppelganger, the composer who sings through the prosaic speaking voice of his amanuensis, Justinian, that (line 124) Diverse voci fanno dolci note (differing voices make sweet music).  The fact that Romeo, the initiator, shows up here, at the end of the canto, shows us that here we have to go back in order to go forward, which is logical nonsense in prose, but, in this case, the very logic of poetry.      

Remember how Beatrice shows that surface interpretations, as in Plato's Timaeus, might veil deeper verities, foreshadowing Justinian’s statement about contradictions inclusive of opposing positions, as if dialectic were true to its name, and always provocative of what Blake called a "cloven fiction," its logic always veiling an underlying illogic.  My intuition sees through this glass darkly, and what it sees is that the emergent surface effects of the ego/Egregore veil, distort, or altogether hide the deeper processes which give rise to them.  We are sinking in deep waters here, and the seeming historical, judicial themes of this canto may well be but the lightest surface tension, which, if we pause at any moment to consider, might well give way to an unsuspected depth, a depth which belies the surface narrative about Roman hegemony, pax Romana, and the establishment of a single monarch with a spiritual advisor as the preconditions for an harmonious civil society.  But things don't necessarily confine themselves to any level particular level of interpretation.  Starting anywhere, we can always postulate another level as a deeper level, some negation of any given surface argument may itself veil a deeper affirmation.  I believe that the dialectic/logic which the text utilizes here is precisely (or nebulously) this kind probing.

I want to deviate for a moment and add a commentary about Bateson's Mind and Nature: A Necessary Unity, because I learned from this book three things that helped me through the issues presented in this canto.  One: "Logic Is a Poor Model of Cause and Effect."  Two: "Language Commonly Stresses Only One Side of Any Interaction."  And three: "Stability and Change describe parts of our descriptions."  To get at why our usual didactic positions are so inherently limiting, we have to approach them from the double descriptions of poetry, its narrative and metaphoric, vertical and horizontal aspects, which is exactly what this canto and the entire Commedia does.  As we penetrate more deeply in the fourfold unity of poetry as listed above, it begins to dawn on us that there is no way to logically solve a contradiction or politically resolve opposing factions, and that the mortal psyche, split between conscious aspirations and unconscious desires, can never from the plane of mortality alone achieve peace.  The propositions which this canto embodies are poetic and are exemplified by Justinian's acceptance of the Agapetus revelation that, like Christ, we are comprised of but one nature of harmoniously melded aspects: human and divine.  As soon as that revelation is experienced and the whole being is saturated with this one harmonizing totality, then the laws that govern peace, as a thermostat governs temperature, or as immune systems govern the human body, are shown to be perpetually operational, and there is no need to use external violence to enforce them, nor are they subverted even by the existence of violence.  This canto, as does the entire Commedia, champions poetry over polemics and poetry over politics, and it is through the linguistic maneuvers of poetry, and not those of dialectic and logic, that we might come to that revelation of unity which the human/divine nature of Jesus embodied.  The model reading is that crucifixion and resurrection are a single act, or if one prefers, transgression and forgiveness are a single act.  These types of apparently conflicting experiences can only be seen as one in what is traditionally called the "fullness of time," (lines 55 - 57: Greek: Kairos, Latin: plenitudinem temporis), so that one can begin to comprehend the allegory of the Roman empire, or of any totalizing political system, with all of its history of violence and supression, as an instrument of the divine, this violence, in the very act of its bloody and unjust commission, summons forth the conditions which expose mortality as an insufficient instrument of peace and blessedness, until it is fused with eternity's perpetual resurrection and forgiveness.  The contradictions of sequential time can only be resolved from the metaposition of eternity.  Unless we realize this while reading Canto VI of the Paradiso, we can only read it as irony.  (And it doesn't matter if the conscious Dante knew this or not, because the poet's unconscious certainly did express this irony as one aspect of the text.  Just think for example of Justinian's use of the word "mirrare" (line 48), a rare word or perhaps a coinage meaning to embalm or preserve in myrrh.  How can this metaphor for his codex of laws comparing it to a corpse whose stink is masked by a the expensive application of this incense, be anything but ironic?)  From a strictly mortal/historical point of view, Justinian's claims that the history  of the Roman empire is one of peace, and the violent examples he gives as premises to prove his conclusion, are glaringly nonsensical.  And the refrain of You know, you know, you know that rings through the territory of his exposition are a reminder that his exemplars are anything but those of peace, but rather those of the most extreme forms of violence, rape, and rapine.  To see things otherwise is to follow the "normal" sequence of history, but that's not what Dante presents here, because he starts with peace and harmony, just as he started in Piccarda's speech by showing that the inconstant spirits in the Heaven of the Moon are afloat in the entire sea of bliss.   What follows here with Justinian and his ilk in the Heaven of Mercury are spirits afloat like fish in a pond.  Yes, the pond is smaller, but the condition of those in its solute is no different than those blissfully suspended in the currents of the ocean. (We know we are still in the domain of water-metaphors here because Justinian maps the progress of the Empire through rivers, their valleys, and the territories, which they drain.  The text ... and the empire ... goes on even to the limits of water, to the deserts, and the dry lightning with which the weather itself marks a fiery boundary to the habitable world.)  And this same beginning preceding the end continues with the metaphor of the arrow, first hitting the target, and then being released from the bowstring.  And again, we see this reversal of time in the image of Constantine reversing the natural movement of the sun and the empire from east to west to that of west to east, the east, where Justinian, as Caesar purified the law, and the west where Belisarius — and we must not forget that historically Justinian, far from rewarding his general and effigy for his own violent nature — repudiated the great warrior, stripped him of his possessions, had him blinded, and left him to die in political exile and penurious beggary.  It is worth noting as well that Agapetus came to Justinian only after Justinian had completed his reforms of the law, and that many of the heavenly sanctioned acts of the Roman republic and empire were carried out before Christ's birth and resurrection.  What the poetry is presenting here is the fullness of time as a kind of orb or sphere, rather than a sequential series of dot-like events on a line, and as has been pointed out, all of the canto sixes in the Commedia deal with the same issue of politics so that if we read backwards we see suspended in its sphere the contraction of the idea of the peace of the Roman Empire back to its most restricted and violent local conflicts, those of Dante's own time, of the Ghibellines and the Guelphs, both of which factions promoted violence as a method of establishing a lasting political harmony.  As the slogan of the nineteen sixties put it: Fighting for peace is like fucking for chastity, and with the rape bookends of the seven kings in this canto, Justinian is saying the same thing.  As long as we hold to the cloven fiction that time and history are a series of sequentially arranged causes and effects, we can never see the sphere of eternal time as a sort of solute in which all actions are suspended in a kind of hidden fluid of affinities, wherein what we view as cause and what we view as effects are only parts of a whole, neither of which factional fragments are in any sense determining, as it is this organizing power of Time in its sort of I Ching-like totality which from moment to moment is expressed either as a moment of peace or of violence, not because Time has evolved, but because we see its actions either from the unified harmony of human/divine or from the fragmented position of our human, historical, evolutionary and mortal condition alone.  What counts, as we might express it in a sort of Bhagavad Gita-like allusion, is our virtue, our vertú, or our power.  We cannot control outcomes, the solute of the Times does that.  And what is the chief virtue?  It is, as Churhill said "courage" because it insures all the others.  We only choose our attitude towards the actions that our Times demand of us ... that is to say, our courage in facing the moment and in fulfilling our temporal destinies so that we might enjoy that courage as our eternal reward. 

1  "After that Constantine the eagle turned
2  Against the course of heaven, which it had followed
3  Behind the ancient who Lavinia took,

1  “Poscia che Costantin l'aquila volse
2  contr' al corso del ciel, ch'ella seguio
3  dietro a l'antico che Lavina tolse,

4  Two hundred years and more the bird of God
5  In the extreme of Europe held itself,
6  Near to the mountains whence it issued first;

4  cento e cent' anni e più l'uccel di Dio
5  ne lo stremo d'Europa si ritenne,
6  vicino a' monti de' quai prima uscìo;

7  And under shadow of the sacred plumes
8  It governed there the world from hand to hand,
9  And, changing thus, upon mine own alighted.

7  e sotto l'ombra de le sacre penne
8  governò 'l mondo lì di mano in mano,
9  e, sì cangiando, in su la mia pervenne.

10  Caesar I was, and am Justinian,
11  Who, by the will of primal Love I feel,
12  Took from the laws the useless and redundant;

10  Cesare fui e son Iustinïano,
11  che, per voler del primo amor ch'i' sento,
12  d'entro le leggi trassi il troppo e 'l vano.

13  And ere unto the work I was attent,
14  One nature to exist in Christ, not more,
15  Believed, and with such faith was I contented.

13  E prima ch'io a l'ovra fossi attento,
14  una natura in Cristo esser, non piùe,
15  credea, e di tal fede era contento;

16  But blessed Agapetus, he who was
17  The supreme pastor, to the faith sincere
18  Pointed me out the way by words of his.

16  ma 'l benedetto Agapito, che fue
17  sommo pastore, a la fede sincera
18  mi dirizzò con le parole sue.

19  Him I believed, and what was his assertion
20  I now see clearly, even as thou seest
21  Each contradiction to be false and true.

19  Io li credetti; e ciò che 'n sua fede era,
20  vegg' io or chiaro sì, come tu vedi
21  ogne contradizione e falsa e vera.

22  As soon as with the Church I moved my feet,
23  God in his grace it pleased with this high task
24  To inspire me, and I gave me wholly to it,

22  Tosto che con la Chiesa mossi i piedi,
23  a Dio per grazia piacque di spirarmi
24  l'alto lavoro, e tutto 'n lui mi diedi;

25  And to my Belisarius I commended
26  The arms, to which was heaven's right hand so joined
27  It was a signal that I should repose.

25  e al mio Belisar commendai l'armi,
26  cui la destra del ciel fu sì congiunta,
27  che segno fu ch'i' dovessi posarmi.

28  Now here to the first question terminates
29  My answer; but the character thereof
30  Constrains me to continue with a sequel,

28  Or qui a la question prima s'appunta
29  la mia risposta; ma sua condizione
30  mi stringe a seguitare alcuna giunta,

31  In order that thou see with how great reason
32  Men move against the standard sacrosanct,
33  Both who appropriate and who oppose it.

31  perché tu veggi con quanta ragione
32  si move contr' al sacrosanto segno
33  e chi 'l s'appropria e chi a lui s'oppone.

34  Behold how great a power has made it worthy
35  Of reverence, beginning from the hour
36  When Pallas died to give it sovereignty.

34  Vedi quanta virtù l'ha fatto degno
35  di reverenza; e cominciò da l'ora
36  che Pallante morì per darli regno.

37  Thou knowest it made in Alba its abode
38  Three hundred years and upward, till at last
39  The three to three fought for it yet again.

37  Tu sai ch'el fece in Alba sua dimora
38  per trecento anni e oltre, infino al fine
39  che i tre a' tre pugnar per lui ancora.

40  Thou knowest what it achieved from Sabine wrong
41  Down to Lucretia's sorrow, in seven kings
42  O'ercoming round about the neighboring nations;

40  E sai ch'el fé dal mal de le Sabine
41  al dolor di Lucrezia in sette regi,
42  vincendo intorno le genti vicine.

43  Thou knowest what it achieved, borne by the Romans
44  Illustrious against Brennus, against Pyrrhus,
45  Against the other princes and confederates.

43  Sai quel ch'el fé portato da li egregi
44  Romani incontro a Brenno, incontro a Pirro,
45  incontro a li altri principi e collegi;

46  Torquatus thence and Quinctius, who from locks
47  Unkempt was named, Decii and Fabii,
48  Received the fame I willingly embalm;

46  onde Torquato e Quinzio, che dal cirro
47  negletto fu nomato, i Deci e ' Fabi
48  ebber la fama che volontier mirro.

49  It struck to earth the pride of the Arabians,
50  Who, following Hannibal, had passed across
51  The Alpine ridges, Po, from which thou glidest;

49  Esso atterrò l'orgoglio de li Aràbi
50  che di retro ad Anibale passaro
51  l'alpestre rocce, Po, di che tu labi.

52  Beneath it triumphed while they yet were young
53  Pompey and Scipio, and to the hill
54  Beneath which thou wast born it bitter seemed;

52  Sott' esso giovanetti trïunfaro
53  Scipïone e Pompeo; e a quel colle
54  sotto 'l qual tu nascesti parve amaro.

55  Then, near unto the time when heaven had willed
56  To bring the whole world to its mood serene,
57  Did Caesar by the will of Rome assume it.

55  Poi, presso al tempo che tutto 'l ciel volle
56  redur lo mondo a suo modo sereno,
57  Cesare per voler di Roma il tolle.

58  What it achieved from Var unto the Rhine,
59  Isere beheld and Saone, beheld the Seine,
60  And every valley whence the Rhone is filled;

58  E quel che fé da Varo infino a Reno,
59  Isara vide ed Era e vide Senna
60  e ogne valle onde Rodano è pieno.

61  What it achieved when it had left Ravenna,
62  And leaped the Rubicon, was such a flight
63  That neither tongue nor pen could follow it.

61  Quel che fé poi ch'elli uscì di Ravenna
62  e saltò Rubicon, fu di tal volo,
63  che nol seguiteria lingua né penna.

64  Round towards Spain it wheeled its legions; then
65  Towards Durazzo, and Pharsalia smote
66  That to the calid Nile was felt the pain.

64  Inver' la Spagna rivolse lo stuolo,
65  poi ver' Durazzo, e Farsalia percosse
66 sì ch'al Nil caldo si sentì del duolo.

67  Antandros and the Simois, whence it started,
68  It saw again, and there where Hector lies,
69  And ill for Ptolemy then roused itself.

67  Antandro e Simeonta, onde si mosse,
68  rivide e là dov' Ettore si cuba;
69  e mal per Tolomeo poscia si scosse.

70  From thence it came like lightning upon Juba;
71  Then wheeled itself again into your West,
72  Where the Pompeian clarion it heard.

70  Da indi scese folgorando a Iuba;
71  onde si volse nel vostro occidente,
72  ove sentia la pompeana tuba.

73  From what it wrought with the next standard-bearer
74  Brutus and Cassius howl in Hell together,
75  And Modena and Perugia dolent were;

73  Di quel che fé col baiulo seguente,
74  Bruto con Cassio ne l'inferno latra,
75  e Modena e Perugia fu dolente.

76  Still doth the mournful Cleopatra weep
77  Because thereof, who, fleeing from before it,
78  Took from the adder sudden and black death.

76  Piangene ancor la trista Cleopatra,
77 che, fuggendoli innanzi, dal colubro
78  la morte prese subitana e atra.

79  With him it ran even to the Red Sea shore;
80  With him it placed the world in so great peace,
81  That unto Janus was his temple closed.

79  Con costui corse infino al lito rubro;
80  con costui puose il mondo in tanta pace,
81  che fu serrato a Giano il suo delubro.

82  But what the standard that has made me speak
83  Achieved before, and after should achieve
84  Throughout the mortal realm that lies beneath it,

82  Ma ciò che 'l segno che parlar mi face
83  fatto avea prima e poi era fatturo
84  per lo regno mortal ch'a lui soggiace,

85  Becometh in appearance mean and dim,
86  If in the hand of the third Caesar seen
87  With eye unclouded and affection pure,

85  diventa in apparenza poco e scuro,
86  se in mano al terzo Cesare si mira
87  con occhio chiaro e con affetto puro;

88  Because the living Justice that inspires me
89  Granted it, in the hand of him I speak of,
90  The glory of doing vengeance for its wrath.

88  ché la viva giustizia che mi spira,
89  li concedette, in mano a quel ch'i' dico,
90  gloria di far vendetta a la sua ira.

91  Now here attend to what I answer thee;
92  Later it ran with Titus to do vengeance
93  Upon the vengeance of the ancient sin.

91  Or qui t'ammira in ciò ch'io ti replìco:
92  poscia con Tito a far vendetta corse
93  de la vendetta del peccato antico.

94  And when the tooth of Lombardy had bitten
95  The Holy Church, then underneath its wings
96  Did Charlemagne victorious succor her.

94  E quando il dente longobardo morse
95  la Santa Chiesa, sotto le sue ali
96  Carlo Magno, vincendo, la soccorse.

97  Now hast thou power to judge of such as those
98  Whom I accused above, and of their crimes,
99  Which are the cause of all your miseries.

97  Omai puoi giudicar di quei cotali
98  ch'io accusai di sopra e di lor falli,
99  che son cagion di tutti vostri mali.

100  To the public standard one the yellow lilies
101  Opposes, the other claims it for a party,
102  So that 'tis hard to see which sins the most.

100  L'uno al pubblico segno i gigli gialli
101  oppone, e l'altro appropria quello a parte,
102 sì ch'è forte a veder chi più si falli.

103  Let, let the Ghibellines ply their handicraft
104  Beneath some other standard; for this ever
105  Ill follows he who it and justice parts.

103  Faccian li Ghibellin, faccian lor arte
104  sott' altro segno, ché mal segue quello
105  sempre chi la giustizia e lui diparte;

106  And let not this new Charles e'er strike it down,
107  He and his Guelfs, but let him fear the talons
108  That from a nobler lion stripped the fell.

106  e non l'abbatta esto Carlo novello
107  coi Guelfi suoi, ma tema de li artigli
108  ch'a più alto leon trasser lo vello.

109  Already oftentimes the sons have wept
110  The father's crime; and let him not believe
111  That God will change His scutcheon for the lilies.

109  Molte fïate già pianser li figli
110  per la colpa del padre, e non si creda
111  che Dio trasmuti l'armi per suoi gigli!

112  This little planet doth adorn itself
113  With the good spirits that have active been,
114  That fame and honour might come after them;

112  Questa picciola stella si correda
113  d'i buoni spirti che son stati attivi
114  perché onore e fama li succeda:

115  And whensoever the desires mount thither,
116  Thus deviating, must perforce the rays
117  Of the true love less vividly mount upward.

115  e quando li disiri poggian quivi,
116  sì disvïando, pur convien che i raggi
117  del vero amore in sù poggin men vivi.
118  But in commensuration of our wages
119  With our desert is portion of our joy,
120  Because we see them neither less nor greater.

118  Ma nel commensurar d'i nostri gaggi
119  col merto è parte di nostra letizia,
120  perché non li vedem minor né maggi.

121  Herein doth living Justice sweeten so
122  Affection in us, that for evermore
123  It cannot warp to any iniquity.

121  Quindi addolcisce la viva giustizia
122  in noi l'affetto sì, che non si puote
123  torcer già mai ad alcuna nequizia.

124  Voices diverse make up sweet melodies;
125  So in this life of ours the seats diverse
126  Render sweet harmony among these spheres;

124  Diverse voci fanno dolci note;
125  così diversi scanni in nostra vita
126  rendon dolce armonia tra queste rote.

127  And in the compass of this present pearl
128  Shineth the sheen of Romeo, of whom
129  The grand and beauteous work was ill rewarded.

127  E dentro a la presente margarita
128  luce la luce di Romeo, di cui
129  fu l'ovra grande e bella mal gradita.

130  But the Provencals who against him wrought,
131  They have not laughed, and therefore ill goes he
132  Who makes his hurt of the good deeds of others.

130  Ma i Provenzai che fecer contra lui
131  non hanno riso; e però mal cammina
132  qual si fa danno del ben fare altrui.

133  Four daughters, and each one of them a queen,
134  Had Raymond Berenger, and this for him
135  Did Romeo, a poor man and a pilgrim;

133  Quattro figlie ebbe, e ciascuna reina,
134  Ramondo Beringhiere, e ciò li fece
135  Romeo, persona umìle e peregrina.

136  And then malicious words incited him
137  To summon to a reckoning this just man,
138  Who rendered to him seven and five for ten.

136  E poi il mosser le parole biece
137  a dimandar ragione a questo giusto,
138  che li assegnò sette e cinque per diece,

139  Then he departed poor and stricken in years,
140  And if the world could know the heart he had,
141  In begging bit by bit his livelihood,

139  indi partissi povero e vetusto;
140  e se 'l mondo sapesse il cor ch'elli ebbe
141  mendicando sua vita a frusto a frusto,

142  Though much it laud him, it would laud him more."

142  assai lo loda, e più lo loderebbe.”

Canto VII
(Preludium/Confession: I suppose one reason I have for writing these notes, of which I am likely to be the sole reader, is to discover for myself some transformational key such as Jung discovered with his psychological insights through a reinterpretation of alchemical texts.  This poem shines a light upon areas of the psyche which could not otherwise be illuminated, and, with equal fervor, it casts into shadow much that one took for granted as a result of social conditioning.)

As one investigates the body, either through dissection or instrumentation, or by the apparati of one's own feeling sense, at some point one is struck by the fact that each level of examination appears only as a surface, the penetration of which leads only to another surface, the idea of function, of life, at every surface retreating into another surface, the whole becoming ever more ephemeral but never fundamentally causal.  It is as if the operation of the mind transforms the object of its contemplation into that which is conducive to its own tools and habits of perception, so that mind itself becomes not only the determinant of how we see but also of the qualities of what we see.  I find the interpretation of Dante's text to be much the same, commentaries, insights, lead to further commentary and insight but nothing is final, and all that we discover about the text becomes an analogue for anything possible to be discovered by the mind in search of itself.  What is this glossalia of Hebrew and Latin that begins this canto, and how are these musical notes transformed into a double light doubling itself, which move as in a dance of  swiftly hurrying lights receding suddenly in the distance as the distance?  Besides the meeting of surface and subsurface at a distinguishing membranous surface, the collusion/collision of photons meeting photons, besides matter and mind, there is this relationship between the two, wherein surface becomes something impossible both to dispense with or to altogether elucidate, an aesthetic whose new style — if it is new — is not so much descriptive in the meaning of its sounds as by its sounds an invocation of that mind/nature duality mimetic of the divine/human nature of Christ.  What is this boundary between being and not being which sound chases into silence, and which matter loses in the cloud of mind?  Is it love? — the attraction of the question for the answer as sure as the baby's cry releases the mother's milk.  Well, if it is love, it is a love which is in its essence an act of imagination, a devotion that conjures connection between those apparently irreconcilable aspects of existence, which logic alone can never conjoin.  We found in the Heaven of the Moon how the inconstancy of grammar spelled out the constancy of salvation for those who had been inconstant in their vows.  And we find in the Heaven of Mercury, a dialectical logic displaying the law as an imbalance of the scales of justice, which find their equilibrium in the salvation of the unjust.  The problems exposed here are insoluble in our three dimensions of space and single dimension of time.  They can only be resolved from the metaposition of another dimension by poetic inference to a universe wherein another degree of freedom is possible, because Time's line is volumized into a simultaneity and the three dimensions of space are linguistically expanded by an imaginative expansion of love.  Is this a communion or a consummation? a linguistic intrusion from a hyperdimension or a poetic escape that leaves the ordinary concerns of such surface dwellers as ourselves lost in a weltering wake of the incomprehensible, and perhaps, from the point of view of our everyday practical concerns, into that which is completely inconsequential to matter or to mind, but indispensable to their relationship.  

An enormous drama is taking place inside of the aspirant Dante, an interior conflict, wherein his voice is swallowed inside of him.   He hears, or he imagines he hears, her childhood nickname, and the mere sound of the syllables BAY  EE CHAY act as a trigger for a conditioned response that sends him into what should be written in capital letters:  THE BEAUTIFUL BEATIFIC STATE, that state that he first felt at the age of nine when gazing for the first time on the nine year-old Beatrice.  He cannot speak, but the text in a flurry of "D" alliterations, sends him reeling back to that moment so vividly described in the Vita Nuova, when once before he did not speak, although here,  gored by doubt, he cries out within himself in a boyhood reiteration of the phrase "IN THE BEGINNING WAS THE WORD" and the Word was a bell tolling three times: Tell her!  Tell her!  Tell her!  

10  Io dubitava e dicea “Dille, dille!”
11  fra me, “dille” dicea, “a la mia donna
12  che mi diseta con le dolci stille.”

Those words express his histrionic thirst to the sweet lady who, alone, through the effluent of her presence, can slake it.  He has to go back to that point of origin again and again because only that feeling gives him the proof that validates this feeling of transcendence, which has lifted him out of the suffering and the corruption that he feels in his own body and in the body politic that has sent him into exile.  Readers who have suffered with him, go back with him through all the ditches of the Inferno, all the torturous ledges of the Purgatorio, and they too know what's at stake in their own bodies, in their own place in history, and they know that no one has so taken to heart that suffering, that injustice displayed throughout all nature and all history, and they too thirst to have that pain justified through some sort of redemption.  They too need to have that pain square somehow with the idea of a Just and Good God, who created a creation so like Himself, so full of pain and corruption in all its mortal elements, in all its plant and animal kingdoms, but so full also of THE BEAUTIFUL BEATIFIC STATE, when, in any moment, all of suffering material matter might be suddenly seen in a NEW STYLE, in a light of praise for what had been in the silent, love-struck self ineffable.  Here, a smile, a word from that LADY, his lady, our lady — or for women, her adored and adoring man — justifies that pain, makes it unreal, and more than balances the intolerable weight of material agony.  This whole canto is an apology for history's tortures, an argument. not only for the existence of a just and good God, but for a sense of beauty and beatitude that Jesus must have felt at the most excruciating moment of the crucifixion, when the sky was rent, and the earth shook, and the secret was at last revealed.  For those of us who have seen such things as the evil of the Nazi's holocaust, or the wholesale ecological destruction of the planet, or who have contemplated the suicide of a nuclear war.  For those of us who know how stars are born in fiery violence and how they die in the crushing, lightless press of perverse gravity.  For those of us who have seen our loved ones die of cancer, or in war, or by accident or disease, and who have felt those same corruptions invading their own bodies, it seems to me, that none of Beatrice's arguments, her mercurial logic, her tortured dialectics ring true.  Her words are neither just nor justified.  They do not balance the scale.  But her voice, her presence, the sound of that new style, that, that is mesmerizing, and the aspirant upon hearing them falls into a swoon, and in that swoon the spurious and silly arguments for a just God and a good creation are seen in a double light, a light that shows death and corruption as clearly a part of something utterly OTHER, utterly convincing, and self-justifying.   And just as it might dawn us that the very first atoms of the very first stars of our universe still comprise everything that is, still in their self-same dance, to the self-same music, enact the drama of THE BEAUTIFUL BEATIFIC STATE again and again right in the midst of all that temporal and temporary pain and corruption, that, that revelation gives solace, and we think, we feel: Maybe all arguments are hollow, but the poetry is as hallowed as a deathbed confession or an infant's primal cry.

The question is this: Can a reader who does not accept as truth the unstated assumptions that Beatrice makes about the motives of a Christian conceived God, find in the poetry, something underlying her arguments which can strip away those assumptions to reveal the riches of a consciousness — that BEAUTIFUL BEATIFIC STATE — that will give to him or her the same assurances of love that made Dante trust Beatrice's accounts as the ultimate salve to his own fears and doubts — which brings us to another question, Does Dante the poet accept what Dante the aspirant accepts of a cosmology that postulates a God much too much like a fallible human in His motives for love and hate, vengeance, justice, and mercy, a God, too much like ourselves, and much, much too full of those all too human attributes to explain the vast miracle of Creation, even in the limited conception of ALL THAT IS,  which held sway in Dante's place and time, let alone what we know now of a Universe with at least 42 levels of magnitude from the pangalactic to the subatomic, and even further, to the explorations of the physicists who postulate other universes with additional dimensions that exceed our own three of space and one of time?   Because, there lurks behind Beatrice's seriousness a kind of adolescent quality that we all may remember from college, when with audacious self-importance, and little experience, we junior philosophers asked the same kind of questions as Dante asks here, although he does not speak, which is a salient point in and of itself.  Does he put things in Beatrice's mouth that he wants to believe or that he wants the reader to believe?  Both?  Neither?  And finally, do we even care if the destruction of Jerusalem by Titus was just or unjust or if the supposed incarnation was the only way to restore humanity to a condition of blessedness that few believe ever existed or ever could exist in a world where a mother may have to struggle with a handicapped child or a man might have to cope with a terminal diagnosis or a wholesale political and economic collapse or a war might launch a great deal of the population into an early or late grave, or into the hells of addiction or homelessness or, as is the case in my own now's now, when a pandemic sweeps across the globe indiscriminately killing the just and the unjust — if this is our world — what possible remedies could poetry or religious belief systems offer that would mitigated these outrages, that would or could explain how such catastrophes might spawn a state of permanent, transcendent bliss.  Can the same life circumstances that foment our terrors and our agonies also be the seed for an ongoing experience of joy, or as some gurus tell us, from what we hope is their own experience derived from spiritual disciplines — a causeless, ceaseless, ever-new joy?   

Between that last sentence and this, my night-long insomnia was intruded upon by a period of sleep, in which I dreamed that the bones of my body became a kind of liquified lava, and that which in waking life was stiff, became, not only malleable, but malleable through volition.  They became flexible with an inner life so that I could change their shape at will.  Eventually I awakened with a cramp in the top of my foot, and that parallel reality of sleep gave way to that state we call awake, which, had I not immediately written this, would have utterly obliterated the dream reality in the course of a few moments.  Note that here, after the lines "tell me, tell me, tell me," interiorly spoken by the aspirant, and quoted in this text above, the speechless Dante falls into a drowse, the entire incident triggered by Beatrice's smile, a conditioned response, identical to a hypnotist's pre-installed suggestion.  Here, the protagonist says something, which is impossible in the logical world we perhaps mistakenly call waking.  He says that the words that that smile ignited him, have made him happy, even had his body been burning in the midst of his fire.  Some might remember that in the early days of America's ill-fated adventure in Vietnam, the protest of a Buddhist monk, who set himself ablaze, and maintained with calm his meditation posture while the horrific flames consumed his body.  The text here presents an analogous situation.  One's experience of reality, maybe even one's reality, is determined by a state of consciousness, which is an absolutely excruciating idea, but an idea that anyone can "prove" for themselves by a simple comparison of waking with dreaming.  Of course, when we are awake, we privilege the waking state above the dreaming one, but the dream state just as thoroughly negates the waking one.   The two states are clearly related, but related by a process of mutual obliteration.   Question: Are the logos of poetry and logic of prose also fused by a like process of reciprical annilation?  The entire text of the Commedia is an exploration, not so much of history, or myth, or theology, or cosmology, or of the self or of our myriad selves, or even or the waking state's  perceptions of time and space, but of consciousness itself.   And the instrument, which probes those worlds of history, myth, theology, et al, is poetic language, woven with both dreamlike fluidity and numerical and even cryptological precision.  The position of reader to the meaning of the text, i.e., the experience of reading while we read, and while contemplating what has been read and anticipating what is yet to be read, is anagogically akin to the position of Dante, the aspirant inside the poem to Dante the writer, creating the poem.  That all these selves are generated by states of consciousness, which is everywhere in the text embodied by its characters, be they that of Virgil, or of the damned, or of the saved, or here, in the person of Beatrice, who brings peace, and love, and not least of all that aesthetic beatific beauty which is able to make and sustain whole universes.

What is being proposed in Canto VI of the Paradiso?  One proposition is that the Adam state of consciousness, which Blake astutely calls the "limit of contraction," cannot from inside that state have any tools to expand or transcend its own limitations.  The text here says that ordinary mortal life with its survival concerns, its prestige concerns, its addictions to sex or food or fashion or belonging is Adamic, and by the mere fact of being born and confining or contracting ourselves to a particular prison of time and space, we all suffer the sin of Adam, and the precise nature of that sin is that it generates its own parameters for contraction.  You do not have to be a Christian to be a son or daughter of Adam, wherein all one's knowledge, all one's experience forges a chain of opposing dualities, of likes and dislikes, goods and evils, preferences and anathemas.  One rule for change, for expansion, is that something out there, beyond the boundary of the rules of the constricted self, be it a devil or an angel, must intrude as an agent of transformation.  Another rule for change is that it is possible only by being simultaneously in the present state and in the parallel expanded presence — i.e. thoroughly and completely being that which one is —  while thoroughly and completely being in a new expanded Is-ness.  For Beatrice, here, the sole Self capable of simultaneously being in both of these positions is what or whom she calls God, and God's instrument of change is on the one hand love, and on the other hand that ability to totally empathize with the suffering, pain, and terror of the state of consciousness of his creations, but always without ever losing the ability to resurrect love in those circumstances, and to leverage that love to achieve states of bliss inconceivable to the contracted self.   Read in this way, all of the rest of Beatrice's scholastic exposition becomes a recipe for the adolescent seeker to achieve spiritual maturity, to ask to be humble enough to realize his or her own state, and to be honest about it, and then, with neither pride nor shame, to explore those domains of consciousness which open at her words.  Are Beatrice's solutions for transcendence of the limited, suffering self, the sole possible ones?  Maybe not, but one thing seems certain, to vacillate, to not choose (remember the fates of those in the anteroom of Hell) is a sure way to the damnation of stuckness, the death that is stasis, and perpetuation of agonizing limitation.  The question is not: Are Beatrice's propositions true?  But rather, do they lead to THE BEAUTIFUL BEATIFIC STATE? 

It has been said that Western religions — Christianity, Judaism, Islam — are religions of the Word, and that Eastern religions — Hinduism, Buddhism, Taoism — religions of practice, i.e. some sort of spiritualizing methodology such as meditation or yoga.  For the West, the Word is exoteric and method is esoteric.  For the East, that hierarchy is reversed.  But it's not true that Beatrice's "Word" is the only guidance given in the text: there is also prayer, contemplative practice, right action, dreams, imagination, music, dance, song, chanting, and of course, mostly the medium of the poetry itself.  The exoteric (the hair) and the esoteric (the horns) are but two sides of the same animal or angel, and they are linked by a relationship that is by turns painful or pleasurable, but always some form of love, some aspect that could be seen as beauty.  And how does Dante discern which contrasting element is being displayed in any given space/time?   He discerns via a seasoned aesthetic, that is, by the practice of an artistry analogous to both Creator and creation.        

1  "Osanna sanctus Deus Sabaoth,
2  Superillustrans claritate tua
3  Felices ignes horum malahoth!"

1  “Osanna, sanctus Deus sabaòth,
2  superillustrans claritate tua
3  felices ignes horum malacòth!”

4  In this wise, to his melody returning,
5  This substance, upon which a double light
6  Doubles itself, was seen by me to sing,

4  Così, volgendosi a la nota sua,
5  fu viso a me cantare essa sustanza,
6  sopra la qual doppio lume s'addua;

7  And to their dance this and the others moved,
8  And in the manner of swift-hurrying sparks
9  Veiled themselves from me with a sudden distance.

7  ed essa e l'altre mossero a sua danza,
8  e quasi velocissime faville
9  mi si velar di sùbita distanza.

10  Doubting was I, and saying, "Tell her, tell her,"
11  Within me, "tell her," saying, "tell my Lady,"
12  Who slakes my thirst with her sweet effluences;

10  Io dubitava e dicea “Dille, dille!”
11  fra me, “dille” dicea, “a la mia donna
12  che mi diseta con le dolci stille.”

13  And yet that reverence which doth lord it over
14  The whole of me only by B and ICE,
15  Bowed me again like unto one who drowses.

13  Ma quella reverenza che s'indonna
14  di tutto me, pur per Be e per ice,
15  mi richinava come l'uom ch'assonna.

16  Short while did Beatrice endure me thus;
17  And she began, lighting me with a smile
18  Such as would make one happy in the fire:

16  Poco sofferse me cotal Beatrice
17  e cominciò, raggiandomi d'un riso
18  tal, che nel foco faria l'uom felice:

19  "According to infallible advisement,
20  After what manner a just vengeance justly
21  Could be avenged has put thee upon thinking,

19  “Secondo mio infallibile avviso,
20  come giusta vendetta giustamente
21  punita fosse, t'ha in pensier miso;

22  But I will speedily thy mind unloose;
23  And do thou listen, for these words of mine
24  Of a great doctrine will a present make thee.

22  ma io ti solverò tosto la mente;
23  e tu ascolta, ché le mie parole
24  di gran sentenza ti faran presente.

25  By not enduring on the power that wills
26  Curb for his good, that man who ne'er was born,
27  Damning himself damned all his progeny;

25  Per non soffrire a la virtù che vole
26  freno a suo prode, quell' uom che non nacque,
27  dannando sé, dannò tutta sua prole;

28  Whereby the human species down below
29  Lay sick for many centuries in great error,
30  Till to descend it pleased the Word of God

28  onde l'umana specie inferma giacque
29  giù per secoli molti in grande errore,
30  fin ch'al Verbo di Dio discender piacque

31  To where the nature, which from its own Maker
32  Estranged itself, he joined to him in person
33  By the sole act of his eternal love.

31  u' la natura, che dal suo fattore
32  s'era allungata, unì a sé in persona
33  con l'atto sol del suo etterno amore.

34  Now unto what is said direct thy sight;
35  This nature when united to its Maker,
36  Such as created, was sincere and good;

34  Or drizza il viso a quel ch'or si ragiona:
35  questa natura al suo fattore unita,
36  qual fu creata, fu sincera e buona;

37  But by itself alone was banished forth
38  From Paradise, because it turned aside
39  Out of the way of truth and of its life.

37  ma per sé stessa pur fu ella sbandita
38  di paradiso, però che si torse
39  da via di verità e da sua vita.

40  Therefore the penalty the cross held out,
41  If measured by the nature thus assumed,
42  None ever yet with so great justice stung,

40  La pena dunque che la croce porse
41  s'a la natura assunta si misura,
42  nulla già mai sì giustamente morse;

43  And none was ever of so great injustice,
44  Considering who the Person was that suffered,
45  Within whom such a nature was contracted.

43  e così nulla fu di tanta ingiura,
44  guardando a la persona che sofferse,
45  in che era contratta tal natura.
46  From one act therefore issued things diverse;
47  To God and to the Jews one death was pleasing;
48  Earth trembled at it and the Heaven was opened.

46  Però d'un atto uscir cose diverse:
47  ch'a Dio e a' Giudei piacque una morte;
48  per lei tremò la terra e 'l ciel s'aperse.

49  It should no longer now seem difficult
50  To thee, when it is said that a just vengeance
51  By a just court was afterward avenged.

49  Non ti dee oramai parer più forte,
50  quando si dice che giusta vendetta
51  poscia vengiata fu da giusta corte.

52  But now do I behold thy mind entangled
53  From thought to thought within a knot, from which
54  With great desire it waits to free itself.

52  Ma io veggi' or la tua mente ristretta
53  di pensiero in pensier dentro ad un nodo,
54  del qual con gran disio solver s'aspetta.

55  Thou sayest, 'Well discern I what I hear;
56  But it is hidden from me why God willed
57  For our redemption only this one mode.'

55  Tu dici: 'Ben discerno ciò ch'i' odo;
56  ma perché Dio volesse, m'è occulto,
57  a nostra redenzion pur questo modo.'

58  Buried remaineth, brother, this decree
59  Unto the eyes of every one whose nature
60  Is in the flame of love not yet adult.

58  Questo decreto, frate, sta sepulto
59  a li occhi di ciascuno il cui ingegno
60  ne la fiamma d'amor non è adulto.

61  Verily, inasmuch as at this mark
62  One gazes long and little is discerned,
63  Wherefore this mode was worthiest will I say.

61  Veramente, però ch'a questo segno
62  molto si mira e poco si discerne,
63  dirò perché tal modo fu più degno.

64  Goodness Divine, which from itself doth spurn
65  All envy, burning in itself so sparkles
66  That the eternal beauties it unfolds.

64  La divina bontà, che da sé sperne
65  ogne livore, ardendo in sé, sfavilla
66  sì che dispiega le bellezze etterne.

67  Whate'er from this immediately distils
68  Has afterwards no end, for ne'er removed
69  Is its impression when it sets its seal.

67  Ciò che da lei sanza mezzo distilla
68  non ha poi fine, perché non si move
69  la sua imprenta quand' ella sigilla.

70  Whate'er from this immediately rains down
71  Is wholly free, because it is not subject
73  Unto the influences of novel things.

70  Ciò che da essa sanza mezzo piove
71  libero è tutto, perché non soggiace
72  a la virtute de le cose nove.

73  The more conformed thereto, the more it pleases;
74  For the blest ardour that irradiates all things
75  In that most like itself is most vivacious.

73  Più l'è conforme, e però più le piace;
74  ché l'ardor santo ch'ogne cosa raggia,
75  ne la più somigliante è più vivace.

76  With all of these things has advantaged been
77  The human creature; and if one be wanting,
78  From his nobility he needs must fall.

76  Di tutte queste dote s'avvantaggia
77  l'umana creatura, e s'una manca,
78  di sua nobilità convien che caggia.

79  'Tis sin alone which doth disfranchise him,
80  And render him unlike the Good Supreme,
81  So that he little with its light is blanched,

79  Solo il peccato è quel che la disfranca
80  e falla dissimìle al sommo bene,
81  per che del lume suo poco s'imbianca;

82  And to his dignity no more returns,
83  Unless he fill up where transgression empties
84  With righteous pains for criminal delights.

82  e in sua dignità mai non rivene,
83  se non rïempie, dove colpa vòta,
84  contra mal dilettar con giuste pene.

85  Your nature when it sinned so utterly
86  In its own seed, out of these dignities
87  Even as out of Paradise was driven,

85  Vostra natura, quando peccò tota
86  nel seme suo, da queste dignitadi,
87  come di paradiso, fu remota;

88  Nor could itself recover, if thou notest
89  With nicest subtilty, by any way,
90  Except by passing one of these two fords:

88  né ricovrar potiensi, se tu badi
89  ben sottilmente, per alcuna via,
90  sanza passar per un di questi guadi:

91  Either that God through clemency alone
92  Had pardon granted, or that man himself
93  Had satisfaction for his folly made.

91  o che Dio solo per sua cortesia
92  dimesso avesse, o che l'uom per sé isso
93  avesse sodisfatto a sua follia.

94  Fix now thine eye deep into the abyss
95  Of the eternal counsel, to my speech
96  As far as may be fastened steadfastly!

94  Ficca mo l'occhio per entro l'abisso
95  de l'etterno consiglio, quanto puoi
96  al mio parlar distrettamente fisso.

97  Man in his limitations had not power
98  To satisfy, not having power to sink
99  In his humility obeying then,

97  Non potea l'uomo ne' termini suoi
98  mai sodisfar, per non potere ir giuso
99  con umiltate obedïendo poi,

100  Far as he disobeying thought to rise;
101  And for this reason man has been from power
102  Of satisfying by himself excluded.

100  quanto disobediendo intese ir suso;
101  e questa è la cagion per che l'uom fue
102  da poter sodisfar per sé dischiuso.

103  Therefore it God behoved in his own ways
104  Man to restore unto his perfect life,
105  I say in one, or else in both of them.

103  Dunque a Dio convenia con le vie sue
104  riparar l'omo a sua intera vita,
105  dico con l'una, o ver con amendue.

106  But since the action of the doer is
107  So much more grateful, as it more presents
108  The goodness of the heart from which it issues,

106  Ma perché l'ovra tanto è più gradita
107  da l'operante, quanto più appresenta
108  de la bontà del core ond' ell' è uscita

109  Goodness Divine, that doth imprint the world,
110  Has been contented to proceed by each
111  And all its ways to lift you up again;

109  la divina bontà che 'l mondo imprenta,
110  di proceder per tutte le sue vie,
111  a rilevarvi suso, fu contenta.

112  Nor 'twixt the first day and the final night
113  Such high and such magnificent proceeding
114  By one or by the other was or shall be;

112  Né tra l'ultima notte e 'l primo die
113  sì alto o sì magnifico processo,
114  o per l'una o per l'altra, fu o fie:

115  For God more bounteous was himself to give
116  To make man able to uplift himself,
117  Than if he only of himself had pardoned;

115  ché più largo fu Dio a dar sé stesso
116  per far l'uom sufficiente a rilevarsi,
117  che s'elli avesse sol da sé dimesso;

118  And all the other modes were insufficient
119  For justice, were it not the Son of God
120  Himself had humbled to become incarnate.

118  e tutti li altri modi erano scarsi
119  a la giustizia, se 'l Figliuol di Dio
120  non fosse umilïato ad incarnarsi.

121  Now, to fill fully each desire of thine,
122  Return I to elucidate one place,
123  In order that thou there mayst see as I do.

121  Or per empierti bene ogne disio,
122  ritorno a dichiararti in alcun loco,
123  perché tu veggi lì così com' io.

124  Thou sayst: 'I see the air, I see the fire,
125  The water, and the earth, and all their mixtures
126  Come to corruption, and short while endure;

124  Tu dici: 'Io veggio l'acqua, io veggio il foco,
125  l'aere e la terra e tutte lor misture
126  venire a corruzione, e durar poco;

127  And these things notwithstanding were created;'
128  Therefore if that which I have said were true,
129  They should have been secure against corruption.

127  e queste cose pur furon creature;
128  per che, se ciò ch'è detto è stato vero,
129  esser dovrien da corruzion sicure.'

130  The Angels, brother, and the land sincere
131  In which thou art, created may be called
132  Just as they are in their entire existence;

130  Li angeli, frate, e 'l paese sincero
131  nel qual tu se', dir si posson creati,
132  sì come sono, in loro essere intero;

133  But all the elements which thou hast named,
134  And all those things which out of them are made,
135  By a created virtue are informed.

133  ma li alimenti che tu hai nomati
134  e quelle cose che di lor si fanno
135  da creata virtù sono informati.

136  Created was the matter which they have;
137  Created was the informing influence
138  Within these stars that round about them go.

136  Creata fu la materia ch'elli hanno;
137 creata fu la virtù informante
138  in queste stelle che 'ntorno a lor vanno.

139  The soul of every brute and of the plants
140  By its potential temperament attracts
141  The ray and motion of the holy lights;

139  L'anima d'ogne bruto e de le piante
140  di complession potenzïata tira
141  lo raggio e 'l moto de le luci sante;

142  But your own life immediately inspires
143  Supreme Beneficence, and enamours it
144  So with herself, it evermore desires her.

142  ma vostra vita sanza mezzo spira
143  la somma beninanza, e la innamora
144  di sé sì che poi sempre la disira.

145  And thou from this mayst argue furthermore
146  Your resurrection, if thou think again
147  How human flesh was fashioned at that time

145  E quinci puoi argomentare ancora
146  vostra resurrezion, se tu ripensi
147  come l'umana carne fessi allora

148  When the first parents both of them were made."

148  che li primi parenti intrambo fensi.”

Canto VIII
The heaven of Venus may be compared to Rhetoric because of two properties: one is the brightness of its aspect, which is sweeter to look upon than that of any other star; the other is its appearance now in the morning, now in the evening. And these two properties are found in Rhetoric: for Rhetoric is sweeter than all of the other sciences, since this is what it principally aims at; and it appears in the morning when the rhetorician speaks before the face of his hearer, and it appears in the evening (that is, behind) when the rhetorician speaks through writing, from a distance.

Convivio, Book II, Chapter 13

 As we get deeper into the Paradiso, we are finding how problematic it becomes to insert God into the history of mortals, with all their self-aggrandizing desires and terrors, and all their capricious violence, which as the Inferno so vividly illustrates, goes so far beyond any of the necessary violence of what a Victorian Darwinian imagination would call "the survival of the fittest,"  because, all of our efforts to escape this violence entangle us in a rhetoric infused with past and future conditional verb tenses.  To make God the judicator of mortal action, he must be God the Good to be God the Just, else his laws are evil, or worse, irrelevant, to actual actions and events.  The main speaker in this canto, never revealed by name, as if to do so would ensnare the speaker in the taboo that the name-saying of the infinite entails — namely particularizing in the mind and in the heart, a figure who can be figured out, fingered and judged.  Note how the Yahweh, or YHWH, has essentially become a name for the Tetragrammatonistic command of: That which shall not be named.   Charles Martel (not the famous, not the Charles Martel) but a petty king, who died young, and who, so the text implies, would have, like Hamlet, ruled most beatifically and justly "had he been put on."  But the point is, he was never "put on," and moreover his spawn, contrary to the generally perceived genetic notion that like begets like, who were in fact put on, turned out to be tyrants, whose misrule degenerated into rapaciousness and had to be consigned by that Just God who did nothing to mitigate their historical horrors to an ahistorical Hell.  How does all this pertain to the sphere of Venus?  And to the art of rhetoric?  These questions devolve to the same slipperiness of the question that still dogs us whenever we look at the physical, mortal world: How has an omnipotent and omniscient Increatum God created a world so rife with the most abominable violence and injustice?  How does an Auschwitz or a Pol Pot or a cancer ward full of children come into existence if a God with the power and the knowledge to do so, does not intervene justly to alleviate unjust suffering?  This is a tough question to be sure, but one that seldom occupies any but an novitiate's mind, insofar as life itself does quite enough to involve either children or mature adults, living itself providing more than sufficient moment to moment grist to keep its pilgrims from straying into the byways of philosophy or theology, which is why at least one commentator, John Saly, Dante's Paradiso: the Flowering of the Self, relegates the sphere of Venus to the life stage of youth, a time when the post-adolescent seeks the solution of all life's problems in the crucible of Love.  But how much of what youth calls love is narcissistic infatuation?   And how many of those early infatuations actually evolve into a mutual admiration and trust, and do not keep circulating round and round the empty rhetoric of pleasure, whose one question remains: What's in it for me?  One could say that rhetoric as the art of pleasant persuasion is the ultimate advertiser's or politician's propagandistic syrup to sweeten this sales pitch for the existence of a Just God, or for that matter, of any kind of a God which might be worthy of worship out of love (Venus) and not fear (Mars).  (The story of Aeneas and Dido alluded to here in line 9, a pagan story, because when Mars leaves Venus, love dies.)  Because the old serpentining of these two opposites, as the opposites of justice and injustice, peace and violence, retribution and mercy, just refuses to stop their fornications, and the whole of our arts of grammar, dialectical logic, and rhetoric, which form the very basis of our minds, find it impossible to speak at all without revealing that beneath the best of their expressions lurks all this irony of the unexpressed construction, and all of the horror that their deceptive and masking arabesquing have entailed.  Always behind those smiling words cruel fangs are dripping blood.  Remember the unnamed speaker here, from a blinding ephemera of light, himself an insubstantial light, does not speak from any kind of probing of facts and their expression, he does not speak to say what is, but to give pleasure, to say what his listener is most soothed and joyed to hear.  The speaker is an adman, a salesman who is selling whatever it is that we are most motivated to buy, and like all good pushers, the first dose of his drug is free.  Only afterwards do we have to deal with the consequences of this rush, the irony that the monarchy that he propose would be a dictatorship which could never exist without enforcing is deviant monotony on deviants.  The paradise that the speaker is pushing must perforce be hypothetical and spoken about in conditional terms, because the speaker himself, and certainly the listener, is ironically entangled in that most obtuse arrogance of the divinely submissive, which is: I am always right.   We would do well to remember, or should I say "not forget" when we read this text, of the diachronic split in Dante himself, the Dante inside the poem accepting of the unnamed speaker's rhetoric, and the nomad, political exile outside the poem, condemned to death in his own home city, and moving about in an historical nightmare, so that it just may be that in this case neither Dante is consciously aware of the other, and moreover, if they were (there's that conditional tense again), that awareness might well occasion the kind of atheistic shock that so shattered 20th Century existentialists like Camus and Sartre.  The gap between what is and could be teems like those areas on old maritime maps, a terra incognita which can only be captioned: Here be monsters.  All that being said, I would not like to exchange the fundamentalism of a conditional hope for the fundamentalism of an unchanging cynical irony.  Both types of fundamentalism have to deal with the issues of free will and the possibility, indeed, the inevitability of change and of difference.  If the conditional is too often the home of false hope, and the apprehension of a current or coming despair, in its domain there is still wiggle room for the creation of a renewing, one might even say, ever-renewing, creative bliss.  Most people in pain do not wish to perpetuate it, although they might well do so to protect an identity (an ideal) in which pain is foundational.  Even the shades in Hell, as Dante shows, although incapable of realizing how their identity perpetuates their suffering, do almost universally (the "almost" is important), no matter how futile their method, hope to mitigate or at least justify their agony through blame, deceit, or some attempt to ensnare others in their fate, and so forth, and in this they differ profoundly with those in Purgatory, who accept their condition without such dodges, and who thereby render their condition of suffering conditional.  There's not much room for the ironic in their situation because they embrace their suffering as a condition of their release from it.  They have given up hiding and evading what Jung would call the shadow, and thus the very idea of rhetorical pleasantries for the purpose of persuasion to some position other than what is is impossible for them.  If rhetoric is the art of playing up one side of an expression and toning down or redacting those things that negate your argument, then irony while being inevitable, is also hoisted on its own petard.  Once we begin examining the multiple-sidedness of any issue, the seeds of rhetoric begin to drift off into poetic tangents, like dreamy adolescents, picking the petals from daisies with the conditional oscillation of "she loves me/she loves me not," a love affair with the open question, which is more of an aesthetic ideal than a philosophical hunt for the truth, the question being more fulfilling, and more fruitful in terms of generating (A good word, seeing as how generation is a major subject in this canto as we know from the first with the reference to the mother and offspring of Venus in lines 7 and 8.) the kind of feelings and behaviors that enhance an exploration of the beloved and also, the state of being in love. 

But here we are in the Heaven of Venus, and of all things, we are talking about Empire, as a foundation for what very few of us in this early 21st Century Western Yuga would call Love.  We have to come to grips here with what for Dante was of paramount importance in determining the relationship — the love relationship — between the physical — and by this he includes the body and all its appetites, which are of the domain of Eros, and the physical senses, and which in Hobbesian fashion are blown up to the proportions of the social collective in the body-politic, and the metaphysical — those things like the biases of belief, or the torrents of emotion, which weigh and value all things relational, and to which his particular historical metaphysics attempted to evaluate by such now quaint notions as an anthropomorphic God.  Whose (or we might say "What") system of laws and mores govern this seemingly ungovernable world of the physical senses and their voracious and — even in, or should we say, especially in the domains of eating and reproduction — violent appetites and lusts?  Going back to Bateson, and his logical hierarchies, we find that Dante's ideas about Empire, be it the Empire of political or Religious authority, can nest quite comfortably in that mental construct, and that these ideals found their template in an idea that came to be known as "The Great Chain of Being," which was a series of linkages connecting the simplest, and in this metaphor, lowest entities, in successive and higher orders of complexity and inclusiveness, to the highest, in this case the angelic orders and finally, the ultimate of ultimates, God.   Dante's philosophical enterprise  of clarifying and determining the order of these relationships and the laws of government should not seem strange to us.  For each of us has a similar enterprise in determining how the myriad cells and biota of the physical body come together to create the entity we call "Me."   And what a strange thing it is that beyond the skin-boundaries of this organ sack, like a single cell of the body, it too is embedded in orders of social and environmental complexities which seem to seethe with capricious and violent appetites, whose evolutionary laws and mores, if we might call them that, too often, seemingly void of any entity-like identity, which might order them, seem more like a chaos ruled by random violence than a system of order which is capable — if not designed — as a home, whether in Nature or Culture, is capable, in fact, with a little interventionist jimmying at least, of providing for its own constituents.  How can this condition in which we find ourselves, of whose chemicals and forces we are composed, be not only inimical to our existence, rather than nourishing, but stranger still: Strange.  Dante realized that love is an encounter with the strangest of all phenomenon, the Other, and the urge to love, to conflate our identity with this alien is the same urge that prompted princes and Papists to build a universal Empire, as body politic, or as universal Church, and to provide metaphysical principals that governed, perhaps we should say, harmonized, those physical and metaphysical realms.  The most pressing need of this hunter/gatherer, terrestrial surface-dweller, which calls itself human, is the need to move into the perpetual unknown to find that which it needs to survive, but even beyond this need, is the need to end its dangerous nomadic condition of exile, the condition of being the Stranger, and find for itself a home, a spouse, a loving family.  But how is this to be accomplished?  Assimilation — eating, digestion — is a violent project that begins in taking life and ends in combustion, while reproduction, the propagation of life of like to like — may be antagonistic, but both share the need to conflate the self with the not-self, the possessed with the dispossessed, and both have to cross the border of that which would be conserved and that which must change to live.

All of this canto, and all of the Commedia preceding it, and proceeding from it, keeps circling around a centralizing force, which in the individual we have come to refer to as the ego, and which, in the collective, I have attributed to that rather bizarre magical term, the Egregore.  In this canto, as in the previous canto, and indeed throughout all three canticles, is the idea of flow, here seen as the description of the course of Empire following the drainage regimes of rivers.  There are two metaphors here, which are irrevocably (note the "vocal" in that word), conflated — that is — flicker and flow.   If there is a God which harmonizes, and in which or whom, everything that is is, with all those questions of origin, generation, development, and destiny, all those questions of language which come to their supreme expression in poetry, than we might best recognize the attributes of such an existence in the conditional and mesmerizing allurements embodied in these conflated yet oppositional pairs: flicker and flow.  That which is here for an instant, and that which is present alway, that which is ever changing and that which is always the same, that which is behind us in the past, around us in the present, and before us in the future.  Of course, the metaphors for God or Self or Time or Language or Cosmos can never be definitive, but that is the magic of metaphor, to say precisely through constant equivocation that which cannot be said.

1  The world used in its peril to believe
2  That the fair Cypria delirious love
3  Rayed out, in the third epicycle turning;

1  Solea creder lo mondo in suo periclo
2  che la bella Ciprigna il folle amore
3  raggiasse, volta nel terzo epiciclo;

4  Wherefore not only unto her paid honour
5  Of sacrifices and of votive cry
6  The ancient nations in the ancient error,

4  per che non pur a lei faceano onore
5  di sacrificio e di votivo grido
6  le genti antiche ne l'antico errore;

7  But both Dione honoured they and Cupid,
8  That as her mother, this one as her son,
9  And said that he had sat in Dido's lap;

7  ma Dïone onoravano e Cupido,
8  quella per madre sua, questo per figlio,
9  e dicean ch'el sedette in grembo a Dido;

10  And they from her, whence I beginning take,
11  Took the denomination of the star
12  That woos the sun, now following, now in front.

10  e da costei ond' io principio piglio
11  pigliavano il vocabol de la stella
12  che 'l sol vagheggia or da coppa or da ciglio.

13  I was not ware of our ascending to it;
14  But of our being in it gave full faith
15  My Lady whom I saw more beauteous grow.

13  Io non m'accorsi del salire in ella;
14  ma d'esservi entro mi fé assai fede
15  la donna mia ch'i' vidi far più bella.

16  And as within a flame a spark is seen,
17  And as within a voice a voice discerned,
18  When one is steadfast, and one comes and goes,

16  E come in fiamma favilla si vede,
17  e come in voce voce si discerne,
18  quand' una è ferma e altra va e riede,

19  Within that light beheld I other lamps
20  Move in a circle, speeding more and less,
21  Methinks in measure of their inward vision.

19  vid' io in essa luce altre lucerne
20  muoversi in giro più e men correnti,
21  al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.

22  From a cold cloud descended never winds,
23  Or visible or not, so rapidly
24  They would not laggard and impeded seem

22  Di fredda nube non disceser venti,
23  o visibili o no, tanto festini,
24  che non paressero impediti e lenti

25  To any one who had those lights divine
26  Seen come towards us, leaving the gyration
27  Begun at first in the high Seraphim.

25  a chi avesse quei lumi divini
26  veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro
27  pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;

28  And behind those that most in front appeared
29  Sounded "Osanna!" so that never since
30  To hear again was I without desire.

28  e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro
29  sonava “Osanna” sì, che unque poi
30  di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.

31  Then unto us more nearly one approached,
32  And it alone began: "We all are ready
33  Unto thy pleasure, that thou joy in us.

31  Indi si fece l'un più presso a noi
32  e solo incominciò: “Tutti sem presti
33  al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.

34  We turn around with the celestial Princes,
35  One gyre and one gyration and one thirst,
36  To whom thou in the world of old didst say,

34  Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti
35  d'un giro e d'un girare e d'una sete,
36  ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:

37  'Ye who, intelligent, the third heaven are moving;'
38  And are so full of love, to pleasure thee
39  A little quiet will not be less sweet."

37  'Voi che 'ntendendo il terzo ciel movete';
38  e sem sì pien d'amor, che, per piacerti,
39  non fia men dolce un poco di quïete.”

40  After these eyes of mine themselves had offered
41  Unto my Lady reverently, and she
42  Content and certain of herself had made them,

40  Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti
41  a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa
42  fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,

43  Back to the light they turned, which so great promise
44  Made of itself, and "Say, who art thou?" was
45  My voice, imprinted with a great affection.

43  rivolsersi a la luce che promessa
44  tanto s'avea, e “Deh, chi siete?” fue
45  la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.

46  O how and how much I beheld it grow
47  With the new joy that superadded was
48  Unto its joys, as soon as I had spoken!

46  E quanta e quale vid' io lei far piùe
47  per allegrezza nova che s'accrebbe,
48  quando parlai, a l'allegrezze sue!

49  Thus changed, it said to me: "The world possessed me
50  Short time below; and, if it had been more,
51  Much evil will be which would not have been.

49  Così fatta, mi disse: “Il mondo m'ebbe
50  giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato,
51  molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.

52  My gladness keepeth me concealed from thee,
53  Which rayeth round about me, and doth hide me
54  Like as a creature swathed in its own silk.

52  La mia letizia mi ti tien celato
53  che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde
54  quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.

55  Much didst thou love me, and thou hadst good reason;
56  For had I been below, I should have shown thee
57  Somewhat beyond the foliage of my love.

55  Assai m'amasti, e avesti ben onde;
56  che s'io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava
57  di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.

58  That left-hand margin, which doth bathe itself
59  In Rhone, when it is mingled with the Sorgue,
60  Me for its lord awaited in due time,

58  Quella sinistra riva che si lava
59  di Rodano poi ch'è misto con Sorga,
60  per suo segnore a tempo m'aspettava,

61  And that horn of Ausonia, which is towned
62  With Bari, with Gaeta and Catona,
63  Whence Tronto and Verde in the sea disgorge.

61   e quel corno d'Ausonia che s'imborga
62  di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona,
63 da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.

64  Already flashed upon my brow the crown
65  Of that dominion which the Danube waters
66  After the German borders it abandons;

64  Fulgeami già in fronte la corona
65  di quella terra che 'l Danubio riga
66  poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.

67  And beautiful Trinacria, that is murky
68  'Twixt Pachino and Peloro, (on the gulf
69  Which greatest scath from Eurus doth receive,)

67  E la bella Trinacria, che caliga
68  tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra 'l golfo
69  che riceve da Euro maggior briga,

70  Not through Typhoeus, but through nascent sulphur,
71  Would have awaited her own monarchs still,
72  Through me from Charles descended and from Rudolph,

70  non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo,
71  attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora,
72  nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,

73  If evil lordship, that exasperates ever
74  The subject populations, had not moved
75  Palermo to the outcry of 'Death! death!'

73  se mala segnoria, che sempre accora
74  li popoli suggetti, non avesse
75  mosso Palermo a gridar: 'Mora, mora!'

76  And if my brother could but this foresee,
77  The greedy poverty of Catalonia
78  Straight would he flee, that it might not molest him;

76  E se mio frate questo antivedesse,
77  l'avara povertà di Catalogna
78  già fuggeria, perché non li offendesse;

79  For verily 'tis needful to provide,
80  Through him or other, so that on his bark
81  Already freighted no more freight be placed.

79  ché veramente proveder bisogna
80  per lui, o per altrui, sì ch'a sua barca
81  carcata più d'incarco non si pogna.

82  His nature, which from liberal covetous
83  Descended, such a soldiery would need
84  As should not care for hoarding in a chest."

82  La sua natura, che di larga parca
83  discese, avria mestier di tal milizia
84  che non curasse di mettere in arca.”

85  "Because I do believe the lofty joy
86  Thy speech infuses into me, my Lord,
87  Where every good thing doth begin and end

85  “Però ch'i' credo che l'alta letizia
86  che 'l tuo parlar m'infonde, segnor mio,
87  là 've ogne ben si termina e s'inizia,

88  Thou seest as I see it, the more grateful
89  Is it to me; and this too hold I dear,
90  That gazing upon God thou dost discern it.

88  per te si veggia come la vegg' io,
89  grata m'è più; e anco quest' ho caro
90  perché 'l discerni rimirando in Dio.

91  Glad hast thou made me; so make clear to me,
92  Since speaking thou hast stirred me up to doubt,
93  How from sweet seed can bitter issue forth."

91  Fatto m'hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro,
92  poi che, parlando, a dubitar m'hai mosso
93  com' esser può, di dolce seme, amaro.”

94  This I to him; and he to me: "If I
95  Can show to thee a truth, to what thou askest
96  Thy face thou'lt hold as thou dost hold thy back.

94  Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: “S'io posso
95  mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi
96  terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.

97  The Good which all the realm thou art ascending
98  Turns and contents, maketh its providence
99  To be a power within these bodies vast;

97  Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi
98  volge e contenta, fa esser virtute
99  sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.

100  And not alone the natures are foreseen
101  Within the mind that in itself is perfect,
102  But they together with their preservation.

100  E non pur le nature provedute
101  sono in la mente ch'è da sé perfetta,
102  ma esse insieme con la lor salute:

103  For whatsoever thing this bow shoots forth
104  Falls foreordained unto an end foreseen,
105  Even as a shaft directed to its mark.

103  per che quantunque quest' arco saetta
104  disposto cade a proveduto fine,
105  sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.

106  If that were not, the heaven which thou dost walk
107  Would in such manner its effects produce,
108  That they no longer would be arts, but ruins.

106  Se ciò non fosse, il ciel che tu cammine
107  producerebbe sì li suoi effetti,
108  che non sarebbero arti, ma ruine;

109  This cannot be, if the Intelligences
110  That keep these stars in motion are not maimed,
111  And maimed the First that has not made them perfect.

109  e ciò esser non può, se li 'ntelletti
110  che muovon queste stelle non son manchi,
112  e manco il primo, che non li ha perfetti.

112  Wilt thou this truth have clearer made to thee?"
113  And I: "Not so; for 'tis impossible
114  That nature tire, I see, in what is needful."

112  Vuo' tu che questo ver più ti s'imbianchi?”
113  E io “Non già; ché impossibil veggio
114  che la natura, in quel ch'è uopo, stanchi.”

115  Whence he again: "Now say, would it be worse
116  For men on earth were they not citizens?"
117  "Yes," I replied; "and here I ask no reason."

115  Ond' elli ancora: “Or dì: sarebbe il peggio
116  per l'omo in terra, se non fosse cive?”
117  “Si,” rispuos' io; “e qui ragion non cheggio.”

118  "And can they be so, if below they live not
119  Diversely unto offices diverse?
120  No, if your master writeth well for you."

118  “E puot' elli esser, se giù non si vive
119  diversamente per diversi offici?
120  Non, se 'l maestro vostro ben vi scrive.”

121  So came he with deductions to this point;
122  Then he concluded: "Therefore it behoves
123  The roots of your effects to be diverse.

121  Sì venne deducendo infino a quici;
122  poscia conchiuse: “Dunque esser diverse
123  convien di vostri effetti le radici:

124  Hence one is Solon born, another Xerxes,
125  Another Melchisedec, and another he
126  Who, flying through the air, his son did lose.

124  per ch'un nasce Solone e altro Serse,
125  altro Melchisedèch e altro quello
