126  che, volando per l'aere, il figlio perse.

127  Revolving Nature, which a signet is
128  To mortal wax, doth practise well her art,
129  But not one inn distinguish from another;

127  La circular natura, ch'è suggello
128  a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte,
129  ma non distingue l'un da l'altro ostello.

130  Thence happens it that Esau differeth
131  In seed from Jacob; and Quirinus comes
132  From sire so vile that he is given to Mars.

130  Quinci addivien ch'Esaù si diparte
131  per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino
132  da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.

133  A generated nature its own way
134  Would always make like its progenitors,
135  If Providence divine were not triumphant.

133  Natura generata il suo cammino
134  simil farebbe sempre a' generanti,
135  se non vincesse il proveder divino.

136  Now that which was behind thee is before thee;
137  But that thou know that I with thee am pleased,
138  With a corollary will I mantle thee.

136  Or quel che t'era dietro t'è davanti:
137  ma perché sappi che di te mi giova,
138  un corollario voglio che t'ammanti.

139  Evermore nature, if it fortune find
140  Discordant to it, like each other seed
141  Out of its region, maketh evil thrift;

139  Sempre natura, se fortuna trova
140  discorde a sé, com' ogne altra semente
141  fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.

142  And if the world below would fix its mind
143  On the foundation which is laid by nature,
144  Pursuing that, 'twould have the people good.

142  E se 'l mondo là giù ponesse mente
143  al fondamento che natura pone,
144  seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.

145  But you unto religion wrench aside
146  Him who was born to gird him with the sword,
147  And make a king of him who is for sermons;

145  Ma voi torcete a la religïone
146  tal che fia nato a cignersi la spada,
147  e fate re di tal ch'è da sermone;

148  Therefore your footsteps wander from the road."

148  onde la traccia vostra è fuor di strada.”

Canto IX
Commentators debate the question of which "bella Clemenza" the narrator is addressing to begin this canto, Charles Martel's wife or his daughter?   (Note the name, she being the clemency that we all so need as the grace we require to be absolved from our own damnable thoughts and actions.)  I vote for the wife, as married man and woman are one flesh, and this intermingling would be befitting for the sphere of Venus, but whether this person is wife or daughter, seems to me to be of less importance than the fact that whoever this person is, she stands for the reader, and as the reader or listener, the rhetorician must sweetly capture them with just such a honey trap.  This maneuver — at least for me — has great significance as we consider why this rhetorical device is so important in interpreting the very problematic text and subtexts of this canto, whose opening might be the weirdest of any of the canti in the entire poem.  Why the past tense "historical" summary of what Martel has prophesied?   Why not just have Martel continue speaking in the present tense?  And why tell Clemenza at all, since we soon will know that the lights here can read minds, why does Clemenza have to be told what Charles has said?   If the equivocal Charles has been used here because of the conditional tense of what might have been, there is a switch now to make a point of what definitely will come to pass — maybe.  It's so disorienting to the reader, which is perhaps deliberate since the reader is being put off her or his guard, softened up, so to speak, so that they will accept what the speakers in this canto are about to peddle.  What does Yeats say?  "The rhetorician would deceive his neighbors, the sentimentalist himself."  Or, since the prophecy alluded to here is one of tragic consequences, must Charles be returned to the silence of having already spoken, and is now as incapable of speech, as his youth and early death rendered him incapable of rule?   Walter Benjamin's insight seems apropos here: "Tragedy is a preliminary stage of prophesy.  It is a content, which exists only in language: what is tragic is the word and the silence of the past, in which the prophetic voice is being tried out, or suffering and death when they are redeemed by the voice ... "  The voice of Charles is absent here, its prophesy echoing from a hole in time.  It wobbles and warbles, like Steven's blackbird ... 

I do not know which to prefer,   
The beauty of inflections   
Or the beauty of innuendoes,   
The blackbird whistling   
Or just after.   

Whatever else it is or means, this opening seems a beautiful flicker at the weird boundary/not boundary of all music, and all speech, unheard until it is gone.  

 As in the previous canti of the Paradiso, Canto IX also contains a great deal of flicker and flow, but here I think it serves like the smooth flow of the somnambulist’s voice and the gadgetry that he uses as the shiny spinning objects that will induce an hypnotic trance.  After probing the ease in which we accept the presence of these lights, these living presences, as the denizens of Heaven and the blessed recipients of God's eternal grace, I look at these speakers and begin to ask myself who these souls have been, and how they could possible merit such divine favor?

Each time a speaker enters, that hypnotic effect is reiterated, along with some imprecation for the reader to consider the speaker's blessed state, and we are even warned in lines 10 - 12 that to ignore what is being said leaves us prey to vain and impious deceptions.  We are given an emotional appeal to our hearts, and told to abandon the "temple" of our heads, and should we not, perhaps we will even suffer punishment to that organ by persisting in such thinking.  No, we cannot be allowed to think.   So before that can happen, the trance is deepened by the appearance of yet another "splendor." 

There are big spheres of reference here, sometimes one growing larger and enclosing the others, and then another expands, and the former are encompassed — these all being juggled through the art of rhetoric.  A list of possible captions for these thematic spheres might be:

Change and Constancy, specifically the idea of change in eternity, i.e., difference without decay or death

Love and War (Venus and Mars, Dido and Aeneas)

Genealogies and Patronymic dynastic rights

Orthodoxy and Heresy

Justice and Retribution: Violence, pain, genocide 

Poetry and Prophesy

Political and Ecclesiastical Power

Fealty and Betrayal

Promise and Realization

Damnation and Salvation

History and Geography

Linguistic expressions and/or fundamental truths

The temperamental predilections of people, their innate tendencies and moral volitions

The list could be extended or contracted, since these are all huge, amorphous, and slippery concepts, each sphere being elastic enough to shrink or stretch as the occasion demands.  Perhaps we might even boil all this down to a single all-encompassing Venetian rubric:

The interrelationships of sex, violence, power, and spirit.

But that being said, this is one of Dante's great talents as a poet, that he is able within a narrative structure to ping just the right spot in that amorphous ovum so that it burgeons with so many areas of human thought and experience.  He's hard to excerpt, since the verses all seem to have a sort of fractal-esque quality, so that when we try to isolate one theme, we find it entangled with so many others.  

In this canto in particular, but really increasingly so, as I've moved through the Paradiso, I've had a devil of a time keeping track of the trek, with all the cross-hatching and backtracking and under and over scent trails, which mirror life about as closely as any art could, but which leave the reader in the same kind of quandaries that life itself presents, that is, what does this all mean? and more importantly, since these notes are not meant to pin down this question in any scholarly or general kind of way — what does this all mean to me NOW.  All of my readings are provisional ones, and I know full well that even if the text remains the same, it will work on me in subsequent readings so that I change my reactions to it.  The only thing that holds constant is the richness and deepening of the interaction — and how many experiences in life can offer that?   

What struck me when examining the histories of those who speak or are spoken about here is that these splendors of the saved, in their mortal lives and actions, did not much differ from those who were being punished in Hell or purged in Purgatory.  They do not talk about the manner of their deaths, or even the conduct of their lives.  But they do seem anxious to pronounce prophetic doom on their adversaries, so they can hardly be seen as forgiving guides to their own state of blessedness.  They are not heroic as are the protagonists of Greek tragedy, who die in defiance of the crushing fates enforced on them by jealous pagan gods, and who thereby assert their humanity, mortality, and above all, pain, against the onslaughts of immortal power.  They are not martyrs for truth, like Socrates, who accepted the poison of death, as a means to reject the poisoning of those eternal probings for truth which exalt the human mind.  They are not sacrifices for the atonement of their own sins or for the sins of the collective, as are Jesus and the subsequent Christian martyrs.  They sing-dance-spin in a joyous light whose single stated purpose is to give pleasure to the querent, Dante.   They are mind-reading molecules whose talk-appearance-protuberances fit exactly into the pleasure receptors of their helpless audience.  And what is this pleasure, this joy?  To prophesize the suffering and demise of their heretical enemies, to lay a curse on the wayward and the vain, to render their compatriots and even their arrogant and violent kin unto the devastation of greater violence, based somehow, not on arrogance, not even on humility, but on a pleasurable devotion.  Reading this canto, it occurred to me that even a poet of the stature of Dante has a secret part in himself which longs for the destruction of the culture that sustains him.

I must say that I find these "Lights," these "Lifes," even more disturbing in some ways than the denizens of Hell, because, I suppose, they seem so consciousless as to believe, and, make no mistake, to be amply rewarded for this belief, that their piety justifies their adulteries, their violence, and their condemnations.  They seem to have achieved the splendor and joy of righteousness, to have found in their own violence and sexual promiscuities the justification for orthodoxy that purifies their consciences, and absolves their actions and beliefs even by means of damning the very same types of actions and beliefs of those whom they hold to be heretical.  Underneath the praise, this canto seems to be camouflaging a harsher truth, namely, that the diseases of lust and power are not more potent than the disease of idealism in wreaking the social havocs of murder and torment.   Once, at the prelude of another of the endless wars we fight for resources, for belief-systems, for economic hegemony or for whatever excuse du jour we have for exercising this need for violence, during a protest, my wife carried a placard saying: We should not become the evil we deplore.  And a man walk up to her and said: "Nice sign.  But I don't agree."  Exactly.  Every type of communication — and violence is certainly a form of communication — arises from a substructure of underlying rules and assumptions, and when these forms meet and clash, the interactive domain that separates and unites them is absurd, rife with non-sequiturs, and is much like an ideal that beckons and frustrates because its main allure is the impossibility of its fulfillment.  The process is so disorienting that violence becomes a kind of return to a recognizable home, a way to use chaos to answer the challenge of what is feared to be a worse chaos.  It is a return to home base, a crazy back-stagger to an understandable blood-letting and devastation, whose syntax, vocabulary, and phonemes are pain, and whose meaning is at the dictates of those with the power to inflict pain.  I have a hard time swallowing, whatever our surface reading of this text, that Dante meant to praise the splendors here, because they were expert progenitors of pain.  What I do believe is that Poetry (with that capital P) is what he viewed as a possible — i.e., conditional — antidote, or better, a transcendence of Pain.

What kind of pain are we talking about?  The text summarizes it, but is not graphic, we have to look into historical accounts to get a picture of what actually happened in the Albigensian Crusade and in the various dynastic wars and political wrangles of the times.  And then we have to ask ourselves why adultery and kinship ties were so instrumental in fomenting these atrocities.  Note this account of the destruction of Béziers, one of the heretical Cathars' strongholds.

The camp-followers were intoxicated with success, inflamed by fanaticism and greed.  They had learned from the preachers of the crusade that the southerners were instruments of Satan, protectors of Jews, immeasurably rich.  Once they had penetrated into the streets, they rushed howling through the streets, killing all who had not had time to hide.  Appalling scenes of destruction and violence followed.  The heavily armed knights, not to be outdone in the pursuit of plunder, charged through the gates and invaded the houses, barging aside the camp-followers with cudgels and seizing valuables from their grasp.  The camp-followers, frustrated in their hopes of a rich booty, spread through the city filled with a lust for the destruction of what they could not take for themselves.  They invaded the churches and slaughtered the terrified citizens who had gathered there for safety.  Priests, women, and children were cut down indiscriminately, as they clung to reliquaries and crucifixes.  Of the crowds which had packed the cathedral and the church of the Madeleine, there was not one survivor.  As they passed through the city, the camp-followers lit brands and set fire to all the finer houses which they came upon.  The flames spread rapidly through the wooden buildings.  In the south-eastern corner of the walls the timbers of the cathedral caught fire and the high vault collapsed to entomb the bodies of the massacred citizens inside.  The work of pillage ended only towards the evening when the heat of the blazing city became intolerable and the crusaders were forced to withdraw to the meadows by the rivers.

Although it had been unplanned, the sack of Béziers was not unwelcome by the clerical leaders of the crusade.  Providence had dealt those 'disgusting dogs' their just punishment, reflected Peter of Vaux-de-Cernay.  A German monk repeated the story that Arnald-Amaury, when asked in the middle of the slaughter how the Catholics could be distinguished from the heretics, replied 'Kill them all; God will recognize his own.'

The Albigensian Crusade
Jonathan Sumption

At what point does literature become some personal foray into the very body of the reader, the words hard, foreign intruders invading the vulnerable soft tissues and fomenting those irritations that result in tumorous pearls?  We want to distract ourselves, stop reading and interest ourselves in other things, we would, to quote Melville's Bartleby: Prefer not.  As Pound said in an interview: "It is difficult to write  a Paradiso when all the superficial indications are that you ought to write an apocalypse."  Where in any age are you going to find exemplars for the blessed?  Not easy in 13th or 14th Century Europe, or, in any historical epoch West or East.  Saints are unrecognizable in any contemporary costume.  The sumptuary laws of the age disguise them.  Their naked radiance is mostly confined to legend.  Dante had his map, his geometrical and geographical form, and it seems pretty solid on the surface, but as soon as we drill down a little, it's all molten lava below this thin crust of gangue.  Maybe Dante is saying: Keep drilling, and that molten lava becomes adamant and assumes a crystalline beauty: spinning rubies here and there, and throwing off light in momentary brilliancies that belie their apparent solidity.  The image holds more of paradise than what the explanation of it ever can.  Forget explanations? no, we can't, but the questions are far more wondrous than their answers, so we ask: Why should we want to occupy our minds with this Folco, who appears here to the aspirant, Dante, as a high exemplar of serene bliss?  He is Foquet de Marseille, a famous troubadour, who began his career as a poet and concluded his life as a fierce persecutor of the victims of one of Europe's first genocides, those heretical Manicheans called the Cathars.  In that role, he did a good job, because the main news we have about the Cathar's beliefs and practices come from the orthodox Catholics, their virulent enemies, and from them we gather that the crimes of this sect were crimes of belief, not flesh.   The Cathars did not burn people or murder children or sack cities.  In fact, their leaders, the Parfaits, abhorred violence, and as once source says "We cannot but be amazed at the self-control which these ultra-pacifists displayed: despite really terrible temptation they managed to stick to their vocation in all its purity.  It was certainly neither through fear nor inertia that they chose to restrict their participation in the bloody drama of the Crusade to passive martyrdom.  Their strength, they knew, was not of this world.  As sworn foes of all violence they could only fight with spiritual weapons."  They did not thirst for martyrdom, but when it came to them to fuel human bonfires, they succumbed "with a serenity that would have shaken the faith of less fanatical adversaries, a "courage that their executioners attributed to their incredible obduracy in crime."   They were the heroes and saints of working class people and peasants, who, like them,  saw and suffered the horrors of the secular and orthodox ecclesiastical authorities.  They saw the corruption of the Church officials, endured the tyranny of princes like Cunizza's brother Ezzelino, and were fodder for the armies of those rulers, who, far from being their protectors, were their murderers and plunderers, and from these conditions, they surmised that this world was a Hell, and could not have been created by a God who was good, but rather by one who was evil, and so they postulated a duality of deities, with Satan the ruler of this World wherein the most atrocious violence and exploitations were the accepted norms.  They vituperated the flesh as a nest of corruption.  They held that the sacraments and the bought and sold indulgences and confessions of the Church were shams, since no man could relieve another of his sins.  They postulated a doctrine of reincarnation and the transmigration of souls, raised the status of women to that of equality, abjured the eating of flesh, and denied the sanctity of the cross, by holding that if Jesus were their friend and savior, it would be perverse to venerate the instrument of his execution.  They saw the rite of communion as a cannibalistic imposture.  Sexual propagation in such a world could be regarded as a crime, since it perpetuated the evils of mortality, and subjected the spirit even of infants to this world's corruption.  They certainly were not suicidal, as their enemies often claimed, since they did all in their power, except resorting to violence, to preserve themselves.  But when death came, it came as at least a temporary release from this world's sufferings.  These were the beliefs that inflamed the orthodox to genocide.  The heresy had long roots in European history and the main features of their beliefs emerged under different names and with different practices, but the gnostic ideas of this world's evil and the need of the individual to be responsible for her or his own spiritual condition seem common to them all.  Their history and their beliefs can be studied in such books as Arthur Guirdham's The Great Heresy: The History and Beliefs of the Cathars, or in Sean Martin's The Cathars: The Most Successful Heresy of the Middle Ages, or in Jean Markale's Montségur and the Mystery of the Cathars, or in Massacre at Montségur: A History of the Albigensian Crusade by Zoe Oldenbourg (quoted above).  Their fate can be traced through many, many other sources, and the story of their annihilation is numerously documented.  This heresy and its persecution exposes a number of issues lurking below the surface in this canto.  One, being the promiscuities, either for pleasure or for propagation of Cunizza’s, and the other being the sexual frustration which lies at the heart of much of the poetic tradition of the troubadours, which as Blake, centuries later pointed out, was the source of much violence in the individual and in the world.  When the lady turns cold, cruel, and refuses, the thwarted lover turns to martial acts of violence as a way to justify himself in hers and in his own eyes.  These themes of unrequitable love and the glorification of war are the métier of the troubadours' poetry, which often but thinly veils a subtext of adulterous seductions.  Here is a prose translation of a poem attributed to Folco before piety overtook him and he became a inquisitorial Bishop:

During the long and dark night,
Which is never too long for me, 
I am, despite the cold weather,
A restless watchmen over lovers' discretion,
Until the first light I stand guard to protect my friend,
Then I urge with my cry:
Beware, here comes the dawn.

The Music of the Troubadours, Vol. 1
Edited by Peter Whigham

Dawn — Alba — was a disaster for the illicit lover, in so far as it exposed his adultery, and all through the tradition, which had its own elaborate rules and forms of action and poetic expression, there is constantly a kind of torture associated with love, a dark play between denial and societally expected but condemned pleasure, a kind of sexual bizzarro world where light is dark, and darkness and secrecy are extolled and venerated along with conspiratorial assignations, and heroic violence.  Their set of virtues, if we can call them that, still survives today in the popular imagination as part of the romantic tradition that has led to such things as an angry lover calling into a radio station to say:  "This song is for Maria, I'm sorry I stabbed you."  Misogyny, frustration, violence — sex as a lever to exercise power, and love denigrated to the so-called battle of the sexes, much of this is the legacy of the courtly love tradition of the troubadours, and is the source of much great and terrible art, while ginning up a huge psychiatric industry.  It should be noted, lest the connection be in anyway obscure, that often these songs of the troubadours followed note for note the music of religious hymns.  These are the contradictions that seethed through the earthly lives of Cunizza and Folco, and these the source of the projections — as Freud would have called them — which led to the kinds of persecutions and extremes of violence of which, even the graphic words quoted above, cannot capture the full horror.  What kind of people were these blessed souls who appear in this canto, and what for them was the expression of spirit?   I find in the following quote from Walter Benjamin, a disturbing historical rhyme:

  

... spirit is the capacity to exercise dictatorship.  This capacity requires both strict inner discipline and unscrupulous external action.  Its practice brought to the world an icy disillusion which is matched in intensity only by the fierce aspiration of the will to power.  Such a conception of the perfect conduct on the part of a man of the world awakens a mood of mourning in the creature stripped of all naive  impulses.  And thus, his mood permits the paradoxical demand for saintliness ... 

The Origin of the German Tragic Drama
Walter Benjamin

I repeat, this canto's business seems to be to explore

The interrelationships of sex, violence, power, and spirit.

Accounts of Folco's life reveal him to have been a militant fanatic with a gift of persuasive rhetoric which he exploited for personal power.  He is said to have treated his Bishopric of Toulouse as his own private domain, wherein he assumed both political and ecclesiastical authority, as accounts affirm, as if he owned the place.  One of his great accomplishments was to found a gang of militant orthodox Catholics called the "White Brotherhood," whose members engaged in avowedly terrorist acts, a sort of self-sanctified mob of thugs, who like Brown Shirts or the Frei Corp went about beating, murdering, and generally fomenting civil war, all the while singing songs composed by their rascal master — perhaps a parody of the singing, dancing spirits we find in this canto.  This Folco was a real piece of work, and if you set about combing the annals of those times for a less likely candidate for the bliss in which Dante, the aspirant, finds him here, you would be hard pressed to find one ... which is why, if you know Folco's career, as Dante's contemporaries undoubtedly did, you could hardly fail to see an irony here that would make the satires of Juvenal seem like the extravagancies of praise.  Red he certainly is, but imagining his spirit burning in a crimson lake of the blood he caused to be shed is more morally palatable then seeing him spin joyfully like a ruby shining in the sun. 

This canto, ah!, the more I dug into it, the more uneasy my stomach became, and the less capable I was to delve more.  For a long time I churned, and wrote nothing.  And I still churn, but now I write too much ... and not just because of the irony, but also because another kind of message might still be gleaned here, one that is free of cynicism, free of that mood of mourning which Benjamin so aptly postulates.  What indeed is the power of devotion?  Not even discipline ... but true devotion ... devotion which saves, no matter how adulterous, or violent its expression when it burns sincerely and joyfully in the devotee's heart and mind?  Is it possible to be saved when committing the most abominable of crimes, because you have an authentic belief in their righteousness?  Or, even eschewing such unsavory ideas, could it be that the power of grace is so great that it redeems and transforms even the most heinous actions and beliefs?  Are the lights of the spirits in this canto exemplars because they never gave up their belief in this power of grace to transform?  If we have lived many lives, or lived through many lives in the life of the mind, surely we have played all roles, been victims as well as victimizers, committed all crimes, and practiced all virtues ... and if this is what underlies the power of grace to bathe us in Lethe and Eunoe, to forget everything but our bliss, to love and to take pleasure in sharing pleasure, then paradise is not a place where the scales of justice are balanced, because the whole dichotomy of justice and injustice, especially retributive justice, which is what we see throughout the Commedia as the privilege and even the duty of God, is simply irrelevant.  Grace has no conditions, it may merely be accepted.  I have to admit that these questions posed in the Commedia's Paradiso hang fire for me.  They stir up emotions  and dredge up thoughts and images more disturbing than any I encountered while reading the Purgatorio or the Inferno.  The auto-de-fay of bliss is inexplicable. 


1  Beautiful Clemence, after that thy Charles
2  Had me enlightened, he narrated to me
3  The treacheries his seed should undergo;

1  Da poi che Carlo tuo, bella Clemenza,
2  m'ebbe chiarito, mi narrò li 'nganni
3  che ricever dovea la sua semenza;

4  But said: "Be still and let the years roll round;"
5  So I can only say, that lamentation
6  Legitimate shall follow on your wrongs.

4  ma disse: “Taci e lascia muover li anni”;
5  si ch'io non posso dir se non che pianto
6  giusto verrà di retro ai vostri danni.
7  And of that holy light the life already
8  Had to the Sun which fills it turned again,
9  As to that good which for each thing sufficeth.

7  E già la vita di quel lume santo
8  rivolta s'era al Sol che la rïempie
9  come quel ben ch'a ogne cosa è tanto.
10  Ah, souls deceived, and creatures impious,
11  Who from such good do turn away your hearts,
12  Directing upon vanity your foreheads!

10  Ahi anime ingannate e fatture empie,
11  che da sì fatto ben torcete i cuori,
12  drizzando in vanità le vostre tempie!
13  And now, behold, another of those splendours
14  Approached me, and its will to pleasure me
15  It signified by brightening outwardly.

13  Ed ecco un altro di quelli splendori
14  ver' me si fece, e 'l suo voler piacermi
15  significava nel chiarir di fori.
16  The eyes of Beatrice, that fastened were
17  Upon me, as before, of dear assent
18  To my desire assurance gave to me.

16  Li occhi di Bëatrice, ch'eran fermi
17  sovra me, come pria, di caro assenso
18  al mio disio certificato fermi.
19  "Ah, bring swift compensation to my wish,
20  Thou blessed spirit," I said, "and give me proof
21  That what I think in thee I can reflect!"

19  “Deh, metti al mio voler tosto compenso,
20  beato spirto,” dissi, “e fammi prova
21  ch'i' possa in te refletter quel ch'io penso!”
22  Whereat the light, that still was new to me,
23  Out of its depths, whence it before was singing,
24  As one delighted to do good, continued:

22  Onde la luce che m'era ancor nova,
23  del suo profondo, ond' ella pria cantava,
24  seguette come a cui di ben far giova:
25  "Within that region of the land depraved
26  Of Italy, that lies between Rialto
27  And fountain-heads of Brenta and of Piava,

25  “In quella parte de la terra prava
26  italica che siede tra Rïalto
27  e le fontane di Brenta e di Piava,
28  Rises a hill, and mounts not very high,
29  Wherefrom descended formerly a torch
30  That made upon that region great assault.

28  si leva un colle, e non surge molt' alto,
29  là onde scese già una facella
30  che fece a la contrada un grande assalto.

31  Out of one root were born both I and it;
32  Cunizza was I called, and here I shine
33  Because the splendour of this star o'ercame me.

31  D'una radice nacqui e io ed ella:
32  Cunizza fui chiamata, e qui refulgo
33  perché mi vinse il lume d'esta stella;

34  But gladly to myself the cause I pardon
35  Of my allotment, and it does not grieve me;
36  Which would perhaps seem strong unto your vulgar.

34  ma lietamente a me medesma indulgo
35  la cagion di mia sorte, e non mi noia;
36  che parria forse forte al vostro vulgo.

37  Of this so luculent and precious jewel,
38  Which of our heaven is nearest unto me,
39  Great fame remained; and ere it die away

37  Di questa luculenta e cara gioia
38  del nostro cielo che più m'è propinqua,
39  grande fama rimase; e pria che moia,

40  This hundredth year shall yet quintupled be.
41  See if man ought to make him excellent,
42  So that another life the first may leave!

40  questo centesimo anno ancor s'incinqua:
41  vedi se far si dee l'omo eccellente,
42  sì ch'altra vita la prima relinqua.

43  And thus thinks not the present multitude
44  Shut in by Adige and Tagliamento,
45  Nor yet for being scourged is penitent.

43  E ciò non pensa la turba presente
44  che Tagliamento e Adice richiude,
45  né per esser battuta ancor si pente;

46  But soon 'twill be that Padua in the marsh
47  Will change the water that Vicenza bathes,
48  Because the folk are stubborn against duty;

46  ma tosto fia che Padova al palude
47  cangerà l'acqua che Vincenza bagna,
48  per essere al dover le genti crude;

49  And where the Sile and Cagnano join
50  One lordeth it, and goes with lofty head,
51  For catching whom e'en now the net is making.

49  e dove Sile e Cagnan s'accompagna,
50  tal signoreggia e va con la testa alta,
51  che già per lui carpir si fa la ragna.

52  Feltro moreover of her impious pastor
53  Shall weep the crime, which shall so monstrous be
54  That for the like none ever entered Malta.

52  Piangerà Feltro ancora la difalta
53  de l'empio suo pastor, che sarà sconcia
54  sì, che per simil non s'entrò in malta.

55  Ample exceedingly would be the vat
56  That of the Ferrarese could hold the blood,
57  And weary who should weigh it ounce by ounce,

55  Troppo sarebbe larga la bigoncia
56  che ricevesse il sangue ferrarese,
57  e stanco chi 'l pesasse a oncia a oncia,

58  Of which this courteous priest shall make a gift
59  To show himself a partisan; and such gifts
60  Will to the living of the land conform.

58  che donerà questo prete cortese
59  per mostrarsi di parte; e cotai doni
60  conformi fieno al viver del paese.

61  Above us there are mirrors, Thrones you call them,
62  From which shines out on us God Judicant,
63  So that this utterance seems good to us."

61  Sù sono specchi, voi dicete Troni,
62  onde refulge a noi Dio giudicante;
63  sì che questi parlar ne paion buoni.”

64  Here it was silent, and it had the semblance
65  Of being turned elsewhither, by the wheel
66  On which it entered as it was before.

64  Qui si tacette; e fecemi sembiante
65  che fosse ad altro volta, per la rota
66  in che si mise com' era davante.

67  The other joy, already known to me,
68  Became a thing transplendent in my sight,
69  As a fine ruby smitten by the sun.

67  L'altra letizia, che m'era già nota
68  per cara cosa, mi si fece in vista
69  qual fin balasso in che lo sol percuota.

70  Through joy effulgence is acquired above,
71  As here a smile; but down below, the shade
72  Outwardly darkens, as the mind is sad.

70  Per letiziar là sù fulgor s'acquista,
71  sì come riso qui; ma giù s'abbuia
72  l'ombra di fuor, come la mente è trista.

73  "God seeth all things, and in Him, blest spirit,
74  Thy sight is," said I, "so that never will
75  Of his can possibly from thee be hidden;

73  “Dio vede tutto, e tuo veder s'inluia,”
74  diss' io, “beato spirto, sì che nulla
75  voglia di sé a te puot' esser fuia.

76  Thy voice, then, that for ever makes the heavens
77  Glad, with the singing of those holy fires
78  Which of their six wings make themselves a cowl,

76  Dunque la voce tua, che 'l ciel trastulla
77  sempre col canto di quei fuochi pii
78  che di sei ali facen la coculla,

79  Wherefore does it not satisfy my longings?
80  Indeed, I would not wait thy questioning
81  If I in thee were as thou art in me."

79  perché non satisface a' miei disii?
80  Già non attendere' io tua dimanda,
81  s'io m'intuassi, come tu t'inmii.”

82  "The greatest of the valleys where the water
83  Expands itself," forthwith its words began,
84  "That sea excepted which the earth engarlands,

82  “La maggior valle in che l'acqua si spanda,”
83  incominciaro allor le sue parole,
84  “fuor di quel mar che la terra inghirlanda,

85  Between discordant shores against the sun
86  Extends so far, that it meridian makes
87  Where it was wont before to make the horizon.

85  tra ' discordanti liti contra 'l sole
86  tanto sen va, che fa meridïano
87  là dove l'orizzonte pria far suole.

88  I was a dweller on that valley's shore
89  'Twixt Ebro and Magra that with journey short
90  Doth from the Tuscan part the Genoese.

88  Di quella valle fu' io litorano
89  tra Ebro e Macra, che per cammin corto
90  parte lo Genovese dal Toscano.

91  With the same sunset and same sunrise nearly
92  Sit Buggia and the city whence I was,
93  That with its blood once made the harbour hot.

91  Ad un occaso quasi e ad un orto
92  Buggea siede e la terra ond' io fui,
93  che fé del sangue suo già caldo il porto.

94  Folco that people called me unto whom
95  My name was known; and now with me this heaven
96  Imprints itself, as I did once with it;

94  Folco mi disse quella gente a cui
95  fu noto il nome mio; e questo cielo
96  di me s'imprenta, com' io fe' di lui;

97  For more the daughter of Belus never burned,
98  Offending both Sichaeus and Creusa,
99  Than I, so long as it became my locks,

97  ché più non arse la figlia di Belo,
98  noiando e a Sicheo e a Creusa,
99  di me, infin che si convenne al pelo;

100  Nor yet that Rodophean, who deluded
101  was by Demophoon, nor yet Alcides,
102  When Iole he in his heart had locked.

100  né quella Rodopëa che delusa
101  fu da Demofoonte, né Alcide
102  quando Iole nel core ebbe rinchiusa.

103  Yet here is no repenting, but we smile,
104  Not at the fault, which comes not back to mind,
105  But at the power which ordered and foresaw.

103  Non però qui si pente, ma si ride,
104  non de la colpa, ch'a mente non torna,
105  ma del valor ch'ordinò e provide.

106  Here we behold the art that doth adorn
107  With such affection, and the good discover
108  Whereby the world above turns that below.

106  Qui si rimira ne l'arte ch'addorna
107  cotanto affetto, e discernesi 'l bene
108  per che 'l mondo di sù quel di giù torna.

109  But that thou wholly satisfied mayst bear
110  Thy wishes hence which in this sphere are born,
111  Still farther to proceed behoveth me.

109  Ma perché tutte le tue voglie piene
110  ten porti che son nate in questa spera,
111  procedere ancor oltre mi convene.

112  Thou fain wouldst know who is within this light
113  That here beside me thus is scintillating,
114  Even as a sunbeam in the limpid water.

112  Tu vuo' saper chi è in questa lumera
113  che qui appresso me così scintilla
114  come raggio di sole in acqua mera.

115  Then know thou, that within there is at rest
116  Rahab, and being to our order joined,
117  With her in its supremest grade 'tis sealed.

115  Or sappi che là entro si tranquilla
116  Raab; e a nostr' ordine congiunta,
117  di lei nel sommo grado si sigilla.

118  Into this heaven, where ends the shadowy cone
119  Cast by your world, before all other souls
120  First of Christ's triumph was she taken up.

118  Da questo cielo, in cui l'ombra s'appunta
119  che 'l vostro mondo face, pria ch'altr' alma
120  del trïunfo di Cristo fu assunta.

121  Full meet it was to leave her in some heaven,
122  Even as a palm of the high victory
123  Which he acquired with one palm and the other,

121  Ben si convenne lei lasciar per palma
122  in alcun cielo de l'alta vittoria
123  che s'acquistò con l'una e l'altra palma,

124  Because she favoured the first glorious deed
125  Of Joshua upon the Holy Land,
126  That little stirs the memory of the Pope.

124  perch' ella favorò la prima gloria
125  di Iosüè in su la Terra Santa,
126  che poco tocca al papa la memoria.

127  Thy city, which an offshoot is of him
128  Who first upon his Maker turned his back,
129  And whose ambition is so sorely wept,

127  La tua città, che di colui è pianta
128  che pria volse le spalle al suo fattore
129  e di cui è la 'nvidia tanto pianta,

130  Brings forth and scatters the accursed flower
131  Which both the sheep and lambs hath led astray
132  Since it has turned the shepherd to a wolf.

130  produce e spande il maladetto fiore
131  c'ha disvïate le pecore e li agni,
132 però che fatto ha lupo del pastore.

133  For this the Evangel and the mighty Doctors
134  Are derelict, and only the Decretals
135  So studied that it shows upon their margins.

133  Per questo l'Evangelio e i dottor magni
134  son derelitti, e solo ai Decretali
135  si studia, sì che pare a' lor vivagni.

136  On this are Pope and Cardinals intent;
137  Their meditations reach not Nazareth,
138  There where his pinions Gabriel unfolded;

136  A questo intende il papa e ' cardinali;
137  non vanno i lor pensieri a Nazarette,
138  là dove Gabrïello aperse l'ali.

139  But Vatican and the other parts elect
140  Of Rome, which have a cemetery been
141  Unto the soldiery that followed Peter

139  Ma Vaticano e l'altre parti elette
140  di Roma che son state cimitero
141  a la milizia che Pietro seguette,

142  Shall soon be free from this adultery."

142  tosto libere fien de l'avoltero.”

Canto X
The heaven of the Sun may be compared to Arithmetic because of two properties: one is that all the other stars are informed by its light; the other is that the eye cannot look at it.  And these two properties are found in Arithmetic: for by its light all sciences are illuminated, because all their subjects are considered under some numerical aspect, and in considering them we always proceed by number.  For example, in Natural Science, the subject is a body in motion, which body in motion has in itself the principle of continuity, and this has in itself the principle of infinite number; and its foremost consideration is to consider the principles of natural things, which are three–namely matter, privation, and form–in which we perceive this numerical aspect.  Number exists not only in all of them together, but also, upon careful reflection, in each one individually; for this reason Pythagoras, as Aristotle says in the first book of the Physics, laid down even and odd as the principles of natural things, considering all things to have numerical aspect.  The other property of the Sun is also seen in number, of which Arithmetic is the science: the eye of the intellect cannot look upon it, because number insofar as it is considered in itself is infinite, and this we cannot comprehend.

Convivio, Book II, Chapter xiii

94  Of the lambs was I of the holy flock
95  Which Dominic conducteth by a road
96  Where well one fattens if he strayeth not.

94  Io fui de li agni de la santa greggia
95  che Domenico mena per cammino
96  u' ben s'impingua se non si vaneggia.

Paradiso, Canto 10

Before beginning to think about Paradiso Canto 10, I want to at first point out, and then put aside for future reference, as Dante himself did, this passage regarding the fattening of lambs.  Here, lambs are perhaps fattened by wisdom or a piety which leads to wisdom, but we all know why lambs are fattened, that is, for slaughter.  We are exhorted to fill ourselves with such wisdom, although the road leads, as it did for Jesus in the temporal world, to crucifixion.  If we delve into the constellation of sheep metaphors which occur throughout the Gospels, and the scriptures in general, but especially in Revelations: the lost sheep, the lamb of God, the prodigal son's homecoming feast, the division of sheep and goats at the apotheosis, we find what we find here, a profoundly unsettling use of language which, in one phrase, contains both a positive and negative emotional pole, so that however much we might like to be fattened or fulfilled by our reading, the sinister undercurrent of the extreme return to the poverty of death lurks just beneath that fulfilling abundance, the emptiness, feeding on fulness, and as we shall see in the next canto, with the long exposition on St. Francis’s marriage with Lady Poverty, the fulness fattening on emptiness.  This seems to be a conundrum that cannot be gainsaid even in paradise, and yet, in this canto, with its arithmetical substructure of order ... well, I think we have reached the very portal here which leads to a higher dimension, since whatever that conundrum is, it seems to be foundational in the construction of any temporal reality whose components are three dimensions of space and one of time.  Dante's audaciousness here is to go beyond that reality, and to create a structure of language which enables himself and his readers to likewise transcend it ... but, how?  how?  Digressions digress and we become entangled in disordered thoughts and feelings, just as we catch a glimpse of this higher dimension's order.

We cannot perceive disorder, because a very complex order of physiology, sensory interpretation, and ideational selection and/or projection must already be present for any act of perception or thought to take place.  Now, we might be able to "create" disorder, say, by means of an atomic explosion, but to manage such an enormity would require an highly ordered process of invention, planning, and execution — so that even in such an extreme case of violence, an ordered procedure would be necessary even to create chaos, and if we should survive such, it would only be by means of a highly ordered process.  Before we get into the arithmetical expression of that order, we need to realize that whether we contemplate this order or we use our own senses and intellect, which are but products of this order to stray away from this essential contemplation, that this process has been the subject of the entire Commedia, with its three realms and terza rima form.  God, as we are told in this canto, never allows his love nor his attention to be diverted from the manifestation of His three part order.  But as we have seen throughout the Inferno, the Purgatorio, and even in the Paradiso up to this point, the spirits, to the degree in which they suffer or are blessed, attend lovingly to this trinity, forget it, or deny it.  God never forgets them, but they forget God, and to the extent that they do so, or as we are reminded as readers, in direct address in this canto, the extent that we do so, and the manner in which we do so, is the precise degree in which we suffer.  God is this trinity, this order, and to allow ourselves to use our God-given senses and reason ( a most important aspect of our contemplation, when the senses are overwhelmed by splendor) to stray from this contemplation is to not only forget God but also to forget our own essence, the purpose of our birth and our life, and finally, our destiny.  To contemplate this trinity is to contemplate Sophia, who is wisdom, the son, and the sun.  It is to taste the divine.  Why taste?  A question that begs to be addressed, as we contemplate this canto ... but that issue will have to wait, while we contemplate the 12, the crown, the circle, the sun, and, finally, Time in its east to west processional and west to east precessional.  In various ways, the 12 spirits we encounter here exemplify by their works and their lives, that, like God, they made their focus a devotion to and a contemplation of the wisdom embodied in this order.  Dante, in spite of his rapture, never forgets reason, but here reason is ratio, an arithmetical order.  As to the subject of "taste," we could say that taste is the ephemera of food, our physical nourishment, and as such it represents, as do numbers, a metaphysical nourishment.  But as we shall see, Dante, uses metaphors for all the senses as they lead us beyond themselves to spirit.  But here, the senses are just signposts on the way to something else.  What that something else is dazzles beyond the grasp of the senses and even the ordinary use of poetic language.  That something else is the essence of this canto. 

Yesterday, January 6th, 2021, the Feast of the Epiphany, and my daughter's birthday, the United States' capitol was breached by a mob of racists incited to violence by the sitting president.  Their goal was not a protest to address a grievance, or change a law, or a policy, their goal, as is that of all people who cannot muster the intelligence to create or maintain order in their own lives, was therefor to subvert it.  That such events, that such people, are the lowest denizens of any kind of social order in any historical period that you may choose seems to be a permanent feature of civilization, a permanent substructure of the temporal human condition.  By lowest, here, I do not mean people without social position or power, I mean people whose moral sense is both violent and chaotic.  If you have the leisure to read this or to read Dante, you probably are at the periphery of these expressions of violent chaos — which is not to be confused with creative ferment — and if so, you probably have but a superficial notion of what Dante personally experienced in his own exile from Florence and the imposition of a death sentence should he return.  The emotional thrust of the entire Commedia has been to bring the ideal of Divine Justice into a temporal realm, because Justice is that which puts a curb on violence and chaos by means of a universal code of fairness under the law.  And as Dante's work shows, with its popes and kings in Hell, Divine Justice operates much like what in Eastern religions acts like the law of Karma, the harm that you do returns in kind as harm that you too must suffer.  But the questions are: What is Justice? and does Justice itself by its very premises of balance and fairness, nevertheless carry the seeds of violence and chaos in the operations of its law.  Is God cruel?  Is the universe cruel?  In Canto IX of the Paradiso we saw the so called blessèd souls of people whose earthly crimes were as heinous, or even more heinous, than those they persecuted.  All through the first two canticles of the Commedia, and even through paradise up to this point, violence, pain, and chaos as well as the mental and emotional states of vengeance and retribution, which subject the soul to violence, pain, and chaos, have been paramount.  But here, in Canto 10 of the Paradiso, all that has suddenly (I should say "atemporally") changed.  We might even say that up to this point we have only been in the anteroom of Paradise, but now we enter into Paradise proper.  Here order reigns, and there is no need for retribution, vengeance, violence or chaos to punish or rectify injustice.  This is one of the most remarkable attributes of Dante and his Commedia, that this poet, this poem, which have expressed so well and with such a sense of ordered creativity the issue of Justice, now is able to rise above the very foundations of  its reason for being.  If we are to believe in the diachronic nature of this poem, that there is always an aspirant learning inside the poem as its protagonist, and always a poet, outside the poem, who has already transcended this deepest and most profound issue, then we have arrived here at the first seed of the poet's inspiration, the condition which his meeting with Beatrice foreshadowed and which was the experience of love described in the Vita Nuova.  We have arrived at this maturation point, where even Beatrice is forgotten.  In this stage of the poem's flight, the earlier stages have been jettisoned.  They were necessary in their way so that the poem could achieve "escape velocity," but now they are not needed nor is the subject of Justice as a system of violence and retribution even mentioned.  In the sphere of the sun, we are in a new world.  And where is this world?  Dante is precise, this world is entered through a portal at the very place where the sun's daily east to west movement, like the meshing of the gears of a clock, connects with the Zodiacal west to east precession.  Blake says, "Eternity is in love with the productions of time," and in other insights, that "all the Great/ events of Time start forth & are conceived in such a Period/Within a Moment: a Pulsation of the Artery." or "There is a Moment in each Day that Satan cannot find/Nor can his Watch Fiends find it, but the Industrious find/This Moment & it multiply. & when it once is found/ It renovates every Moment of the Day if rightly placed."  THis moment is the wormhole that the Commedia in this canto has found.  This is the place where the truths of the text are like jewels which would become paste if they were ever to leave the domain in which their true value shines.  The ineffability theme is reiterated here, but I think that what Dante is saying that if we switch our attention from ordinary linguistic structures, which cannot directly convey the true sense of this Divine Order, we can nevertheless point to an arithmetical and geometric order that does indeed reveal this expression of the Divine when it shines through as the substructure of those linguistic expressions.

I don't want to imply here that there is some universal truth or absolute interpretation that reveals for every reader the layers of order in this text.  I don't even want to assert that the order of this text will be the same for me at another reading.  But I do want to at least hint at a way of reading that is flirtatious (as the language in this canto implies), and self-transforming.
We are veiwing another dimension of reality from a lower dimension, and like flatlanders in a two-dimensional world, the appearance of three-dimensional entities for us will appear as anomolies, or even absurdities, and will be immediately interpreted as a part of the world we know.  So unsettling are the intrusions of these anomolies that our ordinary consciousness will have what amounts to an immune system response, and their threat will be attacked and expunged as much as is possible.  But just imagine this possibility.  The 12 spirits here are arranged in a crown-like shape, each spirit occupying a numbered place in the clock face, and as we proceed in the circle, as Dante instructs us to do, we return to a place where the orthodox Thomas Aquinus is standing next to the heretical Siger, the opposites juxtaposed, and no longer in opposition in any geometrical sense.  Now let's do another operation.  Let's draw lines through the center of the circle and connect the opposites numbers, then add the 6 totals.  12 + 6 would be 18, 1 + 7 would be 8, 2 + 8 would be 10, 3 + 9 would be 12, 4 + 10 would be 14, 5 + 11 would be 16.  Now add these totals: 18, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16.  The answer is 78, and 7 + 8 is 15, and 1 + 5 is  6, the trinity doubled.  You can also arrive at the 6 by doing what numerologists do, which is reducing by addition all mulitiple digit numbers to a single digit.  It we do that, we get a sequence of 9,8,1,3,5,7, the total being 33, and adding 3 + 3 again we get 6, the trinity doubled.  6 is the smallest perfect number, the first positive integer that is equal to the sum of its proper divisors, the sum of 1,2, and 3.  What we have here is the revelation of an underlying order, and when we return to Dante's exposition wherein he allegorically relates the order of the sun to the subject of arithmetic, to number, then this underlying order relates to the subject of the trinity, in what may be an arbitrary interpretation, but it is nevertheless the kind of interpretation that lies beyond the grasp of the senses (all of which Dante is carefull to ennumerate in his various transmutations of metaphors throughout this canto) an interpretation which is only perceivable through the MIND, and an interpretation which dazzles the mind.  I could not find the exact quote (but have listed below several quotes pertaining1) where Jung says something like this: Numbers come into play when the unconscious is most in need of subduing its own chaotic irrationality.  An exercise like the ones demonstrated above is an irrational application of rational law to discover the order lying at the heart of disorder, the ratio at the heart of the irrational.  This irrational ordering power is the trinity: matter, privation, and form, all this being the three-fold entity which is LOVE.  All this language of the senses, this language, quite frankly, of eroticism, of an almost naive and childish kind, is what arithmatic's ordering procedures reveal as that ordering MIND which the 12 scribes of God here exemplify, a love of Sophia, wisdom, not merely in linguistic philosophical proofs, but in Pythagorian allegories.  It seems as if what this canto is saying is that however shifting and strange, however violent and chaotic is the temporal world of personalities, nature, and politics, whenever and wherever we probe deeply enough, we find Divine Order.  The discovery of this truth about order/chaos/love/eroticism, spiritual inception and maturity culminates in this sphere of the sun, where God is described as finding unending delight in making, reciting, and permutating the meanings of this poem of His/Her Creation.

Certainly other numbers are at play in this arithmetical canto.  But the one that draws my attention here, as it did Dante's contemporaries, is the number 5, the number assigned to Solomon, who is here described as

109  The fifth light, that among us is the fairest,
110  Breathes forth from such a love, that all the world
111  Below is greedy to learn tidings of it.

109  La quinta luce, ch'è tra noi più bella,
110  spira di tale amor, che tutto 'l mondo
111  là giù ne gola di saper novella:

112  Within it is the lofty mind, where knowledge
113  So deep was put, that, if the true be true,
114  To see so much there never rose a second.

112  entro v'è l'alta mente u' sì profondo
113  saver fu messo, che, se 'l vero è vero,
114  a veder tanto non surse il secondo.

In Dante's time, whether or not Solomon was saved was a hot issue.  Partly because he succumbed to idolatry, but mainly because of his prolific sexual indulgences.  There is certainly a hint here, especially when we combine these verses with other flirtatious language in the canto that Solomon's wisdom did not come about in spite of his carnal knowledge, but because  of it.  In Sanskrit plays, there is a movement towards something called rasa — peace, serenity, the feeling of oneness arising from a sense of wholeness.  Rasa is a single, ineffable, transcendental joy, and these most ancient examples of theater move towards achieving rasa and experiencing, at least for a moment, a dispassionate delight in the essence of an impersonal emotion.  But to arrive at this state, all the plays begin with desire, affection, and erotic longing, and from there work through various states of giddiness, cynicism, scorn, anger, sadness, pride, fear, aversion, and wonder.  Something like this seems to be occurring here, through a reference to the works of Solomon as another scribe of God.  His is a soul that has been made beautiful and wise by its passage through the flames of eroticism (See Great Sanskrit Plays in Modern Translation, P. Lal).  Solomon is the number 5.  Curiously, if we add the two erotic figures in the center of the circle of 12, we come to a total of 14, added together 5.  5 is the center of all the simple numbers, 1 - 9 — and we know how important the 9 is in Dante's arithmetical cosmology, starting with the fact that he and Beatrice were both 9 years old when they first met.  Thus, 5 is the heart, and this heart can be seen in the following two configurations wherein 5 occupies both center positions.

1   2   3
4   5   6
7   8   9

    or

1   4   7
2   5   8
3   6   9

Any reader with the tenacity for playing such games could probably find many more examples as equally quixotic and trivial as they are fundamental and perhaps profound.  But what occurs to me is that all through these first cantos of the Paradiso, Dante has been looking for ways to describe difference without decay or death or diabolic heresies incompatible with divine unity.  In these allegories of arithmetic, he may have found the wisdom which accomplishes just that.
 
We are in Canto 10 of the Paradiso.  Why this revelation of the trinity and numbers in Canto 10?  Because 10 is the God of Numbers.  Consider, reader, irrational reader, the following penultimate passage from The Meaning and Philosophy of Numbers by Leonard Bosman:

That this number 10 represents Completion and Perfection is also shown by the fact that it is the complete and final number, all others being evolved from it, or from its components.  All numbers are built up from the primordial one, two, and three, and the first step from this trinity, the junction of one and three, gives four, and from these all numbers originate, there total being ten.  Without a manifested trinity of numbers, nothing can be produced, for 1 + 2 = 3, 3 + 1 = 4, 3 + 2 = 5, 3 + 2 + 1 = 6, 4 + 3 = 7, 4 + 3 + 1 = 8, 3 + 3 + 4 = 9, 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 = 10.  Beyond this all is repetition and multiplication.  Hence 10 is rightly named the perfect number, for all numbers subsist therein.

If one is left cold by this possibility that Dante was quite serious about this transference of erotic desire to an armature of abstract numbers, I would very much like to agree.  And it may seem quite ridiculous to assert such a thing.  But a genius of the magnitude of Dante has a way of making interpreters look ridiculous, and if you're going to commit yourself to the serious (but not earnest) task of reading him, you have to be willing to play the fool from time to time as a token of devotion.  That said, I have more than a sneaking suspicion that something like this transference of the sexual to the spiritual, of the intellect to love is actually one of Dante's intents.  The argument that it is his intent — and that there is scriptural and historical support for just such a transference — is ably put forth by Robert Hollander in his commentary on this canto.

Dante, having conflated love and intellect, at least by the opening of this canto, can use the vocabularies interchangeably, or substitute the former for the latter, as he does here. Psychologists refer to another version of this process as sublimation, an attempt to skirt a painful awareness of sexual desire by replacing it with a more “acceptable” activity.  In Jesus' teaching (e.g., the wise virgins preparing for the arrival of the bridegroom [Matth. 25:1-13]) we can see a more positive sense of sexuality, if it is also simultaneously seen as the basis for its own supersession, taking carnal pleasure past its physical expression and its physical limits. E.g., “If you enjoy the thought of consummating a marriage, oh, will you enjoy the kingdom of Heaven!”  It would seem likely that Dante's transposition of terms generally associated with sexual desire to descriptions of the longing for God, as innovative as it may seem to be, is in fact a continuation of a highly similar practice in Jesus' teaching, as it is found with some frequency in the Gospels.
   
1  1. There is no reason why whole numbers possess certain meanings or qualities, and no reason why elephants or men should exist.  These arrangements are simply there as given facts, like the crystalline systems or the discontinuities of physics, even as the whole of creation is a “just-so story.”  ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Page 355.

2. I have got stuck, on the one hand, in the acausality (or “synchronicity”) of certain phenomena of unconscious provenance and, on the other hand, in the qualitative statements of numbers, for here I set foot on territories where I cannot advance without the help and understanding of the other disciplines. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 351-352.

3. Like all the inner foundations of judgment, numbers are archetypal by nature and consequently partake of the psychic qualities of the archetype. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 327-329.

4. It would be a worthy task for a mathematician to collect all the known properties of numbers and also all their “inescapable” statements which should be quite possible up to 10 — and in this way project a biological picture of whole numbers. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 327-329.

5. It is a mathematical structure, which first made me hit on the idea that the unconscious somehow avails itself of the properties of whole numbers. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 327-329.

6. From this it appears that whole numbers are individuals, and that they Possess properties which cannot be explained on the assumption that they are multiple units. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 327-329.

7. The idea that numbers were invented for counting is obviously untenable, since they are not only pre-existent to judgment but possess properties which were discovered only in the course of the centuries, and presumably possess a number of others which will be brought to light only by the future development of mathematics. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 327-329.

8. The fact is that the numbers pre-existing in nature are presumably the most fundamental archetypes, being the very matrix of all others. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Pages 325-327.

9. Archetypes are not mere concepts but are entities, exactly like whole numbers, which are not merely aids to counting but possess irrational qualities that do not result from the concept of counting, as for instance the prime numbers and their behavior. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Page 22.

10. Hence the mathematician Kronecker could say: Man created mathematics, but God created whole numbers. ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. II, Page 23.

11. Where numbers indicate a measure we move into the material.  A concrete image is a manifestation requiring space in which the spirit clothes itself in the material in order to draw to man. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 60.

12. Images and numbers are doors through which the spiritual can reach man. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 60.

13. It is characteristic of the transcendent that it can be pictured and described by numbers; the passage of time, quantity, and identity, are spiritual substances. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 60.

14. The character of the image is not determined by numbers.  Pure spiritual substance is eternal.  An image as such needs neither time nor space. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 60.

15. I should like to study the theory of numbers.  What is a number, an entity, a sequence, an archetype?  We think we can perceive and grasp a number logically and suddenly it behaves quite differently from the way we expected. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 55.

16. It is a fundamental phenomenon of mathematics that numbers are not just mathematical entities but individualities. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 55.

17. We believe we are playing with equations and suddenly it transpires that certain equations express the laws of electric currents.  God played and formulated currents. ~Carl Jung, Jung-Ostrowski, Page 55.

18. Do not forget that the original meaning of all letters and numbers was a magical one!  Hence the “perils of the soul.” ~Carl Jung, Letters Vol. 1, Pages 528-529.

19. Numbers are autonomous. They had their life, their significance before men used them as instruments.  The mathematicians continue to use them as instruments, so in that instant they become dry.  Before they had their proper significance. C. G. Jung, Emma Jung and Toni Wolff – A Collection of Remembrances; Pages 51-70.

20.  … number and synchronicity… were… always brought into connection with one another,… both possess numinosity and mystery as their common characteristics.  Number has invariably been used to characterize some numinous object, and all numbers from 1 to 9 are ‘sacred,’ just as 10, 12, 13, 14, 28, 32, and 40 have a special significance. ~Carl Jung, CW 8, Para 870.

21. The very numbers you use in counting are more than you take them for. They are at the same time mythological entities (for the Pythagoreans they were even divine), but you are certainly unaware of this when you use numbers for a practical purpose. ~Carl Jung, CW 18, Para 461

(The sum of the sequence of numbers, 1 through 21 is 231, the sum of 2, 3, 1 is 6, the trinity doubled.  21 itself is a trinity.)



1  Looking into his Son with all the Love
2  Which each of them eternally breathes forth,
3  The Primal and unutterable Power

1  Guardando nel suo Figlio con l'Amore
2  che l'uno e l'altro etternalmente spira,
3  lo primo e ineffabile Valore

4  Whate'er before the mind or eye revolves
5  With so much order made, there can be none
6  Who this beholds without enjoying Him.

4  quanto per mente e per loco si gira
5  con tant' ordine fé, ch'esser non puote
6  sanza gustar di lui chi ciò rimira.

7  Lift up then, Reader, to the lofty wheels
8  With me thy vision straight unto that part
9  Where the one motion on the other strikes,

7  Leva dunque, lettore, a l'alte rote
8  meco la vista, dritto a quella parte
9  dove l'un moto e l'altro si percuote;

10  And there begin to contemplate with joy
11  That Master's art, who in himself so loves it
12  That never doth his eye depart therefrom.

10  e lì comincia a vagheggiar ne l'arte
11  di quel maestro che dentro a sé l'ama,
12  tanto che mai da lei l'occhio non parte.

13  Behold how from that point goes branching off
14  The oblique circle, which conveys the planets,
15  To satisfy the world that calls upon them;

13  Vedi come da indi si dirama
14  l'oblico cerchio che i pianeti porta,
15  per sodisfare al mondo che li chiama.

16  And if their pathway were not thus inflected,
17  Much virtue in the heavens would be in vain,
18  And almost every power below here dead.

16  Che se la strada lor non fosse torta,
17  molta virtù nel ciel sarebbe in vano,
18  e quasi ogne potenza qua giù morta;

19  If from the straight line distant more or less
20  Were the departure, much would wanting be
21  Above and underneath of mundane order.

19  e se dal dritto più o men lontano
20  fosse 'l partire, assai sarebbe manco
21  e giù e sù de l'ordine mondano.

22  Remain now, Reader, still upon thy bench,
23  In thought pursuing that which is foretasted,
24  If thou wouldst jocund be instead of weary.

22  Or ti riman, lettor, sovra 'l tuo banco,
23  dietro pensando a ciò che si preliba,
24  s'esser vuoi lieto assai prima che stanco.

25  I've set before thee; henceforth feed thyself,
26  For to itself diverteth all my care
27  That theme whereof I have been made the scribe.

25  Messo t'ho innanzi; omai per te ti ciba;
26  ché a sé torce tutta la mia cura
27  quella materia ond' io son fatto scriba.

28  The greatest of the ministers of nature,
29  Who with the power of heaven the world imprints
30  And measures with his light the time for us,

28  Lo ministro maggior de la natura,
29  che del valor del ciel lo mondo imprenta
30  e col suo lume il tempo ne misura,

31  With that part which above is called to mind
32  Conjoined, along the spirals was revolving,
33  Where each time earlier he presents himself;

31  con quella parte che sù si rammenta
32  congiunto, si girava per le spire
33  in che più tosto ognora s'appresenta;

34  And I was with him; but of the ascending
35  I was not conscious, saving as a man
36  Of a first thought is conscious ere it come;

34  e io era con lui; ma del salire
35  non m'accors' io, se non com' uom s'accorge,
36  anzi 'l primo pensier, del suo venire.

37  And Beatrice, she who is seen to pass
38  From good to better, and so suddenly
39  That not by time her action is expressed,

37  È Bëatrice quella che sì scorge
38  di bene in meglio, sì subitamente
39  che l'atto suo per tempo non si sporge.

40  How lucent in herself must she have been!
41  And what was in the sun, wherein I entered,
42  Apparent not by colour but by light,

40  Quant' esser convenia da sé lucente
41  quel ch'era dentro al sol dov' io entra'mi,
42  non per color, ma per lume parvente!

43  I, though I call on genius, art, and practice,
44  Cannot so tell that it could be imagined;
45  Believe one can, and let him long to see it.

43  Perch' io lo 'ngegno e l'arte e l'uso chiami,
44 sì nol direi che mai s'imaginasse;
45 ma creder puossi e di veder si brami.

46  And if our fantasies too lowly are
47  For altitude so great, it is no marvel,
48  Since o'er the sun was never eye could go.

46  E se le fantasie nostre son basse
47  a tanta altezza, non è maraviglia;
48  ché sopra 'l sol non fu occhio ch'andasse.

49  Such in this place was the fourth family
50  Of the high Father, who forever sates it,
51  Showing how he breathes forth and how begets.

49  Tal era quivi la quarta famiglia
50  de l'alto Padre, che sempre la sazia,
51  mostrando come spira e come figlia.

52  And Beatrice began: "Give thanks, give thanks
53  Unto the Sun of Angels, who to this
54  Sensible one has raised thee by his grace!"

52  E Bëatrice cominciò: “Ringrazia,
53  ringrazia il Sol de li angeli, ch'a questo
54  sensibil t'ha levato per sua grazia.”

55  Never was heart of mortal so disposed
56  To worship, nor to give itself to God
57  With all its gratitude was it so ready,

55  Cor di mortal non fu mai sì digesto
56  a divozione e a rendersi a Dio
57  con tutto 'l suo gradir cotanto presto,

58  As at those words did I myself become;
59   And all my love was so absorbed in Him,
60  That in oblivion Beatrice was eclipsed.

58  come a quelle parole mi fec' io;
59  e sì tutto 'l mio amore in lui si mise,
60  che Bëatrice eclissò ne l'oblio.

61  Nor this displeased her; but she smiled at it
62  So that the splendour of her laughing eyes
63  My single mind on many things divided.

61  Non le dispiacque, ma sì se ne rise,
62  che lo splendor de li occhi suoi ridenti
63  mia mente unita in più cose divise.

64  Lights many saw I, vivid and triumphant,
65  Make us a centre and themselves a circle,
66  More sweet in voice than luminous in aspect.

64  Io vidi più folgór vivi e vincenti
65  far di noi centro e di sé far corona,
66  più dolci in voce che in vista lucenti:

67  Thus girt about the daughter of Latona
68  We sometimes see, when pregnant is the air,
69  So that it holds the thread which makes her zone.

67  così cinger la figlia di Latona
68  vedem talvolta, quando l'aere è pregno,
69  sì che ritenga il fil che fa la zona.

70  Within the court of Heaven, whence I return,
71  Are many jewels found, so fair and precious
72  They cannot be transported from the realm;

70  Ne la corte del cielo, ond' io rivegno,
71  si trovan molte gioie care e belle
72  tanto che non si posson trar del regno;

73  And of them was the singing of those lights.
74  Who takes not wings that he may fly up thither,
75  The tidings thence may from the dumb await!

73  e 'l canto di quei lumi era di quelle;
74  chi non s'impenna sì che là sù voli,
75  dal muto aspetti quindi le novelle.

76  As soon as singing thus those burning suns
77  Had round about us whirled themselves three times,
78  Like unto stars neighbouring the steadfast poles,

76  Poi, sì cantando, quelli ardenti soli
77  si fuor girati intorno a noi tre volte,
78  come stelle vicine a' fermi poli,

79  Ladies they seemed, not from the dance released,
80  But who stop short, in silence listening
81  Till they have gathered the new melody.

79  donne mi parver, non da ballo sciolte,
80  ma che s'arrestin tacite, ascoltando
81  fin che le nove note hanno ricolte.

82  And within one I heard beginning: "When
83  The radiance of grace, by which is kindled
84  True love, and which thereafter grows by loving,

82  E dentro a l'un senti' cominciar: “Quando
83  lo raggio de la grazia, onde s'accende
84  verace amore e che poi cresce amando,

85  Within thee multiplied is so resplendent
86  That it conducts thee upward by that stair,
87  Where without reascending none descends,

85  multiplicato in te tanto resplende,
86  che ti conduce su per quella scala
87  u' sanza risalir nessun discende;

88  Who should deny the wine out of his vial
89  Unto thy thirst, in liberty were not
90  Except as water which descends not seaward.

88  qual ti negasse il vin de la sua fiala
89  per la tua sete, in libertà non fora
90  se non com' acqua ch'al mar non si cala.

91  Fain wouldst thou know with what plants is enflowered
92  This garland that encircles with delight
93  The Lady fair who makes thee strong for heaven.

91  Tu vuo' saper di quai piante s'infiora
92  questa ghirlanda che 'ntorno vagheggia
93 la bella donna ch'al ciel t'avvalora.

94  Of the lambs was I of the holy flock
95  Which Dominic conducteth by a road
96  Where well one fattens if he strayeth not.

94  Io fui de li agni de la santa greggia
95  che Domenico mena per cammino
96  u' ben s'impingua se non si vaneggia.

97  He who is nearest to me on the right
98  My brother and master was; and he Albertus
99  Is of Cologne, I Thomas of Aquinum.

97  Questi che m'è a destra più vicino,
98  frate e maestro fummi, ed esso Alberto
99  è di Cologna, e io Thomas d'Aquino.

100  If thou of all the others wouldst be certain,
101  Follow behind my speaking with thy sight
102  Upward along the blessed garland turning.

100  Se sì di tutti li altri esser vuo' certo,
101  di retro al mio parlar ten vien col viso
102  girando su per lo beato serto.

103  That next effulgence issues from the smile
104  Of Gratian, who assisted both the courts
105  In such wise that it pleased in Paradise.

103  Quell' altro fiammeggiare esce del riso
104  di Grazïan, che l'uno e l'altro foro
105  aiutò sì che piace in paradiso.

106  The other which near by adorns our choir
107  That Peter was who, e'en as the poor widow,
108  Offered his treasure unto Holy Church.

106  L'altro ch'appresso addorna il nostro coro,
107  quel Pietro fu che con la poverella
108  offerse a Santa Chiesa suo tesoro.

109  The fifth light, that among us is the fairest,
110  Breathes forth from such a love, that all the world
111  Below is greedy to learn tidings of it.

109  La quinta luce, ch'è tra noi più bella,
110  spira di tale amor, che tutto 'l mondo
111  là giù ne gola di saper novella:

112  Within it is the lofty mind, where knowledge
113  So deep was put, that, if the true be true,
114  To see so much there never rose a second.

112  entro v'è l'alta mente u' sì profondo
113  saver fu messo, che, se 'l vero è vero,
114  a veder tanto non surse il secondo.

115  Thou seest next the lustre of that taper,
116  Which in the flesh below looked most within
117  The angelic nature and its ministry.

115  Appresso vedi il lume di quel cero
116  che giù in carne più a dentro vide
117  l'angelica natura e 'l ministero.

118  Within that other little light is smiling
119  The advocate of the Christian centuries,
120  Out of whose rhetoric Augustine was furnished.

118  Ne l'altra piccioletta luce ride
119  quello avvocato de' tempi cristiani
120  del cui latino Augustin si provide.

121  Now if thou trainest thy mind's eye along
122  From light to light pursuant of my praise,
123  With thirst already of the eighth thou waitest.

121  Or se tu l'occhio de la mente trani
122  di luce in luce dietro a le mie lode,
123  già de l'ottava con sete rimani.

124  By seeing every good therein exults
125  The sainted soul, which the fallacious world
126  Makes manifest to him who listeneth well;

124  Per vedere ogne ben dentro vi gode
125  l'anima santa che 'l mondo fallace
126  fa manifesto a chi di lei ben ode.

127  The body whence 'twas hunted forth is lying
128  Down in Cieldauro, and from martyrdom
129  And banishment it came unto this peace.

127  Lo corpo ond' ella fu cacciata giace
128  giuso in Cieldauro; ed essa da martiro
129  e da essilio venne a questa pace.

130  See farther onward flame the burning breath
131  Of Isidore, of Beda, and of Richard
132  Who was in contemplation more than man.

130  Vedi oltre fiammeggiar l'ardente spiro
131  d'Isidoro, di Beda e di Riccardo,
132  che a considerar fu più che viro.

133  This, whence to me returneth thy regard,
134  The light is of a spirit unto whom
