135  In his grave meditations death seemed slow.

133  Questi onde a me ritorna il tuo riguardo,
134  è 'l lume d'uno spirto che 'n pensieri
135  gravi a morir li parve venir tardo:

136  It is the light eternal of Sigier,
137  Who, reading lectures in the Street of Straw,
138  Did syllogize invidious verities."

136  essa è la luce etterna di Sigieri,
137  che, leggendo nel Vico de li Strami,
138  silogizzò invidïosi veri.”

139  Then, as a horologe that calleth us
140  What time the Bride of God is rising up
141  With matins to her Spouse that he may love her,

139  Indi, come orologio che ne chiami
140  ne l'ora che la sposa di Dio surge
141  a mattinar lo sposo perché l'ami,

142  Wherein one part the other draws and urges,
143  Ting! ting! resounding with so sweet a note,
144  That swells with love the spirit well disposed,

142  che l'una parte e l'altra tira e urge,
143  tin tin sonando con sì dolce nota,
144  che 'l ben disposto spirto d'amor turge;

145  Thus I beheld the glorious wheel move round,
146  And render voice to voice, in modulation
147  And sweetness that can not be comprehended,

145  così vid'ïo la gloriosa rota
146  muoversi e render voce a voce in tempra
147  e in dolcezza ch'esser non pò nota

148  Excepting there where joy is made eternal.

148  se non colà dove gioir s'insempra.

Canto XI
Diseases of the soul, of the body, of the body-politic, all of them accumulating together in a single crisis which comes with the horrible realization that from infancy to old age one has built one's identity through experiences that have accrued both as aspirations and repulsions, the one dependent on the other and both cankers that compel: compel to what?  Take your pick, the text lists eight possibilities, all of which have the taint of temporality, all of which, though seemingly opposed, one good, one bad, work in tandem as wings which propel one into more and more restrictive and painful constrictions, in brief, to downward flight.  We are moving in this canto, and in the poem in toto, towards a radical renunciation of all temporal hindrances.  We are shedding all of those things that are temporal and mortal, all of those things that stick us to the world, and accumulate in us as those leadened desires of dis-ease.  We are talking about freedom, emancipation, and the glorification of that which the world abhors, poverty, nakedness, pain, shame, loss of identity, honor, and even the notoriety which might come from infamy.  We are talking about the embracing of that which is filthy, despised, disparaged, a state of being as seen through mortal eyes as repulsive, and even insane, but which seen from one of the two states referred to in this canto: the seraphic state (love) or the cherubic state (wisdom) as exultation, and above all, as freedom.  In the Hindu tradition we have two paths to freedom: jnana yoga, union with the divine through wisdom, or bhakti yoga, union with the divine through love.  Dante, in this canto conflates these two states, and thus expands the sun of freedom by doubling its light, whereas in the world of temporality they diminished one another through mutual opposition.  Two saints appear here: One, the cherubically wise, Saint Thomas Aquinas, who manifests in order to praise the other, Saint Francis, the seraphic lover of Lady Poverty.  The lesson is plain: The ultimate wisdom humbles itself by praising love.  We may learn of ultimate love later — although we know it now through the figure of Beatrice, who embodies both the spirit of wisdom, Sophia, and the spirit of love.   She stands with Dante at the center of this circling of saints, both the circle and its center pausing in stillness here, rapt by Saint Thomas' hagiography of Saint Francis.

If I put this in the context of my own life, it appears to me now as a series of avoidances.  At age 71, I do not want to be sick.  I do not want to be in pain.  I do not want to be poor.  I do not want to be shamed or humiliated.  I do not want to be unloved or misunderstood or ignored or unappreciated, and I do not want to see any of these things manifested in the politics or communities of my world.  If I imagine the feeling states which accompany any and all of these avoidances, I find myself, my very mortal identity, as a conglomeration of components that lock together and grind out fear.  Fear is the binding agent, and what Freud called the ego, the sense of self which continually defines itself in relation to how successful it can be in keeping these inner terrors from becoming binding outer circumstances.  And, as long as I am occupied in forging these chains of avoidance, I am bound more and more tightly to a state of fear, an ego built around trauma, the perception of trauma, the avoidance of trauma.  Saint Francis turned the world upside-down by embracing what I and others avoid, and if we are to take Dante's word for it here, this madness is wisdom, and this wisdom is love.

None of this to be construed as a sort of romantic idealism.  Would you make friends with cancer or the fatal virus of the current pandemic?  Would you leave your house and remove your shoes to sit barefoot in rags with the homeless on some city street corner?  Would you be thought deranged?  Would you seek to be shunned?  Would you embrace the worst of a worldly condition for the promise of an immortal exultation?  I think there is a shift in this canto from the moral to the aesthetic.  That's a vague and almost sickeningly irresponsible assertion, I know, and I cannot justify making it — just yet.  Just how is Dante's poetry going to shine with love, wisdom, and beauty by literally embracing pain and squalor and ignorance?  It may be that the state of loving wisdom is not a literal state at all, but a literary, and artistic one.  To say this may be arrogance or foolishness, but at the nadir of Saint Francis' suffering is the negation of the fear of suffering, and that negation does not manifest itself in what we mistakenly call life, and what the Yogis call Maya.  It manifests in a poem: The Canticle to the Sun, which is where we are situated in this canto.  Not in the physical sun, which would be ridiculous and impossible, but in a poetic one.  Does this trivialize life experience in favor of an aesthetic escape,  or is it the apotheosis that we have been seeking in order to negate the terror we feel in this ego built from avoidances?  For it to be the latter, we would have to considerably elevate the intensity and, yes, divinity, of the aesthetic experience.  This would certainly not be the way of the world, but it may well have been the way of Dante the poet, and maybe even the way of some of Dante's readers. 

The Divine Seal of Saint Francis was the stigmata of Christ, the appearance of Christ's wounds on his body.  These marks are marks of pain and persecution, not persecution from an outside agency, but an auto-immune disease persecution, pain as faith, or faith as pain.  Can we even imagine a thing so perverse?  And yet mortal life is insolubly wedded to suffering as Gautama discovered as the first step in his journey towards Buddhahood.  We are not talking about tolerance, or acceptance, or surrender here, we are talking about the marriage bed, about the swift heartbeat and swift feet of the bride hungering for the bridegroom, the bereft soul seeking the only consummation which will exult her and bring her peace.  We are talking about beauty in search of the beatific, and we need only recall those passages in the Vita Nuove, when the 9 year-old Dante sees the 9 year-old Beatrice, to understand the complete and ultimately joyful disruption of the senses and devastation of the mind that such a stigmata of heart palpitations and mindlessness occasions.  Such an experience cannot possibly resolve itself in the body or the body politic.  Embracing either of those two is the disease of the soul as an attitude towards the warring compromises with death that mortal life has to make in every moment of its physical existence.  The body kills to live, and finally becomes food for some other form of death-devouring life.  How could this be a paradise or the design of a God or Universe with the syzygy of love and wisdom as its progenitors?  Dante's answer to this dilemma occurs at the beginning of this canto wherein he admonishes the reader to reject those downward flapping wings, and brags, yes, brags, that through his union with Beatrice, he has freed himself of such suffering — and, having freed himself, he thus enjoys the glories of heaven.  He seems to be asking here, that given the conditions of the world, and everything eaten by the jaws of time: What could those glories be but aesthetic ones?  

The mixed metaphors which are the guiding lights of this canto are the cleft plant, and the fattened sheep: the cut flowers on the table of a meal of roasted lamb and sheep's milk.  Who feasts at that table?  This canto says: not the diners, but those who ornament and provide the feast with the sacrifice of their own bodies.  These are the ones who stand at the center of the circling saints: Beatrice and Dante.  If you are a reader here, you should know that you too are being fatted, beatified and beautified, to prepare yourself to be this festive meal.

But it's not about the suffering.  It never was about the suffering.  It's about the love.  It's about the wisdom of the soul, which prompts us to reject the false, death-embracing wisdom of the world, and guides us, by means of the most profound via negativa, through the cherubic path of philosophy — literally the love of wisdom, the love of Sophia — to the seraphic state.  This seraphic state may be that final exultation in which a self is aware of itself, but aware of itself only as the ecstatic contemplation of God's love.  Such a soul has no room in itself for suffering, no breath except the breath of praise.

Still, this life of Saint Francis in the sphere of the sun proposes profoundly unsettling questions.  Here Jean Paul Sartre's Being and Nothingness collides with the Clear Light Void of the Buddha.  In the wake of such a collision, we can only take it on trust that this vacuum is a plenum.  We can only take it on trust that the egg of this zero can birth a cosmos.  Could anything like love thrive without such trust?  Is freedom worth having if it is only the freedom to experience perpetual terror?  Once we start asking such questions, they begin to dangerously proliferate.  Is my trust or distrust in God coincident with my trust in No-thing?  And is my fear of God coincident with my Fear of Nothing?  And, is this Godly Nothingness the primary impetus of my love and the very source of my creativity and freedom?  The dangerous territory that the poem is entering here is much like that post-mortem Bardo spoken of in the Tibetan Book of the Dead: A clear, bright emptiness, a state of being stripped of everything but freedom and the latent potential to become anything at all.  And here, in the act of reading, is a moment, aesthetically like the moment of physical death.   At that moment, time stops and the soul is thrust into eternity.  The soul sees this light, but it offers no more attraction than do leprous wounds.  And the soul also sees a smokiness, full of the allure and promise of mortal fame, fortune, adulation, and sensory delight.  And though the priest will whisper in the corpse's ear to embrace the first, and reject the second, few do so, but the few who do so, find, like Saint Francis, their final home in the celestial palace of liberation.   

1  O Thou insensate care of mortal men,
2  How inconclusive are the syllogisms
3  That make thee beat thy wings in downward flight!

1  O insensata cura de' mortali,
2  quanto son difettivi silogismi
3  quei che ti fanno in basso batter l'ali!

4  One after laws and one to aphorisms
5  Was going, and one following the priesthood,
6  And one to reign by force or sophistry,

4  Chi dietro a iura e chi ad amforismi
5  sen giva, e chi seguendo sacerdozio,
6  e chi regnar per forza o per sofismi,

7  And one in theft, and one in state affairs,
8  One in the pleasures of the flesh involved
9  Wearied himself, one gave himself to ease;

7  e chi rubare e chi civil negozio,
8  chi nel diletto de la carne involto
9  s'affaticava e chi si dava a l'ozio,

10  When I, from all these things emancipate,
11  With Beatrice above there in the Heavens
12  With such exceeding glory was received!

10  quando, da tutte queste cose sciolto,
11  con Bëatrice m'era suso in cielo
12  cotanto glorïosamente accolto.

13  When each one had returned unto that point
14  Within the circle where it was before,
15  It stood as in a candlestick a candle;

13  Poi che ciascuno fu tornato ne lo
14  punto del cerchio in che avanti s'era,
15  fermossi, come a candellier candelo.

16  And from within the effulgence which at first
17  Had spoken unto me, I heard begin
18  Smiling while it more luminous became:

16  E io senti' dentro a quella lumera
17  che pria m'avea parlato, sorridendo
18  incominciar, faccendosi più mera:

19  "Even as I am kindled in its ray,
20  So, looking into the Eternal Light,
21  The occasion of thy thoughts I apprehend.

19  “Così com' io del suo raggio resplendo,
20  sì, riguardando ne la luce etterna,
21  li tuoi pensieri onde cagioni apprendo.

22  Thou doubtest, and wouldst have me to resift
23  In language so extended and so open
24  My speech, that to thy sense it may be plain,

22  Tu dubbi, e hai voler che si ricerna
23  in sì aperta e 'n sì distesa lingua
24  lo dicer mio, ch'al tuo sentir si sterna,

25  Where just before I said, 'where well one fattens,'
26  And where I said, 'there never rose a second;'
27  And here 'tis needful we distinguish well.

25  ove dinanzi dissi: 'U' ben s'impingua,'
26  e là u' dissi: 'Non nacque il secondo';
27  e qui è uopo che ben si distingua.

28  The Providence, which governeth the world
29  With counsel, wherein all created vision
30  Is vanquished ere it reach unto the bottom,

28  La provedenza, che governa il mondo
29  con quel consiglio nel quale ogne aspetto
30  creato è vinto pria che vada al fondo,

31  (So that towards her own Beloved might go
32  The bride of Him who, uttering a loud cry,
33  Espoused her with his consecrated blood,

31  però che andasse ver' lo suo diletto
32  la sposa di colui ch'ad alte grida
33  disposò lei col sangue benedetto,

34  Self-confident and unto Him more faithful,)
35  Two Princes did ordain in her behoof,
36  Which on this side and that might be her guide.

34  in sé sicura e anche a lui più fida,
35  due principi ordinò in suo favore,
36  che quinci e quindi le fosser per guida.

37  The one was all seraphical in ardour;
38  The other by his wisdom upon earth
39  A splendour was of light cherubical.

37  L'un fu tutto serafico in ardore;
38  l'altro per sapïenza in terra fue
39  di cherubica luce uno splendore.

40  One will I speak of, for of both is spoken
41  In praising one, whichever may be taken,
42  Because unto one end their labours were.

40  De l'un dirò, però che d'amendue
41  si dice l'un pregiando, qual ch'om prende,
42  perch' ad un fine fur l'opere sue.

43  Between Tupino and the stream that falls
44  Down from the hill elect of blessed Ubald,
45  A fertile slope of lofty mountain hangs,

43  Intra Tupino e l'acqua che discende
44  del colle eletto dal beato Ubaldo,
45  fertile costa d'alto monte pende,

46  From which Perugia feels the cold and heat
47  Through Porta Sole, and behind it weep
48  Gualdo and Nocera their grievous yoke.

46  onde Perugia sente freddo e caldo
47  da Porta Sole; e di rietro le piange
48  per grave giogo Nocera con Gualdo.

49  From out that slope, there where it breaketh most
50  Its steepness, rose upon the world a sun
51  As this one does sometimes from out the Ganges;

49  Di questa costa, là dov' ella frange
50  più sua rattezza, nacque al mondo un sole,
51  come fa questo talvolta di Gange.

52  Therefore let him who speaketh of that place,
53  Say not Ascesi, for he would say little,
54  But Orient, if he properly would speak.

52  Però chi d'esso loco fa parole,
53  non dica Ascesi, ché direbbe corto,
54  ma Orïente, se proprio dir vuole.

55  He was not yet far distant from his rising
56  Before he had begun to make the earth
57  Some comfort from his mighty virtue feel.

55  Non era ancor molto lontan da l'orto,
56  ch'el cominciò a far sentir la terra
57  de la sua gran virtute alcun conforto;

58  For he in youth his father's wrath incurred
59  For certain Dame, to whom, as unto death,
60  The gate of pleasure no one doth unlock;

58  ché per tal donna, giovinetto, in guerra
59  del padre corse, a cui, come a la morte,
60  la porta del piacer nessun diserra;

61  And was before his spiritual court
62  'Et coram patre' unto her united;
63  Then day by day more fervently he loved her.

61  e dinanzi a la sua spirital corte
62  et coram patre le si fece unito;
63  poscia di dì in dì l'amò più forte.

64  She, reft of her first husband, scorned, obscure,
65  One thousand and one hundred years and more,
66  Waited without a suitor till he came.

64  Questa, privata del primo marito,
65  millecent' anni e più dispetta e scura
66  fino a costui si stette sanza invito;

67  Naught it availed to hear, that with Amyclas
68  Found her unmoved at sounding of his voice
69  He who struck terror into all the world;

67  né valse udir che la trovò sicura
68  con Amiclate, al suon de la sua voce,
69  colui ch'a tutto 'l mondo fé paura;

70  Naught it availed being constant and undaunted,
71  So that, when Mary still remained below,
72  She mounted up with Christ upon the cross.

70  né valse esser costante né feroce,
71  sì che, dove Maria rimase giuso,
72  ella con Cristo pianse in su la croce.

73  But that too darkly I may not proceed,
74  Francis and Poverty for these two lovers
75  Take thou henceforward in my speech diffuse.

73  Ma perch' io non proceda troppo chiuso,
74  Francesco e Povertà per questi amanti
75  prendi oramai nel mio parlar diffuso.

76  Their concord and their joyous semblances,
77  The love, the wonder, and the sweet regard,
78  They made to be the cause of holy thoughts;

76  La lor concordia e i lor lieti sembianti,
77 amore e maraviglia e dolce sguardo
78  facieno esser cagion di pensier santi;

79  So much so that the venerable Bernard
80  First bared his feet, and after so great peace
81  Ran, and, in running, thought himself too slow.

79  tanto che 'l venerabile Bernardo
80  si scalzò prima, e dietro a tanta pace
81  corse e, correndo, li parve esser tardo.

82  O wealth unknown! O veritable good!
83  Giles bares his feet, and bares his feet Sylvester
84  Behind the bridegroom, so doth please the bride!

82  Oh ignota ricchezza! oh ben ferace!
83  Scalzasi Egidio, scalzasi Silvestro
84  dietro a lo sposo, sì la sposa piace.

85  Then goes his way that father and that master,
86  He and his Lady and that family
87  Which now was girding on the humble cord;

85  Indi sen va quel padre e quel maestro
86  con la sua donna e con quella famiglia
87  che già legava l'umile capestro

88  Nor cowardice of heart weighed down his brow
89  At being son of Peter Bernardone,
90  Nor for appearing marvellously scorned;

88  Né li gravò viltà di cuor le ciglia
89  per esser fi' di Pietro Bernardone,
90  90 né per parer dispetto a maraviglia;

91  But regally his hard determination
92  To Innocent he opened, and from him
93  Received the primal seal upon his Order.

91  ma regalmente sua dura intenzione
92  ad Innocenzio aperse, e da lui ebbe
93  primo sigillo a sua religïone.

94  After the people mendicant increased
95  Behind this man, whose admirable life
96  Better in glory of the heavens were sung,

94  Poi che la gente poverella crebbe
95  dietro a costui, la cui mirabil vita
96 meglio in gloria del ciel si canterebbe,

97  Incoronated with a second crown
98  Was through Honorius by the Eternal Spirit
99  The holy purpose of this Archimandrite.

97  di seconda corona redimita
98  fu per Onorio da l'Etterno Spiro
99  la santa voglia d'esto archimandrita.

100  And when he had, through thirst of martyrdom,
101  In the proud presence of the Sultan preached
102  Christ and the others who came after him,

100  E poi che, per la sete del martiro,
101 ne la presenza del Soldan superba
102  predicò Cristo e li altri che 'l seguiro,

103  And, finding for conversion too unripe
104  The folk, and not to tarry there in vain,
105  Returned to fruit of the Italic grass,

103  e per trovare a conversione acerba
104  troppo la gente e per non stare indarno,
105  redissi al frutto de l'italica erba,

106  On the rude rock 'twixt Tiber and the Arno
107  From Christ did he receive the final seal,
108  Which during two whole years his members bore.

106  nel crudo sasso intra Tevero e Arno
107  da Cristo prese l'ultimo sigillo,
108  che le sue membra due anni portarno.

109  When He, who chose him unto so much good,
110  Was pleased to draw him up to the reward
111  That he had merited by being lowly,

109  Quando a colui ch'a tanto ben sortillo
110  piacque di trarlo suso a la mercede
111  ch'el meritò nel suo farsi pusillo,

112  Unto his friars, as to the rightful heirs,
113  His most dear Lady did he recommend,
114  And bade that they should love her faithfully;

112  a' frati suoi, sì com' a giuste rede,
113  raccomandò la donna sua più cara,
114  e comandò che l'amassero a fede;

115  And from her bosom the illustrious soul
116  Wished to depart, returning to its realm,
117  And for its body wished no other bier.

115  e del suo grembo l'anima preclara
116  mover si volle, tornando al suo regno,
117  e al suo corpo non volle altra bara.

118  Think now what man was he, who was a fit
119  Companion over the high seas to keep
120  The bark of Peter to its proper bearings.

118  Pensa oramai qual fu colui che degno
119  collega fu a mantener la barca
120  di Pietro in alto mar per dritto segno;

121  And this man was our Patriarch; hence whoever
122  Doth follow him as he commands can see
123  That he is laden with good merchandise.

121  e questo fu il nostro patrïarca;
122  per che qual segue lui, com' el comanda,
123  discerner puoi che buone merce carca.

124  But for new pasturage his flock has grown
125  So greedy, that it is impossible
126  They be not scattered over fields diverse;

124  Ma 'l suo pecuglio di nova vivanda
125   è fatto ghiotto, sì ch'esser non puote
126  che per diversi salti non si spanda;

127  And in proportion as his sheep remote
128  And vagabond go farther off from him,
129  More void of milk return they to the fold.

127  e quanto le sue pecore remote
128  e vagabunde più da esso vanno,
129  più tornano a l'ovil di latte vòte.

130  Verily some there are that fear a hurt,
131  And keep close to the shepherd; but so few,
132  That little cloth doth furnish forth their hoods.

130  Ben son di quelle che temono 'l danno
131  e stringonsi al pastor; ma son sì poche,
132  che le cappe fornisce poco panno.

133  Now if my utterance be not indistinct,
134  If thine own hearing hath attentive been,
135  If thou recall to mind what I have said,

133  Or, se le mie parole non son fioche,
134  se la tua audïenza è stata attenta,
135  se ciò ch'è detto a la mente revoche,

136  In part contented shall thy wishes be;
137  For thou shalt see the plant that's chipped away,
138  And the rebuke that lieth in the words,

136  in parte fia la tua voglia contenta,
137  perché vedrai la pianta onde si scheggia,
138  e vedra' il corrègger che argomenta

139  'Where well one fattens, if he strayeth not.'"

139  'U' ben s'impingua, se non si vaneggia.'”

Canto XII
In Canto XI we had the hagiographical reflection of the sun of Saint Francis in the exposition of Saint Thomas Aquinas, and here, in Canto XII, we have the same, in the exposition of Saint Dominic's life by Saint Bonaventure.  Is there, in the psychic life of the mind of Saint Dominic, the equivalent of the renunciation of the body made by Saint Francis?  Is there a philosophical Lady Poverty, loathed by the world, but embraced by the saint, and does such a mental marriage lead to a similar glory and freedom, as did the spiritual perversions of Saint Francis?  I wonder.  The sun of Saint Francis was all accepting, nourishing evil and good, and in fact, not even making a distinction between them, except to say that love like this requires a poverty of body and spirit, as a kind of empty channel, which allows the space for such bliss to flow.  But Saint Dominic does make distinctions, he had his orthodox beliefs, and his rejected heresies, he is a good friend and a very bad enemy.  The record is not totally clear, but even if he did not burn his enemies at the stake, the growing popular belief that he presided over the most horrific auto-de-fays not only affirmed such, but shows that he heartily approved, and, in fact, his claim to sainthood, as Dante's text seems to imply, is largely based upon his alacrity in carrying out the eradication of not just the spiritual ideas of those who disagreed with him, but their physical bodies as well.  This brings me up against something that seems to persist in Dante's psyche, and, I must confess, too often in mine as well, of creating what Blake called a "cloven fiction," the splitting of the world into moral/immoral or accepted/unaccepted.  But it is not as if the unaccepted can be allowed to just go its own way.  The Cathars, who were the chief heretics in Dominic's era, were never accused of "bad" behavior.  On the contrary, they were even praised by the orthodox, who were piously bent on murdering them, for their upright lives, often, too often, far more upright than the corrupt officials of the Church.  But their upright behavior did not matter.  They were burned, and indeed, subjected to one of the first historical genocides in Europe, because somehow it was thought that their beliefs were so poisonous that they would infect and destroy the entire edifice of Catholic sanctimony.  They seem to have been equated with those hypocrites whom Jesus denounced as those who not only could not enter the kingdom of heaven, but whose very presence barred the way for others.  From the Catholic point of view of Saint Dominic, such people could never be simply segregated, they must be reformed or liquidated.  Their heresy, and in fact the whole idea of Divine Justice promulgated throughout the Commedia, demands retribution, demands, in fact, that a punishment or correction involving pain be meated out to the offenders in equal measure, and often in far more than equal measure, to the pain that they are alleged to have caused.  One definition of pain could be: Pain is the heresy which dynamically interrupts orthodoxy's comfortable slide towards pre-mortem rigor mortis, pain is the extreme challenge to a moribund rationality and a frozen — as is Dante's Satan — and vacuous post-mortem state.  If the heretic's were allowed to be, the philosophic or theological search for truth in the Universe would imply a frozen stop, like Satan's, and not the unmovable uncaused cause of the Empyrean.  What would remain would be two petrified forces, locked in a perpetual death grip of utter stasis.  Dante's search for transcendence runs the high risk that in seeking the stillness of the Empyrean, he may wind up in the deep freeze of the Satan.  The entire structure of the poem and the very steps ascending to the ultimate transcendence of its pilgrim aspirant is built on this searching and shifting foundation.  We may reach the heaven of acceptance exemplified by Saint Francis, but only by climbing the mountain of pain and of retribution promulgated by Saint Dominic.  Temporal, earthly life, for Dante, as it was later for Darwin, was utterly rooted in pain and death, and as such, much of the process of transcendence involves an unmerciful militancy to root out everything that does not paradoxically lead to Saint Frances' all-embracing mercy.  By placing these two saints together, and linking them with numerous examples of substance and reflection, sound and echo, the poem presents us with a quite perilous recipe for a spiritual apotheosis, one that is perhaps not present at all in Buddhism or Hinduism, but lies at the very core of Christianity.  It is as if Christ's parable of the vineyard workers and his various words on forgiveness was contrasted by his treatment of the moneylenders outside the temple and by Saint John's vision of annihilation in Revelations.  Which of these two positions is substance and which reflection, which sound and which echo?  Dante, I believe has made that choice by presenting Saint Francis first, as an uncaused cause, but Dante is not so naive as to believe that even if one knows the difference between substance and sound, between that which is fundamental and that which is derivative, the former always conjures forth the latter, at least in the temporal world of mortality, and if we are to believe the text of the poem, in these lower reaches of Paradise as well.  

This canto is both densified and rarified by what might be called "The Master Metaphor Mix."  By referring to different realms of thought and experience — the musical, the optic, the geographical, the scriptural, the mythological, the geometrical, the numerological, the agricultural, the mechanical (mills/clocks), the biographical, the historical, the political, the ecclesiastical, the moral, the judicial, and so on and so forth, Dante densifies his text by guiding the reader to go inside and reference all these different fields of consciousness, but he also rarifies it, insofar, as he is constantly demanding his reader to go outside the text to learn about his various references.  In short, the text not only instructs, but illustrates the methods of instruction.  The entire commentary tradition, which has far extended the temporal life of the poem, shows just how effective the Commedia has been in expanding not only the consciousness of its individual readers, but also by expanding our collective consciousness as well.  This accomplishment is not exactly analogous to the philosophic and theological writings of people like Aquinas and Augustine, and of those others whom the text refers to in these twin canti of 11 and 12 of the Paradiso.  Because Dante's accomplishment is poetic, it not only achieves its aims through its content, but also through its mastery of poetic technique.  You can agree or disagree with the Commedia's content, or you can ponder the choices which this content presents for you, but his mastery of technique is inarguable, and is no more subject to acceptance or refutation than is the very existence of the brain and language that has fashioned it, or the attention required to read it.   Dante's proposals are aesthetic, and his paradise is neither quite physical nor quite metaphysical, their truth, like Beatrice's love and beauty, is existential, and as such incontrovertible.  It is the alpha and omega, the thing that is left, when everything else on earth and in heaven has  been sifted and found wanting — that is to say — the poem.

Dante insists in this canto and in the previous one that the characters of the two Saints, Francis and Dominic, be fused in our consideration, and he further insists on sticking to a metaphor of militancy as a description of that dual character.  An attribute which seems especially inappropriate when applied to Saint Francis.  We could be tempted to say that we are in Bhagavad Gita territory here, and that this militancy is, especially in the case of Saint Francis, about an inner battle against one's own destructive habits of action and states of mind.  But that cannot be what the text means, or be solely what it means.  Why?  Because of its emphasis on heresy.  One can have heretical thoughts and beliefs, but you cannot be an heretic to your own self, your own soul, and the heresy spoken about here to which Saint Dominic added a literal fire and fury by presiding over the burning of physical bodies is that enemy in other people which cannot be tolerated by one's own soul.  This heresy is the sin of the other, which threatens and entangles yourself.  By Freud or Jung, this might have been called 'projection,' but just because we can now label it, doesn't mean that we can avoid it, or even mean that we should avoid it.  We can't read this canto without confronting this issue.  I know it's there in me, but for now at least, I don't pretend to understand it.  I found the following quote by Miguel de Unamuno, from his Tragic Sense of Life. 

The real sin — perhaps it is the sin against the Holy Ghost for which there is no remission — is the sin of heresy — the sin of thinking for oneself.

One has to believe in something that is infallible, whether that be in the doctrine of the Catholic Church, mathematics, money, prestige, immortality, the invariable speed of light, Planck's constant, or one's own ego, that one infallible thing becomes one's raison d'etre, the one bastion that preserves one against a universal nihilism, and if that belief in one's infallible thing be blasphemed by those who would promulgate your own "holy ghost's" ghostliness, than the heretics that would dare such a thing must be converted or destroyed.  Even one counter example would show that infallibility itself, under any circumstances, is an illusion.  Such a situation is as impossible as believing in a personal or cosmic existence that is only reflection, without substance, only echo, without sound sense.  Even utter nihilism maintains a belief in its own infallibility, just as irony cannot be ironic but must be taken seriously for it to be itself.  To read these twinned canti is a kind of preparation by paradox.  Here, the poem forces us to consider how such paradoxes operate, not merely in Hell or in Purgatory, where one would expect them, but also here in the Paradisiacal sphere of the Sun.  We should not forget that all of this which remains unsolvable in the context of a theological or psychological language, in the abstraction of numbers, and in the metaphors of poetry, find in the first, amoral proofs, and in the second, aesthetic pleasure.      

1  Soon as the blessed flame had taken up
2  The final word to give it utterance,
3  Began the holy millstone to revolve,

1  Sì tosto come l'ultima parola
2  la benedetta fiamma per dir tolse,
3  a rotar cominciò la santa mola;

4  And in its gyre had not turned wholly round,
5  Before another in a ring enclosed it,
6  And motion joined to motion, song to song;

4  e nel suo giro tutta non si volse
5  prima ch'un'altra di cerchio la chiuse,
6  e moto a moto e canto a canto colse;
7  Song that as greatly doth transcend our Muses,
8  Our Sirens, in those dulcet clarions,
9  As primal splendour that which is reflected.
7  canto che tanto vince nostre muse,
8  nostre serene in quelle dolci tube,
9  quanto primo splendor quel ch'e' refuse.

10  And as are spanned athwart a tender cloud
11  Two rainbows parallel and like in colour,
12  When Juno to her handmaid gives command,

10  Come si volgon per tenera nube
11  due archi paralelli e concolori,
12  quando Iunone a sua ancella iube,
13  (The one without born of the one within,
14  Like to the speaking of that vagrant one
15  Whom love consumed as doth the sun the vapours,)

13  nascendo di quel d'entro quel di fori,
14  a guisa del parlar di quella vaga
15  ch'amor consunse come sol vapori,
16  And make the people here, through covenant
17  God set with Noah, presageful of the world
18  That shall no more be covered with a flood,

16  e fanno qui la gente esser presaga,
17  per lo patto che Dio con Noè puose,
18  del mondo che già mai più non s'allaga:
19  In such wise of those sempiternal roses
20  The garlands twain encompassed us about,
21  And thus the outer to the inner answered.

19  così di quelle sempiterne rose
20  volgiensi circa noi le due ghirlande,
21  e sì l'estrema a l'intima rispuose.
22  After the dance, and other grand rejoicings,
23  Both of the singing, and the flaming forth
24  Effulgence with effulgence blithe and tender,

22  Poi che 'l tripudio e l'altra festa grande,
23  sì del cantare e sì del fiammeggiarsi
24  luce con luce gaudïose e blande,

25  Together, at once, with one accord had stopped,
26  (Even as the eyes, that, as volition moves them,
27  Must needs together shut and lift themselves,)

25  insieme a punto e a voler quetarsi,
26  pur come li occhi ch'al piacer che i move
27  conviene insieme chiudere e levarsi;

28  Out of the heart of one of the new lights
29  There came a voice, that needle to the star
30  Made me appear in turning thitherward.

28  del cor de l'una de le luci nove
29  si mosse voce, che l'ago a la stella
30  parer mi fece in volgermi al suo dove;

31  And it began: "The love that makes me fair
32  Draws me to speak about the other leader,
33  By whom so well is spoken here of mine.

31  e cominciò: “L'amor che mi fa bella
32  mi tragge a ragionar de l'altro duca
33  per cui del mio sì ben ci si favella.

34  'Tis right, where one is, to bring in the other,
35  That, as they were united in their warfare,
36  Together likewise may their glory shine.

34  Degno è che, dov' è l'un, l'altro s'induca:
35  sì che, com' elli ad una militaro,
36  così la gloria loro insieme luca.

37  The soldiery of Christ, which it had cost
38  So dear to arm again, behind the standard
39  Moved slow and doubtful and in numbers few,

37  L'essercito di Cristo, che sì caro
38  costò a rïarmar, dietro a la 'nsegna
39  si movea tardo, sospeccioso e raro,

40  When the Emperor who reigneth evermore
41  Provided for the host that was in peril,
42  Through grace alone and not that it was worthy;

40  quando lo 'mperador che sempre regna
41  provide a la milizia, ch'era in forse,
42  per sola grazia, non per esser degna;

43  And, as was said, he to his Bride brought succour
44  With champions twain, at whose deed, at whose word
45  The straggling people were together drawn.

43  e, come è detto, a sua sposa soccorse
44  con due campioni, al cui fare, al cui dire
45  lo popol disvïato si raccorse.

46  Within that region where the sweet west wind
47  Rises to open the new leaves, wherewith
48  Europe is seen to clothe herself afresh,

46  In quella parte ove surge ad aprire
47  Zefiro dolce le novelle fronde
48  di che si vede Europa rivestire,

49  Not far off from the beating of the waves,
50  Behind which in his long career the sun
51  Sometimes conceals himself from every man,

49  non molto lungi al percuoter de l'onde
50  dietro a le quali, per la lunga foga,
51  lo sol talvolta ad ogne uom si nasconde,

52  Is situate the fortunate Calahorra,
53  Under protection of the mighty shield
54  In which the Lion subject is and sovereign.

52  siede la fortunata Calaroga
53  sotto la protezion del grande scudo
54  in che soggiace il leone e soggioga:

55  Therein was born the amorous paramour
56  Of Christian Faith, the athlete consecrate,
57  Kind to his own and cruel to his foes;

55  dentro vi nacque l'amoroso drudo
56  de la fede cristiana, il santo atleta
57  benigno a' suoi e a' nemici crudo;

58  And when it was created was his mind
59  Replete with such a living energy,
60  That in his mother her it made prophetic.

58  e come fu creata, fu repleta
59  sì la sua mente di viva virtute
60  che, ne la madre, lei fece profeta.

61  As soon as the espousals were complete
62  Between him and the Faith at holy font,
63  Where they with mutual safety dowered each other,

61  Poi che le sponsalizie fuor compiute
62  al sacro fonte intra lui e la Fede,
63  u' si dotar di mutüa salute,

64  The woman, who for him had given assent,
65  Saw in a dream the admirable fruit
66  That issue would from him and from his heirs;

64  la donna che per lui l'assenso diede,
65  vide nel sonno il mirabile frutto
66  ch'uscir dovea di lui e de le rede;

67  And that he might be construed as he was,
68  A spirit from this place went forth to name him
69  With His possessive whose he wholly was.

67  e perché fosse qual era in costrutto,
68  quinci si mosse spirito a nomarlo
69  del possessivo di cui era tutto.

70  Dominic was he called; and him I speak of
71  Even as of the husbandman whom Christ
72  Elected to his garden to assist him.

70  Domenico fu detto; e io ne parlo
71  sì come de l'agricola che Cristo
72  elesse a l'orto suo per aiutarlo.

73  Envoy and servant sooth he seemed of Christ,
74  For the first love made manifest in him
75  Was the first counsel that was given by Christ.

73  Ben parve messo e famigliar di Cristo:
74  ché 'l primo amor che 'n lui fu manifesto,
75  fu al primo consiglio che diè Cristo.

76  Silent and wakeful many a time was he
77  Discovered by his nurse upon the ground,
78  As if he would have said, 'For this I came.'

76  Spesse fïate fu tacito e desto
77  trovato in terra da la sua nutrice,
78  come dicesse: 'Io son venuto a questo.'

79  O thou his father, Felix verily!
80  O thou his mother, verily Joanna,
81  If this, interpreted, means as is said!

79  Oh padre suo veramente Felice!
80  oh madre sua veramente Giovanna,
81  se, interpretata, val come si dice!

82  Not for the world which people toil for now
83  In following Ostiense and Taddeo,
84  But through his longing after the true manna,

82  Non per lo mondo, per cui mo s'affanna
83  di retro ad Ostïense e a Taddeo,
84  ma per amor de la verace manna

85  He in short time became so great a teacher,
86  That he began to go about the vineyard,
87  Which fadeth soon, if faithless be the dresser;

85  in picciol tempo gran dottor si feo;
86  tal che si mise a circüir la vigna
87  che tosto imbianca, se 'l vignaio è reo.

88  And of the See, (that once was more benignant
89  Unto the righteous poor, not through itself,
90  But him who sits there and degenerates,)

88  E a la sedia che fu già benigna
89  più a' poveri giusti, non per lei,
90  ma per colui che siede, che traligna,

91  Not to dispense or two or three for six,
92  Not any fortune of first vacancy,
93  'Non decimas quae sunt pauperum Dei,'

91  non dispensare o due o tre per sei,
92  non la fortuna di prima vacante,
93  non decimas, quae sunt pauperum Dei,

94  He asked for, but against the errant world
95  Permission to do battle for the seed,
96  Of which these four and twenty plants surround thee.

94  addimandò, ma contro al mondo errante
95  licenza di combatter per lo seme
96  del qual ti fascian ventiquattro piante.

97  Then with the doctrine and the will together,
98  With office apostolical he moved,
99  Like torrent which some lofty vein out-presses;

97  Poi, con dottrina e con volere insieme,
98  con l'officio appostolico si mosse
99  quasi torrente ch'alta vena preme;

100  And in among the shoots heretical
101  His impetus with greater fury smote,
102  Wherever the resistance was the greatest.

100  e ne li sterpi eretici percosse
101  l'impeto suo, più vivamente quivi
102  dove le resistenze eran più grosse.

103  Of him were made thereafter divers runnels,
104  Whereby the garden catholic is watered,
105  So that more living its plantations stand.

103  Di lui si fecer poi diversi rivi
104  onde l'orto catolico si riga,
105  sì che i suoi arbuscelli stan più vivi.

106  If such the one wheel of the Biga was,
107  In which the Holy Church itself defended
108  And in the field its civic battle won,

106  Se tal fu l'una rota de la biga
107  in che la Santa Chiesa si difese
108  e vinse in campo la sua civil briga,

109  Truly full manifest should be to thee
110  The excellence of the other, unto whom
111  Thomas so courteous was before my coming.

109  ben ti dovrebbe assai esser palese
110  l'eccellenza de l'altra, di cui Tomma
111  dinanzi al mio venir fu sì cortese.

112  But still the orbit, which the highest part
113  Of its circumference made, is derelict,
114  So that the mould is where was once the crust.

112  Ma l'orbita che fé la parte somma
113  di sua circunferenza, è derelitta,
114  sì ch'è la muffa dov' era la gromma.

115  His family, that had straight forward moved
116  With feet upon his footprints, are turned round
117  So that they set the point upon the heel.

115  La sua famiglia, che si mosse dritta
116  coi piedi a le sue orme, è tanto volta,
117  che quel dinanzi a quel di retro gitta;

118  And soon aware they will be of the harvest
119  Of this bad husbandry, when shall the tares
120  Complain the granary is taken from them.

118  e tosto si vedrà de la ricolta
119  de la mala coltura, quando il loglio
120  si lagnerà che l'arca li sia tolta.

121  Yet say I, he who searcheth leaf by leaf
122  Our volume through, would still some page discover
123  Where he could read, 'I am as I am wont.'

121  Ben dico, chi cercasse a foglio a foglio
122  nostro volume, ancor troveria carta
123  u' leggerebbe 'I' mi son quel ch'i' soglio';

124  'Twill not be from Casal nor Acquasparta,
125  From whence come such unto the written word
126  That one avoids it, and the other narrows.

124  ma non fia da Casal né d'Acquasparta,
125  là onde vegnon tali a la scrittura,
126  ch'uno la fugge e altro la coarta.

127  Bonaventura of Bagnoregio's life
128  Am I, who always in great offices
129  Postponed considerations sinister.

127  Io son la vita di Bonaventura
128  da Bagnoregio, che ne' grandi offici
129  sempre pospuosi la sinistra cura.

130  Here are Illuminato and Agostino,
131  Who of the first barefooted beggars were
132  That with the cord the friends of God became.

130  Illuminato e Augustin son quici,
131  che fuor de' primi scalzi poverelli
132  che nel capestro a Dio si fero amici.

133  Hugh of Saint Victor is among them here,
134  And Peter Mangiador, and Peter of Spain,
135  Who down below in volumes twelve is shining;

133  Ugo da San Vittore è qui con elli,
134  e Pietro Mangiadore e Pietro Spano,
134  lo qual giù luce in dodici libelli;

136  Nathan the seer, and metropolitan
137  Chrysostom, and Anselmus, and Donatus
138  Who deigned to lay his hand to the first art;

136  Natàn profeta e 'l metropolitano
137  Crisostomo e Anselmo e quel Donato
138  ch'a la prim' arte degnò porre mano.

139  Here is Rabanus, and beside me here
140  Shines the Calabrian Abbot Joachim,
141  He with the spirit of prophecy endowed.

139  Rabano è qui, e lucemi dallato
140  il calavrese abate Giovacchino
141  di spirito profetico dotato.

142  To celebrate so great a paladin
143  Have moved me the impassioned courtesy
144  And the discreet discourses of Friar Thomas,

142  Ad inveggiar cotanto paladino
143  mi mosse l'infiammata cortesia
144  di fra Tommaso e 'l discreto latino;

145  And with me they have moved this company."

145  e mosse meco questa compagnia.”

Canto XIII
The Nine Orders of Angels (plus God: Primum Mobile) equal the decad) in ascending order
Liberal Arts
Trivium
Angels — Moon — Grammar
Archangels — Mercury — Dialectic
Thrones — Venus — Rhetoric
Quadrivium
Dominions — Sun — Arithmetic
Virtues— Mars — Music
Principalities — Jupiter — Geometry
Powers — Saturn — Astrology

Philosophy
Cherubim
Seraphim

God, Primum Mobile (Inclusive of them all).

The world is beautiful in something like the way it is mathematical.  Neither aesthetic or mathematical experience exist prior to humans.  But these inventions succeed because they map form, symmetry, harmony, distribution of patterns, causal interrelationships, order, unity, and diversity, discovered to actually be there.

Holmes Rolston III,
"Landscape: Landscape from the Eighteenth Century to the Present."
Encyclopedia of Aesthetics, Volume 3, page 96.



We should not forget that these canti in the domain of the sun are in the domain arithmetic and of the angelic realm of Dominions.  Dante's numbers are allegoric, just as are the mathematics of contemporary physicists.  They are indicators of relationships between the human mind "in-here" and whatever is "out there" in the cosmos.  From one perspective, numbers, and we have a lot of them in these sun-canti, 24, 12, 6, 5 (Solomon) 15, 9, 7, 2, 1, etc., and especially 3.  Like Buckminster Fuller, Dante builds his universe on the concept of triangularities, which remain ever present as the rock solid (verse 3, here) stability of the poem.  We might argue that the appeal of numbers is precisely that they are stripped of all qualia, and like the universal embrace of the sun, an emblem of God's love, they cannot be besmirched by concepts of pain and pleasure, good and evil, beautiful or ugly.  The temporal senses cannot subject them to the subjectivity of judgement.  Our assessment of some formula might be incorrect, but that does not make mathematical or even cabbalistic formulation morally wrong.  Like God, the mysteries of numbers can be logically probed, in fact they are the quintessential paradigms of logic, but they can never be — since their existence infinite — reduced to mere ratiocination — they are, in the Jungian sense, irrational, that is, reasonable, but beyond reason.  To turn the imagination loose, as Dante explicitly does here in the opening verses, with the magical invocation of "imagini" three times repeated, is to set the human mind free to explore and absorb the infinitude of the Divine.  The canto loops back to an open question left hanging in Canto XI regarding Solomon's wisdom, and entirely reframes a statement that seemed absolute, that is, that none have been or ever will be greater exemplars of wisdom than was Solomon, to something that is made relative by changing the context.  This same shifting of values occurs in numbers with the idea of greater than/less than.  For example, the number 5 is greater than 4, but less than 6, but these relative values can also be permanently fixed.  And by allowing Thomas Aquinas to re-evaluate the position of Solomon's wisdom in the context of the prelapsarian Adam and redemptive figure of Christ, this wider context of proportionality as a principle is established as an absolute, although our understanding of the implications of this principle will always be relative and always subject to recontextualization.   The canto begins with a long set of what amounts to an instruction manual on how to apply these realizations to the reading of not only this canto, but to the poem as a whole.  This canto makes it clear at the very beginning (I say what you see), in which two monologues are distinctly present.  One is the monologue of the poet to the reader, two characters outside the poem, the other is the monologue of Thomas Aquinas and the aspirant protagonist inside the poem.  The long opening gambit the reader is Dante's maneuver to unite these two worlds.  This has the effect of injecting the imaginal world of Dante's Paradise into the "real" world of the reader's temporal experience.  In fact, it has the effect of reversing the object/reflection argument presented in the previous canti, from the usual sensory experience of the temporal, mortal world as that which is real, and the imaginative world as a reflection.  This device creates a vertigo which leads to the Experience that there is a REALITY of IDEATIONAL, IMAGINAL OBJECTIVITY which makes the mutable, perishable entities of the mortal world an ephemeral reflection.  In brief, if we follow the text's instructions, we too will find ourselves in Paradise, and are therein prepared to receive the instruction of the saint.  How is that possible?  It is made possible because we have already received the instruction of the poet.  

Thomas' exposition tells the aspirant protagonist Dante WHAT to think, or how to resolve an apparent, particular theological/philosophic paradox, but the diachronic poet, Dante, in these opening lines, tells us HOW to think.  Dante, the poet, here, is making a claim that poetry — for which one synonym is "numbers" — is superior to theology and philosophy because imagination allows us to not only probe the meanings of those two endeavors, but to contextualize them in this aesthetic sphere which encloses the theologic and the philosophic and arranges their contextualized values.  Imagine one of those toy spheres containing a little landscape in a solute filled with little particles meant to simulate snowflakes.  When we shake this toy, the flakes swirl around, constantly changing their positions relative to one another.  Poetry, because it can present both the qualia of experience in language and the mathematical abstracts of its own formal structures (terza rime, here), is the Word of God.  This is THE WORD which births the cosmos.  Theologians and philosophers merely observe and study it, contesting with one another as to which of their observations are the orthodox, logical, or correct ones.  Poetry is a sun that shines its light upon these observations, but is all inclusive, the aesthetic realm it establishes may make judgements, indulge in mathematics and theology, but is itself beyond the things whose qualities it determines.  The influence of poetry, however, is not like that of a king or a politician, whose power might be analogous to the power of the ego in waking consciousness.  Poetry's influence is subtle, and almost invisible to the mere candle flicker of the ego.  Solomon realizes this in his dream, when he is wise enough to ask for wisdom, and not more political power.  He puts his ego desire for power under the authority of that which is the progenitor and interpreter of power, and as such, his wisdom, comes from an atemporal realm, that atemporal perfect template which was innate in Adam and Jesus, and did not have to be sought, observed, studied, or argued about.  Though in many ways Solomon remain disastrously fallible as a king, an ego, in this aspect of wisdom, gifted to him through this infallible domain, his gift could not by definition ever be surpassed, although his ego behaviors still retained their faults and foibles, some of which proved to be fatal to his roles as king, lover, and father.  Solomon's case for inclusion in Paradise is a paradoxical one based upon how his moral failures as a sexual profligate and inept exemplar as a father and king have been redeemed because he is the poet of the Song of Songs.  In general, this is also the path of the Commedia, which in the Inferno we see as a contraction to a point of pain and paralysis, which finally opens into the starry heavens (also seen in this canto), and which in the Purgatorio is a contraction of the dissipations of sin, culminating in a liberation into Paradise.  These two follow the same movement as the birth contractions which drive the foetus through the dangerous narrow portal of the vagina to its birth into the finite sphere of an independent existence.  This movement is ever present, but mostly covertly hidden, and its most hidden permutations is what Walter Arensberg, in his book, The Cryptography of Dante, tracks in his chapter entitled "The Seal."  The gist of this is that Dante's work has both overtly and covertly (through cryptograms) made of his poem both in content and process, a linguistic embodiment of sexual intercourse, sexual organs, birth, and finally a release from the temporal domain which is rife with pain and death, and the slavish servitude to the body.  Dante's "seal", his emblem and motto is the Latin Peremas: which means, as according to Arensberg, and as far as I have been able to determine, "to withhold" or to "hinder."  The poem itself represents a withdrawal from the Created world of sexual reproduction and temporal mortality to the aesthetic world of the poem.  Is this true?  If it is true, and that is a part of his overall endeavor, than aesthetics is the ground where the soul can fight for and achieve a release from a fallen physical world.  I don't know if this is true, but it is a legitimate question, and the artifact, or should we say organism, of the Commedia, provides, if not a definitive answer, a plausible one. 

In temporal, physical life, sexuality, and eating, have both a necessary function and a pleasure function.  But that which is a necessity for the ephemeral life of the body, is not a necessity for the life of the soul, and these effluents of pleasure — all that's sublime or transcendent — these are the necessities for what might be called the atemporal physiology of the soul.  What Dante is exploring ever more intensely as he ascends through the spheres of paradise are the domains of idealization, ideas, whose bodily components are the métier of philosophers and theologians, just as anatomy is the study required for the understanding of the physical body.   The anatomist parses the body ever more finely and minutely, and likewise the scholastic theologian and philosopher parses ideas ever more finely and minutely.  These metaphysical inquiries, as Dante reminds us in this canto are not necessary and may even be a hindrance to the conduct of everyday, temporal life.  Their practice is impractical.  But let's remember what Blake said: 

The Infant Joy is beautiful, but its anatomy
Horrible ghast & deadly! nought shalt thou find in it
But dark despair & everlasting brooding melancholy!

The joy of poetry may not be practical,  but aside from mundane accounting functions, neither is mathematics.  We don't need a mathematical description of the moon's phases to see how those phases affect the tides and the tides of human emotion.  And yet both poetry and higher mathematics are aesthetic necessities for any truth which stays true across all contexts.  Dante is not writing history, he is showing us that the anatomy of soul and the anatomy of the poem have an aesthetic immortality, not subject to the corruption and death of that which is merely physical.  As Unamuno has shown us, the restriction of our existences without a corresponding view of that which is immortal can only lead to a tragic sense of life.  The Commedia is not that, even in the Inferno, and it has become the Divine Comedy because it affirms in every life situation of an ensouled human, that which contains, animates, and transcends physical mortality.  It is not Darwin's survival of the fittest, which is true enough in the context of physical life, but Darwin's wife's survival of the most devout, which is affirmed here.  And this is a sense that has been lost to the modern materialist, and I would assert cannot ever be regained by the literalist material explanations of science, nor can such explanations explain or explain away the persistence of aesthetics in the lives of human beings.  The body cannot live without food, cannot propagate without sex, but the soul cannot live without imagination.  And from the most depraved to the most exulted, human life is dominated, even more than by food and sex, by the imaginative auras which emanate from, infuse, sustain, and create them.  This is where Schopenhauer got it wrong, he did not go far enough in his quite accurate assessment of physical human life.  He did not understand that what kept him alive as a man was his life as a philosopher, and that life was always evolving toward bliss, even if that bliss was primarily concerned with painful explanations.  For Dante, a lover of physical life, politics, philosophy, and theology, seems to have the realization that none of these had the power to save him, or even to explain to him, why he should love these imperfect, damaging, and ultimately death-dealing domains.  What he does seem to see as that which had the power to transform these entities and to transcend them, is poetry. 

1  Let him imagine, who would well conceive
2  What now I saw, and let him while I speak
3  Retain the image as a steadfast rock,

1  Imagini, chi bene intender cupe
2  quel ch'i' or vidi – e ritegna l'image,
3  mentre ch'io dico, come ferma rupe –,

4  The fifteen stars, that in their divers regions
5  The sky enliven with a light so great
6  That it transcends all clusters of the air;

4  quindici stelle che 'n diverse plage
5  lo cielo avvivan di tanto sereno
6  che soperchia de l'aere ogne compage;

7  Let him the Wain imagine unto which
8  Our vault of heaven sufficeth night and day,
9  So that in turning of its pole it fails not;

7  imagini quel carro a cu' il seno
8  basta del nostro cielo e notte e giorno,
9  sì ch'al volger del temo non vien meno;

10  Let him the mouth imagine of the horn
11  That in the point beginneth of the axis
12  Round about which the primal wheel revolves,—

10  imagini la bocca di quel corno
11  che si comincia in punta de lo stelo
12  a cui la prima rota va dintorno,

13  To have fashioned of themselves two signs in heaven,
14  Like unto that which Minos' daughter made,
15  The moment when she felt the frost of death;

13  aver fatto di sé due segni in cielo,
14  qual fece la figliuola di Minoi
15  allora che sentì di morte il gelo;

16  And one to have its rays within the other,
17  And both to whirl themselves in such a manner
18  That one should forward go, the other backward;

16  e l'un ne l'altro aver li raggi suoi,
17  e amendue girarsi per maniera
18  che l'uno andasse al primo e l'altro al poi;

19  And he will have some shadowing forth of that
20  True constellation and the double dance
21  That circled round the point at which I was;

19  e avrà quasi l'ombra de la vera
20  costellazione e de la doppia danza
21  che circulava il punto dov' io era:

22  Because it is as much beyond our wont,
23  As swifter than the motion of the Chiana
24  Moveth the heaven that all the rest outspeeds.

22  poi ch'è tanto di là da nostra usanza,
23  quanto di là dal mover de la Chiana
24  si move il ciel che tutti li altri avanza.

25  There sang they neither Bacchus, nor Apollo,
26  But in the divine nature Persons three,
27  And in one person the divine and human.

25  Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana,
26  ma tre persone in divina natura,
27  e in una persona essa e l'umana.

28  The singing and the dance fulfilled their measure,
29  And unto us those holy lights gave need,
30  Growing in happiness from care to care.

28  Compié 'l cantare e 'l volger sua misura;
29  e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi,
30  felicitando sé di cura in cura.

31  Then broke the silence of those saints concordant
32  The light in which the admirable life
33  Of God's own mendicant was told to me,

31  Ruppe il silenzio ne' concordi numi
32  poscia la luce in che mirabil vita
33  del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,

34  And said: "Now that one straw is trodden out
35  Now that its seed is garnered up already,
36  Sweet love invites me to thresh out the other.

34  e disse: “Quando l'una paglia è trita,
35  quando la sua semenza è già riposta,
36  a batter l'altra dolce amor m'invita.

37  Into that bosom, thou believest, whence
38  Was drawn the rib to form the beauteous cheek
39  Whose taste to all the world is costing dear,

37  Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa
38  si trasse per formar la bella guancia
39  il cui palato a tutto 'l mondo costa,

40  And into that which, by the lance transfixed,
41  Before and since, such satisfaction made
42  That it weighs down the balance of all sin,

40  e in quel che, forato da la lancia,
41  e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece,
42  che d'ogne colpa vince la bilancia,

43  Whate'er of light it has to human nature
44  Been lawful to possess was all infused
45  By the same power that both of them created;

43  quantunque a la natura umana lece
44  aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso
45  da quel valor che l'uno e l'altro fece;

45  And hence at what I said above dost wonder,
47  When I narrated that no second had
48  The good which in the fifth light is enclosed.

46  e però miri a ciò ch'io dissi suso,
47  quando narrai che non ebbe 'l secondo
48  lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.

49  Now ope thine eyes to what I answer thee,
50  And thou shalt see thy creed and my discourse
51  Fit in the truth as centre in a circle.

49  Or apri li occhi a quel ch'io ti rispondo,
50  e vedräi il tuo credere e 'l mio dire
51  nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.

52  That which can die, and that which dieth not,
53  Are nothing but the splendour of the idea
54  Which by his love our Lord brings into being;

52  Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire
53  non è se non splendor di quella idea
54  che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;

55  Because that living Light, which from its fount
56  Effulgent flows, so that it disunites not
57  From Him nor from the Love in them intrined,

55  ché quella viva luce che sì mea
56  dal suo lucente, che non si disuna
57  da lui né da l'amor ch'a lor s'intrea,

58  Through its own goodness reunites its rays
59  In nine subsistences, as in a mirror,
60  Itself eternally remaining One.

58  per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna,
59  quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze,
60  etternalmente rimanendosi una.

61  Thence it descends to the last potencies,
62  Downward from act to act becoming such
63  That only brief contingencies it makes;

61  Quindi discende a l'ultime potenze
62  giù d'atto in atto, tanto divenendo,
63  che più non fa che brevi contingenze;

64  And these contingencies I hold to be
65  Things generated, which the heaven produces
66  By its own motion, with seed and without.

64  e queste contingenze essere intendo
65  le cose generate, che produce
66  con seme e sanza seme il ciel movendo.

67  Neither their wax, nor that which tempers it,
68  Remains immutable, and hence beneath
69  The ideal signet more and less shines through;

67  La cera di costoro e chi la duce
68  non sta d'un modo; e però sotto 'l segno
69  idëale poi più e men traluce.

70  Therefore it happens, that the selfsame tree
71  After its kind bears worse and better fruit,
72  And ye are born with characters diverse.

70  Ond' elli avvien ch'un medesimo legno,
71  secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta;
72  e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.

73  If in perfection tempered were the wax,
74  And were the heaven in its supremest virtue,
75  The brilliance of the seal would all appear;

73  Se fosse a punto la cera dedutta
74  e fosse il cielo in sua virtù supprema,
75  la luce del suggel parrebbe tutta;

76  But nature gives it evermore deficient,
77  In the like manner working as the artist,
78  Who has the skill of art and hand that trembles.

76  ma la natura la dà sempre scema,
77  similemente operando a l'artista
78  ch'a l'abito de l'arte ha man che trema.

79  If then the fervent Love, the Vision clear,
80    Of primal Virtue do dispose and seal,
81  Perfection absolute is there acquired.

79  Però se 'l caldo amor la chiara vista
80  de la prima virtù dispone e segna,
81  tutta la perfezion quivi s'acquista.

82  Thus was of old the earth created worthy
83  Of all and every animal perfection;
84  And thus the Virgin was impregnate made;

82  Così fu fatta già la terra degna
83  di tutta l'animal perfezïone;
84  così fu fatta la Vergine pregna;

85  So that thine own opinion I commend,
86  That human nature never yet has been,
87  Nor will be, what it was in those two persons.

85  sì ch'io commendo tua oppinïone,
86  che l'umana natura mai non fue
87  né fia qual fu in quelle due persone.

88  Now if no farther forth I should proceed,
89  'Then in what way was he without a peer?'
90  Would be the first beginning of thy words.

88  Or s'i' non procedesse avanti piùe,
89  'Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?'
90  comincerebber le parole tue.

91  But, that may well appear what now appears not,
92  Think who he was, and what occasion moved him
93  To make request, when it was told him, 'Ask.'

91  Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare,
92  pensa chi era, e la cagion che 'l mosse,
93  quando fu detto 'Chiedi,' a dimandare.

94  I've not so spoken that thou canst not see
95  Clearly he was a king who asked for wisdom,
96  That he might be sufficiently a king;

94  Non ho parlato sì, che tu non posse
95  ben veder ch'el fu re, che chiese senno
96  acciò che re sufficïente fosse;

97  'Twas not to know the number in which are
98  The motors here above, or if 'necesse'
99  With a contingent e'er 'necesse' make,

97  non per sapere il numero in che enno
98  li motor di qua sù, o se necesse
99  con contingente mai necesse fenno;

100  'Non si est dare primum motum esse,'
101   Or if in semicircle can be made
102  Triangle so that it have no right angle.

100  non si est dare primum motum esse,
101  o se del mezzo cerchio far si puote
102  trïangol sì ch'un retto non avesse.

103  Whence, if thou notest this and what I said,
104  A regal prudence is that peerless seeing
105  In which the shaft of my intention strikes.

103  Onde, se ciò ch'io dissi e questo note,
104  regal prudenza è quel vedere impari
105  in che lo stral di mia intenzion percuote;

106  And if on 'rose' thou turnest thy clear eyes,
107  Thou'lt see that it has reference alone
108  To kings who're many, and the good are rare.

106  e se al 'surse' drizzi li occhi chiari,
107  vedrai aver solamente respetto
108  ai regi, che son molti, e ' buon son rari.

109  With this distinction take thou what I said,
110  And thus it can consist with thy belief
111  Of the first father and of our Delight.

109  Con questa distinzion prendi 'l mio detto;
110  e così puote star con quel che credi
111  del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.

112  And lead shall this be always to thy feet,
113  To make thee, like a weary man, move slowly
114  Both to the Yes and No thou seest not;

112  E questo ti sia sempre piombo a' piedi,
113  per farti mover lento com' uom lasso
114  e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:

115  For very low among the fools is he
116  Who affirms without distinction, or denies,
117  As well in one as in the other case;

115  ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso,
116  che sanza distinzione afferma e nega
117  ne l'un così come ne l'altro passo;

118  Because it happens that full often bends
119  Current opinion in the false direction,
120  And then the feelings bind the intellect.

118  perch' elli 'ncontra che più volte piega
119  l'oppinïon corrente in falsa parte,
120  e poi l'affetto l'intelletto lega.

121  Far more than uselessly he leaves the shore,
122  (Since he returneth not the same he went,)
123  Who fishes for the truth, and has no skill;

121  Vie più che 'ndarno da riva si parte,
122  perché non torna tal qual e' si move,
123  chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l'arte.

124  And in the world proofs manifest thereof
125  Parmenides, Melissus, Brissus are,
126  And many who went on and knew not whither;

124  E di ciò sono al mondo aperte prove
125  Parmenide, Melisso e Brisso e molti,
126  li quali andaro e non sapëan dove;

127  Thus did Sabellius, Arius, and those fools
128  Who have been even as swords unto the Scriptures
129  In rendering distorted their straight faces.

127  sì fé Sabellio e Arrio e quelli stolti
128  che furon come spade a le Scritture
129  in render torti li diritti volti.

130  Nor yet shall people be too confident
131  In judging, even as he is who doth count
132  The corn in field or ever it be ripe.

130  Non sien le genti, ancor, troppo sicure
131  a giudicar, sì come quei che stima
132  le biade in campo pria che sien mature;

133  For I have seen all winter long the thorn
134  First show itself intractable and fierce,
135  And after bear the rose upon its top;

133  ch'i' ho veduto tutto 'l verno prima
134  lo prun mostrarsi rigido e feroce,
135  poscia portar la rosa in su la cima;

136  And I have seen a ship direct and swift
137  Run o'er the sea throughout its course entire,
138  To perish at the harbour's mouth at last.

136  e legno vidi già dritto e veloce
137  correr lo mar per tutto suo cammino,
138  perire al fine a l'intrar de la foce.

139  Let not Dame Bertha nor Ser Martin think,
140  Seeing one steal, another offering make,
141  To see them in the arbitrament divine;

139  Non creda donna Berta e ser Martino,
140  per vedere un furare, altro offerere,
141 ché quel può surgere, e quel può cadere.”

142  For one may rise, and fall the other may."

142  ché quel può surgere, e quel può cadere.”

Canto XIV
The heaven of Mars may be compared to music because of two properties: one is its most beautiful relation, for in counting the moving heavens, from whichever we begin, whether from the lowest or the highest, this heaven of Mars is the fifth and the middlemost of them all, that is, of the first, second, third, and fourth pairs. The other, as Ptolemy says in the Quadripartitus, is that Mars dries things out and incinerates them because its heat is like that of fire; and this is why it appears fiery in color, sometimes more and sometimes less, according to the density or rarity of the vapors which accompany it, which often ignite by themselves, as is established in the first book of Meteorics.  For this reason Albumassar says that the ignition of these vapors signifies the death of kings and the changing of kingdoms, because they are effects of the lordship of Mars, and this is why Seneca says that at the death of the Emperor Augustus he saw on high a ball of fire. This is also why in Florence, at the beginning of its ruin, there was seen in the sky in the shape of a cross a great quantity of these vapors which accompany the star of Mars. And these two properties are found in Music, which consists entirely of relations, as we see in harmonized words and in songs, whose harmony is so much the sweeter the more the relation is beautiful, which relation is the principal beauty in this science, because it is its principal aim. Moreover, Music attracts to itself the human spirits, which are, as it were, principally vapors of the heart, so that they almost completely cease their activity; this happens likewise to the entire soul when it hears music, and the virtue of all of them, as it were, runs to the spirit of sense which receives the sound.

The Convivio, Book II, Chapter 13

If one were describing the electromagnetic waves which travel across the brain and not water in a vase, these first three verses of Canto XIV might not be inapt.  All through these sun canti Dante is playing with circular and elliptical movements, and, if we might speculate, it is as if in the depths of his meditation/imaginings, he is able to see those holographic interference patterns from which existence arises.  I takes these observations not as the mechanistic truths of 21st Century science, but as metaphoric — which may be the only way to really get to the heart of them.  They seem to be statements about consciousness.  Always I am stunned by Dante's prescience.  However far the reader proceeds in penetrating these texts with her or his own insights, Dante's insights, like lights in a darkness, are always already beyond, shimmering, beckoning.  I had hoped as I proceeded in the text, that when I reached the Paradiso, after having been educated in Dante's cosmology and poetry by reading the first two canticles, that I would be having an easier time of it.  I'm not.  But I don't think that is solely because of any technical deficiencies I have in applying myself to the poetry.  No, rather, the insights that Dante presents are addressed to a person who must have certain of those same insights in order to have a receptacle for the kinds of experiences that Dante is expressing.  All this seemingly arcane excursion into Medieval theology, which seem so irrelevant, perhaps even historically passé and naive to the 21st Century reader, must be slipped into, fitting like a glove around one's own thought, so to speak, before this particular state of consciousness can be experienced.  Like the protagonist Dante, who, like some conscious remote operating vehicle of the poet living outside the poem, we must slip into the center of these circling/countercircling singing/dancing entities with this anima/muse as our guide.  Beatrice here, not only reads Dante's mind, she reads that portion of his mind that has yet to evolve in the future.  Her statement here is not therefore solely about the state of mind of her ward and chela, it is about MIND, in all caps, the MIND that creates space/time and therefore embodies an omnipresence synonymous with omniscience.  For a 21st Century reader the very possibility of such a MIND is flabbergasting, an historical relic, an impossibility, and yet, if we begin to adopt the parameters of a belief system that Dante tells us are the necessary criteria for the kind of transcendent experience expressed in and through the poem, then we too will experience MIND in this fantastical way.  Dante, the poet, is saying, through all this seemingly arcane theology is: If you are to have this experience, the philosophy is the hallucinogen you must take in order for my psychedelia to engulf you.  This is a deep, deep psychic pilgrimage, whose kaleidoscopic arrays of historical figures, mythological and angelic entities, geographical locales, and celestial configurations become the reader's new parameters of mind, and the questions about the dimensions of these new parameters are Dante's (the protagonist, aspirant) questions.  The question that needs to be answered if that protagonist/aspirant is going to continue to ascend in this transitional canto between the Sun's arithmetical dimensions (given a parting shot here in verses 27 -30 about the trinity) and the music that is manifested in the sphere of Mars is this stark one: How can even the fully spirit-saturated mind of even a great saint, in the joyous spinning and brilliant depths of its deepest meditations, possibly turn its attention to the temporal, decaying cadaver of its former physical self?  These two visions, that of spiritual exhilaration and that of the dead, putrefying corruption could not be further apart.  In fact, they are so far apart that they seem not to be able to co-exist in the same universe, one or the other of them must be illusory, and in the 21st Century we have chosen the latter as the real, and the former as the illusion.  The allure of this poem in all its musical, mathematical, and metaphorical splendor is that it is telling us this: In order to experience the ultimate ecstasy, you cannot have these worlds in any kind of opposition to one another which affirms one as authentic and the other as fantasy, both exist right here and right now in the physical sound- and-meaning-body of this poem, and that is the philosophical/poetical MIND that you must inhabit if you want the "proof," which is only available within the ever-expanding parameters of this belief system.  Yet, the phrase "belief system" that I've used here is but a bridge to help my 21st century mind move into the ENTITY of universal MIND that Dante has been proposing all along.
