How easy the protagonist and his beatific muse, Beatrice, ascend here from the transcendence of the Sun to the wider, deeper transcendence of Mars!  This protagonist is so enraptured by the Sun sphere, that he hardly notices that he has ascended to an even more enthralling rapture.  And how hard it is for the 21st century mind to accept the grace of this Cosmic MIND.  When Eliot says that "we had the experience, but we missed the meaning," he seems to be referring to this terrible entrapment of the cadaver-mind that we have chosen to accept as real.  Inside the mortal, brain there can be no more than temporary exultations, never Eternal ones, and the question that Beatrice foresees in her chela's future frames that dilemma profoundly.  To make any form stable enough to exist, let alone Eternally exist, it cannot be tainted with temporality, therefore a new resurrected body is not only a necessity for our future, but a necessity if we are going to have a future.  In verses 73-75, the pilgrim's body and his bodily organs of perception are undergoing this temporal passage from the two contrary-revolving spheres to a third motion beyond them and encompassing them.  This is a circling, all of whose boundaries are but provisional states of joy.  But their states, their templates, as Blake says, are permanent, so that they may be experienced, but they then widen unto greater states of joy, the greater states not obliterating the lesser, but incorporating them in ever-renewed, ever more perceptually potent bodies, bodies that are aesthetic, poetic, and musical, bodies that are capable of utilizing the temporal, historical, and physical as the ecstatic fuel of an hallucinogenic communion wafer whose assimilation allows us to experience Universal MIND: "The true incandescence of the Holy Breath."  Such a vision is needed to reorganize the temporally oriented mind, whose experiences all end in obliteration.  Such a vision triggers the sudden infusion of a new language.  And this is what happens to Dante, the aspirant, here.  His temporal memory is brightened-out, and he begins to speak in tongues.  A new galaxy, compared to the Milky Way, appears as the new permeable and expanding boundary of the transformed belief "system," a galaxy that baffles all the temporal understandings of the wisest of mortal sages, and in which the opposites of the temporal and the eternal appear as a flaming cross that Christs both Heaven and Earth.  The old cloddish beliefs are granulated into the atoms of the everlasting, and the poet compares these new entity-atoms to motes of light spinning in a shaft of sun.  But these motes are notes, notes of a transcendent music, the music of a love song, which, returning to the union of Dante and Beatrice here, remind the reader that the whole of the Divina Commedia is a love song.   


1  From centre unto rim, from rim to centre,
2  In a round vase the water moves itself,
3  As from without 'tis struck or from within.

1  Dal centro al cerchio, e sì dal cerchio al centro
2  movesi l'acqua in un ritondo vaso,
3  secondo ch'è percosso fuori o dentro:

4  Into my mind upon a sudden dropped
5  What I am saying, at the moment when
6  Silent became the glorious life of Thomas,

4  ne la mia mente fé sùbito caso
5  questo ch'io dico, sì come si tacque
6  la glorïosa vita di Tommaso,

7  Because of the resemblance that was born
8  Of his discourse and that of Beatrice,
9  Whom, after him, it pleased thus to begin:

7  per la similitudine che nacque
8  del suo parlare e di quel di Beatrice,
9  a cui sì cominciar, dopo lui, piacque:

10  "This man has need (and does not tell you so,
11   Nor with the voice, nor even in his thought)
12   Of going to the root of one truth more.

10  “A costui fa mestieri, e nol vi dice
11  né con la voce né pensando ancora,
12  d'un altro vero andare a la radice.

13  Declare unto him if the light wherewith
14   Blossoms your substance shall remain with you
15   Eternally the same that it is now;

13  Diteli se la luce onde s'infiora
14  vostra sustanza, rimarrà con voi
15  etternalmente sì com' ell' è ora;

16  And if it do remain, say in what manner,
17  After ye are again made visible,
18  It can be that it injure not your sight."

16  e se rimane, dite come, poi
17  che sarete visibili rifatti,
18  esser porà ch'al veder non vi nòi.”

19  As by a greater gladness urged and drawn
20  They who are dancing in a ring sometimes
21  Uplift their voices and their motions quicken;

19  Come, da più letizia pinti e tratti,
20  a la fiata quei che vanno a rota
21  levan la voce e rallegrano li atti

22  So, at that orison devout and prompt,
23  The holy circles a new joy displayed
24  In their revolving and their wondrous song.

22  così, a l'orazion pronta e divota,
23  li santi cerchi mostrar nova gioia
24  nel torneare e ne la mira nota.

25  Whoso lamenteth him that here we die
26  That we may live above, has never there
27  Seen the refreshment of the eternal rain.

25  Qual si lamenta perché qui si moia
26  per viver colà sù, non vide quive
27  lo refrigerio de l'etterna ploia.

28  The One and Two and Three who ever liveth,
29  And reigneth ever in Three and Two and One,
30  Not circumscribed and all things circumscribing,

28  Quell' uno e due e tre che sempre vive
29  e regna sempre in tre e 'n due e 'n uno,
30  non circunscritto, e tutto circunscrive,

31  Three several times was chanted by each one
32  Among those spirits, with such melody
33  That for all merit it were just reward;

31  tre volte era cantato da ciascuno
32  di quelli spiriti con tal melodia,
33  ch'ad ogne merto saria giusto muno.

34  And, in the lustre most divine of all
35  The lesser ring, I heard a modest voice,
36  Such as perhaps the Angel's was to Mary,

34  E io udi' ne la luce più dia
35  del minor cerchio una voce modesta,
36  forse qual fu da l'angelo a Maria,

37  Answer: "As long as the festivity
38  Of Paradise shall be, so long our love
39  Shall radiate round about us such a vesture.

37  risponder: “Quanto fia lunga la festa
38  di paradiso, tanto il nostro amore
39  si raggerà dintorno cotal vesta.

40  Its brightness is proportioned to the ardour,
41  The ardour to the vision; and the vision
42  Equals what grace it has above its worth.

40  La sua chiarezza séguita l'ardore;
41  l'ardor la visïone, e quella è tanta,
42  quant' ha di grazia sovra suo valore.

43  When, glorious and sanctified, our flesh
44  Is reassumed, then shall our persons be
45  More pleasing by their being all complete;

43  Come la carne glorïosa e santa
44  fia rivestita, la nostra persona
45  più grata fia per esser tutta quanta;

46  For will increase whate'er bestows on us
47  Of light gratuitous the Good Supreme,
48  Light which enables us to look on Him;

46  per che s'accrescerà ciò che ne dona
47  di gratüito lume il sommo bene,
48  lume ch'a lui veder ne condiziona;

49  Therefore the vision must perforce increase,
50  Increase the ardour which from that is kindled,
51  Increase the radiance which from this proceeds.

49  onde la visïon crescer convene,
50  crescer l'ardor che di quella s'accende,
51  crescer lo raggio che da esso vene.

52  But even as a coal that sends forth flame,
53  And by its vivid whiteness overpowers it
54  So that its own appearance it maintains,

52  Ma sì come carbon che fiamma rende,
53  e per vivo candor quella soverchia,
54  sì che la sua parvenza si difende;

55  Thus the effulgence that surrounds us now
56  Shall be o'erpowered in aspect by the flesh,
57  Which still to-day the earth doth cover up;

55  così questo folgór che già ne cerchia
56  fia vinto in apparenza da la carne
57  che tutto dì la terra ricoperchia;

58  Nor can so great a splendour weary us,
59  For strong will be the organs of the body
60  To everything which hath the power to please us."

58  né potrà tanta luce affaticarne:
59  ché li organi del corpo saran forti
60  a tutto ciò che potrà dilettarne.”

61  So sudden and alert appeared to me
62  Both one and the other choir to say Amen,
63  That well they showed desire for their dead bodies;

61  Tanto mi parver sùbiti e accorti
62  e l'uno e l'altro coro a dicer “Amme!”
63  che ben mostrar disio d'i corpi morti:

64  Nor sole for them perhaps, but for the mothers,
65  The fathers, and the rest who had been dear
66  Or ever they became eternal flames.

64  forse non pur per lor, ma per le mamme,
65  per li padri e per li altri che fuor cari
66  anzi che fosser sempiterne fiamme.

67  And lo! all round about of equal brightness
68  Arose a lustre over what was there,
69  Like an horizon that is clearing up.

67  Ed ecco intorno, di chiarezza pari,
68  nascere un lustro sopra quel che v'era,
69  per guisa d'orizzonte che rischiari.

70  And as at rise of early eve begin
71  Along the welkin new appearances,
72  So that the sight seems real and unreal,

70  E sì come al salir di prima sera
71  comincian per lo ciel nove parvenze,
72  sì che la vista pare e non par vera,

73  It seemed to me that new subsistences
74  Began there to be seen, and make a circle
75  Outside the other two circumferences.

73  parvemi lì novelle sussistenze
74  cominciare a vedere, e fare un giro
75  di fuor da l'altre due circunferenze.

76  O very sparkling of the Holy Spirit,
77  How sudden and incandescent it became
78  Unto mine eyes, that vanquished bore it not!

76  Oh vero sfavillar del Santo Spiro!
77  come si fece sùbito e candente
78  a li occhi miei che, vinti, nol soffriro!

79  But Beatrice so beautiful and smiling
80  Appeared to me, that with the other sights
81  That followed not my memory I must leave her.

79  Ma Bëatrice sì bella e ridente
80  mi si mostrò, che tra quelle vedute
81  si vuol lasciar che non seguir la mente.

82  Then to uplift themselves mine eyes resumed
83  The power, and I beheld myself translated
84  To higher salvation with my Lady only.

82  Quindi ripreser li occhi miei virtute
83  a rilevarsi; e vidimi translato
84  sol con mia donna in più alta salute.

85  Well was I ware that I was more uplifted
86  By the enkindled smiling of the star,
87  That seemed to me more ruddy than its wont.

85  Ben m'accors' io ch'io era più levato,
86  per l'affocato riso de la stella,
87  che mi parea più roggio che l'usato.

88  With all my heart, and in that dialect
89  Which is the same in all, such holocaust
90  To God I made as the new grace beseemed;

88  Con tutto 'l core e con quella favella
89  ch'è una in tutti, a Dio feci olocausto,
90  qual conveniesi a la grazia novella.

91  And not yet from my bosom was exhausted
92  The ardour of sacrifice, before I knew
93  This offering was accepted and auspicious;

91  E non er' anco del mio petto essausto
92  l'ardor del sacrificio, ch'io conobbi
93  esso litare stato accetto e fausto;

94  For with so great a lustre and so red
95  Splendours appeared to me in twofold rays,
96  I said: "O Helios who dost so adorn them!"

94  ché con tanto lucore e tanto robbi
95  m'apparvero splendor dentro a due raggi,
96  ch'io dissi: “O Elïòs che sì li addobbi!”

97  Even as distinct with less and greater lights
98  Glimmers between the two poles of the world
99  The Galaxy that maketh wise men doubt,

97  Come distinta da minori e maggi
98  lumi biancheggia tra ' poli del mondo
99  Galassia sì, che fa dubbiar ben saggi;

100  Thus constellated in the depths of Mars,
101  Those rays described the venerable sign
102  That quadrants joining in a circle make.

100  sì costellati facean nel profondo
101  Marte quei raggi il venerabil segno
102  che fan giunture di quadranti in tondo.

103  Here doth my memory overcome my genius;
104  For on that cross as levin gleamed forth Christ,
105  So that I cannot find ensample worthy;


103  Qui vince la memoria mia lo 'ngegno;
104  ché quella croce lampeggiava Cristo,
105  sì ch'io non so trovare essempro degno;

106  But he who takes his cross and follows Christ
107  Again will pardon me what I omit,
108  Seeing in that aurora lighten Christ.

106  ma chi prende sua croce e segue Cristo,
107  ancor mi scuserà di quel ch'io lasso,
108  vedendo in quell' albor balenar Cristo.

109  From horn to horn, and 'twixt the top and base,
110  Lights were in motion, brightly scintillating
111  As they together met and passed each other;

109  Di corno in corno e tra la cima e 'l basso
110  si movien lumi, scintillando forte
111  nel congiugnersi insieme e nel trapasso:

112  Thus level and aslant and swift and slow
113  We here behold, renewing still the sight,
114  The particles of bodies long and short,

112  così si veggion qui diritte e torte,
113  veloci e tarde, rinovando vista,
114  le minuzie d'i corpi, lunghe e corte,

115  Across the sunbeam move, wherewith is listed
116  Sometimes the shade, which for their own defence
117  People with cunning and with art contrive.

115  moversi per lo raggio onde si lista
116  talvolta l'ombra che, per sua difesa,
117  la gente con ingegno e arte acquista.

118  And as a lute and harp, accordant strung
119  With many strings, a dulcet tinkling make
120  To him by whom the notes are not distinguished,

118  E come giga e arpa, in tempra tesa
119  di molte corde, fa dolce tintinno
120  a tal da cui la nota non è intesa,

121  So from the lights that there to me appeared
122  Upgathered through the cross a melody,
123  Which rapt me, not distinguishing the hymn.

121  così da' lumi che lì m'apparinno
122  s'accogliea per la croce una melode
123  che mi rapiva, sanza intender l'inno.

124  Well was I ware it was of lofty laud,
125  Because there came to me, "Arise and conquer!"
126  As unto him who hears and comprehends not.

124  Ben m'accors' io ch'elli era d'alte lode,
125  però ch'a me venìa “Resurgi” e “Vinci”
126  come a colui che non intende e ode.

127  So much enamoured I became therewith,
128  That until then there was not anything
129  That e'er had fettered me with such sweet bonds.

127  Ïo m'innamorava tanto quinci,
128  che 'nfino a lì non fu alcuna cosa
129  che mi legasse con sì dolci vinci.
 
130  Perhaps my word appears somewhat too bold,
131  Postponing the delight of those fair eyes,
132  Into which gazing my desire has rest;

130  Forse la mia parola par troppo osa,
139  posponendo il piacer de li occhi belli,
140  ne' quai mirando mio disio ha posa;

133  But who bethinks him that the living seals
134  Of every beauty grow in power ascending,
135  And that I there had not turned round to those,

133  ma chi s'avvede che i vivi suggelli
134  d'ogne bellezza più fanno più suso,
135  e ch'io non m'era lì rivolto a quelli,

136  Can me excuse, if I myself accuse
137  To excuse myself, and see that I speak truly:
138  For here the holy joy is not disclosed,

136  escusar puommi di quel ch'io m'accuso
137  per escusarmi, e vedermi dir vero:
138  ché 'l piacer santo non è qui dischiuso,

139  Because ascending it becomes more pure.

139  perché si fa, montando, più sincero.

Canto XV
The heaven of Earth's temporal life is simple day-to-day peaceful domesticity, and which of us would not prefer this to the endless golden and neon spectacles of Heaven?  Mark Twain in his work "Extract from Captain Stormfield's Visit to Heaven" has a good deal of fun parodying the conventional views of heaven, and these chiefly fall into category of a such a stultifying boredom that it would have gratified Schopenhauer's most exalted pessimism, except for the fact that suicide could not provide the relief of an escape hatch.  We could not bear to spend a single afternoon in such a Heaven, let alone an eternity.  And if we look back on the cantos of the Paradiso and the last ones of the Purgatorio, they all seem to carry a sort of patina of perpetual holiday, quite entertaining, and quite enthralling to be sure, but would we want to spend all of our energies parading about with palm branches, or whirling about singing and dancing?  Dante, in the previous Canto, surely realized this, since he goes to some pains to say that the bodies that we now have, will be, and must be changed, because they are not equipped to endure such celebratory pleasures.  One wonders, if God, and God's redeemed, are so different, so fitted to these Heavenly aesthetic exaltations, why then did the Supreme Creator bother to make Earth and its flawed and suffering denizens at all?  Something is missing.  And what's missing is this: All the pleasures and placid pasttimes of simple conversation, simple domestic tasks, simple familial warmth and affection, the dawdling and tinkering and general geneality of doing what is practical and useful, but is so routine, that our minds are allowed the delight of simple reverie.  And what's missing also are all of the idle moments too, where reverie finds a home in doing nothing.  Heretofor, none of these things exist in Dante's Paradise, or for that matter, in most theologically imagined Paradises. This canto aims in some way to correct that almost totally embittered view that Dante had of his Earthly sojourn, his true Christain vision of a fallen Creation.  And it is characteristic of him that he places his correction out of reach, in this case, in his Earthly past, in some Viconian Golden Age, in the realm of the ancestors.  There is a resurrection here, but it is not the resurrection of the Entelechy's last trump, but one of naming, of giving renown by naming, of reifying his own metaphysical and physical inheiretance, and showing us that we, the living, should consider ouselves as the possible fulfillment of the hopes and dreams of our forbears and as the fruitful seeds of our descendents, and that our living, mortal breath, is the growing tip of all of the past's and the future's aspirations.  The image presented here is extraordinarily conservative.  Here the grandfathers and grandmothers are stripped of the vanity and ambition which has so infected and damned the present, and they are allowed the purity which only a loving nostalgia can provide.  And as an added bonus, Cacciaguida tells Dante that his status as a poet, his work on the present poem, has justified the ancestors' own lives on Earth.  Dante, the poet, through a kind of mind-meld with his ancestor, comes to understand that the virtues of his work, are the virtues of his ancestors, brought to fruition by their mutual merging with God.  There is an almost animalistic innocence and return to native naivite here, the husband dressed in skins, the distaff wives weaving the tapestries of mundane time.  It is a place of everyday pleasures, where couples are more than placated for their domestic labors by sharing their rest at night, and by knowing for certain that they will share their home in earth when they are buried ... but ... and this is the big caveat: We must remember that we are in the heaven of Mars, when Cacciaguida leaves this domestic peace to enter the political fray on behalf of the Emporer Conrad, a second Fall and expulsion from the Garden ensues.  And with this second fall, a second redemption must follow to expunge it: Namely: the martyrdom of Cacciaguida, which is the cause of his salvation and of his present joy.  Somehow, in a way, that I confess, I do not quite understand, that domestic bliss was not sufficient, another sacrifice seems to have been required, a sacrifice of death, of defeat, of the loneliness of widows, and of the orphaning of children, a descent into suffering and injustice, which our ordinary pleasures could neither prevent, nor once experienced, heal.  Because, even after living this domestic bliss, and praising it so extravagantly, Cacciaguida, in the last verses of this Canto calls this the "mondo fallace," the "deceitful world."  Here, as also in Eastern religions, this world, even at its most attractive, is an illusion, is Maya.  Clearly to set right this deceit, to see through this illusion even in, and perhaps most particularly in, its most comfortable aspects, something extraordinary must come into play — something like the martyrdom of Cacciaguida, the crucifixion of Jesus, the exile of Dante, or something like the writing of this extraordinary poem with its Paradise of spectacular happenings.

1  A will benign, in which reveals itself
2  Ever the love that righteously inspires,
3  As in the iniquitous, cupidity,

1  Benigna volontade in che si liqua
2  sempre l'amor che drittamente spira,
3 come cupidità fa ne la iniqua,

4  Silence imposed upon that dulcet lyre,
5  And quieted the consecrated chords,
6  That Heaven's right hand doth tighten and relax.

4  silenzio puose a quella dolce lira,
5 e fece quïetar le sante corde
6 che la destra del cielo allenta e tira.

7  How unto just entreaties shall be deaf
8  Those substances, which, to give me desire
9  Of praying them, with one accord grew silent?

7  Come saranno a' giusti preghi sorde
8  quelle sustanze che, per darmi voglia
9  ch'io le pregassi, a tacer fur concorde?

10  'Tis well that without end he should lament,
11  Who for the love of thing that doth not last
12  Eternally despoils him of that love!

10  Bene è che sanza termine si doglia
11  chi, per amor di cosa che non duri
12  etternalmente, quello amor si spoglia.

13  As through the pure and tranquil evening air
14  There shoots from time to time a sudden fire,
15  Moving the eyes that steadfast were before,

13  Quale per li seren tranquilli e puri
14  discorre ad ora ad or sùbito foco,
15  movendo li occhi che stavan sicuri,

16  And seems to be a star that changeth place,
17  Except that in the part where it is kindled
18  Nothing is missed, and this endureth little;

16  e pare stella che tramuti loco,
17  se non che da la parte ond' e' s'accende
18  nulla sen perde, ed esso dura poco:

19  So from the horn that to the right extends
20  Unto that cross's foot there ran a star
21  Out of the constellation shining there;

19  tale dal corno che 'n destro si stende
20  a piè di quella croce corse un astro
21  de la costellazion che lì resplende;

22  Nor was the gem dissevered from its ribbon,
23  But down the radiant fillet ran along,
24  So that fire seemed it behind alabaster.

22  né si partì la gemma dal suo nastro,
23  ma per la lista radïal trascorse,
24  che parve foco dietro ad alabastro.

25  Thus piteous did Anchises' shade reach forward,
26  If any faith our greatest Muse deserve,
27  When in Elysium he his son perceived.

25  Sì pïa l'ombra d'Anchise si porse,
26  se fede merta nostra maggior musa,
27  quando in Eliso del figlio s'accorse.

28  "O sanguis meus, O superinfusa
29  Gratia Dei, sicut tibi, cui
30  Bis unquam Coeli janua reclusa?"

28  “O sanguis meus, O superinfusa
29  gratïa Deï, sicut tibi cui
30  bis unquam celi ianüa reclusa?”

31  Thus that effulgence; whence I gave it heed;
32  Then round unto my Lady turned my sight,
33  And on this side and that was stupefied;

31  Così quel lume: ond' io m'attesi a lui;
32  poscia rivolsi a la mia donna il viso,
33  e quinci e quindi stupefatto fui;

34  For in her eyes was burning such a smile
35  That with mine own methought I touched the bottom
36  Both of my grace and of my Paradise!

34  ché dentro a li occhi suoi ardeva un riso
35  tal, ch'io pensai co' miei toccar lo fondo
36  de la mia gloria e del mio paradiso.

37  Then, pleasant to the hearing and the sight,
38  The spirit joined to its beginning things
39  I understood not, so profound it spake;

37  Indi, a udire e a veder giocondo,
38  giunse lo spirto al suo principio cose,
39  ch'io non lo 'ntesi, sì parlò profondo;

40  Nor did it hide itself from me by choice,
41  But by necessity; for its conception
42  Above the mark of mortals set itself.

40  né per elezïon mi si nascose,
41  ma per necessità, ché 'l suo concetto
42  al segno d'i mortal si soprapuose.

43  And when the bow of burning sympathy
44  Was so far slackened, that its speech descended
45  Towards the mark of our intelligence,

43  E quando l'arco de l'ardente affetto
44  fu sì sfogato, che 'l parlar discese
45  inver' lo segno del nostro intelletto,

46  The first thing that was understood by me
47  Was "Benedight be Thou, O Trine and One,
48  Who hast unto my seed so courteous been!"

46  la prima cosa che per me s'intese,
47  “Benedetto sia tu,” fu, “trino e uno,
48  che nel mio seme se' tanto cortese!”

49  And it continued: "Hunger long and grateful,
50  Drawn from the reading of the mighty volume
51  Wherein is never changed the white nor dark,

49  E seguì: “Grato e lontano digiuno,
50  tratto leggendo del magno volume
51  du' non si muta mai bianco né bruno,

52  Thou hast appeased, my son, within this light
53  In which I speak to thee, by grace of her
54  Who to this lofty flight with plumage clothed thee.

52  solvuto hai, figlio, dentro a questo lume
53  in ch'io ti parlo, mercé di colei
54  ch'a l'alto volo ti vestì le piume.

55  Thou thinkest that to me thy thought doth pass
56  From Him who is the first, as from the unit,
57  If that be known, ray out the five and six;

55  Tu credi che a me tuo pensier mei
56  da quel ch'è primo, così come raia
57  da l'un, se si conosce, il cinque e 'l sei;

58  And therefore who I am thou askest not,
59  And why I seem more joyous unto thee
60  Than any other of this gladsome crowd.

58  e però ch'io mi sia e perch' io paia
59  più gaudïoso a te, non mi domandi,
60  che alcun altro in questa turba gaia.

61  Thou think'st the truth; because the small and great
62  Of this existence look into the mirror
63  Wherein, before thou think'st, thy thought thou showest.

61  Tu credi 'l vero; ché i minori e ' grandi
62  di questa vita miran ne lo speglio
63  in che, prima che pensi, il pensier pandi;

64  But that the sacred love, in which I watch
65  With sight perpetual, and which makes me thirst
66  With sweet desire, may better be fulfilled,

64  ma perché 'l sacro amore in che io veglio
65  con perpetüa vista e che m'asseta
66  di dolce disïar, s'adempia meglio,

67  Now let thy voice secure and frank and glad
68  Proclaim the wishes, the desire proclaim,
69  To which my answer is decreed already."

67  la voce tua sicura, balda e lieta
68  suoni la volontà, suoni 'l disio,
69  a che la mia risposta è già decreta!”

70  To Beatrice I turned me, and she heard
71  Before I spake, and smiled to me a sign,
72  That made the wings of my desire increase;

70  Io mi volsi a Beatrice, e quella udio
71  pria ch'io parlassi, e arrisemi un cenno
72  che fece crescer l'ali al voler mio.

73  Then in this wise began I: "Love and knowledge,
74  When on you dawned the first Equality,
75  Of the same weight for each of you became;

73  Poi cominciai così: “L'affetto e 'l senno,
74  come la prima equalità v'apparse,
75  d'un peso per ciascun di voi si fenno,

76  For in the Sun, which lighted you and burned
77  With heat and radiance, they so equal are,
78  That all similitudes are insufficient.

76  però che 'l sol che v'allumò e arse,
77  col caldo e con la luce è sì iguali,
78  che tutte simiglianze sono scarse.

79  But among mortals will and argument,
80  For reason that to you is manifest,
81  Diversely feathered in their pinions are.

79  Ma voglia e argomento ne' mortali,
80  per la cagion ch'a voi è manifesta,
81  diversamente son pennuti in ali;

82  Whence I, who mortal am, feel in myself
83  This inequality; so give not thanks,
84  Save in my heart, for this paternal welcome.

82  ond' io, che son mortal, mi sento in questa
83  disagguaglianza, e però non ringrazio
84  se non col core a la paterna festa.

85  Truly do I entreat thee, living topaz!
86  Set in this precious jewel as a gem,
87  That thou wilt satisfy me with thy name."

85  Ben supplico io a te, vivo topazio
86  che questa gioia prezïosa ingemmi,
87  perché mi facci del tuo nome sazio.”

88  "O leaf of mine, in whom I pleasure took
89  E'en while awaiting, I was thine own root!"
90  Such a beginning he in answer made me.

88  “O fronda mia in che io compiacemmi
89  pur aspettando, io fui la tua radice”:
90  cotal principio, rispondendo, femmi.

91  Then said to me: "That one from whom is named
92  Thy race, and who a hundred years and more
93  Has circled round the mount on the first cornice,

91  Poscia mi disse: “Quel da cui si dice
92  tua cognazione e che cent' anni e piùe
93  girato ha 'l monte in la prima cornice,

94  A son of mine and thy great-grandsire was;
95  Well it behoves thee that the long fatigue
96  Thou shouldst for him make shorter with thy works.

94  mio figlio fu e tuo bisavol fue:
95  ben si convien che la lunga fatica
96  tu li raccorci con l'opere tue.

97  Florence, within the ancient boundary
98  From which she taketh still her tierce and nones,
99  Abode in quiet, temperate and chaste.

97  Fiorenza dentro da la cerchia antica,
98  ond' ella toglie ancora e terza e nona,
99  si stava in pace, sobria e pudica.

100  No golden chain she had, nor coronal,
101  Nor ladies shod with sandal shoon, nor girdle
102  That caught the eye more than the person did.

100  Non avea catenella, non corona,
101  non gonne contigiate, non cintura
102  che fosse a veder più che la persona.

103  Not yet the daughter at her birth struck fear
104  Into the father, for the time and dower
105  Did not o'errun this side or that the measure.

103  Non faceva, nascendo, ancor paura
104  la figlia al padre, ché 'l tempo e la dote
105  non fuggien quinci e quindi la misura.

106  No houses had she void of families,
107  Not yet had thither come Sardanapalus
108  To show what in a chamber can be done;

106  Non avea case di famiglia vòte;
107  non v'era giunto ancor Sardanapalo
108  a mostrar ciò che 'n camera si puote.

109  Not yet surpassed had Montemalo been
110  By your Uccellatojo, which surpassed
111  Shall in its downfall be as in its rise.

109  Non era vinto ancora Montemalo
110  dal vostro Uccellatoio, che, com'è vinto
111  nel montar sù, così sarà nel calo.

112  Bellincion Berti saw I go begirt
113  With leather and with bone, and from the mirror
114  His dame depart without a painted face;

112  Bellincion Berti vid' io andar cinto
113  di cuoio e d'osso, e venir da lo specchio
114  la donna sua sanza 'l viso dipinto;

115  And him of Nerli saw, and him of Vecchio,
116  Contented with their simple suits of buff
117  And with the spindle and the flax their dames.

115  e vidi quel d'i Nerli e quel del Vecchio
116  esser contenti a la pelle scoperta,
117  e le sue donne al fuso e al pennecchio.

118  O fortunate women! and each one was certain
119  Of her own burial-place, and none as yet
120  For sake of France was in her bed deserted.

118  Oh fortunate! ciascuna era certa
119  de la sua sepultura, e ancor nulla
120  era per Francia nel letto diserta.

121  One o'er the cradle kept her studious watch,
122  And in her lullaby the language used
123  That first delights the fathers and the mothers;

121  L'una vegghiava a studio de la culla,
122  e, consolando, usava l'idïoma
123  che prima i padri e le madri trastulla;

124  Another, drawing tresses from her distaff,
125  Told o'er among her family the tales
126  Of Trojans and of Fesole and Rome.

124  l'altra, traendo a la rocca la chioma,
125  favoleggiava con la sua famiglia
126  d'i Troiani, di Fiesole e di Roma.

127  As great a marvel then would have been held
128  A Lapo Salterello, a Cianghella,
129  As Cincinnatus or Cornelia now.

127  Saria tenuta allor tal maraviglia
128  una Cianghella, un Lapo Salterello,
129  qual or saria Cincinnato e Corniglia.

130  To such a quiet, such a beautiful
131  Life of the citizen, to such a safe
132  Community, and to so sweet an inn,

130  A così riposato, a così bello
131  viver di cittadini, a così fida
132  cittadinanza, a così dolce ostello,

133  Did Mary give me, with loud cries invoked,
134  And in your ancient Baptistery at once
135  Christian and Cacciaguida I became.

133  Maria mi diè, chiamata in alte grida;
134  e ne l'antico vostro Batisteo
135  insieme fui cristiano e Cacciaguida.

136  Moronto was my brother, and Eliseo;
137  From Val di Pado came to me my wife,
138  And from that place thy surname was derived.

136  Moronto fu mio frate ed Eliseo;
137  mia donna venne a me di val di Pado,
138  e quindi il sopranome tuo si feo.

139  I followed afterward the Emperor Conrad,
140  And he begirt me of his chivalry,
141  So much I pleased him with my noble deeds.

139  Poi seguitai lo 'mperador Currado;
140  ed el mi cinse de la sua milizia,
141  tanto per bene ovrar li venni in grado.

142  I followed in his train against that law's
143  Iniquity, whose people doth usurp
144  Your just possession, through your Pastor's fault.

142  Dietro li andai incontro a la nequizia
143  di quella legge il cui popolo usurpa,
144  per colpa d'i pastor, vostra giustizia.

145  There by that execrable race was I
146  Released from bonds of the fallacious world,
147  The love of which defileth many souls,

145  Quivi fu' io da quella gente turpa
146  disviluppato dal mondo fallace,
147  lo cui amor molt'anime deturpa;

148  And came from martyrdom unto this peace."

148  e venni dal martiro a questa pace.”

Canto XVI
(Some of my marginalia on an essay by E. van Alphen, entitled "Symptoms of Discursivity: Experience, Memory, and Trauma" in the book Acts of Memory: Cultural Recall in the Present, editors Mieke Bal, Jonathan Crewe, and Leo Spitzer.)

The past can only be found in the province of language, and not in the so-called "subjective experience" of historical individuals, reduced by their temporality to illusory ephemera.

Failed experience, or trauma, exceeds the boundaries of what can be perceived, represented, or remembered.  It is  the cesura, the gap, the vacuole — that gravity well in which everything about the past that was inexpressible in the discourse of that time becomes mythologized in the present as a "factual" memory.

"Reality is a rather discontinuous chaos (E. van Alphen)."  This is not a statement about reality.  It is the declaration of a trauma victim.  The nature of time may be quantum, and not a narrative at all.  Hence, our attempts to make a narrative, from what may well be packets of coiled simultaneities, presuppose failure and trauma.  All stories are therefore fiction, and all fictions are based upon a temporal/spatial dissociation from the ever-present-ever absent HERE.

What is the self?  Essentially it is not something, at least according to Dante's worldview, confined to a "skin-encapsulated ego,(Alan Watt's coinage)" but is something spread out in time, through a river of ancestors and descendants, both physical and metaphysical, and as we go further back in time, a curious alchemy takes place.  Historicity becomes legend, and in times of present trouble, and for an exile and a nomad like Dante, the present is all wrong, and quintessentially a time of trouble, the self is like a river (his metaphor, for the Commedia thrives on the essential metaphors of water and fire) which has been polluted as it flowed from its purer source.  By what means polluted?  By an admixture of elements not proper to its nature.  If you are 20 years old, in a progressive country like America, the past is anathema, a burden, and a constant source of restraint.  But when you are seventy, the past is such a checkerboard of trauma, that one constantly resorts to apply the Midas touch of Nostalgia to polish, clean, selectively remember and selectively forget, the past, so that the further back one goes, the more golden it becomes, just as when one follows a river from its turbid, turgid mouth, back to its original high-country spring, the purer it becomes.  For Dante that essential past purity, and golden glory is the Roman Empire, specifically the legend of Pax Romana, and the music of Cacciaguida's litany of names (and it is very musical in Tuscan Italian, even though the sound of the names which mean nothing to us are hollow sounds), has a golden quality — glorious — is Dante's word, as in the glorioles of halos.  We who have lived in the last century of art movements such as abstract expressionism or minimalism should not be shocked by the severe abstraction and minimalistic character of this canto.  In Hell and in Purgatory, specific, historical details are fleshed out, and they are always in the Nature of a fall, a trauma, something has gone wrong, and it is God's business, and the poet's, to trace that flow of blood back to the wound, and cauterize it.  Blood here, in this context, means bloodlines, the genetic river that flows through each separate life and unites it to life as a whole, and not just contemporary life, but life through all times.  

In another sense however, Cacciaguida’s, who in Paradise, takes immense joy in his discovery of what went wrong, is talking about an historical process, and doing his darnedest to identify the sources of corruption for what was originally, in the shine of nostalgia, glorious, pure, and peaceful.  His diagnosis of the pathogen?  Miscegenation, the intermingling of peoples.  Our modern sensibilities are shocked by this conservatism, and yet we can hardly fail to notice how Cacciaguida's history so resembles our own — the movement of rural peoples to the cities, and the transformation of cities from feudal networks of homogeneous people with the same customs, traditions, language (and Dante points out that the language of the past, for those of us in the present, is a foreign language) to a place of commerce, mercantilism, a place where naked economics rule, where the moral codebook is not a bible but a ledger of profit and loss, and in this commerce world, the old ideals of family, blood-lines, moral or feudal obligations and reciprocities are meaningless.  A couple of centuries later the Medici's moral code prevails: "Money to get power.  Power to get Money."  In this view, temporality itself, as well as history, becomes the trauma of which Wordsworth says: "Getting and spending we lay waste our powers."  Blake speaks of Satanic Mills.  And Eliot calls it "The unreal city."  In a sense, Plato was right, but for the wrong reasons, when he said that history has no place for a poet, and Dante, in Paradise, while reviewing history from an atemporal elevation beyond and above it, tells us in his circular way that starting from the desultory comment of the first verses of this canto, to the bitter verses which conclude it, that history must become legend for the soul, that the soul desires the musical litanies of glorious names, but not the grubby futilities and vain aspirations of the actual people who lived within the ever-shrinking, every-patched cloak of that skin of names and those hollow blazons of their heraldries.  For the poet, especially the Christian poet, history must be transformed into legend, and as in Vico's past, that legendary language was the language of gods and heroes, Giant Forms, to use Blake's term, whose speech glorified and made golden what were no doubt the same violent and petty deeds of the forbears so prevalent in the present, and so destined to be prevalent in the future.  Greek myth makes this clear.  The God's are people with unrestrained appetites, still chock-full, like children, of unrestrained libidinous powers.  And Dante makes it clear that he knows this, which is why through the whole of the Commedia, myth and the Bible are the two opposing visions whose binocularity deepens our view of reality.  Christianity is historical, not mythical, and yet its history is emblematic and archetypal.  And just as the protagonist Dante is wending his way from his chaotic life at the start of the poem, to rediscover his pure source in Beatrice, and to finally ascend through Paradise to a history-ending apotheosis, Dante's soul has a temporal shape, just as does his poem: a beginning, middle, and end, and that's why a canto like this has to be not only recounted, absent almost all of its trauma and tragedy, but recounted joyfully, because it reminds us of the shape of the soul as this journey.  

The question of ancestry, the meaning of the present (good or bad), and the destiny of our descendants in the future are always going to entail a sudden exhilaration of the individual ego as it escapes its single skin-encapsulation and realizes that the self extends through the whole domain of Time.  But along with this exhilaration, there is also this irrepressible trauma that comes as the self realizes that Time itself is the source of its trauma, and that the ego's only salvation is an escape from the wheel of traumas and retributions into an eternal world, to what I would say, is a poetic, aesthetic world, where even harsh judgements and litanies of the dead are resurrected by the music of the redeeming Word.

1  O thou our poor nobility of blood,
2  If thou dost make the people glory in thee
3  Down here where our affection languishes,

1  O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue,
2  se glorïar di te la gente fai
3  qua giù dove l'affetto nostro langue,

4  A marvellous thing it ne'er will be to me;
5  For there where appetite is not perverted,
6  I say in Heaven, of thee I made a boast!

4  mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai:
5  ché là dove appetito non si torce,
6  dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.

7  Truly thou art a cloak that quickly shortens,
8  So that unless we piece thee day by day
9  Time goeth round about thee with his shears!

7  Ben se' tu manto che tosto raccorce:
8  sì che, se non s'appon di dì in die,
9  lo tempo va dintorno con le force.

10  With 'You,' which Rome was first to tolerate,
11  (Wherein her family less perseveres,)
12  Yet once again my words beginning made;

10  Dal “voi” che prima a Roma s'offerie,
11  in che la sua famiglia men persevra,
12  ricominciaron le parole mie;

13  Whence Beatrice, who stood somewhat apart,
14  Smiling, appeared like unto her who coughed
15  At the first failing writ of Guenever.

13  onde Beatrice, ch'era un poco scevra,
14  ridendo, parve quella che tossio
15  al primo fallo scritto di Ginevra.

16  And I began: "You are my ancestor,
17  You give to me all hardihood to speak,
18  You lift me so that I am more than I.

16  Io cominciai: “Voi siete il padre mio;
17  voi mi date a parlar tutta baldezza;
18  voi mi levate sì, ch'i' son più ch'io.

19  So many rivulets with gladness fill
20  My mind, that of itself it makes a joy
21  Because it can endure this and not burst.

19  Per tanti rivi s'empie d'allegrezza
20  la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia
21  perché può sostener che non si spezza.

22  Then tell me, my beloved root ancestral,
23  Who were your ancestors, and what the years
24  That in your boyhood chronicled themselves?

22  Ditemi dunque, cara mia primizia,
23  quai fuor li vostri antichi e quai fuor li anni
24  che si segnaro in vostra püerizia;

25  Tell me about the sheepfold of Saint John,
26  How large it was, and who the people were
27  Within it worthy of the highest seats."

25  ditemi de l'ovil di San Giovanni
26  quanto era allora, e chi eran le genti
27  tra esso degne di più alti scanni.”

28  As at the blowing of the winds a coal
29  Quickens to flame, so I beheld that light
30  Become resplendent at my blandishments.

28  Come s'avviva a lo spirar d'i venti
29  carbone in fiamma, così vid' io quella
30  luce risplendere a' miei blandimenti;

31  And as unto mine eyes it grew more fair,
32  With voice more sweet and tender, but not in
33  This modern dialect, it said to me:

31  e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella,
32  così con voce più dolce e soave,
33  ma non con questa moderna favella,

34  "From uttering of the 'Ave,' till the birth
35  In which my mother, who is now a saint,
36  Of me was lightened who had been her burden,

34  dissemi: “Da quel dì che fu detto 'Ave'
35  al parto in che mia madre, ch'è or santa,
36  s'allevïò di me ond' era grave,

37  Unto its Lion had this fire returned
38  Five hundred fifty times and thirty more,
39  To reinflame itself beneath his paw.

37  al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta
38  e trenta fiate venne questo foco
39  a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.

40  My ancestors and I our birthplace had
41  Where first is found the last ward of the city
42  By him who runneth in your annual game.

40  Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco
41  dove si truova pria l'ultimo sesto
42  da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.

43  Suffice it of my elders to hear this;
44  But who they were, and whence they thither came,
45  Silence is more considerate than speech.

43  Basti d'i miei maggiori udirne questo:
44  chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi,
45  più è tacer che ragionare onesto.

46  All those who at that time were there between
47  Mars and the Baptist, fit for bearing arms,
48  Were a fifth part of those who now are living;

46  Tutti color ch'a quel tempo eran ivi
47  da poter arme tra Marte e 'l Batista,
48  erano il quinto di quei ch'or son vivi.

49  But the community, that now is mixed
50  With Campi and Certaldo and Figghine,
51  Pure in the lowest artisan was seen.

49  Ma la cittadinanza, ch'è or mista
50  di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine,
51  pura vediesi ne l'ultimo artista.

52  O how much better 'twere to have as neighbours
53  The folk of whom I speak, and at Galluzzo
54  And at Trespiano have your boundary,

52  Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine
53  quelle genti ch'io dico, e al Galluzzo
54  e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,

55  Than have them in the town, and bear the stench
56  Of Aguglione's churl, and him of Signa
57  Who has sharp eyes for trickery already.

55  che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo
56  del villan d'Aguglion, di quel da Signa,
57  che già per barattare ha l'occhio aguzzo!

58  Had not the folk, which most of all the world
59  Degenerates, been a step-dame unto Caesar,
60  But as a mother to her son benignant,

58  Se la gente ch'al mondo più traligna
59  non fosse stata a Cesare noverca,
60  ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,

61  Some who turn Florentines, and trade and discount,
62  Would have gone back again to Simifonte
63  There where their grandsires went about as beggars.

61  tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca,
62  che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti,
63  là dove andava l'avolo a la cerca;

64  At Montemurlo still would be the Counts,
65  The Cerchi in the parish of Acone,
66  Perhaps in Valdigrieve the Buondelmonti.

64  sariesi Montemurlo ancor de' Conti;
65  sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d'Acone,
66  e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.

67  Ever the intermingling of the people
68  Has been the source of malady in cities,
69  As in the body food it surfeits on;

67  Sempre la confusion de le persone
68  principio fu del mal de la cittade,
69  come del vostro il cibo che s'appone;

70  And a blind bull more headlong plunges down
71  Than a blind lamb; and very often cuts
72  Better and more a single sword than five.

70  e cieco toro più avaccio cade
71  che cieco agnello; e molte volte taglia
72  più e meglio una che le cinque spade.

73  If Luni thou regard, and Urbisaglia,
74  How they have passed away, and how are passing
75  Chiusi and Sinigaglia after them,

73  Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia
74  come sono ite, e come se ne vanno
75  di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,

76  To hear how races waste themselves away,
77  Will seem to thee no novel thing nor hard,
78  Seeing that even cities have an end.

76  udir come le schiatte si disfanno
77  non ti parrà nova cosa né forte,
78  poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.

79  All things of yours have their mortality,
80  Even as yourselves; but it is hidden in some
81  That a long while endure, and lives are short;

79  Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte,
80  sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna
81  che dura molto, e le vite son corte.

82  And as the turning of the lunar heaven
83  Covers and bares the shores without a pause,
84  In the like manner fortune does with Florence.

82  E come 'l volger del ciel de la luna
83  cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa,
84  così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:

85  Therefore should not appear a marvellous thing
86  What I shall say of the great Florentines
87  Of whom the fame is hidden in the Past.

85  per che non dee parer mirabil cosa
86  ciò ch'io dirò de li alti Fiorentini
87  onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.

88  I saw the Ughi, saw the Catellini,
89  Filippi, Greci, Ormanni, and Alberichi,
90  Even in their fall illustrious citizens;

88  Io vidi li Ughi e vidi i Catellini,
89  Filippi, Greci, Ormanni e Alberichi,
90  già nel calare, illustri cittadini;

91  And saw, as mighty as they ancient were,
92  With him of La Sannella him of Arca,
93  And Soldanier, Ardinghi, and Bostichi.

91  e vidi così grandi come antichi,
92  con quel de la Sannella, quel de l'Arca,
93  e Soldanieri e Ardinghi e Bostichi.

94  Near to the gate that is at present laden
95  With a new felony of so much weight
96  That soon it shall be jetsam from the bark,

94  Sovra la porta ch'al presente è carca
95  di nova fellonia di tanto peso
96  che tosto fia iattura de la barca,

97  The Ravignani were, from whom descended
98  The County Guido, and whoe'er the name
99  Of the great Bellincione since hath taken.

97  erano i Ravignani, ond' è disceso
98  il conte Guido e qualunque del nome
99  de l'alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.

100  He of La Pressa knew the art of ruling
101  Already, and already Galigajo
102  Had hilt and pommel gilded in his house.

100  Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come
101  regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio
102  dorata in casa sua già l'elsa e 'l pome.

103  Mighty already was the Column Vair,
104  Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifant, and Barucci,
105  And Galli, and they who for the bushel blush.

103  Grand' era già la colonna del Vaio,
104  Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci
105  e Galli e quei ch'arrossan per lo staio.

106  The stock from which were the Calfucci born
107  Was great already, and already chosen
108  To curule chairs the Sizii and Arrigucci.

106  Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci
107  era già grande, e già eran tratti
108  a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.

109  O how beheld I those who are undone
110  By their own pride! and how the Balls of Gold
111  Florence enflowered in all their mighty deeds!

109  Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti
110  per lor superbia! e le palle de l'oro
111  fiorian Fiorenza in tutt' i suoi gran fatti.

112  So likewise did the ancestors of those
113  Who evermore, when vacant is your church,
114  Fatten by staying in consistory.

112  Così facieno i padri di coloro
113  che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca,
114  si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.

115  The insolent race, that like a dragon follows
116  Whoever flees, and unto him that shows
117  His teeth or purse is gentle as a lamb,

115  L'oltracotata schiatta che s'indraca
116  dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra 'l dente
117  o ver la borsa, com' agnel si placa,

118  Already rising was, but from low people;
119  So that it pleased not Ubertin Donato
120  That his wife's father should make him their kin.

118  già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente;
119  sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato
120  che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.

121  Already had Caponsacco to the Market
122  From Fesole descended, and already
123  Giuda and Infangato were good burghers.

121  Già era 'l Caponsacco nel mercato
122  disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era
123  buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.

124  I'll tell a thing incredible, but true;
125  One entered the small circuit by a gate
126  Which from the Della Pera took its name!



124  Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera:
125  nel picciol cerchio s'entrava per porta
126  che si nomava da quei de la Pera.

127  Each one that bears the beautiful escutcheon
128  Of the great baron whose renown and name
129  The festival of Thomas keepeth fresh,

127  Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta
128  del gran barone il cui nome e 'l cui pregio
129  la festa di Tommaso riconforta,

130  Knighthood and privilege from him received;
131  Though with the populace unites himself
132  To-day the man who binds it with a border.

130  da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio;
131  avvegna che con popol si rauni
132  oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.

133  Already were Gualterotti and Importuni;
134  And still more quiet would the Borgo be
135  If with new neighbours it remained unfed.

133  Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni;
134  e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto,
135  se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.

136  The house from which is born your lamentation,
137  Through just disdain that death among you brought
138  And put an end unto your joyous life,

136  La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto,
137  per lo giusto disdegno che v'ha morti
138  e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,

139  Was honoured in itself and its companions.
140  O Buondelmonte, how in evil hour
141  Thou fled'st the bridal at another's promptings!

139  era onorata, essa e suoi consorti:
140  o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti
141  le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!

142  Many would be rejoicing who are sad,
143  If God had thee surrendered to the Ema
144  The first time that thou camest to the city.

142  Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi,
143  se Dio t'avesse conceduto ad Ema
144  la prima volta ch'a città venisti.

145  But it behoved the mutilated stone
146  Which guards the bridge, that Florence should provide
147  A victim in her latest hour of peace.

145  Ma conveniesi, a quella pietra scema
146  che guarda 'l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse
147  vittima ne la sua pace postrema.

148  With all these families, and others with them,
149  Florence beheld I in so great repose,
150  That no occasion had she whence to weep;

148  Con queste genti, e con altre con esse,
149  vid' io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo,
150  che non avea cagione onde piangesse.

151  With all these families beheld so just
152  And glorious her people, that the lily
153  Never upon the spear was placed reversed,

151  Con queste genti vid' io glorïoso
152  e giusto il popol suo, tanto che 'l giglio
153  non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,

154  Nor by division was vermilion made."

154  né per divisïon fatto vermiglio.”

Canto XVII
All through the poem, our certain knowledge of the past is projected, that is, prophesied, as potential knowledge of the future, but this maneuver is no more prevalent than here, as Dante's ancestor from 300 years previous makes predictions about Dante's future from Easter week, in the year 1300 A.D. — that is, from the time of the poem to presumably the time of the poet's death.  It seems that Time, historical Time, is subtly or not so subtly, saturated with knowledge of itself, its patterns in the past, which anyone can see, as one might see the completed patterns in a woven tapestry, seeming to be readable, that is, predictive of the future.  If they are, they would be so by virtue of this characteristic of pattern-making, which encompasses the future as well as the past.  (See the metaphor on weaving, verses 101 - 102.)  Certainly an artist of Dante's caliber must have become aware of this as he worked out the schema of his poem, for things merely intuited in the first canti of the Inferno are brought to what seems an often surprising fruition in the subsequent canticles of the poem.  These "surprises" are seen in retrospect to result in inevitabilities, because the template has, as it were, a fractal-like nature, any minute segment of Time being but a hologram for the All-Timeliness of Eternity.  Is this predestination?  Dante says no, but it is something like a deepening awareness of any moment or movement in Time, which when examined with increasing penetration reveals these repeating patterns.  Pound, in his own Cantos compares these like historical events separated by space, time, and cultures to rhyme in poetry.  These events are all of a pattern, just as similar sounds in a poem might form a predictable scheme.  If a rhyme scheme is ABAB for example, we cannot predict which specific word is going to be used for the rhyme, but we can tell what the sound of that word will be.  Perhaps prophecies work something like this, repeating past events with similarities, but not necessarily with exactitudes.  Time can be kaleidoscopic as well as sequential, and we can see how the same moments, depending upon our awareness or point-of-view, can configure and reconfigure themselves into apparently different patterns without changing their essential elemental nature.  (For an interesting take on time-fractals as quantum-like packets of similarities connecting in a non-linear way, see Albert-László Barabási's book, Bursts: The Hidden Pattern Behind Everything We Do.)  These concepts are difficult if not impossible to grasp in any linearly logical way, but through poetic metaphor and the layered nature of experience, we are made aware of them if only in a tangential way.  There seems to be a movement from vagueness to articulation as awareness penetrates such mysteries, and in this canto, that movement is mirrored in a pattern in which thought is made more articulate in speech, speech in writing, and writing in turn prompting more articulated thought in the form of establishing something we call meaning.  (Note verses 7 - 12, where Beatrice, who can read Dante's mind, asks him to speak his thoughts aloud so that he may more fully hear them.)  If there is any work of art in which pattern — as a networked system of references which are mythological, scriptural, philosophical, geological, astrological, political, theological, historical, natural, and especially structural in the terza rima and canti/canticle numeric/linguistic template of the poem — which is any better model of this kind of fractal patterning, it is more likely to be found in music (or architecture) than in another poem, which is why we find in the Commedia this thorough-composed attribute, both musical and architectural, and why its author could predict with such apparent arrogant certainty the poem's future fame.  Among all the Commedia's many virtues, this quality of being a mirror image of Time has perhaps few equals in the Western Canon.  And in this sense, we might place it with works like the I Ching, as something more than the usual literary production. (Another example of this temporal network patterning is explored as  Time-Wave Models in Terence McKenna's The Invisible Landscape: Mind, Hallucinogens and the I Ching.)  

For me, this is the saddest of all the cantos, not the most horrifying, but the saddest.  Because, in this canto, in the plainest of language, Dante the protagonist and Dante the poet become one: Dante the exile and nomad.  Why here?  In the Heaven of Mars, in the Paradise of militant spirits?  In the midst of the most exquisite of unearthly joys, why this heavy, hopeless pronouncement of Dante's temporal life?  In these verses, you can hear a great metaphysical crash.  The terrestrial world's girders snap and collapse as the great tree of life, an Yggdrasil of historical fate, comes down, exploding in a cloud of duff and dust.  Why this is heavenly and not tragic is the magic of the canto.

This is a canto of reversals, reversals that linguistically are embodied in paradoxes, the back looping of Time's seemingly inexorable forward push, a figure from the past, Cacciaguida’s, foretelling the Dante's future.  The swift arrow of time, here is slowed, mentioned first in verse 27, but not finding its target until verse 57.  Rich men changing states with beggars.  Enemies praising the virtues of their foe.  The poet, master of a communal art, becomes a party of one.  The exile descends stairs before ascending them.  The innocent is punished by the guilty.  The prophet of the future is speaking from the distant past.  A man of peace is martyred in war to establish peace.  These paradoxical "truths" are woven into the pattern of Time, and are geometrically certain, as sure as the conclusion of a book is foretold in its beginning, as certain as a ship must flow with the current that sustains it, and cast its reflection, and he who tells all this is himself compared to a reflection, that of a reversing mirror, reflecting the brightness of the sun.  Here, Dante, who has bathed in the waters of Lethe, shows that he has not been cleansed of memory, for he remembers his journey through the lower worlds, his poetry's guide, Virgil, the dark prophecies that he has heard of his temporal fate by those in Hell and in Purgatory.  I have had the hardest time coming to grips with the deep lessons of this canto, the hardest time accepting that these paradoxes and tragedies of temporal life could possibly lead to the aesthetic exultation embodied in Cacciaguida, and in the poem, the hardest time finding peace in the message of this militant spirit.  I don't know that I have accepted these lessons, or ever will, and that might be the most transforming lesson of them all, because it is plain, brutal, exalting.  And here I am, strung up and strung out on these verses, needing to move on, crippled and incomplete, wanting above all to have been more certain by this point in Paradise, but now having to swallow this bitter pill, which Dante promises will become sweet, just as that misanthrope on Patmos promised, but which here and now still seems bitter, indigestible, and yet utterly resistant to any attempt to vomit it forth, to read it as irony, and not be choking on these plain bones of contention, which seem to be my own wracked skeleton.  Here the discomfort of the doubt that the first verses of the canto refer to is magnified by the faith that is exposed at the canto's conclusion.  Here, amidst all the amazement that I experience from the intense mastery displayed in the Commedia, is the regret that this mastery is so irrefutable in delivering this canto's message.  Here one must accept a fatal diagnosis as an invitation to impregnable health.  Here we are forced to ask: What have my limitations, catastrophes, and woundings allowed me to be or do that would have been otherwise impossible?  Or to put it another way, how am I enabled to fulfill my destiny as a consequence of this war against myself?  It makes no sense, it transcends sense: It's Dante.  But the Real, to use a Lacanian term is absolute, whole, and without fissure.  The Real is the shining void of liberation that the Tibetan Buddhist promulgate.  Thus the Real is the most stunning reversal and paradox of them all.  It is set forth in these lines:

73  Who such benign regard shall have for thee
74  That 'twixt you twain, in doing and in asking,
75  That shall be first which is with others last.

73  ch'in te avrà sì benigno riguardo,
74  che del fare e del chieder, tra voi due,
75  fia primo quel che tra li altri è più tardo.

Here Dante is in the position of infant to child, or even that of fetus to womb, but most crucially that of Creature to Creator.  This is the grace wherein one's needs and one's desires are fulfilled before they are sought, the behest supplied before requested, and this is the relationship that the poet has with his Muse, and the aspirant has with the Divine.  After such a realization, militancy has no meaning, for every dissonant event in that pattern of temporal life is harmonized to bliss in the music of eternity.  The reflection — the speculation, the contemplation, the poem — shines as the sun in a mirror, and the bliss of the Creator is experienced by the aspirant as his own body, insubstantial and illusory in every way but one, it is the very image of its God.
 

The key to this canto is at the end, where Dante asks Cacciaguida about how or if his work will survive to a time when he and his contemporaries are thought of as the ancients.  It is here that the protagonist and the poet are most fully one, because as one they realize that their exile and nomad life is not a punishment, but a metaposition, a necessary place of perspective to be what is needed to confer fame and to achieve it.  When Dante asks his ancestor, his ancient, if he should uphold the truth, this is the truth that he vows to express.  How could Dante the poet have spoken the truth of his times and of all times for the artist if he were not an embodiment of that truth?  Inside the walls of a city, a country, a culture, is no place to rise above and see the patterns that extend from the past to the future, and which are everywhere weaving the present.  Dante's fate is a blessing, and not only for him, but for the art of poetry, and for those who have been blessed by his work in the centuries that have since seen in it a source of illumination.  
   
1  As came to Clymene, to be made certain
2  Of that which he had heard against himself,
3  He who makes fathers chary still to children,

1  Qual venne a Climenè, per accertarsi
2  di ciò ch'avëa incontro a sé udito,
3  quei ch'ancor fa li padri ai figli scarsi;

4  Even such was I, and such was I perceived
5  By Beatrice and by the holy light
6  That first on my account had changed its place.

4  tal era io, e tal era sentito
5  e da Beatrice e da la santa lampa
6  che pria per me avea mutato sito.

7  Therefore my Lady said to me: "Send forth
8  The flame of thy desire, so that it issue
9  Imprinted well with the internal stamp;

7  Per che mia donna “Manda fuor la vampa
8  del tuo disio,” mi disse, “sì ch'ella esca
9  segnata bene de la interna stampa:

10  Not that our knowledge may be greater made
11  By speech of thine, but to accustom thee
12  To tell thy thirst, that we may give thee drink."

10  non perché nostra conoscenza cresca
11  per tuo parlare, ma perché t'ausi
12  a dir la sete, sì che l'uom ti mesca.”

13  "O my beloved tree, (that so dost lift thee,
14  That even as minds terrestrial perceive
15  No triangle containeth two obtuse,

13  “O cara piota mia che sì t'insusi,
14  che, come veggion le terrene menti
15  non capere in trïangol due ottusi,

16  So thou beholdest the contingent things
17  Ere in themselves they are, fixing thine eyes
18  Upon the point in which all times are present,)

16  così vedi le cose contingenti
17  anzi che sieno in sé, mirando il punto
18  a cui tutti li tempi son presenti;

19  While I was with Virgilius conjoined
20  Upon the mountain that the souls doth heal,
21  And when descending into the dead world,

19  mentre ch'io era a Virgilio congiunto
20  su per lo monte che l'anime cura
21  e discendendo nel mondo defunto,

22  Were spoken to me of my future life
23  Some grievous words; although I feel myself
24  In sooth foursquare against the blows of chance.

22  dette mi fuor di mia vita futura
23  parole gravi, avvegna ch'io mi senta
24  ben tetragono ai colpi di ventura;

25  On this account my wish would be content
26  To hear what fortune is approaching me,
27  Because foreseen an arrow comes more slowly."

25  per che la voglia mia saria contenta
26  d'intender qual fortuna mi s'appressa:
27  ché saetta previsa vien più lenta.”

28  Thus did I say unto that selfsame light
29  That unto me had spoken before; and even
30  As Beatrice willed was my own will confessed.

28  Così diss' io a quella luce stessa
29  che pria m'avea parlato; e come volle
30  Beatrice, fu la mia voglia confessa.

31  Not in vague phrase, in which the foolish folk
32  Ensnared themselves of old, ere yet was slain
33  The Lamb of God who taketh sins away,

31  Né per ambage, in che la gente folle
32  già s'inviscava pria che fosse anciso
33 l'Agnel di Dio che le peccata tolle,

34  But with clear words and unambiguous
35  Language responded that paternal love,
36  Hid and revealed by its own proper smile:

34  ma per chiare parole e con preciso
35  latin rispuose quello amor paterno,
36  chiuso e parvente del suo proprio riso:

37  "Contingency, that outside of the volume
38  Of your materiality extends not,
39  Is all depicted in the eternal aspect.

37  “La contingenza, che fuor del quaderno
38  de la vostra matera non si stende,
39  tutta è dipinta nel cospetto etterno;

40  Necessity however thence it takes not,
41  Except as from the eye, in which 'tis mirrored,
42  A ship that with the current down descends.

40  necessità però quindi non prende
41  se non come dal viso in che si specchia
42  nave che per torrente giù discende.

43  From thence, e'en as there cometh to the ear
44  Sweet harmony from an organ, comes in sight
45  To me the time that is preparing for thee.

43  Da indi, sì come viene ad orecchia
44  dolce armonia da organo, mi viene
45  a vista il tempo che ti s'apparecchia.

46  As forth from Athens went Hippolytus,
47  By reason of his step-dame false and cruel,
48  So thou from Florence must perforce depart.

46  Qual si partio Ipolito d'Atene
47  per la spietata e perfida noverca,
48  tal di Fiorenza partir ti convene.

49  Already this is willed, and this is sought for;
50  And soon it shall be done by him who thinks it,
51  Where every day the Christ is bought and sold.

49  Questo si vuole e questo già si cerca,
50  e tosto verrà fatto a chi ciò pensa
51  là dove Cristo tutto dì si merca.

52  The blame shall follow the offended party
53  In outcry as is usual; but the vengeance
54  Shall witness to the truth that doth dispense it.

52  La colpa seguirà la parte offensa
53  in grido, come suol; ma la vendetta
54  fia testimonio al ver che la dispensa.

55  Thou shalt abandon everything beloved
56  Most tenderly, and this the arrow is
57  Which first the bow of banishment shoots forth.

55  Tu lascerai ogne cosa diletta
56  più caramente; e questo è quello strale
57  che l'arco de lo essilio pria saetta.
58  Thou shalt have proof how savoureth of salt
59  The bread of others, and how hard a road
60  The going down and up another's stairs.

58  Tu proverai sì come sa di sale
59  lo pane altrui, e come è duro calle
60  lo scendere e 'l salir per l'altrui scale.

61  And that which most shall weigh upon thy shoulders
62  Will be the bad and foolish company
63  With which into this valley thou shalt fall;

61  E quel che più ti graverà le spalle,
62  sarà la compagnia malvagia e scempia
63  con la qual tu cadrai in questa valle;

64  For all ingrate, all mad and impious
65  Will they become against thee; but soon after
66  They, and not thou, shall have the forehead scarlet.

64  che tutta ingrata, tutta matta ed empia
65  si farà contr' a te; ma, poco appresso,
66  ella, non tu, n'avrà rossa la tempia.

67  Of their bestiality their own proceedings
68  Shall furnish proof; so 'twill be well for thee
69  A party to have made thee by thyself.

67  Di sua bestialitate il suo processo
68  farà la prova; sì ch'a te fia bello
69  averti fatta parte per te stesso.

70  Thine earliest refuge and thine earliest inn
71  Shall be the mighty Lombard's courtesy,
72  Who on the Ladder bears the holy bird,

70  Lo primo tuo refugio e 'l primo ostello
71  sarà la cortesia del gran Lombardo
71  che 'n su la scala porta il santo uccello;

73  Who such benign regard shall have for thee
74  That 'twixt you twain, in doing and in asking,
75  That shall be first which is with others last.

73  ch'in te avrà sì benigno riguardo,
74  che del fare e del chieder, tra voi due,
75  fia primo quel che tra li altri è più tardo.

76  With him shalt thou see one who at his birth
77  Has by this star of strength been so impressed,
78  That notable shall his achievements be.

76  Con lui vedrai colui che 'mpresso fue,
77  nascendo, sì da questa stella forte,
78  che notabili fier l'opere sue.

79  Not yet the people are aware of him
80  Through his young age, since only nine years yet
81  Around about him have these wheels revolved.

79  Non se ne son le genti ancora accorte
80  per la novella età, ché pur nove anni
81  son queste rote intorno di lui torte;

82  But ere the Gascon cheat the noble Henry,
83  Some sparkles of his virtue shall appear
84  In caring not for silver nor for toil.

82  ma pria che 'l Guasco l'alto Arrigo inganni,
83  parran faville de la sua virtute
84  in non curar d'argento né d'affanni.

85  So recognized shall his magnificence
86  Become hereafter, that his enemies
87  Will not have power to keep mute tongues about it.

85  Le sue magnificenze conosciute
86  saranno ancora, sì che ' suoi nemici
87  non ne potran tener le lingue mute.

88  On him rely, and on his benefits;
89  By him shall many people be transformed,
90  Changing condition rich and mendicant;

88  A lui t'aspetta e a' suoi benefici;
89  per lui fia trasmutata molta gente,
90  cambiando condizion ricchi e mendici;

91  And written in thy mind thou hence shalt bear
92  Of him, but shalt not say it"—and things said he
93  Incredible to those who shall be present.

91  e portera'ne scritto ne la mente
92 di lui, e nol dirai”; e disse cose
93  incredibili a quei che fier presente.

94  Then added: "Son, these are the commentaries
95  On what was said to thee; behold the snares
96  That are concealed behind few revolutions;

94  Poi giunse: “Figlio, queste son le chiose
95  di quel che ti fu detto; ecco le 'nsidie
96  che dietro a pochi giri son nascose.

97  Yet would I not thy neighbours thou shouldst envy,
98  Because thy life into the future reaches
99  Beyond the punishment of their perfidies."

97  Non vo' però ch'a' tuoi vicini invidie,
98  poscia che s'infutura la tua vita
99  via più là che 'l punir di lor perfidie.”

100  When by its silence showed that sainted soul
101  That it had finished putting in the woof
102  Into that web which I had given it warped,

100  Poi che, tacendo, si mostrò spedita
101  l'anima santa di metter la trama
102  in quella tela ch'io le porsi ordita,

103  Began I, even as he who yearneth after,
104  Being in doubt, some counsel from a person
105  Who seeth, and uprightly wills, and loves:

103  io cominciai, come colui che brama,
104  dubitando, consiglio da persona
105  che vede e vuol dirittamente e ama:

106  "Well see I, father mine, how spurreth on
107  The time towards me such a blow to deal me
108  As heaviest is to him who most gives way.

106  “Ben veggio, padre mio, sì come sprona
107  lo tempo verso me, per colpo darmi
108  tal, ch'è più grave a chi più s'abbandona;

109  Therefore with foresight it is well I arm me,
110  That, if the dearest place be taken from me,
111  I may not lose the others by my songs.

109  per che di provedenza è buon ch'io m'armi,
110  sì che, se loco m'è tolto più caro,
111  io non perdessi li altri per miei carmi.

112  Down through the world of infinite bitterness,
113  And o'er the mountain, from whose beauteous summit
114  The eyes of my own Lady lifted me,

112  Giù per lo mondo sanza fine amaro,
113  e per lo monte del cui bel cacume
114  li occhi de la mia donna mi levaro,

115  And afterward through heaven from light to light,
116  I have learned that which, if I tell again,
107  Will be a savour of strong herbs to many.

115  e poscia per lo ciel, di lume in lume,
116  ho io appreso quel che s'io ridico,
117  a molti fia sapor di forte agrume;

108  And if I am a timid friend to truth,
109  I fear lest I may lose my life with those
110  Who will hereafter call this time the olden."

118  e s'io al vero son timido amico,
119  temo di perder viver tra coloro
120  che questo tempo chiameranno antico.”

121  The light in which was smiling my own treasure
122  Which there I had discovered, flashed at first
123  As in the sunshine doth a golden mirror;

121  La luce in che rideva il mio tesoro
122  ch'io trovai lì, si fé prima corusca,
123  quale a raggio di sole specchio d'oro;

124  Then made reply: "A conscience overcast
125  Or with its own or with another's shame,
126  Will taste forsooth the tartness of thy word;

124  indi rispuose: “Coscïenza fusca
125  o de la propria o de l'altrui vergogna
126  pur sentirà la tua parola brusca.

127  But ne'ertheless, all falsehood laid aside,
128  Make manifest thy vision utterly,
129  And let them scratch wherever is the itch;

127  Ma nondimen, rimossa ogne menzogna,
128  tutta tua visïon fa manifesta;
129  e lascia pur grattar dov' è la rogna.

130  For if thine utterance shall offensive be
131  At the first taste, a vital nutriment
132  'Twill leave thereafter, when it is digested.

130  Ché se la voce tua sarà molesta
131  nel primo gusto, vital nodrimento
132  lascerà poi, quando sarà digesta.

133  This cry of thine shall do as doth the wind,
134  Which smiteth most the most exalted summits,
135  And that is no slight argument of honour.

133  Questo tuo grido farà come vento,
134  che le più alte cime più percuote;
135  e ciò non fa d'onor poco argomento.

136  Therefore are shown to thee within these wheels,
137  Upon the mount and in the dolorous valley,
138  Only the souls that unto fame are known;

136  Però ti son mostrate in queste rote,
137  nel monte e ne la valle dolorosa
138  pur l'anime che son di fama note,

139  Because the spirit of the hearer rests not,
140  Nor doth confirm its faith by an example
142  Which has the root of it unknown and hidden,
139  che l'animo di quel ch'ode, non posa
140  né ferma fede per essempro ch'aia
142  la sua radice incognita e ascosa,

143  Or other reason that is not apparent."

143  né per altro argomento che non paia.”

Canto XVIII

The heaven of Jupiter may be compared to Geometry because of two properties: one is that it moves between two heavens that are antithetical to its fine temperance, namely that of Mars and that of Saturn; consequently Ptolemy says, in the book referred to, that Jupiter is a star of temperate constitution between the cold of Saturn and the heat of Mars; the other is that among all the stars it appears white, almost silvery.  And these things are found in the science of Geometry.  Geometry moves between two things antithetical to it, namely the point and the circle – and I mean “circle” in the broad sense of anything round, whether a solid body or a surface; for, as Euclid says, the point is its beginning, and, as he says, the circle is its most perfect figure, which must therefore be conceived as its end.  Therefore Geometry moves between the point and the circle as between its beginning and end, and these two are antithetical to its certainty; for the point cannot be measured because of its indivisibility, and it is impossible to square the circle perfectly because of its arc, and so it cannot be measured exactly.  Geometry is furthermore most white insofar as it is without taint of error and most certain both in itself and in its handmaid, which is called Optics.
