Convivio, Book II, Chapter 13

When you begin reading Dante closely, by this point in the Commedia, you reach a condition which might be called "excellence fatigue."  The reader has been infused and enthused by almost too many insights, no small number of which pertain to Dante's unequaled technical skill in organizing his material in such a way that it is productive of this capacity to not just express meaning, but like life itself, to embody it.  Thus stunned, you begin to ask yourself more fundamental questions about how Dante's use of language enables him to create so much wonder and beauty, which fruit as so much genuine knowledge about how language works in modeling the world, an attribute that as the previous canto suggested, that is productive of fame.  Fame in this case cannot be compared to what we ordinarily think of as celebrity, that is, renown among a large number of people for a long period of time.  Rather, it is something like the ability to generate insight across different historical eras, different subjects, different types of readers, and different idioms.  Dante's idiom is that of an educated Western Christian in the year 1300, but note how he is able to present something so sophisticated as our contemporary subjects of chaos theory or fuzzy thinking, and how randomness organizes itself, partly through processes of human observation and perception, into meaningful form.  Rereading and rereading the first 30 lines of this canto, infuses us with a feeling in which an exuberant loving joy bursts out of the sacred marriage of language and the effects of language, his poetry, no matter what its content — sad, horrifying, judging, despairing, glittering with spectacle — is always a triumph that comes from mere, naked existence itself, conjuring first the void, and then the primal chaos which initially negates the void.  In this canto, sparks flying up from a burning log (random, inorganic), or birds rising and flocking (seemingly random, organic, and the result of living appetites and processes), the formation of letters, their shapes derived from the geometrical constants of lines and curves ... all of this is embedded in an intricate network of historical, astrological, geological, scriptural, natural, mythological, theological (etc. as noted in these comments on the previous canto) all meticulously arranged in a strict order of sound geometries, which even allow for cryptological messaging.  Examples of this network occur not just in those I've cited here, but throughout this canto.  In fact, a good exercise for a skilled mathematical/linguist would be to graph how this whole network of metaphors and idioms operate throughout the Commedia.  The spectacle here of the intelligent lights arranging themselves into the shape of a cross, the letters of the alphabet, a lily, reminds us of those marching bands at half-time shows, or those shots from above where costumed dances form various geometric shapes, but here these are the enactments of an extremely agile and gifted imagination, with the linguistic skill to not only present such spectacles but to infuse them with those flexible and multivalent embodiments of meaning which lead to that excellence noted above.  From these techniques we are able to derive insights, certainly in this case on the theme of justice, but also on how language, and especially poetic language, is in itself a vehicle for establishing justice.  That is, as readers, we expand our notions about justice into the realms of aesthetics and linguistics, the idea of justice no longer merely a concept confined to sociological and legal domains.  In this canto, we are made aware that something has happened to the protagonist's mind as a result of his associations with Beatrice and the other communicants in Paradise.  The following verses show that just as Dante's mind has been read by these heavenly beings, he is becoming a bit of a mind reader himself, anticipating that a spirit is about to address him, by what might be called a mirroring of moods.  From these exalted ones he is becoming exultant.

22  Even as sometimes here do we behold
23  The affection in the look, if it be such
24  That all the soul is wrapt away by it,

22  Come si vede qui alcuna volta
23  l'affetto ne la vista, s'elli è tanto,
24  che da lui sia tutta l'anima tolta,

25  So, by the flaming of the effulgence holy
26   To which I turned, I recognized therein
27  The wish of speaking to me somewhat farther.

25  così nel fiammeggiar del folgór santo,
26  a ch'io mi volsi, conobbi la voglia
27  in lui di ragionarmi ancora alquanto.

I cannot really leave this canto without commenting on the almost retrograde denunciations of the current political and ecclesiastical corruption of Dante's historical situation.  His idiom giving us the corrupt Vicars of Christ, the evil popes, personas of a type which tragically seem to recur in every generation.  These denunciations pose a very startling consideration.  Can paradise tolerate emotions of sadness or indignation, or for that matter, any number of emotions which we might consider to be negative.  Another way to phrase this: Can what we conceive of as justice even exist without the presence of injustice?  That these are moral questions is obvious, that they might also be aesthetical questions, wherein harmony is a process by which the static or chaos of inharmonies seem most surprising, most satisfying, and most inspiring when these attributes of chaos become elegant elements of expression.  At the end of the canto the metaphor which exemplifies this is that Peter and Paul are not passé historical figures, but living spiritual beings with an appetite for justice and aesthetic exultation. 

1  Now was alone rejoicing in its word
2  That soul beatified, and I was tasting
3  My own, the bitter tempering with the sweet,

1  Già si godeva solo del suo verbo
2  quello specchio beato, e io gustava
3  lo mio, temprando col dolce l'acerbo;

4  And the Lady who to God was leading me
5  Said: "Change thy thought; consider that I am
6  Near unto Him who every wrong disburdens."

4  e quella donna ch'a Dio mi menava
5  disse: “Muta pensier; pensa ch'i' sono
6  presso a colui ch'ogne torto disgrava.”

7  Unto the loving accents of my comfort
8  I turned me round, and then what love I saw
9  Within those holy eyes I here relinquish;

7  Io mi rivolsi a l'amoroso suono
8  del mio conforto; e qual io allor vidi
9  ne li occhi santi amor, qui l'abbandono:

10  Not only that my language I distrust,
11  But that my mind cannot return so far
12  Above itself, unless another guide it.

10  non perch' io pur del mio parlar diffidi,
11  ma per la mente che non può redire
12  sovra sé tanto, s'altri non la guidi.

13  Thus much upon that point can I repeat,
14  That, her again beholding, my affection
15  From every other longing was released.

13  Tanto poss' io di quel punto ridire,
14  che, rimirando lei, lo mio affetto
15  libero fu da ogne altro disire,

16  While the eternal pleasure, which direct
17  Rayed upon Beatrice, from her fair face
18  Contented me with its reflected aspect,

16  fin che 'l piacere etterno, che diretto
17  raggiava in Bëatrice, dal bel viso
18  mi contentava col secondo aspetto.

19  Conquering me with the radiance of a smile,
20  She said to me, "Turn thee about and listen;
21  Not in mine eyes alone is Paradise."

19  Vincendo me col lume d'un sorriso,
20  ella mi disse: “Volgiti e ascolta;
21  ché non pur ne' miei occhi è paradiso.”

22  Even as sometimes here do we behold
23  The affection in the look, if it be such
24  That all the soul is wrapt away by it,

22  Come si vede qui alcuna volta
23  l'affetto ne la vista, s'elli è tanto,
24  che da lui sia tutta l'anima tolta,

25  So, by the flaming of the effulgence holy
26   To which I turned, I recognized therein
27  The wish of speaking to me somewhat farther.

25  così nel fiammeggiar del folgór santo,
26  a ch'io mi volsi, conobbi la voglia
27  in lui di ragionarmi ancora alquanto.

28  And it began: "In this fifth resting-place
29  Upon the tree that liveth by its summit,
30  And aye bears fruit, and never loses leaf,

28  El cominciò: “In questa quinta soglia
29  de l'albero che vive de la cima
30  e frutta sempre e mai non perde foglia,

31  Are blessed spirits that below, ere yet
32  They came to Heaven, were of such great renown
33  That every Muse therewith would affluent be.

31  spiriti son beati, che giù, prima
32  che venissero al ciel, fuor di gran voce,
33  sì ch'ogne musa ne sarebbe opima.

34  Therefore look thou upon the cross's horns;
35  He whom I now shall name will there enact
36  What doth within a cloud its own swift fire."

34  Però mira ne' corni de la croce:
35  quello ch'io nomerò, lì farà l'atto
36  che fa in nube il suo foco veloce.”

37  I saw athwart the Cross a splendour drawn
38  By naming Joshua, (even as he did it,)
39  Nor noted I the word before the deed;

37  Io vidi per la croce un lume tratto
38  dal nomar Iosuè, com' el si feo;
39  né mi fu noto il dir prima che 'l fatto.

40  And at the name of the great Maccabee
41  I saw another move itself revolving,
42  And gladness was the whip unto that top.

40  E al nome de l'alto Macabeo
41  vidi moversi un altro roteando,
42  e letizia era ferza del paleo.

43  Likewise for Charlemagne and for Orlando,
44  Two of them my regard attentive followed
45  As followeth the eye its falcon flying.

43  Così per Carlo Magno e per Orlando
44  due ne seguì lo mio attento sguardo,
45  com' occhio segue suo falcon volando.

46  William thereafterward, and Renouard,
47  And the Duke Godfrey, did attract my sight
48  Along upon that Cross, and Robert Guiscard.

46  Poscia trasse Guiglielmo e Rinoardo
47  e 'l duca Gottifredi la mia vista
48  per quella croce, e Ruberto Guiscardo.

49  Then, moved and mingled with the other lights,
50  The soul that had addressed me showed how great
51  An artist 'twas among the heavenly singers.

49  Indi, tra l'altre luci mota e mista,
50  mostrommi l'alma che m'avea parlato
51  qual era tra i cantor del cielo artista.

52  To my right side I turned myself around,
53  My duty to behold in Beatrice
54  Either by words or gesture signified;

52  Io mi rivolsi dal mio destro lato
53  per vedere in Beatrice il mio dovere,
54  o per parlare o per atto, segnato;

55  And so translucent I beheld her eyes,
56  So full of pleasure, that her countenance
57  Surpassed its other and its latest wont.

55  e vidi le sue luci tanto mere,
56  tanto gioconde, che la sua sembianza
57  vinceva li altri e l'ultimo solere.

58  And as, by feeling greater delectation,
59  A man in doing good from day to day
60  Becomes aware his virtue is increasing,

58  E come, per sentir più dilettanza
59  bene operando, l'uom di giorno in giorno
60  s'accorge che la sua virtute avanza,

61  So I became aware that my gyration
62  With heaven together had increased its arc,
63  That miracle beholding more adorned.

61  sì m'accors' io che 'l mio girare intorno
62  col cielo insieme avea cresciuto l'arco,
63  veggendo quel miracol più addorno.

64  And such as is the change, in little lapse
65  Of time, in a pale woman, when her face
66  Is from the load of bashfulness unladen,

64  E qual è 'l trasmutare in picciol varco
65  di tempo in bianca donna, quando 'l volto
66  suo si discarchi di vergogna il carco,

67  Such was it in mine eyes, when I had turned,
68  Caused by the whiteness of the temperate star,
69  The sixth, which to itself had gathered me.

67  tal fu ne li occhi miei, quando fui vòlto,
68  per lo candor de la temprata stella
69  sesta, che dentro a sé m'avea ricolto.

70  Within that Jovial torch did I behold
71  The sparkling of the love which was therein
72  Delineate our language to mine eyes.

70  Io vidi in quella giovïal facella
71  lo sfavillar de l'amor che lì era
72  segnare a li occhi miei nostra favella.

73  And even as birds uprisen from the shore,
74  As in congratulation o'er their food,
75  Make squadrons of themselves, now round, now long,

73  E come augelli surti di rivera,
74  quasi congratulando a lor pasture,
75  fanno di sé or tonda or altra schiera,

76  So from within those lights the holy creatures
77  Sang flying to and fro, and in their figures
78  Made of themselves now D, now I, now L.

76  sì dentro ai lumi sante creature
77  volitando cantavano, e faciensi
78  or D, or I, or L in sue figure.

79  First singing they to their own music moved;
80  Then one becoming of these characters,
81  A little while they rested and were silent.

79  Prima, cantando, a sua nota moviensi;
80  poi, diventando l'un di questi segni,
81  un poco s'arrestavano e taciensi.

82  O divine Pegasea, thou who genius
83  Dost glorious make, and render it long-lived,
84  And this through thee the cities and the kingdoms,

82  O diva Pegasëa che li 'ngegni
83  fai glorïosi e rendili longevi,
84  ed essi teco le cittadi e ' regni,

85  Illume me with thyself, that I may bring
86  Their figures out as I have them conceived!
87  Apparent be thy power in these brief verses!

85  illustrami di te, sì ch'io rilevi
86  le lor figure com' io l'ho concette:
87  paia tua possa in questi versi brevi!

88  Themselves then they displayed in five times seven
89  Vowels and consonants; and I observed
90  The parts as they seemed spoken unto me.

88  Mostrarsi dunque in cinque volte sette
89  vocali e consonanti; e io notai
90  le parti sì, come mi parver dette.

91  'Diligite justitiam,' these were
92  First verb and noun of all that was depicted;
93  'Qui judicatis terram' were the last.

91  “DILIGITE IUSTITIAM,” primai
92  fur verbo e nome di tutto 'l dipinto;
93  “QUI IUDICATIS TERRAM,” fur sezzai.

94  Thereafter in the M of the fifth word
95  Remained they so arranged, that Jupiter
96  Seemed to be silver there with gold inlaid.

94  Poscia ne l'emme del vocabol quinto
95  rimasero ordinate; sì che Giove
96  pareva argento lì d'oro distinto.

97  And other lights I saw descend where was
98  The summit of the M, and pause there singing
99  The good, I think, that draws them to itself.
97  E vidi scendere altre luci dove
98  era il colmo de l'emme, e lì quetarsi
99  cantando, credo, il ben ch'a sé le move.

100  Then, as in striking upon burning logs
101  Upward there fly innumerable sparks,
102  Whence fools are wont to look for auguries,

100  Poi, come nel percuoter d'i ciocchi arsi
101  surgono innumerabili faville,
102  onde li stolti sogliono agurarsi,

103  More than a thousand lights seemed thence to rise,
104  And to ascend, some more, and others less,
105  Even as the Sun that lights them had allotted;

103  resurger parver quindi più di mille
104  luci e salir, qual assai e qual poco,
105  sì come 'l sol che l'accende sortille;

106  And, each one being quiet in its place,
107  The head and neck beheld I of an eagle
108  Delineated by that inlaid fire.

106  e quïetata ciascuna in suo loco,
107  la testa e 'l collo d'un'aguglia vidi
108  rappresentare a quel distinto foco.

109  He who there paints has none to be his guide;
110  But Himself guides; and is from Him remembered
111  That virtue which is form unto the nest.

109  Quei che dipinge lì, non ha chi 'l guidi;
110  ma esso guida, e da lui si rammenta
111  quella virtù ch'è forma per li nidi.

112  The other beatitude, that contented seemed
113  At first to bloom a lily on the M,
114  By a slight motion followed out the imprint.

112  L'altra bëatitudo, che contenta
113  pareva prima d'ingigliarsi a l'emme,
114  con poco moto seguitò la 'mprenta.

115  O gentle star! what and how many gems
116  Did demonstrate to me, that all our justice
117  Effect is of that heaven which thou ingemmest!

115  O dolce stella, quali e quante gemme
116  mi dimostraro che nostra giustizia
117  effetto sia del ciel che tu ingemme!

118  Wherefore I pray the Mind, in which begin
119  Thy motion and thy virtue, to regard
120  Whence comes the smoke that vitiates thy rays;

118  Per ch'io prego la mente in che s'inizia
119  tuo moto e tua virtute, che rimiri
120  ond' esce il fummo che 'l tuo raggio vizia;

121  So that a second time it now be wroth
122  With buying and with selling in the temple
123  Whose walls were built with signs and martyrdoms!

121  sì ch'un'altra fiata omai s'adiri
122  del comperare e vender dentro al templo
123  che si murò di segni e di martìri.

124  O soldiery of heaven, whom I contemplate,
125  Implore for those who are upon the earth
126  All gone astray after the bad example!

124  O milizia del ciel cu' io contemplo,
125  adora per color che sono in terra
126  tutti svïati dietro al malo essemplo!

127  Once 'twas the custom to make war with swords;
128  But now 'tis made by taking here and there
129  The bread the pitying Father shuts from none.

127  Già si solea con le spade far guerra;
128  ma or si fa togliendo or qui or quivi
129  lo pan che 'l pïo Padre a nessun serra.

130  Yet thou, who writest but to cancel, think
131  That Peter and that Paul, who for this vineyard
132  Which thou art spoiling died, are still alive!

130  Ma tu che sol per cancellare scrivi,
131  pensa che Pietro e Paulo, che moriro
132  per la vigna che guasti, ancor son vivi.

133  Well canst thou say: "So steadfast my desire
134  Is unto him who willed to live alone,
135  And for a dance was led to martyrdom,

133  Ben puoi tu dire: “I' ho fermo 'l disiro
134  sì a colui che volle viver solo
135  e che per salti fu tratto al martiro,

136  That I know not the Fisherman nor Paul."

136  ch'io non conosco il pescator né Polo.”

Canto XIX
Just as there is the protagonist Dante, the aspirant/pilgrim, and the poet Dante, the exile/nomad/mystic/lover/poet, there is this fight in the soul of the poem that plays out in Paradise as a conflict between the presentation of an astonishing spectacle backdropped by a dark philosophical didacticism.   This canto aims to answer some age-old bugaboos undermining the pretense of a just and merciful Christian God.  How can God, who is omniscient and all-good, on the basis of the historical or geographical conditions which He Himself has made, exclude souls from Heaven or condemn them to Hell?  The spectacles that we see and the love and joy that we feel in the Christian Paradise of the Commedia are transporting, and although they seem to render these insoluble philosophical doubts irrelevant, as the aspirant is overwhelmed by ecstatic wonder, these points, like a burr that has gotten under the skin of logic, keep re-festering.  On the surface, the Eagle's attempt to resolve them is just a reiteration of the Cyclonic God's bluster in the Book of Job, where the question of morality and justice is simply side-stepped.  All such impertinent questioning quails to a quivering insignificance when confronted by the Divine's awesome creative power.  Illogically, that power here is equated with an unassailable wisdom.  Here, the philosophical question of justice is simply blotted out by the glare of a blinding spectacle, the mere posing of the conundrum derided by the Eagle as a demonstration of the questioner's ignorance and the Divine's inscrutability.  This inscrutability is the twin of the theme of ineffability.  And if we present it as an attribute of the fight that we proposed at the beginning of this paragraph, then we see that what is being demonstrated here is that the very core of our being, and of beingness itself, is hidden, shrouded in darkness or obliterated by light, and it is the height of either arrogance or of naivite to attempt to express or explain it.  We are asked by the Eagle — a composite being, which, or rather who, is a Phoenix arising from the ruby lights of the souls of just rulers — to imagine Christian Justice as a geometrical figure, not in its outward shape, but in its movements, which form a circle.   The metaphor of drawing with a compass in verses 40 - 42 makes this clear, as do the reference to the circling stork in lines 91 - 93, and the wheeling ("roteando") Eagle in line 97.  Note too the dual avian references: a stork or birth emblem, and the raptor eagle, the potent enforcer.  The inner nature of the Phoenix is dynamic, and like true justice, assumes the role that is most required to achieve not only balance, but the intense joy that comes from this coherent harmony.  The intermingling of these composite joys is like the intermingling of a field of flowers (verses 22 - 24) to make one delicious perfume, this but one of many "hidden" operations of divine justice, which reveal what seems varied and even violently contradictory as a single melded exultation.  (For an contemporary materialistic and evolutionary exposition of how the trillions of cells and bacteria of a human body are able to operate in an apparent unity see Rodolfo R. Llinás' book i of the vortex: From Neurons to Self.)   Inside the  circumference this metaphorical circle is a shining darkness of impenetrable mystery, in Christian theology, this circle is curiously centered at the point of the historical birth of Jesus.  This mystery spot is assumed to be void of the consequences of suffering, pain, and death due to a likewise historical center of last judgement and salvation.  These two points are one: the birth of Jesus and this last judgement.  They are the famous center which is everywhere and whose circumference is nowhere.  Outside the membrane of this living cell is mere superfluity: incoherence, decoherence, dissonance, chaos, pox, plague — a superfluity incapable by its very placement as the other side of the line of the circle's circumference of ever entering the inner circle without destroying the very concept of completeness which the symbolic geometry of the circle embodies.  How astonishing to imagine that the essence of Judgment cannot be a moral or legal code, which essentially could not be anything other than a list of precepts, like the Mosaic Covenant of the Ten Commandments, but must instead be a geometric creation that defines, by means of its very spherical shape — Wholeness. (For an in depth 21st Century exploration of this idea, see Peter Sloterdijk's monumental trilogy Spheres.)  The question presented here is not merely psychological, but lies at the very heart of the epistemology of knowledge.  In this case, whatever falls outside of or at the obscure dot of the center is always beyond the domain of the knowable.  If we see here an analogy of the unknowable, inscrutable, and the ineffable, we might feel the uneasy encroachment of a mysterious shadow spreading forth from the light of the Christian trinity, not a squaring of the circle, but some sort of impossible to conceive Buckminster Fullerish triangulation of it.

I am aware that these comments go beyond anything explicitly stated in this canto, except as the overall inferences to be derived from the imagery and structural shapes of turning and counter-turning presented as the very armature of the poem.  Everything on the surface here is simply the orthodox Christian position regarding the nature of God's Judgements as they pertain to the salvation or damnation of Christian, pre-Christian, and un-Christian souls.  (Although in the next canto, we see that God is the arbiter of salvation, not God's Word or Law, and not time, circumstance, or geography, all of which, as the Eagle takes pains to relate, are circumstantial temporal issues, pertaining to God's Creation, which God Himself in his omnipotent, omniscient essence, far exceeds, and is not bound by.)  So, surely our experience of reading the poem invariably tempts us to consider that Dante is always a more subtle thinker than any surface reading suggests.  In brief, if the reader accepts this premise as a given, then peering into substructures and penumbras seems always to set the mind and heart, like the nomad/ exile of a true aspirant, into unexplored areas of speculation.  Perhaps Dante, the Christian, would be appalled by such blasphemies, but it may be that the more devious and questioning persona of Dante the poet would be intrigued by them.  My evidence for these speculations is tenuous, and admittedly based upon an unreasonable faith — as suggested here that the protagonist accept — that the unknowable, the inscrutable, and the ineffable can still be hinted at, if not overtly defined, by the very virtue that poetry — above physics, theology, psychology, cosmology, philosophy or history — can subtly suggest what cannot be overtly stated.  Its net of mists and vapors is aptly suited to caress into sound and image the unknowable, the inscrutable, and even the so-called ineffable. 

What is hidden from human view is embodied in the content and structure of this canto.  The song of the Eagle is unheard — like a dog whistle to a human.  Likewise, the litany of damnable kings is mostly presented in a paraphrastic fashion without in most case naming names.  This is the technique perhaps unique to poetry, and especially to Dante's mastery of the artful science of poetry, by which it also embodies ignorance, by which it implies that which is discoverable and that which is not.  And the acrostic of LVE beginning the tercets from verses 115 - 139 which spell "lue," that is, "plague" or "pox" are a way to show what is hidden, ineffable.  However, with the right tilt of vision or reading of the poem, indeed the ineffable can be read.  In this case it is read as political corruption, an infectious, fatal disease of running sores that from place to place, age to age, infects the ego-bound, arrogant political leaders in Dante's world, whose disease is both an inner and outer punishment which administers its own inherent justice not by means of a human agency of a prescribed and enforced set of laws, but rather by a the deep inner workings of conscience, whose operations are only discernable by those who have attained what has often been referred to as "Christ Consciousness."  So now we return to the spectacle, because the spectacle of the composite being is none other than that consciousness in which the truly, not merely "nominally," saved, enjoy in their oneness the cosmic joy of existence itself.

No one reaches the level of joy attained by the spirits in this canto without knowledge of Christ, and Dante, the aspirant, asks, "Is this just?"  The idea here is that even in our limited temporal life as a person, the essence of justice can manifest itself in our being, although not in our limited ideas about being.  By this means a person is Christed — a verb that denotes the realization of the joy of these just spirits.  Without this Christing, no person in their limited human — one might even say — animal self — for the human is an animal, but one which has forgone animal innocence in his arrogant ambition to contemplate the meanings and actions of the cosmos with only animal faculties — an animal endowed, in brief, with the distinguishing and abrogated features of guilt, of pride, and of shame.  No such person, infected with such attributes, can attain to the level of ecstasy which is expressed by the spirits in this canto who have willingly, even rationally, surrendered their human/animal concepts of justice to that greater, unknowable — from a human point of view — process of cosmic justice.  Here it might be better to say that Jesus is not the only one Christed, but rather one of any number of humans who have fully accepted his human self as One with the Divine.  Such a Christed human has stepped into that circle of joy whose center is everywhere and in every point inside himself, and whose circumference is everywhere manifested as another manifestation, however mysterious, of the Divine.  What this Divine "knows" is its joy, its brilliance, and its creative power, and it is this innate knowledge which allows the Divine to be Divine, to be the embodiment, the encyclopedia (encyclopedia means circle or circulation of wisdom) of all possible knowledge as the ever evolving and revolving expression of ITs love.  Inside this circle is salvation, outside it is damnation, and the line or membrane which defines the two domains is that verb Christed.  The Eagle in this canto uses this word, as the personhood of Christ, not the person of Jesus, although in their geometric motion they travel the same path and are thus one and the same.  What the Commedia illustrates here is that Justice has a boundary, a boundary which might be temporal — those born before the manifestation of the Christed person; or geographic — those born in a place where the possibility of the Christed person is unknown; or moral — those who by their own actions and beliefs have excluded themselves from the possibility of being Christed.  There is another idea inherent in this Christing, but one that in this canto is only inferred, which is, that from the human/animal side of the circle no movement towards inclusion is possible, that is human/animal justice is always tainted with the injustice of human/animal limitations.  So it is, that the grace of salvation, one's inclusion in this ecstatic circle, must always come about by the embrace of the Divine.  It is the cosmic Christed Self which is fit to judge because its Justice is the essence of its own being.  Justice alone knows the Just and Justice alone can include the human/animal as one with the human/Christed.  When the human qua animal abrogates the function of justice, that arrogance, that pride, however well-meaning, is always outside the circle, always a form of poxy incoherence.  Grace alone, that grace which is magnetically attracted by our humility, is the arbiter of a kind of Justice whose exultation is not infected by its opposite: injustice.  As far as Justice is concerned, our pride designates the limit of our perceptions.  Our pride puts us beyond the pale.  The Eagle/Phoenix gives the aspirant — and by extension — the reader, a dressing down, even a sort of humiliation, because it is only by surrendering our own human/animal concept of Justice that the soul may be included in that ever-circling, and always harmonizing light of composite, joyful unity.

1  Appeared before me with its wings outspread
2  The beautiful image that in sweet fruition
3  Made jubilant the interwoven souls;

1  Parea dinanzi a me con l'ali aperte
2  la bella image che nel dolce frui
3  liete facevan l'anime conserte;

4  Appeared a little ruby each, wherein
5  Ray of the sun was burning so enkindled
6  That each into mine eyes refracted it.

4  parea ciascuna rubinetto in cui
5  raggio di sole ardesse sì acceso,
6  che ne' miei occhi rifrangesse lui.

7  And what it now behoves me to retrace
8  Nor voice has e'er reported, nor ink written,
9  Nor was by fantasy e'er comprehended;

7  E quel che mi convien ritrar testeso,
8  non portò voce mai, né scrisse incostro,
9  né fu per fantasia già mai compreso;

10  For speak I saw, and likewise heard, the beak,
11  And utter with its voice both 'I' and 'My,'
12  When in conception it was 'We' and 'Our.'

10  ch'io vidi e anche udi' parlar lo rostro,
11  e sonar ne la voce e “io” e “mio,”
12  quand' era nel concetto e “noi” e “nostro.”

13  And it began: "Being just and merciful
14  Am I exalted here unto that glory
15  Which cannot be exceeded by desire;

13  E cominciò: “Per esser giusto e pio
14  son io qui essaltato a quella gloria
15  che non si lascia vincere a disio;

16  And upon earth I left my memory
17  Such, that the evil-minded people there
18  Commend it, but continue not the story."

16  e in terra lasciai la mia memoria
17  sì fatta, che le genti lì malvage
18  commendan lei, ma non seguon la storia.”

19  So doth a single heat from many embers
20  Make itself felt, even as from many loves
21  Issued a single sound from out that image.

19  Così un sol calor di molte brage
20  si fa sentir, come di molti amori
21  usciva solo un suon di quella image.

22  Whence I thereafter: "O perpetual flowers
23  Of the eternal joy, that only one
24  Make me perceive your odours manifold,

22  Ond' io appresso: “O perpetüi fiori
23  de l'etterna letizia, che pur uno
24  parer mi fate tutti vostri odori,

25  Exhaling, break within me the great fast
26  Which a long season has in hunger held me,
27  Not finding for it any food on earth.

25  solvetemi, spirando, il gran digiuno
26  che lungamente m'ha tenuto in fame,
27  non trovandoli in terra cibo alcuno.

28  Well do I know, that if in heaven its mirror
29  Justice Divine another realm doth make,
30  Yours apprehends it not through any veil.

28  Ben so io che, se 'n cielo altro reame
29  la divina giustizia fa suo specchio,
30  che 'l vostro non l'apprende con velame.

31  You know how I attentively address me
32  To listen; and you know what is the doubt
33  That is in me so very old a fast."

31  Sapete come attento io m'apparecchio
32  ad ascoltar; sapete qual è quello
33  dubbio che m'è digiun cotanto vecchio.”

34  Even as a falcon, issuing from his hood,
35  Doth move his head, and with his wings applaud him,
36  Showing desire, and making himself fine,

34  Quasi falcone ch'esce del cappello,
35  move la testa e con l'ali si plaude,
36  voglia mostrando e faccendosi bello,

37  Saw I become that standard, which of lauds
38  Was interwoven of the grace divine,
39  With such songs as he knows who there rejoices.

37  vid' io farsi quel segno, che di laude
38  de la divina grazia era contesto,
39  con canti quai si sa chi là sù gaude.

40  Then it began: "He who a compass turned
41  On the world's outer verge, and who within it
42  Devised so much occult and manifest,

40  Poi cominciò: “Colui che volse il sesto
41  a lo stremo del mondo, e dentro ad esso
42  distinse tanto occulto e manifesto,

43  Could not the impress of his power so make
44  On all the universe, as that his Word
45  Should not remain in infinite excess.

43  non poté suo valor sì fare impresso
44  in tutto l'universo, che 'l suo verbo
45  non rimanesse in infinito eccesso.

46  And this makes certain that the first proud being,
47  Who was the paragon of every creature,
48  By not awaiting light fell immature.

46  E ciò fa certo che 'l primo superbo,
47  che fu la somma d'ogne creatura,
48  per non aspettar lume, cadde acerbo;

49  And hence appears it, that each minor nature
50   Is scant receptacle unto that good
51  Which has no end, and by itself is measured.

49  e quinci appar ch'ogne minor natura
50  è corto recettacolo a quel bene
51  che non ha fine e sé con sé misura.

52  In consequence our vision, which perforce
53  Must be some ray of that intelligence
54  With which all things whatever are replete,

52  Dunque vostra veduta, che convene
53  essere alcun de' raggi de la mente
54  di che tutte le cose son ripiene,
55  Cannot in its own nature be so potent,
56  That it shall not its origin discern
57  Far beyond that which is apparent to it.

55  non pò da sua natura esser possente
56  tanto, che suo principio non discerna
57  molto di là da quel che l'è parvente.

58  Therefore into the justice sempiternal
59  The power of vision that your world receives,
60  As eye into the ocean, penetrates;

58  Però ne la giustizia sempiterna
59  la vista che riceve il vostro mondo,
60  com' occhio per lo mare, entro s'interna;

61  Which, though it see the bottom near the shore,
62  Upon the deep perceives it not, and yet
63  'Tis there, but it is hidden by the depth.

61  che, ben che da la proda veggia il fondo,
62  in pelago nol vede; e nondimeno
63  èli, ma cela lui l'esser profondo.

64  There is no light but comes from the serene
65  That never is o'ercast, nay, it is darkness
66  Or shadow of the flesh, or else its poison.

64  Lume non è, se non vien dal sereno
65  che non si turba mai; anzi è tenèbra
66  od ombra de la carne o suo veleno.

67  Amply to thee is opened now the cavern
68  Which has concealed from thee the living justice
69  Of which thou mad'st such frequent questioning.

67  Assai t'è mo aperta la latebra
68  che t'ascondeva la giustizia viva,
69  di che facei question cotanto crebra;

70  For saidst thou: 'Born a man is on the shore
71  Of Indus, and is none who there can speak
72  Of Christ, nor who can read, nor who can write;

70  ché tu dicevi: 'Un uom nasce a la riva
71  de l'Indo, e quivi non è chi ragioni
72  di Cristo né chi legga né chi scriva;

73  And all his inclinations and his actions
74  Are good, so far as human reason sees,
75  Without a sin in life or in discourse:

73  e tutti suoi voleri e atti buoni
74  sono, quanto ragione umana vede,
75  sanza peccato in vita o in sermoni.

76  He dieth unbaptised and without faith;
77  Where is this justice that condemneth him?
78  Where is his fault, if he do not believe?'

76  Muore non battezzato e sanza fede:
77  ov' è questa giustizia che 'l condanna?
77  ov' è la colpa sua, se ei non crede?'

79  Now who art thou, that on the bench wouldst sit
80  In judgment at a thousand miles away,
81  With the short vision of a single span?

79  Or tu chi se', che vuo' sedere a scranna,
80  per giudicar di lungi mille miglia
81  con la veduta corta d'una spanna?

82  Truly to him who with me subtilizes,
83  If so the Scripture were not over you,
84  For doubting there were marvellous occasion.

82  Certo a colui che meco s'assottiglia,
83  se la Scrittura sovra voi non fosse,
84  da dubitar sarebbe a maraviglia.

85  O animals terrene, O stolid minds,
86  The primal will, that in itself is good,
87  Ne'er from itself, the Good Supreme, has moved.

85  Oh terreni animali! oh menti grosse!
86  La prima volontà, ch'è da sé buona,
87  da sé, ch'è sommo ben, mai non si mosse.

88  So much is just as is accordant with it;
89  No good created draws it to itself,
89  But it, by raying forth, occasions that."

88  Cotanto è giusto quanto a lei consuona:
89  nullo creato bene a sé la tira,
90  ma essa, radïando, lui cagiona.”

91  Even as above her nest goes circling round
92  The stork when she has fed her little ones,
93  And he who has been fed looks up at her,

91  Quale sovresso il nido si rigira
92  poi c'ha pasciuti la cicogna i figli,
93  e come quel ch'è pasto la rimira;

94  So lifted I my brows, and even such
95  Became the blessed image, which its wings
96  Was moving, by so many counsels urged.

94  cotal si fece, e sì leväi i cigli,
95  la benedetta imagine, che l'ali
96  movea sospinte da tanti consigli.

97  Circling around it sang, and said: "As are
98  My notes to thee, who dost not comprehend them,
99  Such is the eternal judgment to you mortals."

97  Roteando cantava, e dicea: “Quali
98  son le mie note a te, che non le 'ntendi,
99  tal è il giudicio etterno a voi mortali.”

100  Those lucent splendours of the Holy Spirit
101  Grew quiet then, but still within the standard
102  That made the Romans reverend to the world.

100  Poi si quetaro quei lucenti incendi
101  de lo Spirito Santo ancor nel segno
102 che fé i Romani al mondo reverendi,

103  It recommenced: "Unto this kingdom never
104  Ascended one who had not faith in Christ,
105  Before or since he to the tree was nailed.

103  esso ricominciò: “A questo regno
104  non salì mai chi non credette 'n Cristo,
105  né pria né poi ch'el si chiavasse al legno.

106  But look thou, many crying are, 'Christ, Christ!'
107  Who at the judgment shall be far less near
108  To him than some shall be who knew not Christ.

106  Ma vedi: molti gridan 'Cristo, Cristo!'
107  che saranno in giudicio assai men prope
108  a lui, che tal che non conosce Cristo;

109  Such Christians shall the Ethiop condemn,
110  When the two companies shall be divided,
111  The one for ever rich, the other poor.

109  e tai Cristian dannerà l'Etïòpe,
110  quando si partiranno i due collegi,
111  l'uno in etterno ricco e l'altro inòpe.

112  What to your kings may not the Persians say,
113  When they that volume opened shall behold
114  In which are written down all their dispraises?

112  Che poran dir li Perse a' vostri regi,
113  come vedranno quel volume aperto
114  nel qual si scrivon tutti suoi dispregi?

116  There shall be seen, among the deeds of Albert,
117  That which ere long shall set the pen in motion,
118  For which the realm of Prague shall be deserted.

115  Lì si vedrà, tra l'opere d'Alberto,
116  quella che tosto moverà la penna,
117  per che 'l regno di Praga fia diserto.

118  There shall be seen the woe that on the Seine
119  He brings by falsifying of the coin,
120  Who by the blow of a wild boar shall die.

118  Lì si vedrà il duol che sovra Senna
119  induce, falseggiando la moneta,
120  quel che morrà di colpo di cotenna.

121  There shall be seen the pride that causes thirst,
122  Which makes the Scot and Englishman so mad
123  That they within their boundaries cannot rest;

121  Lì si vedrà la superbia ch'asseta,
122  che fa lo Scotto e l'Inghilese folle,
123  sì che non può soffrir dentro a sua meta.

124  Be seen the luxury and effeminate life
125  Of him of Spain, and the Bohemian,
126  Who valour never knew and never wished;

124  Vedrassi la lussuria e 'l viver molle
125  di quel di Spagna e di quel di Boemme,
126  che mai valor non conobbe né volle.

127  Be seen the Cripple of Jerusalem,
128  His goodness represented by an I,
129  While the reverse an M shall represent;

127  Vedrassi al Ciotto di Ierusalemme
128  segnata con un i la sua bontate,
129  quando 'l contrario segnerà un emme.

130  Be seen the avarice and poltroonery
131  Of him who guards the Island of the Fire,
132  Wherein Anchises finished his long life;

130  Vedrassi l'avarizia e la viltate
131  di quei che guarda l'isola del foco,
132  ove Anchise finì la lunga etate;

133  And to declare how pitiful he is
134  Shall be his record in contracted letters
135  Which shall make note of much in little space.

133  e a dare ad intender quanto è poco,
134  la sua scrittura fian lettere mozze,
135  che noteranno molto in parvo loco.

136  And shall appear to each one the foul deeds
137  Of uncle and of brother who a nation
138  So famous have dishonoured, and two crowns.

136  E parranno a ciascun l'opere sozze
137  del barba e del fratel, che tanto egregia
138  nazione e due corone han fatte bozze.

139  And he of Portugal and he of Norway
140  Shall there be known, and he of Rascia too,
141  Who saw in evil hour the coin of Venice.

139  E quel di Portogallo e di Norvegia
140  lì si conosceranno, e quel di Rascia
141  che male ha visto il conio di Vinegia.

142  O happy Hungary, if she let herself
143  Be wronged no farther! and Navarre the happy,
144  If with the hills that gird her she be armed!

142  O beata Ungheria, se non si lascia
143  più malmenare! e beata Navarra,
144  se s'armasse del monte che la fascia!

145  And each one may believe that now, as hansel
146  Thereof, do Nicosia and Famagosta
147  Lament and rage because of their own beast,

145  E creder de' ciascun che già, per arra
146  di questo, Niccosïa e Famagosta
147  per la lor bestia si lamenti e garra,

148  Who from the others' flank departeth not."

148  che dal fianco de l'altre non si scosta.”

Canto XX
And he said unto them: wheresoever the body is, thither will be eagles gathered together.

Luke 17: 37.

Justice, human; Justice, Divine; Geometry as absolute proportionality; Geometry as a juxtaposition of propinquity and distance; where is this in relation to where is that; the question of the specificities and contingencies of places and times, whose fixity seems deterministic, even in a legal sense, as natural and moral laws; and the question of the ubiquity of a unified intelligence of a cosmic Mind.  This canto tells us that Divine Justice is not bound by contingencies, and is not that which is defined as a pair of opposites: Just and Unjust.  Dante's poem knows more than Dante's person.  That is a shock, since a poem by human logic is the product of its poet.  But the reverse is true, and must be true, otherwise the poet would learn nothing from his own inspiration/intuition, and in an analogous sense, human justice can never be the arbiter of Divine Justice, for it is the later which must always inform the former by virtue, not of what we deduce what should be, but as we perceive what is.  That the eagle is the composite vision of all those who have, in various places and times, imagined and executed that which they intuit is just.  Yet even if we compound all these visions together, their total composite can still not penetrate the unfathomable, for it is out of that depth that the virtues of their justice emerge, so it can never be their own vision, however far-seeing and acute, which can ever create that depth.  Divine Justice may create contingencies from its own will, but can never be bound by those contingencies which it has created.  In this canto we see how that Divine Justice has created impossible events in violation of theological precepts and Natural Laws.  Geometrically speaking, it — or HE — has gone beyond the boundaries which HE has set for his creatures in creation, because his criteria for creativity are as infinite as is HE, and his freedom to employ that creativity is Just because it is absolute and inviolable.  This is why both in the Book of Job and in the previous canto the Divine Will insists that Justice is not a moral code of right and wrong, just and unjust, but is the product of this absolute creative freedom.  Another way to say this is that everything we see and name as an instance of justice has its ultimate source, not in law, which is both blind and binding, but in this creative freedom.

This canto is about focus, the metaphor: the eye of the eagle, which contains the 6 spirits of the just rulers — exposited in 36 verses, in 6 tercets, each of 6 lines.  These are arranged in a five-pointed arc, which define the top of the eye, symmetrically placed atop the pupil of the eye, which is the pre-Christian: King David.  The figures are not arranged chronologically, and in fact neither the logic of historical time, nor even the logic that the exemplars devoted to just rulers would all be rulers, or even real people in history.  The rulers are Trajan, because he showed mercy on a humble widow; Hezekiah, because he was penitent; Constantine, because he had good intentions, although according to Dante his gift of lands to the Church initiated centuries of ecclesiastical corruption and the church's usurpation of temporal power; William the Good, who died young, but was mourned as a just ruler; and most astonishing of all, Ripheus, the Trojan, a character mentioned only briefly in Virgil's Aeneid.  None of these, according the Eagle's pronouncements in the previous canto, with the possible exception of Constantine, have any business being in Paradise.  But they're here in what only can be described as the most bizarre and miraculous of circumstances, circumstances which include death, resurrection, the backwards looping of the arrow of time, and in the case of Ripheus, the canonization of a fictional person who was pagan, not a ruler, and like William the Good, not famous (as a previous Paradiso canto asserts that he should be.)!  The reader's focus here is totally blurred when it comes to any temporal, logical — should we say "just,"  explanation, and must instead be fixed  upon God's creative freedom.  This creative freedom is what makes His justice alone infallible, although inscrutable.  Why? Because, as stated above, His justice alone is rooted in his absolute freedom to rise above the rules He has created to govern his universe.  As artists, as readers, as souls trapped in temporal bodies which are subject to physical laws, this should make us whoop for joy, since that part of us which, as we are made in God's image, and so is able to create, is not bound by our past decisions, and is free in every moment to do and be that which in its previous actions, thoughts, and feelings would have been impossible, except for this ability that we each have to enact, against all conditions, the absolutely miraculous.  It should be pointed out here that the Dante who wrote the humanly inconceivable Commedia is a wondrous example of this freedom, and in spite of all the judgements the poem — not the poet —has made, aesthetically it is just, because it is an effort wherein a mere human being has allowed himself to be infused by an inspiration, which can hardly, even in our atheistic condition, be read as anything but Divine.

1  When he who all the world illuminates
2  Out of our hemisphere so far descends
3  That on all sides the daylight is consumed,

1  Quando colui che tutto 'l mondo alluma
2  de l'emisperio nostro sì discende,
3 che 'l giorno d'ogne parte si consuma,

4  The heaven, that erst by him alone was kindled,
5  Doth suddenly reveal itself again
6  By many lights, wherein is one resplendent.

4  lo ciel, che sol di lui prima s'accende,
5  subitamente si rifà parvente
6  per molte luci, in che una risplende;

7  And came into my mind this act of heaven,
8  When the ensign of the world and of its leaders
9  Had silent in the blessed beak become;

7  e questo atto del ciel mi venne a mente,
8  come 'l segno del mondo e de' suoi duci
9  nel benedetto rostro fu tacente;

10  Because those living luminaries all,
11  By far more luminous, did songs begin
12  Lapsing and falling from my memory.

10  però che tutte quelle vive luci,
11  vie più lucendo, cominciaron canti
12  da mia memoria labili e caduci.

13  O gentle Love, that with a smile dost cloak thee,
14  How ardent in those sparks didst thou appear,
15  That had the breath alone of holy thoughts!

13  O dolce amor che di riso t'ammanti,
14  quanto parevi ardente in que' flailli,
15  ch'avieno spirto sol di pensier santi!

16  After the precious and pellucid crystals,
17  With which begemmed the sixth light I beheld,
18  Silence imposed on the angelic bells,

16  Poscia che i cari e lucidi lapilli
17  ond' io vidi ingemmato il sesto lume
18  puoser silenzio a li angelici squilli,

19  I seemed to hear the murmuring of a river
20  That clear descendeth down from rock to rock,
21  Showing the affluence of its mountain-top.

19  udir mi parve un mormorar di fiume
20  che scende chiaro giù di pietra in pietra,
21  mostrando l'ubertà del suo cacume.

22  And as the sound upon the cithern's neck
23  Taketh its form, and as upon the vent
24  Of rustic pipe the wind that enters it,

22  E come suono al collo de la cetra
23  prende sua forma, e sì com' al pertugio
24  de la sampogna vento che penètra,

25  Even thus, relieved from the delay of waiting,
26  That murmuring of the eagle mounted up
27  Along its neck, as if it had been hollow.

25  così, rimosso d'aspettare indugio,
26  quel mormorar de l'aguglia salissi
27  su per lo collo, come fosse bugio.

28  There it became a voice, and issued thence
29  From out its beak, in such a form of words
30   As the heart waited for wherein I wrote them.

28  Fecesi voce quivi, e quindi uscissi
29  per lo suo becco in forma di parole,
30  quali aspettava il core ov' io le scrissi.

31  "The part in me which sees and bears the sun
32  In mortal eagles," it began to me,
33  "Now fixedly must needs be looked upon;

31  “La parte in me che vede e pate il sole
32  ne l'aguglie mortali,” incominciommi,
33  “or fisamente riguardar si vole,

34  For of the fires of which I make my figure,
35  Those whence the eye doth sparkle in my head
36  Of all their orders the supremest are.

34  perché d'i fuochi ond' io figura fommi,
35  quelli onde l'occhio in testa mi scintilla,
36  e' di tutti lor gradi son li sommi.
37  He who is shining in the midst as pupil
38  Was once the singer of the Holy Spirit,
39  Who bore the ark from city unto city;

37  Colui che luce in mezzo per pupilla,
38  fu il cantor de lo Spirito Santo,
39  che l'arca traslatò di villa in villa:

40  Now knoweth he the merit of his song,
41  In so far as effect of his own counsel,
42  By the reward which is commensurate.

40  ora conosce il merto del suo canto,
41  in quanto effetto fu del suo consiglio,
42  per lo remunerar ch'è altrettanto.

43  Of five, that make a circle for my brow,
44  He that approacheth nearest to my beak
45  Did the poor widow for her son console;

43  Dei cinque che mi fan cerchio per ciglio,
44  colui che più al becco mi s'accosta,
45  la vedovella consolò del figlio:

46  Now knoweth he how dearly it doth cost
47  Not following Christ, by the experience
48  Of this sweet life and of its opposite.

46  ora conosce quanto caro costa
47  non seguir Cristo, per l'esperïenza
48  di questa dolce vita e de l'opposta.

49  He who comes next in the circumference
50  Of which I speak, upon its highest arc,
51  Did death postpone by penitence sincere;

49  E quel che segue in la circunferenza
49  di che ragiono, per l'arco superno,
50  morte indugiò per vera penitenza:

52  Now knoweth he that the eternal judgment
53  Suffers no change, albeit worthy prayer
54  Maketh below to-morrow of to-day.

52  ora conosce che 'l giudicio etterno
53  non si trasmuta, quando degno preco
54  fa crastino là giù de l'odïerno.

55  The next who follows, with the laws and me,
56  Under the good intent that bore bad fruit
57  Became a Greek by ceding to the pastor;

55  L'altro che segue, con le leggi e meco,
56  sotto buona intenzion che fé mal frutto,
57  per cedere al pastor si fece greco:

58  Now knoweth he how all the ill deduced
59  From his good action is not harmful to him,
60  Although the world thereby may be destroyed.

58  ora conosce come il mal dedutto
59  dal suo bene operar non li è nocivo,
60  avvegna che sia 'l mondo indi distrutto.

61  And he, whom in the downward arc thou seest,
62  Guglielmo was, whom the same land deplores
63  That weepeth Charles and Frederick yet alive;

61  E quel che vedi ne l'arco declivo,
62  Guiglielmo fu, cui quella terra plora
63  che piagne Carlo e Federigo vivo:

64  Now knoweth he how heaven enamoured is
65  With a just king; and in the outward show
66  Of his effulgence he reveals it still.

64  ora conosce come s'innamora
65  lo ciel del giusto rege, e al sembiante
66  del suo fulgore il fa vedere ancora.

67  Who would believe, down in the errant world,
68  That e'er the Trojan Ripheus in this round
69  Could be the fifth one of the holy lights?

67  Chi crederebbe giù nel mondo errante
68  che Rifëo Troiano in questo tondo
69  fosse la quinta de le luci sante?

70  Now knoweth he enough of what the world
71  Has not the power to see of grace divine,
72  Although his sight may not discern the bottom."

70  Ora conosce assai di quel che 'l mondo
71  veder non può de la divina grazia,
72  ben che sua vista non discerna il fondo.”

73  Like as a lark that in the air expatiates,
74   First singing and then silent with content
75  Of the last sweetness that doth satisfy her,

73  Quale allodetta che 'n aere si spazia
74  prima cantando, e poi tace contenta
75  de l'ultima dolcezza che la sazia,

76  Such seemed to me the image of the imprint
77  Of the eternal pleasure, by whose will
78  Doth everything become the thing it is.

76  tal mi sembiò l'imago de la 'mprenta
77  de l'etterno piacere, al cui disio
78  ciascuna cosa qual ell' è diventa.

79  And notwithstanding to my doubt I was
80  As glass is to the colour that invests it,
81  To wait the time in silence it endured not,

79  E avvegna ch'io fossi al dubbiar mio
80  lì quasi vetro a lo color ch'el veste,
81  tempo aspettar tacendo non patio,

82  But forth from out my mouth, "What things are these?"
83  Extorted with the force of its own weight;
84  Whereat I saw great joy of coruscation.

82  ma de la bocca, “Che cose son queste?”
83  mi pinse con la forza del suo peso:
84  per ch'io di coruscar vidi gran feste.

85  Thereafterward with eye still more enkindled
86  The blessed standard made to me reply,
87  To keep me not in wonderment suspended:

85  Poi appresso, con l'occhio più acceso,
86  lo benedetto segno mi rispuose
87  per non tenermi in ammirar sospeso:

88  "I see that thou believest in these things
89  Because I say them, but thou seest not how;
90  So that, although believed in, they are hidden.

88  “Io veggio che tu credi queste cose
89  perch' io le dico, ma non vedi come;
90  si che, se son credute, sono ascose.

90  Thou doest as he doth who a thing by name
91  Well apprehendeth, but its quiddity
92  Cannot perceive, unless another show it.

90  Fai come quei che la cosa per nome
91 apprende ben, ma la sua quiditate
92  veder non può se altri non la prome.

94  'Regnum coelorum' suffereth violence
95  From fervent love, and from that living hope
96  That overcometh the Divine volition;

94  Regnum celorum vïolenza pate
95  da caldo amore e da viva speranza,
96  che vince la divina volontate:

97  Not in the guise that man o'ercometh man,
98  But conquers it because it will be conquered,
99  And conquered conquers by benignity.

97  non a guisa che l'omo a l'om sobranza,
98  ma vince lei perché vuole esser vinta,
99  e, vinta, vince con sua beninanza.

100  The first life of the eyebrow and the fifth
101  Cause thee astonishment, because with them
102  Thou seest the region of the angels painted.

100  La prima vita del ciglio e la quinta
101  ti fa maravigliar, perché ne vedi
102  la regïon de li angeli dipinta.

103  They passed not from their bodies, as thou thinkest,
104  Gentiles, but Christians in the steadfast faith
105  Of feet that were to suffer and had suffered.

103  D'i corpi suoi non uscir, come credi,
104  Gentili, ma Cristiani, in ferma fede
105  quel d'i passuri e quel d'i passi piedi.

106  For one from Hell, where no one e'er turns back
107  Unto good will, returned unto his bones,
108  And that of living hope was the reward,—

106  Ché l'una de lo 'nferno, u' non si riede
107  già mai a buon voler, tornò a l'ossa;
108  e ciò di viva spene fu mercede:

109  Of living hope, that placed its efficacy
110  In prayers to God made to resuscitate him,
111  So that 'twere possible to move his will.

109  di viva spene, che mise la possa
110  ne' prieghi fatti a Dio per suscitarla,
111 sì che potesse sua voglia esser mossa.

112  The glorious soul concerning which I speak,
113  Returning to the flesh, where brief its stay,
114  Believed in Him who had the power to aid it;

112  L'anima glorïosa onde si parla,
113  tornata ne la carne, in che fu poco,
114  credette in lui che potëa aiutarla;

115  And, in believing, kindled to such fire
116  Of genuine love, that at the second death
117  Worthy it was to come unto this joy.

115  e credendo s'accese in tanto foco
116  di vero amor, ch'a la morte seconda
117  fu degna di venire a questo gioco.

118  The other one, through grace, that from so deep
119  A fountain wells that never hath the eye
120  Of any creature reached its primal wave

118  L'altra, per grazia che da sì profonda
119  fontana stilla, che mai creatura
120  non pinse l'occhio infino a la prima onda,

121  Set all his love below on righteousness;
122  Wherefore from grace to grace did God unclose
123  His eye to our redemption yet to be,

121  tutto suo amor là giù pose a drittura:
122  per che, di grazia in grazia, Dio li aperse
123  l'occhio a la nostra redenzion futura;

124   Whence he believed therein, and suffered not
125  From that day forth the stench of paganism,
126  And he reproved therefor the folk perverse.

124  ond' ei credette in quella, e non sofferse
125  da indi il puzzo più del paganesmo;
126 e riprendiene le genti perverse.

127  Those Maidens three, whom at the right-hand wheel
128  Thou didst behold, were unto him for baptism
129  More than a thousand years before baptizing.

127  Quelle tre donne li fur per battesmo
128  che tu vedesti da la destra rota,
129  dinanzi al battezzar più d'un millesmo.

130  O thou predestination, how remote
131  Thy root is from the aspect of all those
132  Who the First Cause do not behold entire!

130  O predestinazion, quanto remota
131  è la radice tua da quelli aspetti
132  che la prima cagion non veggion tota!

133  And you, O mortals! hold yourselves restrained
134  In judging; for ourselves, who look on God,
135  We do not know as yet all the elect;

133  E voi, mortali, tenetevi stretti
134  a giudicar: ché noi, che Dio vedemo,
135  non conosciamo ancor tutti li eletti;

136  And sweet to us is such a deprivation,
137  Because our good in this good is made perfect,
138  That whatsoe'er God wills, we also will."

136  ed ènne dolce così fatto scemo,
137  perché il ben nostro in questo ben s'affina,
138  che quel che vole Iddio, e noi volemo.”

139  After this manner by that shape divine,
140  To make clear in me my short-sightedness,
141  Was given to me a pleasant medicine;

139  Così da quella imagine divina,
140  per farmi chiara la mia corta vista,
141  data mi fu soave medicina.

142  And as good singer a good lutanist
144  Accompanies with vibrations of the chords,
145  Whereby more pleasantness the song acquires,

142  E come a buon cantor buon citarista
143  fa seguitar lo guizzo de la corda,
144  in che più di piacer lo canto acquista,

145  So, while it spake, do I remember me
146  That I beheld both of those blessed lights,
147  Even as the winking of the eyes concords,

145  sì, mentre ch'e' parlò, sì mi ricorda
146  ch'io vidi le due luci benedette,
147  pur come batter d'occhi si concorda,

148  Moving unto the words their little flames.

148  con le parole mover le fiammette.

Canto XXI
The heaven of Saturn has two properties by which it may be compared to Astrology: one is the slowness of its movement through the 12 signs, for according to the writings of the astrologers, a time of more than 29 years is required for its revolution; the other is that it is high above all the other planets.  And these two properties are found in Astrology: for in completing its circle (that is to say, to master this science) a very great span of time passes, both because of its handmaids, which are more numerous than those of any of the above-mentioned sciences, and because of the experience required in it for making proper judgments.  Furthermore, it is far higher than all the others, since, as Aristotle says at the beginning of On the Soul, a science is high in nobility by virtue of the nobility of its subject and by virtue of its certainty; and this one, more than any of those mentioned above, is high and noble because of its high and noble subject, which regards the movement of the heaven, and high and noble because of its certainty, which is flawless, as coming from a most perfect and regular principle.  And if anyone believes that there is a flaw in it, it does not pertain to the science, but as Ptolemy says, it results from our negligence, and so must be attributed to that.

Convivio, Chapter 13 

A canto of contemplation, which is something different than meditation, in that contemplation directs the subjective self to an unfathomable object — that object to Dante, which is most unfathomable, is God.  Suppose there are two directions in which one might turn one's mind, desires, and activities.  In one direction the mind and heart pursue a temporal object to satiate a temporal aspiration for the subjective temporal self.  These objects might be such things sensual enjoyment, power, prestige, admiration, expertise, skill, and so forth.  Beauty too can fall into this category, with the caveat that what we're talking about in the sensory temporal world is a type of beauty subject to the temporal laws of accident, blooming and decay.  The other direction in which one might turn one's mind is towards that which is infinite, is not subject to temporal process, and is always opening horizons steeped with a second kind of more dangerous beauty, the kind of beauty of perpetual, unattainable allure, the kind of contemplation which swallows up the contemplative, and may very well immolate his temporal self in an atemporal vision.  This kind of contemplation can fix one in an incommunicable fanaticism, set one on a course of martyrdom and world denial, or, if the contemplative remains steadfast and understands the limitation that there can be no possible temporal fulfillment of his quest, then, one becomes like Peter Damian and his cohorts here, eaten away by an intense — and for mortals — an intolerable joy.  Those in this 7th heaven, the heaven of Saturn, the heaven of contemplation on the highest and noblest of things, have become so like the object of their contemplation that their own subjectivity is consumed.  We know this here, because Peter Damian corrects Dante by telling him that it was not a personal affection for Dante which impelled his actions, but rather an impulse for the Infinite.  From the point of view of a temporal human, the spirits in the this sphere have become, in the slow maturation process of Saturn's slowly completed orbit, inhuman presences, their songs inaudible, their bodies bolts of lightning.

Ecstasy is a shock to the system, and this is especially so for those who attain it too suddenly without some long tempering process wherein its intensities can be absorbed piecemeal, and not brought on in a rush, like a surge of electricity in a circuit incapable of handling its load.  This great sphere of Saturn is a great buffering zone against any such sudden shock.  Saturn is slow, deliberate, the father of long contemplations, and disciplined processes, which dilute the hallucinogens of its soul-medicinals into small acceptable doses.  We may think we all long for bliss, and that all our actions, thoughts, and emotions are devoted to achieving that end, but anyone who has experienced even the smallest portion of this expansive condition, will know with what alacrity we retreat from its realization.  Which is why, I would guess, that less hardy souls are content to wallow interminably in the self-tortures of Hell in preference to the self-abnegating joys of heaven, whose high harmonies and celestial lights, as this canto makes clear, would quickly annihilate the uninitiated.  I cannot think of a canto in which the aspirant Dante is more mature in spirit, or one in which he is more childlike in his acceptance.  This is illustrated in his readiness to forego what for him has been his most supreme joy, and his one sure validation of the truth — the beautiful visage of Beatrice, polestar of his love and life, a joy which for the first time here he forgoes for a higher yet much more subtle and more difficult to attain condition, that is: obedience.

I have pondered over this canto for many days, having read and mentally rehearsed what I wanted to say about it.  I have taken long walks trying to arrange my thoughts about it.  I have studied the Western commentary tradition, and read some of Peter Damian's letters.  I have even discovered that he wrote about the stages of the ladder of contemplation, and I have discovered how the commentators have made the obvious connection between the ladder we see here and Jacob's ladder in the Bible.  I have read too what an Eastern commentator steeped in meditative practice had to say about what Doctor Lee Sannella calls the physio-kundalini process, and how this ladder is equated with the spine, and how this process opens the cerebrospinal centers of the chakras, which leads to the ecstatic state shown here.  But every time I think I am ready to tackle these notes, my mind and emotions are captured by the process this canto expresses, and I am carried away on my own flights to infinity.  I have been slowed to the speed of the throne of Saturn, the father of time infecting me with his timelessness.  Dante is up to his old tricks here, his bird metaphors of how jackdaws, rise, wheel, flock, some departing on their own, some returning to their perches, and we recall the other times he has used birds as a way to express processes of the spirit.  Peter's denunciation of the corruption of church officials is also familiar, and the rich fur acting as the skin which covers the two beasts of horse and man is another in a long line of brilliant depictions, which succinctly use a powerful image to brand the readers mind with an indelible impression.  Even the amazing move from undetectable song which seems but a silence to the aspirant to a sound so loud at the conclusion of the canto that it also exceeds the capacity of the aspirant's hearing to absorb it — all of this is wrought clearly and exquisitely in Dante's usual, incomparable poetic fashion.  But for me, the deeper effect of this canto is that it actually has seemed to facilitate the transference of the ecstatic state from Peter Damian, through Dante and his remarkable verse, to a brain state, which for me, the reader, is akin to those elsewhere expressed as kundalini-arousing phenomenon.  Here Dante takes his art to a new level.  The commentator-tradition does not mention this transference, but for some readers no doubt a miraculous thing is beginning to occur here, which is perfectly analogous to the situation described in this canto.  By contemplating the words here, we ourselves do not just experience a description of the psychical-physiological state of the spirits in this canto, but find ourselves entrained, spellbound, to the slowly unwinding swiftly transcending condition that is not only expressed by the verse, but which is embodied in it.  Yes, creature can never be more than Creator, but by contemplating the Creator's creation, the creature begins to take on more and more of the Creator's  ecstatic life and love.  And here, just as we rise to the last, and seventh Heaven, we succumb to something new in the process of reading, and begin to experience what the aspirant inside the poem is experiencing.  Our momentum up to now has been an acceleration of ground speed, but we are changing now to air speed, we are beginning the flight from our temporal to our atemporal selves.  I know there are more canti left to read, a further ascent in store for us, but I am content to be here.  And if the poem ended with this Big Bang of the last verses of this canto, I feel I could happily live indefinitely in the stunning aftershock of this primal sound.     


1  Already on my Lady's face mine eyes
2  Again were fastened, and with these my mind,
3  And from all other purpose was withdrawn;

1  Già eran li occhi miei rifissi al volto
2  de la mia donna, e l'animo con essi,
3  e da ogne altro intento s'era tolto.

4  And she smiled not; but "If I were to smile,"
5  She unto me began, "thou wouldst become
6  Like Semele, when she was turned to ashes.

4  E quella non ridea; ma “S'io ridessi,”
5  mi cominciò, “tu ti faresti quale
6  fu Semelè quando di cener fessi:

7  Because my beauty, that along the stairs
8  Of the eternal palace more enkindles,
9  As thou hast seen, the farther we ascend,

7  ché la bellezza mia, che per le scale
8  de l'etterno palazzo più s'accende,
9  com' hai veduto, quanto più si sale,

10  If it were tempered not, is so resplendent
11  That all thy mortal power in its effulgence
12  Would seem a leaflet that the thunder crushes.

10  se non si temperasse, tanto splende,
11  che 'l tuo mortal podere, al suo fulgore,
12  sarebbe fronda che trono scoscende.

13  We are uplifted to the seventh splendour,
14  That underneath the burning Lion's breast
15  Now radiates downward mingled with his power.

13  Noi sem levati al settimo splendore,
14  che sotto 'l petto del Leone ardente
15  raggia mo misto giù del suo valore.

16  Fix in direction of thine eyes the mind,
17  And make of them a mirror for the figure
18  That in this mirror shall appear to thee."

16  Ficca di retro a li occhi tuoi la mente,
17  e fa di quelli specchi a la figura
18  che 'n questo specchio ti sarà parvente.”

19  He who could know what was the pasturage
20  My sight had in that blessed countenance,
21  When I transferred me to another care,

19  Qual savesse qual era la pastura
20  del viso mio ne l'aspetto beato
21  quand' io mi trasmutai ad altra cura,

22  Would recognize how grateful was to me
23  Obedience unto my celestial escort,
24  By counterpoising one side with the other.

22  conoscerebbe quanto m'era a grato
23  ubidire a la mia celeste scorta,
24  contrapesando l'un con l'altro lato.

25  Within the crystal which, around the world
26  Revolving, bears the name of its dear leader,
27  Under whom every wickedness lay dead,

25  Dentro al cristallo che 'l vocabol porta,
26  cerchiando il mondo, del suo caro duce
27  sotto cui giacque ogne malizia morta,

28  Coloured like gold, on which the sunshine gleams,
29  A stairway I beheld to such a height
30  Uplifted, that mine eye pursued it not.

28  di color d'oro in che raggio traluce
29  vid' io uno scaleo eretto in suso
30  tanto, che nol seguiva la mia luce.

31  Likewise beheld I down the steps descending
32  So many splendours, that I thought each light
33  That in the heaven appears was there diffused.

31  Vidi anche per li gradi scender giuso
32  tanti splendor, ch'io pensai ch'ogne lume
33  che par nel ciel, quindi fosse diffuso.

34  And as accordant with their natural custom
35  The rooks together at the break of day
36  Bestir themselves to warm their feathers cold;

34  E come, per lo natural costume,
35  le pole insieme, al cominciar del giorno,
36  si movono a scaldar le fredde piume;

37  Then some of them fly off without return,
38  Others come back to where they started from,
39  And others, wheeling round, still keep at home;

37  poi altre vanno via sanza ritorno,
38  altre rivolgon sé onde son mosse,
39  e altre roteando fan soggiorno;

40  Such fashion it appeared to me was there
41  Within the sparkling that together came,
42  As soon as on a certain step it struck,

40  tal modo parve me che quivi fosse
41  in quello sfavillar che 'nsieme venne,
42  sì come in certo grado si percosse.

43  And that which nearest unto us remained
44  Became so clear, that in my thought I said,
45  "Well I perceive the love thou showest me;

43  E quel che presso più ci si ritenne,
44  si fé sì chiaro, ch'io dicea pensando:
45  “Io veggio ben l'amor che tu m'accenne.

46  But she, from whom I wait the how and when
47  Of speech and silence, standeth still; whence I
48  Against desire do well if I ask not."

46  Ma quella ond' io aspetto il come e 'l quando
47  del dire e del tacer, si sta; ond' io,
48  contra 'l disio, fo ben ch'io non dimando.”

49  She thereupon, who saw my silentness
50  In the sight of Him who seeth everything,
51  Said unto me, "Let loose thy warm desire."

49  Per ch'ella, che vedëa il tacer mio
50  nel veder di colui che tutto vede,
51  mi disse: “Solvi il tuo caldo disio.”

52  And I began: "No merit of my own
53  Renders me worthy of response from thee;
54  But for her sake who granteth me the asking,

52  E io incominciai: “La mia mercede
53  non mi fa degno de la tua risposta;
54  ma per colei che 'l chieder mi concede,

55  Thou blessed life that dost remain concealed
56  In thy beatitude, make known to me
57  The cause which draweth thee so near my side;

55  vita beata che ti stai nascosta
56  dentro a la tua letizia, fammi nota
57  la cagion che sì presso mi t'ha posta;

58  And tell me why is silent in this wheel
59  The dulcet symphony of Paradise,
60  That through the rest below sounds so devoutly."

58  e dì perché si tace in questa rota
59  la dolce sinfonia di paradiso,
60  che giù per l'altre suona sì divota.”

61  "Thou hast thy hearing mortal as thy sight,"
62  It answer made to me; "they sing not here,
63  For the same cause that Beatrice has not smiled.

61  “Tu hai l'udir mortal sì come il viso,”
62   rispuose a me; “onde qui non si canta
63  per quel che Bëatrice non ha riso.

64  Thus far adown the holy stairway's steps
65  Have I descended but to give thee welcome
66  With words, and with the light that mantles me;

64  Giù per li gradi de la scala santa
65  discesi tanto sol per farti festa
66  col dire e con la luce che mi ammanta;

67  Nor did more love cause me to be more ready,
68  For love as much and more up there is burning,
69  As doth the flaming manifest to thee.

67  né più amor mi fece esser più presta,
68  ché più e tanto amor quinci sù ferve,
69  sì come il fiammeggiar ti manifesta.

70  But the high charity, that makes us servants
71  Prompt to the counsel which controls the world,
72  Allotteth here, even as thou dost observe."

70  Ma l'alta carità, che ci fa serve
71  pronte al consiglio che 'l mondo governa,
72  sorteggia qui sì come tu osserve.”

73  "I see full well," said I, "O sacred lamp!
74  How love unfettered in this court sufficeth
75  To follow the eternal Providence;

73  “Io veggio ben,” diss' io, “sacra lucerna,
74  come libero amore in questa corte
75  basta a seguir la provedenza etterna;

76  But this is what seems hard for me to see,
77  Wherefore predestinate wast thou alone
78  Unto this office from among thy consorts."

76  ma questo è quel ch'a cerner mi par forte,
77  perché predestinata fosti sola
78  a questo officio tra le tue consorte.”

79  No sooner had I come to the last word,
80  Than of its middle made the light a centre,
81  Whirling itself about like a swift millstone.

79  Né venni prima a l'ultima parola,
80  che del suo mezzo fece il lume centro,
81  girando sé come veloce mola;

82  When answer made the love that was therein:
83  "On me directed is a light divine,
84  Piercing through this in which I am embosomed,

82  poi rispuose l'amor che v'era dentro:
83 “Luce divina sopra me s'appunta,
84   penetrando per questa in ch'io m'inventro,

85  Of which the virtue with my sight conjoined
86  Lifts me above myself so far, I see
87  The supreme essence from which this is drawn.

85  la cui virtù, col mio veder congiunta,
86  mi leva sopra me tanto, ch'i' veggio
87  la somma essenza de la quale è munta.

88  Hence comes the joyfulness with which I flame,
89  For to my sight, as far as it is clear,
90  The clearness of the flame I equal make.

88  Quinci vien l'allegrezza ond' io fiammeggio;
89  per ch'a la vista mia, quant' ella è chiara,
90  la chiarità de la fiamma pareggio.

91  But that soul in the heaven which is most pure,
92  That seraph which his eye on God most fixes,
93  Could this demand of thine not satisfy;

91  Ma quell' alma nel ciel che più si schiara,
92  quel serafin che 'n Dio più l'occhio ha fisso,
93  a la dimanda tua non satisfara, 

94  Because so deeply sinks in the abyss
95  Of the eternal statute what thou askest,
96  From all created sight it is cut off.

94  però che sì s'innoltra ne lo abisso
