95  de l'etterno statuto quel che chiedi,
96  che da ogne creata vista è scisso.

97  And to the mortal world, when thou returnest,
98  This carry back, that it may not presume
99  Longer tow'rd such a goal to move its feet.

97  E al mondo mortal, quando tu riedi,
98  questo rapporta, sì che non presumma
99  a tanto segno più mover li piedi.

100  The mind, that shineth here, on earth doth smoke;
101  From this observe how can it do below
102  That which it cannot though the heaven assume it?"

100  La mente, che qui luce, in terra fumma;
101  onde riguarda come può là giùe
102  quel che non pote perché 'l ciel l'assumma.”

103  Such limit did its words prescribe to me,
104  The question I relinquished, and restricted
105  Myself to ask it humbly who it was.

103  Sì mi prescrisser le parole sue,
104  ch'io lasciai la quistione e mi ritrassi
105  a dimandarla umilmente chi fue.

106  "Between two shores of Italy rise cliffs,
107  And not far distant from thy native place,
108  So high, the thunders far below them sound,

106  “Tra ' due liti d'Italia surgon sassi,
107  e non molto distanti a la tua patria,
108  tanto che ' troni assai suonan più bassi,

109  And form a ridge that Catria is called,
110  'Neath which is consecrate a hermitage
111  Wont to be dedicate to worship only."

109  e fanno un gibbo che si chiama Catria,
110  di sotto al quale è consecrato un ermo,
111  che suole esser disposto a sola latria.”

112  Thus unto me the third speech recommenced,
113  And then, continuing, it said: "Therein
114  Unto God's service I became so steadfast,

112  Così ricominciommi il terzo sermo;
113  e poi, continüando, disse: “Quivi
114  al servigio di Dio mi fe' sì fermo,

115  That feeding only on the juice of olives
116  Lightly I passed away the heats and frosts,
117  Contented in my thoughts contemplative.

115  che pur con cibi di liquor d'ulivi
116  lievemente passava caldi e geli,
117  contento ne' pensier contemplativi.

118  That cloister used to render to these heavens
119  Abundantly, and now is empty grown,
110  So that perforce it soon must be revealed.

118  Render solea quel chiostro a questi cieli
119  fertilemente; e ora è fatto vano,
120  sì che tosto convien che si riveli.

121  I in that place was Peter Damiano;
122  And Peter the Sinner was I in the house
123  Of Our Lady on the Adriatic shore.

121  In quel loco fu' io Pietro Damiano,
122  e Pietro Peccator fu' ne la casa
123  di Nostra Donna in sul lito adriano.

124  Little of mortal life remained to me,
125  When I was called and dragged forth to the hat
126  Which shifteth evermore from bad to worse.

124  Poca vita mortal m'era rimasa,
125  quando fui chiesto e tratto a quel cappello,
126  che pur di male in peggio si travasa.

127  Came Cephas, and the mighty Vessel came
128  Of the Holy Spirit, meagre and barefooted,
129  Taking the food of any hostelry.

127  Venne Cefàs e venne il gran vasello
128  de lo Spirito Santo, magri e scalzi,
129  prendendo il cibo da qualunque ostello.

130  Now some one to support them on each side
131  The modern shepherds need, and some to lead them,
132  So heavy are they, and to hold their trains.

130  Or voglion quinci e quindi chi rincalzi
131  li moderni pastori e chi li meni,
132  tanto son gravi, e chi di rietro li alzi.

133  They cover up their palfreys with their cloaks,
134  So that two beasts go underneath one skin;
135  O Patience, that dost tolerate so much!"

133  Cuopron d'i manti loro i palafreni,
134  sì che due bestie van sott' una pelle:
135  oh pazïenza che tanto sostieni!”

136  At this voice saw I many little flames
137  From step to step descending and revolving,
138  And every revolution made them fairer.

136  A questa voce vid' io più fiammelle
137  di grado in grado scendere e girarsi,
138  e ogne giro le facea più belle.

139  Round about this one came they and stood still,
140  And a cry uttered of so loud a sound,
141  It here could find no parallel, nor I

139  Dintorno a questa vennero e fermarsi,
140  e fero un grido di sì alto suono,
141  che non potrebbe qui assomigliarsi;

142  Distinguished it, the thunder so o'ercame me.

142 né io lo 'ntesi, sì mi vinse il tuono.

Canto XXII
We who have taken on a temporal body are so ill-equipped to accept that we are the constant recipients of unconditional love.  Thus we must always be channeling that love which flows constantly towards us and through us, as if through the sieve of our own questionings and our own sense of justice.  Here in the Heaven of Saturn, the aspirant, Dante, the poet Dante — and the reader too — all, as if we were children clinging to our mother, are finding out how much we apply limits to our own acceptance of grace, how much we want the emissaries of Heaven — in this case, Saint Benedict — to converse with us through the medium of our own need for vengeance and retribution.  Vengeance against what?  Retribution against who?  I think against those good intentions that we all start out with, and yet through our weakness and limited mortal perceptions, like those church prelates denounced here, we not only fall far short of the goal of redemption, we betray ourselves through our own corruption.  A balance must, we mortals feel, be restored, through our own mortal need for punishment.  Beatrice, at the beginning of this canto exhorts her ward to remember that he is in heaven, that we are in heaven, but is that even possible when any kind of rancor against ourselves, or by psychological projection, against others, continues to eat away at our aspirations to experience joy?  How could the joy that Benedict feels, whirled as he is through the composite community of his blessed sibling souls in this last sphere of Heaven, have any need of vengeance in his experience of profound grace?  Does Saint Benedict speak the way he does in this canto because this expression of mortal justice is the only language that will satisfy Dante's, and our, sense that God must be just, and that the whole previous rigmarole of passing through the baptism of the River Lethe, did not cleanse us of the remembrance of sin at all.  We merely forgot our own sins, not the sins of others, and especially not the sins of those who have violated our need to see their sins purged through pain and punishment.  That need is the quintessential brand of our mortality, our morality, it is the scar which is the mark of Cain, that scar which differentiates our sense of the divine from Divinity itself.  If we saw and felt God's unconditional love, our whole sense of self would be immolated, and nothing would remain but our communal joy in the single community of those immersed in God's love.  What does the poem actually say here?  And is this marvelous verse confronting us with the supreme challenge of questioning its own aesthetic precepts?  Questions abound and proliferate.  Can we even accept grace if it does not come with our own limited sense of justice?  Can the rule of Saint Benedict be followed even to the point of accepting its most serene existence in the nest of vipers which is the temporal world?  What does unconditional mean if it's mystery is obscured by our own illnesses, hurts, and disappointments?  We see in this canto that the Inferno's theme of retribution has been brought from the depths of Hell to infect us, even here, in the Highest of the High Heavens.  However far we have come through all the consciousness states of the Inferno, Purgatory, and Paradise, our journey has been but an inch compared to how far we still must travel to experience face to face this thing called God. The point of transition would be hopelessly far off, where it not for Divine grace, depicted here as an instantaneity, which like a whirlwind, sucks the seemingly individual souls of the contemplatives into a unified vortex of ascension.  In this canto, Saint Benedict does not so much give us his joy as he gives us a mirror in which we see the reflection of that sense of injustice which prevents us from experiencing his joy.  How incongruent it is that Dante shows us such a dazzle of unearthly speed and brilliance, community and connection, but only to carry a message of vengeance.  If that indeed is what he is doing, and not illustrating how in an instant, all that need for vengeance is whirled away, leaving us breathless in the stillness of the Empyrion.  The verse shows that there is a split here between body and soul, a split, which in Christianity, is only healed through the crucifixion and resurrection of Jesus' unjustly tortured body redeemed through Christ's transfiguration.  This, and the doctrine of forgiveness, perhaps constitute the uniqueness of Christianity.  The Book of Revelations with its trumpet call to damnation for the lost simultaneously being that of the clarion for the bodily redemption of the saved seems a to me to be a false note in the harmonies of these spheres.  How can this cloven fiction be the culmination of the gospels?  And what in fact is the source of that peace which the Benedictines sought in their contemplations?  Contemplations of what?  And what could have possibly been lost when Benedict passed from his sanctuary into world, and which indeed was the true contemplation?  The sequestered?  Or the corruption of the trial of the world?  The retribution that the indignant virtuous are forever seeking is always in the future, even the near future, but it never seems to come.  The unjust seem free to perpetually perpetuate their injustices, and they never quite arrive at that point where, as far off as the last judgement, their perfidies will be expunged.  This canto seems a kind of launching pad, wherein the very sense of injustice is but the rocket fuel which must be burned away if we are to spurt beyond the feeling that something is terribly wrong with the universe, terribly wrong with God, as long as this division exists wherein we feel this is Good, this Evil, this mortality and death, this the everlasting Divine.  The trope here is that there is a point in time which negates time, and transforms the temporal to the eternal, an energy in the spine of the temporal body which whirls the mortal into immortality.

This canto also has a retrospective quality, Dante is exhorted to look back on how far he has come, and he looks back onto the stars of his nativity.  Perhaps we all have a destiny prefigured in the stars, if so, this twinness, this binocular vision, its oscillations between good and evil, the just and the unjust, between irony and sincerity, reason and heart, chance and order, and so forth, is Dante's destiny.  But even this destiny through a chrysalis — as Beatrice implies here — must be shed in preparation for the ultimate apotheosis.  As long as there is a Self to measure, to judge, to question, the desire of Divine communion is just that: a desire, not a fulfillment.  Even the fabulous spectacles of heaven remain outside of us, something seen, described, but still over there, separate from us.  For us to be this blessedness, and close the gap to zero, something else must happen.  What that something might be, remains not only unknown, but lies in the fact that we have not yet accepted that the ultimate plenum/vacuum/God is perpetually unknowable, and this is exactly the source of our fulfillment.  It seems that we must still ask the two-year-old's question "Why?", not knowing that we do not so much desire to be given the answer as we desire to be connected to that mysterious source through our willingness to engage with our limited perceptions, the unlimited Divine.

Epilog (Wikipedia Summation of the Rule of Saint Benedict) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_Saint_Benedict

The Rule opens with a hortatory preface, drawing on the Admonitio ad filium spiritualem,[8] in which Saint Benedict sets forth the main principles of the religious life, viz.: the renunciation of one's own will and arming oneself "with the strong and noble weapons of obedience" under the banner of "the true King, Christ the Lord" (Prol. 3). He proposes to establish a "school for the Lord's service" (Prol. 45) in which the "way to salvation" (Prol. 48) shall be taught, so that by persevering in the monastery till death his disciples may "through patience share in the passion of Christ that [they] may deserve also to share in his Kingdom" (Prol. 50, passionibus Christi per patientiam participemur, ut et regno eius mereamur esse consortes; note: Latin passionibus and patientiam have the same root, cf. Fry, RB 1980, p. 167).[9]
•	Chapter 1 defines four kinds of monk:
1.	Cenobites, those "in a monastery, where they serve under a rule and an abbot".
2.	Anchorites, or hermits, who, after long successful training in a monastery, are now coping single-handedly, with only God for their help.
Regula, 1495
3.	Sarabaites, living by twos and threes together or even alone, with no experience, rule and superior, and thus a law unto themselves.[9]
4.	Gyrovagues, wandering from one monastery to another, slaves to their own wills and appetites.[9]
 
Saint Benedict delivering his rule to the monks of his order, Monastery of St. Gilles, Nimes, France, 1129
•	Chapter 2 describes the necessary qualifications of an abbot, forbids the abbot to make distinctions between persons in the monastery except for particular merit, and warns him he will be answerable for the salvation of the souls in his care.[9]
•	Chapter 3 ordains the calling of the brothers to council upon all affairs of importance to the community.[9]
•	Chapter 4 lists 73 "tools for good work", "tools of the spiritual craft" for the "workshop" that is "the enclosure of the monastery and the stability in the community". These are essentially the duties of every Christian and are mainly Scriptural either in letter or in spirit.[9]
•	Chapter 5 prescribes prompt, ungrudging, and absolute obedience to the superior in all things lawful,[9] "unhesitating obedience" being called the first degree, or step, of humility.
•	Chapter 6 recommends moderation in the use of speech, but does not enjoin strict silence, nor prohibit profitable or necessary conversation.[9]
•	Chapter 7 divides humility into twelve degrees, or steps in the ladder that leads to heaven:[9](1) Fear God; (2) Subordinate one's will to the will of God; (3) Be obedient to one's superior; (4) Be patient amid hardships; (5) Confess one's sins; (6) Accept the meanest of tasks, and hold oneself as a "worthless workman"; (7) Consider oneself "inferior to all"; (8) Follow examples set by superiors; (9) Do not speak until spoken to; (10) Do not readily laugh; (11) Speak simply and modestly; and (12) Express one's inward humility through bodily posture.
•	Chapters 8–19 regulate the Divine Office, the Godly work to which "nothing is to be preferred", namely the eight canonical hours. Detailed arrangements are made for the number of Psalms, etc., to be recited in winter and summer, on Sundays, weekdays, Holy Days, and at other times.[9]
•	Chapter 19 emphasizes the reverence owed to the omnipresent God.[9]
•	Chapter 20 directs that prayer be made with heartfelt compunction rather than many words.[9] It should be prolonged only under the inspiration of divine grace, and in community always kept short and terminated at a sign from the superior.
•	Chapter 21 regulates the appointment of a Dean over every ten monks.[9]
•	Chapter 22 regulates the dormitory. Each monk is to have a separate bed and is to sleep in his habit, so as to be ready to rise without delay [for early Vigils]; a light shall burn in the dormitory throughout the night.[9]
•	Chapters 23–29 specify a graduated scale of punishments for contumacy (refusal to obey authority), disobedience, pride, and other grave faults: first, private admonition; next, public reproof; then separation from the brothers at meals and elsewhere;[9] and finally excommunication (or in the case of those lacking understanding of what this means, corporal punishment instead).
•	Chapter 30 directs that a wayward brother who has left the monastery must be received again, if he promises to make amends; but if he leaves again, and again, after his third departure all return is finally barred.[9]
•	Chapters 31 & 32 order the appointment of officials to take charge of the goods of the monastery.[9]
•	Chapter 33 forbids the private possession of anything without the leave of the abbot, who is, however, bound to supply all necessities.[9]
•	Chapter 34 prescribes a just distribution of such things.[9]
•	Chapter 35 arranges for the service in the kitchen by all monks in turn.[9]
•	Chapters 36 & 37 address care of the sick, the old, and the young. They are to have certain dispensations from the strict Rule, chiefly in the matter of food.[9]
•	Chapter 38 prescribes reading aloud during meals, which duty is to be performed by those who can do so with edification to the rest. Signs are to be used for whatever may be wanted at meals, so that no voice interrupts the reading. The reader eats with the servers after the rest have finished, but he is allowed a little food beforehand in order to lessen the fatigue of reading.[9]
•	Chapters 39 & 40 regulate the quantity and quality of the food. Two meals a day are allowed, with two cooked dishes at each. Each monk is allowed a pound of bread and a hemina (about a quarter litre) of wine. The flesh of four-footed animals is prohibited except for the sick and the weak.[9]
•	Chapter 41 prescribes the hours of the meals, which vary with the time of year.[9]
•	Chapter 42 enjoins the reading of an edifying book in the evening, and orders strict silence after Compline.[9]
•	Chapters 43–46 define penalties for minor faults, such as coming late to prayer or meals.[9]
•	Chapter 47 requires the abbot to call the brothers to the "work of God" (Opus Dei) in choir, and to appoint chanters and readers.[9]
•	Chapter 48 emphasizes the importance of daily manual labour appropriate to the ability of the monk. The duration of labour varies with the season but is never less than five hours a day.[9]
•	Chapter 49 recommends some voluntary self-denial for Lent, with the abbot's sanction.[9]
•	Chapters 50 & 51 contain rules for monks working in the fields or travelling. They are directed to join in spirit, as far as possible, with their brothers in the monastery at the regular hours of prayers.[9]
•	Chapter 52 commands that the oratory be used for purposes of devotion only.[9]
•	Chapter 53 deals with hospitality. Guests are to be met with due courtesy by the abbot or his deputy; during their stay they are to be under the special protection of an appointed monk; they are not to associate with the rest of the community except by special permission.[9]
•	Chapter 54 forbids the monks to receive letters or gifts without the abbot's leave.[9]
•	Chapter 55 says clothing is to be adequate and suited to the climate and locality, at the discretion of the abbot. It must be as plain and cheap as is consistent with due economy. Each monk is to have a change of clothes to allow for washing, and when travelling is to have clothes of better quality. Old clothes are to be given to the poor.[9]
•	Chapter 56 directs the abbot to eat with the guests.[9]
•	Chapter 57 enjoins humility on the craftsmen of the monastery, and if their work is for sale, it shall be rather below than above the current trade price.[9]
•	Chapter 58 lays down rules for the admission of new members, which is not to be made too easy. The postulant first spends a short time as a guest; then he is admitted to the novitiate where his vocation is severely tested; during this time he is always free to leave. If after twelve months' probation he perseveres, he may promise before the whole community stabilitate sua et conversatione morum suorum et oboedientia – "stability, conversion of manners, and obedience". With this vow he binds himself for life to the monastery of his profession.[9]
•	Chapter 59 allows the admission of boys to the monastery under certain conditions.[9]
•	Chapter 60 regulates the position of priests who join the community. They are to set an example of humility, and can only exercise their priestly functions by permission of the abbot.[9]
•	Chapter 61 provides for the reception of strange monks as guests, and for their admission to the community.[9]
•	Chapter 62 deals with the ordination of priests from within the monastic community.
•	Chapter 63 lays down that precedence in the community shall be determined by the date of admission, merit of life, or the appointment of the abbot.[9]
•	Chapter 64 orders that the abbot be elected by his monks, and that he be chosen for his charity, zeal, and discretion.[9]
•	Chapter 65 allows the appointment of a provost, or prior, but warns that he is to be entirely subject to the abbot and may be admonished, deposed, or expelled for misconduct.
•	Chapter 66 appoints a porter, and recommends that each monastery be self-contained and avoid intercourse with the outer world.[9]
•	Chapter 67 instructs monks how to behave on a journey.[9]
•	Chapter 68 orders that all cheerfully try to do whatever is commanded, however hard it may seem.[9]
•	Chapter 69 forbids the monks from defending one another.[9]
•	Chapter 70 prohibits them from striking one another.[9]
•	Chapter 71 encourages the brothers to be obedient not only to the abbot and his officials, but also to one another.[9]
•	Chapter 72 briefly exhorts the monks to zeal and fraternal charity.[9]
•	Chapter 73 is an epilogue; it declares that the Rule is not offered as an ideal of perfection, but merely as a means towards godliness, intended chiefly for beginners in the spiritual life.[9]
 

1  Oppressed with stupor, I unto my guide
2  Turned like a little child who always runs
3  For refuge there where he confideth most;

1  Oppresso di stupore, a la mia guida
2  mi volsi, come parvol che ricorre .
3  sempre colà dove più si confida;

4  And she, even as a mother who straightway
5  Gives comfort to her pale and breathless boy
6  With voice whose wont it is to reassure him,

4  e quella, come madre che soccorre
5  sùbito al figlio palido e anelo
6  con la sua voce, che 'l suol ben disporre,

7  Said to me: "Knowest thou not thou art in heaven,
8  And knowest thou not that heaven is holy all
9  And what is done here cometh from good zeal?

7  mi disse: “Non sai tu che tu se' in cielo?
8  e non sai tu che 'l cielo è tutto santo,
9  e ciò che ci si fa vien da buon zelo?

10  After what wise the singing would have changed thee
11  And I by smiling, thou canst now imagine,
12  Since that the cry has startled thee so much,

10  Come t'avrebbe trasmutato il canto,
11  e io ridendo, mo pensar lo puoi,
12  poscia che 'l grido t'ha mosso cotanto;

13  In which if thou hadst understood its prayers
14  Already would be known to thee the vengeance
15  Which thou shalt look upon before thou diest.

13  nel qual, se 'nteso avessi i prieghi suoi,
14  già ti sarebbe nota la vendetta
15  che tu vedrai innanzi che tu muoi.

16  The sword above here smiteth not in haste
17  Nor tardily, howe'er it seem to him
18  Who fearing or desiring waits for it.

16  La spada di qua sù non taglia in fretta
17  né tardo, ma' ch'al parer di colui
18  che disïando o temendo l'aspetta.

19  But turn thee round towards the others now,
20  For very illustrious spirits shalt thou see,
21  If thou thy sight directest as I say."

19  Ma rivolgiti omai inverso altrui;
20  ch'assai illustri spiriti vedrai,
21  se com' io dico l'aspetto redui.”

22  As it seemed good to her mine eyes I turned,
23  And saw a hundred spherules that together
24  With mutual rays each other more embellished.

22  Come a lei piacque, li occhi ritornai,
23  e vidi cento sperule che 'nsieme
24  più s'abbellivan con mutüi rai.

25  I stood as one who in himself represses
26  The point of his desire, and ventures not
27  To question, he so feareth the too much.

25  Io stava come quei che 'n sé repreme
26  la punta del disio, e non s'attenta
27  di domandar, sì del troppo si teme;

28  And now the largest and most luculent
29  Among those pearls came forward, that it might
30  Make my desire concerning it content.

28  e la maggiore e la più luculenta
29  di quelle margherite innanzi fessi,
30  per far di sé la mia voglia contenta.

31  Within it then I heard: "If thou couldst see
32  Even as myself the charity that burns
33  Among us, thy conceits would be expressed;

31  Poi dentro a lei udi': “Se tu vedessi
32  com' io la carità che tra noi arde,
33  li tuoi concetti sarebbero espressi.

34  But, that by waiting thou mayst not come late
35  To the high end, I will make answer even
36  Unto the thought of which thou art so chary.

34  Ma perché tu, aspettando, non tarde
35  a l'alto fine, io ti farò risposta
36  pur al pensier, da che sì ti riguarde.

37  That mountain on whose slope Cassino stands
38  Was frequented of old upon its summit
39  By a deluded folk and ill-disposed;

37  Quel monte a cui Cassino è ne la costa
38  fu frequentato già in su la cima
39  da la gente ingannata e mal disposta;

40  And I am he who first up thither bore
41  The name of Him who brought upon the earth
42  The truth that so much sublimateth us.

40  e quel son io che sù vi portai prima
41  lo nome di colui che 'n terra addusse
42  la verità che tanto ci soblima;

43  And such abundant grace upon me shone
44  That all the neighbouring towns I drew away
45  From the impious worship that seduced the world.

43  e tanta grazia sopra me relusse,
44  ch'io ritrassi le ville circunstanti
45  da l'empio cólto che 'l mondo sedusse. 

46  These other fires, each one of them, were men
47  Contemplative, enkindled by that heat
48  Which maketh holy flowers and fruits spring up.

46  Questi altri fuochi tutti contemplanti
47  uomini fuoro, accesi di quel caldo
48  che fa nascere i fiori e ' frutti santi.

49  Here is Macarius, here is Romualdus,
50  Here are my brethren, who within the cloisters
51  Their footsteps stayed and kept a steadfast heart."

49  Qui è Maccario, qui è Romoaldo,
50  qui son li frati miei che dentro ai chiostri
51  fermar li piedi e tennero il cor saldo.”

52  And I to him: "The affection which thou showest
53  Speaking with me, and the good countenance
54  Which I behold and note in all your ardours,

52  E io a lui: “L'affetto che dimostri
53  meco parlando, e la buona sembianza
54  ch'io veggio e noto in tutti li ardor vostri,

55  In me have so my confidence dilated
56  As the sun doth the rose, when it becomes
57  As far unfolded as it hath the power.

55  così m'ha dilatata mia fidanza,
56  come 'l sol fa la rosa quando aperta
57  tanto divien quant' ell' ha di possanza.

58  Therefore I pray, and thou assure me, father,
59  If I may so much grace receive, that I
60  May thee behold with countenance unveiled."

58  Però ti priego, e tu, padre, m'accerta
59  s'io posso prender tanta grazia, ch'io
60  ti veggia con imagine scoverta.”

61  He thereupon: "Brother, thy high desire
62  In the remotest sphere shall be fulfilled,
63  Where are fulfilled all others and my own.

61  Ond' elli: “Frate, il tuo alto disio
62  s'adempierà in su l'ultima spera,
63  ove s'adempion tutti li altri e 'l mio.

64  There perfect is, and ripened, and complete,
65  Every desire; within that one alone
66  Is every part where it has always been;

64  Ivi è perfetta, matura e intera
65  ciascuna disïanza; in quella sola
66  è ogne parte là ove sempr' era,

67  For it is not in space, nor turns on poles,
68  And unto it our stairway reaches up,
69  Whence thus from out thy sight it steals away.

67  perché non è in loco e non s'impola;
68  e nostra scala infino ad essa varca,
69  onde così dal viso ti s'invola.

70  Up to that height the Patriarch Jacob saw it
71  Extending its supernal part, what time
72  So thronged with angels it appeared to him.

70  Infin là sù la vide il patriarca
71  Iacobbe porger la superna parte,
72  quando li apparve d'angeli sì carca.

73  But to ascend it now no one uplifts
74  His feet from off the earth, and now my Rule
75  Below remaineth for mere waste of paper.

73  Ma, per salirla, mo nessun diparte
74  da terra i piedi, e la regola mia
75  rimasa è per danno de le carte.

76  The walls that used of old to be an Abbey
77  Are changed to dens of robbers, and the cowls
78  Are sacks filled full of miserable flour.

76  Le mura che solieno esser badia
77  fatte sono spelonche, e le cocolle
78  sacca son piene di farina ria.

79  But heavy usury is not taken up
80  So much against God's pleasure as that fruit
81  Which maketh so insane the heart of monks;

79  Ma grave usura tanto non si tolle
80  contra 'l piacer di Dio, quanto quel frutto
81  che fa il cor de' monaci sì folle;

82  For whatsoever hath the Church in keeping
83  Is for the folk that ask it in God's name,
84  Not for one's kindred or for something worse.

82  ché quantunque la Chiesa guarda, tutto
83  è de la gente che per Dio dimanda;
84  non di parenti né d'altro più brutto.

85  The flesh of mortals is so very soft,
86  That good beginnings down below suffice not
87  From springing of the oak to bearing acorns.

85  La carne d'i mortali è tanto blanda,
86  che giù non basta buon cominciamento
87  dal nascer de la quercia al far la ghianda.

88  Peter began with neither gold nor silver,
89  And I with orison and abstinence,
90  And Francis with humility his convent.

88  Pier cominciò sanz' oro e sanz' argento,
89  e io con orazione e con digiuno,
90  e Francesco umilmente il suo convento;

91  And if thou lookest at each one's beginning,
92  And then regardest whither he has run,
93  Thou shalt behold the white changed into brown.

91  e se guardi 'l principio di ciascuno,
92  poscia riguardi là dov' è trascorso,
93  tu vederai del bianco fatto bruno.

94  In verity the Jordan backward turned,
95  And the sea's fleeing, when God willed were more
96  A wonder to behold, than succour here."

94  Veramente Iordan vòlto retrorso
95  più fu, e 'l mar fuggir, quando Dio volse,
96  mirabile a veder che qui 'l soccorso.”

97  Thus unto me he said; and then withdrew
98  To his own band, and the band closed together;
99  Then like a whirlwind all was upward rapt.

97  Così mi disse, e indi si raccolse
98  al suo collegio, e 'l collegio si strinse;
99  poi, come turbo, in sù tutto s'avvolse.

100  The gentle Lady urged me on behind them
101  Up o'er that stairway by a single sign,
102  So did her virtue overcome my nature;

100  La dolce donna dietro a lor mi pinse
101  con un sol cenno su per quella scala,
102  sì sua virtù la mia natura vinse;

103  Nor here below, where one goes up and down
104  By natural law, was motion e'er so swift
105  That it could be compared unto my wing.

103  né mai qua giù dove si monta e cala
104  naturalmente, fu sì ratto moto
105  ch'agguagliar si potesse a la mia ala.

106  Reader, as I may unto that devout
107  Triumph return, on whose account I often
108  For my transgressions weep and beat my breast,—

106  S'io torni mai, lettore, a quel divoto
107  trïunfo per lo quale io piango spesso
108  le mie peccata e 'l petto mi percuoto,

109  Thou hadst not thrust thy finger in the fire
110  And drawn it out again, before I saw
111  The sign that follows Taurus, and was in it.

109  tu non avresti in tanto tratto e messo
110  nel foco il dito, in quant' io vidi 'l segno
111  che segue il Tauro e fui dentro da esso.

112  O glorious stars, O light impregnated
113  With mighty virtue, from which I acknowledge
114  All of my genius, whatsoe'er it be,

112  O glorïose stelle, o lume pregno
113  di gran virtù, dal quale io riconosco
114  tutto, qual che si sia, il mio ingegno,

115  With you was born, and hid himself with you,
116  He who is father of all mortal life,
117  When first I tasted of the Tuscan air;

115  con voi nasceva e s'ascondeva vosco
116  quelli ch'è padre d'ogne mortal vita,
117  quand' io senti' di prima l'aere tosco;

118  And then when grace was freely given to me
119  To enter the high wheel which turns you round,
120  Your region was allotted unto me.

118  e poi, quando mi fu grazia largita
119   d'entrar ne l'alta rota che vi gira,
120  la vostra regïon mi fu sortita.

121  To you devoutly at this hour my soul
122  Is sighing, that it virtue may acquire
123  For the stern pass that draws it to itself.

121  A voi divotamente ora sospira
122  l'anima mia, per acquistar virtute
123  al passo forte che a sé la tira.

124  "Thou art so near unto the last salvation,"
125  Thus Beatrice began, "thou oughtest now
126  To have thine eves unclouded and acute;

124  “Tu se' sì presso a l'ultima salute,”
125  cominciò Bëatrice, “che tu dei
126  aver le luci tue chiare e acute;

127  And therefore, ere thou enter farther in,
128  Look down once more, and see how vast a world
129  Thou hast already put beneath thy feet;

127  e però, prima che tu più t'inlei,
128  rimira in giù, e vedi quanto mondo
129  sotto li piedi già esser ti fei;

130  So that thy heart, as jocund as it may,
131  Present itself to the triumphant throng
132  That comes rejoicing through this rounded ether."

130  sì che 'l tuo cor, quantunque può, giocondo
131  s'appresenti a la turba trïunfante
132  che lieta vien per questo etera tondo.”

133  I with my sight returned through one and all
134  The sevenfold spheres, and I beheld this globe
135  Such that I smiled at its ignoble semblance;

133  Col viso ritornai per tutte quante
134  le sette spere, e vidi questo globo
135 tal, ch'io sorrisi del suo vil sembiante;

136  And that opinion I approve as best
137  Which doth account it least; and he who thinks
138  Of something else may truly be called just.

136  e quel consiglio per migliore approbo
137  che l'ha per meno; e chi ad altro pensa
138  chiamar si puote veramente probo.

139  I saw the daughter of Latona shining
140  Without that shadow, which to me was cause
141  That once I had believed her rare and dense.

139  Vidi la figlia di Latona incensa
140  sanza quell' ombra che mi fu cagione
141  per che già la credetti rara e densa.

142The aspect of thy son, Hyperion,
143  Here I sustained, and saw how move themselves
144  Around and near him Maia and Dione.

142  L'aspetto del tuo nato, Iperïone,
143  quivi sostenni, e vidi com' si move
144  circa e vicino a lui Maia e Dïone.

145  Thence there appeared the temperateness of Jove
146  'Twixt son and father, and to me was clear
147  The change that of their whereabout they make;

145  Quindi m'apparve il temperar di Giove
146  tra 'l padre e 'l figlio; e quindi mi fu chiaro
147  il varïar che fanno di lor dove;

148  And all the seven made manifest to me
149  How great they are, and eke how swift they are,
150  And how they are in distant habitations.

148  e tutti e sette mi si dimostraro
149  quanto son grandi e quanto son veloci
150  e come sono in distante riparo.

151  The threshing-floor that maketh us so proud,
152  To me revolving with the eternal Twins,
153  Was all apparent made from hill to harbour!

151  L'aiuola che ci fa tanto feroci,
152  volgendom' io con li etterni Gemelli,
153  tutta m'apparve da' colli a le foci;

154  Then to the beauteous eyes mine eyes I turned.

154  poscia rivolsi li occhi a li occhi belli.

Canto XXIII
Even as the last canto begins with placing Dante, the aspirant, as a child, as in the Jesus' injunction that none can enter heaven lest they become as children, this canto begins where that childlike human undergoes a metaphoric transformation to that of a celestial creature, namely a bird, and moreover this long introduction begins from the point of view of Beatrice, a mother bird, awaiting in the predawn darkness for the dawn whose light will allow her to begin the search to feed her brood.  We then move quickly back to Dante, that celestial chick, who in his feeling of anticipation, finds his satiation, not in being fed, but in the mere hope that he will be fed.  The whole thing is a remarkable trope, the very idea of darkness and the sun, now in an astrological transformation, the physical sun below the couple now, and whatever we might have thought of day and night as an east/west movement, has changed, the dawn above us, lined up to an ultimate North, this new dawn shining straight down and aligning itself with the earthly Jerusalem, the rays of its ascent/descent filling with photonic beings, whose presence announce the triumph of Christ.  A momentary vision of Christ himself, and all in the aspirant is changed.  How difficult with a mortal mind, thrown behind the curtain of its mortal senses, for the reader to grasp all this!  The poetry has undergone a phase shift, the verses, like water, which was ice at the nadir of Hell, has here become vapor.  A jump has occurred, sudden and irrevocable.  We don't know how the jump has occurred, for its suddenness has obliterated whatever process has enabled the change to be made, and now the poetry itself has changed shape, its music, however formerly moving, its meanings, however formerly profound, have been transformed into something like the attainment of freedom, a freedom that allows the reader to navigate in another dimension, just as a bird, having left the earth, is now able to move freely in the expanded domain of air.  However, all this is but preparation for the apotheosis at the appearance of the queen of Heaven.  In all this expanse of consciousness, we are but embryonic entities gestating in a celestial womb, and the cervix of light which is opening above us, is the passageway to a new form of being, wherein, in our newly granted celestial bodies we are being prepared to meet He who holds the keys to a final revelation.  The spiraling elliptical shape of the poem which has had us going round and round, augering down in the Inferno to the tightest frozen nub of stasis, automaticity, and a point of interminable pain, then uncoiling with pain accepted through the Purgatorio, and then moving in wider and wider circles of wonder throughout Paradise, to finally attain to this sudden transformation of all that spiraling to now be on that straight and narrow path which Christ says so few find.  Although even this straight and narrow path can be said to be a kind of sushumna of a metaphorical tube formed by the rotational energies which constitute Mary's crown.

One thing that stuns the reader is that no matter how long one reads and studies this poem, no matter how many commentaries one reads, one's inadequacy grows.  One wants to do more to somehow penetrate its mysteries, and be more privy to its splendors.  But it's no use, the mysteries grow, the splendors grow, and one is overwhelmed by such a welter of beauties that like the aspirant here, one hopes somehow to be fortified by the contact, so that one becomes somehow, however seemingly impossible, a worthy recipient.  As readers, we are put in the position of Dante, a mere mortal, who astonishes all the entities he meets in these realms, by being inexplicably present.  And it begins to dawn on us, that Dante is not here as a Christian, or even a Christian saint, he is here as a poet.  And we are here because we have honored poetry as a vehicle that connects heaven and earth, so that now all the dancing and singing we have encountered as we ascend, becomes a kind of whirling pillar that not only connects earth to heaven, but upholds the heavens, and serves as a support for its highest glories.  This is a vision and a revelation that stretches back to the very first canto of the Inferno, that these domains of consciousness owe their existence to the poetic enterprise that sustains them because they are a story that must and has been told.   

1  Even as a bird, 'mid the beloved leaves,
2  Quiet upon the nest of her sweet brood
3  Throughout the night, that hideth all things from us,

1  Come l'augello, intra l'amate fronde,
2  posato al nido de' suoi dolci nati
3  la notte che le cose ci nasconde,

4  Who, that she may behold their longed-for looks
5  And find the food wherewith to nourish them,
6  In which, to her, grave labours grateful are,

4  che, per veder li aspetti disïati
5  e per trovar lo cibo onde li pasca,
6  in che gravi labor li sono aggrati,

7  Anticipates the time on open spray
8  And with an ardent longing waits the sun,
9  Gazing intent as soon as breaks the dawn:

7  previene il tempo in su aperta frasca,
8  e con ardente affetto il sole aspetta,
9  fiso guardando pur che l'alba nasca;

10  Even thus my Lady standing was, erect
11  And vigilant, turned round towards the zone
12  Underneath which the sun displays less haste;

10  così la donna mïa stava eretta
11  e attenta, rivolta inver' la plaga
12  sotto la quale il sol mostra men fretta:

13  So that beholding her distraught and wistful,
14  Such I became as he is who desiring
15  For something yearns, and hoping is appeased.

13  sì che, veggendola io sospesa e vaga,
14  fecimi qual è quei che disïando
15  altro vorria, e sperando s'appaga.

16  But brief the space from one When to the other;
17  Of my awaiting, say I, and the seeing
18  The welkin grow resplendent more and more.

16  Ma poco fu tra uno e altro quando,
17  del mio attender, dico, e del vedere
18  lo ciel venir più e più rischiarando;

19  And Beatrice exclaimed: "Behold the hosts
20  Of Christ's triumphal march, and all the fruit
21  Harvested by the rolling of these spheres!"

19  e Bëatrice disse: “Ecco le schiere
20  del trïunfo di Cristo e tutto 'l frutto
21  ricolto del girar di queste spere!”

22  It seemed to me her face was all aflame;
23  And eyes she had so full of ecstasy
24  That I must needs pass on without describing.

22  Pariemi che 'l suo viso ardesse tutto,
23  e li occhi avea di letizia sì pieni,
24  che passarmen convien sanza costrutto.

25  As when in nights serene of the full moon
26  Smiles Trivia among the nymphs eternal
27  Who paint the firmament through all its gulfs,

25  Quale ne' plenilunïi sereni
26  Trivïa ride tra le ninfe etterne
27  che dipingon lo ciel per tutti i seni,

28  Saw I, above the myriads of lamps,
29  A Sun that one and all of them enkindled,
30  E'en as our own doth the supernal sights,

28  vid' i' sopra migliaia di lucerne
29  un sol che tutte quante l'accendea,
30  come fa 'l nostro le viste superne;

31  And through the living light transparent shone
32  The lucent substance so intensely clear
33  Into my sight, that I sustained it not.

31  e per la viva luce trasparea
32  la lucente sustanza tanto chiara
33  nel viso mio, che non la sostenea.

34  O Beatrice, thou gentle guide and dear!
35  To me she said: "What overmasters thee
36  A virtue is from which naught shields itself.

34  Oh Bëatrice, dolce guida e cara!
35  Ella mi disse: “Quel che ti sobranza
36  è virtù da cui nulla si ripara.

37  There are the wisdom and the omnipotence
38  That oped the thoroughfares 'twixt heaven and earth,
39  For which there erst had been so long a yearning."

37  Quivi è la sapïenza e la possanza
38  ch'aprì le strade tra 'l cielo e la terra
39  onde fu già sì lunga disïanza.”

40  As fire from out a cloud unlocks itself,
41  Dilating so it finds not room therein,
42  And down, against its nature, falls to earth,

40  Come foco di nube si diserra
41  per dilatarsi sì che non vi cape,
42  e fuor di sua natura in giù s'atterra,

43  So did my mind, among those aliments
44  Becoming larger, issue from itself,
45  And that which it became cannot remember.

43  la mente mia così, tra quelle dape
44  fatta più grande, di sé stessa uscìo,
45  e che si fesse rimembrar non sape.

46  "Open thine eyes, and look at what I am:
47  Thou hast beheld such things, that strong enough
48  Hast thou become to tolerate my smile."

46  “Apri li occhi e riguarda qual son io;
47  tu hai vedute cose, che possente
48  se' fatto a sostener lo riso mio.”

49  I was as one who still retains the feeling
50  Of a forgotten vision, and endeavours
51  In vain to bring it back into his mind,

49  Io era come quei che si risente
50  di visïone oblita e che s'ingegna
51  indarno di ridurlasi a la mente,

52  When I this invitation heard, deserving
53  Of so much gratitude, it never fades
54  Out of the book that chronicles the past.

52  quand' io udi' questa proferta, degna
53  di tanto grato, che mai non si stingue
54  del libro che 'l preterito rassegna.

55  If at this moment sounded all the tongues
56  That Polyhymnia and her sisters made
57  Most lubrical with their delicious milk,

55  Se mo sonasser tutte quelle lingue
56  che Polimnïa con le suore fero
57  del latte lor dolcissimo più pingue,

58  To aid me, to a thousandth of the truth
59  It would not reach, singing the holy smile
60  And how the holy aspect it illumed.

58  per aiutarmi, al millesmo del vero
59  non si verria, cantando il santo riso
60  e quanto il santo aspetto facea mero;

61  And therefore, representing Paradise,
62  The sacred poem must perforce leap over,
63  Even as a man who finds his way cut off;

61  e così, figurando il paradiso,
62  convien saltar lo sacrato poema,
63  come chi trova suo cammin riciso.

64  But whoso thinketh of the ponderous theme,
65  And of the mortal shoulder laden with it,
66  Should blame it not, if under this it tremble.

64  Ma chi pensasse il ponderoso tema
65  e l'omero mortal che se ne carca,
66  nol biasmerebbe se sott' esso trema:

67  It is no passage for a little boat
68  This which goes cleaving the audacious prow,
69  Nor for a pilot who would spare himself.

67  non è pareggio da picciola barca
68  quel che fendendo va l'ardita prora,
69  né da nocchier ch'a sé medesmo parca.

70  "Why doth my face so much enamour thee,
71  That to the garden fair thou turnest not,
72  Which under the rays of Christ is blossoming?

70  “Perché la faccia mia sì t'innamora,
71  che tu non ti rivolgi al bel giardino
72  che sotto i raggi di Cristo s'infiora?

73  There is the Rose in which the Word Divine
74  Became incarnate; there the lilies are
75  By whose perfume the good way was discovered."

73  Quivi è la rosa in che 'l verbo divino
74  carne si fece; quivi son li gigli
75  al cui odor si prese il buon cammino.”

76  Thus Beatrice; and I, who to her counsels
77  Was wholly ready, once again betook me
78  Unto the battle of the feeble brows.

76  Così Beatrice; e io, che a' suoi consigli
77  tutto era pronto, ancora mi rendei
78  a la battaglia de' debili cigli.

79  As in the sunshine, that unsullied streams
80  Through fractured cloud, ere now a meadow of flowers
81  Mine eyes with shadow covered o'er have seen,

79  Come a raggio di sol, che puro mei
80  per fratta nube, già prato di fiori
81  vider, coverti d'ombra, li occhi miei;

82  So troops of splendours manifold I saw
83  Illumined from above with burning rays,
84  Beholding not the source of the effulgence.

82  vid' io così più turbe di splendori,
83  folgorate di sù da raggi ardenti,
84  sanza veder principio di folgóri.

85  O power benignant that dost so imprint them!
86  Thou didst exalt thyself to give more scope
87  There to mine eyes, that were not strong enough.

85  O benigna vertù che sì li 'mprenti,
86  sù t'essaltasti per largirmi loco
87  i li occhi lì che non t'eran possenti.

88  The name of that fair flower I e'er invoke
89  Morning and evening utterly enthralled
90  My soul to gaze upon the greater fire.

88  Il nome del bel fior ch'io sempre invoco
89  e mane e sera, tutto mi ristrinse
90  l'animo ad avvisar lo maggior foco;

91  And when in both mine eyes depicted were
92  The glory and greatness of the living star
93  Which there excelleth, as it here excelled,

91  e come ambo le luci mi dipinse
92  il quale e il quanto de la viva stella
93  che là sù vince come qua giù vinse,

94  Athwart the heavens a little torch descended
95  Formed in a circle like a coronal,
96  And cinctured it, and whirled itself about it.

94  per entro il cielo scese una facella,
95  formata in cerchio a guisa di corona,
96  e cinsela e girossi intorno ad ella.

97  Whatever melody most sweetly soundeth
98  On earth, and to itself most draws the soul,
99  Would seem a cloud that, rent asunder, thunders,

97  Qualunque melodia più dolce suona
98  qua giù e più a sé l'anima tira,
99  parrebbe nube che squarciata tona,

100  Compared unto the sounding of that lyre
101  Wherewith was crowned the sapphire beautiful,
102  Which gives the clearest heaven its sapphire hue.

100  comparata al sonar di quella lira
101  onde si coronava il bel zaffiro
102  del quale il ciel più chiaro s'inzaffira.

103  "I am Angelic Love, that circle round
104  The joy sublime which breathes from out the womb
105  That was the hostelry of our Desire;

103  “Io sono amore angelico, che giro
104  l'alta letizia che spira del ventre
105  che fu albergo del nostro disiro;

106  And I shall circle, Lady of Heaven, while
107  Thou followest thy Son, and mak'st diviner
108  The sphere supreme, because thou enterest there."

106  e girerommi, donna del ciel, mentre
107  che seguirai tuo figlio, e farai dia
108  più la spera supprema perché lì entre.”

109  Thus did the circulated melody
110  Seal itself up; and all the other lights
111  Were making to resound the name of Mary.

109  Così la circulata melodia
110  si sigillava, e tutti li altri lumi
111  facean sonare il nome di Maria.

112  The regal mantle of the volumes all
113  Of that world, which most fervid is and living
114  With breath of God and with his works and ways,

112  Lo real manto di tutti i volumi
113  del mondo, che più ferve e più s'avviva
114  ne l'alito di Dio e nei costumi,

115  Extended over us its inner border,
116  So very distant, that the semblance of it
117  There where I was not yet appeared to me.

115  avea sopra di noi l'interna riva
116  tanto distante, che la sua parvenza,
117  là dov' io era, ancor non appariva:

118  Therefore mine eyes did not possess the power
119  Of following the incoronated flame,
120  Which mounted upward near to its own seed.

118  però non ebber li occhi miei potenza
119  di seguitar la coronata fiamma
120  che si levò appresso sua semenza.

121  And as a little child, that towards its mother
122  Stretches its arms, when it the milk has taken,
123  Through impulse kindled into outward flame,

121  E come fantolin che 'nver' la mamma
122  tende le braccia, poi che 'l latte prese,
123  per l'animo che 'nfin di fuor s'infiamma;

124  Each of those gleams of whiteness upward reached
125  So with its summit, that the deep affection
126  They had for Mary was revealed to me.

124  ciascun di quei candori in sù si stese
125  con la sua cima, sì che l'alto affetto
126  ch'elli avieno a Maria mi fu palese.

127  Thereafter they remained there in my sight,
128  'Regina coeli' singing with such sweetness,
129   That ne'er from me has the delight departed.

127  Indi rimaser lì nel mio cospetto,
128  “Regina celi” cantando sì dolce,
129  che mai da me non si partì 'l diletto.

130  O, what exuberance is garnered up
131  Within those richest coffers, which had been
132  Good husbandmen for sowing here below!

130  Oh quanta è l'ubertà che si soffolce
131  in quelle arche ricchissime che fuoro
132  a seminar qua giù buone bobolce!
133  There they enjoy and live upon the treasure
134  Which was acquired while weeping in the exile
135  Of Babylon, wherein the gold was left.

133  Quivi si vive e gode del tesoro
134  che s'acquistò piangendo ne lo essilio
135  di Babillòn, ove si lasciò l'oro.

136  There triumpheth, beneath the exalted Son
137  Of God and Mary, in his victory,
138  Both with the ancient council and the new,

136  Quivi trïunfa, sotto l'alto Filio
137   di Dio e di Maria, di sua vittoria,
138  e con l'antico e col novo concilio,

139  He who doth keep the keys of such a glory.

139  colui che tien le chiavi di tal gloria.

Canto XXIV
I declare that the Heaven of Fixed Stars may be compared to Physics on account of three properties, and to Metaphysics on account of another three.  For it displays to us two properties visible within it, the multitudinous stars and the Galaxy, that is the whole circle popularly known as Saint James' Way; and it displays to us one of its movements, that from east to west, while keeping almost hidden from us, its other movement, from west to east.  And so I must explain the similarities first with Physics, then with Metaphysics {...}  Furthermore, the pole of this heaven, which we see signifies things that can be perceived by the senses, which form the subject of Physics; and the pole that signifies things which are without matter, things which cannot be perceived by the senses, which form the subject of Metaphysics.  For this reason then, the heaven under discussion has a close similarity to each of these sciences.  Moreover by its movements it signifies these two sciences. For by the movement in which it every day goes through a revolution, and circles anew to the very point from which it started, it signifies those things in Nature which are subject to decay, which day by day complete their passage, and have their matter transferred from one form to another; these are what Physics considers.  By the almost imperceptible movement this heaven makes from west to east, shifting one degree in a hundred years, it signifies beings not subject to decay, which had a beginning through God's act of creation but will never have an end; these are what Metaphysics considers.  Consequently, I declare that this movement signifies these beings in that their revolution comes  to an end when it returns to the same point, a point which this heaven in pursuing this movement will never reach. For since the beginning of the world little more than a sixth of the revolution has been completed, while we live in the final stage of history, and indeed in expectation of the consummation of the movement of the heavens.  It is clear, then, that the Heaven of the Fixed Stars may on account of many properties be compared to Physics and Metaphysics.  

Convivio II, 1-2, 9-13

What is faith that is not tested?  That's the question that confronts us here.  But by a testing of faith, we usually mean having to confront circumstances that offer no rational or even irrational way out, and not the test that Dante, the aspirant, is subjected to here — an intellectual test wherein a bachelor candidate must stand before the master and give an oral presentation to questions posed to him.  This may seem a rather tame culmination, until we realize that the ordeal that Dante faces, and is still facing, is the ordeal of the poem itself, Dante, the poet, as well as Dante, the aspirant and protagonist of the poem, has staked everything on an impossibility — the witnessing by a mortal man of that which is invisible except to those who have leaped out of temporal existence to become the miracle that is revealed here, and revealed throughout the poem, a miracle that also involves the reader in a high stakes game which catches the reader unawares, and being tested, like the protagonist to find out if he or she has learned or is learning the faith lesson, to find out if this mundane act of reading really can be elevated to the stature of Saint Paul's definition: "faith is the substance of things hoped for/ the evidence of things that are not seen (lines 64,65).  

In the last canto we began with the image of the mother bird awaiting the dawn so that she might hunt for food for her brood, and here Beatrice declares that that food is the food that drops down like manna from the Empyrean, and the satiation of hope itself is here manifested as the evidence that Providence has indeed provided, because the poem itself is the proof that the poet has taken nourishment from his journey and can now stand as master himself revealing his mastery to a Master.  We have here a clear conflation of the poet outside the poem and the aspirant inside the poem, the two conjoined as the single master of faith.  The image of clock wheels turning, and the spinning of the entities encountered here along with that of the movement of the sun and the precession of the constillations provides Dante with a trope which shows how the temporal world of the seen interacts with the eternal world of the unseen, just as the seen aspirant inside the poem is the manifestation of the unseen poet outside the poem.  Two other tropes from subsequent poets come to mind.  Eliot's "still point of the turning world," and Blake's "eternity is in love with the productions of time."  But Dante's imagination is more motile, his figures turn faster or slower depending of the faith that propels them, and it does not take much of a projection by the reader to realize that the stillness at the center of these whirling dervishes must also be greater or lesser according to each entities contemplative depths.

Who then spins fastest, shines brightest of these entities?  Although not mentioned by name, and therefore his name at this point is unseen, the entity which manifests is Saint Peter.  A duple personage, that is, Simon/Peter.  The wavering disciple.  And as often the case with Dante, he has chosen the disciple whose faith is shot through with an undercurrent of doubt, a faith, in other words which has been tested.  The example here is Peter's faith enabling him to walk upon the waves, wherein he is borne up for a while, but then, succumbing to doubt, he sinks, and would have drowned if it were not for the grace of Jesus.  We remember too that Peter three times denied Christ prior to the crucifixion.  The number three is obviously important throughout the canto, and throughout the entire Commedia, which we may assume, in addition to its reference to the trinity, can also be said to correspond to the turn, counter turn, and stand familiar to us from Grecian antiquity — the oscillation is important insofar as it represents the rhythm of faith, doubt, and finally the metaphoric rock of faith tested and holding firm in an invisible stillness.  These movements prevent the verses here from succumbing to the cynicism of irony, irony itself redeemed by a faith whose evidence is the conviction which can withstand the assault of counter example, and instead incorporate it as the proof which moves us to believe without equivocation, which is the miracle non-miracle that the two testaments of the Bible were sufficient and more than sufficient to move the whole Western pagan world to transform itself, and to these two testaments, we may complete another trinity with a third, namely the testament of the Commedia itself.  The 8-century commentary tradition is evidence that Dante's assertion of faith was not authorial arrogance, but a truth that he understood the force that faith has in establishing the transformative power of art.   
												
1  "O company elect to the great supper
2  Of the Lamb benedight, who feedeth you
3  So that for ever full is your desire,

1  “O sodalizio eletto a la gran cena
2  del benedetto Agnello, il qual vi ciba
3  sì, che la vostra voglia è sempre piena,

4  If by the grace of God this man foretaste
5  Something of that which falleth from your table,
6  Or ever death prescribe to him the time,

4  se per grazia di Dio questi preliba
5  di quel che cade de la vostra mensa,
6  prima che morte tempo li prescriba,

7  Direct your mind to his immense desire,
8  And him somewhat bedew; ye drinking are
9  For ever at the fount whence comes his thought."

7  ponete mente a l'affezione immensa
8  e roratelo alquanto: voi bevete
9  sempre del fonte onde vien quel ch'ei pensa.”

10  Thus Beatrice; and those souls beatified
11  Transformed themselves to spheres on steadfast poles,
12  Flaming intensely in the guise of comets.

10  Così Beatrice; e quelle anime liete
11  si fero spere sopra fissi poli,
12  fiammando, volte, a guisa di comete.

13  And as the wheels in works of horologes
14  Revolve so that the first to the beholder
15  Motionless seems, and the last one to fly,

13  E come cerchi in tempra d'orïuoli
14  si giran sì, che 'l primo a chi pon mente
15  quïeto pare, e l'ultimo che voli;

16  So in like manner did those carols, dancing
17  In different measure, of their affluence
18  Give me the gauge, as they were swift or slow.

16  così quelle carole, differente–
17  mente danzando, de la sua ricchezza
18  mi facieno stimar, veloci e lente.

19  From that one which I noted of most beauty
20  Beheld I issue forth a fire so happy
21  That none it left there of a greater brightness;

19  Di quella ch'io notai di più carezza
20  vid' ïo uscire un foco sì felice,
21  che nullo vi lasciò di più chiarezza;

22  And around Beatrice three several times
23  It whirled itself with so divine a song,
24    My fantasy repeats it not to me;

22  e tre fïate intorno di Beatrice
23  si volse con un canto tanto divo,
24  che la mia fantasia nol mi ridice.

25  Therefore the pen skips, and I write it not,
26  Since our imagination for such folds,
27  Much more our speech, is of a tint too glaring.

25  Però salta la penna e non lo scrivo:
26  ché l'imagine nostra a cotai pieghe,
27  non che 'l parlare, è troppo color vivo.

28  "O holy sister mine, who us implorest
29   With such devotion, by thine ardent love
30  Thou dost unbind me from that beautiful sphere!"

28  “O santa suora mia che sì ne prieghe
29  divota, per lo tuo ardente affetto
30  da quella bella spera mi disleghe.”

31  Thereafter, having stopped, the blessed fire
32  Unto my Lady did direct its breath,
33  Which spake in fashion as I here have said.

31  Poscia fermato, il foco benedetto
32  a la mia donna dirizzò lo spiro,
33  che favellò così com' i' ho detto.

34  And she: "O light eterne of the great man
35  To whom our Lord delivered up the keys
36  He carried down of this miraculous joy,

34  Ed ella: “O luce etterna del gran viro
35  a cui Nostro Segnor lasciò le chiavi,
36  ch'ei portò giù, di questo gaudio miro,

37  This one examine on points light and grave,
38  As good beseemeth thee, about the Faith
39  By means of which thou on the sea didst walk.

37  tenta costui di punti lievi e gravi,
38  come ti piace, intorno de la fede,
39  per la qual tu su per lo mare andavi.

40  If he love well, and hope well, and believe,
41  From thee 'tis hid not; for thou hast thy sight
42  There where depicted everything is seen.

40  S'elli ama bene e bene spera e crede,
41  non t'è occulto, perché 'l viso hai quivi
42  dov' ogne cosa dipinta si vede;

43  But since this kingdom has made citizens
44  By means of the true Faith, to glorify it
45  'Tis well he have the chance to speak thereof."

43  ma perché questo regno ha fatto civi
44  per la verace fede, a glorïarla,
45  di lei parlare è ben ch'a lui arrivi.”

46  As baccalaureate arms himself, and speaks not
47  Until the master doth propose the question,
48  To argue it, and not to terminate it,

46  Sì come il baccialier s'arma e non parla
 47 fin che 'l maestro la question propone,
48  per approvarla, non per terminarla,

49  So did I arm myself with every reason,
50  While she was speaking, that I might be ready
51  For such a questioner and such profession.

49  così m'armava io d'ogne ragione
50  mentre ch'ella dicea, per esser presto
51  a tal querente e a tal professione.

52  "Say, thou good Christian; manifest thyself;
53  What is the Faith?" Whereat I raised my brow
54  Unto that light wherefrom was this breathed forth.

52  “Dì, buon Cristiano, fatti manifesto:
53  fede che è?” Ond' io levai la fronte
54  in quella luce onde spirava questo;

55  Then turned I round to Beatrice, and she
56  Prompt signals made to me that I should pour
57  The water forth from my internal fountain.

55  poi mi volsi a Beatrice, ed essa pronte
56  sembianze femmi perch'ïo spandessi
57  l'acqua di fuor del mio interno fonte.

58  "May grace, that suffers me to make confession,"
59  Began I, "to the great centurion,
60  Cause my conceptions all to be explicit!"

58  “La Grazia che mi dà ch'io mi confessi,”
59  comincia' io, “da l'alto primipilo,
60  faccia li miei concetti bene espressi.”

61  And I continued: "As the truthful pen,
62  Father, of thy dear brother wrote of it,
63  Who put with thee Rome into the good way,

61  E seguitai: “Come 'l verace stilo
62  ne scrisse, padre, del tuo caro frate
63  che mise teco Roma nel buon filo,

64  Faith is the substance of the things we hope for,
65  And evidence of those that are not seen;
66  And this appears to me its quiddity."

64  fede è sustanza di cose sperate
65  e argomento de le non parventi;
66  e questa pare a me sua quiditate.”

67  Then heard I: "Very rightly thou perceivest,
68  If well thou understandest why he placed it
69  With substances and then with evidences."

67  Allora udi': “Dirittamente senti,
68  se bene intendi perché la ripuose
69  tra le sustanze, e poi tra li argomenti.”

70  And I thereafterward: "The things profound,
71  That here vouchsafe to me their apparition,
72  Unto all eyes below are so concealed,

70  E io appresso: “Le profonde cose
71  che mi largiscon qui la lor parvenza,
72  a li occhi di là giù son sì ascose,

73  That they exist there only in belief,
74  Upon the which is founded the high hope,
75  And hence it takes the nature of a substance.

73  che l'esser loro v'è in sola credenza,
74  sopra la qual si fonda l'alta spene;
75  e però di sustanza prende intenza.

76  And it behoveth us from this belief
77  To reason without having other sight,
78  And hence it has the nature of evidence."

76  E da questa credenza ci convene
77  silogizzar, sanz' avere altra vista:
78  però intenza d'argomento tene.”

79  Then heard I: "If whatever is acquired
80  Below by doctrine were thus understood,
81  No sophist's subtlety would there find place."

79  Allora udi': “Se quantunque s'acquista
80  giù per dottrina, fosse così 'nteso,
81  non lì avria loco ingegno di sofista.”

82  Thus was breathed forth from that enkindled love;
83  Then added: "Very well has been gone over
84  Already of this coin the alloy and weight;

82  Così spirò di quello amore acceso;
83  indi soggiunse: “Assai bene è trascorsa
84  d'esta moneta già la lega e 'l peso;

85  But tell me if thou hast it in thy purse?"
86  And I: "Yes, both so shining and so round
87  That in its stamp there is no peradventure."

85  ma dimmi se tu l'hai ne la tua borsa.”
86  Ond' io: “Sì ho, sì lucida e sì tonda,
87  che nel suo conio nulla mi s'inforsa.”

88  Thereafter issued from the light profound
89  That there resplendent was: "This precious jewel,
90  Upon the which is every virtue founded,

88  Appresso uscì de la luce profonda
89  che lì splendeva: “Questa cara gioia
90  sopra la quale ogne virtù si fonda,

91  Whence hadst thou it?" And I: "The large outpouring
92  Of Holy Spirit, which has been diffused
93  Upon the ancient parchments and the new,

91  onde ti venne?” E io: “La larga ploia
92  de lo Spirito Santo, ch'è diffusa
93  in su le vecchie e 'n su le nuove cuoia,

94  A syllogism is, which proved it to me
95  With such acuteness, that, compared therewith,
96  All demonstration seems to me obtuse."

94  è silogismo che la m'ha conchiusa
95  acutamente sì, che 'nverso d'ella
96  ogne dimostrazion mi pare ottusa.”

97  And then I heard: "The ancient and the new
98  Postulates, that to thee are so conclusive,
99  Why dost thou take them for the word divine?"

97  Io udi' poi: “L'antica e la novella
98  proposizion che così ti conchiude,
99  perché l'hai tu per divina favella?”

100  And I: "The proofs, which show the truth to me,
101  Are the works subsequent, whereunto Nature
102  Ne'er heated iron yet, nor anvil beat."

100  E io: “La prova che 'l ver mi dischiude,
101 son l'opere seguite, a che natura
102  non scalda ferro mai né batte incude.”

103  'Twas answered me: "Say, who assureth thee
104  That those works ever were? the thing itself
105  That must be proved, nought else to thee affirms it."

103  Risposto fummi: “Dì, chi t'assicura
104  che quell' opere fosser? Quel medesmo
105  che vuol provarsi, non altri, il ti giura.”

106  "Were the world to Christianity converted,"
107  I said, "withouten miracles, this one
108  Is such, the rest are not its hundredth part;

106  “Se 'l mondo si rivolse al cristianesmo,”
107  diss' io, “sanza miracoli, quest' uno
108  è tal, che li altri non sono il centesmo:

109  Because that poor and fasting thou didst enter
110  Into the field to sow there the good plant,
111  Which was a vine and has become a thorn!"

109  ché tu intrasti povero e digiuno
110  in campo, a seminar la buona pianta
111  che fu già vite e ora è fatta pruno.”

112  This being finished, the high, holy Court
113  Resounded through the spheres, "One God we praise!"
114  In melody that there above is chanted.

112  Finito questo, l'alta corte santa
113  risonò per le spere un “Dio laudamo”
114  ne la melode che là sù si canta.

115  And then that Baron, who from branch to branch,
116  Examining, had thus conducted me,
117  Till the extremest leaves we were approaching,

115  E quel baron che sì di ramo in ramo,
114   essaminando, già tratto m'avea,
115   che a l'ultime fronde appressavamo,

118  Again began: "The Grace that dallying
119  Plays with thine intellect thy mouth has opened,
120  Up to this point, as it should opened be,

118  ricominciò: “La Grazia, che donnea
119  con la tua mente, la bocca t'aperse
120  infino a qui come aprir si dovea,

121  So that I do approve what forth emerged;
122  But now thou must express what thou believest,
123  And whence to thy belief it was presented."

121  sì ch'io approvo ciò che fuori emerse;
122  ma or convien espremer quel che credi,
123  e onde a la credenza tua s'offerse.”

124  "O holy father, spirit who beholdest
125  What thou believedst so that thou o'ercamest,
126  Towards the sepulchre, more youthful feet,"

124  “O santo padre, e spirito che vedi
125  ciò che credesti sì, che tu vincesti
126  ver' lo sepulcro più giovani piedi,”

127  Began I, "thou dost wish me in this place
128  The form to manifest of my prompt belief,
129  And likewise thou the cause thereof demandest.

127  comincia' io, “tu vuo' ch'io manifesti
128  la forma qui del pronto creder mio,
129  e anche la cagion di lui chiedesti.

130  And I respond: In one God I believe,
131  Sole and eterne, who moveth all the heavens
132  With love and with desire, himself unmoved;

130  E io rispondo: Io credo in uno Dio
131  solo ed etterno, che tutto 'l ciel move,
132  non moto, con amore e con disio;

133  And of such faith not only have I proofs
134  Physical and metaphysical, but gives them
135  Likewise the truth that from this place rains down

133  e a tal creder non ho io pur prove
134  fisice e metafisice, ma dalmi
135  anche la verità che quinci piove

136  Through Moses, through the Prophets and the Psalms,
137  Through the Evangel, and through you, who wrote
138  After the fiery Spirit sanctified you;

136  per Moïsè, per profeti e per salmi,
137  per l'Evangelio e per voi che scriveste
138  poi che l'ardente Spirto vi fé almi;

139  In Persons three eterne believe, and these
140  One essence I believe, so one and trine
141  They bear conjunction both with 'sunt' and 'est.'

139  e credo in tre persone etterne, e queste
140  credo una essenza sì una e sì trina,
141  che soffera congiunto 'sono' ed 'este.'

142  With the profound condition and divine
143  Which now I touch upon, doth stamp my mind
144  Ofttimes the doctrine evangelical.

142  De la profonda condizion divina
143  ch'io tocco mo, la mente mi sigilla
144  più volte l'evangelica dottrina.

145  This the beginning is, this is the spark
146  Which afterwards dilates to vivid flame,
147  And, like a star in heaven, is sparkling in me."

145  Quest' è 'l principio, quest' è la favilla
146  che si dilata in fiamma poi vivace,
147  e come stella in cielo in me scintilla.”

148  Even as a lord who hears what pleaseth him
149  His servant straight embraces, gratulating
150  For the good news as soon as he is silent;

148  Come 'l segnor ch'ascolta quel che i piace,
149  da indi abbraccia il servo, gratulando
150  per la novella, tosto ch'el si tace;

151  So, giving me its benediction, singing,
152  Three times encircled me, when I was silent,
153  The apostolic light, at whose command

151  così, benedicendomi cantando,
152  tre volte cinse me, sì com' io tacqui,
153  l'appostolico lume al cui comando

154  I spoken had, in speaking I so pleased him.

154  io avea detto: sì nel dir li piacqui!

Canto XXV
My first notes on this canto dictated into my phone while I was in the hospital read:

The hope Dante abandoned upon entering Hell is here restored.  That circle impossibly completed, not through arrogance on the poet’s part, but by divine grace. Thus the truth of Dante’s definition of hope is ratified, and if any pride is on display here it is Beatrice’s pride in her protégée.  Dante goes to great lengths in this Canto to exalt his status as a poet without seeming to resort to braggadocio.  His own name is exalted and except that of Saint Peter his other interlocutors are only periphrastically alluded to.

That was to be my opening salvo, and this paragraph was meant to wrap things up:

The various references to the blinding radiance of revelations obscuring yet revealing the nature of hope bring this canto to a conclusion with a couple of rhyming tropes: one the statement by an unnamed Saint John that his body is clay on earth and not where Dante supposes it is, in heaven.  And the final poignant disappearance of Beatrice wherein her inspiration obliterates her very presence.  When a meditator grows calm enough that the blue pearl of the third eye suddenly appears between the brows, the shock of that inner effulgence shakes one out of the state.  So here when hope comes to fruition, Beatrice, the source that has led to this transformation, is disconcertingly effaced.

Nothing wrong with either of these two gambits, except that they are in style, if not in substance, so much intellectual dodginess attempting to avoid an emotion that perhaps Hope is the antidote for — an emotion that modernity refers to as "anxiety."  I have read this canto over and over, had many revelations concerning its theme, but in the end, my own health problems, my own anxiety, has prevented me from being able to read anything genuine and honest — emotionally honest at least — in the argument that the baccalaureate Dante is putting forth here.  Until those last verses, when Dante tumbles into despair at losing sight of Beatrice, and experiencing that sudden anxiety, even in the very midst of Paradise — this happy world — I cannot say that I believe that the entire rest of the canto on Hope is anything but a brave whistling in the dark facade that Dante, the orthodox Christian philosopher, would dearly like to be true, but which Dante the poet feels is not.  Just as that little vignette which begins this canto — of him returning to Florence to receive the laurel crown — is a bit wishful thinking, and maybe even his crowning by Saint Peter is only an exalted form of the same, something to make his contemporaries jealous or ashamed, surely Dante negates all that in the end: When John reminds the aspirant, Dante, that John's body is but rotting clay — earth on Earth, and that the chimera his eyes search for and his ears want to believe, is not really there.  

Dante is making some extraordinary claims in this canto regarding the role of, and the powers of poetry — whose power is on a par with scripture to not only inculcate belief and foment Hope — but to do something more miraculous.  To do what I am doing right now, up in the middle of the night, at 5 a.m., anxiously awaiting a medical procedure whose outcome I fear, that is to say, to bring the mind to a calmer place through the radiance of The Word.  Though the eye may be dazzled, the dream-body solaced by ecstatic dance, the ears delighted by joyful song, the soul is in its essence something which needs more than those things, it needs Earth, not the metaphor of sheep and wolves that begin this canto, but the actual smell and presence of the animal, the fleece of one's skin, the fear of becoming prey, a weight of physicality which each of us possesses as we read this poem.  There are only three physical beings in Paradise, which James makes clear: and two of them are not here, namely, Jesus and Mary.  The third who is here, and who has brought all of his readers with him, through the power of his verse, is Dante — not Dante the promulgator of Christian orthodoxy — but Dante the poet.  In this canto, for the first time, he actually calls himself a poet.  Nobody can say that, but somebody must be bold, or arrogant, or crazy enough to say it.  The hope of poetry requires poets who may themselves by fixated by despair, but that does not prevent them from carrying on with their impossible task, not just to find felicity in the midst of Earth's unending injustices, pains, and anxiety, but also to remind us in Paradise of smells and tastes which the Word exalts, even though they are so often productive of our deepest terrors. 

I do not want to end these notes by implying that some kind of exalted or noble form of acceptance of our Earthly condition, even through the medium of poetry, in any way dispels or mitigates those anxieties.  There is a shadow that clings to us even in the midst of our brightest and most blinding inspirations.  The miracle of Paradise is that its immortal joys arise from the maw of suffering and death.  The anxious insomniac at the end of his or her rope in the smallest hours of night continues to peer into that shadow until it shines, shines like the red retinas of those wolves lurking just beyond the sheepfold.  The irony of this canto is that the wolf too is hopeful.

1  If e'er it happen that the Poem Sacred,
2  To which both heaven and earth have set their hand,
3  So that it many a year hath made me lean,

1  Se mai continga che 'l poema sacro
2  al quale ha posto mano e cielo e terra,
3  sì che m'ha fatto per molti anni macro,

4  O'ercome the cruelty that bars me out
5  From the fair sheepfold, where a lamb I slumbered,
6  An enemy to the wolves that war upon it,

4  vinca la crudeltà che fuor mi serra
5  del bello ovile ov' io dormi' agnello,
6  nimico ai lupi che li danno guerra;

7  With other voice forthwith, with other fleece
8  Poet will I return, and at my font
9  Baptismal will I take the laurel crown;

7  con altra voce omai, con altro vello
8  ritornerò poeta, e in sul fonte
9  del mio battesmo prenderò 'l cappello;
