10  Because into the Faith that maketh known
11  All souls to God there entered I, and then
12  Peter for her sake thus my brow encircled.

10  però che ne la fede, che fa conte
11  l'anime a Dio, quivi intra' io, e poi
12  Pietro per lei sì mi girò la fronte.

13  Thereafterward towards us moved a light
14  Out of that band whence issued the first-fruits
15  Which of his vicars Christ behind him left,

13  Indi si mosse un lume verso noi
14  di quella spera ond' uscì la primizia
15  che lasciò Cristo d'i vicari suoi;

16  And then my Lady, full of ecstasy,
17  Said unto me: "Look, look! behold the Baron
18  For whom below Galicia is frequented."

16  e la mia donna, piena di letizia,
17  mi disse: “Mira, mira: ecco il barone
18  per cui là giù si vicita Galizia.”

19  In the same way as, when a dove alights
20  Near his companion, both of them pour forth,
21  Circling about and murmuring, their affection,

19  Sì come quando il colombo si pone
20  presso al compagno, l'uno a l'altro pande,
21  girando e mormorando, l'affezione;

22  So one beheld I by the other grand
23  Prince glorified to be with welcome greeted,
24  Lauding the food that there above is eaten.

22  così vid' ïo l'un da l'altro grande
23   principe glorïoso essere accolto,
24  laudando il cibo che là sù li prande.

25  But when their gratulations were complete,
26  Silently 'coram me' each one stood still,
27  So incandescent it o'ercame my sight.

25  Ma poi che 'l gratular si fu assolto,
26  tacito coram me ciascun s'affisse,
27  ignito sì che vincëa 'l mio volto.

28  Smiling thereafterwards, said Beatrice:
29  "Illustrious life, by whom the benefactions
30  Of our Basilica have been described,

28  Ridendo allora Bëatrice disse:
29  “Inclita vita per cui la larghezza
30  de la nostra basilica si scrisse,

31  Make Hope resound within this altitude;
32  Thou knowest as oft thou dost personify it
33  As Jesus to the three gave greater clearness."—

31  fa risonar la spene in questa altezza:
32  tu sai, che tante fiate la figuri,
33  quante lesù ai tre fé più carezza.”

34  "Lift up thy head, and make thyself assured;
35  For what comes hither from the mortal world
36  Must needs be ripened in our radiance."

34  “Leva la testa e fa che t'assicuri:
35  ché ciò che vien qua sù del mortal mondo,
36  convien ch'ai nostri raggi si maturi.”

37  This comfort came to me from the second fire;
38  Wherefore mine eyes I lifted to the hills,
39  Which bent them down before with too great weight.

37  Questo conforto del foco secondo
38  mi venne; ond' io leväi li occhi a' monti
39  che li 'ncurvaron pria col troppo pondo.

40  "Since, through his grace, our Emperor wills that thou
41   Shouldst find thee face to face, before thy death,
42  In the most secret chamber, with his Counts,

40  “Poi che per grazia vuol che tu t'affronti
41  lo nostro Imperadore, anzi la morte,
42  ne l'aula più secreta co' suoi conti,

43  So that, the truth beholden of this court,
44  Hope, which below there rightfully enamours,
45  Thereby thou strengthen in thyself and others,

43  sì che, veduto il ver di questa corte,
44  la spene, che là giù bene innamora,
45  in te e in altrui di ciò conforte,

46  Say what it is, and how is flowering with it
47  Thy mind, and say from whence it came to thee."
48  Thus did the second light again continue.

46  dì quel ch'ell' è, dì come se ne 'nfiora
47  la mente tua, e dì onde a te venne.”
48  Così seguì 'l secondo lume ancora.

49  And the Compassionate, who piloted
50  The plumage of my wings in such high flight,
51  Did in reply anticipate me thus:

49  E quella pïa che guidò le penne
50  de le mie ali a così alto volo,
51  a la risposta così mi prevenne:

52  "No child whatever the Church Militant
53  Of greater hope possesses, as is written
54  In that Sun which irradiates all our band;

52  “La Chiesa militante alcun figliuolo
53  non ha con più speranza, com' è scritto
54  nel Sol che raggia tutto nostro stuolo:

55  Therefore it is conceded him from Egypt
56  To come into Jerusalem to see,
57  Or ever yet his warfare be completed.

55  però li è conceduto che d'Egitto
56  vegna in Ierusalemme per vedere,
57  anzi che 'l militar li sia prescritto.

58  The two remaining points, that not for knowledge
59  Have been demanded, but that he report
60  How much this virtue unto thee is pleasing,

58  Li altri due punti, che non per sapere
59  son dimandati, ma perch' ei rapporti
60  quanto questa virtù t'è in piacere,

61  To him I leave; for hard he will not find them,
62  Nor of self-praise; and let him answer them;
63  And may the grace of God in this assist him!"

61  a lui lasc' io, ché non li saran forti
62  né di iattanza; ed elli a ciò risponda,
63  e la grazia di Dio ciò li comporti.”

64  As a disciple, who his teacher follows,
65  Ready and willing, where he is expert,
66  That his proficiency may be displayed,

64  Come discente ch'a dottor seconda
65  pronto e libente in quel ch'elli è esperto,
66  perché la sua bontà si disasconda,

67  "Hope," said I, "is the certain expectation
68  Of future glory, which is the effect
69  Of grace divine and merit precedent.

67  “Spene,” diss' io, “è uno attender certo
68  de la gloria futura, il qual produce
69  grazia divina e precedente merto.

70  From many stars this light comes unto me;
71  But he instilled it first into my heart
72  Who was chief singer unto the chief captain.

70  Da molte stelle mi vien questa luce;
71  ma quei la distillò nel mio cor pria
72  che fu sommo cantor del sommo duce.

73  'Sperent in te,' in the high Theody
74  He sayeth, 'those who know thy name;' and who
75  Knoweth it not, if he my faith possess?

73  'Sperino in te,' ne la sua tëodia
74  dice, 'color che sanno il nome tuo':
75  e chi nol sa, s'elli ha la fede mia?

76  Thou didst instil me, then, with his instilling
77  In the Epistle, so that I am full,
78  And upon others rain again your rain."

76  Tu mi stillasti, con lo stillar suo,
77  ne la pistola poi; sì ch'io son pieno,
78  e in altrui vostra pioggia repluo.”

79  While I was speaking, in the living bosom
80  Of that combustion quivered an effulgence,
81  Sudden and frequent, in the guise of lightning;

79  Mentr' io diceva, dentro al vivo seno
80  di quello incendio tremolava un lampo
81  sùbito e spesso a guisa di baleno.

82  Then breathed: "The love wherewith I am inflamed
83  Towards the virtue still which followed me
84  Unto the palm and issue of the field,

82  Indi spirò: “L'amore ond'ïo avvampo
83  ancor ver' la virtù che mi seguette
84  infin la palma e a l'uscir del campo,

85  Wills that I breathe to thee that thou delight
86  In her; and grateful to me is thy telling
87  Whatever things Hope promises to thee."

85  vuol ch'io respiri a te che ti dilette
86  di lei; ed emmi a grato che tu diche
87  quello che la speranza ti 'mpromette.”

88  And I: "The ancient Scriptures and the new
89  The mark establish, and this shows it me,
90  Of all the souls whom God hath made his friends.

88  E io: “Le nove e le scritture antiche
89  pongon lo segno, ed esso lo mi addita,
90  de l'anime che Dio s'ha fatte amiche.

91  Isaiah saith, that each one garmented
92  In his own land shall be with twofold garments,
93  And his own land is this delightful life.

91  Dice Isaia che ciascuna vestita
92  ne la sua terra fia di doppia vesta:
93  e la sua terra è questa dolce vita;

94  Thy brother, too, far more explicitly,
95  There where he treateth of the robes of white,
96  This revelation manifests to us."

94  e 'l tuo fratello assai vie più digesta,
95  là dove tratta de le bianche stole,
96  questa revelazion ci manifesta.”

97  And first, and near the ending of these words,
98  "Sperent in te" from over us was heard,
99  To which responsive answered all the carols.

97  E prima, appresso al fin d'este parole,
98  “Sperent in te” di sopr' a noi s'udì;
99  a che rispuoser tutte le carole.

100  Thereafterward a light among them brightened,
101  So that, if Cancer one such crystal had,
102  Winter would have a month of one sole day.

100  Poscia tra esse un lume si schiarì
101  sì che, se 'l Cancro avesse un tal cristallo,
102  l'inverno avrebbe un mese d'un sol dì.

103  And as uprises, goes, and enters the dance
104  A winsome maiden, only to do honour
105  To the new bride, and not from any failing,

103  E come surge e va ed entra in ballo
104  vergine lieta, sol per fare onore
105  a la novizia, non per alcun fallo,

106  Even thus did I behold the brightened splendour
107  Approach the two, who in a wheel revolved
108  As was beseeming to their ardent love.

106  così vid' io lo schiarato splendore
107  venire a' due che si volgieno a nota
108  qual conveniesi al loro ardente amore.

109  Into the song and music there it entered;
110  And fixed on them my Lady kept her look,
111  Even as a bride silent and motionless.

109  Misesi lì nel canto e ne la rota;
110  e la mia donna in lor tenea l'aspetto,
111  pur come sposa tacita e immota.

112  "This is the one who lay upon the breast
113  Of him our Pelican; and this is he
114  To the great office from the cross elected."

112  “Questi è colui che giacque sopra 'l petto
113  del nostro pellicano, e questi fue
114   di su la croce al grande officio eletto.”

115  My Lady thus; but therefore none the more
116  Did move her sight from its attentive gaze
117  Before or afterward these words of hers.

115  La donna mia così; né però piùe
116  mosser la vista sua di stare attenta
117  poscia che prima le parole sue.

118  Even as a man who gazes, and endeavours
119  To see the eclipsing of the sun a little,
120  And who, by seeing, sightless doth become,

118  Qual è colui ch'adocchia e s'argomenta
119  di vedere eclissar lo sole un poco,
120  che, per veder, non vedente diventa;

121  So I became before that latest fire,
122  While it was said, "Why dost thou daze thyself
123  To see a thing which here hath no existence?

121  tal mi fec'ïo a quell' ultimo foco
122  mentre che detto fu: “Perché t'abbagli
123  per veder cosa che qui non ha loco?

124  Earth in the earth my body is, and shall be
125  With all the others there, until our number
126  With the eternal proposition tallies.

124  In terra è terra il mio corpo, e saragli
125  tanto con li altri, che 'l numero nostro
126  con l'etterno proposito s'agguagli.

127  With the two garments in the blessed cloister
128  Are the two lights alone that have ascended:
129  And this shalt thou take back into your world."
127  Con le due stole nel beato chiostro
128  son le due luci sole che saliro;
129  e questo apporterai nel mondo vostro.”

130  And at this utterance the flaming circle
131  Grew quiet, with the dulcet intermingling
132  Of sound that by the trinal breath was made,

130  A questa voce l'infiammato giro
131  si quïetò con esso il dolce mischio
132  che si facea nel suon del trino spiro,

133  As to escape from danger or fatigue
134  The oars that erst were in the water beaten
135  Are all suspended at a whistle's sound.

133  sì come, per cessar fatica o rischio,
134  li remi, pria ne l'acqua ripercossi,
135  tutti si posano al sonar d'un fischio.

136  Ah, how much in my mind was I disturbed,
137  When I turned round to look on Beatrice,
138  That her I could not see, although I was


136  Ahi quanto ne la mente mi commossi,
137  quando mi volsi per veder Beatrice,
138  per non poter veder, benché io fossi

139  Close at her side and in the Happy World!

139  presso di lei, e nel mondo felice!

Canto XXVI
If we try to understand Dante with only the tools we natively possessed before encountering him, we will have wasted our experience of reading him.  For more than any poet or author that I know, he gives us the tools in his work to expand our methods of understanding — with heart, with mind, with senses.   He not only gives us the tools to deeply delve his Commedia, but he also shows us how it is possible to use language as a catalyst of understanding between ourselves and other human beings, and, more astonishingly, as a tool to evolve how our understanding can reach out to explore and to augment the nature of Nature and the nature of the underlying intelligence from which Nature evolves.

I find that as I have proceeded in these readings, and especially in these notes, that my approach has slowed down, my confidence waning.  Maybe this is due to my illness, and the difficulty I have in finding as my body has suffered, that bliss, which is described repeatedly in the Paradiso.  But I think there is more to it than that.  He asks here that the mind and heart explore limits, or boundaries, which in Dante's text is the word "segno," sign, a word that has a huge number of meanings, 18 according to Google Translate, and it is the transgression of this segno, which Adam says was the cause of his expulsion from Eden.  But let me backtrack, and see if I can iterate some of the signs, the boundary lines, that make this canto a cosmos, and not a chaos.  Dante seems here to be linking things together, Virgil's, or to be more precise, philosophic reason, and Beatrice's love.  The whole thing whirls around the metaphor of blindness, the limits of sight have been transcended, and now it is hearing, and specifically speech, which forges cosmos from chaos.  I think it is weird that Saint John's speech is heard on a breath — spiro — a trope is used twice in the canto.  Previously in the Commedia, breath has been an exclusive property of Dante, a living physical being among shades and spirits, but here, a spirit, who has already in the previous canto declared himself an illusion — not there/here — his body buried on Earth, is breathing, and launching articulate speech upon the current of that breath.  Speaking and breath are the prerogative of the living, whether on Earth or in any of the three domains of what we now refer to as the afterlife.  And at the end of this canto, Adam makes it clear that these signs, made comprehensible by speaking, are mutable, precisely because they lie within the orbit of human logic and reason.  Reason's boundaries are flexible.  But in an inflexible way, they are determined by speech.  We might note that so often in the Inferno — since so much of that realm was dark, and impenetrable to light and sight — the order of sense modalities was hear/see, or even smell/hear/see.  This sequence has often been reversed in the Paradiso, so that we see first, and then hear.  But in this canto, the blind Dante, must hear first, and what he hears is the breathy speech of Saint John.  The obvious allusion here is to Saint Paul on his road to Damascus.  Paul is blinded and knocked off his horse, and when restored, he has a new name, a new life, and a new goal.  Indeed goals, the soul's goals, are an issue in this canto, when, using the arrow trope again, Saint John askes Dante what are his goals.  Everywhere here signs set boundaries, those limits being placed between philosophic reason and the allure of love, the Old testament of Genesis and the New of John's gospel, the beginning of Dante's journey through the realms of the Commedia and the ultimate earthly beginning of Adam in Eden.  The original Eden here is defined as the same place from which Dante, lost and in despair, begins his poetic trek.  One of the things that has puzzled me is how much of the pain of Hell is constantly and bitterly referred to in Heaven.  Is this too a question of setting boundaries?  Here it is an eagle, a bird of prey, and God's bite, that sets a boundary to suffering by imposing suffering.  On the other side of this suffering, is the love and healing (let's not forget that!), which pours from the light of the Beatrice's eyes.  We are guided to the ultimate revelation by the lure of love, the radiance of goodness, and, by the bite of wrath, regret, and retribution.  I think it is significant too, that in this canto, Dante asserts that all of existence is the expression of love, although that love can become twisted — "torto" — as it is in Hell, where the denizens have chosen to continuously embrace the evil, which causes them pain. 

The ending of this canto sounds very strange to modern ears, all those numbers of years and hours which Adam has endured from the moment of his creation.  Adam tells us the times of his life in Eden, his physical life, and the lifespan of the Earth since his expulsion from Eden.  To the medieval mind, these numbers might have seemed quite literal, for us, they must be symbols, references to proportionality.  The proportion the moments of innocence and bliss is tiny compared to the days and years of our life, and the proportion of our lives to the life of Earth is but a fraction.   Above all, these numbers are an indication that just as there are spatial limits to the created cosmos, there are also temporal ones.  To transgress either of these two boundaries, for Dante, is to descend into inarticulate non-existence, a taste of which seems to be emblematically presented in that frozen, wind machine of Satan, who has lost all subjective presence and exists merely as a pain-producing process.  But it should be noted, that still this figure sets a boundary, a boundary defined by linguistic signs.  Beyond this humans cannot go.  Blake had a curious aphorism which may be apropos as a conclusion here:  

There is a limit of Opakeness, and a limit of Contraction:
In every individual man, and the limit of Opakeness
Is named Satan, and the limit of Contraction is named Adam.

1  While I was doubting for my vision quenched,
2  Out of the flame refulgent that had quenched it
3  Issued a breathing, that attentive made me,

2  de la fulgida fiamma che lo spense

6  'Tis well that speaking thou shouldst compensate it.

4  dicendo: “Intanto che tu ti risense
5  de la vista che haï in me consunta,
6  ben è che ragionando la compense.

8  Is aimed, and count it for a certainty,
9  Sight is in thee bewildered and not dead;

19  The selfsame voice, that taken had from me

140  fu'io, con vita pura e disonesta,
141  da la prim' ora a quella che seconda,

142  come 'l sol muta quadra, l'ora sesta.”

Canto XXVII
Years ago, I had a friend whose mother was a closet devotee of a certain television fire and brimstone evangelical.  For her it was like a shameful addiction, like watching snuff-video porn.  She tried to quit, told friends and family, that she had quit, and overtly converted to the milder forms of the dearly belovèd sects of Christianity.  But always she would go back to her secret love.  When I asked my friend why his mother would do such a thing, he said, "She cannot give up the pleasures of Hell."  Punishment, retribution, the violent righting of perceived wrongs, these themes persist in Dante, and for the reader, as we proceed with him into these higher and higher domains of Paradise, the contrast between the love and bliss of apotheosis and the continued dark rumblings of damnation and punishment, become ... well ... become more and more ironic.  It may be that even so fine a mind as Dante's is incurably addicted to a Medieval idea of punishment, and that the taint of crime cannot be forgiven, until the scales of justice are balanced by inflicting an equal amount of pain on the perpetrators of pain.  Jehovah is not Jesus, and there will be no 70 times 70 forgivenesses of sin or turning of the other cheek.  And the Jesus who stood silent before Pilate is hardly the Jesus of Revelation.  We keep going back to the dark because in spite of our outward need to show that we are not like that, we are indeed like that, and we like it.  It may be too, that the Commedia's Medieval mania for punishment is an ineradicable part of the cosmos, which will forever infect humanity.  We cannot seem to expunge that metaphor which tells us life is war, and this field of competing violences is as much a part of the quest for peace and love as is the practice of peace and love.  To me, this is a sickening thought, which in Christianity is only placated by an imaginargy period following the Last Judgement.  To get to that imaginary place, in this trope, there must be a final paroxysm of violence that ends violence by ending the violent.  If we review the previous canto on hope, we see that hope includes the hope that our enemies may suffer and be destroyed.  The world being what the world seems to be, and we ourselves being what we seem to be, what exactly could my friend's mother experience in terms of prolonged joy and love?  And how exactly could she could begin to find as much solace in sermons of Heaven as she did in tirades threatening Hell?  Aspirations can live in the imagination, but the history of physical bodies is not lived soley in the imagination, and when push comes to shove, sickness, injustice, and violence make up a large part of actual human experience.  We know that in our 20th/ 21st century world, we are just as keen on violence and punishment as were the worst of the post-Medieval inquisitors.  Aren't the rationales for violence often conceived as a quest for justice or purity.  And doesn't retributive violence contain with in its atrocities, the momentum of joy? There is no doubt that for every reader of the Commedia who persists in their readings through the canticles depicting Purgatory and Paradise, there are 1O readers who stop with reading the Inferno, and maybe this is so for the same reasons that a lie will travel 6 times faster through the labyrinths of social media than the truth.  What revolution or revelation needs to take place in the psyche for peace and love to obliterate violence and hate?  One could almost say that violence and hate — and pain, let's not forget pain — are the fuel which propels the soul to not only search for, but to actually enjoy the bliss of Heaven.  To me, this is a scary, cynical thought.  And maybe it should be.  Maybe we really do have to be as little children, as naive about pulling the wings off flies as we are in seeking the sweetness of maternal warmth.  It has taken me much longer to read each canto of the Paradiso, than it did to get through the canti of the Purgatorio and the Inferno, and perhaps this is because these paradoxes that continue to slice through our lives as disease, aging, pain can find no permanent analgesic in stories of eternal joy and bliss, and like Saint Peter — the chameleon — in this canto, when we confront these verities in the world, we change color, and more than color, we change the very sound of our voice, and growl the threats of Hell, even while submersed in the bliss and light of Heaven.

We could see the issue of proportionality regarding time at the end of canto 26, and here that issue is examined again, not just in the context of space and time, but also regarding the proportionality of the Commedia itself.  While it's obvious that Saint Peter's prophetic denunciation looms large, emotionally, and also in the number of lines devoted to it, immediately following this, for the second time, Beatrice asks Dante to look down and review the vast distance, I would say, in terms of spirit, that he has come.  Point of view is everything, and now that the aspirant and his guide have ascended above the spheres of the fixed stars, Dante finds that his vision of space has also expanded.  We might well ask, as readers at this point, just how important are the affairs of Earth, and just how much consideration do their petty crimes and injustices merit?  In the context of Earth, they are abominations, and they are most abominable (literally this word means "against man") when those in supposed spiritual authority sink into corruption, fomenting war, fraud, and greed.  But in this place above the fixed stars, above our physical sun, they shrink, as do most objects on Earth, as we travel far into outer space, to insignificant invisibilities.  That's what happens to space, when the point of view of a person is expanded by spiritual transfiguration, they see that all those things that were so big, so important in their physical, moral, and emotional lives were in their cramping finitude as nothing compared to infinity.  But it is not only the perception of space that changes, time too changes.  This is illustrated in Canto 27 by the fact that the precession of the fixed stars through the Zodiac, which takes eons on Earth, here is accomplished in Saint Paul's twinkling of an eye.  Just as when the senses, in a spiritual experience become exponentially more acute, and we become more aware by slowing down our ordinary mind chatter, time seems to slow down, because awareness has speeded up.  The moments grow in volume, as there speed becomes inconsequential.  So at the center of this cyclone of awareness, the outer events on the wheel are seen to be whirling around one's own core stillness.

The way this canto proceeds shows us that the aspirant, and hopefully the reader too, is nearing the final stages of what could be seen as an initiation ceremony, painful and arduous at first, but becoming more and more enlightening as it approaches its final apotheosis.  One illusion after another has been experienced as if it were the only reality, and yet none of those realities had anything like an impregnable boundary line.  In the journey of the spirit, one by one, no matter how intense were our experiences in certain contexts, they are shown only to be dominant within those contexts.  As their boundaries were transcended, they are seen, at best, to be only the dumbshows of bad actors, playing their tragically ridiculous roles amidst shabby sets, and forgetting that the world they live in is only cardboard, the bodies they act in only costumes of vapor.  What happens when all those attributes by which we identified ourselves as our self, are seen through, and when space and time, the very bedrock of those attributes are seen to be changing?  That is the question we are occupied with here.  But, that is not the most important question.  The more crucial question is: What's next? 

1  "Glory be to the Father, to the Son,
2  And Holy Ghost!" all Paradise began,
3  So that the melody inebriate made me.

1  Al Padre, al Figlio, a lo Spirito Santo,
2  cominciò, “gloria!” tutto 'l paradiso,
3  sì che m'inebrïava il dolce canto.

4  What I beheld seemed unto me a smile
5  Of the universe; for my inebriation
6  Found entrance through the hearing and the sight.

4  Ciò ch'io vedeva mi sembiava un riso
5  de l'universo; per che mia ebbrezza
6  intrava per l'udire e per lo viso.

7   O joy! O gladness inexpressible!
8  O perfect life of love and peacefulness!
9  O riches without hankering secure!

8  oh vita intègra d'amore e di pace!
9  oh sanza brama sicura ricchezza!

11  Enkindled, and the one that first had come
12  Began to make itself more luminous;

15  Were birds, and they should interchange their feathers.

13  e tal ne la sembianza sua divenne,
14  qual diverrebbe Iove, s'elli e Marte
15  fossero augelli e cambiassersi penne.

16  That Providence, which here distributeth
17  Season and service, in the blessed choir
18  Had silence upon every side imposed.

16  La provedenza, che quivi comparte
17  vice e officio, nel beato coro
18  silenzio posto avea da ogne parte,

19  When I heard say: "If I my colour change,
20  Marvel not at it; for while I am speaking
21  Thou shalt behold all these their colour change.

19  quand'ïo udi': “Se io mi trascoloro,
20  non ti maravigliar, ché, dicend' io
21  vedrai trascolorar tutti costoro.

22  He who usurps upon the earth my place,
23  My place, my place, which vacant has become
24  Before the presence of the Son of God,

22  Quelli ch'usurpa in terra il luogo mio,
23  il luogo mio, il luogo mio che vaca
24  ne la presenza del Figliuol di Dio,

25  Has of my cemetery made a sewer
26  Of blood and stench, whereby the Perverse One,
27  Who fell from here, below there is appeased!"

25  fatt' ha del cimitero mio cloaca
26  del sangue e de la puzza; onde 'l perverso
27  che cadde di qua sù, là giù si placa.”

28  With the same colour which, through sun adverse,
29  Painteth the clouds at evening or at morn,
30  Beheld I then the whole of heaven suffused.

28  Di quel color che per lo sole avverso
29  nube dipigne da sera e da mane,
30  vid'ïo allora tutto 'l ciel cosperso.
 
31  And as a modest woman, who abides
32  Sure of herself, and at another's failing,
33  From listening only, timorous becomes,

31  E come donna onesta che permane
32  di sé sicura, e per l'altrui fallanza,
33  pur ascoltando, timida si fane,

34  Even thus did Beatrice change countenance;
35  And I believe in heaven was such eclipse,
36  When suffered the supreme Omnipotence;

34  così Beatrice trasmutò sembianza;
35  e tale eclissi credo che 'n ciel fue
36  quando patì la supprema possanza.

37  Thereafterward proceeded forth his words
38  With voice so much transmuted from itself,
39  The very countenance was not more changed.

37  Poi procedetter le parole sue
38  con voce tanto da sé trasmutata,
39  che la sembianza non si mutò piùe:

40  "The spouse of Christ has never nurtured been
41  On blood of mine, of Linus and of Cletus,
42  To be made use of in acquest of gold;

40  “Non fu la sposa di Cristo allevata
41  del sangue mio, di Lin, di quel di Cleto,
42  per essere ad acquisto d'oro usata;

43  But in acquest of this delightful life
44  Sixtus and Pius, Urban and Calixtus,
45  After much lamentation, shed their blood.

43  ma per acquisto d'esto viver lieto
44  e Sisto e Pïo e Calisto e Urbano
45  sparser lo sangue dopo molto fleto.

46  Our purpose was not, that on the right hand
47  Of our successors should in part be seated
48  The Christian folk, in part upon the other;

46  Non fu nostra intenzion ch'a destra mano
47  d'i nostri successor parte sedesse,
48  parte da l'altra del popol cristiano; 

49  Nor that the keys which were to me confided
50  Should e'er become the escutcheon on a banner,
51  That should wage war on those who are baptized;

49  né che le chiavi che mi fuor concesse,
50  divenisser signaculo in vessillo
51  che contra battezzati combattesse;

52  Nor I be made the figure of a seal
53  To privileges venal and mendacious,
54  Whereat I often redden and flash with fire.

52  né ch'io fossi figura di sigillo
53  a privilegi venduti e mendaci,
56  ond' io sovente arrosso e disfavillo.

55  In garb of shepherds the rapacious wolves
56  Are seen from here above o'er all the pastures!
57  O wrath of God, why dost thou slumber still?

55  In vesta di pastor lupi rapaci
56  si veggion di qua sù per tutti i paschi:
57  o difesa di Dio, perché pur giaci?

58  To drink our blood the Caorsines and Gascons
59  Are making ready. O thou good beginning,
60  Unto how vile an end must thou needs fall!

58  Del sangue nostro Caorsini e Guaschi
59  s'apparecchian di bere: o buon principio,
60  a che vil fine convien che tu caschi!

61  But the high Providence, that with Scipio
62  At Rome the glory of the world defended,
63  Will speedily bring aid, as I conceive;

61  Ma l'alta provedenza, che con Scipio
62  difese a Roma la gloria del mondo,
63  soccorrà tosto, sì com' io concipio;

64  And thou, my son, who by thy mortal weight
65  Shalt down return again, open thy mouth;
66  What I conceal not, do not thou conceal."

64  e tu, figliuol, che per lo mortal pondo
65  ancor giù tornerai, apri la bocca,
66  e non asconder quel ch'io non ascondo.”

67  As with its frozen vapours downward falls
68  In flakes our atmosphere, what time the horn
69  Of the celestial Goat doth touch the sun,

67  Si come di vapor gelati fiocca
68  in giuso l'aere nostro, quando 'l corno
69  de la capra del ciel col sol si tocca

70  Upward in such array saw I the ether
71  Become, and flaked with the triumphant vapours,
72  Which there together with us had remained.

70  in sù vid' io così l'etera addorno
71  farsi e fioccar di vapor trïunfanti
72  che fatto avien con noi quivi soggiorno.

73  My sight was following up their semblances,
74  And followed till the medium, by excess,
75  The passing farther onward took from it;

73  Lo viso mio seguiva i suoi sembianti,
74  e seguì fin che 'l mezzo, per lo molto,
75  li tolse il trapassar del più avanti.

76  Whereat the Lady, who beheld me freed
77  From gazing upward, said to me: "Cast down
78  Thy sight, and see how far thou art turned round."

76  Onde la donna, che mi vide assolto
77  de l'attendere in sù, mi disse: “Adima
78  il viso e guarda come tu se' vòlto.”

79  Since the first time that I had downward looked,
80  I saw that I had moved through the whole arc
81  Which the first climate makes from midst to end;

79  Da l'ora ch'ïo avea guardato prima
80  i' vidi mosso me per tutto l'arco
81  che fa dal mezzo al fine il primo clima;

82  So that I saw the mad track of Ulysses
83  Past Gades, and this side, well nigh the shore
84  Whereon became Europa a sweet burden.

82  sì ch'io vedea di là da Gade il varco
83  folle d'Ulisse, e di qua presso il lito
84  nel qual si fece Europa dolce carco.

84  And of this threshing-floor the site to me
85  Were more unveiled, but the sun was proceeding
86  Under my feet, a sign and more removed.

85  E più mi fora discoverto il sito
86  di questa aiuola; ma 'l sol procedea
87  sotto i mie' piedi un segno e più partito.

88  My mind enamoured, which is dallying
89  At all times with my Lady, to bring back
90  To her mine eyes was more than ever ardent.

88  La mente innamorata, che donnea
89  con la mia donna sempre, di ridure
90  ad essa li occhi più che mai ardea;

91  And if or Art or Nature has made bait
92  To catch the eyes and so possess the mind,
93  In human flesh or in its portraiture,

91  e se natura o arte fé pasture
92  da pigliare occhi, per aver la mente,
93  in carne umana o ne le sue pitture,

94  All joined together would appear as nought
95  To the divine delight which shone upon me
96  When to her smiling face I turned me round.

94  tutte adunate, parrebber nïente
95  ver' lo piacer divin che mi refulse,
96  quando mi volsi al suo viso ridente.

97  The virtue that her look endowed me with
98  From the fair nest of Leda tore me forth,
99  And up into the swiftest heaven impelled me.

97  E la virtù che lo sguardo m'indulse,
98  del bel nido di Leda mi divelse
99  e nel ciel velocissimo m'impulse.

100  Its parts exceeding full of life and lofty
101  Are all so uniform, I cannot say
102  Which Beatrice selected for my place.

100  Le parti sue vivissime ed eccelse
101  sì uniforme son, ch'i' non so dire
102  qual Bëatrice per loco mi scelse.

103  But she, who was aware of my desire,
104  Began, the while she smiled so joyously
105  That God seemed in her countenance to rejoice:

103  Ma ella, che vedia 'l mio disire,
104  incominciò, ridendo tanto lieta,
105  che Dio parea nel suo volto gioire:

106  "The nature of that motion, which keeps quiet
107  The centre and all the rest about it moves,
108  From hence begins as from its starting point.

106  “La natura del mondo, che quïeta
107  il mezzo e tutto l'altro intorno move,
108  quinci comincia come da sua meta;

109  And in this heaven there is no other Where
110  Than in the Mind Divine, wherein is kindled
111  The love that turns it, and the power it rains.

109  e questo cielo non ha altro dove
110  che la mente divina, in che s'accende
111  l'amor che 'l volge e la virtù ch'ei piove.

112  Within a circle light and love embrace it,
113  Even as this doth the others, and that precinct
114  He who encircles it alone controls.

112  Luce e amor d'un cerchio lui comprende,
113  sì come questo li altri; e quel precinto
114  colui che 'l cinge solamente intende.

115  Its motion is not by another meted,
116  But all the others measured are by this,
117  As ten is by the half and by the fifth.

115  Non è suo moto per altro distinto,
116  ma li altri son mensurati da questo,
117  sì come diece da mezzo e da quinto;

118  And in what manner time in such a pot
119  May have its roots, and in the rest its leaves,
120  Now unto thee can manifest be made.

118  e come il tempo tegna in cotal testo
119  le sue radici e ne li altri le fronde,
120  omai a te può esser manifesto.

121  O Covetousness, that mortals dost ingulf
122  Beneath thee so, that no one hath the power
123  Of drawing back his eyes from out thy waves!

121  Oh cupidigia, che i mortali affonde
122  sì sotto te, che nessuno ha podere
123  di trarre li occhi fuor de le tue onde!
 
124  Full fairly blossoms in mankind the will;
125  But the uninterrupted rain converts
126  Into abortive wildings the true plums.

124  Ben fiorisce ne li uomini il volere;
125  ma la pioggia continüa converte
126  in bozzacchioni le sosine vere.

127  Fidelity and innocence are found
128  Only in children; afterwards they both
129  Take flight or e'er the cheeks with down are covered.

127  Fede e innocenza son reperte
128  solo ne' parvoletti; poi ciascuna
129  pria fugge che le guance sian coperte.

130  One, while he prattles still, observes the fasts,
131  Who, when his tongue is loosed, forthwith devours
132  Whatever food under whatever moon;

130  Tale, balbuzïendo ancor, digiuna,
131  che poi divora, con la lingua sciolta,
132  qualunque cibo per qualunque luna;

133  Another, while he prattles, loves and listens
134  Unto his mother, who when speech is perfect
135  Forthwith desires to see her in her grave.

133  e tal, balbuzïendo, ama e ascolta
134  la madre sua, che, con loquela intera,
135  disïa poi di vederla sepolta.

136  Even thus is swarthy made the skin so white
137  In its first aspect of the daughter fair
138  Of him who brings the morn, and leaves the night.

136  Così si fa la pelle bianca nera
137  nel primo aspetto de la bella figlia
138  di quel ch'apporta mane e lascia sera.

139  Thou, that it may not be a marvel to thee,
140  Think that on earth there is no one who governs;
141  Whence goes astray the human family.

139  Tu, perché non ti facci maraviglia,
140  pensa che 'n terra non è chi governi;
141  onde sì svïa l'umana famiglia.

142  Ere January be unwintered wholly
143  By the centesimal on earth neglected,
144  Shall these supernal circles roar so loud

142  Ma prima che gennaio tutto si sverni
143  per la centesma ch'è là giù negletta,
144  raggeran sì questi cerchi superni,

145  The tempest that has been so long awaited
146  Shall whirl the poops about where are the prows;
147  So that the fleet shall run its course direct,

145  che la fortuna che tanto s'aspetta,
146  le poppe volgerà u' son le prore,
147  sì che la classe correrà diretta;

148  And the true fruit shall follow on the flower."

148  e vero frutto verrà dopo 'l fiore.”

Canto XXVIII
Any novice writer who has swallowed the prohibition against mixed metaphors, needs to ponder the masterful way that Dante has juxtaposed and interwoven the variety of metaphors that he employs in this canto.  Yes, he has been doing this throughout the Commedia, but perhaps here, as much or more as in any canto before, he delights in directing the readers mind in trope after trope, image after image, so that true to the theme of the canto, it seems to the attentive reader that his brain has been stimulated in so many different places, that his mind lights up, just as does the protagonist-Dante's in this splendid canto.  This lighting up of the mind or the soul is what Dante calls "seeing," or better "vision," and he makes so bold here to say that this type of seeing is the progenitor of love, and not the other way around.  Generally speaking we define light with contrasting shadows, here Dante does not do that, but rather he defines different qualities of light in comparison to others, so that the mind of the reader is left dazzled.  And yet that dazzle is in effect made tolerable to the mind and eyes, instead of blinding them, by his switching back and forth to those many metaphors he employs, many of which refer to experiences that we might have in everyday life.  The double candled lamp seen in a mirror, the eyes of Beatrice, a swiftly revolving sphere whose brightest highlight, like the eye of God, attracts all gazes, a star which would dwarf in the night the light of the moon, halos, rings of fire, speeds speeding ever faster, fingers plied to a knot, the mind needing, like a body, to be fed, skies cleared by soft breezes, smelting iron shooting out fiery sparks, puzzled thoughts, and the puzzle of doubling numbers in the 64 squares that constitute the geography of a chess board, blossoms in spring, astrological signs, and of course those recurring number motifs of threes and nines.  It would be a mistake for the modern reader to think this ordering of angels is but a bit or archaic jugglery, too arcane to merit our attention.  We need only remember that these angelic orders are each one indicative of an area of study or knowledge as presented in the Trivium (grammar, rhetoric, logic), and Quadrivium (arithmetic, astronomy, geometry, and music), whose combined curriculums constitute the complete source of knowledge, which any scholar of the period, or any scholar now, might pursue in a lifetime of study, comparing how these orders of realities relate to the acquisition of knowledge and the perfecting of the mind.  But essentially we find that all of these interwoven entities are here "seen" as when an advanced meditator sees the blue light of the so-called third eye, pierced by a star, and centered as Dante relates here in the forehead.  After looking at a bright light, and closing one's eyes, a light, appears — usually red, but sometimes neon green or blue, with these colors circling one another.  These are called entoptic phenomena, and are the result of the optic nerve being stimulated when the eyelids are closed and no external light enters.  Archeologists hypothesize that a great many shapes carved into those petroglyphs found throughout the world are the result of these internal visions.  Whatever is in there, in terms of knowledge, generally dazzles the psychonaut, and has about it such a shocking and numinous quality that these voyages into the deeper areas of consciousness strike the one who experiences them as hyper-real, revelations with a cosmological aspect, which seem to be interconnected, and yet still divided into phases of creativity, which are coincident here with the order of divine entities circling around the light of God.  These phases become apparent to any artist who penetrates deeply enough into his craft — craft here taken to mean a mastery of unseen power, as Masons refer to their rites as the craft.  These phenomena are not only seen, but made use of.  This is what Dante is revealing about his own mastery, a mastery that is two-fold: aesthetic and spiritual.  This is a more primeval way of looking at poetry.  In primeval cultures art, healing, and spirituality are all one thing, whereas we have divided them — I think to our peril — into entertainment, medical science, and religion.  If this is so, then we are the fragmented degenerate epigone of peoples who knew more about living harmoniously on this physical plane and beyond, than we now do — which may be the cause of all the angst and violence that we suffer trying to find a meaningful joyous life in the absence of any essential unity.  The one thing, the one obsession, we may call it, of Dante, the poet, is to create a unified form from the worst to the blessed, and as we come to the close of the Commedia, his formalization of cosmological insights have acquired a deeper and vaster sweep.  I would add one more thing to this.  Why should we bother with this craft which seems no more than the exposition of Medieval theology.  The terms Dante uses are long out of fashion for us, and we are apt to view them as obsolete, and therefore, inconsequential.  But I think that what the reader  — in this or in any age — is called upon to learn is a certain type of metaskill, that is, the art and craft of cross-context learning.  We are being gifted here a methodology to achieve not only mastery but transcendence, and yet the idiom by which this methodology is expressed is alien to us.  To make these insights, our own insight, we must be able to lift them out of the context of 14th century Italy, and by certain operations, permutate that idiom so that it becomes pertinent to where we are now and to what we need to experience and know in order to repair our own fragmented and violent inner lives and social and political disjunctions.  We must study, and learn, but study cannot be only that of academic footnotes.  Our study must be made by means of linking our consciousness with that of an internal Dante, to see our world as Dante saw his, by means of adopting his masterful way of seeing, and by that means translating his idiom into our own.  Dante learned something in the decades he spent writing his poem, and what he learned and, more crucially, how he learned, is encoded in the poem.  For more than eight centuries that code has stood the test of time, and of the radical changes of worldviews and cultures, which have ensued.  To decipher that code in our own here and now is the task of each reader, and if we look deeply enough into ourselves and into the poem, that code can be read and made to create our own guidance system through the troubling baffles of our own chaotic times. 

1  After the truth against the present life
2  Of miserable mortals was unfolded
3  By her who doth imparadise my mind,

1  Poscia che 'ncontro a la vita presente
2  d'i miseri mortali aperse 'l vero
3  quella che 'mparadisa la mia mente,

4  As in a looking-glass a taper's flame
5  He sees who from behind is lighted by it,
6  Before he has it in his sight or thought,

4  come in lo specchio fiamma di doppiero
5  vede colui che se n'alluma retro,
6  prima che l'abbia in vista o in pensiero,

7  And turns him round to see if so the glass
8  Tell him the truth, and sees that it accords
9  Therewith as doth a music with its metre,

7  e sé rivolge per veder se 'l vetro
8  li dice il vero, e vede ch'el s'accorda
9  con esso come nota con suo metro;

10  In similar wise my memory recollecteth
11  That I did, looking into those fair eyes,
12  Of which Love made the springes to ensnare me.

10  così la mia memoria si ricorda
11  ch'io feci riguardando ne' belli occhi
12  onde a pigliarmi fece Amor la corda.

13  And as I turned me round, and mine were touched
14  By that which is apparent in that volume,
15  Whenever on its gyre we gaze intent,

13  E com' io mi rivolsi e furon tocchi
14  li miei da ciò che pare in quel volume,
15  quandunque nel suo giro ben s'adocchi,

16  A point beheld I, that was raying out
17  Light so acute, the sight which it enkindles
18  Must close perforce before such great acuteness.

16  un punto vidi che raggiava lume
17  acuto sì, che 'l viso ch'elli affoca
18  chiuder conviensi per lo forte acume;

19  And whatsoever star seems smallest here
20  Would seem to be a moon, if placed beside it.
21  As one star with another star is placed.

19  e quale stella par quinci più poca,
20  parrebbe luna, locata con esso
21  come stella con stella si collòca.

22  Perhaps at such a distance as appears
23  A halo cincturing the light that paints it,
24  When densest is the vapour that sustains it,

22  Forse cotanto quanto pare appresso
23  alo cigner la luce che 'l dipigne
24  quando 'l vapor che 'l porta più è spesso,

25  Thus distant round the point a circle of fire
26  So swiftly whirled, that it would have surpassed
27  Whatever motion soonest girds the world;

25  distante intorno al punto un cerchio d'igne
26  si girava sì ratto, ch'avria vinto
27  quel moto che più tosto il mondo cigne;

28  And this was by another circumcinct,
29  That by a third, the third then by a fourth,
30  By a fifth the fourth, and then by a sixth the fifth;

28  e questo era d'un altro circumcinto,
29  e quel dal terzo, e 'l terzo poi dal quarto,
30  dal quinto il quarto, e poi dal sesto il quinto.

31  The seventh followed thereupon in width
32  So ample now, that Juno's messenger
33  Entire would be too narrow to contain it.

31  Sopra seguiva il settimo sì sparto
32  già di larghezza, che 'l messo di Iuno
33  intero a contenerlo sarebbe arto.

34  Even so the eighth and ninth; and every one
35  More slowly moved, according as it was
36  In number distant farther from the first.

34  Così l'ottavo e 'l nono; e ciascheduno
35  più tardo si movea, secondo ch'era
36  in numero distante più da l'uno;

37  And that one had its flame most crystalline
38  From which less distant was the stainless spark,
39  I think because more with its truth imbued.

37  e quello avea la fiamma più sincera
38  cui men distava la favilla pura,
39  credo, però che più di lei s'invera.

40  My Lady, who in my anxiety
41  Beheld me much perplexed, said: "From that point
42  Dependent is the heaven and nature all.

40  La donna mia, che mi vedëa in cura
41  forte sospeso, disse: “Da quel punto
42  depende il cielo e tutta la natura.

43  Behold that circle most conjoined to it,
44  And know thou, that its motion is so swift
45  Through burning love whereby it is spurred on."

43  Mira quel cerchio che più li è congiunto;
44 e sappi che 'l suo muovere è sì tosto
45  per l'affocato amore ond' elli è punto.”

46  And I to her: "If the world were arranged
47  In the order which I see in yonder wheels,
48  What's set before me would have satisfied me;

46  E io a lei: “Se 'l mondo fosse posto
47  con l'ordine ch'io veggio in quelle rote,
48  sazio m'avrebbe ciò che m'è proposto;

49  But in the world of sense we can perceive
50  That evermore the circles are diviner
51  As they are from the centre more remote

49  ma nel mondo sensibile si puote
50  veder le volte tanto più divine,
51  quant' elle son dal centro più remote. 

52  Wherefore if my desire is to be ended
53  In this miraculous and angelic temple,
54  That has for confines only love and light,

52  Onde, se 'l mio disir dee aver fine
53  in questo miro e angelico templo
54  che solo amore e luce ha per confine,
55  To hear behoves me still how the example
56  And the exemplar go not in one fashion,
57  Since for myself in vain I contemplate it."

55  udir convienmi ancor come l'essemplo
56  e l'essemplare non vanno d'un modo,
57  ché io per me indarno a ciò contemplo.” 

58  "If thine own fingers unto such a knot
59  Be insufficient, it is no great wonder,
60  So hard hath it become for want of trying."

58  “Se li tuoi diti non sono a tal nodo
59  sufficïenti, non è maraviglia:
60  tanto, per non tentare, è fatto sodo!”

61  My Lady thus; then said she: "Do thou take
62  What I shall tell thee, if thou wouldst be sated,
63  And exercise on that thy subtlety.

61  Così la donna mia; poi disse: “Piglia
62 quel ch'io ti dicerò, se vuo' saziarti;
63 e intorno da esso t'assottiglia.

64  The circles corporal are wide and narrow
65  According to the more or less of virtue
66  Which is distributed through all their parts.

64  Li cerchi corporai sono ampi e arti
65  secondo il più e 'l men de la virtute
66  che si distende per tutte lor parti. 

67  The greater goodness works the greater weal,
68  The greater weal the greater body holds,
69  If perfect equally are all its parts.

67  Maggior bontà vuol far maggior salute;
68  maggior salute maggior corpo cape,
69  s'elli ha le parti igualmente compiute.

70  Therefore this one which sweeps along with it
71  The universe sublime, doth correspond
72  Unto the circle which most loves and knows.

70  Dunque costui che tutto quanto rape
71  l'altro universo seco, corrisponde
72  al cerchio che più ama e che più sape:

73  On which account, if thou unto the virtue
74  Apply thy measure, not to the appearance
75  Of substances that unto thee seem round,

73  per che, se tu a la virtù circonde
74  la tua misura, non a la parvenza
75  de le sustanze che t'appaion tonde,

76  Thou wilt behold a marvellous agreement,
77  Of more to greater, and of less to smaller,
78  In every heaven, with its Intelligence."

76  tu vederai mirabil consequenza
77  di maggio a più e di minore a meno,
78  in ciascun cielo, a sua intelligenza.”

79  Even as remaineth splendid and serene
80  The hemisphere of air, when Boreas
81  Is blowing from that cheek where he is mildest,

79  Come rimane splendido e sereno
80  l'emisperio de l'aere, quando soffia
81  Borea da quella guancia ond' è più leno,

82  Because is purified and resolved the rack
83  That erst disturbed it, till the welkin laughs
84  With all the beauties of its pageantry;

82  per che si purga e risolve la roffia
83  che pria turbava, sì che 'l ciel ne ride
84  con le bellezze d'ogne sua paroffia;

85  Thus did I likewise, after that my Lady
86  Had me provided with her clear response,
87  And like a star in heaven the truth was seen.

85  così fec'ïo, poi che mi provide
86  la donna mia del suo risponder chiaro,
87  e come stella in cielo il ver si vide.

88  And soon as to a stop her words had come,
89  Not otherwise does iron scintillate
90  When molten, than those circles scintillated.

88  E poi che le parole sue restaro,
89  non altrimenti ferro disfavilla
90  che bolle, come i cerchi sfavillaro.

91  Their coruscation all the sparks repeated,
92  And they so many were, their number makes
93  More millions than the doubling of the chess.

91  L'incendio suo seguiva ogne scintilla;
92  ed eran tante, che 'l numero loro
93  più che 'l doppiar de li scacchi s'inmilla.

94  I heard them sing hosanna choir by choir
95  To the fixed point which holds them at the 'Ubi,'
96  And ever will, where they have ever been.

94  Io sentiva osannar di coro in coro
95  al punto fisso che li tiene a li ubi,
96  e terrà sempre, ne' quai sempre fuoro.

97  And she, who saw the dubious meditations
98  Within my mind, "The primal circles," said,
99  "Have shown thee Seraphim and Cherubim.

97  E quella che vedëa i pensier dubi
98  ne la mia mente, disse: “I cerchi primi
99  t'hanno mostrato Serafi e Cherubi.

100  Thus rapidly they follow their own bonds,
101  To be as like the point as most they can,
102  And can as far as they are high in vision.

100  Così veloci seguono i suoi vimi,
102  per somigliarsi al punto quanto ponno;
103  e posson quanto a veder son soblimi.

103  Those other Loves, that round about them go,
104  Thrones of the countenance divine are called,
105  Because they terminate the primal Triad.

103  Quelli altri amori che 'ntorno li vonno,
104  si chiaman Troni del divino aspetto,
105  per che 'l primo ternaro terminonno;

106  And thou shouldst know that they all have delight
107  As much as their own vision penetrates
108  The Truth, in which all intellect finds rest.

106  e dei saper che tutti hanno diletto
107  quanto la sua veduta si profonda
108  nel vero in che si queta ogne intelletto.

109  From this it may be seen how blessedness
110  Is founded in the faculty which sees,
111  And not in that which loves, and follows next;

109  Quinci si può veder come si fonda
110  l'esser beato ne l'atto che vede,
111  non in quel ch'ama, che poscia seconda;

112  And of this seeing merit is the measure,
113  Which is brought forth by grace, and by good will;
114  Thus on from grade to grade doth it proceed.

112  e del vedere è misura mercede,
113  che grazia partorisce e buona voglia:
114  così di grado in grado si procede.

115  The second Triad, which is germinating
116  In such wise in this sempiternal spring,
117  That no nocturnal Aries despoils,

115  L'altro ternaro, che così germoglia
116  in questa primavera sempiterna
117  che notturno Arïete non dispoglia,

118  Perpetually hosanna warbles forth
119  With threefold melody, that sounds in three
120  Orders of joy, with which it is intrined.

118  perpetüalemente 'Osanna' sberna
119  con tre melode, che suonano in tree
120  ordini di letizia onde s'interna.

121  The three Divine are in this hierarchy,
122  First the Dominions, and the Virtues next;
123  And the third order is that of the Powers.

121  In essa gerarcia son l'altre dee:
122  prima Dominazioni, e poi Virtudi;
123  l'ordine terzo di Podestadi èe.

124  Then in the dances twain penultimate
125  The Principalities and Archangels wheel;
126  The last is wholly of angelic sports.

124  Poscia ne' due penultimi tripudi
125  Principati e Arcangeli si girano;
126  l'ultimo è tutto d'Angelici ludi. 

127  These orders upward all of them are gazing,
128  And downward so prevail, that unto God
129  They all attracted are and all attract.

127 Questi ordini di sù tutti s'ammirano,
128  e di giù vincon sì, che verso Dio
129  tutti tirati sono e tutti tirano.

130  And Dionysius with so great desire
131  To contemplate these Orders set himself,
132  He named them and distinguished them as I do.

130  E Dïonisio con tanto disio
131  a contemplar questi ordini si mise,
132  che li nomò e distinse com' io.

133  But Gregory afterwards dissented from him;
134  Wherefore, as soon as he unclosed his eyes
135  Within this heaven, he at himself did smile.

133  Ma Gregorio da lui poi si divise;
134  onde, sì tosto come li occhi aperse
135  in questo ciel, di sé medesmo rise.

136  And if so much of secret truth a mortal
137  Proffered on earth, I would not have thee marvel,
138  For he who saw it here revealed it to him,

136  E se tanto secreto ver proferse
137  mortale in terra, non voglio ch'ammiri:
138  ché chi 'l vide qua sù gliel discoperse

139  With much more of the truth about these circles."

139  con altro assai del ver di questi giri.”

Canto XXIX
What is a moment?  In temporal linguistic terms it is too infinitesimally small to measure, but in the first terzets of this canto, Dante does not measure, but rather maps a moment.  Aries, the Ram, a symbol of oppositional conflict, and Libra, the balanced scales of Justice, respectively indicate the spring equinox and the autumn one.  Between these two are the pivot points of the two solstices, summer and winter.  For Dante, time is a position, which one determines by looking up, up, up to the heavens, which is where we are now, passing even above the highest of heavens to the Empyrean.  The condensation of meanings converging around this flash of a smile from Beatrice is remarkable, and Dante's method of poetizing, which he has been training his readers — should I say his "devotees?" — to experience, now for 95 cantos, succinctly states that every moment of time, no matter how infinitesimal is an encapsulation of the whole of time.  And what better way to demonstrate how eternity differs from the seeming sequential nature of historical, mortal time, than through this metaphor of complete balance, each moment eternal in the sense that it is a holographic image of something infinite, not because it is on an infinite, serpentine line, whose beginning and ending are unknown, but because it is a kind of pulsating sphere whose circumference follows the movement of an infinite number of still points around whose centers it revolves — all this in the first three terzets.  (Three times three, that is, the nine, the mystic number, because, for one among other reasons, Dante met Beatrice when they were nine years old, his first glance being that which pierced him with the love that set him on his course and centered him through his whole nomadic life of exile.)  I defy anyone to consider the moment in which they perceive each one of these words as they are passing through the mind, to really imagine time like this as they read, and not be overwhelmed by the experience.  This condition of being overwhelmed, is a trope that occurs again and again throughout the Commedia, and especially, but for different reasons, in the Inferno, and here, in the Paradiso.  Where are we on that map of time?  Between the ubi (the where) and the quando (the when).  Dante uses some Latin terms here, I think to emphasize that all of this is framed as a poetic/linguistic event.  I am reminded of a quote from David Lewis-Williams' book, The Mind in the Cave, in which he says that what differentiated Neanderthals from modern humans, and caused Homo sapiens to win out, was not intelligence per se, but a certain kind of intelligence, which enabled them to remember, symbolize, and mythologize altered states of awareness.  He says that without these types of linguistic markers that can delineate the past and the future, and I would add here, hold them together in the simultaneity of a single act of awareness, "there can be no gods."  Thus Saint John says: "In the beginning was the word."  And what is it that happens here between the where and the when?  The Muse, the inspiration bestowed by Love, begins her dictation: she tells, she does not ask.  I think here of Julian Jaynes' The Origin of Consciousness and the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind.  Wherein Jaynes hypothesizes that the voice which originated from the holistic side of the brain, was heard as the voice of the Divine other, and this voice determined the actions of every person.  Jaynes thought that once the opposite sequential side of the brain became dominant, that is to say, "reason," the holoistic side's voice was understood to be one's own voice, no longer Divine, and no longer irresistibly dictatorial.  His theory implies that every human being, in this archaic situation, is a kind of schizophrenic controlled by audio hallucinations.  Dante, if he had heard this theory, would have said Jaynes is right in all particulars, but wrong in his conclusion; that in fact, Jaynes had it exactly backwards, that the fall of man is due to the fact that his actions are corrupted by this very movement from divine reason (for Dante exalts Reason as being sourced in the Divine) to human self-centered logic.  Everything is turned around in that moment in which humans imagine that their own appetites and ambitions are the sole motivations for action.  Thus, again and again, the Commedia juxtaposes the consequences obtaining from these two positions, and Dante never hesitates to assert that the saved, the saints, are devoted to the former, and the damned are addicted to the latter.  For Dante, as he has the voice of Beatrice tell us, the joy of salvation is a glory derived from this divine point, whence comes the voice which says: Exist.  And when we are at this point we reflect on the infinite goodness imbodied by the Word.  Here too the verses tell us that given this form of eternity, it is a mistake to speculate on the before and after.  Where could they possibly be in this sphere whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere?  To think in this realm of befores and afters is serpent thinking, and this reminds me of Blake's trope, that man is a worm, seventy inches long.  (Inches means years.) What follows here, in Canto 29, are metaphors of light and shining.  And even though now we have measured the speed of photons, it is still impossible to separate light from the quality of light that shines.  So too we are the shinings of the ultimate light of this cosmos, not just the photons, but their ineradicable effect.  Grace comes automatically with the realization that the false, dark chaos of the insatiable ego's appetites and ambitions was simply the result of the pride of that worm seventy inches long imagining that it is slithering somewhere where it is not on the path of suffering and death.  Eliminate that adder's puffing, and grace pours in, as it has into all the Saints now visible to Dante in this canto.  One receives this joy as one's heart humbly inclines to it.  What makes an angel?  The unceasing awareness of this truth's light.  They cannot, as Beatrice tells Dante, even for a single instant, look away.  To be other than in this state of grace is, in Beatrice's words, to dream that you are awake.  Oppossed to this, in the earthly "fallen," are all the spectacle of falsehood, all the shows with no true shine, and these are preached to the gullible for the amusing diversion that we now call entertainment, mere momentary tittilations, which must be repeated again and again, lest one fall into the utter alienation of boredom, that depressing state, which always follows when one tires of the show, or when one sees behind the curtain or the screen into the voids of the utterly trivial.  The canto concludes with the trope of the true light shining amidst myriads of mirrors.  Although this light appears to be many, and 'though any one of these reflections might dull or the mirrors break, no accident, no change, no addition or subtraction of reflective surfaces can in any way affect this slendor.

1  At what time both the children of Latona,
2  Surmounted by the Ram and by the Scales,
3  Together make a zone of the horizon,

1  Quando ambedue li figli di Latona,
2  coperti del Montone e de la Libra,
3  fanno de l'orizzonte insieme zona,

4  As long as from the time the zenith holds them
5  In equipoise, till from that girdle both
6  Changing their hemisphere disturb the balance,

4  quant' è dal punto che 'l cenìt inlibra
5  infin che l'uno e l'altro da quel cinto,
6  cambiando l'emisperio, si dilibra,

7  So long, her face depicted with a smile,
8  Did Beatrice keep silence while she gazed
9  Fixedly at the point which had o'ercome me.

7  tanto, col volto di riso dipinto,
8  si tacque Bëatrice, riguardando
9  fiso nel punto che m'avëa vinto.

10  Then she began: "I say, and I ask not
11  What thou dost wish to hear, for I have seen it
12  Where centres every When and every 'Ubi.'

10  Poi cominciò: “Io dico, e non dimando,
11  quel che tu vuoli udir, perch' io l'ho visto
12  là 've s'appunta ogne ubi e ogne quando.

13  Not to acquire some good unto himself,
15  Which is impossible, but that his splendour
16  In its resplendency may say, 'Subsisto,'

13  Non per aver a sé di bene acquisto,
14  ch'esser non può, ma perché suo splendore
15  potesse, risplendendo, dir 'Subsisto,'

16  In his eternity outside of time,
17  Outside all other limits, as it pleased him,
18  Into new Loves the Eternal Love unfolded.

16  in sua etternità di tempo fore,
17  fuor d'ogne altro comprender, come i piacque,
18  s'aperse in nuovi amor l'etterno amore.

19  Nor as if torpid did he lie before;
20  For neither after nor before proceeded
21  The going forth of God upon these waters.

19  Né prima quasi torpente si giacque;
20  ché né prima né poscia procedette
22  lo discorrer di Dio sovra quest' acque.

22  Matter and Form unmingled and conjoined
23  Came into being that had no defect,
24  E'en as three arrows from a three-stringed bow.

22  Forma e materia, congiunte e purette,
23  usciro ad esser che non avia fallo,
24  come d'arco tricordo tre saette.
25  And as in glass, in amber, or in crystal
26  A sunbeam flashes so, that from its coming
27  To its full being is no interval,

25  E come in vetro, in ambra o in cristallo
26  raggio resplende sì, che dal venire
27  a l'esser tutto non è intervallo,

28  So from its Lord did the triform effect
29  Ray forth into its being all together,
30  Without discrimination of beginning.

28  così 'l triforme effetto del suo sire
29  ne l'esser suo raggiò insieme tutto
30  sanza distinzïone in essordire.

31  Order was con-created and constructed
32  In substances, and summit of the world
33  Were those wherein the pure act was produced.

31  Concreato fu ordine e costrutto
32  a le sustanze; e quelle furon cima
33  nel mondo in che puro atto fu produtto;

34  Pure potentiality held the lowest part;
35  Midway bound potentiality with act
36  Such bond that it shall never be unbound.

34  pura potenza tenne la parte ima;
35  nel mezzo strinse potenza con atto
36  tal vime, che già mai non si divima.

37  Jerome has written unto you of angels
38  Created a long lapse of centuries
39  Or ever yet the other world was made;

37  Ieronimo vi scrisse lungo tratto
38  di secoli de li angeli creati
39  anzi che l'altro mondo fosse fatto;

40  But written is this truth in many places
41  By writers of the Holy Ghost, and thou
42  Shalt see it, if thou lookest well thereat.

40  ma questo vero è scritto in molti lati
41  da li scrittor de lo Spirito Santo,
42  e tu te n'avvedrai se bene agguati;

43  And even reason seeth it somewhat,
44  For it would not concede that for so long
45  Could be the motors without their perfection.

43  e anche la ragione il vede alquanto,
44  che non concederebbe che ' motori
45  sanza sua perfezion fosser cotanto. 

46  Now dost thou know both where and when these Loves
47  Created were, and how; so that extinct
48  In thy desire already are three fires.

46  Or sai tu dove e quando questi amori
47  furon creati e come: sì che spenti
48  nel tuo disïo già son tre ardori.

49  Nor could one reach, in counting, unto twenty
50  So swiftly, as a portion of these angels
51  Disturbed the subject of your elements.

49  Né giugneriesi, numerando, al venti
50  sì tosto, come de li angeli parte
52  turbò il suggetto d'i vostri alimenti.

52  The rest remained, and they began this art
53  Which thou discernest, with so great delight
54  That never from their circling do they cease.

52  L'altra rimase, e cominciò quest' arte
53  che tu discerni, con tanto diletto,
54  che mai da circüir non si diparte.

55  The occasion of the fall was the accursed
56  Presumption of that One, whom thou hast seen
57  By all the burden of the world constrained.

55  Principio del cader fu il maladetto
56  superbir di colui che tu vedesti
57  da tutti i pesi del mondo costretto.

58  Those whom thou here beholdest modest were
59  To recognise themselves as of that goodness
60  Which made them apt for so much understanding;

58  Quelli che vedi qui furon modesti
59  a riconoscer sé da la bontate
60  che li avea fatti a tanto intender presti:

61  On which account their vision was exalted
62  By the enlightening grace and their own merit,
63  So that they have a full and steadfast will.

61  per che le viste lor furo essaltate
62  con grazia illuminante e con lor merto,
63  sì c'hanno ferma e piena volontate;

64  I would not have thee doubt, but certain be,
65  'Tis meritorious to receive this grace,
66  According as the affection opens to it.

64  e non voglio che dubbi, ma sia certo,
65  che ricever la grazia è meritorio
66  secondo che l'affetto l'è aperto.

67  Now round about in this consistory
68  Much mayst thou contemplate, if these my words
69  Be gathered up, without all further aid.

67  Omai dintorno a questo consistorio
68  puoi contemplare assai, se le parole
69  mie son ricolte, sanz' altro aiutorio.

70  But since upon the earth, throughout your schools,
71  They teach that such is the angelic nature
72  That it doth hear, and recollect, and will,

70  Ma perché 'n terra per le vostre scole
71  si legge che l'angelica natura
72  è tal, che 'ntende e si ricorda e vole,

73  More will I say, that thou mayst see unmixed
74  The truth that is confounded there below,
75  Equivocating in such like prelections.

73  ancor dirò, perché tu veggi pura
74  la verità che là giù si confonde,
75  equivocando in sì fatta lettura.

76  These substances, since in God's countenance
77  They jocund were, turned not away their sight
78  From that wherefrom not anything is hidden;

76  Queste sustanze, poi che fur gioconde
77  de la faccia di Dio, non volser viso
78  da essa, da cui nulla si nasconde:

79  Hence they have not their vision intercepted
80  By object new, and hence they do not need
81  To recollect, through interrupted thought.

79  però non hanno vedere interciso
80  da novo obietto, e però non bisogna
81  rememorar per concetto diviso;

82  So that below, not sleeping, people dream,
83  Believing they speak truth, and not believing;
84  And in the last is greater sin and shame.

82  sì che la giù, non dormendo, si sogna,
83  credendo e non credendo dicer vero;
84  ma ne l'uno è più colpa e più vergogna.

85  Below you do not journey by one path
86  Philosophising; so transporteth you
87  Love of appearance and the thought thereof.

85  Voi non andate giù per un sentiero
86  filosofando: tanto vi trasporta
87  l'amor de l'apparenza e 'l suo pensiero!

88  And even this above here is endured
89  With less disdain, than when is set aside
90  The Holy Writ, or when it is distorted.

88  E ancor questo qua sù si comporta
89  con men disdegno che quando è posposta
90  la divina Scrittura o quando è torta.
91  They think not there how much of blood it costs
92  To sow it in the world, and how he pleases
93  Who in humility keeps close to it.

91  Non vi si pensa quanto sangue costa
92  seminarla nel mondo e quanto piace
93  chi umilmente con essa s'accosta.

94  Each striveth for appearance, and doth make
95  His own inventions; and these treated are
96  By preachers, and the Evangel holds its peace.

94  Per apparer ciascun s'ingegna e face
95  sue invenzioni; e quelle son trascorse
96  da' predicanti e 'l Vangelio si tace.

97  One sayeth that the moon did backward turn,
98  In the Passion of Christ, and interpose herself
99  So that the sunlight reached not down below;

97  Un dice che la luna si ritorse
98  ne la passion di Cristo e s'interpuose,
99  per che 'l lume del sol giù non si porse;

100  And lies; for of its own accord the light
101  Hid itself; whence to Spaniards and to Indians,
102  As to the Jews, did such eclipse respond.

100  e mente, ché la luce si nascose
101  da sé: però a li Spani e a l'Indi
102  come a' Giudei tale eclissi rispuose.

103  Florence has not so many Lapi and Bindi
104  As fables such as these, that every year
105  Are shouted from the pulpit back and forth,

103  Non ha Fiorenza tanti Lapi e Bindi
104  quante sì fatte favole per anno
105  in pergamo si gridan quinci e quindi:

106  In such wise that the lambs, who do not know,
107  Come back from pasture fed upon the wind,
108  And not to see the harm doth not excuse them.

106  sì che le pecorelle, che non sanno,
107  tornan del pasco pasciute di vento,
108  e non le scusa non veder lo danno.

109  Christ did not to his first disciples say,
110  'Go forth, and to the world preach idle tales,'
111  But unto them a true foundation gave;

109  Non disse Cristo al suo primo convento:
110  'Andate, e predicate al mondo ciance';
111  ma diede lor verace fondamento;

112  And this so loudly sounded from their lips,
113  That, in the warfare to enkindle Faith,
114  They made of the Evangel shields and lances.

112  e quel tanto sonò ne le sue guance,
113  sì ch'a pugnar per accender la fede
114  de l'Evangelio fero scudo e lance.

115  Now men go forth with jests and drolleries
116  To preach, and if but well the people laugh,
117  The hood puffs out, and nothing more is asked.

115  Ora si va con motti e con iscede
116  a predicare, e pur che ben si rida,
117  gonfia il cappuccio e più non si richiede.

118  But in the cowl there nestles such a bird,
119  That, if the common people were to see it,
120  They would perceive what pardons they confide in,

118  Ma tale uccel nel becchetto s'annida,
119  che se 'l vulgo il vedesse, vederebbe
120  la perdonanza di ch'el si confida:

121  For which so great on earth has grown the folly,
122  That, without proof of any testimony,
123  To each indulgence they would flock together.

121  per cui tanta stoltezza in terra crebbe,
126  che, sanza prova d'alcun testimonio,
127  ad ogne promession si correrebbe.

124  By this Saint Anthony his pig doth fatten,
125  And many others, who are worse than pigs,
126  Paying in money without mark of coinage.

124  Di questo ingrassa il porco sant' Antonio,
125  e altri assai che sono ancor più porci,
126  pagando di moneta sanza conio.

127  But since we have digressed abundantly,
128  Turn back thine eyes forthwith to the right path,
129  So that the way be shortened with the time.

127  Ma perché siam digressi assai, ritorci
128  li occhi oramai verso la dritta strada,
129  sì che la via col tempo si raccorci.

130  This nature doth so multiply itself
131  In numbers, that there never yet was speech
132  Nor mortal fancy that can go so far.

130  Questa natura sì oltre s'ingrada
131  in numero, che mai non fu loquela
132  né concetto mortal che tanto vada;

133  And if thou notest that which is revealed
134  By Daniel, thou wilt see that in his thousands
135  Number determinate is kept concealed.

133  e se tu guardi quel che si revela
134  per Danïel, vedrai che 'n sue migliaia
135  determinato numero si cela.

136  The primal light, that all irradiates it,
137  By modes as many is received therein,
137  As are the splendours wherewith it is mated.

136  La prima luce, che tutta la raia,
137  per tanti modi in essa si recepe,
138  quanti son li splendori a chi s'appaia.

139  Hence, inasmuch as on the act conceptive
140  The affection followeth, of love the sweetness
141  Therein diversely fervid is or tepid.

139  Onde, però che a l'atto che concepe
140  segue l'affetto, d'amar la dolcezza
141  diversamente in essa ferve e tepe.

142  The height behold now and the amplitude
143  Of the eternal power, since it hath made
144  Itself so many mirrors, where 'tis broken,

142  Vedi l'eccelso omai e la larghezza
143  de l'etterno valor, poscia che tanti
144  speculi fatti s'ha in che si spezza,

145  One in itself remaining as before."

145  uno manendo in sé come davanti.”

Canto XXX
If one could condense the lifespan of enumerable lives devoted to the study of this poem, down to one moment of transcendent comprehension, that would still be inadequate to complete one's understanding.  In this Canto, Beatrice calls the brilliance of this realization an "intellectual light," a light whose comprehensive luminance animates the entirety of the cosmos, and whose presence so subdues the physical eyes of any mortal being, that only the extremities of hyperbole can approach its description, and approach it solely through a perception which transcends the reach of all physical senses.  This canto begins with a convoluted and elaborate paraphrasis to mark the time — which is the hour before dawn — why?  Because, I think, Dante has come to an intellectual realization that time, like space, is everywhere all at once, and that like space, which seems subdivided by limited human perception into localities, time too appears relative, as moments and hours, days and years, but that everywhere from the brilliance of this intellectual light, the simultaneity of its true nature touches all.
