Dante has reached an understanding of this phenomenon through an arithmetical calculation involving 6's, 7's and 24's, all Biblical Numbers, so that the spiritual symbolism of his calculation also corresponds to the actual movement of the sun's light across the surface the of the earth.  I have but the crudest understanding of the significance of this elaborate configuration condensed down to a few verses at the opening of this canto, because, although I can begin to make an inventory of how these verses resonate with all of their other harmonic siblings in the entirety of the Commedia, my mind quickly is dazzled into stupefaction in the midst of its retrospection.  The heart of the reader here races to the point of a heartbreak which is simultaneously stilled by an overwhelming compassion, as that which seems to be outside in the cosmos suddenly merges with the inner cosmos of one's human existence.  Words here have reached a limit, not because words are inadequate, because we must remember Saint John's proclamation that "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God."  It is only the Word which arises from the substrate of the Infinite, which tells us that the infinite exists at all, but the Word also tells us that the metaphysical and the physical both have limits as to our understanding.  This universe has a beginning, as a Big Bang, or as the Word of God, or as a single exhalation of the breath of Brahma, and so likewise it will have a heat death end.  But even knowing this, we cannot know if this single beginning and end is only part of an infinite number of cycles of beginnings and endings.  In this Canto, twice, Dante uses the metaphor of an infant searching for the breast of his or her cosmic mother, once to partake of that nourishment, and once as a negative exemplar of those souls who are offered that breast, and though starving, push it away.  In typical Dante style, this metaphor of drinking is extended to the aspirant, at Beatrice's urging, to the drinking from the divine river pictured here.  This is a river of light that is both flowing like Bergsonian time, and spherical like that famous medieval dictum, that God is a sphere whose center is everywhere and whose circumference is nowhere.  The aspirant Dante, drinks first in the linear stream, and then, nourished by that enlightenment, has the vision of the river becoming spherical.  

This Canto begins the end of the entire Commedia, because here Beatrice, who has represented one pole of a circuit the other pole of which is Dante's love, has also reached a limit.  The Canto deals with this extraordinary development in two ways.  One, in which the aspirant declares that if all the praise of Beatrice, which has to this point been the inspirational source of Dante's entire ouvre, where gathered into one effusive burst of exaltation, this praise would not even begin to express the true merit of her deserving.  The second way in which this limitation is denoted is by the simple statement that Beatrice's tone of voice is like that of a guide who has fulfilled their obligation.  What could possibly be more poignant?  And what could possibly follow this development which would save it from being tragic?  

Things now become utterly psychedelic.  As if they has not been throughout the Commedia, and especially so throughout the Paradiso.  What psychic experiences did the poet Dante, who, behind the scenes, is ordering — and I might add — supremely ordering — all this splendor.  What inner adventures have enabled him to conjure forth the miracle of his poem?  My conviction is that those experiences could only have occurred through the imaginative immersion in the act of writing the poetry itself.  In other words, the true inspiration occurring here, is the grace of the poet receiving/discovering/inventing the substance of the poem.  In the decades that Dante devoted himself to the composition of the Commedia, he learned from the poem's initial dawning what his calling was to be.  He learned from his own work as a poet how to write his poem.  He sat at the foot of his own best poet-self, as the aspirant, whose humility enabled him to be the first reader/devotee of the Commedia.  Blake says that the whole of a poet's work takes place in the space of time between a pulse and a pulse, and there must have been a moment, when Dante had reached the nadir of his own despair, a moment when the bitterness of exile dawned on him as the fate of the entire remainder of his life, a moment when he intuited that henceforth the satisfactions of home, family, social prestige and acceptance were to be permanently denied him, just in that moment, his savior, the composition of the Commedia, came to him.  In this Canto, as in the Canto of limbo where he meets the great pagan poets of the past, and is accepted into their company, here we see Dante, both abasing himself — we would say, his ego self — and elevating his calling as a poet to a position in which he, as the recipient and creator of his poem, becomes, as close as is humanly possible, one with the Creative force by which the Cosmos itself has come into existence out of a seeming background of chaotic potential.  The formula for Dante seems to have been: despair leads to humility, humility leads to inspiration, inspiration transforms despair into bliss.  

The Canto proceeds to what I might call a luminous metaphysical template, which provides the form of a physical phenomenon — that is, a river flowing between flower bedecked banks at the apogee of Spring.  The flowers here are connected to the this river of light by the emittance of sparks, which spring like divine bees from the river, nourish the flowers, and then return to the hive of their source.  What a simple image!  Bees in the flowers of Spring, beside a clear flowing river, how utterly earthy, and how utterly transcendent.  We see in this, the beginning of that single flower, the yellow rose, whose petals are the entire company of saved humans and unfallen angels, described here as soldiers, who militantly overcame the pull of that metaphysical gravity represented by Satan and the fallen angels, and of that physical gravity represented by the pull of self-indulgence, which we call vice.  

Maybe the most remarkable and puzzling thing about this Canto is how it concludes with the most important yet most debased political activities of human beings.  What an oddity it seems that Dante in this Canto, which has elevated his readers to this penultimate pinnacle of transcendence, returns them now to the quite grungy and jarring violence and corruption of 13th and 14th century Italian secular/theological politics — that old bugaboo of the Guelf and Ghibelline irreconcilable conflict.  Is Dante revealing to us that that thorn in his side, which poisoned his whole life, is not yet healed?  To me that seems a diminishment and tarnishing of the splendor of his joy.  Clearly he is still bitter about these earthly affairs.  And although he puts this condemnation into the mouth of Beatrice almost as her lover's adieu, clearly it is Dante, the poet, who still yearns to see his enemies punished.  Is Dante's vision of the cosmos one where joy sucks, along with the milk of blessedness, the poison of crime?  And do these poisoners serve as a prod to those who purify themselves only by the militant destruction of those whose road is traveled by the darkness of night and not by the light of day, of those who are the despoilers of life's joys, and whose subterfuge leads to the ultimate treason committed under the hypocritical guise of their holy offices?  If the Hindu's have their divine Destroyer as one third of their tripartite conception of the Divine, Christian Dante seems to require this conflict between the Godly and the ungodly, light still requiring darkness. Or more disturbingly, light creating the shadow of its corrupting double.  I am not Dante, and I admit that it is difficult for me to conceive of a state of bliss, which still carries within it this poison dart of bitterness.  But I am mightily impressed by Dante the poet, who has begun this Canto with the image of that shadow which races across our planet when it revolves its sunlit face into darkness, and then, by a passage through the most brilliant light, returns us here to darkness and the shadowy entities who travel, like nightmares, on the sinuous road, which leads again to despair.  Like the alchemist's infamous ouroboros, that snake which circles round to bite and perhaps even feed upon the venom of its own tail, Dante has repeated the metaphor of the line becoming a circle, and has brought the Commedia's Inferno round to infect the bliss of paradise.  If this is so, then Dante has hit upon a psychic truth centuries before Jung presented it to the modern world.  But then Jung himself discovered this truth by going backwards in time to the alchemists and inward to dreams and nightmares, that is to say, by showing that these revelations, almost like mathematical proofs, can be discovered and forgotten, again and again, but they can never be lost, because they are the constants, which sustain and evolve the life itself. 
    
1  Perchance six thousand miles remote from us
2  Is glowing the sixth hour, and now this world
3  Inclines its shadow almost to a level,

1  Forse semilia miglia di lontano
2  ci ferve l'ora sesta, e questo mondo
3  china già l'ombra quasi al letto piano,

4  When the mid-heaven begins to make itself
5  So deep to us, that here and there a star
6  Ceases to shine so far down as this depth,

4  quando 'l mezzo del cielo, a noi profondo,
5  comincia a farsi tal, ch'alcuna stella
6  perde il parere infino a questo fondo;

7  And as advances bright exceedingly
8  The handmaid of the sun, the heaven is closed
9  Light after light to the most beautiful;

7  e come vien la chiarissima ancella
8   del sol più oltre, così 'l ciel si chiude
9  di vista in vista infino a la più bella.

10  Not otherwise the Triumph, which for ever
11  Plays round about the point that vanquished me,
12  Seeming enclosed by what itself encloses,

10  Non altrimenti il trïunfo che lude
11  sempre dintorno al punto che mi vinse,
12  parendo inchiuso da quel ch'elli 'nchiude,

13  Little by little from my vision faded;
14  Whereat to turn mine eyes on Beatrice
15  My seeing nothing and my love constrained me.

13  a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse:
14  per che tornar con li occhi a Bëatrice
15  nulla vedere e amor mi costrinse. 

16  If what has hitherto been said of her
17  Were all concluded in a single praise,
18  Scant would it be to serve the present turn.

16  Se quanto infino a qui di lei si dice
17  fosse conchiuso tutto in una loda,
18  poca sarebbe a fornir questa vice.

19  Not only does the beauty I beheld
20  Transcend ourselves, but truly I believe
21  Its Maker only may enjoy it all.

19  La bellezza ch'io vidi si trasmoda
20   non pur di là da noi, ma certo io credo
21  che solo il suo fattor tutta la goda.

22  Vanquished do I confess me by this passage
23  More than by problem of his theme was ever
24  O'ercome the comic or the tragic poet;

22  Da questo passo vinto mi concedo
23  più che già mai da punto di suo tema
24  soprato fosse comico o tragedo:

25  For as the sun the sight that trembles most,
26  Even so the memory of that sweet smile
27  My mind depriveth of its very self.

25  ché, come sole in viso che più trema,
26  così lo rimembrar del dolce riso
27  la mente mia da me medesmo scema.

28  28  From the first day that I beheld her face
29  In this life, to the moment of this look,
30  The sequence of my song has ne'er been severed;

28  Dal primo giorno ch'i' vidi il suo viso
29  in questa vita, infino a questa vista,
30  non m'è il seguire al mio cantar preciso;

31  But now perforce this sequence must desist
32  From following her beauty with my verse,
33  As every artist at his uttermost.

31  ma or convien che mio seguir desista
32  più dietro a sua bellezza, poetando,
33  come a l'ultimo suo ciascuno artista.

34  Such as I leave her to a greater fame
35  Than any of my trumpet, which is bringing
36  Its arduous matter to a final close,

34  Cotal qual io la lascio a maggior bando
35  che quel de la mia tuba, che deduce
36  l'ardüa sua matera terminando,

37  With voice and gesture of a perfect leader
38  She recommenced: "We from the greatest body
39  Have issued to the heaven that is pure light;

37  con atto e voce di spedito duce
38  ricominciò: “Noi siamo usciti fore
39  del maggior corpo al ciel ch'è pura luce:

40  Light intellectual replete with love,
41  Love of true good replete with ecstasy,
42  Ecstasy that transcendeth every sweetness.

40  luce intellettüal, piena d'amore;
41  amor di vero ben, pien di letizia;
42  letizia che trascende ogne dolzore. 

43  Here shalt thou see the one host and the other
44  Of Paradise, and one in the same aspects
45  Which at the final judgment thou shalt see."

43  Qui vederai l'una e l'altra milizia
44  di paradiso, e l'una in quelli aspetti
45  che tu vedrai a l'ultima giustizia.”

46  Even as a sudden lightning that disperses
47  The visual spirits, so that it deprives
48  The eye of impress from the strongest objects,

46  Come sùbito lampo che discetti
47  li spiriti visivi, sì che priva
48  da l'atto l'occhio di più forti obietti,

49  Thus round about me flashed a living light,
50  And left me swathed around with such a veil
51  Of its effulgence, that I nothing saw.

49  così mi circunfulse luce viva,
50  e lasciommi fasciato di tal velo
51  del suo fulgor, che nulla m'appariva.

52  "Ever the Love which quieteth this heaven
53  Welcomes into itself with such salute,
54  To make the candle ready for its flame."

52  “Sempre l'amor che queta questo cielo
53  accoglie in sé con sì fatta salute,
54  per far disposto a sua fiamma il candelo.”

55  No sooner had within me these brief words
56  An entrance found, than I perceived myself
57  To be uplifted over my own power,

55  Non fur più tosto dentro a me venute
56  queste parole brievi, ch'io compresi
57  me sormontar di sopr' a mia virtute;

58  And I with vision new rekindled me,
59  Such that no light whatever is so pure
60  But that mine eyes were fortified against it.

58  e di novella vista mi raccesi
59  tale, che nulla luce è tanto mera,
60  che li occhi miei non si fosser difesi;

61  And light I saw in fashion of a river
62  Fulvid with its effulgence, 'twixt two banks
63  Depicted with an admirable Spring.

61  e vidi lume in forma di rivera
62  fulvido di fulgore, intra due rive
63  dipinte di mirabil primavera.

64  Out of this river issued living sparks,
65  And on all sides sank down into the flowers,
66  Like unto rubies that are set in gold;

64  Di tal fiumana uscian faville vive,
65 e d'ogne parte si mettien ne' fiori,
66 quasi rubin che oro circunscrive;

67  And then, as if inebriate with the odours,
68  They plunged again into the wondrous torrent,
69  And as one entered issued forth another.

67  poi, come inebrïate da li odori,
68  riprofondavan sé nel miro gurge,
69  e s'una intrava, un'altra n'uscia fori.

70  "The high desire, that now inflames and moves thee
71  To have intelligence of what thou seest,
72  Pleaseth me all the more, the more it swells.

70  “L'alto disio che mo t'infiamma e urge,
71  d'aver notizia di ciò che tu vei,
72  tanto mi piace più quanto più turge;

73  But of this water it behoves thee drink
74  Before so great a thirst in thee be slaked."
75  Thus said to me the sunshine of mine eyes;

73  ma di quest' acqua convien che tu bei
74  prima che tanta sete in te si sazi”:
75  così mi disse il sol de li occhi miei.

76  And added: "The river and the topazes
77  Going in and out, and the laughing of the herbage,
78  Are of their truth foreshadowing prefaces;

76  Anche soggiunse: “Il fiume e li topazi
77  ch'entrano ed escono e 'l rider de l'erbe
78  son di lor vero umbriferi prefazi. 

79  Not that these things are difficult in themselves,
80  But the deficiency is on thy side,
81  For yet thou hast not vision so exalted."

79  Non che da sé sian queste cose acerbe;
80  ma è difetto da la parte tua,
81  che non hai viste ancor tanto superbe.”

82  There is no babe that leaps so suddenly
83  With face towards the milk, if he awake
84  Much later than his usual custom is,

82  Non è fantin che sì sùbito rua
83  col volto verso il latte, se si svegli
84  molto tardato da l'usanza sua 

85  As I did, that I might make better mirrors
86  Still of mine eyes, down stooping to the wave
87  Which flows that we therein be better made.

85  come fec' io, per far migliori spegli
86  ancor de li occhi, chinandomi a l'onda
87 che si deriva perché vi s'immegli;

88  And even as the penthouse of mine eyelids
89  Drank of it, it forthwith appeared to me
90  Out of its length to be transformed to round.

88  e sì come di lei bevve la gronda
89  de le palpebre mie, così mi parve
90  di sua lunghezza divenuta tonda.

91  Then as a folk who have been under masks
92  Seem other than before, if they divest
93  The semblance not their own they disappeared in,

91  Poi, come gente stata sotto larve,
92  che pare altro che prima, se si sveste
93  la sembianza non süa in che disparve,

94  Thus into greater pomp were changed for me
95  The flowerets and the sparks, so that I saw
96  Both of the Courts of Heaven made manifest.

94  così mi si cambiaro in maggior feste
95  li fiori e le faville, sì ch'io vidi
96  ambo le corti del ciel manifeste.

97  O splendour of God! by means of which I saw
98  The lofty triumph of the realm veracious,
99  Give me the power to say how it I saw!

97  O isplendor di Dio, per cu' io vidi
98  l'alto trïunfo del regno verace,
99  dammi virtù a dir com'ïo il vidi!

100  There is a light above, which visible
101  Makes the Creator unto every creature,
102  Who only in beholding Him has peace,

100  Lume è là sù che visibile face
101 lo creatore a quella creatura
102 che solo in lui vedere ha la sua pace.

103  And it expands itself in circular form
104  To such extent, that its circumference
105  Would be too large a girdle for the sun.

103  E' si distende in circular figura,
104 in tanto che la sua circunferenza
105 sarebbe al sol troppo larga cintura.

106  The semblance of it is all made of rays
107  Reflected from the top of Primal Motion,
108  Which takes therefrom vitality and power.

106  Fassi di raggio tutta sua parvenza
107  reflesso al sommo del mobile primo,
108  che prende quindi vivere e potenza.

109  And as a hill in water at its base
110  Mirrors itself, as if to see its beauty
111  When affluent most in verdure and in flowers,

109  E come clivo in acqua di suo imo
110  si specchia, quasi per vedersi addorno,
111  quando è nel verde e ne' fioretti opimo,

112  So, ranged aloft all round about the light,
113  Mirrored I saw in more ranks than a thousand
114  All who above there have from us returned.

112  sì, soprastando al lume intorno intorno,
113  vidi specchiarsi in più di mille soglie
114  quanto di noi là sù fatto ha ritorno.

115  And if the lowest row collect within it
116  So great a light, how vast the amplitude
117  Is of this Rose in its extremest leaves!

115  E se l'infimo grado in sé raccoglie
116  sì grande lume, quanta è la larghezza
117  di questa rosa ne l'estreme foglie!

118  My vision in the vastness and the height
119  Lost not itself, but comprehended all
120  The quantity and quality of that gladness.

118  La vista mia ne l'ampio e ne l'altezza
119  non si smarriva, ma tutto prendeva
120  il quanto e 'l quale di quella allegrezza.

121  There near and far nor add nor take away;
122  For there where God immediately doth govern,
123  The natural law in naught is relevant.

121  Presso e lontano, lì, né pon né leva:
122 ché dove Dio sanza mezzo governa,
123 la legge natural nulla rileva.

124  Into the yellow of the Rose Eternal
125  That spreads, and multiplies, and breathes an odour
126  Of praise unto the ever-vernal Sun,

124  Nel giallo de la rosa sempiterna,
125 che si digrada e dilata e redole
126  odor di lode al sol che sempre verna,

127  As one who silent is and fain would speak,
128  Me Beatrice drew on, and said: "Behold
129  Of the white stoles how vast the convent is!

130  Behold how vast the circuit of our city!
131  Behold our seats so filled to overflowing,
132  That here henceforward are few people wanting!

130  Vedi nostra città quant' ella gira;
131  vedi li nostri scanni sì ripieni,
132  che poca gente più ci si disira.

133  On that great throne whereon thine eyes are fixed
134  For the crown's sake already placed upon it,
135  Before thou suppest at this wedding feast

133  E 'n quel gran seggio a che tu li occhi tieni
134  per la corona che già v'è sù posta,
135  prima che tu a queste nozze ceni,

136  Shall sit the soul (that is to be Augustus
137  On earth) of noble Henry, who shall come
138  To redress Italy ere she be ready.

136  sederà l'alma, che fia giù agosta,
137  de l'alto Arrigo, ch'a drizzare Italia
138  verrà in prima ch'ella sia disposta.

139  Blind covetousness, that casts its spell upon you,
140  Has made you like unto the little child,
141  Who dies of hunger and drives off the nurse.

139  La cieca cupidigia che v'ammalia
140  simili fatti v'ha al fantolino
141  che muor per fame e caccia via la balia.



142  And in the sacred forum then shall be
143  A Prefect such, that openly or covert
144  On the same road he will not walk with him.

142  E fia prefetto nel foro divino
143  allora tal, che palese e coverto
144  non anderà con lui per un cammino.

145  But long of God he will not be endured
146  In holy office; he shall be thrust down
147  Where Simon Magus is for his deserts,

145  Ma poco poi sarà da Dio sofferto
146  nel santo officio: ch'el sarà detruso
147  là dove Simon mago è per suo merto,

148  And make him of Alagna lower go!"

148  e farà quel d'Alagna intrar più giuso.”

Canto XXXI
Moreover, the Empyrean Heaven by its peace resembles the Divine Science, which is full of all peace and suffers no diversity of opinion or sophistical reasoning because of the supreme certainty of its subject, which is God. Christ says of this science to his disciples: “My peace I give to you, my peace I leave with you,” giving and leaving to them his teaching, which is this science of which I speak.  Solomon, speaking of this science, says: “The queens number sixty, and the concubines eighty; and of the young handmaids there is no number: one is my dove and my perfect one.”  He calls all sciences queens and friends and handmaids, but this one he calls perfect because it makes us see truth perfectly, in which our souls find rest.

Convivio, Chapter 14

The conclusion of Canto 30 is shocking because, here, in paradise, there is still the acrimony, which properly belongs to earth, and specifically to the historical, temporal earth of Dante's time.  Here in Canto 31 that feeling of acrimony has been purged.  I've been thinking of two words in conjunction with this canto: the ordinary and the extraordinary.  The ordinary is a state of bondage to sequential time, it belongs to memory and to anticipation, and in this state we can be nothing but pilgrims, aspirants, exiles, and nomads.  Where is time going?  Where are any narrative structures, as has been the whole of the Commedia, going?  It and they are interminable, either as a wreckage of regrets or as the poignancy of nostalgia and unrecoverable past happiness, or a just out of our grasp future paradise, or the oncoming shadow of annihilation and death.  There is no place on this sinuous line where peace can become the home and habitation of a perfected Self.  This canto contains mini-narratives having to do with the astonishment of a pilgrim reaching the goal of their quest and finding there something utterly extraordinary — of barbarians reaching the splendors of Rome, of a pilgrim seeing the veil of Veronica, and these narratives are linked to the astonishment that Dante, the aspirant, succumbs to when he turns to address Beatrice, and finds instead an old man, not a lover, but a father-figure.  This is perhaps the true image of any persistent spiritual seeker who is male, that is, he finds at the end of his pilgrimage the image of his self, perfected, like fine wine, by the vicissitudes of time.  Dante is experiencing his own ordination, a word etymologically rooted in the word "order."  That earth time of the serpentine sequence was the mother of disorder, spectacular in her disappointments and injustices.  I choose the word spectacular deliberately, because there is in this canto another lesson which cannot be learned in the ordinary sequence of narration, which is, the transmutation of images into essences.  It must have dawned on the reader by now that Dante as he reaches the apotheosis of this poem must have a way to make words descriptive of the ineffable.  He does this by breaking the membrane of the illusory, which can be described in the language which linguists call signs, words that stand for things or even ideas, a false equivalency that confuses us into believing that the complexity of the world of temporal things, temporary images, can be conveyed in a vehicle composed of small mouth noises.  To overcome this inherent ineffability, one has to create a structure of like complexity to the thing being expressed.  Dante, more than almost any other artist does just this.  His poetry is so rich, that he escapes this fog of comparisons of mists intermingling with mists, the very progenitors of disorder, the no man's land of nominalisms, things pretending to be fixed in nouns, but actually ever being/becoming, ever moving and changing actions, the most vital of which are that thing we call ourselves, a face in the mirror, or in the mirror of the eyes of others, a name, a reputation, a marker that places us somewhere in the social and natural order — as if that order could be in any such fashion fixed!  But here we are in a paradise, which is not fixed, in the sense that it has no differences, no movement.  On the contrary, this paradise is full of movement, an immense revolving rose of dancing light and dignified music — in a word, this is a world of imperishable essence, of imperishable order.  And this world, us readers, if we have been paying attention, leaving our footprints, like the blessed Beatrice, in Hell, as well as in Purgatory, and finding suddenly that this entire sequential narration has been in actuality the perfected shape of a single ineffable metaphor.  The distance between Dante and Beatrice, although it exceeds the distance from the highest to the lowest, is, as metaphor, as close and clear as any intimacy could be, the last shred of appearance being shredded by its inner radiance of essence.  We have gone in our love from Eros to agape, from Beatrice to Bernard, and yet we have not lost the former to enjoy the latter.  True wholeness can never be about loss, and if we think of the petals of this eternal rose as the petals of a vagina into which love enters and from which the generations burgeon, we will not find it sacrilegious to share in this experience of Dante, as he is ordained by Bernard, into the cult of Mary, the sea of infinitude from which the finite is born — but with this difference:  Mary's sea is unlike the sea of this planet's oceans, however fecund they are and have been.  Mary's sea is a sea of motherly care, a sea that engenders devotion in its children, and it is this devotion which changes the tragic scenarios of mortal life into joy and love.   One verse in this canto stands out as a signal for this change, in which Dante says that his words cannot keep pace with the images that are inundating him.  He has literally found what John Keats calls the blushful Hippocrene, the wellspring of infinitude that inspires the kind of poetry that the Commedia embodies, a spring whose baptismal font, not only satisfies every thirst, purges every misperception, but also brings with it a transformation from chaos to order.  Of all that poems that I can think of, none are so astonishingly well ordered as this poem by Dante, and none so adept at completely avoiding the stagnation of a rigid order freezing solidity into stasis.  (Recall here the image of Satan totally frozen at the nadir of Hell, with absolutely no freedom to change his state, and forever productive of evil by mere mechanical automaticity.)  Dante's order, like Bach's, is an order that flows, an order, that in fact, circulates.  It circulates like the blood in a living human body, renewing and feeding the entire inner cosmos with all its enumerable cells and selves.  His poem is finite, but its influence, like the influenza of the stars, is infinitely productive of insight and the rush of joy which each new insight breeds.  I think one of the most astonishing things about his poetry, one that sets him apart from great poets like Whitman, or Blake, or Garcia Lorca, is that he has found a way to transform his irrational griefs and ecstasies into logic and reason.  The whole poem, like some great linguistic Chartres Cathedral, is architecturally sound, a rhetoric of reason, with an utterly miraculous totality of effect.  His rationality orders the irrational and makes it both loving and beautiful at the same time.  And if we extend this beauty and love which infects us as readers, it is as if we have been on a pilgrimage all along and suddenly come upon that face imprinted as the true icon, the vera icona, the veil of Veronica, this thin illusion of language and imagination impossibly giving us the true essence of the divine.  We blink our eyes and wonder: Can this be?  A question, any answer to which diminishes that state of wonder which comes with any confrontation with our own cosmic destiny.

1  In fashion then as of a snow-white rose
2  Displayed itself to me the saintly host,
3  Whom Christ in his own blood had made his bride,

1  In forma dunque di candida rosa
2  mi si mostrava la milizia santa
3  che nel suo sangue Cristo fece sposa;

4  But the other host, that flying sees and sings
5  The glory of Him who doth enamour it,
6  And the goodness that created it so noble,

4  ma l'altra, che volando vede e canta
5  la gloria di colui che la 'nnamora
6 e la bontà che la fece cotanta,

7  Even as a swarm of bees, that sinks in flowers
8  One moment, and the next returns again
9  To where its labour is to sweetness turned,

7  sì come schiera d'ape che s'infiora
8  una fïata e una si ritorna
9  là dove suo laboro s'insapora,

10  Sank into the great flower, that is adorned
11  With leaves so many, and thence reascended
12  To where its love abideth evermore.

10  nel gran fior discendeva che s'addorna
11  di tante foglie, e quindi risaliva
12  là dove 'l süo amor sempre soggiorna.

13  Their faces had they all of living flame,
14  And wings of gold, and all the rest so white
15  No snow unto that limit doth attain.

13  Le facce tutte avean di fiamma viva
14  e l'ali d'oro, e l'altro tanto bianco,
15  che nulla neve a quel termine arriva.

16  From bench to bench, into the flower descending,
17  They carried something of the peace and ardour
18  Which by the fanning of their flanks they won.

16  Quando scendean nel fior, di banco in banco
17  porgevan de la pace e de l'ardore
18  ch'elli acquistavan ventilando il fianco.

19  Nor did the interposing 'twixt the flower
20  And what was o'er it of such plenitude
21  Of flying shapes impede the sight and splendour;

19  Né l'interporsi tra 'l disopra e 'l fiore
20  di tanta moltitudine volante
21  impediva la vista e lo splendore:

22  Because the light divine so penetrates
23  The universe, according to its merit,
24  That naught can be an obstacle against it.

22  ché la luce divina è penetrante
23  per l'universo secondo ch'è degno,
24  sì che nulla le puote essere ostante.

25  This realm secure and full of gladsomeness,
26  Crowded with ancient people and with modern,
27  Unto one mark had all its look and love.

25  Questo sicuro e gaudïoso regno,
26  frequente in gente antica e in novella,
27  viso e amore avea tutto ad un segno.

28  O Trinal Light, that in a single star
29  Sparkling upon their sight so satisfies them,
30  Look down upon our tempest here below!

28  Oh trina luce che 'n unica stella
29  scintillando a lor vista, sì li appaga!
30  guarda qua giuso a la nostra procella!

31  If the barbarians, coming from some region
32  That every day by Helice is covered,
33  Revolving with her son whom she delights in,

31  Se i barbari, venendo da tal plaga
32  che ciascun giorno d'Elice si cuopra,
33  rotante col suo figlio ond' ella è vaga,

34  Beholding Rome and all her noble works,
35  Were wonder-struck, what time the Lateran
36  Above all mortal things was eminent,—

34  veggendo Roma e l'ardüa sua opra,
35  stupefaciensi, quando Laterano
36  a le cose mortali andò di sopra;

37  I who to the divine had from the human,
38  From time unto eternity, had come,
39  From Florence to a people just and sane,

37  ïo, che al divino da l'umano,
38  a l'etterno dal tempo era venuto,
39  e di Fiorenza in popol giusto e sano,

40  With what amazement must I have been filled!
41  Truly between this and the joy, it was
42  My pleasure not to hear, and to be mute.

40  di che stupor dovea esser compiuto!
41  Certo tra esso e 'l gaudio mi facea
42  libito non udire e starmi muto.

43  And as a pilgrim who delighteth him
44  In gazing round the temple of his vow,
45  And hopes some day to retell how it was,

43  E quasi peregrin che si ricrea
44  nel tempio del suo voto riguardando,
45  e spera già ridir com' ello stea,

46  So through the living light my way pursuing
47  Directed I mine eyes o'er all the ranks,
48  Now up, now down, and now all round about.

46  su per la viva luce passeggiando,
47  menava ïo li occhi per li gradi,
48  mo sù, mo giù e mo recirculando.

49  Faces I saw of charity persuasive,
50  Embellished by His light and their own smile,
51  And attitudes adorned with every grace.

49  Vedëa visi a carità süadi,
50  d'altrui lume fregiati e di suo riso,
51  e atti ornati di tutte onestadi.

52  The general form of Paradise already
53  My glance had comprehended as a whole,
54  In no part hitherto remaining fixed,

52  La forma general di paradiso
53  già tutta mïo sguardo avea compresa,
54  in nulla parte ancor fermato fiso;

55  And round I turned me with rekindled wish
56  My Lady to interrogate of things
57  Concerning which my mind was in suspense.

55  e volgeami con voglia rïaccesa
56  per domandar la mia donna di cose
57  di che la mente mia era sospesa.

58  One thing I meant, another answered me;
59  I thought I should see Beatrice, and saw
60  An Old Man habited like the glorious people.

58  Uno intendëa, e altro mi rispuose:
59  credea veder Beatrice e vidi un sene
60  vestito con le genti glorïose.

61  O'erflowing was he in his eyes and cheeks
62  With joy benign, in attitude of pity
63  As to a tender father is becoming.

61  Diffuso era per li occhi e per le gene
62  di benigna letizia, in atto pio
63  quale a tenero padre si convene.

64  And "She, where is she?" instantly I said;
65  Whence he: "To put an end to thy desire,
66  Me Beatrice hath sent from mine own place.

64  E “Ov' è ella?” sùbito diss' io.
65  Ond' elli: “A terminar lo tuo disiro
66  mosse Beatrice me del loco mio;

67  And if thou lookest up to the third round
68  Of the first rank, again shalt thou behold her
69  Upon the throne her merits have assigned her."

67  e se riguardi sù nel terzo giro
68  dal sommo grado, tu la rivedrai
69  nel trono che suoi merti le sortiro.”

70  Without reply I lifted up mine eyes,
71  And saw her, as she made herself a crown
72  Reflecting from herself the eternal rays.

70  Sanza risponder, li occhi sù levai,
71  e vidi lei che si facea corona
72  reflettendo da sé li etterni rai.

73  Not from that region which the highest thunders
74  Is any mortal eye so far removed,
75  In whatsoever sea it deepest sinks,

73  Da quella regïon che più sù tona
74  occhio mortale alcun tanto non dista,
75  qualunque in mare più giù s'abbandona,

76  As there from Beatrice my sight; but this
77  Was nothing unto me; because her image
78  Descended not to me by medium blurred.

76  quanto lì da Beatrice la mia vista;
77  ma nulla mi facea, ché süa effige
78  non discendëa a me per mezzo mista.
79  "O Lady, thou in whom my hope is strong,
80   And who for my salvation didst endure
81  In Hell to leave the imprint of thy feet,

79  “O donna in cui la mia speranza vige,
80  e che soffristi per la mia salute
81  in inferno lasciar le tue vestige,

82  Of whatsoever things I have beheld,
83  As coming from thy power and from thy goodness
84  I recognise the virtue and the grace.

82  di tante cose quant' i' ho vedute,
83  dal tuo podere e da la tua bontate
84  riconosco la grazia e la virtute.

85  Thou from a slave hast brought me unto freedom,
86  By all those ways, by all the expedients,
87  Whereby thou hadst the power of doing it.

85  Tu m'hai di servo tratto a libertate
86  per tutte quelle vie, per tutt' i modi
87  che di ciò fare avei la potestate.

88  Preserve towards me thy magnificence,
89  So that this soul of mine, which thou hast healed,
90  Pleasing to thee be loosened from the body."

88  La tua magnificenza in me custodi,
89  sì che l'anima mia, che fatt' hai sana,
90  piacente a te dal corpo si disnodi.”

91  Thus I implored; and she, so far away,
92  Smiled, as it seemed, and looked once more at me;
93  Then unto the eternal fountain turned.

91  Così orai; e quella, sì lontana
92  come parea, sorrise e riguardommi;
93  poi si tornò a l'etterna fontana.

94  And said the Old Man holy: "That thou mayst
95  Accomplish perfectly thy journeying,
96  Whereunto prayer and holy love have sent me,

94  E 'l santo sene: “Acciò che tu assommi
95  perfettamente,” disse, “il tuo cammino,
96  a che priego e amor santo mandommi,

97  Fly with thine eyes all round about this garden;
98  For seeing it will discipline thy sight
99  Farther to mount along the ray divine.

97  vola con li occhi per questo giardino;
98  ché veder lui t'acconcerà lo sguardo
99  più al montar per lo raggio divino.

100  And she, the Queen of Heaven, for whom I burn
101  Wholly with love, will grant us every grace,
102  Because that I her faithful Bernard am."

100  E la regina del cielo, ond'ïo ardo
101  tutto d'amor, ne farà ogne grazia,
102  però ch'i' sono il suo fedel Bernardo.”

103  As he who peradventure from Croatia
104  Cometh to gaze at our Veronica,
105  Who through its ancient fame is never sated,

103  Qual è colui che forse di Croazia
104  viene a veder la Veronica nostra,
105  che per l'antica fame non sen sazia,

106  But says in thought, the while it is displayed,
107  "My Lord, Christ Jesus, God of very God,
108  Now was your semblance made like unto this?"

106  ma dice nel pensier, fin che si mostra:
107   “Segnor mio Iesù Cristo, Dio verace,
108   or fu sì fatta la sembianza vostra?”;

109  Even such was I while gazing at the living
110  Charity of the man, who in this world
111  By contemplation tasted of that peace.

109  tal era io mirando la vivace
110  carità di colui che 'n questo mondo,
111  contemplando, gustò di quella pace.

112  "Thou son of grace, this jocund life," began he,
113  "Will not be known to thee by keeping ever
114  Thine eyes below here on the lowest place;

112  “Figliuol di grazia, quest' esser giocondo,”
113  cominciò elli, “non ti sarà noto,
114  tenendo li occhi pur qua giù al fondo;

115  But mark the circles to the most remote,
116  Until thou shalt behold enthroned the Queen
117  To whom this realm is subject and devoted."

115  ma guarda i cerchi infino al più remoto,
116  tanto che veggi seder la regina
117  cui questo regno è suddito e devoto.”

118  I lifted up mine eyes, and as at morn
119  The oriental part of the horizon
120  Surpasses that wherein the sun goes down,

118  Io levai li occhi; e come da mattina
119  la parte orïental de l'orizzonte
120  soverchia quella dove 'l sol declina,

121  Thus, as if going with mine eyes from vale
122  To mount, I saw a part in the remoteness
123  Surpass in splendour all the other front.

121  così, quasi di valle andando a monte
122  con li occhi, vidi parte ne lo stremo
123  vincer di lume tutta l'altra fronte.

124  And even as there where we await the pole
125  That Phaeton drove badly, blazes more
126  The light, and is on either side diminished,

124  E come quivi ove s'aspetta il temo
125  che mal guidò Fetonte, più s'infiamma,
126  e quinci e quindi il lume si fa scemo, 

127  So likewise that pacific oriflamme
128  Gleamed brightest in the centre, and each side
129  In equal measure did the flame abate.

127  così quella pacifica oriafiamma
128  nel mezzo s'avvivava, e d'ogne parte
129  per igual modo allentava la fiamma;

130  And at that centre, with their wings expanded,
131  More than a thousand jubilant Angels saw I,
132  Each differing in effulgence and in kind.

130  e a quel mezzo, con le penne sparte,
131  vid' io più di mille angeli festanti,
132  ciascun distinto di fulgore e d'arte.

133  I saw there at their sports and at their songs
134  A beauty smiling, which the gladness was
135  Within the eyes of all the other saints;

133  Vidi a lor giochi quivi e a lor canti
134  ridere una bellezza, che letizia
135  era ne li occhi a tutti li altri santi;

136  And if I had in speaking as much wealth
137  As in imagining, I should not dare
138  To attempt the smallest part of its delight.

136  e s'io avessi in dir tanta divizia
137  quanta ad imaginar, non ardirei
138  lo minimo tentar di sua delizia.

139  Bernard, as soon as he beheld mine eyes
140  Fixed and intent upon its fervid fervour,
141  His own with such affection turned to her

139  Bernardo, come vide li occhi miei
140  nel caldo suo caler fissi e attenti,
141  li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei,

142  That it made mine more ardent to behold.

142  che ' miei di rimirar fé più ardenti.

Canto XXXII
Here, in the penultimate canto of the Commedia, we have reached that rose-shaped eternity wherein the brightest, the most loving, and the most joyful, take simultaneously the shapes of the petals of the robe, and the shapes of their own individual spirits.  No animals nor plants nor any geologic features exist here, this is, as Blake would later have it, the Divine Human.  And what has made these humans divine?  They have turned their love and devotion to something outside of themselves — to the human shapes, of those, like themselves, who had their eyes and hearts and actions fixed upon that brightness, love, and joy, which embodies them, but also which gives them a body and an identity, and whose effulgence has brought them to this pinnacle of ineffable splendor.  What does a person love most?  Other people.  And so, in this canto we get a litany of the loving/lovable, all of whom are sanctified by a name and an identity made everlasting by their capacity to love.  Nothing exists in this heaven that any human child could fail to understand, and indeed, the children who make up a large part of this petaled paradise have no other merit except that of having been loved.  For Dante, Heaven is a rose whose living form is entirely comprised of the beloved.  Beatrice, Saint Lucy, and Mary, are respectively: personal love, love of light, love of the engendering ocean of the infinite.  The end of the canto, however, has what might be thought quite curious, if as readers, we have not been cognizant that this pilgrimage, this geometry which has brought us here, is entirely composed of words, and the metaphors, indeed, the simile that Bernard proclaims, and that through him, Dante also proclaims, is that through words blessedness is obtained — words of poetry, which are simultaneously words of prayer and praise.  Throughout these last canti the words of the poem have been, as it were, weaving webs to contain the ineffable, and here we have arrived at that condition in which specific human beings — who are not ineffable in their forms, histories, and identities — but in their love.  Now astonishingly we have come to understand that our entire comprehension of these entities, these identities — their communal shape ever becoming this fantastical rose — is entirely made possible by words.  Wallace Stevens says "it is a world of words to the end of it," and here, where we have indeed almost reached the limit, that end, of what words are, and of what they can do, Bernard tells us flat out, that if we want to attain apotheosis, we must follow his words as they comprise and are comprised by the Mother of God.

1  Absorbed in his delight, that contemplator
2  Assumed the willing office of a teacher,
3  And gave beginning to these holy words:

1  Affetto al suo piacer, quel contemplante
2  libero officio di dottore assunse,
3  e cominciò queste parole sante:

4  "The wound that Mary closed up and anointed,
5  She at her feet who is so beautiful,
6  She is the one who opened it and pierced it.

4  “La piaga che Maria richiuse e unse,
5  quella ch'è tanto bella da' suoi piedi
6  è colei che l'aperse e che la punse.

7   Within that order which the third seats make
8  Is seated Rachel, lower than the other,
9  With Beatrice, in manner as thou seest.

7  Ne l'ordine che fanno i terzi sedi,
8  siede Rachel di sotto da costei
9  con Bëatrice, sì come tu vedi.

10  Sarah, Rebecca, Judith, and her who was
11  Ancestress of the Singer, who for dole
12  Of the misdeed said, 'Miserere mei,'

10  Sarra e Rebecca, Iudìt e colei
12  che fu bisava al cantor che per doglia
13  del fallo disse 'Miserere mei'

13  Canst thou behold from seat to seat descending
14  Down in gradation, as with each one's name
15  I through the Rose go down from leaf to leaf.

13  puoi tu veder così di soglia in soglia
14  giù digradar, com' io ch'a proprio nome
15  vo per la rosa giù di foglia in foglia.

16  And downward from the seventh row, even as
17  Above the same, succeed the Hebrew women,
18  Dividing all the tresses of the flower;

16  E dal settimo grado in giù, sì come
17  infino ad esso, succedono Ebree,
18  dirimendo del fior tutte le chiome;

19  Because, according to the view which Faith
20  In Christ had taken, these are the partition
21  By which the sacred stairways are divided.

19  perché, secondo lo sguardo che fée
20  la fede in Cristo, queste sono il muro
21  a che si parton le sacre scalee.

22  Upon this side, where perfect is the flower
23  With each one of its petals, seated are
24  Those who believed in Christ who was to come.

22  Da questa parte onde 'l fiore è maturo
23  di tutte le sue foglie, sono assisi
24  quei che credettero in Cristo venturo;

25  Upon the other side, where intersected
26  With vacant spaces are the semicircles,
27  Are those who looked to Christ already come.

25  da l'altra parte onde sono intercisi
26  di vòti i semicirculi, si stanno
27  quei ch'a Cristo venuto ebber li visi.

28  And as, upon this side, the glorious seat
29  Of the Lady of Heaven, and the other seats
30  Below it, such a great division make,

28  E come quinci il glorïoso scanno
29  de la donna del cielo e li altri scanni
30  di sotto lui cotanta cerna fanno,

31  So opposite doth that of the great John,
32  Who, ever holy, desert and martyrdom
33  Endured, and afterwards two years in Hell.

31  così di contra quel del gran Giovanni,
32  che sempre santo 'l diserto e 'l martiro
33  sofferse, e poi l'inferno da due anni;

34  And under him thus to divide were chosen
35  Francis, and Benedict, and Augustine,
36  And down to us the rest from round to round.

34  e sotto lui così cerner sortiro
35  Francesco, Benedetto e Augustino
36  e altri fin qua giù di giro in giro.

37  Behold now the high providence divine;
38  For one and other aspect of the Faith
39  In equal measure shall this garden fill.

37  Or mira l'alto proveder divino:
38  ché l'uno e l'altro aspetto de la fede
39  igualmente empierà questo giardino.

40  And know that downward from that rank which cleaves
41  Midway the sequence of the two divisions,
42  Not by their proper merit are they seated;

40  E sappi che dal grado in giù che fiede
41  a mezzo il tratto le due discrezioni,
42  per nullo proprio merito si siede,

43  But by another's under fixed conditions;
44  For these are spirits one and all assoiled
45  Before they any true election had.

43  ma per l'altrui, con certe condizioni:
44  ché tutti questi son spiriti asciolti
45  prima ch'avesser vere elezïoni.

46  Well canst thou recognise it in their faces,
47  And also in their voices puerile,
48  If thou regard them well and hearken to them.

46  Ben te ne puoi accorger per li volti
47  e anche per le voci püerili,
48  se tu li guardi bene e se li ascolti.

49  Now doubtest thou, and doubting thou art silent;
50  But I will loosen for thee the strong bond
51  In which thy subtile fancies hold thee fast.

49  Or dubbi tu e dubitando sili;
50  ma io discioglierò 'l forte legame
51  in che ti stringon li pensier sottili.

52  Within the amplitude of this domain
53  No casual point can possibly find place,
54  No more than sadness can, or thirst, or hunger;

52  Dentro a l'ampiezza di questo reame
53  casüal punto non puote aver sito,
54  se non come tristizia o sete o fame:

55  For by eternal law has been established
56  Whatever thou beholdest, so that closely
57  The ring is fitted to the finger here.

55  ché per etterna legge è stabilito
56  quantunque vedi, sì che giustamente
57  ci si risponde da l'anello al dito;

58  And therefore are these people, festinate
59  Unto true life, not 'sine causa' here
60  More and less excellent among themselves.

58  e però questa festinata gente
59  a vera vita non è sine causa
60  intra sé qui più e meno eccellente.

61  The King, by means of whom this realm reposes
62  In so great love and in so great delight
63  That no will ventureth to ask for more,

61  Lo rege per cui questo regno pausa
62  in tanto amore e in tanto diletto,
63  che nulla volontà è di più ausa

64  In his own joyous aspect every mind
65  Creating, at his pleasure dowers with grace
66  Diversely; and let here the effect suffice.

64  le menti tutte nel suo lieto aspetto
65  creando, a suo piacer di grazia dota
66  diversamente; e qui basti l'effetto.

67  And this is clearly and expressly noted
68  For you in Holy Scripture, in those twins
69  Who in their mother had their anger roused.

67  E ciò espresso e chiaro vi si nota
68  ne la Scrittura santa in quei gemelli
69  che ne la madre ebber l'ira commota.

70  According to the colour of the hair,
71  Therefore, with such a grace the light supreme
72  Consenteth that they worthily be crowned.

70  Però, secondo il color d'i capelli,
71  di cotal grazia l'altissimo lume
72  degnamente convien che s'incappelli.

73  Without, then, any merit of their deeds,
74  Stationed are they in different gradations,
75  Differing only in their first acuteness.

73  Dunque, sanza mercé di lor costume,
74  locati son per gradi differenti,
75  sol differendo nel primiero acume.

76  'Tis true that in the early centuries,
77  With innocence, to work out their salvation
78  Sufficient was the faith of parents only.

76  Bastavasi ne' secoli recenti
77  con l'innocenza, per aver salute,
78  solamente la fede d'i parenti;

79  After the earlier ages were completed,
80  Behoved it that the males by circumcision
81  Unto their innocent wings should virtue add;

79  poi che le prime etadi fuor compiute,
80  convenne ai maschi a l'innocenti penne
81  per circuncidere acquistar virtute;

82  But after that the time of grace had come
83  Without the baptism absolute of Christ,
84  Such innocence below there was retained.

82  ma poi che 'l tempo de la grazia venne,
83  sanza battesmo perfetto di Cristo
84  tale innocenza là giù si ritenne.

85  Look now into the face that unto Christ
86  Hath most resemblance; for its brightness only
87  Is able to prepare thee to see Christ."

85  Riguarda omai ne la faccia che a Cristo
86  più si somiglia, ché la sua chiarezza
87  sola ti può disporre a veder Cristo.”

88  On her did I behold so great a gladness
89  Rain down, borne onward in the holy minds
90  Created through that altitude to fly,

88  Io vidi sopra lei tanta allegrezza
89  piover, portata ne le menti sante
90  create a trasvolar per quella altezza,

91  That whatsoever I had seen before
92  Did not suspend me in such admiration,
93  Nor show me such similitude of God.

91  che quantunque io avea visto davante,
92  di tanta ammirazion non mi sospese,
93  né mi mostrò di Dio tanto sembiante;

94  And the same Love that first descended there,
95  "Ave Maria, gratia plena," singing,
96  In front of her his wings expanded wide.

94  e quello amor che primo lì discese,
95  cantando “Ave, Maria, gratïa plena,”
96  dinanzi a lei le sue ali distese.

97  Unto the canticle divine responded
98  From every part the court beatified,
99  So that each sight became serener for it.

97  Rispuose a la divina cantilena
98  da tutte parti la beata corte,
99  si ch'ogne vista sen fé più serena.

100  "O holy father, who for me endurest
101  To be below here, leaving the sweet place
102  In which thou sittest by eternal lot,

100  “O santo padre, che per me comporte
101  l'esser qua giù, lasciando il dolce loco
102  nel qual tu siedi per etterna sorte,

103  Who is the Angel that with so much joy
104  Into the eyes is looking of our Queen,
105  Enamoured so that he seems made of fire?"

103  qual è quell' angel che con tanto gioco
104  guarda ne li occhi la nostra regina,
105  innamorato si che par di foco?”

106  Thus I again recourse had to the teaching
107  Of that one who delighted him in Mary
108  As doth the star of morning in the sun.

106  Così ricorsi ancora a la dottrina
107  di colui ch'abbelliva di Maria,
108  come del sole stella mattutina.

109  And he to me: "Such gallantry and grace
110  As there can be in Angel and in soul,
111  All is in him; and thus we fain would have it;

109  Ed elli a me: “Baldezza e leggiadria
110  quant' esser puote in angelo e in alma,
111  tutta è in lui; e sì volem che sia,

112  Because he is the one who bore the palm
113  Down unto Mary, when the Son of God
114  To take our burden on himself decreed.

112  perch' elli è quelli che portò la palma
113  giuso a Maria, quando 'l Figliuol di Dio
114  carcar si volse de la nostra salma.

115  But now come onward with thine eyes, as I
116  Speaking shall go, and note the great patricians
117  Of this most just and merciful of empires.

115  Ma vieni omai con li occhi sì com' io
116  andrò parlando, e nota i gran patrici
117  di questo imperio giustissimo e pio.

118  Those two that sit above there most enrapture
119  As being very near unto Augusta,
120  Are as it were the two roots of this Rose.

118  Quei due che seggon là sù più felici
119  per esser propinquissimi ad Agusta,
120  son d'esta rosa quasi due radici:

121  He who upon the left is near her placed
122  The father is, by whose audacious taste
123  The human species so much bitter tastes.

121  colui che da sinistra le s'aggiusta
122  è 'l padre per lo cui ardito gusto
123  l'umana specie tanto amaro gusta;

124  Upon the right thou seest that ancient father
125  Of Holy Church, into whose keeping Christ
126  The keys committed of this lovely flower.

124  dal destro vedi quel padre vetusto
125  di Santa Chiesa a cui Cristo le chiavi
126  raccomandò di questo fior venusto.

127  And he who all the evil days beheld,
128  Before his death, of her the beauteous bride
129  Who with the spear and with the nails was won,

127  E quei che vide tutti i tempi gravi,
128  pria che morisse, de la bella sposa
129  che s'acquistò con la lancia e coi clavi,

130  Beside him sits, and by the other rests
131  That leader under whom on manna lived
132  The people ingrate, fickle, and stiff-necked.

130  siede lungh' esso, e lungo l'altro posa
131  quel duca sotto cui visse di manna
132  la gente ingrata, mobile e retrosa.

133  Opposite Peter seest thou Anna seated,
134  So well content to look upon her daughter,
135  Her eyes she moves not while she sings Hosanna.

133  Di contr' a Pietro vedi sedere Anna,
134  tanto contenta di mirar sua figlia,
135  che non move occhio per cantare osanna;

136  And opposite the eldest household father
137  Lucia sits, she who thy Lady moved
138  When to rush downward thou didst bend thy brows.

136  e contro al maggior padre di famiglia
137  siede Lucia, che mosse la tua donna
138  quando chinavi, a rovinar, le ciglia.

139  But since the moments of thy vision fly,
140  Here will we make full stop, as a good tailor
141  Who makes the gown according to his cloth,

139  Ma perché 'l tempo fugge che t'assonna,
140  qui farem punto, come buon sartore
141  che com' elli ha del panno fa la gonna;

142  And unto the first Love will turn our eyes,
143  That looking upon Him thou penetrate
144  As far as possible through his effulgence.

142  e drizzeremo li occhi al primo amore,
143  sì che, guardando verso lui, penètri
144  quant' è possibil per lo suo fulgore.

145  Truly, lest peradventure thou recede,
146  Moving thy wings believing to advance,
147  By prayer behoves it that grace be obtained;

145  Veramente, ne forse tu t'arretri
146  movendo l'ali tue, credendo oltrarti,
147  orando grazia conven che s'impetri

148  Grace from that one who has the power to aid thee;
149  And thou shalt follow me with thy affection
150  That from my words thy heart turn not aside."

148  grazia da quella che puote aiutarti;
149  e tu mi seguirai con l'affezione,
150  sì che dal dicer mio lo cor non parti.”

151  And he began this holy orison.

151  E cominciò questa santa orazione:

Canto XXXIII
Here in the Empyrean, at the end, where all true converts of this poem, are moved towards tears, and whether those tears be of joy, of having completed such a spiritual and aesthetic pilgrimage, or whether they be of grief, because all those joys of discovery, even in the midst of sorrow, have come to end, it is rightly impossible to say.  And how strange to find at the end that the cosmos of the spirit rests on pillars of paradox and ineffability.  This Buddhistic phrase: " E io ch'al fine di tutt' i disii," and as "I reached the end of all desire," is where Dante finds the ultimate desire, pure ardor for the vision which will obliterate both his memory and his speech.
What is it that makes a person a person, if not memory and speech?  And what is so sanctified as memory and speech that can lead us to this vision wherein their functions are fulfilled in a present moment of a speaking immemorial light, a light that sets a limit to their enterprise by making them irrelevant?  Here all the angels and saints turn their eyes and their hearts to Dante, this lone supplicant, praying that he attain the vision.  That the universe is always bending its hopes and prayers for the salvation of a single person, that is the ultimate paradox, the ultimate paradise, which in Dante has been reached step by arduous, ardent, inspired step of memory and speech, and here, having exhausted the limits of his invention, his imagination, his majestic emotional range, here where he is exalted the most, he is most humble.  If as readers, we remember all those canti in the Inferno, where Dante, the aspirant, fainted, unable to sustain the horrors which Dante the poet was so vividly enumerating, it should not surprise us that here, at the last, Dante and Poseidon are fused.  In the beginning Dante compared his embarcation on this journey and his rescue by saint Lucy and Virgil to the condition of a swimmer, who having reached shore, looks back upon the water which nearly drowned him.  Here we find that that ultimate goal of that exhausted swimmer was not to reach the shore but rather to make the chaotic, fecund element his domain.  Mary, whose name of course means "sea," has made him Lord of the Waters, where paradoxically he has been most humbled, most supplicating, yet most elevated.  Ah, what can you say, there are so many wonders here, that your thoughts explode and your feelings overwhelm!  Here, in the cosmic rose, the most High's high, Dante has achieved his lowest point!  The nadir of Hell and the zenith of Paradise have circled round to kiss one another in the marraige of opposites, whose marraige rite is the poem itself.  No Divine personage, no paradox of the God/Human Christ, fulfill his vision, they are only the initiating source, the light which makes light.  It is Mary, however, whose love is the ultimate aim of the most exalted, Mary who was so humble that the Divine's aim was to fulfill itself in her womb.  All the conflicts between theists and phycists come to an end in this motherly devotion to all that is.  If all theology and astrophysics are stripped away, what remains is the paradox of LOVE.  God is Love, without beginning or end, just the simple love we might have towards anything and everything in our lives, our love of parents, children, friends, nature, and even our love of food and the humblest objects, events, and experiences.  For me all the supreme grandeurs of this poem are fulfilled mostly in how my love for it has increased my love for other things, even those things like sickness, or want, or loneliness.  Dante's poem ends here with this canto, the Commedia's enormous design has set chaos in order and is complete.  But here the commentators, readers, and what I have referred to above, as his converts, is where their interpretations begin — thus far, the Commedia has extended itself for 800 years past the date where its mortal author merged his flesh with dust.  In the first canto Dante says that he could not speak of the horrors of hell, were it not that he wished to save others from its agonies.  In this last canto he prays that he might remember enough of his vision so that he could inspire with his joy coming generations.  Dante could finish his work on his poem, but he could not end it.  Yes, Dante's Commedia stops here, but the ray of its illumination keeps extending itself into an indefinite future, where his readers, like us, in every generation, continue to discover this rose whose beauties sanctify our lives. 

1  "Thou Virgin Mother, daughter of thy Son,
2  Humble and high beyond all other creature,
3  The limit fixed of the eternal counsel,

1  “Vergine Madre, figlia del tuo figlio,
2  umile e alta più che creatura,
3  termine fisso d'etterno consiglio,

4  Thou art the one who such nobility
5  To human nature gave, that its Creator
6  Did not disdain to make himself its creature.

4  tu se' colei che l'umana natura
5  nobilitasti sì, che 'l suo fattore
6  non disdegnò di farsi sua fattura.

7  Within thy womb rekindled was the love,
8  By heat of which in the eternal peace
9  After such wise this flower has germinated.

7  Nel ventre tuo si raccese l'amore,
8  per lo cui caldo ne l'etterna pace
9  così è germinato questo fiore.

10  Here unto us thou art a noonday torch
11  Of charity, and below there among mortals
12  Thou art the living fountain-head of hope.

10  Qui se' a noi meridïana face
11  di caritate, e giuso, intra ' mortali,
12  se' di speranza fontana vivace.

13  Lady, thou art so great, and so prevailing,
14  That he who wishes grace, nor runs to thee,
15  His aspirations without wings would fly.

13  Donna, se' tanto grande e tanto vali,
14  che qual vuol grazia e a te non ricorre,
15  sua disïanza vuol volar sanz' ali.

16  Not only thy benignity gives succour
17  To him who asketh it, but oftentimes
18  Forerunneth of its own accord the asking.

16  La tua benignità non pur soccorre
17  a chi domanda, ma molte fïate
18  liberamente al dimandar precorre.

19  In thee compassion is, in thee is pity,
20  In thee magnificence; in thee unites
21  Whate'er of goodness is in any creature.

19  In te misericordia, in te pietate,
20  in te magnificenza, in te s'aduna
21  quantunque in creatura è di bontate.

22  Now doth this man, who from the lowest depth
23  Of the universe as far as here has seen
24  One after one the spiritual lives,

22  Or questi, che da l'infima lacuna
23  de l'universo infin qui ha vedute
24  le vite spiritali ad una ad una,

25  Supplicate thee through grace for so much power
26  That with his eyes he may uplift himself
27  Higher towards the uttermost salvation.

25  supplica a te, per grazia, di virtute
26  tanto, che possa con li occhi levarsi
27  più alto verso l'ultima salute.

28  And I, who never burned for my own seeing
29  More than I do for his, all of my prayers
30  Proffer to thee, and pray they come not short,

28  E io, che mai per mio veder non arsi
29  più ch'i' fo per lo suo, tutti miei prieghi
30  ti porgo, e priego che non sieno scarsi,

31  That thou wouldst scatter from him every cloud
32  Of his mortality so with thy prayers,
33  That the Chief Pleasure be to him displayed.

31  perché tu ogne nube li disleghi
32 di sua mortalità co' prieghi tuoi,
33 sì che 'l sommo piacer li si dispieghi.

34  Still farther do I pray thee, Queen, who canst
35  Whate'er thou wilt, that sound thou mayst preserve
36  After so great a vision his affections.

34  Ancor ti priego, regina, che puoi
35 ciò che tu vuoli, che conservi sani,
36 dopo tanto veder, li affetti suoi.
37  Let thy protection conquer human movements;
38  See Beatrice and all the blessed ones
39  My prayers to second clasp their hands to thee!"

37  Vinca tua guardia i movimenti umani:
38  vedi Beatrice con quanti beati
39  per li miei prieghi ti chiudon le mani!”

40  The eyes beloved and revered of God,
41  Fastened upon the speaker, showed to us
42  How grateful unto her are prayers devout;

40  Li occhi da Dio diletti e venerati,
41  fissi ne l'orator, ne dimostraro
42  quanto i devoti prieghi le son grati;

43  Then unto the Eternal Light they turned,
44  On which it is not credible could be
45  By any creature bent an eye so clear.

43  indi a l'etterno lume s'addrizzaro,
44  nel qual non si dee creder che s'invii
45  per creatura l'occhio tanto chiaro.

46   And I, who to the end of all desires
47  Was now approaching, even as I ought
48  The ardour of desire within me ended.

46  E io ch'al fine di tutt' i disii
46  appropinquava, sì com' io dovea,
47  l'ardor del desiderio in me finii.

49  Bernard was beckoning unto me, and smiling,
50  That I should upward look; but I already
51  Was of my own accord such as he wished;

49  Bernardo m'accennava, e sorridea,
50  perch' io guardassi suso; ma io era
51  già per me stesso tal qual ei volea:

52  Because my sight, becoming purified,
53  Was entering more and more into the ray
54  Of the High Light which of itself is true.

52  ché la mia vista, venendo sincera,
53  e più e più intrava per lo raggio
54  de l'alta luce che da sé è vera.

55  From that time forward what I saw was greater
56  Than our discourse, that to such vision yields,
57  And yields the memory unto such excess.

55  Da quinci innanzi il mio veder fu maggio
56  che 'l parlar mostra, ch'a tal vista cede,
57  e cede la memoria a tanto oltraggio.

58  Even as he is who seeth in a dream,
59  And after dreaming the imprinted passion
60  Remains, and to his mind the rest returns not,

58  Qual è colüi che sognando vede,
59  che dopo 'l sogno la passione impressa
60  rimane, e l'altro a la mente non riede,

61  Even such am I, for almost utterly
62  Ceases my vision, and distilleth yet
63  Within my heart the sweetness born of it;

61  cotal son io, ché quasi tutta cessa
62  mia visïone, e ancor mi distilla
63  nel core il dolce che nacque da essa.

64  Even thus the snow is in the sun unsealed,
65  Even thus upon the wind in the light leaves
66  Were the soothsayings of the Sibyl lost.

64  Così la neve al sol si disigilla;
65  così al vento ne le foglie levi
66  si perdea la sentenza di Sibilla.

67  O Light Supreme, that dost so far uplift thee
68  From the conceits of mortals, to my mind
69  Of what thou didst appear re-lend a little,

67  O somma luce che tanto ti levi
68  da' concetti mortali, a la mia mente
69  ripresta un poco di quel che parevi,

70  And make my tongue of so great puissance,
71  That but a single sparkle of thy glory
72  It may bequeath unto the future people;

70  e fa la lingua mia tanto possente,
71  ch'una favilla sol de la tua gloria
72  possa lasciare a la futura gente;

73  For by returning to my memory somewhat,
74  And by a little sounding in these verses,
75  More of thy victory shall be conceived!

73  ché, per tornare alquanto a mia memoria
74  e per sonare un poco in questi versi,
75  più si conceperà di tua vittoria.

76  I think the keenness of the living ray
77  Which I endured would have bewildered me,
78  If but mine eyes had been averted from it;

76  Io credo, per l'acume ch'io soffersi
77  del vivo raggio, ch'i' sarei smarrito,
78  se li occhi miei da lui fossero aversi.

79  And I remember that I was more bold
80  On this account to bear, so that I joined
81  My aspect with the Glory Infinite.

79  E' mi ricorda ch'io fui più ardito
80  per questo a sostener, tanto ch'i' giunsi
81  l'aspetto mio col valore infinito.

82  O grace abundant, by which I presumed
83  To fix my sight upon the Light Eternal,
84  So that the seeing I consumed therein!

82  Oh abbondante grazia ond' io presunsi
83  ficcar lo viso per la luce etterna,
84  tanto che la veduta vi consunsi!

85  I saw that in its depth far down is lying
86  Bound up with love together in one volume,
87  What through the universe in leaves is scattered;

85  Nel suo profondo vidi che s'interna,
86  legato con amore in un volume,
87  ciò che per l'universo si squaderna:

88  Substance, and accident, and their operations,
89  All interfused together in such wise
90  That what I speak of is one simple light.

88  sustanze e accidenti e lor costume
89  quasi conflati insieme, per tal modo
90  che ciò ch'i' dico è un semplice lume.

91  The universal fashion of this knot
92  Methinks I saw, since more abundantly
93  In saying this I feel that I rejoice.

91  La forma universal di questo nodo
92  credo ch'i' vidi, perché più di largo,
93  dicendo questo, mi sento ch'i' godo.

94  One moment is more lethargy to me,
95  Than five and twenty centuries to the emprise
96  That startled Neptune with the shade of Argo!

94  Un punto solo m'è maggior letargo
95  che venticinque secoli a la 'mpresa
96  che fé Nettuno ammirar l'ombra d'Argo.

97  My mind in this wise wholly in suspense,
98  Steadfast, immovable, attentive gazed,
99  And evermore with gazing grew enkindled.

97  Così la mente mia, tutta sospesa
98  mirava fissa, immobile e attenta,
99 e sempre di mirar faceasi accesa.

100  In presence of that light one such becomes,
101  That to withdraw therefrom for other prospect
102  It is impossible he e'er consent;

100  A quella luce cotal si diventa,
101  che volgersi da lei per altro aspetto
102  è impossibil che mai si consenta;
103  Because the good, which object is of will,
104  Is gathered all in this, and out of it
105  That is defective which is perfect there.

103  però che 'l ben, ch'è del volere obietto,
104  tutto s'accoglie in lei, e fuor di quella
105  è defettivo ciò ch'è lì perfetto.

106  Shorter henceforward will my language fall
107  Of what I yet remember, than an infant's
108  Who still his tongue doth moisten at the breast.

106  Omai sarà più corta mia favella,
107  pur a quel ch'io ricordo, che d'un fante
108  che bagni ancor la lingua a la mammella.

109  Not because more than one unmingled semblance
110  Was in the living light on which I looked,
111  For it is always what it was before;

109  Non perché più ch'un semplice sembiante
110  fosse nel vivo lume ch'io mirava,
111  che tal è sempre qual s'era davante;

112  But through the sight, that fortified itself
113  In me by looking, one appearance only
114  To me was ever changing as I changed.

112  ma per la vista che s'avvalorava
113  in me guardando, una sola parvenza,
114  mutandom' io, a me si travagliava.

115  Within the deep and luminous subsistence
116  Of the High Light appeared to me three circles,
117  Of threefold colour and of one dimension,

115  Ne la profonda e chiara sussistenza
116  de l'alto lume parvermi tre giri
117  di tre colori e d'una contenenza;

118  And by the second seemed the first reflected
119  As Iris is by Iris, and the third
120  Seemed fire that equally from both is breathed.

118  e l'un da l'altro come iri da iri
119  parea reflesso, e 'l terzo parea foco
120  che quinci e quindi igualmente si spiri.

121  O how all speech is feeble and falls short
122  Of my conceit, and this to what I saw
123  Is such, 'tis not enough to call it little!

121  Oh quanto è corto il dire e come fioco
122  al mio concetto! e questo, a quel ch'i' vidi,
123  è tanto, che non basta a dicer “poco.”

124  O Light Eterne, sole in thyself that dwellest,
125  Sole knowest thyself, and, known unto thyself
126  And knowing, lovest and smilest on thyself!

124  O luce etterna che sola in te sidi,
125  sola t'intendi, e da te intelletta
126  e intendente te ami e arridi!

127  That circulation, which being thus conceived
128  Appeared in thee as a reflected light,
129  When somewhat contemplated by mine eyes,

127  Quella circulazion che sì concetta
128  pareva in te come lume reflesso,
129  da li occhi miei alquanto circunspetta,

130  Within itself, of its own very colour
131  Seemed to me painted with our effigy,
132  Wherefore my sight was all absorbed therein.

130  dentro da sé, del suo colore stesso,
131  mi parve pinta de la nostra effige:
132  per che 'l mio viso in lei tutto era messo.

133  As the geometrician, who endeavours
134  To square the circle, and discovers not,
135  By taking thought, the principle he wants,

133  Qual è 'l geomètra che tutto s'affige
134  per misurar lo cerchio, e non ritrova,
135  pensando, quel principio ond' elli indige,

136  Even such was I at that new apparition;
137  I wished to see how the image to the circle
138  Conformed itself, and how it there finds place;

136  tal era io a quella vista nova:
137  veder voleva come si convenne
138  l'imago al cerchio e come vi s'indova;

139  But my own wings were not enough for this,
140  Had it not been that then my mind there smote
141  A flash of lightning, wherein came its wish.

139  ma non eran da ciò le proprie penne:
140  se non che la mia mente fu percossa
141  da un fulgore in che sua voglia venne.

142  Here vigour failed the lofty fantasy:
143  But now was turning my desire and will,
144  Even as a wheel that equally is moved,

142  A l'alta fantasia qui mancò possa;
143  ma già volgeva il mio disio e 'l velle,
144  sì come rota ch'igualmente è mossa,

145  The Love which moves the sun and other stars.

145  l'amor che move il sole e l'altre stelle.

SIX SONNETS ON DANTE’S DIVINE COMEDY BY HENRY WADSWORTH LONGFELLOW
(1807-1882)
I
Oft have I seen at some cathedral door
    A laborer, pausing in the dust and heat,
    Lay down his burden, and with reverent feet
    Enter, and cross himself, and on the floor
Kneel to repeat his paternoster o’er;
    Far off the noises of the world retreat;
    The loud vociferations of the street
    Become an undistinguishable roar.
So, as I enter here from day to day,
    And leave my burden at this minster gate,
    Kneeling in prayer, and not ashamed to pray,
The tumult of the time disconsolate
    To inarticulate murmurs dies away,
    While the eternal ages watch and wait.
II
How strange the sculptures that adorn these towers!
    This crowd of statues, in whose folded sleeves
    Birds build their nests; while canopied with leaves
    Parvis and portal bloom like trellised bowers,
And the vast minster seems a cross of flowers!
    But fiends and dragons on the gargoyled eaves
    Watch the dead Christ between the living thieves,
    And, underneath, the traitor Judas lowers!
Ah! from what agonies of heart and brain,
    What exultations trampling on despair,
    What tenderness, what tears, what hate of wrong,
What passionate outcry of a soul in pain,
    Uprose this poem of the earth and air,
    This mediaeval miracle of song!
III
I enter, and I see thee in the gloom
    Of the long aisles, O poet saturnine!
    And strive to make my steps keep pace with thine.
    The air is filled with some unknown perfume;
The congregation of the dead make room
    For thee to pass; the votive tapers shine;
    Like rooks that haunt Ravenna’s groves of pine,
    The hovering echoes fly from tomb to tomb.
From the confessionals I hear arise
    Rehearsals of forgotten tragedies,
    And lamentations from the crypts below
And then a voice celestial that begins
    With the pathetic words, “Although your sins
    As scarlet be,” and ends with “as the snow.”
IV
With snow-white veil, and garments as of flame,
    She stands before thee, who so long ago
    Filled thy young heart with passion and the woe
    From which thy song in all its splendors came;
And while with stern rebuke she speaks thy name,
    The ice about thy heart melts as the snow
    On mountain heights, and in swift overflow
    Comes gushing from thy lips in sobs of shame.
Thou makest full confession; and a gleam
    As of the dawn on some dark forest cast,
    Seems on thy lifted forehead to increase;
Lethe and Eunoe—the remembered dream
    And the forgotten sorrow—bring at last
    That perfect pardon which is perfect peace.
V
I Lift mine eyes, and all the windows blaze
    With forms of saints and holy men who died,
    Here martyred and hereafter glorified;
    And the great Rose upon its leaves displays
Christ’s Triumph, and the angelic roundelays,
    With splendor upon splendor multiplied;
    And Beatrice again at Dante’s side
    No more rebukes, but smiles her words of praise.
And then the organ sounds, and unseen choirs
    Sing the old Latin hymns of peace and love
    And benedictions of the Holy Ghost;
And the melodious bells among the spires
    O’er all the house-tops and through heaven above
    Proclaim the elevation of the Host!
VI
O star of morning and of liberty!
    O bringer of the light, whose splendor shines
    Above the darkness of the Apennines,
    Forerunner of the day that is to be!
The voices of the city and the sea,
    The voices of the mountains and the pines,
    Repeat thy song, till the familiar lines
    Are footpaths for the thought of Italy!
Thy fame is blown abroad from all the heights,
    Through all the nations; and a sound is heard,
    As of a mighty wind, and men devout,
Strangers of Rome, and the new proselytes,
    In their own language hear thy wondrous word,
    And many are amazed and many doubt.
